BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A preacher's homiletic guide that uses the nature of eye and vision described in Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> as a basis for similes of the moral life.
BP_Description_1: <i>De Oculo Morali<i> by Peter of Limoges is a Franciscan exemplum book; that is, a preacher's homiletic guide containing an anthology of illustrations and examples for homilies. Written late in the 13th century, this important training manual for preachers was produced in the hope making homilies interesting and relevant by making moral parallels and allegories to the principal aspects of Perspectiva‚Äîthe medieval study encompassing the eye, vision, and optics. Perspectiva originated with De Aspectibus, the Latin translation of Katib al-Manazir by the great Arabic scholar Ab≈´  øAlƒ´ al-·∏§asan ibn al-·∏§asan ibn al-Haytham, known as Alhazen in the Latin West. Much of the natural philosophy of vision in the Katib al-Manazir found its way into the De Oculo Morali, via De Aspectibus, becoming similes for the moral life. The book is important as it reveals what was commonly know from the Latin translation of ibn al-Haytham's Katib al-Manazir, giving one aspect of the depth and extent of its influence. More startling is what it shows a preacher's audience could be expected to be familiar with and grasp and, evidently, how common was a general understanding of vision and the eye.||<i>De Oculo Morali<i> is part of a wider tradition of exempla books and is similar to the <i>Lumen Animae<i> attributed to Berengar of Landora, Archbishop of Santiago de Compostela. The <i>Lumen Animae<i> uses natural history and source including Avicenna, Galen, Hippocrates, Pliny the elder, and Theophrastus of Eresus in the same way that the <i>De Oculo Morali<i> uses Alhazen and the De Aspectibus.||<i>De Oculo Morali<i> was widely copied, circulated, and used for more than two centuries. More than 160 manuscript copies still exist. By way of its popularization in homilies of the new natural philosophy in Perspectiva, it was responsible for the spread of perspectivist ideas to a much wider audience than any of the specialized texts of Peckham, Bacon, or Witelo.||The earliest printings appeared at Augsburg in 1475, 1476, and 1477. An edition of the Latin text, and an Italian translation based on it, appeared at Venice in 1496.
BP_Description_2: The <i>De Oculo Morali<i> contains 15 chapters. 1: The anatomy of the eye; relating its seven components to the seven virtues. 2: Alignment of the type of eye component (soft or hard) with aspects of mercy and justice. 3: Enunciates the three types of vision: direct, reflected, refracted. Each with a lessened ability to convey veracity, and related to spiritual vision. 4: Claims that both intromission (species of objects coming into the eye) and extramission (vision rays leaving the eye) are required for sight. This is aligned with the requirement for the requirement of an individual‚Äôs cooperation with God‚Äôs grace. 5: The role of the single nerve behind the eye (after the optic chiasm) as the seat of vision. The brain is presented having an internal sense that acts as vision‚Äôs gatekeeper. 6: Explains 13 optical illusions, with moral and spiritual illusions being paired with physical and optical ones. 7: From the 12 ‚Äònatural properties‚Äô of the eye (such as the fact that it is spherical), Limoges builds a system of moral instruction. 8: Characterizes types of eyes with types of sin. 9: How the eyes incur more debt than other parts of the body. 10: Loss and damage to vision 11: Seven conditions necessary for vision in the instruction of students. 12: From the 12 ‚Äònatural properties‚Äô of the eye, develops instruction for priests. 13: The four appropriate objects of spiritual vision. 14: Beautiful visual experiences interpreted in spiritual terms. 15: Divine sight, the eye and vision of God.||Peter of Limoges is interested in aspects of vision beyond their utility for moral allegory. This is clear from Chapter 1 where he gives a description of the eye, together with a brief account of eye diseases and their treatment, as well as Chapter 3 devoted to vision. It is also apparent in the chapter on optical illusions where what was understood about refraction at the time is considered in detail. In general, though, the <i>De Oculo Morali<i> extracts and uses only the qualitative and descriptive aspects of Alhazen's <i>De Aspectibus<i>. Not surprisingly, none of its elaborate mathematics or optical experiments appears in the <i>De Oculo Morali<i>.

L.|<i>Michigan Academician<i>, Vol 9,  No 3, 1977, pp 329-343||Peter of Limoges, Optics, and the Science of the Senses|Newhauser, R.G.|<i>Senses & Society<i>, Vol 5, No 1, 2010, pp 28-44.||MS from 1363:|http://www.wbc.poznan.pl/dlibra/doccontent?id=87070|MS from 1350: http://digital.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/objects/7ca24a5b-d70e-4882-9966-594486cb9421/surfaces/18e44134-896b-4989-b0c3-03483c8b4ac8

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of the most widely read Medieval encyclopedias. Written for students and preachers, it covered divine and human life, the natural world, Earth and the heavens, with numerous sources cited.
BP_Description_1: The <i>De proprietatibus Rerum<i> of Bartholomaeus Anglicus (Bartholomew the Englishman) is one of the most widely read Medieval encyclopedias and one of the most frequently printed. Written for students and preachers no later than 1240, it covered divine and human life, the natural world, Earth and the heavens. Bartholomew's encyclopedia filled a need for a compact source of knowledge for those without access to libraries or large specialized textbooks. One of the reasons it was immensely popular for centuries was that is was not a manual of the arts but a source for 'science' and secular knowledge; there are more than 200 manuscript copies extant. Nevertheless, Bartholomew wrote not to consider the nature of things for their own sake, but rather to better reveal Scripture. The book gives a view of middle and late medieval common knowledge and because Bartholomew did not consider nor wish to present himself as an authority, the many sources he cites gives insight into information and texts available at end of the 13th century. The book was popular enough to be translated into French in 1372 by Jean Corbichon, into English in 1398 by John Trevisa, into Spanish by Vincent de Burgos late in the 14th century, and into Dutch, Italian, and Proven√ßal.||Latin editions appeared in ca 1472, ca 1475, 1480, 1481, two in 1482, 1483, 1485, 1488, 1491, 1492, 1505, 1519, 1601, and 1609. French editions appeared in 1482, two in 1485, 1487, 1491, 1500, 1510, 1518, 1522 (2), 1525, 1538, 1539, six in 1556. A Dutch printing appeared in 1485. A Spanish printing in 1494 and 1529. Printed editions appeared in England in 1495, 1535, and 1582; the later being Thomas Berthelet's English edition, amended and enlarged by Stephen Batman. The present copy and is number 6 in Voight's bibliographic list.
BP_Description_2: <i>De Proprietatibus Rerum<i> contains 19 books. 1: God. 2: Angels and demons. 3: Psychology. 4-5: Physiology. 6: Family life and domestic economy. 7: Medicine. 8: Cosmology and astrology. 9: Time divisions. 10: Form and matter, the elements. 11: Air and meteorology, 12: Flying creatures. 13: Waters and fishes, dolphins, and whales. 14-15: Physical and political geography. 16: Gems, minerals, and metals. 17: Trees and herbs. 18: Animals. 19: Color, odor, savor; food and drink; weights and measures; musical instruments. All of the material in Chapter 17 of Book 3 is on vision, giving the anatomy of the eye and detailed account of the mechanism of vision. Bartholomew gives an unnamed author's work precedence over that of Constantine the African on matters of vision. Presumably this is a reference to Constantine's translation, the<i>Liber Pantegni<i>, of an Arabic medical text. The unnamed author and work cannot be Alhazen and <i>De Apsectibus<i>; it is likely to be Robert Grosseteste since as his source Bartholomew cites the the first chapter of 'Perspectiva' and, importantly, describes the multiplication of visible species. Bartholomew presents vision based on three coincident pyramids, with apex at the pupil and base at the viewed object. The three pyramids contain: species emitted from the object, a visual fluid emitted by the eye, and light--a substance illuminating the object. Though Light is always present, it illuminates only a body in a condition to receive it. Following the ancients, three types of vision are presented: direct, reflected, and refracted.||The eye and ocular anatomy is presented in Chapters 5, 6, and 7 of Book 5. The material comes from Isidore of Saville's <i>Etymologiae<i> and from the medical translations of Constantine the African (the <i>Liber Pantegni<i>, most likely), both of which are cited. The anatomy presented is entirely Galenic. Bartholomew's material on color in chapter 1 of book 19 is copied, almost verbatim, from Robert Grosseteste's <i>De Colore<i> of around 1220. In all, the <i>De Proprietatibus Rerum<i> contains a summary of the developments in optics up to the end of the 13th century. Rays, pyramids, and species are presented with the mixed vagueness typical before the wide-spread appearance  Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> in the Latin West at the very beginning of the 14th century.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Bartholomaeus Anglicus and His Encyclopaedia|Se Boyar, G.E.|<i>Journal of English and Germanic Philology<i>, Vol 19, No 2, 1920, pp 168-189||<i>A History of Magic and Experimental Science<i>, Vol II|Thorndike, L.|Columbia University Press, 1923, pp 401-435, 409 on light and vision.||The Dimensions of Colour Robert Grosseteste‚Äôs <i>De Colore<i>|Dinkova-Bruun, G., and others, editors, translators|Institute of Medieval and Renaissance Studies Durham University, Toronto, 2013, 94 pp, NB: pp 74-79.||(A bibliogrraphy of early printed copies) Bartholomaeus Anglicus, de Proprietatibus Rerum. Literarhistorisches und bibliopgraphisches|Voigt, E.|<i>Englische Studien<i>, Vol 41, 1910, pp 337-359.||Seeing Through the Veil: Optical Theory and Medieval Allegory|Akbari, S.C.|Toronto, 2004, 353 pp, NB: pp 21-44.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Marsilio Ficino (1433-1499) priest and important Florentine scholar, translator of Plato's works.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first printing of the works of Plotinus, gathered together by his disciple Porphyry and here translated and with commentary by Marsilio Ficino. This printing was the primary document of Neoplatonism and had an important role in the revival of Plato in the Renaissance.
BP_Description_1: This printing of Plotinus' works, translated and edited with commentary by Marsilio Ficino, marks their reappearance in the Latin West. Before this, Plotinus was virtually unknown; none of his works had been translated, and early translations had been lost. The printing was made possible by the emergence of two manuscripts of Plotinus in the early fifteenth century in Florence. The second had come from Constantinople and was eventually owned by Cosimo de 'Medici who gave it to Ficino in 1462. Though Ficino appears to have worked with the manuscript for nearly 20 years, it was only after finishing his grand project of translating all of Plato in 1484 that he returned to the Plotinus translation and commentary project, producing the present edition. The book was two years in press.||From his Preface, it is clear than Ficino considers Plotinus the supreme interpreter of Plato and that Platonic ideas presage Christian ones. The availability of Plotinus' <i>Enneads<i> brought about a revival of Neoplatonism in Renaissance Europe and producing a confluence of Platonic philosophy and Christianity would become a major project of European scholarship in the 16th century.||Editions appeared at Florence in 1492, at Sollingen in 1542, at Basel in 1559, 1562, 1576, and 1641, at Basel with the Greek in 1580 and 1615, at Hamburg in 1711, 1723, 1796, in a French translation at Paris in 1747, in a German translation at Frankfurt in 1805, and an English translation at London in 1817.
BP_Description_2: The divisions and labeling of the Enneads were introduced by Ficino and are still used. There are VI Enneads, each having 9 Tracts. Their subject range and complexity is suggested by their titles. Ennead I: Animate man, Virtue, On Dialectic, On true happiness, Happiness and time, Beauty, Primal Good, Nature and source of Evil, Dismissal of the Soul. Ennead II: On the cosmos, Heavenly circuit, Starts as causes, Two kinds of matter, Potentiality and Actuality, Quality and form, Transfusion, Why distant object appear small, Against the Gnostics. Ennead III: Fate, Providence 1, Providence 2, Teaching Spirit, Love, Impassivity of the unembodied, Time and Eternity, Nature Contemplation and the One, Detached considerations. Ennead IV: Essence of the Soul 1, Essence of the Soul 2, Problems of the Soul 1, Problems of the Soul 2, Problems of the Soul 3 ('On sight'), Perception and Memory, Immortality of the Soul, Soul's decent in the Body, Are all Souls one?. Ennead V: Three initial Hypostases, Origin and Order of Beings, Knowing Hypostases and the Transcendent, How Secondaries rise from the First, Intellectual Beings and the Nature of the Good, Principle Transcending Being has no Intellectual Act, Is there an ideal Archetype?, Intellectual Beauty, Authentic Existence. Ennead VI: On kinds of Being 1, On kinds of Being 2, On kinds of Being 3, Omnipresence of the Authentic Existent 1, Omnipresence of the Authentic Existent 2, On Numbers, How Multiplicity of Ideal-Forms Arose, Free Will and the Will of the One, On The Good, or The One.||The treatise that forms Ennead IV, Tract 5, came to be known as 'On Sight.' In it, the Soul is described as the animator of inanimate body and how it functions as the active receptor of the senses. Plotinus then gives a refutation of both Aristotle's and Plato's theory of vision. Importantly, Light is described as the radiant <i>activity<i> of a luminous object and Vision as the reception of this activity. In addition to simple sensory input, memory's role in visual perception is described.

Vol. I. Travaux pr√©liminaires et index grec complet|Brisson, L., Goulet-Caz√©, M.-O., Goulet, R., O‚ÄôBrien, D., editors|Vrin,  Paris, 1982, 438 pp, NB: pp 143-186.||Plotinus on Light and Vision|Gurtler, S.J., G.M,|<i>The International Journal of the Platonic Tradition<i>, Vol 12, No 2, 2018, pp 151-162.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 130-143.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Girolamo Donato (1457-1511) Venetian patrician, diplomat, man of letters.
BP_Short or Common Title: Enarratio de anima ex aristotelis institutione
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The most famous commentator on Aristotle describes and advances his theory of light and vision; being the first to apply geometrical optics to Aristotelian theory.
BP_Description_1: Alexander of Aphrodisias was the most famous commentator on Aristotle, writing to clarify Aristotle's ideas, to remove (in the main) Platonic ideas that had become attached to Aristotelian teaching, and to modify and extend Aristotle's ideas. The later is particularly the case regarding the senses, including vision. Alexander's commentaries were  vastly influential, affecting later philosophers beginning in late antiquity through late medieval times, including and especially Plotinus and his theory of vision as well as several Arabic scholars. The Scholastic teaching on vision formed by Alexander's commentary on Aristotle's De Anima, was in continual opposition to Perspectiva after it arose, first appeared in print in the present edition, and finally ended with the publication of Fortunio Liceti's <i>De Luminis Natura<i> of 1640.||Girolamo Donato produced this, the first Latin translation of De Anima in 1495. Angelo Canini produced another Latin translation in 1546. As Donato points out in his Preface, Alexander's Greek text had long been influential and earned him the name 'The Commentator.' Donato's Latin made Alexander's assessment of and extension to Aristotle's teaching on the senses and the intellect available to a wide late medieval and early Renaissance readership.
BP_Description_2: Alexander of Aphrodisias describes and advances Aristotle's theory of light and vision which, as stated by  Alexander, has its basis in the proposition that 'The proper sensible object of sight is colors.' Media between the eye and an object of color has the potential to be transparent. The eye gains access to colors when the intervening medium has that potentiality actualized. That is, the medium's potential transparency is made actual. The medium must be illuminated by light for this to take place. Alexander considers that colors and light set potentially transparent media in motion, bringing about the actualization of transparency, and as a result, color moves and tinctures light itself. He cites the example of a wall taking on the color of an opposing wall that is deeply pigmented. Alexander explicitly denies an 'efflux' or emission of any type; motion is transferred but there is nothing emitted. In this Alexander explicitly opposed the theory of the Atomists, who consider vision to take place when 'eidola' (spirit-images, idols)  were emitted by an object and entered the eye.||Alexander set out the full process of vision this way: A transparent substance is illuminated and becomes actually transparent and is acted upon by color, setting the transparent substance in motion which, in turn, acts upon the sense of sight. Light, therefore, takes on color from different visible objects, and is directed by these objects in a straight line to the organ of vision and transmits to the eye the very same affection which it received from the colored objects. Importantly 'Light' for Alexander (and for Aristotle) is not an emitted substance, rather it is 'the activity of what is transparent.' Stated in terms of Aristotle's four causes, light is the efficient cause, color the formal cause, the medium the material cause, and vision the final cause. The idea that color-motion moves in straight lines from object to eye is the first application of geometrical optics to Aristotelian vision theory and would later prompt medieval extensions involving vision by reflection and refraction. Additionally, Alexander's extension of the idea of color-motion allows him to account for other aspects of visual perception including motion, position, and shape by making a distinction between color appearance and perception.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Late 13th century Tuscan encyclopedic preaching handbook with allegories, examples, and similes from the natural world, including the human body and vision. Circulated widely in Central Europe and used until the late 17th century.
BP_Description_1: Giovanni da San Gimignano wrote the <i>Liber de Exemplis<i> between 1298 and 1314. It is a Tuscan encyclopedic preaching handbook with allegories, examples, and similes from the natural world, including the human body and vision. In his Prologue, da San Gimignano makes clear his intent: to give a large collection of examples for use in sermons. His sources for cited text excerpts are the Bible and sacred writers (Augustine, Gerolamo, Gregory, Isidoro, Bede, and Bernardo) but also profane authors (Cicero, Seneca, Pliny, Aristotle, Plato, Avicenna, Hippocrates, Galen, Constantine the African, Solino, and Ptolemy). Interestingly, he excludes stories, tales, and legends and uses only what he calls 'natural' examples. The long appeal of the <i>Liber<i> rested on this reliance on sophisticated examples and citations from the natural world. In addition, the structure of the <i>Liber de Exemplis<i> is designed to function as a memory device for preachers and gives a method for training and facilitating memory. Importantly, and unlike the De Oculo Morali of Peter of Limoges, the <i>Liber de Exemplis<i> shows no influence or knowledge of the <i>De Aspectibus<i> of Alhazen. Both these exempla for preachers were written just as the De Aspectibus was becoming widely known and studied.||The <i>Liber de Exemplis<i> was widely used; there are still 56 manuscript copies extant. It was first printed in 1477 and again in 1499. An edited version appeared a Lyon in 1585. Circulated widely in Central Europe and used until the late 17th century.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Liber de Exemplis<i> is in 10 books. Books 1-5 are the order of creation and books 6-10 are man, his body, senses, soul, and society. Within each books the material is in alphabetical order and separate directories to the 'Realia' and 'Moralia.' Every natural example has properties, each of which has an explanation and a moral allegory, each of which, in turn, is accompanied by a biblical, patristic, or profane text excerpt. The books are as follows  1: The heavens and the elements (88 leaves). This includes natural elements and celestial bodies, all of which are related moral states or principles; fire  to goodness or abstinence; stars to the Church Doctors; Moon to the active life. 2: On metals and gems (22 leaves) 3: On Vegetables and Plants (46 leaves). 4: Fish and birds (28 leaves). 5: Animals of the Earth (34 Leaves). Numerous elaborate relationships are drawn between animals and man, including sources of food, their strength for work, remedies for health, and moral lessons. 6: Man and his parts (57 leaves) begins with a consideration of Greek doctrines and the Aristotelian binding of soul and body. From this comes examples of internal and external man, physical and spiritual life, codes of conduct. 7: Visions and Dreams (35 leaves) gives the ancient rules developed for their interpretation. 8: Law and judicial activity (25 leaves) 9: Crafts and Manufactured things. (33 leaves) This includes different agricultural techniques, processing metals, arts of writing and book production, and construction of musical instruments. 10: Actions and Behavior of Man (17 leaves)||The first 6 books borrow heavily from the  <i>De Proprietatibus Rerum<i> of Bartholomaeus Anglicus, including the material on vision. The eye and vision are considered in book 6, chapters 16 and 22 and present  visual pyramids with apex at the eye and based at the viewed object. These conduct object species into the eye, facilitated by light and the luminous fire from the eye. This is essentially the description found in the De proprietatibus Rerum of Bartholomaeus Anglicus. The <i>Liber de Exemplis<i> also mentions 'ocularia de vitro'--one of the earliest references to spectacles.
BP_Reference(s): Giovanni da San Gimignano|At: Treccani Institute|Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani|http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/giovanni-da-san-gimignano_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/||Medical Similes in Religious Discourse: The Case of Giovanni di San Gimignano OP (ca. 1260‚Äìca. 1333)|Zieglar, J.|<i>Science in Context<i>, Vol 8, No 1, 1995 , pp 103-131.
BP_Title: Liber de Exemplis et Similtudinibus Rerum
BP_Title English Translation: Book of Examples and Similes
BP_Biographical Statement: Dominican from Siena, wrote imporant aids, outlines, and encyclopedias for preachers. Used sacred, profane, and natural worldly sources. Famous for the first mention of eye spectacles.
BP_Provenance: Notes on free endpapers.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1499 da San Gimignano - Liber de Exemplis  - Images.JPG
BP_Image2: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1499 da San Gimignano - Liber de Exemplis  - Images 2.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Luca Gaurico (1475-1558)  Italian astrologer, astronomer, mathematician
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Most widely used elementary textbook on optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics in Europe from the 13th to the 17th centuries.
BP_Description_1: John Peckham wrote this widely used elementary textbook on optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics sometime between 1265 and 1279; before he became Archbishop of Canterbury. Peckham's chief source was <i>De Aspectibus<i>, a 13th century Latin translation of KitƒÅb al-ManƒÅ·∫ìir, 'The Book of Optics,' written at the Fatimid capital of Cairo between 1010-1020 by Ab≈´  øAl·øë al-·∏§asan ibn al-·∏§asan ibn al-Haytham, the greatest physicist of the Islamic Golden Age. Peckham refers to  <i>De Aspectibus<i> and its author with an indirectness that makes clear Peckham assumed his reader would know both well. This aspect of Peckham's book makes clear how influential the <i>De Aspectibus<i> was by the end of the 13th century. Peckham follows the order, content, and material of the De Aspectibus. Robert Grosseteste and Roger Bacon also influenced Peckham's optics, but to a considerably less degree; Grosseteste did not know the <i>De Aspectibus<i>, and Bacon tinctured it deeply with Neoplatonic optics. Peckham can be considered the earliest of writers to break away from Neoplatonic optics and fully embrace a physical, rather than a metaphysical basis for light and vision. Following  Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> rather than Grosseteste and Bacon||From his introduction, it  clear that Peckham thought his book  would serve as an introduction to Alhacen's much longer, more detailed, and abstruse work: 'I shall compress into concise summaries the teachings of perspective, which are often presented with great obscurity . . .' Although Peckham either summarizes or omits most of the elaborate geometry in the <i>De Aspectibus<i> and its tedious details, nothing of the basic principles or central ideas are missing. It is this character of the <i>Perspectiva Communis<i>--at once complete, summative, and accessible--that made it so popular. It was used throughout Europe as a textbook from the 13th to the 17th centuries and was the basis for lectures, commentaries, and paraphrases, and is cited in most optics books in 16th and 17th centuries.||This Venice edition of 1504 is particular interesting and important. It was edited by the famed astrologer Luca Gaurico, with figures not only more numerous than those of the editio princeps of 1482, but considerably augmented with printed labeling and guides. Clearly the book was prepared to use as a textbook. This copy has the final leaf containing errata and the epigram to the editor by Donatus Zerbus. The edition at Valencia in 1503 and Leipzig in 1504 also have labeled figures, but they have numerous printing errors but without errata. The woodblock image on the title page of the Venice edition of 1504 had been used by Sessa in his 1502 printing of Liber Secretorum, attributed to Albertus Magnus. A counterfeit of this edition without name or date appeared in Italy sometime after 1504, complete with a slightly altered version of the title page image. ||At least 70 manuscript copies of the <i>Perspectiva Communis<i> are still extant. It was first printed at Milan in 1482/3 and then at Valencia in 1503, Venice and Leipzig in 1504, Paris in 1510, Nuremburg in 1542, Paris in 1556, Cologne in 1580 and 1592, Venice in 1593, and Cologne in 1627. This last printing being more than 20 years after Kepler's optics work. Importantly, beginning with the edition of 1542 edited by Georg Hartmann at Cologne, the printed texts begin to be updated and modernized, and departs significantly from the manuscript tradition that informed the early printings. By 1580 the printing only resembled the manuscripts in content. Even with its changes, Peckham's <i>Perspectiva Communis<i> is an accurate mirror of general optical knowledge from the advent of Ahazen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> late in the 13th century to the appearance of Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> in 1604.
BP_Description_2: Peckham's <i>Perspectiva Communis<i> has a structure that follows the <i>De Aspectibus<i> of Alhazen and is in three parts: Vision by direct rays, Vision by reflected rays, Vision by refracted rays. Part 1, Vision by direct rays includes the properties and propagation of light and color, anatomy and function of the eye, physical requirements for vision, psychology of vision, visual errors. Unlike most of the rest of the work, this section adopts the medieval theory of species to describe direct light propagation and direct vision and does not invoke geometric images. Peckham's book gives one of the first depictions of the optic chiasm in print.  Part 2, Vision by reflected rays includes the law and properties of reflection, images by reflection, visual errors, burning mirrors and twinkling stars. Part 3, Vision by refracted rays includes rays through transparent media, image formation and visual errors from refracted rays, refraction within the eye, the burning glass and kindling rays, the rainbow and Milky Way. While Peckham generally presents and describes Alhazen's intromission theory of vision--in which rays from a luminous object fall on the glacial humor (the lens) of the eye in a manner that preserves a map of the object--he occasionally adopts Euclid's theory of vision rays emitted from the eye, particularly for highly geometrical optics. Peckham is particularly selective and qualitative about refraction, presenting no general law or data.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>John Pecham and the Science of Optics: Perspectiva Communis<i>|Lingberg, D. C.|University of Wisconsin Press, 1970, 300 pp.||<i>Le teorie della luce e della visione ottica dal IX al XV secolo. Studi sulla prospettiva medievale e altri saggi<i>|Federici-Vescovini, G.|Morlacchi Editore, Perugia, 2003, 508 pp, NB pp 171-187. (edited reprint of the 1965 original work)||Oxford and the Revival of Optics in the Thirteenth Century|ten Doesschate, G.|<i>Vision Research<i>, Vol 1, No 1, 1962, pp 313-342.||<i>Geometry and Space: The Celebrated Collection of Books on Geometry, Optics, and Perspective of M. Arnaud De Vitry<i>|Description, Lot 657|Sotheby's, Sale Catalogue, 2002, 430 pp.
BP_Title: Jo. Archiepiscopi Cantauriensis Perspectiva Communis
BP_Title English Translation: General Perspectiva by John, the Archbishop of Canterbury.
BP_Biographical Statement: English¬†Franciscan, lecturer at Oxford, and eventually Archbishop of Canterbury. Deeply influenced by Roger Bacon's views on the value of experimental science.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Luca Gaurico (1475-1558)  Italian astrologer, astronomer, mathematician
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Most widely used elementary textbook on optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics in Europe from the 13th to the 17th centuries.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 8. The present work is a counterfeit of Sessa's Venice edition of 1504. It appeared without name or date in Italy sometime after 1504, complete with a slightly altered version of Sessa's title page woodblock image and newly carved copies of all the Sessa's woodblock figures in the text, though with some differences in the labeling. It lacks the dedicatory letter of Sessa's edition. The composing and printing must have been hasty. It is tighter, much less ornamental, and with no corrigenda for its many misprints. Nevertheless, it testifies to the demand for and market in Peckham's text.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 8.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 8.
BP_Title: Jo. Archiepiscopi Cantauriensis Perspectiva Communis
BP_Title English Translation: General Perspectiva by John, the Archbishop of Canterbury.
BP_Biographical Statement: English¬†Franciscan, lecturer at Oxford, and eventually Archbishop of Canterbury. Deeply influenced by Roger Bacon's views on the value of experimental science.
BP_Provenance: Marginalia and annotations throughout. Several elaborate figures added, with with extensive labels and commentary.
BP_BibliographicNotes: The date and publication place are given by the British Museum catalogue; they are reasonable conjectures. This copy has been carefully studied, with the many notes, added labeling to figures, and additional hand-drawn figures making clear how closely it was read.

BP_Short or Common Title: Questiones Super Quatuor Libros Metheorerum Aristotelis
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A consideration of the optical issues raised in Aristotle's <i>De Meteorologica<i>: vision theory, the rainbow, and halos.
BP_Description_1: Themon Judaeus wrote his Questions on Aristotle's Meteorology while at the University of Paris around 1350. This is part of the scholastic <i>Questiones<i> literature on Aristotle's physical treatises, and in Themon Judaeus's case considers the <i>De Meteorologica<i>. The disputation of questions by the elaborate mechanisms of logic had been a prominent scholastic teaching method since the 12th century. The printing of the 14th century text of Themon Judaeus gives evidence of the continuing humanistic interest in this form of scholastic teaching--but it also marks the beginning of its decline and eventual abandonment.||As an intellectual and teaching exercise, Themon lists questions that scholastic teaching considered to be implied by Aristotle's writing but left unaddressed and, remaining unsettled, demanded study and consideration. Most of the 65 questions are presented with pros and cons. Some of Themon's questions related to optics, vision theory, the rainbow, and halos, among others. ||<i>Questiones Super Quatuor Libros Metheororum<i> (Questions on the Four Books of Meteorology of Aristotle) of Themon Judaeus was widely popular and studied until the 17th century. It was first printed at Pavia in 1480, in an edition of Aristotle's <i>De Meterologica<i> accompanied by commentary and Themon's questions appeared at Venice in 1496, 1507, 1515, and 1522, and in a complete course of physics at Paris in 1516, 1517, and 1518.
BP_Description_2: Themon considers 19 questions in book 1 of <i>De Meteorologica<i>, 11 in book 2, 27 in book 3, and 8 in book 4. Questions 8 in book 1, 1-7 and 10-18 in book 2 deal with optical matters and the rainbow. Some of the issues raised by Themon are considered by Aristotle in the <i>De Meteorologica<i>, several are not. Themon asks and answers questions regarding the basic aspects of reflection and refraction and whether just color is reflected in mirrors but not shape and figure--just color according to Aristotle, but this certainly in not supported by simple geometric optics. Themon considers atmospheric halos, mock suns, and the rainbow. It is asked whether the rainbow is produced by reflection, refraction or both. Aristotle considered it a purely reflective phenomena; Themon plumps for both.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Questions on the Four Books of Aristotle's Meterologica|Grant, E., translator|In: <i>A Source Book in Medieval Science<i>|Grand, E., editor|Harvard University Press, 1974, 864 pp, NB: pp 207-211.||Medieval and Renaissance scholastic conceptions of the influence of the celestial region on the terrestial|Grant, E.|<i>Journal of Medieval and Renaissance Studies<i>, Vol 17, No 1, 1987, pp 1-23.||The threefold object of the scientific knowledge. Pseudo-Scotus and the literature on the Meteorologica in fourteenth-century Paris|Petrescu, L|<i>Franciscan Studies<i>, Vol 72, 2014, pp 465-502. NB: pp 472-476.||The Rise and Decline of the Scholastic ‚Äòquaestio disputata‚Äô, With Special Emphasis on its Use in the Teaching of Medicine and Science|Lawn, B.|Brill, 1993, 176 pp, NB: pp 85-101.
BP_Title: Questiones perspicacissimi philosophi Thimonis super quattuor libros metheore[rum]. In: libros Metheor[rum] Aristotelis Stragirite peripathetico[rum] principis c≈´ comentarijus (sic)
BP_Title English Translation: The Questions of that most Perspicacious Philosopher Themon, on Aristotle's Four Book on Meteorology. In: Aristotle the Stagirite's Books on Meteorology with the Commentary of the Leading Peripatetics
BP_Biographical Statement: Westphalian student of Albert of Saxony and eventually one of the four University of Paris scholars central to the so-called Paris school of physical thought.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1507 Themon Judaeus - Questiones Super Quatuor Libros Metheorerum Aristotelis - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook of all of natural philosophy, with an extensive section on optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics. The section on the rainbow contains the first printing of Theodoric of Freiberg's theory, with a large woodcut of Theodoric's figure showing raindrop refraction.
BP_Description_1: Judocus Trutfetter wrote this textbook of natural philosophy while teaching at Erfurt. Within its large scope it has material on light, vision, and color. The section on the rainbow contains the first printing of Theodoric of Freiberg's theory from 1300, with a large woodcut of Theodoric's figure showing raindrop refraction. Trutfetter reestablished Theodoric's theory in the Renaissance after it had been forgotten for nearly 200 years. The material on optics and the rainbow is unusual, in that much of the rest of the material in Trutfetter's book adheres closely to late Scholastic teaching.
BP_Description_2: Trutfetter's text is in in eight books. 1: General Principles of Nature, including causes and forms, motion and rest, and location, vacuum, and time. 2: On the Heavens. 3: Generation and Corruption. 4: Meteorology. 5: The Elements, Gems, and Metals. 6: Vegetables and Plants. 7: On Animals. 8: On the Soul and Activity. Book eight is in two tracts and come, respectively from Aristotle's <i>De Anima<i> and the <i>Parva Naturalia<i>. Book Four contains Trutfetter's presentation of Theodoric of Freiberg's theory of the formation of the rainbow. Theodoric's discovery that light enters raindrops by refraction, is then totally-internally reflected at the back of the drop, and exits again by refraction out the front of the drop is explained in the text and presented in a large out-sized woodcut diagram. No mention is made of other theories. The material on light and vision is in the first tract in Book Eight. The material on the generation of color is in the second tract. As part of Trutfetter's consideration of the senses, including vision, is how sense perception affects cognition.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, pp 376, NB: pp 143-144.||<i>Color and Meaning: Art, Science, and Symbolism<i>|Gage, J.|University of Chicago Press, 1999, 321 pp, NB: pp 120-126.
BP_Title: Summa in tota[m] physicen: hoc est philosophiam naturalem conformiter siquidem ver[a]e sophi[a]e: que est Theologia per. D. Judocum JsennachcenÃÉ in gymnasio ErphodienÃÉ elucrabata et edita.
BP_Title English Translation: Summary of the Whole of Physics: This is Natural Philosophy in conformity with True Wisdom, which is Theology. Editied and Elucidated by Dr. Judocus Isennachcensis [Judocus Trutfetter] in the Gymnasium of Erfurt.
BP_Biographical Statement: German philosopher and theologian, professor at the Universities of Erfurt and Wittenburg. Teacher of Martin Luther. Foremost dialectician of the age and writer of important textbooks.
BP_Provenance: Very occasional marginalia and highlighting
BP_BibliographicNotes: Front and back pastedowns are MSS waste.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Monumental humanist encyclopedia with a significant section on Aristotelian optics.
BP_Description_1: Raffaello Maffei's Commentaries is actually a humanist encyclopedia, reflecting his own particular interests and those important at the time. It is devoted largely to geography and biography but with  a significant section on natural philosophy including optics and vision.||The <i>Commentariorum Urbanorum<i> was tremendously popular. First printed at Rome in 1506, then at Paris in 1511, 1515, and 1526, at Basel in 1530, 1544, 1559, and 1565, at Lyon in 1552 and 1599, at Frankfurt in 1603, and at Genoa in 1652.
BP_Description_2: Maffei's commentaries are in three tomes. Tome 1 contains books 1-12 on geography. Tome 2 contains books 13-23 giving biographies of 'famous men from all times.' Tome 3 contains books 24-38 on 'Philology; that is various rudimentary arts.' The books on geography cover Europe, North Africa, and the Levant. The books of biographies cover famous lives of clerics, artists, and politicians. Ever interested in archeology and antiquities, Maffei's Book 21 records the feat of Jacopo Ripanda climbing the entire height of Trajan's Column around 1500, erected in Rome in 113 A.D., and make a complete recording of its imagery and text. The books on arts cover not only the law and politics but also most of natural philosophy in the scholastic tradition, including animals, plants, metals and gems, arithmetic, geometry, and optics. Books 36, 37, and 38 are on Optics, Catoptrics, and the Heavens and Astrology. The optics material is Euclidian, with a geometric cone of vision being postulated having apex at the eye and base at the viewed object. vision rays in the center of the cone being stronger than those at is periphery. The material also covers elementary refraction, particularly regarding atmospheric refraction and effects such as sun-dogs, coronae, and halos.
BP_Reference(s): Revisiting Renaissance Encyclopaedism|Blair, A.|In: <i>Encyclopaedism from Antiquity to the Renaissance<i>, K√∂nig, J., Woolf, G., editors|Cambridge University Press, 2013, pp 377-397.
BP_Title: Commentariorum Urbanorum Raphaelis Volaterrani, octo et triginta libri cum duplici eorundem indice secundum Tomos collecto. Item Oeconomicus Xenophontis, ab eodem latio donatus.
BP_Title English Translation: Thirty-eight books of Urbane Commentaries of Raphael Volaterranus, with a Divided Index of the Same Following the Collected Tomes. Also, the Economics of Xenophon, Given in the Same Rendering.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Servite friar, humanist, historian and theologian. Pius, studious, and a prolific writer.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate and supralibros of Jos√© G√≥mez de la Cortina
BP_Publisher or Seller: Ioanne Paruo & Iodoco Badio; Claudio Chevallonio; Conrad Resch
BP_BibliographicNotes: Anno 1526' added to titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Optics as applied to perspective with detailed, practical instruction and examples.
BP_Description_1: The collected works of Joachim Sterck Ringelbergh reflect his itinerant career as a scholar of encyclopedic interests who lectured over all of Europe. Some of the innumerable subjects of his lecturing and writing are contained in the 24 works gathered here, covering language, rhetoric, dialectics, mathematics, astronomy, perspective, astrology, and letters.||Editions of the <i>Opera<i> appeared at Lyon in 1531 and 1556, and at Basel in 1538.
BP_Description_2: Ringelbergh's works printed here include the famed piece on methods of study, four works on grammar and language, two on dialectics, six on rhetoric, eight on mixed mathematics and natural philosophy, three on divination, and three on nature and man. Some letters of Ringelbergh as appended at the end. The section on optics (pp 459-480 'Optice') deals with linear perspective in an elementary but detailed manner, with practical instruction and several examples accompanied by woodcut figures, two in the style of Jean P√©lerins <i>De Artificali Perspectiva<i> of 1509. This work on perspective is mentioned by Jean-Fran√ßois Niceron in his La Perspective Curieuse of 1638.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Geometry of an Art: The History of the Mathematical Theory of Perspective from Alberti to Monge<i>|Andersen, K.|Springer, 2007, pp 166-169
BP_Title: Opera, quae proxima pagina enumenatur
BP_Title English Translation: The Works of Joachim Ringelberg of Antwerp, which are enumerated on the next page.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch scholar originally from Antwerp, studied and taught at serveral universities. He wrote on mathematics and optics with the the keen eye of a practitioner. (6)
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1531 Ringelbergh - Opera - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Acerbic attack on the pretensions of the learned, artists and poets, physicians, clerics, and courtly life. A consideration of many professions and sciences.
BP_Description_1: Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa von Nettesheim's consideration of human nature and knowledge, their rupture from the divine, and their subsequent corruption. Agrippa's declamatory invective considered trades, professions, leisure, and persons--nothing and no one was spared. Though deeply interested in science, he thought ‚Äúthere is nothing more fatal than a science stuffed with impiety‚Äù and so it is not faulty epistemology he inveighs against, rather it is human frailty, vanity, pretentions, and credulity. He does not oppose science, he opposes scholastic teaching, worldly preoccupation, and sources of unbelief. <i>De incertitude<i> was widely read and tremendously influential.||The book was condemned by Margaret of Austria, Governess of the Habsburg Netherlands, and the faculties at the Sorbonne and Louvain; to which Agrippa would write vigorous rebuttals.||First printed at Antwerp in 1530, at Cologne in 1531, 1532, 1536, 1537, 1568, 1582, 1584, at Paris in 1533, at Antwerp 1534, at London in 1575, at Lyon in 1624, 1630, 1643, at the Hague in 1653, 1662, Frankfurt and Leipzig in 1693, 1714. It was also printed several times without the place or printer being identified, 1539, 1544, 1550, 1556, 1564, 1609, and 1622. It was translated into German in 1534, Italian in 1543, English in 1569, Dutch in 1651, and French in 1582.
BP_Description_2: The most important aspect of Agrippa's <i>De Incertitudine & Vanitate Scientiarum<i> is its denial of the power of reason, and by extension, the sciences. He considered scientific result so weak and uncertain that it was better not to know things. The motto on the title page is <i>Nihil scire felicissima vita<i>, 'The Happiest Life is that of the Ignorant.' This included the occult sciences. The <i>De Incertitudine & Vanitate Scientiarum<i> is more famous for the acerbic attack it mounts on a long list of targets: the learned, artists and poets, physicians, clerics, courtly life, along with many professions and sciences--102 chapters in all. In natural philosophy and professions he considers arithmetic, geomancy, geometry, optics and perspective, painting, sculpture, architecture, metallurgy, astronomy, astrology, magic in various forms, agriculture, military arts, anatomy, the law and lawyers, and theologians. Astrology and magic are particular targets. The material on optics and perspective is in chapter 23. It briefly reiterates the nature of direct, reflected and refracted vision. To exemplify the uncertainty in this science, he cites nine sources and their varying theories of light, ranging from the Greeks and Aristotle, through the Arabs and Al-Kindi, to St. Augustine. Illusions, false images, uncertainty of distance, size, and motion are presented as cautions regarding vision and how it can mislead the intellect.
BP_Reference(s): De incertitudine et vanitate scientiarum|In: <i>Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy<i>, Stanford University, 2016|http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/agrippa-nettesheim/||<i>Magic and Technology in Early Modern Europe<i>|Grafton, A.|Dibner Library Lecture 2002|Smithsonian Institution Libraries, 2005, 52 pp, NB: pp 31-35.||Agrippa and the Crisis of Renaissance Thought|Nauert, C.G. Jr.,|University of Illinois Press, 1965, 374 pp.||<i>De ineertitudine et vanitate scientiarum<i> Tradition und Wandlung der wissenschaftlichen Skepsis von Agrippa von Nettesheim bis zum Ausgang des 18. Jahrhunderts|Rudolph, G.|<i>Gesnerus<i>, Vol 23, No 3-4, pp 247-265.
BP_Title: Henrici Cornilii Agrippae ab Nettesheym. De incertitudine & Vanitate scientiarum declamatio invectiva, qua universa illa sophorum gigantomachia plus quaÃÄm Herculea impugna[tur] audacia, doceturque nusquam certi quicquam, perpetui, & divini, nisi in solidis dei eloquiis atque eminentia verbi dei latere. Captia tractandorum totiu operis, sequens indicabit pagella. Anno MD XXXII mense Ianuario.
BP_Title English Translation: Henry Cornelius Agrippa of Nettesheim. An invective declaimation  on the uncertainty and vanity of the Sciences, in which the audacity of the whole of those wisemen is assailed by war greater than Hercules, and in which is taught that nothing whatsoever is certain, perpetual, and devine, except in the firm eloquence of God and the eminence  of the word of the hidden God. The chapters of that which are discussed is indicated on the following page. January, 1532.
BP_Biographical Statement: German ocultist, theologian, one-time astrologer and alchemist, and itinerent professor.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Louis, Archbishop of Bourges, probably Louis-Ernest Dubois (1909‚Äì1916)

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Sigismund Gelenius (1497-1554), famed Czech humanist and Greek scholar.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Pliny's uncritical assembly of information gathered from many sources and forming an encyclopedia of all knowledge of the ancient world.
BP_Description_1: This is the second edition of Pliny from the press of Hieronymus Froben. It was contemporaneous with the Aldine edition of Pliny of 1535-1538. It contains numerous fine woodcut initials in the text, including large historiated ones measuring up to 40 x 40 mm, designed by Hans Holbein the Younger, and presenting classical, mythological and Biblical characters, such as Socrates, Diogenes and Alexander, Heracles and Antaeus, Gaius Julius Caesar, Job, and Balaam. Text printed in single columns, in an elegant, relatively large roman type; Gelenius' commentary is printed in single columns in a smaller roman type, indexes printed in quadruple columns in small italic type.||Pliny's monumental work is divided into 37 books covering all aspects of ancient knowledge. He explicitly and scrupulously cites over 2,000 sources and though often showing great and varied erudition, Pliny is credulous regarding some of them. In either case, from these sources he extracted some 20,000 facts, placed them into categories, and wrote explanatory text. Generally, Pliny is interested in practical phenomena and useful data, not the understanding of causes or the pursuit of knowledge. That is, he is a compiler and not an investigator. And there was no unifying principle or theory for Pliny: Nature was the sum of its parts, and he attempted to locate and describe all those parts. There is a lightly-imposed structure to the work: It begins with the heavens, then moves to the Earth and geography, to animals (beginning with humans), sea creatures, and insects. Then to plants and medicines derived from them (a large portion of the work is medical). And finally to metals and minerals. With its extensive tables and indexes, the <i>Historia Naturalis<i> fulfilled Pliny's ambition to create a universal reference book, and continued to be the object of study and considerable authority. Pliny's text was influential in Rome's empire, and beyond its end into Medieval times and the Renaissance. The complete text was copied and extracted, for example, by Isidore of Seville for his  Etymologiae. Even as the veracity of its facts and reliability of its sources dimmed, Pliny's text continued to be read for pleasure and for knowledge of the ancient world. Unlike many other ancient authors who were lost and rediscovered, knowledge of Pliny's text has existed continuously in the two millennia since his time.||The commentary by Sigismundus Gelenius first appeared in this edition and covers the entire text of the <i>Historia<i>. It begins with a dedicatory epistle in which Gelenius' keenness for the authority of manuscripts is apparent. Gelenius' commentary became the most authoritative, and a standard part of editions of Pliny in the remainder of the 16th and much of the 17th century. He revised it in 1545 and again in 1553. It appeared in 28 editions of Pliny's text between 1535 and 1669 issued from Basel, Paris, Lyons, Venice, Frankfurt, and Geneva.
BP_Description_2: Preliminaries begin with Hieronymus Froben's short address to the reader, then Erasmus of Rotterdam's dedicatory epistle to Stanislav I Thurzo, bishop of Olomouc, dated 1525. Book I of the <i>Historia<i> is a table of contents for the subsequent 36 books. They are followed the annotations of Sigismund Gelenius (1497-1554), famed Czech humanist and Greek scholar. Gelenius' annotations are prefaced with his dedication to Dami√£o de G√≥is, Portuguese humanist philosopher and historian. This is followed by a general index and finally a geographic index.||Pliny's 37 books have content as follows. Book I: Preface and tables of contents, lists of authorities; Book II: mathematical and physical description of the world, Astronomy and meteorology; Books III-VI: geography and ethnography; Book VII: anthropology and human physiology; Books VIII-XI: zoology: land animals, marine animals and fish, birds, and insects.; Books XII-XXVII: botany, including agriculture, farming, gardening and horticulture with much material on wine & viticulture; Books XXVIII-XXXII: medicine, pharmacology, medicinal use of plants & animals. Including chapters on occult arts and magic in Book XXX; Books XXXIII-XXXVII: mineralogy, metals, gemstones, glass. The emphasis is on applications in arts and crafts, including chasing in silver, statuary in bronze, painting and making paints and pigments, and sculpture in marble.  Books XII-XXVII contain botany material related to medicine and pharmacology, and include large portions of the writings of two of the ancient herbalists, Diocles and Crataeus, which would otherwise not have survived.||The optics material in Pliny's text is brief, but described reflection, refraction, colors, magnification, and some aspects of vision. The material on reflection is borrowed from Lucretius' <i>De Rerum Natura<i> and describes the appearance of images in plane and curved mirrors. Pliny also mentions multiple and distorted images from facetted mirrors. Refraction is described in water and crystals and particular mention is made of 'rainbow stones'--prismatic colors produced by quartz and crystal. Magnification is mentioned in regard to the properties of certain gemstones. The concentration of light that produces burning by vessels filled with water is also described. In the material on geography, Pliny describes how direct line-of-sight and the curvature of the Earth are responsible for the appearance and disappearance of ships  at the horizon.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Pliny the Elder on Science and Technology<i>|Healy, J.F.|Oxford, 1999, 488 pp, NB: pp 142-152.||Pliny's Historia naturalis. The Most Popular Natural History Ever Published|Gudger, E.W.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 6, No 3, 1924, pp 269-281.||Caius Plinius Secundus|Nauert, C.G., Jr.|In: Catalogus Tranlationum et Commentariorum: Mediaeval and Renaissance latin Translaltions and Commentaries, Catholis University of America Press, Washtington, D.C., Vol IV, 1980, 523 pp, NB: pp 297-422.

BP_Biographical Statement: Roman author, naturalist, and natural philosopher. A naval and army commander of the early Roman Empire, friend of emperor Vespasian, and perished at Pompeii with erruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79.
BP_Provenance: Title-page with an undeciphered ownership inscription dated 10 April 1684, and another unsigned entry dated Sept 1618. 20th-century bookplate of Nazario Pavoni (1929 - 2014), a Swiss geologist and seismologist. Some 16th and 17th century underlining and marginalia. A note on page 182 stating that a white pelican - onocrotalus - was captured in Germany, in 'lacus Brandenburgensis' (Lake Brandenburg?) near 'oppidum Baier Reuth', that is, the town of Bayreuth in northern Bavaria, on April 27, 1561. The annotator further gives Hebrew and German words for pelican.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Georg Tannstetter [Collimitius] (1482-1535)  Viennese humanist, medical doctor, mathematician, astronomer, cartographer, taught at the University of Vienna. Petrus Apianus [Peter Benewitz] (1501-1552)  German humanist, mathematician, astronomer and cartographer, student of Tannstetter.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Tannstetter's editing of Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>, his widely used redaction of <i>De Aspectibus<i>, the 13th century Latin translation of ùë≤ùíäùíïùíÇÃÑùíÉ ùíÇùíç-ùë¥ùíÇùíèùíÇÃÑùíõÃ£ùíäùíì‚Äé,the Arabic original of Ibn al-Haytham. Prefaced by a significant exposition of necessary mathematics.
BP_Description_1: This, the first printing of <i>Perspectiva<i> by the Thuringian scholar Witelo, has it roots in the manuscript tradition. Written in about 1275 while Witelo was at the Papal court at Viterbo, it is a redaction and augmenting of Alhazen's De Aspectibus which had begun to circulate in the Latin West early in the 13th century. It, in turn, was a Latin translation of KitƒÅb al-ManƒÅ·∫ìir‚Äé, the Arabic original of Ab≈´  øAlƒ´ al-·∏§asan ibn al-·∏§asan ibn al-Haytham of around 1050. While John Peckham's Perspectiva Communis was medieval Europe's most used basic optics text, Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> was the advanced, comprehensive equivalent; more than 25 manuscripts are still extant. There were several reasons for its utility.  First, though following Alhazen closely, Witelo imposed a Euclid-like structure of theorems or propositions, including enunciations, definitions, and proofs. This made the text more accessible and didactic; significantly more useful as a textbook than Alhazen's <i>De Aspectibus<i>. Second, Witelo's Perspectiva included a long first book that introduced all the plane and three-dimensional geometry that would be required to study the subsequent text. Though it contained no original mathematics, it brought the necessary geometry to bear directly on optics. Third, Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> included topics not covered in the De Aspectibus, including mirror foci, refraction by glass spheres, and atmospheric refraction.||By the end of 15th century perspectival optics was in the curriculum at the universities of Paris, Vienna, Prague, Leipzig, Krakow, Oxford, Cambridge, and others, and Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> among the principal optics texts in use. In 1472 Johannes M√ºller von K√∂nigsberg, better known as Regiomontanus, published at Nuremburg a prospectus of manuscripts he intended to edit and have printed; number 12 on the list was 'Perspectiva Vitelonis.' But a printed edition did not appear until 1535 when Georg Tannstetter and his astronomer-pupil Peter Apian edited the text for the Nuremburg press of Johannes Petreius. The intention was to produce a book that could be used at the University of Vienna where Tannstetter taught. It would be from the Perspectiva of Witelo that Renaissance Europe learned optics and the source for many optical texts that would appear subsequently. Including Johannes Kepler, prompting him to publish his <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> in 1604. Tannstetter and Apian's edition appeared in 1535, was reprinted in 1551, and would remain Europe's comprehensive optical textbook until Risner's edition of 1572.
BP_Description_2: Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> is in 10 books. 1: Geometry. 2: Light, light rays, and shadows. 3: Structure and function of the eye. 4: Seeing and perception. 5: Reflection at plane surfaces. 6: Reflection at curved surfaces. 7: Reflection at conical surfaces. 8: Reflection at spherical surfaces. 9: Burning mirrors, their foci and construction. 10: Refraction, the rainbow, and other meteorics. Aside from the important Euclidian structure imposed on the De Aspectibus, Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> contains most of Alhazen's material and does not differ in any fundamental way on most optical issues: Theory of vision, nature and propagation of light, the empirical method, apparatus, and experiments, and geometric analysis--all are in the <i>Perspectiva<i>  as they are in the <i>De Ascpectibus<i>. In this sense, Witelo has been called Alhazen's commentator or more derogatorily, as Maurolyco had it, his ape. But in some ways, <i>Perspectiva<i> is importantly different from <i>De Aspectibus<i>. The first book devoted to geometry is important and unique to the <i>Perspectiva<i>. Like Alhazen, Witelo cites Ptolemy on angles of refraction, repeating the values from the <i>Optica<i>. But unlike Alhazen, Witelo attempts and analysis and extension and gets tangled in errors. Witelo's extensive treatment of the parabolic burning mirror and his treatment of the rainbow is not found in the <i>De Aspectibus<i>.

J., translator|University of Missouri-Columbia, 2003||ùëª <i>Witelionis Perspectivae Liber Quintus<i>|English translation of Book 5 of Witelo's Perspectiva|Smith, A. M., translator|Polish Academy of Sciences, 1983|http://kpbc.umk.pl/dlibra/editions-content?id=32536

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First appearance of all of Euclid's geometrical optics.
BP_Description_1: The first complete assemblage of the Euclidean texts, with printings of both Campanus of Navara's and Bartolomeo Zamberti's versions of the Elements. This edition begins with a Preface by Philipp Melanchthon, which censorship had often removed. The Campanus of Navara version of Books I-XV of the Elements was common in the late Middle Ages and Ratdolt used it in his editio princeps of 1482. In addition is the version of Bartolomeo Zamberti which he had based on a Greek text and so, he claimed, rendered a more accurate and faithful Euclid. Latin translations of Euclid's Optica and Catoptrica were first printed in Georgius Valla's massive compendium <i>De Expetendis et Fugiendis Rebus Opus<i> printed by Aldus at Venice in 1501, but this is the first edition of Euclid's collected works to contain them both. The <i>Optica<i> is a Latin translation of the first Greek work on vision and perspective--the earliest surviving text on optics and light in the western world. The <i>Optica<i> presents the phenomena of visible light and the Euclidian idea of vision rays emanating from the eye, comfortably aligned with and analyzed by geometry. It re-emerged as an important text in the 15h century for it use in the theory of linear perspective. The <i>Catoptrica<i>, a treatise on mirrors attributed by Proclus to Euclid, covers the mathematical theory of mirrors, particularly the images formed by plane and spherical concave mirrors.
BP_Description_2: This edition contains the Elements, Phaenomena, Optica, Catoptrica, Data, and the Opusculum de Levi & Ponderoso. The last work is of questionable authorship but Arabic sources attest to a Euclidian work on moving bodies. The Optica begins with 7 postulates which together detail the nature of the visual cone, with its apex at the center of the eye, its circular base out at the limit of vision, and its interior filled with straight rays, spaced equally within. vision takes place when rays fall on an object. From this basis, the subsequent 58 propositions define vision and aspects of visual perception including apparent size, acuity, motion, shape, judgements of distance--all based on the visual angle subtended by the viewed object. Each proposition is based on or proved with geometry. Some of the propositions arise from geometric astronomy, some deal with the practical matters of surveying and mensuration. All this can be considered a geometricization of the Platonic tradition that vision is caused by rays that emanate from the eye.||The Catoptrica begins with six postulates that establish vision as the result of straight vision rays, even when their course is altered by reflection. They also set down the equal-angle law of specular reflection, and the so-called cathetus rule regarding reflected object position and visibility in plane and spherical mirrors. The cathetus being the line passing through the object and perpendicular to the reflecting surface. The rule was held to be universally true until the end of 16th century. Thirty six propositions follow the postulates, established images positions in mirrors of various forms. The latter propositions establish image position using the cathetus rule, attempting to explain image anomalies (size, magnification, position) in curved mirrors. Like the Optica, the Catoptrica is entirely geometric; there is nothing physical or physiological in the material, aside from the fundamental assumption of rectilinear vision rays emitted from the eye, the propagation, direction, and interaction of which can be described entirely by geometry.
BP_Reference(s): ùëª The Optics of Euclid|Burton, H.E., translator|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 46, No 5, 1945, pp 357-372.||ùëª <i>The medieval Latin traditions of Euclid's Catoptrica: A Critical Edition of De speculis with an Introduction, English Translation, and Commentary<i>|Takahashi, K.|Kyushu University Press, 1992, 373 pp.||<i>Campanus of Novara and Euclid's Elements<i>|Busard, H.L.L.|Franz Steiner Verlag, 2005, 535 pp, NB pp 1-46.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 47-64.||Pseudo-Euclidean reflections in ancient optics: a re-examination of textual issues pertaining to the the Euclidean Optica and Catoptrica|Knorr, W.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 1-45.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Georg Hartmann (1489-1564) German engineer, instrument maker, author, printer, humanist, churchman, and astronomer.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Georg Hartmann's editing of Peckham‚Äôs optics textbook with changes and additions, particularly to ocular anatomy. This text is used in all subsequent editions, editions, and translations.
BP_Description_1: Georg Hartmann's editing of Peckham's optics textbook was something of a second-hand project. He had first intended to edit and publish and edition of Ptolemy's optics. Hartmann knew that Johannes M√ºller von K√∂nigsberg, better known as Regiomontanus, had intended edit and publish an edition of Ptolemy's optics. In 1472 Regiomontanus published at Nuremburg a prospectus of manuscripts he intended to edit and have printed; number 13 on the list was 'Perspectiva Ptolemei.' But Regiomontanus died before the project was undertaken. Hartmann had access to some of Regiomontanus papers and manuscripts but was forced to abandon the project for lack of an adequate manuscript. As he mentions in his forward, Harmann worked on the Peckham text instead, intending to improve and update the text with changes and additions, particularly to ocular anatomy. Hartmann also inserts citations of Witelo's Perspectiva which are entirely spurious. This edition marks a significant change in the tradition of printed editions of the <i>Perspectiva Communis<i>, as Hartmann's text was used in all subsequent editions, editings, and translations. Though the principal ideas of Peckham are present, the text is altered considerably. These alterations include typographic and sentence structure--inserting diphthongs and moving verbs to the end of sentences, for example--to comply with the humanistic sensibilities of the times.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 8.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 8.

BP_Short or Common Title: In Tres Libros de Anima Aristotelis Breves Annotationes
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A significant reinterpretation of Aristotelian theory of light and vision, and the first description of light as an entity emitted from sources and vision resulting from its intromission to the eye.
BP_Description_1: John Philoponus' commentary on the three books of <i>De Anima<i> of Aristotle. Commentators of late antiquity, Philoponus in particular, began to break with Aristotelian teaching; expanding, explaining and in some cases completely recasting Aristotle's ideas. With Philoponus begins the rejection of Aristotelian natural philosophy. This was particular true with Philoponus and especially so regarding the nature of light and vision. Philoponus argued against the Aristotelian idea that light actualized the potential transparency of media, proposing instead that is was emitted by a luminous object. This was the late antiquarian beginnings of the medieval idea of species emitted by luminous objects that entered the eye. Soon after his death, Philoponus' break with Aristotle and his theological views were judged to be too radical if not heretical, and so his commentaries had little initial effect in the Latin West, though they would be an important influence on the Arabic scholar Al-Kindi and the formulation of his theory of vision. Most of Philoponus' commentaries were unknown in medieval times, not having been translated into Latin. Only a section of book three of <i>De Anima<i> had been translated from the Greek by William of Moerbeke in the 13th century. But interest in Philoponus' thought, his recasting of Aristotle's ideas, and an interest in a non-Aristotelian natural philosophy awoke in the early Renaissance and created a demand for his works. His commentary on <i>De Anima<i> was first printed in Greek and in Latin at Venice in 1535. Latin editions appeared at Lyon in 1544 and 1558, and at Venice in 1544, 1547, 1551, 1554, 1560, and 1581.
BP_Description_2: Philoponus' commentary and reassessment of Aristotle's theory of light and vision is in book two of <i>De Anima<i>. It was an attempt in late antiquity to reconcile Aristotelian teaching on light and vision with then contemporary knowledge of optics, principally geometric optics. The reconciliation begins with assessing Aristotelian shortcomings and modifying Aristotelian ideas. Philoponus' principle objections to Aristotle's theory of light and vision were that it could not account for or be aligned with the readily observed facts of geometric optics, it could not account for the generation of images in mirrors, nor could it account for the thermal effects produced by burning mirrors.  Philoponus effected a significant reinterpretation of Aristotelian theory of light and vision, changing Aristotle's notion of <i>energia<i> from something that changed transparency from potential to actual, to something that moved from object to the eye within a medium that allowed such motion. Philoponus changed Aristotle's light from an incorporeal quality to an entity emitted from sources, with vision resulting from its intromission to the eye.
BP_Reference(s): Philoponus' Interpretation of Aristotle's Theory of Light|Sambursky, S.|<i>Osiris<i>, Vol 13, 1958, pp 114-126||ùëª <i>Aristotle and Philopnous on Light<i>|De Groot, J.|Routledge, 2016, 137 pp, NB: pp 102-123.||<i>Philoponus and the Rejection of Aristotelian Science<i>|Sorabji, R., editor|Cornell University Press, 1987, NB: pp 66-70, Chapter 12.||Optics and Natural Philosophy in Late Antiquity|Berryman, S.|<i>Apeiron<i>, Vol 45, 2012, pp 201‚Äì220.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Translation and commentary on the pseudo-Aristotelian <i>De Coloribus<i>, a theoretical discussion of light and color.
BP_Description_1: Simone Porzio's Translation and commentary on the Aristotelian work on color, generally attributed to Aristotle's follower Theophrastus. Aristotle's thinking on color is scattered throughout his works but set out most clearly (and collectedly) in his <i>De Sensu et Sensibili<i> and in <i>De Coloribus<i>. Porzio had been teaching at Naples but in 1545 had moved to Pisa, accepting a very substantial offer to teach and assume the chair of natural philosophy. At this time his interests, teaching, and scholarly work turned away from theology and ecclesiastical questions, to physics and medicine. He took up the principal physics and medical texts of Aristotle and their peripatetic tradition. It is known that he read, commented on, and taught from <i>De Celo<i>, <i>De Sensu<i>, <i>De Coloribus<i>, and <i>De Physica<i>, and used commentaries of Galen and late antiquity on these texts. It was at Pisa that he produced this rendering of and commentary on the <i>De Coloribus<i>, giving an analysis and discussion of light and color. Like his other texts, it was quickly printed and in use in several Italian universities, becoming the principal peripatetic text on color in the Renaissance. Editions appeared at Florence in 1548 and at Paris in 1549.
BP_Description_2: Prozio presented Aristotle's theory of color in six chapters. 1: The nature of color. 2: Simple colors. 3: 'Middle' or mixed colors. 4: 'Infinite' colors. 5: Mutation of color by mixing. 6: Colors of hair, feathers, and skin. The introduction gives the color theories of the Pythagoreans, Plato, and Aristotle. He also gives an analysis of Greek color terms and their Latin equivalent. Prozio presents the principal aspects of Aristotelian color theory: color was a property of an object's surface; color was transmitted to eye by filling an actualized transparent medium--and therefore was not a perception; color was the  result of mixing whiteness and blackness in various proportions. On these three aspects he provides considerable commentary. Prozio graded and arranged colors according to their 'shine'--what would now be called their luminance. Yellow was the brightest end of this scale, and violet at the dark end, red in the middle. The place on this scale indicated the proportion of white and black that produced the color.
BP_Reference(s): Tra Aristotele, Alessandro di Afrodisia de Vald√©s: Note su Simone Porzio|Vasoli, C.|<i>Rivista di Storia della Filosofia<i>, Vol 56, No 4, 2001, pp 561-607.
BP_Title: De coloribus libellus
BP_Title English Translation: A Small Book on Colors
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian philosopher and lecturer in medicine at Pisa. Early interest in natural philosophy eventually turned to pure philosophy.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Errata on recto Bb‚ÇÑ, table of contents in old hand on verso
BP_Binding: Modern 1/4 Vellum Over Old Blackletter Printed Leaf Covered Boards
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1548 Porzio - De coloribus libellus - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Textbook on mathematical optics and parabolic burning mirrors, with mathematical analyses and methods of construction. Part of Fine's effort to revive mathematics at the University of Paris.
BP_Description_1: Oronce Fine set out to revive mathematics in Renaissance France, specifically in the curriculum at the Coll√®ge de France. <i>De Speculo Ustorio<i> and other books were his effort to provide the necessary awareness of mathematic and provide students textbooks. This is the origin of and intention for his textbook on mathematical optics and parabolic burring mirrors, which included mathematical analyses and methods of construction. As Fine stats in the preface, his most important optical source for <i>De Speculo Ustorio<i> was Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>. Though Fine likely had access to the <i>Perspectiva's<i> printing in 1535, it is known that he worked from a manuscript copy before the 1535 printing. His other optical source was an edited version of Alhazen‚Äôs <i>De Speculis Comburentibus<i> which had been printed in 1548. Fine's parabolic geometry comes from Georgius Valla‚Äôs <i>De Expetendis et Fugiendis Rebus Opus<i> of 1501 and from Johann Werner‚Äôs Libellus of 1522. Though not of original material, the <i>De Speculo Ustorio<i> was a carefully crafted  compilation of sections of select texts, comprising a much-need textbook on catoptrics. It was the first such book printed in France and like his other books was widely popular, esteemed for its careful presentation, straightforward Latin, and the excellence of its figures. <i>De Speculo Ustorio<i>, along with several other of his books, became widely used throughout Europe at universities in need of up-to-date textbooks. In this, Fine took advantage not only of his knowledge of optics and geometry, but also of the need and ability of students.||An Italian translation of <i>De Speculo Ustorio<i> appeared in 1587 as an appendix to a translation of another of Fine‚Äôs books, <i>Protomathesis<i>. Fine's Propositions 8 and 9 were repeated nearly verbatim in Giovanni Battista Della Porta's <i>Magiae Naturalis<i> of 1558.
BP_Description_2: Fine's textbook has the intention of exercising mathematical analysis in catoptrics, of showing the superior nature of paraboloids as burring mirrors, and to show practical methods to make such mirrors. First, there are 12 definitions involving conic sections, then four postulates involving the laws of reflection. There follow propositions, proved using Euclid's Elements, culminating in Proposition 7, showing that incoming rays parallel to the axis of the parabola are all reflected to the same point, the focus. Proposition 8 shows a way to draw a parabola and Proposition 9 demonstrates a way to construct a parabolic burning mirror using the method in Proposition 8. Proposition 10 involves the hyperbolic conic section, though it is not named as such.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Oronce Fine's De Speculo Ustorio|Ross, R. P.|<i>Historia Mathematica<i>, Vol 3, 1976, pp 63-70.||Oronce Fine's De speculo ustorio between paper and Craft|Dupre, S|In: <i>The Worlds of Oronce Fine<i>|Marr, A, editor|Lincolnshire, Shaun Tyas, 2009, 224 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Reissue of Witelo's recension and gloss of Alhacen, used in the new Jesuit schools.
BP_Description_1: Second printing of Witelo's redaction and extension of Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i>. In 1548 Geronimo Nadal, SJ, began working on the constitution that would govern the new Jesuit schools that were being established across Europe as part of the Counter-Reformation, and wrote the <i>Constitutiones Cottegli Messanensis<i>, which can be considered the first draft of Jesuit <i>Ratio Studiorum<i>. This included curriculum and texts, among which Nadal specifically lists 'Communis' or 'Vitellio, Norimbuergae 1535' as the optics texts. 'Communis' is undoubtedly the <i>Perspectiva Communis<i> of John Peckham, and the other is Tannstetter's 1535 edition of Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>. With such a recommendation and requirement, it does not seem to go too far to suggest this as one of the reasons for the reissue of Tannstetter edition of Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> in 1551.
