BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Encyclopedia on natural phenomena with a significant section on optics drawn from Peckham and Witelo, and containing the first mention of using a biconvex lens in a camera obscura.
BP_Description_1: Girolamo Cardano's attempt to present a complete compendium of natural philosophy. The material is fundamentally Aristotelian but not in any pure peripatetic form; it is amended, changed, and sometimes subverted with a wide variety of refinements and deviations. Though presented as an encyclopedia on natural phenomena, De Subtilitate is more of a miscellany; a kind of verbal cabinet of wonders that highlights Aristotelian shortfalls and opportunities for new explanations. In that way, <i>De Subtilitate<i> was at the vanguard of the reform of natural philosophy by introducing experientialism and empiricism, insisting as Cardano did, that experience is the only authority. This is a unique aspect of the <i>De Subtilitate<i>, for Cardano frequently introduces his own experience into his descriptions, making the entire narrative somewhat personal. Another unique aspect is the frequent use of mathematical calculations or demonstrations. That mathematics would be part of a natural philosophical discussion was uncommon, since mathematics was held to be incapable of revealing causes or characteristics of phenomena--it could only give a technical description. Cardano is also unique in rejecting the occult and esotericism, wanting to reform Aristotelian natural philosophy, revealing the  workings of the natural world to all, and not replace it with 'natural magic' that could be understood only by the initiated. This was one of the reasons for the book's great influence: it was read by craftsmen, mathematicians, alchemists, and such--any who used knowledge of the natural world--as well as the learned. Editions appeared at Paris in 1550 and 1551, at Nuremburg in 1550, at Basel in 1553, 1554, 1559, 1560, 1582, and 1611,  at Lyon in 1551, 1554, 1559, 1580, and 1615, and at Frankfurt in 1576, 1602, 1607.
BP_Description_2: Cardano's <i>De Subtiltate<i> is in 21 books. 1: The Principles, Matter, Form, the Vacuum, the Resistance of Bodies, Natural Motion, and Position 2: The Elements, and Their Movements and Actions. 3: On Heaven. 4: On Light and Illumination. 5: On Mixture, and Incomplete or Metallic Mixed Things. 6: On Metals. 7: On Stones. 8: On Plants. 9: On Animals that are Generated from Decay. 10: On Perfect Animals. 11: On the Necessity and Form of Man. 12: On Man's Nature and Temperament. 13: On the Senses, What Can be Sensed, and Pleasure. 14: On the Soul and the Intellect. 15: On Useless Subtleties. 16: On the Sciences. 17: On the Arts and Artefacts. 18: On Marvels, and the Way to Represent Diverse Things Beyond Belief. 19: On Demons. 20: On Primary Substances or Lives. 21: On God and the Universe. Book 4 ranges over a wide variety of topics in optics, vision, and light without any apparent order: Celestial light sources, including the Milky Way; condensing mirrors; heat from light; luminous hot objects; color; light and color as requirements for vision; illumination as light in a transparent body and as color in an opaque one; mirrors and their making; reflection from objects; shadows; the atmosphere and twilight; the rainbow; the camera obscura; solar eclipse; burning mirrors; viewing mirrors convex and concave; sundials; sun shadows and surveying; refraction from crystals; illusions; painting and colors and pigments; solar and lunar motion. Most topics are treat briefly, and much is drawn from Peckham and Witelo, but the section on the rainbow is long and detailed. The section of the camera obscura is extended and contains the first mention of using a biconvex lens (a glass sphere, actually) in the aperture to make the cast image brighter and sharper.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>The De Subtilitate of Girolamo Cardano<i>|Forrester, J.M., translator|Arizona Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, Tempe, AZ, Vol 426, 2013, 1058 pp.

DuHamel includes Hartmann's original preface. The periodic appearance of Peckham's <i>Perspective Communis<i> demonstrates its continued use as a textbook on optics in the Renaissance up to the time of Kepler. Editions of DuHamel's editing appeared in 1556 and 1580. An Italian translation appeared in 1593.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean Pena (Jean de la P√®ne) (1528 - 1558) French educational reformer and student of the royal mathematician of France, Peter Ramus. Wrote and translated knowingly in mathematics and optics and famed for the preface written for this text: De usu optices praefatio, Preface on the use of optics.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Pena's Latin translation from the Greek of Euclid's geometrical optics of vision and mirrors; includes the influential preface 'The Use of Optics.'
BP_Description_1: Jean Pena's Latin translation from the Greek of Euclid's <i>Optica<i> and the <i>Catoptrica<i> was prompted by his poor assessment of the commonly available translations. He was referring either to the text that appears in Georgius Valla's  <i>De Expetendis et Fugiendis Rebus Opus<i> in 1501 or to the translation of Bartolomeo Zamberti. In his preface, Pena agrees with the assessment of Francesco Maurolyco that earlier translators had insufficient knowledge of Perspectiva. Pena also notes that some theorems and many of the scholia are missing and that some demonstrations accompanied the wrong theorem. Pena worked from a Greek text of the <i>Optica<i> and <i>Catoptrica<i> that he was given by his mentor Peter Ramus. Pena sought to completely and accurately present the whole of the optical and vision teaching of Euclid, in part as a balance to what he considered the uncritical acceptance of Witelo and Peckham common at that time. ('I am not moved by the credulity of the vulgar, nor do I fear the opinion of Witelo, an optician of authority . . .') Pena presents the Euclidian work on the geometrical optics of vision and mirrors and even more influentially, includes the preface <i>De Usu Optices<i>, 'The Use of Optics.'-- for which Pena's book became famous. In it, he summarized optical principles including refraction, and claimed that practical astronomical knowledge and optical laws, demonstrated that Aristotle's celestial spheres could not exist. Aristotle's spheres and aether were simply air. The heavens were not fixed but fluid and that 'everything that the natural philosophers maintain about the sphere of fire, is imagination.' Pena's dismissal of Aristotelian cosmology was widely discussed and became part of the 16th century challenge to Aristotelianism generally. Pena's <i>De Usu Optices<i> was cited by Johannes Kepler in his <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611.||Editions appeared in 1557 and 1604. An Italian translation by Ignatio Danti appeared in 1573. A French translation of the Geek of the Optica appeared in 1663. <i>De Usu Optices<i> appeared as an introduction to Friedrich Risner's <i>Optice Libri Quatuor<i> of 1606 and 1615. It also was printed in the posthumous collected works <i>Petri Rami Professoris Regii, Et Audomari Talaei Collectaneae Praefationes, Epistolae, Orationes<i> in 1577 and 1599.
BP_Description_2: In Pena's Greek and Latin texts, presented side-by-side, there are 61 theorems in the Optica and 31 in the Catoptrica. He had studied optics carefully and knew it well, so the Latin translation was more accurate than previous translations. The  texts are preceded by Pena's long introductory essay 'De Usu Optices,' On the use of Optics, in which he assessed some of the teachings of Witelo and Peckham that he considered erroneous. He argued that though both authors were great scholars, nothing should be accepted until experimentally demonstrated. Pena rejects Witelo's accounting (coming from Alhazen's De Aspectibus) of the intromission theory of vision, supporting the Euclidian idea of rays emanating from the eye. Pena also criticized Peckham's account of the Milky Way light reflected from sun and stars. More importantly, Pena sets out his ideas on astronomy, cosmology, and physics, supporting them by optical arguments. According to Pena, the matter of the heavens was not Aristotelian aether but air. In the essay, Pena detailed how optical theory spoke against a heavenly ether and the celestial spheres that moved the planets and stars. Given the irrefutable facts of refraction, Pena states, that light from the fixed stars would be refracted each time it passed through one of the celestial spheres and 'the fixed stars observed elsewhere than at the zenith, through other media, would never be perceived in their true place.' If that is so, he says, astronomy is worthless. Pena also discussed how optics can explain coronae, the rainbow, and mock suns.||Latin translations of Euclid's <i>Optica<i> and <i>Catoptrica<i> were first printed in Georgius Valla's massive compendium <i>De Expetendis et Fugiendis Rebus Opus<i> printed by Aldus at Venice in 1501, but they both first appeared together in the first Latin edition of Euclid's collected works in 1537. The <i>Optica<i> is the first Greek work on vision and perspective--the earliest surviving text on optics and light in the western world. The <i>Optica<i> presents the phenomena of visible light and the Euclidian idea of vision rays emanating from the eye, comfortably aligned with and analyzed by geometry. It re-emerged as an important text in the 15h century for its use in the theory of linear perspective. The <i>Catoptrica<i>, a treatise on mirrors attributed by Proclus to Euclid, covers the mathematical theory of mirrors, particularly the images formed by plane and spherical concave mirrors.
BP_Reference(s): Liber de visu : The Greco-Latin Translation of Euclid's Optics|Theisen, W.R.|<i>Mediaeval Studies<i>, Vol 41, 1979, pp 44-105.||ùëª The Optics of Euclid|Burton, H.E., translator|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 46, No 5, 1945, pp 357-372.||ùëª <i>The medieval Latin traditions of Euclid's Catoptrica: A Critical Edition of De speculis with an Introduction, English Translation, and Commentary<i>|Takahashi, K.|Kyushu University Press, 1992, 373 p.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 47-64.||Jean Pean (1528-58) and Stoic Physics in the Sixteenth Century|Barker, P.|<i>The Southern Journal of Philosophy<i>, 1985, Vol XXIII, Supplement||<i>Change and Continuity in Early Modern Cosmology<i>|Boner, P.J., editor|Spring, 2011, 181 pp, NB: 40-48.||The Challenge of Applied Optics|In: <i>The Unmaking of the Medieval Christian Cosmos, 1500‚Äì1760<i>|Randles, W.G.L.|Routledge, 2016, 296 pp||Atmospheric Refraction and the Ramus Circle: Aspects of a Late Sixteenth-Century Dispute|Peoux, G.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 67, No 4 , 2010, pp 457-484.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Natural Magic is presented as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. Vison, mirrors and lenses are considered in the optics section.
BP_Description_1: Giambattista Della Porta's <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri IIII<i>, his early book on natural magic appeared in 1558. For Della Porta, Natural Magic was the practical part of natural philosophy and focused on exceptional, unusual, extraordinary phenomena, rather than the quotidian. It was the recognition and mastering of natural phenomena, in particular, those phenomena that had to be sought out, phenomena that were otherwise hidden. The point was not to explain the phenomena, but to be able to (re)produce it, display it, describe it and thus reveal nature's secrets. Girolamo Ruscelli, a member of Napes <i>Accademia Segreta<i> published his <i>I Segreti del reverendo dono Alessio Piemontese<i> in 1553. This academy and the famed book of secrets likely inspired Della Porta, being the pattern for his own <i>'Accademia dei Segreti<i>, The Academy of Mysteries, in Naples. He and its few members pursued experiments, demonstrations, crafts, and recipes. These formed the basis for the <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri IIII<i> of 1558, which was an immediate success and  established Della Porta‚Äôs reputation as a magus and professor of secrets in Europe. Della Porta was only 23 at the time and his notions of Natural Magic were quite grandly conceived. Though the book and its author would change in the thirty-year course of its expansion, one aspect did not: the notion that explaining natural phenomena and unlocking the secrets of nature are fundamentally esoteric activities. The book is dedicated to Philip II of Spain--in hopes of patronage, no doubt. Editions of the <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri IIII<i> appeared at Naples in 1558, at Antwerp in 1560, 1561, 1562, 1564, 1567, 1576 , 1584, 1585, and 1586, at Leyden  in 1561, at Colone in 1562, at Lyons in 1565, 1569, 1572, and 1578, at Venice in 1588. The second, much expanded edition, appeared in 1588
BP_Description_2: Giambattista Della Porta presents natural magic as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. Della Porta gives his meaning of Natural Magic at the opening of the first book: 'What is Natural Magic? . We divide the magic into two parts, namely in an infamous one, composed of enchantments, of foul spirits and born of an evil curiosity, that the Greeks, more learned call Go√´tsia or Theurgia; it is the one that arouses charms and phantoms or illusions, which suddenly disappear, without leaving the slightest trace. The other part is natural magic, which everyone reveres or honors, because there is nothing higher or more enjoyable for lovers of good literature, who feel that it is nothing else than natural philosophy, or the supreme science.'||There are 4 books, the first sets out the basic principles which govern natural magic. The later three books are compilations of 'wonderful' recipes and phenomena. Each entry is brief and is usually just an oracular statement; no evidence or analysis is given. Those entries related to optics deal with miraculous lights and lamps, and mirrors of several types. The material on mirrors became some of the books most famous entries, involving concave mirrors that produced startling virtual images.
BP_Reference(s): Knowing by doing in sixteenth-century natural magic: Giambattista della Porta and the wonders of nature|Saito, F.|<i>Circumscribere<i>, Vo1 14, 2014, pp 17-39||<i>Science and the Secretes of Nature: Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture<i>|Eamon, W.|Princeton University Press, 1994, 490 pp, NB: pp 210-233.||<i>The Optics of Giambattista della Porta(ca. 1535‚Äì1615): A Reassessment<i>|Borrelli, A., Hon, G., Zik, Y., editors|Springer, 2017, 205 pp, NB: pp 11-39.
BP_Title: Magiae Naturalis sive De Miraculis Rerum Natualium Libri IIII. Jo. Baptista Porta Neapolitano Auctore.
BP_Title English Translation: Natural Magic, or On the Wonderful Things of Nature in Four Books. Authored by Giovanni Battista della Porta, Neapolitan.
BP_Biographical Statement: Neoplitan scholar, polymath, and natural philosopher. Prolific author, showman, and founder of the Academia Secretorum Naturae, the first scientific society.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1560 Porta - Magi√¶ Naturalis Libri IIII - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook of Aristotelian natural philosophy, designed for use in the Quadrivium, tinctured deeply with Christian orthodoxy and instruction, and  widely used in religious schools. The theory of vision, color, and light is entirely Peripatetic .
BP_Description_1:
Frans Titelmans' textbook of Aristotelian natural philosophy was written for use in the Quadrivium. The Reformation and Counter Reformation had a significant impact on natural philosophy, making it important for Christians of any denomination as an exploration of God's creation and a method for moral and catechetical instruction. In his preface Titelmans writes 'I saw that the discipline of physics, if it was treated rightly and according to
its dignity, was of the greatest importance to sacred Theology and for the fuller knowledge of God.' Textbooks of all confessions framed natural philosophy as a pious exercise, including Titelmans which is tinctured deeply with Christian orthodoxy and instruction--in his case with psalmist piety. The book was widely used in religious schools and remained so into the next century until Jesuit textbooks began to appear. Editions of the <i>Compendium<i> appeared at Paris in 1542, 1547, 1562, and 1566, at Lyon in 1545, 1551, 1564, and 1596, at Antwerp in 1570, and at Venice in 1572.
BP_Description_2: Titelmans' text is in 12 books. 1: Principles of natural things. 2: Cause of natural things. 3: Motion and its accidents. 4: Infinity, place, vacuum, and time. 5: Generation and corruption of natural things. 6: meteorics. 7: The heavens and the earth. 8: Life in general, plants, lives of animals. 9: Exterior senses and what they sense. 10: Interior senses, sleep and vision. 11: The intellect. 12: Appetites and the excellence of will. The optical material is in book 9. The theory of vision, color, and light is entirely Aristotelian, modified by medieval Perspectiva. Titlemans describes the structure of the Aristotelian-Galenic eye, with the 'crystalinus' (crystalline lens) being the seat of vision, receiving species from visible objects. Color is the precipitator of vision and what is received by eye from the viewed object, color being an inherent property of the object. Light actualizes the potential transparency of a medium, allowing the transmission of color's species to the eye. Though species themselves are not visible, they produce the visual sensation. Lumen is a type of light, and Lux is what is seen in Lumen.
BP_Reference(s): The Rise of the Philosophical Textbook|Schmitt, C.B.|In: <i>The Cambridge History of Renaissance Philosophy<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1988, 969 pp, NB: pp 795-796.||<i>Subverting Aristotle: Religion, History, and Philosophy in Early Modern Science<i>|Martin C.|Johns Hopkins University Press, 2014, 272 pp.
BP_Title: Compendium Philosophiae Naturalis, seu De Consideratione rerum naturalium, earumque ad suum Creatorem reductione. Libri XII. Authore Francisco Titelmanno Hasselleni, ordinis fratrum minorum, sanctarum scripturarum apud Louaniense Praelectore.
BP_Title English Translation: A Compendium of Natural Philosophy; that is, On the Consideration of Natural Things and their reduction to its Creator. Twelve Books. Authored by Frans Titelman of Hasselt, Order of Friars Minor, Praelector of Sacred Scripture at Louvain.
BP_Biographical Statement: Flemish Francisan scholar, commentator, philosopher, theologian, exegete, and catechist. Tusseled famously with Erasmus about the his Greek and Latin edition of the New Testament.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1564 Titelmans - Compendium Philosophi√¶ Naturalis - Images.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Hubert van Giffen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Hubert van Giffen's edited text of 'On the Nature of Things' by Titus Lucretius Carus, presenting Epicurean natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Plantin's first printing of the text edited by the Dutch humanist Hubert van Giffen, professor of law in Strasbourg, Altdorf and Ingolstadt and advisor to Emperor Rudolf II. As with most copies, though printed in 1565, this copy 's title page  bears the date 1566; printed for purposes of marketing it at the Frankfurt book fair that year. In addition to the Lucretian poem, this edition also contains the original Greek text of Epicurus' Letter to Herodotus, in which he expresses his theories on Physics and Meteorics, various passages on Epicurus taken from the works of Cicero, and an extract from the Greek text of Thucydides on the plague of Athens. van Giffen dedicated the work to Johannes Sambucus (that is, J√°nos Zs√°mboky) Hungarian humanist, physician, philologist and historian. Zs√°mboky is the source for the editions' marginal philological notes and the very extensive final index.||Early printings of  <i>De Rerum Natura<i> vary widely in accuracy, detail, and emphasis--its manuscript tradition being uncertain. The oldest two manuscripts are of 9th century Carolingian origin. Another tradition is formed by Italian manuscripts all originating from Poggio Bracciolini's discovery in 1417 of a manuscript of Lucretius‚Äôs <i>De natura rerum<i> in  the library of a Swiss monastery. Thus, when printed edition began to appear, the result depended heavily on the editor, his available sources, the manuscript tradition he adhered to, and his background. There are 54 Renaissance manuscripts extant.||The editio princeps appeared at Brescia around 1473 and, like the editions that appeared in 1486 Verona and in 1495 at Venice, was filled with errors. A corrected Aldine quarto edited by Hieronymus Avancius appeared at Venice in 1500. The last Aldine edition appeared in 1515, printing a text edited by Andrea Navagero. It's text dominated printed editions for 50 years. The Parisian Aristotelian Denys Lambin (1520‚Äì1572) published a corrected text accompanied by a massive 300,000-word commentary In 1563. Though scholarly important, Lambin's work was impractically large and expensive. Its rival became this edition produced by van Giffen, which was better suited for general and student use. Both were used until the 18th century. In all, 30 editions were printed before 1600. Translations appear in French in 1650, in English in 1656 and 1680, in Italian in 1669, in Dutch in 1701, and German in 1784.
BP_Description_2: Lucretius adhered to the philosophy of Epicurus, who, writing 200 years before, advanced an atomism as the foundation of the natural world and, of a consequence, held that the gods cannot and do not influence the affairs of men. In its nearly 7500 lines, Lucretius's didactic poem has as its object the freeing of man from ignorance and the thralldom of religion and to provide guidance for a better lived life. It has six books. Book 1: The nature of atoms and the void; Rook 2: The properties and combinations of atoms in the diverse phenomena of the world; Book 3: The nature of the soul and its mortality; Book 4: The nature of our perception of the physical world, dreams, illusions and sex; Book 5: The history of the world and the development of mankind and a range of celestial and terrestrial phenomena; Book 6: A description of the great plague of Athens of 430 BC.||Book 4 begins with a long explanation of the physical nature of perception, including the idea of vision based on the ocular reception of simulacra emitted by viewed objects, and a list of and reasons for optical illusions. Though the senses, including vision, are presented as limited, Lucretius holds they are reliable enough to be the basis for behavioral choice.
BP_Reference(s): Some problems in Lucretius‚Äô account of vision'|Sharples, R.W.|Leeds International Classical Studies, Vol 1, No 2, 2002, pp 1-11.||Titi Lucreti Cari De Rerum Natura Libri Sex|Bailey, C.|3 vols, Oxford, Oxford University Press, , 1947.||Lucretius: ‚ÄòDe Rerum Natura‚Äô IV, Godwin, J.|Aris & Phillips Classical Texts, 1986, pp 182.||A bibliography of Lucretius|Gordon, C.A.|St. Paul‚Äôs Bibliographies,Winchester, 1985, 323 pp.
BP_Title: De rerum natura libri sex, mendis innumerabilibus liberati; & in pristinum paen√®, veterum potissim√® librorum ope ac fide, ab Oberto Gifanio Burano iuris scholar, restituti. Qua praeterea ab eodem in hoc opere sint praestita, inversa pagina indicabit.
BP_Title English Translation: Six Books on the Nature of Things. Liberated from innumerable mistakes, and restored to its former state with the help of faith and the principal books of the ancients, by Hubert van Giffen, legal scholar. Those [things] presented in this same work, will be found on the reverse page.
BP_Biographical Statement: Roman poet and philosopher. Defender of Epicurus.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Binding includes  MSS wastepaper

BP_Author AKA: Ab≈´  øAlƒ´ al-·∏§asan ibn al-·∏§asan ibn al-Haytham
BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Friedrich Risner(1522 - 1580) German mathematician and student of Petrus Ramus, studied and wrote in optics in France.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Risner's editing and first printing of the most influential optics book ever written. Based on <i>De Aspectibus<i>, the 13th century Latin translation of ùë≤ùíäùíïùíÇÃÑùíÉ ùíÇùíç-ùë¥ùíÇùíèùíÇÃÑùíõÃ£ùíäùíì‚Äé, Ibn al-Haytham's Arabic original.
BP_Description_1: Friedrich Risner's editing and the first printing of the most influential optics book ever written was a milestone in the history of optics. Risner's text is from manuscripts of the <i>De Aspectibus<i>, a 13th century Latin translation of KitƒÅb al-ManƒÅ·∫ìir, 'The Book of Optics.' The KitƒÅb al-ManƒÅ·∫ìir was completed at the Fatimid capital of Cairo sometime between 1028 and 1038 by Ab≈´  ΩAlƒ´ al-·∏§asan ibn al-·∏§asan ibn al-Haytham, the greatest physicist of the Islamic Golden Age. A Latin translation appeared in the  West no later than 1200--perhaps earlier--and began circulating. While <i>De Aspectibus<i> and Alhacen are the title and author given in the incipit of most medieval manuscripts, Risner titled his edition <i>Opticae Thesaurus Alhazeni Arabis<i>. The <i>De Aspectibus<i> was not only a cogent synthesis of ancient and early medieval optics but also a major advance. Alhacen subsumed Aristotle, Euclid, and Ptolemy, and produced an experimentally-based physics of light, a revolutionary theory of vision, a detailed consideration of perception, and an elaborate, highly mathematical geometrical optics. <i>De Aspectibus<i> advanced experimental natural philosophy, established a taxonomy of visual perception, created a centripetal system that unified the many centrifugal aspects of optics, and so laid the foundations of medieval Perspectiva.||Risner's preface gives the edition's origin: Prompted by his mentor Petrus Ramus, he undertook the editing task using two manuscripts, one provided by Ramus. Risner's editorial work was extensive and significant: structure was added to the text, including dividing it into propositions, adding enunciations and cross-references, and citing sources. All of this made it easier to study than any of the manuscript copies. The typography is easy to read, abbreviations were kept to a minimum, and the figures were added to and significantly improved. The latter was particularly important in the highly technical parts of the text.||The influence of Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> was profound. Between the time of its appearance and about 1400, virtually every optics text in the Latin West either cited it explicitly or bore its influence, and all were derivative, smaller in scope, and shorter in length. By 1325 it was in use at Universities. Optics texts from the advent of printing until the end of the 17th century all show the influence of the <i>De Aspectibus<i>. The greatest opticians of the age read and learned from Risner's Opticae Thesaurus; Thomas Hariot, Johannes Kepler, Willebrord Snell, and Ren√© Descartes all cited the work. 100 years after its publication, Isaac Barrow cited the work in his Lectiones Opticae et Geometricae of 1674. The Opticae Thesaurus swept the field of optics, being considered by contemporaries to treat all of then-current optics and becoming the foremost advanced optics text of the Renaissance.
BP_Description_2: Risner divides the <i>De Aspectibus<i> into seven books. Book 1: Mechanisms of vision, involving the nature of light and color, their propagation, and the structure of the eye. Book 2: Direct vision by incident rays, visual perception and its 22 'intentions.' Book 3: Vision defects, failures, and deceptions involving size, shape, and position. Book 4: Reflection and its laws, its mathematics, its cause. A discussion of mirrors and their making, and an analysis of reflection from plane, spherical, and cylindrical mirrors. Book 5: A detailed, nearly opaque mathematical analysis of image-formation from mirrors, including two-dimensional and 3-dimensional problems. Book 6: Visual errors caused by reflected images. Book 7: Refraction and its laws, its mathematics, its cause, including a discussion of image formation by refraction at surfaces of various shapes. Modern scholarship has revealed that the Latin <i>De Aspectibus<i> lacks the first three of the eight chapters in Book 1 of the Arabic original which deal with the direct propagation of light. Book 1 presents many of Alhacen's experiments to determine the nature of light; it linear propagation, it's failure to interact when beams intersect, and its diffusion when striking surfaces. Book 2 presents a theory of vision that solves the problem of all earlier intromissionist theories: if objects emit light rays from every point into every direction, how can such a confusion of rays reaching the eye result in a clear image? Alhacen proposes that only rays perpendicular to the spherically-curved cornea are sufficiently strong to get to the crystalline. The result is a one-to-one mapping of points on an object to points on the eye. It is also in this book that Alhacen considers and develops his 22 intentions of visual perception, classifying and describing the steps from the physical input of rays, to the final mental perception. He wrote 'Nothing visible is understood by the sense of sight alone, save light and colors.' Alhacen's sophisticated ideas regard visual perception had a significant effect on Medieval thought. Book 4 also presents experiments, these to verify the nature of reflection from mirrors. It is here that Alhacen presents his ballistic metaphor for reflection; the trajectory of a ball encountering a hard, fixed surface. Book 5 presents and solves (among other things) what has come to be called 'Alhacen's Problem': given the positions of object and eye, find the place on a spherical mirror where image reflection takes place. Book 7 is considerably more brief in its treatment of refraction then that given to reflection in Books  4-6. In it, Ptolemy's tables of refraction angles are considered, edited, and extended.
BP_Reference(s): The literature on Alhacen and the De Aspectibus is vast. The following is what I have found most helpful.||‚ÅÇ <i>Opticae Thesaurus<i>|Introduction to this reprint edition by Lindberg, D.C.|Johnson Reprint Corporation|New York, 1972, pp v-xxxiv||For an analysis and translation of ùë≤ùíäùíïùíÇÃÑùíÉ ùíÇùíç-ùë¥ùíÇùíèùíÇÃÑùíõÃ£ùíäùíì‚Äé, Ibn al-Haytham's Arabic text,‚Äé see:|ùëª <i>The Optics of Ibn al-Haytham<i>|Sabra A.I.|Warburg Institute, University of London|London, 1989||For an analysis and translation of  ùë´ùíÜ ùë®ùíîùíëùíÜùíÑùíïùíäùíÉùíñùíî, the 13th century latin translation of the Arabic original see:|ùëª <i>Alhacen's Theory of Visual Perception<i>|Smith A.M.|Transactions of the American Philosophical Society, Nos 91, 95, 98, 100|2001, 2006, 2008, 2010|http://www.jstor.org/stable/3657358|http://www.jstor.org/stable/3657357|http://www.jstor.org/stable/20020399|http://www.jstor.org/stable/20020403|http://www.jstor.org/stable/27757395|http://www.jstor.org/stable/27757399|http://www.jstor.org/stable/20787647|http://www.jstor.org/stable/20787651||MS 14th century: http://daten.digitale-sammlungen.de/~db/0004/bsb00042717/images/||http://db.biblhertz.it/alhacen/ms?&p=4
BP_Title: Opticae thesaurus. Alhazeni Arabis libri septem, nunc primum editi. Eiusdem liber De Crepusculis et nubium ascensionibus. Item Vitellonis Thuringopoloni libri X. Omnes instaurati, figuris illustrati & aucti, adiectis etiam in Alhazenum commentarijs, A Federico Risnero.
BP_Title English Translation: A Treasury of Optics. The Seven Books of Alhazen of Arabia, now Edited for the First Time. By the Same Author: A book on Twilight and the Height of Clouds. Also, Ten books of Vitelo of Thuringopolis. All restored, Augmented and Illustrated with Figures, and Augmented with Commentary on Alhazen as Well.  By Friedrich Risner.
BP_Biographical Statement: Greatest of the Medieval Islamic natural philosophers, author of many texts, earliest of experimentalists.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Witelo 1572
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Calf Over Drab Boards Rebacked

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Friedrich Risner (1522 - 1580) German mathematician and student of Petrus Ramus, studied and wrote in optics in France.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Risner's editing of Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>, a widely used redaction of <i>De Aspectibus<i>, the 13th century Latin translation of the Arabic original ùë≤ùíäùíïùíÇÃÑùíÉ ùíÇùíç-ùë¥ùíÇùíèùíÇÃÑùíõÃ£ùíäùíì‚Äé, of Ibn al-Haytham. Prefaced by a significant exposition of necessary mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Friedrich Risner's editing and additions to the text produced by Georg Tannstetter and Peter Apian and printed in 1535 and  reprinted in 1551.  Risner's edition of 1572 superseded Tannstetter and Apian's edition.  He added references to Euclid's Elements to most of the propositions in Witelo's first book covering geometry. Risner adds numbering to the defintions and propositions in the Tannstetter text, and uses the same figures. The numbering of those sections in the Tannstetter text that have Roman Numerals is preserved but change to Arabic numbers. In this way, Risner had a very light touch when dealing with the Tannstetter text.||Tanstetter had edited Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>, the widely used redaction of <i>De Aspectibus<i>, the 13th century Latin translation of the Arabic original KitƒÅb al-ManƒÅ·∫ìir, 'Book of Optics', of Ibn al-Haytham. As with other printings of the <i>Perspectiva<i>, this has it roots in the manuscript tradition. Written in about 1275 while Witelo was at the Papal court at Viterbo, it is a redaction and augmenting of Alhazen's De Aspectibus which had begun to circulate in the Latin West early in the 13th century. It, in turn, was a Latin translation of KitƒÅb al-ManƒÅ·∫ìir‚Äé, the Arabic original of Ab≈´  øAlƒ´ al-·∏§asan ibn al-·∏§asan ibn al-Haytham of around 1050. While John Peckham's Perspectiva Communis was medieval Europe's most used basic optics text, Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> was the advanced, comprehensive equivalent; more than 25 manuscripts are still extant. There were several reasons for its utility.  First, though following Alhazen closely, Witelo imposed a Euclid-like structure of theorems or propositions, including enunciations, definitions, and proofs. This made the text more accessible and didactic; significantly more useful as a textbook than Alhazen's <i>De Aspectibus<i>. Second, Witelo's Perspectiva included a long first book that introduced all the plane and three-dimensional geometry that would be required to study the subsequent text. Though it contained no original mathematics, it brought the necessary geometry to bear directly on optics. Third, Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> included topics not covered in the De Aspectibus, including mirror foci, refraction by glass spheres, and atmospheric refraction.||By the end of 15th century perspectival optics was in the curriculum at the universities of Paris, Vienna, Prague, Leipzig, Krakow, Oxford, Cambridge, and others, and Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> among the principal optics texts in use. In 1472 Johannes M√ºller von K√∂nigsberg, better known as Regiomontanus, published at Nuremburg a prospectus of manuscripts he intended to edit and have printed; number 12 on the list was 'Perspectiva Vitelonis.' But a printed edition did not appear until 1535 when Georg Tannstetter and his astronomer-pupil Peter Apian edited the text for the Nuremburg press of Johannes Petreius. The intention was to produce a book that could be used at the University of Vienna where Tannstetter taught. It would be from the <i>Perspectiva<i> of Witelo that Renaissance Europe learned optics and the source for many optical texts that would appear subsequently. Including Johannes Kepler, prompting him to publish his <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> in 1604.
BP_Description_2: Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i> is in 10 books. 1: Geometry. 2: Light, light rays, and shadows. 3: Structure and function of the eye. 4: Seeing and perception. 5: Reflection at plane surfaces. 6: Reflection at curved surfaces. 7: Reflection at conical surfaces. 8: Reflection at spherical surfaces. 9: Burning mirrors, their foci and construction. 10: Refraction, the rainbow, and other meteorics. Aside from the important Euclidian structure imposed on the De Aspectibus, Witelo's Perspectiva contains most of Alhazen's material and does not differ in any fundamental way on most optical issues: Theory of vision, nature and propagation of light, the empirical method, apparatus, and experiments, and geometric analysis--all are in the <i>Perspectiva<i> as they are in the <i>De Aspectibus<i>. In this sense, Witelo has been called Alahzen's commentator or more derogatorily, as Maurolyco had it, his ape. But in some ways, Perspectiva is importantly different from De Aspectibus. Witelo's Perspectiva begins with a significant exposition of necessary mathematics; the first book is devoted to geometry and is important and unique to the Perspectiva. Like Alhazen, Witelo cites Ptolemy on angles of refraction, repeating the values from the Optica. But unlike Alhazen, Witelo attempts and analysis and extension and gets tangled in errors. Witelo's extensive treatment of the parabolic burning mirror and his treatment of the rainbow is not found in the <i>De Aspectibus<i>. This is the edition of Witelo's work used by and referred to Johannes Kepler.
BP_Reference(s): <i> Opticae Thesaurus<i>|Introduction to this reprint edition by Lindberg, D.|Johnson Reprint Corporation, 1972, pp v-xxxiv.||ùëª <i>Witelionis Perspectivae Liber Primus<i>|English translation of Book I of Witelo's Perspectiva|Unguru, S., translator|Polish Academy of Sciences, 1977|http://kpbc.umk.pl/dlibra/editions-content?id=31621||ùëª <i>Witelonis Perspectivae Liber Secundus Et Liber Tertius<i>|Engligh translation of Books II and III of Witelo's Perspectiva|Unguru, S., translator|Polish Academy of Sciences, 1991|http://kpbc.umk.pl/dlibra/editions-content?id=32531||ùëª <i>Witelionis Perspectivae Liber Quartus<i>|English translation of Book 4 of Witelo's Perspectiva (Thesis)|Kelso C. J., translator|University of Missouri-Columbia, 2003||ùëª <i>Witelionis Perspectivae Liber Quintus<i>|English translation of Book 5 of Witelo's Perspectiva|Smith, A. M., translator|Polish Academy of Sciences, 1983|http://kpbc.umk.pl/dlibra/editions-content?id=32536

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Egnatio Danti(Ignatio Danti, Pellegrino) (1536 - 1586) Dominican friar and mathematician, tutor to the wealthy of Florence, taught at Bologna, and eventually pontifical mathematician.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Danti's Italian translation of Pena's Greek text of Euclid's Optika. Commentaries and figures accompany the translation.
BP_Description_1: Egnatio Danti worked on his translations of the optics works of Euclid and Heliodorus at the end of his time in Florence. He based his Italian translation on Jean Pena's Latin translation of 1557 of the Greek text of Euclid's <i>Optica<i>. Though Danti had access to Greek manuscripts of the Euclid <i>Optica<i> held in the Medici Library, he chose to use Pena's Latin; doing so with only indirect attribution. Additionally, Danti's preface is a translated, shortened unacknowledged paraphrase of the preface <i>De Usu Optices<i> from Jean Pena's text of 1557. Commentaries and figures accompany Danti's translation, with the commentaries being more important and influential than the Euclidian text itself. Included is Danti's Latin and Italian translations the <i>Capita Optica<i> of Heliodorus of Larrisa.
BP_Description_2: Egnatio Danti's interest in optics centered on its relation to and support of linear perspective and art and thus his extensive commentaries focus on that. The paraphrase of Pena's De Usu Optices is used to support Danti's view that astronomy, geography, and particularly perspective, need to be in the hands of natural philosophers and those that understand optics. Danti's commentaries focus on the first two of Euclid's suppositions: the linear propagation of emitted visual rays, and their composition into the cone of vision. Danti also gives a considerable historical summary of optics, particularly that dealing with the conflicting theories of extromission, as in Euclid, and medieval intromission as presented by Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>. Though Danti seems to support the intromission theory, he is coyly avoids explicit endorsement. Importantly, Danti does not feel the need to present arguments one way or the other, only to make clear Euclid's ideas.||A significant aspect of Danti's comments derive from commentaries on Aristotle's <i>De Anima<i> and <i>De Sensu<i>, particularly Maynetius' commentary of 1555. Importantly Danti claims that siding with either the extromission or intromission theories--the Euclidian or Aristotelian--is unnecessary, since straight rays, regardless of their direction of travel, are the essential aspect of optics that supports the theory of linear perspective.
BP_Reference(s): Egnatio Danti's Optics: Cinquecento Aristotelianism and the Medieval Tradition|<i>Nuncius<i>, Vol 3, No 1, 1988, pp 3 -38.ùëª The Optics of Euclid|Burton, H.E., translator|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 46, No 5, 1945, pp 357-372.||ùëª <i>The medieval Latin traditions of Euclid's Catoptrica: A Critical Edition of De speculis with an Introduction, English Translation, and Commentary<i>|Takahashi, K.|Kyushu University Press, 1992, 373 pp.||<i>Campanus of Novara and Euclid's Elements<i>|Busard, H.L.L.|Franz Steiner Verlag, 2005, 535 pp, NB pp 1-46.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 47-64.||Pseudo-Euclidean reflections in ancient optics: a re-examination of textual issues pertaining to the the Euclidean Optica and Catoptrica|Knorr, W.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 1-45.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Egnatio Danti(Ignatio Danti, Pellegrino) (1536 - 1586) Dominican friar and mathematician, tutor to the wealthy of Florence, taught at Bologna, and eventually pontifical mathematician.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Danti's Italian translation of Heliodorus's <i>Capita Opticorum<i>, a commentary on and abridgement of Euclid's optics; includes Heliodorus's Greek text, ùûôùûÆùûøùû™ùû¥ùû™ùû≤ùû™ ùûΩùüâùû∂ ùûûùûπùûΩùû≤ùû≥ùüâùû∂.
BP_Description_1: Egnatio Danti worked on his translations of the optics works of Euclid and Heliodorus at the end of his time in Florence. It is generally thought that the text, though traditionally associated with Heliodorus, is actually an edited version by Damianus, his son or perhaps his student. The original work, Œ§Œ± ŒöŒµœÜŒ±ŒªŒ±ŒπŒ± œÑœâŒΩ ŒüœÄœÑŒπŒ∫œâŒΩ Œ•œÄŒøŒ∏ŒµœÉŒµœâŒΩ, <i>Chapters of Optical Cases<i>, is a collection of short chapters on the fundamental principles of optics. It is important for its allusions to various ancient sources and for giving information on optics as generally understood at the time. The text of Heliodorus gives one of the very few references to Ptolemy's optics and his instrument for tracing rays. Heliodorus also references Hero's least-path argument for equal angle reflection. The Greek of Heliodorus and its parallel Latin translation is printed at the end.
BP_Description_2: Heliodorus of Larissa's <i>Capita Opticorum<i> is a commentary on and abridgement of Euclid's optics, Ptolemy's optics, and Theon's recension of Euclid. It is a popularization of the simplest ideas from optics. Assembled without any particular structure, the simple nature of the work suggests it was an abridgement meant as an introduction to more advanced texts. There are 14 very brief chapters that cover the eye, visual rays, the visual cone, reflection and refraction. The material is concise and nontechnical, the style is informal, discursive, and interspersed with anecdote.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Archimedes and the Pseudo-Euclidean Catoptrics: Early Stages in the Ancient Geometric Theory of Mirrors|Knorr, W.R.|<i>Archives Internationales d‚Äôhistoire des sciences<i>, Vol 35, No 1, 1985, pp 28-105, NB: pp 52-53, 89-96.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second printing of a work on calculating the length of Twilight. Includes spherical astronomy, atmospheric refraction, other aspects of optics, and instruments including the nonius.
BP_Description_1: Second printing of the collected works of Pedro Nu√±es, contains Latin translations of Portuguese works: The geometry of rhomb lines or loxodromes extracted from his 1537 Portuguese version of Sacro Bosco's <i>Sphaera Mundi<i>; Nu√±es commentary on the planetary theories of Georg Peurbach; Commentaries on Oronce Fine's solutions to the classical problems of squaring the circle, trisecting an angle, and doubling the cube; and Nu√±es treatise on twilight including a comments on Gerard of Cremona's translation of Ibn al-Haytham's work on meteorological optics. The material on twilight includes Nu√±es' calculations of its length and a description of the nonius, an instrument of his invention to increase the accuracy of astrolabes and their use in navigation. Importantly, Nu√±es was the first to determine the date of 'minimum crepuscule'-- the shortest twilight. Editions of the collected works appeared in 1566 and 1573. The material on twilight first appeared in 1542.
BP_Description_2: This collecting of works by Nu√±es includes: On the art and method of navigation; Annotations of the theory of the planets of Georg Peurbach; Annotation on a mechanical problem of Aristotle regarding navigational boat propulsion; On the errors of Oronce Fine; A book on Twilight along with a small book by Alhacen on the cause of twilight.||The material on twilight is a early work of Nu√±es and considers twilight from a navigational mathematician's point of view. The first section gives six theorems on geometry and trigonometry that are required for subsequent calculations. The second and longest part of the book describes the use of the astrolabe, determining latitude of observations, the mathematical procedure for reducing twilight observations, tables of values of the length of twilight, calculations to determine the height of the atmosphere, and corrections to observations based on elevation.||The edited translation of the crepuscular work of Alhacen is attributed to Gerard of Cremona. Alhacen discusses twilight sky appearance, the cause of twilight, the height of the atmosphere and the size of the earth as determined by twilight observations, and the position of the at the commence of twilight. Nu√±es work on twilight involved spherical astronomy, atmospheric refraction and other aspects of optics, and instrumentation. Regarding the latter, Nu√±es describes what came to be called eponymously (after the Latin of his name), the Nonius. This was an addition to an astrolabe that allowed more accurate determination of angles using a Vernier-like succession of graduated concentric circles. The Nonius would later be used by Tyco Brahe in his Quadrant instruments.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª Pedro Nu√±es and the First Printed Treatise on Twilight Observation|Gadsden, M.|EOS, <i>Transactions of the American Geophysical Union<i>, Vol 67, No 30, 1986, pp 593-597.||Time and Pedro Nunes‚Äô pursuit of mathematical certainty|Lopes, A., Ralha, M.E., Vilar, C.|In: <i>Research Seminar on History and Epistemology of Mathematics Proceedings<i>, Centro de Matem¬¥atica da Universidade do Minho, 2010, pp 185-204.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Pascal Duhamel (? - 1565) (Paschasius Hamellius, Pasquier DuHamel, Pascasio Hamelius) French mathematician and geometer, professor in the College de France
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of Pascal DuHamel's editing of Peckham‚Äôs optics textbook, with commentary and new figures.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 25. Second edition of Pascal DuHamel's slight editing of and commentary on Georg Hartmann's edition of Peckham's optics textbook, <i>Perspectiva Communis<i>, with some additional woodcut figures in the text. This is essentially a reprinting of the edition of 1556, save that it does not include Hartmann's preface of 1542. The periodic appearance of Peckham's Perspective Communis demonstrates its continued use as a textbook on optics in the Renaissance up to the time of Kepler. Editions of DuHamel's editing appeared in 1556 and 1580. An Italian translation appeared in 1593.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 8.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Stephen Batman (1533?-1584) Protestant cleric, scholar, and bibliophile.
BP_Short or Common Title: Batman vppon Bartholome, his booke De proprietatibus rerum
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The last English translation and printing of one of the most widely read Medieval encyclopedias. Written for students and preachers, it covered divine and human life, the natural world, Earth and the heavens. Numerous sources were cited.
BP_Description_1: The <i>De proprietatibus Rerum<i> of Bartholomaeus Anglicus (Bartholomew the Englishman) is one of the most widely read Medieval encyclopedias and one of the most frequently printed. Written for students and preachers no later than 1240, it covered divine and human life, the natural world, Earth and the heavens. Bartholomew's encyclopedia filled a need for a compact source of knowledge for those without access to libraries or large specialized textbooks. One of the reasons it was immensely popular for centuries was that is was not a manual of the arts but a source for 'science' and secular knowledge; there are more than 200 manuscript copies extant. Nevertheless, Bartholomew wrote not to consider the nature of things for their own sake, but rather to better reveal Scripture. The book gives a view of middle and late medieval common knowledge and because Bartholomew did not consider nor wish to present himself as an authority, the many sources he cites gives insight into information and texts available at end of the 13th century. The book was popular enough to be translated into French in 1372 by Jean Corbichon, into English in 1398 by John Trevisa, into Spanish by Vincent de Burgos late in the 14th century, and into Dutch, Italian, and Proven√ßal.||Latin editions appeared in ca 1472, ca 1475, 1480, 1481, two in 1482, 1483, 1485, 1488, 1491, 1492, 1505, 1519, 1601, and 1609. French editions appeared in 1482, two in 1485, 1487, 1491, 1500, 1510, 1518, 1522 (2), 1525, 1538, 1539, six in 1556. A Dutch printing appeared in 1485. A Spanish printing in 1494 and 1529. Printed editions appeared in England in 1495, 1535, and 1582; the later being Thomas Berthelet's English edition, amended and enlarged by Stephen Batman; the present copy.
BP_Description_2: <i>De Proprietatibus Rerum<i> contains 19 books. 1: God. 2: Angels and demons. 3: Psychology. 4-5: Physiology. 6: Family life and domestic economy. 7: Medicine. 8: Cosmology and astrology. 9: Time divisions. 10: Form and matter, the elements. 11: Air and meteorology, 12: Flying creatures. 13: Waters and fishes, dolphins, and whales. 14-15: Physical and political geography. 16: Gems, minerals, and metals. 17: Trees and herbs. 18: Animals. 19: Color, odor, savor; food and drink; weights and measures; musical instruments. The material on vision is in Chapter 17 of Book 3 and Bartholomew gives an unnamed author's work precedence over that of Constantine the African on matters of vision. Presumably this is a reference to Constantine's translation, the<i>Liber Pantegni<i>, of an Arabic medical text. The unnamed author and work cannot be Alhazen and <i>De Apsectibus<i>; it is likely to be Robert Grosseteste. Bartholomew presents vision based on three coincident pyramids, with apex at the pupil and base at the viewed object. The three pyramids contain: species emitted from the object, a visual fluid emitted by the eye, and light--a substance illuminating the object. Though Light is always present, it illuminates only a body in a condition to receive it. Following the ancients, three types of vision are presented: direct, reflected, and refracted.||The eye and ocular anatomy is presented in Chapters 5, 6, and 7 of Book 5. The material comes from Isidore of Saville's <i>Etymologiae<i> and from the medical translations of Constantine the African (the <i>Liber Pantegni<i>, most likely), both of which are cited. The anatomy presented is entirely Galenic. Rays, pyramids, and species are presented with the mixed vagueness typical before the wide-spread appearance  Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> in the Latin West in the 13th century. Bartholomew's material on color in chapter 1 of book 19 is copied, almost verbatim, from Robert Grosseteste's <i>De Colore<i> of around 1220.||When Batman took up the project of producing a new edition of Bartholomew, he repurposed the <i>De Proprietatibus Rerum<i> from its original intent--meeting the needs of then-new 13th century Franciscans working at expanding Christendom--to the needs of Elizabethan England. The work Batman produced can be consider a contemporary commentary of Bartholomew. This is reflected in the changes and updating he made to Bartholomew's text, the additional material he added, and the extensive range of modern authorities he cites. This is particular apparent in the material on cosmography. Batman also makes a significant alteration to Book 19 by inserting a long passage on limning into the sequence of chapters on colors, altering the focus from the properties of light and its spiritual significance, to the properties of pigments and the techniques of applying them to surfaces. Throughout the rest of the text, Batman's glosses, commentaries, and addenda appear in the printed margins.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Journey of a Book: Bartholomew the Englishman and the Properties of Things|Keen, E.|ANU E Press, 2007, 199 pp, NB: pp 133-151.||Batman vppon Bartholome, His Booke De Proprietatibus Rerum. Facsimile Edition with an Introduction and Index|Sch√§fer, J.|Georg Olms Verlagsbuchhandlung, 1976, 882 pp.||<i>Bartholomaeus Anglicus. Batman vppon Bartholome, His Booke De Proprietatibues Rerum, 1582. With an Introduction and Index by Jurgen Schafer<i>|Georg Olms Verlag, 1976, 441 pp, NB: I-XX,
BP_Title: Batman uppon Bartholome, His Booke De Proprietatibus Rerum; newly corrected, enlarged, & amended, with such Additions as are requisite, unto every severall Booke. Taken foorth of the most approved Authors, the like heretofore not translated in English. Profitable for all Estates, as well for the benefite of the Mind as the Bodie.
BP_Biographical Statement: English¬†Franciscan, may have studied at Oxford, more likely at Chartres. Taught in the Franciscan school at Paris, where he wrote his famed, widely-read encyclopedia, and finally at Magdeburg.
BP_Provenance: Contemporary inscription (partly cropped) at head of title; old inscription on dedication, scribbled out.

BP_Short or Common Title: Compendiosa Introduttione alla prima parte della specularia
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary consideration of the utility and properties of mirrors; fundamentally geometric  but larded with verse from Dante, Petrarch, Horace to support arguments.
BP_Description_1: Rafael Mirami's <i>Compendiosa<i> is a late Renaissance consideration of the utility and properties of mirrors. It is the product of the transition from the catoptrical optics of antiquity and its attempt to produce images from distant objects, to the development of dioptrical optics in the early 17th century that led to the telescope. Interestingly, and suggestive of late Renaissance humanism, Mirami's fundamentally geometric text is larded with verse from Dante, Petrarch, Horace to support his arguments. Glass developments in Venice early in 16th century made mirrors widely available and Mirami's work was written in hopes of elevating the intellectual study of mirrors, considering not only their manufacture, but also practical, astronomical, theoretical, and moral aspects; deemphasizing, if not ignoring, their use to amplify vanity or to produce visual tricks and 'lascivious use.' Mirami includes an elaborate Tavola that gives a schema of types of mirrors, their properties, their uses, and the types and place of images they produce.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Compendiosa<i> has 25 chapters, each elaborating a different aspect of the phenomenon of reflection. Mirami begins by enumerating the fields of application of mirrors, among which astrology and philosophy; avoiding the usual parade of games and entertainments. In addition to its practical applications, Mirami deals with techniques of mirror making, problem related to images produced by mirrors, how images can be illusional or misleading. Columnar and pyramidal mirrors are considered, as well as how mirrors can multiply images. In the second part of the work, Mirami describes the application of mirrors for the construction of interior solar clocks by bringing the moving image of the sun to an interior space via mirrors. This work anticipated that of Athanasius Kircher and Emmanuel Maignan on catoptric meridians.
BP_Reference(s): Corrispondenze ottico-prospettiche tra le opere di Maignan e di Borromini a palazzo Spada|C√†ndito, C.|<i>M√©langes de l'Ecole fran√ßaise de Rome<i>, Vol 117, No 1, 2005, pp 73-89.||http://www.nicolaseverino.it/Articoli/La meridiana a riflessione fu inventata da Raffaele Mirami.pdf||<i>Galileo's Glassworks: The Telecsope and the Mirror<i>|Eileen Reeves|Harvard University Press, 2008, 240 p.
BP_Title: Compendiosa Introduttione alla prima parte della specularia, Ci√≤ e dell scienze de gli specchi. Opera nova, nell a quale brevementa, e con facil modo si discorreintorno agli specchi e si rende la cagione, di tutti I loro miracolosi effetti. Composta da Rafael Mirami Hebreo Fisico, e Matematico.
BP_Title English Translation: Compendius Introduction to the First Part of Looking Glasses; This and the Science of Mirrors. A New Work Which Briefly and with a Facile Way Addresses Mirrors and the Cause of their Mircaculous Effects. Composed by Rafael Mirami, Jewish Physicst and Mathematician.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jewish Farrarese naturalist, physician and mathematician.
BP_Printer: Heirs of Franceso Rossi and Paolo Tortoriono

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Famous encyclopedic exposition of arts; that is, 'secrets'. Recipes, experiments, and observations from 129 authorities, set out according to the logic of Peter Ramus, ranged from God to games.
BP_Description_1: Johann Jakob Wecker's <i>De Secretis Libri XVII<i> is the most famous, widely used, and frequently reprinted books of secrets. It is a 16th century encyclopedic exposition of arts, that is 'secrets,' in the form of a Latin compilation of recipes, experiments, and observations culled from 129 authorities ranging from Greek and Roman antiquity to then-contemporary European. His long list of authors supported Wecker's idea that history showed that 'the treasury of revelation of natural secrets is inexhaustible.' He organized his secrets according to the logic of Peter Ramus, and in a schema ranging from the secrets of God to the secrets of games and pastimes he produced a schema giving elaborate, nested, branching sets of subjects. The schema also served at a table of contents. <i>De Secretis Libri XVII<i>  is partly an encyclopedia of sciences, mainly physical, chemical, medical, and astrological, and partly a vast collection of various recipes. It includes secrets of metals, of glass, of jewels, and how to counterfeit them; of meteorics such as hail, rain, snow, thunder, lightning, tempests, and the like; of sciences, natural magic, mathematics, music, and astrology; secrets mechanical; secrets of sports, delights and recreations; medicine and herbal remedies; and a large section on cookery. Latin editions appeared in 1582, 1587, 1588, 1592, 1598, 1604, 1613, 1629, 1642, 1662, 1701, 1750. French translations appeared in 1586, 1596, 1606, 1614, 1620, 1627, 1633, 1639, 1651, 1652, 1653, 1680, 1699. German translations appeared in 1593, 1605, and 1616. An English translation appeared at London in 1660.
BP_Description_2: Johann Jakob Wecker's <i>De Secretis Libri XVII<i> contains material on optics that of its nature is popular, practical, and elementary. It is often a credulous mix of legend, oft-repeated folk lore, and natural philosophy. Scattered through the text are descriptions of: Archimedes' burning mirror; torches, candles, and lamps for lighting; color's nature and sources; object colors; light and its sources; the eye and vision; mirrors of various types; and optical illusions. However unreliable the source, or uncertain the fact itself, each entry reveals what was known and what was desired to be known about light, vision, and optics by popular readers in the Renaissance.||The most extensive material is on burning mirrors with a discussion based on authorities, including the explicit mention of Francesco Maurolyco and figures showing the construction of a parabola.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Science and the Secrets of Nature: Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture<i>|Eamon, W.|Princeton University Press, 1994, 490 pp, NB: pp 276-279.||<i>The Library: Curtis Schuh's Bibliography of Mineralogy<i>|http://mineralogicalrecord.com/libdetail.asp.
BP_Title: De Secretis Libri XVII
BP_Title English Translation: Seventeen Books of Secrets.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss physician
BP_Collation: (?)‚Å∏ ùî¥‚Å∏ ¬∂‚Å∏ a-z‚Å∏ A-Z‚Å∏ (V‚ÇÖ missigned as T‚ÇÖ) Aa-Oo‚Å∏

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Joannes Piscator (1526-1625) German theologian, translator, textbook writer.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: In the guise of a textbook, a running argument with the 8 books of Aristotle‚Äôs Physics. Part of the effort to reform education and replace Scholasticism.
BP_Description_1: Pierre de la Ram√©e's textbook <i>Scholarum Physicarum<i> is actually a running argument with the 8 books of Aristotle's Physics. Ram√©e famously broke with Aristotelianism in 1536, titling the disputation he defended for his master's examination 'All that Aristotle has said is false.' Textbooks and teaching were at the core of Ramee's effort to reform education and replace Scholasticism and he began writing textbooks in 1543 which by 1559 had generated a complete set for Trivium. He then wrote texts for the Quadrivium, including mathematics and physics. The <i>Scholarum Physicarum<i> presents a general alternative to Aristotelian physics, which Ram√©e considered to indulge in too many speculations and complains that 'if one should by means of his senses and reason investigate heaven and earth and all that therein is, as a physicist ought to do, then compare his results with the Physics of Aristotle, he would find in that work no observation of anything in nature, but only sophisms, theoretical speculations, and unsupported assertions.' However, much he disapproved of Aristotle, Ram√©e did not go so far as to embrace an inductive method for natural philosophy.|Editions appeared in 1565, 1583, and 1606.
BP_Description_2: It is in his books on physics that Aristotle classifies the study of optics with mathematics, as opposed to physics, but considers it to have applications in the physical world. Aristotle notes that some types of mathematics are more physical than others, optics being the chief of these, being as it is so closely related to geometry. In his physics he gives an example, writing 'While geometry investigates natural lines but not qua natural, optics investigates mathematical lines, but qua natural, not qua mathematical.' That is, geometry treats lines, but not as boundaries of physical objects; optics, however, studies lines as they related to vision and rays of light. To all this Pierre de la Ram√©e objects, claiming that optics is part of physics, not mathematics, no matter how much it relies on geometry. He writes: 'Optics is of light, it presents itself to opaque, rare and dense media; the chief of which are qualities both physical and sensible.'
BP_Reference(s): <i>Peter Ramus and the Educational Reformation of the Sixteenth Century<i>|Graves, F.P.|MacMillian, New York, 1912, 226 pp.
BP_Title: Scholarum Physicarum Libri Octo, in totidem Acromaticos libros Aristoteles. Recens emendait per Joannem Piscatorem Argent. Cum Indice Accurato.
BP_Title English Translation: Eight books of Scholastic Physics; the same number as the books read of Aristotle. Recently amended by Joannes Piscator. With an accurate Index.
BP_Biographical Statement: French academic, mathematician, teacher and famed anti-Aristotelian
BP_Provenance: Marginalia scattered throughout

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Friedrich Sylburg (1536-1596) German classical scholar.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collecton of questions based on observatons in natural philosophy, medicine, and meteorology.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Probelmata<i> is a multisided text that can be considered observational natural philosophy, medicine, and meteorology. It posses many questions, each stemming from a single observation of an everyday phenomena, and usually presents an answer (often tentative, hypothetical, or interrogative themselves) based on peripatetic teaching. The <i>Problemata<i> was always considered peripheral to the core of Aristotelian work, since it was not an attempt to establish a general overall explanatory system, but rather was a scattered collection of individual and particular instances of observations of phenomena. A kind of intellectual Pointillism. The collection formed an integral part of a vibrant tradition of medical-naturalist problemata literature in the Graeco-Roman imperial era, which included works such as Plutarch‚Äôs Naturales Quaestiones, the so-called Supplementa Problematorum, and the iatrosophist Cassius‚Äô Medical Problems. It is significance testimony to the role the <i>Problemata<i> played to the transmission of medical and natural scientific knowledge during the Roman Empire.||Although called 'pseudo-Aristotelian' in their final form of 38 books containing nearly 900 problems accumulated over the centuries by the Peripatetic school possibly as late as the 5th or 6th century CE, the 'Problems of Aristotle' developed from an authentic Aristotelian core and spawned a vigorous tradition of editions and imitations--the latter outlasting the active use of the rest of Aristotle's natural science, down to the eighteenth-century publication of works entitled 'Problems of Aristotle.' Collections of problemata, variously copied or imitated from Aristotle and other ancient models (notably Alexander of Aphrodisias, Plutarch and Cassius as in this edition), consisted of questions and answers about the causes of natural phenomena and elicited learned and popular interest to fuel over one hundred editions in the genre during the early modern period. The present Greek work is often confused with the medieval Latin collection <i>Problemata<i> that developed between the 13th and 15th centuries; a collection not based on the ancient text at all.||The editor of this text, Friedrich Sylburg, produced numerous Greek and Latin classics and patristic texts for the great printers Wechel in Frankfurt and Commelius in Heidelberg. His complete Aristotle, published over several years and in various combinations, was considered by many scholars to have been the finest edition to date. The present work is the forth time the Greek text of the <i>Problemata<i> appeared in print. The first was the Aldine Aristotle in 1495-1498, the second was that of Simon Grynaeus and Desiderius Erasmus printed by Johann Bebel at Basel in 1531 and reissued in 1539 and 1550, and Joannes Baptista Camotius' edition published by Aldine at Venice in 1551. Sylburg's edition contains the corrections of former publications and an improved text, as well as an <i>Adnotatio<i> and two indexes. The <i>Adnotatio<i> considers various readings of the Greek text, referencing Gaza's Latin translation to show his readings. The first index is to Greek vocabulary used in the <i>Problemata<i> and the second is a Latin subject index.
BP_Description_2: Many problems in the <i>Problemata<i> deal with the eye, optics, and vision: ||Book XV, Problem 6:  Why is it the case that when the sun passes through quadri-laterals, as for instance in wickerwork, it does not produce a figure rectangular in shape but circular?||Book XV, Problem 11: Why is it the case that an eclipse of the sun, if one looks at it through a sieve or through leaves, such as a plane-tree or other broadleaved tree, or if one joins the fingers of one hand over the fingers of the other, the rays are crescent-shaped where they reach the earth? Is it for the same reason as that when light shines through a rectangular peep-hole, it appears circular in the form of a cone?||These problems show the ancient origin of the problem of describing how pin-hole images were formed. This is a topic visited by all medieval writers in optics and not correctly treated until the work of Marolyco and Kepler. Problem 13 Book XVI contains Aristotle's presentation of the mechanical analogy of reflection when describing a mirror image. There are also problems related to visual perception, such as 'Why is it that, although the moon is spherical, we see a straight line when it is halved?' and 'Why is it that, although the sun and moon are spherical, they appear flat?'||Several problems in the medical material deal with aspects of vision: Book 31, Problems 11, 14-17b, 19-22, and 25-28. Aristotle was also probably the first Greek author to try to explain why old people‚Äôs eyes see worse than those of younger people. This includes an explicit reference to presbyopia. Indeed, the word ‚Äòpresbyopes‚Äô was first used here in the <i>Problemata<i>, formed from the prefix 'presbys', meaning old man, in Greek, and the suffix 'ops', meaning eye.
BP_Reference(s): The Problemata as a Natural Philosophical Genre|Blair, A.|In: Natural Particulars: Nature and the Disciplines in Renaissance Europe|Grafton, A., Sirasi, N., editors, MIT Press, 1999,  pp 171-204.||The Problemata‚Äôs Medical Books: Structural and Methodological Aspects|Oikonomopoulou, K. |In: The Aristotelian Problemata Physica: Philosophical and Scientific Investigations|Mayhew, R. editor|Brill, 2015, pp. 61-78.||Observing Eclipses: An Optical Question in Problemata 15.11|Bowen, A.C.|In: The Scaffolding of Our Thoughts|Crisostomo, C.J., Escobar, E.A., Tanaka, T., Veldhuis, N., editors|Brill, 2018, 446 pp, NB: pp 353-391.||An ancient explanation of presbyopia based on binocular vision|Barbero, S.|<i>Acta Ophthalmologica<i>, Vol 92, 2014, NB: pp 394-399.||Optical Reflection and Mechanical Rebound: The Shift from Analogy to Axiomatization in the Seventeenth Century|Smith, R.|<i>The British Journal for the History of Science<i> , 2008, Vol 41, No 1, pp 1-18.||Aristotles' <i>Problemata<i> in Different Times and Tongues|De Leemans, P., Goyens, M., editors|Leuven University Press, 2006, 325 pp.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.||ùëª Pseudo-Aristoteles (Pseudo-Alexander), Supplementa Problematorum: A New Edition of the Greek Text with Introduction and Annotated Translation|Kapetanaki, S., Sharples, R.W., editors and translators|De Gruyter, 2006, 308 pp.
BP_Title: Aristotelous, Alexandrou te kai Kasiou Problemata, syn Theophrasteion tinon eklogais [GREEK] Aristotelis, Alexandri, et Cassii Problemata, cum Theophrasteorum quorundam collectaneis. Addita in fine varia locorum lectio e diuersis exemplaribus tum impressis tum calamo exaratis. Emendationes etiam non paucae ex interpretum versione, aliorumque doctorum virorum scriptis. BP_Title English Translation: The Problems of Aristotle, Alexander [of Aphrodisias] and Cassius [Iatrosophista], along with certain collections of Theophrastus. Added at the end of various places, a reading from diverse printed and manuscript copies. And not a few emendations from versions of  translators and the writings of other learned doctors. In addition, an index of chapters and two alphabetical lists of remarkable words in Greek and Latin.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Pedro Ambrosio Onderiz (??-1596), Spanish mathematician, astronomer and cartographer.
BP_Short or Common Title: La Perspectiva y Especularia de Euclides
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First edition in Spanish of Euclid's <i>Optica et Catoptrica<i>.
BP_Description_1: The translator, Pedro Ambrosio Onderiz, was appointed by King Philip II to a chair in the newly established Academia de Matem√°ticas, and was expressly charged with the translation of scientific works into Spanish. This work was part of a general program to provide students at the academy with textbooks. The only earlier work by Euclid that had been translated into Spanish was the 1576 Los seis libros primeros de la geometria; prior to that, the only printing of Euclid in Spain was a truncated <i>Mathematicae quaedam selectae<i>, done in 1566.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Optica<i> of Euclid is the first Greek work on vision and perspective--the earliest surviving text on optics and light in the western world. The <i>Optica<i> presents the phenomena of visible light and the Euclidian idea of vision rays emanating from the eye, comfortably aligned with and analyzed by geometry. The lines and angles of Euclid's geometry were used to describe the position and trajectory of vision rays--direct and reflected by mirrors. The <i>Optica<i> of Euclid re-emerged as an important text in the 15h century for it use in the theory of linear perspective. The <i>Catoptrica<i>, a treatise on mirrors attributed by Proclus to Euclid, covers the mathematical theory of mirrors, particularly the images formed by plane and spherical concave mirrors.
BP_Reference(s): ùëª The Optics of Euclid|Burton, H.E., translator|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 46, No 5, 1945, pp 357-372.||ùëª <i>The medieval Latin traditions of Euclid's Catoptrica: A Critical Edition of De speculis with an Introduction, English Translation, and Commentary<i>|Takahashi, K.|Kyushu University Press, 1992, 373 pp.||<i>Campanus of Novara and Euclid's Elements<i>|Busard, H.L.L.|Franz Steiner Verlag, 2005, 535 pp, NB pp 1-46.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 47-64.||Pseudo-Euclidean reflections in ancient optics: a re-examination of textual issues pertaining to the the Euclidean Optica and Catoptrica|Knorr, W.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 1-45.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.
BP_Title: La Perspectiva y Especularia de Euclides. Traduzidas en vulgar Castellano y dirigidas a la S.C.R.M. del Rey don Phelippe nuestro Se√±or. Por Pedro Ambrosio Onderiz su criado.
BP_Title English Translation: The Perspective and Specularia of Euclid. Translated into common Castellano and addressed to His Scared Majesty King Don Phelippe our Lord. By Pedro Ambrosio Onderiz, his servant.
BP_Biographical Statement: Ancient author of geometry, taught at Athens and Alexandria.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Thomas Vroom
