BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Natural Magic is presented as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. Vison, mirrors and lenses are considered in the optics section.
BP_Description_1: Giambattista Della Porta's <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> was a significant expansion of his early book on natural magic of 1558. For Della Porta, Natural Magic was the practical part of natural philosophy and focused on exceptional, unusual, extraordinary phenomena, rather than the quotidian. It was the recognition and mastering of natural phenomena, in particular, those phenomena that had to be sought out, phenomena that were otherwise hidden. The point was not to explain the phenomena, but to be able to (re)produce it, display it, describe it and thus reveal nature's secrets. The author and the book changed considerably in the nearly thirty years that separated the first and second editions. Della Porta had mastered a large portion of classical humanist studies by 1589, including the medieval encyclopedias of secrets. From the latter, the scope of the book expanded considerably, and Della Porta established a long list of secrets which the second edition of the Magiae Naturalis was to 'reduce all those secrets into their  proper places.' The second edition is also considerably more experimental in the sense of the direct manipulation of nature. But one aspect of the book and its author did not change: the notion that explaining natural phenomena and unlocking the secrets of nature are fundamentally esoteric activities. Alchemy and Optics are significant portions of the Magiae Naturalis of 1589.|The <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> established Della Porta's reputation as Europe's leading authority on natural magic. The book was tremendously popular and commercially successful; Antwerp's Pantin Press and Frankfurt's Wechel press were among dell Porta's publishers. Printings of the second, expanded Latin edition appeared in 1589, 1591, 1592, 1597, 1600, 1607, 1619, 1644, 1650, 1651, and 1664. An Italian translation appeared in 1611, a German translation appeared at Magdeburg in 1612 and 1617, French translations appeared at Lyon in 1615 and 1669, and at Rouen in 1657, an English translation appeared at London in 1658 and 1659.
BP_Description_2: Giambattista Della Porta presents natural magic as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. There are 20 books: 1: Of the Causes of Wonderful things, 2: Of the Generation of Animals. 3:Of the Production of New Plants. 4: Of increasing Household Stuff. 5: Of changing Metals. 6: Of counterfeiting Gold. 7: Of the Wonders of the Loadstone. 8: Of strange Cures. 9: Of Beautifying Women. 10: Of Distillation.11: Of Perfuming. 12: Of Artificial Fires. 13: Of Tempering Steel. 14: Of Cookery. 15: Of Fishing, Fowling, Hunting, etc. 16: Of Invisible Writing. 17: Of Catoptric Images. 18: Of Statick Experiments. 19: Pneumatic Experiments. 20: Of the Chaos.  Of all the material covered, that considered in book 17 on vison, mirrors and lenses, (pp 259-286) is probably the most important, it was certainly that with the most extensive and lasting effect. It contains 23 topics: Plane mirrors; Plane mirror illusions; Mirrors for display and the theater; Concave mirrors; Plane and concave mirrors together; Other operations with concave mirrors; How to see in the dark, that which is illuminated by torches; How without a mirror or other device an image can hand in the air; Mixtures of mirrors and their images; The Crystalline Lens and its effects; Lenses for seeing far beyond what can be imagined; Camera obscura; Crystal prism; Burning mirrors; Parabolic burning mirrors and their construction; Parabolic section construction; Parabolic section for burning at infinite distances; Burning glass from spherical sections; Kindling fire more forcefully with refraction; Image outside a concave mirror; Making mirrors; Making plane, convex, and concave mirrors with applied and bonded foil; Making metallic mirrors.||Della Porta is not interested in explaining optical phenomena--he refers the reader to Archimedes, Euclid, Ptolemy, and Witelo--nor does he aim to discern and study the laws of optics to explain the effects. Rather, he seeks to demonstrate and show how it is possible to increase the effect of optical phenomena. The most influential topics are the camera obscura and lenses. Della Porta had added a mirror to the camera obscura to right the image, but by 1589 he places a lens in the aperture to clarify and amplify the image, and more importantly, to make the first suggestion that the eye is like a camera obscura. Concave mirrors are discussed and their numerous images presented in considerable detail. It is in connection with mirror images that Della Porta introduces the point of inversion (where rays cross, the focus) and the use of the cathetus to predict image location.
BP_Reference(s): Knowing by doing in sixteenth-century natural magic: Giambattista della Porta and the wonders of nature|Saito, F.|<i>Circumscribere<i>, Vo1 14, 2014, pp 17-39||<i>Science and the Secretes of Nature: Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture<i>|Eamon, W.|Princeton University Press, 1994, 490 pp, pp 210-233.||<i>The Optics of Giambattista della Porta(ca. 1535‚Äì1615): A Reassessment<i>|Borrelli, A., Hon, G., Zik, Y., editors|Springer, 2017, 205 pp, NB: pp 184-188.
BP_Title: Io. Baptistae Portae Neopolitani, Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti. In Quibus Scientiarum Naturalium divitiae, & deliciae demonstratur. Iam de novo ab omnibus mendis repurgati, in lumen prodierunt. Accessit Index, rem omne dilucide repraesentans, copiosissimus. Librorum ordinen, qui in hoc opere continentur, versa pagina indicabit.
BP_Title English Translation: Giambattista della Porta, Neapolitan. Twenty Books of Natural Magic. In Which the Riches and Pleasures of Natural Science are Given Account. Now newly cleansed of all defects and brought forth. A Very Copius Index is Added Clearly Presenting Each Thing. The Order of the Books Contained in this Work is Indicated on the Back of This Page.
BP_Biographical Statement: Neoplitan scholar, polymath, and natural philosopher. Prolific author, showman, and founder of the Academia Secretorum Naturae, the first scientific society.
BP_Provenance: A scattering of marginalia
BP_BibliographicNotes: Title with woodcut border, Della Porta's medallion portrait on the title verso
BP_Binding: Contemporary Vellum With Marbled Pastedowns And Endpapers

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Isaac Casaubon (1559 - 1614) French born English classical scholar and philologist.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Famed Renaissance Greek scholar Casaubon's edition of Aristotle. Treated as the 'received text' for subsequent editors and editions for 200 years.
BP_Description_1: Isaac Casaubon seems to have inherited the task of editing Aristotle's works from his teacher Julius Pacius. Casaubon's introduction gives other reasons this edition was undertaken. These include Casaubon's idea that philosophy was being left behind in the renaissance of arts and sciences, and more importantly to establish a bulwark against 'the new philosophy'--the anti-Aristotelianism of Pierre de la  Ram√©e. Though Ram√©e had been dead nearly 20 years in 1590, his thought was in fashion at the time and Casaubon was tendentiously opposed to it's neglect of the Ancients and its opposition to Aristotle. More distressing to Casaubon was the Ramist ignorance of High Literature.|Though he was already a famous Greek scholar by the time he worked on this edition of Aristotle's works, Casaubon's principle sources for his edition were earlier Latin editions; apparently, he consulted Greek manuscripts sparingly. An innovative aspect of this edition is Casaubon's use of marginalia to note textual variants, particularly those arising from manuscripts. He also uses marginalia to set discussion of difficult points, dubious readings, and his own conjectures. Casaubon's use of marginalia was the forerunner of the apparatus criticus of later textual scholarship. Casaubon's edition appeared in 1590 and was reprinted in 1605. Editions of Casaubon's text was prepared by subsequent editors and appeared in 1597, 1619, 1629, 1639, 1654 and many times in the 18th century. Casaubon's text was, for nearly 200 years, something near to a 'received text.' It was, for example, the basis for the <i>Aristotelis Opera Omnia Quae Extant Graec√® & Latin√®<i> of Guillaume Duval of 1619. The appearance of Casaubon's text marks the beginning of the end of the translation and commentary literature based on Aristotle. Early in the 17th century, philosophical textbooks became the principal mechanism by which Aristotle was studied. Their summaries and pedagogical reworkings replaced the reading of the original text.
BP_Description_2: Casaubon's texts include all the works of Aristotle that contain some component of optics: The four books of <i>De Meteorologicorum<i>; the four books of <i>De Caelo<i>; the three books of <i>De Anima; De Sensu et Sensibilia<i>; <i>De Coloribus<i>; and the <i>Problemata<i>. Aristotle's writings that concerned optics dealt with visual perception and thought, the mechanisms involved in vision, the rainbow, and color.||The second book of De Anima gives Aristotle's theory of sense perceptions. Vision has a sense-organ: the eye. Vision has a medium: air or water. Vision has its proper object: color--which for Aristotle is an object's sensible quality. Perception is the reception of a perceptible form, resulting in an alteration in the mental faculty. it is here that Aristotle gives his famous wax analogy: '. . . each sense receives the perceptible forms without the matter. Wax, for instance, receives the design on a signet ring without the iron or gold; it acquires the design in the gold or bronze, but not insofar as the design is gold or bronze.' The passing of a perceptible form from object to eye involves Aristotle's theory of light. If the medium between object and eye is potentially transparent, then in the presence of light, vision can take place because light turn potential transparency to actually transparency and perceptible forms can move from object to eye. Thus, the things necessary for vision are: the eye, an object to be viewed, a potentially transparent medium separating object and eye, and light to change the medium's transparency from potential to actual. The nature of light and the notion of objects radiating perceptible forms were topics that received considerable attention from Aristotelian commentators in late Antiquity and early Medieval times.||Aristotle theory of the rainbow is stated in book three of <i>De Meteorologicorum<i>. The phenomenon is caused by sunlight reflecting off raindrops in a cloud. The <i>Problemata<i> pose questions, each stemming from a single observation of an everyday phenomena. Many deal with the eye, optics, and vision: Book XV, Problem 6:  Why is it the case that when the sun passes through quadri-laterals, as for instance in wickerwork, it does not produce a figure rectangular in shape but circular? Book XV, Problem 11: Why is it the case that an eclipse of the sun, if one looks at it through a sieve or through leaves, such as a plane-tree or other broadleaved tree, or if one joins the fingers of one hand over the fingers of the other, the rays are crescent-shaped where they reach the earth? These problems show the ancient origin of the problem of describing how pin-hole images were formed. Problem 13 Book XVI contains Aristotle's presentation of the mechanical analogy of reflection when describing a mirror image. There are also problems related to visual perception
BP_Reference(s): Casaubon's Aristotle|Glucker, J.|<i>Classica et Mediaevalis<i>, Vol 26, 1964, pp 274-296.||The Aristotelian Explanation of the Rainbow|Sayili, A.M.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 30, No 1, 1939, pp 65-83.||Sight and the philosophy of vision in Classical Greece: Democritus, Plato and Aristotle|Nightingale, A.|In: <i>Sight and the Ancient Senses<i>, Squire, M., editor|Routledge, 2016, 336 pp, NB: pp 54-68.||Aristotle and the Renaissance|Schmitt, C.B.|Harvard University Press, 1983, 187 pp, NB: pp 36-40, 83-86.||The Rise of the Philosophical Textbook|Schmitt, C. B.|In: The Cambridge History of Renaissance Philosophy, Schmitt C.B. editor, Cambridge University Press, 1988, pp. 792‚Äì804.
BP_Title: Aristotelous tou Stageiritou Ta S√¥zomena (in Greek) Operum Aristotelis Stagiritae philosophorum omnium longe principis, nova editio, graece et latine. Graecus contextus quam emendatissime praeter omnes omnium editiones est editus : adscriptis ad oram libri et interpretum veterum recentiorumque et aliorum doctorum virorum emendationibus : in quibus plurimae nunc primum in lucem prodeunt, ex bibliotheca Isaaci Casauboni. Latinae interpretationes adjectae sunt quae graeco contextui melius responderent, partim recentiorum, partim veterum interpretum : in quibus et ipsis multa nunc emendatius quam antehac eduntur. Accesserunt ex libris Aristotelis, qui hodie desiderantur, fragmenta quaedam. Adjecti sunt etiam indices duo perutiles : quorum alter nomina auctorum qui in Aristotelem scripserunt, continet : alter quid sit √† quoque in singulas librorum ejus partes scriptum indicat. Necnon alius index rerum omnium locupletissimus.
BP_Title English Translation: Aristotelous tou Stageiritou Ta S√¥zomena (in Greek) All the Works of the Foremost Philosopher by far, Aristotle the Stagirite. A New Edition in Greek and Latin. The interleaved Greek text more carefully corrected more than all earlier editions. Added to the margins are new and ancient interpretatons and other emendations of the learned, now brought forth in to the light from the library of Isaac Casaubon. Latin translation is added, corresponding well to the Greek; some are recent translations, some are old, and all are much more correct than any in the past. Added to the books of Aristotle are what are today considered frangments. This also contains two added useful indices, one of names of authors who wrote on Aristotle, the other indicates the parts of individual books. Not even a general index is more reliable.
BP_Biographical Statement: Greatest natural philosopher of ancient Greece. Pupil of Plato, teacher of Alexander the Great. [French and later English classical scholar and philologist]
BP_Provenance: Notes and diagrams in the margins of the Problemata

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Giovanni Paolo Gallucci (1538 - 1621) Italian astronomer and translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Gallucci's Italian translation and commentary of Hartmann's 1542 edition of Peckham‚Äôs optics textbook, with new figures.
BP_Description_1: Giovanni Paolo Gallucci's Italian translation and commentary of Hartmann's 1542 edition of Peckham's optics textbook, <i>Perspectiva Communis<i>. This is one of several translations Gallucci produced (he is famed for his <i>Margarita Filosfica<i>, an Italian translation of Reisch's encyclopedia) and is the last printing of the <i>Perspectiva Communis<i> to appear before Johannes Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604. In his prefatory dedication to the apostolic secretary Giovanni Battista Cucina, Gallucci praises the value of Peckham's book: 'we must be grateful to those who offer us instruments to help us discern the true from the false, as the author of this manual that communicates to us in a clear and exhaustive manner every rule concerning perfect vision.' Gallucci‚Äôs vernacular translation made Peckham's work available to a broader audience. Gallucci‚Äôs glosses feature examples taken from everyday life. For instance, <i>‚ÄòPropositio IX‚Äô<i> illustrates why a fire appears bigger at night, and bigger from afar, when one cannot distinguish the individual flames. Gallucci compares this to what happens in church to a short-sighted person who looks at the many lit candles: without his spectacles on, the candles will appear like they are big, and touching one another; with his spectacles on, the individual flames will be discernible and the candles smaller. The long section on mirrors discusses the reflection of colors, the angles of incidence, transparency, the function of lead on glass mirrors, mirrors made of iron or diamond, spherical or plain or shaped like a column, and the appearance of images on broken mirrors.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 8.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 8.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An analysis of refraction in spheres and its application to concave and convex lenses. Important advances in the use of geometric diagrams in optics. Also considers various theories of vision.
BP_Description_1: Giambattista Della Porta's <i>De Refractione<i> has its beginnings in his earlier work, the second edition of the Magia Naturalis of 1589. An early version of the <i>De Refractione<i> must already have been underway, if not completed, since he mentions it several times in the Magia Naturalis. In the nearly 30 years that separated the first and second editions of the Magia, Della Porta's understanding of optics and his knowledge of existing works on the subject had grown; he cites earlier works liberally in <i>De Refractione<i>, mentioning Aristotle, Euclid, Galen, Ptolemy, Alhazen, Avicenna, Averroes, Bacon, Witelo, Peckham, and many others. And his manner of presentation changed considerably. The optical part of the Magia was a collection of descriptions of optical effects with only faint attempts at explanation, the <i>De Refractione<i> was based on geometry, with definitions, postulates, theorems, and proofs. His preface makes clear why he (re)wrote <i>De Refractione<i>:  'The circumstance which impelled us to write <i>De Refractione<i> was that we might see the matter covered briefly by our ancestors and become a more  satisfying treatise, so that rather than traces, the foundations of the art could be seen.'|<i>De Refractione<i> is important as a bridge between medieval Perspectiva and the imagining by dioptrics established by Johannes Kepler in 1604. As a prelude to his analysis of refraction in spheres, Della Porta undertakes an extensive analysis of spherical mirrors and this is perhaps the most important advance in <i>De Refractione<i>. It is also witness to the change in optics in the 16th century: a new interest in and insistence upon the use of experiments and observation of nature, and the need and value of constructing geometric models of natural phenomena. Though Della Porta reports many observations, ultimately, he was unable to construct a sufficiently encompassing geometric framework that would have led to a successful treatment of lenses. But even with that, De Refractione had considerable influence, if only because of its introduction of the camera obscura as a model for the eye and the acknowledged starting point this provide for Johannes Kepler.
BP_Description_2: <i>De Refractione<i> is in nine books. 1: Refraction of light and vision at the interface of two media. 2: Refraction in the glass sphere. 3: Structure of the eye. 4: Vision as penetration of direct and refracted rays into the eye. 5: Perspective vision. 6: binocular vision. 7: Various issues from the optics, physiology and psychology of vision. 8: Spherical lenses. 9: Various issues on refraction including the rainbow, meteorological phenomena and so on.||De Refractione can be divided into three parts: books 1-2 develop a theory of refraction in spheres (64 pages), books 3-7 analyze the eye and a theory of vision (93 pages), books 8-9 give a  theory of lenses and their application (72 pages).||The work begins with a review of optical basics in the form of propositions and a description of Della Porta's instrument for measuring angles of refraction. His tables of values reveal that he must have actually built and used this device. The basic propositions are used to explain well-known phenomena, some explanations are successful (objects appearing bent when partially submerged in water, atmospheric refraction changing stellar positions), some are not (the position of fully submerged objects).  Before considering spherical refraction, Della Porta considers reflection in concave spherical mirrors and the images it produces; desiring to produce principles valid for refraction and spherical surfaces. The analysis of spherical mirrors is the most successful part of <i>De Refractione<i> and introduced the notion of the 'inversion point' (where reflected/refracted rays cross) as a method of image analysis. The porting of principles of spherical reflection to spherical refraction was erroneous and blinkered most of the later developments in De Refractione. Spherical refraction is applied to the analysis of the eye and the mechanism of vision, combining refraction with traditional ideas involving the visual pyramid and it composite rays and the crystalline humor as the seat of vision. It is here that Della Porta makes his observation that the pupil acts like the aperture in a camera obscura, creating an image that falls on the front surface of the crystalline. Della Porta's consideration of vision includes his somewhat confused theory of vision, including binocular vision. The last part of De Refractione attempts to apply the theory of the refractive sphere and the inversion point to convex and concave lenses and, unhappily, exhibits many instances of an ingenious carelessness on Della Porta's part, with even simple cases of refraction wrongly constructed. Geometry was used more as analogy than a demonstrative tool.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ ùëª <i>Optical Magic in the Late Renaissance: Giambattista Della Porta's De Refractione of 1593<i>|Smith, A.M.|American Philosophical Society Press, Philadelphia, 2019, 524 pp.||<i>The Optics of Giambattista della Porta(ca. 1535‚Äì1615): A Reassessment<i>|Borrelli, A., Hon, G., Zik, Y., editors|Springer, 2017, 205 pp, NB: pp 97-124, 169-200.||Optics in Sixteenth Century Italy|Lindberg, D.|In: <i>Novita Celesti e Crisi del Sapere<i> (Conference Proceedings, Convegno Internzationale de Studi Galeleio)|Istituto e Muse di Storia della Scienze, Florence, 1983, 408 pp, NB: 131-148.||Thinking with Optical Objects: Glass Spheres, Lenses and Refraction in Giovan Battista Della Porta‚Äôs Optical Writings|Borelli, A.|<i>Journal of Early Modern Studies<i>, Vol 3, No 1, 2014, pp 39-62.||Perspectivist Aristotelianism: Three Case-Studies of Cinquecento Visual Theory|Frangenberg, T.|<i>Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes<i>, Vol 54, 1991, pp 137-158.||Perception and optics in the 16th century: some features of Della Porta‚Äôs theory of vision|Saito, F.|<i>Circumscribere: International Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 8, 2010, pp 28-35.
BP_Title: De refractione optices parte:- Libri Novem. 1 De refractione, & ejus accidentibus. 2 De pylae crystallinae refractione. 3 De oculorum partium anatome, & earum muniis. 4 De visione. 5. De visionis accidentibus. 6 Cur binis oculis rem unam cernamus. 7 De his, quae intra oculum fiunt, & foris existimantur. 8 De specillis. 9 De coloribus ex refractione, s. de iride, lacteo circulo, &c.
BP_Title English Translation: On the Refractive Part of Optics; in Nine Books. 1 Refraction and its accidents. 2 Refraction of the crystalline lens. 3 The anatomy of parts of the eye and their duties. 4 Vision. 5 The accidents of vision. 6 Why we see a single thing with two eyes. 7 Those things which happen inside and outside the eye are considered. 8 Glasses. 9. Colors from refraction, the rainboe, the Milky Way, etc.
BP_Biographical Statement: Neoplitan scholar, polymath, and natural philosopher. Prolific author, showman, and founder of the Academia Secretorum Naturae, the first scientific society.
BP_Provenance: Old owners' names crossed out on titlepage.
BP_Printer: Giovanni Giacomo Carlino and Antonio Pace
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1593 Porta - De refractione - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Late Renaissance encyclopedia of nature, including natural philosophy. The brief sections on vision and light (11 pages) deal with the rainbow, simple ocular anatomy, vision, the nature of light and color, reflection and mirrors. The treatment is question and answer; the material a mix of Euclidian rays and Aristotelian qualities.
BP_Description_1: Bondin's encyclopedia reflects the scope and content of late Renaissance natural philosophy and the challenge it faced accommodating new information from contemporary and newly discovered antiquarian sources. Boudin reconsiders, remakes, and often replaces Scholastic Aristotelian explanations; the result is a book on the cusp between pure authoritarianism and the later empiricism of Cartesianism. The books' clear intent and audience was to enlighten and entertain the average reader. It was widely read; copies are found from England to Russia, from Sweden to Spain. The book was in active used for  more than three-quarters a century, with three Latin editions (1596, 1597, and 1605), a French translation in 1597, and a German adaptation in 1602. Though the philosophical and theological parts of the book drew criticism, those dealing with natural philosophy were praised, cited, and copied.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Universae Naturae Theatrum<i> is a late Renaissance encyclopedia of nature, including natural philosophy. The brief sections on vision and light (11 pages) deal with the rainbow, simple ocular anatomy, vision, the nature of light and color, reflection and mirrors. The treatment is elementary in the form of questions and answers; the material a mix of ray geometry from Euclid's <i>Optica<i> and points from Aristotle's <i>De Anima<i>.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>The Theater of Nature: Jean Bodin and Renaissance Science<i>|Ann Blair|Princeton University Press, 1997, 397 pp.
BP_Title: Universae Naturae Theatrum. In quo rerum omnium effectrices causae, & fines contemplantur, & continuae series quinque libris discutiuntur.
BP_Title English Translation: The Universal Theater of Nature. In which the Efficient and Final Causes of all of Things are contemplated, dispersed in a continuous series of Five Books.
BP_Biographical Statement: French jurist and political phlosopher, law professor at Toulouse, and excentric natural philosopher.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1597 Bodin - Univers√¶ Natur√¶ Theatrum - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Natural Magic is presented as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. Vison, mirrors and lenses are considered in the optics section.
BP_Description_1: Giambattista Della Porta's <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> was a significant expansion of his early book on natural magic of 1558. For Della Porta, Natural Magic was the practical part of natural philosophy and focused on exceptional, unusual, extraordinary phenomena, rather than the quotidian. It was the recognition and mastering of natural phenomena, in particular, those phenomena that had to be sought out, phenomena that were otherwise hidden. The point was not to explain the phenomena, but to be able to (re)produce it, display it, describe it and thus reveal nature's secrets. The author and the book changed considerably in the nearly thirty years that separated the first and second editions. Della Porta had mastered a large portion of classical humanist studies by 1589, including the medieval encyclopedias of secrets. From the latter, the scope of the book expanded considerably, and Della Porta established a long list of secrets which the second edition of the <i>Magiae Naturalis<i> was to 'reduce all those secrets into their  proper places.' The second edition is also considerably more experimental in the sense of the direct manipulation of nature. But one aspect of the book and its author did not change: the notion that explaining natural phenomena and unlocking the secrets of nature are fundamentally esoteric activities. Alchemy and Optics are significant portions of the Magiae Naturalis of 1589.|<i>The Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> established Della Porta's reputation as Europe's leading authority on natural magic. The book was tremendously popular and commercially successful; Antwerp's Pantin Press and Frankfurt's Wechel press were among dell Porta's publishers. Printings of the second Latin edition appeared in 1589, 1591, 1592, 1597, 1600, 1607, 1619, 1644, 1650, 1651, and 1664. An Italian translation appeared in 1611, a German translation appeared at Magdeburg in 1612 and 1617, French translations appeared at Lyon in 1615 and at Rouen in 1657, an English translation appeared at London in 1658 and 1659.
BP_Description_2: Giambattista Della Porta presents natural magic as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. There are 20 books: 1: Of the Causes of Wonderful things, 2: Of the Generation of Animals. 3:Of the Production of New Plants. 4: Of increasing Household Stuff. 5: Of changing Metals. 6: Of counterfeiting Gold. 7: Of the Wonders of the Loadstone. 8: Of strange Cures. 9: Of Beautifying Women. 10: Of Distillation.11: Of Perfuming. 12: Of Artificial Fires. 13: Of Tempering Steel. 14: Of Cookery. 15: Of Fishing, Fowling, Hunting, etc. 16: Of Invisible Writing. 17: Of Catoptric Images. 18: Of Statick Experiments. 19: Pneumatic Experiments. 20: Of the Chaos.  Of all the material covered, that considered in book 17 on vison, mirrors and lenses, is probably the most important, it was certainly that with the most extensive and lasting effect. It contains 23 topics: Plane mirrors; Plane mirror illusions; Mirrors for display and the theater; Concave mirrors; Plane and concave mirrors together; Other operations with concave mirrors; How to see in the dark, that which is illuminated by torches; How without a mirror or other device an image can hand in the air; Mixtures of mirrors and their images; The Crystalline Lens and its effects; Lenses for seeing far beyond what can be imagined; Camera obscura; Crystal prism; Burning mirrors; Parabolic burning mirrors and their construction; Parabolic section construction; Parabolic section for burning at infinite distances; Burning glass from spherical sections; Kindling fire more forcefully with refraction; Image outside a concave mirror; Making mirrors; Making plane, convex, and concave mirrors with applied and bonded foil; Making metallic mirrors.||Della Porta is not interested in explaining optical phenomena--he refers the reader to Archimedes, Euclid, Ptolemy, and Witelo--nor does he aim to discern and study the laws of optics to explain the effects. Rather, he seeks to demonstrate and show how it is possible to increase the effect of optical phenomena. The most influential topics are the camera obscura and lenses. Della Porta had added a mirror to the camera obscura to right the image, but by 1589 he places a lens in the aperture to clarify and amplify the image, and more importantly, to make the first suggestion that the eye is like a camera obscura. Concave mirrors are discussed and their numerous images presented in considerable detail. It is in connection with mirror images that Della Porta introduces the point of inversion (where rays cross, the focus) and the use of the cathetus to predict image location.
BP_Reference(s): Knowing by doing in sixteenth-century natural magic: Giambattista della Porta and the wonders of nature|Saito, F.|<i>Circumscribere<i>, Vo1 14, 2014, pp 17-39||<i>Science and the Secretes of Nature: Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture<i>|Eamon, W.|Princeton University Press, 1994, 490 pp, NB: pp 210-233.||<i>The Optics of Giambattista della Porta(ca. 1535‚Äì1615): A Reassessment<i>|Borrelli, A., Hon, G., Zik, Y., editors|Springer, 2017, 205 pp, NB: pp 184-188.
BP_Title: Io. Baptistae Portae Neopolitani, Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti. In Quibus Scientiarum Naturalium divitiae, & deliciae demonstratur. Iam de novo ab omnibus mendis repurgati, in lumen prodierunt. Accessit Index, rem omne dilucide repraesentans, copiosissimus. Librorum ordinen, qui in hoc opere continentur, versa pagina indicabit.
BP_Title English Translation: Giambattista della Porta, Neapolitan. Twenty Books of Natural Magic. In Which the Riches and Pleasures of Natural Science are Given Account. Now newly cleansed of all defects and brought forth. A Very Copius Index is Added Clearly Presenting Each Thing. The Order of the Books Contained in this Work is Indicated on the Back of This Page.
BP_Biographical Statement: Neoplitan scholar, polymath, and natural philosopher. Prolific author, showman, and founder of the Academia Secretorum Naturae, the first scientific society.
BP_Provenance: Two old owner inscriptions on free endpaper. Bookplage of Lucien Derode.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Giovanni Paolo Gallucci
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian translation of Reisch's medieval encyclopedia, with additions by Oronce Fin√© and an introduction by Faber Stapulensis to the arithmetic of Boethius and Jordanus. The substantial additions comprise instructions on arithmetic and music.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting with a new date on the title page of Giovanni Paolo Gallucci's Italian translation of 1599 of Reisch's early Renaissance work the <i>Margarita Philosophica<i> of 1503. Though often called the first modern encyclopedia to appear in print, it is, rather, an epitome, a compendium, a textbook, written for students. It was the first printed text in widespread use that presented the disciplines in a university course of study--a distillation of most of Aristotelian philosophy. The book was meant to be read through; it gives a threaded, contiguous presentation and not a collection of isolated articles for dipping into. The Philosophical Pearl is patterned after the curriculum of the University of Freiburg, where Reisch had studied. He collected the specified texts, from them generated an accessible dialogue format, and added the complete array of trivium and quadrivium subjects. Though no evidence exists that it was actually prescribed, Reisch's Philosophical Pearl was used at universities throughout Europe. Andreas Vesalius records reading its anatomy section while at student at Louvain--and he was not impressed. Of particular importance are books 8-11 which deal with natural philosophy.|The Italian translation has (with the exception of books 8-11) considerably fewer illustrations than the earliest Latin editions, but it has additions by Oronce Fin√© and an introduction by Faber Stapulensis to the arithmetic of Boethius and Jordanus. The substantial additions include: Latin Grammar, Arithmetic, Music, Squaring the circle, Architecture, Sundials, Astrolabe construction, Mirrors, the Torquetum, Cosmography, and Perspective. These additions are half as large as the original work, added significant and detailed modern material to Reisch's content, and undoubtedly increased the book's instructional value.|Editions of the Latin text appeared in 1503, 1504, 1504, 1508, 1508, 1512, 1515, 1517, 1535, 1583. The augmented Italian translation appeared at Venice in 1599 and 1600.
BP_Description_2: The optical material in the 10th book (20 pages) consisting of chapters 3 - 14 and deal with light and vision. 3: Multiplication of species by media, immediately and successively. 4: How different species are distinctly multiplied in a medium. 5: On the powers of the universal sensitive soul. 6: On vision and its excellence. 7: The object of vision, on light, the conditions for seeing, and how opaque bodies block vision.  8: Color and specie. The generation of color according to the different opinions of philosophers. 9: The organ of sight, the eye, its qualities and structure with 7 fabrics and 4 humors. 10: The manner of vision, fireflies and waves that emit light, and why they are not seen in daylight. 11: The quality of the medium--so that the thing is seen correctly by direct, reflected, and refracted visual rays--is perfect and invisible. 12: The reason a thing seems larger or smaller than another, and what is correct. 13: The nature and types of mirrors. 14: Is the manner of seeing sending rays from the eye to the object or receiving species? And is the act of sensing assimilation to the sense's spirit?||The visual process material is Scholastic, with the multiplication of species presented as the basis for vision. The geometric optics covers simple reflection and refraction, plane mirrors, is from Euclid's Optica, and is accompanied by woodblock figures. Chapter 9 contains the first printed schematic image of the eye. The 18-page added section on perspective is by Carlo Bouillo de Cambrai. It contains a basic review of elementary optics, a discussion of light and shadow, scholastic color theory, the operation of convex and concave spherical mirrors and their images, and aspects of visual perception.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ ùëª <i>Natural Philosophy Epitomised: A translation of books 8‚Äì11 of Gregor Reisch‚Äôs Philosophical pearl (1503)<i>|Kusukawa, S., Cunningham, A.|Routledge, 2010, 420 pp, NB: pp 218-275.
BP_Title: Margarita filosofica del R.do P.F. Gregorio Reisch, nella quale si trattano con bellissimo, & breue metodo non solo tutte le dottrine comprese nella ciclopedia dagli antichi, cio√® cerchio, ouer rotolo delle scienze; ma molte altre ancora aggiunteui di nouo da Orontio Fineo matematico regio. Tradotta nuovamente dalla lingua latina nell'italiana da Giouan Paolo Gallucci Salodiano Accademico Veneto; E dal medesimo accresciuta di varie, e bellissime cose come nella Nona Pagina si vede. Non meno per i curiose dilettevole, che util, e giouevole per gli studiosi. Con Licenza de' Superior, & Privilegij.
BP_Title English Translation: Pearl of Philosophy of the Reverend Father Gregor Reisch. In which is delt in a beautiful and brief method not only all the doctrines included in the encyclpoldiae of the ancients--that is, the full course of the sciences --but also many more added by Oronce Fine, royal mathematician. Newly translated from the Latin into Italian by Giovanni Paolo Gallucci, Salodian academic of Venice. And similar various and beautiful things as you see on page nine. And no less curiously delightful, useful, and beneficial for Students. With license and Priviledge.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Carthusian, humanist, encyclopedist, combater of Lutheranism
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Giovanni Rossi on front pastedown.
BP_Collation: a-c‚Å¥ (c bound before b) A-Z‚Å∏ Aa-Zz‚Å∏ Aaa-Ccc‚Å∏ Ddd‚Å¥ Eee-Zzz‚Å∏ Aaaa-Bbbb‚Å∏ Cccc‚Å∂

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: 10th edition of Clavius's commentaries on Sacrobosco's <i>De Sphaera Mundi<i>. Written for use in the Collegio Romano and thus entirely Ptolemaic and strictly anti-Copernican.
BP_Description_1: 10th edition of Clavius's commentaries on Sacrobosco's <i>De Sphaera Numdi<i>.  This, the principal astronomical work of Clavius, was his commentary on the <i>Tractatus de sphaera<i>  written by the Englishman Johannes Sacrobosco (John Holywood),  professor in Paris in the thirteenth century. Sacrobosco  presented a simplified version of the second century Alexandrian astronomy of Ptolemy which gained wide popularity, attracted numerious commentators and glosses, and became the most-used astronomy textbook throughout the Middle Ages.||First published in 1570, this is the penultimate edition of Clavius's commentary on Sacrobosco and the last to appear before Galileo's <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> in 1610. The differences between this edition and the next are small but striking. Clavius would edit the work once more, just after the <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> appeared, and in it felt compelled to express some flexibility about the rigid adherence to Ptolemy and Aristotle. in the last edition of 1611, Clavius mentions discoveries such as those of the novae stars seen in 1570, 1600 and 1604 and also the comet of 1577 among others by Tycho Brahe; all indicating that, contrary to the Aristotelian doctrine, the celestial spheres were not incorruptible. Clavius acknowledges that Galileo's discovery of the phases of Venus and the satellites of Jupiter showed that not everything was in orbit around the Earth and that the celestial orbits needed to be 'reformed'.
BP_Description_2: Clavius sets out his view of then-contemporary astronomy, with his commentaries being far more extensive than the original text of Sacrobosco. Clavius presents a geocentric Ptolemaic astronomy, with the physically-real celestial spheres: seven for the five planets, the Sun and the Moon, one for the fixed stars,  three more to explain certain motions of the stars, and finally the sphere of the empyrean heaven. All with with Ptolemaic eccentrics and epicycles, centered on the Earth at the center of the universe. All allowing an accord with both the physics of Aristotle and a literal interpretation of the Bible.||In the edition of 1581 and repeated here, Clavius pays acknowledges the astronomical work of Copernicus, whom he calls 'the outstanding renovator of astronomy in our times whom posterity will celebrate and admire like a second Ptolemy.'  Nevertheless, though he recognized the great value of Copernicus as a source of observations, tables and calculations, he considered the theory of Ptolemy preferable to what he called the 'inventions' of Copernicus. Writing that many observations and the common opinion of philosophers disprove the heliocentric system, presents many observations and phenomena which prove that the Earth is at the center of the universe; the most important arguments were from Aristotelian physics.
BP_Reference(s): Doctrine of the Sphere, In: <i>The Sun in the Church<i>|Heilbron J.L.|Harvard Universtiy Press, Cambridge, 1999 pp 51-62||The Tracts on the Sphere, In: <i>The Structures of Practical Knowledge<i>|Valleriani, M.|Springer, 2017, PP 421-474||Clavius and Mathematics in the <i>Collegio Romano<i>|Ud√≠as, A.|In: Jesuit Contribution to Science, Springer, 2015, pp 1-22.
BP_Title: In sphaeram Joannis de Sacro Bosco commentarius
BP_Title English Translation: Commentary on 'The Sphere' of John of Holywood.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit teacher at the Collegio Romano, author of important texts in mathematics and astronomy.
BP_Provenance: Owner's signature on title page.
BP_Collation: œÄ¬π a-b‚Å∏ (a‚ÇÇ signed as a‚ÇÉ) A-Z‚Å∏ Aa-Ff‚Å∏ Gg¬π‚Å∞
BP_BibliographicNotes: Engraved portrait of Clavius on verso of front pastedown
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1601 Clavius - Sph√¶ram - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An anatomy for medical students. Stated that the retina, as a continuation of the optic nerve, was the seat of vision. First edition, second issue, this is the text that Kepler studied for ocular anatomy. First use of etchings for medical illustration.
BP_Description_1: Felix Platter published <i>De Corporis Humani Structura et Usu Libri III<i> when he was nearly fifty; producing an anatomy for medical students that benefited from his own 30-year medical and teaching career, and the pioneering anatomical work of Andreas Vesalius. Platter was the first Vesalian anatomist in Germany and the first physician in that country to dissect a human body--performing hundreds of dissections in his lifetime. The  <i>De Corporis Humani Structura et Usu Libri III<i> copied much Vesalian material and was one of the principal books that spread Vesalian anatomy to European medical centers. The book's format is highly structured and presented in a format that made student use easy; lists of anatomical parts are grouped in a series of schemas.|First edition, second issue, this is the text that Kepler studied for ocular anatomy, and the first use of etchings for medical illustration. Editions appeared in 1583 and 1603, the latter being a reissue of the 1583 text with new printing of the first quire of preliminary material. Platter's text deeply influenced Johannes Kepler and his analysis of ocular optics.
BP_Description_2: Felix Platter in his <i>De Corporis Humani Structura et Usu Libri III<i>  of 1583 produced a Vesalian anatomy book specifically for medical students. The work is in three books: Book I The structure and use of the simple parts of the human body including bones, muscles, blood vessels, ligaments, skin, and fat; Book II The structure and use of the composite parts of the human body including membranes, stomach, thorax, head, arm, and leg; Book III Explanation of parts of the human body delineated by pictures. The first two Books present anatomical parts of the body arranged in in a series of elaborate schemas of text and layers of grouping brackets to show structure, hierarchy, and relationship. Book III includes the 50 plates with the relevant text on the facing page of the preceding leaf, an innovation of the De Corporis Humani Structura et Usu Libri III. Though Platter plagiarized much of Vesalius's anatomy (as did many others), the copying was not slavish. Book III contains the first printed illustration of a female skeleton and the more famous child skeleton.||Platter also corrected several aspects of Galenic-Vesalian ocular anatomy with, for example, Platter's drawing of eye showing the crystalline lens closer to the front of the eye, reflecting more recent and accurate information. He also noted the differences in curvature of the front and back of the lens. Importantly, Platter stated that the lens functioned only to form an image on the retina and reiterated the opinion introduced four centuries earlier by Ibn Rushd that the retina, not the crystalline lens, is the seat of vision.
BP_Reference(s): The Eye of Vesalius|De Laey, J.J.|<i>Acta Ophthalmologica<i>, Vol 89, pp 293-300.|The Great Anatomical Atlases|Thomas, K.B.|<i>Proceeding of the Royal Society of Medicine<i>, Vol 67, 1974, pp 223-232.
BP_Title: De corporis humani structura et usu Libri III
BP_Title English Translation: Three Books on the Structure and Function of the Human Body.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss physician, anatomist, and professor in Basel. First proponents of the Germ theory of disease.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'Gabriel Lantonuis' on titlepage
BP_Collation: Œ±‚Å¥ A-Z‚Å¥ (Z‚ÇÅ signed Y, Z‚ÇÇ signed X) Aa-Bb‚Å¥; œÄ¬π œá‚Åµ¬π
BP_Plates: Plates [1-50]|Plates on recto of text leaves

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean Pena (1528 - 1558) French educational reformer and student of Peter Ramus, famous for the preface written for this text: <i>De usu optices praefatio<i>, Preface on the use of optics.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of Pena's Latin translation from the Greek of Euclid's geometrical optics of lenses and mirrors that first appeared in 1557. Includes the influential preface The Use of Optics.
BP_Description_1: Second edition of Jean Pena's Latin translation from the Greek of Euclid's <i>Optica<i> and the <i>Catoptrica<i> was prompted by his poor assessment of the commonly available translations. He was referring either to the text that appears in Georgius Valla's  <i>De Expetendis et Fugiendis Rebus Opus<i> in 1501 or to the translation of Bartolomeo Zamberti. In his preface, Pena agrees with the assessment of Francesco Maurolyco that earlier translators had insufficient knowledge of <i>Perspectiva<i>. Pena also notes that some theorems and many of the scholia are missing and that some demonstrations accompanied the wrong theorem. Pena sought to completely and accurately present the whole of the optical and vision teaching of Euclid, in part as a balance to what he considered the uncritical acceptance of Witelo and Peckham common at that time. Pena presents the Euclidian work on the geometrical optics of vision and mirrors and even more influentially, includes the preface The Use of Optics.||Editions appeared in 1557 and 1604.
BP_Description_2: Pena prefaces his Greek and Latin text with an assessment of some of the teachings of Witelo and Peckham that he considered erroneous. He argued that though both authors were great scholars, nothing should be accepted until experimentally demonstrated. Pena rejects Witelo's accounting (coming from Alhazen's De Aspectibus) of the intromission theory of vision, supporting the Euclidian idea of rays emanating from the eye. Pena also criticized Peckham's account of the Milky Way light reflected from sun and stars. In Pena's text, there are 61 theorems in the <i>Optica<i> and 31 in the <i>Catoptrica<i>. The Greek and Latin texts are given side-by-side. The book also contains Pena long introductory essay 'On the use of Optics', in which he sets out his ideas on astronomy and cosmology, supporting them by optical arguments. According to Pena, the matter of the heavens was not Aristotelian ether but air. In the essay, Pena detailed how optical theory spoke against a heavenly ether and the celestial spheres that moved the planets and stars.
BP_Reference(s): Liber de visu : The Greco-Latin Translation of Euclid's Optics|Theisen, W.R.|<i>Mediaeval Studies<i>, Vol 41, 1979, pp 44-105.||ùëª The Optics of Euclid|Burton, H.E., translator|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 46, No 5, 1945, pp 357-372.||ùëª <i>The medieval Latin traditions of Euclid's Catoptrica: A Critical Edition of De speculis with an Introduction, English Translation, and Commentary<i>|Takahashi, K.|Kyushu University Press, 1992, 373 pp.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 47-64.||Jean Pean (1528-58) and Stoic Physics in the Sixteenth Century|Barker, P.|<i>The Southern Journal of Philosophy<i>, 1985, Vol XXIII, Supplement||<i>Change and Continuity in Early Modern Cosmology<i>|Boner, P.J., editor|Spring, 2011, 181 pp, NB: pp 40-48.||The Challenge of Applied Optics|In: <i>The Unmaking of the Medieval Christian Cosmos, 1500‚Äì1760<i>|Randles, W.G.L.|Routledge, 2016, 295 pp.||Atmospheric Refraction and the Ramus Circle: Aspects of a Late Sixteenth-Century Dispute|Peoux, G.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 67, No4 , 2010, pp 457-484.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.
BP_Title: Euclidis Optica et Catoptrica e Graeco versa Per Ioan. Penam Mathematicum Regium. His praeposita est eiusdem Ionnis Penae de usu Optices praefatio, ad Illumstrissimum principem CarolumLotharincum Cardinalem.
BP_Title English Translation: The Optics and Catroptrics of Euclid, Turned from the Greek by Jean Pena. This is preceded by a preface by the same Jean Pena: The Use of Optics. [Dedicated] To the most Illustirious Prince Carol  Cardinal Lotharing.
BP_Biographical Statement: Ancient author of geometry, taught at Athens and Alexandria.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1604 Euclid - Optica et Catoptrica - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Establishes the beginning of modern optics. Contains advances in the nature of light, images from pin -holes, mirrors and lenses, and the optics of the eye.
BP_Description_1: The origin of Johannes Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> is the solar eclipse of 10 July 1600. Tycho Brahe had previously described the errors using a camera obscura to determine sun and moon sizes and so Kepler, hoping to find their cause, recorded the instrument's aperture size, screen distance, image size--just has Brahe had done--along with other eclipse data. He recorded all his observations in an 'eclipse notebook.' In the following weeks Kepler studies optics, consulting Friedrich Risner's editions of the De Aspectibus of Alhacen and the <i>Perspectiva<i> of Witelo of 1572, the <i>De Corporis Humani Structura et Usu Libri III<i> of Platter of 1603, the <i>Anatomia Pragensis<i> of Johannes Jessen of 1601, and Della Porta's <i>Magia Naturalis<i> of 1589 and <i>De Refractione<i> of Della Porta of 1593. He then added two sets of numbered propositions to the eclipse notebook: 17 set out his theory of pin-hole image formation, and 14 listed problems to be solved. The eclipse notebook became a draft outline of the Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena. For three years Kepler divided his efforts between work on determining the orbit of Mars and turning his eclipse notebook into his optics book. The first five chapters are the paralipomena to Witelo, covering the nature of light, the eye, and vision. The final 6 chapters are the optical parts of astronomy, applying his optical developments to observations and instruments. Kepler had completed his manuscript by the end of 1603 and presented it to the Holy Roman Emperor, Rudolph II, on New Year‚Äôs Day, 1604. Printing was completed in time for the book to appear at the autumn book fair of 1604.||Kepler's ocular anatomy came directly from Flex Platter's <i>De Corporis Humani Structura et Usu Libri III<i> of 1583/1603. Particularly import was Platter's size and placement of the lens and retina, and his idea that the retina was the seat of vision. Indeed, the images in the plate of ocular anatomy in the <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> are direct copies from Platter's work.||Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> produced four significant advances in optics: the nature of light, the formation of images from pin -holes (the camera obscura), the nature of images from mirrors and lenses, and the optics and function of the eye. The first and second arose from Kepler's dogged insistence on the rectilinear propagation of light. The third arose from careful and accurate application of geometry to reflection and refraction. The fourth arose from the first three and his study of ocular anatomy--and permanently established the camera obscura as the model of the eye. In this way, the <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> fissioned medieval Perspectiva into two sciences: that of light and that of vision. Though the influence of the <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> was  permanent and profound, if slow to develop. Early adopters of its physical optics included Ambrosius Rhode in his <i>Optica<i> of 1611, and of its theory of ocular optics included Vopiscus Plemp in his <i>Ophthalmographia<i> of 1632. The Jesuit Francois Aguil√≥n in his <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> of 1613 did not know of Kepler and held to the perspectivist idea of intromission of species.  But the Jesuit Christoph Scheiner in his <i>Oculus<i> of 1619 followed Kepler's optics and his ocular function.  And Ren√© Descartes would famously claim he learned optics from Kepler. <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> also affected astronomy; showing how to precisely determine changing sun and moon diameters and thus orbit eccentricities.
BP_Description_2: The book is in two parts: Chapters 1-5 are the paralipomena to Witelo, and chapters 6-11 are the optical part of astronomy. 1: Nature of Light, 2: Shape of Light, 3: Catoptrics and Images, 4: Measure of Refraction, 5: Means of Vision, 6: Varied Lights of Stars, 7: Earth's Shadow, 8: Moon's Shadow, 9: Parallaxes, 10: Optics of Heavenly Bodies' Motions, 11: Observation of Sun and Moon Diameters and Eclipses. Chapter 1 presents the nature of light and its propagation. From his fixed principle of rectilinear propagation and the nature of reflection and refraction, Kepler lays out 38 propositions. Number 9 is the first enunciation of the inverse-square nature of illumination. Chapter 2 presents 12 propositions that solve the problem of images from pin-holes. He begins with an object sending rays of light through a vanishingly small hole; elegantly demonstrating how light 'paints' an image or 'picture' of the object on a screen. Larger apertures of any shape can be considered a collection of vanishingly small holes, and so explains how an object's image changes shape as the screen assumes different distances from the aperture and why  at great distances the 'picture' is that of the object and not the aperture. Importantly, larger apertures made for brighter sun and moon images, with more easily determined diameters that were less affected by diffraction. And apertures of any size could be accounted for in calculating image diameter. Chapter 3 presents 19 propositions that are careful, geometric considerations of reflection and the size and position of images produced. Kepler makes a distinction between the image formed by a curved mirror (Della Porta's floating images) and that projected onto a screen by pin-hole or a lens: 'imago' and 'pictura.' That is, what came to be called virtual and real images.  Chapter 4 describes the measurement of the angle of refraction and gives a table values to correct that of Witelo. Kepler struggles without success to obtain a general law relating the angles of incidence and refraction, settling for what he recognizes to be an approximation good for small angles. Chapter 5 presents Kepler's distillation of ocular anatomy and his work on refraction: his theory of the optical function of the eye. Kepler is unfamiliar with lenses, using instead a sphere to represent the crystalline humor. He traces rays through the sphere to show how a 'pictura' of an object is painted on the retina by rays coming from the object and are refracted by the crystalline humor. Kepler separates the crystalline humor and retina completely--only the retina is sensitive to light. Kepler goes no further that a 'pictura' painted on the retina, how visual perception arises from this inverted image he 'leaves to the philosophers.'
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Kepler's Optics: A Study in the Development of Seventeenth-century Natural Philosophy<i>|Straker, S.M.|Dissertation, Indiana University, 1970, 585 p.||ùëª <i>Optics: Paralipomena to Witelo & Optical Part of Astronomy<i>|Donahue, W.H., translator|Green Lion Press, Santa Fe, 2000||Expectation, Modelling and Assent in the History of Optics II: Kepler and Descartes|Crombie, A.C.|<i>Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 22, No. 1, 1992, pp 89-115.||Ptolemy, Alhazen, and Kepler and the Problem of Optical Images|Smith, A.M.|<i>Arabic Sciences and Philosophy<i>, Vol 8, No 1, 1998, pp 9-44.||Kepler‚Äôs Optical Part of Astronomy (1604): Introducing the Ecliptic Instrument|Hon, G., Zik, Y.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 17, No 3, 2009, pp 307-345.
BP_Title: Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena, quibus Astronomiae part Optica Traditur; Postissimum de artificiosa observatiosne et aestimatione diametroum deliquiorumque; Solis & Lunae. Cum examplis insignium eclipsium. Habes hoc libro, lector, inter alia multa nova, Tractatum luculentum de modo visionis, & humorum oculi usu, contra Optics & Anatomicos, Authore Jonne Keplero, S.C.Mthis Mathematico.
BP_Title English Translation: A supplement to Vitelo, in which the Optical Part of Astronomy is Propounded. Above all, on the Skillful Observation and Appraisal of the Diameters of Eclipses of the Sun and Moon. With Examples of Important Eclipses. In this Book, Reader, You have, among many other new things, A Lucid Treatment of the Means of Vision, and the Use of the Humors of the Eye, against the Opticians and Anatomists. By the author Johannes Kepler, His Imperial Majesty's Mathematician.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, astrologer. Worked extensively in celestial mechanics and innovated radically in vision and optics.
BP_Printer: Claude de Marne and  Jean Aubry

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Nikolaus Krug (1575-1648)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Influential, posthumously published brief compendium of optics, including a reprinting of Pena's 'The Use of Optics.' Willebrord Snell famously annotated a copy.
BP_Description_1: Posthumous publication of a compendium of optics by Pierre de la Ram√©e and Friedrich Risner. Risner's library contained an unfinished manuscript of a book he and Pierre de la Ram√©e had begun previous to the publication of Risner's <i>Opticae Thesaurus<i> of 1572. The <i>Opticae Libri Quatuor<i> has a preface to the reader undoubtedly written by the editor and publisher, Nikolaus Krug, a teacher, mathematician, librarian, and school rector at Kassel. Krug notes that the text was the work of both Ramus and Risner: '... a common work, first begun and arranged by the promise and desire of the great Peter Ramus; Risner finished and corrected some parts, and only moved and formed others.' Ramus mentions the unfinished text in his will that funded a Professor of Mathematics at the Coll√®ge Royal. He nominated Risner for the position 'so that he will be able to finish the work on optics which we began by our common labors ...' Risner never finished the project and of the manuscript that Krug brought to the press, only the first book was in a complete state. Apparently, Risner contribution was limited to a few mathematical demonstrations and references to Alhacen and Witelo. Krug included a reprinting of Jean Pena's <i>De Usu Optices<i>, 'The Use of Optics.' as a preface to the four books of Ramus and Risner.||The <i>Opticae Libri Quatuor<i> summarizes the optics of Euclid and Aristotle, but particularly of Alhacen, and Witelo. It is the optics of the <i>Opticae Thesaurus<i> of 1572 with the details summarized or omitted and the mathematical demonstrations much reduced. It was, however abbreviated or incomplete, a useful summary of pre-Keplerian optics. Willebrord Snell considered it so and famously annotated a copy in the years 1611-1622.||Editions appeared in 1606 and 1615.
BP_Description_2: The work contains the introduction 'De Usu Optices' from Jean Pena's <i>Euclidis Optica et Catoptrica<i> of 1557, and four books written by Ramus and emended by Risner. Book 1: On the Visible. Book 2: On Direct Vision. Book 3: On Vision Established by Reflection. Book 4: On Refracted Vision. Book 1 presents a medieval perspectivist account of light, color, and vision, mixed with Euclidian rays propagating in straight lines. Vision is the intromission of light and color species emitted by the visible object, made possible by the transparency of intervening medium which, in turn, is affected by light. Witelo's theory of images from pin-holes is given, along with a Euclidian account of light and shadow, and the Scholastic account of color as the mixing of light and dark, white and black. Book 2 is on direct vision and the intromission of species, including the cone of vision and various aspects of visual perception. These include color, size, shape, place, number, and motion. Book 3 is on reflection vision and covers basic reflection, true and false reflection (true images and illusions), plane and curved mirrors, convex and concave mirrors. Book 4 is on refracted vision and covers images from refraction, measurement of refraction, the rainbow, atmospheric refraction and meteorics. Book 1 is the longest and most complete, by far. The material is descriptive, with very little mathematics. Though there are extensive references to the <i>Opticae Thesaurus<i> of 1572, none of the elaborate material on the formation, placement, or size of images from mirrors is present.

A.|<i>Osiris<i>, Vol 1, 1936, pp 718-725.||<i>Risneri Opticam cum Annotationibus Willebrordi Snellii<i>|Vollgraff, J.A., editor|Plantin, 1918, 312 pp.|Gives Willebrored Snell's annotations on and the complete Latin text of Risner's Opticae Libri Quatuor.
BP_Title: Opticae libri quatuor ex voto Petri Rami novissimo per Fridericum Risnerum ejusdem in Mathematicis Adjutorum olim conscripti, nunc demum asupiciis Illustris. & Ptenstis. Principis ac Domini, Dn Mauritii Hassiae, Landgrave, & e situ & tenebris in usum & lucem publicam producti.
BP_Title English Translation: Four Books of Optics written at the last wish of Peter Rami by Friderich Risner, formerly [his] Mathematical Assistant. Under the auspices of the illustrius and power prince Lord Mauritius Hassia, Landgrave of Hesse-Cassel, now finally out from neglect and darkness and revealed into utility and public light.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician and student of Petrus Ramus, studied and wrote in optics in France.
BP_Provenance: Inscription from Jesuit College at Munich dated 1607  on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A fully annotated teaching edition of Euclid's Elements.
BP_Description_1: Ambrosius Rhode's fully annotated teaching edition of Euclid's Elements. The idea for the Execution of textbook of the Elements goes back at least as early as 1608.  In a letter to Johannes Kepler, Rhode wrote of his plan to publish the Euclid in "short form". He acknowledged the elaborate edition of the Jesuit Christoph Clavius, but  based on their difficulty, density, and the price due to its immense size, it was not a text accessible by the general student. Rhode hoped to present Euclid in a less dense, clearer, and less expensive form. But, fearing the judgments of others. he asked Kepler for council; and it seems that Kepler advised him to publish such a work. The result was a book is deeply informed by Rhode's experience in teaching mathematics.||Often bound with his <i>Optica<i> of 1611. This, the first edition of Rhode's Euclid, appeared in 1609, a corrected edition was published posthumously in 1634.
BP_Description_2:
Rhode adheres strictly to the axiomatic structure of Euclid, believing that this was the key to the clarity required of beginning mathematics students. He follows this ordered structure throughout: Formulation of the problem
Presentation of the data given, Explain what is to be proven, Construction,  Proof, and Conclusion. The text is filled with necessary figures in woodblock. Rhode covers all of Euclid's thirteen books with a clarity that made the text useful and successful.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Zur mathematischen Lehrt√§tigkeit an der Universit√§t Wittenberg im 16. und fr√ºhen 17. Jahrhundert, dargestellt unter besonderer Ber√ºcksichtigung des Wittenberger Mathematikers Ambrosius Rhodius (1577-1633)|Sch√∂neburg, S.|Dissertation, Martin-Luther-Universit√§t Halle-Wittenberg, 2007, 211 pp, NB pp 69-79.
BP_Title: Euclidis Elementorum Libri XIII. Succinctis & perspicuis demonstrationibus comprehensi
BP_Title English Translation: The 13 Books of Euclid's Elements Comprehended, Succinctly and Clearly Demonstrated
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, and physician. Worked with Tyco Brahe and Johannes Kepler. Taught for many years at the  University of Wittenberg.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp of Frederikborg Gymnasiums on front free endpaper.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Rhode's Optica of 1611

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Giovanni Bartoli (?-?) Italian courtier, diplomat, antagonist of Galileo. Wrote the preface to this work.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Based on teaching notes and prompted by Galileo's Sidereus Nuncius, a brief exposition of three aspects of optics: Vision, lenses and the telescope, and the rainbow.
BP_Description_1: Marco Antonio de Dominis was teaching mathematics at the universities of Padua and Brescia between 1588 and 1593. He had developed teaching notes which became the text of <i>De Radiis Visus et Lucis<i>. Though de Dominis had not been active in natural philosophy for 20 years, sometime before the text was printed, he added material on the telescope, having prompted by his friend Giovanni Bartoli and the general intellectual ferment created by Galileo's <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> of 1610. The date of this added material is uncertain, and it is unclear if de Dominis knew of Galileo's work or of Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611, since the imprimatur for the  preface of <i>De Radiis Visus et Lucis<i> is dated early in 1610 but its preface is dated late in 1611. Bartoli edited the text, wrote a preface, and was responsible for bringing the text to print. The preface describes the long path from composition to printing.||The material on optics and vision comes from Witelo and was entirely conventional. <i>De Radiis Visus et Lucis<i> was known for its theory of the rainbow and its claims to priority regarding the telescope. By using a glass sphere filled with water, de Dominis proposed and demonstrated that the rainbow was caused by reflection from the back of raindrops. On this basis, later writers would give de Dominis credit for explaining the rainbow; this included Isaac Newton. It is commonly held that, de Dominis (and subsequent others) did not know of Theodoric of Freiburg and his explanation of the rainbow early in the 14th century, even though Theodoric's full explanation appeared in print in Trutfetter's <i>Summa in totƒÅ physicen<i> of 1514.
BP_Description_2: <i>De Radiis Visus et Lucis<i> has three principal parts: Basic mathematical and physical optics, Vision and the use of spectacles, Theory of the rainbow. Chapters 1-4 present the basic propositions of optics, basic aspects of reflection and refraction, and the consequences of rectilinear propagation. Convex and concave lenses are considered, but only to the extent of describing ray paths and convergence or divergence. This material lays the foundation for principal topics of the book: the operation of lenses and the function of the rainbow. Chapter 5-7 present the eye and vision and the use of lenses in spectacles to correct near and far-sightedness. de Dominis is unaware of any previous mathematical work on lenses, and his understanding comes from his own experiments. Chapters 8-9 are on the telescope. It is here that de Dominis makes his famous claim regarding the telescope: 'I am the first to break the ice.' Chapters 10-17 give de Dominis' theory of the rainbow. He starts with an historical review of rainbow theories from Aristotle's <i>De Meteorologica<i> to Renaissance writers, then considers <i>De Meteorologica's<i> commentators, and finally gives his own theory. This includes the rainbow's formation, shape, the cause of its colors, its angular size, and the cause of the secondary bow. The treatment is marked by an inconsistent use of de Dominis' own principles of refraction developed earlier in the book. This, confusion between the path of a single ray and that of ray bundles, and the poorly executed figures, contributes to the obscurity of the explanation. Chapter 18 is on other refractive atmospheric phenomena: coronae, parahelia, and others. Though supported by geometry, the material is generally descriptive and not analytic.
BP_Reference(s): Marco Antonio de Dominis and His Explanation of the Rainbow|Ockenden, R. E.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 26 No 1, 1936, pp 40-49||Die Erklarung des Regenbogens durch Marcantonio de Dominis, 1611. Zum Optikunterricht am Ende des 16. Jahrhunderts|Ziggelaar, A.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 23, No 1, 1979, pp 21-50||Optiƒça Rasprava Marka Antuna de Dominisa: Genze, Metodoligija Znaƒçenje|Martinoviƒá, I.|<i>Prilozi<i>, Vol 55-56, 2002, pp 67-145.
BP_Title: De radiis visus et lucis in Vitris Perspectivis et Iride Tractatus
BP_Title English Translation: Tract on Rays of Vision and Light in Perspective Glasses and the Rainbow
BP_Biographical Statement: Dalmatian Jesuit, eventual Archbishop of Split, redoutable eclesiastical politician, dilettante in natural philosophy.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Errata on K‚ÇÑ ≥
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1611 de Dominis - De radiis visus et lucis - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Prompted by Galileo's Sidereus Nuncius, the earliest complete analysis of dioptrics. Axioms, principles, and experimental results about the refraction of light are applied to lenses, explaining image formation, magnification and its measurement, image inversion, and the operation of the telescope.
BP_Description_1: Johannes Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> was a direct result of Galileo's <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i>. In March of 1610, Kepler had learned of Galileo‚Äôs discoveries from his friend Johannes Matthaeus Wacker von Wackenfels, and in April the ambassador from Tuscany, Giuliano de' Medici, provided Kepler with a copy of the <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> and asked him, via a letter from Galileo, to provide a response. The result was Kepler's <i>Dissertatio<i> of May 1610, praising Galileo and defending his claim to have discovered Jovian satellites and lunar mountains; sight unseen, as it were. In August and September 1610 Kepler verified Galileo's observations, using a telescope the Medici's had provide the Archbishop of Cologne, and described them in his Narratio of October 1610.|In his extensive preface to the <i>Dioptrice<i>, Kepler considers Pena's <i>Usu De Optices<i>, the preface to his translation of Euclid's <i>Optica<i>. Kepler also mentions the <i>Dissertatio<i>, recounts parts of the <i>Narratio<i>, and reproduces letters of Galileo regarding other observations included the phases of Venus. The text of <i>Dioptrice<i> is highly structured, containing: optical, visual, and physical axioms; definitions; problems, postulates, proposition; findings and notes. Kepler begins by considering refraction, measurement of refractive index, and planar refracting media. He then considers refraction at curved surfaces and lenses, making a complete study of the convex lens and the concave-convex lens combination. All this is finally used to describe the operation of the telescope. Here Kepler proposes a telescope using two convex lenses. The analysis is entirely in the context of vision and what is observed; lenses make objects appear larger, inverted, distinct. This is not the analytic geometrical optics of images that would appear 60 years later in Isaac Barrow's Lectiones Opticae of 1674.|The <i>Dioptrice<i> was understood, widely read, and exerted considerable influence until Isaac Barrow's time. The section on dioptrics of Pierre Herigone's <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> of 1634 is a close paraphrase of the <i>Dioptrice<i>; acknowledged by Herigone in the 2nd edition. Pierre Gassendi repeatedly reprinted the <i>Dioptrice<i>. Johannes Hevelius‚Äô Selenographia of 1647 cites Kepler as an authority on lenses. Schyrleus de Rheita's Oculus Enoch et Eliae of 1645 cites the <i>Dioptrice<i>. In Carlo Antonio Manzini‚Äôs <i>L‚ÄôOcchiale all‚ÄôOcchio<i> of 1660, Kepler is frequently cited. Cherubin d‚ÄôOrleans‚Äô <i>La Dioptrique Oculaire<i> of 1671 shows extensive influence of the <i>Dioptrice<i>, including using Kepler approximate law of refraction. He calls himself Kepler's follower and names Kepler the principal author of modern dioptrics.|<i>Dioptrice<i> appeared at Prague in 1611, was reprinted by Gassendi in at Paris in 1647, at London in 1653 and 1683, and at Amsterdam in 1682.
BP_Description_2: Johannes Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> is in 141 numbered sections. They are variously labeled Definition, Axiom, Optical Axiom, Perceptual Axiom, Problem, Proposition, or Notes. There are several sections, each building upon material in previous sections.  1: Refraction at plane surfaces. 2: Light.  3: The lens. 4: Convergence point of a lens.  5: Action of both lens surfaces. 6: The effect of a convex lens by itself. 7: The lens of eye and vision. 8: The use of the lens with respect to the eye. 9: Convex lenses acting together. 10: Concave lenses. 11: Convex and concave lenses acting together. 12: Simple lensed instruments. 13: 'Criptical' lensed instruments.||Sections 1-5 are physical, treating light, glass, and refraction. It begins with Kepler's device for measuring refractive power. It is an idea and image that will appear is optics texts for 150 years, encompassing as it does a demonstration of refraction and means for its measure. Kepler states his approximate law of refraction here: for incidence angles less than 30‚Å∞, the refracted angle is ‚Öî the incidence angle. He establishes convergence points for convex lenses and relates their position to the radius of curvature of the lens, but does not generate any general analytical method for imaging. Sections 6-7 are devoted to the formation of images at the convergence points of convex lenses. Sections 8 deals with how lenses modify vision. The basis is the convergence of rays at the eye, however they may have been modified by lenses after they were emitted by an object. Magnification, minification, and inversion are all treated by assessing the visual angle of rays at the eye; lager angle gives magnification, small angle gives minification. Using this, Kepler explains how a single convex lens can magnify, minify, and invert an object as seen by the eye. It is here that Kepler recognizes spherical aberration. Sections 9-12 describe the operation of the Keplerian telescope and, in Propositions 107-115, the Galilean telescope; that being the highlight and Kepler's goal for the entire work. The last section deals with instruments with various forms of lenses, including menisci.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇKepler and the Telescope|Malet, A.|<i>Annales of Science<i>, Vol 60, 2003, pp 107-136.||Kepler's legacy: Telescopes and geometrical optics, 1611-1669|Malet, A.|In: <i>The Origins of the Telescope<i>, KNAW Press, Amsterdam, 2010, pp 281-300.
BP_Title: Dioptrice seu Demonstratio eorum quae visui & visbilibus propter Conspicilla non ita pridem inventa accidunt.
BP_Title English Translation: Dioptrics, or, A Demonstation of those things that happen to vision and visibles because of the Conspicilla invented not long ago.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, astrologer. Worked extensively in celestial mechanics and innovated radically in vision and optics.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of 'Doctor Mario E. Spada' on front pastedown
