BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Chrosopher Clavius (1538-1612) German Jesuit teacher at the Collegio Romano, author of important texts in mathematics and astronomy.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Spartan march of propositions and proofs coving general optics, with commentary and editing by Clavius. Contains the earliest explanation of the operation of the pin-hole camera.
BP_Description_1: Francesco Maurolyco finished his <i>Photismi de Lumine et Umbra<i> in October of 1521 and the first two books of his <i>Diaphaneon<i> in January of 1522.  In 1554 he added a third book on vision to the <i>Diaphaneon<i> and by the end of 1567 had completed the entire work. Though these manuscripts circulated in a limited way for 50 years after they were written, they became widely known after the Jesuit Christopher Clavus from the Collegium Romano visited Maurolyco at Messina in 1574. Clavius was entrusted with the manuscripts of these and other works, in the hope of their being printed at Rome. Optics had gradually become more important at the Collegium Romanum by the end of the 16th century. Though Clavius would edit the <i>Photismi<i> and the <i>Diaphaneon<i>, the midwife of the Naples printing of 1611 was the Naples Jesuit Giovanni Giacomo Staserio. It was Staserio who convinced Clavius of the value and need for Maurolyco's optics work and it was Staserio who found a nobleman in Genoa to pay for the printing--Giovanni Battista Airolo, the dedicatee. The book appeared not long after Kepler's Ad Vitellionem of 1604 and Galileo's <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> of 1609 when optics assumed a critical part of natural philosophy throughout Europe.|Maurolyco fashioned his texts after the Euclidian model: a Spartan march of propositions, proofs, and demonstrations. They present the earliest explanation of the operation of the pin-hole camera, a theory of vision, a consideration of spectacles for correcting vision, and an explanation of the rainbow--albeit faulty. Maurolyco was the greatest mathematician to work in optics between Ibn al-Haytham in 950 and Johannes Kepler in 1604. He was the first to systematically consider illumination, dealt successfully with penumbral shadow, solved the problem of radiation through small apertures and images from pin-holes, attacked the problem of the rainbow, was the first to explore the geometry of radiation through thin lenses and so gained an understanding of visual theory that pointed to the cause and cure of near and far-sightedness. His extensive work in mathematics allowed him to bring a sophistication to optics beyond that of medieval times and bring a Euclidian clarity of structure to its presentation and demonstration. The <i>Photismi<i>||Editions appeared at Naples in 1611 and, with a slightly changed title, at Lyon in 1613.
BP_Description_2: Francesco Maurolyco's <i>Photismi de Lumine et Umbra<i> has three topics: Illumination, pin-hole images, and reflections in curved mirrors. The work begins with four definitions and 6 postulates. From these foundations on the rectilinear propagation of light, Maurolyco develops 35 theorems. Theorems 1-21 deal with illumination, shadows, and penumbral shadows. Theorems 22-24 deal with images from small apertures. Theorems 25-35 deal with reflection and curved mirrors. Though theorems 1-21 are geometrically analytic, they are not quantitative so it would be inaccurate to describe them as dealing with photometry. However, they do consider the basic aspects of illumination and the projection of shadows in a qualitative way. Images from small apertures is analyzed using facing pyramids, bases formed by object and image and each apex coincident at point over the aperture. With an analysis of the angles involved, Maurolyco explains how the shape of the image changes with the distance from the aperture. The material on mirrors is entirely traditional, covering convex and concave mirrors, image inversion and burning mirrors.||The <i>Diaphaneon<i> is in three books. Book 1: On refraction. Book 2: On the Rainbow. Book 3: On the Eye and Vision. Book 1 begins with four postulates and presents 24 theorems on refraction and refracted images. This includes images displaced by refraction a plane interfaces, an approximate law of refraction, and ray paths in glass spheres. Book 2 is an unsuccessful attempt to analyze the rainbow based on reflection with a single raindrop. Book 3 is on the structure of the eye and the use of lenses to correct vision. The ocular anatomy is from Vesalius and the rest is traditional perspectivist vision with the crystalline humor as the seat of vision. In this context, Maurolyco investigates the convergence and divergence of rays in concave and convex lenses and, appealing to the requirement for ray symmetry on either side of the crystalline (with its assumed symmetrical lenticular shape), assumes that divergent light entering the crystalline, produced symmetric convergence exiting the crystalline and onto the optic nerve. He then reasoned that if the crystalline were wrongly shaped far or near-sightedness could occur, which could be correct by spectacles.||The commentary and editing by Clavius is particularly important in the Photismi, with evidence of changes and cancels made during the press run. In his letter to the reader, the printer makes clear that Clavius' additions, comments, and corrections have been set in italics.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Optics in Sixteenth-century Italy|Lindberg, D.|In: <i>Proceedings; Novita Celesti e Crisi del Sapere, Atti del Convegno Inernzionale de Studi Galileiani<i>, Istituto e Museo de Storia della Scienze, Florence, 1983, pp 131-148.||Francesco Maurolico, Giambattista della Porta and Their Theories on Refraction|Bell√©, Riccardo|In: <i>The Optics of Giambattista della Porta(ca. 1535‚Äì1615): A Reassessment<i>|Borrelli, A., Hon, G., Zik, Y., editors|Springer, 2017, 205 pp, NB: pp 172-184.||I Gesuiti e la pubblicazione dell'ottica di Francesco Maurolico|Bell√®, R.|<i>Bollettino di storia delle scienze matematiche<i>, Vol 26, 2006, pp 211-243||Geometry of Light and Shadow: Francesco Maurolyco (1494-1575) and the Pinhole Camera|Hon, G. and Zik, Y.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 64, No 4, 2007, pp 549-578.||Ptolomey, Alhazen, and Kepler and the Problem of Optical Images|Smith, A.M.|<i>Arabic Sciences and Philosophy<i>, Vol. 8, 1998, pp 9-44.||ùëª<i>The Photismi de lumine of Maurolycus : A Chapter in Late Medieval Optics<i>|Crew, H. translator|MacMillian, New York, 1940.||Bibliographic Analysis: <i>Edizione Nazionale dell'Opera matematica di Francesco Maurolico<i>|http://maurolico.elabor.biz/Maurolico/index.html
BP_Title: Abbatis Francisci Maurolyci Messanensis. Photismi de lumine, & umbra ad perspectivam, & radiorum incidentiam facientes. Diaphanorum Partes, seu Libri tres: in quorum primo de per spicuis corporibus: in secudno de iride: in tertio de organi visualis structura, and conspiciliorum formis agitur. Problemata ad Perspectivam, & Iridem pertinentia. Omina nunc primum in lumen edita.
BP_Title English Translation: From Abbot Francesco Maurolyco of Messina. Light on light and shadow, having to do with Perspectiva and incident rays. The aspects of Transparency, or Three Books: in which the first on transparent bodies, the second on the rainbow, the third on the structure of the human eye & considering the forms of spectacles. Problems pertaining to optics and the rainbow. All now newly issued.
BP_Biographical Statement: Sicilian Benedictine monk, mathematician, astronmer, worked at Messina. The greatest mathematician of the 16th century, wrote knowingly and extensively in natural philosophy and edited works of classical authors.
BP_Provenance: Inscrition from the College of St. Ignatius, Society of Jesus on titlepage.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Extensively illustrated contemporary textbook of theoretical and practical optics, closely following and promoting Johannes Kepler's optical work. Focused on the applications and utility of optics.
BP_Description_1: Ambrosius Rhode's textbook of theoretical and practical optics has its origin in the dissertation he defended in 1608, <i>Exercitationes Opticae<i>, at the University of Wittenberg where he taught. He soon presented a course in optics and developed notes, building on his <i>Exercitationes<i>, that form the basis for his optics textbook. Rhode's dedicatory letter makes clear the high value and utility he places on optics and the need for a contemporary textbook that avoids the prolixity and involved detail of many primary works. He writes that knowledge of optics and vision guides perception, advances physics and astronomy, and aides the practical arts of painting, architecture, and surveying. The preface is a relatively detailed history of optics, beginning with the Greeks and ending with Kepler and his <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604. It also serves to list the sources Rhode used which included Riser's edition of Alhacen and Witelo of 1574. The core of textbook is a very extensively illustrated introduction to optics, closely following and promoting Johannes Kepler's optical work, but following the structure of Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>. It is clearly written by a skilled teacher with applications, problems, and detailed solutions with figures. Rhode's textbook is focused on the application and utility of optics; making no claims of innovation. It is was the cusp between perspectivist and Keplerian optics, and marked the beginning of new optical teaching in universities--containing, for example, the last direct reference to Ptolemy's optics until the late 18th century, but making no reference to the newly invented telescope.|The <i>Optica<i> is usually bound with Rhode's <i>Tractatus de Crepusculis<i> with a separate title page, as in the present copy.
BP_Description_2: The work has a dedicatory letter on the value and utility of optics, a preface that gives the history of optics and Rhode's sources, and three books. Book 1: On direct vision. Book 2: On Mirrors. Book 3: On Refraction. Book 1 begins with 22 definitions and 21 'petitions' visual perception then 13 chapters. Chapter 1 Visibility in General, Chapter 2 On Light, Chapter 3 On Shadow and Darkness, Chapter 4 On Color, Chapter 5 On Transparency, Chapter 6 Structure of the Eye, Chapter 7 Direct Vision, Chapter 8 Perception of Light and Color, Chapter 8 (sic) Perception of Size, Chapter 10 Perception of Shape, Chapter 11 Perception of Location, Chapter 12 Perception of Number, Chapter 12 (sic) Perception of Motion. The material in chapters 2, 3, 6 and 7 follow Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> very closely. The others adhere to Witelo. Book 2 begins with 15 definitions involving reflection followed by 8 chapters. Chapter 1 Reflected Vision, Chapter 2 Specular Materials, Chapter 3 True mirrors, Chapter 4 Illusions from Mirrors, Chapter 5 Plane and Spherical Mirrors, Chapter 6 Convex Mirrors, Chapter 7, Concave Mirrors, Chapter 8 Burning Mirrors. The material on images from  mirrors follows Kepler, the sharp distinction between Kepler's 'pictura' and 'imago' is not made. Book 3 begins with 12 definitions involving refraction followed by two chapters. Chapter 1 Refracted Vision, Chapter 2 Mixed Reflection and Refraction. The material on refraction is very brief.||The <i>Tractatus de Crepusculis<i> presents Rhode's summary of traditional material on twilight. As with the <i>Optica<i>, it begins with a history, reaching back to Strabo, Alhacen, and Witelo. As with its antecedents, it attempts to find the times and lengths of twilight, and the height of the Earth's atmosphere.

Jahrhundert, dargestellt unter besonderer Ber√ºcksichtigung des Wittenberger Mathematikers Ambrosius Rhodius (1577-1633)|Sch√∂neburg, S.|Dissertation, Martin-Luther-Universit√§t Halle-Wittenberg, 2007, 211 pp, NB pp 69-82.
BP_Title: Optica Ambrosii Rhodii, Kembergensis, Philosoophiae ac Medicine Doctoris, & Mathematicum Professorisi in Academia Leucoria. Cui additus est Tractatus. De Crepusculis.
BP_Title English Translation: Optics of Ambrose Rhode of Kemberg. Philosopher and Medicaal Doctor, and Mathematics Professor in University of Wittenberg. To which is added the Tract: Twilight.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, and physician. Worked with Tyco Brahe and Johannes Kepler. Taught for many years at the  University of Wittenberg.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Euclidis Elementorum

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A text for Jesuit schools, adhering to Aristotelian orthodoxy and covering: Light and vision, Colors, Binocular vision, Perception, Propagation of light, and Projections. Famously illustrated with etchings based on drawings by Rubens.
BP_Description_1: Francois d' Aguil√≥n was teaching at the Jesuit school in Antwerp when he wrote his <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i>. In his preface Aguil√≥n states that this is the first of three books on optics, intended to be followed by a second on catoptrics and a third on dioptrics. Only a few manuscript sections of a Catoptrica were produced. The <i>Opticorum<i> was written in 1609-1611 and the manuscript received the approval of the censor in December 1611. Widow Martina Moretus and her sons Balthazar and Jan issued it from the Plantin Press late in 1613. The growing number of Jesuit schools in Europe and the <i>Ratio Studiorum<i> of 1599 created a need for a text to support the teaching of optics. Aguil√≥n's book was an optics teaching manual for Jesuits. It covers only optics--that is, the nature of light, the eye, and vision by rays direct from an object. More than 50 authors are cited, the most frequent are Risner's edition of Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i>, Witelo's <i>Perspectiva<i>, and John Peckham‚Äôs Perspectiva Communis. Importantly, Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604 and Pierre de la Ram√©e's <i>Opticae Libri Quatuor<i> of 1606  were unknow to Aguil√≥n. Though he adds interesting material on binocular vision, Aguil√≥n adheres closely to Scholastic optical teaching and so his <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> never becomes more than a guide for teaching late medieval optics. Aguil√≥n was a mathematician and though it covers only optics, his book is filled with detailed mathematical proofs and justifications; helpful for the tyro, tedious and pedantic for the initiated.||But unlike many other early texts, the <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> is also filled with descriptions of apparatus and demonstrations displaying for the reader many of the phenomena Aguil√≥n describes. Some of these are shown in the vignettes at the beginning of each book.The <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> is famed for these as well as its frontispiece, all drawn by Pieter Paul Rubens and engraved by Theodoor Galle.  The drawing of the  frontispiece is held by the British Museum, two vignette drawings by Washington‚Äôs National Gallery, and a third in the drawings collection of Marquis de Lagoy. The frontispiece is solemn and heavily freighted with allegory, but the vignettes are much more lively. One is at the head of each of the six books, depicting a philosopher, assisted by putti, engaged in an activity described in the book--which Rubens must have studied in order to have produced his drawings with their detail.|Though the <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> was used in Jesuit schools after its publication, it was rapidly overtaken by Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i>, Christoph Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> of 1619, and Pierre de la Ram√©e's <i>Opticae Libri Quatuor<i>. Its awkward outdatedness is due in some measure to ahistorical hindsight, but not entirely; it puts into relief how rapidly optics was changing in the 17th century. However, its material on binocular vision and color theory continued to be referenced until the middle of the century.
BP_Description_2: Francois d' Aguil√≥n's work has six books. 1: The Organ, Object, and Nature of Vision. The ocular anatomy of Vesalius is presented with the crystalline humor being the seat of vision, receiving species of shape and color emitted by an object and entering the eye. Aguil√≥n adheres to the Aristotelian idea of potential transparency actualized by light, and once transparent it could conduct species from object to eye. In this regard, he maintains the distinction between lux and lumen; intrinsic and transmitted light. Light and color are presented as the proper objects of vision, and here Aguil√≥n introduces his modification of Aristotle's color theory and presents a color diagram showing color relationships. 2: On Optical Rays and the Horopter. The cone of vision consists of optical rays propagating rectilinearly and here Aguil√≥n deals with binocular vision and two cones of vision and, famously, describes the Horopter: places in the field of vision where an object is seen singly, though viewed by both eyes. He considered the Horopter to be a plane passing through the binocular fixation point and perpendicular to the combined line-of-sight. 3: Common Objects of Cognition. Covers aspects of perception that had long been part of Perspectiva: Distance, quantity, shape, location, situation, continuity and discreteness, motion, and the conditions of such perceptions. 4: On the Fallacies of Vision. Based on the idea of the horopter, the perceptual mistakes that can be made are considered for: distance, size, situation, shapes (circle, squares, spheres, cylinders, and cones), location, number, motion, and light and shadow. 5: On Light and Dark. The first part deals with the nature of light; it's propagation and diminution as it does so. Aguil√≥n applies the Aristotelian idea of a 'minium naturale' to light. After being divided or extended beyond its 'minimum naturale', light intensity is extinguished. An experiment is presented to determine how light's power diminishes with propagation distance; the first recorded photometric experiment. This book also treats illumination and shadows, ending with a section on a pre-Keplarian consideration of the camera obscura. 6: On Projections. This book, the longest by far, encompasses nearly one-third of the entire work. It presents an elaborate, geometric consideration of projection, with particular emphasis on utility for architects, sculptors, scenographers, and painters.||The material in all six books has a Euclidian form, with definitions, propositions, proofs and conclusions. It is elaborately supported and demonstrated with geometry.
BP_Reference(s): The Publication of the Opticorum Libri Sex|Ziggelaar, A.|<i>Strabismus<i>, Vol 20, No 1, 2012, pp 37-41||The Contents of the Opticorum Libri Sex|Ziggelaar, A.|<i>Strabismus<i>, Vol 20, No 2, 2012, pp 84-104||The Impact of the Opticorum Libri Sex|Ziggelaar, A.|<i>Strabismus<i>, Vol 20, No 3, 2012, pp 133-138||<i>The Quest for Perfect Vision<i>|Gallay, A.|Dissertation|University of Cambridge, 2013.||<i>Die Illustrationen von Peter Paul Rubens zum Lehrbuch der Optik des Franciscus Aguilonius/1613<i>|Jaeger, W.|Brausdruck GmbH, 1976, 58 p.||Rubens and Optics: Some Fresh Evidence|Jaff√©, Michael|<i>Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes<i>, Vol 34, 1971, pp 362-366.
BP_Title: Opticorum Libri Sex Philosophis iuxta ac Mathematicis utiles.
BP_Title English Translation: Six Books of Optics, Useful for Philosophers and Mathematicians as well.
BP_Biographical Statement: Belgian Jesuit mathematician, natural philosopher, and archittect. Founded an important Jesuit school in Antwerp. An Aristotelian in most matters but an orgininator in vision studies.
BP_Engraver: Galle, Theodoor (after drawings by Peter Paul Rubens)
BP_BibliographicNotes: Errata on Ppp‚ÇÉÕ¨

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Chrosopher Clavius (1538-1612) German Jesuit teacher at the Collegio Romano, author of important texts in mathematics and astronomy.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the spartan march of propositions and proofs coving general optics, with commentary and editing by Clavius. Contains the earliest correct explanation of the operation of the pin-hole camera.

The errata page and dedication letter of the 1611 printing is omitted, and the Lyons printer adds his own letter to the reader to that of the 1611 printing. The text of this printing is that of 1611 and its cancels. The figures had been recut and are larger and clearer than those of 1611.||Francesco Maurolyco finished his <i>Photismi de Lumine et Umbra<i> in October of 1521 and the first two books of his Diaphaneon in January of 1522. BP_Title: Theoremata de lumine et umbra, ad perspectivam, & radiorum incidentiam facientia.
BP_Title English Translation: Theorems on light and shadow, to do with Perspectiva and incident rays.
BP_Biographical Statement: Sicilian Benedictine monk, mathematician, astronmer, worked at Messina. The greatest mathematician of the 16th century, wrote knowingly and extensively in natural philosophy and edited works of classical authors.
BP_Provenance: Blind stamp of the Macclesfield Library on first three leaves.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Johannes Combach (1585 - 1651) German professor of physics, librarian, theologian.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Combach's editing of the widely influential medieval optics text, covering light and vision, perception, and reflection and refraction.
BP_Description_1: Johann Combach's editing of the widely influential medieval <i>Perspectiva<i> of Roger Bacon is one of several texts written or edited by Combach covering a broad range of subjects taught in the Scholastic tradition in northern European universities in the 17th century. In his dedicatory letter to Count Adolph of Bentheim-Tecklenburg-Rheda, Combach states that he worked from an Oxford manuscript of Bacon's <i>Perspectiva<i> (that cannot now be identified) and that he produced this work to make libraries complete; of all the important traditional works in optics, only Bacon's had not been printed. Though it was never as widely used at John Peckham‚Äôs Perspectiva Communis, there are 40 extant manuscripts of Bacon's Perspectiva, ranging in date from the late 13th to the early 16th centuries. If nothing else, it was widely known. A late manuscript and Combach's printing of the <i>Perspectiva<i> were shelved side-by-side in Samuel Pepys' library.|The <i>Perspectiva<i> was part of Bacon's on-going work in optics written between 1240 and when he sent it and other manuscripts to Pope Clement IV at his court in Viterbo in 1267. It became part of the <i>Opus Maius<i>. His sources were Euclid's <i>Optica<i>, Grosseteste's <i>De Luce<i>, Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i>, and the Aristotelian tradition in optics. The three parts of the <i>Perspectiva<i> present Bacon's theory of vision, a perspectival account of several aspects of direct vision and perception, and finally vision by reflected and refracted rays. These last sections make use of--and shows Bacon's facility with--geometrical principles and demonstration.|Bacon's <i>Perspectiva<i> had an important influence on Witelo's recension of Alhacen's <i>De Aspectibus<i> and on John Peckham‚Äôs <i>Perspectiva Communis<i> in medieval times, but it's editing and printing in early modern times when Scholasticism had nearly faded away, was clearly and simply a humanists' self-imposed historical and scholarly task.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Perspectiva<i> is in three parts. Part 1: Eye, Brain, and Vision. Species are replicants of light and color, emitted by an object, and propagated through a transparent medium by multiplying (reproducing) them selves. Species enter the eye and are communicated to the brain where they bring about cognition. The optics of the eye works to receive the species and get them to the crystalline humor (lens) which is the seat of vision. It accepts only rays (specified paths) that are perpendicular to it's surface. Species are then  guided to the optic nerve which takes them to the brain.  Eight conditions are required for vision, including species, light, suitable distance to viewed object, sufficient size, object density, transparent medium, sufficient time, and healthy eye. Part 2: Perception, Conditions and Modes of seeing. Bacon presents three modes of knowing: by sense alone, by previous knowledge, and by reason. Various phenomena in vision are considered as relationships between these ways of knowing and the eight requirements for vision. These include near-sightedness, far-sightedness, double vision, visual judgements, and the moon illusion. Part 3: Reflected and Refracted Vision. Euclidian catoptrics and dioptrics provide the framework, with the metaphysics of species providing the reason for the way reflection and refraction behave as they do.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>Roger Bacon and the Origins of 'Perspectiva' in the Middle Ages: A Critical Edition and English Translation of Bacon's 'Perspectiva' with Introduction and Notes<i>|Lindberg, D.C.|Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1996, 411 pp.||<i>Geometry and Space: The Celebrated Collection of Books on Geometry, Optics, and Perspective of M. Arnaud De Vitry<i>|Description, Lot 40|Sotheby's, Sale Catalogue, 2002, 430 pp.
BP_Title: Perspectiva. In qua, quae ab aliis fuse traduntur, succincte, nervose & ita pertractantur, ut omnium intellectui facile pateant. Nunc primum in lucem edita. Opera & studio Johannis Compachii, Philosoophiae Professoris in Academia Marpurgensi ordinarii.
BP_Title English Translation: Perspectiva. In which those things, given by others at length, are investigated so succinctly and vigorously, that all are open to easy understanding. Now first brought to light by the work and study of Johann Combach, professor in ordindary of philosophy at the University of Marburg.
BP_Biographical Statement: English¬†Franciscan, lecturer at Oxford and University of Paris. Interested in emperical natural philosophy and prompted by the pope, he wrote extensively on mathematics, optics, alchemy, and cosmology. [German academic, librarian. Educated at Oxford, librarian at the University of Marburg]
BP_BibliographicNotes: Insets [4] (8 Woodcut digrams) opp. u‚Å¥

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Johannes Combach (1585 - 1651) German professor, librarian, theologian.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Combach's editing of the medieval text presenting a 'physics of light' that is a radiative process that propagates visual effects by the multiplication of luminous objects' likenesses.
BP_Description_1: Johann Combach's editing of the medieval <i>De Multiplicatione Specierum<i> of Roger Bacon is one of several texts written or edited by Combach covering a broad range of subjects taught in the Scholastic tradition in northern European universities in the 17th century. 'Species' were held to be simulacra given off by objects, and their propagation by multiplying themselves through media was the principal explanation for radiation and action-at-distance. Examples were the radiant effects of the sun's heat and light, or the visual perception of a distant object. In his dedicatory letter, Combach summarizes the development of the concept of species and names the philosophers since Aristotle who found it not only a satisfactory explanation for emanating power in general and light in particular, but also truth in its alignment with the nature, power, and work of God.||<i>The De Multiplicatione Specierum<i> was part of Bacon's on-going work in optics written between 1240 and when he sent it and other manuscripts to Pope Clement IV at his court in Viterbo in 1267. It became part of the <i>Opus Maius<i>. Aristotelian teaching and Robert Grosseteste's light metaphysics are Bacon's sources. After defining species and their properties, Bacon considers objects that produce them, how they are produced, how they multiply through a medium, and finally how they are received, weakened, or corrupted. Bacon's adds a detailed mathematically analysis--that is, a geometric analysis--to the propagation of species which had been left vague in the past. The editing and printing of <i>De Multiplicatione Specierum<i> in early modern times when Scholasticism had nearly faded away, was clearly and simply a humanists' self-imposed historical and scholarly task.
BP_Description_2: Bacon's <i>De Multiplicatione Specierum<i> has six parts. Part 1: Definition of species, their properties, their nature, and their modes of action.  Part 2: Description of how species multiply through a medium. Propagation of visual species along direct line, along a reflected line, and along a refracted line are considered. The behavior of reflection and refraction is ascribed to the density of media. Euclidian geometrical optics is used here to describe the behavior of mirrors. Also considered are the consequences of species having the shape of the emitting object, including spheres, cylinders, and cones. Part 3: The corporeal nature of species has they exist in a medium. This includes the mixing of species in a medium and the generation of color. Part 4: The weakening of species and the relationship to the density or resistance of the medium. Included is a consideration of the time it take species to propagate. Part 5: the degrees of action of species. This is a consideration of the directionality of both emission and incidence and its effect on the power of species, with the perpendicular direction being the strongest and most efficacious. Part 6: The corruption of species. This includes considerations of propagation distance, their continual renewal, and their effect on other species.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>Roger Bacon's Philosophy of Nature: A Critical Edition, with English Translation, Introduction, and Notes, of De multiplicatione specierum and De speculis comburnetibus<i>|Lindberg, D.C.|St. Augustine's Press, South Bend, 1998, 420 pp.||Vision and Certitude in the Age of Ockham|Tachau, K.|Brill, 1988, 428 pp, NB: pp 3-27.
BP_Title: Specula mathematica: in qua, de specierum multiplicatione, earundemque in inferioribus virtute agitur.
BP_Title English Translation: The Mathematical Mirror: In which the multiplication of species, and the lesser power of the same, is dealt with.
BP_Biographical Statement: English¬†Franciscan, lecturer at Oxford and University of Paris. Interested in emperical natural philosophy and prompted by the pope, he wrote extensively on mathematics, optics, alchemy, and cosmology. [German academic, librarian. Educated at Oxford, librarian at the University of Marburg]

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Small work on the elliptical appearance of the sun near the horizon and the atmospheric refraction that causes it.
BP_Description_1: The origin of Christoph Scheiner's <i>Refractiones Coelestes<i> is a small pamphlet <i>Sol Elliptic<i> he published in 1615. He had built a helioscope to project images of the sun and late in 1612 he observed sun spots and the flattening of the circular solar image to an ellipse as it approached the horizon. His <i>Sol Elliptic<i> reports both these discoveries, the flattening being attributed to atmospheric refraction. Two years later and after many more observations of the sun, Scheiner published <i>Refractiones Coelestes<i>. He correctly reasoned that the atmospheric density decreases with elevation and so if light is incident obliquely, it travels in a path of increased curvature as it reached an observer. The closer to the horizon, the more oblique, and so the more curved is the path. Tables of values are given showing the degree of vertical compression for different heights of the sun above the horizon.|Scheiner's instrument and observations were studied and cited by many practical, observational astronomers, including William Gascogne, William Oughtred, and John Flamsteed.
BP_Description_2: Scheiner begins with a review of the nature of the atmosphere and its changing density with altitude. This is followed by a theoretical consideration of the altered path of light that enters the atmosphere obliquely, from near the horizon, and the consequences of its curved path. Points closer to the horizon have a more altered path and appear higher above the horizon. That is, the sun appears flattened because rays from its lower edge are refracted more, and so appeared higher above the horizon (more elevated than the actual lower edge of the sun) than rays from its upper edge. This is followed with considerations of mists and clouds and how they affect observations. Scheiner then describes the instrument used to produced the solar images he examined; essentially a telescope used to project a solar image on a screen. Importantly, such instruments were of Scheiner's own construction. As is characteristic of all of Scheiner's writing, the material is tedious in its detail and repetition. An extensive index is provided at the end.
BP_Reference(s): The Optical World of William Gascoigne|Sellers, D.|In: <i>In Search of William Gascoigne<i>, Springer, 2012, pp 69-82.||<i>Christoph Scheiners 'Sol ellipticus'<i>|Daxacker, F.|Ver√∂ffentlichungen der Universit√§t Innsbruck, Vol 226, 1998.
BP_Title: Refractiones coelestes, sive solis elliptici phaenomenon illustratum; in quo variae atque antiquae astronomorum circa hanc materiam difficultates enodantur, dubia multiplicia dissoluuntur, via ad multa recondita eruenda sternitur. Opusculum tam Astronomis quam Physicis per quam utile, perque necesssarium. Auctore, Christophor Scheiner, Soceit. Iesu Presbytero.
BP_Title English Translation: Celestial Refraction, or The Phenomenon of the Elliptical Sun Made Clear; in which the Difficulties of what Various Ancient Astronomers have to say on this Matter are untangled, numerous doubts resolved, and the road is set out to uproot many hidden things. A small work extremely useful and necessary to Physical Astronomers. Authored by Chrisoph Scheiner, priest of the Society of Jesus.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, astronomer, mathematician, early ocular physiologist. Talented, tetchy, and a prolific author.
BP_Binding: Old 1/4 Green Morocco Over Marbled Boards

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An early 17th century Aristotelian consideration of vision, the eye, and the nature of light.
BP_Description_1: This is a textbook in the Scholastic style of the process of vision, including a consideration of the structure and function of the eye, the nature of light, and how vision leads to perception. Timpler attempts to bring optics--that is, vision--under his general philosophical umbrella, much as he did with his general physics textbook. That a separate work is devoted to optics, indicates its continuing importance in philosophical and educational systems. In his Dedicatory Letter, Timpler  mentions he has used four optical authors extensively: Alhacen, Vitellus, Risner, and Della Porta. This works are: the <i>Peri Optices<i> and <i>Perspectiva<i> of Alhacen and Witelo that appeared in the <i>Opticae Thesaurus<i> of 1574, edited by Friedrich Risner, Risner's own <i>Opticae libri quatuor<i> of 1606, and Giovanni Battista Della Porta's <i>De Refractione<i> if 1593.||The material is presented in the form of main theorems that begin each chapter. These are followed by problems in which the aspects of the theorem are disputed and proved. Though Timpler cites work that are rich in mathematics, only the more philosophical aspects are considered here.
BP_Description_2: Timpler's optical work is in two books. Book one has 8 chapters: 1 The Nature of Optics, 2 Vision in General, 3 The Visible, 4 On Shadows, 5 The Medium of Seeing, 6 On the Visual Ray, 7 Inside the Visual Organ, 8 The Conditions of Efficient Vision. Book two has 5 chapters: 1 Simple Vision, 2 Reflected Vision, 3 Refracted Vision, 4 True Vision, 5 False or Mistaken Vision and its Causes.||Timpler defines Optics as the study of the process by which vision occurs.  The is emitted by visible objects and this emission Timpler calls brightness. Brightness is comprised of visual rays or species of visible objects and moves through transparent media. These enter the eye, are 'gathered' by the aqueous humor, fall on the crystalline lens and are carried away by an 'animal spirit'--a kind of visual pneuma--that conducts the species to they brain via the hollow optic nerve. In the brain, the visual rays or species generate sight; that is, perception. The second book considers variations of this basic visual process, depending on whether the line of sight is direct, reflected, or refracted. Book two ends with a consideration of misjudgments of vision and optical illusions and their causes.||The material is entirely Aristotelian and descriptive; no mathematics of any kind is used.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Life, Significance, and Philosophy of Clemens Timpler, 1563/4-1624|Freedman, J.S.|Dissertation, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1982, 916 pp, NB: pp 740-752.
BP_Title: Optic√¶ systema methodicum per theoremata et problemata selecta concinnatum et duobus libris comprehensum. Cui subjecta est Physiognomia humana, itidem duobus libris breviter et perspicue pertractata.
BP_Title English Translation: A Methodic System of Optics Constructed by theorems and select problems, and encompassed in two books. To which is Added Human Physiognomy, Similalry briefly and clearly provided in two books.
BP_Biographical Statement: German phiosopher and physicist
BP_BibliographicNotes: Title page and index for Physiognomiae Humanae is in ‚Ä†‚Å¥

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First edition of a seminal work on physiological optics, showing: correct position of the lens, cornea curvature, nasal exit of the optic nerve, lens change in accommodation, light reaction of the pupil and narrowing in accommodation, double images in near and far-sightedness, refractive indices of the various parts of the eye, beam-crossing in the camera obscura, and a functioning model of the eye.
BP_Description_1: First edition of a seminal work on what is now called physiological optics. Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> has its origins in his work in optics and observational astronomy. He had studied, made, and used lenses in telescopes and in his projector for examining sun spots. By 1619 he had extensive experience with instruments and experiments, and his preface for Oculus makes clear his notion that knowledge is advanced by both mathematics or physics and by experiment. Scheiner is an adherent to Scholastic teachings and so is at pains to show how Aristotelian physics and modern optics are compatible; carefully fitting his experimental results into the Scholastic schema. Including, in the case of the present work, dissection of the eye. He also makes is clear that his treatise is not on the whole of optics 'which is infinite, but only the narrow consideration of the eye itself and of how vision occurs. The Oculus set out the best information available on the eye and the mechanisms of vision, corrected several aspects of ocular anatomy, and included data, experiments, and tests conducted by Scheiner himself. It gave the correct position of the lens, cornea curvature, nasal exit of the optic nerve, lens change in accommodation, light reaction of the pupil and narrowing in accommodation, double images in near and far-sightedness, refractive indices of the various parts of the eye, beam-crossing in the camera obscura and in the eye, and described a functioning model of the eye.||<i>Oculus<i> appeared at Innsbruck in 1619, at Freiberg in 1621, and was closely reprinted at London 1652.
BP_Description_2: Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> is in three books. Book 1 is in two parts: the first on ocular anatomy, the second on the function of various parts of the eye. Book 2 is in two parts: the first on refraction and the refractive power and function of parts of the eye, the second gives an analysis of rays refracted through parts of the eye. Book 3 is on the retina and is in two parts: the first on the optical components of the eye and the forming an image on the retina, the second considers various questions regarding vision and eye function.||A seminal work on physiological optics, showing: correct position of the lens, cornea curvature, nasal exit of the optic nerve, lens change in accommodation, light reaction of the pupil and narrowing in accommodation, double images in near and far-sightedness, refractive indices of the various parts of the eye, beam-crossing in the camera obscura, and a functioning model of the eye.
BP_Reference(s): Christoph Scheiner's eye studies|Daxecker, F.|<i>Documenta Ophthalmologica<i>, Vol 81, No 1, 1992, pp 27-35.||Further studies by Christoph Scheiner concerning the optics of the eye|Daxecker, F.|<i>Documenta Ophthalmologica<i>, Vol 86, No 2, 1995, pp 153-161.||Jesuit mathematical science and the reconstitution of experience in the early seventeenth century|Dear, P.|<i>Studies in History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 18, No 2, 1987, pp 133-175.||<i>The Physicist and Astronomer Christopher Scheiner: Biography, Letters, Works<i>|Daxecker, F.|University of Innsbruck Press, 2004.||The Anatomay of the Eye in the Seventeenth Century|d'A. Maycock, W.|<i>Journal of the Canadian Medical Association<i>, Vol 26, No 1, 1932, pp 83-88.
BP_Title: Oculus; Hoc est Fundamentum Opticum: in quo ex Accurata Oculi Anatome, Abstrusarum Experientiarum Sedula pervestigatione, ex invIsis specierum visibilium tam everso quam erecto situ spectaculis, nec non solidis rationum momentis. Radius Visualis Eruitur; sua Visioni in oculo Sedes Decernitur; Anguli Visorii Ingenium Aperitur. Difficultates veteres, novae innumerae expediuntur; adstrusa, obscura, curiosa plurima in medium proferuntur; plura depromendi occasio harum rerum studiosis datur: Opus multorum votis diu expetitum; Philosophis omnibus, praesertim qui naturae vim in Medicina, Physica aut Mathesi addiscenda rimantur, neque inutile neque ingratum, imo necessarium futurum.
BP_Title English Translation: The Eye. That is, the Foundation of Optics. In which Ocular Anatomy is Given Attention, Abstruse Experiments are Assiduously Investigated,  from which is Observed the Appearance of Visible Objects Inverted,  but Seen Upright, by the firm effort of reasoning. The Visual Ray Elicited, its Place in Vision in the Eye Decided, The Nature of Visual Angles Revealed. Innumerable old and new Difficulties are explained; Many Common Curious, Abstruse, Obscure things are Revealed; Students are Given the Opportunity of Drawing out Much. The Work was long Sought after many Prayers. For all Philosophers, Especially those who by Nature Search for Required Additional Learning in  the Power in Medicine, Physics, and Mathematics. Neither Useless nor Unpleasant; indeed it will be Necessary.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, astronomer, mathematician, early ocular physiologist. Talented, tetchy, and a prolific author.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Thomas Vroom on pastedown
BP_BibliographicNotes: Frontispiece on ‚àó‚ÇÉ. Woodcut diagrams throughout.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean Jacques Boyssier
BP_Short or Common Title: Les Apparences et Admirables Effects du Miroir Concave Spherique
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: French translation of Magini's important work on spherical burning mirrors
BP_Description_1: French translation of Giovanni Antonio Magini‚Äôs work on spherical burning mirrors. Magini's interest was practical and craft-based, as well as theoretical.  He presented large concave spherical mirrors to Jacopo Boncompagni (son of Pope Gregory XIII and Prince of Sora), to Cardinal Alessandro Farnese (son Pier Luigi Farnese, Duke of Parma), and to the Holy Roman Emperor Rudolf II, and  the Duke of Mantua. Spherical mirrors were of keen interest to Galileo as well. Indeed, Maginis' text was written at Galileo‚Äôs request in order to facilitate the Grand Duke‚Äôs purchase of Magini‚Äôs curved mirrors through the mediation of Galileo.||Ettore Ausonio had produced a widely circulated manuscript <i>Theorica Speculi Concavi Sphaerici<i> in which concave spherical mirrors were analyzed. Particular attention given to focusing properties. Magini saw this through the press, appearing at Bologna in 1602. It was this work that Magini had decided to edit and then completely revise and publish as his 'Brief Instructions' which appeared in 1611. In addition to this French translation that appeared in 1620, the Italian text was published again at Bologna in 1628.
BP_Description_2: Magini brief text begins with methods for describing concave spherical mirrors and the effects that they can produced using the sun. Using laws of reflection, two 'fundamental principles' are presented that can be used to understand the operation of all mirrors and the determination of a focal point or the 'point of inversion.' Different image sizes and placements are described, based on position of object and viewing point, including number, magnification, and minification.  Application of a spherical mirror in the camera obscura is also described. The material is descriptive, with only geometry invoked in the demonstrations. Twelve woodblock images appear in the text. Mirror theory with its analysis of focal points and images, was an essential part of the development of the telescope.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Galileo, the Telescope, and the Science of Optics in the Sixteenth Century: A Case Study of Instrumental Practice in Art and Science<i>|Dupr√©, S.|University of Gent, Dissertation, 2002, 366 pp, NB: pp 143-163.||<i>Galileo Engineer<i>|Valleriani M.|Springer, Boston Studies in the Philosophy of Science, 2010, 320 pp, NB: pp 60-66.
BP_Title: Briefve Instruction, sur Les Apparences et Admirables Effects du Miroir Concave Spherique. Composee en Italien par Iean Anthonie Maginus, Professeur √©s Mathematiques √† Bolongne: Et traduite en Fran√ßois per Iean Iacques Boyssier Proven√ßal, Professeur √©s Mathematiques √† Paris.
BP_Title English Translation: Brief Instruction on the Appearances and Admirable Effects of the Concave Spherical Mirror. Composed in Italian by Giovanni Antonio Magini, Professor of Mathematics at Bologna, and Translated into French by Jean Jacques Boyssier, Provincal Professor of Mathematics at Paris.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian mathematician and physicist, professor at the University of Bologna, astronomer and mirror maker.
BP_Provenance: NOAM' written on the title page along with '(1)' for page number

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of experiments, problems, and parlor tricks in cosmology, optics, perspective, mechanics, statics, practical geometry, fortification and gunnery. Designed to entertain and instruct. The camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow are presented in a rudimentary way.
BP_Description_1: Third edition of the text that first appeared in 1624. Ninety-one 'problems' are presented, some of several parts, with solutions constituting a collection of experiments, apparatus demonstrations, recipes, and parlor tricks in cosmology, optics, perspective, mechanics, statics, practical geometry, fortification and gunnery. Designed to entertain and instruct. The source for the arithmetical problems was Claude Bachet's <i>Problems Plaisans et Delectables<i> of 1612. The problems in geometry are in the Renaissance tradition of 'practical geometry'; geometry applied to surveying, mensuration, and fortification. Many of the other problems come from the tradition of secretes and natural magic, such as Girolamo Ruscelli's <i>De' Secretis del Alessio Piemontese<i> in the edition of 1615. Some of the problems in natural philosophy appear to be from works by Giambattista Della Porta, Girolamo Cardano, and Salomon de Caus. Renaissance books on conjuring and prestidigitation were a source for the <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>.||Tradition has assigned authorship to the Jesuit Jean Leurechon, though there is little scholarly evidence for this. Whoever assembled this collection of problems and secrets produced a book that was tremendously popular, being in print in various forms for more than 150 years. Thirty editions in French appeared between 1624 and 1680. Denis Henrion and Claude Mydorge were contributors and commentators for editions between 1626 and 1639, adding significant value to the book. Jacques Ozanam began editing editions in 1694, adding material and changing the content to be more like an encyclopedia. Jean-Etienne Montucla and Edm√© Gilles Guyot were subsequent editors and by 1769 there were four volumes. Translations appeared in English, Latin, Dutch, and German. This edition is the first to abandon the etched plates of figures used in the editions of 1624 and 1626, substituting woodcut illustrations placed in the text.
BP_Description_2: This and other early editions R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques have a dedicatory letter signed by H. Van Etten and a preface to the reader from the author which names some of his sources and the general nature of what he tried to accomplish. This is followed by a table on contents titles 'Collection of the Principal Mathematical Recreations Contained in the Booklet According to Problem Numbers'. The sections listed are: Arithmetic, Geometry, Optics and Perspective, Music, Cosmographical Matters. There follows 91 'Problems' in these various subjects. The camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow are presented in a rudimentary way. In this and other early editions, the optical material is limited to display and demonstration, with little or no explanation of the phenomena itself. Nevertheless, they give witness to the abiding interest in everyday optical phenomena.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.||Sources in Recreational Mathematics: an Annotated Bibliography|Singmaster, D.|online at http://www.puzzlemuseum.com/singma/singma-index.htm
BP_Title: Recreation mathematique composee de plusieures problemes plaisants et facetieux. En faict d'Arithmetique, Geometrie, Mechanqiue, Optique, Catoptrique, & autres parties de cette belle science. Augment√©e en cette Edition de plusieurs Problems non encore veus. Ensemble les Figures adioust√©es au comencement de chacune Proposition, ce qui n'a point encore est√© fait aux precedentes Impressions.
BP_Title English Translation: Mathematical Recreation, Composed of Several Pleasant and Humerous Problems. Indeed, of Arithmetic, Geometry, Mechanics, Optics, Catoptrics, and Other Parts of this Beautiful Science. This edition augmented with several problems not yet seen. Together with figures added to the makeup of each proposition, something not done in preceeding editions.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, mathematician, and professor.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1627 Leurechon - R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Two books on the nature, properties, and generation of conic sections, presented as a necessary preliminary to and geometric basis of reflective and refractive optics.
BP_Description_1: Claude Mydorge's two books on the nature, properties, and generation of conic sections, were presented as a necessary preliminary to and geometric basis of reflective and refractive optics. Mydorge's <i>Prodromi<i> originates in the 1620s when he worked on lenses and refraction theory with Marin Mersenne, who knew Mydorge's manuscript and mentions it a letter of 1623. By 1627 Mydorge, Ren√© Descartes, and lens maker Jean Ferrier had studied the anaclastic lens of hyperbolic figure and managed to make one. By the time of the Prodromi, Mydorge had intimate knowledge of the optical properties of curves and surfaces and had developed descriptions based not on their figure as produced by sectioning a cone, but rather on their focal properties. He was equally interested in and inventive of ways in which to actually produces these curves. Both aspects would define the <i>Prodromi<i>. Mydorge source for Apollonius was the Latin paraphrase produced by Jacobus Golius from an Arabic manuscript he had collected in the Levant.|The <i>Prodromi<i> would have a considerable effect on Ren√© Descartes and Frans van Shooten. Two more books would be added, and the quartet published in an edition of 1639, followed by reprints in 1640, 1641, 1644, and 1660.
BP_Description_2: Claude Mydorge begins with 'Monitum ad Conicorum Opus', a summary of Apolloinius' work and what use Mydorge made of it. Book 1 is titled: On the Elements of Conics, or the Origin, Generation, and Nature Proper to Each Conic Section. The first book covers classical conic sections but adds many problems and their solution new with Mydorge; particularly for elliptical, parabolic, and hyperbolic curves. Book 2 is titled: Description of the Geometry of Linear Conics in a Plane through a Point. The second book deals with practical methods of generating parabolic and hyperbolic curves. These methods are set in the context of constructing curves and surfaces to be used in optics.||The material in the first book is Euclidian in form; definitions, propositions, proofs, and conclusions. Given its practical purpose, the material in the second book is much more geometric and demonstrative. Mydorge sets out the traditional theory of conic sections as described by Apollonius of Perga in the second century BC, using sections of a right circular cone. Mydorge's first important advance is to define these curves optically; that is, in terms of their foci and what would now be called the directrix, rather than as sections of a cone as Apollonius did. Mydorge then showed how to generate an elliptic, parabolic, or hyperbolic curves of a given size, or with given foci. All these method lent themselves to drawing methods with practical tools that could generate the desired curve.
BP_Reference(s): The Development of Mersenne‚Äôs Optics|Cozzoli, D.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 2010, pp 9-25.||Constructive thinking: a case for dioptrics|Dijksterhuis, F.J.|In: <i>The Mindful Hand: Inquiry and Invention from the late Renaissance to Early Industrialization<i>|Koninkliijke, Amsterdam, 2007, 468 pp, NB: pp 59-82.
BP_Title: Prodromi Catoptricorum et Dioptricorum  sive: Conicorum Operis ad Abdita Radii Refleci et Refracti mysteria praeuii & praeferentis. Libri Primus et Secundus. D.A.L.G
BP_Title English Translation: Forerunners of Catoptics and Dioptrics: or Leading the Way and Carrying a Torch to the Hidden Mysteries of Rays Reflected and Refracted with the Aid of a Cone. The First and Second Books.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician and confidant of Ren√© Descartes and Marin Mersenne. His sinecure in the government allowed time for his extensive work in mathamtics, optics, and optical instruments.
BP_Provenance: Dedication copy signed by Mydorge on the title page
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1631 Mydorge - Prodromi Catoptricorum et Dioptricorum - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A very early printed ophthalmology, presenting the structure, function, problems, and 'curiosities' (phosphenes) of the eye. Earliest clear presentation and promotion of Kepler's work on vision.
BP_Description_1: Vopiscus Fortunatus Plemp wrote his <i>Ophthalmographia<i> at the end of his 10-year professional career in Amsterdam. Two years earlier he had published a brief anatomical tract in Dutch describing muscles in the human body for students of surgery. By the time he began writing the <i>Ophthalmographia<i>, Plemp had studied Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604 as well as his Dioptrice of 1611, Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> of 1619, had complete knowledge of Scholastic teaching regarding the eye and vision, and had begun translating Avicenna's Canon of Medicine from Arabic to Latin. Plemp's books is a very early printed ophthalmology, presenting the structure, function, problems, and 'curiosities' (phosphenes) of the eye.|In his preface to the reader, Plemp describes the need for a text on the eye, citing the advances that had been made in ocular anatomy and the clarification that Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> brought to the understanding of eye-function, fulling embracing the notion of eye as camera obscura, but at the same time shying away from the elaborate mathematics of geometrical optics. However reserved, it is the earliest presentation, promotion, and defense of Kepler's work on the ocular optics. Editions appeared at Amsterdam in 1632, and at Louvain in 1648 and 1659.
BP_Description_2: Plemp's <i>Ophthalmographia<i> is in five books. Book 1: Description of the External and Internal Eye. Plemp covers the anatomy and structure of the eye, correcting the errors of Galen--chastising him for dissecting only animal eyes--and correctly identifying the six muscles of the eye. Book 2: The Action of the Eye Revealed. This covers  the Aristotelian teaching of light, vision, and perception. The distinction between lux and lumen is maintained, as well as 'visual species' traveling through a potentially transparent medium actualized to transparency by light. Color is produced by the mixing of light and dark, being either real or apparent. Various aspects of vision are discussed, including the conditions necessary for vision to take place. But, it is here that Plemp invokes Kepler's notion of the eye as camera obscura, going to the extent of describing how the reader can construct a camera obscura, including fitting the aperture with a lens, and observing the images it creates. The analogy with the eye is cemented by the direct comparison Plemp makes between parts of the camera obscura and part of the eye. Finally, he describes the partial dissection of an ox eye to fully demonstrate image formation. Book 3: The Function of the Individual Parts. The function of and effect on vision of each part of the eye. Book 4: Problems of the Eye and Vision. Sixty-seven Problems are presented, covering: diseases of the eye and other problems that can affect vision including, double vision, blurred vision, vision from only one eye, methods of maintaining vision, vision in the elderly, vision in the dark, vision in mirrors, illusions and ways in which vision is deceived. Book 5: Effects on the Eye. This is devoted to phosphenes and states that they are produced by mechanical stress within the eye when it is deformed, initiating a chemical response in the 'visual fluid' that flows to the brain.||Though Plemp accepted Kepler's basic notion of lensed image falling on the retina and that the retina was the seat of vision, he did not fully embrace Kepler's geometrical optics. And though he had studied Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611, he did not include any of its results in his description of the function of the eye, not wanting to introduce the 'teaching of the mathematicians' into medicine. Plemp was an Aristotelian and still wrote of 'visible species', emitted or cast from an object, traveling through a medium, and entering the eye, suffering reflection or refraction by mirror or lens along the way.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Vopiscus Fortunatus Plempius|Tricot, J.P.|<i>Vesalius, Journal of the International Society for the History of Medicine<i>, Vol 6, No 1, 2000, pp 11-19.||Early Modern Medical Thinking on Vision and the Camera Obscura. V.F. Plempius‚Äô Ophthalmographia|Vanagt, K.|In: <i>Blood, Sweat and Tears: The Changing Concepts of Physiology from Antiquity into Early Modern Europe<i>, Horstmanshoff, M., King, H., Zittel, C., editors|Brill, 2012, 772 pp, NB: pp 569-593.
BP_Title: Ophthalmographia, sive Tractatio de oculi fabrica, actione, & usu praeter vulgatas hactenus Philosophorum ac Medicorum opiniones.
BP_Title English Translation: Ophthalmology, or a Tract on the fabric, action and function of the eyes, contrary to what till now has been the widespread opinions of Philosophers and Physicians.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss physician and professor at Louvain. Ocular physiologist, eye-to-eye with Kepler on the eye, and early promoter of Harvey's idea of blood circulation .
BP_Provenance: Extensive marginalia and notes throughout. Bookplate of the Henn-Wolfram Riedesel
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1632 Plemp - Ophthalmographia - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Athanasius Kircher's very early work on the construction and operation of sundials that function by reflected light.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Primitiae Gnomonicae Catoptricae<i> is a very early work of Kircher's on the construction and operation of sundials functioning by reflected light. Interest in sundials had expanded greatly since the early Renaissance and Kircher's work is a summary of the developments made in this art in the previous century. Among the earliest being the <i>Compositio Horologiorum<i> of 1531 and the <i>Typus Universalis Horologiorum Muralium<i> of 1533, both by Sebastian M√ºnster. A work likely known to Kircher was Rafael Mirami's <i>Compendiosa Introduttione alla Prima Parte della Specularia<i> of 1582, in which reflective mural sundials were first described. By the time he wrote the <i>Primitiae Gnomonicae Catoptricae<i>, Kircher had studied horological works and had designed and built two mural sundials for churches.|For Kircher, solar horology was a part of optics and thought it part of the art of light and shadow. Light and its reflection are treated in a completely traditional Scholastic manner, with the elementary geometric aspects of Euclidian optics used as necessary. The material in the <i>Primitiae Gnomonicae Catoptricae<i> would be later reused in Kircher‚Äôs much large work, the <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i> of 1646.
BP_Description_2: Kircher's <i>Primitiae Gnomonicae Catoptricae<i> is in two books. Book 1: On the Nature and Properties of Reflected Light. The book begins with 13 definitions that present a mix of scholastic teaching on light and reflection and the simpler parts of Euclidean geometric optics. The distinction is made between lux and lumen, between internal and propagated light. Lumen travels in straight lines that can be traced with luminous rays. The Cathetus Rule is used to locate rays after reflection from a mirror's surface. Ten theorems present the fundamental geometry of Euclidian reflection and an additional 11 theorems are devoted to the sun's path in the sky. The book closes with a consideration of the parabolic, hyperbolic, and elliptical mirrors. Book 2: Methods of Constructing Sundials by Rays of Reflected Light. After describing the differences between sundials that work by shadow casting and those that work catoptrically, the book then presents 29 Problems. Each problem presents and solves various aspects of constructing sundials that operate by reflected light. The basis for most of these is the 'bow tie' projection of solar position onto a plane. The catoptrical sundials include those that reflect sunlight into a space and onto a surface, plane or curved, delineated to mark the time. Woodcut figures accompany the text.
BP_Reference(s): <i>La Meridiana a Riflessione fu Inventata da Raffaele Mirami?<i>|Saverino, N.|http://nicolaseverino.it, 2007.||<i>Athanasius Kricher's Theatre of the World<i>|Godwin, J.|Inner Traditions, Rochester, 2009, 304 pp, NB: pp 198-206.
BP_Title: Primitiae gnomonicae catoptricae hos est horologiographiae novae specularis. In qua breviter nova, certa, exacta, & facilis demonstratur horologiorum per reflexi luminis radium construendorum methodus ; item qua ratione pr√¶dicto reflexi luminis radio, in qualibet quantumvis irregulari muri superficie, in interioribus domorum, aliisque locis obscuris, & umbrosis, cum horologia omnis generis, tuÃÄm omnium circulorum, qui in primo mobili considerati possunt, projectur√¶, & curv√¶ sectorum conorum line√¶, processus solis, & lun√¶ in planis indices, aliaÃÅque plurima scitu digna representari possint, varieÃÅ docetur. Authore R. P. Athanasio Kircher Bvchonio. e Societate Iesu Mathematicum, & Orientalium linguarum Professore.
BP_Title English Translation: The Beginnings of Catoptrical Gnomics: Which is New Mirrored Horology. In Which a Brief, New, Certain, Exact and Easily Demonstrated Method of Constructing Clocks by Reflected Luminous Rays. Also, the Way by Which the Above-Mentioned Reflected Rays of Light are Projected onto Walls, However Irregular, in the Interiors of Houses and other Dark and Shaded Places, by Means of Clocks of All Kinds as well as Circles Which can be Considered First.  And the Curved line of the Sector of the Cone, Indicating the Path of the Sun and Moon, and Many Other Worth Things that are able to be Represented are Taught.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, scholar, polymath. A writer of vast but uneven output: natural magic, language, history, culture.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Privileges on Hh‚ÇÇ ≥·µõ
