BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A Latin translation of a  collection  of  mathematical, physical,  chemical  and  technical  puzzles  and  experiments  based on Jean Leurechon's  "Recr√©ation mathematique"  of 1624.
BP_Description_1: A Latin translation and slight reworking of the <I>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>  of 1624 by the Jesuit Jean Leurechon.  Ninety-one 'problems' are presented, some of several parts, with solutions constituting a collection of experiments, apparatus demonstrations, recipes, and parlor tricks in cosmology, optics, perspective, mechanics, statics, practical geometry, fortification and gunnery. Designed to entertain and instruct. The ultimate source for the arithmetical problems was Claude Bachet's <i>Problems Plaisans et Delectables<i> of 1612. The problems in geometry are in the Renaissance tradition of 'practical geometry'; geometry applied to surveying, mensuration, and fortification. Many of the other problems come from the tradition of secretes and natural magic, such as Girolamo Ruscelli's <i>De' Secretis del Alessio Piemontese<i> in the edition of 1615. Some of the problems in natural philosophy appear to be from works by Giambattista Della Porta, Girolamo Cardano, and Salomon de Caus. Renaissance books on conjuring and prestidigitation were a source for the <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>.||Ens text is somewhat longer than Leurechon's but his descriptions are based on the same figures, being recut for the <i>Thaumaturgus<i> but following Leurechon's very closely. Though it's existance is sometimes disputed, a second edition of the <i>Thaumaturgus<i> did appear in 1651. Both editions of Ens book attest to the lasting popularity of the <I>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> and books like it. In addition to Ens' Latin, Leurechon's text was also translated in English in 1653, and into Ducth by Wynant van Westen in 1641.
BP_Description_2: The work begins with a dedicatory letter to Johann Schellart von Obbendorf and a preface to the reader from the author which names some of his sources and the general nature of what he tried to accomplish. Ens used 89 of van Etten's problems, omitting 38 and 46, and adding 25 new problems, with some numbering errors so the last is numbered 113.  This is followed by 55 problems of Alcuin, using the Bede version of 56 problems, but omitting 18. The material covers: Arithmetic, Geometry, Optics and Perspective, Music, Cosmographical Matters. This includes the camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow, all described in a rudimentary way. In this and other early editions, the optical material is limited to display and demonstration, with little or no explanation of the phenomena itself. Nevertheless, they give witness to the abiding interest in everyday optical phenomena.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.||Sources in Recreational Mathematics: an Annotated Bibliography|Singmaster, D.|online at http://www.puzzlemuseum.com/singma/singma-index.htm
BP_Title: Thaumaturgus mathematicus, id est, Admirabilium effectorum e mathematicarum disciplinarum fontibus profluentium sylloge. Gasparo Ens L. Collectore & Interprete
BP_Title English Translation: Amazing Mathematics. That is, A Compilation of Wonderful Effects Flowing from the Fountnain of Mathematical Disciplines. Gaspar Ens, Collector and Interpreter.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, lived and worked in the Netherlands.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1636 Ens - Thaumaturgus mathematicus - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of mathematical puzzles, games, and inventions in diverse fields. The optics sections cover the utility and history of optics, citing many historical sources, the camera obscura, optical instruments, the rainbow and the solar spectrum from a prism, vision, refraction, perspective, mirrors and mirror instruments and viewing boxes.
BP_Description_1: Daniel Schwenter's <i>Deliciae Physico-Mathematicae<i> is a collection of mathematical puzzles, games, and inventions in diverse fields. Written while teaching arithmetic, geometry, stereotomy, optics, and gnomonics at the University of Altdorf outside Nuremburg, it was published the year of Schwenter's death. The work was written to educate and entertain and culled many popular works for its subjects; the forward contains 12 pages of authors consulted in the book's composition. Most sections begin with a history of the topic and citations of works. It would later be significantly expanded by Schwenter's student, Georg Harsd√∂rffer. As with other books of science popularization of the time, the <i>Deliciae Physico-Mathematicae<i> was widely read. The first edition appeared posthumously in 1636 and was likely edited by Schwenter's student, Georg Harsd√∂rffer, who would expend the work with editions appearing in, 1651, 1653, 1677, and 1692.
BP_Description_2: The 16 sections of puzzles and entertainments cover: arithmetic, geometry, stereometry, music, optics, catoptrics, astronomy and astrology , gnomics, statics, motion, fire and heat, pneumatics, hydraulics, writing, architectural and mechanics, and chemistry. The arithmetic section gives the first appearance in German of the use of continued fractions. Some of the arithmetic and geometric problems were borrowed from Leurechon‚Äôs <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> of 1624. Nearly 100 problems from Leurechon are adopted by Schwenter--but always with the attribution 'aus dem Frankosen'. Several mechanical devices and inventions are described or pictured for the first time, including a sinker for determining specific gravity, a magnetic telegraph, a fountain pen made of two quills and a swivel mount for microscopes. The optics sections (25 pages) cover the utility and history of optics, citing many historical sources. The material includes: the camera obscura, optical instruments, the rainbow and the solar spectrum from a prism, vision, refraction, perspective, mirrors and mirror instruments and viewing boxes. Schwenter also describes a version of his 'scioptric ball' having a hole through its diameter and a lens fitted at each end. This device was placed in the aperture of a camera obscura and because it could swivel over a large range of directions, could produce larger, shaper images of sections from the outdoor scene. In addition, the two lenses did not invert the projected image. The section on the colors formed from sunlight by a prism is an example of what Newton referred to in his letter on a new theory of light and color where wrote that he had determined to 'try therewith the celebrated Phaenomena of Colour'. The treatment of optics is Aristotelian and elementary. The presentation is descriptive and accompanied by simple xylographic figures.
BP_Reference(s): Folding in Recreational Mathematics during the 17th‚Äì18th Centuries: Between Geometry and Entertainment|Friedman, M., Lisa Rougetet, L.|<i>Acta Baltica Historiae et Philosophiae Scientiarum<i>, Vol 5, No 2, 2007, pp 5-34.||R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.||<i>Sources in Recreational Mathematics: An Annotated Bibliography<i>|Singmaster, D.|School of Computing, Information Systems and Mathematics, South Bank University, 2004.
BP_Title: Deliciae physico-mathematicae, Oder Mathemat: und philosophische Erquickstunden, darinnen Sechshundert drey und Sechzig schoÃàne, liebliche und annehmliche KunststuÃàcklein, Auffgaben und Fragen au√ü der Rechenkunst, Landtmessen, Perspectiv, Naturkundigung und andere Wissenschaften genommen, begriffen seindt.  Wie solche uf der andern seiten dieses blats Ordentlich nacheinander verzeichnet worden.
BP_Title English Translation: The delights of Physical-Mathematics, or Refreshing Mathematical and Philosophical Hours; Therein 663 beautiful, lovely, and acceptable little artpieces. Exercises and questions taken from Arithemtic, Surveying, Perspective, Natural History, and taken and grasped from other Sciences. All of which has been recorded on the other side of this sheet in neat succession.
BP_Biographical Statement: German academic. Taught language and mathematics at the University of Altdorf.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Engraved Titlepage by Johann Pfann
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1636 Schwenter - Delici√¶ physico-mathematic√¶ - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Two of the three essays Descartes wrote to demonstrate his new method of natural philosophy: La Dioptrique on optics and  vision, Les Meteores on atmospheric phenomena.
BP_Description_1: Ren√© Descartes's <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i> has it roots in what has been called his micro-mechanical conception of natural philosophy--all physical action, activity, or result was generated, transmitted, or sensed by means of the interaction of particulate matter. He referred to this as 'physico-mathematics' and was his replacement for Scholastic teachings in natural philosophy. Optics was a life-long interest of Descartes, and his earliest study was that of refraction, written in 1619-1621. The first full expression of these and other ideas was his <i>La Monde<i>, nearly completed by 1633, but not published in his lifetime due to the shock created by the condemnation of Galileo in that year. <i>La Monde<i> set out Descartes' mechanical theory of light, described vortex celestial mechanics, and advanced a Copernican cosmography.||In the following three years, Descartes reworked <i>La Monde<i>, removing its Copernican elements, writing what would become the <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i>, along with its three demonstrative essays <i>La Dioptrique<i> on light and vision, <i>Les Meteores<i> on atmospheric phenomena and optics, and <i>La Geomoetrie<i> which introduced analytic geometry. It is known that the essays were produced in order of <i>La Dioptrique, Les Meteores, La Geomoetrie<i> and that the <i>Discours<i> itself was written last. Printing was also in that order and took nearly a year. Written and printed before the rest of the book, copies of <i>La Dioptrique<i> and <i>Les Meteores<i> were known to circulate in Europe in 1636. The present copies are from the library of Count Ricatti. These advanced copies--as it were--of two of the essays drew responses, questions, and criticisms from several European scholars. These and others Descartes received after the <i>Discours<i> appeared in 1637 prompted Descartes to consider a second French edition which would include objections and responses. But by 1639 the publisher Jean Maire reported that the book had sold poorly and a second French edition was not practical. In 1644 a Latin translation appeared, the <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i>, lightly edited by Descartes and lacking the <i>La Geometrie<i>. The Latin would sell well and begin the advance of Cartesian thought in Europe. The initial intellectual interest in Descartes' work was limited to the natural philosophy contained in the essays. Within 30 years, Descartes' physics was augmented with an experimental component, became part of the teaching curriculum in an ever-larger number of schools, and formed the basis of widely used textbooks. Cartesian physics would sweep aside Scholasticism and be dominant in Europe until the rise of Newtonianism in the first quarter of the 18th century.||Editions of the French text of the <i>Discours<i> appeared at Leiden in 1637 and at Paris in 1658, and twice in 1668. The Latin translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1644, twice in 1650, twice in 1656, in 1663, 1664, 1672, 1677, 1685, and twice in 1692; at London in 1664 and Frankfurt in 1692. An English translation appeared at London in 1649. A Dutch translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1656, 1659, and 1692.
BP_Description_2: Two of the three essays Ren√© Descartes wrote for the <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i>to demonstrate his new method of natural philosophy: <i>La Dioptrique<i> on optics and  vision, <i>Les Meteores<i> on atmospheric phenomena. La Dioptrique has three principal topics: the nature of light and the laws of optics, vision, and dioptric improvement of vision. These are covered in 10 sections or discourses: nature of light, law of refraction, ocular anatomy, the senses in general, image formation in the eye, visual perception, quality of vision, figure of spectacles, microscopes and telescopes, methods for figuring lenses. Descartes presents light as the percussive effect of a luminous source, transmitted through transparent media such as air and glass, to the eye. This is what Descartes called 'tendency to motion'. The laws of reflection and refraction are obtained from mechanical analogies: the ballistics of tennis balls. It is here that the sine law of refraction first appears in print. Discourse three is on ocular anatomy, influenced by Scheiner. Discourse four is on the senses in general, presenting the mind, situated in the brain, as receiver of impressions of external objects brought to it by the nerves. Discourse five presents ocular function and contains the famed diagram of the eye and an object's image, formed by the cornea and lens, on the retina, which is visible from the back of the eye after the outer tunic is removed. Discourse six gives an account of visual perceptions, including object distance and visual errors. Discourse seven is on the aspects of  vision that account for its acuity, or its lack, including near and far-sightedness and presbyopia. Discourse eight presents lens shapes that can alter light ray paths before entrance into the eye and improve vision. Discourse nine applies the principles of the eighth to microscopes and telescopes, suggesting designs for optical instruments. Discourse ten is on practical aspects of lens production including the formidably difficult problem of producing lenses of hyperbolic figure which would eliminate spherical aberration.||Les Meteores is in ten sections or discourses. Discourse eight presents the correct explanation of the geometric aspects of the primary and secondary rainbows. Using the sine law of refraction, Descartes performed an elaborate calculation and tabulation to show how light from the sun behind an observer is projected by a wall of water drops in front of the observer, back into the observer's eye in the form of an arc. His calculations correctly predicted the angular size of the primary and secondary rainbow arcs. The ninth and tenth discourses offer similar, though qualitative rather than quantitative explanations for halos and parahelia.
BP_Reference(s): The literature on Descartes and his optics is vast. I have found the following particularly helpful||ùëª <i>Ren√© Descartes: Discourse on Method, Optics, Geometry, and Meteorology<i>|Olscamp, P.J., Translator|Hackett, Cambridge, 2001, 388 p.||ùëª <i>Descartes: The World and Other Writings<i>|Gaukroger, S., Translator|Cambridge University Press, 1998, 208p.||<i>Descartes and the Hyperbolic Quest: Lens Making Machines¬†and their Signifcance in the Seventeenth Century<i>|Burnett, D.G.|American Philosophical Society, 2005, 152 p.||<i>A Bibliography of the Works of Descartes I & II<i>|van Otegem, M.|Quaestiiones Infinitae, Vol 37|Publications of the Leiden-Utrecht Research Institute of Philosophy, Utrecht, 2002, 780 p.||'Dioptrics' and 'Optics'|McDonough, J.|In: <i>The Cambridge Descartes Lexicon<i>|Cambridge University Press, 2015, NB: pp 197-199 and 550-559.||Descartes's Experimental Journey Past the Prism and Through the Invisible World to the Rainbow|Buchwald, J.Z.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 65, No 1, pp 1-46.||<i>Descartes's Theory of Light and Refraction: A Discourse on Method<i>|Smith, A.M.|Transactions of the American Philosophical Society, New Series, Vol 77, No 3, 1987, 92 p.||The logic of disguise: Descartes' discovery of the law of refraction|Heeffer, A.|<i>Historia Scientiarum<i>, Vol 16, No 2, 2006, pp 144-165.|https://www.researchgate.net/publication/293490604_The_Logic_of_Disguise_Descartes'_Discovery_of_the_Sine_Law||Descartes, A Biography|Clarke, D.|Cambridge University Press, 2006, 519 pp, NB: pp 126-175.||<i>Geometry and Space: The Celebrated Collection of Books on Geometry, Optics, and Perspective of M. Arnaud De Vitry<i>|Description, Lot 178|Sotheby's, Sale Catalogue, 2002, 430 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Last volume of the popular 5-volume mathematical encyclopedia, dealing with optics, catoptrics, dioptrics and perspective. Closely following Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i>, it states but does not use the sine law of refraction.
BP_Description_1: Pierre H√©rigone is actually a pseudonym for the Baron Cl√©ment Cyriaque de Mangin. <i>Cursus Mathematici<i> is his popular 5-volume mathematical encyclopedia, which appeared between 1634 and 1642 and in which he introduced his version and development of Fran√ßois Vi√®te's symbolic language. H√©rigone considered it useful in Pure and Mixed Mathematics and used it throughout the <i>Cursus Mathematici<i>. In this fifth and last volume, H√©rigone deals with optics, catoptrics, dioptrics and perspective, among other topics. With text in French and Latin, it closely following Kepler's Dioptrice, and states but does not use the sine law of refraction. H√©rigone text presents optics immediately before the influence of Descartes and, as stated in his preface, is part of his effort to present an encyclopedic summary of all knowledge with concision and accessibility. The latter is clear from his unusual arrangement of presenting his text in Latin and French, side-by-side. Though read and mentioned by Pierre Fermat, Charles Cavendish,  and Giovanni Borelli, and Isaac Barrow, the influence of H√©rigone's work was limited--it was soon eclipsed by Descartes'. Editions appeared at Paris in 1634-1637 and in 1644.
BP_Description_2: H√©rigone's 5th volume covers optics, perspective, spherical astronomy, spherical trigonometry, theory of the planets, gnomics, and music. The 5th volume begins with the optics of Euclid, stating the definitions and elementary parts of geometric optics. The descriptions and proofs of the 61 propositions of geometric optics use H√©rigone's famous mathematical symbology. The presentation of the eye and vision is modern, borrowing the image of the eye from Scheiner's Oculus of 1619 and the description of ocular function from Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604. Euclid's catoptrics is then presented in 33 propositions, again presented and proved with the concision of H√©rigone's symbolic method. The topics include plane and curved mirrors and their focal points. The material on dioptrics is a paraphrase of Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611 and it is here that H√©rigone states the sine law of refraction--though it is not actually used in the text. The operation of single and multiple lenses are considered and their effect on vision. In all, the optics material involves 190 pages and is essentially a summary of traditional Euclidian optics and catoptric and modern Keplerian dioptrics and vision. Where geometric or trigonometric proofs are required, H√©rigone's symbolic methods are used.
BP_Reference(s): Kepler's legacy: Telescopes and geometrical optics, 1611-1669|Malet, A.|In: <i>The Origins of the Telescope<i>, KNAW Press, Amsterdam, 2010, pp 281-300.||Pierre H√©rigone In: http://dictionnaire.sensagent.leparisien.fr||Keplerian Astronomy after Kepler: Researches and Problems|Applebaum, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vol 34, No 4, 1996, pp 451-504.||Symbolic language in early modern mathematics: The Algebra of Pierre H√©rigone (1580‚Äì1643)|Esteve, R.M.|<i>Historia Mathematica<i>, Vol 35, No 4, 2008, pp 285-301.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Forty propositions on the nature of light; refuting scholastic notions and adopting most, but not all, Keplerian ideas. The first explicit statement of the inverse-square law of illumination.
BP_Description_1: <i>De Natura Lucis<i> of Ismael Boulliau has its roots in his interest in and practice of astronomy and his conversations with his friend Pierre Gassendi. Like Johannes Kepler, Boulliau believed that the study of light and vision was an essential part of astronomy and that optics could be used not only to gather astronomical data but also to understand it. Boulliau considered, for example, the link or similarity between light and the 'motive force' postulated by Kepler to explain planetary motion so strong, that he proposed by way of analogy that this force decreased as the inverse square of the distance from its source, the sun. In this he opposed Kepler, who thought it varied simply as the inverse distance. Boulliau adopted and adapted the optical ideas of Kepler and was, by way of the <i>De Natura Lucis<i> and his vast correspondence, Western Europe's most important popularizer of Kepler's ideas.||In his long letter to the reader, Boulliau references Alhazen, Vitellio, Peckham, and Kepler and recognizes the honorable Aristotelian tradition regarding optics. Though Boulliau was an anti-scholastic in pro-Copernican in celestial matters, he finds it necessary to blend the old ideas with new ones; in particular regarding the nature of light. In addition to his own explication of the nature of light, Boulliau presents in the last half of the book a history of light of the ancient philosophers.
BP_Description_2: The <i>De Natura Lucis<i> first presents forty propositions on the nature of light; refuting scholastic notions and adopting most, but no all, Keplerian ideas. Propositions 1-27 involve the nature of light, its propagation, and simple reflection and refraction. The first explicit statement of the inverse-square law of illumination appears in Proposition 27: 'The intensities of light on surfaces are alternately as the squares of the distances of those surfaces from the light source.' Propositions 28-32 involve color and its nature. Propositions 33 and 34 are about luminous species and it is here that <i>De Natura Lucis<i> exhibits a tentative blending of Scholastic ideas with early modern ones. Light is presented as a mean of  corporeal and incorporeal substance. Propositions 35-40 involve light and its propagation in materials. The propositions are followed by notes and explications. The last half of the book is titled Beliefs Regarding Light of the Ancient Philosophers. The philosophies of Plato, Anaximander, Anaxagoras, Heraclitus, the Pythagoreans, Empedocles, the Stoics, the Epicureans, the Aristotelians, Peckham, Alhacen, Witelo, and Ferrari are presented briefly and considered. The book ends with a comparison of light with the human soul or intellect.
BP_Reference(s): Gassendi and Boulliau on Light and Vision|Hatch, R.|In: <i>Quadricentenaire de la naissance de Pierre Gassendi, 1592-1992: Actes du Colloque international Pierre Gassendi, Digne-les-Bains 18-21 mai 1992<i>|Societe Scientific et Litteraire des Alpes de Haute-Provence, 1994, 452 pp, NB: pp 365-385.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A detailed, geometrically practical guide to anamorphosis: Producing distorted perspective images on plane or curved surfaces that require special mirrors or viewing points. Niceron's optics is an illusionist art, rather than a science of light and vision.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Francois Niceron's <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> is a detailed, geometrically practical guide to anamorphosis. That is, the production of distorted perspective images on plane or curved surfaces that require special mirrors or viewing points. For Niceron, optics as an illusionist art, rather than a science of light and vision. As the title implies, Niceron considered anamorphosis a type of perspective, engaging the question of visual representation and the reliability of the visual sense. In his Letter to the Reader, Niceron lists the great developers of and contributors to the science of perspective but notes how few books on the subject do little more than display figures and scenes, without showing in detail how they were produced. He states that his goal is to remedy that for readers of French and that the title, Curious Perspective, could also have been Artificial Magic--'The one that produces for us the most beautiful and admirable effects, bringing about the art and industry of man.' He cautions new readers not to skip the initial material on geometry or the initial drawing exercises. Published when he was 25, Niceron had been working on anamorphosis (direct, catoptric, and dioptric) since he was 18 and a novice in the Order of Minims, and so the work is that of a practitioner with a deep understanding of geometry, not that of just a theoretician. With La Perspective Curieuse, Niceron makes significant advances in perspective projection methods from his predecessors Salomon de Caus and Jean-Louis Vaulezard. This is particularly the case for spherical projection; without Niceron's technique, interior dome work would have been beyond the ability of virtually all painters. This aspect of Niceron's work also affected the design of instruments, such as astrolabes and globes. La Perspective Curieuse was an acknowledged influence on Emmanuel Maignan's <i>Horographia<i> of 1648 and Charles Plumier's <i>L' Art de Tourner en Perfection<i> of 1749.||The plates were engraved by Joan Blanchin, based on Niceron‚Äôs drawings. Editions appeared in 1638 and edited by Roberval in 1651 and 1663. Niceron's Latin translation, edited by Mersenne, appeared posthumously in 1646 and edited by Roberval in 1663.
BP_Description_2: Jean-Francois Niceron's  <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> begins with a Geometric Preliminaries, followed by four books. The Preliminaries set out geometric basics in 7 Propositions. Book 1: Principles of Perspective. Describes a general method for the linear perspective of solid figures, included the complex cases where the figures contact the horizontal plane only along a line or at a point. The process is fundamentally geometric and presented in 15 Propositions, each demonstrated with one or more figures. Examples of the process are give for several solid objects. Book 2: Planar Anamorphosis. Projections are introduced for distorting a regular image so that it appears undistorted only when viewed from a particular viewing point. The undistorted rectangular grid of the image is mapped into a grid distorted by projection. The process is presented in 7 Propositions accompanied by figures. Book 3: Anamorphosis with Cylindrical and Conical Mirrors. Five Propositions and figures present the method for generating a doubly-projected grid. The rectangular grid of an image is mapped onto the projection and an undistorted view is presented only the appropriate mirror. Niceron gives practical advice on metal-casting for mirrors and instructions for their polishing. Book 4: Dioptric Anamorphosis. Five Propositions give the method for generating a projected grid that separates and distorts an image into several pieces. The projection depends on the nature of the intended facetted, dioptrical viewer. The rectangular grid of an image is segregated and distorted according to projected grid and reveals an assembled and undistorted image when viewed with the required facetted dioptric element. The material in all four books is presented with a brevity that requires close reading and careful reference to the many figures in the plates.
BP_Reference(s): Jean Fran√ßois Niceron: Perspective and Artificial Magic|DeRose, A.|<i>FME Transactions<i>, Vol  45, No 2, 2017, pp 215-226.||The Mathematical Treatment of Anamorphoses from Piero della Francesca to Niceron|Andersen, K.|In: <i>History of Mathematics: States of the Art<i>, Christoph J. Scriba, C.J.,  Dauben, J.W., editors|Academic Press, San Diego, 1996, 394 pp.||The refractive anamorphic viewer of J.-F. Niceron: Reconstructing a 17th century optical toy|Hunt, J.L, Sharp, J.|<i>American Journal of Physics<i>, Vol 79, No 10, 2011, pp 1023-1029.||<i>Anamorphic Art<i>|Baltrusaitis, J., Strachan, W.J., translator|Cambridge, 1977, 192 pp, NB: pp 37-60.||Jean Fran√ßois Niceron: Prospettiva, Catottrica & Magia Artificiale|De Rosa, A., editor|<i>ARACNE editrice<i>, Rome, 2013, 472 pp.||<i>The Order of Minims in Seventeenth-Century France<i>|Whitmore, P.J.S.|Matinus Nijhoff, The Hague, 1967, 367 pp, NB: pp 155-162.
BP_Title: La Perspective Curieuse ou Magie Artificiele des effets merveilleux. De L'Optique, par la vision directe; La Catoptrique, par the reflexion des miroirs plat, Cylindriques & Coniques; La Dioptrique, par la refraction des Crystaux. Dans laquelle, outre un abbregeÃÅ & methode generale de la perspective commune, reduite en pratique sur les cinq corps reguliers, est encore enseignee la facÃßon de faire & construire toute sortes de figures difformes, qui estant veueÃàs de leur poinct paroissent dans une juste proportion: le tout par des pratiques si familieres, que les moins versez en la geometrie s'en pourront servir avec le seul compas & la regle.  "And with Geometry, Enter"  Oeuvre tres-utile aux peintres, architectes, graveurs, sculpteurs, & aÃÄ tous autres qui se servent du dessein de leurs ouvrages. Par le Pere F. Jean FrancÃßois Niceron Parisien de l'ordre des Minimes.
BP_Title English Translation: Curious Perspective, or the Artificial Magic of Mavelous Effects. On: Optics, by direct vision; Catoptrics, by reflection in plane, cylindrical, and conical mirrors; Dioptrics, by  Refraction of Crystals. In which, besides an abbreviated & General Method of General Perspective, reduced in practice to the five regular solids, is also taught how to build all kinds of deformed figures which, being viewed from their point appear in appropriate proportion. All by what is Familiar and Practical, which the poorest in Geometry can achieve with only compass and rule.   "And with Geometry, Enter"  A Work Useful to Painters, Architects, Engravers, Sculptors, and all Others who use a Plan in their Work. By Father Jean-FrancÃßois Niceron, of the Order of Minims.

BP_Short or Common Title: Examen du livre des recreations mathematiques (b)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Claude Mydorge's commentary, analysis, and notes on Leurechon's R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques.
BP_Description_1: Late edition of Claude Mydorge's commentary, analysis, and notes on the 1630 edition of Leurechon's <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>. This edition contains the original forward by Leurechon and a preface from the publisher of the edition of 1630, Rolet Boutonn√©, regarding Mydorge's notes. It is stated there that Mydorge's notes were in unpublished circulation for a number of years and then used without consent in earlier editions. Mydorge was eventually  prevailed upon to get them into print. The publisher of this edition, Anthoine Robinot, simply reprinted this preface; replacing  Boutonn√©'s name with his. There are notes labeled with the acronym D.H.P.E.M., signifying Denis Henrion, that had been added in 1627. To these are added 'examinations' by Mydorge, labeled with his D.A.L.G. This and subsequent editions contain three parts: The original 91 Problems, annotated and examined by Henrion and Mydorge; An additional 45 Problems on optics, geometry and mechanics perhaps by Mydorge; Seventeen short chapters on artillery and fireworks, probably by Jean Appier Hanzelet,  coming as they do from his <i>Receuil de Plusiers Machines Militaires<i> of 1620. The latter two section have their own title page.||The commentaries and explanations contributed by Henrion to the mathematical problems and by Mydorge to the optical ones added significantly to the value of the book. It became a book of popular sciences, and the subsequent printings, editions, and enlargements demonstrate its popularity. Thirty editions in French appeared between 1624 and 1680. Jacques Ozanam began editing editions in 1694, adding material and changing the content to be more like an encyclopedia. Jean-Etienne Montucla and Edm√© Gilles Guyot were subsequent editors and by 1769 there were four volumes. Translations appeared in English, Latin, Dutch, and German.
BP_Description_2: This and subsequent editions of <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> omit the dedicatory letter signed by H. Van Etten, though his note about 'Five or Six things' and a preface to the reader from the author which names some of his sources and the general nature of what he tried to accomplish is retained. This is followed by a table on contents titled 'Recueil de Principlales Faceties Mathematical Recreations Contained in the Booklet According to Problem Numbers'. The sections listed are: Arithmetic, Geometry, Optics and Perspective, Music, Cosmographical Matters. There follows the first section with 91 'Problems' in these various subjects. The camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow are presented in a rudimentary way. In early editions, the optical material is limited to display and demonstration, with the original text giving little or no explanation of the phenomena itself. Most of the problems involving optics and some involving mechanics have added 'examinations' by Claude Mydorge. The are usually detailed provide an explanation for the phenomenon reported in the problem. Problem II, dealing with the camera obscura, is an example. Mydorge's examination begins with 'The compiler of these Recreations was not a great mathematician.' He then gives a description involving light rays. He adds that one must study the matter more deeply if they are to understand why the brightness and clarity of the image are directly and inversely related, respectively, to the size of the hole.||There are a few problems in the second section devoted to optics and projection. These have a very different character than the original problems of section one--more detailed and  explanatory, rather than just reporting. The problems in the first section and their examinations, and the problems in the second section, never involve mathematics above the simplest geometry, thus maintaining their popular science character.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.
BP_Title: Examen du livre des recreations mathematiques et de ses problems en Geometrie, Mechanique, Optique, & Catoptrique. Ou sont aussi discutees & restablies plusieurs experiences Physiques y proposees.
BP_Title English Translation: Review of a Book of Mathematical Recreations and its Problems in Geometry, Mechanics, Optics, and Catoptrics. Where also are Discussed and Re-established Several Proposed Physical Experiments.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician and confidant of Ren√© Descartes and Marin Mersenne. His sinecure in the government allowed time for his extensive work in mathamtics, optics, and optical instruments.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1639 Mydorge - Examen du livre des recreations mathematiques (b) - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Books I and II of the 1631 edition on the generation of focal curves for optics, augmented with books III and IV on generating the same and similar conic sections from one another.
BP_Description_1: Claude Mydorge's four books on the nature, properties, and generation of conic sections, were presented as a necessary preliminary to and geometric basis of reflective and refractive optics. Mydorge's <i>Prodromi<i> originates in the 1620s when he worked on lenses and refraction theory with Marin Mersenne, who knew Mydorge's manuscript and mentions it a letter of 1623. By 1627 Mydorge, Ren√© Descartes, and lens maker Jean Ferrier had studied the anaclastic lens of hyperbolic figure and managed to make one. By the time of the <i>Prodromi<i>, Mydorge had intimate knowledge of the optical properties of curves and surfaces and had developed descriptions based not on their figure as produced by sectioning a cone, but rather on their focal properties. He was equally interested in and inventive of ways in which to actually produces these curves. Both aspects would define the Prodromi. Mydorge source for Apollonius was the Latin paraphrase produced by Jacobus Golius from an Arabic manuscript he had collected in the Levant. The <i>Prodromi<i> would have a considerable effect on Ren√© Descartes and Frans van Shooten.||This edition contains the reissue of books one and two from the edition of 1631, with the addition of books three and four. Edition of all four books appeared in 1639, followed by reprints in 1640, 1641, 1644, and 1660.
BP_Description_2: This edition of the Prodromi omits the Monitum ad Conicorum Opus of the edition of 1631 and adds two books to the first two. Book 1 is titled: On the Elements of Conics, or the Origin, Generation, and Nature Proper to Each Conic Section. The first book covers classical conic sections but adds many problems and their solution new with Mydorge; particularly for elliptical, parabolic, and hyperbolic curves. Book 2 is titled: Description of the Geometry of Linear Conics in a Plane through a Point. The second book deals with practical methods of generating parabolic and hyperbolic curves. These methods are set in the context of constructing curves and surfaces to be used in optics. Book 3 is titled: Conic Sections that are the Same. The first part presents Propositions that detect conic sections that are the same using their parameters. The second part shows how to duplicate a give conic by sectioning a cone. Book 4 is titled: Conic Sections that are similar. Propositions are presented to detect similar conic sections.||The material in the first book is Euclidian in form; definitions, proposition, proofs, and conclusions. Given its practical purpose, the material in the second book is much more geometric and demonstrative. Mydorge sets out the traditional theory of conic sections as described by Apollonius of Perga in the second century BC, using sections of a right circular cone. Mydorge's first important advance is to define these curves optically; that is, in terms of their foci and what would now be called the directrix, rather than as sections of a cone as Apollonius did. Mydorge then showed how to generate an elliptic, parabolic, or hyperbolic curves of a given size, or with given foci. All these method lent themselves to drawing methods with practical tools that could generate the desired curve. The added material in books three and four is an application of the methods of constructing conic section from book two, but used to either detect duplicate or similar curves, or to generate them.
BP_Reference(s): The Development of Mersenne‚Äôs Optics|Cozzoli, D.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 2010, pp 9-25.||Constructive thinking: a case for dioptrics|Dijksterhuis, F.J.|In: <i>The Mindful Hand: Inquiry and Invention from the late Renaissance to Early Industrialization<i>|Koninkliijke, Amsterdam, 2007, 468 pp, pp 59-82.
BP_Title: Prodromi Catoptricorum et Dioptricorum  sive: Conicorum Operis ad Abdita Radii Refleci et Refracti mysteria praeuii & praeferentis. Libri Quatuor Priories.
BP_Title English Translation: Forerunners of Catoptics and Dioptrics: or Leading the Way and Carrying a Torch to the Hidden Mysteries of Rays Reflected and Refracted with the Aid of a Cone. The First Four Books.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician and confidant of Ren√© Descartes and Marin Mersenne. His sinecure in the government allowed time for his extensive work in mathamtics, optics, and optical instruments.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The last great Renaissance Aristotelian considers the history of light theories, cites and praises the Perspectivists, and presents and defends peripatetic ideas about light and its properties.
BP_Description_1: The last great Renaissance Aristotelian considers the history of light theories, cites and praises the Perspectivists, and presents and defends peripatetic ideas about light and its properties. This includes the nature, propagation, reflection, refraction, and visible effects of light. The origin of this work is, in part, the exchange of letters between Liceti and Galileo and Liceti and Pierre Gassendi. The letters record the changes on the nature of light in general and the whether the phenomenon of the Bologna Stone (Lapide Bononiensi) supported or spoke against Aristotelian teachings on light. These exchanges also involved disagreements regarding the relationship between heat and light. At the same time Liceti wrote <i>De Natura et Efficientia de Luminis<i>, he was writing <i>Litheosphorus sive de Lapide Bononiensi<i> and <i>De Quaesitis Per Epistolas a Claris Viris Responsa Fortunii Liceti Genevenis<i>--all published in 1640. Liceti was setting bulwarks against the rising tide of Italian Renaissance humanist anti-Aristotelianism.||Liceti's intellectual context for considerations concerning light was astronomy, and much of the material in <i>De Natura et Efficientia de Luminis<i> springs from astronomical issues: light emanating from stars and comets, light from the moon, light and heat from the sun. His summary of Scholastic thought regarding light includes citations of Alhazen, Witelo, Peckham, and the medieval Aristotelian commentators. He knows of Maurolyco, Aguil√≥n, Kepler, and Brahe but does not think their work overthrows the Scholastic framework; rather, that it can be incorporated. The <i>De Natura et Efficientia de Luminis<i> is among the last significant texts on Aristotelian optics published in Europe. Kircher's <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i>--who borrowed significantly from Liceti--appeared in 1646 and Marin Cureau de La Chambre's <i>La Lumi√®re<i> appeared in 1657. None of these were influential. With the appearance in 1644 of the Latin translation of Ren√© Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i>, Cartesian optics would begin to sweep the field.
BP_Description_2: The <i>De Luminis Natura<i> is in three books. Book 1: In which Other Opinions are Presented and Briefly Examined. Liceti examines, in turn, the ideas of Ibn B√¢jja (Avempace), then the various emission theories involving material particles, then the light metaphysics involving intromission of luminous species, and finally the ideas of John Philoponus. Liceti labors to return to what he considers the original ideas of Aristotle, and is not deterred from attacking the ideas of various commentators when he felt they strayed too far from original Aristotelian ideas and concepts. Particularly since these were not just early medieval ideas without influence; many of the notions of the commentators  had contemporary supporters. Liceti's arguments are entirely Scholastic in content and form, lengthy, and tedious. Arguments are won with tight logic and counting up the pros and cons. Book 2: In which all the Essential Attributes of Light-- it's Cause, Origin, Nature, Power, Action, and Effects--are Considered and Carefully Explained. Central to Liceti's presentation of Aristotelian teaching is the distinction between lux and lumen, between internal, powering light, and external, emitted or propagated light. The four Aristotelian causes (final, formal, effective, and material) of light are set out, including the actualization of potential transparency in a diaphanous material. Particularly important is Liceti's consideration of the issue of light's speed of propagation and his compromise of Aristotelian purity to use Euclidian light rays, bestowed with physical reality, to fully account for light's propagation. 'Secondary light' from reflection and refraction is also considered. Then, eleven functions of light are described, including dispelling darkness, providing for vision, producing images, generating colors, casting shadows, generating fire, generating cold, affect humors in the human body, and promoting the lives of animals. Book 3: In which Doubts About the Preceding are Stated and Resolved. In this brief section, raises conventional arguments against the central ideas of Aristotelian optics, and refutes them.
BP_Reference(s): Une th√©orie aristot√©licienne de la lumi√®re du XVIIe si√®cle|Zoubov, V.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 24, No 2, 1935, pp 343-360.
BP_Title: Fortunii Liceti Genuensis in Bononiensi Archigymnasio Philosophi Eminentis. De Luminis Natura & Efficientia libri tres:  in quibus luminis nomenclatura, necessitas, caussa finalis, materialis, efficiens, formalis, productio, quidditas, affectiones, facultates, et operationes omnes diligenter explicantur ex rei natura ; de medio sublatis alienis dogmatibus, & difficultatibus in proposito contingentibus. Eminentissimo principi Francisco Cardinali Barberino, S.R.E. Vicecancellario.
BP_Title English Translation: Fortunio Liceti of Genoa, Eminent Philosopher in the University of Bologna. Three Books on the Nature and Efficacy of Light. In which the nature of light; its final, material, efficient, and formal cause; its essennce, effects, means, and workings; all are diligently explained from the nature of the thing. Lifted from the midst of other doctrines and difficulties in what has been proposed. To the eminent Prince Francesco Cardinal Barberini, Vice-Chancellor.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physician, natural philosopher, and influential teacher in the Universities of Padua and Bologna. Last of the great Aristotlians.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1640 Liceti - De Luminis Natura - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fundamentals of several fields, light and vision among them, each presented by a plate of 9 figures, each demonstrating a fundamental element and accompanied by paragraph of rudimentary explanation.
BP_Description_1: Bourdin's <i>Le Cours de Math√©matique<i> has its origin in a course he taught at the Coll√®ge de Clermont beginning in 1636. Its content was informed by the Jesuit's <i>Ratio Studiorum<i>. Existing student notes reveal a very modern pedagogy based on images and figures. Bourdin drew and etched the figures used in the course, had them printed, and distributed them to his students to lighten the note-taking burden and assure accuracy. The etchings and notes form the basis for <i>Le Cours de Mathematique<i>. The course presents a brief introduction to several fields of Mixed Mathematics appropriate for engineers: Arithmetic, Geometry, Music, Mechanics, Optics, and Cosmography. Each is presented by a plate of figures accompanied by numbered notes that are topic outlines and references to figures. This bound with Bourdin's similar works on geometry and fortification; material that would later be incorporated into the body of <i>Le Cours de Mathematique<i>. Editions appeared in 1641, 1645, and a considerably expanded posthumous edition in 1661.
BP_Description_2: Pierre Bourdin's <i>Le Cours de Mathematique<i> presents a brief introduction to several fields of Mixed Mathematics: Arithmetic, Geometry, Music, Mechanics, Optics and Vision, and Cosmography. Each is presented by a plate of 9 figures, each figure demonstrating a fundamental element and accompanied by numbered notes that are topic outlines with references to figures.  The coverage is of the greatest possible concision is clearly designed to support a course of lectures that would provide necessary detail. The section on optics presents figures and notes for: Fundamentals, Economy of the Senses, Laws of Vision, Reflection and Mirrors, Refraction and Lenses, Illusions, Perspective Theory, Perspective Practice, Anamorphosis, Mirror Anamorphosis, Dioptric Anamorphosis. The accompanying figures are the merest suggestions or demonstration of the phenomenon described in the outline notes.
BP_Reference(s): √âtudes  & Formation des Ing√©nieurs sous Vauban|Catherine Bousquet-Bressolier, C.|In: <i>La commission 'Histoire' du Comit√© Fran√ßais de Cartographie<i>, No 195, 2008, pp 15-26.|http://www.lecfc.fr/new/articles/195-article-3.pdf||<i>Descartes and His Contemporaries: Meditations, Objections, and Replies<i>|Ariew, R., Grene, M.|University of Chicago Press, 1995, NB: pp 209-215.||Descartes and the Jesuits|Ariew, R.|In: <i>Jesuit Science and the Rebulic of Letters<i>|Feingold, M., editor|MIT Press, Cambridge, 2003, 489 pp, NB: pp 157-194.
BP_Title: Le cours de Mathematique, Represente par Figures, & cartes, & clairement explique dans toutes ses parties, avec quantitie de connoissances & pratiques nouvelles. Le Tout en Faveur de Ceux qui veulent apprendre les Mathematiques en peu de temps Premiere Partie.
BP_Title English Translation: Optics, Including Knowledge of the Eye, of Light, and of Colors.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, teacher, author. Tangled famously with Descartes.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'Jean Francois Peysson' on free endpaper
BP_BibliographicNotes: Printing and engraved image on only one side of each sheet of paper. Folios grouped in 4s, so that outer (1,8) and inner (4,5) pages of each gathering are blank

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by √âtienne de Courcelles (1586-1659)  Friend of Descartes, Arminian Greek scholar and translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i> is the Latin translation of Descartes' Discours de la Methode of 1637, except for its third essay La G√©om√©trie. The <i>Specimina<i> is responsible for the general accessibility and wide-spread advance of Cartesian natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: The Latin translation of Descartes' <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i> has its origins before the French edition appeared late in 1637; Descartes had written earlier to Marin Mersenne about preparing a Latin version himself. In 1638 Descartes gathered comments and objections from readers including Libertus Fromond of Louvain, Vopiscus Plemp, Pierre Fermat, Blaise Pascal, Gilles de Roberval, Jean-Baptiste Morin, and Alphonse Pollot. Most of these objections were written in Latin and so Descartes asked Mersenne to tell his other correspondents to write in Latin. Evidently, by summer 1638 Descartes was planning a second edition of the <i>Discours<i>, in Latin, containing the objections he had received and his answers. But this was set aside, and work began on a second edition in French, with Descartes making corrections and Mersenne acting as editor. But Descartes' publisher, Jan Maire, reported that the first French edition sold very poorly and that a second French edition was not economically practical; Mersenne stopped his editorial work and the project was dropped.||Printed versions of <i>La Dioptrique<i> and <i>Les Meteores<i> had circulated even before the complete <i>Discours<i> appeared in 1637 and not long after, a Latin translations of the <i>Discours, La Dioptrique<i>, and <i>Les Meteores<i> were circulating. Descartes obtained a copy and made corrections and changes intended for the second French edition. The Latin translation--titled <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i>--is traditionally attributed to Etienne de Courcelles, though the evidence is only indirect from Adrien Baillet, the biographer of Descartes. By 1644 Elsevier was publishing Descartes' <i>Principia Philosophiae<i> and proposed to publish the <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i> as well. Jan Maire refused to sell the woodcuts for the figures to Elsevier, and so new (and poorer) ones were produced. Baillet states that the <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i> appeared without <i>La G√©om√©trie<i> because Courcelles did not have mastery of the subject or that it was known that Van Schooten has already translated it.||The <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i> was widely read, influenced natural philosophy profoundly, and marked the real beginning of Cartesianism. It was the <i>Specimina<i>, not the <i>Discours<i>, that was studied by natural philosophers for more than two centuries, was the fons et origo of textbooks for students, and it was here that Europe first read 'Cogito, ergo sum'. Editions appeared at Amsterdam in 1644, twice at Amsterdam in 1650, twice at Amsterdam in 1656, twice at Amsterdam in 1664, at London in 1664, at Amsterdam in 1672, 1677, 1685, twice at Amsterdam in 1692, and at Frankfurt in 1692.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i> contains Latin translations of two of the three essays Descartes wrote to demonstrate his new method of natural philosophy: La Dioptrique on optics and  vision, Les Meteores on atmospheric phenomena. La Dioptrique has three principal topics: 1, the nature of light and the laws of optics, 2, vision, and 3, dioptric improvement of vision. These are covered in 10 sections: nature of light, law of refraction, ocular anatomy, the senses in general, image formation in the eye, visual perception, quality of vision, figure of spectacles, microscopes and telescopes, methods for figuring lenses.  Les Meteores contains the correct explanation of the geometric aspects of the primary and secondary rainbows.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A Bibliography of the Works of Descartes I & II<i>|van Otegem, M.|Quaestiiones Infinitae, Vol 37|Publications of the Leiden-Utrecht Research Institute of Philosophy, Utrecht, 2002, 780 pp, NB pp 29-37.||<i>Ren√© Descartes: Specimina Philosophiae, Introduction and Critical Edition<i>|Vermeulen, C.L.|Quaestiones Infinitae, Vol 53|Publications of the Leiden-Utrecht Research Institute of Philosophy, Utrecht, 2007.||ùëª<i> Ren√© Descartes: Discourse on Method, Optics, Geometry, and Meteorology<i>|Translated with Introduction by Paul J. Olscamp|Hackett, Cambridge, 2001.||<i>Descartes and the Hyperbolic Quest: Lens Making Machines¬†and their Signifcance in the Seventeenth Century<i>|Burnett, D.G.|American Philosophical Society, 2005.||'Dioptrics' and 'Optics'|McDonough, J.|In: <i>The Cambridge Descartes Lexicon<i>|Cambridge University Press, 2015, pp 197-199 and 550-559.
BP_Title: Renati Des Cartes Specimina philosophiae: seu Dissertatio de methodo recte regendae rationis, & veritatis in scientiis investigandae; Dioptrice, et Meteora. Ex Gallico translata, & ab Auctore perlecta, variisque in locis emdendata.

BP_Short or Common Title: Cogitata Physico-mathematica; Universae Geometriae, Mixtaeque Mathematicae Synopsis; Novarum Observationum Physico-Mathematicarum
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Three volumes of collected works on mensuration, mathematics, music, mechanics, hydraulics, ballistics, ancient geometry, conics, optics, and systems of the world.
BP_Description_1: The works collected here report the culmination of Mersenne's 25 year-long study and investigation into a wide range of topics in Mixed Mathematics; that is, the application of arithmetic and geometry to physics, mechanics, astronomy, music, optics, and conic sections. The <i>Cogitata<i> and the <i>Universae Geometriae<i>  were assembled and published late in his life, Mersenne being 56 when they appeared. He died two years later. From his friar's cell in Paris, he had kept current of most developments in natural philosophy, contributed to mathematics and optics, and struggled to form an amalgam of new ideas that had arisen from experiment, and traditional Peripatetic teaching. Both works show three aspects of Mersenne's thought and work. First, Mersenne held that experimental facts were paramount, and stood above all theorizing. He showed how the reality of these facts must be demonstrated, and their number and strength multiplied by experiment. Many of the pages of the <i>Cogitata<i> are devoted to this endeavor. Second, with the help of his younger mathematician colleague, Gilles Personne de Roberval, Mersenne was able to cast experimental facts into what would now be called mathematical models, attempting to build theories of the physical world. Third, Mersenne strove to make things clear to the reader. This included adding examples, corollaries and extensions, and monita or advice about difficult points. Mersenne's writings also show that he held figures to be important, however complicated, in visualizing a problem and understanding its solution.||The <i>Universae Geometriae<i> of 1644 is a reworking and extension of his <i>Synopsis Mathematica<i> of 1626, a collection of classical and recent texts on mathematics and mechanics. Even at that early date, Mersenne had established an extensive network of correspondents from all over Europe. Information from this network and Mersenne's own study and experiments form the basis for the revision and the extension in the <i>Universae Geometriae<i> of 1644. From the earlier work of 1626, Mersenne includes treatises of Archimedes, Theodosius, Maurolyco, and Apollonius. In the 1644 work the following are included: Euclid's Elements, Ramus' Geometry, Mersenne's own Cosmographia, Mydorge's Conics, Pappus of Alexandria, and extended optics work by Mersenne, Walter Warner, and Hobbes. The <i>Universae Geometriae<i> is a detailed summary of what was held as venerably true and what was new in mathematics and physics in mid-17th century Europe. As such it is a reference work that would be consulted for 50 years, the last significant reference being by de Challes in his <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> of 1690.||The <i>Cogitata<i>  and the <i>Universae Geometriae<i> form Volumes 1 and 2 of a series (though not labeled as such) of three of Mersenne‚Äôs late works. The <i>Novarum Observationum<i> of 1647 is a supplement to the two earlier works and is explicitly labeled as Volume III. A much shorter work, it is a collection of essays on mechanics, pneumatics, hydrostatics, navigation, mensuration, and a consideration of Aristarchus' heliocentric theory. In his Preface, Mersenne states that the <i>Novarum Observationum<i> continues of the <i>Cogitata<i> and this third volumes takes into account new thoughts and experiments, and information from his trips to Italy during 1644-1645 and to southern France in 1646.||There are two important characteristics of the works collected here: Mersenne's rejection of metaphysics as a foundation for physical science, and the role he sees for natural philosophy in defending orthodox Christianity and refuting the rising tide of religious heterodoxy. Regarding the first, he departed from Descartes' ideas and became one of the most modern natural philosophers in early 17th-century France. The tension implied in the second did not prevent Mersenne from becoming an important promoter of Galileo's ideas, including heliocentrism, in France.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Cogitata<i>  is dedicated to the General of the Minims, Fr. Lorenzo da Spezzano in an epistle, followed by a General Preface that defines terms and list problems, followed by a table of contents. There are five treatises. 1: On weights, measures, and numismatics of Greece, Rome, France, Palestine, and elsewhere. 40 pages. 2: Hydraulics and Pneumatics. This is the earliest attempt of Mersenne to mathematicise physical phenomena and covers a wide range of water-related topics. 174 pages. 3: Four books on: Navigation on and under water, The Magnet, Theory and Practice of Harmony, Musical Instruments. 146 pages. 4: Theoretical and Practical Mechanics. 96 pages. 5: Ballistics, covering the launch and trajectory of cannon and arrows, military bombs, rope properties, and several optical topics. 140 pages.||The <i>Universae Geometriae<i> begins with a Preface and Mathematical Dictionary and Topical Index. There are six sections. 1: The 15 Elements of Euclid in Commandino's translation along with three additional by Fran√ßois de Foix-Candale. 64 pages. 2: Twenty-seven books on geometry by  Pierre de La Ram√©e (Peter Ramus). 27 pages. 3: Archimedes work on the sphere and the cylinder, conics, and other short works. With supplements from Snell and Kepler on cyclometric proportions and the squaring of the parabola. 4: Theodosius of Bithynia, Menelaus Of Alexandria, and Francesco Maurolyco on the sphere. 165 pages 4: Cosmographia by Mersenne, 5: Apollonius of Perga on conics, Claude Mydorge on conics, and Centers of Gravity. 216 pages. 6: Optics, with the first five books by Mersenne, book 6 by English mathematician and natural philosopher Walter Warner, and book 7 being the <i>Tractatus Opticus<i> of Thomas Hobbes. 120 pages.||The <i>Novarum Observationum<i> is in 25 chapters covering a wide range of topics that had long interested Mersenne. 1: Physical phenomena, use of the microscope, ballistics, and center of gravity. 2-3: Weights and measures. 4-5: Problems in water and the vacuum. 6-7: Problems in air, barometers, underwater work. 8: Percussion. 9-13: Free fall, moving bodies, motion experiments. 14: Sound and ballistics experiments made while traveling. 15-16: Free fall, more experiments with material from Galileo and Torricelli. 17: Projectiles. 18: Cylinders and springs. 19: Free fall and the work of Italian mathematician Giovanni Battista Baliani. 20: Harmony. 21: Aspects of number theory. 22: Musical Pitch. 23: Errata. 24: Travelogue to the south of France. 25: Vacuum experiments with tubes and liquids.||The optical material in the <i>Cogitata<i> is contained in the treatise on Ballistics.  Proposition XXV of the Ballistica presents Thomas Hobbes theory of the nature of light. For Hobbes, light propagations by the expansion and contraction of the light source, producing motion in the medium which is transmitted to the eye. Analogies with light, including light speed, reflection, and refraction are presented. Descartes' sine law of refraction is reported, but is explained using Hobbes' theory of light and, importantly, not Descartes' physics.||The seven books of optics in the <i>Universae Geometriae<i> begins with a Preface to the Reader that gives an overview of the material. It includes a figure of eye with an accurate positioning of components. This is clearly from Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> of 1619. Accompanying the figure is an explanation of image formation by the cornea and lens on the retina, clearly following Kepler. Book 1 gives definitions for light, luminous bodies, shadows, and colors. The structure of the eye, vision, aspects of visual perception are presented. Book 2 covers catoptrics, and mirrors in the shapes of the standard conics. Book 3 covers dioptrics, lenses, and the various types of telescopes. Book 4 is on parallax. Book 5 is on perspective. Book 6 presents problems in refraction, and their solution. This is a posthumous publication of a work of Walter Warner. Book 7 is the <i>Tractatus Opticus<i> of Thomas Hobbes, presenting his theory of light, including its nature, propagation, reflection, and refraction. It is here that Hobbes presents his idea of the light ray as a physical entity with finite extent.||In all of this optics material, Mersenne presents only results. The definitions and theorems presented in the proposition are not proved, merely stated. That Mersenne presents Kepler's, Warner's, and Hobbes' views on refractions aligns with Mersenne‚Äôs notion that seeking the truth requires that various data and points of view be presented and examined. A similar apparent conflict exits in Mersenne presentation of both Witelo's perspectivist explanation of vision based on intromission of visual species into the eye in Book 1, and the Keplerian formulation of retinal images presented in Book 3. By presenting multiple theories on these and other aspects of light and vision, and showing how they can be compatible, Mersenne attempted to establish a bridge between new developments and Scholastic teaching in optics.
BP_Reference(s): Mersenne and Mixed Mathematics|Malet, A., Cozzoli, D.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 2010, pp 1-8.||The Development of Mersenne‚Äôs Optics|Cozzoli, D.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 2010, pp 9-25.||<i>The Order of Minims in Seventeenth-Century France<i>|Whitmore, P.J.S.|Matinus Nijhoff, The Hague, 1967, 367 pp, NB: pp 140-154.||<i>Mersenne: le grand minime<i>|Beaulieu, A.|Fondation Nicolas-Claude Fabri de Peiresc , Brussels, 1995, 379 pp.
BP_Title: F. Marini Mersenni Minimi, Cogitata Physico-mathematica. In quibus tam naturae quam artis effectus admirandi certissimis demonstrationibus explicantur.; Universae Geometriae, Mixtaeque Mathematicae Synopsis, et Bini Refractionum Demonstratarum Tractatus. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Ten books on the natural magic of Light and Shadow. Two books deal with light, color, and vision in Aristotelian terms, seven books deal with horology, and one book deals with the metaphysics of light and light-related phenomena including optical illusions, mirrors, lenses, and the camera obscura.
BP_Description_1: Athanasius Kircher was visited in Rome by Marin Mersenne in 1644 as Kircher, who by then was known throughout Europe, was finishing the <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i>. It and other topics engaged both scholars, particularly as this was Kercher's first book on natural philosophy. Since 1630 he had produced seven books, each becoming evermore elaborate, encyclopedic, and costly. <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> appeared in 1645 and was the most elaborate thus far. it contained nearly 1000 pages of facts, imaginings, devices, and topics--however distantly related--regarding light and shadow, augmented with 36 plates of figures, 41 pages of tables, and about 480 in-text drawings. Dazzled, perhaps by the book's elaborateness, it had been approved by two Jesuit censors, both literary men, neither with the understanding necessary to review the contents. And so, the book went to press unfiltered by anyone with a knowledge of optics. But even by mid 18th century standards, 'optics' would not have been considered the principal topic of Kircher's book. As the title makes clear, it is about Light and Shadow, not optics; Perspectiva, Alhazen, Witelo, and Euclid are given only glancing mention. At the end of his preface to the reader, Kircher states he did not want to write a theoretical work and apologizes to his mathematical colleagues for neglecting the material's rigor, especially geometric optics. Kircher is more interested in phenomena and applications.||The disparate, elaborate, compilational nature of <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> is an expression of a view of knowledge and the world. Kircher believed all human knowledge was linked, is derived from divine wisdom, could be manifested by natural or artificial magic (what today would be called technology), and, following the medieval philosopher Ramon Llull, could be comprehended if the correct organizing framework could be found. The book is not so much structured by its content as it is bound together by--and freighted with--symbolism, Christian Kabbalah, metaphysics, and references to and use of ancient languages. The last is an aspect of Kircher's belief in a single ancient language, his deep interest in philology, and responsible for the strange, Greek-based neologisms in many of the book's section titles.||The elaborate nature of the book made it expensive and limited its audience. Its reception by European scholars was generally negative, expecting as they were a book on optics. It did not help that the book contained what purported to be a geometric method for squaring the circle; natural philosophers and mathematicians across Europe hooted their derision. However strange and unfiltered its content, the book presents the baroque culture of esotericism, natural magic, and the desire to overlay the natural world with an elaborate interconnected structure that spanned history, culture, and geography. Kircher's influence in this regard would be most apparent in his student Gaspar Schott's <i>Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis<i> of 1657. Editions of <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> appeared in 1646 and 1671. There are two states to the first edition, one with the title page dated 1645 (which is very rare) and one dated 1646. Some copies have a title page for the second half of the book. The emblematic frontispiece was by Pierre Miotte.
BP_Description_2: <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> contains ten books on subjects related--however tenuously--to Light and Shadow and a final section on optical cryptography and metaphysical epilogue. The meaning of section or book titles are given, rather than direct or literal translation of section titles, since most consist of words Kircher invented.  Book 1: The Nature of Light and Shadow.  Book 2: On Radiation Propagation. Book 3: Curious Gnomics. Book 4: Various Gnomic Horologies. Book 5: Anamorphosis Gnomics. Book 6: Gnomic Shapes for Astrolabes. Book 7: Gnomics by Reflection. Book 8: Gnomics by Refraction. Book 9: Cosmographical Gnomics. Book 10: The Natural Magic of Light and Shadow. Book 1 has three parts. It begins with light sources, including the sun, moon, stars, fire, animal and vegetable light, and light from minerals. This is followed by a 'Scholastic Disquisition' on the nature and effects of light, much of which was lifted from Fortunio Liceti's <i>De Luminis Natura<i> of 1640. The second part of Book 1 considers shadow and its applications including the production of shadow, degrees of shadow, and gnomic shadows. Shadow for Kircher is not the lack of light, but an entity per se. The third part of Book 1 considers colors. This includes various color source and phenomena including atmospheric, sea, refractive, mineral, and animal color. It is here that Kircher presents his color diagram, derived from Francois d' Aguil√≥n's <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> of 1613 and adhering to the Scholastic teaching that color arises from a blending of white and black. Book 2 has two parts. It begins with a general consideration of the propagation of 'radiations' from objects; the prototype is light as propagated visible species rendering objects visible when their species are received by the eye. This notion is applied to sound and odor as well. The second part of Book 2 deals with the eye and vision. Though modern ocular anatomy is briefly described, no details are given; most of the material is devoted to projections and scenography. Book 10 is a survey of applications, phenomena, and devices and has three parts. The first part shows the use of reflection and refraction in sundials of various forms. The second part considers projections of various forms and refraction. The camera obscura is described but not explained and it is here that lenses are discussed and Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604 is quoted, leading to a discussion of the telescope. The third part is a general consideration of catoptrics. This includes the nature and properties of plane, spherical, parabolic, and hyperbolic mirrors. Burning mirrors and applications for 'optical wonders' using plane, multiple, and segmented mirrors are presented.||The material in Books 1, 2, and 10 is entirely descriptive; phenomena or apparatus are simply presented, there is rarely any explanation of cause or operation. Mathematics is very rarely used, and then never more than elementary geometry. Aside from some of the material in Books 1, 2, and 10, the majority of the book is on horology.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Gilles Personne de Roberval (1602-1675) French mathematician, founding member of the French Academy of Sciences.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first two sections of the text of the 1638 edition, considerably augmented with material on light and shadow, rendered into Latin, and edited by Mersenne.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Francois Niceron's <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> is a partial reworking and translation into Latin, of his <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> of 1638. Like the earlier version, it is a detailed, geometrically practical guide to anamorphosis. That is, the production of distorted perspective images on plane or curved surfaces that require viewing points. As the Latin title implies, Niceron came to consider anamorphosis a type of natural magic or wonder-working. In his Preface to the reader, Niceron set out his plan for reworking the text of 1638: A section giving the principles of geometry followed by revised books one and two, and these followed by a section on a new scenographic instrument and an appendix on Light and Shadow. There was to be a second part containing revisions of books three and four of the 1638 text on catoptric and dioptric anamorphosis. Niceron worked on the Thaumaturgus Opticus for eight years after the publication of 1638 but his early death in 1646 prevented him from completing what was to be the second half of the work. His fellow Minim member Marin Mersenne edited the manuscript. Niceron's plan must have been fixed from the start, for the revised book one contains references to books three and four. The geometric prelude that precedes Book One is a close Latin translation of the French original. The reworked Books One and Two are considerable expansions of the originals, with more theorems, propositions, and detail.||Niceron had continued to work on practical anamorphosis and the <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> since <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> of 1638, and so his experience had deepened the detail and examples he brought to the revised work was considerably richer. In 1638 the first two books were accompanied by 10 plates of figures, in 1646 by 35 plates. The last eight plates are devoted to Niceron's scenography and his appendix on light and shadow. The title frontispiece was drawn by Simon Vouet and engraved by Charles Audran. The portrait, executed by Michel Lasne, shows Niceron not long before his death.||With <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i>, Niceron's significant advances in perspective projection methods over his predecessors Salomon de Caus and Jean-Louis Vaulezard are more developed and reach a wider audience. Edited by Mersenne, it appeared posthumously in 1646 and edited by Roberval in 1663.
BP_Description_2: Jean-Francois Niceron's <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> begins with Geometric Preliminaries, followed by two books on anamorphosis, then a description of a scenographic instrument, and ends with an appendix on light and shadow. The Preliminaries set out geometric basics in 8 Propositions and two appendices. Book 1: Principles of Perspective. Describes a general method for the linear perspective of solid figures, included the complex cases where the figures contact the horizontal plane only along a line or at a point. The process is fundamentally geometric and presented in 12 axioms, 37 Propositions, and a synopsis. Each proposition is demonstrated with one or more figures. Examples of the process are give for several solid objects. Book 2: Planar Anamorphosis. Projections are introduced for distorting a regular image so that it appears undistorted only when viewed from a particular viewing point. The undistorted rectangular grid of the image is mapped into a grid distorted by projection. The process is presented in 12 Propositions accompanied by figures. The material in both books is presented with a brevity that requires close reading and careful reference to the many figures in the plates. The Universal Scenograph describes a device of Niceron's invention that allows by direct viewing the drawing of an object in linear or anamorphic projection. It operates as an optical-mechanical equivalent of Durer's perspective grid. The Appendix on Light and Shadow demonstrates techniques for drawing shadows in linear perspective. Interestingly, it includes not only umbral shadows from point light sources but also penumbral shadows from area light sources such as windows. Both the Universal Scenograph and the Appendix are accompanied by plates of figures.

Niceron: Reconstructing a 17th century optical toy|Hunt, J.L, Sharp, J.|<i>American Journal of Physics<i>, Vol 79, No 10, 2011, pp 1023-1029.||<i>Anamorphic Art<i>|Baltrusaitis, J., Strachan, W.J., translator|Cambridge, 1977.||<i>Jean Fran√ßois Niceron: Prospettiva, Catottrica & Magia Artificiale<i>|De Rosa, A., editor|ARACNE editrice, Rome, 2013, 472 p.||<i>The Order of Minims in Seventeenth-Century France<i>|Whitmore, P.J.S.|Matinus Nijhoff, The Hague, 1967, 367 pp, NB: pp 155-162.
BP_Title: R.P. Ionannis Francisci Niceronis Parisini, ex ord. Minim. Thaumaturgus Opticus, seu Admiranda: Optices per radium directum; Catoptrices, per reflexum e politis corporibus, planis, cylindricis, conicis, polyedris, polygonnis & aliis; Dioptrices, per refractum in diaphanus. In quibus Scenogaphia seu Perspectivae communis fundamenta, praxes facillimas & demonstrationes, exhibita etiam ex illius praescripto omnis generis solida regularia simplicia & composita, & irregularia multiformia, polyedra, stellata, perforata, nec non Architecturae civilus & militaris diagrammata, & alia in graphide spectacula non iniucunda: certissimae quoque & expeditissimae dantur regulae, pro triplici videndi ratione directa reflexa & fracta, figuras & imagines quascunque deformes & improportionatas in quacunque superficie delineandi, ita ut ex certo spectatae puncto videnantur venuste proportionatae, picturaeque & symmetriae legibus non dissonae; imo & cuicunque objecto data simillimae. Opus curiosum & utile Pictoribus, Architectis, Statuariis, Sculptoribus, Caelatoribus, and quibuscumaue aliis, quorum opera in delineandi studio posita est. PARS PPRIMA  De iis quae spectant ad Visionem Directam. As Eminnum Cardinalem MAZARINUM.
BP_Title English Translation: From the Reverend Father John Francis Niceron of Paris, Order of Minims. The Miracle-Worker Optician, or Wonderful: Optics, by Direct Rays; Catoptrics, by Reflection from Polished Bodies Planar, Cylindrical, Conical, Polyhedral, Polygonal, and others; Dioptrics, by Refraction in Transparent Bodies. In which the foundations, simple practice and demonstrations of scenographics or ordinary perspective are presented, and from that precept drawings all types of simple regular and compound solids, multiform irregular stellated and perforated polyhedra, as well as civil architetural and military geometrical constructions, and other things can be done by instrument not disagreeably. Certain and expeditious rules are also given when, by three-fold seeing (direct, reflected, and refracted), figures and images however deformed and improportionate, are to be deliniated on any surface, and thus when viewed from a certain point are see as graceful, proportionate, and by laws of symmetry and painting not dissonant; and no given presentation is the same. A careful work useful for painters, architects, statuaries, sculptors, engravers and any others whose work is delinating with care what is before them. The first part: regarding that seen by direct vision.  To His Eminance Cardinale Mazarin.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Minim friar, student of Marin Mersenne, an artist of note, and keenly interested in the mathematics of perspective. [Royal professor of mathematics at the Coll√®ge de Maistre Gervais and Ramus Chair at the Coll√®ge Royal de France]
