BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Exhaustive mathematical and practical treatment of catoptric and dioptric sundials, including lenses and related instrumentation. The most elaborate and detailed book on solar horology ever produced. Also promulgated an influential mechanical kinematic theory of light propagation.
BP_Description_1: Emanuel Maignan wrote the <i>Perspectiva Horaria<i> near the end of his stay at Santa Trinita Dei Monti in Rome, from 1636 to 1650. A mathematical autodidact in earlier years, he had been stationed there to teach what he had learned. While there, he developed an interest in solar horography, studied it carefully, and experimented extensively with mirrors, lenses, and projections. It is reported that his cell looked more like a work shop or a laboratory. His interests in mirrors and lenses extended into the nature and propagation of light and this broad interest made for a wide interpretation of what was part of solar horography.||Maignan's text was a significant advance in the art of catoptric and dioptric sundials, and though ostensibly about solar horography, it also contained important advances regarding a mechanical theory of light. His source for basic ideas regarding light was Hobbes' <i>Tractatus Opticus<i> published by Marin Mersenne in his <i>Universae Geometriae, Mixtaque, Synopsis<i> of 1644. Building on Hobbes, Maignan proposed a mechanical, kinematic theory of light and its propagation.||As it happened, the <i>Perspectiva Horaria<i> became widely known and cited in the 17th century not for its solar horography, but rather for its material on the nature and propagation of light and its mechanical theory of reflection and refraction. It was read by and influenced Francesco Grimaldi, Pierre de Fermat, Robert Boyle, David Gregory, Jean-Jacques Dortous de Mairain, Isaac Barrow, Christian Huygens, Robert Hooke, and Ignace Pardies; in some cases, if only to argue for an alternative. The <i>Perspectiva Horaria<i> was the most important way in which the mechanical kinematic theory of light, reflection, and refraction was propagated in Europe. Editions appeared in 1648, 1725, and 1748.
BP_Description_2: Emanuel Maignan's <i>Perspectiva Horaria<i> is in four books. Book 1: Theoretical Part, or Gnomic Horography. Including the meaning of time, notions of time in different nations, and systems of measurement of time. Basic solar horology including refraction of the sunlight by the atmosphere, a theory of shadows, and the projection of shadows onto plane and spherical surfaces. Book 2: Optical Horography. Including direct or classical sundials on a plane with a gnomon. Practical, detailed instructions for obtaining a plane surface and erecting the gnomon perpendicularly. How to construct inclined planes, calculate the meridian, and determine the elevation of the sun. Instructions in this book are particularly detailed and are accompanied by many figures. Book 3: Catoptric Horography. Methods for projection of sundial maps onto spherical surfaces with detailed instructions on the construction of the instruments required. Sundials that project the solar image onto a vaulted roof and those that admit a 'solar spot' moving on sundial map. The astrolabe painted on the ceiling in the Palazzo Spadani illustrated with a large engraving. The problems of perspective that vault projections cause. Book 4: Dioptric Horography. Maignan presents a mechanical kinematic theory of light, adopted from Hobbes and considerably augmented. Light is regarded as a luminous, fiery effluvium, traveling by 'ray-fronts' moving through a subtle medium. Light speed is shown to be finite and from a kinematic analysis of a ray-front encountering a surface, a theory of specular reflections was obtained. From this same purely mechanical basis, Maignan also established a sine law of refraction. The rest of the book links  dioptrical instruments to the sundial, including determining the angle of refraction. Instructions are give for the construction of the bowl-type of dial which was aligned by means of a magnetic compass. This was the first step towards the miniature portable dials, important as navigational aids in the eighteenth century. The book includes descriptions of instruments and instructions for the figuring and polishing of lenses.||Maignan's text is incomparably clearer, more detailed, and more practical than any previous work on projective horography; direct, catoptrical, or dioptrical. Though the horographical material is elaborately geometric, the material on the theory of light and its reflection and refraction is less so, being more descriptive. Nevertheless, the mechanical theory of light presented in the <i>Perspectiva Horaria<i> would be widely influential for 50 years.
BP_Reference(s): Emmanuel Maignan|Whitmore, P.J.S.|In: <i><i>The Order of Minims in Seventeenth-Century France<i><i>|Nijhof, The Hague, 1967, 367 pp, NB: pp 163-186.||Kinematic Optics: A Study of the Wave Theory of Light in the Seventeenth Century|Shapiro, D.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1973, pp 134-266.||Emmanuel Maignan|In: <i>Biographie Gnomoniche<i>|Severino, N.|Roccasecca, 2011, 404 pp, NB: pp 369-401.||Emmanuel Maignan: Su Vida, Su Obra, Su Influencia|Ce√±al, R.|<i>Revista de Estudios Politicos<i>, Vol 46, 1952, pp 111-149.||<i>Picturing Space, Displacing Bodies: Anamorphosis in Early Modern Theories of Perspective<i>|Massey, L.|Pennsylvania State University Press, 2007, 192 pp.||<i>The Order of Minims in Seventeenth-Century France<i>|Whitmore, P.J.S.|Matinus Nijhoff, The Hague, 1967, 367 pp, NB: pp 163-186.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A nonce volume of Marci of Kronland major works on mechanics and optics, including the rainbow.
BP_Description_1: A nonce volume of Marci of Kronland's major works on mechanics and optics. Containing: <i>Idearum Operatri<i> of 1635, <i>Thaumantias Liber de Arcu Coelesti<i> of 1648, <i>De Proportione Motus Figurarum Recti<i> of 1648, and <i>De Proportione Motus seu Regula Sphygmica<i> of 1639. The <i>Thaumantias<i> was his first and principal work in optics, written to explain the rainbow. The more brief <i>Dissertatio de Natura Iridis<i> followed in 1650. Marci's explanation of the rainbow encompasses general considerations of color such as prismatic color, thin film colors from soap bubbles, the nature of white light, and light's propagation. Though Marci cites Alhazen, Roger Bacon, Witelo, Marolyco, and Kepler., he was unaware of the work of Theodoric of Freiberg or Ren√© Descartes, and so independently and correctly determined the refractions and reflections in water drops that produce the primary and secondary rainbows. Marci's work with prismatic colors anticipated Newton's but did not take the final step regarding white light heterogeneity. Though Marci rejected the Peripatetic idea that color arose from blending light and dark he was essentially a Scholastic, and his style of thought, manner of presentation, and assumptions regarding the properties of light are those of late peripatetic teaching. The entire work is framed in classic form and is pedantically tedious:  64 theorem, proofs, examples, and problems.  Caught in and isolated by the 30-years war, Marci's optics work was not widely known, though Huygens mentions Marci in his correspondence. By the time the British scientific establishment became aware of his work and attempted to make contact, Marci had been dead for two years.||A reprint of the <i>Thaumantias<i>, with commentary, was produced at Prague in 1968.
BP_Description_2: The sections dealing with light and color are as follows. General Introduction; On Condensation and Rarefaction in General; On the Effects of Gunpowder and Fire; On the Transient Nature of Gold and its Effects; On the Nature and Cause of Refraction in General; On the Condensation of Light; Whether the Condensation of Light is the same as Intensity; The way by which the Luminous Sphere is Produced; The Triangular [Prism] Rainbow; Whether the Color Purple is Created by a Ray more Perpendicular than the Red Ray; Of Different Colors; The Nature of Colors White and Black; Tincture of Lignum Nephriticum; What, How and by what Cause Comes Reflection; The Phenomena of the Triangle [Prism] and their Causes; On the Location of Images and their Cause; On Multiplication of Species in the same Medium; Whether Light is Effected as a Form of Fire, and Whether all Light Sources are Fiery; Whether Light and Luminous Appearances from All Sources are one Species; On the Contraction and Distraction of Objects; On The Coloration of Objects; On the Halo or Corona; On the Corona of Lamps; The Color of Aroras and Clouds; Assessment of Other Opinions Regarding the Rainbow; Bubbles and Foams and their Colors; Another Opinion Regarding the Secondary Rainbow; Whether the Angle of the Conical Rays Containing the Rainbow is a Right Angle; Great Rainbow; A Triangular Armillary; The Atmosphere.||The early sections deal with fire and fire related topics since Marci held that fire and light were manifestations of the same fundamental fiery substance. He considered light has a substance that could be compressed, its state of compression proportional to its intensity. Its state of compression was altered by the material in which it traveled and Marci used this to explain reflection and refraction. Light contained color and a motive power by which propagated from a source in a spherical way, and when it struck a reflecting object it re-radiated again in another, secondary luminous sphere. Marci explained color as the direct result of refraction; that is, refraction itself is colorogenic and the angle of refraction determined the color. The smaller the angle of refraction the redder the color, the greater the angle of refraction the  bluer the color. This meant that the angle of incidence also was part of color generation. Color was inherent in light, and need only be 'refracted out of it' to appear. Marci experimented extensively with prisms (his "Triangles") and produced rainbows by prismatic refraction--what he called 'Iris Trigonia.' His experiments showed that once refraction had produced a color, that color was immutable and refraction would not alter it. This was something that Newton would later insist on as proving his theory of color and his view of heterogeneous white light.||Marci produced a correct theory of how the primary and secondary rainbows are formed, using two refractions and a reflection to alter the direction of propagation, produced the bow shape, and generate colored bands. He used this same theory explained halos and coronae and, assuming bubble and foam were filled with very tiny water drops, used it to explain the thin film colors in soap bubbles.
BP_Reference(s): Ioannes Marcus Marci (1595-1667)|Aiton, E.J.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 26, No 2, 1970, pp 153-164.||Chymical Wonders of Light: J. Marcus Marci's Seventeenth-Century Bohemian Optics|Garber, M.D.|<i>Early Science and Medicine<i>, Vol 10, No 4, 2005, pp 478-509.
BP_Title: Thaumantias: Liber de arcu coelesti deque colorum apparentium natura ortu et causis. In quo pellucidi Opticae fontes a sua scaturigine, ab his vero colorigeni riui deriuantur. Ducibus Geomteria, et Physica Hermetoperipatetica. Author Iaonne Maro Marci, Philosophiae et Medicine Doctore et eiusdem Medicine Primario Professore in Universitate Pragensi, SCM Medico Cubiculario et in Bohemia Physico Seniore.
BP_Title English Translation: Iris: A book on the nature, source and causue of the apparent colors of the rainbow. In which transparent optics is derived as the principal source of its colored rills. Drawn from Geometry and Peripatetic Physics. By Ioannes Marcus Marci, Philosopher and Medical Doctor as well as Professor of Medicine at the University of Prague. Royal Medical Chamberlain and Senior Natural Philosopher in Bohemia.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Frans van Schooten (1615-1660) Dutch mathematician and professor at the University of Leiden.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: van Schooten's Latin translation, with added explanations and commentary, of Descartes' <i>La g√©om√©trie<i>. Algebra and geometry combined to give Analytic Geometry, in a language and explanatory style that produced a book of wide influence.
BP_Description_1: Van Schooten knew Ren√© Descartes in 1632 and read his <i>La G√©om√©trie<i> while it was still unpublished. Like virtually all other readers of the original French text of La G√©om√©trie, Van Schooten found it difficult to understand. Nevertheless, he recognized its importance and so reworked the text, added clarifying explanations and commentaries, and translated the result into Latin. It was from Van Schooten's Latin text that Europe's mathematical community learned of Descartes's work.  In the decade following the appearance of the 1649 text, Van Schooten worked with other mathematicians to produce a two volume work containing greatly extended commentaries. This two volume work appeared in 1659 and 1651. It was from this edition that Leibniz and Newton would learn of Descartes's analytic geometry.||Descartes‚Äôs friend Florimond de Beaune wrote the introduction to the 1649 edition. Editions of the Latin text appeared in 1649, 1659, and 1683.
BP_Description_2: Descartes's La G√©om√©trie is in three books. Book I applies algebra to geometry to solve many of classical construction problems in geometry; finding points, line lengths, and curves. Book II presents analytic geometry more fully, dealing with the algebraic expression of geometric curves, their use, and their manipulation. Part of this book deals with optics and the use of coordinate geometry to solve optical problems. It is here that Descartes the anaclastic surfaces now called Descartes' Ovals.  Book III takes up geometry construction problems again but in greater detail and with the full power of analytic geometry. Descartes formulates construction problems algebraically, solves the algebraic equations, and then interprets the solutions in geometric terms.||In Descartes's original text he claimed that 'Any problem in geometry can easily be reduced to such terms that a knowledge of the length of certain straight lines is sufficient for construction.' He showed how arithmetic, algebra, and geometry could be combined to solve problems. Descartes believed that the systematic application of algebra to what is now called coordinate geometry could produce solutions to problems that geometry alone was powerless to do. Algebraic coordinate geometry had a generality and mechanizing-like process that gave it great power. He used it, for example, to demonstrate procedures for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing line segments and for graphically determining roots of equations. The extreme concision and lack of explanation made the text difficult to follow; thus the value and influence of Van Schooten's translation, examples, and commentary.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Geometry of Ren√© Descartes<i>|Smith, D.E, and Latham, M.|Dover, 1954.
BP_Title: Geometria a Renato Des Cartes Anno 1637 Gallice edita; nunc autem Cum Notis Florimundi de Beaune, In Curia Blaesensi Consiliarii Regii, in linguam Latinam versa, & commentariis illustrata, Opera atque studio Fancisci a Schooten, Leydensis in Academia Lugduno-Batava, Mathesoes Professoris, Belgice docentis.
BP_Title English Translation: Geometry by Ren√© Descartes, published in French in 1637; But now, with the notes of Florimond de Beaune Royal Counselor in the Court of Blois, translated into Latin and Elucidated by Commenarties, by the Effort and Care of Frans van Schooten of Leiden, Professor of Mathematics in the University of Leiden, Docent of Belgium.
BP_Biographical Statement: French philosopher and mathematician. Resident of the Dutch Republic, revolutionary founder of rationalism, prolific writer.
BP_Provenance: Signature of Conrad Hanfling on verso of free endpaper.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mathematical explication of conic sections; their properties and applications to optics, gravitational motion, and other mechanical problems. Famous for presenting Galileo's work on parabolic projectile motion, a way to determine the focal length of a thin lens, and considering how Archimedes' burning mirror might have worked.
BP_Description_1: Second, posthumous edition of Bonaventura Cavalieri's <i>Lo Specchio Ustorio<i> of 1632. Cavalieri's dedication is replaced by a brief letter by Urbano Davisi, but his letter to the reader is retained. The text is an unedited reprint of that of 1632 and using the same figures. Cavalieri hoped to emulate the methods of his great model, Galileo Galilei: abandoning Scholastic teaching, adhering to mathematical rigor, and working to establish a new physics. Cavalieri cites works on mirrors by Roger Bacon and Witelo, among others, but believes Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604 and the <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611 had swept aside the old optics. Cavalieri's title belies the nature and extensive content of the book. He analyzed four conic curves: sphere, ellipse, parabola, and hyperbola. The method of analysis was the law of specular (equal angular) reflection, which he takes as a given.  Cavalieri is not so much interested in the nature of the curves themselves, but how they transform light rays by specular reflection. He extends his analysis using the law of specular reflection beyond the luminous; he writes: ‚ÄòWe shall accept [this] principle not only with respect to light but also to motion as well as sound‚Ä¶heat, cold and in short for anything the motion of which is in straight lines.‚Äô Though he is interested in and considers burning mirrors, Cavalieri extends his analysis of conic surfaces to involve any motive or radiant process that proceeds rectilinearly: motion, sound, heat, and cold. He was the first to define conic section properties in terms of the specular law of reflection, bring rays onto the curves from both convex and concave sides and noting the patterns and intersections of the reflected rays. <i>Lo Specchio Ustorio<i> shows the importance optics attained in 17th century as expressing the power and applicability of the geometric analysis of specular reflection. In was in this manner that Cavalieri assessed the practicality of burning mirrors, dismissed the extravagant claims of Della Porta, was the first to demonstrate that in the absence of air resistance the ballistic trajectory of a cannon ball was a parabola, and described a reflective telescope.||The most lasting influence of Cavalieri's <i>Lo Specchio Ustorio<i> was its derivation of the parabolic cannon ball trajectory and its designs for reflecting telescopes. Though not widely cited, it was a direct influence on Marin Mersenne and his optical work. The book first appeared in 1632 and was reprinted in 1650.
BP_Description_2: <i>Lo Specchio Ustorio<i> has 55 chapters. Chapters 1-8 introduce the cone and its sections, from which Cavalieri's four conics are obtained. The process of generating each conic is described, their general application, and their history in solar horology and medieval Perspectiva. Chapters 9-20 describe the properties of the parabola, hyperbola, ellipse, and the circle. 'Properties' for Cavalieri means what the conics do to light ray propagation assuming that their surfaces are mirrors. These have to do with foci, caustics, images, path lengths. Chapters 21-23 covers the generation of surfaces from the conic sections and their properties. A general 'Table of Mirrors' is then given, describing how convex and concave mirrors formed from the conic surfaces affect and effect parallel, convergent, divergent light rays. Chapter 24 describes the use of the Table of Mirrors and presents a 'digression on refraction.' Chapters 25-27 consider burning mirrors of various types. Chapter 28 is devoted to the burning mirror of Archimedes. Chapter 29 is a similar consideration of Della Porta's mirror which he claimed could burn at any distance. Chapters 30-32 present Cavalieri's analysis of Archimedes' and Della Porta's mirrors, how they might have worked (or not) and what was their likely form. Chapters 33-36 consider the application of conic surface to the gathering and intensification of light and sound. It is here that Cavalieri presents his ideas for a mirror telescope. He notes that Galileo's convex and concave telescope lenses can be replaced with mirrors that produce the same convergence and divergence of light rays. Chapters 37-40 consider conic sections and motion. It is here that Cavalieri demonstrates the parabolic trajectory of a cannon ball. Chapters 41-51 present ways to construct (that is, draw) conic sections. Various methods are presented involving points, strings, and lines, as well as various criteria the curves must met. Chapters 52-55 discuss the relationships between the conics, their similarities, and distinguishing features.
BP_Reference(s): Bonaventura Cavalieri, Marin Mersenne, and the Reflecting Telescope|Ariotti, P.E.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 66, No 3, 1975, pp 302-321.||Lo 'Specchio Ustorio' di bonaventura Cavalieri|Baroncelli, G.|<i>Giornale Critiico della Filosofia Italiana<i>, Vol 3, No 6, 1983, pp153-172.
BP_Title: Lo specchio ustorio del P.F. Bonaventura Cavalieri Giesuato, overo trattato Delle Settioni Coniche, E di alcuni loro miralbili effetti Intorno al Lume, Caldo, Freddo, Suono, e Moto
BP_Title English Translation: The Burning Mirror of Father Bonaventura Cavalieri, that is, A Treatise on Conic Sections, and Some of their Remarkable Effects on Light, Heat, Cold, Sound, and Motion.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jesuati mathematician. Worked in optics, innovated in geometry, and developed the precursor to the calculus.
BP_Provenance: Occasional marginalia in Italian.
BP_Binding: Old Paper Over Boards, Spine Gilt
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1650 Cavalieri - Lo specchio ustorio - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: Nouvelles Observations et Conjectures sur l'Iris
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An explanation of the appearance, shape, and colors of the rainbow; Aristotelian in character and written as if Theodoric of Freiberg or Descartes had never existed.
BP_Description_1: <i>Nouvelles Observations et Conjectures sur l'Iris<i> appeared the year Ren√© Descartes died, 13 years after the appearance of <i>La Dioptrique<i> and <i>Les Meteores<i>, yet neither Descartes, his optics, or his analysis of the rainbow are mentioned in La Chambre's book. The analysis is entirely Aristotelian, with details added by La Chambre. That a modified Aristotelian explanation of the rainbow should appear in print so long after Descartes' clear analysis appeared in French in 1637 and in Latin 1644, is an important indication of the initial slow and limited reach of Descartes' optics. La Chambre's implied opposition to Descartes reflects the divide over Descartes' ideas and the position of some, but not all French natural philosophers. Jean Baptiste DuHamel, perpetual secretary of the Acad√©mie des Sciences, dismissed Descartes and supported La Chambre in his <i>De Meteoris et Fossilibus Libri Duo<i> of 1660, while the famed atomist Pierre Gassendi in his <i>Syntagma Philosophicum<i> of 1658 considered Descartes' explanation of the rainbow as the last word on the subject.||<i>Nouvelles Observations et Conjectures sur l'Iris<i> appeared at Paris in 1650 and again in 1662. For all of La Chambre's status and influence, he had a checkered reputation even in his own lifetime. The book must have sold poorly; the appearance in 1662 is a reissue of the sheets printed in 1650, with a new title page. A generation later, the Marquis Nicolas de Condorcet, dismissed La Chambre‚Äôs scientific efforts as without value and speculated that perhaps he escaped persecution for his unorthodox views only because his books had so little success even in his own time.
BP_Description_2: <i>Nouvelles Observations et Conjectures sur l'Iris<i> has three chapters: The Place of the Rainbow, The Colors of the Rainbow, The Shape of the Rainbow. Chapter 1 is brief and introduces in a negative way the characteristics of the rainbow; that is, where and how La Chambre considers it not be formed. Two types of reflection are introduced, that from mirrors and that from rough and uneven surfaces. These are used later in the explanation of the formation of the rainbow. Chapter 2, by far the longest with 13 Articles, considers color and the colors of the rainbow. Much of this chapter contains material that would later appear in La Chambre's La Lumiere of 1657. In addition to two types of reflectance, two types of transparent media are defined, establishing what La Chambre considers to be four kinds of light. Several articles deal with the general nature of color and the senses. Color is produced by the mixing of reflected and refracted light, and prismatic colors are explained by the mixing that takes place inside a prism or crystal of ice or water as light repeatedly reflects inside the prism, mixing with refracted light and finally exiting in a mixed, that is colored, state. Chapter 3 explains how the rainbow is formed and why it has the shape it does. For La Chambre, light from the sun is refracted and reflected in a subtle, crystalline material, producing colors. This colored light leaves this material and strikes distant clouds where it is reflected back to the observer.||There is no mathematics of any kind in the explanation, and the only reference to experiment or observation is La Chambre's mention of a rainbow he saw in 1625 with an angle of 60‚Å∞ (sic). The elaborately conjectural nature of the explanation of the rainbow--written as if Theodoric of Freiberg or Descartes had never existed--is startling, given the general state of natural philosophy at the time.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, 376 pp, NB: pp 225-232.
BP_Title: Nouvelles Observations et Coniectures sur l'iris
BP_Title English Translation: New Observations and Conjectures about the Rainbow
BP_Biographical Statement: Physican to Louis XIII and Louis XIV, founding member of the the Acad√©mie des Sciences, associate of Richelieu and Mazarin, confidant of Pierre de Fermat,and self-styled reader of human character.
BP_Provenance: Blind stamp of the Macclesfield Library on first four leaves.
BP_Collation: a‚Å¥ A‚Å¥(¬±A‚ÇÇ) B-Z‚Å¥ Aa-Gg‚Å¥(¬±Gg‚ÇÅ) Hh-Vv‚Å¥ Xx¬≤

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A significant expansion of Schwenter's 1636 work. Much of the optics section deals with optical illusions, phantasma, and projections.
BP_Description_1: Georg Harsd√∂rffer was a student of Daniel Schwenter and wrote expansions of the latter's <i>Delici√¶ Physico-Mathematic√¶<i> of 1636. In 1651 and 1653 Harsd√∂rffer produced two volumes to follow Schwenter's: <i>Deliti√¶ Philosophic√¶ Et Mathematic√¶ der Philosophischen und Erquickstuden, Zwenter and Dritter Theil<i>. Perhaps more than Schwenter‚Äôs work,  Harsd√∂rffer's was decidedly pedagogical and the most well-known baroque work of 'serious amusement.' In the forward, Harsd√∂rffer write of his hope that school masters would use his book to teach beginning students pleasantly. The 'Erquickstuden' of the title is 'an enlightening pleasure' and Harsd√∂rffer held it was possible to both entertain and instruct. As did Schwenter,  Harsd√∂rffer wrote in German, his audience being the educated lay reader and craftsman, not academics. And though his text was a recreational popularization of natural philosophy, it presented serious contemporary knowledge. He was particularly taken with optics and the illusions produced by those that knew something of that science. He cites Johannes Kepler, Marin Mersenne, Ren√© Descartes, Jan Amos Comenius, and Athanasius Kircher.||Editions of  Harsd√∂rffer's additional volumes appeared at NuÃàrnberg in 1651 and1653 and reprinted in 1677 and 1692.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Deliti√¶ Mathematic√¶ et Physic√¶<i> is in 16 Sections: Arithmetic, Geometry, Art of Stereometry or Measurement, Art of Music, Art of Seeing, Mirrors, Astronomy, Clockworks, Weighing, Motion, Fire, Air and Wind, Fountains, Writing, Architecture, Chemistry. Sections 5 and 6 present recreations related to optics. Section 5 (56 pages) presents 39 topics, beginning with a forward that outlines the general nature of light and vision, it's importance in literature and religious symbolism, and ends with a list of historical sources including Danti's translation of Heliodorus of Larrisa, Ptolemy, Alhazen, Witelo ('Tritellio'), John Peckham, Roger Bacon, Giambattista Della Porta, Robert Fludd, Ren√© Descartes, Samuel Marolois, and Athenasius Kircher. Topics 1-5 deal with light and vision, including Descartes vision analogy of a man and his stick. Topics 6-7 deal with perspective. Topics 8-11 deal with refraction, lenses, and images. Topics 12-15 deal with the camera obscura and the eye as its equivalent. Topics 16-24 deal with projects of various kinds including those using lenses. Topics 25-39 deal with vision, shadow, and color, including prismatic colors produced by a glass prism. Section 6 (36 pages) presents 29 topics beginning with a forward that outlines mirrors in history and their appearance in literature and religion. Topics 1-6 deal with the nature of glass, how mirrors are made, characteristics of good mirrors. Topic 7 deals with making a mirror from ice. Topics 8-15 deal with mirror making, curved mirrors of cones and cylinders, mirror anamorphosis, focus of mirrors, segmented burning mirrors, parabolic mirrors. Topic 16 discusses Archimedes burning mirror. Topics 17-29 deal with applications of mirrors including projecting light, mirrored rooms, multiple reflections, and projections.||All of the material is elementary and descriptive, with only the simplest geometry invoked very occasionally.
BP_Reference(s): The Poet And The Philosopher: Francis Bacon And Georg Philipp Harsd√∂rffer|Heinecke, B.|In: <i>Philosophies of Technology: Francis Bacon and his Contemporaries<i>, Brill, 2008, Vol 1, pp 373-409.||<i>Artful Science: Enlightenment Entertainment and the Eclipse of Visual Education<i>|Stafford, B.M.|MIT Press, Cambridge, 1994, pp - 41-46.||R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.||<i>Sources in Recreational Mathematics: An Annotated Bibliography<i>|Singmaster, D.|School of Computing, Information Systems and Mathematics, South Bank University, 2004.|https://www.puzzlemuseum.com/singma/singma6/SOURCES/singma-sources-edn8-2004-03-19.htm

In Two Parts: 500 Useful and Amusing Art Questions, Thoughtful Tasks; and for these, Basic and Correct Explanations from Athenasius Kircher, Pietro Bettino, Marin Mersenne, Ren√© Descartes, Orontio Fino, Marin Getaldiƒá, Cornelius Drebbel, Alessandro Tassoni, Sanctorius, Marci √† Kroland, and many other Mathematicians and Physicists. Assembled by Georg Philip Harsd√∂rffern.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Gilles Personne de Roberval (1602-1675) French mathematician, founding member of the French Academy of Sciences.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Roberval's editing of Mersenne's final optical text, presenting what he considered the best theories of the nature and properties of light, vision, and catoptrics. Though citing and considering many authors, he accepts Cartesian optical ideas.
BP_Description_1: The origins of <i>L'Optique et La Catoptrique<i> are manuscripts on optics and catoptrics  Mersenne left at the time of his death in 1648; the later less complete than the former. These works define the end of an arc of ideas that began with his <i>Quaestiones Celeberrimae<i> of 1623 and developed in his <i>Optica<i>  as part of  the <i>Universae mixtaeque geometriae mathematicae synopsis<i> of 1644. Mersenne was a committed Aristotelianism and attempted to accommodate the developments in Johannes Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604 with Scholastic teaching in optics. With the advent of Ren√© Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> of 1637 and Thomas Hobbes' <i>Tractatus Opticus<i> (published by Mersenne in 1644), he established a synthesis of Cartesian and Hobbesian ideas. This is the  <i>L'Optique et La Catoptrique<i>, which, unlike his earlier work, is not a compendium but rather a series of proposition that state what to Mersenne were the most likely explanations for light and optical phenomena. By 1648 and the writing of the <i>L'Optique et La Catoptrique<i>, Mersenne had adopted Descartes' idea on the nature of light and vision. He does, however, present Descartes' sine law of refraction underpinned with Hobbes' analogy of light as physically moving lines or 'ray fronts.' Unlike the dogmatic Cartesianism that many would later adopt, Mersenne was flexible, always open to alternatives in natural philosophy, and prepared to present and weigh differing views.||Gilles Personne de Roberval is credited with editing Mersenne's manuscripts (which Roberval named <i>L'Optique et La Catoptrique<i>), it is known that he had to do more than just edit. Even though Roberval hewed close to Mersenne's ideas, he added considerably to the text, filled many lacunae, and clarified many sections.||<i>L'Optique et La Catoptrique<i> marks the mid-17th century transition from Scholastic teaching on optics to an accommodation of the developments of Kepler and Descartes. It appeared in 1651 and 1663, often bound with the third edition of Niceron's <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i>, which was also edited by Roberval.
BP_Description_2: Roberval's editing of Mersenne's <i>L'Optique et La Catoptrique<i> has a preface from the publisher followed by two books. In a few initial sentences, the preface states the intention of bringing Mersenne's last optics thoughts into print. The next six pages are, strangely, devoted to a long posthumous defense of Mersenne against the charge brought by Jesuits that he had endorsed a method for squaring the circle. Book 1 is devoted to optics and presents 31 Propositions. The first 9 propositions present the sources, nature, and propagation of light, with luminous rays being the explanatory mechanism. Kepler's influence is very clear, including the inverse-square relationship of distance and illumination. Proposition 10 gives Mersenne's mechanico-ballistic explanation for reflection. Propositions 11-14 deal with illumination and primitive photometry. The power of sunlight is compared to that of candles by way of the inverse-square distance law. Propositions 15-21 deal with the camera obscura and its uses to produce images and assess light sources. Propositions 22 and 23 are on color and shadow. Propositions 24-31 discuss the eye, the process of vision, and visual perceptions. Book 2 is devoted to catoptrics and presents 16 Propositions. The first 5 are on the nature of reflection and a consideration of the various theories that have been proposed to explain the equal-angle law of reflection. Propositions 6-8 consider different types and forms of mirrors. Proposition 10 considers reflected rays and their paths to the eyes. Propositions 11-15 consider image formation by mirrors, magnification, blur. Proposition 16 is on burning mirrors.||The material is on the nature of light is Cartesian, but that on the physics of light is deeply tinctured by Hobbes' physics. The material on the eye and vision is taken directly from Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i>. The arguments or demonstrations of the propositions are by way of analogy; the only mathematics involved is elementary geometry. The material on catoptrics is on the nature and cause of reflection and the general properties of mirrors; it is not what would have been considered geometrical optics.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇThe Development of Mersenne's Optics|Cozzoli, D.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 2010, pp 9-25.||Roberval ¬´√©diteur¬ª de Mersenne et du P. Niceron|Lenoble, R.|<i>Revue d'histoire des sciences et de leurs applications<i>, Vol 10,  No 3, 1957,  pp. 235-254.||Mersenne et Roberval|Gabby, A.|In: '1588 - 1988, Quatri√®me Centenaire de la Naissance de Marin Mersenne: Colloque Scientifique International et C√©l√©bration Nationale; actes du colloque' , 1994, Universit√© du Maine, Le Mans, 207 pp, NB: pp 93-111.
BP_Title: L'Optique et La Catoptrique du Reverend Pere Mersenne Minime. Nouvellement Mise en Lumiere, apres the la mort de l'Autheur.
BP_Title English Translation: The Optics and Catroptrics of the Reverend Father Mersenne, Minium. Newly Highlighted after the Death of the Authror.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Minim friar, center of the scientific world of letters, prolific correspondant. Wrote knowingly on music, optics, and ballistics.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Niceron La Perspective Curieuse  2nd edition 1663
BP_BibliographicNotes: Frontispiece; Portrait

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of a seminal work on physiological optics, showing: correct position of the lens, cornea curvature, nasal exit of the optic nerve, lens change in accommodation, light reaction of the pupil and narrowing in accommodation, double images in near and far-sightedness, refractive indices of the various parts of the eye, beam-crossing in the camera obscura, and a functioning model of the eye.
BP_Description_1: Posthumous, second printing of a seminal work on what is now called physiological optics. See Entry 68.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 68.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 68.
BP_Title: Oculus; Hoc est Fundamentum Opticum: in quo ex Accurata Oculi Anatome, Abstrusarum Experientiarum Sedula pervestigatione, ex invIsis specierum visibilium tam everso quam erecto situ spectaculis, nec non solidis rationum momentis. Radius Visualis Eruitur; sua Visioni in oculo Sedes Decernitur; Anguli Visorii Ingenium Aperitur. Difficultates veteres, novae innumerae expediuntur; adstrusa, obscura, curiosa plurima in medium proferuntur; plura depromendi occasio harum rerum studiosis datur: Opus multorum votis diu expetitum; Philosophis omnibus, praesertim qui naturae vim in Medicina, Physica aut Mathesi addiscenda rimantur, neque inutile neque ingratum, imo necessarium futurum.
BP_Title English Translation: The Eye. That is, the Foundation of Optics. In which Ocular Anatomy is Given Attention, Abstruse Experiments are Assiduously Investigated,  from which is Observed the Appearance of Visible Objects Inverted,  but Seen Upright, by the firm effort of reasoning. The Visual Ray Elicited, its Place in Vision in the Eye Decided, The Nature of Visual Angles Revealed. Innumerable old and new Difficulties are explained; Many Common Curious, Abstruse, Obscure things are Revealed; Students are Given the Opportunity of Drawing out Much. The Work was long Sought after many Prayers. For all Philosophers, Especially those who by Nature Search for Required Additional Learning in  the Power in Medicine, Physics, and Mathematics. Neither Useless nor Unpleasant; indeed it will be Necessary.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, astronomer, mathematician, early ocular physiologist. Talented, tetchy, and a prolific author.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1652 Scheiner - Oculus - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Modeled on the pirated Frankfurt edition of 1610 and presenting Galileo's telescopic discovery of the moons of Jupiter, the topography of the moon, and the starry enumeration of the Milky Way.
BP_Description_1: The origin of this collected volume is Pierre Gassendi's appointment as Chair of Mathematics at the Coll√®ge Royal in Paris in 1645. There he delivered a course of lectures on astronomy, the notes for which he used in writing a textbook. Gassendi published this in 1647 as his <i>Institutio Astronomica<i>. Like other of his writing, it was decidedly anti-Aristotelian. In addition to basic astronomy, the text considered the Tyconian and Copernican system of the world; but Gassendi plumped (clearly and unmistakably) for the Copernican and the text became widely used, particularly in English universities. The collection appears to have been the idea of the prominent London printer, James Flesher. In his letter to the reader he sets out briefly the value and importance of all three works. The Institutio Astronomica is a reprinting of the 1647 Paris text, including dedicatory letter. The <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> is from the pirated Frankfurt edition of 1610. The <i>Dioptrice<i> is a close reprinting of the 1611 Prague text. with the woodcut figures redone, somewhat larger and more clearly executed.||Gassendi's introduction to astronomy was the first elementary textbook to present new theories as those, and only those, supported by recent astronomical observations. It was clearest and most accessible textbook of the time, and his fame as a practicing observational astronomer gave the text considerable cachet. The practical, technically optical, and philosophical aspects of observational astronomy are made clear by the <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> and the <i>Dioptrice<i>, both of which had already become almost unprocurably rare by 1650. Including them with the <i>Institutio Astronomica<i> produced a textbook of high pedagogical value. It was of wide influence, being in common use for more than half a century, not only in European universities but also those in the American colonies. It was this edition from which Isaac Newton read Gassendi, Galileo, and Kepler.||Editions of the <i>Institutio Astronomica<i> appeared at Paris in 1647, and in the present collection at London in 1653, 1670, and 1683, at the Hague in 1656 and 1666, with the Opera Omnia at Lyon in 1658, at Amsterdam in 1680, and at Cambridge in 1702.
BP_Description_2: This edition of the <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> is based on the pirated Frankfurt edition of 1610 and presents Galileo's telescopic discovery of the moons of Jupiter, the topography of the moon, and the stary enumeration of the Milky Way. Though it is a common place to cite its disruptive influence on astronomy and natural philosophy, its effect on optics was just as immediate and profound. That dioptrics could be used to augment vision by magnifying celestial objects--and thus challenge ideas regarding the heavens--prompted the feverish search to understand how the telescope worked, to know how lenses functioned and so be made to perform evermore powerfully, and to evaluate the trustworthiness of vision with lenses and the augmented senses in general. Optical theory and craft sprang up in Europe almost immediately; but most importantly, craft. By 1650 telescopes of sufficient power and clarity had been used to see the shadows on Jupiter cast by its moons, discovered the nebula in the constellation Orion, detected the belts of Jupiter and the markings on Mars, mapped detailed lunar features, and seen that Mizar was a double star.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Sidereus Nuncius, Or The Sidereal Messenger. Galileo Galilei<i>|Translatied  with Introduction, Conclusion, and Notes|Van Helden, A.|Universtiy of Chicago Press, 1989.||<i>Pierre Gassendi: From Aristotelianism to a New Natural Philosophy<i>|Brundell, B.|Reidel Publishing, 1987, 251 p.||Gassendi in America|Gorman, M.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 55, No 4, 1964, pp 409-417.
BP_Title: Sidereus Nuncius, Magna Longeque Admirabilia Spectacula pandens, suspiciendaque proponens unicuique, praesertim vero Philosophis, atque Astronomis, que a Galileo Galileo, Patritio Florentino, Patavini Gymnasii Publico Mathematico, Perspicilli.  Nuper a se reperti beneficio sunt observata in Lunae Facia, Fixis Innumeris, Lacteo Circulo, Stellis Nebulosis, Apprime vero in Quatuor Planetis Circa Jovis Stellam disparibus intervallis, atque Periodis, celeritate mirabili circumvolutis; quos, nemini in hanc usque diem cognitos, novissime Auctor deprehendit primus; atque Medicea Sidera nuncupandos decrevit.
BP_Title English Translation: The Starry Messenger, Unfolding Great and Boundlessly Astonishing Spectacles, and Presenting to Everyone for Admiration, but Especially Philosophers and Astronomers, by the Telescope of Galileo Galilei, Patrician of Florence, Public Mathematician of the School at Padua. Recently Invented by him and by its Help Obervations are made of the Face of the Moon, Innumerable Fixed Starts, the Miky Way, Clouded Stars. But Especially About the Four Planets Revolving around the Star of Jupiter with Marvelous Swiftness in Unequal Intervals and Periods; Which, Known to no one Until Now, the Author Discovered First, and Determined to Name the Medicean Stars.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicist, mathematician, astronomer. Pushed the frontiers of mechanics, optics, and cosmology--to his cost.
BP_Provenance: Godain 1798' inscribed on the titlepage.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Kepler Dioptrice

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Reprinting of the Prague text of 1611. Prompted by Galileo's Sidereus Nuncius, the earliest complete analysis of dioptrics. Axioms, principles, and experimental results about the refraction of light are applied to lenses, explaining image formation, magnification and its measurement, image inversion, and the operation of the telescope.
BP_Description_1: The origin of this collected volume is Pierre Gassendi's appointment as Chair of Mathematics at the Coll√®ge Royal in Paris in 1645. There he delivered a course of lectures on astronomy, the notes for which he used in writing a textbook. Gassendi published this in 1647 as his <i>Institutio Astronomica<i>. Like other of his writing, it was decidedly anti-Aristotelian. In addition to basic astronomy, the text considered the Tyconian and Copernican system of the world; but Gassendi plumped (clearly and unmistakably) for the Copernican and the text became widely used, particularly in English universities. The collection appears to have been the idea of the prominent London printer, James Flesher. In his letter to the reader he sets out briefly the value and importance of all three works. The <i>Institutio Astronomica<i> is a reprinting of the 1647 Paris text, including dedicatory letter. The <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> is from the pirated Frankfurt edition of 1610. The <i>Dioptrice<i> is a close reprinting of the 1611 Prague text. with the woodcut figures redone, somewhat larger and more clearly executed.||Gassendi's introduction to astronomy was the clearest and most accessible of the time, and his fame as a practicing observational astronomer gave the text considerable cachet. The practical, technically optical, and philosophical aspects of observational astronomy are made clear by the <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i> and the <i>Dioptrice<i>, both of which had already become almost unprocurably rare by 1650. Including them with the <i>Institutio Astronomica<i> produced a textbook of high pedagogical value. It was of wide influence, being in common use for more than half a century, not only in European universities but also those in the American colonies.||Editions of the <i>Institutio Astronomica<i> appeared at Paris in 1647, and in the present collection at London in 1653, 1670, and 1683, at the Hague in 1656 and 1666, with the Opera Omnia at Lyon in 1658, at Amsterdam in 1680, and at Cambridge in 1702.
BP_Description_2: Johannes Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> is in 141 numbered sections. They are variously labeled Definition, Axiom, Optical Axiom, Perceptual Axiom, Problem, Proposition, or Notes. There are several sections, each building upon material in previous sections.  1: Refraction at plane surfaces. 2: Light.  3: The lens. 4: Convergence point of a lens.  5: Action of both lens surfaces. 6: The effect of a convex lens by itself. 7: The lens of eye and vision. 8: The use of the lens with respect to the eye. 9: Convex lenses acting together. 10: Concave lenses. 11: Convex and concave lenses acting together. 12: Simple lensed instruments. 13: 'Criptical' lensed instruments.||Sections 1-5 are physical, treating light, glass, and refraction. It begins with Kepler's device for measuring refractive power. It is an idea and image that will appear is optics texts for 150 years, encompassing as it does a demonstration of refraction and means for its measure. Kepler states his approximate law of refraction here: for incidence angles less than 30‚Å∞, the refracted angle is ‚Öî the incidence angle. He establishes convergence points for convex lenses and relates their position to the radius of curvature of the lens, but does not generate any general analytical method for imaging. Sections 6-7 are devoted to the formation of images at the convergence points of convex lenses. Sections 8 deals with how lenses modify vision. The basis is the convergence of rays at the eye, however they may have been modified by lenses after they were emitted by an object. Magnification, minification, and inversion are all treated by assessing the visual angle of rays at the eye; lager angle gives magnification, small angle gives minification. Using this, Kepler explains how a single convex lens can magnify, minify, and invert an object as seen by the eye. It is here that Kepler recognizes spherical aberration. Sections 9-12 describe the operation of the Keplerian telescope and, in Propositions 107-115, the Galilean telescope; that being the highlight and Kepler's goal for the entire work. The last section deals with instruments with various forms of lenses, including menisci.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Kepler and the Telescope|Malet, A.|<i>Annales of Science<i>, Vol 60, 2003, pp 107-136.||Kepler's legacy: Telescopes and geometrical optics, 1611-1669|Malet, A.|In: <i>The Origins of the Telescope<i>, KNAW Press, Amsterdam, 2010, pp 281-300.
BP_Title: Dioptrice seu Demonstratio eorum quae visui & visbilibus propter Conspicilla non ita pridem inventa accidunt.
BP_Title English Translation: Dioptrics, or, A Demonstation of those things that happen to vision and visibles because of the Conspicilla invented not long ago.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, astrologer. Worked extensively in celestial mechanics and innovated radically in vision and optics.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Galileo Sidereus Nuncius

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by William Oughtred (1574 - 1660) English mathematician and cleric, inventor of the slide rule and innovator of mathematical symbols.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First English translation of Leurechon's R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques of 1626
BP_Description_1: Reissue of the first English translation of 1633 of <i>Leurechon's R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> from the French edition of 1630. Ninety-one 'Problems' are presented, some of several parts, with solutions constituting a collection of experiments, apparatus demonstrations, recipes, and parlor tricks in cosmology, optics, perspective, mechanics, statics, practical geometry, fortification and gunnery. Designed to entertain and instruct. The source for the arithmetical problems was Claude Bachet's <i>Problems Plaisans et Delectables<i> of 1612. The problems in geometry are in the Renaissance tradition of 'practical geometry'; geometry applied to surveying, mensuration, and fortification. Many of the other problems come from the tradition of secretes and natural magic, such as Girolamo Ruscelli's <i>De' Secretis del Alessio Piemontese<i> in the edition of 1615. Some of the problems in natural philosophy appear to be from works by Giambattista Della Porta, Girolamo Cardano, and Salomon de Caus. Renaissance books on conjuring and prestidigitation were a source for the <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>.|Tradition has assigned authorship to the Jesuit Jean Leurechon, though there is little scholarly evidence for this. Whoever assembled this collection of problems and secrets produced a book that was tremendously popular, being in print in various forms for more than 150 years. Thirty editions in French appeared between 1624 and 1680. Denis Henrion and Claude Mydorge were contributors and commentators for editions between 1626 and 1639, adding significant value to the book. Jacques Ozanam began editing editions in 1694, adding material and changing the content to be more like an encyclopedia. Jean-Etienne Montucla and Edm√© Gilles Guyot were subsequent editors and by 1769 there were four volumes. Translations appeared in English, Latin, Dutch, and German.||Editions of the English translation appeared in 1633, 1653, and 1674. This, the second edition, uses the woodcut illustrations placed in the text of 1627.
BP_Description_2: This and other early editions <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> have a dedicatory letter signed by H. Van Etten and a preface to the reader from the author which names some of his sources and the general nature of what he tried to accomplish. This is followed by a table on contents titled 'Collection of the Principal Mathematical Recreations Contained in the Booklet According to Problem Numbers'. The sections listed are: Arithmetic, Geometry, Optics and Perspective, Music, Cosmographical Matters. There follows 91 'Problems' in these various subjects. The camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow are presented in a rudimentary way. In this and other early editions, the optical material is limited to display and demonstration, with little or no explanation of the phenomena itself.
BP_Reference(s): R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.
BP_Title: Mathematicall Recreations Or a Collection of sundrie excellent problems out of ancient & moderne Phylosophers. Both Usefull and Recreative.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, mathematician, and professor. [English mathematician and Anglican minister. Inventer of the slide-rule and other mathematical innovations.]
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with The Description and use of the Double Horizontall Dyall

BP_Short or Common Title: Meditationes de Prima Philosophia, Passiones Anim√¶, Principia Philosophi√¶, and Specimina Philosophi√¶
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A nonce volume of Descartes major works, in Latin.
BP_Description_1: A nonce volume of Descartes major works, in Latin. Containing: <i>Meditationes de Prima Philosophia, Passiones Anim√¶, Principia Philosophi√¶<i>, and <i>Specimina Philosophi√¶<i>. After the appearance of the Latin translation of <i>Les Passion de l'Amme<i> in 1650, Nonce volumes containing Latin versions of all of Descartes's principle works--with the exception of the Geometria--became common. Beginning in 1650, Louis Elzeviers published a set titled <i>Operia Philosophica<i> that contained the <i>Meditationes<i>, the <i>Principia<i>, the <i>Specimina<i> and the <i>Passiones.<i> The set appeared at Amsterdam twice in 1650, and in 1656, 1663-1664, 1670-1672, and 1677-1678. Beginning with the 1656 edition (the present one) an engraved portrait of Descartes appeared at the front.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Meditations<i> consists of preliminary material and six medications: Preface to the Reader; Synopsis of the Six Following Meditations; Meditations On the First Philosophy In Which the Existence of God, and the Real Distinction of Mind and Body, Are Demonstrated; Meditation I. Of the Things On Which We May Doubt; Meditation II. Of the Nature of the Human Mind and That It Is More Easily Known Than the Body; Meditation III. Of God: That He Exists; Meditation IV. Of Truth and Error; Meditation V. Of the Essence of Material Things ; and , Again , of God; That He Exists; Meditation VI. Of the Existence of Material Things , and of the Real Distinction Between the Mind and Body of Man.||The Principles of Philosophy contains preliminary material, three Parts, and an appendix: The Principles of Philosophy; Part I. Of the Principles of Human Knowledge; Part II. Of the Principles of Material Things; Part III. Of the Visible World; Part IV.: Of the Earth; Appendix.||The Passions of the Soul in three books: Book I considers the passions in general and occasionally of the whole nature of man; Book II considers the number, and order of the passions, and the explication of the six primitive ones; Book III considers particular passions.||The Specimina Philosophiae is the Latin translation of the <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i> and two of the three essays Descartes wrote to demonstrate his new method of natural philosophy: La Dioptrique on optics and  vision, and Les Meteores on atmospheric phenomena. <i>La Dioptrique<i> has three principal topics: 1, the nature of light and the laws of optics, 2, vision, and 3, dioptric improvement of vision. These are covered in 10 sections: nature of light, law of refraction, ocular anatomy, the senses in general, image formation in the eye, visual perception, quality of vision, figure of spectacles, microscopes and telescopes, methods for figuring lenses.  <i>Les Meteores<i> contains the correct explanation of the rainbow.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Method, Meditations and Philosophy of Descartes<i>|Veitch, J.|Dunne, Washington, 1901, 371 p.||<i>A Bibliography of the Works of Descartes I & II<i>|van Otegem, M.|Quaestiiones Infinitae, Vol 37|Publications of the Leiden-Utrecht Research Institute of Philosophy, Utrecht, 2002, 779 pp, NB: pp 679-689/
BP_Title: Meditationes de Prima Philosophia, In quibus Dei existentia, & animae humanae a corpore distinctio, demonstrantur. His adjuctae sunt variae objections deoctorum virorum in istas de Deo & ania demonstrationes; Cum Responsionibus Authoris. Edition ultima prioribus auctior & emendatior.||Passiones Animae, per Renatum Des Cartes: Gallice ab ipso conscriptae, nunc autem in exterorum gratiam Latina civitate donatae.||Principia Philosophiae. Nunc demum hac Editione diligenter recognita, & mendis expurgata.||Specimina Philosophiae: sue Dissertatio de Methodo Recta regendae rationis, & veritatis in scientiis investigandae: Dioptirce, et Meteora. Ex Gallico translata, & ad Auctore perlecta, veriisque in locis emendata. Nunc denuo hac Editione diligenter recognita, & mendis expurgata.
BP_Title English Translation: Meditations on First Philosophy, In which the Existence of God and the distinction between the human body and soul are demonstrated. Adjunct to these are Various Objections of Learned Men to such Demonstrations of God and the soul. With the Responses of the Author. The Latest Edition Augmented and Emandated.
BP_Biographical Statement: French philosopher and mathematician. Resident of the Dutch Republic, revolutionary founder of rationalism, prolific writer.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Principia Philosophia,Specimina, Passiones of 1656

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A nonce volume of Descartes major works, in Latin.
BP_Description_1: A nonce volume of Descartes major works, in Latin. Containing: <i>Meditationes de Prima Philosophia, Passiones Anim√¶, Principia Philosophi√¶<i>, and <i>Specimina Philosophi√¶<i>. After the appearance of the Latin translation of <i>Les Passion de l'Amme<i> in 1650, Nonce volumes containing Latin versions of all of Descartes's principle works--with the exception of the Geometria--became common. Beginning in 1650, Louis Elzeviers published a set titled <i>Operia Philosophica<i> that contained the <i>Meditationes<i>, the <i>Principia<i>, the <i>Specimina<i> and the <i>Passiones.<i> The set appeared at Amsterdam twice in 1650, and in 1656, 1663-1664, 1670-1672, and 1677-1678. Beginning with the 1656 edition (the present one) an engraved portrait of Descartes appeared at the front.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Meditations<i> consists of preliminary material and six medications: Preface to the Reader; Synopsis of the Six Following Meditations; Meditations On the First Philosophy In Which the Existence of God, and the Real Distinction of Mind and Body, Are Demonstrated; Meditation I. Of the Things On Which We May Doubt; Meditation II. Of the Nature of the Human Mind and That It Is More Easily Known Than the Body; Meditation III. Of God: That He Exists; Meditation IV. Of Truth and Error; Meditation V. Of the Essence of Material Things ; and , Again , of God; That He Exists; Meditation VI. Of the Existence of Material Things , and of the Real Distinction Between the Mind and Body of Man.||The Principles of Philosophy contains preliminary material, three Parts, and an appendix: The Principles of Philosophy; Part I. Of the Principles of Human Knowledge; Part II. Of the Principles of Material Things; Part III. Of the Visible World; Part IV.: Of the Earth; Appendix.||The Passions of the Soul in three books: Book I considers the passions in general and occasionally of the whole nature of man; Book II considers the number, and order of the passions, and the explication of the six primitive ones; Book III considers particular passions.||The Specimina Philosophiae is the Latin translation of the <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i> and two of the three essays Descartes wrote to demonstrate his new method of natural philosophy: La Dioptrique on optics and  vision, and Les Meteores on atmospheric phenomena. <i>La Dioptrique<i> has three principal topics: 1, the nature of light and the laws of optics, 2, vision, and 3, dioptric improvement of vision. These are covered in 10 sections: nature of light, law of refraction, ocular anatomy, the senses in general, image formation in the eye, visual perception, quality of vision, figure of spectacles, microscopes and telescopes, methods for figuring lenses.  <i>Les Meteores<i> contains the correct explanation of the rainbow.

BP_Description_1: A nonce volume of Descartes major works, in Latin. Containing: <i>Meditationes de Prima Philosophia, Passiones Anim√¶, Principia Philosophi√¶<i>, and <i>Specimina Philosophi√¶<i>. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fifth volume of a six-volume textbook in the Scholastic manner and an example of the Jesuit opposition to Descartes. Topics in Mixed Mathematics are covered in a series of Disputations, with a section on light, color, and vision presenting both the Scholastic and the Keplerian theory of vision. Descartes is not mentioned. Widely used, popular, and produced in many expanded editions.
BP_Description_1: Pierre Gaultruche taught mathematics at the Jesuit schools at La Fl√®che and Caens and it was at this time that he produced this compendium-textbook for use in his courses. In is broad scope, coverage, and level of detail, it was like other compendia of the time: Claude Milliet Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> of 1674 or William Leybourne's <i>Cursus Mathematics<i> of 1690. Though committed to Scholastic teachings, Gaultruche was an eclectic Aristotelian; as seen in the mix of theories he presented in physics and mixed mathematics.||Editions appeared Caens in 1656 and 1665, at Vienna in 1661, at London in 1683. A separate edition of Volume 5, <i>Mathematica<i>, appeared at Cambridge in 1668, and was the basis for a German science and mathematics popularization that appeared at Ulm in 1695.
BP_Description_2: Fifth volume of six textbooks in the Scholastic manner and an example of the Jesuit opposition to Descartes. Topics in Mixed Mathematics are covered in a series of Disputations, with a section on light, color, and vision. The 'Mathematica' volume consists of nine parts: arithmetic, elements of geometry, practical geometry, world sphere, chronology, gnomonics, terrestrial sphere, optics and music. The optics material is brief (30 pages) and deals only with vision and images. Geometric or physical optics is not presented, nor is Descartes' La Dioptrique cited or used. Ocular anatomy is briefly presented and then the Scholastic theory of vision is presented, detailing how species of light and color are emitted from an object, enter the eye, and impinge on the crystalline lens.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Natural Philosophy in Some Early Seventeenth Century Scholastic Textbooks<i>|Reif, P.M.|St. Louis University, Dissertation, 1962, 365 pp.||The Mathematical Sciences and New Philosophies|Feingod, M.|In: <i>Seventeenth-Century Oxford<i>, Vol VI of The History of the University of Oxford|Tyacke, N., editor|Oxford University Press, 1997, 1014 pp, NB: pp 211-358.||Pierre Gautruche et l'enseignement de la philosophie de la nature dans les coll√®ges j√©suites fran√ßais vers 1650|Brockliss, L.W.B.|In: <i>Les Jesuites a la Renaissance<i>, 1995, NB: pp 187-219.
BP_Title: Philosophiae ac mathematicae Totius Institutio, Cum Assertionibus disputatis, & vario genere Problematum. Ad usum Studiosae Ivuentutis.
BP_Title English Translation: Instruction in All of Philosophy and Mathematics. With Debated Assertions and Various Types of Problems. For the use of Young Students.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, taught at the College Henri IV de la Fl√®che and eventually at Clermont, the main Jesuit college in Paris. Wrote a series of textbooks on astronomy and 'mixed mathematics'.
BP_Plates: Plates Tabula[I-IV] at D‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ, Tabula[I-IX, Pro Optica] at L‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ, Pro Musica at O‚ÇÑ

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A curriculum giving an abridged and simplified course in Philosophy and, usually, aspects of natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Cornaeus' <i>Curriculum philosophiae Peripateticae<i> is a curriculum giving an abridged and simplified course in Philosophy. Unusually, it includes aspects of natural philosophy that are not contained in most Jesuit philosophy courses: doctrines from experimental physics and applied mathematics. This unusual aspect of the <i>Curriculum<i> is justified in the dedication to the Mainz Elector and the letter to the Reader. Cornaeus believes that philosophy can serve not just rulers and the learned but a wider audience only if it includes the applied and natural sciences. The structure of the <i><Curriculum<i> follows the usual elements of Aristotle: Dialectics and Logic; Physics; The Heavens; Meteorology; Life and the Soul; and Metaphysics. Though much of the <i>Curriculum<i> is narrowly scholastic Aristotelianism, Cornaeus admits to the value and importance of knowledge that comes from evidence, and evidence that comes not just from logic but also from the senses--that is, experiment. This includes the sense of vision and its treatment results in a large section on optics. Since optics was considered part of Mathematics, it was very unusual to have it included in a course in philosophy.||Regarding astronomy, Cornaeus defends geocentrism using extracts from Scheiner's <i>Rosa Ursina<i> of 1630 and then quotes extensively from Copernicus' <i>De Revolutionibus<i> of 1543 for the purpose of refuting it with scholastic arguments. Another unusual aspect of the <i>Curriculum<i> is its consideration of the vacuum. Aristotle and the scholastics held that the vacuum was not possible in any natural way. But Cornaeus posits the existence of 'imaginary space' and considers thought experiments conducted in it. This leads to a report of instruments and experiments with vacuum, including those of Torricelli, Berti, and von Guericke. In the end, Cornaeus thinks the experiments support the ancient notion of <i>metus vacui<i>, 'fear of the vacuum' and not the vacuum itself. That is, that mechanical forces observed in the experiments are manifestations of efforts to prevent the vacuum. Cornaeus ends the section on vacuum by noting that (in Latin)  'Every novelty is usually pleasant, but ancient truth is better.' It summarizes the tension between the old and new that is present throughout the entire work and shows Cornaus' textbook to be on the cusp between the the narrowly Aristotelian textbooks still in use early in the 17th century and the new textbooks that would be sparked by Carteisanism later in the century and Newtonianism early in the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: The material on optics (filling 70 pages) is an aspect of sensations of the soul, treated by Cornaeus in a way grounded in scholastic teaching, but describing modern experimental developments. This includes the physics of light, the physiology of vision, the anatomy of the eye according to Vesalius, and concludes with a series of <i>axiomata optica<i> with diagrams of light cones, perspective, mirrors with their images and burning points, and finally refraction and lenses.||Aristotle's idea that light actualizes the potential transparency of materials, allowing color--the fundamental visual property of an object--to enter the eye. The medieval perspectivist concept of multiplication of visual species is also presented. Some of the experiments performed by Alhacen are also recounted to demonstrate the properties of light. It is in the section of <i>axiomata optica<i> that simple geometric optics is used to analyze perspective, mirrors, and lenses. Consistent with the nature of the curriculum and its audience, there is no mathematics presented and only the simplest geometry in invoked in some of the geometric optics.
BP_Reference(s): The Jesuits and the Janus-Faced History of Natural Sciences|Blum, P.R.|In: <i>Studies on Early Modern Aristotelianism<i>, Brill, 2012, 367 pp, NB: pp 113-138.||Aristotle Among the Jesuits: A Note Concerning a Recent Publication|Garcia, B.|<i>Rivista di Filosofia Neo-Scolastica<i>, Vol 106, No 1, 2014, pp 177-194.||The Rise of the Philosophical Textbook|Schmitt, C. B.|In: The Cambridge History of Renaissance Philosophy, Schmitt C.B. editor, Cambridge University Press, 1988, pp. 792‚Äì804.
BP_Title: Curriculum philosophiae Peripateticae, uti hoc tempore in scholis decurri solet, multis figuris et curiositatibus e mathesi petitis, et ad physin reductis, illustratum.
BP_Title English Translation: A Course in Peripatetic Philosophy. Illustrated by many forms and curiosities drawn from mathematics and reduced from physics, so that it is accustomed to be followed at this time in the schools.
BP_Biographical Statement: French-born philosopher and theologian. Taught at Toulouse, Mainz, and W√ºrzburg.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An extended, essentially Aristotelian discourse of the nature of light, its sources, motion, color, reflection, and refraction. Most, but not all, in the philosophical tradition of the scholastics. Interwoven with metaphysics, distinctions without differences (four types of light are posited),  and decidedly anti-Cartesian.
BP_Description_1: La Lumi√®re has its roots in La Chambre's previous publication <i>Nouvelles Pens√©es sur les Causes de la Lumi√®re<i> of 1634.  Most of La Chambre's ideas--and unique vocabulary--regarding the nature of light and its interaction with objects are here considerably expanded to present an eclectic, Scholastic treatment of light and color. La Chambre rejects Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> of 1647 and all of the developments in physical optics since Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1640 and ignores most of geometrical optics. Like much of La Chambre's work, <i>La Lumi√®re<i> is a fashionable, gracious, and elaborately written 'discourse' intended, perhaps, to startle and attract with novel theories, but lacking any substantiation let alone experimental support. Even within its temporal context, <i>La Lumi√®re's<i> elaborate light metaphysics, reliance on Scholastic distinctions, and absence of any empirical basis make it something of a medieval throw-back.||La Chambre was a successful physician, well-known physiognomist, well-connected politically--one of the elites of France. All of which may account for <i>La Lumi√®re's<i> publication. But  it was of little influence and must not have a commercial success. It appeared in 1657 and was reissued in 1662 with the sheets of the 1657 printing and a new title page. However lacking in import, La Chambre's <i>La Lumi√®re<i> does mark how slow and gradual was the advance of Cartesianism, even in France.
BP_Description_2: <i>La Lumi√®re<i> is in two books. Book 1 'Radical' Light, has four chapters: Four kinds of light in nature; Radical light; The essence of radical light; The cause that produces light. Book 2 'Exterior' Light, has eight chapters: How exterior light is produced; How exterior light subsists in the objects receiving it; The extension of light; The action of light; The movement of light; The reflection of light; The refraction of light; The purpose and usage of light.||The distinction between 'radical' and 'exterior' light is akin to the Scholastic distinction between lux and lumen. The former having to do with the innate or interior luminous power of a light source, the latter the propagated luminous result and subsequent effects of a light emitting object. Invoking the additional Scholastic distinction between substance and accident, color is held to be an accident of light, it's second alternative manifestation. Unlike the traditional Scholastic teaching that color arises from the mixing of light/dark, white/black, La Chambre holds that color arises inherently, not the mixing, of light. Color can be fixed in an object or propagated from it as species and can be changed by attenuation as it moves through a medium. There are then, four kinds of light; two radical (one fixed color, one species color) and two exterior (one fixed color, one species color). Light and transparency is considered as a consequence of the four causes: material, formal, efficient, and final cause. Exterior light is discussed in terms of rays; how they propagate, what they  affect, how they are reflected and how they are refracted. Refraction is treated in the simplest manner, with no reference to Descartes, his <i>La Dioptrique<i>, or the sine law of refraction.||The presentation is entirely descriptive; no mathematics of any kind is involved. It presents what is fundamentally a philosophical treatment of light, rather than a physical or mathematical treatment.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, 376 pp, NB: pp 225-232.||De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Duhamel en Vossius in de periode 1640‚Äì1670|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.||Marin Cureau de La Chambre (1594‚Äì1669)|Diamond, S.|<i>Journal of the History of the Behavioral Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 1, 1968, pp 40-54.||Un Optician M√©connu: Le Sieur de la Chambre|Savelli, R.|In: <i>Actes du VIII Congr√®s International d'Histoire des Sciences<i>, 1956, pp 275-281.
BP_Title: La Lumi√®re. A Monseigneur L'Eminentissime Cardinal Mazarin. Per Le Sieur De La Chambre, Conseilleur du Roy en ses Conseils, &son Medecin ordinaire.
BP_Title English Translation: Light. To the Most Reverened Eminence Cardinal Mazarin. By Le Sieur De La Chambre, Advisor to the King and his Counciles, and his Physician in Ordinary.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physican, confidant of Pierre de Fermat, self-styled reader of human character.
BP_Provenance: ex libris of Joseph de Banneuille inscribed on titlepage
