BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Four volume encyclopedia on 'artificial magic'--that is, technical inventions, phenomena of nature, and artifices--and the attempt 'to bring hidden, recondite things to light'.
BP_Description_1: The root of Caspar Schott's <i>Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis<i> is his work with his teacher Athanasius Kircher. In the <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i> of 1646, Kircher promised to write a <i>Magia Universalis<i> but other projects, other books always interfered. Eventually the task, along with Kircher's notes and outline, was give to Schott, who began the two-year project after he left Rome and returned to W√ºrzburg. While in Rome under Kircher, Schott acquired the belief that all human knowledge was linked and manifested by natural or artificial magic (what today would be called technology), and, following the medieval philosopher Ramon Llull, could be comprehended if the correct organizing framework could be found. These ideas are the origin of the scope and style of the Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis, coving in its four volumes optics, acoustics, mechanics and mathematics, and physical phenomena.||Schott makes his expectations and intended audience clear in his Prooemium to the whole work. In his travels he found students, craftsmen, and philosophers in need of careful explanations for phenomena, machines, and inventions. Writing in Latin and yet engaging in the practical, Schott attempts a balance between Aristotelian theory and craft practice. The result is a reference that could be consulted by scholar or practitioner-craftsman. The first and second volumes are devoted to optics and vision and to sound and audition. Their scope is such that they encompass all aspects of these two important senses, a large number of natural phenomena, and many instruments. The third and fourth volumes are devoted to mechanics and mathematics and to physics and phenomena--those things in Mixed Mathematics not covered in the first two volumes. Unlike a traditional Aristotelian course in natural philosophy, astronomy and cosmology are not treated. Unlike Kircher's lager works, Schott's work contains few figures--and those present are of low quality. In most cases, figures were borrowed from previous publications, with the details left to the engraver. The results were often confusing or strange. Presumably all this was to keep costs low.||<i>Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis<i> appeared in 1657 and reprinted at Bamberg in 1677. A German translation of the volume on optics appeared at Bamberg in 1671.
BP_Description_2: <i>Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis<i> is in four volumes. Volume 1: Optics and Vision. Volume 2: Sound and Audition. Volume 3: Mechanics, Hydrostatics, and Mathematics. Volume 4: Physics and Physical Phenomena. The first volume on optics contains 10 Books. Book 1: Introduction, the nature of magic--natural, artificial, prohibited--and discussion of each. Book 2: Ocular anatomy and vision, the nature of light and it propagation. Book 3: Anamorphosis and projection. Book 4: Naturally Occurring Images and Visual Phenomena. Book 5: Color. Book 6: Catoptrics and Mirrors. Book 7: Burning Mirrors. Book 8: Images from Mirrors. Book 9: Dioptrics and Lenses. Book 10: Telescopes and Microscopes.||Book 1 is an overview of Magic; that is the study and revelation of the operation of the world. Its purpose was 'to bring hidden, recondite things to light'--as the work's preface has it. Magic was Natural, Artificial, and Prohibited. Natural magic reveal phenomena in nature, artificial magic reveal the functioning of machines and instruments, and prohibited magic delt with the demonic and supernatural. Book 2 presents the ocular anatomy of Scheiner's Oculus of 1619 and a considerable simplification and practicalization of the scholastic teaching on the nature of light. Schott suppresses the distinction between lux and lumen, and regards the fundamental mechanism of vision as the intromission of visible species emitted by objects. Visible species move rectilinearly, and so traditional geometrical optics can be used to both explain and analyze direct, reflected, and refracted vision. Though citing Kepler, Descartes, and Scheiner, Schott find them 'dark, difficult, and almost unbelievable' and so presents a hybrid of ideas: visible species enter the eye, pass through the lens and fall the retina, which he asserts is the seat of vision. There is no ray gathering or focusing by the lens--visible species is the communicating entity between object and retina. Even at the relatively late date at which Schott wrote, he holds it necessary to present an elaborate refutation of the theory of vision rays emitted by the eye.||The anamorphosis material in book 3 is from Niceron's <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> of 1638. The material on catoptrics in book 6 is traditional and borrows heavily from Kircher's <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i> of 1646. The material on burning mirrors is an example of the renaissance interest in this subject, and borrows heavily from Della Porta and Kircher. The material on refraction covers the elementary aspects of convex and concave lenses and is entirely practical and instrument-based, including magnifiers and lanterns generating beams of light.||The telescope and microscope material in book 10 is likewise practical, giving and overview and directions for constructing and using both instruments, including lens grinding and mounting. The figures in this section suffer from the fancy of the engraver; what should be shown as (just) an eye, is depicted as an entire man, and so the instruments appear wildly out of proportion.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Philosophia, Historia, Technica: Caspar Schotts Magia Universalis<i>|Unverzagt, D.|Dissertation, Technical Universtiy of Berlin, 2000, 340 p.||<i>Jesuit Science and the End of Nature‚Äôs Secrets<i>|Waddell, M.A.|Routledge, New York, 2015, pp 165-182.
BP_Title: P. Gasparis Schotti Regis Curiani e Societate Jesu, Olim in Panormitano Siciliae, nunc in Herbipolitano Franconiae Gymnasio ejusdem Societatis Jesu Matheseos Professoris. Magia Univeralis Naturae et Artis, sive: Recondita naturalium & artificialium rerum scientia, cujus ope per variam applicationem activorum cum passivis, admirandorum effectuum spectacula, abditarumque inventionum miracula, ad various humanae vitae usus, eruuntur. Opus Quadripartitum. Pars I. continet Optica, II. Acoustica, III. Mathematica, IV. Physica. Singularum Epitomen sequens Praefatio obiter, accuratius vero uniuscuiusque peculiare praeloquium exponit. Cum figuris aeri inc<i>Isis<i>, & Privilegio Sacrae Caesareae Majestatis.
BP_Title English Translation: Father Gaspar Schott, Royal Council and The Society of Jesus, Formerly of Palermo Sicily, now Professor of Mathematics in the School of the same Society of Jesus at Wurzburg Bavaria. The Universal Magic of Nature and Art, or:  Recondite Knowledge of Natural and Artificial Things Unearthed with the Help of Some Active and Passive Agents, Wonderful Spectacular Effects, and Hidden Miraculous Inventions, For Various Uses in Human LIfe. A Four-Part Work: I contains Optics, II Acoustics, III Mathematics, IV Physics. Incidently, An Eptiome Follows the Preface, But  Each is Explained More Accurately in Individual Prologues. With Copper-Incised Figures and the Privilage of His Sacred Imperial Majesty.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, student of Athanasius Kircher, taught in Sicily, studied in Rome. An experimentalist and extensive correspondant, a compiler and editor rather than an author.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Posthumous, second French edition of Descartes' natural philosophy, including two of the three essays Descartes wrote to demonstrate his new method of natural philosophy: La Dioptrique on optics and  vision, Les Meteores on atmospheric phenomena.
BP_Description_1: Ren√© Descartes's <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i> has it roots in what has been called his micro-mechanical conception of natural philosophy--all physical action, activity, or result was generated, transmitted, or sensed by means of the interaction of particulate matter. He referred to this as 'physico-mathematics' and was his replacement for Scholastic teachings in natural philosophy. Optics was a life-long interest of Descartes, and his earliest study was that of refraction, written in 1619-1921. The first full expression of these and other ideas was his <i>La Monde<i>, nearly completed by 1633, but not published in his lifetime due to the shock created by the condemnation of Galileo in that year. <i>La Monde<i> set out Descartes' mechanical theory of light, described vortex celestial mechanics, and advanced a Copernican cosmography.||Criticisms and commentaries Descartes received after the <i>Discours<i> appeared in 1637 prompted him to consider a second French edition which would include objections and responses. But by 1639 the publisher Jean Maire reported that the book had sold poorly and a second French edition was not practical. In 1644 a Latin translation appeared, lightly edited by Descartes and lacking the <i>La Geometrie<i>. The Latin would sell well and begin the advance of Cartesian thought in Europe. The initial intellectual interest in Descartes' work was limited to the natural philosophy contained in the essays. Within 30 years, Descartes' physics was augmented with an experimental component, became part of the teaching curriculum in an ever-larger number of schools, and formed the basis of widely used textbooks. Cartesian physics would sweep aside Scholasticism and be dominant in Europe until the rise of Newtonianism in the first quarter of the 18th century.||This edition is a very close reprinting of the text of 1637, excluding <i>La Geometrie<i>. The latter had been found too technical for general reading, and a separate edition of a Latin translation of <i>La Geometrie<i> with commentary had by this time been produced by van Schooten, so it was not printed in this or subsequent editions. It is known that the edition of 1637 did not sell well, and the same was true for this edition. At the time of publisher Henry le Gras' death in 1662, there were still 480 copies unsold. Editions of the French text of the <i>Discours<i> appeared at Leiden in 1637 and at Paris in 1658, and twice in 1668.
BP_Description_2: Ren√© Descartes's <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i> has it roots in what has been called his micro-mechancial conception of natural philosophy--all physical action, activity, or result was generated, transmitted, or sensed by means of the interaction of particulate matter. He referred to this as 'physico-mathematics' and was his replacement for Scholastic teachings in natural philosophy. Optics was a life-long interest of Descartes, and his earliest study was that of refraction, written in 1619-1921. The first full expression of these and other ideas was his <i>La Monde<i>, nearly completed by 1633, but not published in his lifetime due to the shock created by the condemnation of Galileo in that year. <i>La Monde<i> set out Descartes' mechanical theory of light, described vortex celestial mechanics, and advanced a Copernican cosmography.||In the following three years, Descartes reworked La Monde, removing its Copernican elements, writing what would become the <i>Discours de la M√©thode<i>, along with its three demonstrative essays <i>La Dioptrique<i> on light and vision, <i>Les Meteores<i> on atmospheric phenomena and optics, and <i>La Geomoetrie<i> which introduced analytic geometry. It is known that the essays were produced in order of <i>La Dioptrique, Les Meteores, La Geomoetrie<i> and that the <i>Discours<i> itself was written last. Printing was also in that order and took nearly a year. Written and printed before the rest of the book, copies of La Dioptrique and Les Meteores were known to circulate in Europe in 1636. These copies are from the library of Count Ricatti. These advanced copies--as it were--of two of the essays drew responses, questions, and criticisms from several European scholars. These and others Descartes received after the <i>Discours<i> appeared in 1637 prompted Descartes to consider a second French edition which would included objections and responses. But by 1639 the publisher Jean Maire reported that the book had sold poorly and a second French edition was not practical. In 1644 a Latin translation appeared, lightly edited by Descartes and lacking the <i>La Geometrie<i>. The Latin would sell well and begin the advance of Cartesian thought in Europe. The initial intellectual interest in Descartes' work was limited to the natural philosophy contained in the essays. Within 30 years, Descartes' physics was augmented with an experimental component, became part of the teaching curriculum in an ever-larger number of schools, and formed the basis of widely used textbooks. Cartesian physics would sweep aside Scholasticism and be dominant in Europe until the rise of Newtonianism in the first quarter of the 18th century.||Editions of the French text of the <i>Discours<i> appeared at Leiden in 1637 and at Paris in 1658, and twice in 1668. The Latin translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1644, twice in 1650, twice in 1656, in 1663, 1664, 1672, 1677, 1685, and twice in 1692; at London in 1664 and Frankfurt in 1692. An English translation appeared at London in 1649. A Dutch translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1656, 1659, and 1692.
BP_Reference(s): The literature on Descartes and his optics is vast. I have found the following particularly helpful||ùëª <i>Ren√© Descartes: Discourse on Method, Optics, Geometry, and Meteorology<i>|Olscamp, P.J., Translator|Hackett, Cambridge, 2001, 388 p.||ùëª <i>Descartes: The World and Other Writings<i>|Gaukroger, S., Translator|Cambridge University Press, 1998, 208p.||<i>Descartes and the Hyperbolic Quest: Lens Making Machines¬†and their Signifcance in the Seventeenth Century<i>|Burnett, D.G.|American Philosophical Society, 2005, 152 p.||<i>A Bibliography of the Works of Descartes I & II<i>|van Otegem, M.|Quaestiiones Infinitae, Vol 37|Publications of the Leiden-Utrecht Research Institute of Philosophy, Utrecht, 2002, 779 p.||'Dioptrics' and 'Optics'|McDonough, J.|In: <i>The Cambridge Descartes Lexicon<i>|Cambridge University Press, 2015, NB: pp 197-199 and 550-559.||Descartes's Experimental Journey Past the Prism and Through the Invisible World to the Rainbow|Buchwald, J.Z.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 65, No 1, pp 1-46.||<i>Descartes's Theory of Light and Refraction: A Discourse on Method<i>|Smith, A.M.|Transactions of the American Philosophical Society, New Series, Vol 77, No 3, 1987, 92 p.||The logic of disguise: Descartes' discovery of the law of refraction|Heeffer, A.|<i>Historia Scientiarum<i>, Vol 16, No 2, 2006, pp 144-165.|https://www.researchgate.net/publication/293490604_The_Logic_of_Disguise_Descartes'_Discovery_of_the_Sine_Law
BP_Title: Discours de la Methode Pour bien conduire sa raison, & chercher la verit√© dans les sciences. Plus La Dioptrique et les Meteores Qui sont des essais de cete Methode.
BP_Title English Translation: Discourse on the Method for Rightly Conducting Reason, and Investigating the Truth in the Sciences:  Plus Dioptrices and Meteorology, which are essays on this Method.
BP_Biographical Statement: French philosopher and mathematician. Resident of the Dutch Republic, revolutionary founder of rationalism, prolific writer.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Unknown
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: English translation of the <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> of 1589. Natural Magic is presented as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. Vison, mirrors and lenses are considered in the optics section.
BP_Description_1: This is an anonymous English translation of Giambattista Della Porta's <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> of 1589, which was significant expansion of his early book on natural magic of 1558. For Della Porta, Natural Magic was the practical part of natural philosophy and focused on exceptional, unusual, extraordinary phenomena, rather than the quotidian. It was the recognition and mastering of natural phenomena, in particular, those phenomena that had to be sought out, phenomena that were otherwise hidden. The point was not to explain the phenomena, but to be able to (re)produce it, display it, describe it and thus reveal nature's secrets. The author and the book changed considerably in the nearly thirty years that separated the first and second editions. Della Porta had mastered a large portion of classical humanist studies by 1589, including the medieval encyclopedias of secrets. From the latter, the scope of the book expanded considerably, and Della Porta established a long list of secrets which the second edition of the Magiae Naturalis was to 'reduce all those secrets into their  proper places.' The second edition is also considerably more experimental in the sense of the direct manipulation of nature. But one aspect of the book and its author did not change: the notion that explaining natural phenomena and unlocking the secrets of nature are fundamentally esoteric activities. Alchemy and Optics are significant portions of the Magiae Naturalis of 1589.|The <i>Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti<i> established Della Porta's reputation as Europe's leading authority on natural magic. The book was tremendously popular and commercially successful; Antwerp's Pantin Press and Frankfurt's Wechel press were among dell Porta's publishers. Printings of the second Latin edition appeared in 1589, 1591, 1592, 1597, 1600, 1607, 1619, 1644, 1650, 1651, and 1664. An Italian translation appeared in 1611, a German translation appeared at Magdeburg in 1612 and 1617, French translations appeared at Lyon in 1615 and at Rouen in 1657, an English translation appeared at London in 1658 and 1659.
BP_Description_2: Giambattista Della Porta presents natural magic as the practical part of natural philosophy; that is, instruments, practice, and effects. There are 20 books: 1: Of the Causes of Wonderful things, 2: Of the Generation of Animals. 3:Of the Production of New Plants. 4: Of increasing Household Stuff. 5: Of changing Metals. 6: Of counterfeiting Gold. 7: Of the Wonders of the Loadstone. 8: Of strange Cures. 9: Of Beautifying Women. 10: Of Distillation.11: Of Perfuming. 12: Of Artificial Fires. 13: Of Tempering Steel. 14: Of Cookery. 15: Of Fishing, Fowling, Hunting, etc. 16: Of Invisible Writing. 17: Of Catoptric Images. 18: Of Statick Experiments. 19: Pneumatic Experiments. 20: Of the Chaos.  Of all the material covered, that considered in book 17 on vison, mirrors and lenses, is probably the most important, it was certainly that with the most extensive and lasting effect. It contains 23 topics: Plane mirrors; Plane mirror illusions; Mirrors for display and the theater; Concave mirrors; Plane and concave mirrors together; Other operations with concave mirrors; How to see in the dark, that which is illuminated by torches; How without a mirror or other device an image can hand in the air; Mixtures of mirrors and their images; The Crystalline Lens and its effects; Lenses for seeing far beyond what can be imagined; Camera obscura; Crystal prism; Burning mirrors; Parabolic burning mirrors and their construction; Parabolic section construction; Parabolic section for burning at infinite distances; Burning glass from spherical sections; Kindling fire more forcefully with refraction; Image outside a concave mirror; Making mirrors; Making plane, convex, and concave mirrors with applied and bonded foil; Making metallic mirrors.||Della Porta is not interested in explaining optical phenomena--he refers the reader to Archimedes, Euclid, Ptolemy, and Witelo--nor does he aim to discern and study the laws of optics to explain the effects. Rather, he seeks to demonstrate and show how it is possible to increase the effect of optical phenomena. The most influential topics are the camera obscura and lenses. Della Porta had added a mirror to the camera obscura to right the image, but by 1589 he places a lens in the aperture to clarify and amplify the image, and more importantly, to make the first suggestion that the eye is like a camera obscura. Concave mirrors are discussed and their numerous images presented in considerable detail. It is in connection with mirror images that Della Porta introduces the point of inversion (where rays cross, the focus) and the use of the cathetus to predict image location.
BP_Reference(s): Knowing by doing in sixteenth-century natural magic: Giambattista della Porta and the wonders of nature|Saito, F.|<i>Circumscribere<i>, Vo1 14, 2014, pp 17-39||<i>Science and the Secretes of Nature: Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture<i>|Eamon, W.|Princeton University Press, 1994, 490 pp, pp 210-233.||The Optics of Giambattista della Porta(ca. 1535‚Äì1615): A Reassessment|Borrelli, A., Hon, G., Zik, Y., editors|Springer, 2017, 205 pp, NB: pp 169-200.
BP_Title: Natural Magick in Twenty Books
BP_Biographical Statement: Neoplitan scholar, polymath, and natural philosopher. Prolific author, showman, and founder of the Academia Secretorum Naturae, the first scientific society.
BP_Provenance: Bookplates of T.N. Brushfield, E.N. da C. Andrade, and Norman Travis

BP_Short or Common Title: Observationes ad Pomponium Melam de Situ Orbis
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An editing of Pomponius Mela's Latin text <i>De situ orbis libri III<i>, followed by Voss's observations. In those, Voss attempts to explain Mela's recording of mountain residents' and sailors' reports of 'atmospheric fire' by considering the nature of light and atmospheric refraction.
BP_Description_1: Isaac Voss was interested in geography and the texts of the ancients, which led him to take up the project of editing Pomponius Mela's <i>Chorographia<i>, later popularized by Petrarch as <i>De situ orbis libri III<i>. Voss's text was more commentary than philology and included his own extensive observations. His commentary is approximately 5 times longer than Mela's text. This included attempts to explain what Mela recorded being seen by mountain top residents' and sailors' reports of 'atmospheric fire' by considering the nature of light and atmospheric refraction. This project was at the cusp of Voss's interests turning from textual work to the study of the phenomena texts described. In the present case, Voss's interest in and commentary on the optical phenomenon reported by Mela marked the beginning of his work in optics. Optical concepts Voss outlined and invoked in his <i>Observationes<i> would be developed and form the basis for his <i>De Lucis Natura<i> of 1662.||Editions of Voss's <i>Observationes<i> appeared at the Hague in 1658 and at Franeker in 1700.
BP_Description_2: Voss's work is a commentary is on Mela's recording of mountain residents' and sailors' reports of 'atmospheric fire.' Residents of Mount Ida in northwestern Turkey, some 20 miles southeast of the ruins of Troy, reported a luminous phenomena at sunrise: lights would begin appearing on the sea's horizon, then gather into a single 'flame', into which the sphere of the sun would then rise. Voss's extensive commentary includes ancient sources citing the same phenomena at Ida and other mountains, and more recent accounts of seamen for similar phenomena. All of which Voss presents as proof of the actual existence of the optical display. The problem had been historically interesting--and unexplained to Voss's satisfaction--because it was only seen from near the top of the mountain, and not from the plains at its base. Voss's explanation was essentially an analysis of lines-of-sight as affected by atmospheric refraction--as defined by Voss. His explanation of the phenomenon was based on claims he made for the nature of the atmosphere,  the properties of atmospheric refraction, and the nature of refraction itself. In these, Voss parted from most recognized optical authorities of the time, asserting, for example, that the atmosphere was homogeneous and that refraction did not take place only at the interface of media but within (even homogeneous) media. These would be extensively developed and become tenets in his <i>De Lucis Natura<i> of 1662.
BP_Reference(s): A View from the Mountaintop: The Development of Isaac Vossius' Optics, 1658-1666|Dijksterhus, F.J.|In: <i>Isaac Vossius (1618-1689) between Science and Scholarship<i>, Brill, Leiden, 2012, pp 159-187.||Pomponius Mela|Milham, M.E.|In: <i>Catalogus Translationum et Commenariorum<i>,  Vol 5.|The Catholic Universrity of America Press, 1984, pp 257-285.
BP_Title: Observationes ad Pomponium Melam de Situ Orbis. Ipse Mela a longe quam antehac emendatior praemittitur
BP_Title English Translation: Observations on Pomponius Mela's De Situ Orbis.  Which Mala himself brought forward more correctly than any in the distant past.
BP_Biographical Statement: German scholar, linguist, libraian, and book collector on a grand scale. Came late in life to mathematics and natural philosophy, and then only via books not experimentation.
BP_Provenance: Old inscriptions and library stamp of Grefeld Gymnasium on titlepage.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A work on the nature of light and colors and planetary astronomy. Unimpressed with Descartes or Gassendi, the presentation on light and color is strictly Aristotelian.  All in the form of a classic scholastic dialog.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Baptiste Du Hamel's work on light and color is a summary of then-current theories of Gassendi and Descartes set against traditional Aristotelian teaching. 'Modern' theories are considered, explained, and found wanting. His work on planetary astronomy has its root in his early <i>Elementa Astronomia<i> of 1643 and considers: the nature and motion of celestial bodies; various theories of the motion of the earth, moon, and sun; the fixed stars; and various aspects of practical observational astronomy. Both the optical and astronomical material is presented in the form of a Galilean dialogue involving Simplicius (expressing the views of La Chambre), Meander (expressing the views of Descartes), and Theophilus (the views of Honor√© Fabri).||Though Du Hamel had a considerable reputation during his life--first secretary and historian of the Acad√©mie Royale des Sciences--his works of this type were of little influence, being essentially summaries and reactionary defenses of Aristotelianism. Nevertheless, and for that very reason, the <i>Astronomia Physica<i> marks and documents the mounting struggle against Cartesianism in France.||Editions appeared in 1660 and again in the <i>Operum Philosophicorum<i> of 1681.
BP_Description_2: Du Hamels' work is in two books. Book 1: On Light and Color; Book 2: On the Nature and Motion of Celestial Bodies. The book on light and color (60 pages) has four chapters. Chapter 1: On the Nature of Light; Chapter 2: On the Motion of Light; Chapter 3: On the Cause of Light; Chapter 4: On the Nature and Diversity of Color.||Chapter 1 presents the Peripatetic theory of light with the distinction between lux and lumen, the Epicurean theory of Gassendi in which light is an effluvium continuously emitted by luminous objects, and the Cartesian in which light an impulse in an aetherial substance that fills the plenum. All are rejected and the Aristotelian theory is defended. Chapter 2 presents light diffusing from all points on a luminous object, until it strikes an opaque surface and is reflected, or a transparent surface and is refracted. Various laws of and mechanisms for refraction are presented. Chapter 3 briefly examines the Aristotelian causes of light and the nature of vision. Chapter 4 presents a color theory similar to La Chambre, with color being fixed and innate and the distinction between real and apparent colors is incorrect. The number and sequence of colors is also discussed.||The material is presented in the form of a Galilean dialogue involving Simplicius (expressing the views of La Chambre), Meander (expressing the views of Descartes), and Theophilus (the views of Honor√© Fabri). The arguments made by Meander are, by far, the weakest. The presentation is entirely descriptive, no mathematics of any kind is used.||Appended at the end of Book 2 are a series of papers by Petit on the solar eclipse visible from Paris on 14 November 1639, on magnetic dip, and on the system of the world.
BP_Reference(s): De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Duhamel en Vossius in de periode 1640‚Äì1670 (in Dutch)|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.
BP_Title: Astronomia Physica seu de luce, natura, et motibus corporum caelestium libro duo. In Priori Libro de lumine, & coloribus agitur. In posteriori universa Astronomia tum speculatrix, tum practica Physice, & Geometrice, citra Euclidis opem demonstratur. Accessere Petri Petiti Observationes aliquot eclipsum soli & Lunae: cum Dissertationibus de laittudine Lutetiae, Declinatione Magnetis, necnon de novo systemate mundi quod Anonymus dudum proposit.
BP_Title English Translation: Physical Astronomy, or Two Books on the Light, Nature and Motion of Celestial Bodies. In the First Book Light and Colors is discussed. In the Second: Speculative as well as Univeral Astronomy, Practical Physics and Geometry without the help of Euclid is Demonstrated. Added are a Number of Observations of Peter Petit on the Eclipse of the Sun and Moon, with a Dissertation on the Latitude of Paris, the Magnetic Declination, and also a new System of the World Proposed Anonymously a Short While Ago.
BP_Biographical Statement: French scholar, one-time member of the Congregation of the Oratory, and founding secretary of the Academie Royale des Sciences. By avocation an historian of science.
BP_Provenance: Inscription for the Jesuit College at Paris. Bookplate of R. Rickaert.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with De Meteoris et Fossiblibus Libri Duo

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary of meteorological phenomena and a consideration of the nature and Use of things excavated from the ground. The Aristotelian views of La Chambre on nature of light, color, and the rainbow are aggressively presented, and those of Descartes weakly so. All in the form of a classic scholastic dialog involving.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Baptiste Du Hamel's work on meteorics and excavated things (earths, stones, gems, and metals) was written in defense of long-held Aristotelian teachings and as a bulwark against the rising tide of Cartesianism and the 'new chemistry' based on elements rather than differing aggregations of fundamental corpuscles. Editions appeared in 1660 and again in the <i>Operum Philosophicorum<i> of 1681.
BP_Description_2: Du Hamel's work is in two books. Book 1: On Meteorics. Book 2: On the Nature, Cause, and Use of Things Excavated. Book 1 has five chapters: On meteorics in general and their material; On the sources of the heat and salt of the oceans and seas; On the influence of the ground and air; Fiery meteorics; The rainbow, corona, and other apparent influences. Book 2 has 12 chapters: The principles and causes of fossils in general; Types of earth; On salt and niter; Other salts in general; Sulfur and bitumen; Stones in general; Different types of stones; Gems; Metals in general; Separation of precious metals; Preparation of metals; Uses of metals. The Aristotelian views of La Chambre on nature of light, color, and the rainbow are aggressively presented, and those of Descartes weakly so. All in the form of a classic scholastic dialog involving Menander, Simplicius, and Theophilus.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, 376 pp, NB: pp 228-230.||De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Duhamel en Vossius in de periode 1640‚Äì1670|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.
BP_Title: De Meteoris et Fossilibus Libri Duo. In Priore Libro mixta imperfecta, quaeque in sublimi aere vel gignuntur, bel apparent, fuse pertractantur. Posterior Liber mixta perfecta complectitur; ube salium, bituminium, lapidum, gemmarum, & metalllorum naturae, causae, & usus inquiruntur.
BP_Title English Translation: Two Books on Meteorology and Fossils. In the first book, an incomplete collection of those things that appear high in the air are fully investigated. In the second book, a complete collection, where the nature, causes, and uses of salts, asphalt, stones, gems, and metals are investigated.
BP_Biographical Statement: French scholar, one-time member of the Congregation of the Oratory, and founding secretary of the Academie Royale des Sciences. By avocation an historian of science.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Astronomia Physica

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Early, detailed guide to manufacturing lenses for telescopes, spectacles, and microscopes. Though citing and influenced by the theory in Kepler's Dioptrice of 1611, the material is based on perfected practice and experience.
BP_Description_1: The origin and purpose of Manzini's <i>L' Occhiale all'occhio<i> are clear from his preface: He hopes to provide both theoretical basis and practical guidance for the making of spectacle and telescope lenses. He reports traveling around Italy and finding practitioners keeping craft secrets and passing on knowledge orally to apprentices; all without a sound understanding of principles. None of this helps the 'divine mission', he writes, since hard-won and valuable experience is not being recorded and passed on to other practitioners. And he can find no satisfactory written guide to lens making. By Manzini's time, spectacle making had been a craft practiced for three centuries, but though telescope lens making had it roots in that craft, the requirements for precision and quality for telescope lenses surpassed what was acceptable for spectacle lenses. By 1650 telescopes of sufficient power and clarity had been used to see the shadows on Jupiter cast by its moons, discovered the nebula in the constellation Orion, detected the belts of Jupiter and the markings on Mars, mapped detailed lunar features, and seen that Mizar was a double star. The demand for quality telescope lenses was very great.||Manzini's book was a watershed in telescope technology literature. Had built on his Bologna estate an observatory, made his own telescopes, and ground and polished his own lenses. So, he was both user and creator of telescope lenses. In addition, he had worked with the prominent lens-makers, including Eustachio Divini, the greatest practitioner of the age. Manzini's book was a compendium of basic optical theory and practical experience regarding lens making. He distilled optical theory into brief, preliminary chapters, leaving the majority of the book for extensive, detailed, discussions of lens making practice. Significant attention is devoted to spectacle lenses as well, resulting in specific recommendations for lens curvature and age.||Manzini honors Divini by using his portrait as a frontispiece.
BP_Description_2: Manzini's books has 28 short chapters. Chapters 1-5 present a history of the telescope lens, a discussion of the nature of light and its refraction, and an overview the eye and vision. Chapters 6-12 deal with glass, spectacles, and correction of vision. Chapters 13-18 consider types of telescopes and the lenses that are required. Finally, Chapters 19-28 give the detailed process for cutting, figuring, and polishing lenses.||Though Manzini knows Ren√© Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> and Johannes Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i>, he gives only a descriptive summary of the theories of light and its interaction with with materials. He does explain how to measure the refractive power of glass. The material on the eye and vision has an emphasis on the mechanism of vision, how it can be or become defective, and how spectacle lenses and correct vision. This includes tables for finding the radius of curvature for lenses for a given visual correction. The discussion on glass types is entirely practical, giving brief descriptions of formulations and qualities. Examples are provided for designing telescopes, including determining lens types, focal lengths, and resulting required radii of lens curvature. For this, Manzini develops his own symbolic notion for the analysis and specification of multiple lens systems. Though Manzini believes the very best lenses are hand made, he does give examples of vertical and horizontal lathes and machines that can be used for shaping and polishing lenses. The final 70 pages give a detailed and step-by-step process for making lenses, including the materials required for forms and patterns, types of glass, cutting glass blanks, figuring methods both by hand and my machine, the use of test methods and instruments to check lens properties, and lens polishing.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Renaissance Vision from Spectacles to Telescopes<i>|Ilardi, V.|American Philosophical Society, 2007, 366 pp, NB: pp 229-233.||Lens Making for Scientific Instrumentation in the Seventeenth Century|Bedini, S.A.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 5, No 5, 1966, pp 687-694.||Kepler's legacy: Telescopes and geometrical optics, 1611-1669|Malet, A.|In: <i>The Origins of the Telescope<i>, KNAW Press, Amsterdam, 2010, pp 292-295.||Testing Telescope Optics of Seventeenth-Century Italy|Molesini, G.|In: <i>The Origins of the Telescope<i>, KNAW Press, Amsterdam, 2010, pp 271-279.
BP_Title: L' Occhiale all'occhio, Dioptrica Pratica: Dove si tratta della luce; della refrattione de raggi; dell'occhio; della vista; e de gli aiuti, che dare si possono a gli occhi per vedere quasi l'impossibile. Dove oltre si spiegano le Regole Pratiche di Fabbricare Occhilai a tutte le Viste, e Cannocchiali da osservare i Pianeti, e le Stelle Fisse, da Terra, da Mare et altri da ingrandire Migliaia de volte i minimi de gli Oggetti vicini.
BP_Title English Translation: Eye Glasses: Practical Dioptrics. Which deals with Light, Refraction of Rays, Vision and its Aid, and that Which Can Permit Your Eyes to See Almost the Impossible. Besides which explains the Practical Rules for Making Eye Glasses for All Views, and Telescopes to Observe the Planets, and the Fixed Stars from the Earth from the Sea, and Others to be Magnified Thousands of Times the Minimum of Nearby Objects.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian craftsman, optical theoretician, and one of the greatest early practitioners of lens grinding and finishing.
BP_Provenance: With the author's dedication on the titlepage
BP_BibliographicNotes: Portrait of Eustachio Divini drawn by Johann Paul Schor and engraved by Joseph Testana on recto of œá¬π

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A chronology of mixed mathematics in a nonce volume of several works. A brief list of optical works among other lists in Arithmetic, Geometry, Music, Astrology, Geography, and Mechanics.
BP_Description_1: A reissue of the book first printed in 1650, a year after Voss's death, issued with a new title page. Though Voss was primarily interest in the general history of literature, his interests and collected material were so extensive that they included material on the history of pure and mixed mathematics. Voss was a philologist and historian, not a mathematician, so some of his information was inaccurate but he was the first to use philology and new methods of the study of his sources to produce his historical review of mathematics. He emphasized the translations of Greek classic authors into Arabic and thereafter from Arabic into Latin. Voss considered the publication of translations as important as the publication of original works. The indices include those for objects, words, names, and subjects.||The book first appears in 1650 and was reissued in 1660.
BP_Description_2: Voss began with the history of numbers and symbols, and then systematically presented sections on geometry, arithmetic, optics, music, mechanics, logistics, geodesy, astronomy, calendar, chronology.||Optics is considered in the context of several topics: geometry, the rainbow, perspective, vision, architecture, painting, war, geography and its triple nature: direct, reflected, and refracted vision. The optical works cited include the usual ancient authors, including some obscure ones, the major medieval Arabic and Western authors, works on geometric optics and meteorological optics, Renaissance authors, and contemporary works including those of Descartes.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Historia matheseos. Early development stage of the history of mathematics, historiography<i>|Sinkevich G.I.|At: Cornell University,  arXiv:1707.01774v1|http://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.01774
BP_Title: Chronologia Mathematicorum Libri Tres.  In: De Quatuor Artibus Popularibus, de Philologia, et scientiis mathematicis, cui operi subjungitur, chronologia mathematicorum
BP_Title English Translation: Three books of the Chronology of Mathematics. In: The four Popular Arts of Philology and the Mathematical Sciences, to which is added the Chronology of Mathematics.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch scholar, linguist, historian, and theologian.
BP_Provenance: Bookplates of the Turner Collection at the University of Keele, and David Smyth
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Quatuor Artibus Popularibus de Philologica and Scientiis Mathematicis

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third, posthumous edition of Bourdin's textbook on the fundamentals of several fields, light and vision among them, each presented by a single plate of figures, each demonstrating a fundamental element and accompanied by paragraph of rudimentary explanation. Bound with Bourdin's larger but similar works on geometry and military fortification, with an expanded, separately-titled, 25-page section devoted to optics.
BP_Description_1: Third, considerably expanded posthumous edition of Bourdin's <i>Le Cours de Math√©matique<i> has its origin in a course he taught at the Coll√®ge de Clermont beginning in 1636. Its content was informed by the Jesuit's Ratio Studiorum. Existing student notes reveal a very modern pedagogy based on images and figures. Bourdin drew and etched the figures used in the course, had them printed, and distributed them to his students to lighten the note-taking burden and assure accuracy. The etchings and notes form the basis for <i>Le Cours de Mathematique<i>. The course presents a brief introduction to several fields of Mixed Mathematics appropriate for engineers: Arithmetic, Geometry, Music, Mechanics, Optics, and Cosmography. Each is presented by a plate of figures accompanied by numbered notes that are topic outlines and references to figures. Unlike previous editions, Bourdin's material on geometry and fortification is not separated from the main text, but a new, separate 25-page section on optics is added.||It is over optics that in 1640 Bourdain began to famously tangle with Ren√© Descartes, principally over Descartes' plenum of subtle matter, and the mechanisms of reflection and refraction. Editions of <i>Le Cours de Math√©matique<i> appeared in 1641, 1645, and in 1661.
BP_Description_2: Pierre Bourdin's <i>Le Cours de Mathematique<i> presents a brief introduction to several fields of Mixed Mathematics: Arithmetic, Geometry, Music, Mechanics, Optics and Vision, and Cosmography. Each is presented by a plate of 9 figures, each figure demonstrating a fundamental element and accompanied by numbered notes that are topic outlines with references to figures.  The coverage is of the greatest possible concision and is clearly designed to support a course of lectures that would provide necessary detail. The separate section on optics presents figures and notes for: The eye and ocular anatomy, Laws of Vision, Visual Perception, Vison by Direct, Reflected, and Refracted View, Spectacles and Optical Instruments, Keeping Good Vision, Mechanism of Vision and Formation of Images, Perspective View, Camera Obscura and Telescopes, Magnifiers, Plane Mirrors, Convex and Concave Mirrors, Anamorphosis Mirrors, Burning Mirrors. The accompanying figures give the merest, most schematic suggestions or demonstration of the phenomenon described in the outline notes. The notes are detailed but only descriptive; no mathematics is involved. Each subject in covered in one page of notes in small print and one plate of figures.
BP_Reference(s): √âtudes  & Formation des Ing√©nieurs sous Vauban|Catherine Bousquet-Bressolier, C.|In: <i>La commission 'Histoire' du Comit√© Fran√ßais de Cartographie<i>, No 195, 2008, pp 15-26.|http://www.lecfc.fr/new/articles/195-article-3.pdf||<i>Descartes and His Contemporaries: Meditations, Objections, and Replies<i>|Ariew, R., Grene, M.|University of Chicago Press, 1995, NB: pp 209-215.||Descartes and the Jesuits|Ariew, R.|In: <i>Jesuit Science and the Rebulic of Letters<i>|Feingold, M., editor|MIT Press, Cambridge, 2003, 489 pp, NB: pp 157-194.
BP_Title: Le cours de mathematique. (Containing) L'Optique comprenant la Connoissance de L'oeil, de la Lumiere, et des Couleurs
BP_Title English Translation: Optics, Including Knowledge of the Eye, of Light, and of Colors.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, teacher, author. Tangled famously with Descartes.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris inscriptions on title page
BP_Plates: Plates [4-154, 158-187] (Plates appear on recto of leaves, with even page numbering)

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Encyclopedic presentation of all elements of Mixed Mathematics, with three brief sections and 19 figures devoted to light and vision, catoptrics, and dioptrics.
BP_Description_1: Gaspar Schott wrote <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> as a textbook for beginning students of Mixed Mathematics. He makes it clear in his Prooemium that his goal is to explain the essentials of all the subjects in Mixed Mathematics with clarity, limited detail, and in a way appropriate for beginners. He cites Johann Heinrich Alsted's Encyclopaedia of 1630 and Pierre H√©rigone's <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> of 1634-1642 as earlier attempts at encyclopedic textbooks but believes them both unsatisfactory because they attempted to be exhaustive and were too detailed. With beginning students in mind, Schott begins every section with an introduction, sometimes of considerable length, and cites works which the beginner can consult to learn more detail. There are more than 100 different works in Schott's citations and the text is accompanied by 577 figures.||The <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> is organized according to the generally accepted divisions of Mixed Mathematics, covering many areas that would branch into the various fields of natural philosophy. Linking all of them both in order and in connections made between sections, is Schott's belief in the Universality of knowledge, a manifestation of the Llullism he acquired from his teacher Athanasius Kircher. Knowledge is both revealed and understood if the correct structure is adopted and connections made.||The work is dedicated to the young Leopold I, Holy Roman emperor, depicted in the elaborate frontispiece. Even as he wrote it, Schott's <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> was known to and supported by the Jesuit community. It contains three Par√¶neses--exhortations--he received from fellow Jesuits: Athanasius Kircher, the mathematics teacher Balthazar Conrad, and the Polish mathematician and physicist Adam Adamandy Kocha≈Ñski. Schott's encyclopedic textbook would be the model for that of Fran√ßois Milliet Dechales' <i>Cursus<i> of 1674. Editions of <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> appeared at W√ºrzburg in 1661, at Frankfurt in 1674, at Bamburgh in 1677, and Frankfurt in 1699.
BP_Description_2: The  <i>Cursus Mathematicus<i> covers the following subjects with Mixed Mathematics. Arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, astronomy, astrology, chronology, geography, navigation, gnomonics, mechanics, statics, hydrostatics, hydraulic engineering, optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, fortification, warfare, tactics, musical theory, algebra, and logarithms. The only traditional part of Mix Mathematics not covered is civil architecture. Each topic is presented in a book, with some requiring more, for a total of 28 books.  Subjects treated at the greatest length are geography, trigonometry, algebra, and astronomy. The most briefly treated are dioptrics, statics, and tactics.||Three brief books and 19 figures are devoted to light and vision, catoptrics, and dioptrics. Book 19 covers the eye and ocular anatomy, the theory of intromission of luminous species, lux and lumen, and what is called 'practical optics' involving rectilinear propagation and the elementary ideas of geometric optics, simple projection, and shadow casting. Book 20 covers catoptrics including simple mirrors, images produced by reflection, the cathetus law. Plan, convex, and concave mirrors are described and finally burning mirrors are considered. Book 21 covers dioptrics including refraction in general, convex and concave lenses, and magnification. The treatment in the three books devoted to optics is elementary and descriptive. The principal ideas of optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics are merely introduced and very briefly described. No mathematics of any kind is invoked, and though very limited, the material would be accessible (and helpful) to a student with no prior knowledge.
BP_Reference(s): Kaspar Schott's 'encyclopedia of all mathematical sciences.'|Knoblock, E.|<i>Poiesis & Praxis<i>, Vol 7, No 4, pp 225-247.
BP_Title: Cursus Mathematicus, sive Absoluta omnium Mathematicarum Disciplinarum encyclopaedia, in Libro XXVIII disgesta, eoque ordine disposita, ut quivis, vel mediocri praeditus ingenio, totam Mathesin a primis fundamentis proprio Marte addiscere possit. Opus desideratum diu, promissum a multis, a non paucis tentatum, a nullo numeris omnibus adsolutum. Accesserunt in fine Theoreses Mechanicae Novae.
BP_Title English Translation: A Mathematical Course, or  The Encyclopedia of Absoluately All Mathematical Disciplines, Arranged in 23 Books, and placed in that Order such that Anyone with Even Modest Ability, can Learn the Fundamentals of Mathematics From their Own Strength. The Work Desired for a Long Time, Promissed to Many, Tried by not a Few with None Complete in Every Way.  There is Added at the End New Theories of Mechanics.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, student of Athanasius Kircher, taught in Sicily, studied in Rome. An experimentalist and extensive correspondant, a compiler and editor rather than an author.
BP_Provenance: Inscription from Dachsberg (Germany) on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The nature of light and refraction. Adhering to image formation ideas from Witelo and Alhazen rather than those of ray propagation of Kepler. Famously accused Descartes of plagiarism by presenting a manuscript of Snell that shows the sine law of refraction.
BP_Description_1: Isaac Voss' <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> has its origins with Voss' study of the optical phenomena reported by  Pomponius Mela involving, the sea, the atmosphere, and the rising sun. In his commentary on Mela of 1658, Voss added an extended note offering an explanation for the phenomena. In doing so he set down several controversial claims that departed significantly from generally accepted ideas. The most bumptious of which was that refraction does not take place only at the interface between two media of different densities, but rather continuously throughout a medium. The denser the medium, the more pronounced the continuous refraction. The most important and detailed response to Voss' claims was from Pierre-Daniel Huet, Voss' friend, colleague in philology, and cleric-scholar from Caen. Huet objected to Voss claims about the atmosphere and how it refracts, but most strenuously to the claim that refraction is continuous in a medium. The <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> is essentially an extended reply to Huet's objections. In it, the treatment of optics is based on visual perception and images, rather than Keplerian ray propagation. That is, from visual phenomena Voss deduces physical phenomena, rather than the other way around. Though an anti-Cartesian, Voss was not an Aristotelian--he had developed his own peculiar ideas regarding optics.||The <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> contains Voss' recounting of his examination of a manuscript of Willebrord Snell and that he discovered the sine law of refraction before Descartes and its appearance in his La Dioptrique of 1637. This alone made the book popular. Though widely read, the book's collection of extreme differences from Keplerian and Cartesian optics generated wide-spread negative reaction among Cartesians. One was the publication in 1664 of <i>De Natura Ignis, Lucis et Colorum Dissertatio<i> by Andr√© Graindorge, a close acquaintance of Pierre-Daniel Huet. Voss would publish a response in the form of the Appendix <i>ad Scriptum de Natura et Proprietate Lucis<i>, added at the end of his <i>De Nili<i> of 1666.
BP_Description_2: Isaac Voss' <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> has 32 Chapters. Chapters 1-4 cover the theory of light, presenting and dismissing both Cartesian and Gassendian ideas, maintaining instead that light is a type of luminous fire. Chapters 5-13 consider non-corporeal rays of light and their motion in vacuum. Chapters 14-23 presents Voss' ideas on continuous refraction, and refraction in air, water, glass objects. It is in chapter 16 that Voss recounts what he learned from examining a manuscript of Willebrord Snell and in chapter 18 that atmospheric refraction is considered. Chapters 24-28 are on color, which is presented as an entity separate from light, the intrinsic 'sulfurous quality' of an object. Chapters 29-32 cover various aspects of visual perception including the appearance of coronae, the apparent size of objects, what refraction does to solar and lunar observations, and refraction in general.||Voss adheres to image formation ideas from Witelo and Alhazen rather than those of ray propagation of Kepler, emphasizing the continuity of optical phenomena that take place throughout a transparent material, and not at (just) its surface. That is, Voss contends that light is continuously interacting with the transparent medium through which it travels, and so refraction is continuous, as appearances in some visual experiments seem to support.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ A View from the Mountaintop: The Development of Isaac Vossius' Optics, 1658-1666|Dijksterhus, F.J.|In: <i>Isaac Vossius (1618-1689) between Science and Scholarship<i>, Brill, Leiden, 2012, pp 159-187.||De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Dulianiel en Vossius in de periode 1640-1670|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.
BP_Title: De lucis natura et proprietate
BP_Title English Translation: On the Nature and Properties of Light
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch scholar, linguist, libraian, and book collector on a grand scale. Came late in life to mathematics and natural philosophy, and then only via books not experimentation.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of Jules Cuisinier on free endpaper

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by William Rawley
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Small works edited and published by Bacon's friend and literary executor William Rawley, including 12 inquires relating to lux and light. These include sources of light, motion of light, photometry, colors, reflection, chemical effects of light,  phosphoric light, transparency and opacity, and both the affinity and hostility to light.
BP_Description_1: William Rawley was chaplain to Francis Bacon, his literary executor, and foremost champion in the 17th century. As Rawley makes clear in his letter to the reader, he published this posthumous collection of Bacon's essays to bring more of Bacon's ideas to the public, and in particular his ideas on natural philosophy and 'the art of knowing'. The latter includes Bacon's method for the role, type, and use of experiments in establishing certainty in matter of natural philosophy. Newton owned a copy of the 1658 edition of Rawley's Opuscula Francisci Baconi and it was dog-eared at page 17. This page is from Bacon's Historia Densi et Rari and describes Bacon's experimental process (in this case for establishing a table of material densities) culminating in an <i>experimentun crucis<i>. Newton was certainly aware of Bacon's process and its influence can be detected in Newton's letter Concerning a New Theory of Light and Colors of 1672. In addition to Bacon's <i>Historia Densi <i>and <i>Rari<i>, Rawley's text includes the brief <i>Topica Inquisitionis de Luce & Lumine<i>, Bacon's directions for a general inquiry of the nature of light and color.||Editions of Rawley's edited text appeared at London in 1658 and at Amsterdam in 1663.
BP_Description_2: William Rawley's  <i>Opuscula Francisci Baconi<i> contains smaller works on philosophy, government, and theology. The work begins with a life of Bacon written by Rawley, then: Historia Densi et Rari, Historia & Inqusisition de Sone & Audibilibus; Articuli Inquistionis de Metallis & Mineralibus; Inquisitio de Magnete; Inquisition de Versionibus, Transmutationibus, Mutiplicationibus, & Effectionbus Corporum; Topica Inquistionis de Luce & Lumine; Espistol Fugentium; In felicem memoriam Elizabethae Anglliae Reginae; Imago Civilis Julii Caesaris; Imago Civilis Aususti Caesaries; Confessio Fidei Anglicano.||The bulk of the material deals with natural philosophy, including the measurement of densities, the nature of sound, metals, magnetism, alchemy, and light. The material on densities includes a detailed example of Bacon's experimental process, to test, distinguish, and finally make certain with an experimentum crucis. This was of particular interest to Isaac Newton. The material on light is a list of 12 inquires Bacon considered essential to investigate lux and lumen--Bacon maintaining the medieval distinction between lux and lumen, between interior luminous power and external emitted light. These inquires include sources of light, motion of light, photometry, colors, reflection, chemical effects of light,  phosphoric light, transparency and opacity, and both the affinity and hostility to light. Each is accompanied by commentary and research subjects.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Art of Experimental Natural History: Francis Bacon in Context<i>|Jalobeanu, D.|Zeta Book, 2015, 344 pp, NB: pp 307-315.||Crucial Instances and Crucial Experiments in Bacon, Boyle, and Hooke|Dumitru, C.|<i>Society and Politics<i>, Vol 7, No 1 ,2013, pp 45-61.||<i>Precis de la Philoslophie de Bacon<i>, Vol 2|Delac, J.-A.|Paris, Jean-Luc Nyon, 1802, pp 91-99.||Topica Inquisitionis de Luce et Lumine|In: <i>The Works of Francis Bacon Vol II<i>|Spedding, J., Ellis, R.L., Heath, D.D., editors|Longmon & Co, London, 1857, pp 313-325.
BP_Title: Opuscula Varia Posthuma, Philosophica, Civilia, et Theologica.  Francisci Baconi (Contains) De Topica inquisitionis de luce et lumine
BP_Title English Translation: On the Topic of Inquiry into Lights and Light
BP_Biographical Statement: English philosopher and statesman. Developer of a method of natural philosophy based on observation and data, inference and induction, experimentation and testing.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Roland Freart de Chantelou, sieur de Chambray (1606 - 1676)  French writer, collector, and a theorist of architecture and the arts.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Euclid's Greek text of the theorems of his Optica, as produced by Jean Pena in 1557, translated to French and accompanied by the translator‚Äôs commentary and demonstrations.
BP_Description_1: Roland Freart de Chantelou's dedication to the king gives his reason for translating Euclid's <i>Optica<i>: Though his work on geometry had been known, studied, and used for 2000 years, his work on optics was relatively unknown and had never appeared in French. It's importance to and effect on perspective, painting, and architecture required that it be better known. In de Chantelou's long letter to the reader, he gives a summary of the principal aspects of Euclid's theory of optics--the extromission of visual rays and their rectilinear propagation--and presents several ancient and medieval commentator's arguments of its plausibility. In the end,  de Chantelou writes that it makes no difference in which direction rays move--out from or into the eye--their geometry is the same as is their importance to the foundation of perspective, art, and architecture.||de Chantelou presents the 12 axioms and the statements of the 61 theorems as found in Jean Pena's Greek text of 1557, but provides his own demonstrations and commentary. A translation of Euclid's optics is a natural consequence of and support for de Chantelou's more famous work, <i>IdeÃÅe de la perfection de la peinture deÃÅmonstreÃÅe par les principes de l'art<i>, published in 1662. They are sometimes found bound together.
BP_Description_2: In de Chantelou's long letter to the reader he presents Euclid's Greek text as having come down from Theon of Alexandria and adopted by several ancient and medieval commentators.  de Chantelou notes that Euclid's 12 axioms are contested by 'the Moderns' but are reconsidered in light of practical considerations that make them plausible. The basic Euclidian idea of rectilinear visual rays being emitted by the eye as the foundation for vision is presented as plausible in that is explains several common experiences. These include visual size being proportional to the angle of visual rays apprehending an object and the difficulty of seeing a needle on the ground. The latter is presented as speaking against the idea that objects forming images in the eye, since such a needle is often not found in one glance. Repeated looking is usually required, supporting the idea that eventually visual rays strike the needle and it is visually apprehended. This would not be case if apprehension were image-based, since any glance would provide an image of the needle. That de Chantelou presents this and other visual experiences that support Euclid's ideas arises from his attachment to the knowledge and sense of the ancients. A kind of epistemological piety. In the end, de Chantelou states it doesn't matter in which direction rays move, since the geometry is the same and so the laws of perception and linear perspective are unchanged.||He presents the 12 axioms and text of the 61 theorems as found in Jean Pena's Greek of 1557, but does not translate the demonstrations; rather, he provides his own. They are longer and more descriptive than those of the Greek text, rely heavily on the 12 axioms, and use his own figures.
BP_Reference(s): Les traductions fran√ßaises des ≈ìuvres d'Euclide|Lacoarret, M.|<i>Revue d'histoire des sciences et de leurs applications<i>, Vol 10, No 1, 1957,  pp 38-58.||Liber de visu : The Greco-Latin Translation of Euclid's Optics|Theisen, W.R.|<i>Mediaeval Studies<i>, Vol 41, 1979, pp 44-105.||ùëª The Optics of Euclid|Burton, H.E., translator|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 46, No 5, 1945, pp 357-372.||<i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp, NB: pp 47-64.||Jean Pean (1528-58) and Stoic Physics in the Sixteenth Century|Barker, P.|<i>The Southern Journal of Philosophy<i>, 1985, Vol XXIII, Supplement||<i>Change and Continuity in Early Modern Cosmology<i>|Boner, P.J., editor|Spring, 2011, 181 pp, NB: pp 40-48.||The Challenge of Applied Optics|In:<i>The Unmaking of the Medieval Christian Cosmos, 1500‚Äì1760<i>|Randles, W.G.L.|Routledge, 2016, 295 pp.||Atmospheric Refraction and the Ramus Circle: Aspects of a Late Sixteenth-Century Dispute|Peoux, G.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 67, No 4 , 2010, pp 457-484.||Peripatetic and Euclidean theories of the visual ray|Jones, A.|<i>Physis<i>, Vol 31, No 1, 1994, pp 47-76.
BP_Title: La perspective d'Euclide, traduite Francois sur le texte Grec, Original de L'Autheur, et demonstree par Rol. Freart De Chantelov, Sieur de Chambray.
BP_Title English Translation: The Perspective of Euclid, Translated into French from the Original Greek Text of the Author, and Demonstrated by Roland Freart de Chantelou, Lord de Chambray.
BP_Biographical Statement: Ancient author of geometry, taught at Athens and Alexandria. [Theorist of and writer on architecture and the arts]

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Extensive, primarily practical compendium of optics with topics and content extracted from mediaeval and contemporary authors, accompanied by glosses and additions.
BP_Description_1: Johann Kohlhans makes it clear in his letter to the reader his reasons and methods for writing the <i>Tractatus Opticus<i>. He states that that the study of optics is not only pleasant but useful. Kohlhans writes: 'In times of war and peace, much damage arises from an ignorance of optics.' He cites the many developments in optics and the need for an understanding of them, mentioning the camera obscura, the telescopes, the microscope, mirrors of various forms, lenses, color, and the theories of vision. To this end, he writes, he had been assembling for several years‚Äô material for a new book. He makes no claim to originality, but rather to completeness, citing many authors and works from which he drew his material.  The result is an extensive, primarily practical and descriptive compendium of optics with topics and content extracted from mediaeval and contemporary authors, with a small amount of Aristotelian theory. Subjects include: light, color, vision, and perception; catoptrics; dioptrics; mixed reflection and refraction, the rainbow; ocular anatomy and function; camera obscura; lenses; Telescopes; Microscopes. The section on the camera obscura is the most extensive. The book as the form of extended extracts from and glosses on other texts, making it something of a 'guide to the literature.' Presentation is entirely qualitative; no mathematics or figures accompany the descriptions.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Tractaus Opticus<i> is in three books.  Book 1 is in five parts: Part 1, definitions and parts of optics; Part 2 on optics including vision, light, color, perception, and shadow; Part 3 on catoptrics covers reflection, type of mirrors, and burning mirrors; Part 4 on anaclastics or refraction, including refracted vision, magnification, Part 5 on mixed refraction and reflection, including images, the rainbow, and coronae.||Book 2 is in two parts. Part 1 presents additional detail to material in Book 1, including ocular anatomy, theories of light and color, convex and concave mirrors, the nature of refraction, and refraction in a sphere. Part 2 covers the camera obscura, including its function, the use of a lens, and the use of the camera obscura as an instrument for drawing and for astronomy. Kohlhans devotes 60 pages to the camera obscura, making this one of the book's longest sections. Kohlhans cites Christoph Scheiner for the camera obscure as a model for the function of the eye.||Book 3 in in two parts. Part 1 is on lenses, including glass, the types and figures of lenses, and lens making. Part 2 in on 'Optical Tubes' and is in three sections. Section 1 is on the telescope, including the types and forms of telescopes, lenses for telescopes, construction of telescopes. Section 2 is on the helioscope, the microscope, and the polemoscope. Section 3 is on the astronomical Galilean telescopes, how they are made, and how they are used.||Kohlanns sources include summaries such as Ambrosius Rhode's Optica of 1661 from which Kohlans acquires Keplerian optics and Niccol√≤ Zucchi's <i>Optica Philosophia<i> of 1652, collections such as Johann Wecker's <i>De Secretis<i> of 1582 and Georg Philipp Harsd√∂rffer's <i>Deliti√¶ Mathematic√¶ et Physic√¶<i> of 1651, specialized works like Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> of 1619, and books of practice such as Anton Schyrleus de Rheita's <i>Oculus Enoch et Eliae<i> of 1645 and Johannes Hevelius' <i>Selenographia<i> of 1647. From these and other works, Kohlhans either gives a summary or extracts sections, some of considerable length, to which he adds explanatory glosses and his own expansions. His citations are always specific, including author, work, and page.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Camera Obscura: A Chapter in the Pre-History of Photography<i>|Hammond, M.S.|Dissertation, The Ohio State University, 1985, 429 pp, NB: pp 259, 293.
BP_Title: Tractatus Opticus, Qui res quam plurimas, utiles, jucundas, ludicras, & admirandas, naturaliter sistere docet, nec non Vitra, Specula, Tubosque opticos parandi & conficiendi rationes describit, ex optimis quibusdam autoribus, propriisque observationibus & inventis, studiose collectus atque conscriptus. Accessit, ab ingeniosis cognitionisque rerum avidis inventorum & a non invidis detectorum, centum optices Arcanorum congestio.
BP_Title English Translation: An Optical Tract, Which Teaches many Useful, Pleasing, Recreational, Naturally Occurring Things, and Describs as well an Account of the Preparing and Constructing of Lenses, Mirrors and Optical Tubes, From Some of the Best Authors, and their own Observations, Findings, Collected Studies and Writings. Added from Ingenious Things and Learning Eagerly Sought and not Ill-Disposed to Discovery, a Collection of 100 Optical Mysteries.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician and linguist. Taught at Cobur and Gottingen.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp on titlepage

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Gilles Personne de Roberval (1602-1675) French mathematician, founding member of the French Academy of Sciences.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Roberval's editing of the final, augmented text on anamorphosis produced by Niceron and overseen by Mersenne.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Francois Niceron's <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> is a detailed, geometrically practical guide to anamorphosis. That is, the production of distorted perspective images on plane or curved surfaces that require special mirrors or viewing points. For Niceron, optics as an illusionist art, rather than a science of light and vision. As the title implies, Niceron considered anamorphosis a type of perspective, engaging the question of visual representation and the reliability of the visual sense. In his Letter to the Reader, Niceron lists the great developers of and contributors to the science of perspective but notes how few books on the subject do little more than display figures and scenes, without showing in detail how they were produced. He states that his goal is to remedy that for readers of French and that the title, Curious Perspective, could also have been Artificial Magic--'The one that produces for us the most beautiful and admirable effects, bringing about the art and industry of man.' He cautions new readers not to skip the initial material on geometry or the initial drawing exercises. Published when he was 25, Niceron had been working on anamorphosis (direct, catoptric, and dioptric) since he was 18 and a novice in the Order of Minims, and so the work is that of a practitioner with a deep understanding of geometry, not that of just a theoretician. With La Perspective Curieuse, Niceron makes significant advances in perspective projection methods from his predecessors Salomon de Caus and Jean-Louis Vaulezard. This is particularly the case for spherical projection; without Niceron's technique, interior dome work would have been beyond the ability of virtually all painters. This aspect of Niceron's work also affected the design of instruments, such as astrolabes and globes. La Perspective Curieuse was an acknowledged influence on Emmanuel Maignan's Horographia of 1648 and Charles Plumier's l' Art de Tourner en Perfection of 1749.||The plates were engraved by Joan Blanchin, based on Niceron‚Äôs drawings. Editions appeared in 1638 and edited by Roberval in 1651 and 1663. Niceron's Latin translation, <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i>, edited by Mersenne, appeared posthumously in 1646 and edited by Roberval in 1663.
BP_Description_2: Jean-Francois Niceron's  <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> begins with a Geometric Preliminaries, followed by four books. The Preliminaries set out geometric basics in 7 Propositions. Book 1: Principles of Perspective. Describes a general method for the linear perspective of solid figures, included the complex cases where the figures contact the horizontal plane only along a line or at a point. The process is fundamentally geometric and presented in 15 Propositions, each demonstrated with one or more figures. Examples of the process are give for several solid objects. Book 2: Planar Anamorphosis. Projections are introduced for distorting a regular image so that it appears undistorted only when viewed from a particular viewing point. The undistorted rectangular grid of the image is mapped into a grid distorted by projection. The process is presented in 7 Propositions accompanied by figures. Book 3: Anamorphosis with Cylindrical and Conical Mirrors. Five Propositions and figures present the method for generating a doubly-projected grid. The rectangular grid of an image is mapped onto the projection and an undistorted view is presented only the appropriate mirror. Niceron gives practical advice on metal-casting for mirrors and instructions for their polishing. Book 4: Dioptric Anamorphosis. Five Propositions give the method for generating a projected grid that separate and distorts an image into several pieces. The projection depends on the nature of the intended facetted, dioptrical viewer. The rectangular grid of an image is segregated and distorted according to projected grid and reveals an assembled and undistorted image when viewed with the required facetted dioptric element. The material in all four books is presented with a brevity that requires close reading and careful reference to the many figures in the plates.

BP_Title: La Perspective Curieuse Divisee en quatre livres. Avec L'Optique et La Catoptrique, mise on lumiere apres la mort de l'Autheur.
BP_Title English Translation: Curious Perspective Divided into Four Books, With Optics and Catroptics, brought to light after the death of the author
BP_Biographical Statement: French Minim friar, student of Marin Mersenne, an artist of note, and keenly interested in the mathematics of perspective. [Royal professor of mathematics at the Coll√®ge de Maistre Gervais and Ramus Chair at the Coll√®ge Royal de France]

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Gilles Personne de Roberval (1602-1675) French mathematician, founding member of the French Academy of Sciences.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Roberval's editing and enlarging of the 1646 edition of the text on anamorphosis that was considerably augmented by Niceron with material on light and shadow and rendered by him into Latin.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Francois Niceron's <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> is a partial reworking and translation into Latin, of his <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> of 1638. Like the earlier version, it is a detailed, geometrically practical guide to anamorphosis. That is, the production of distorted perspective images on plane or curved surfaces that require viewing points. As the Latin title implies, Niceron came to consider anamorphosis a type of natural magic or wonder-working. In his Preface to the reader, Niceron set out his plan for reworking the text of 1638: A section giving the principles of geometry followed by revised books one and two, and these followed by a section on a new scenographic instrument and an appendix on Light and Shadow. There was to be a second part containing revisions of books three and four of the 1638 text on catoptric and dioptric anamorphosis. Niceron worked on the <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> for eight years after the publication of 1638 but his early death in 1646 prevented him from completing what was to be the second half of the work. His fellow Minim member Marin Mersenne edited the manuscript. Niceron's plan must have been fixed from the start, for the revised book one contains references to books three and four. The geometric prelude that precedes Book One is a close Latin translation of the French original. The reworked Books One and Two are considerable expansions of the originals, with more theorems, propositions, and detail.||Niceron had continued to work on practical anamorphosis and the <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> since <i>La Perspective Curieuse<i> of 1638, and so his experience had deepened the detail and examples he brought to the revised work was considerably richer. In 1638 the first two books were accompanied by 10 plates of figures, in 1646 by 35 plates. The last eight plates are devoted to Niceron's scenography and his appendix on light and shadow. The title frontispiece was drawn by Simon Vouet and engraved by Charles Audran. The portrait, executed by Michel Lane, shows Niceron not long before his death.||With Thaumaturgus Opticus, Niceron's significant advances in perspective projection methods over his predecessors Salomon de Caus and Jean-Louis Vaulezard are more developed and reach a wider audience. Edited by Mersenne, it appeared posthumously in 1646 and edited by Roberval in 1663.
BP_Description_2: Jean-Francois Niceron's  <i>Thaumaturgus Opticus<i> begins with Geometric Preliminaries, followed by two books on anamorphosis, then a description of a scenographic instrument, and ends with an appendix on light and shadow. The Preliminaries set out geometric basics in 8 Propositions and two appendices. Book 1: Principles of Perspective. Describes a general method for the linear perspective of solid figures, included the complex cases where the figures contact the horizontal plane only along a line or at a point. The process is fundamentally geometric and presented in 12 axioms, 37 Propositions, and a synopsis. Each proposition is demonstrated with one or more figures. Examples of the process are give for several solid objects. Book 2: Planar Anamorphosis. Projections are introduced for distorting a regular image so that it appears undistorted only when viewed from a particular viewing point. The undistorted rectangular grid of the image is mapped into a grid distorted by projection. The process is presented in 12 Propositions accompanied by figures. The material in both books is presented with a brevity that requires close reading and careful reference to the many figures in the plates. The Universal Scenograph describes a device of Niceron's invention that allows by direct viewing the drawing of an object in linear or anamorphic projection. It operates as an optical-mechanical equivalent of Durer's perspective grid. The Appendix on Light and Shadow demonstrates techniques for drawing shadows in linear perspective. Interestingly, it includes not only umbral shadows from point light sources but also penumbral shadows from area light sources such as windows. Both the Universal Scenograph and the Appendix are accompanied by plates of figures.
