BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A defense of Aristotelian teachings on light and fire, attacking the work of Isaac Voss
BP_Description_1: Petit wrote in defense of Aristotle: a fierce anti-Cartesian who defended peripatetic doctrines. He wrote this brief work to set out his objections to Isaac Voss's ideas on light and vision, particularly concerning the nature of light and fire, questioning the way fire might affect the soul. Though Voss was no Cartesian, he was not an Aristotelian either. In his view he himself had gained a novel insight in the understanding of visual perception that exceeded conceptual differences between ancients and moderns. Voss responded to his critics point by point, but they had not in any way changed his opinion.||With the appearance of Descartes' <i>Principia Philosophiae Specimina<i> in 1644, Cartesianism began to displace Aristotelianism in scholarly circles and university curricula. Petit and his <i>Ignis et Lucis Natura<i> is an example of the defense that was mounted by traditional Aristotelians.
BP_Description_2: Petit's text is in the form of 33 exercises. Each is considers a separate aspects of fire and light and shows how Aristotelian teaching explains observations within a consistent framework. Arguments are presented to show the failures of Descartes and Gassendi.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ A View from the Mountaintop: The Development of Isaac Vossius' Optics, 1658-1666|Dijksterhus, F.J.|In: <i>Isaac Vossius (1618-1689) between Science and Scholarship<i>, Brill, Leiden, 2012, pp 157-187, NB pp 178-180.||'Les objections de Pierre Petit contre le Discours et les Essais de Descartes'|Waard, C. de|<i> Revue de M√©taphysique et de Morale<i>, Vol 32, 1925, pp 53-89.
BP_Title: Petri Petiti De ignis et lucis natura exercitationes ad Is. Vossium
BP_Title English Translation: Exercises on the Nature of Fire and Light against Isaac Voss. By Pierre Petit.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physician, scholar, and man of letters.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A course in Aristotelian physics. The section on vision distinguishes between lux and lumen, presents a Galenic ocular anatomy, and a hyriid scholastic-Cartesian processes that brings about vision. An attempt to bridge Aristotelian and Cartesian natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Friedemann Bechmann's letter to the reader makes it clear why he wrote the <i>Systema Physicum<i>. It was at the request of Prince Ernest of Saxony and to fill the need for a single book that brought most of physics together. Bechmann points out the new developments in physics that need to be taught and, in this regard, mentions specifically that the book has been prepared for use in the Gymnasium at Gotha. Bechmann's text covers general and particular physics, meteorics, minerals, plants, animals, and man. Written on the cusp of the transition from Aristotelian to Cartesian natural philosophy, Bechmann's text is an example of the teaching material developed to bridge the gap. The bulk of the treatment is Aristotelian, but in many cases (such as meteorics, light and vision) Bechmann describes the Cartesian alternative. But Descartes is not singled out--Gassendi and Voss are also cited in this way.||Editions appeared at Jena in 1664, 1675, 1681, and 1683.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Systema Physicum<i> is a course in Aristotelian physics, peppered with brief mentions of Gassendian and Cartesian alternatives. There are seven books. Book 1: General Physics. Book 2: Particular Physics. Book 3: Corporeal Bodies. Book 4: Minerals in General. Book 5: Life in General. Book 6: Animals. Book 7: Man. The section on vision (pp 647-660) distinguishes between corporeal lux and incorporeal lumen, presents a Galenic ocular anatomy, and a hybrid scholastic-Cartesian processes that brings about vision. An example of texts attempting to bridge Aristotelian and Cartesian natural philosophy at the time of the cusp of the end of Aristotelianism and the triumph of Cartesianism.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Natural Philosophy in Some Early Seventeenth Century Scholastic Textbooks<i>|Reif, P.M.|St. Louis University, Dissertation, 1962, 365 p.
BP_Title: Systema Physicum. Mandato Serenissimi Principis Ernesti, Sax. Jul. Clivi√¶ et Mont. Ducis, & c. Ad usum gymnasii Gothani ex optimis atqve probatissimis tam veteribus quam recentioribus autoribus compositum, et in duos cursus typorum diversitate notatos distinctum, Ut non solum incipientibus, sed et proficientibus solida nobilissim√¶ hujus scienti√¶ fundamenta et incrementa suppeditare queat.
BP_Title English Translation: A Phyisal System. By Order of the Most Gracious Prince Ernest I, Duke of Saxe-Gotha, for use in the Gotha Gymnasium. Composed of the Best of the Best from Old Authors as well as Recent and Written into Two Distinct Diverse Types of Courses. Not only for Beginers but also for the Proficient, Making Solid the Foundations of the Most Nobel Science and be able to Provide Growth.
BP_Biographical Statement: German philosopher, theologian, and academic in the University of Jena. Wrote textbooks in several disciplines.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Boyle's Greek-like monologue addressed to 'Pyrophilus' contain three parts: A presentation of then-current knowledge about color; A study and assessment of White and Black; Descriptions of 50 experiments involving light, color, color production, color mixing, and color perception. Boyle concluded that colors from objects are not different from those produced by prisms or the rainbow.
BP_Description_1: Like many natural philosophers of the time, Robert Boyle was interested in color. For some years he had conducted various experiments involving light and color, recording the results in various forms and places. Pressed by friends, he returned to these separate pieces of years earlier and assembled them into an essay for private circulation, eventually appearing in print. Boyle recognized that he had not produced a general theory of color, but rather had assembled experimental results from which such a theory might be built. For that reason, his title is, in part, and expression of his purpose: <i>The Beginning of an Experimental History of Colours<i>.  The publisher, for his part considers the work more than a beginning: 'I think it so well begun, that the work is more than half dispactcht.'||Boyle recognized he had not written a popular account of color, but something for other natural philosophers:   '‚Ä¶ for my part, I had much rather deserve the thanks of the Ingenious, than enjoy the Applause of the Ignorant.' He separated his Experiments and Considerations into three parts, the first giving a general summary of what was know about color, the second presenting the results of his extensive study of white and black, and the third records the results of more than 50 various experiments. These experiments were not limited to strictly optical phenomena, but, being a chemist, often involved the changing, appearance, and disappearance of colors in various chemical experiments. Importantly, Boyle's experiment had him conclude there was no difference between prismatic colors, colors of objects, colors from meteorological phenomena, and colors of pigments and glass.||It is known that Newton read Boyle's <i>Experiments and Considerations<i> when he began his own optical experiments around 1665 and that Boyle's book was the earliest and most influential of Newton's early sources. Editions appeared at London in 1664 and 1670, and Latin translations appeared at London in 1665, at Amsterdam in 1667, at Rotterdam in 1671, at Geneva in 1680, and in the Collected Works of 1744. An edition revised by John Hoofnail appeared at London in 1738.
BP_Description_2: Robert Boyle's <i>Experiments and Considerations Touching Colours<i> is a monologue addressed to 'Pyrophilus' and contains three parts. Part I is presentation of then-current knowledge about color and has five chapters covering Boyle's method and reason for experimentation, the general lack of experimental information about color, review of then-current color information and properties, the distinction between real and apparent colors, size color hypotheses rejected by Boyle. Part II presents an extended study and assessment of White and Black in two chapters. Here Boyle rejects the old idea that color arises from the mixing of white and black, properties of whiteness drawn from objects in nature, properties of blackness including it heat-holding properties. The part ends with a description of 15 experiments conducted on whiteness and blackness. Part III presents the results of 50 experiments related to color, including color perception, optical and prismatic colors, colors in chemistry, pigment colors, color from adding colored lights.||Boyle briefly summarizes the color theories of the Scholastics, Neoplatonists, Epicureans, and the Cartesians--and finds them all wanting. Importantly, his own idea is that color is light itself that has been modified in some way. He is aware of the vast array of color phenomena involving optics, chemistry, natural history, color in gems, phosphoric colors, and color phenomena that appear to be purely perceptual, and cannot conceive of a theoretical mechanism to explain them all. But his is more certain about his notions regarding whiteness and blackness: whiteness being produced by the surface of an object that consists of tiny surfaces the reflect most incident light into many directions, and blackness being produced by a surface that does not reflect light but absorbs it. Several of his experiments are conducted to demonstrates these ideas, particularly those involving the heating of black surfaces in sunlight. Importantly, Boyle considers whiteness and blackness a result of reflection and absorption, and not as primitives of color that are responsible in some fashion for their generation.||The text includes an appendix of observations Boyle made with a diamond that was said to be phosphorescent.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ On Reading Boyle's 'Experiments and Considerations Touching Colours'|Kuehni, R.G.|<i>Color Research and Application<i>, Vol 18, No 3, pp 193-196.||Isaac Newton: The Rise of a Scientist 1661-1671|Lohne. J.A.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 20, No 2, 1965, pp 125-139.||Can We Date Newton's Early Optical Experiments?|Guerlac, H.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 74, No 1, 1983, pp 74-80.||Glass Work|Schaffer, S.|In: <i>The Uses of Experiment: Stuides in the Natural Sciences<i>|Gooding, D., Pinch, T., and Schaffer, S., editors|Cambridge University Press, 1989, pp 66-104.
BP_Title: Experiments and Considerations touching Colours. First occasionally Written, amng some other Essays, to a Friend; and now Suffer'd to come abroad as the Beginning of an Experimental History of Colours.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish natural philosopher and chemist. Committed to the scientific method, an active experimentalist, wrote clearly and extensively on what he observed and inferred.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Posthumous publication of an early work on all of natural philosophy and intended as the first part of a work on the World and Man. The section on Light, the longest by far, would later be reworked to become the essay La Dioptrique, part of the Discours de La M√©thode of 1637.
BP_Description_1: Ren√© Descartes' Treatise on Light--published as <i>Le Monde<i>--had it roots in what has been called his micro-mechanical conception of natural philosophy--all physical action, activity, or result was generated, transmitted, or sensed by means of the interaction of particulate matter. He referred to this as 'physico-mathematics' and was his replacement for Scholastic teachings in natural philosophy. Optics was a life-long interest of Descartes, and his earliest study was that of refraction, written in 1619-1921. The first full expression of these and other ideas was his <i>La Monde<i>, which he began in 1629 and had nearly completed by 1633 but abandoned due to the shock created by the condemnation of Galileo in that year. The text ends with an unfinished 15th chapter. When Descartes heard of the condemnation wrote to Mersenne of his surprise, the difficulty of removing the Copernican elements of his treatise, and his decision not to publish: '... I wouldn't want to publish a discourse which had a single word that the Church disapproved of; so, I prefer to suppress it rather than publish it in a mutilated form.' The work was not published in his lifetime.||Treatise on Light set out Descartes' theory of light, described vortex celestial mechanics, and advanced a Copernican cosmography; all based on a fundamentally mechanical view of physics. Even sense perception was described in terms of mechanical interaction. During the time Descartes was writing the Treatise on Light, he was deeply involved in geometrical optics including his work on making lenses of hyperbolic figure. The optical material in Treatise on Light would eventually appear in the essay La Dioptrique and Les Meteores, with all Copernican cosmography removed. The cosmological material appeared with much hedging and indirection in the <i>Principia Philosophia<i> of 1644.||The text of <i>Le Monde<i> was edited by Claude Clerselier (1614-1684) who added without attribution G√©rauld de Cordemoy‚Äôs <i>Discours ‚Ä¶touchant le mouvement et le repos<i>. The Treatise on Light was published as <i>Le Monde de Mr. Descartes ou le Trait√© de la Lumi√®re in Paris <i> in 1664 with different title pages, one by Jacques LeGras and another by Michel Bobin & Nicolar LeGras. There is another issue with a the title page of Theodore Gira[r]d also dated 1664. The Treatise on Light together with his essay <i>L'Homme<i> appeared at Paris in 1677 and 1726, and at Paris in the editions of the Oeuvres des Descartes of 1824 and 1897.
BP_Description_2: <i>Le Monde des Mr. Descartes<i>, the posthumously published version of his Treatise on Light, contains 15 chapters. The first five set out Descartes view of the mechanical basis for all of natural philosophy. In these, he refutes Scholastic teachings regarding the nature of sense perceptions in general and those from light in particular. It is here he introduces his mechanical theory of the nature of light and mechanisms of sense perception. Descartes then presents a mechanistic view of fluids and air and in chapter 5 explains how fire, air, and earth are involved in the generation, propagation, and reflection and refraction of light: generation by fire, propagation by pressure in fluids, and reflection and refraction by terrestrial objects.||Chapters 6 and 7 present Descartes three laws of motion and inertia: conservation of states of bodies (size, motion, rest, position), conservation of the 'force of motion' of bodies, and the constancy of rectilinear direction of motion. Chapters 8-12 use the theory of matter developed in chapters 1-5 and the laws of motion and inertia in 6 and 7 to develop a Copernican cosmography based on vortices, fluids, and mechanical interaction. Chapters 13-15 deal with physical optics and, using his theory of matter and laws of motion, and the properties of the 'tendency to motion' of closely-packed particles, explain light's rectilinear propagation, specular reflection, and refraction.||As with his later writings, Descartes' presentation is based more on analogy than on analysis, particularly regarding the nature of light and it propagation.
BP_Reference(s): ùëª <i>Le Monde,¬†ou Traite de la Lumiere.¬†Translation and introduction<i>|Mahoney, M. S.|Abaris Books, New York, 1979.||ùëª <i>The World and Other Writings<i>|Gaukroger, S.|Cambridge University Press, 1998.||Descartes Opticien: The Construction of the Law of Refraction and The Manufacture of its Physical Rationales 1618-1629|Schuster, J.A.|In: <i>Descartes‚Äô Natural Philosophy<i>, Gaukroger, S., Schuster, J.A., Sutton, J., editors|Routledge, 2000, pp 258-312.
BP_Title: Le Monde de Mr. Descartes, ou Le Trait√© de la Lumiere, et des autres Principaux objets des sens. Avec un Discours du Mouvement Local, & un autre desFievre, composez selon les principes de meme Auteur.
BP_Title English Translation: The World of Mr. Descartes, or Treatise on Light, and Other Principle Objects of the Senses. With a Discours on Local Movement, another on Fever, Composed According to the Same Principles of the Author.
BP_Biographical Statement: French philosopher and mathematician. Resident of the Dutch Republic, revolutionary founder of rationalism, prolific writer.
BP_Provenance: Owner inscription on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Nineteen Observations on light and color are stated and defended. Voss's <i>De Lucis Natura et Propretate<i> of 1662 is quoted and refuted extensively, along with Gassendi and Descartes. Light is held to be a non-corporeal emanation, color is held to be a mix of white, 'maximum color', and black ,'minimum color'.
BP_Description_1: The origin of Grandorge's <i>Natura Ignis, Lucis, et Colorum<i> is the sparing between Pierre-Daniel Huet, a close acquaintance of Grandorge, and Isaac Voss.  In 1658 Voss published a commentary on Pomponius Mela's <i>Chorographia<i> including attempts to explain what Mela recorded being seen by mountain top residents' and sailors' reports of 'atmospheric fire.'  Huet published objections to Voss's ideas regarding refraction and in 1662 Voss published <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i>, an extended response to Huet. Huet did not respond, but Grandorge, his colleague did. The central issue was the nature of refraction. Voss would publish a response to Grandorge in the form of the <i>Appendix ad Scriptum de Natura et Proprietate Lucis<i>, added at the end of his <i>De Nili<i> of 1666. Nineteen Observations on light and color are stated and defended. Voss's <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> of 1662 is quoted and refuted extensively, along with Gassendi and Descartes. Light is held to be non-corporeal emanation, color is held to be a mix of white ('maximum color') and black ('minimum color'). The content and style are scholastic, certainly not empirical.
BP_Description_2: Grandorge's <i>Natura Ignis, Lucis, et Colorum<i> states and defends 19 Observations on light and color. Most begin with a citation from Voss's <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> of 1662 and develop a methodical critique of Voss's statements. Generally, Grandorge refutes Voss's conception of light, focusing on the latter's comparison of light and fire. Contrary to Voss, Grandorge asserted that light is a non-corporeal emanation and color is held to be a mix of white ('maximum color') and black ('minimum color'). In addition to Voss, Gassendi and Descartes are cited and refuted. The content and style are scholastic, and certainly not empirical.
BP_Reference(s): A View from the Mountaintop: The Development of Isaac Vossius' Optics, 1658-1666|Dijksterhus, F.J.|In: <i>Isaac Vossius (1618-1689) between Science and Scholarship<i>, Brill, Leiden, 2012, pp 159-187.||De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Dulianiel en Vossius in de periode 1640-1670|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.
BP_Title: Andreae Grandorgae de Natura Ignis, Lucis, et Colorum, dissertatio
BP_Title English Translation: The Dissertation on the Nature of Fire, Light, and Color of Andre Grandorge
BP_Biographical Statement: French physican and natural philosopher. Friend of scholar  Pierre-Daniel Huet and with him founded the Academy of Sciences, Arts and Letters of Caen.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris Petri Cadomes on the title page
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1664 Grandorge - Natura Ignis, Lucis, et Colorum - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A review of then-recent experiments and instruments, particularly regarding the vacuum and its production.
BP_Description_1: Schott's work on what would become the <i>Technical Curiosa<i> began in the late 1650's and delt with the recording and reproducing Otto von Guericke's experiments with vacuum. By 1661, Schott had finished Book I of the <i>Technical Curiosa<i> devoting it to Guericke's work. Schott was a collector and disseminator of developments and not an originator, and upon receiving a copy of Robert Boyle's <i>Nova Experimenta<i> of 1661, asked and received permission from Boyle to use its content. Schott including a summary of this work on air pumps as Book II. Letters and correspondence from around Europe altered Schott to other developments and these were also included in the <i>Technical Curiosa<i>. Schott's correspondents included Mario Bettini, Michael Boym, Niccol√≤ Cabeo, Philipp Colbinus, Melchior Cornaeus, Albert Curtz, Honor√© Fabri, Fran√ßois Line, Martino Martini, Giovanni Battista Riccioli and Niccol√≤ Zucchi.||Schott work almost constantly on the <i>Technical Curiosa<i> from 1661 to 1664, when it finally appeared in April. Editions appeared a Nuremberg in 1664 and at W√ºrzburg in 1687.
BP_Description_2: The work is divided into two parts. Part I has 7 books: I Wonders from Magdeburg, II English Wonders, III Varia, IV Scrutiny of Earlier Physical Experiments, V Hydrotechnics, VI Mechanics, VII Graphology. Part II has 5 Books: VIII Cyclometrica, IX Chrometrica, X Automatica, XI Miscellanea, XII Cabalistica. Book I first published description of Guericke's famous Magdeburg demonstration, the announcement here being eight years before Guericke's <i>Experimenta Nova<i>, and contains the famed image of horses pulling at two evacuated hemispheres. Book II describes Boyle's work on air pumps. Book IX gives the first description of a universal joint and a classification of gear teeth. Book XI describes new mirrored optical instruments and announces the developments of Balthsar Conrad, SJ on the manufacture of spherical lenses.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ 'Kaspar Schott's letters to Philip Vegelin 1661-1664'|Conlon, T.E., Vollrath, H.-J.|<i>Archivum Historicum Societatis Iesu<i>, Vol 82, No 2, 2014, pp 273-305.
BP_Title: P. Gasparis Schotti Regis Curiani e Societate Jesu, Olim in Panormitano Siciliae, nunc in Herbipolitano Franconiae Gymnasio ejusdem Societatis Jesu Matheseos Professoris.  Technica curiosa, sive, Mirabilia artis, libris XII. comprehensa : quibus varia experimenta, variaque technasmata pnevmatica, hydraulica, hydrotechnica, mechanica, graphica, cyclometrica, chronometrica, automatica, cabalistica, aliaque artis arcana ac miracula, rara, curiosa, ingeniosa, magnamque partem nova & antehac inaudita, eruditi orbis utilitati, delectationi, disceptationique proponuntur. Ad eminentissimum S.R.I. Principem Joannem Philippum Elector. Mogunt. Cum figuris aeri incisis, & Privilegio.
BP_Title English Translation: Father Gaspar Schott, Royal Council and The Society of Jesus, Formerly of Palermo Sicily, now Professor of Mathematics in the School of the same Society of Jesus at Wurzburg Bavaria. Twelve Books of Technical Curiosities or Wonderful Arts, In which are Included several experiments and various devices in  pneumatics, hydraulics, hydrotechnics, mechanics, graphology, cyclometrics, chronometrics, automata, cabalistics and other trade secrets and miracles that are rare, curious, ingeneous, and are in large part new previously unheard of; presented for the benefit, pleasure and debate of the learned circle. To his Excellency Supreme Royal Highness Prince Johann Philipp von Sch√∂nborn Archbishop-Elector of Mainz. With copper engraved figures and Privilege.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, student of Athanasius Kircher, taught in Sicily, studied in Rome. An experimentalist and extensive correspondant, a compiler and editor rather than an author.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the library of the Congregation of the Oratory.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Johann Andreas Endter and his heir Wolfgang

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second, expanded edition of the work of 1656. Fifth of Six volumes, covering Mixed Mathematics, including optics. A textbook in the Scholastic manner and an example of the Jesuit opposition to Descartes.
BP_Description_1: Pierre Gaultruche taught mathematics at the Jesuit schools at La Fl√®che and Caens and it was at this time that he produced this compendium-textbook for use in his courses. In is broad scope, coverage, and level of detail, it was like other compendia of the time: Claude Milliet Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> of 1674 or William Leybourne's <i>Cursus Mathematics<i> of 1690. Though committed to Scholastic teachings, Gaultruche was an eclectic Aristotelian; as seen in the mix of theories he presented in physics and mixed mathematics. Topics in Mixed Mathematics are covered in a series of Disputations, with a section on light, color, and vision presenting both the Scholastic and the Keplerian theory of vision. Descartes is not mentioned. Widely used, popular, and produced in many expanded editions.||Editions appeared Caens in 1656 and 1665, at Vienna in 1661, at London in 1683. A separate edition of Volume 5, <i>Mathematica<i>, appeared at Cambridge in 1668, and was the basis for a German science and mathematics popularization that appeared at Ulm in 1695.
BP_Description_2: Fifth volume of second edition of a six-volume textbook in the Scholastic manner and an example of the Jesuit opposition to Descartes. Topics in Mixed Mathematics are covered in a series of Disputations, with a section on light, color, and vision. The 'Mathematica' volume consists of nine parts: arithmetic, elements of geometry, practical geometry, world sphere, chronology, gnomonics, terrestrial sphere, optics and music. The optics material is brief (30 pages) and deals only with vision and images. Geometric or physical optics is not presented, nor is Descartes' La Dioptrique cited or used. Ocular anatomy is briefly presented and then, strangely, both the Scholastic and Keplerian theory of vision is presented. The former detailing how species of light color are emitted from an object, enter the eye, and impinge on the crystalline lens. The later showing how the lens forms images on the retina which sends information via the optics nerves to the brain. Conditions necessary for distinct vision are presented including the cause of near and far-sightedness, and brief presentations on the camera obscura and catoptric anamorphosis are made. Refraction is considered only to the extent necessary to explain the focusing of the crystalline lens.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Natural Philosophy in Some Early Seventeenth Century Scholastic Textbooks<i>|Reif, P.M.|St. Louis University, Dissertation, 1962, 365 p.
BP_Title: Philosophiae ac mathematicae totius clara, brevis et accurata instituto. Cum Introductione ad alias Facultates. Ad usum Studiosae Iuventutis.
BP_Title English Translation: All of Philosophy and Mathematics: A Clear, Brief, and Accurate Instruction. With an Introduction to other Resources. For the use of Young Students.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, taught and wrote on astronomy and 'mixed mathematics'.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Idea et Summa Simulaque Index Universiae

BP_Short or Common Title: Physico-mathesis de lumine, coloribus, et iride
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Experiments, measurements, and mathematics on light's nature and propagation are described in 60 Propositions. It is proposed that light is a subtle fluid, colors arise from variations in its vibrations, and diffraction be added to light's direct, reflective, and refractive propagation.
BP_Description_1: The origin of Grimaldi's <i>Physico-mathesis de Lumine, Coloribus, et Iride<i> was his work in astronomy with Giovanni Battista Riccioli at the Collegio di Santa Lucia in Bologna. Grimaldi had used a form of the camera obscura to measure the sizes of the sun and moon and had noticed discrepancies, particularly with small apertures, even after the corrections for aperture size recommended by Kepler in his <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604. This, among other problems, convinced Grimaldi that the nature of light had not been established and experiments were required. The Prooemium makes clear he intended to report on such experiments, conducted to determine the nature of light, color, and the rainbow. In 1658 Grimaldi began experimenting and generating results that would appear in the <i>Physico-mathesis de Lumine, Coloribus, et Iride<i>. The manuscript was finished in December 1661 and submitted to Jesuit censors--apparently with only what finally became Book 1. Publication was denied and Grimaldi added the second, Peripatetic book, and completed further revision just before he died in December 1663. The final text was approved by Provincial, rather than Roman, Jesuit auditors in May of 1664.||The first and much longer book presents 60 propositions and describes experiments that support them. The second, much shorter book, presents 6 propositions that give the Peripatetic theory of light and color. Grimaldi's book was published after his death, the dedication written by the printer and the Prooemium presumably coming from his notes. The book was described and reviewed in the January 1671 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. Grimaldi's discovery and description of diffraction became widely known, but the rest of the book appears to have had little influence. Grimaldi plumped for light being a vibratory phenomenon in a subtle fluid, but this would eventually be overshadowed by the Newtonian idea of corpuscles.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Physico-mathesis de Lumine, Coloribus, et Iride<i> is in two Books. Book 1 presents 60 Propositions, supported by experiments and measurements, on light's nature and propagation, diffraction,  the nature of transparent objects, refraction, color and the rainbow. For balance, or to satisfy the censors, Book 2 to gives 6 Propositions on the Peripatetic teaching that light is and accident of a substance that has had its potential transparency actualized. The 60 Propositions of Book 1 are arranged as follows. Propositions 1-3 one the nature of light, its direct, reflect, refracted, and diffracted propagation. Propositions 4-9 on the nature of transparency. Proposition 10-24 on the substantial nature of light. Propositions 25-27 on images and the camera obscura. Propositions 28-42 on the nature and cause of color. Propositions 43-45 on vision and color. Propositions 46-60 on the rainbow. Several of these propositions are accompanied by descriptions of experiments. The most important of these involve slit apertures and narrow sunbeams projecting diffraction fringes and colors, and those involving prisms and water-filled globes showing the mechanisms of the rainbow.||Book 1 proposes and defends the idea that light is a subtle fluid, that colors arise from variations in its vibrations, and that diffraction be added to light's direct, reflective, and refractive propagation. Diffraction is the fluid being 'split apart' by an object's edge. For balance, or to satisfy the censor, six more propositions are added at the end to give the Scholastic view of light as accident of a transparent substance. In the last propositions, Grimaldi's presents a very clear, detailed, and extensive  exposition of the formation of the primary and secondary rainbows, and adds that the rainbow, under suitable refraction and reflection, 'can appear double, or even triple, etc.' This is the first reference to and support for the reality of the tertiary rainbow. The material is devoted entirely to physical optics. Aside from brief considerations of the operation of single lenses, geometric optics is not considered.
BP_Reference(s): Francesco Maria Grimalci (1618-1663)|Straker, S.|In: <i>Encyclopedia of the Scientific Revolution: From Copernicus to Newton<i>|Taylor-Francis, 2000.||Beyond the Fringe: Diffraction as Seen by Grimaldi, Fabri, Hooke and Newton|Hall, A.R.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol  44, No 1, 1990, pp 13-23.||The Role of Practice in Marxism-Leninism: The Idea of Limits as Impetus in the Development of 17th-Century Physics|Marek, J.|<i>Studies in Soviet Thought<i>, Vol 25, No 1, 1983, pp 1-10.||Measurements of the solar diameter in Kepler's time|Sigismondi, C. & Fraschetti, F.|<i>The Observatory<i>, Vol 121, 2001, p. 380-385.||Riccioli e Grimaldi|Baldini, U.|<i>Nuncius<i>, Firenze, Vol 44, 2002, pp 1-47.
BP_Title: Physico-mathesis de lumine, coloribus, et iride, aliisque sequenti pagina indicatis.
BP_Title English Translation: The Physical Mathematics of Light, Colors, and the Rainbow. And Other Things Indicated on the Following Page.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jesuit, mathematician and natural philosopher. An active and careful experimentalist in mechanics, astronomy, and optics.
BP_Provenance: Macclesfield bookplate and William Jones' signature on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Tracts on Plants and Humans. In the latter, a thirty-five-page section describes ocular anatomy, physiology of vision, binocular vision, a few aspects of visual perception, operation of the Galilean and Keplerian telescopes, optical illusions, and ends with various questions and answers.
BP_Description_1: Honor√© Fabri wrote the <i>Tractatus Duo<i> after he had been stationed in Rome for 15 years and following a long period of study. The book marked the start of his most productive period of publications on natural philosophy. The <i>Tractatus Due<i>--two tracts, one on plants the other on Man--was well received and prompted Fabri to revive his writing and publishing efforts that had stopped when he was sent to Rome in 1648. In the second tract, a thirty-five-page section describes ocular anatomy, physiology of vision, binocular vision, a few aspects of visual perception, operation of the Galilean and Keplerian telescopes, distinct and indistinct vision, and ends with various optical and perception questions and answers. While adhering to a general Aristotelianism, Fabri incorporates Keplerian and Cartesian ideas, producing a hybrid that is forward-looking but sails close to the wind of Jesuit conservatism. Some the optical material appearing here would be developed in expanded form in Fabri's <i>Synopsis Optica<i> of 1667 and the <i>Dialogi Physici<i> of 1669.
BP_Description_2: The second <i>Tractatus, De Homine<i>, has seven books. Book 1, the vegetative and generation faculties of man. Books 2, The senses in general and the exterior senses. Book 3, The interior senses. Book 4, Animal and natural motion. Book 5, The appetitive sense. Book 6. The affections of man including indolence, temperament, life, and death. Book 7, The rational soul.||The optics material is presented in the context of Fabri's analysis of the 'external senses,' which is the subject of Book 2. Propositions 1-52 deal with the senses in general, the nature of sense objects, and perceptions from the senses. Propositions 53-58 deal briefly with the senses of touch, taste, smell,  and hearing. Proposition 59-97 deal with optics and vision and describe ocular anatomy, physiology of vision, binocular vision, a few aspects of visual perception, operation of the Galilean and Keplerian telescopes, and optical illusions. The 97th and last proposition presents various questions and answers.||The ocular anatomy is modern, with the seat of vision ascribed to the retina onto which objects impress images by way of Lumen. Distinct and indistinct vision is ascribed to images not impressed properly on the retina. Fabri also acknowledges the role of Francois Aguilon's Horopter in distinct vision as well as giving the analogy of the camera obscura for the function of the eye. Binocular vision is explained in Proposition 93, proposing that vision presents a single perception from two eyes because points on the object are projected 'onto the same spot on each retina.' Dioptrics is presented with detail just sufficient to explain the function of the eye's crystalline lens and the operation of the Galilean and Keplerian telescopes. The issue of the nature of light is not addressed and is avoided throughout with the artifice of using 'visual rays' in all demonstrations and expositions, rather than light rays. The 20 questions and answers in Proposition 97 deal with several aspects of the eye, visual perception, lenses, and the telescope. The book contains a single plate of 10 figures, all of which are devoted to vision and optics.
BP_Reference(s): La philosophie naturelle d‚ÄôHonor√© Fabri (1607-1688)|Roux, S.|In: <i>Les J√©suites √† Lyon<i>|√âFouilloux, √â., Hours, B., editors|ENS √âditions, Lyon, 2005, 275 pp, NB pp 75-94.||Aristotelianism More Geometrico: Honor√© Fabri|Paul Richard Blum, P.R.|In: <i>Studies in Early Modern Aristotelianism<i>, Brill, 2012, 366 pp, NB: pp 199-216.||Deux essais de renouvellement de la Scolastique au XVIIe si√®cle. II. ‚Äî L'aristot√©lisme d'Honor√© Fabri|Boehm, A.|<i>Revue des Sciences Religieuses<i>, Vol 39, No 4, 1965 pp 305-360.
BP_Title: Tractatus Duo: Quorum Prior est ee Plantis, et de generatione animalum; Posterior de Homine
BP_Title English Translation: Two Tracts: Of which the first is on Plants and the Generation of Animals; the second is on Man.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, mathematician, natural philosopher. Disputatious and extravagent with his claims for what he discovered.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp and ex libris inscription dated 1670 on title page

BP_Short or Common Title: Ad Scriptum de nature et proprietate lucis
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A rebuttal to critics and clarification of the ideas regarding light and refraction presented in the <i>De Lucis Natura<i> of 1662.
BP_Description_1: Isaac Voss' <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> has its origins with Voss' study of the optical phenomena reported by  Pomponius Mela involving the sea, the atmosphere, and the rising sun. In his commentary on Mela of 1658, Voss added an extended note offering an explanation for the phenomena. In doing so he set down several controversial claims that departed significantly from generally accepted ideas. The most bumptious of which was that refraction does not take place only at the interface between two media of different densities, but rather continuously throughout a medium. The denser the medium, the more pronounced the continuous refraction. The most important and detailed response to Voss' claims was from Pierre-Daniel Huet, Voss' friend, colleague in philology, and cleric-scholar from Caen. Huet objected to Voss claims about the atmosphere and how it refracts, but most strenuously to the claim that refraction is continuous in a medium. The <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> is essentially an extended reply to Huet's objections. In it, the treatment of optics is based on visual perception and images, rather than Keplerian ray propagation. That is, from visual phenomena Voss deduces physical phenomena, rather than the other way around. Though an anti-Cartesian, Voss was not an Aristotelian--he had developed his own peculiar ideas regarding optics.||The <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> contains Voss' recounting of his examination of a manuscript of Willebrord Snell and that he discovered the sine law of refraction before Descartes and its appearance in his <i>La Dioptrique<i> of 1637. This alone made the book popular. Though widely read, the book's collection of extreme differences from Keplerian and Cartesian optics generated wide-spread negative reaction among Cartesians. One was the publication in 1664 of <i>De Natura Ignis, Lucis et Colorum Dissertatio<i> by Andr√© Graindorge, a close acquaintance of Pierre-Daniel Huet. Voss would publish a response in the form of the <i>Appendix ad Scriptum de Natura et Proprietate Lucis<i>, added at the end of his <i>De Nili<i> of 1666.
BP_Description_2: Isaac Voss' <i>De Lucis Natura et Proprietate<i> has 32 Chapters. Chapters 1-4 cover the theory of light, presenting and dismissing both Cartesian and Gassendian ideas, maintaining instead that light is a type of luminous fire. Chapters 5-13 consider non-corporeal rays of light and their motion in vacuum. Chapters 14-23 presents Voss' ideas on continuous refraction, and refraction in air, water, glass objects. It is in chapter 16 that Voss recounts what he learned from examining a manuscript of Willebrord Snell and in chapter 18 that atmospheric refraction is considered. Chapters 24-28 are on color, which is presented as an entity separate from light, the intrinsic 'sulfurous quality' of an object. Chapters 29-32 cover various aspects of visual perception including the appearance of coronae, the apparent size of objects, what refraction does to solar and lunar observations, and refraction in general.||Voss adheres to image formation ideas from Witelo and Alhazen rather than those of ray propagation of Kepler, emphasizing the continuity of optical phenomena that take place throughout a transparent material, and not at (just) its surface. That is, Voss contends that light is continuously interacting with the transparent medium through which it travels, and so refraction is continuous, as appearances in some visual experiments seem to support.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ A View from the Mountaintop: The Development of Isaac Vossius' Optics, 1658-1666|Dijksterhus, F.J.|In: <i>Isaac Vossius (1618-1689) between Science and Scholarship<i>, Brill, Leiden, 2012, pp 159-187.||De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Dulianiel en Vossius in de periode 1640-1670|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.
BP_Title: Appendix Ad scriptum de nature et proprietate lucis
BP_Title English Translation: On a Letter Concerning the Nature and Properties of Light
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch scholar, linguist, libraian, and book collector on a grand scale. Came late in life to mathematics and natural philosophy, and then only via books not experimentation.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris inscription of Joseph Vares dated 1753 on front pastedown
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with De Nili et aliorum Fluminum origine

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: 58 Propositions surveying optics, admitting the practical parts of Descartes optics, but rejecting the theoretical and keeping Aristotelian ideas. The Function and use of microscopes and telescopes are described; the 'field lens' being an original contribution.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Synopsis Optica<i> of Honor√© Fabri is one of the many texts produced during his years of high productivity, 1665-1680, while stationed in Rome. It incorporates material that had appeared in his <i>Tractatus de Homine<i> of 1666 but is of considerably wider scope and greater detail. It follows the traditional optical trinity--optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics--but side-steps questions in physical optics and the nature of light, dealing almost exclusively with geometric optics.  Ostensibly Aristotelian, its content shows a recognition of the importance of Descartes' optics in matters practical and mathematical but does not adopt any aspect of Descartes' physical optics. The book's scope, level of detail, concision, and lack of advanced or elaborate mathematics, made it useful synopsis; a reasonable reference book and overview. But it lacked examples and could not be and was not used as a textbook. Fabri's grasp of optics was entirely theoretical, he was not a practitioner of any of its arts. This led him to errors, particular regarding the operation of multiple lens systems, which would be pointed out by John Flamsteed and William Molineux. It shows, however, that the <i>Synopsis Optica<i> was read by other opticians.||Fabri had a European reputation at the time and so the <i>Synopsis Optica<i> received reviews--neutral and little more than content summaries--in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, Vol 2, No 32, February 1667/8, p 626, and in Le Journal des Scavans, No 14, December 1667, pp 167-168.||This copy with the very rare errata for the <i>Synopsis Optica<i> at the end of the Appendix.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Synopsis Optica<i> of Honor√© Fabri has a traditional form, containing 58 Propositions surveying optics, each with demonstrations and corollaries. The general topics are: The eye and vision, Optics, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Astronomical Applications. Propositions 1-10 survey the eye, visual mechanisms, the nature and function of visual rays, and how they account for perceptions of size and distance of visual objects. Propositions 11-15 give the fundamentals of linear perspective and scenography. Propositions 16-19 discuss vision when objects or the eye are in motion, views through openings, whiteness and lightness, and binocular vision. Propositions 20-24 consider visual species and lumen and how they project through openings, the projection of shadows, and the appearance of Saturn explained by optical principles. Propositions 25-40 give an overview of reflected luminous rays on plane, convex, and concave mirrors. This includes mirrors of spherical, cylindrical, conical, parabolic, elliptical, and hyperbolic figure. A brief explanation of images in mirrors is given. Propositions 41-53 give an overview of refracted luminous rays in water and glass with plane, spherical, elliptical and hyperbolic faces. Telescopes and microscopes are considered, along with color. It is here that Fabri presents his two-lens 'field lens' for use in telescopes. Propositions 54-58 consider refraction and parallax and other celestial optical phenomena and the consequences for cosmogony. An appendix considers the celestial system of Ptolemy and argues for a stationary Earth. Three letters are attached that involve Fabri's ongoing tussles with Huygens and others over the nature and consequences of astronomical observations--particularly those of Saturn.||Fabri maintains a general, if vague, Aristotelianism but admits the practical parts of Keplerian and Cartesian optics. The general question of the nature of light--and most of physical optics--is not dealt with; virtually all the material is geometric optics, using the artifice of 'luminous rays.' The catoptric and dioptric material is basic but thorough, supported with extensive geometric demonstrations that possess a concision requiring both close reading and careful reference to the book's 152 figures.
BP_Reference(s): Images: Real and Virtual, Projected and Perceived, from Kepler to Dechales|Shapiro, A.E.|<i>Early Science and Medicine<i>, Vol 13, 2008, pp 270-312.||<i>Huygens' Ring, Cassini's Division, & Saturn's Children<i>|Van Helden, A.|Dibner Library Lecrture, Smithsonian Institution Libraries, 2004, 42 pp.||<i>The Correspondence of John Flamsteed, The First Astronomer Royal, Volume 2<i>|Institute of Physics, 1997, 1099 pp, NB: pp 300-326.
BP_Title: Synopsis Optica, in Qua Illa Omnia Quae ad Opticam, Dioptricam, Catoptricam Pertinent, id est, ad Triplicem Radium Visualem Directum, Refractum, Reflexum, Breviter Quidem, Accurate tamen demonstrantur.

BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Physica 1669

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook used in England, covering Mixed Mathematics including optics, consisting of most of the fifth volume of Gautruche's six volume work <i>Philosophi√¶ ac Mathematic√¶ Totius Institutio<i> of 1656.
BP_Description_1: Pierre Gaultruche taught mathematics at the Jesuit schools at La Fl√®che and Caens and it was at this time that he produced this compendium-textbook for use in his courses. In is broad scope, coverage, and level of detail, it was like other compendia of the time: Claude Milliet Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> of 1674 or William Leybourne's <i>Cursus Mathematics<i> of 1690. Though committed to Scholastic teachings, Gaultruche was an eclectic Aristotelian; as seen in the mix of theories he presented in physics and mixed mathematics. Though Kepler or Descartes are not mentioned, Keplerian and Cartesian optics are blended with Aristotelian ideas to form a hybrid of visual species, geometric optics, and image-based vision.||Editions appeared Caens in 1656 and 1665, at Vienna in 1661, and at London in 1683. This is the separate edition of Volume 5, <i>Mathematicae Totius<i>, that appeared at Cambridge in 1668. Used at English universities, it was also the basis for a German science and mathematics popularization that appeared at Ulm in 1695.
BP_Description_2: This English textbook extracted 8 of the 9 parts of the fifth volume of Gautruche's six volume work <i>Philosophi√¶ ac Mathematic√¶ Totius Institutio<i> of 1656. in the Scholastic manner, topics in Mixed Mathematics are covered in eight sections, each with a series of disputations: arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, chronology, gnomonics, geography, optics, and music.  The optics section covers light and vision. The optics material is brief (30 pages) and deals only with vision and images. There are seven brief chapters: Ocular anatomy; Optical function; Conditions of the eye for vision; Conditions of an object for vision;  Direct, reflected, and refracted vision, briefly mentioning lenses and Galileo's telescope, and images produced by mirrors; Visual perceptions of size, distance, motion, position; Illusions and errors of vision, citing Augilon's <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> of 1613. Geometric or physical optics is not presented. Though Descartes' La Dioptrique is not cited, ocular anatomy is covered and then a hybrid of Scholastic, Keplerian, and Cartesian theory of vision is presented. It details how species of light and color are emitted from an object, enter the eye, and impinge on the retina.||The material is elementary and entirely descriptive; no mathematics is involved.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Natural Philosophy in Some Early Seventeenth Century Scholastic Textbooks<i>|Reif, P.M.|St. Louis University, Dissertation, 1962, 365 p.
BP_Title: Mathematicae Totius, Clara, Brevis & Accurata Institutio. In Gratiam Studiosae Juventutis Adornata.
BP_Title English Translation: A Clear, Brief, and Accurate Instruciton in All of Mathematics. Prepared in Favor of Young Students.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, taught and wrote on astronomy and 'mixed mathematics'.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris inscription of Jac Petrie
BP_Plates: Plates [Tabula I -XI, Pro Musica] at O‚ÇÅ;  Plates[Pro Optica I-II] at Q‚Çá
BP_BibliographicNotes: Frontispiece on verso of œá¬π

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Thomas Hobbes' complete works, written in Latin, up to 1668. This includes his works on Man, Matter, Mathematics, Physics, and Politics: <i>De Corpore, De Homine, Leviathen, De Cive, De Natura Aeris et Duplicatione Cubi, Quadratura Circuli, Problemata Physica, De Principis Geometrarum, and Examinatio Mathematiae<i>.
BP_Description_1: The origins of Thomas Hobbes' writings on optics are his relationship with Marian Mersenne which began in 1635 and his acquisition and study of Ren√© Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> in 1638. By the early 1640s Hobbes had written what is now known as the <i>Tractatus Opticus I<i> in which contained the essence of his theory of light. His theory was mediumistic and mechanical and inextricably linked to vision: Light was pulsed motion in an aethereal medium produced by a luminous object, the pulses moved through the medium along paths that defined physical rays, the front of which were a type of 'pulse front' that interacted kinematically with objects producing reflection and refraction. The <i>Tractatus Opticus I<i> appeared in edited form in Mersenne‚Äôs <i>Universae Geometriae Mixtaeque Mathematicae Synopsis<i> of 1644. In 1646 Hobbes completed A Minute or First Draught of the Optiques which contained applications of the material in the <i>Tractatus Opticus I<i> and Hobbes' theory of vision. The second part this work, translated into Latin, appeared in published form in <i>De Homine<i> of 1658 and is included in the <i>Opera Philosophica<i>. Some parts of the <i>Tractatus Opticus I<i> were incorporated in <i>De Corpore<i> of 1665, which also appears here. The <i>Opera Philosophica<i> contains all of Hobbes' printed optical works, aside from the <i>Tractatus Opticus I<i> edited by Mersenne.||Emmanuel Maignan and Isaac Barrow were aware of Hobbes' theory of light, including it pulsed-motion mediumistic basis and the theory of rays and their role in refraction. Though both adopted the theory of physical light rays, they rejected the mediumistic theory and held to one involving emission. Maignan used Hobbes' 'ray line' explicitly in his explanation of reflection in the <i>Perspectiva Horaria<i> of 1648.||The <i>Opera Philosophica<i> appeared at Amsterdam in 1668 and edited by William Molesworth at London in 1839-1845.
BP_Description_2: Material on optics and vision appears in several places in the <i>Opera Philosophica<i>. In the first part, the work De Corpore contains Chapters 19, 24, and 27. Chapter 19 gives explanation and consequences of the equal angle law of reflection considering plane and spherical mirrors in the form of elementary ray analysis. Chapter 24 one the law of reflection and the sine law of refraction. Chapter 27 is on the nature, causes, and propagation of light, the nature of color as 'perturbed light', the cause of prismatic colors, the nature of white and black.||in the second part of the <i>Opera Omina<i>, the work De Homine contains 50 pages on vision, catoptrics and dioptrics, most of it an analysis of images produced by mirrors and lenses using geometrical optics, all in the context of human vision. It includes an analysis of vision through microscopes and telescopes. De Homine  contains 15 chapters, with chapters 2-9 devoted to optics and vision. Chapter 2: ocular anatomy, visual function, Keplerian theory of retinal images. Chapter 3: Visual perception of location and size of objects, visual errors, the moon illusion, illumination from the stars and the moon. Chapter 4: Simple linear perspective. Chapter 5: Images and apparent location of objects seen in plane and convex spherical mirrors. Chapter 6: Images and apparent location of objects seen in concave spherical mirrors. Chapter 7: Objects seen by a single refraction. Chapter 8: Objects seen by two refractions, dioptrics, convex and concave surfaces. Chapter 9: Dioptrics of the telescope and microscope.||At the time of his works of the 1640s, Hobbes' theory of light was a pulsed motion in a medium produced by a source. Rays of light were the paths of this motion and were considered as physical objects with extension. The analysis of reflection and refraction was conducted using the front of the ray, a 'ray line' perpendicular to the ray's direction of travel, and its interaction with mirror or refractive surfaces. This was the first kinematic explanation for the the laws of reflection and refraction. Vision was caused by this pulsed motion being received by the retina and transmitted to the brain--a rejection of Keplerian retinal images. The material in De Homine is an application of Hobbes' general theory of optics to human vision. In De Corpore, which touched on light's interaction with objects, Hobbes' had modified his pulsed motion in the aetherial medium to a circular motion. The work De Corpore considers light's interaction with objects by reflection and refraction.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Most Curious of Sciences: Hobbes‚Äôs Optics|Giudice, F.|In: <i>Oxford Handbook of Hobbes<i>, Martinich, A.P., editor|Oxford University Press, 2016 , pp 146‚Äì165.||Hobbes‚Äôs Geometrical Optics|Medina, J.|<i>Hobbes Studies<i>, Vol 29, No 1, pp 39 ‚Äì 65.||Hobbes und das Sinusgesetz der Refraktion|Horstmann, F.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 57, No 4, 2000, pp 415-440.||Kinematic Optics: A Study the Wave Theory of Light in the Seventeenth Century|Shapiro, A.E.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2/3, 1973, pp 134‚Äì266.||<i>Luce e Visione: Thomas Hobbes e la Scienza dell'Ottica<i>|Giudice, F.|Olschki, Fierenze, 1999, 182 p.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Simone Lorenzo Veterani
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Posthumous editing and publication of a set of teaching manuals for the Jesuit schools. One, of 70 pages, is devoted to optics and, being practical rather than theoretical, uses geometrical-optics and experiments to present propositions on optics, perspective, projections for astrolabes, and the catoptrics of plane and curved mirrors.
BP_Description_1: Andr√© Tacquet taught at the Flemish Jesuit school in Louvain from 1644 until his death in 1660. His <i>Elementa Euclidea Geometriae Planae et Solidae<i> of 1654 and <i>Arithmeticae Teor√≠a et Praxis<i> of 1656 were famous and tremendously successful textbooks; the <i>Elementa<i> saw more than 30 editions and was translated into English. This demonstrated success as a textbook writer had the Jesuit General Goswin Nickel request Tacquet to write a broader <i>cursus mathematicus<i> suitable for use in Jesuit schools. This meant an elementary exposition of Mixed Mathematics, used by a large number of beginning students, supporting the courses taught at Louvain and other Jesuit schools. Tacquet's response was to write an extensive series of teaching manuals covering arithmetic, geometry, statics, optics, astronomy and cosmography, ballistics, and military architecture. Of these only those on arithmetic and geometry were published in his lifetime; the others were unfinished. Some of these were, in turn, edited and assembled by Simon Laurent and published as the <i>Opera Mathematica<i>. He included Astronomy, Practical Geometry, Optics, and Catoptrics. Though Tacquet's text refers to a work on dioptrics, it was never found.||In keeping with his charge--and his own interests--Tacquet's approach to all aspects of Mixed Mathematics was practical and rarely ventured into theory. The geometric treatise on cyclinders and rings rejects Cavalieri's indivisibles--points make lines, lines make planes, planes make solids--for something more Archimedean: a method of exhaustion. Which led, via Blaise Pascal, to the development of infinitesimals. The treatise on astronomy--the largest by far, and probably the most complete at the time of Tacquet's death--presents but does not embrace Kepler's planetary elliptical orbits since he thought them as being of little practical  importance. For the same failure of practicality, he does not present arguments either for or against Copernican cosmography since he finds them merely statements of what is or is not probable.  Practicality is also the byword for the optics material.||An aspect of Tacquet‚Äôs pedagogical style is his unwillingness to present 'explanations' that he considers to be mere suppositions and not demonstrations. Another is his presentation of competing explanations but failure to discriminate between them or plump for one. These are seen in the treatise on astronomy and on optics.||A long summary and review of the <i>Opera Mathematica<i> appeared in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, Vol 3, No 43, January 1668. Editions appeared at Antwerp in 1668, 1699, and 1707.
BP_Description_2: Tacquet's <i>Opera Mathematica<i> contains a treatise on astronomy in 8 books, a summary of practical geometry in 3 books, a treatise on optics in 3 books, a treatise on catoptrics in 3 books, and brief treatise on military architecture.  The first book of optics covers the appearance of things; that is, the nature of visual perception. Tacquet presents hypotheses that are actually what he considers to be statement of fact, followed by propositions that are presented as direct consequences. The result is an eclectic hybrid: light travels in straight lines, but objects 'project images that are captured by the eye' and produce perception. Position, size, and shape are governed by simple geometric optics and an appeal to the authority of Euclid, Alhazen, and Witelo. The appearance of circles, cones, and spheres (including the phases of the moon) from various view are described in this way. The second book of optics is on simple linear perspective, projection scenography, and anamorphosis. The third book of optics is on 'projective astronomy.' This covers dialling and the construction of astrolabes.||The first book of catoptrics covers basic reflection, presents the equal-angle law of reflection, its Cartesian and Witelian explanations, and its application to various mirrors. Tacquet believed the law of reflection could be also considered a consequence of a more general law: 'nature always acts along the shortest path.' The second book of catoptrics considers plane mirrors and their images. The third book of catoptrics considers curved mirrors and their images. This includes spherical parabolic, elliptical, and hyperbolic mirrors. Though its generality had been disproved by Kepler, Tacquet kept the 'Ancient Principle' of the cathetus for locating reflected images; a principle he considered 'the most fruitful in all of catoptrics', even though by his own experimentation he found cases involving spherical mirrors where it did not properly locate images.||Some of the Propositions involve experiments that range from simple, common visual observations to more elaborate investigations, particularly in optics. Physical optics is only touched upon, but the geometric optics is detailed, analytic, and accompanied by elaborate figures.
BP_Reference(s): Jesuit Science in the Spanish Netherlands|Vanpaemel, G. H. W|In: <i>Jesuit Science and the Republic of Letters<i>|Feingold, M., editor|MIT Press, 2003, 483 pp, NB: pp 389-432.||‚ÄòTo the adornment and honour of the city‚Äô: the mathematics course of the Flemish Jesuits in the seventeenth century|de Bruycker, A.|<i>Journal of the British Society for the History of Mathematics<i>, Vol 24, No 3, 2009, pp 135‚Äì146.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of brief discourses. The most famous, in the form of a letter to Giovanni Ciampoli, is the Discorso sulla Vista and deals with vision and its preservation, perceptions and illusions, and causes of poor eyesight. Another discourse is a letter to Galileo and deals with surface colors and radiant heat, and luminous effect decreasing with the square of the distance from the source.
BP_Description_1: Benedetto Castelli was the oldest, closest, and most faithful of Galileo's pupils. Though Galileo himself and most of his pupils had little interest in matters related to biology, one of the exceptions was Castelli, who had begun work on vision in about 1630. In 1639 he summarized his work in the <i>Discorso sulla Vista<i> in the form of a long letter to Giovanni Ciampoli, another friend of Galileo and camerlengo to Pope Urban VIII. Manuscript copies of the <i>Discorso<i> circulated in Galileo's circle and members of the Accademia del Cimento in Florence and so was not widely known, even in Italy, until its posthumous appearance with Castelli's  other work on light and heat in the <i>Alcuni Opuscoli Filosofici del Padre D. Benedetto Castelli<i> of 1669. The decision to publish the <i>Discorso<i> was, apparently, prompted by the appearance of Edm√© Mariotte's <i>Nouvelles Decouvertes Touchant la V»óe<i> in 1668 and the subsequent interest of Cardinal Leopoldo de'Medici. And so, members of the Accademia del Cimento gathered Castelli's Discorsi together and had them printed in Bologna.||The <i>Discorso sulla Vista<i> presents the clear recognition of the retina's fundamental role, mentions early cataract surgery and the optical diaphragm, recognizes and describes the persistence of visual images, and--most advanced of Catelli's ideas--a clearly stated phenomenology of vision. Castelli also presents experiments on the Moon Illusion, and his explanatory theory which anticipates 20th century perceptual research. The other discourse presents among the earliest experiments on heat absorption by colored bodies and a theory to explain the results.||Editions appeared at Bologna in 1669 and reprinted at Florence in 1874.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Discorso sulla Vista<i> begins with advice, based on experiments, on improving presbyopia: view through a small aperture. He then describes a series of experiments with a camera obscura and a lens, to show that small apertures exclude rays and produce a sharper image. From followed a careful consideration of the parallels between the camera obscura and the optical operation of the eye. This is followed by 24 questions regarding phenomena of vision. In modern terms the questions consider the following. Questions 1-3 deal with correction of near and far-sightedness, 4 considers clouded vitreous humor, 5-6 deal with spherical aberration and correction by diaphragms, 7-10 deal with image persistence and the 'slowness' of the retina, 11 presents Castelli's theory of vision based on the kinetic impact of light particles on the retina. Castelli contends that most visual phenomena can be explained by a consideration of what happens to the retina in the visual process.  Questions 12-13 consider irradiance and the increase in apparent size of luminous objects, and 14-22 apply his theory of retinal function to an explanation of various vision abnormalities, impairments, animal vision, and changing sensitivities.||Questions 23-24 consider the Moon Illusions and the problem of distance and size perception in general. Castelli is most ingenious and original on these matters. He formulates a theory that involves not just image size on the retina, but the context of the image, the history and judgement of the observer. He applies all this to explanations for the Moon Illusion and the similar apparent size increase of the Big Dipper asterism when it is near the horizon.||In the letter to Galileo, Castelli recounts his experiments with heat and light. He conducts several experiments showing the differential heating produced by white and black surfaces, hypothesizes that heat is the manifestation of the motion of particles. These demonstrations and those described in the Discorso sulla Vista reveal the thoroughgoing experimental nature of  Castelli's work.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª A Little Known Early Seventeenth Century Treatise on Vision: Benedetto Castelli's Discorso Sopra La Vista (1639, 1669)|Arrioti, P.E.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 30, No 1, 1973, pp 1-30.||Mattoni al sole: Benedetto Castelli, la luce e il calore|Campogalliani, P.|<i>Atti dell'Istituto Veneto di Scienze, Lettere e Arti<i>, Vol 152, 1993-1994, pp 15-31.||Benedetto Castelli and George Berkeley as Anticipators of Recent Findings on the Moon Illusion|Arrioti, P.E.|<i>Journal of the History of the Behavioral Sciences<i>, Vol 9, No 4, 1973, pp 328-332.
BP_Title: Alcuni Opuscoli Filosofici del padre abbate D. Benedetto Castellli da Bresica. Monaco casinese, e Mathematico della Fel. Memoria di Nostro Sig. Papa Urbano VIII. Non piu stampati. Al Serensisimo, e Reverendiss. Principe Il Sig. Cardinatel De Medici.
BP_Title English Translation: Some Philosophical Writings of Father Benedetto Castelli of Brescia Abbot of Monte Cassino, and Mathematician to our Pope Urban VIII of Fond Memory. No Longer Printed. To the most Serene, most Reverend Cardinal De Medici.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian (Brescian) Benedictine priest, student of Galileo, abbot at Monte Cassino.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Volume 1 of Honor√© Fabri's monumental 4-volume, 8-tract work on physics; that is, the 'knowledge of corporeal things'. A comprehensive work covering all aspects of bodies, from motion, mechanical properties, luminous properties, on to the corporeality of man, and finally anthropology. Essentially Aristotelian, but with significant accommodation of the ideas of Galileo, Gassendi, and others.
BP_Description_1: Volume 1 of Honor√© Fabri's monumental 4-volume, 8-tract work on physics; that is, the 'knowledge of corporeal things'. Honor√© Fabri began work on the <i>Physica<i> after he had been stationed in Rome for 20 years. With the appearance of his <i>Tractatus Duo<i> in 1666 and its success, Fabri had revived his writing and publishing efforts that had stopped when he was sent to Rome in 1648||Originally intended to consist of 5 volumes containing 10 tracts, only four volumes containing 8 tracts were published, appearing at Lyon between 1669 and 1671. Fabri sets out the plan for the <i>Physica<i> in his letter to the reader, showing that it was conceived and executed as a comprehensive work covering all aspects of physics, with tracts 1-4 devoted to sensible bodies and their states, tract 5 on natural bodies and the four elements, tracts 6-7 on mixed and unmixed matter, tract 8 on celestial bodies, and tracts 9-10 on plants, animals, and man. The material ranging from elementary properties, motion, mechanical properties, luminous properties, on to the corporeality of man, and finally anthropology. Volume 1 contains Tractatus I and II. Book 3 of Tract 1 deals with opacity and transparency and Book 3 of Tract 2 deals with light sources and their light (Luce et Lumine) and color.||Fabri's plan was a complete reformation of physics. Though a committed Aristotelian, he was keen on returning to Aristotle's original ideas, clearing away what others considered commentaries, but what he considered to be Scholastic and Arabic accretions. He believed that physics could be based on the four elements of matter, what he called impetus, heat, and a few ideas from metaphysics: action, extension, time, and place. From these he believed universal physical hypotheses could be obtained, accounting for all observed physical phenomena. All informed by the certainty of geometry. And so, the fundamental ideas of Aristotle could accommodate the new science of Galileo, Gassendi, Grimaldi, Borelli, and Gilbert. And so, for example, light is described as an accident of a substance and color as a modification of light, though luminous rays and geometrical optics are used to describe the elementary aspects of emanation, reflection, and refraction.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1 of Honor√© Fabri's <i>Physica<i> contains two tracts. Tractatus I is in five books: On Quantity of Bodies, On Compression and Tension, On Rarity and Density, On Heaviness and Lightness, On Opacity and Translucency. Tractatus II is in five books: On Cold, On Heat, On Luminance and Light, On Wetness, Dryness, Hardness, Softness, etc.||Book 5 of Tract 1 (14 pages) deals with opacity and transparency vis-√†-vis luminous rays. Two Definitions, two axioms on Aristotelian Form, two hypotheses on the angles of reflection and refraction, and 64 brief Propositions are devoted to the nature of opacity and transparency, materials exhibiting either, and a range of examples. Transparency is presented as the property of an object to conduct luminous rays, such as air, glass, and water. Logically, but strangely, vacuum is declared to be opaque, since there would be nothing present to conduct luminous rays. Book 3 of Tract 2, longer and more detailed (70 pages), has 109 propositions on light sources and their light (Lux et Lumine) and color. Of all his optical works, this is Fabri's most extensive consideration of the nature of light. He rejects both the theory of emanation of corpuscles of Democretus and Empedocles and that of it being motion in a tenuous medium; he adheres to the Aristotelian: Lux is inherent luminous power and lumen is its effect transmitted through transparent bodies. Potential transparency is actualized by lux, with color being a modification of of light. Light and heat are presented as the same 'quality' of an object, light being 'pure heat'. The elementary aspects of vision are presented and luminous rays are used to describe the elementary aspects of emanation, reflection, and refraction.||The material is entirely descriptive, no mathematics is involved. Fabri uses 'Hypothesis' to indicate a fact of nature, something that can be observed with certainty or demonstrated simply. Thus, for example, equal angles of specular reflection is an hypothesis.
BP_Reference(s): Deux essais de renouvellement de la Scolastique au XVIIe si√®cle. II. ‚Äî L'aristot√©lisme d'Honor√© Fabri|Boehm, A.|<i>Revue des Sciences Religieuses<i>, Vol 39, No 4, 1965, pp 305-360.||Aristotelianism more geometrico: Honr√© Fabri|Blum, P.R.|In: <i>Philosophy in the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuires: Conversations with Aristotle<i>|Blackwell, C., Kusukawa, S., editors|Aldershot , 1999, pp 234-247.
BP_Title: Physica, id est, Scientia rerum Corporearum, in Decem Tractatus Distributa. Auctore Honorato Fabri Soc. Iesu. Cum indice duplici; primo Tractatuum, Librorum & Propositionum; Rerum Notabilium, altero. Nunc Primum in Lucem Produt.
BP_Title English Translation: Physics, that is: The Science of Corporeal Things, Arranged in Ten Tracts. Authored by Honore Fabri, SJ. With a Double Index: First of the Tracts, Books, and Propositions; followed by Notable Things. Now First Brought to Light.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, mathematician, natural philosopher. Disputatious and extravagent with his claims for what he discovered.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Synopsis Optica 1667

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An expansion of previous editions, in three parts; the first a reprinting of the problems of the edition of 1626, the second part a reprinting of problems of the second part of the edition of 1629. New optical problems include rudimentary optical devices for surveying, the use of mirrors in viewing instruments, and lanterns with reflectors.
BP_Description_1: One of the many editions of the text that appeared in the last half of 17th century. 'Problems' are presented, some of several parts, with solutions constituting a collection of experiments, apparatus demonstrations, recipes, and parlor tricks in cosmology, optics, perspective, mechanics, statics, practical geometry, fortification and gunnery. Designed to entertain and instruct. The source for the arithmetical problems was Claude Bachet's <i>Problems Plaisans et Delectables<i> of 1612. The problems in geometry are in the Renaissance tradition of 'practical geometry'; geometry applied to surveying, mensuration, and fortification. Many of the other problems come from the tradition of secretes and natural magic, such as Girolamo Ruscelli's <i>De' Secretis del Alessio Piemontese<i> in the edition of 1615. Some of the problems in natural philosophy appear to be from works by Giambattista Della Porta, Girolamo Cardano, and Salomon de Caus. Renaissance books on conjuring and prestidigitation were a source for the <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>.||Tradition has assigned authorship to the Jesuit Jean Leurechon, though there is little scholarly evidence for this. Whoever assembled this collection of problems and secrets produced a book that was tremendously popular, being in print in various forms for more than 150 years. Thirty editions in French appeared between 1624 and 1680. Denis Henrion and Claude Mydorge were contributors and commentators for editions between 1626 and 1639, adding significant value to the book. Jacques Ozanam began editing editions in 1694, adding material and changing the content to be more like an encyclopedia. Jean-Etienne Montucla and Edm√© Gilles Guyot were subsequent editors and by 1769 there were four volumes. Translations appeared in English, Latin, Dutch, and German. This edition uses the same woodcut illustrations from the text of 1627.
BP_Description_2: This and other editions of <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> have a preface to the reader from the author which names some of his sources and the general nature of what he tried to accomplish. This is followed by Part I containing 91 'Problems' on various subjects, including: Arithmetic, Geometry, Optics and Perspective, Music, Cosmographical Matters. The camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow are presented in a rudimentary way. In this and other early editions, the optical material is limited to display and demonstration, with little or no explanation of the phenomena itself. Part II contains 45 Problems on similar subjects, these first appeared in the edition of 128. Part III is the briefest, containing 17 problems in fireworks and artillery. There are a few problems in Part II devoted to optics and projection that have a very different character than the original problems of Part I--more detailed and  explanatory, rather than simply reporting. The problems in Part I and their examinations, and the problems in Part II, never involve mathematics above the simplest geometry, thus maintaining their popular science character.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.
BP_Title: Recreations mathematiques composees de plusieures problemes plaisants et facetieux d'Arithmetique, Geometrie, Astrologie, Optique, Perspective, Mechanqiue, & autres rares & curius Secrets: Et d'un Recueil de plusieurs gentilles & recratives inventions de feux d'artifice; avec la maniere de faire toutes fortes de fusees simples, & composees. Le tout represente par figures.
BP_Title English Translation: Mathematical Recreations, Composed of Several Pleasant and Humerous Problems of Arithmetic, Geometry, Astrology,  Optics, Perspective,  Mechanics, and Other Rare and Curious Secrets: And a Collection of Several Nice and Recreational Inventions of Fireworks; with the Manner of Making All Sortes of Simple and Compound Rockets. All Represented with Figures.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, mathematician, and professor.
