BP_Short or Common Title: Dissertationes Anatomic√¶, et Pathologic√¶ sensibus, & eorum Organis
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The sense organs and their diseases. Ocular anatomy is presented in detail, along with diseases of the eye and causes for poor vision.
BP_Description_1: Antonio Molinetti was appointed professor of surgery and anatomy at the University of Padua in 1649. While there, his studies focused on the organs of sense and on what anatomy can reveal on pathology and treatment. And that is the basis for this text on sense organs and their diseases.
BP_Description_2: The work describes the sense organs and their diseases. Ocular anatomy is presented in detail, along with diseases of the eye and causes for poor vision. The book contains 5 chapters on eye anatomy and disease. The illustrations and plates were particularly important as teaching tools. The text deals with the muscles, function, parts and conditions of the eyes, ears, tongue and nose, the four senses they provide, the nerves, the brain (which he considered the first sense organ), and, more generally, the internal workings of the senses. Molinetti applied his anatomical knowledge of the eye represented here in detail as an engraved diagram and  to the construction of the most detailed model of the ocular cavity to date, working with the Venetian instrument maker Giovanni Battista Verle to produce an elaborate model of the eye. The ivory model was presented to Cosmo III of the Medics, and described in Verle's book <i>Anatomia Artifiziale dell' Occhio Umano<i> of 1679.
BP_Reference(s): Eye Representation and Ocular Terminology from Antiquity to Helmholtz|Raynaud, D.|Wayenborgh, Amsterdam, 2020, 635 pp, NB: pp 140-157.||Dates in Ophthalmology|Albert, D.M.|CRC Press, Boca Raton, 2002, 232 pp.||The Anatomay of the Eye in the Seventeenth Century|d'A. Maycock, W.|<i>Journal of the Canadian Medical Association<i>, Vol 26, No 1, 1932, pp 83-88.
BP_Title: Antonii Molinetti Phil et Medici Veneti. Prima Sede In Celeberrimo Patavino Lyceo Theorice Medicinae, & Anatomes Professoris. Dissertationes Anatomicae, et Pathologicae sensibue, & eorum Organis.
BP_Title English Translation: Antonio Molinetti, Philosopher and Doctor of Venice. Chair of the Most Celebrated School of Theoretical Medicine in Padua, and Professor of Anatomy.  An Anatomical and Pathological Disseration on the Senses and their Organs.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physician and influential teacher in the University of Padua.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Describes the discovery of double refraction while experimenting with crystals from Iceland.
BP_Description_1: In 1668, Frederic III of Denmark ordered the keepers of curiosity cabinet to arrange a two-man expedition of a stone-cutter and assistant to Iceland in 1668 to mine crystals of Icelandic Spar--calcite, or crystallized calcium carbonate. Bartholin began experimenting with samples and saw that, when properly cleaved and placed on a surface with a small image, the crystal produced two images, one in the usual place and another displaced. Eventually, he realized that the two images we being formed by two paths of refraction; he had found 'dioptrical refraction.' Though Bartholin noted the change in brightness of these images, depending on their position, the reason for this and the existence of two images he did not attempt to explain. The two rays he called 'solita' and 'insolita'--ordinary and extraordinary--and showed that both were produced by refraction.||Samples of the crystal were eventually obtained by Robert Hooke, Christiaan Huygens, and Isaac Newton. Bartholin worked until 1674 to share his experimental results but the return was slow in coming. Eventually, Huygens would study the phenomena and propose an explanation for double refraction in his <i>Trait√© de la Lumi√®re<i> of 1690. Newton's Opticks of 1704 did not deal with double refraction. But in Query 17 of the Latin Optice of 1706, which became Query 25 of later English editions, Newton stated a ‚Äòrule‚Äô purporting to give the direction of the extraordinary ray in terms of that of the ordinary ray. This was later shown to be incorrect by the French mineralogist Ren√© Just Ha√ºy in an experiment published in 1788. Icelandic Spar become a common item in collections and cabinets of curiosities, but though described often and at length, it was not until Jean Etienne Malus experimental work trying to establish a corpuscular theory of double refraction, that Huygens ideas were proved correct. It was Malus who detected that the two rays were differently polarized. The discovery of double refraction by Bartholin was the beginning of important developments in physical optics.||Editions appeared in 1669 and as a reissue with a redated title page in 1670. The work was translated in German, French, Dutch, and English.
BP_Description_2: Bartholin begins with a dedication to Frederick III of Denmark followed by two parts of the work. The first begins with a general remarks about the nature of the crystal, followed by a description of 17 experiments. The second part is subtitled 'Observations to prove the preceding remarks.' These are a series of hypotheses regarding the behavior of the crystal followed by propositions purporting to show how well the hypotheses align with his experimental results. One of these hypotheses was based on Descartes' theory that light moved along 'pores' in transparent material, coupled with his own idea that there were two sets of 'pores' in the crystal.||Experiments I - IV involve the rhombic shape and other physical, chemical, and 'electrical' properties of the crystal. Experiments V and VI describe the discovery and nature of double images. Experiments VII and VIII give some crystallographic details including face orientations and edge angles. Experiments IX - X investigate the orientation, placement, and motion of the double images. Experiments XI determines the nature of the double images. Experiments XII - XVI properties of the images, whether from reflection of refraction, how they rotated, and their varying brightness. Experiment XVII reports measurements of the two refractive indices of the crystal.||The figures are generally clear and essential to an understanding of Bartholin's description of his experiments and their results. This include crystal shape, orientation, and optical paths. One of the images is an edge-net that, when cut out, can be folded into a three-dimensional model of the crystal. Bartholin's title used a neologism of his own, the the Greco-Latin 'disdiaclasticus' (Œ¥ŒπœÉŒ¥ŒπŒ±Œ∫ŒªŒ±œÉœÑŒπŒ∫œåœÇ), from which came 'birefringent.'
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Nova Experimenta Crystalli Islandici Disdiaclastici|Lohne, J.A.|Centaurus, Vol 21, No 2, 1977, pp 106-148.||Kinematic Optics: A Study of the Wave Theory of Light in the Seventeenth Century|Shapiro, D.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1973, pp 134-266.
BP_Title: Experimenta Crystalli Islandici disdiaclastici, quibus mira et insolita refractio detegitur
BP_Title English Translation: Experiments with the Double Refracting Iceland Crystal, by which a Remarkable and Extraordinary Refraction was Revealed.
BP_Biographical Statement: Danish physician, mathematician, and physicist. Professor at the University of Copenhagen.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Woodcut figures throughout

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Lana's book presents and analyzes a wide range of technical developments. Famed for its discussion of flight and its figure of a ship afloat with copper balloons, it contains much else. One third of the book is devoted to the design, construction and use of telescopes and microscopes.
BP_Description_1: Francesco Lana de Terzi was at the Collegium Romanum under Athanasius Kircher where learned natural philosophy and witnessed first-hand the power and utility of experiment, the popularity of books on natural philosophy, and the pedagogical importance of cabinets of instruments. When he returned to his native Northwestern Italy, he began to experiment and write. Unlike those of his fellow Jesuit and contemporary Gaspar Schott, who also was a student of Kircher, Lana de Terzi's work are not deeply tinctured with the ideas of natural magic and Llullism. Rather, Lana de Terzi is interested in mechanics and physics, mathematical analysis, and experiment. All this to the end of obtaining practical knowledge and use instruments and devices.||From the long Proemio, it is clear that Lana de Terzi was eclectic about Aristotelianism and developed a hybrid that often blended it, and on occasion replaced it, with new science. He states that Niccol√≤ Cabeo and Pierre Gassendi are the best modern writers in physics. An enthusiastic experimenter, he also cites impediments to advancing science: attachment to antiquity and pet subjects such as logic and theology.||The <i>Prodromo<i> (from the Greek, œÄœÅœåŒ¥œÅoŒºo, precursor) was written in Italian and clearly intended for students and a limited public audience. Nevertheless, it aims considerably above works  of popular science of the time. Topics in the <i>Prodromo<i> include flying ships and early theory of the aerostatics, research in communication including reading and writing systems for the blind, clocks of various kinds, odometers, hygrometers, and considerable material on optics. One third of the text is devoted to lenses, telescopes, and microscopes.||Though the <i>Prodromo<i> was never reviewed in any prominent journal, it was widely read. Robert Hooke would later comment on the book's proposal of an aerial ship. Via John Dodington, English diplomatic agent in Venice, Lana de Terzi sent a copy to the Royal Society of London. Presumably, Hooke read this copy in preparation for his talk to the Society in 1672 on Lana de Terzi's 'aerial globe' and for which he constructed a model. A discussion of the 'aerial globe' appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Society of London in 1679.  Gottfried Leibniz reviewed the principles involved in his <i>Hypothesis Physica Nova<i> of 1671. The <i>Prodromo<i> was edited and reprinted at Milano in 1977.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Prodromo<i> is in three parts. The first part, Prodromo all' Arte Maestra, contains 24 chaptes on instruments and devices. The second part, L' Arte della Pittura, contains 4 chapters on painting, paints, color, drawing and drawing instruments. The third part, Molti sorti di Cannocchiali e Microscopi (83 pages and 50 figures), contains 8 chapters on lens optics and applications to instruments.||The first part, Chapter 6, presents Lana di Terzi's famed description of a ship floated by evacuated copper balloons, and a theory of aeronautics based on concepts of air density, weight, and the principle of Torriceli. Several instruments are discussed, including the thermometer, hygrometer, odometer, and the pendulum clock. It also contains his system of reading and writing for the blind. The third part of the book is devoted to the design and making of lenses and the construction and use of telescopes and microscopes. Galilean, Keplerian, and multiple-lensed telescopes are discussed. Lens working, grinding, and testing are described, with the desire being elliptical, hyperbolic, or parabolic figures. The source of lens imperfections and how they can be remedied is presented, and concludes by describing the uses of telescopes and microscopes. It ends, whimsically, by describing how to use the telescope 'to deceive friends with a delightful show', that is to obtain effects of trompe-l‚Äôoeil.
BP_Reference(s): Seventeenth-century inventions and drawings in the Francesco Lana's works|Chirone, E. and Dassa, L.|In: <i>Conference Proceedings XXI Congreso Internacional INGEGRAF, at Lugo<i>, 2009.||<i>Francesco Lana Terzi e la scienza barocca<i>|Pighetti, C.|Commentari dell' Ateneo di Brescia, 1985, pp 97-117|http://www.ateneo.brescia.it/controlpanel/uploads/commentari-1908-2008/CAB1985.pdf||Pious Ambition: Natural Philosoophy and the Jesuit Quest for the Patrongage of Printed Book in the Seventeenth Century|Baldwin, M.|In: <i>Jesuit Science and the Rebulic of Letters<i>|Feingold, M., editor|MIT Press, Cambridge, 2003, 489 pp, NB: pp 283-329.
BP_Title: Prodromo Overo saggio de alcune inventioni nuove premesso all' arte maestra. Opera che prepara il P. Francesco Lana Bresciano Della Compagnia de Giesu. Per mostrare li piu reconditi principii della Naturale Filosofia, reconosciuti con accurata Teorica nell piu segnalate inventioni, ed isperienze sin' hora ritrovate dal gli scrittori de questa materia & altre nuove dell' autore re medsimo. Dedicato alla sacra maesta cesarea del Imperatore Leopoldo I.
BP_Title English Translation: A Precuror, or an Essay on Certain New Inventions Given by  the Art Master. A Work Prepared by Father Francesco Lana of Brescia of the Society of Jesus.  To Show the Most Recondite Principles of Natural Philosophy, Identified with Accurate, Theoretical, most Signal Inventions, and Experiments, Found in Previous Writers on this Matter and Other New Ones of the Author Himself. Dedicated to His Sacred Roman Majesty The Emperor Leopold I.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jesuit, mathematician and naturalist. Sometime professor of mathematics, a successful author, famed for his early work in aeronautics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of several technical dissertations from the University of Rinteln under the direction of Arnold Eckhard on the subject of light and color. This is In five parts: the three on sources of light, the fourth on the rainbow, and the fifth on so-called permanent colors.
BP_Description_1: This is the second of at least four detailed, technical dissertations on light and color from the University of Rinteln under the direction of Arnold Eckhard, professor of physics. This, the second, is on the nature of light and was produced in the first year of his tenure at Rinteln. The fourth, published a month later, deals exclusively with the rainbow.  As was the custom, the dissertation was actually written by the presiding professor but publicly defended by the student being examined; in this case, one Ernest Adam Buss. This dissertation examines the nature of light and gives evidence of the considerable importance of physical optics in university curricula.
BP_Description_2: Detailed, technical dissertation from the University of Rinteln. In five parts: the first three on sources of light, their light, and colors; the fourth on the rainbow; the fifth on so-called permanent colors. The nature of light, its rectilinear propagation, and the geometry of reflection and refraction are stated in a series of propositions; all with detailed proofs or demonstrations. The sun, stars, and flame sources are discussed. A Cartesian explanation of the rainbow is given, as well as how the color of objects is produced.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Form and Freedom: Dissertation writing in the 17th century<i>|Fredriksson, A.|From: Digitala Vetenskapliga Arkivet|http://uu.diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf.

Publ. Ad diem Martii hora locoue consuetis Publicae ventilationis subjiciet Ernestus Adamus Bussius, Holthusa-Mindanus.

Considered at the place, hour and day of March customary for Public Discussion by Ernest Adam Buss of Minden.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicst, mathematician, ardent Cartesian and teacher at the Hess-Schaumburg Academy in Rinteln, Germany.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the work of 1646 with additions. Ten books on the natural magic of Light and Shadow. Two books deal with light, color, and vision in Aristotelian terms, seven books deal with horology, and one book deals with the metaphysics of light and light-related phenomena including optical illusions, mirrors, lenses, and the camera obscura. In this edition, this last book included a description of the magic lantern along with a new but incorrect figure.
BP_Description_1: Athanasius Kircher was visited in Rome by Marin Mersenne in 1644 as Kircher, who by then was known throughout Europe, was finishing the <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i>. It and other topics engaged both scholars, particularly as this was Kercher's first book on natural philosophy. Since 1630 he had produced seven books, each becoming evermore elaborate, encyclopedic, and costly. <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> appeared in 1646 and was the most elaborate thus far. it contained nearly 1000 pages of facts, imaginings, devices, and topics--however distantly related--regarding light and shadow, augmented with 36 plates of figures, 41 pages of tables, and about 480 in-text drawings. Dazzled, perhaps by the book's elaborateness, it had been approved by two Jesuit censors, both literary men, neither with the understanding necessary to review the contents. And so, the book went to press unfiltered by anyone with a knowledge of optics. But even by mid 18th century standards, 'optics' would not have been considered the principal topic of Kircher's book. As the title makes clear, it is about Light and Shadow, not optics; Perspectiva, Alhazen, Witelo, and Euclid are given only glancing mention. At the end of his preface to the reader, Kircher states he did not want to write a theoretical work and apologizes to his mathematical colleagues for neglecting the material's rigor, especially geometric optics. Kircher is more interested in phenomena and applications.||The disparate, elaborate, compilational nature of <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> is an expression of a view of knowledge and the world. Kircher believed all human knowledge was linked, is derived from divine wisdom, could be manifested by natural or artificial magic (what today would be called technology), and, following the medieval philosopher Ramon Llull, could be comprehended if the correct organizing framework could be found. The book is not so much structured by its content as it is bound together by--and freighted with--symbolism, Christian Kabbalah, metaphysics, and references to and use of ancient languages. The last is an aspect of Kircher's belief in a single ancient language, his deep interest in philology, and responsible for the strange, Greek-based neologisms in many of the book's section titles.||The elaborate nature of the book made it expensive and limited its audience. Its reception by European scholars was generally negative, expecting as they were a book on optics. It did not help that the book contained what purported to be a geometric method for squaring the circle; natural philosophers and mathematicians across Europe hooted their derision. However strange and unfiltered its content, the book presents the baroque culture of esotericism, natural magic, and the desire to overlay the natural world with an elaborate interconnected structure that spanned history, culture, and geography. Kircher's influence in this regard would be most apparent in his student Gaspar Schott's <i>Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis<i> of 1657. Editions of <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> appeared in 1646 and 1671.
BP_Description_2: <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbr√¶<i> contains ten books on subjects related--however tenuously--to Light and Shadow and a final section on optical cryptography and metaphysical epilogue. The meaning of section or book titles are given, rather than direct or literal translation of section titles, since most consist of words Kircher invented.  Book 1: The Nature of Light and Shadow.  Book 2: On Radiation Propagation. Book 3: Curious Gnomics. Book 4: Various Gnomic Horologies. Book 5: Anamorphosis Gnomics. Book 6: Gnomic Shapes for Astrolabes. Book 7: Gnomics by Reflection. Book 8: Gnomics by Refraction. Book 9: Cosmographical Gnomics. Book 10: The Natural Magic of Light and Shadow. Book 1 has three parts. It begins with light sources, including the sun, moon, stars, fire, animal and vegetable light, and light from minerals. This is followed by a 'Scholastic Disquisition' on the nature and effects of light, much of which was lifted from Fortunio Liceti's <i>De Luminis Natura<i> of 1640. The second part of Book 1 considers shadow and its applications including the production of shadow, degrees of shadow, and gnomic shadows. Shadow for Kircher is not the lack of light, but an entity per se. The third part of Book 1 considers colors. This includes various color source and phenomena including atmospheric, sea, refractive, mineral, and animal color. It is here that Kircher presents his color diagram, derived from Francois d' Aguil√≥n's <i>Opticorum Libri Sex<i> of 1613 and adhering to the Scholastic teaching that color arises from a blending of white and black. Book 2 has two parts. It begins with a general consideration of the propagation of 'radiations' from objects; the prototype is light as propagated visible species rendering objects visible when their species are received by the eye. This notion is applied to sound and odor as well. The second part of Book 2 deals with the eye and vision. Though modern ocular anatomy is briefly described, no details are given; most of the material is devoted to projections and scenography. Book 10 is a survey of applications, phenomena, and devices and has three parts. The first part shows the use of reflection and refraction in sundials of various forms. The second part considers projections of various forms and refraction. The camera obscura is described but not explained and it is here that lenses are discussed and Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena<i> of 1604 is quoted, leading to a discussion of the telescope. In this edition a section on the magic lantern was added to this second part, though the description is somewhat confused. The third part is a general consideration of catoptrics. This includes the nature and properties of plane, spherical, parabolic, and hyperbolic mirrors. Burning mirrors and applications for 'optical wonders' using plane, multiple, and segmented mirrors are presented.||The material in Books 1, 2, and 10 is entirely descriptive; phenomena or apparatus are simply presented, there is rarely any explanation of cause or operation. Mathematics is very rarely used, and then never more than elementary geometry.
BP_Reference(s): L' 'Ars Magan Lucis et Umbrae' di Athanasius Kircher|Corradion, S. SJ|<i>Archivum Historicum Societatius Jesu<i>, Vol 62, 1993, pp 249-280.||L‚ÄôArs Magna Lucis et Umbrae d'Athanase Kircher. N√©oplatonisme, herm√©tisme et 'nouvelle philosophie'|Chevalley, C.|<i>Baroque<i>, Vol 12, 1987, pp 95-109|http://journals.openedition.org/baroque/584||<i>A Study of the Life and Works of Athanasius Kircher, 'Germanus Incredibilis'<i>|Fletcher, J.E.|Brill, Leiden, 2011, 607 p.||<i>Gnomonica Kircheriana: Ouvero l'estensione del Cielo negli orologi Solari<i>|Severino, N.|Roccasecca, Italy, 1995.||Kircher and the Lanterna Magica ‚Äî A Reexamination|Gosser, H.M.|<i>SMPTE Journal<i>, Vol 90 , No 10 , 1981, pp 972-978.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The most exhaustive treatise on lens making in the 17th century. Comprehensive regarding the telescope, it includes microscopes, opera glasses, optical pantographs, and binocular instruments, all delt with from first-hand experience.
BP_Description_1: The origins of Ch√©rubin d‚ÄôOrl√©ans‚Äôs <i>La Dioptrique Oculaire<i> are clear from his letter to the reader.  He was captivated by Galileo's <i>Sidereus Nuncius<i>, was inspired by the possibilities of optical instruments, and came to desire the approbation of the learned. He knew his own mathematical abilities and sought to study dioptrics. Later, he began his optical work, wanting to reduce theory of dioptrics to practice. That is, he would design and make optical instruments admired by natural philosophers. This desire is clear from the subtitle of the work: The Theory, The Practice, and The Mechanics of Oculars. Theory is used to envision instruments, their properties, and their function. Practice is used to design and make the dioptric parts of instruments. And Mechanics guides their actual construction.||Ch√©rubin worked on the dioptrics manuscript from 1665 to 1668 and which, presumably, Capuchin modesty kept him from publishing. But it was read by the bishop of Tulles, Louis de Rechignevoisin de Guron, who circulated it and received positive responses. Ch√©rubin was then sent to Paris to meet Guron's friends and have the work published. There, Ch√©rubin met Colbert, to whom he dedicated the work. The frontispiece half-title was drawn by Jean le Pautre and engraved by Gerard Edelinck.||In the 'Order and Plan of the Author', Ch√©rubin makes clear that his theory and principles come from his own experiments and those of Kepler, whom he 'found more to conform with his own findings'. Ch√©rubin follows Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611 very closely and draws from it extensively. Additionally, only his own experimentation and practice is reported; nothing is presented that he himself has not performed, examined, constructed, or practiced. This grounding in practice is an aspect of <i>La Dioptrique Oculaire<i> that made it so important to optical instrumentation in the late 17th century. Another important aspect was Ch√©rubin's insistence on the coupling of vision and optics; the best instruments would not result from considerations of light and lenses that excluded vison, and central to this was Ch√©rubin's commitment to idea of the superiority of binocular vision. Several binocular instruments are described.||Though microscopes are considered, <i>La Dioptrique Oculaire<i> is essentially a complete manual on telescope making. It is remarkable for its coverage: principles of telescope operation; lens design; principles for lenses spacing; lens grinding, figuring, and polishing; equipment necessary for lens working; proper lens apertures for best viewing; mechanical details of tubes, mountings, aiming, and instrument use; and a cataloguing of observations made with his instruments including selenography, sun spots, planetary observations, and comets. Ch√©rubin's manual was the most detailed, exhaustive treatment of lens making in the 17th century and was referenced and cited for more than 50 years. One of his lens lathes was taken up and perfected by the great Italian lens maker Giuseppe Campani. Ch√©rubin is cited in Robert Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_2: <i>La Dioptrique Oculaire<i> is in three parts. Part 1, on the eye and vision, is in 5 sections, 52 pages. Section 1: The eye and vision in general. Sections 2 and 3: Direct Vision. Sections 4 and 5: Refracted Vision. Part 2, on refraction and the telescope, is in 12 sections, 110 pages. Sections 1 and 2: Refraction at spherical surfaces. Section 3: Convex lenses for telescopes of the first type. Section 4: Concave lenses and telescopes of the first type. Section 5: Convex and concave lenses and telescopes of the first type. Section 6: Convex lenses and telescopes of the second type. Section 7: Multiple lenses for telescopes of the second type. Section 8: Magnification of small objects. Section  9: Microscopes. Section 10: Catadioptric telescopes using reflection and refraction. Section 11: Binocular telescopes. Section 12: Lens design and specification. Part 3-Practice, on the construction and use of telescopes and microscopes, is in 12 Sections, 173 pages. Part 3-Mechanics, on lens making, equipment, and mechanics, is in 6 sections, 75 pages. Section 1: Lens forming, grinding, and polishing by hand. Section 2: Lens forming, grinding, and polishing with a 'guided' hand. Section 3: Lens forming, grinding, and polishing by simple machines. Section 4: Lenses by machines guided by hand. Section 5: Making accurate concave lenses. Section 6: A universal method for spherical surfaces.||Part 1 presents the optical properties of the main parts of the eye and their function, following Kepler. This is supplemented with material from Christopher Scheiner‚Äôs <i>Oculus<i> of 1619 and <i>Rosa Ursina<i> of 1632.||Part 2 presents the theory of telescopes. Lens analysis is based on Kepler's approximate law of refraction. Foci for convex, concave, biconvex, biconcave, and meniscus lenses are given, and Kepler's result for the interaction of two convex lenses is extended and used to consider Keplerian telescopes with up to 5 lenses. Ch√©rubin labels Galilean and Keplerian telescopes the first and second type, respectively. Part 2 also presents the analysis of multiple lens microscopes. In general, Part 2 builds on and extends the theory of lenses in Kepler's Dioptrice, with analysis limited to paraxial rays.||The first section of Part 3 presents the use of optical instruments and reports the observations Ch√©rubin made with them, including sun spot projection and lunar mapping.||The second section of Part 3 presents lens making. Cherubin gives (and used) three ways of making lenses: with a 'free and flowing hand' using only handcraft, with a 'constrained but flowing hand' using a mechanical tool, and with 'a machine that guides the hand.' such as with a lathe. The level of elaboration and detail in this Part is remarkable, covering every aspect of glass preparation, grinding, polishing materials and methods, mould use, and elaborate drawings and instructions for lathes and other tools.||The material clearly reflects Ch√©rubin's experience in lens making. He does not believe that a good lens can be made by machine alone--some handcraft is always required--and scoffs at the 'speculative mechanizers' struggling to make lenses of hyperbolic figure, citing the difficulty in just working with spherical surfaces.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Descartes and the hyperbolic quest: Lens making machines and their significance in the seventeenth century<i>|Burnett, D.G.|American Philosophical Society, Philadelphia, 2005, pp 107‚Äì121.||Kepler's legacy: Telescopes and geometrical optics, 1611-1669|Malet, A.|In: <i>The Origins of the Telescope<i>, KNAW Press, Amsterdam, 2010, pp 281-300.||<i>Scientific Instruments of the 17th & 18th Centuries and their Makers<i>|Daumas, M.|Holbrook, M., translator|Portman, London, 1989.||<i>Prism and Lens Making<i>|Tyman, F.|Adam Hilger, London, 1942, pp. 1-10.||Lens Making for Scientific Instrumentation in the Seventeenth Century|Bedini, S.A.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 5, No 5, 1966, pp 687-694.||<i>The Quest for Perfect Vision: Ch√©rubin d‚ÄôOrl√©ans‚Äôs Optical Instruments and the Development of Theories of Binocular Perception in Late Seventeenth-Century France<i>|Gallay, A.|Mphil Dissertation, University of Cambridge, 2013, 34 p.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Complete textbook of Cartesian-based natural philosophy. Fully empirical, with numerous experiments and observations reported to test theory and hypothesis. 115 pages are devoted to Cartesian optics and the theory of vision.
BP_Description_1: Jacques Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> arose from his weekly 'Conferences' on natural philosophy that he began giving in 1659. Though an enthusiastic and committed Cartesian, Rohault was also a curious, skilled, and keen experimenter. The results were experiments, lectures, and notes that supported virtually every aspect of Cartesian physics with demonstrations and explanations. Copies of these notes circulated, being drafts of parts of what would become the <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>. Importantly and unlike other Cartesian textbooks of the era, Rohault's does not present any of Descartes' metaphysics and epistemology, nor was the book ever planned as part of wider course in Cartesian philosophy. Rather, it was written as a stand-alone text on Cartesian physics with extensive experimental underpinning, often making small of speculative philosophy and praising practice, experiment, and craft. In this regard, Rohault's experiments and demonstrations often overshadow, if not supplant, the metaphoric reasonings of Descartes. This is particularly the case in maters dealing with motion and with optics.||Rohault's reasons for writing his <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> are clear from his long preface. He sets out to overcome five impediments to physics' progress: ancient authority, metaphysics, extremes of experiment and reason, rejection of mathematics, and Scholastic distortion of Aristotle. His aim is not to write an encyclopedia but a carefully ordered textbook with experimentation at its core.||Rohault was the foremost Cartesian philosopher of this time. His pedagogical demonstrations, use of instruments, and numerous experiments informed his writing. This, and his reputation, had his text widely accepted and used, helping to cement Cartesian success for 50 years. It was used across Europe, being the physics textbook in use at the Universities of Utrecht, Frankfurt, Groningen, Louvain, Leyden, Cambridge, and Oxford, for example. It was described in the Journal des S√ßavans of June 22, 1671 as 'nothing other than a collection of reasoned experiments, methodically ordered' and soon became the foremost physics textbook in Europe. Twenty-five years later, Samuel Clarke's Latin translation of the <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>, accompanied by his notes, would become the Trojan Horse carrying Newtonian physics into the heart of Cartesianism. Extensively influential, there were editions of the French text in 1671, 1672, 1675, 1676, 1682, 1683, 1692, 1705, 1708, 1723, and 1730; translation into Latin appearing in 1674, 1682, 1697, 1700, 1702, 1708, 1710, 1713, 1718, and 1739; and into English appearing in 1723, 1728, 1735.
BP_Description_2: Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> is in four parts. Part 1 is in 35 chapters and covers principles of physics, nature of matter, motion and its analysis, forms of matter, heat and cold, the senses of taste, smell, and hearing, and finally the eye, optics, and vision. The Cartesian principles of extension, divisibility, motion, and rest are used to deduce general laws of statics, dynamics, and--via ballistic conceptions  of reflection and refraction--optics. Part 2 is in 29 chapters and covers cosmography, astronomy, selenography, the planets and their movements, the fixed stars, and finally the competing theories of the sun and planets. Rohault plumps for the Copernican as the most rational. Part 3 is in 17 chapters and covers geology in general, including the Earth and things that are part of it, such as the atmosphere, the seas, metals and minerals, fountains, winds, fogs and clouds, rain and hail, snow and frosts, lighting, and finally the rainbow. Part 4 is in 26 chapters and covers anatomy, muscles and movement, blood and circulation, digestion and breathing, and finally maladies and disease.||The optics material covers 115 pages and though patterned closely after Descartes' essay <i>La Dioptrique<i>, it is fully empirical with experiments, demonstrations, and observations reported to test theory and hypothesis. The topics include: the nature of light, color, transparency and opacity. Direct, reflected, and refracted light are demonstrated as well as the simpler forms of image formation by mirrors and lenses. Descartes theory of vision is presented in full. All the optical topics are treated in an elementary but thorough manner. Thus, for example, the focusing properties of spherical convex lenses are demonstrated, but nothing is said of spherical aberration.||Experiment receives a double role: on the one hand, it is shown how it discriminates between conjectures pointing to the ones that are empirically confirmed; on the other hand, it is a powerful pedagogical tool that can convince the reader of explanations given and laws stated.
BP_Reference(s): Rohault's Cartesian Physics|Dobre, M.|In: <i>Cartesian Empiricisms<i>, Springer, 2013, pp 203-226.||Rohault's Traite de Physique and its Newtonian Reception|Dobre, M.|In: <i>Proceedings of the 4th International Conference of the ESHS<i>, 2010, pp 389-394.||The experimental physics of Jacques Rohault|Spink A.|<i>British Journal for the History of Philosophy<i>, Vol 26, No 5, 2017, pp 850-870.||The Study of Early Scientific Textbooks|Sarton, G.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 38, No 3/4, 1948, pp 137-148.||Motion and God in XVIIth Century Cartesian manuals: Rohault, R√©gis and Gadroys|Milani, N.E.|<i>Noctua<i> Vol 2, Nos.1-2, 2015, pp 481-516.

BP_Short or Common Title: New Theory about Light and Colors
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Newton's letter describing his new theory of light and color, based on his interpretation of results from experiments he had begun in 1666, claiming that white light was a heterogeneous mixture of all colors.
BP_Description_1: Newton's famed paper on his theory of light and colors reports results from experiments which he had begun in 1666 and pursued with some long interruptions until I671. A careful consideration of the shape of the well-known display of colors refracted from a prism led Newton to conclude that white light was heterogeneous, a compound of lights of different colors, with differing refragibility.||Johannes Marcus Marci de Cronland in his <i>Thaumantias<i> of 1648 had described prismatic colors and observed that once isolated, a color was not further dispersed by refraction and that 'diverse species of colors are the products of refraction.' But he attributed dispersion to varying angles of incidence and did not develop a general theory. For Newton, the separation into a spectrum was the result of inherently different properties of colored light and not an artifact of the prism, the light source, or any aspect of his experiment. The <i>experimentum crucis<i> that Newton described--and which proved difficult to duplicate carefully--was offered as proof of the inherent, differing but unchanging refractive property of colors.||Newton's idea ran counter to most previous conceptions of light. That the prism produced colors from white light was doubted by no one; that what it was doing was separating its inherently different colored components was doubted by virtually everyone. The appearance of Newton's letter provoked an intellectual thrust-and-parry that appeared in the Philosophical Transactions in multiple letters, the last which appeared in Vol XI, No 128, September 1676. Those involved were Robert Hooke, James Gregory, Robert Moray, Ignace-Gaston Pardies, Christiaan Huygens, Franciscus Linus, John Gascoines, and finally Anthony Lucas. From notes and letters, it is now known that Newton had begun to draft a large work on optics at this time, but the difficulties provoked by the publication of his theory of light and colors began a series of starts and stops, long delays, and abandonings that would last 30 years.
BP_Description_2: Newton begins his letter with a description of the production of a prismatic spectrum. Apparently, Newton was the first to use 'spectrum', the Latin for appearance, apparition. He describes the small hole, 1/4 inch diameter, in the window shutter of a darkened room, casting a narrow beam of sunlight onto a prism which cast the spectrum onto a wall 22 feet away. The spectrum was 2-5/8 inches wide and 13-1/4 inches long. The prism was rotated so that angle of incidence of sunbeam onto the prism face was equal to the angle of exitance of the green rays from the opposite prism face; that is, minimum deviation. The spectrum was incident nearly perpendicularly onto the distant wall. In the paper, Newton names five colors: red, yellow, green, blue, and violet. He would later add orange and indigo.||Newton recounts his surprise at the elongation of the spectrum and reports his efforts to find the cause. He finally supposes that the sunbeam is composed of rays with different refrangibility and are thus separated into a spectrum. That is, white light is heterogenous. He tested his supposition with an 'experimentum crucis.' He placed a card with a hole in it behind the prism. The prism could be rotated to move the spectrum over the hole, and so the hole could be made to transmit various colors of light. Twelve feet distant from this hole was placed another card with another hole, behind which was another prism. Light of different colors could thus be made to fall on the second prism. From this he determined that for any one color, the amount of refraction was the same for both prisms. Changing the color involved changed the refraction, but it was always the same for both prisms. Newton concluded: 'And so the true cause of the length of that Image (of the spectrum) was detected to be no other, then that Light consists of Rays differently refrangible, which without any respect to a difference in their incidence, were, according to their degrees of refrangibility, transmitted toward diverse parts of the wall.'||Newton then sets out 13 propositions which present his theory of light and color: 1: Rays having different refrangibility exhibit different colors. 2: Color and refrangibility are inherently linked. 3: Color and refrangibility are not altered by reflection or refraction. 4: Color transformation is only by mixing rays. 5: There are two types of colors, original or simple, and compound. 6: Some simple colors and be produced by mixing others. 7: Whiteness is not a property of any ray. 8: Whiteness is the 'confused aggregate of rays.' 9: The prism produces colors because of their different refrangibility. 10: This is the cause of the colors of the rainbow. 11: Various color phenomena (Lignum Nephriticum, gold leaf, colored glass) are also explained this way. 12: Explains Robert Hooke's blue-red color experiment. 13: Objects have color because they reflect only some of the many colored rays incident on them. The letter ends with Newton's description of using a lens to recombine the colors dispersed by a prism and thus (re)producing white light.
BP_Reference(s): Discovery of the Dispersion of Light and of the Nature of Color (1672)|Sarton, G.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 14, No 2, 1930, pp 326-341.||Experimentum Crucis|Lohne, J.A.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 23, No 2, 1968, pp 169-199.||Newton's Prisms and His Experiments on the Spectrum|Mills, A.A.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 36, No 1, 1981, pp 13-36.||'A Less Agreeable Matter': The Disagreeable Case of Newton and Achromatic Refraction|Bechler, Z.|<i>The  British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 8, No 2, 1975, pp 101-126.||Newton Defends His First Publication: The Newton-Lucas Correspondence|Westfall, R.S.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 57, No 3, 1966, pp 299-314.||The Reception of Newton's Optical Work|Shapiro, A.E.|In: The Reception of Isaac Newton in Europe, Pulte, H., Mandelbrote, S., editors, Bloomsbury Academic, 2019, 1004 pp, NB: pp 407-414.

BP_Short or Common Title: An Accompt of a New Catadioptrical Telescope
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Newton's description of his spherical mirror telescope. Prompted by his discovery of chromatic aberration in lenses, he devised his catadioptric telescope.
BP_Description_1: Isaac Newton sent his letter describing his reflecting telescope to Henry Oldenburg <i>before<i> the letter describing his new theory of light and color. Oldenburg decided to print the material in the letters in reverse order, the letter on theory first, followed later by the description of the new telescope. Newton's intention was to present his new telescope as a practical manifestation of and test piece for his theory of light and color and to show its superiority to previous theories. Catoptric telescopes had been described early in the century by Bonaventura Cavalieri and Marin Mersenne, and Newton turned to the idea not as a new invention, but as an alternative to lenses as a light-gathering and magnifying mechanism. But the general reaction to his telescope had little to do with chromatic aberration, it was praised for showing how telescopes could be shortened without sacrificing magnification. The account appearing in the Transactions was written by Oldenburg and emphases the compactness of the instrument, rather than any freedom from chromatic aberration. The engraving that accompanied the account showed two images of 'a crown on the weathercock about 300 feet distant', one representing that produced by Newton's mirrored telescope, the other by 'a common tube of 25 inches long'. The point being that the smaller mirrored telescope performed as well as much large instruments. The image of the telescope in the etching accompanying the article was taken from a drawing in a letter Oldenburg had sent to Christiaan Huygens, made from the instrument at the Royal Society. Newton owned a copy of James Gregory's <i>Optica Promota<i> of 1663, and though perhaps influenced by it and the reflecting telescopes it described, Newton adopted a simpler design.||Newton's telescope made a considerable impression at the Royal Society, and immediately elected him a Fellow. Newton and his telescope rapidly become known in Europe. The same general image of the telescope appeared with its description, along with Huygens' comments, in the Journal de S√ßavans in February 1672. The article emphasized the instruments' compactness. At the time of this article and his initial fame, very few knew that Newton had developed a new theory of light color and thus it was not that that ushered Newton onto the world stage, rather it was his telescope and its description in the Transactions.
BP_Description_2: Oldenburg's description--based on details in the letter from Newton--gives not only the nature of the telescope, but its construction, and performance. The mirror is of 'bell metal' with a significant portion of arsenic to make it hard, less porous, and better able to take a polish. The figure was spherical, since he reasoned that the resulting spherical aberration would be far less than the chromatic aberration of a lens, so an attempt at a parabolic figure was not made. A small flat oval mirror at the axis reflected the image to an eye-piece to the side of the telescope tube. Focusing was accomplished by a screw that move the concave mirror along the axis of the instrument. At Newton's request, the measurements of the instrument are proved, emphasizing its small size. The accompanying engraved figure shows not only the instrument but the path of rays within it. At the end, Oldenburg summarizes two additional letters Newton sent regarding the telescope; one regarding details of the speculum metal, and another regarding an optical sighting mechanism. Lastly, Oldenburg summarizes a letter from Christiaan Huygens, written in response to Oldenburg's request for comments on Newton's new telescope. Huygens with quite complementary, citing the short focal-length that could be achieved, the high magnification, and the potential to gather more light and produce brighter images than was possible with lenses.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Reflecting Telescope Optics: Basic Design Theory and its Historical Development<i>|Wilson, R.N.|Springer, Berlin, 2007, pp 1-20.||Newton‚Äôs Telescope in Print: The Role of Images in the Reception of Newton‚Äôs Instrument|Dupr√©, S.|<i>Perspectives in Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, pp 328-359.||'A Less Agreeable Matter': The Disagreeable Case of Newton and Achromatic Refraction|Bechler, Z.|<i>The British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 8, No 2, 1975, pp 101-126.||An Account of the Royal Society's Newton Telescope|A. Rupert Hall, A., Simpson, A.D.C.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 50, No 1, 1996, pp. 1-11.||Bonaventura Cavalieri, Marin Mersenne, and the Reflecting Telescope|Ariotti, P.E.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 66, No 3, 1975, pp 303-321.||The Reception of Newton's Optical Work|Shapiro, A.E.|In: The Reception of Isaac Newton in Europe, Pulte, H., Mandelbrote, S., editors, Bloomsbury Academic, 2019, 1004 pp, NB: pp 404-407.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A vast, baroque overview of natural philosophy, architecture, music, history, law and politics, and theology. The 20-page section on optics deals narrowly with vision and perception.
BP_Description_1: Weber's Discursus is in the tradition of Johann Heinrich Alsted's Trait√© de PhysiqueEncyclopaedia-Septem Tomis DistinctaTrait√© de Physique of 1630, influenced deeply by the idea of Universal Knowledge of Petrus Ramus and Ramon Llull. The long introduction sets out Weber's framework for Universal Knowledge and defines the general subjects and topics that he treats in the Discursus. An historian, philosopher, and encyclopedist, Weber sought to organize knowledge, set it in a universalist framework, and to show connections. The Introduction gives Weber's framework: 'Hexilogy', the habitual disposition of character, morals, or knowledge; Craft; Principles; Teaching. The material itself is often presented in the form of 'secrets' or 'questions'.||Editions appeared at Salzburg in 1673 and 1690. A German translation appeared at NuÃàrnburg in 1684.
BP_Description_2: Johann Adam Weber's <i>Discursus<i> is a vast, baroque encyclopaedic overview of natural philosophy, architecture, music, history, law and politics, and theology. In the encyclopaedist tradition, the <i>Discursus<i> presents a universalist framework for its organization: The Settled Order; Craft; Principles; Teaching. These are presented as both organizing principles and methods of study. The <i>Discursus<i> groups natural philosophy with Mixed Mathematics under Principles, listing them as: Geometry, Poetics, Rhetoric, Logic, Physics, Metaphysics, Mathematics, Arithmetic, Geometrics, Astronomy, Geography, Optics, Music, Ethics, Economics, Politics, Medicine, Law, and Theology.||Discourse 26 is on optics and considers vision, the viewed, and the visible. This 20 page section on optics deals narrowly with visual perception and, after a few assertions, covers its material in the form of 13 questions about sight and vision, each with answers that invoke authority rather than demonstration or proof. Questions include the spatial extent of vision, impaired vision, vision and the other senses, vision and the state of moral or physical health. Sources from Aristotle to Cardano are cited.
BP_Title: Discursus curiosi & fructuosi ad praecipuas Totius Letteraturae Humanae Scientias Illustradas accommodati. Opus tam Lectu Jucundum, quam Fructo Foecundum; in quo De Macrocosmo & Microsomso, sive Magno et Parvo Mundo, Sub schematae universalis Litteraturae, Non minus accurate, quam succincte differitur.
BP_Title English Translation: A Curious and Fruitful Discourse, Especially on all the Literature Suited for Illustrating of Human Knowledge. A Work as Pleasurably Read as Abundantly Fruitful; in which the Macrocosmos and Microcosmos, or the Large and Small Word, is Presented Briefly but no less Accurately Under a Schema of Universal Literature.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Augustinian Canon, academic, theologian, lawyer, and historian. Taught at the Gymnasium at Altenberg.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris inscription on titlepage 'R.P. Francisci' and 'Ad usum Simplicem' to the same on the verso

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third edition of van Westen's Dutch translation of Leurechon's <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> using the expanded French text of 1669 with most of the same figures.
BP_Description_1: Wynant van Westen, organist and mathematician from Nijmengen, produced a Dutch translation of the <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>. 'Problems' are presented, some of several parts, with solutions constituting a collection of experiments, apparatus demonstrations, recipes, and parlor tricks in cosmology, optics, perspective, mechanics, statics, practical geometry, fortification and gunnery. Designed to entertain and instruct. The source for the arithmetical problems was Claude Bachet's <i>Problems Plaisans et Delectables<i> of 1612. The problems in geometry are in the Renaissance tradition of 'practical geometry'; geometry applied to surveying, mensuration, and fortification. Many of the other problems come from the tradition of secretes and natural magic, such as Girolamo Ruscelli's <i>De' Secretis del Alessio Piemontese<i> in the edition of 1615. Some of the problems in natural philosophy appear to be from works by Giambattista Della Porta, Girolamo Cardano, and Salomon de Caus. Renaissance books on conjuring and prestidigitation were a source for the <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i>.||Dutch editions appeared at Arnhem and Amsterdam in 1636, 1641, 1644, 1662, 1671, and 1673. Westen's translation of 1636 was of the only the first 91 Problems of the French text of 1626. After Westen's death in 1636 and beginning with the 1641 edition, the Dutch translation presents all three parts. The Dutch edition of 1671 omitted the original 1636 dedication of Westen, substituted one by the Amsterdam printer J.T. Loots-Man, and used the French text of 1669.
BP_Description_2: van Westen's Dutch translation of a late edition of Leurechon's <i>R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques<i> and like other late editions has a preface to the reader from the author which names some of his sources and the general nature of what he tried to accomplish. This is followed by Part I containing 91 'Problems' on various subjects, including: Arithmetic, Geometry, Optics and Perspective, Music, Cosmographical Matters. The camera obscura, burning mirrors and lenses, plane and curved mirrors, clear and colored looking-glasses, and the rainbow are presented in a rudimentary way. In this and other early editions, the optical material is limited to display and demonstration, with little or no explanation of the phenomena itself. Part II contains 45 Problems on similar subjects, these first appeared in the edition of 128. Part III is the briefest, containing 17 problems in fireworks and artillery. There are a few problems in Part II devoted to optics and projection that have a very different character than the original problems of Part I--more detailed and  explanatory, rather than simply reporting. The problems in Part I and their examinations, and the problems in Part II, never involve mathematics above the simplest geometry, thus maintaining their popular science character.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ R√©cr√©ations Math√©matiques (1624) A Study on its Authorship, Sources and Influence|Heefer, A.|<i>Gibeci√®re<i>, Vol. 1, No 2, 2006, pp. 79-167.
BP_Title: Mathematische Vermaecklyckheden
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch¬†organist and mathematicus to the city of Nijmegen
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1673 Westen - Mathematische Vermaecklyckheden - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Elaborate development of the theory of optical images. Includes preliminaries on the nature of light and color and a full mathematical treatment of images formed by mirrors and lenses.
BP_Description_1: Isaac Barrow's optics work has its origin in his growing interest in natural philosophy while studying at Cambridge and was expressed in his thesis on the insufficiency of Descartes' geometrical optics--that is, the shortcomings of the mechanical basis for optics. Continental Cartesianism had evolved elaborate mechanical models for light's rectilinear propagation, reflection, refraction, and double refraction; all deduced from a mechanical model of light's nature. Though Barrow considered it necessary to present the briefest summaries of these theories in his lectures, he considered them all hypothetical and inconsequential, since, regarding light's nature, 'proofs cannot be given.' Thus, aside from some material in the first two <i>lectiones<i>, Barrow does not deal with the nature of light. His lectures deal narrowly but completely with optical images, their formation, their size, their placement.||The optical lectures were developed between 1664 and 1669, fulfilling the requirement of the Lucasian Chair of Mathematics, to which Barrow had been appointed in 1663. In 1669 Barrow resigned the Lucasian Chair in favor of Isaac Newton and would have left the lectures unpublished, but John Collins, fellow mathematician, urged him to publish, to which he finally agreed. The work of seeing a manuscript through the press was left to Collins and Isaac Newton. In was in this way that Newton edited and corrected Barrow's lectures for print. The <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> presented a modern theory of images in spherical mirrors and lenses, the location of focal points including those for thick lenses, and a derivation of the radius of the rainbow.||The audience for Barrow's Lectures was small--the mathematics presented was daunting for all but the very learned. Within its small audience, the Lectures were well received. They formed the most advanced treatise on geometrical optics then available and would form the basis and beginning point for Newton's own, later Optical Lectures. References to Barrow's <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> were later made and some of its developments used by Christiaan Huygens, Jakob Bernoulli, David Gregory, Jean-√âtienne Montucla, and Robert Smith.||Barrow's <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> appeared at London in 1669, and again together with the <i>Lectiones Geometricae<i> in 1674, edited by Whewell in 1860, and a translation into English appeared in 1987.
BP_Description_2: Barrow's elaborate development of the the theory of optical images is presented in 18 Lectures.  1: Nature and propagation of light. 2: Laws of reflection and refraction. 3: Application of the laws. 4 & 5: Refraction at a plane surfaces. 6 & 7: Reflection at spherical surfaces. 8 & 9: Reflection at convex spherical surfaces. 10: Reflection at concave spherical surfaces. 11 , 12, & 13: Refraction at spherical surfaces. 14: Thick lenses. 15: Images of extended objects. 16: Images of line objects. 17: Curvature of images of lines. 18: Images of line objects by refraction at spherical surfaces.||In lectures 1-3 Barrow presents a hybrid theory of light that combines corpuscular emission with mediumistic pulses, giving him six hypotheses or axioms on which he based his geometric optics: linear propagation, emission from every point on a luminous surface, normal incidence is a special case for reflection and refraction, reflected and refracted rays are coplanar with the incident ray and surface normal, equal angle law of reflection, and sine law of refraction. Barrow invokes 'ray fronts' of Thomas Hobbes, as used by Emanuel Maignan, to derive the laws of reflection and refraction. The heart of the material is in lectures 4-13. He first presents what came to be known as 'Barrow's Principal for Image Location': an image is located at that place from which rays entering the eye appear to diverge. He then establishes his new and fundamental analysis tool: the oblique pencil of rays. With these tools, and often elaborate geometrical analysis, Barrow establishes methods for determining image locations produced by mirrors and refactors with the eye both on and off the optical axis. This allows him to determine the image point after any collection of reflections and refractions at plane and spherical surfaces. All this, in turn, is applied to lenses and focal points and image locations for single or multiple thin and thick lenses. The same method is used in a derivation of the primary rainbow radius and an elegant solution to Alhazen's Problem.||The analysis throughout is detailed, elaborately geometrical, and tediously complete.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Optical Lectures and the Foundations of the Theory of Optical Imagery|Shapiro, A.E.|In: <i>Before Newton: the Life and Times of Isaac Barrow<i>, Feingold M., editor|Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1990, pp 105-178.||ùëª <i>Isaac Barrow's Optical Lectures<i>|Fay, H.C. translator, Bennet, A.G., editor|The Worshipful Company of Spectacle Makers, London, 1987, 243 pp.||The Works of Isaac Barrow|Hill, A.|Riker, New York, 1845, Vol 1, 628 pp, NB: xxxix-xli.
BP_Title: Archimedis Opera: Apollonii Pergaei Conicorum Libri IIII. Theodosii sphaerica: Methodo Nova Illustrata, & Succincte Demonstrata. Accedunt eiusdem lections opticae & Geometricae.
BP_Title English Translation: The Works of Archimedes: The Four Books of Conics of Apollonius of Perga, The Spherics of Theodosius. Illustrated and Succinctly Demonstrated by a New Method. By Isaac Barrow, ex Lucasian Professor at Cambridge and Member of the Royal Society. Optical and Geometric Lectures  of the same (author) are added.
BP_Biographical Statement: English cleric, thologian, mathematician. Teacher of Isaac Newton, first to occupy the Lucasian Chair of Mathematics at Cambridge.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A complete course of Mixed Mathematics expressly meant for teaching, becoming a popular, widely-used textbook.
BP_Description_1: The origin of Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> was his long experience in teaching Mixed Mathematics, from which he had acquired not only an understanding of the audience for such material but also skill in its presentation. In his Preface, Dechales gives the reason for writing the Cursus: He wanted to produce a work for young students that would be used for self-study, that did not presume a previous knowledge of mathematics, and from which they could learn without the need for a teacher or guide. Dechales' purpose informs the content, style, and order of the work. Most of what he considered necessary in mathematics is presented in the first 400 pages of Tome I. In the rest of the work, geometry and the laws of proportions are used most often, along with a little trigonometry. The presentations are clear, sufficiently detailed, and often accompanied by figures which, though relatively simple wood-cuts, are important to the material. No derivations are given, only statements of results or facts, and though advancing no novelties of his own, Deschales exercises considerable discernment, presenting what he held to be the best of the then-current theories and formulations of the topics covered. He presents (and defends), for example, Galileo‚Äôs theory of motion, but generally rejects Cartesianism.||That the work was entirely self-contained and gave presentations of great clarity helped make it popular and widely used. It was, for example, still used as a textbook at the University of Upsala early in the 18th century.||Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> was reviewed--in the form of a summary--in the Transactions of the Royal Society in Vol 9, No 110, Jan 1675, pp 229-233. Editions appeared 1674 and posthumously, slightly expanded to 4 volumes, in 1690.
BP_Description_2: A complete course of Mixed Mathematics expressly meant for self-study and as an aid to teaching. It covers practical geometry, arithmetic, plane and spherical trigonometry, mechanics, statics, geography, magnetism, military architecture, hydrostatics and fountains, optics, music, pyrotechnics, astrolabes, dialling, astronomy, calendars, algebra, method of indivisibles, and conic sections.||Optics takes up 385 pages of volume 2, presenting Tracts 18-21 covering Optics, Perspective, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, and lastly a Mechanical Digression. The Optics tract is in three books: Suppositions and Vision; Binocular vision; Propagation of Light. The Perspective tract is in six books: Fundamentals; Iconographic projection; Scenographics; Aspects of linear perspective. The Catoptrics tract is in four books: Plane mirrors; Convex mirrors; Concave mirrors; Cylindrical mirrors. The Dioptrics tract is in two books: Refraction and individual lenses; Combined lenses. The Mechanical Digression covers image locations, refracted colors, and aspects of meteorological phenomena.||The material includes: The eye's structure and function, monocular and binocular vision; the nature, propagation, reflection, and refraction of light; plain and curved mirrors and the images they produce, lenses and multiple lenses and the magnified images they produce; the operation of microscopes and telescopes. Dechales deals only briefly with physical optics, giving reasons for reflection and refraction, and most often in very short sections titled 'Digressio Physica.'  Most of the material is geometric optics and the fundamental quantity is the luminous ray. Dechales gives a competent overview of geometrical optics and images but never presents anything as densely mathematical as Barrow's Optical Lectures. However circumscribed by the intended purpose and audience, Dechales' presentations are remarkably clear, and along the way he introduces the term 'virtual image' as companion to 'real image' and so clarifies the physical meaning of image, uses pencils of rays to qualitatively analyze the position and size of images in lensed optical systems, and accurately describes the operation of the magic lantern.||Though dependent on many sources for his material, Dechales rarely cites them. Dechales' optical material includes some that comes from uncited works by Christoph Scheiner, Bonaventura Cavalieri, Gilles Personne de Roberval, James Gregory, and Francesco Eschinardi.
BP_Reference(s): Images: Real and Virtual, Projected and Perceived, from Kepler to Dechales|Shapiro, A.E.|In: <i>Inside the Camera Obscura ‚Äì Optics and Art under the Spell of the Projected Image<i>|Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, preprint 333, 2007, pp 75-95.||<i>A Philosophical and Mathematical Dictiionary<i>|Hutton, C.|London, 1815, Vol I, pp 395-396.
BP_Title: R.P. Claudii Francisci Milliet Dechales Camberiensis e Societate Jesu. Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus.  Tomus Primus Complectens euclidis Libros Octo, Arithemticam, Theodosii Sphaerica, Trignometriam, Geometriam practicam, Mechanicam, Staticam, Geographiam universalem, Tractatum de Magnete, Achitecturam Civilim, & Artem tignariam. Nunc Primum in Lucem Prodit. Tomus Secundus Complectens Tractatum de Sectione Lapidum, Architecturam militarem, Hydrostaticam, tractaum de fontibus & Fluviis, tractatum de machinis Hydraulicis, Navigationem, Opticam, Perspectivam, Catoptricam, & Dioptricam. Nunc Primum in Lucem Prodit. Tomus Tertius Complectens Musicam, Phyrotechnicam, Astrolabia, Gnomicam, Astronomiam, Kalendarium, Astrologiam, Algebram, Indivisibilium methodum, aliasque. Nunc Primum in Lucem Prodit.

First Tome Encompassing Eight Book of Euclid, Arithmetic, the Sphericas of Theodosius, Trigonometry, Practical Geometry, Mechanics, Statics, Universal Geography, A Treatise on Magnetism, Civil Architecture, and The Art of Beams. Second Tome Encompassing a Tract on the Cutting of Rocks, Military Architecture, Hydrostatics, A Tract on Springs and Rivers, A Tract on Hydraulic Machines, Navagation, Optics, Perspective, Catoptrics, and Dioptrics. Now First Brought to Light. Third Tome Encompassing Music, Fireworks, Astrolabs, Sundials, Astronomy, Calendars, Astrology, Algegra, the Method of Indivisibles, and other things. Now Frist Brought to Light.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, teacher, author. A thorough compiler and talented pedagogue, rather than an innovator.
BP_Provenance: Bookplates of Coward College, New College London, and armorial bookplate with 'nil conscire sibi'
