BP_Short or Common Title: De la Recherche de la Verit√©
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A philosophical work describing human errors that affect the pursuit of truth: error of the senses, the imagination, and the mind. Book One is devoted to the senses, including vision and optics.
BP_Description_1: Nicholas Malebranche sets out the general plan for his work at the start of Book one, listing the principal topics: errors of the senses, of the imagination, of pure understanding, of the inclinations, and of the passions, ending with his 'general method for conducting the search after truth.' At the time when he first wrote the work, Malebranche was a thorough Cartesian, particularly regarding the senses. Malebranche's conception of vision and the eye is that of the Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> of 1637, and light was percussively transmitted pressure or 'tendency to motion' in the plenum. Though Malebranche's interest in optics did not extend beyond an elementary consideration of the nature of light, his ideas on that subject would later be affected by his reading of Huygens, Newton, and Romer's discovery of the finite speed of light. These changes would appear in the edition of 1700 and in their final form in that of 1712.||The first three books of <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>, appeared at Paris in 1674. The last three appeared in 1675. Further editions appeared in 1677, 1678, 1681, 1683, 1688, 1700, 1712, 1721, 1735, 1749, 1762, 1772, 1829, and in the Oeuvres of 1842. A Latin translation appeared in 1690 and 1753, English translations in 1694 and 1700, an Italian translation in 1767, and a German translation in 1776.
BP_Description_2: <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i> is fundamentally a philosophical work that sets out a general method for the search after Truth. For Malebranche, such a method means avoiding the errors that can and do arise and so these errors and their sources must be explicated first before the method can be developed. These ideas establish the organization of the work. Book 1: The world is apprehended through the senses, and it is here that the nature and potential problems with visual perception are described. Books 2-5 describes the subsequent errors that can be introduced by the imagination, by the logic and reasoning of pure understanding, by the mind's inclinations and impulses, and by the passions. Book 6 presents the general method for the search after truth.||The Cartesian doctrine of vision is presented in Book 1 and the concept of light as percussively transmitted 'tendency to motion' in the plenum filled with aetherial matter is briefly discussed in Book 6.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ ùëª <i>The Search after Truth¬†and¬†Elucidations<i>|Lennon, T.M. and  Olscamp, P.J.|Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1997, 775 p.||L'Optique de Malebranche|Duhem, P.|<i>Revue de Metaphysique et de Morale<i>|Vol 23, 1916, pp 37-91.
BP_Title: De la Recherche de la Verit√©.  Ou l'on traitte de la nature de l'esprit de l'homme, & de l'usage qu'il en doit faire pour eviter l'erreur dans les Sciences.
BP_Title English Translation: On the Search for Truth. Or, One Treatise on the Nature of the Mind of Man, and the Right Exercise he Must Make (of it) to Avoid Error in the Sciences.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Oratorian, philosopher, theologian, Cartesian. Theoritician in natural philosophy, writing on mathematics, optics and mechanics.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris inscription on title page
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1674 Malebranche - De la Recherche de la Verit√© - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A description of the uses of the telescope in surveying. First description of distance measurement using a telescope as a range-finder.
BP_Description_1: Geminiano Montanari brought his experience and skill at lens grinding and figuring to the construction of the level and range-finder described in his <i>La livella Diottrica<i>. At 20 pages, it was tittle more than a pamphlet, but described the first accurate method and optical instrument for distance determination.||Editions appeared at Bologna in 1674 and at Venice in 1680.
BP_Description_2: Montanari gives a description of the 'dioptric level,' an instrument that allowed extremely accurate leveling, in part because the spirit level was fitted onto a telescope. The telescope was also equipped with a distance-measuring, reticle made from hairs arranged on the focal plane of the eyepiece. The hairs, arranged horizontally, were equally spaced and so a distant rod could be sighted, it's image against the horizontal hairs determined, and a calculation using constants of the instrument would give the distance. This was, essentially, a form of measuring angular subtense. Montanari was sufficiently knowledgeable to understand that Keplerian telescopes (two convex lenses) could have small objects (hairs) placed at the focus and so they and distance objects were in focus at the same time. Knowing the particulars of a set of lenses, the computational constants could be determined from which scaled height--that is, distance--could be determined.
BP_Reference(s): Evolution of mines surveying instruments|Scott, D.D.|<i>Transactions of the American Institute of Mining Engineers<i>, New York, 1902, NB pp 301-302.||<i>Geminiano Montanari<i>|Lugli, M.L.|Edizioni il Fiorino, Modena, 2004, 279 p.||<i>Nel terzo centenario dalla nascita di Geminiano<i>|Bonacini, C.|https://www.liberliber.it/mediateca/libri/b/bonacini/nel_terzo_centenario_dalla_nascita_di_geminiano_montanari/odt/bonacini_nel_terzo_centenario_dalla_nascita_di_geminiano_montanari.odt
BP_Title: La livella Diottrica Del Dott. Geminiano Montanari Modanese, Professore delle Scienze Mattematiche nello Studio de Bologna. Nuova Invenzione per Livellare col Cannocchiale con maggiore esattezza, e facilita, che per l'addietro con altre Livelle non s'e fatto. Aggiontouvi il modo misurare una distanza incognita con una sola stazione guardando nel Cannocchiale, & un nuovo, e facile modo die misurare mediante la Livellea medesima il vero circuito della Terra.
BP_Title English Translation: The Dioptric Level of Dr. Geminiano Monanari of Modena, Professor of Mathematical Science in the University of Bologna. A New Invention for a Level with a Telescope with Greater Accuracy and Facility than that Achived by Other Previous Levels. In Addition, a Method to Measure an Unknown Distance with Only one Station by Looking in the Telescope, and a New and Easy Method to Measure by Means of the Same Level the True Circumference of the Earth.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian astronomer and oculist. A keen astronomical observer and building of optical instruments.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1674 Montanari - La livella Diottrica - Images.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by TheÃÅophile Bonet (1620-1689) Swiss scholar and physician.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First Latin translation of Jacques Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> of 1671.
BP_Description_1: At the end of his preface to the first French edition of the <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> 1671, Jacques Rohault mentions that he was 'preparing a Latin version in favor of foreigners, in whom I dare promise myself a fairly favorable reception.' But Rohault never publish a Latin translation. The first was this very close translation produced by the Geneva physician TheÃÅophile Bonet which appeared at Geneva in 1674 (this edition). It was reprinted at London and Amsterdam in 1682, at Amsterdam in 1691 and 1700 and at London in 1691 with notes by the Franciscan Antoine Le Grand, at Amsterdam in 1708 and Cologne in 1713 with notes by both Le Grand and Samuel Clarke. For use at English universities, Clarke made a second Latin translation that appeared at London in 1697 and preprinted in 1702, 1710, and 1718. It was into these editions of his Latin translation of Rohault that Clarke added every more numerous and lengthy notes, augmenting, supplanting, and eclipsing Cartesianism with Newtonianism.
BP_Description_2: Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> is in four parts. Part 1 is in 35 chapters and covers principles of physics, nature of matter, motion and its analysis, forms of matter, heat and cold, the senses of taste, smell, and hearing, and finally the eye, optics, and vision. The Cartesian principles of extension, divisibility, motion, and rest are used to deduce general laws of statics, dynamics, and--via ballistic conceptions  of reflection and refraction--optics. Part 2 is in 29 chapters and covers cosmography, astronomy, selenography, the planets and their movements, the fixed stars, and finally the competing theories of the sun and planets. Rohault plumps for the Copernican as the most rational. Part 3 is in 17 chapters and covers geology in general, including the Earth and things that are part of it, such as the atmosphere, the seas, metals and minerals, fountains, winds, fogs and clouds, rain and hail, snow and frosts, lighting, and finally the rainbow. Part 4 is in 26 chapters and covers anatomy, muscles and movement, blood and circulation, digestion and breathing, and finally maladies and disease.||The optics material covers 115 pages and though patterned closely after Descartes' essay La Dioptrique, it is fully empirical with experiments, demonstrations, and observations reported to test theory and hypothesis. The topics include: the nature of light, color, transparency and opacity. Direct, reflected, and refracted light are demonstrated as well as the simpler forms of image formation by mirrors and lenses. Descartes theory of vision is presented in full. All the optical topics are treated in an elementary but thorough manner. Thus, for example, the focusing properties of spherical convex lenses are demonstrated, but nothing is said of spherical aberration.||Experiment receives a double role: on the one hand, it is shown how it discriminates between conjectures pointing to the ones that are empirically confirmed; on the other hand, it is a powerful pedagogical tool that can convince the reader of explanations given and laws stated.
BP_Reference(s): Rohault's Cartesian Physics|Dobre, M.|In: <i>Cartesian Empiricisms<i>, Springer, 2013, pp 203-226.||Rohault's Traite de Physique and its Newtonian Reception|Dobre, M.|In: <i>Proceedings of the 4th International Conference of the ESHS<i>, 2010, pp 389-394.||The experimental physics of Jacques Rohault|Spink A.|<i>British Journal for the History of Philosophy<i>, Vol 26, No 5, 2017, pp 850-870.||The Study of Early Scientific Textbooks|Sarton, G.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 38, No 3/4, 1948, pp 137-148.||Motion and God in XVIIth Century Cartesian manuals: Rohault, R√©gis and Gadroys|Milani, N.E.|<i>Noctua<i> Vol 2, Nos.1-2, 2015, pp 481-516.
BP_Title: Jacobi Rohaulti Tractatus Physicus. Gallice Emissus et Recens Latinitate Donatius Per th. Bonetum D.M.
BP_Title English Translation: The Physics Tract of Jacques Rohault, Published in French and Recently Given in Latin by TheÃÅophile Bonet DM.
BP_Biographical Statement: French natural philosopher and mathematician. Experimentalist and textbook writer, the first and greatest promoter of Cartesian physics.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1674 Rohault - Tractatus Physicus - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A manuscript of a course in optics devoted to the construction and use of the telescope and microscope. The manuscript originates from Rome and may have accompanied a course taught by Jesuit at the Collegium Romanum.
BP_Description_1: A manuscript of a text presumably used in a course in optics or perhaps mathematics or astronomy. It is likely that the course was one of several small tutorials offered by Jesuits in the Collegium Romanum in the last quarter of the 17th century, perhaps 1670-1680. The text cannot be student notes; the repeated use of first-person singular and the structure and detail of the text suggest it is meant as a teaching guide for a similar course in other Jesuit schools where small tutorials for advanced students were offered. Another copy of this manuscript resides in the Houghton Library at Harvard University; it is in the same hand, with exactly the same text, but in a narrower format and thus contains more pages. The Harvard copy contains a sheet of 10 hand-drawn figures to accompany the text. Other copies are listed at the Biblioth√®que de Toulouse, the Biblioteca Boncompagni and Bibliotheque Slusiane in Rome. It seems likely that these copies were produced by the lecturer or a copyist for use by teachers giving a similar course in another Jesuit school. The extant manuscripts must all have been copied from the same original. The text, and presumably the course which it accompanied, demonstrates the interest in practical optical instruments and their use. The text presumes that convex and concave lenses are available and concentrates on the construction and use of instruments built from them.||World Cat confusingly assigns David P. Wheatland as the author of this text. This is an error; Wheatland was donor of the copy of the manuscript given to Harvard. Other references confuse this text with the <i>L'Occhiale all'Occhio Dioptrica Practica<i> of Manzini and so give it an erroneous, Macclesfield, provenance.
BP_Description_2: The manuscript is in seven chapters. Chapter 1: Gives the history of the invention of the telescope, mentioning its Dutch origins and perfection and use by Galileo. Chapter 2: Covers the parts of telescopes and microscopes, particularly the tubes, mountings, and lenses. Although lensing making per se is not described, lens assessment is, including: determining lens figure, focal length, and quality. Chapter 3: The construction of multi-lensed telescopes, both Galilean and Keplerian. This includes sizing the objective, the ocular, and the use of diaphragms or stops. Chapter 4: The ordinary use of the telescope and microscope. This includes mounting, adjusting and focusing, and placement of object being viewed. The use of the telescope in perspective is described. Chapter 5: The use of the telescope in practical geometry such as surveying and measurement. It is here that Rome is explicitly mentioned, as measurement of distances between points in the city are described. Chapter 6: the use of the microscope in practical geometry. Chapter 7: The use of the telescope in astronomy. Sunspots, among other phenomena, are considered here.||The text is entirely practical, with emphasis on the construction of use of telescopes and microscopes. No theory is presented. A description of common telescopes built until about 1660 is given, using both convex and concave lenses. The works of Riccioli, Scheiner, Redi, and Hooke are cited. The presentation style is scholastic: each topic is introduced by a question, which is then answered.
BP_Reference(s): The Academy of Mathematics at the Collegio Romano|Baldini, U.|In: <i>Jesuit Science and the Rebulic of Letters<i>|Feingold, M., editor|MIT Press, Cambridge, 2003, 489 pp, NB: pp 47-98.
BP_Title: Dioptrica Practica. Sive de Microscopiorum ac Telescopiorum Utilitate, Fabrica, et Usu.
BP_Title English Translation: Practial Dioptrics. Or, the Advantage, Fabrication and Use of Microscopes as well as Telescopes.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian student
BP_Provenance: Jesuit inscription on front free endpaper
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1675 Anonymous - Dioptrica Practica - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A presentation of very basic optical theory and its elaborate and numerous applications to the design and construction of optical phenomena, displays, devices, amusements, and instruments.
BP_Description_1: Zacharias Traber's <i>Nervus Opticus<i> has its roots in his work designing and constructing optical displays for the summer palace garden of Archbishop Gy√∂rgy Lippay in Bratislava. Renowned for its mechanical, hydraulic, and optical features, Traber began working on part of the garden in 1648 and did so on-and-off until the bishop's death in 1666. Traber used his knowledge of optics to design and construct camerae obscurae, dioramas, distorting and anamorphic mirrors, 'catoptrical theaters' that generated multiple images, and various dioptric displays including fountains and mists for generating rainbows. The <i>Nervus Optics<i> sets out not only what Traber knows about optics, but--much more importantly--how optical theory can be used to generate all manner of optical instruments, displays, and devices. Following his Preface to the Reader, Traber added a synopsis of the entire work which set out not only the book's content but also principles he used for writing it. He makes clear that he finds most texts off-putting because of 'their prolixity and confusing proofs and demonstrations'. For Traber, optical theory has value only in application. Experience and experiment are uppermost and this, he states, is 'why only three theoretical parts in the three books will be sufficient.' In this regard, there is very little theory and no mathematics or analysis in the Nervus Opticus. All topics are treated descriptively. Thus, even though Descartes ballistic metaphor for refraction is presented, the sine law of refraction is not. Instead, Traber presents Kepler's approximations from the Dioptrice of 1611.||Traber cites the works of many authors, including Aristotle, Euclid, Albertus Magnus,  Giambattista Della Porta, Ren√© Descartes, Antoine Mizauld, Johannes Kepler, Gaspar Schott, Christoph Scheiner, Athanasius Kircher, and Francois Aguil√≥n. With the exception of Schott, these are limited to the first three chapters of each of the three books; that is, the theoretical sections. Schott, and to a less extent Kircher, are the most prominent models for the rest of <i>Nervus Optics<i>. Many of its chapter titles and text can be found in the first volume, on optics and vision, of Schott's <i>Magia Universalis Natur√¶ et Artis<i> of 1657. Traber does not adopt Schott's (or Kircher's) foundation of Natural Magic, but he is, like them, fascinated with optical devices and objects. The frontispiece of <i>Nervus Opticus<i> reflects this emphasis, with putti engaging with a cornucopia--literally--of lenses, mirrors, prisms, and instruments. Traber's manuscript was handed over to the Vienna printer Matthaeus Cosmerovius in 1673. Cosmerovius' death delayed the printing which was eventually taken up by his son Johann Cosmerovius who printed three or four hundred copies in 1675.||Nervus Opticus appeared at Vienna in 1675 and was reissued in 1690 with a new title page.
BP_Description_2: Zacharias Traber's <i>Nervus Opticus<i> is in three books. Book 1 is on optics; that is, vision by direct rays but also presents some dioptric phenomena. Topics include: The nature, propagation of light; color of surfaces and the rainbow; eye function; visual species; focusing properties of lenses; use of telescopes, microscopes, and helioscopes. Book 2 in on catoptrics. Topics include: Law of reflections; images in convex and concave mirrors, images produced by interreflection in multiple plane mirrors; burning mirrors; polygonal mirrors; cylindrical mirrors; and 'magia catoptrica' constructions for gardens and entertainment. Book 3 is on dioptrics. Topics include: Refraction and Kepler's approximate law; hypotheses regarding refraction; prismatic colors; lenses and lens making; convex and concave lens properties; operation of the eye's lens; vision with lenses; rays through multiple lenses; magnification by lenses; microscopes and telescopes; lenses of elliptical, parabolic, and hyperbolic figures; and an Appendix on dialling.||The material on physical optics that is presented in the first few chapters of each book is just sufficient to support applications. It is a hybrid of medieval Perspectiva and the ideas of Kepler and Descartes, with visual species being conflated with optical images. Visual rays and luminous rays are used interchangeably in the text and some complications, such as spherical aberration in mirrors, are not considered at all. The presentation is entirely qualitative with no mathematics or calculations. Most material, by far, is devoted to optical devices, instruments, and entertainment pieces. This is particularly so for the book on catoptrics, where the emphasis is on the production, multiplication, and distortion of images. The material on dioptrics has its emphasis on the production of colors, the prismatic generation of rainbows, and the use of lenses in spectacles, telescopes, and microscopes. The geometrical optics is purely qualitative and uses rays and presumed focal points, rather than image analysis. This is the case regarding the description of non-spherical lenses and  the effects of multiple spherical lenses on rays, which are enumerated and described in qualitative ways, somewhat in the manner of Christoph Scheiner's <i>Rosa Ursina<i> of 1630.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Plenus Sapientia: Lippay Gy√∂rgy esztergomi √©rsek pozsonyi kertj√©nek l√°tv√°nyoss√°gai<i> (in Hungarian)[<i>Plenus Sapientia: Spectacles of Archbishop Gy√∂rgy Lippay's Summer Palace Garden in Pozsony<i>]|Ecsedy, A.|<i>M≈±v√©szett√∂rt√©neti √ârtes√≠t≈ë<i>, Vol 62, No 2, 2013, pp 171-232.
BP_Title: Nervus Opticus. Sive, Tractatus Theoricus, in Tres Libros Opticam, Catoptricam, Dioptricam Distributus. Zacharia Traber, Styro Martiaffluensi, Societatis Jesu Sacerdote.
BP_Title English Translation: The Optic Nerve. Or, A Theoretical Tract Divided into Three Books: Optics, Catoptrics, Dioptrics. Authored by Father Zacharia Traber of Mortzthal in Styria (Austria), priest of the Society of Jesus.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, natural philosopher. Taught at and rector of Jesuit College at Vienna.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Servite Order's 'Conventus Viennensis in Rossaugia'. Donatiion note dated 1675 on pastedown

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The anatomy of the eye and theory of its functioning. The first description of the retinal nerve fibers and their convergence into the optic nerve.
BP_Description_1: The origin of the <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> is Brigg's time abroad, beginning in 1670, when he studied neural anatomy with Raymond Vieussens, professor of anatomy at Montpellier. Briggs returned to Cambridge, concentrating on the anatomy of the visual system and wrote his <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> at this time. Its 80 pages appeared in 1676 and advanced the understanding of the anatomy of the retina and optic nerve. It was prelude to and provided ideas that were incorporated within Brigg's later more famous work the Nova Visionis Theoria, first presented to the Royal Society of London in 1682 and printed in 1686.||This first edition appeared with a dedication to Sir Ralph Montagu. The sheets of this 1676 printing were reused with a new title leaf and bound with the printing of the Nova Visionis Theoria in the first appearance of the latter in 1685 and again in 1686. The <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> and <i>Nova Visionis Theoria<i> was read and praised by Isaac Newton and was the source of his knowledge of ocular anatomy and visual physiology.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> presents the anatomy of the eye and the theory of its functioning. Importantly, it presents the first description of the retinal nerve fibers and their convergence upon the optic nerve to form the feature Briggs named the 'optic papilla.' The retinal nerve fibers were thought to vibrate when stimulated by light, the vibrations traveling along the optic nerve to the brain. The other aspects of Brigg's ocular anatomy were modern, with the crystalline lens shown in the correct size, in the correct place, and its function of image generation on the retina made clear. Briggs devotes chapters to eye muscles, veins and arteries, the optic nerve, lacrimal glands, animal eyes, and mentions Marriotte and his discovery of the blind spot.
BP_Reference(s): Dr. William Briggs: Ophthalmic Physician at St. Thomas‚Äô Hospital, London|Winstanley, J.|<i>Survey of Opthalmology<i>, Vol 46, No 1, 2001, pp 81-88.|William Briggd, M.D. ( 1650-1704)|James, R.R.|<i>The British Journal of Ophthalmology<i>, Vol 16, No 6, 1932, pp 360-368.
BP_Title: Ophthalmo-graphia, sive Oculi ejusque partium descriptio Anatomica.
BP_Title English Translation: Ophthalmology, or An Anotomical Descipition of the Eye and its Parts.
BP_Biographical Statement: British physician, first specialist in ophthalmology. A significant contributor to vision science, worked at Cambridge,  friend of and collaborator with Isaac Newton.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1676 Briggs - Ophthalmo-graphia - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Qualitative description of images produced by reflection and refraction.
BP_Description_1: This manuscript of Jacob Jan on catoptrics, dated 1676,  was first printed in the <i>Miscellanea Curiosa Medico-Physica Academiae Naturae Curiosorum<i> that appeared in 1677. The <i>Miscellanea<i> was published Johann Fritsch from 1670 until 1715, collecting short works of a physico-medical nature, usually from Germany. Jan manuscript was printed again in the The <i>Miscellanea<i> of 1688. The preface of the publisher credits the Dresden mathematician, lawyer, and jurist Christian Erndel with seeing the manuscript through the press.
BP_Description_2: Jan's work is in ten parts, presenting 72 propositions. Part 1: On simple images; Part 2: On mixed reflection and refraction and the size of images; Part 3: Plano-convex mirrors; Part 4: Convex-plane mirrors; Part 5: Plano-convex mirrors; Part 6: Convex-plane mirrors; Part 7: Double concave mirrors; Part 8: Double convex mirrors; Part 9: Convex-concave mirrors; Part 10: Concave-convex mirrors. The material is entirely descriptive and qualitative. Jan begins by citing the basic qualitative propositions of Kepler's <i>Ad Vitellionem<i> of 1604 regarding light and reflection. Jan then considers the number and nature of the images form by polished glass of various figures, partially covered with mercury or lead-tin alloy.

Fully empirical, with numerous experiments and observations reported to test theory and hypothesis. 115 pages are devoted to Cartesian optics and the theory of vision is presented in full.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The presentation of mechanistic natural philosophy in which experiment trumps theories and hypotheses. Sixteen experiments, with 16 addenda, are presented and discussed. Three deal with optics including material direct from Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i>.
BP_Description_1: The roots of Johann Sturms' <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> are in his studies at Leiden under the renowned pedagogue Burchard de Volder and the experimental basis for his courses in natural philosophy. De Volder had introduced experimental demonstrations into his lectures which took place in a special classroom he had purpose-built. Sturm adopted the same pedagogical ideas and in 1672 established a '<i>Collegium Experimentale<i>' at the University of Altdorf. But Sturm took these ideas further: For him, experiment was the only way to successfully teach natural philosophy and to settle disputed points in natural philosophy between the then-current factions: Aristotelian, Cartesian, Gassendian. In his Preface, Sturm cites Caspar Schott, Robert Boyle, and Otto van Guericke as models for experimental lectures. Following his Preface, Sturm included a Programma Invitatorium (Invitational Proclamation) in which he makes clear the role of experiment, writing that scholars use 'the experimental method, because it is no longer based on the subtleties of empty quarrels and disputes, but searches the recondite recesses of nature itself and rests on experiments which are not conducted according to chance, but are planned.'||Patterned after the Accademia del Cimento in Florence, Sturm describes 16 experiments, performed before 20 'scrutatores naturae'--whom he lists after the Programma Invitatorium and were students of or observers in the Collegium--to attest to the correctness of and conclusions from the experiments. The second half of the book is an Auctaria (Supplement) that revisits, explains, and comments on the experiments and the phenomena investigated. With the publication of the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i>, Sturm inaugurated his experiment-based teaching program.||Aside from a few cases where measurements were made, neither the experiments themselves nor the analysis Sturm gives are attempts to establish mathematical laws or descriptions. Rather, the effort was to find cause-and-effect, isolate general properties, demonstrate principles, or decide between hypotheses.||<i>Collegium Experimentale<i> was summarized and reviewed very positively in the Journal de S√ßavans, Vol 6, No 2, January 1678.The influence of Sturm and the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> was extensive. These formal experimental sessions were repeated in 1675, 1679, 1681, 1683, and 1684 and were summarized in a second part to the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> that was published in 1685 in which 15 experiments were described and lists of auditors given for each year. One of the auditors in 1683 was Georg Albrecht Hamberger who would teach at the University of Jena and have Christian Wolff as a student. Wolff, in turn, would take up the experimental pedagogical standard and produce one of the most influential textbooks of natural philosophy of the 18th century.||Though both parts of the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> could be considered textbooks, they were actually testimonials to Sturm's belief in the experimental method and its role in teaching. Both were preludes to Sturm's textbook, Mathesis Juvenilis, that first appeared in 1699. Both parts of the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> appeared at NuÃàrnburg in 1685, 1701, and 1715.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> of 1676 presents experiments, grouped around 16 subjects: 1, The diving bell; 2, the camera obscura and the eye; 3, the barometer; 4, on swimming; 5, hydrostatic phenomena; 6, conclusions from the previous experiments; 7, a 36 foot water barometer; 8, on phenomena observed in small pipes in water; 9, effects with various thermometers; 10, Francesco Lana's air ship; 11, mechanical forces; 12, artificial language; 13, Gerricke's air pump; 14, a hydroscope and chronometer of recent invention; 15, the making of telescopes and microscopes; 16, portable camera obscure and the magic lantern.||For each experiment, the apparatus is described,  observed phenomena are listed, and conclusions or consequences are presented. The 'conclusions' are usually explanations given for the phenomena. In some cases, such as with Lana-Terzi's air ship or Gerricke's vacuum-bells, explicit reference is made to claims or details from the original publication.||Three subject areas deal with optics: The eye and the nature of vision, reflection, refraction, and lenses, including material direct from Kepler's Dioptrice; Microscopes and telescopes, their types, operation and use, and objects viewed with them; The camera obscura and the magic lantern, their construction and operation, and the images obtained. The material on telescopes, microscopes, and magic lanterns is accompanied by large, folded plates of figures, showing the geometric optics involved. The 'Auctaria' gives more detail and extended discussions for some of the phenomena of some of the experiments. The auctarium for the 2nd experiment on the camera obscura and the eye is an extended extract and summary from Johannes Kepler's <i>Dioptrice<i> of 1611.
BP_Reference(s): The Culture of Experimentalism in the Holy Roman Empire: Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703) and the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i>|Ahnert, T.|http://sammelpunkt.philo.at/308/||Das <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> sive curiosum und die Anf√§nge experimenteller Naturlehre in Deutschland [The <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> sive Curiosum and the beginnings of experimental natural philosophy in Germany]|Wiesenfeldt, G.|In: <i>Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703)<i>|Verlag Harri Deutsch, 2004, pp 184-203.||Experiment in Cartesian Courses: The Case of Professor Burchard de Volder|Nyden, T.|In: <i>4th International Conference of the European Society for the History of Science<i>, Barcelona, 2010, pp 384-390.
BP_Title: <i>Collegium Experimentale<i>, Sive Curiosum, in quo Primaria huius Seculi Inventa & Experimenta Physico-Mathemtica, Speciatim Campanae Urinatoriae, Camerae obscurae, Tubi torricelliani, seu Baroscopii, Antliae Pneumaticae, Thermomertrorum, Hygroscopiorum, Telescopiorum, Microscopiorum, Etc. Phaenomena & effecta, Partim ab aliis iam pridem exhibita, partim noviter istis superaddita, per ultimum quadrimestre Anni M.DC.LXXII. Viginti Naturae Scrutatoribus, ex parte Illustri Nobilique, Prosapia oriundis, & spectanda oculis subjecit, et ad causas suas naturales demonstrativa method reduxit, Quodque nunc Accessione multa, demonstrationum ac hypothesium veritatem porro illustrante, confirmante, & a nonnullorum cavillationibus vindicante, locupletatum amicorum quorundam su a su & confilio publicum adspicere voluit.
BP_Title English Translation: The Experimental School, or The Inquirer. In which the Primary Inventions and Physico-Mathematical Experiments of this Age--Specifially, the Diving Bell, Camera Obscura, Torricelli Tube or Baroscope, Air Pump, the Phenomena and Effects of Thermometers, Hygroscopes, Telescopes, Microscopes Etc.--are Presented, Some  Previously, Others that are Newly Added through the last Four Months of the year 1672. Exposed to the Visual Scrutiny of Twenty Natural Philosophers, Descended from Illustrious and Noble Families, Reduced to their Natural Causes by a Demonstrative Method, And now, the Addition of Many Demonstrations and Hypotheses Confirming  and Further Illuminating and  Vindicating (them) From Many Cavaillings, Emboldened by the Persuation and Council of Certain Friends that the Public Wanted to See (them).
BP_Biographical Statement: German philosopher, mathematician, influenital pedagogue, experimentalist, and textbook author. Taught at the University of Altdorf, reforming the curriculum to include experimentation.
BP_Printer: Heirs of Johann Andreas Endter and Wolfgang Mortiz Endter
BP_Binding: Contemporary Vellum, Title Inked On Spine

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mathematical and optical instruments for surveying, fortifications, perspective, and entertainments. Contains the first description of the use of a large convex lens to view a flat image and produce depth perception, the zograscope.
BP_Description_1: Kohlans's text contains one of the earliest histories of the magic lantern in Germany, citing Johann Franz Griendel and the earliest manufacturer, showman, and instrument maker in the city of N√ºrnberg, which Johann Zahn identified as one of the centers of magic lantern production in 1686. This development that Kohlhans identified, was a separate magic lantern tradition from that of the Dutch and Danish Christiaan Huygens and Thomas Walgensten. Kohlans is also the first to describe the effect of viewing a flat image through biconvex lens--producing a mild stereoscopic depth effect. This would eventually lead to the instrument called the zograscope.||In the <i>Neu-erfundene mathematische und optische CuriositaÃàten<i>, Kohlhans's optical material is given in the vernacular and strictly in the craft tradition. He describes materials, forming, construction, and manufacture, all with sufficient detail to allow for the instruments to be replicated. Throughout this extensive section on optical instruments (nearly 80 pages) one finds short but critical sections presented in Hebrew, Greek, Latin, and transliterated Arabic and Syrian. Kohlhans ends the material on optics with a section titled <i>Secreta Optica<i>. Here he explains his attempt to both honor the tradition of secrets in optical craft and the apparent need for openness in describing optical advances granted by God's grace. He cuts this Gordian knot by presenting the secrets in languages that only the learned will understand and so prevents the secrets from being revealed to the vulgar, which if that happened ‚Äòthen these things would become common and the art contemptible.'
BP_Description_2: Mathematical and optical instruments for surveying, fortifications, and optics. The optical instruments include mirrored periscopes and the shaping of parabolic mirrors. Dioptric instruments include prismatic viewers, telescopes, the polemoscope, the magic lantern, and a camera obscure concealed in a book. Contains the first description of the use of a large convex lens to view a flat image and produce depth perception, the zograscope.
BP_Reference(s): Perspective Views|Kaldenbach, C.J.|<i>Print Quarterly<i>, Vol 2, No 2, 1985 pp 1-14.||Zograscopes, virtual reality, and the mapping of polite society in eighteenth-century England|Blake, E.C.|In: <i>New Media 1740-1915<i>, Gitelman, L., Pingree, G.B., editors, MIT Press, Cambridge 2003, 271 pp, NB: pp 1-30.
BP_Title: Neu-erfundene mathematische und optische CuriositaÃàten : bestehend so wohl in einem sattsamen Unterricht zum Feldmessen und itzt uÃàblichen Fortification, nechst deutlichem Entwurff in selbiger benoÃàthigten Linien durch ein sonderbahres Vortheil zu erfinden ; als auch in einer gantz neuen und bewaÃàhrten Art, allerhand ohne Rechnung mit geringer MuÃàhe durch ein kleines Instrument genau und kuÃànstlich zu messen ; und dann in beygefuÃàgten unterschiedlichen optischen RaritaÃàten auch andern zu Perspectiven und so genandter finstern Kammer gehoÃàrigen merckwuÃàrdigen Sachen: beydes zur Lust und annehmlichen Nutzen eroÃàffnet und an Tag gegeben durch Johann Christofph Kohlhansen.
BP_Title English Translation: Newly Invented Mathematical and Optical Curiosities. Consisting of Sufficient Lessions in Surveying and Common Fortification; In Addition for Drawing, Generating Required Lines with Particular Advantage. As well as a Completely New and Proven Way for Measuring Without Calculation, with Little Effort, Artfully and Accurately with a Small Instrument. Attached are Different Optical Raraties and Others for Perspective and the co-called Camera Obscura and Associated Strange Things. Presented for Both Pleasure and Relaxing Benefit, and Now Given by Johann Christoph Kohlhans.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician and linguist. Taught at Cobur and Gottingen.
BP_Binding: Contemporary 3/4 Vellum Over Marbled Paper Boards
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1677 Kohlhans - Neu-erfundene mathematische und optische CuriositaÃàten - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A consideration of binocular vision and optical instruments. Experiments are presented to show the superiority of binocular vision and the resulting requirements for instruments. Methods for the design, construction, testing, and use of binocular microscopes, telescopes, 'binoculars', and spectacles are given.
BP_Description_1: In his <i>La Dioptrique Oculaire<i> of 1671, Ch√©rubin d'Orl√©ans noted the inferiority of monocular vision and refuted the notion that it is more natural and efficacious to use one eye. Aside from questions of stereoscopy, he considered binocular vision superior: with both eyes open, the pupils are larger and 'more rays enter the humors of the eye'--though he does admit that vision is more distinct with one eye. In his Preface to <i>La Vision Parfaite<i>, Ch√©rubin continue to insist that vision is more powerful when both eyes are used, and that to this end binocular optical instruments need to permit the visual axes of the two eyes to converge to a single point on the viewed object, rather than be parallel. He also states in the Preface that he had resolved to make a binocular microscope and because he had succeeded beyond his expectations, he had 'determined to make it the principal subject of the present work.'  <i>La Vision Parfaite<i> describes the first binocular microscope and though it never explicitly considers the potential for stereopsis that binocular vision affords, sections of the book would later be cited by Robert Smith in his <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738 in this regard and by Charles Wheatstone in his work on stereoscopic pictures in 1853. <i>La Vision Parfaite<i> had a reception that ranged from politely cool to antagonistic and prompted Ch√©rubin to write a second part, defending his ideas.||The first part of <i>La Vision Parfaite<i> appeared in 1677. A Latin rendition of the French text of the first part appeared in 1678. A second part appeared in 1681.
BP_Description_2: <i>La Vision Parfaite<i> is in four parts. Part 1, by far the longest, is in three sections. Section 1 presents a theory of binocular vision, emphasizing the convergent optical axes of the two eyes. This is followed by descriptions of five experiments with results that support the theory. Section 2 presents refutations of opinions and ideas opposed to the binocular theory, including: parallel optical axes, dominance of one eye, and alternating suppression. Finally, a consideration of why previous binocular systems with parallel axes fail, and what principles are required for proper binocular instruments. Section 3 details the requirements for a binocular telescope, including the optical and mechanical features that are required.   A consideration of binocular vision and optical instruments. Experiments are presented to show the superiority of binocular vision and the resulting requirements for instruments. Methods for the design, construction, testing, and use of binocular microscopes, telescopes, 'binoculars', and spectacles are given.||Part 2 is in two sections. Section 1 is a detailed description of the construction of a binocular microscope including the optical and mechanical components. Section 2 describes the construction of what would now be called binoculars. Part 3 is in three sections. Section 1 describes the construction of spectacles based on the binocular theory of vision. Sections 2 and 3 consider some of the visual effects of binocular vision. Part 4 is in two sections. Section 1 is a manual for the design and construction of the lenses required for  binocular optical systems. Section 2 describes a binocular drawing machine for use by artists.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Quest for Perfect Vision<i>|Gallay, A.|Dissertation|University of Cambridge, 2013, 34 p.||The disparate histories of binocular vision and binaural hearing|Wade, N.J.|<i>Journal of the History of the Neurosciences<i>, Vol 27, No 1, 2018, pp 10‚Äì35.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Reprinting of the second, posthumous edition of 1663 of Heinlin's elementary and qualitative teaching survey of Mixed Mathematics including: Arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, geography, statics, and optics.
BP_Description_1: Heinlin's Preface to the Reader in the edition of the <i>Synopsis Mathematica Universali<i> 1653 states that the book was written to re-establish the teaching of Mixed Mathematics at Tubingen after the 30 Years War. What was needed in the public and monastic schools was a survey of arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, geography, and optics, suitable for beginning students. Interestingly, the book was not intended for self-study, but--as the Preface states--assumes that students require the guidance of a teacher. Regarding students, teachers must not 'charge their memory with prolix and misunderstood lessons.' Heinlin also makes it clear that the order of material, as presented in the Synopsis, should be followed. Though a mathematics student of Johannes Kepler, and later lecturer in that subject, Heinlin rarely invokes even arithmetic in the Synopsis, and its epitomization of optics contains no mathematics at all.||The new Preface states that the fist edition of the book was highly successfully and had been revised and added to by Heinlin before his death in 1660. Friends and former students worked with the manuscript, added material on geography and introduced a new section on statics.||This printing contains the original dedication and both the author's old and printer's new Preface. Editions appeared in 1653, 1663, and 1679. An English translation appeared at London in 1709 and was reprinted in 1729.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Synopsis Mathematica Universalis<i> contains six books: Arithmetic, Geometry, Astronomy, Geography, Optics, and Statics. The 130-page optic section is titled 'An Epitome of Optics' and accurately describes the nature of the material. It contains: Ocular anatomy and vision; the nature and propagation of light; color as a modification of light and dark; visual perception of objects, light, shade, and color; catoptrics including plane, curved, and burning mirrors; 'mesoptics' (dioptrics) including simple lenses, atmospheric refraction, and the rainbow. The physical optics material is Aristotelian and Perspectivist, with references made to visual species, the distinction between lux and lumen, color as a 'secondary object of sight' resulting from the mixing of light and dark, and rays having strength varying with their obliquity. The longest section is the first, on direct vision, with detailed and elaborate descriptions of many aspects of visual perception. The sections on catoptrics and dioptrics give little more than definitions and descriptions of reflection and refraction. Throughout, the presentation is elementary, descriptive, qualitative only, and wearyingly prolix. No mathematics is used.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Allgemeines Gelehrten-Lexicon<i>|Christian Gottlieb J√∂cher|Vol 2, col 1325.
BP_Title: Synopsis Mathematica Universalis: Nunc Tertium, Longe emendatius & auctius, Edita.
BP_Title English Translation: Universal Mathematical Synopsis: Now a Third (edition) lately corrected and greatly augmented.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Anders Spole (dissertation director)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A brief, elementary dissertation on light rays under the supervision of Anders Spole, professor of mathematics at the University of Uppsala.
BP_Description_1: This is among the first dissertations under the direction of Anders Spole after he took up a professorship in astronomy at Uppsala University In 1679. He would eventually oversee more than 35 dissertation defenses. As was often the case, the dissertation was written by the presiding professor--this case, Anders Spole--and defended by the disputant--in this case, one Nicolaus Petriin. An example of the extensive series of dissertations on optics at Uppsala University in the 17th and 18th centuries.
BP_Description_2: A brief summary of the properties of optical rays, including their nature, propagation, and displacement by reflection, refraction, and diffraction. Contemporary optical authors are cited.
BP_Reference(s): Lectures and Practices. The Variety of Mathematical and Mechanical Teaching at the University of Uppsala in the 17th Century|Kallinen, M.|In: <i>Universities and Science in the Early Modern Period<i>, Feingold, M., Navarro-Brontons, V., editors|Springer, 2006, 390 pp, NB: pp 111-126.

Petriin of Gotha, a stipendary of Her SeRen√© Majesty The Queen.

BP_Author AKA: WordCat list Robert Cooper and "R.H." [Abrahm Woodhead] as coauthors. No author name is given in the book. DNB cites the book as by Walker
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Description of a series of experiments and demonstrations with convex and concave lenses, having the format of a laboratory note book or journal.
BP_Description_1: The attribution to Obadiah Walker is common, but scholarship's best guess is that the work was originally written, and figures sketched by Robert Cooper, mathematician in Pembroke College, Oxford. It then seems likely that  Abraham Woodhead of University College was attracted to the subject and some of Cooper's ideas and so reviewed and prepared the manuscript which was left at his death. Obadiah Walker likely found the manuscript among Woodhead's papers and, as he did with several other of Woodhead's works, saw it through the press with 500 copies printed.
BP_Description_2: There are 51 experiments and demonstrations, accompanied by explanations; 41 devoted to convex lenses, 10 devoted to concave lenses. These are followed by considerations of image position. The language is idiosyncratic: 'glass' is used rather than 'lens'; 'prospective' rather than 'telescope'; 'conical' and 'circumferential' rays rather than 'convergent' and 'divergent'. After a brief, qualitative consideration of refraction, the analysis considers convex lenses: their focal points, operation of multiple lenses, and generation of images. Though the analysis is detailed, it is not mathematical, with geometry invoked only occasionally, and the results expressed descriptively but very concisely. The whole work having the format of a laboratory note book or journal and not a finished treatise--a technical brown study, as it were. It is, however, an example of early modern science, based on experiment and observation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Oxford Books<i>|Madan, F.|Oxford, 1931, Vol 3 (Oxford Literature, 1651-1680), pp 370-371.||The History of the Royal Society of London, Volume III|Birch, T.|Philosophical Transactions Supplement, London, 1757, p 499.
BP_Title: Propositions concerning optic-glasses, with their natural Reasons, drawn from Experiments.
BP_Biographical Statement: English academic, political and religious activist. Educated and taught at Oxford, but aligence to The Catholic James cost him his liberty and position.

BP_Short or Common Title: Il Fosforo O' vero La Pietra Bolognese
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First work in Italian on the Bolognian stone.
BP_Description_1: As an instrument maker and professor in Rome, Cellio would have been well aware of Vincenzo Cascariolo's 1603 discovery of persistent luminescent material in the form of volcanic rock near Bologna, his method for activating it by heat, and the several treatises previously written on the phenomenon of the 'Bologna Stone.' This is the first work in the vernacular on the preparation and properties of the Bologna Stone, all previous work had been published in Latin; much of it speculative, little of it practical. Robert Hooke noted, reviewed, and described the work in his Philosophical Collections, Number 3, December 1681.
BP_Description_2: First work in Italian on the Bolognian stone. The geographical sources for the stone are described, as well as the nature and different colors of stone, how they appeared to function, and methods for preparing phosphor sensitive enough to 'capture' candlelight or moonlight. The production of luminescent pictures is described, using phosphor and tempera paint.  Cellio experimented to determine the treatment that produced the most sensitive material and how to treat, refine, and make the phosphorescent material more sensitive. This description of Cellio's method includes the furnace which he devised for calcinating the stones, since too little heat was insufficient to activate the stone and too much would destroy the phosphorescent property.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of Luminescence<i>|Harvey, E.N.|American Philosophical Society, Philadelphia, 1957, 692 pp, NB:  pp 315-318.||The Bologna Stone: history's first persistent luminescent material|Lastusaari, M., and others|<i>European Journal of Minerology<i>, Vol 24, No 5, pp 885-890.
BP_Title: Il Fosforo O' vero La Pietra Bolognese Preparata per rilucere fra l'ombre Fatica di Marc Antonio Cellio Dell' Accademia Fisicomattematica de Roma, E dal medemo consecrata All' Eccellentissimo Prencipe Signor D. Marc' Antonio Borghese.
BP_Title English Translation: Phosphorous, or the true Bologna Stone prepared to shine in the darkness. A Work of Marc Antonio Cellio of the Academy of Mathematical Physics of Rome, and dedicated by the same to the Most Excellent Prince, Lord Marc Antonio Borghese.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian astronomer, professor, and instrument maker. Taught at Del Academia Fisico-Mattemattica di Roma.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A selection and editing of demonstrations, apparatus, and experiments from Kircher's books. The most numerous are from the work on Light and Shadow, with brief descriptions and many of the original figures. The preface is long essay attempting to address Kircher's critics.
BP_Description_1: Johann Stephan Kestler, along with Gaspar Schott and Gioseffo Petrucci, was one of the principle defenders and promoters of Athanasius Kircher's works and reputation late in his life. In the nearly 50 years Kircher had been writing books, experimental science had arisen in Europe, and Kestler's compilation was an attempt to extract, summarize, and re-present Kircher as an experimenter and his work as experimentally-based. Kircher promoted it to the potential Dutch publisher as a work of particular relevance, given the interest in such compilations--such as that from the Florentine Accademia del Cimento or the works of Robert Boyle. Kestler himself was completely unknown and the fact that his compilation appeared in print evidences the publisher's trust in the name of Kircher. Kestler's <i>Physiologia<i> of 1680, Giorgio de Sepibus's <i>Romani Collegii Musaeum Celeberrimum<i> of 1678, and Gioseffo Petrucci's <i>Prodromo Apologetico<i> of 1677,  were all meant to defend and rehabilitate Kircher's experimental, collecting, and Egyptological work.||Kestler's preface gives the ostensible reason for the work: to refute Kircher's critics and assemble a collection his most important experimental work. In the Preface, Kestler briefly summarizes criticisms of Kircher's work and dismisses them and their authors as dishonorable. But he writes no specific refutations, simply relying on the sheer amount of compiled material to tip the scales. The <i>Physiologia Kircheriana<i> brings together 337 experiments from Kircher's publications with an emphasis on the Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae. Kestler edited and assembled near verbatim extracts from Kircher's books to accompany the many figures and, compared the well-known and wearying prolixity of the original works, Kestler's summaries are clear and concise--whatever the value of the information itself. Kestler's <i>Physiologia Kircheriana<i> was produced with the same opulence as many of Kircher's later and most famous productions.||Though 'Experimentum' is used throughout the <i>Physiologia Kircheriana<i> to label the individual pieces, it is not a word found in, for example, the <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i>. They are actually demonstrations, often involving a piece of apparatus, to show a phenomenon. The use of 'Experimentum' was, evidently, part of Kestler's attempt to recast Kircher's work as experimental. But even in their late 17th century context, these would not have been considered hypothesis-testing or phenomena-exploring exercises; rather, they were demonstrations of what Kircher had always considered expressions of the natural magic that drove, connected, and explained the natural world.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Physiologia Kircheriana<i> is in 7 books. Book 1: 'Centrographography', dealing generally with the center of things, including the Earth, the cosmos, central motions, placement and measurement on a sphere. Book 2: A miscellany including the nature of motion of the sea, horology, hydrology, chemistry, insects, and vegetables. Book 3: Light and Shadow. Book 4: Magnetics. Book 5: Sound and Music. Book 6: Ancient mechanics of Egypt. Book 7: Miscellany including ballistics and pyrotechnics.||Book three contains extractions and editings from the second edition of Kircher's <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i> of 1671. It is in five sections. Section 1: The nature and production of color. Section 2: Light rays, light of the Sun and Moon, pin-hole projections. Section 3: Analogies between color and tones. Section 4: Optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics devoted to horology. This section includes eye-function. Section 5: Optical spectacles including the magic lantern and anamorphosis.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A Study of the Life and Works of Athanasius Kircher, 'Germanus Incredibilis'<i>|Fletcher, J.E.|Brill, Leiden, 2011.||<i>Scientia Kircheriana : die Fabrikation von Wissen bei Athanasius Kircher<i>|Asmussen, T.|Didymos-Verlag, 2016, 220 p.||<i>Athanasius Kircher: The Last Man W ho Knew Everything<i>|Findlen, P.|Routledge, 2004, 431 pp, NB: pp 4-6, 39-40.
BP_Title: Physiologia Kircheriana experimentalis : qua summa argumentorum multitudine & varietate naturalium rerum scientia per experimenta physica, mathematica, medica, chymica, musica, magnetica, mechanica comprobatur atque stabilitur. Quam Ex Vastis Operibus Adm. Rev. P. Athanasii Kircheri extraxit, & in hunc ordinem per classes redegit Romae. Anno MDCLXXV. Joannes Sephanus Kestlerus Alsata, Authoris discipulus, & in re litteraria assecla, & coadjutor.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of a collection of brief expositions or conversations on a wide range of subjects for use in Jesuit grammar schools. The optics section is very concise; little more than a long list of definitions and statements. At the end is a Latin-German dictionary.
BP_Description_1: Pexenfelder's <i>Apparatus Eruditionis<i> is the result of his long teaching experience at the Jesuit Gymnasium in Bavaria. The book is as much an exercise in Latin vocabulary and grammar as it is an elementary encyclopedia. The intended audience clearly was young students and the method of instruction deeply informed by Pexenfelder's experience. The material is presented in the form of conversations between teacher and pupil with the intention of building an extensive and detailed vocabulary and so providing the ability to read learned works--thus the title, <i>Apparatus of Erudition<i>. Words and things are explained at the same time, using clear language in brief passages.||The material is presented in an order that reflects the medieval 'Great Chain of Being', beginning with the inanimate, then plants, animals, man and his many characteristics and activities, and finally theology.||Editions appeared at N√ºrnburg in 1670, at Sutlzbach in 1680, 1682, 1687, 1704, at Basel in 1744, and expanded by Benito Monfort at Valencia in 1798. Up to 1744, the editions were virtually unchanged, attesting to the utility and popularity of the work.
BP_Description_2: Second edition of Pexenfelder's <i>Apparatus Eruditionis<i>, a collection of brief expositions in the form conversations on a wide range of subjects for use in Jesuit grammar schools. It contains 101 chapters. 1: Introduction; 11-14: Plants; 15-19: Animals; 20-31: Man; 32-38: Agriculture and housekeeping; 39-43: Crafts; 44-47: Locomotion; 48: Sensory perception; 49-60: Liberal arts; 61-67: Measurement, Coins, Optics, Earth and Sky Description, Timing; 68-69: History; 70-74: Moral teaching; 75-78: Higher faculties; 79-82: Household nature and economy; 83-91: Constitution, Customs, Trade; 92-97: Religion; 98-100: Symbols; 101: Conclusion||Chapter 64 is on optics and is very concise; little more than an long list of definitions and statements. Optics is presented as the science of sight, involving light, color, and shadow. Sight is the reception of visual species, received either directly, by reflection, or by refraction. The action of mirrors is briefly considered, but lenses are not.||Apparatus Eruditionis ends with Latin-German and German-Latin dictionaries.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Pexenfelder, Michael: Apparatus eruditionis tam rerum quam verborum per omnes artes et scientias<i>|http://www2.uni-mannheim.de/mateo/camenaref/pexenfelder.html
BP_Title: Apparatus eruditionis tam rerum quam verborum per omnes artes et scientias instructus opera et studio P. Michaelis Pexenfelder Soc. jesu sacerdotis. Cum indicibus. I. Capitum. II. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Contains Du Hamel's <i>Astronomia Physica<i>, A work on the nature of light and colors and planetary astronomy, and <i>De Meteoris et Fossilibus<i>, a summary of meteorological phenomena and a consideration of the nature and Use of things excavated from the ground.
BP_Description_1: Du Hamel's work on light and color is a summary of then-current theories of Gassendi and Descartes set against traditional Aristotelian teaching. 'Modern' theories are considered, explained, and found wanting. His work on planetary astronomy has its root in his early <i>Elementa Astronomia<i> of 1643 and considers: the nature and motion of celestial bodies; various theories of the motion of the earth, moon, and sun; the fixed stars; and various aspects of practical observational astronomy. Both the optical and astronomical material is presented in the form of a Galilean dialogue involving Simplicius (expressing the views of La Chambre), Meander (expressing the views of Descartes), and Theophilus (the views of Honor√© Fabri).||Though Du Hamel had a considerable reputation during his life--first secretary and historian of the Acad√©mie Royale des Sciences--his works of this type were of little influence, being essentially summaries and reactionary defenses of Aristotelianism. Nevertheless, and for that very reason, the <i>Astronomia Physica<i> marks and documents the mounting struggle against Cartesianism in France.||Du Hamel's work on meteorics and excavated things (earths, stones, gems, and metals) was written in defense of long-held Aristotelian teachings and as a bulwark against the rising tide of Cartesianism and the 'new chemistry' based on elements rather than differing aggregations of fundamental corpuscles.||Both <i>Astronomia Physica<i> and <i>De Meteoris et Fossilibus<i> appeared in 1660 and again in this opera omnia. Their republication here is an indication of the persistence of Aristotelian teaching late in the 17th century.
BP_Description_2: <i>Astronomia Physica<i> is in two books. Book 1: On Light and Color; Book 2: On the Nature and Motion of Celestial Bodies. The book on light and color (60 pages) has four chapters. Chapter 1: On the Nature of Light; Chapter 2: On the Motion of Light; Chapter 3: On the Cause of Light; Chapter 4: On the Nature and Diversity of Color.||Chaper 1 presents the Peripatetic theory of light with the distinction between lux and lumen, the Epicurean theory of Gassendi in which light is an effluvium continuously emitted by luminous objects, and the Cartesian in which light an impulse in an aetherial substance that fills the plenum. All are rejected and the Aristotelian theory is defended. Chapter 2 presents light diffusing from all points on a luminous object, until it strikes an opaque surface and is reflected, or a transparent surface and is refracted. Various laws of and mechanisms for refraction are presented. Chapter 3 briefly examens the Aristotelian causes of light and the nature of vision. Chapter 4 presents a color theory similar to La Chambre, with color being fixed and inate and the distinguishing between real and apparent colors is incorrect. The number and sequence of colors is also discussed.||The material is presented in the form of a Galilean dialogue involving Simplicius (expressing the views of La Chambre), Meander (expressing the views of Descartes), and Theophilus (the views of Honor√© Fabri). The arguments made by Meander are, by far, the weakest. The presentation is entirely descriptive, no mathematics of any kind is used.||Appended at the end of Book 2 are a series of papers by Petit on the solar eclipse visible from Paris on 14 November 1639, on magnetic dip, and on the system of the world.||De Meteoris et Fossilibus is in two books. Book 1: On Meteorics. Book 2: On the Nature, Cause, and Use of Things Excavated. Book 1 has five chapters: On meteorics in general and their material; On the sources of the heat and salt of the oceans and seas; On the influence of the ground and air; Fiery meteorics; The rainbow, corona, and other apparent influences. Book 2 has 12 chapters: The principles and causes of fossils in general; Types of earth; On salt and niter; Other salts in general; Sulfur and bitumen; Stones in general; Different types of stones; Gems; Metals in general; Separation of precious metals; Preparation of metals; Uses of metals. The Aristotelian views of La Chambre on nature of light, color, and the rainbow are aggressively presented, and those of Descartes weakly so. All in the form of a classic scholastic dialog involving Menander, Simplicius, and Theophilus.
BP_Reference(s): De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Duhamel en Vossius in de periode 1640‚Äì1670 (in Dutch)|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.||<i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, 376 pp, NB: pp 228-230.||De kleurtheorie van de Aristotelianen en de opvattingen van De la Chambre, Duhamel en Vossius in de periode 1640‚Äì1670|MacLean, J.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Vol 10, 1968, pp 209-225.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Presentation of a long series of experiments and analyses probing the cause, nature, and appearance of color. Mariotte presents correct theories for atmospheric halos and arcs but famously fails to replicate Newton's Experimentum Crucis.
BP_Description_1: <i>La Nature des Couleurs<i> has its origin in experimental work Mariotte began in 1677 on the rainbow, lenses, and effects of small apertures, and the reports of this work he began presenting to the French Royal Academy of Sciences in 1678 . In 1679 Pierre de Carcavi, mathematician and secretary of the National Library of France, proposed that Mariotte, along with mathematician and astronomer Philippe de La Hire and astronomer Jean Picard produce a full treatise on optics for the Academy. Though the collaboration never took place, Mariotte was prompted to present a draft of <i>La Nature des Couleurs<i> to the Academy later that same year. He continued to work for two years on what would become his 'Fourth Essay on Physics', publishing it in 1681.||<i>La Nature des Couleurs<i> presents an extensive catalog of experimental results on refraction, prismatic colors, the composition, shape, and intensity of spectra, and the geometric conditions involved. Using these results, Mariotte examined Descartes' proposal of variously rotating particles, Newton's proposal of the heterogeneity of white light, and the much older idea that light is modified by interaction with material such as water or glass. Descartes' rotating particles imply color patterns contrary to observation and Newton's demonstration of the monochromatic nature of already-dispersed light--his famed 'experimentum crucis'--fails to be duplicated. Rejecting these theories, Mariotte adopts eight behaviors he observed in his experiments and treats them as principles. These, in turn, are then used to account for various optical phenomena, culminating in his complete account of the rainbow. Mariotte's work on the rainbow typifies the care, detail, and craftsmanship he brought to experiments, by which he found, for example, the effect that temperature had on water and air's index of refraction and so explaining variations in the rainbow's angular size.||Mariotte's reputation as an experimenter was unequaled and unquestioned, and so his conclusion that 'the ingenious hypothesis of Mr. Newton must not be accepted' became, in France at lease, the last word on the subject. Mariotte's experiment and conclusion would long be cited, referenced as late as 1713 in the Acta Eruditorum and beginning with the 3rd edition of Du Hamel's <i>Philosophia Vetus Et Nova<i> which was in wide use until 1700. It would not be until 1715 and John Theophilus Desaguliers' successful demonstration of the Newtonian experiment to a delegation from the French Academy, that the Newtonian notion of heterogeneous light was reconsidered in France. In his preface to 1720 edition of his French translation of the Opticks, Pierre Coste reported that Desaguliers' experimental demonstration was successfully repeated in Paris in 1719. That, and Coste's book itself, marks the time when the long-standing effect of Mariotte's experiment ended.||Editions appeared at Paris in 1681 and in the Oeuvres at The Hague in 1740.
BP_Description_2: <i>La Nature des Couleurs<i> is in two parts. The first and longest deals with the origin of colors generated by refraction, the attempt to establish principles, and the subsequent application to meteoric optical phenomena, including halos and the rainbow. the second part is a compilation and overview of object colors.||The first part begins with four 'suppositions' and accompanying 'explications'  that review the basic aspects of reflection and refraction at the interface of transparent material of different density. This is followed by three experiments, each with many parts, that demonstrate the generation of colors by refraction. It is here that Mariotte repeated some of Newton's color experiments, replicating most of them. But he also tested color dispersion in two steps and found that the second appeared to further modify or separate colors, prompting the rejection of Newton's hypothesis of heterogeneous white light. Mariotte admits to establishing no general laws (he considers the sine law of refraction as unproven) but allows that experimentation establishes eight principles that can subsequently be used in the analysis of refractive optical phenomena. The most extensive and detailed (by far) of these is that of the rainbow, but coronas, halos, and false suns are considered as well.||The second part is considerably briefer than the first, less detailed, less organized and not driven by application. It is in four discourses and is essentially a compilation of what was known about surface colors.||For Mariotte, there are two types of colors: fixed or permanent, and apparent. The former is object color, the latter is that produced by light's modification by a prism or drop of water. Colors produced by refraction remain a phenomenon of light-modification, caused by interaction with transparent substances and not, as Newton had it, the manifestation of varying intrinsic properties that refraction separates. For Mariotte, primary colors were red, blue, and yellow, with 'blue' used for what Newton named 'indigo' and green not being primary but blue and yellow mixed.
BP_Reference(s): La Trait√© de la nature des couleurs, de Mariotte|Acloque, C.|In: <i>Mariotte, Savant et Philosophe, Analyse d'une Renomme√©<i>|J. Vrin, Paris, 1986, pp 133-154.||<i>Newton on the Continent<i>|Guerlac, H.|Cornell University Press, 1981, , 169 pp, NB: pp 99-117.||Experimentum Crucis|Lohne, J.A.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 23, No 2, 1968, pp 169-199.||When Huygens and Mariotte agree|Tape, W.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 47, No 34, 2008, pp 85-90.||The Reception of Newton's Optical Work|Shapiro, A.E.|In: The Reception of Isaac Newton in Europe, Pulte, H., Mandelbrote, S., editors, Bloomsbury Academic, 2019, 1004 pp, NB: pp 415-417.||Edme Mariotte 1620-1684|Davies, B.|<i>Physics Education<i>, Vol 9, No 4, 1975,  pp 275-278.

BP_Title English Translation: Fourth Essay: On the Nature of Colors.
BP_Biographical Statement: French cleric, natural philosopher, and early member of L'Acad√©mie des Sciences. Wide-ranging, prolific author.
BP_Provenance: Charles de Liniere' inscribed on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Developed from notes left by Ignace-Gaston Pardies, a consideration of the propagation of light. The propagation of light is conceived as traveling waves, but other aspects of light and color are treated in the way of Aristotle.
BP_Description_1: Pierre Ango's <i>L'Optique<i> is based on a manuscript written by his coreligionist Ignace Gaston Pardies. The manuscript, begun around 1670 and title 'On the Motion of Undulations', is mentioned by Pardies in the Preface to his <i>La Statique<i> of 1673. He mentions conjectures on the propagation of light, proposing aethereal waves analogous to those of sound in air and how such wave would explain many properties of light and colors. The work is referred to in a way that implies it was finished and would be published. Though never published, it was known to Christiaan Huygens and inherited by Pierre Ango.||The result of Ango's simplifying and editing was a consideration of the propagation of light, firmly grounded in the analogy to sound and water waves, based on Pardies' own research into harmonic motion. Beginning with an analogy to sound, the propagation of light is conceived as traveling waves and the propagation, reflection, and refraction are analyzed using the properties of waves. Central to this analysis was Pardie's association of light rays with the perpendiculars to wave fronts. Included in the application of wave-front analysis was a demonstration of the sine law of refraction. Though waves were central to the analysis of propagation, other aspects of light and color were treated in the way of Aristotle and shows Pardies eclecticism involving Aristotle, Descartes, Gassendi, and others.||Importantly, though Pardies' theory of light was a significant advance, it was but one application of his general theory of undulations which was, in turn, part of Pardies' studies in mechanics, and so was purely kinematic.
BP_Description_2: Pierre Ango's editing of Ignace Gaston Pardies optics manuscript is in three books. Book 1: Properties of light explained by wave motion. Book 2: How vision is accomplished. Book 3: Methods to aid and perfect vision.||Book 1 begins by using water waves to establish the properties of wave propagation. Reflection at planar and curves surfaces, rectilinear propagation, and what would now be called superposition. Reflectors of conic sections were used to demonstrate that undulations produced such surfaces well-known focal properties. A long section on sound waves follows, including a derivation of the sine law of refraction. Finally, light is presented as undulations produced by luminous bodies in the all-pervading aether. Like air and water waves, undulations are presented as purely local displacements, no transport of material, be it air, water, or aether, takes place. Luminous rays are associated with perpendiculars to wave fronts. Color is treated in the peripatetic manner: that is it is the result of the mixing of white and black. Book 2 presents a Cartesian explanation of vision, beginning with a consideration of refraction, the focal properties of lenses, and image generation. Book 3 builds on the material in Book 2, considering the images received by the eye that are produced by single and multiple lenses, of both convex and concave figure. This includes the telescope, microscope, and spectacles. The material in Books 2 and 3 is descriptive only, no mathematical analysis is presented.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Kinematic Optics: A Study of the Wave Theory of Light in the Seventeenth Century|Shapiro, A.E.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2/3, 1973, pp 134-266, NB: pp 209-218.||The Analogy between Light and Sound in the History of Optics from the ancient Greeks to Isaac Newton. Part 2|Darrigol, O.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 52, No 3, 2010, pp 206-257.||<i>Theories of Light from Descartes to Newton<i>|Sabra, I.A.|Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1981, pp 185-197.||

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A universal course in philosophy in four volumes covering: logic, metaphysics; moral philosophy; general physics; and special physics. Disputations are presented which consider the old and new views of Aristotle, Gassendi, and Descartes.
BP_Description_1: Du Hamel's <i>Philosophia Vetus Et Nova<i> has its origins in the general course he taught at the Coll√©ge du Plessis in the 1660s and 1670s. By the late 1670s, the alarm caused by the rise of the teaching of Cartesian mechanical philosophy in France prompted church, school, and king to attempt to stem the tide. French minister Jean-Baptiste Colbert ordered DuHamel's course material to be published as a textbook for colleges. It would be widely used for 25 years. Though generally a reactionary, DuHamel's work in natural philosophy was characterized by accommodation of old and new ideas, producing a mix of the Peripatetic and the Cartesian. Thus, De Hamel's text presents modern natural philosophical phenomena and concepts supported by an eclectic blur of Descartes' mechanical analogies and metaphysics, and Scholastic forms and distinctions. For many of the details regarding phenomena and concepts, Du Hamel refers the reader to Jacques Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>.||Published in four volumes, the <i>Philosophia Vetus Et Nova<i> was a universal course in philosophy covering logic, metaphysics, moral philosophy, and general and special physics. All material is presented in the form of disputations.||Editions appeared at Paris in 1678, 1681, 1682, 1684, 1687, at Nuremburg in 1682, at London in 1685, at Amsterdam in 1700, and at Venice in 1704, 1730, 1736. This edition of 1682 is a reprinting of the first of 1678.
BP_Description_2: <i>Philosophia Vetus Et Nova<i> is in four volumes. Vol 1 covers logic, metaphysics; Vol 2 covers moral philosophy; Vol 3 covers general physics; Vol 4 covers special physics. All material is presented in the form of disputations. Special Physics is in three parts, Part 1: The Earth and the Heavens covered in 3 Tracts; Part 2: On Living Bodies and the Senses including meteorics and the rainbow covered in 4 Tracts; Part 3: Animate objects and senses covered in 3 Tracts.||The rainbow is described in Chapter 11, Tract 2, Part 1. After a brief consideration of the nature of refraction, the explanations of Descartes and Mariotte of the rainbow are given, with light refracted by and reflected in rain drops and color resulting from light mixing and interacting with water. Vision is described in Chapters 5-7, Dissertation 3, Tract 1, Part 3. The ocular anatomy is from Christoph Scheiner and the visual process from Descartes. Finally, aspects of perception are considered, including perceptions of distance and size. Optics and the nature of light is described in Chapters 5-10, Dissertation 4 of Tract 1, Part 3. The nature of light is described in Scholastic terms, including the transmission of visual species. Reflected light is treated with Euclidian geometry and refracted light with Descartes' ideas and used to describe the action of lenses. Rays are traced through lenses to show how telescopes and microscopes produced magnified images. Finally, some color phenomena are presented from Mariotte's and Boyle's books on the subject. Color is described as disturbed or mixed light, having interacted with water or glass. In all cases, the treatment is elementary but thorough and contemporary, and is often a hybrid of Aristotle, Gassendi, and Descartes.
BP_Reference(s): The Moment of No Return: The University of Paris and the Death of Aristotelianism|Brockliss, L.|<i>Science & Education<i>, Vol 15 No 2-4,  2006, pp 259‚Äì278.
