BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Leibnitz's article in the Acta Eruditorum deriving the equal angle law of reflection and the sine law of refraction from his assumption that light travels that path, among all possible paths, that offers the least 'resistance.'
BP_Description_1: Leibnitz's article in the Acta Eruditorum of 1682 is the second time he published on the question of the principle for optical laws. His <i>Leges Reflexionis et Refractionis Demonstratae<i> of 1671 attempted a ballistic explanation--successful for reflection but not for refraction. In the Acta Eruditorum article of 1682, Leibniz abandons any consideration of mechanics and derives the equal angle law of reflection and the sine law of refraction from his assumption that 'light shining from a point arrives at an illuminated point by the easiest of all ways.' This is given as 'the first principle of optics.' Geometry and differential calculus are used to show how the principle leads to both optical laws and so Leibniz calls it a 'unitary principle.' He sided with Pierre Fermat against most Cartesians and assumed the slower speed of light in denser materials. Leibniz's innovation is to invoke the 'ease' of a light path: the distance of a path multiplied by its resistance. This is distinct from the shortest path. Leibniz's approach can be considered that of 'optimality', as opposed to a Cartesian mechanical one. Leibnitz is gratified that his analysis leads to Snell's sine law of refraction and even though Descartes' analysis came to the same end, it is considered flawed because of its mechanical foundation. Leibnitz's article opens the dispute on the principle of least action in the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: Leibnitz's article in the <i>Acata Eruditorum<i> derives the equal angle law of reflection and the sine law of refraction from the assumption that 'light shining from a point arrives at an illuminated point by the easiest of all ways.' The assumptions is stated at the very beginning of the article and is considered a first principle. As part of this principle, the 'ease' of a light path is defined as the distance of a path multiplied by its resistance. For the case of reflection, geometry is used to express the path length between the source and illuminated points as a function of possible points on reflecting plane. Minimization using differentiation gives the path of greatest 'ease' and which exhibits equal angles of incidence and reflection, a result known since Euclid and verifying Leibniz's method. For the case of refraction, the source and illuminated points are in media of difference densities, and to the 'ease' of any path must take into account by summing two paths, each in a different medium. Geometry is again used to establish a function that expresses the total 'ease' of the path as the point on the media boundary is moved. Minimization by differentiation is used again to find the path. and it accords with the sine law of refraction. Importantly, Leibniz's procedure gives the correct result regardless of which medium is the more dense.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Optics, Catoptrics and Dioptrics from a Single Principle<i>|Bruce, I., Translator and editor, 2014|http://www.17centurymaths.com/contents/leibnizcontents.html||Leibnitz on Optics|McDonough, J.K.|In: <i>The Oxford Handbook of Leibniz<i>|Sprinter, 2014.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: La Hire's work on conic sections, with the significant use of Descartes' analytic geometry.
BP_Description_1: La Hire was a pupil of Girard Desargues and this work on conic sections is based on the teaching of Desargues. La Hire had published earlier works on curves and conic sections: the <i>Nouvelle m√©thode en g√©om√©trie pour les sections des superficies coniques et cylindriques<i> of 1673 and the <i>Nouveaux √©l√©ments des sections coniques: Les lieux g√©om√©triques: Les constructions ou effections des √©quations<i> of 1679. The present work is a culmination and extension of La Hire's work in the field of conic sections and the significant application of Descartes' analytic geometry. In his Preface La Hire writes of his decision to write the present work: 'I had decided to dispose in a safe order, what had been discovered by me a few years before and I had tried at the same time to bring together what I had encountered in the writings of the ancients and the moderns, who turned with praise to this greater part of Geometry.'
BP_Description_2: La Hire provided an exposition of the properties of conic sections. He began with their focal definitions and applied Cartesian analytic geometry to the study of equations and the solution of indeterminate problems; he also displayed the Cartesian method for solving certain types of equations by intersections of curves. La Hire's work summarizes the progress achieved in analytical geometry during half a century and contained some interesting ideas, among them the possible extension of space to more than three dimensions. Particularly important for optics was La Hire's work on catacaustics.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ 'Les sections coniques chez Philippe de La Hire|≈†√çR, Z.|Dissertation, Universit√© Paris & Universit√© Charles - Prague, 2002, 270 pp. Online: http://www.karlin.mff.cuni.cz/~sir/papers/These.pdf||'Conic Sections in Early Modern Europe. Second Part: Philippe de la Hire on Conics|Baltus, C.|In: <i>Collineations and Conic Sections<i>|Springer, 2020, pp 71-86.|'The work of Tschirnhaus, La Hire and Leibniz on catacaustics and the birth of the envelopes of lines in the 17th century'|Scarpello G.M., Scimone, A.|<i>Archives for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 59, No 3, 2005, pp 223-250.
BP_Title: Sectiones conicae in novem libros distributae, in quibus quidquid hactenus observatione dignum cuÃÄm aÃÄ veteribus, tuÃÄm aÃÄ recentioribus geometris traditum est, novis contractisque demonstrationibus explicatur; Multis etiam & exquisitis propositionibus recens inventis illustratur. Accesserunt sectiones pyramidum super basibus parabolicis ellipticis, & hyperbolicis, und cum sectionibus cylindrorum, quibus substernuntur circuli, aut conic√¶ sectionibus. Cum appendice de sectionibus conicis omnium generum, eadem & universali methodo, ac magna facilitate demonstratis, & alii curvis ex iisdem fontibus deductis. Adjecta demum est brevis expositio propositionum septem librorum conicorum Apollonii Perg√¶i, qu√¶ cum superius demonstratis conferuntur. Autore PH. de la Hire Regio Matheseos Professore & Regiae Scientiarum Academiae Socio.
BP_Title English Translation: Conic Sections divided into Nine Books. In which whatever worthy observations of the ancients as well as those reported from more recent geometers, new and brief demonstrations  are set forth. And many exquisite and recently discovered propositions are illustrated. Added are sections on the pyramids with elliptical, parabolic and hyperbolic bases, along with a section on cylinders which are from circles, or conic sections. With an appendix on the generation of all conic sections, the same by a universal method of great utility is described, as well as other curves drawn from the same source. And finally, adding a brief explanation of propositions of the Seven Books of Conics of Apollonius of Perga, that have been consulted in the above demonstrations. Authored by P.H. La Hire, Royal Mathematics Professor and member of the Royal Academy of Sciences.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Heizo Buscher (1564-1598) German cleric, mathematician, natural philosopher.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Aristotelian manual of natural philosophy. The brief section on optics is a list of statements and assertions regarding vision, light, shade, reflection, and refraction.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Philosophia Compendiosa<i> has its origins in Christoph Scheibler's years of teaching  the University of Giessen beginning in 1610, his belief that clerical magistrates should oversee the teaching in schools, and his Lutheran Protestantism. Scheibler wrote a text that was intended to accompany a complete course in philosophy, providing the barest overview of the several areas it covered. Early editions had the subtitle of 'Presenting A Synopsis of Philosophy', which accurately described the overview it presented. With the exception of Arithmetic, subjects are presented in a Spartan, numbered march of statements with no discussion. The logic, ethics, physics, metaphysics, and optics are entirely Scholastic.||The book saw many editions and was widely used. It was the principal text at Oxford for undergraduate arts courses for many years. Editions appeared at Marburg in 1623, 1628, 1634, 1639, at Oxford in 1631, 1647, 1657, 1671, at London in 1685.
BP_Description_2: Aristotelain manual of natural philosophy. The brief section on optics is a list of statements and assertions regarding vision, light, shade, reflection, and refraction.
BP_Reference(s): Hobbes, the universities and the history of philosophy|Serjeantson, W.|In: <i>The Philosopher in Early Modern Europe<i>|Condren, C.,  Gaukroger, S., Hunter, I., editors|Cambridge University Press, 2006, 302 pp, NB: pp 113-139.
BP_Title: Philosophia Compendiosa, exhibnes, 1. Logicae, 2, Metaphysicae, 3. Physicae, 4. Geometriae, 5. Astronomiae, 6. Opticae, 7. Ethicae, 8. Politicae, 9. Occonnomicae. Compendium Methodicum. Authore Christophoro Scheiblero Logicae & Methaphysize professore. Editio Decima prioribus muto correctior, & variis in locis, praecipue in Logica, aliquantulum auctior. Huic Editioni 1. Praefigitur TechnolgiaProemialis. 2. Annectirur Arithmetica plenior quam fuit illa Heizonis Bushcheri prius annexa.
BP_Title English Translation: Succinct Philosophy, Exhibiting 1. Logic, 2, Metaphysic, 3. Physic, 4. Geometry, 5. Astronomy, 6. Optics, 7. Ethics, 8. Politics, 9.Econnomics. In Brief Summaries. Author: Christoph Scheibler, Professor of Logic & Methaphysics. Tenth edition, much corrected, & in various places augmented, principally in Logic. In this Edition: 1. Prefaced with Technical Preliminaires. 2. Annexed with an Arithmetic which has been made fuller than it was before by Heizo Bushcher.
BP_Biographical Statement: German academic, Aristotelian scholastic, influeneital textook author. Taught at the University of Giessen.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Bookplate and blind stamp of the Macclesfield Library

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A beginner‚Äôs introduction to physics, with material presented in brief question and paragraph answer form. The small sections on vision and the nature of light are principally Aristotelian, with a mention of Descartes' notion of a 'tendency to motion' regarding light propagation.
BP_Description_1: The 'Methodo Erotematica' of the title describes the methods of presentation: by asking and answering rhetorical questions. The <i>Compendium Physic√¶<i> is essentially a dictionary of natural philosophy, written for beginners, and designed to give an overview of many topics, without resorting to technical details or to mathematics. The 'Brief and Succinct Theater of Theoretical Philosophy' serves as an introduction and gives an elementary overview of Aristotelian philosophy, method, categories, and terms. Its 59 numbered paragraphs are each devoted to a single idea, word, or concept. Editions after 1691 did not include this introduction. In the peripatetic manner, physics is divided into general and particular, and for many, thought not all, topics, both the Aristotelian and Cartesian idea or theory is presented. Schweitzer's text merely presents and describes, there is no disputation about or siding with either the Aristotelian or the Cartesian.||Editions appeared at Amsterdam and Basel in 1685, at London 1687, at Basel in 1691, at Amsterdam in 1695, at Marburg in 1696, at Frankfurt in 1709, 1715, and at Link√∂ping in 1725.
BP_Description_2: The book contains a series of short questions on various subjects which are answered in a (usually) very short paragraph.  Though the range of subjects considered in this question-answer process is considerable, in keeping with the book's intent, nothing is considered in detail. Subjects include air, animals, water, metals, comets, solar and lunar eclipses, stars, the elements, herbs, man, light, magnets, clouds and rain, planets, the Earth, minerals, and light and vision. The order of presentation has only a very slight structure, so the index is essential for using the book.||The brief material on light is a hybrid of the Aristotelian distinction between lux and lumen, and the Cartesian idea of percussive propagation and vortices. Similarly, a hybrid of luminous rays and visual species is used to describe the visual process. All material is qualitatively descriptive; there is no mathematics nor are figures used.
BP_Reference(s): A book from the collection of John Ellis (c. 1710‚Äì1776), naturalist, now in the library of Isaac Norris held in Dickinson College, Pennsylvania, USA|Wyse Jackson, P.N.|<i>Annals of Bryozoology 2: Aspects of the History of Research on Bryozoans<i>|International Bryozoology Association, Dublin, 2008, 442 pp, NB: pp 427-434.|http://www.researchgate.net/publication/264383617_A_book_from_the_collection_of_John_Ellis_c_1710-1776_naturalist_now_in_the_library_of_Isaac_Norris_held_in_Dickinson_College_Pennsylvania_USA
BP_Title: Compendium Physic√¶ Aristotelico-Cartesian√¶. in usum tironum methodo erotematica adornatum.: cui pr√¶figitur breve & succinctum philosophi√¶ theoretic√¶ theatrum.
BP_Title English Translation: A Compendium of Aritotelian-Cartesean Physics, Prepared for the use of Beginners by the Method of Questions. To which is attached a brief and succinct Theater of Theoretical Philosophy.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss cleric, teacher, pastor. Written works appeared under a misleading array of pseudonyms.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp of the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A treatise on Galenic and Aristotelian optics tucked between an astrological casting for 1685 and a Christian chronology.
BP_Description_1: Beginning in the 1660s, the Jesuits at the University Trnava, Hungary (now Slovakia) began publishing calendars that included astrological prognostications and a surprisingly long educational treatise or dissertation. Initially these were written by Johann Misch SJ, using the pseudonym 'Astrophilus.' Beginning in 1675, this annual task was assumed by M√°rton Szentiv√•nyi SJ, who maintained the same pseudonym, Astrophilus. The treatises Szentiv√•nyi wrote to accompany the calendars where pedagogical works of considerable erudition. The <i>Dissertatio Optica Physico-Mathematica<i>, along with other treatises on natural philosophical subjects, would be collected and reprinted in the Curiositora et Selectiora Variarum Scientiarum Miscellanea appearing at Trnava in 1691.
BP_Description_2: A treatise on optics covering ocular anatomy, vision, light's nature and propagation, color, catoptrics, and dioptrics. The anatomy is Galenic and the optics Aristotelian. Presentation is in the form of questions and answers and disputations, with a treatment that is entirely qualitative.
BP_Reference(s): Johann Misch Astrophilus Nagyszombatban (in Hungarian)|Gabor, K.F.|<i>Magyar K√∂nyvszemle<i> (Hungarian Book Review), Vol 121, No 2, 2005, pp 140-166.||http://epa.oszk.hu/00000/00021/00045/Ksz2005-2-02.ht
BP_Title: Dissertatio optica  In: Calendarium tyrnaviense Anni 1685
BP_Title English Translation: Optical Disseration
BP_Biographical Statement: Hungarian Jesuit, teacher at the University of Luxemburg. Wrote astrological tracts anonymously and prolifically.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Frontispiece inserted at front. <i>Dissertatio Optica<i> in E-K‚Å¥

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A complete treatment of the construction and use of lensed optical instruments. Presented in three 'Fundamenta', that is, bases: The physical, the mathematical, and the practical or mechanical.
BP_Description_1: In his Preface to the reader, Johannes Zahn adopts the word 'Teledioptrica' to indicate generally the art, craft, science, and practice of using lenses to extend, enhance, and correct vision. For Zahn, teledioptrics includes magnification by telescope and microscope, vision correction by spectacles, image capture by the camera obscura, and image projection by the magic lantern. He cites the benefits that teledioptrics has brought to man in peace, war, natural philosophy, economy, and medicine. And so, he makes clear the purpose and reason for his book: to describe in a full and complete form, all aspects of teledioptrics. The presentation is in three 'bases': the physical or natural basis including the eye, vision, color, the nature of light, and image formation; the mathematical basis of dioptrics including refraction, materials, lens design, compound lenses, and images from lenses; and the practical or mechanical basis including lens figuring, grinding and polishing equipment and methods, instrument construction, and the making of spectacles, telescopes, microscopes, camera obscurae, and projectors.||Zahn's references are extensive and he was in clear command of both the theory and practice of dioptrics. His teacher of practical optics (and co-religionist) was the microscopist Johann Franz Griendel von Ach and he is noted throughout the <i>Oculus Artificialis<i>, particularly regarding microscopes and the magic lantern. Griendel, in turn, would recommend the <i>Oculus Artificialis<i> to readers of his Micrographia Nova of 1687. Zahn's first-hand knowledge of practical optics is apparent, and though particularly so in the third Fundamentum, it informs the entire work. The result is an emphasis on application and practice that makes the <i>Oculus Artificialis<i> a handbook of optical instruments. Theory is presented in sufficient detail to make concepts clear and to support applications, but rather than equations for lens design, for example, Zahn provides elaborate tables.||The three Fundamentum appeared in separate volumes, though are usually found bound together. The first and second Fundamenta appeared in 1685, the third in 1686. A second edition appeared in 1702.
BP_Description_2: A synopsis of all three Fundamenta of the work precedes a detailed list of the contents. The first Fundamentum covers the physical basis for teledioptrics and is in three parts. Part 1 includes the nature and structure of the eye and its parts. Part 2 covers the nature and properties of vision and visible objects, including the nature and properties of light, reflection and refraction, and color. Part 3 covers vision itself and the optical function of the eye, including light through small apertures, image formation in the eye, indistinct vision, and aspects of visual perception.||The second Fundamentum covers the mathematical basis of dioptrics and is in three parts. Part 1 covers the materials and forms of transparent materials, suitable for teledioptrics. This includes glass and its properties, refraction in general, refraction in lenses of various figures, foci and image formation, and tables of lens sizes, curvatures, and focal lengths. Part 2 covers the functioning of combination of lenses and their effect of vision (what Zahn terms the 'natural eye'), polygonal lenses, and the construction of a 'material eye'; that is, a model of the human eye and its uses. Part 3 covers the function of various instruments including microscopes, telescopes, polemoscopes, binoculars, the camera obscura, and the magic lantern. The Fundamentum ends with a concise summary and overview of all its material: Refraction in general; the convex lens with its various modes of use and applications; the concave lens with its modes and uses; the meniscus lens; the focal properties of spheres and half-spheres; combinations of convex lenses; combinations of concave and convex lenses; microscopes; 'optical tubes' in general; telescopes of various types.||The third Fundamentum covers the practical and mechanical aspects of teledioptric instruments and is in five parts. Part 1 covers the grinding of convex and concave spherical surfaces, including the processes, equipment, and machines. Part 2 covers the properties of glass, figuring and polishing surfaces, and non-spherical figures. Part 3 covers the use and application of multiple lenses in various optical instruments, including microscopes, telescopes, and spectacles. This part includes aspects of the metal works required for optical instruments. Part 4 is devoted to astronomical telescopes, including aspects of their construction and use. Part 5 is devoted to microscopes and to magic lanterns and other optical projections, including horological applications.||The ocular anatomy of Fundamentum 1 reflects the latest contemporary knowledge, and although the physical optics presented is Peripatetic, (Descartes is not mentioned), luminous rays emerge has the principle, practical description of light. They are used as the mechanism to explain vision and the camera obscura. Theory regarding refraction at the beginning of Fundamentum 2 is very brief and is quoted from Maignon and Dechales; practical measurement aspects come from Kepler. Though the sine law of refraction is quoted, tables of angles of refraction are given, in keeping with the handbook-nature of the work. The general geometric optical properties of lenses are derived in detail using the sine law, trigonometry, and geometry to relate surface radius and focal point. The practical result are the magnification and image-place properties of lenses, which are presented in tables. The section on the effects of multiple lenses, including that of the eye, is particularly detailed and considers spectacles for indistinct vision and magnification by lenses. Fundamentum 2 concludes with a description of an optical model of the human eye, followed by a long series of applications of magnification and image-placement properties of lenses to optical instruments. Interestingly, the Fundamentum ends with a outline summary of all the material it contains. Though Zahn cites Cherubin d'Orleans extensively in Fundementum 3, it is clear that it is not just a compilation of other works but is informed by Zahn's own experience making optical instruments. This includes all aspects of lens making including glass, grinding, figuring and polishing, the use of hand tools, various machines and lathes, and lens testing. Detailed construction instructions and examples are given for microscopes, survey and astronomical telescopes, binoculars, solar projectors, elaborate camerae obscurae, and magic lanterns.
BP_Reference(s): Projecting Nature in Early-Modern Europe|Gorman, M.J.|In: <i>Inside the Camera Obscura ‚Äì Optics and Art under the Spell of the Projected Image<i>|Max Planck Institute for the History of Science Prepint 333, 2007, pp 31-50.||<i>A Survey of the Newtorks Bringing a Knowledgge of Optical Glass-Working to the Londong Trade, 1500-1800<i>|Mc Connell, A.|Whipple Museum of the History of Science, 2016||The origins of the magic lantern in Germany: an example of the use and mis-use oftechnological argument in media history|Rossell, D.|In: <i>Die Medien und ihre Technik. Theorien - Modelle - Geschichte<i>, Marburg, 2004, pp 221-234.||Notes on the early history of microscopy|Singer, C.|<i>Proceedings of the Royal Society of Medicine<i>, Vol 7, 1914, pp 247-279.||The Binocular Microscope of the Seventeenth Century|West, C.E.|In: <i>Proceedings of the American Society of Microscopists<i>, Vol 12, Thirteenth Annual Meeting, 1890, pp 57-66.
BP_Title: Oculus Artificialis Teledioptricus Sive Telescopium. Ex Abditis rerum Naturalium & Artificialium principiis protractum nova methodo, eaque solida explicatum ac comprimis e triplici Fundamento: Physico seu Naturali, Mathematico Dioptrico, Et Mechanico, seu Practico stabilitum. Opus curiosum Practico-Theoricum magna rerum varietate adornatum, multorum votis diu expetitum, omnibus Artium novarum studiosis perquam utile: quo Philosophiae atque Mathesi praesertim mixtae, nec non universo pene hominum statui amplissimis adjumentis consulitur; nova plurima abstrusa curiosa Technasmata recluduntur, ipsaque Ars Telescopiaria facillime addiscenda, ac sumptibus non adeo magnis in praxin adducenda proponitur, adeoque Telescopium ex tenebris in lucem asseritur.
BP_Title English Translation: Teledioptric Artificial Eye, or: The Telescope. By which the Hidden Origins of Natural and Artificial are Things Brought to Light by a New Method, and the Whole Set Out and Compressed into a Three-Fold Established Basis: Physical or Natural, Mathematically  Dioptrical, and Mechanical or Practical. A Careful, Theoretical-Practical Work, Providing a Great Variety of Things, at the Wishes of Many and Long Desired, Extremely Useful to all Students of the New Arts. In Which is Consulted Philosophy and Mathematics, especially Mixed (mathematics), and also by the Help of almost all of Abundant Human Standing. Many New Hidden Technical Curiosities are Disclosed. And so the Art of Telesocpy is Easily Learned and the Cost of the Proposed Practice not so great that from the darkness, the Telescope is brought to Light.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Premonstratensian canon, oculist. Wrote knowingly and extensively on optics, credulously on natural history.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reprinting of the <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> and the <i>Nova Visionis Theoria<i> of 1685.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 168. Both the  <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> and the <i>Nova Visionis Theoria<i> appeared again at Amsterdam in 1686. The <i>Ophthalmo-graphia<i> and <i>Nova Visionis Theoria<i> were read and praised by Isaac Newton and was the source of his knowledge of ocular anatomy and visual physiology. Though the fundamentally mechanical idea of nerve vibration was an innovation of Briggs, his idea of corresponding image points in the two eyes, and what this meant for binocular vision, proved be to a far more durable idea.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 168.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 168.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third edition of a collection of brief expositions or conversations on a wide range of subjects for use in Jesuit grammar schools. The optics section is very concise; little more than a long list of definitions and statements. At the end is a Latin-German dictionary.
BP_Description_1: Pexenfelder's <i>Apparatus Eruditionis<i> is the result of his long teaching experience at the Jesuit Gymnasium in Bavaria. The book is as much an exercise in Latin vocabulary and grammar as it is an elementary encyclopedia. The intended audience clearly was young students and the method of instruction deeply informed by Pexenfelder's experience. The material is presented in the form of conversations between teacher and pupil with the intention of building an extensive and detailed vocabulary and so providing the ability to read learned works--thus the title, <i>Apparatus of Erudition<i>. Words and things are explained at the same time, using clear language in brief passages.||The material is presented in an order that reflects the medieval 'Great Chain of Being', beginning with the inanimate, then plants, animals, man and his many characteristics and activities, and finally theology.||Editions appeared at N√ºrnburg in 1670, at Sutlzbach in 1680, 1682, 1687, 1704, at Basel in 1744, and expanded by Benito Monfort at Valencia in 1798. Up to 1744, the editions were virtually unchanged, attesting to the utility and popularity of the work.
BP_Description_2: Third edition of Pexenfelder's <i>Apparatus Eruditionis<i>, a collection of brief expositions in the form conversations on a wide range of subjects for use in Jesuit grammar schools. It contains 101 chapters. 1: Introduction; 11-14: Plants; 15-19: Animals; 20-31: Man; 32-38: Agriculture and housekeeping; 39-43: Crafts; 44-47: Locomotion; 48: Sensory perception; 49-60: Liberal arts; 61-67: Measurement, Coins, Optics, Earth and Sky Description, Timing; 68-69: History; 70-74: Moral teaching; 75-78: Higher faculties; 79-82: Household nature and economy; 83-91: Constitution, Customs, Trade; 92-97: Religion; 98-100: Symbols; 101: Conclusion||Chapter 64 is on optics and is very concise; little more than an long list of definitions and statements. Optics is presented as the science of sight, involving light, color, and shadow. Sight is the reception of visual species, received either directly, by reflection, or by refraction. The action of mirrors is briefly considered, but lenses are not.||Apparatus Eruditionis ends with Latin-German and German-Latin dictionaries.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Bernhard Albinus (1653 - 1721) German physician
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The history of the discovery of phosphorus. A dissertation defended by Christoph Kletwich under the direction of Bernard Albinus, father to the famed German anatomist.
BP_Description_1: This is one of several theses written in the 17th century dealing with 'Things that Shine in the Night.' Characteristically, they were written by university men and were typically commentaries on and collections of observations that other made.
BP_Description_2: The thesis deals principally with the element phosphorus and its discoverers and investigators: Henning Brandt, J. D. Krafft, and Robert Boyle. Little is said of the other phosphors that were known at the time. In this thesis, Kletwich describes 40 experiments dealing with phosphor, some conducted in a vacuum and making use of a pump patterned after Boyle's.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of Luminescence<i>|Harvey, E.N.|American Philosophical Society, Philadelphia, 1957, 692 pp, NB:  pp 124.

BP_Short or Common Title: Kurtze Anweisung Die Glasser zu schleiffen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An anonymous work on the techniques of lens grinding and polishing for telescopes, eyeglasses, and other instruments.
BP_Description_1: An anonymous work on the techniques of lens grinding and polishing for telescopes, eyeglasses, and other instruments. There are references to Schott, Kircher, and Schyrlaeus de Rheita. The work also deals very briefly with matters of 'perspective'--actually anamorphosis. The material is devoted entirely to the craft of lens making. The text is highly detailed and clearly was written by someone familiar with lens-craft. Materials, griding and figuring machines, polishing, and lens testing are described. More than 60 figures accompany the text.||It was a popular, practical guide to the craft and mechanics of lens making. Christiaan Huygens library had a copy. This must have become something of a standard work; it was in print for more than 60 years. Editions appeared at Dresden in 1680, 1689, 1718, and 1741. Usually bound with Johann Georg Leutmann's <i>Neue Anmerckungen vom Glasschleiffen<i> that first appeared in 1718 and reviewed in the Acta Eruditorum of August 1719.
BP_Description_2: The book has three chapters. Chapter 1: Geometry required for the purpose of lens making (3 pages). Chapter 2: Conic sections (6 pages). Chapter 3: Grinding, figuring, and polishing lenses. Using them in instruments. (20 pages). Three-part Appendix.
BP_Reference(s): Litteratur der mechanischen und optischen Wissenschaften|Murhard, W.A.|Leipzig, Breitkof & H√§rtel, Vol 5, Part 3, p 125.
BP_Title: Kurtze Anweisung Die Glasser zu schleiffen und Perspective zuzurichten.
BP_Title English Translation: Brief Notes on Glass Grinding and Preparing Perspective
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'Gregory Haller' on the titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> of 1674; a complete course of Mixed Mathematics expressly meant for teaching, it became a popular, widely-used textbook.
BP_Description_1: The origin of Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> was his long experience in teaching Mixed Mathematics, from which he had acquired not only an understanding of the audience for such material but also skill in its presentation. In his Preface, Dechales gives the reason for writing the <i>Cursus<i>: He wanted to produce a work for young students that would be used for self-study, that did not presume a previous knowledge of mathematics, and from which they could learn without the need for a teacher or guide. Dechales' purpose informs the content, style, and order of the work. Most of what he considered necessary in mathematics is presented in the first 400 pages of Tome I. In the rest of the work, geometry and the laws of proportions are used most often, along with a little trigonometry. The presentations are clear, sufficiently detailed, and often accompanied by figures which, though relatively simple wood-cuts, are important to the material. No derivations are given, only statements of results or facts, and though advancing no novelties of his own, Deschales exercises considerable discernment, presenting what he held to be the best of the then-current theories and formulations of the topics covered. He presents (and defends), for example, Galileo‚Äôs theory of motion, but generally rejects Cartesianism.||The second, posthumous edition was overseen by Father Aim√© Varcin, who has been entrusted by Dechales' brother to bring the Cursus back into print. Among the papers in Dechales' estate was an incomplete draft of a history of mathematics. Varcin reworked this and it appears as the 108-page Tractatus Proemialis at the start of Volume 1 of the second edition. Apart from some small additions by Varcin, the second edition is essentially a reprinting of the first, using the same wood blocks for the figures.||That the work was entirely self-contained and gave presentations of great clarity helped make it popular and widely used. It was, for example, still used as a textbook at the University of Upsala early in the 18th century.||Dechales' <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> was reviewed--in the form of a summary--in the Transactions of the Royal Society in Vol 9, No 110, Jan 1675, pp 229-233. Editions appeared 1674 and posthumously, slightly expanded to 4 volumes, in 1690.
BP_Description_2: A complete course of Mixed Mathematics expressly meant for self-study and as an aid to teaching. It covers practical geometry, arithmetic, plane and spherical trigonometry, mechanics, statics, geography, magnetism, military architecture, hydrostatics and fountains, optics, music, pyrotechnics, astrolabes, dialling, astronomy, calendars, algebra, method of indivisibles, and conic sections.||Optics takes up 385 pages of volume 2, presenting Tracts 18-21 covering Optics, Perspective, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, and lastly a Mechanical Digression. The Optics tract is in three books: Suppositions and Vision; Binocular vision; Propagation of Light. The Perspective tract is in six books: Fundamentals; Iconographic projection; Sceneographics; Aspects of linear perspective. The Catoptrics tract is in four books: Plane mirrors; Convex mirrors; Concave mirrors; Cylindrical mirrors. The Dioptrics tract is in two books: Refraction and individual lenses; Combined lenses. The Mechanical Digression covers image locations, refracted colors, and aspects of meteorological phenomena.||The material includes: The eye's structure and function, monocular and binocular vision; the nature, propagation, reflection, and refraction of light; plain and curved mirrors and the images they produce, lenses and multiple lenses and the magnified images they produce; the operation of microscopes and telescopes. Dechales deals only briefly with physical optics, giving reasons for reflection and refraction, and most often in very short sections titled 'Digressio Physica.'  Most of the material is geometric optics and the fundamental quantity is the luminous ray. Dechales gives a competent overview of geometrical optics and images but never presents anything as densely mathematical as Barrow's Optical Lectures. However circumscribed by the intended purpose and audience, Dechales' presentations are remarkably clear, and along the way he introduces the term 'virtual image' as companion to 'real image' and so clarifies the physical meaning of image, uses pencils of rays to qualitatively analyze the position and size of images in lensed optical systems, and accurately describes the operation of the magic lantern.||Though dependent on many sources for his material, Dechales rarely cites them. Dechales' optical material includes some that comes from uncited works by Christoph Scheiner, Bonaventura Cavalieri, Gilles Personne de Roberval, James Gregory, and Francesco Eschinardi.
BP_Reference(s): Images: Real and Virtual, Projected and Perceived, from Kepler to Dechales|Shapiro, A.E.|In: <i>Inside the Camera Obscura ‚Äì Optics and Art under the Spell of the Projected Image<i>|Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Preprint 333, 2007, pp 75-95.||<i>A Philosophical and Mathematical Dictiionary<i>|Hutton, C.|London, 1815, Vol I, pp 395-396.

Second Edition augmented and corrected from the Author's Manuscripts; the Work and Study of Reverend Father Amati Varcin, of the same Society.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Huygens proposes a theory that light is a wave or pulse in an all-pervading aether and mode of propagation now known as Huygens's Principle. The propagation and interference of waves is used to explain the rectilinear propagation of light, its reflection, refraction, and diffraction.
BP_Description_1: The origins of the <i>Trait√© De La Lumiere<i> were, in part, Huygens' treatise on dioptrics he had worked on since the early 1650s, the appearance of Newton's paper on the nature of light in 1672, and Ole R√∏mer's demonstration of light's finite speed in 1676.  With  R√∏mer's announcement, the nature of light came to the fore of scientific debate and theorizing in Europe. Huygens renewed his work on a wave theory of light after R√∏mer's announcement and, apparently while attempting to explain the caustics that refraction can generate, came upon the idea of wavelets and how they form new wave fronts--the basis for his theory of light. As a type of experimentum crucis, Huygens found that this theory could explain double refraction, a perplexing phenomenon exhibited by Icelandic spar and announced by Erasmus Bartholinus in 1669. Critical to Huygens developments was the finite speed of light: ordinary refraction was caused by waves traveling at different speeds in two media, and double refraction in Icelandic spar by differing speeds that depend on the orientation to the crystal axis. As he makes clear, light travels in waves because it travels with a finite speed.||Huygens presented his theory in a series of lectures to the French academy in 1679. Always slow to publish (if ever), Huygens finally saw his theory through the press eleven years later as the <i>Trait√© De La Lumiere<i>. Huygens had criticized Newton for not having had a physical or mechanical underpinning for his theory and so Huygens aim was to give a mathematical-physical explanation of the classical properties of light, based on a mechanism by which waves propagated through a corpuscular, all-pervading aether. The rays of geometrical optics were the perpendiculars to wave fronts, and on this basis most optical phenomena could be explained, including spherical aberration. Huygens acknowledged the work of Ignace Gaston Pardies and Robert Hooke regarding waves but believed that his explanation of double refraction demonstrated the economy, correctness, and explanatory power of this idea. At the same time, however, he acknowledged that he could not explain colors, diffraction, or the phenomenon of polarization.||The <i>Trait√© De La Lumiere<i> fell into obscurity not long after it appeared. After the initial positive reactions of Philippe de la Hire, Denis Papin, and Gottfried Leibniz, and the negative ones of Robert Hooke, Isaac Newton, Edmond Halley, and Johann Bernoulli, the Trait√© De La Lumiere was ignored and then forgotten. It was reviewed in the Acta Eruditorum in 1690 and in the Journal des S√ßavans in 1691. In the later case, the anonymous review clearly did not understand what he read. Generally, the <i>Trait√© De La Lumiere<i> came to be ignored because double refraction came to be ignored. With the rise of Newtonian optics, Huygens work was completely eclipsed. Interest in double refraction, and therefore in the <i>Trait√© De La Lumiere<i> arose again only with the work on crystals and double refraction of Ren√© Ha√ºy of 1788, William Wollaston of 1802, and √âtienne-Louis Malus of 1808, confirming Huygens results for double refraction. Huygens' Principle of wavefronts would be applied to profound effect by Augustin Fresnel in 1814.||This is likely the first issue; the title page contains only Huygens' initials. The second issue presents Huygens' full name.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Traite De La Lumiere<i> is in six chapters. Chapter 1: On Rays Propagated  in Straight Lines. Chapter 2: On Reflection. Chapter 3: On Refraction. Chapter 4: On Refraction of the Air. Chapter 5: On the Strange Refraction of Iceland Crystal. Chapter 6: On the Figures of Transparent Bodies Which Serve for Refraction and Reflection.||Chapter 1 reviews the classic phenomena of optics and how their nature and properties comprise required outcomes for any theory of light. These include rectilinear propagation of rays, equal angle reflection, and the sine law of refraction. The chapter then sets out Huygens' theory of wave propagation: A wave front produces wavelets with all but motion locally perpendicular to the original wave cancel, the cumulative effect leaves a new, advancing wave front. Spherical wave fronts generated in this way radiate from each point on a luminous surface. Rays of light are taken as the perpendiculars to wave fronts. Chapter 2 applies this principle to explain the equal angle law of specular reflection. By invoking the finite speed of light wave travel, the perpendiculars to the series of reflected wave fronts (reflected rays) are are show to make angles with the surface perpendicular that are equal to those of the rays of the incoming waves. Chapter 3 applies the same analysis, based on finite light wave speed to explain the sine law of refraction. Wave front speed is slower in denser media; the denser, the slower. Wave fronts travel more slowly once in the denser medium and a geometric construction shows their perpendiculars (the refracted rays) form an angle with the refracting surface perpendicular whose sine in ratio to that of incident rays is the ratio of the media densities. That is, the sine law of refraction. Chapter 4 applies wave front refraction to atmospheric refraction, showing how it produces curved rays. Chapter 5 explains the double refraction observed in Icelandic spar. In this case, Huygens proposes that refracted waves propagate in two directions in the crystal.   The wavelets for waves propagating in the 'extraordinary' direction are not spherical but elliptical and the resulting non-spherical wave fronts have perpendiculars that are the extraordinary rays of double refraction. Chapter 6 uses wave front analysis to determine ideal figures for reflecting and refracting surfaces. It is here that the cause of spherical aberration is derived. Huygens was a practiced oculist and though he shows the theoretical benefits of elliptical and hyperbolic figures for lenses, he is aware that as a practical matter, they were essentially impossible to produce.||As Ernst Mach made clear, Huygens great advance was to show that the essential features of rectilinear propagation, reflection, and simple and double refraction could all be derived from simply the rate of propagation of light.

BP_Short or Common Title: Curiosa et Selectiora Variarum Scientiarum Miscellanea
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of brief dissertations previously published by the University of Trnava. A brief history of the telescope is given in the dissertation on inventions. The dissertation on optics is a word-for-word resetting of  Szentiv√•nyi's <i>Dissertatio Optica<i> of 1685.
BP_Description_1: Beginning in the 1660s, the Jesuit at the University Trnava, Hungary (now Slovakia) began publishing calendars that included astrological prognostications and a surprisingly long educational treatise or dissertation. Initially these were written by Johann Misch SJ, using the pseudonym 'Astrophilus.' Beginning in 1675, this annual task was assumed by M√°rton Szentiv√•nyi SJ, who maintained the same pseudonym, Astrophilus. The treatises Szentiv√•nyi wrote to accompany the calendars where pedagogical works of considerable erudition. The <i>Dissertatio Optica Physico-Mathematica<i>, along with other treatises on natural philosophical subjects, were collected and reprinted in the Curiositora et Selectiora Variarum Scientiarum Miscellanea appearing at Trnava in 1691.
BP_Description_2: A collection of brief dissertations previously published by the University of Nagyszombat.  They are: geography, islands, caves, mountains, and depths; local properties of the earth; horographic, political, and historical data on the sacred crown of Hungary; gems, disease, optics, newly invented things, the end of the world, doubtful or imaginary things. A brief history of the telescope is given in the dissertation on inventions. The dissertation on optics covers ocular anatomy, vision, light's nature and propagation, color, catoptrics, and dioptrics. The anatomy is Galenic and the optics Aristotelian. Presentation is in the form of questions and answers and disputations, with a treatment that is entirely qualitative.
BP_Reference(s): Johann Misch Astrophilus Nagyszombatban (in Hungarian)|Gabor, K.F.|<i>Magyar K√∂nyvszemle<i> (Hungarian Book Review), Vol 121, No 2, 2005, pp 140-166.||http://epa.oszk.hu/00000/00021/00045/Ksz2005-2-02.ht
BP_Title: Curiosa et Selectiora Variarum Scientiarum Miscellanea. Auctore P. Martino Szent-Jvany, Societatis Jesu Scerdote. Decadis Secundae Part Prima. Cum Facultate Superiorum, & Privilegio Sacra Casarea Regisague Majestatis, Speciali.
BP_Title English Translation: A Miscellany of Curious and Select Branches of Science. Author: Father Martin Szent-Ivany, priest of the Society of Jesus. First Part of the Second Decade. With the Facility of Superiors, and the Special Privilege of His Sacred Royal Majesty.
BP_Biographical Statement: Hungarian Jesuit, mathematician, philosopher. Wrote much in theology but most importantly in natural philosophy.
BP_Printer: Academic Press at Trnava of the Jesuits

BP_Short or Common Title: De varii generis instrumentis cum maximeÃÄ opificum
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A legal-economic work concerning the manufacture, uniformity, and sale of instruments of all types, including optical instruments. Lists of the most important manufacturers of various kinds optical instruments and their usual prices.
BP_Description_1: Beier's book describes the manufacture, uniformity and sale of instruments of all types, and gives the most important manufacturers of various kinds the instruments. One of the purposes of the work is to provide the proper legal terms and definitions to instruments, instrument makers, and anything relating to them. It deals with all types of scientific instruments for craftsmen, tradesmen, manufacturers, professionals, the military, and the navy. Articles deal with everything from musical instruments made of metal (brass & tin), medical instruments, instruments for dental work, barbers, apothecaries, engraving instruments, instruments for writing, bookbinders tools, libraries, tools for making various moving parts, agriculture, metal working, and screw making, Often particular manufacturers are mentioned along with the instruments that they specialized in. In the section on optical instruments he provides an appendix consisting of detailed descriptions of 13 different types of telescopes, microscopes, eyeglasses and other optical instruments with details on the range of power for each of different instruments along with the related price range one would expect to pay. Beier appears to have taken his information from a price list of instruments made by Johann Franz Griendl von Ach, author of the pioneering work on microscopy, Micrographia Nova of 1687.  Griendl von Ach was also an important manufacturer of optical devices in Nuremberg for 70 years of the 17th century and so the information regarding his instruments would have been easily accessible to Beier.
BP_Description_2: Beier's book is in 11 Chapters. Chapter 1: The study of the formation of terms. Chapter 2: Instruments that separate all things by type. Chapter 3: Of equipment propagated into various types. Chapter 4: Related instruments. Chapter 5: Authors. Chapter 6: Handling, or the use of instruments. Chapter 7: Equipment for animals. Chapter 8: The invention of instruments. Chapter 9: Disposition, use, and purpose of instruments. Chapter 10: Ownership and contracts. Chapter 11: Removal of instruments.||The text is a mix of German and Latin. Given Beier's intention to establish precise terms, the book's descriptions are very precise and detailed.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Goldsmiths'-Kress Library of Economic Literature<i>. No 2873.1.

BP_Title English Translation: Various Types of Instruments with Especial Utility. On the Occasion of the Repute of the Encyclopedias of the Skilled, or: the Trusted Instrument. XXXIII.7  Tract on Hand Tools.
BP_Biographical Statement: Famed German jurist, teacher, and textbook writer.
BP_Provenance: Owner's signature on title page.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of long, descriptive essays containing definitions of terms and solved problems in a wide range of subjects in Mixed Mathematics. The section 'Optica,' though elementary, is detailed and elaborately geometric.
BP_Description_1: Ozanam declares in his Preface his reason for writing the dictionary: Mathematics and the sciences had advance to such an extent, and their application to many aspects of commercial, intellectual, and military life was so extensive, that a general dictionary of terms and concepts was necessary. He makes it clear that the work is the compilation of a dictionary of the term of Mixed Mathematics. It contained definitions from algebra and geometry in addition to general notions of the disciplines which are founded on mathematics, such as naval architecture and music. It ends with an index which allows for the dictionary to be used for consultation, placing it in the tradition of scientific dictionaries. Ozanam's dictionary was acknowledged by Harris in his <i>Lexicon Technicum<i> of 1704. Editions appear at Paris and Amsterdam in 1691, and an English translation and abridgement by Joseph Raphson appeared at London in 1702.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Dictionnaire Mathematique<i> is a collection of long, descriptive essays containing definitions of terms and solved problems in a wide range of subjects in Mixed Mathematics. The section 'Optica' (50 pages) includes: optics, perspective, gnomics, reflection, and refraction. The treatment, though elementary, is detailed and elaborately geometric. Each section begins with terms and their definitions, followed by exemplifying problems. The demonstrations and proofs for the problems are particularly clear, with highly detailed and careful diagrams. The sections on optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics reference and follow Pierre Rohault's textbook. Each of these sections ends with several problems, nominally involving the topic at hand, but which are elaborate demonstrations of the use of mathematics.
BP_Reference(s): Jacques Ozanam (1640‚Äì1718)|C√†ndito, C.|In: <i>Distinguished Figures in Descriptive Geometry and Its Applications for Mechanism Science: From the Middle Ages to the 17th Century<i>|Springer, 2016, 248 pp, pp 223-248.

With Arguments that Gradually Lead the Mind to a Universal Understanding of Mathematics.  By M. Ozanam, Professor of Mathematics.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician. Successful private teacher, prolific mathematical author.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp of the Gro√üherzogliche (Grand Ducal) Bibliothek at Neustrelitz on verso of titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A complete course in Cartesian philosophy, including logic, morals, metaphysics, and physics.
BP_Description_1: R√©gis studied under Rohault at the Sorbonne and became an ardent admirer and partisan expositor of the philosophy of Descartes. Sent by Rohault to spread the doctrine, R√©gis taught the principles of Cartesianism at Toulouse (1665), Aigues-Mortes, Montpellier (1671), and in Nicolas Lemery's laboratory in Paris (1680). Though recognized as the leading Cartesian Philosopher, R√©gis's late success came at a time when ecclesiastical defense of Aristotelian teaching produced powerful opponents to Cartesianism. The Archbishop of Paris condemned Cartesianism in 1671 and finally, in 1680, R√©gis was forced to suspend his lecturing. His years of teaching had made clear how Cartesian ideas should be expressed and his own orientation brought more empiricism to the Cartesian body of thought. All of this appeared in the <i>Cours<i>, but it would not be until 1690 when the work was allowed to appear in Paris. Even with permission to print, the Paris edition of 1690 could not have Descartes's name on the title page. The Dutch edition of the work, revised and printed in Amsterdam 1691, does carry Descartes's name.||Ostensibly Cartesian, R√©gis work shows the influence of the thought of Pierre Gassendi and Rohault‚Äôs extensive attempt to empiricize Catesianism. Other parts of it are, as a contemporary of R√©gis noted, amalgams of treatises of various sources: percussion by Edme Mariotte, chemistry by Nicolas Lemery, medicine by Raymond Vieussens and Guichard Joseph  du Verney, meteorics by Guillaume Lamy, and Hygrometers by Simon Foucher.||After Rohault‚Äôs <i>Treatise<i> of 1671, R√©gis's <i>Cours<i> was the most important popularizer of Descartes's ideas. Though titled so as to contain Logic, Metaphysics, Physics, and Morals, more than half of the work is devoted to Cartesian Physics.
BP_Description_2: Tome Premier begins with the <i>Discours sur la Philosophie<i>, a brief history of philosophy leading up to Descartes. This is followed by sections containing 4 parts on  Logic, 3 books in 5 parts on Metaphysics, and the first 2 books in 3 parts on Physics. The volume ends with a dictionary of philosophical terms. Tome Second contains 11 parts in book 3 through 7 on Physics. Tome Troisi√®me contains 4 parts of book 8 on Physics and 6 parts in 3 books on Ethics. The material on light and vision comprises 157 pages of book 8 in Tome Troisi√®me. The material is a selected recension of Descartes's <i>La Deioptrique<i>, augmented by Rohault. This includes: visual anatomy, sight and vision, the nature of light, light propagation, reflection, refraction, dioptrics and lenses, and correcting vision with lenses.
BP_Reference(s): The Prince of Cartesian Philosophers: Pierre-Sylvain R√©gis'|del Prete, A.|In: The Oxford Handbook of Descartes and Cartesianism|Nadler, S., Schmaltz, T.M., Antoine-Mahut, D., editors|Oxford University Press, 2018.||'Pierre-Sylvain R√©gis: A Paradigm of Cartesian Methodology'|Clarke, D.M.|<i>Archiv f√ºr Geschichte der Philosophie<i>, Vol 62, No 3, 1980, pp 289-310.||<i>Descartes and the First Cartesians<i>|Ariew, R.|Oxford University Press, 2014, 236 pp, NB: pp 183-194.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first detailed presentation of dioptrics in English. The first of its two parts presents experiments, definitions, and 59 propositions, principally on geometric optics. The second part is a miscellany of practical and applied topics.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Dioptrica Nova<i> is based on the notes Molyneux generated while studying optics with John Flamsteed who, in turn, had studied the optical papers of William Gascoigne left after his death. Molyneux wanted to write a book that encompassed he earlier work in astronomy and that demonstrated the utility of mathematics in optics--and do so in English, since most detailed and practical texts on optical instruments were in Latin. The book was written during 1689-1690 while Molyneux was in England. When he returned to Ireland 1691, Edmond Halley reviewed and correct the draft, added an appendix giving the first printing of his method for finding the focus of a spherical lens, and saw the work through the press.||The first part presents experiments, definitions, and propositions, principally on geometric optics, covering reflection, refraction, thin and thick lenses of convex and concave figure, the operation of the telescope, and the nature of vision corrected and uncorrected. Some of the proofs of the propositions are from Molyneux and are original, geometric and algebraic. Other are taken directly from Flamsteed. The second part is a miscellany of practical and applied topics. Importantly, this includes optical fabrication methods and their history and literature. The <i>Dioptrica Nova<i> was the best synthesis of dioptrics then available.||A copy of the book sent by Molyneux to John Locke was the beginning of a long friendship and correspondence. It was Locke who made famous 'Molyneux's Problem' concerning the consequences of immediate recovery from blindness. It was, perhaps, the publishing of 'Some Familiar Letters Between Mr. Locke, and Several of his Friends' in 1708 and in which Molyneux was so prominent, that interest arose again in the <i>Dioptrica Nova<i>, prompting a reprinting the following year.||In the Acta Eruditorum for January 1693, Leibniz gave a positive review of the book and Huygens studied the book carefully and was complimentary, writing that he thought it explained the telescope better than anyone had. The 'second edition' of 1708 is a reprinting of the 1692 text with a new title page.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Diptrica Nova<i> is in two parts. The first (184 pages) presents experiments, definitions, and 59 propositions, principally on geometric optics, covering reflection, refraction, thin and thick lenses of convex and concave figure, the operation of the telescope, and the nature of vision corrected and uncorrected. Most of the proofs of the propositions are original, geometric and algebraic. The second part (110 pages) is a miscellany of practical and applied topics. Importantly, this includes optical fabrication methods and their history and literature.||In part one, one proposition is on vision (in which he muses on the inverted retinal image), two are on microscopes, and 56 are on the geometric optics of the telescope. These latter propositions come from Barrow, Leibniz, Halley, and Flamsteed. They are presented clearly and proven in often  tedious detail, but in the detail came clarity and conviction. The proofs are usually Molyneux's own, though he adds a few from John Flamsteed. The propositions involve plano-convex, double-convex, plano-concave, double-concave, and meniscus lenses. In addition, several conditions of multiple lens interaction are considered. For all these cases there are propositions for determining required surface radii given focal distance, focal distances given surface radii, and various combinations. But for all the detail, and unlike Kepler who considered bundles of rays, Molyneux's analysis of focal distance involved determining the place where an extreme ray crossed the optical axis of the lenses, limiting the applicability of the results.||Part two contains seven chapters. Chapter 1 considers refraction in general. Chapter 2: A lengthy descriptive of the four-lensed telescope and its non-inverted image. Chapter 3: Spectacles for indistinct vision. Chapter 4: A literature review and assessment for grinding and figuring lenses. Chapter 5: Telescopic instruments including telescopic sights, quadrants, sextants, and micrometers. It is here that Molyneux weights in on the controversy regarding dioptric instrument sights, rather than unaided sights. Chapter 6: A brief history of the telescope and microscope a review of the discoveries made with them; from Galileo to Hevelius, and from Hooke to Leeuwenhoek. Chapter 7: A consideration of the nature and operation of binocular vision. The Appendix presents the first printing of Edmond Halley's famous formula relating the conjugate foci of a thin spherical lenses to its focal length.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ When an Eye is armed with a Telescope: The Dioptrics of William and Samuel Molyneux|Abrahams, P.|<i>Acta Historica Astronomiae<i>, Vol 33, pp 229-246.||<i>Lenses and Waves<i>|Dijksterhuis, F.J.|Kluwer, 2004, pp 41-47.||William Molyneux and the Optometry Content of his 1692 Book <i>Dioptrica Nova<i>|Goss, D.A.|Hindsight: <i>Journal of Optometry History<i>, Vol 39, No 2, 2008, pp 67-71.||William Molyneux and his <i>Dioptrica Nova<i>|Shepard, C.|<i>The American Journal of Physiological Optics<i>, Vol 3, No 1, 1922, pp 1-24.||Molyneux's Answer|Wade, N.J.|<i>Perception<i>, Vol 35, 3006, pp 1579-1582.||William Molyneux of Dublin, 1656-1698|Simms, J.G.|Dublin, Irish Academic Press, 1982, p 176.||<i>The Common Scientist of the Seventeenth Century: A Study of the Dublin Philosophical Society, 1683-1708<i>|Hoppen, K.T.|University of Virginia, 1970, Routledge, 2009, 298 p.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Laurent Pothenot (1650-1732) French mathematician, French Academy of Sciences, and professor at the Coll√®ge de France.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of varied works by members of the French Academy of Sciences including Frenicle, Roberval, Huygens, Picard, Auzout, Mariotte, and R√∏mer. It includes an edited draft of a text on dioptrics from lectures given by Picard to the academy: the <i>Fragmens Dioptrique<i>, presenting 49 propositions and proofs on the geometrical optics of lenses.
BP_Description_1: Between 1677 and 1679, Jean Picard presented a series of lectures on dioptrics to the French academy. In 1679 Pierre de Carcavi, mathematician and secretary of the National Library of France, proposed that Edm√© Mariotte, astronomer Philippe de La Hire and Picard produce a full treatise on optics for the Academy. Though the collaboration never took place, it was this project that apparent prompted Picard to begin a set of notes which he worked on until his death.||As the Preface makes clear, the volume collects works from several prominent authors in many areas, and in most cases is based on presentations made to the French Academy of Sciences. The editor was Philippe de la Hire, who had received several manuscripts from Jean Picard, who, in turn, had been entrusted with manuscripts of Bernard Fr√©nicle de Bessy, Christiaan Huygens, and Gilles Personne de Roberval for printing. Eventually, de la Hire would add the other works the volume contains, including works by Jean Picard. The Preface also states that at the time of Picard's death, Picard's collection of notes on dioptrics 'was in great confusion' and that the French mathematician and academician Laurent Pothenot oversaw their ordering and editing. This is likely the reason for their title: Les Fragmens de Dioptrique. Picard's extensive work with optical instruments in gnomics, astronomy, and surveying lead naturally to a keen interest in optics. The 77-page manuscript Pothernot worked on was a draft of Picard's text on dioptrics. It contained 49 propositions covering: refraction at spherical surfaces, focal characteristics of various types of lenses, and refraction at water, air, and glass interfaces. The text was based on presentations Picard had made to the French Academy in 1680.||Picard had carefully studies the optics of Christiaan Huygens and Isaac Barrow and wrote a summary of dioptrics expressly for applications to optical instruments.||This work on dioptrics by Picard would be printed again in 1730, pages 550-626 of volume 6, of the Memoires published by the French Academy that collected material from 1666 to its reorganization in 1699. It would appear again in 1736 in <i>Ouvrages de Mathematique de M. Picard<i>, a collection of astronomical and physical works of Picard.
BP_Description_2: A collection of 31 treatises from 17th century French natural philosophers. All but one appearing here for the first time. Gilles Roberval (9), Frenicle de Besay (4), Christiaan Huygens (8), Jean Picard (5), Auzout (2), Mariotte (1) and Ole R√∏mer (2).||Jean Picard's <i>Fragmens de Dioptrique<i> comprise pages 375-412 of the volume. The text is a collection of propositions that deal with the essential aspects of the geometrical optical aspects of dioptrics. Propositions 1-3 cover the fundamentals of refraction as curved interfaces. Propositions 4-16 establish the basic properties of lenses, giving the relationship between figure, curvature, focal distance, and image position and size for many types of spherically-figured lenses, for rays that are parallel and oblique to the optical axis. It is here that Picard gives his expression for spherical aberration. Propositions 17-24 solve various problems that relate curvature radii and conjugate focal points for various types of lenses. Picard obtains essentially the same result as Edmond Halley regarding thin lenses. Propositions 25-35 consider similar problems, but with lenses fully or partially immersed in water.  Propositions 36-44 consider oculars and their interaction with objective lenses. Propositions 45-49 consider the effects of refracted rays that reflect off the interior surfaces of a lens, and how this effects lens use, particularly in surveying.||The 49 propositions are proved or demonstrated with detailed geometric analysis. They are often accompanied by corollaries that extend the utility of the proposition, and in some cases 'rules' are given that summarize characteristics or can be used to guide the construction of a lens. The material is entirely mathematical; though Picard was very much a practitioner, no practical aspects regarding lens making are presented.
BP_Reference(s): Recherches sur les travaux de dioptrique et de catoptrique de Jean Picard √† l'acad√©mie royale des sciences|Blay, M.|In: <i>Jean Picard et les d√©buts de l'astronomie de pr√©cision au XVIIe si√®cle<i>|√âditions du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, 1987, pp 329-344.
BP_Title: Fragmens de dioptrique  In: Divers ouvrages de matheÃÅmatique et de physique par Messieurs de l'AcadeÃÅmie Royale des Sciences
BP_Title English Translation: Fragments on Dioptrics. In: Diverse Works of Mathematics and Physics by Gentlemen of the Royal Academy of Sciences.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A precis of peripatetic teaching regarding the eye, color, and vision.
BP_Description_1: Volume three of a five-volume work meant as a text for self-study and an example of the late and lingering presence of peripatetic teaching. The work was begun in 1689 and completed three years later. This volume deals with Physics as was understood in scholastic thought. He wrote this work at the end of his long career, writing in his Preface that "I have shaken off the yoke of school and am not subject to the words of teachers," and so he had time to write.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1 contains Logic, Volume 2 contains Metaphysics, and Volumes 3-5 are devoted to Physics. Volume three is in three tracts: On the vegetative soul in 12 chapters, On the sensitive soul in 49 chapters, and On the rational soul in 6 chapters. The material on the eye, color and vision occupy chapters 25-29 (30 pages) of the second tract. The anatomy of the eye is essentially Galenic, with the lens placed in the center of the eye surrounded by spherical tunics.  The only influence of Plater and Kepler is the account of the retina as the receiver of light. Visual spirit is brought from the brain. The material on Color is classical, with no influence of Descartes or Newton, and is considered a separate entity from light but like it, radiated from objects to be received by the eye. The last two chapters deal with vision and its function. Vision is defined to be motion of animal spirit to the brain from the retina, having been impressed by rays entering the eye from the viewed object. Direct and reflected vision are briefly considered, as is the manner in which two eyes generate a single perceived object.||The presentation is entirely descriptive and is in the form of Scholastic Disputation, with point, counter-point, objections, and resolutions.
BP_Reference(s): Dictionnaire Historique Biographique et Bibliographique|Barjavel, C.-F.-H.|Tome Premier, A-F|Capentras, 1841, 591 pp, NB: pp 60-61.

BP_Short or Common Title: Memoires de Mathematique et de Physique
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: La Hire considers vision from a perceptual and physiological point, all in a Cartesian framework.
BP_Description_1: La Hire's interest in vision, sight, and color motivates this consideration of vision from a perceptual and physiological point of view. Essentially Cartesian, La Hire reviews the basics of eye-function and considers perfect and imperfect vision and their causes and discusses several aspects of visual perception. All consistent with his work as painter, architect, and geometer.
BP_Description_2: La Hire begins the treatise on vision with a general discussion of perception of objects: size, color, position, and orientation. Vision with two eyes is then described. Imperfect vision, myopia, and visual acuity are then discussed. Vision correction with convex and concave lenses as described by Descartes is discussed. Distant vision, presbyopia and its correction, and cataracts are described. Methods to improve vision are then described including vignetting, summarizing the views of Descartes and Rohault. Vision improvement is described and analyzed in terms of rays and simple geometric optics, ocular anatomy, vision being due to images formed on the retina. The more practical aspects of sight are also considered, including visual cues and why in which we process things in the visual field. He touches on how these cues and perspective are used in the theater. La Hire noted that certain color perceptions change in dim light.  In the second and shorter part of the treatise La Hire takes up and considers various options concerning the function of the eye and the nature of sight.
BP_Reference(s): Les Publications de l'Acad√©mie Royale des Sciences de Paris (1666-1793): Tome I: Description bibliographique. Tome II: Etude statistique, Index g√©n√©raux|Xhayet, G.,  McClellan, J., Halleux R., editors|Brepols, 2001, 688 pp, NB pp  45-54.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A detailed treatise on lens making and their use in telescopes and microscopes, direct from hands-on experience.
BP_Description_1: Hartsoeker's <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> is his first publication and the culmination of 20 years of lens grinding and instrument making, including not only time as an independent craftsman but also his years working in the Paris observatory. It is also the first expression of his developing work in natural philosophy. Hartsoeker was living in Paris at the time he wrote <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> and had acquired a European reputation for lens-craft and instrument making. Unlike most other European lens makers, Hartsoeker made no secret of his craft and the <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> gives long, detailed descriptions of all aspects of lens making. Beyond the technical details of lens-craft, he includes his notions regarding the nature of light and the reasons for and processes of reflection and refraction, and his telescopic and microscopic observations and their interpretation. Given the range of material covered, the work's title is, perhaps, too diminutive.||Hartsoeker's treatment of technical details is thoroughly mathematical, written in the style of textbook, and his practical and mechanical descriptions are informed by his long and deep experience. His natural philosophy is significantly more speculative and, particularly when interpreting his own telescopic and microscopic observations, opened a door for considerable criticism. The interpretations he gave to some of his microscopical observations were influenced by 'animalculist' beliefs. It is in this regard that he makes his famous conjecture, provided with an accompanying and equally famous figure, that a tiny, preformed human resides in a spermatozoon.||A Dutch translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1699.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Essay Dioptrique<i> contains 10 chapters. Chapter 1: nature and origin of light rays. Chapter 2: opaque and transparent bodies. Chapter 3: rectilinear light rays. Chapter 4: on reflection and refraction. Chapter 5: the radiant point. Chapter 6: the eye. Chapter 7: vision. Chapter 8: making glass lenses. Chapter 9: proper use of lenses. Chapter 10: observations made with telescopes and microscopes||Hartsoeker considers light a fiery liquid, one of the two substances that make up all matter. Opaque or transparent bodies are made up of the second substance; its particulate arrangement allowing, or not, the passage of light at a finite speed that depends on the body's density. Mechanical forces are invoked to explain reflection and refraction, and these same forces, varying with different rays, cause different colors as 'they strike the organ of vision.' Color are produced by the interaction of rays with materials, culling some rays, enhancing others; thus the color appearance of objects. The material on ocular anatomy is contemporary and that on vision is Keplerian.||The material on lens making is very detailed and includes: the proper chemical composition of glass; glass forming and its difficulties; glass types; grinding, figuring, polishing, and testing lenses. Hartsoeker describes grinding lenses in metal forms, rather than turning on a lathe. The construction of spectacles, telescopes, and microscopes are also described in detail, including examples of the calculations necessary to determine lens radii, spacing, and size. The last chapter included reports of Hartsoeker's extensive observations with a microscope of his own construction, including his famed description of spermatozoa.
BP_Reference(s): The Natural Philosopher and the Microscope: Nicolas Hartsoeker Unravels Nature's 'Admirable ≈íconomy'|Abou-Nemeh, S.C.|<i>History of Science<i>,Vol 51, No 1, 2013, pp 1-32.|Images and Ideas: Leeuwenhoek's Perception of the Spermatozoa|Ruestow, E.G.|<i>Journal of the History of Biology<i>, Vol 16, No 2, 1983, pp 185-224.||Constructive thinking: a case for dioptrics|Dijksterhuis, F.J.|In: <i>The Mindful Hand: Inquiry and Invention from the late Renaissance to Early Industrialization<i>|Koninkliijke, Amsterdam, 2007, 468 pp, NB: pp 59-82.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A scientific encyclopedia based on works of Bachet, Mydorge, Leurechon, and Schwenter. The subjects are presented in the form of problems with an emphasis that is practical and demonstrative. The section on optics problems is extensive.
BP_Description_1: Ozanam assembled problems from the works of Claude Gaspard Bachet De M√©ziriac of 1612, Jean Leurechon of 1624, Claude Mydorge of 1630, and Daniel Schwenter of 1636. The result is an elementary scientific encyclopedia to which Ozanam added brief commentaries and notes of his own. The second volume has, as an appendix, an elementary treatise on clocks, a text of Domenico Martinelli of Spoleto that Ozanam translated from the Italian. The work was written to be pedagogical, but always in the form scientific recreation. The mathematics, mechanics, and physical principles are always presented in an example and in an almost playful manner. By 1723 it had expanded to four volumes and in 1778 the work was revised and expanded by Jean-√âtienne Montucla. He introduced many additional topics and, more importantly, expositions of theory, changing the nature of the work considerably and extending is utility and appeal.||The <i>ReÃÅcreÃÅations MatheÃÅmatiques<i> was immensely successful, in print for 150 years. Editions appeared at Paris in 1694, 1696, 1697, 1698, 1700, 1723, 1725, 1735, 1741, 1749, 1770, 1778, 1790, 1803, 1814, 1844. English translations appeared at London in 1708, 1803, and 1814, and at Dublin in 1756
BP_Description_2: The subjects are presented in the form of problems and include: arithmetic, geometry, optics, gnomonics, cosmology, mechanics, pyrotechnics, physics, and clocks. The emphasis is practical and demonstrative; there is almost no theory. The section on optics problems (60 pages) includes: images in flat and concave mirrors; optical surveying; perspective drawing of various objects; burning mirrors; spherical lenses and burning lenses; properties of lenses of convex and concave figure; the lensed camera obscura; image anamorphosis onto various surfaces; and projecting lanterns. The optics material is elementary and no mathematics is used, but the presentations are clear and accompanied by numerous figures.
BP_Reference(s): Jacques Ozanam (1640‚Äì1718)|C√†ndito, C.|In: <i>Distinguished Figures in Descriptive Geometry and Its Applications for Mechanism Science: From the Middle Ages to the 17th Century<i>|Springer, 2016, pp 223-248.
BP_Title: ReÃÅcreÃÅations matheÃÅmatiques et physiques, qui contiennent plusieurs probleÃÇmes d'arithmetique, de geometrie, d'optique, de gnomonique, de cosmographie, de mecanique, de pyrotechnie, & de physique. Avec un traiteÃÅ nouveau des horloges elementaires. Par Mr Ozanam, Professeur des Mathematiques.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Undergraduate Oxford teaching notes adapted from lectures delivered at Edinburgh in 1684.
BP_Description_1: David Gregory oversaw only a few student theses on Newtonian optics and physical optics was never was part of the material covered in the course Gregory taught at Edinburgh beginning in the early 1680s until he left for Oxford in 1691. That is clear from the content of these notes printed in 1695. Gregory had a utilitarian view of education and expressed such to Parliament's Visiting Committee: teaching Latin was a waste of time, philosophy should not consume three years, and mathematics should be compulsory. Regarding optics, he was teaching the function and use of optical machines in life, commerce and industry and in such an environment, Newtonian theories had no place. Besides, his Scottish students were too young to have had the necessary mathematics. Editions appeared in 1695 and 1713 and an English translation in 1715 and 1735.
BP_Description_2: Undergraduate Oxford teaching notes adapted from lectures delivered at Edinburgh in 1684. 24 Propositions and 17 Problems are presented with a concision that can be daunting. The notes cover: geometrical optics of plane and curved mirrors; images from mirrors; refraction; geometrical optics of refraction at spherical surfaces; images formed by lenses of convex and concave figure; images formed by multiple lenses; thick lenses and the famed suggestion for constructing an achromatic lens based on the differing refractive power of the eye's lens and humors. The material is concise, detailed, and a mixture of experiment and mathematics including fluxions. Aside from brief material on the eye, topics are limited to geometrical optics, with sources consisting of Descartes's <i>La Dioptrique<i>, Barrow's <i>Optical Lectures<i>, and the <i>Optica Promota<i> of his uncle James Gregory. Nothing is presented regarding the nature of light, color, or the causes of reflection and refraction.
BP_Reference(s): David Gregory and Newtonian Science|Eagles, C.M.|<i>The British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 10, No 3, 1977, pp 216-225.||Manuscript at: http://arts.st-andrews.ac.uk/digitalhumanities/fedora/repository/default%3A885#page/1/mode/2up
