BP_Short or Common Title: Moyen de diminuer la longueur des lunettes
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A letter addressed to the Royal Academy at Paris by de Hautefeuille, defending his work on telescopes.
BP_Description_1: A letter addressed to the Royal Academy at Paris, this is a revision of and extraction from an earlier work that de Hautefeuille published in 1683 on the same subject. de la Montre and de Hautefeuille exchanged views in the Journal des Savans in 1698 regarding de la Montre's questioning the basic principle de Hautefeuille used in his analysis. This is one of 20 descriptions, in various forms, that de Hautefeuille published describing his inventions. These covered a wide range of subjects including the pendulum, pumps and engines, and optical instruments. It is known this work reached England: A five-page manuscript review of de Hautefeuille's idea exists in the papers of Robert Hooke dated 8 December 1697.
BP_Description_2: de Hautefeuille cites Fabri, Hevelius, and Dechales as works that suggested the use of multiple lenses in the oculars of telescopes. de Hautefeuille proposes a multi-lensed ocular that preserves the angles of rays but shortens the distance to the focal plane, thus shortening the length of the telescope. Convex and concave lenses are used to accomplish this.
BP_Reference(s): On M. [Jean] de Hautefeuille's method of shortening the telescope without diminishing its effect by Robert Hooke'|In: Classified Papers of the Royal Society: Robert Hooke's Papers, Vol 20, paper 91, code CLP/20/91.
BP_Title: Moyen de diminuer la longueur des lunettes d'approche sans diminuer leur efect
BP_Title English Translation: A Way to Diminish the Length of Telescopes without Diminishing Their Power.
BP_Biographical Statement: French cleric, natural philosopher. A gifted experimentalist and instrument maker, can be considered among the earliest successful philosophical instrument engineers.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1697 Hautefeuille - Moyen de diminuer la longueur des lunettes  - Images.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Thesis directed by Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703) German philosopher, mathematician, influential pedagogue and textbook author. Taught at the University of Altdorf, reforming the curriculum to include experimentation.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Thesis under the direction of Christoph Sturm on vision, the optics of the eye, and its similarity to the camera obscura.
BP_Description_1: Johann Gabriel Doppelmayr came to the University of Altdorf in 1696 to study under Johann Christoph Sturm, the leading experimental physicist in Germany at the time. Sturm was the thesis director and had and developed the   idea of the camera obscura as a model for the eye in his <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> of 1676. In the Preface to his thesis, Doppelmayr singles out the peripatetic teaching on the functioning of the eye, and cites the widely read Aristotelian commentary by Jacopo Zabarella which had appeared less than a decade earlier. Doppelmayr writes his thesis to both correct the mistaken but authoritative peripatetic teaching on eye-function, and to record his work on the camera obscura as a model of the eye. The theory and practice of the camera obscura are presented, both with small and large  apertures and with lenses. Works by Ren√© Descartes, Christoph Scheiner, and Jacques Rohault are cited. Like Johannes Zahn's <i>Oculis Artificialis<i> or Christoph Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i>, Doppelmayr's thesis is one of the earliest works on the camera obscura as a model of the eye, but unlike Zahn or Scheiner's works, its scarcity has had it overlooked in written histories of the camera obscura.
BP_Description_2: Johann Gabriel Doppelmayr's thesis is in 12 chapters. 1: construction, operation, and use of the camera obscura; 2: how the eye is like a small camera obscura; 3: how the camera obscura generates an inverted images; 4: preparing a camera obscura to imitate the eye; 5: vision and the way simple objects are seen; 6: seeing light, color, shadow, and objects; 7: requisites and conditions for direct vision; 8: view of shapes; 9: view of site and distance; 10: view of size; 11: view of number; 12: view of motion.||Doppelmayr presents an analysis similar to that in Johannes Kepler's Ad Vitellionem Paralipomena of 1604 regarding images produced by pinhole and large apertures in a camera obscura. To this is added the functioning of a double convex lens placed in the aperture, showing how the image is brighter and more clear. This is carefully compared to the eye. Doppelmayr describes how an artificial eye can be constructed as a spherical camera obscura. The retinal image is the basis for Doppelmayr's analysis of the perception of color and objects. This includes showing how spectacles can correct near and short-sightedness. The material is not mathematical, but is detailed and complete.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Science, Art and Nature in Medieval and Modern Thought<i>|Crombie, A.C.|Hambledon Press, 1996, pp 345-348.
BP_Title: Dissertatio Visionis Sensum Nobilissimum ex Obscurae Camerae Tenebris Illustrans quam sue Praesidio Joh. Christoph. Sturmii Ph. M. & Phys. Mathematumque  P.P. Defendet: Gabriel Doppelmayer, Norimbuergensis.
BP_Title English Translation: A Disseration Illustrating the Nobelest Sense, vision, as a Camera Obscura. Presided over by Johann Christoph Sturm, Professor of Philosophy and Mathematical Physics. Defendant: Johann Gabriel Doppelmayer of Nuremburg.
BP_Biographical Statement: German academic, natural philosopher, historian. Author and translator of scientific texts, experimentor, and star atlas composer.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by  A. Block
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Ameldonck Block's Dutch translation of Nicolaas Hartsoeker's <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> of 1694. The last chapter include reports of Hartsoeker's extensive observations with a microscope of his own construction, including his famed description of spermatozoa.
BP_Description_1: Hartsoeker's <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> is his first publication and the culmination of 20 years of lens grinding and instrument making, including not only time as an independent craftsman but also his years working in the Paris observatory. It is also the first expression of his developing work in natural philosophy. Hartsoeker was living in Paris at the time he wrote <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> and had acquired a European reputation for lens-craft and instrument making. Unlike most other European lens makers, Hartsoeker made no secret of his craft and the <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> gives long, detailed descriptions of all aspects of lens making. Beyond the technical details of lens-craft, he includes his notions regarding the nature of light and the reasons for and processes of reflection and refraction, and his telescopic and microscopic observations and their interpretation. Given the range of material covered, the work's title is, perhaps, too diminutive.||Hartsoeker's treatment of technical details is thoroughly mathematical, written in the style of textbook, and his practical and mechanical descriptions are informed by his long and deep experience. His natural philosophy is significantly more speculative and, particularly when interpreting his own telescopic and microscopic observations, opened a door for considerable criticism. The interpretations he gave to some of his microscopical observations were influenced by 'animalculist' beliefs. It is in this regard that he makes his famous conjecture, provided with an accompanying and equally famous figure, that a tiny, preformed human resides in a spermatozoon.||This Dutch translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1699. The translator provided his own Preface and explains that Hartsoeker's book is so 'lucid, veracious, and judicious' that he translated it for those wishing to learn lens-craft who did not read Latin or French. The¬†cover illustration by Jan Luykens; an engraving by Jan Goeree shows Hartsoeker‚Äôs long telescope with a wooden tube, hoisted on a mast. To the left side is another tubeless telescope with the objective lens being hoisted onto the mast of the large wooden telescope.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Essay Dioptrique<i> contains 10 chapters. Chapter 1: nature and origin of light rays. Chapter 2: opaque and transparent bodies. Chapter 3: rectilinear light rays. Chapter 4: on reflection and refraction. Chapter 5: the radiant point. Chapter 6: the eye. Chapter 7: vision. Chapter 8: making glass lenses. Chapter 9: proper use of lenses. Chapter 10: observations made with telescopes and microscopes||Hartsoeker considers light a fiery liquid, one of the two substances that make up all matter. Opaque or transparent bodies are made up of the second substance; its particulate arrangement allowing, or not, the passage of light at a finite speed that depends on the body's density. Mechanical forces are invoked to explain reflection and refraction, and these same forces, varying with different rays, cause different colors as 'they strike the organ of vision.' Color are produced by the interaction of rays with materials, culling some rays, enhancing others; thus the color appearance of objects. The material on ocular anatomy is contemporary and that on vision is Keplerian.||The material on lens making is very detailed and includes: the proper chemical composition of glass; glass forming and its difficulties; glass types; grinding, figuring, polishing, and testing lenses. Hartsoeker describes grinding lenses in metal forms, rather than turning on a lathe. The construction of spectacles, telescopes, and microscopes are also described in detail, including examples of the calculations necessary to determine lens radii, spacing, and size. The last chapter include reports of Hartsoeker's extensive observations with a microscope of his own construction, including his famed description of spermatozoa.
BP_Reference(s): The Natural Philosopher and the Microscope: Nicolas Hartsoeker Unravels Nature's 'Admirable ≈íconomy'|Abou-Nemeh, S.C.|<i>History of Science<i>,Vol 51, No 1, 2013, pp 1-32.||Images and Ideas: Leeuwenhoek's Perception of the Spermatozoa|Ruestow, E.G.|<i>Journal of the History of Biology<i>, Vol 16, No 2, 1983, pp 185-224.||Constructive thinking: a case for dioptrics|Dijksterhuis, F.J.|In: <i>The Mindful Hand: Inquiry and Invention from the late Renaissance to Early Industrialization<i>|Koninkliijke, Amsterdam, 2007, 468 pp, pp 59-82.||<i>A Certain Instrument to See Far: Four Centuries of Styling the Telescope Illustrated by a Selection of Treasures from the Louwman Collection of Historic Telescopes<i>|Louwman, P.J.K., Zuidervaart, H.J.|Wassenaar, 2013, 256 p.
BP_Title: Proeve der deurzicht-kunde, in het Frans beschreeven van de Heer Nicolaas Hartsoeker, en vertaald door A. Block.
BP_Title English Translation: Demonstration of Vision Science. Written in French by Mr. Nicolas Hartsoeker and Translated by A. Block.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch mathematician, natural philosopher, oculist, microscopist. Famous in his time, a member of  French Academy of Sciences and the Prussian Academy of Sciences.

BP_Author AKA: The author is actually Christoph Sturm
BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Thesis directed by Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703) German philosopher, mathematician, influential pedagogue and textbook author. Taught at the University of Altdorf, reforming the curriculum to include experimentation.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Thesis, under the direction of Christoph Sturm, surveys all that was known about the rainbow.
BP_Description_1: Christoph Sturm had a keen interest in the rainbow, among other optical phenomena, so it was natural that one of his students should study the subject in detail. As was the custom at the time, the thesis was actually written by Sturm and defended by his student. The work is interesting in that it gives clear insight into what was known and had generally been read about the rainbow at the end of the 17th century. Sturm's student and thesis respondent, Christoph Gottlieb, was a member of the ancient Patrician  N√ºrnburg family of Volckammer von Kirchensittenbach. After his studies at Altdorf he became an architect. The folding engraved plates are by Cornelius Nicolaus Schurtz after designs by the author.
BP_Description_2: The thesis, under the direction of Christoph Sturm, by Christoph Gottlieb  'Volckammer von Kirchensittenbach', surveys all that was known about the rainbow. In two parts: the first considers the history, appearance, characteristics, and theories of the rainbow's appearance. The explanations, spanning all the rainbow's recorded history, of Aristotle, Maurolyco, Witelo, DuHamel, Fabri, and Descartes are presented. Though the geometric optics of Descartes' rainbow is acknowledged as ingenious, its explanation for rainbow color is rejected. Mariotte is preferred.  The second part considers the generation of the rainbow's colors and size, examining in detail the work of Mariotte, Descartes, Eckard, and Fabri. These latter sections present considerable calculational detail. The work of Newton, Deschales, and Grimaldi is mentioned in passing. Generally, the material is collected uncritically but described carefully. The plates of figures are detailed and are essential to the explanations given, particular the contemporary ones.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, 376 pp, NB: pp 246-248.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A course in natural philosophy that maintains Aristotelian structure but substitutes modern developments for its content.
BP_Description_1: Bayle's vast textbook of natural philosophy was designed to replace Aristotelian and Peripatetic physics and mechanics with the developments of Galileo, Kepler, Descartes, and Gassendi. Bayle was the foremost critic of Aristotle and preeminent supporter and promoter of Cartesian empiricism in the last quarter of the 17th century.||Editions appeared Toulouse in 1700 and at Frankfurt in 1703.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Institutiones<i> keeps the Scholastic structure and method of disputations, answers, proofs and corollaries, but substitutes modern content of physics and mechanics. The work is in three volumes. 1: General and Particular Physics, including matter, motion, materials, and the elements. 2: The World, including sun, moon and planet motions, time, calendars, the Earth, fixed stars, gravitation, geophysics, magnetism, metals, water and rivers and tides, the atmosphere, fire, and plants and animals. 3: Bodies in General, including anatomy, bones, muscles, and blood, the senses, and generation and morbidity.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Cartesian empiricism of Fran√ßois Bayle<i>|Lennon, T., Easton, P.|Garland, New York, 1992, 127 pp.||<i>Bayle, Fran√ßois (1622‚Äì1709)<i>|Eaton, P|In: L. Nolan (Ed.), The Cambridge Descartes Lexicon, pp. 53-55, Cambridge, 2015.

BP_Biographical Statement: French physician, philosopher, Cartesian empiricist, and critic of Aritotelianism and ancient authority in matters of natural philosophy.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Prompted by the thermometer, barometer, and the hygrometer for measuring temperature, pressure, and humidity, a <i>Lucimetre<i> is proposed for the measurement of light.
BP_Description_1: A brief text on the measurement of light, arising in part, from the need to be able to produce reliable ratios of different amounts of light. At the start of the 18th century there were instruments that made it possible to determine such ratios of temperature, humidity, and atmospheric pressure; but not for light. Jean Fran√ßois-Marie describes a simple way to make such a determination, using attenuation to extinction. It is likely that this small work would ever have received any attention at all, had it not been mentioned by Pierre Bouguer in the preface of his posthumous <i>Trait√© d'Optique<i> of 1760.
BP_Description_2: In his 'From the Author to the Reader', Jean Fran√ßois-Marie describes in the utility and importance of the thermometer, barometer, and the hygrometer for measuring temperature, pressure, and humidity. He finds the lack of a similar instrument for the measurement of light a serious lacuna and proposes a <i>Lucimetre<i> for the measurement of light. The instrument is an opaque tube through which a source is viewed. Multiple glass plates are placed in the tube until the source cannot be seen. The number of plates is inversely proportional to the 'degree of light.' Alternative methods using multiple mirrors or varying depths of liquid are also proposed, as well as alternate names: <i>Photometre, Phangometre, Metrophote<i>.
BP_Reference(s): The Beginnings of Photometry|Knowles Middleton, W. E.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 10, No 12, 1971, pp 2592-2594.

BP_Short or Common Title: De la Recherche de la Verit√©
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A philosophical work describing human errors that affect the pursuit of truth: error of the senses, the imagination, and the mind. Book One is devoted to the senses, including vision and optics. Later editions included the long 'Eclairissment' on light, color, and vision.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 163.  In 1699 Malebranche communicated to the Academy his memoire 'R√©lxions sur la lumi√®re et couleurs' and this would become an additional, unnumbered Elucidation, 'On Light and Colors, the Generation of Fire', that first appeared in this edition of 1700.<i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i> first appeared at Paris in 1674 and 1675. Further editions appeared in 1677-1678, 1681, 1683, 1688, 1700, 1712, 1721, 1735, 1749, 1762, 1772, 1829, and in the Oeuvres of 1842. A Latin translation appeared in 1690 and 1753, English translations in 1694 and 1700, an Italian translation in 1767, and a German translation in 1776.
BP_Description_2: Seen Entry 163. In the new, unnumbered Elucidation on light and colors, Malebranche sets out his theory of optics, particularly the origin of colors. Color, he maintains, is produced by the different rates of vibration of the subtle matter set up by the luminous object and received by the eye. Variations in brightness are caused by the strength (not the rate) of the vibrations. Importantly, Malebranche considers white as a kind of color, caused by the highest rates of vibration. Malebranche is concerned with the nature of things and thus, is attracted to questions on the nature of light, color, and vision, but not, for example, on anything related to geometric optics.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 163.
BP_Title: De la Recherche de la Verit√©.  Ou l'on traitte de la nature de l'esprit de l'homme, & de l'usage qu'il en doit faire pour eviter l'erreur dans les Sciences.
BP_Title English Translation: On the Search for Truth. Or, One Treatise on the Nature of the Mind of Man, and the Right Exercise he Must Make (of it) to Avoid Error in the Sciences.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Oratorian, philosopher, theologian, Cartesian. Theoritician in natural philosophy, writing on mathematics, optics and mechanics.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Thomas Taylor (1669-1735) English philosopher at Oxford.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the English translation of the 3rd edition of the <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i> of 1678, which included the Elucidations. The Elucidation on light and color presents a theory based on the transmission of pressure or 'tendency toward motion': Light is pressure transmitted through the plenum and color a result of the changing rate of vibrations.
BP_Description_1: By the time Thomas Taylor was working on the second edition of his translation of the third edition of Malebranche's <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>, Malebranche's ideas concerning light and color had under gone considerable development. In 1687 his writing reflected an idea he had introduced into Descartes' concept of light being a percussively transmitted pressure in the plenum: the pressure or 'tendency to motion' was not static but consisted of periodic variations, which he called 'pressure vibrations.' In 1699 Malebranche was elected an honorary academician of the French Academy of Science to which he read his memoire 'Reflection Light and Colors and the Generation of Fire.' By the time of this memoire he had significantly modified Descartes' ideas of regarding the nature of light in part because of Romer's discovery of light's finite travel speed Huygens ideas concerning wave propagation. Malebranche developed his idea of pressure vibrations to explain color: vibrations of different 'promptitude' (what would now be described as frequency) produced different colors, and different amplitudes produced different intensities. But however changed from Descartes' original ideas, it was fundamentally a mechanical philosophy.||This memoire would eventually become the 16th Elucidation Malebranche added to the 1700 edition of <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>. Before it appeared, a manuscript of it was obtained by Taylor who included its translation at the end this edition of his translation of De la Recherche de la Verit√©. Though Malebranche would later complain about its infidelity, Taylor's translation of the memoire was the mechanism by which Malebranche's ideas on light and color were known in England. Taylor's translation and Malebranche's new edition, both of 1700, would bring into print the first theory of light and color based on amplitude and frequency of vibrations.||The final version of Malebranche‚Äôs ideas on light and color--informed by his reading of Newton's Optice of 1706--appeared in the 1712 edition of the <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>.
BP_Description_2: The second edition of the English translation of <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i> of 1678, includes what Taylor named a 'Short Discourse on Light and Colours' which is a translation of Malebranche's memoire on that subject read to the French Academy in 1699, giving his theory of light as percussive vibrations, traveling with a finite speed, with 'promptitude' that determined its color and amplitude that determined its intensity. The percussive vibrations were transmitted among vanishingly-small vortices. Malebranche theorizes that it is the changing pressure, the pressure vibrations, to which the retina of the eye is sensitive. A constant pressure, he argues by way of analogy, is not sensed in the same way that we are unaware of the constant air pressure that surrounds us. Similarly, as small and large amplitude determine light's intensity, if a body diminishes the incident amplitude--that is, it weakly reflects--then the reflected light has reduced intensity. Similarly, Malebranche proposes that if a body changes the 'promptitude' of percussive vibrations then the light it reflects will have a color changed from that of the incident light. If the reflected body is specular, then the reflected angle equals the incident angle, as would be expected ballistically. The basic properties of light--the amplitude and 'promptitude' of its percussive vibrations--are explained by the forces acting on vanishingly-small vortices and the forces they themselves produce. These force interactions are invoked to explain the sine law of refraction.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 163.
BP_Title: Father Malebranche his Treatise concerning the search after truth. The whole work complete. To which is added the author's Treatise of nature and grace: being a consequence of the principles contain'd in the search. Together with his answer to the animadversions upon the first volume, his defense against the accusations of Mr. De La Ville, &c. relating to the same subject. All Translated by t. Taylor, MA, Late of Magdalen College in Oxfor. The second edition, corrected with great Exactness. With the addition of A Shorty Discourse upon Light and Colours, by the same Author. Communicated in Manuscript to a person of Quality in England: and never before Printed in any Language.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Oratorian, philosopher, theologian, Cartesian. Theoritician in natural philosophy, writing on mathematics, optics and mechanics.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Thomas Bennet and T[homas] Leigh and W[Daniel] Midwinter

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Dissertation on the camera obscura and magic lantern.
BP_Description_1: One of many dissertations under the direction of Harald Vallerius, musician and mathematician at the University of Upsala. His son is the defendant of the thesis. The thesis makes clear several aspects of optics as studied at the end of the 17th century: Cartesian notions of light prevailed, there was general acceptance of Kepler's  analog of the camera obscura for the eye, the camera obscura was widely used for art and drawing, and the actual functioning of the magic lantern was generally not well understood.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation is in four short chapters. 1: The nature of light; 2: Natural Camerae Obscurae, the Eye; 3: Artificial Camerae Obscurae; 4: 'Megalographia' or the inverse of the Camera Obscura. Chapter one is a review of the the theories of the conception of the nature of light and its propagation. Descartes, Rohault, and Dechales are cited. The cartesian conception is used to explain reflection and refraction. Chapter two presents the Keplerian and Cartesian analysis of the eye as a camera obscura. Chapter three presents typical camerae obscurae, including simple pin-hole instruments and those fitted with a convex lens. Descartes, Kepler, Scheiner, Kircher, Schott, Deschales, and Hevelius are cited. Chapter four presents the 'inversion' of the camera obscura. That is, instead of bring an image in, an image is projected out. This is the magic lantern, the 'Mealographia' of the title. The presentation is very brief and passes over the actual geometric optics of the magic lantern, citing Kircher and presenting a very simplified and flawed image of the workings of a magic lantern.
BP_Reference(s): Introducing the Instrument|Lefevre, W., Wenczel, N., and Gorman, M.J.|In: <i>Inside the Camera Obscura ‚Äì Optics and Art under the Spell of the Projected Image<i>|Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, preprint 333, 2007, pp 1-31.
BP_Title: Dissertatio physico-mathematica de camera obscura, quam Permissu Ampl: Coll: Philsoph: Upsaliensis, moderatore patre carissimo Mag. Haraldo Vallerio Math. Prof. reg. et ord. In Audit. Gustav. Maj. ad d. XXXI. Octob. Anno MDCC ad publicum examen modeste defert S:√¶ R:√¶ Maj:tis Alumnus Haraldus Vallerius filius.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mansuscript describing perspective, catoptric and dioptric anamorphosis for artists
BP_Description_1: Mansuscript describing perspective and catoptric and dioptric anamorphosis for artists. Late 17th or early 18th century descriptive instroduction to various types of projection used in painting and anamorphosis, all in the manner of Niceron. Though reference is made to diagrams, they do not appear in the text.
BP_Description_2: The text is in three parts: Optic, Catoptric, and Dioptric anamorphosis. The first is a review of linear perspective and includes descriptions of producing anamorphosic views from particular points. Catoptric anamorphosis from cylincrical, conical and pyramidal mirrors is described in the second section. Dioptric anamorphosis using facetted lenses is briefly described in the third section.
BP_Reference(s): The Mathematical Treatment of Anamorphoses from Piero della Francesca to Niceron|Andersen, K.|In: <i>History of Mathematics: States of the Art<i>, Christoph J. Scriba, C.J.,  Dauben, J.W., editors|Academic Press, San Diego, 1996, 394 p.||<i>Anamorphic Art<i>|Baltrusaitis, J., Strachan, W.J., translator|Cambridge, 1977, 192 pp, NB: 37-60.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An omnibus volume of reprints, Latin translations, academic dissertations, and short treatises.
BP_Description_1: Bayle's <i>Opuscula<i> collects reprints, Latin translations of works previously publi¬≠shed in French and first editions of academic dissertations, and short treatises on medicine, physics, optics and philosophy.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Opuscula<i> includes Bayle's <i>Dissertatio de necessitate conjungendi experietiam cum ratione in physicis<i>, the Latin translation of work in French that appeared in 1675. It is Bayle's manifesto on the importance of critical thought, reasoning, and experiment in natural philosophical research. This collection also includes the <i>Informatio circa quasdam mulieres quae a daemone possessae credebantur<i>, the Latin translation of a work in French that appeared in 1682. It is amount the earliest work on mental health, opposing outright alleged demonic possession and the accompanying abuses. Bayle approached mental illness from a medical and what would now be called a physiological point of view, invoking Cartesian physiology and iatrochemistry.||Disputation IV is devoted to material on optics, contained in 5 Articles in 35 pages: The organ of vision, On vision, The apprehension of distance and placement, Vision by reflection and Colors, Questions around light and vision. The ocular anatomy is up to date and informed by Kepler, Descartes, and Scheiner. Vision is analyzed on the basis of images generated by light rays falling on the retina. The brief section on catoptrics describes the action of plan and spherical mirrors, showing virtual image position and how minification and magnification result. Color is described as resulting from different species of rays impinging on the retina and provoking different responses. The difference is attributed to the different rotations of the minute 'globules' that comprise light. The work of R√∏mer is sited to support the idea that light does not propagate instantaneously. The entire treatment of optics is descriptive; no mathematics is presented.
BP_Reference(s): The Cartesian doctor, Fran√ßois Bayle (1622‚Äì1709), on psychosomatic explanation|Easton, P.|In: <i>Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences<i>, Vol 42, No 2, 2011, pp 102-209.

Eorum omnium Catalogum continet sequens pagina.

Small Works, of which some are first brought to light, some which were produced in Latin and amended by the Author, and some first written in French by the Author are turned into Latin. A catalogue of all of them is contained in the following pages.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physician, philosopher, Cartesian empiricist, and critic of Aritotelianism and ancient authority in matters of natural philosophy.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of <i>Oculus Artificialis<i> of 1685. Most changes and additions are in the third section on practical optical instruments. A complete treatment of the construction and use of lensed optical instruments, presented in three 'Fundamenta', that is, bases: The physical the mathematical, and the practical or mechanical.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 192. The three Fundamentum appeared in separate volumes, though are usually found bound together. The first and second Fundamenta appeared in 1685, the third in 1686. The second edition appeared in 1702, containing the first complete history of the microscope.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 192. The second edition includes the first complete history of the microscope and the Appendix Dioptrico-Microscopica, an extensive illustrated chapter on microscopes that describes a number of microscopes after Hooke and Ch√©rubin.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 192.
BP_Title: Oculus artificialis teledioptricus sive telescopium, ex abditis rerum naturalium & artificialium principiis protractum nova methodo, eaque solida explicatum ac comprimis e triplici fundamento physico seu naturali, mathematico dioptrico et mechanico, seu practico stabilitum. Opus curiosum theorico-practicum magna rerum varietate adornatum, omnibus artium novarum studiosis perquam utile: quo philosophi√¶ atque methesi pr√¶sertim mixt√¶, nec non universo pene hominum statui amplissimis adjumentis consulitur; nova plurima abstrusa curiosa technasmata recluduntur, ipsaque ars telescopiaria facillime addiscenda, ac sumptibus non adeo magnis in praxin adducenda proponitur, adeoque telescopium ex tenebris in lucem asseritur. Authore Joanne Zahn Franco-Carolopolitano. Sacri & Candidi ordinis Praemonstratensis Canonico Regulari nec non Parthenonis Cellae inferioris ejusdem Ordininis prope Herbipolim Praeposito. Editio Secunda Auctior. Cum Facultate Superiorum.
BP_Title English Translation: Teledioptric Artificial Eye, or: The Telescope. By which the Hidden Origins of Natural and Artificial Things are Brought to Light by a New Method, and the Whole Set Out and Compressed into a Three-Fold Established Basis: Physical or Natural, Mathematically  Dioptrical, and Mechanical or Practical. A Careful, Theoretical-Practical Work, Providing a Great Variety of Things, at the Wishes of Many and Long Desired, Extremely Useful to all Students of the New Arts. In Which is Considered Philosophy and Mathematics, especially Mixed, and also by the Help of the Whole Stock of Very Ample Human State. Many New Hidden Technical Curiosities are Displosed. And so the Art of Telesocpy is Easily Learned and the Cost of the Proposed Practice not so great that from the darkness, the Telescope is brought to Light. Author: Joannes Zahn of Charleville-M√©zi√®res. Regular Canon of the Sacred and Pure Premonstraten Order, and Stationed at the Monestary near W√ºrzburg. Second, Augmented edition. With the Facility of the Superiors.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by David Gregory (1661 - 1708) Scottish mathematician. Taught at University of Edinburgh and Oxford. Promoter of Newtonian ideas in the university curriculum.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First collected edition of Euclid's works, in Greek and Latin, including the Optica and the Catoptrica. This was the standard, pre-nineteenth-century source for the Greek text of Euclid.
BP_Description_1: The Scottish mathematician David Gregory's Euclid published at Oxford in 1703 is from Commandine's Latin edition and makes use of Bernard's corrections and contains all the then-known works of Euclid.  It is the first collected edition, in Greek and Latin, including the Optica and the Catoptrica.  Gregory states that he followed Commandine in the main, but corrected numerous passages by means of books in the Bodleian Library that had belonged to Edward Bernard, the former Savilian Professor of Astronomy, who had started but not finished a plan to publish Euclid's complete works. Though Gregory also mentions that he consulted many Greek manuscripts, the Greek text is essentially that edited by Simon Grynaeus and published by Johannes Herwagen at Basel in 1533. For the Greek text, Gregory has the help of the Bodley's Librarian, John Hudson. Hudson annotated the Basel text, calling out passages that differed importantly from the Latin. It is these for which Gregory then consulted Greek manuscripts to attempt to determine the correct text.||Gregory's text would remain the only edition of Euclid's complete works until the edition of J.L. Heiberg and H. Menge, published at Leipzig in 1883. The frontispiece illustrates a story that Vitruvius relates in Book VI of <i>De Anchitectura<i>. The shipwrecked Socratic philosopher Aristippus and his companions make it safely to the shore of Rhodes--land unknown to them. When he saw geometric figures drawn in the sand, Aristippus exclaimed 'Let us be of good hope, for I see the traces of men.'
BP_Description_2: This was the standard, pre-nineteenth-century source for the Greek text of Euclid. It was the first edition of the Greek-Latin parallel text, including the texts of Euclid's small writings. The contents includes: Elementorum libri XV, Data, Introductio harmonica, Sectio canonis, Phenomena, Optica, Catoptrica, De divisionibus liber, De levi et ponderoso fragmentum. Latin translations of Euclid's <i>Optica<i> and <i>Catoptrica<i> were first printed in Georgius Valla's massive compendium <i>De Expetendis et Fugiendis Rebus Opus<i> printed by Aldus at Venice in 1501, but they both first appeared together in the first Latin edition of Euclid's collected works in 1537. The <i>Optica<i> is a Latin translation of the first Greek work on vision and perspective--the earliest surviving text on optics and light in the western world. The <i>Optica<i> presents the phenomena of visible light and the Euclidian idea of vision rays emanating from the eye, comfortably aligned with and analyzed by geometry. It re-emerged as an important text in the 15h century for it use in the theory of linear perspective. The <i>Catoptrica<i>, a treatise on mirrors attributed by Proclus to Euclid, covers the mathematical theory of mirrors, particularly the images formed by plane and spherical concave mirrors.
BP_Reference(s): Early editions of Euclid in England|Simpkins, D.M.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 22, No 4, 1966, pp 225-249.||The Thirteen Books of Euclid's Elements, Translated from the Text of Heiberg|Cambridge, Vol 1, 1908, NB: pp 100-103.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Burchard de Volder, Bernard Fullenius
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A printing of edited manuscripts left by Huygens after his death including, most importantly, the Dioptrica. The collection also includes Huygens' commentaries on figuring and polishing lenses, a dissertation on coronae and parahelia, tracts on motion and centrifugal force, and a description of Huygens' planetarium or orrery.
BP_Description_1: When Christiaan Huygens died in 1695, he bequeathed to the University of Leiden his workbooks, papers, and letters. In his will he requested that Bernard Fullenius Jr (friend and government official) and Burchard de Volder (famed natural philosopher at the University of Leiden) prepare for publication the manuscripts of his Dioptrics, his Laws of Percussion, his Dutch treatise on lenses, and anything else that they felt worth printing. Fullenius and de Volder acted as editors and produced the <i>Opuscula Postuma<i> of 1703. The editors invoked the help of 'curators and councilors' whom they list before their own Preface.||Unlike the other the material, the manuscript for the <i>Dioptrica<i> was in a state ready for publishing at the time of Huygens' death. He had worked on it nearly constantly for more than 30 years; always promising to publish but never doing so. He had carefully ordered and numbered the pages, had them copied, and personally corrected the copy. There was little for the editors to do but see the manuscript through the press.||Unlike the Trait√© de la Lumi√®re, his later work which was narrowly concerned with the nature and propagation of light, the <i>Dioptrica<i> dealt only with mathematical geometrical optics, practical lens craft, and optical instruments. The first part of the <i>Dioptrica<i> dates from around 1652 and contains Huygens earliest work on refraction and lenses. The second part which deals with spherical aberration dates from around 1665. This section was considerably revised when Huygens read of Newton's discovery of chromatic dispersion in 1672. The third part on telescopes and microscopes was written 1685.||The influence of the <i>Opuscula Postuma<i> was limited, since many of the most striking advances that Huygens had made and recorded in the <i>Dioptrica<i> had subsequently been made by others and published earlier. This was the case with both Isaac Barrow in his <i>Lectiones Optic√¶<i> of 1674 and William Molyneux in his <i>Dioptrica Nova<i> of 1692. However superseded its content may have been  by the time it was published, the <i>Dioptrica<i> revealed the workings of one of the 17th century's most singular talent in optics. Interestingly, the anonymous editor of Isaac Newton's <i>Optical Lectures<i> of 1729 claimed that the appearance of Huygens's <i>Dioptrica<i> in the <i>Opuscula Postuma<i> in 1703 was one of the factors that overcame Newton's famed refractory reluctance to publish his Opticks--which finally appeared in 1704. A second edition of the <i>Opus Postuma<i> appeared in 1728.
BP_Description_2: Huygens' <i>Dioptrica<i> is in three parts. The first is a tract on refraction and the telescope, the Tractatus de Refractione et Telescopiis; the second is on spherical aberration, the De Aberratione Radiorum a Foco; and the third on practical telescopes and microscopes, the De Telescopiis et Microscopiis. The <i>Dioptrica<i> contains much original work. In the first part Huygens uses the sine law of refraction to establish fundamental characteristics of lens imaging for paraxial rays. In the same part, and more importantly, he derives his theorem on the unchanged image formed by a system of lenses when the eye and object are interchanged. This theorem was a great analytic power and would later be (re)discovered by Smith and presented in his <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.||In the second part, Huygens presents his theorem and practical embodiment of a lens doublet which overcomes spherical aberration using only spherical figures. In the third part, telescope magnification is shown to be the ratio of object-to-ocular focal lengths. This section also contains considerable material on physiological optics, the efficacious functioning of telescopes and microscopes, and describes a 'simplified eye': the eye modeled with concentric hemispheres of different radii. The Dioptrica and Huygens work on meteorological optics of coronas and halos take 370 of the collection's 430 pages.

Tome XIII. Dioptrique<i>|Nijhoff, M., Haag, D., (Korteweg, D.J., editor)|Societe Hollandiase des Sciences, 1916, 906 pp, NB: pp i-clxviii.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A review of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. A summary of the content, with slight commentary, rather than a technical review.
BP_Description_1: This notice of the publication of Isaac Newton's <i>Opticks<i> appeared in The History of the Works of the Learned, a weekly journal summarizing books, papers, and reports and which, as its title page states, was 'An Impartial Account of Books Lately Printed in all Parts of Europe. With a Particular Relation of the State of Learning in each Country.' It was published in London from 1699 until 1711, after which it appeared biannually until 1743. The notice reflects the high standing Newton had with the anonymous editor--and virtually all of England at the time. The appearance of the notice following so immediately after the publication of the Opticks speaks not only of knowledge circulating within London's printing community, but also of the general anticipation of a major work by Newton. This was the first review or notice of Newton's <i>Opticks<i>. The author is unknown. Leibniz would review the Opticks--much more thoroughly and with considerably less credulity--in the Acta Eruditorum of February 1706.
BP_Description_2: The notice for the <i>Opticks<i> appeared in <i>The History of the Works of the Learned<i> for the month of April 1704 on pages 225-231. It begins with fulsome praise of Newton himself and the general excellence of the book. There follows a detailed summary of the principal components of Book I of the Opticks. Particular emphasis is placed on the claims Newton made about the chromatic heterogeneity of white light and the prismatic experiments supporting them. The notice summarizes and praises, but, not surprisingly for a general magazine, does no analysis and certainly presents no criticism. Only Book I of the <i>Opticks<i> is reviewed. The notice ends with 'An Account of the 2nd and 3rd Books the Reader may expect some other Time.' A notice of these books of the <i>Opticks<i> never appeared. No mention is made of the highly technical and mathematical tracts dealing with fluxions that Newton appended to the Opticks of 1704. They had little if anything to do with optics and appeared only to allow Newton to claim priority of the invention of the calculus.
BP_Title: Opticks: or, a Treatise of the Reflexions, Refractions, Inflexions, and Colours of Light. By the Celebrated Mr. Isaac Newton. In: The History of the Works of the Learned. Or, An Impartial Account of Books Lately Printed in all Parts of Europe. With a Particular Relation of the State of Learning in each Country. April 1704. p 225-231.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the Latin rendering of the optics text Le Monde of 1664 and other smaller work previously unpublished.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Opuscula Pothuma<i> has its origins in the unpublished manuscripts left Descartes' death. A few would appear in the original French, sometimes added to other works, sometimes published alone. The most notable was La Monde which first appeared in 1664, with a second edition in 1677. These works remained unpublished even though they came into the hands of various editors, including Claude Clerselier, Walther von Tschirnhaus, Johannes de Raei, and and Gottfried Leibniz. These were all eventually translated into Latin by an unrecorded translator and included: <i>Mundus, sive Disseratio de Lumine; Rebulae ad directionem ingenii; Inquisitiio Veritatis per Lumen Naturale; Primae Cognitationes circa Generationaem Animalium; Nonnulla de Saporibus<i>; and <i>Excerpta ex Mss. R. Des-Cartes.<i> These were collected first in the <i>Opuscula Posthuma<i> that appeared at Amsterdam in 1701. The edition of 1704 is a line-for-line reprint of the 1701 text. The 1704 printer's mark is an imitation and the paper shows the water mark of Italian manufacture. Thus, the 1704 edition was likely printed in Rome.
BP_Description_2: <i>Mundus<i> is the close Latin translation of <i>Le Monde<i>, Descartes' early treatise on Light, containing 15 chapters. The first five set out Descartes view of the mechanical basis for all of natural philosophy. In these, he refutes Scholastic teachings regarding the nature of sense perceptions in general and those from light in particular. It is here he introduces his mechanical theory of the nature of light and mechanisms of sense perception. Descartes then presents a mechanistic view of fluids and air and in chapter 5 explains how fire, air, and earth are involved in the generation, propagation, and reflection and refraction of light: generation by fire, propagation by pressure in fluids, and reflection and refraction by terrestrial objects.||Chapters 6 and 7 present Descartes three laws of motion and inertia: conservation of states of bodies (size, motion, rest, position), conservation of the 'force of motion' of bodies, and the constancy of rectilinear direction of motion. Chapters 8-12 use the theory of matter developed in chapters 1-5 and the laws of motion and inertia in 6 and 7 to develop a Copernican cosmography based on vortices, fluids, and mechanical interaction. Chapters 13-15 deal with physical optics and, using his theory of matter and laws of motion, and the properties of the 'tendency to motion' of closely-packed particles, explain light's rectilinear propagation, specular reflection, and refraction.||As with his later writings, Descartes' presentation is based more on analogy than on analysis, particularly regarding the nature of light and it propagation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A Bibliography of the Works of Descartes I & II<i>|van Otegem, M.|Quaestiiones Infinitae, Vol 37|Publications of the Leiden-Utrecht Research Institute of Philosophy, Utrecht, 2002, NB: pp 657-678.
BP_Title: Opuscula posthuma, physica et mathematica
BP_Title English Translation: Ren√© Descartes. Postumous Small Physical and Mathematical Works.
BP_Biographical Statement: French philosopher and mathematician. Resident of the Dutch Republic, revolutionary founder of rationalism, prolific writer.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Johan Jansson von Waesberg, Jan Hendriksz Boom, Rembertus Goethals

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Newton's long-gestated record of optical experiments and their results, which he used to deduce the nature of light, refraction, diffraction, and color. The work's three books deal exclusively with physical optics. 'Queries' appear at the end, being rhetorical questions proposing ideas about the nature of light and color.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 is Newton's third attempt at producing a full description of his work in optics; and the only one published. Between 1670 and 1672 he fulfilled the requirements of his Lucasian Professorship and wrote his <i>Optical Lectures<i>, a comprehensive treatise on refraction and colors. But the criticism of his letter in the Philosophical Transactions announcing his theory of light and color had him set the work aside. They would not be printed until after his death. Newton did not take up optics again until after the publication of the Principia in 1687. This was a work he called the 'Fundamentum Opticae' and would eventually become Book I of the Opticks of 1704. What would become Books II and III were written by 1691 and involved that last experimental work Newton would do in optics. Material in what would have been Book IV dealt with diffraction and proved to be troublesome. His original theory regarding diffraction he himself experimentally disproved in 1692. What remained and eventually appeared in Book III regarding diffraction is, compared to Books I and II, tentative and incomplete. The uncertainly regarding diffraction, a half-hearted intention to conduct more thorough investigations into diffraction, and fear of more disputes delayed publication 12 years.||The <i>Opicks<i> appeared in February of 1704. It is a record of experiments and their results used to deduce the nature of light, refraction, diffraction, and color. The book deals with physical optics, rather than geometrical optics, and records Newton's final and most mature ideas regarding light and colors. At its core is Newton's desire to establish a mathematical foundation for what is now called physical optics. Book one deals with prism experiments, the spectral heterogeneity of white light, and the link between color and varying refractivity. The results of experiment 8 appear to show the invincibility of lens chromatic aberration--a result that cast a long shadow over lens development in the 18th century and was unchallenged until Samuel Klingenstierna's remarkable paper of 1754. Book two deals with color fringes in thin and thick plates. Book three deals briefly with diffraction. Queries appear at the end, rhetorically proposing ideas about the nature of light and color. This is the only edition that included two mathematical treatises on the calculus, published as part of Newton's priority dispute with Leibniz.||The two Latin mathematical tracts dealing with the calculus were immediately reviewed by Leibniz in the Acta Eruditorum, a review appeared in The History of the Works of the Learned in 1704, and a general review appeared in the Nouvelles de la R√©publique des Lettres for March 1706. Interestingly, this last review ends by expressing the hope that the work would be translated into Latin but notes that 'cependant l'auteur souhaite que personne ne le fasse sans sa participation.'--'however, the author does not want anyone to do it without his participation.'  The <i>Opticks<i> would have vast influence, particularly in the form of its Latin translation that appeared in 1706. It's fundamental propositions of the chromatic heterogeneity of white light and varying chromatic refrangibility would be generally accepted within 20 years. The corpuscular theory of light's nature, proposed in the Queries, would set the terms of the debate with the wave theory of light for all of the 17th century. English editions of the Opticks appeared in 1704, 1717, 1721, 1730, and 1931. A Latin translation appeared at London in 1706, 1719, at Geneva in 1740, at Padua in 1749 and 1773. A French translation appeared at Paris in 1720 and 1722.||This copy from the Tixall Library, a collection originally formed by the recusant Sir Walter Aston, First Lord Aston (1584-1639) of Tixall, Staffordshire, friend and patron of the poet Michael Drayton and British Ambassador to Spain under James I and Charles I. By the nineteenth century the library had descended to the Constable family. It was finally sold at Sotheby‚Äôs in London on 6th November 1899, as the late property of Sir F.A.J.C. Constable of Burton Constable and Aston Hall, in Yorkshire. Sale noted in the London Daily Mail, November 8, 1899.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Opticks<i> is in three Books. Book I is in two parts. Part I deals with prism experiments and the spectral heterogeneity of white light. It begins with definitions and axioms that review the basic aspects of geometric optics of reflection and refraction. This is followed by 8 propositions based on 16 experiments dealing with chromatic inhomogeneity and its consequences. Propositions 7 and 8 deal specifically with the limitations imposed on telescope objectives by what is now called chromatic aberration. Part II presents 11 propositions based on 17 experiments investigating the nature of color and the application of the theory of chromatic heterogeneity, particularly to the rainbow. It is here that Newton's 'experimentum crucis' of his letter of 1672 is presented in refined form and great detail.||Book II is in four parts. Part I presents 24 observations of the colored fringes produced by light passing through glass plates and thin lenses in contact in air and water. Part II presents a mathematical analysis of these observations, including Newton's method for determining small separating distances. Part III presents 20 propositions dealing with colors of natural bodies and their relationship to prismatic colors and color production in thin plates. it is here that Newton proposes that light has 'Fits of easy reflection and fits of easy transmission.' Part IV presents 13 observations of colors produced by thick plates.||Book III presents 11 descriptive observations of the color and placement of diffraction fringes produced by various objects.||Book III ends with 16 Queries; Newton's rhetorical questions proposing ideas about the nature of light and color. It is here that Newton dismisses wave theories of light as incapable of explaining its observed properties.
BP_Reference(s): Twenty-Nine Years in the Making: Newton's <i>Opticks<i>|Shapiro, A.E.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 417-438.||Opticks, or a Treatise of Light, 1687‚Äì1704|Rupert Hall, A.|In: <i>Isaac Newton: Adventurer in Thought<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1996, pp 279-293.||Skating on the Edge: Newton‚Äôs Investigation of Chromatic Dispersion and Achromatic Prisms and Lenses|Shapiro, A.E.|In: <i>Wrong for the Right Reasons<i>, Buchwald, J.Z., Franklin, A., editors, Springer, 2005, pp 99-125.||The Evolving Structure of Newton's Theory of White Light and Color|Shapiro, A.E.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 71, No 2,1980, pp 211-235.||Facing the Limits of Deductions from Phenomena: Newton‚Äôs Quest for a Mathematical-Demonstrative Optics|Ducheyne, S.|In: <i>The main Business of natural Philosophy<i>, Springer, 2011, pp 179-224.||Newton's theory of fits of easy reflection and transmission|Sakkopoulos, S.|<i>European Journal of Physics<i>, Vol 9, 1988, pp 123-126.||<i>Fits, Passions and Paroxysms<i>|Shapiro, A.E.|Cambridge, 1993, 391 pp, NB: pp 136-179.||Preface and Introduction|Cohen, I.B. and Whittaker, E.|In: <i>Opticks, Sir Isaac Newton<i>|Dover, New York, 1952, pp ix-lvii.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An encyclopedic dictionary that briefly defines words or describes concepts in what ranges from single sentences to essays. The emphasis is on mathematics and science.
BP_Description_1: John Harris, Secretary of the Royal Society from 1709, was the first lexicographer to distinguish between a word-book, that is a dictionary, and a subject-book, that is, an encyclopedia. Harris' work is a hybrid, with entries varying in length from those typical of dictionaries to those of encyclopedias. It is also the first English encyclopedia presenting entries in alphabetical order. In his Preface, Harris makes clear his intention to provide a reference work of high utility, focusing on the 'arts and sciences' and to do more than just explain words, he wanted to explain the arts themselves. Harris's work was focused primarily on the mathematical sciences and their application. This emphasis was due, in part, to Harris's own background, the contributors he managed to assemble, and what he felt was missing in existing dictionaries. This content gave the work a unique and general appeal and, as Harris hoped, the reader would find the book 'useful to be read carefully over, as well as to be consulted like other Dictionaries occasionally.'||A review of the work, extending to the unusual length of four pages, appeared in the Philosophical Transactions for 1704. The <i>Lexicon Technicum<i> was long very popular, enduring through at least 1744 as the main rival of Ephraim Chambers's <i>Cyclopaedia<i>. Harris's Lexicon greatly influenced other dictionaries, providing material which was incorporated to increase the modernize the scientific and mathematical content of general dictionaries in England including The New World of Word by Phillips and Kersey, the anonymous <i>Glossographia Anglicana Nova<i>, the <i>Dictionarium Britannicum<i> of Nathan Bailey, and <i>New General English Dictionary<i> of Thomas Dyche and William Pardon. It is also clear that the <i>Lexicon Technicum<i> influenced Ephraim Chambers's <i>Cyclopedia<i> and Diderot's <i>Encyclop√©die<i>. The second volume of Harris' encyclopedic dictionary is mostly mathematical and astronomical tables, intended to serve as a small mathematical library.||Volume 1 of the <i>Lexicon Technicum<i> appeared in five editions: 1704, 1708, 1716, 1725, and 1736. Only the edition of 1704 included the list of subscribers. Volume2 appeared in three editions: 1710, 1723, and 1736. The final publication of the two volumes of the <i>Lexicon Technicum<i> was in 1736 and was the first time the two volumes were edited and issue simultaneously. A supplement was published in 1774, labeled Volume 3. It is not known who edited the work after Harris' death in 1719.
BP_Description_2: John Harris's encyclopedic dictionary had an emphasis on mathematics and science, though it included topics from the humanities, arts, law, commerce, music, and heraldry. The contributors were recognized experts and generally produced essays that presented the latest contemporary information. Though considered a technical lexicon, this did not mean machines or manufacturing. It meant, rather, mathematics and its applications such as navigation, dialling, shipbuilding, architecture, fortification, optics and perspective. The second volume is mostly mathematical and astronomical tables, intended to serve as a small mathematical library.||The material on light and color is from Newton's 1672 letter in the Philosophical Transactions--Harris mentioning that the Opticks of 1704 came to late to hand be be studied and extracted carefully. The article on the Rainbow is by Edmond Halley. Additionally, there are articles on Optics, Optic Glasses, Optic Nerve, Reflection, Refraction in glass and air, Foci real and virtual, Colour, Eye, and Vision. The material related to physical optics is entirely Newtonian. The geometric optics material is contemporary, detailed, and analytic.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ John Harris's <i>Lexicon Technicum<i>|Bradshaw, L.E.|In: <i>Notable Encyclopedias of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries<i>, Kafker, F.A., editor, Voltaire foundation, 1981, pp 107-123.||<i>Encyclopaedic Visions: Scientific Dictionaries and Enlightenment Culture<i>|Yeo, R.|Cambridge Universtiy Press, 2001, 341 p.||Diction and Dictionaries in the Diffusion of Scientific Knowledge: An Aspect of the History of the Popularization of Science in Great Britain|Layton, D.|<i>British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 2, No 3, 1965, pp 221-234.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Experimental philosophy turned to apologetical use, attempting to draw a strong connection between Newton‚Äôs natural philosophy and evidence for God‚Äôs hand in creation.
BP_Description_1: This work he dedicated to the earl of Roxburgh, at whose request, and for¬†whose instruction, it appears to have been originally written. Though drawing on many authors--principally Newton--Cheyne gives no direct quotations, since he felt that 'my Subject wanted no Authorities, but Demonstration.'  He constructs his arguments from the contents of the works he often does not name.
BP_Description_2: Cheyne's work attempts to turn experimental philosophy to apologetical use. It is in four chapters. Chapter I presents physical laws governing motion, gravity, light, and statics. Chapter II is on the origin of the World and of Man. Chapter III deals with the existence of the Deity. Chapter IV deals with the infinite and the limits of human knowledge. Essentially, Cheyne used natural philosophy to support the idea that life could not spring forth from inorganic matter; rather, it 'must of necessity have existed from all eternity.'
BP_Reference(s): Mysticism and mechanism: the religious context of George Cheyne's representation of the body and its ills|Gibbons, B.J.|<i>Journal for Eighteenth-Century Studies<i>, Vol 21, No 1, 1998, pp 1-23.
BP_Title: Philosophical Principles of Natural Religion: Containing the Elements of Natural Philosophy, and the Proofs for Natural Religion, Arising from them. By George Cheyne, M.D. and F.R.S.
BP_Biographical Statement: English physician, philosopher, mathematician. Wrote importantly and popularly on health and diet.
BP_Provenance: Ownership note dated 1706 on front free endpaper

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Review of Newton's mathematical tracts in the Opticks of 1704, bringing the invention of the calculus priority dispute between Newton and Leibniz from a simmer to a boil.
BP_Description_1: With the publication of the two mathematical tracts demonstrating his method of fluxions--On the Quadrature of Curves, and Enumeration of Lines of the Third Order--with the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704, Newton laid claim to priority of the invention of the calculus. Leibniz's immediate response as an anonymous review in the Acta Eruditorum set out his counter claim and made public a dispute that began 15 years earlier. Disputes aside, the review shows how quickly copies of the <i>Opticks<i> reached the continent. Leibniz must have had a copy just a few months after it appeared in February of 1704, since his review appeared in the Acta Eruditorum in January of 1705.
BP_Description_2: Leibniz reviews Newton's mathematical tracts, writing 'Accordingly, instead of the Leibnizian differences, Mr. Newton employs, and has always employed, fluxions, .... He has made elegant use of these both in his <i>Principia Mathematica<i> and in other publications since, just as Honore Fabri in his <i>Synopsis Geometrica<i> substituted the advance of movements for the method of Cavalieri.' In this Leibniz casts Newton as an adaptor and borrower, just as it was well known that Honor√© Fabri had borrowed from Cavalieri.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Philosophers at War: The Quarrel between Newton and Leibniz<i>|Rupert Hall, A.|Cambridge University Press, 1980, 332 pp, NB: pp 129-156.
BP_Title: Review of Newton's mathematical tracts in Opticks of 1704. In: Acta Eruditorum. January 1705 p 30-36.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, rationalist philosopher, prolific author of journal articles and letters.
BP_Collation: œÄ¬π A-Z‚Å¥ Aa-Zz‚Å¥ Aaa-Zzz‚Å¥ Aaaa-Eeee‚Å¥ Ffff¬≤

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First edition in German of the pioneering textbook on natural philosophy and Mixed Mathematics, including: optics, astronomy, horology.
BP_Description_1: Sturm first published the two parts of his <i>Mathesis Juvenilis<i> in 1699 and 1701 in Latin. It was written specifically for use in the gymnasium with the express intention of raising the level of teaching in mathematics and natural philosophy. Sturm recognized the need to elevate what teacher's understood and so, unusually and significantly, the book was addressed to both teacher and student.||The Latin edition appeared in 1699. German language editions appeared at N√ºrnberg in 1705 and 1716. An English translation of the Latin text appeared at London in 1708.
BP_Description_2: German language edition of a textbook on natural philosophy and Mixed Mathematics, including: optics, astronomy, horology. The optics section (271 pages) covers: vision, the eye, and the eye compared to a camera obscura; nature of light and color; perspective; mirrors and catoptrics; reflective anamorphosis; refraction and dioptrics; refractive anamorphosis; optical instruments including the magic lantern, camera obscura, and the periscope. The optics material is limited to vision and simple geometric optics; physical optics is not considered. It can be considered Keplerian, but certainly pre-Newtonian, if not Cartesian. The treatment is elementary and demonstrative, but complete. The pedagogical method is to present phenomena and then offer the simplest reasonable explanations. Geometric demonstrations are provided for much of the optical material, but the text dealing with the rest of natural philosophy is, in general, not mathematical.
BP_Reference(s): Johann Christoph Sturm's contribution to the saeculum mathematicum (in German: Der Beitrag von Johann Christoph Sturm zum Saeculum Mathematicum)|Radbruch, K.|In: <i>Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703)<i>|Verlag Harri Deutsch, 2004, pp 136-152.||The Real Schools of Germany (translated from the German)|Raumer, K.|In: <i>German schools and pedagogy. Organization and instruction of common schools in Germany<i>|American Journal of Eduction, New York, 1861, 245 pp, NB: pp 123-148.

BP_Biographical Statement: German philosopher, mathematician, influencital pedagogue and textbook author. Taught at the University of Altdorf, reforming the curriculum to include experimentation.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Posthumous, second edition, revised and significantly enlarged, of a detailed compendium of furnace-based engineering, chemistry, metallurgy and their application of the arts and crafts. Glass manufacture and lens making are considered at length.
BP_Description_1: Johann von L√∂wenstern Kunckel first published his <i>'Ars Vitraria Experimentalis<i> or Glasmacher Kunst' In 1679 . It was a collection and translation of several previous works on glass, along with his own extensive experience with glass manufacture and working. Much of this material was incorporated into his <i>Curieuse Kunst-und Werck-Schul<i> of 1696. This is the posthumous, second revised and enlarged edition.
BP_Description_2: Second edition, revised and significantly enlarged from that of 1696. A detailed compendium of furnace-based engineering, chemistry, metallurgy and their application of the arts and crafts. Part 1 is primarily about the "Fire Arts", including sheaths of gold and silver, casting, alloys, ceramics, china, glazes, glass making, ruby glass, grinding of optical glass, stained glass, precious stones, pearls, coral, production of phosphorus, embalming , Part 2 provides detailed recipes for making and application of paints, varnishes, stains, gilding, leather colors for bookbinders, marble, ivory, paper, parchment, sealing wax, ink, plaster, desalination of sea water||Book three of Part 1 (214 pages) is on glass making and optical instruments, including: glass composition, smelting, and molding; equipment and methods for lens grinding and figuring;  telescopes and microscopes; the camera obscura; anamorphosis; burning mirrors and catoptrics.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Glass<i>|Dillon, E.|Putnam, 1907, pp 278-291.||The Waldenburg Beakers and Johann Kunckel: Analytical and technological study of four corner-cut coloured glasses|Richter, R.W.|<i>Studies in Conservation<i>, Vol 57, No Supplement 1, 2012, pp  S234-S243.||http://deacademic.com/dic.nsf/dewiki/703810.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A review of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. Summary and positive consideration of the first six propositions of Book One, dealing the inhomogeneity of white light and the varying of refraction with color.
BP_Description_1: <i>Nouvelles de la r√©publique des lettres<i> was a periodical devoted to reviews of current publications, edited and in large part written by Pierre Bayle. It began publication in 1684, and is the first known book review journal. Bayle edited it from March 1684 through February 1687. It was continued by Daniel de Larroque, Jean Barrin and Jean Le Clerc through April 1689. Publication was suspended from then until January 1699 when it was resumed under the editorship of Jacques Bernard. He continued it through December 1710. It was then suspended until January 1716, when he resumed and continued until the final issue in June 1718.
BP_Description_2: A review of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. Summary and positive consideration of the first six propositions of Book One, dealing the the inhomogeneity of white light and the varying of refraction with color. The reviewer states the rest of the work will be considered at a future time and closes with the hope that the work will appear in Latin so it is available to everyone. Clearly the editor did not know that the Latin translation, <i>Optice<i>, was about to appear.
BP_Title: Review of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> 1704. In: Nouvelles de la republique des lettres. March 1706. p 307-323.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Protestant cleric, journal editor. Known for his religious and historical treatises.
BP_Provenance: Owner name crosshatched out on title page

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The review of Newton's Optice of 1706 that appeared in the Acta Eruditorum the same year.
BP_Description_1: Leibniz is often credited with the review that appeared in the Acta Eruditorum for February 1706, citing both the English <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 and the Latin <i>Optice<i> of 1706. Though edited by Leibniz, the review was written by Christian Wolff. The review is a neutral summary of the <i>Optice<i>.
BP_Description_2: The review of Newton's <i>Optice<i> of 1706 is actually a brief summary of the work, written in a neutral tone. Wolff seems to to accept Newton's theory of color and the heterogeneity of white light--making no mention, for example, of Mariotte's well-known objections to Newton's 'experimentum crucis.' Wolff would later present and support Newton's theory of color in his textbook of 1710
BP_Reference(s): The gradual acceptance of Newton‚Äôs theory of light and color, 1672‚Äì1727:|Shapiro, A.E.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 4, 1996, pp 59-140.||The Reception of Newton‚Äôs Theory of Light and Colour|Shapiro, A.E.|In: <i>Report No. 10 Mini-Workshop: On the Reception of Isaac Newton in Europe<i>, Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach, 2006, pp 567-569.
BP_Title: Review of Newton's Optice 1706. In: Acta Eruditorum. February 1706. p 59-64.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Johann Gross, Johann Friedrich Gletitsch and Friedrich Groschuf

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Samuel Clarke (1675-1729) English philosopher and cleric, correspondent, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Samuel Clarke's Latin translation of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. Seven new queries are added to the sixteen that appeared in the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. These queries famously dealt with the nature of light and related aspects of natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Since the appearance of the <i>Opticks<i> in February 1704, Newton had intended to produce a Latin version, but by 1699 he had been in London, master of the Royal Mint, and had no time and little interest is performing the translation himself. His friend and younger contemporary Samuel Clarke was given the commission. Clarke was a seasoned Latinist as well as possessing the background necessary to understand the content of the Opticks. Famously, Newton was so satisfied with Clarke‚Äôs ‚Äúpure and intelligible Latin‚Äù, he paid Clarke 500 pounds for the work, 100 pounds for each of Clarke's five children. In his biography of Newton, David Brewster claimed that Abraham De Moivre eventually oversaw or edited the translation, but this apears to be confusion on Brewster's part about another Latin work of De Moivre.||Though no longer active in natural philosophy, Newton did produce new Queries for the Latin version of his <i>Opticks<i> in 1706. These additions include references double refraction and to Hauksbee‚Äôs early experiments dealing with the mercurial light. Newton added Query 23, the longest and most important, dealing with forces by which bodies act at a distance. This would be numbered Query 31 in subsequent English editions. Clarke worked closely with Newton on the project as evidenced by their decision to slightly change the text in new Query 20 involving space as God's Sensorium. The change was made after printing had begun, resulting in a cancel at Ss1.||The appearance of the <i>Opticks<i> in 1704 drew little attention. In letters to Abraham Sharp and  James Pound in May and November of 1704, John Flamsteed wrote 'Mr Newton has publisht his treaty of light and Colours (he calls it Opticks).' Flamsteed was generally critical and wrote  that it ‚ÄòMakes no noyse in Town (as the principia did).' But the <i>Optice<i> of 1706 was the most influential edition of any of Newton's optical writings. It was widely read in continental Europe and was the principle mechanism for the spread of Newtonian optics. The earliest references to Newton's optics in a European textbook appeared in Christian Wolff's <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde Aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften<i> of 1710, citing the <i>Optice<i> of 1706. But a far more extensive exposition appeared in Germany with the second edition of Johann Jakob Scheuchzer's <i>Physica, Order Natur-Wissenschaft<i> of 1711. It devoted a 30-page chapter to a description of Newton's experiments, his numerical results, and had 5 plates of figures replicating many of those in the <i>Optice<i>. In France, the <i>Optice<i> was read by Nicholas Malebranche and he cited it as supporting his idea that color was an inherent property of light related to the 'promptness' of its percussive vibrations.  The importance of the queries that appeared in the <i>Optice<i> was considerable; they set the agenda and tone of the debate regarding the wave or particle nature of light for much of the 18th century.||Editions of the Latin translation appeared in London in 1706 and 1719, in Geneva in 1740, in Graz in 1747, and in Padua in 1749.
BP_Description_2: Like the <i>Opticks<i>, the <i>Optice<i> is in three Books. Book I is in two parts. Part I deals with prism experiments and the spectral heterogeneity of white light. It begins with definitions and axioms that review the basic aspects of geometric optics of reflection and refraction. This is followed by 8 propositions based on 16 experiments dealing with chromatic inhomogeneity and its consequences. Propositions 7 and 8 deal specifically with the limitations imposed on telescope objectives by what is now called chromatic aberration. Part II presents 11 propositions based on 17 experiments investigating the nature of color and the application of the theory of chromatic heterogeneity, particularly to the rainbow. It is here that Newton's 'experimentum crucis' of his letter of 1672 is presented in refined form and great detail.||Book II is in four parts. Part I presents 24 observations of the colored fringes produced by light passing through glass plates and thin lenses in contact in air and water. Part II presents a mathematical analysis of these observations, including Newton's method for determining small separating distances. Part III presents 20 propositions dealing with colors of natural bodies and their relationship to prismatic colors and color production in thin plates. it is here that Newton proposes that light has 'Fits of easy reflection and fits of easy transmission.' Part IV presents 13 observations of colors produced by thick plates.||Book III presents 11 descriptive observations of the color and placement of diffraction fringes produced by various objects. Queries--rhetorical questions--were Newton's means of proposing ideas about natural philosophy in general and the nature of light and color in particular. It is here that Newton dismisses wave theories of light as incapable of explaining its observed properties.  The Optice ends with the original 16 Queries of the Opticks, adds 7 new ones, and adds extensively to Queries 10 and 11. The Optice also provides an addendum describing luminescent light sources. Queries  17-23 are new in the Optice and deal with the nature of space, the plenum, the aether, and luminous corpuscles. Newton makes reference to Hauksbee's mercurial light and, ever-skeptical of Huygens' wave theory of light, adds an explanation for double refraction of certain crystals; an explanation based the corpuscular assumption of the nature of light. Query 23 is the longest and most important of all, by far, pondering the existence gravitational, magnetic, and electrical forces by which bodies can produce action-at-a-distance. He argues why these cannot be dismissed as 'occult forces' and suggest that other, more powerful forces may exist that are responsible for the interaction of light and matter. In this regard, Newton wonders if such forces could be both attractive and repulsive, depending on the distance over which they act. It would be this idea that Boscovich took up and developed it into his force law as part of his point-element theory of matter and force interaction. Query 23 ends with Newton's remarkable paragraph linking the development of natural and moral philosophy.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics in the Age of Euler: Conceptions of the Nature of Light, 1700-1795<i>|Hakfoot, C.|Cambridge University Press, 1995, 243 pp, NB: pp 5-17.||The methodological origins of Newton‚Äôs queries|Anstey, P.R.|<i>Studies in History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 35, No 2, 2004, pp 247-269.||The Case of the Missing Tanquam: Leibniz, Newton & Clarke:|Koyre, A. and Cohen, I.B.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 52, No 4, 1961 pp 555-566.||Les Queries de l'Optique|Koyre, A.|<i>Archieves Internationales d'Histoire des Sciences<i>, Vol 13, 1960, pp 15-29.||Sir Isaac and the ingenious Mr. Hauksbee|Guerlac, H.|In: <i>M√©langes Alexandre Koyr√©: L'aventure de la science<i>|Hermann, Paris, 1964, pp 228-253, NB 250-253.||Newton and God's Sensorium|Connolly, P.J.|<i>Intellectual History Review<i>, Vol 24, No 2, 2014, pp 185-201.||Enlarging the bounds of moral philosophy: Why did Isaac Newton conclude the Opticks the way he did?|Henry, J.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, 2016, online.||The Reception of Newton's Optical Work|Shapiro, A.E.|In: The Reception of Isaac Newton in Europe, Pulte, H., Mandelbrote, S., editors, Bloomsbury Academic, 2019, 1004 pp, NB: pp 403-432.
