BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary of Hartsoeker's physical theories on the Earth, elements, materials, and meteorics including light and vision. Later addenda were on the human body and the senses.
BP_Description_1: The origin, in part, of Hartsoeker's <i>Conjectures Physiques<i> was his anti-Newtonian ideas and his ongoing desire to participate in the European community of letters. Though working primarily in optics, he was interested in many aspects of physics, particularly mechanics and its application to the natural world. He added to his conjectures on physics in 1708 and 1712 and answered his critics in the 'Clarifications' of 1710 and 1712. Unlike Hartsoeker's later <i>Course de Physique<i> of 1730, the <i>Conjectures Physiques<i> was not written to teach but to present and dispute.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Conjectures Physiques<i> is in four books. Book 1: The system of the work. Book 2: The Earth and its properties. Book 3: Principles of physics. Book 4: Meteorics. Discourse 4 in Book 3 is on Refraction and reflection of light and the luminous point. Hartsoeker presents a physical theory for reflection and refraction, based on the idea of the physical extent of light rays --patterned after the proposals of Emanuel Maignan. In Book 4 Hartsoeker presents a summary of atmospheric optical phenomena and a recension of Descartes's explanation of the formation of the rainbow. This includes the calculations showing the clustering of refracted rays around the angle 42 degrees, giving rise the angular size of the rainbow. Rainbow colors are considered to be the result of differing refractions at the last water air interface.||The <i>Suite de Conjectures Physiques<i> considers aspects of human anatomy and the <i>Seconde Partie de la Suite de Conjectures Physiques<i> considers vision, the eye, and the optical functions of seeing. This includes how lenses can aid and correct vision. Bound at the end is a copy of Hartsoeker's <i>Essay de Dioptrique<i> of 1694.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Nicolas Hartsoeker's Syst√®me of Nature: Physics by Conjecture and Optics by Design in Early Modern Europe<i>|Abou-Nemeh, S.C.|Dissertation, Princeton University, 2012, 254 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first high school textbook of Mixed Mathematics for German-speaking students. A summary overview of several aspects of mathematics and applied mathematics, used in Military and Civil Engineering, Architecture, and other trades.
BP_Description_1: In his forward, Sturm makes clear his reason for writing this textbook. High schools in the German-speaking lands do not have suitable books for teaching Mixed Mathematics and applications. Books suitable for university use are too abstract and rest too heavily on theory for use in high schools. The presentation of the material must take the skill level of the student in mind and have an emphasis on the practical and the applied, if the students' interest is to be held. University text are usually in Latin and if a high school textbook is to be useful, it must be in German. The result is the first German-language high school textbook of Mixed Mathematics. The emphasis is mathematics applied to the practice of engineering, architecture, and other trades.||Editions appeared at Frankfurt in 1707 and 1710.
BP_Description_2: A summary overview of several aspects of Mixed Mathematics, with application is several fields. There are five parts. Part I, Mathematics including Universal Mathematics, The Science of Numbers, Size and Measure, Of Gravity and Movement, and Algebra.  Part II Application including  Arithmetic, Measuring Art,  Military Construction, Civil Construction, Artillery, and Mechanics. Part III includes  Astronomy, Geography, and Chronology. Part IV includes Description of Sundials, Optics, and Perspective. Part V is an Appendix of Necessary Mathematical Tables.||The section on optics and perspective is in four parts: Part I, General optics; Part II, Lens making; Part III, Perspective; Part IV, Anamorphosis. The material is almost entirely geometric optics; other than to establish the light ray as the principal manifestation of light, neither vision nor physical optics is treated. Light propagation, reflection, and refraction are described. Mirrors, plane and spherical, are discussed including the images they produce. Lens function is described in general terms, giving the basic properties of focal length and magnification. Lens use and function in telescopes is described. Finally, an elementary consideration is given to perspective and anamorphosis.||The treatment of optics is entirely descriptive, though detailed. Emphasis is on practical results and their application. The style has the form of questions and answers.
BP_Reference(s): Johann Christoph Sturm's contribution to the saeculum mathematicum (in German: Der Beitrag von Johann Christoph Sturm zum Saeculum Mathematicum)|Radbruch, K.|In: <i>Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703)<i>|Verlag Harri Deutsch, 2004, pp 136-152.||The Real Schools of Germany (translated from the German)|Raumer, K.|In: <i>German schools and pedagogy. Organization and instruction of common schools in Germany<i>|American Journal of Eduction, New York, 1861, 245 pp, NB: pp 123-148.

Einen Anhand von allerhand nethign mathematischne Tabellen. Nicht nur den Lehrenden und Lernenden zu Nutzen auffgesctzet. Sondern auch vor die Geubten hin und wieber mit neuen Anmerckungen kurtz und zu weiterem Nachsinnen untermenget. Von Leonhard Christoph Sturm. Math. Not only for Teachers and Students, but also occasionally for the Practiced. With New Notes for Further Consideration.  By Leonhard Christoph Sturm, Professor in Ordinary of Mathematics at Frankfurt and Member of the Royal Society of Science of Berlin.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by William Oughtred
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: William Oughtred's English translation and emendation of Jacques Ozanam's <i>Recreations Mathematiques et Physiques<i> of 1694.
BP_Description_1: Ozanam assembled problems from the works of Claude Gaspard Bachet De M√©ziriac of 1612, Jean Leurechon of 1624, Claude Mydorge of 1630, and Daniel Schwenter of 1636. The result is an elementary scientific encyclopedia to which Ozanam added brief commentaries and notes of his own. The second volume has, as an appendix, an elementary treatise on clocks, a text of Domenico Martinelli of Spoleto that Ozanam translated from the Italian. The work was written to be pedagogical, but always in the form scientific recreation. The mathematics, mechanics, and physical principles are always presented in an example and in an almost playful manner. By 1723 it had expanded to four volumes and in 1778 the work was revised and expanded by Jean-√âtienne Montucla. He introduced many additional topics and, more importantly, expositions of theory, changing the nature of the work considerably and extending is utility and appeal.||The <i>ReÃÅcreÃÅations MatheÃÅmatiques<i> was immensely successful, in print for 150 years. Editions appeared at Paris in 1694, 1696, 1697, 1698, 1700, 1723, 1725, 1735, 1741, 1749, 1770, 1778, 1790, 1803, 1814, 1844. English translations appeared at London in 1708, 1803, and 1814, and at Dublin in 1756
BP_Description_2: The subjects are presented in the form of problems and include: arithmetic, geometry, optics, gnomonics, cosmology, mechanics, pyrotechnics, physics, and clocks. The emphasis is practical and demonstrative; there is almost no theory. The section on optics problems includes: images in flat and concave mirrors; optical surveying; perspective drawing of various objects; burning mirrors; spherical lenses and burning lenses; properties of lenses of convex and concave figure; the lensed camera obscura; image anamorphosis onto various surfaces; and projecting lanterns. The optics material is elementary and no mathematics is used, but the presentations are clear and accompanied by numerous figures.
BP_Reference(s): Jacques Ozanam (1640‚Äì1718)|C√†ndito, C.|In: <i>Distinguished Figures in Descriptive Geometry and Its Applications for Mechanism Science: From the Middle Ages to the 17th Century<i>|Springer, 2016, pp 223-248.
BP_Title: Recreations mathematical and physical; Laying down and solving many profitable and delightful problems of arithmetick, geometry, opticks, gnomonicks, cosmography, mechanicks, physicks, and pyrotechny. By Monsieur Ozanam Professor of the Mathematicks at Paris. Done into English, and illustrated with very many cuts.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician. Successful private teacher, prolific mathematical author.
BP_Provenance: S. Dutton' on titlepage. Library stamp of St. Patrick's College, Maynooth, on verso

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A theory purporting to show how the distance, size, and orientation of an object are perceived through vision. Heralding the famed 'Immatialism' of Berkeley and his consideration of 'Molyneux's Question.'
BP_Description_1: Berkeley began writing <i>An Essay towards a new Theory of Vision<i> in 1707 and its publication in 1709 was an immediate success. Widely read and referenced by the educated public and specialists alike; Smith, Hartley, Porterfield are among the later writers in optics that drew on Berkeley and cited the <i>New Theory<i>--if only to refute it. The first two editions of the New Theory were published in Dublin in 1709. Revised versions appeared in 1732 being printed with the first and second editions of <i>Alciphron<i>. Significant changes were made in the Second Edition of 1709: In particular, sections 79 and 73 were reworded, modified and considerably extended, and an appendix was added.
BP_Description_2: A theory purporting to show how the distance, size, and orientation of an object are perceived through vision; providing a general criticism of vision theories based on geometry. The argument is made that, because all sensible objects are things we perceive by sense, and because nothing is perceived besides our own ideas, it follows that all sensible objects are ideas. Berkeley held that there were only four direct, immediate objects of visual sensation: shape, color, degree of faintness or clearness, and degree of confusion or distinctness. No others; all perceptions were held to arise from only these four--augmented perhaps by the sense of touch--and therefore perceptions involve learning and judgement. Additionally, the objects of sight and touch (or any two of the senses) are distinct and share no standard of measurement. These herald the later famed immatialism of Berkeley and his consideration of 'Molyneux's Question.'
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Berkeley's Theory of Vision and its Reception|Atherton, M.|In: <i>The Cambridge Companion to Berkeley<i>|Winkler, K.P., editor|Cambridge University Press, 2005, pp 94-124.||<i>Berkeley‚Äôs Theory of Vision: A Critical Examination of Bishop Berkeley‚Äôs Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision<i>|Armstrong, D. M.|Melbourne University Press,  1960.||Molyneux's Question in Berkeley's Theory of Vision|Loaiza, J.R.|<i>Theoria<i>, Vol 32, No 2, 2017, 231-247.||The Indirect Perception of Distance: Interpretive Complexities in Berkeley‚Äôs Theory of Vision|Braund, M.J.|<i>Kritike<i>, Vol 1, No 2, 2007, pp 49-64.
BP_Title: An essay towards a new theory of vision. By George Berkeley, M.A. Fellow of Trinity College, Dublin. The Second Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish philosopher, mathematician. Wrote importantly on perception and epistemology; particular on vision.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Experiments and resulting propositions regarding electricity and the generation of 'barometric light.'
BP_Description_1: Francis Hauksbee performed important experiments with electrical apparatus of his design before meetings of the Royal Society. Newton's ideas on the nature of electricity were largely shaped by Hauksbee's experiments. These and other experiments were written up into papers that appeared in the Philosophical Transactions, which Hauksbee eventually collected and cast into book form. Editions appeared in 1709 and 1719. An Italian translation appeared at Florence in 1716, and a French translation at Paris in 1754.
BP_Description_2: Hauksbee's book presents experiments and resulting propositions regarding electricity and the generation of 'barometric light', sometimes referred to as 'mercurial light.'  These experiments involved partial vacuum, static electricity, and what is now recognized as electro-luminescence of low-pressure discharges. The experiments and apparatus are described in great detail, with elaborate engraved figures. Taken together, the discussions present a theory of electricity and established a source of light that challenged current theories about the nature of light. Hauksbee used an air pump of his own design and construction to evacuate rotatable glass globes and cylinders, creating 'a fine purple light' inside them by rubbing the outside surface. The light would disappear gradually when air was let into the vessels, but at atmospheric pressure, rubbing (and so electrifying) the glass would enable it to attract woolen threads, etc. Hauksbee reports a series of experiments in optics, some of them concerning the refraction indices for a variety of substances, as measured by Snell‚Äôs law. In one such experiment he determined the indices for common air, vacuum and compressed air, using a hollow prism as well as an air pump and a condensing engine. He also developed a special instrument, made up of the prism, a stopcock, a gauge and a telescope.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Francis Hauksbee and his air pump|Brundtland, T.|<i>Notes and Records of The Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 66, 2012, pp 253-272.||Early Electricity between Chemistry and Physics: The Simultaneous Itineraries of Francis Hauksbee, Samuel Wall, and Pierre Polini√®re|Freudenthal, G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1981, pp 203-229.||Francis Hauksbee's theory of electricity|Home, R.W.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 3, 1967, pp 203‚Äì217.
BP_Title: Physico-mechanical experiments on various subjects. Containing an account of several surprizing phaenomena touching light and electricity, producible on the attrition of bodies. Together with the explanations of all the machines, (the Figures of which are Curiouslly engrav'd on Copper) and other apparates us'd in making the Experiments. By F. Hauksbee, F.R.S.
BP_Biographical Statement: English natural philosopher, experimentalist. Lab assistant to Isaac Newton, then instrument maker and experimentalist of the Royal Society; most importantly in electricity.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the Turner Collection at the University of Keele on pastedown. That of 'Carrington'  on free endpaper. Inscription 'R. Waller Roy Soc: Secr.' This Richard Waller, secretary to the Royal Society.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A manual of 100 experiments in natural philosophy; given is great detail, the results are explained with equal care. Experiments 84 through 100 deal with light and color.
BP_Description_1: Poliniere first gave physics lectures at the College d'Harcourt at Paris in the mid 1690s and their success had them repeated in other colleges and in subsequent years. Poliniere was one of the first academic lecturers to incorporate demonstrations of physical principles. His lectures became demonstration/experiment based and their written form produced a kind of manual or list of experiments. Widely used and very popular, editions appeared in 1709, 1718, 1728, a posthumous edition based on manuscript notes in 1734, and a reprinting in 1741. King Louis XV himself attended the course given in 1722--according to the preface of the posthumous edition. The successive editions reveal a growing certainty about and reliance on experiment; first, simply to demonstrate principles, but eventually to discover them. The second edition of 1718 both introduces Newton's ideas regarding color, but also shows the lingering hesitancy about reliance on experiment. By the time of the third edition, Poliniere had become completely convinced of the soundness of the experimental method as the basis for physics. The experiments, their results, and conclusions drawn from them are now presented without the caution and hedging found in the earlier editions; he now asserts that the principles of physics can be discovered directly and reliably by experiment.
BP_Description_2: A manual of 100 experiments in natural philosophy; given is great detail, the results are explained with equal care. Experiments 84 through 100 deal with light and color. This includes: colors in chemical solutions and materials; refraction, prismatic colors, the rainbow and its production; burning mirrors; vision; lenses of convex and concave figure; camera obscura; spectacles and optical instruments; and phosphor. The treatment is Cartesian, elementary and qualitative, but very clear in presentation.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Notion of Experimental Physics in Early Eighteenth-Century France|Home, R.W.|In: <i>Change and Progress in Modern Science<i>|Reidel Publishing, 1985, pp 107-131.||Poliniere and the teaching of physics at Paris: 1700-1730, Hanna, B.T.|In: <i>Eighteenth-Century Studies Presented to Arthur M. Wilson<i>, Gay, P., editor|University Press of New England, 1972, 197 p.||Early Electricity between Chemistry and Physics: The Simultaneous Itineraries of Francis Hauksbee, Samuel Wall, and Pierre Polini√®re|Freudenthal, G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1981, pp 203-229.||Francis Hauksbee's theory of electricity|Home, R.W.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 3, 1967, pp 203‚Äì217.||Pierre Poliniere, Francis Hauksbee, and Electroluminescence: A Case of Simultaneous Discovery|Corson, D.W.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 59, No. 4, 1968, pp 402-413.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A compendium of optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics. The treatment is geometric-qualitative, but complete. Early description of the endoscope.
BP_Description_1: A summary of geometrical optics for the purpose of self-study and the consideration of optical instruments. Conradi's text does not rely on mathematics beyond geometry and is generally descriptive. Though it touches on the nature of light and color, the bulk of the text deals the geometric optics of instruments. In his preface Conradi claims that some of the instruments described are of his invention.  Conradi's text was reviewed and summarized in the Acta Eruditorum for July 1711 and a century later cited by Goethe in his <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i> of 1810 to support his theory of color. Conradi is also cited by Hertels in his <i>Neue Anmerckungen Vom Glasschleiffen<i> of 1738. Conradi's material on the magic lantern was used in Georg Kr√ºnitz's <i>Ekonomisch-technologische Encyclop√§die<i> Vol 65 that appeared in 1794. This included one of Conradi's images. The book was self-published by Conradi and  dedicated to the duke of Saxony, Anton Ulrich.
BP_Description_2: A compendium of optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics applied to optical instruments and practice. The treatment is geometric-qualitative and descriptive, but detailed and complete. Simple ray-tracing is used to demonstrate function but there is nothing of optical design. The material covered includes: vision, simple ocular anatomy, and color; mirrors, catoptrics, catoptrical images, and reflective anamorphosis; dioptrics, lenses and lens making, dioptrical images, and optical instruments. The instruments include anamorphosis viewers, telescopes, microscopes, periscopes, camera obscura, and magic lanterns. In addition, Conradi demonstrates two-lens objectives for microscopes.
BP_Reference(s): The Quest for the Invisible: Microscopy in the Enlightenment|Ratcliff, M.J.|Routeledge, London, 2016, 314 pp, NB: pp 13-32.||VD18 2:01135075X In: Das Verzeichnis der im deutschen Sprachraum erschienenen Drucke des 18. Jahrhunderts (VD 18). Online at http://https://kxp.k10plus.de/DB=1.65/PPNSET?PPN=01135075X

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first great vernacular textbook of natural philosophy in Germany, and begins the so-called 'Anfangsgr√ºnde tradition' of textbooks. In four volumes with extensive figures.
BP_Description_1: The first great vernacular textbook of natural philosophy in Germany, and begins the so-called 'Anfangsgr√ºnde tradition' of textbooks. Wolff is preoccupied with correct teaching and what is necessary of full student understanding and so begins the book with Kurzer Unterricht von Der Mathematischen Methode oder Lehr-Art - Short Lessons about the Mathematical Method or, The Art of Teaching. One of the reasons for the text's great success was Wolff's refusal to make assumptions about what the reader or student knew, and his subsequent care in providing background, examples, and definitions. Wolff's textbook had little for almost fifty years. Editions appeared in 1710, 1716, 1725, 1730, 1737, 1743, 1750, 1755, 1763, 1775, with translations into Latin, Dutch, Polish, Russian, French, and Swedish. It was replaced only with books authored by the next generation of mathematicians in the second half of the 18th century: K√§stner, von Segner, Karsten, Clemm, and Kl√ºgel. A revised version of the text appeared in 1797.
BP_Description_2: The first introductory teaching compendium in German on Mixed Mathematics. There are four volumes. Vol I: arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry and architecture. Vol II: artillery, fortification, mechanics, hydrostatics, aerometry, and Hydraulics. Vol III: optics, spherical trigonometry, astronomy, chronology, geography, and horology. Vol IV: rudiments of algebra and the differential and integral calculus. The optics section (118 pages) includes: optics, with a euclidean-geometrical explanation of perception; making and figuring glass and metal mirrors; burning mirrors and images from mirrors; mirrors for anamorphosis; refraction, lenses and their focal and imagining properties; making and use of microscopes and telescopes; magic lanterns. The treatment is practical and geometric, with the dioptrics receiving a more extensive and mathematical treatment.  The presentation is formal and very concise, with axioms, theorems and their demonstration, and comments in scholia introducing most material. Examples by way of problems are presented and solved. The optics material draws heavily from Dechales, Huygens, and Zahn. Newton's color theory is described, though Wolff freighted it with a mediumistic/mechanical basis.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 29-93.||Christian Wolff (1679-1754) and his contribution for the Mathematics Education|Nobre, S|<i>Proceedings of the XXth International Congress of History of Science<i>|Brepols, 2002, pp 89-94.

Von Chrisitian Wolffen, Mathem. Prof. P.O. auf der Konigl. Preussischen Friederischs Universitat zu Halle.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary of physics for the general reader. The earliest presentation of Newtonian optics in Germany.
BP_Description_1: Second edition of Scheuchzer's <i>Physica<i>. It presents a summary of late 17th century natural philosophy for the interested lay reader. Like Bernard Nieuwentyt, Scheuchzer felt that the natural world directly reflected the work and presence of God. Though he presents a compendium of natural philosophy, it is explicitly grounded in his religious beliefs. His preface makes clear his idea of the relation between physics and scripture. Physics is based on experience and reason, not on authority. Though the Bible does speak about certain natural facts, it is not a complete textbook on natural knowledge and cannot be used to decide controversies in physics. Still, he says 'it is uncontrovertible that any time that [the Bible], in the representation of spiritual and celestial things, speaks about the nature and properties of natural things, this saying has to be taken as divine and infallible.' However tictured with religion, Schenchzer work usually avoided such questions, and simply reported the results of works in natural philosophy. He is careful and detailed to cite the authors from he draws his material. He makes no original contributions of his own.||The second and subsequent editions of Scheuchzer‚Äôs <i>Physica<i> differ from the first, principally by  their changes to the original chapter on light and an entirely  new  chapter, some thirty pages long, devoted to Newton's theory of prismatic colors. Scheuchzer cites the <i>Optice<i> of 1706, the Latin translation of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704, and brings to the wider German public the first description of  Newton‚Äôs discoveries. Scheuchzer's <i>Physica<i> was cited by Goethe in his <i>Geschichte der Farbenlehre<i>, as an example of how Newton's color theory came to be accepted in Germany. Scheuchzer's summary of Newton's optics was  widely-known in Germany--the publication  history of Scheuchzer‚Äôs compendium  attests to its popularity--and  was  probably  the  chief  source  for the  dissemination  of Newton‚Äôs  optical theories in Germany after 1711. The only earlier reference was much shorter reference in Chrisitan Wolff's <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde Aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften<i> textbook of 1710.||Scheuchzer's <i>Physica<i> is the earliest of a series of works that brought Newtonian optics to Germany early in the 18th century. These include Johann George Hoffman‚Äôs <i>Kurtze Fragen  von  den Natiirlichen Dingen<i> of 1719, which fully accepts Newton‚Äôs  color theory, and Johann Matthaes Barth‚Äôs <i>Physica Generalior, oder kurze Satze von denen natiirlichen Korpern √ºberhaupt<i> of 1724, which describes and explains it. Editions of Scheuchzer's <i>Physica<i> appeared in 1701, 1711, 1721, 1729, and 1743.
BP_Description_2: In his Forward, Scheuchzer cautions against adhering to one school of thought, mentioning Aristotle, Plato, Epicurus, Descartes, and Gassendi. Further, he argues for a mix of both sense-data (experiments) and reason, neither excluding the other. He cites Descartes as an example of reasoning without data. Scheuchzer holds that experiments, observations, and mathematics are required for natural philosophy, while hypotheses should be avoided.||The body of the <i>Physica<i> is in two parts and follows the traditional separation of <i>Physica Generalis<i> from <i>Physica Particularis<i>. Part 1 contains 37 chapters, dealing with the general aspects of natural philosophy: Mater and its properties, Motion of several types, Nature of Light. It is here that Scheuchzer devotes twenty-nine pages to a detailed summary of the <i>Optice,<i> including descriptions of the principal experiments and the precise reproduction of Newton's mathematical  tables  and  calculations. And though the section on motion presents several theories, the laws of motion from Newton's <i>Principia<i> have pride of place.||Part 2 contains 38 chapters dealing with particular aspects of natural philosophy: The heavens and planets, Air, Fire, Heat and Cold. Plants, Animals, and Man. In the chapters on astronomy, Scheuchzer discusses the geocentric and heliocentric systems of the universe and presents a extensive array of data about the planets and stars. Though he holds with the Copernican system, he does explain the Ptolemaic and Tychonian systems. He also gives, in  detail, the arguments both for and against the heliocentric system. His discusses Kepler‚Äôs planetary laws and how they are supported by Newton. In the chapters on the earth, he focuses on natural phenomena above, on, and beneath the its surface. This material is treated as a natural historian would,  describing and classifying a wide range of specific phenomena. There is a natural history of the waters, winds, stones and an especially detailed consideration of minerals. Animals and Man receive a briefer and more traditional treatment.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics in the Age of Euler: Conceptions of the Nature of Light, 1700-1795<i>|Hakfoot, C.|Cambridge University Press, 1995, 243 pp, NB: pp 23-24.||<i>Scientific Themes in the Popular Literature and the Poetry of the German Enlightenment, 1720-1760<i>|Schatzberg, W.|Peter Lang, Bern, 1973, NB: pp 47-49.||Newton‚Äôs Opticks and Brockes‚Äô Early Poetry|John, D.G.|<i>Orbis Litterarum<i>, Vol 38, 1983, pp 205-214.||Physico-Theology or Biblical Physics?|Vermij, R.|In: <i>Physico-theology: Religion and Science in Europe, 1650‚Äì1750<i>|Blair, A., von Greyerz, K., editors|Johns Hopkins University Press, 2020, 273 pp, NB: pp 166-169.
BP_Title: Physica, Order Natur-Wissenschaft. Verfasset Durch Johnann Jacob Scheuchzer, Med. D. Math. P.  Zweyte Verbesserte Auflag so mit nothigen Kuperen versehen
BP_Title English Translation: Physics, or Natural Science. Written by Johann Jacob Scheuchzer, MD and Prof of Mathematics. Second improved edition and provided with the necessary engravings.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss physician, scholar, author.  Famed for his multi-volume publication <i>Physica Sacra<i>.
BP_Provenance: Book plate of Heinz Prinzler, chemist and director of the Institut f√ºr Petrochemie. Author of <i>Vom Werden und Vergehen der Alchemie<i> 'The Rise and Fall of Alchemy.'

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A notes for lectures or demonstrations on light, color, and  vision and its correction and augmentation by lenses, especially the hyperbolic lens. Includes a very brief discussion of the telescope, microscope, and the prism.
BP_Description_1: The book is not a textbook, though Leonard David was regent at the Coll√®ge de Gen√®ve. It was, apparently, a set of notes to accompany lectures or demonstrations in optics. Under the printer's imprint on the title page: 'Sold at the home of the author, along with all sorts of materials which serve for demonstrations in optics.'
BP_Description_2: The notes are in two parts. The first covers the eye and vision. Basic ocular anatomy is presented, the material and figures based on the <i>Ophthalmo-Graphia<i> of William Briggs, rather than the earlier <i>Oculus<i> of Christoph Scheiner. The material on physical optics is very brief, luminous rays being the stated as the primary manifestation of light. Color is presented as the effect the length 'longueur' of the rays, as distinct from their size 'grandeur.' Different colors arise from different 'lengths' and mixed colors arise from rays of mixed 'lengths.' This is followed by the presentation of vision and aspects of visual perception including the perceptions of orientation, size, distance, and shape.||The second part deals exclusively with geometric optics and only that part concerning dioptrics. The material covered includes glass and its properties, spherical lenses both convex and concave. Lens properties are discussed briefly, but not their making. Interestingly, considerable attention is given the lens of hyperbolic figure and its anaclastic properties. Telescopes and microscopes are considered from the standpoint of the application of lenses. The final section is on the prism, and although prismatic colors are described, Newton and his theory of prismatic colors is not mentioned.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An anonymous students' lecture notes in Latin accompanied by diagrams, for a course in the eye, vision, and optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: By the time these notes were produced (1713) The University of Parma had been staffed with a mixed Civil and Jesuit faculty for more than a century. Jesuits taught theology, philosophy (logic, natural philosophy, metaphysics), mathematics, and humanities. The Civil faulty taught law and medicine. These notes are for a course in optics given by one Padre Becano, SJ. The title <i>Institutiones Optice sive de Oculo Naturali<i>  show the intention of the text is to study the eye and vision. Just enough geometric optics is covered to allow for a consideration of ocular optics and the function of simple optical instruments. The text is accompanied by 20 leaves giving 63 very carefully hand-drawn figures. The text is in a small, round hand, in brown ink.
BP_Description_2: The material centers on the eye and its function, the nature and characteristics of vision, and how simple optical instruments can aid vision. The ocular anatomy is that of Felix Plater and Kepler, but not yet that of Scheiner. Anatomy is covered just sufficiently to show how the eye forms images. Refraction and its role in the function of lenses is presented, along with the principles of focus, magnification, and images. The only material on geometric optics is simple ray-tracing through lenses. No physical optics is presented. The aspects of vision covered include size, position, motion, and binocular view. The material is descriptive, no mathematics in used. The presentation is elementary and traditionally Scholastic: Propositions, discussions, conclusions.
BP_Reference(s): The Jesuits and Italian Universities, 1548-1773|Grendler, P.F.|The Catholic University of America Press, 2017, 506 pp, NB: pp 154-187.
BP_Title: Optice Institutiones In Universitate Parmensi exhibituqe Anno millisimo septuagesimo decimo tertio. a P. Becano SI
BP_Title English Translation: Optical Instruction in the University of Parma, given in 1713 by Father Becano, SJ.
BP_Collation: Unsigned manuscript. Quires alternate gatherings of 3 and 4 leaves.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1713 Anonymous - Optice Institutiones - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A listing of terms and theories from philosophy and natural science, from Aristotelian to Cartesian but also Gassendian and other contemporary authors.
BP_Description_1: This is a reworking and significant extension of Chauvin's <i>Lexicon Rationale sive Thesaurus Philosophicus<i> of 1692, one of the earliest of dictionaries that covered natural philosophy. As the title implies, this is essentially a new work. It presenta a listing of terms and theories from philosophy and natural science, mostly Cartesian but also Gassendian and other contemporary authors, and so it reflects the state of learning at the start of the 18th century. The optical entries (<i>color, lens, lumen, lux, oculus<i>) are particularly long, detailed, and accompanied by clear engraved figures.||The Lexicon gives considerable space to each of three historical traditions: Scholastic teachings, the ideas of Descartes and the developments of Cartesians, and more modern impericist ideas. In general, the entries present an historical overview of the topic. It would be this aspect of the Lexicon that would cause it to be cited so often in the half-century following its publication.||Chauvin's <i>Lexicon<i> was widely used, being found in most European libraries. It was cited by scholars and reviewed in the Journal des S√ßavans and the Philosophical Transactions. Some of Chauvin's definitions and longer articles were reproduced later in Ephraim Chamber's <i>Cyclopedia<i> and in Diderot's <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, the <i>Encyclopedia Britanica<i>, and in Webster's <i>American Dictionary of the English Language<i>. Both John Harris in his <i>Lexicon Technicum<i> of 1704 and Ephraim Chambers in his <i>Cyclopedia<i> of 1728 cite Chauvin as inspiration and some-time source for their works. Regarding entries in natural philosophy, Chauvin's <i>Lexicon<i> was cited by Johann Sturm, Johannes Zahn, Pieter van Musschenbroek, by Thomas Johnson in his <i>Questiones Philosophicum<i>. Later textbook writers would cite entries from Chauvin's <i>Lexicon<i> not for the latest developments in natural philosophy, but rather for useful summaries of the history of the development of ideas.
BP_Description_2: In the sections of the Lexicon dealing with natural philosophy, Chauvin begins with a lexicographical lemma which is followed Chauvin's own summary definition. This is usually followed by extended, modified extracts from the many sources Chauvin uses. In natural philosophy these include: Aristotle, Albertus Magnus, Galileo, Kircher, Schott, Lana Terzi, Gobart, Descartes, Fabri, Grimaldi, Beckman, DuHamel, Boyle, Sturm, Dalrymple, Cally, and Newton.||The entry on color begins with Aristotle's definition and explanation, followed by that of the Cartesians. The entry ends with a long summary of Newton's hypothesis of prismatic colors and its consequences. The entry on lenses defines the various types, including that in the eye. Lens imaging is briefly described and spherical and chromatic aberration are mentioned. The entry for Lumen begins with a presentation of the history of ideas regarding the nature of light; from Aristotle to Descartes. The rest of the entry, the light ray is presented as the principle manifestation of light. Direct, reflected, and refracted light are considered. The entry for 'Luminis Trajectus' discusses the rectilinear propagation of light and the formation of pin-hole images. Given the extreme concision of all these entries, the accompanying figures play an important role in their presentation.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>√âtienne Chauvin (1640 - 1725) and his Lexicon philosophicum<i>|Gaspari, G., translated by Poole, F.|Georg Olms Verlag, 2016, 264 pp, NB: pp 146-175.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First edition of the first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Volume six contains optics, perspective, catoptrics, dioptrics, and atmospheric optics.
BP_Description_1: First edition of the first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Tosca wrote for his students, and the style and clarity of the books benefited from his long practice in teaching. The nine volumes are meant to cover all of mathematics and philosophy: I Arithmetic and Geometry, II Algebra and music, III Trigonometry and conics, IV Statics and Hydrostatics, V Civil and Military Architecture, VI Optics and Meteorics, VII Astronomy, VIII Geography and Navigation, IX Gnomics and Astrology. Tosca's textbooks were widely used and responsible, in part, for the introduction of modern science in Spain. The volumes of the first edition appeared at Valentia: V 1: 1707; V2: 1709; V3: 1710; V 4-5: 1712; V 6: 1713; V 7-9: 1715. The entire set was reprinted in Madrid in 1727 and 1757. Later in the century, Benito Bails would produced an equally comprehensive compendium, <i>Elementos de Mathem√°tica<i>, in which he acknowledged Tosca's work and its place in Spanish intellectual history.
BP_Description_2: The first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Volume six contains five sections on optics and meteorics, treatises XVIII - XXII. Section I Optics: general considerations and definitions; nature and propagation of light; nature of colors; transparent and opaque bodies; view and vision; eye-function; perception of size and shape; binocular vision. Section II Perspective: principles, iconographic and orthographic projection; methods for representing objects in various orientations; linear perspective; perspective of light, shadow, and reflected bodies; perspective of curved surfaces. Section III Catoptrics: general considerations an definitions; plane mirrors and their properties; convex and concave mirrors; cylindrical mirrors; spherical mirrors, caustics; simple rules for placing images from mirrors. Section IV Dioptrics:  refraction and its effects; cause and properties of refraction; location of refracted images; refractive glasses and their properties; combining refracting bodies; convex lenses, concave lenses; refraction and the generation of colors. Section V Meteorics: the sea and the wind; atmosphere and clouds, all type of precipitation; lighting; lights generated in the air; the rainbow; other forms of light; comets.||Though the basis is essentially Cartesian, Tosca also cites Grimaldi, Kircher, Scheiner, Zahn, Dechales, Rheyta, Zucchi, but not Huygens (1690) or Newton (1704). The wave and corpuscular theories of the nature of light are presented, but each is considered unproven. But Tosca presents experiments that support the wave hypothesis and he invokes the the analogy to sound propagation as also supporting the wave hypothesis. Color theory follows Pardies and is a hybrid of Aristotelian and Cartesian. The material is detailed, descriptive, and presented with mathematics no more advanced than geometry.
BP_Reference(s): El "Compendio Mathem√°tico" del padre Tosca y la introducci√≥n de la ciencia moderna en Espa√±a|Cu√©llar, M.R.|In: <i>Actas del Segundo Congreso Espa√±ol de Historia de la Medicina<i>,  Vol 1|Salamanca, 1965, pp 325-359.||<i>La introducci√≥n de la ciencia moderna en Espa√±a<i>|L√≥pez Pi√±ero, J. M.|Ediciones Ariel, 1969, pp 137-144.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching compendium on Mixed Mathematics in Latin. Based on and greatly expanding Wolff's own <i>Anfangs-Grunde<i> of 1710.
BP_Description_1: First edition of one of the greatest compendia of mathematics and natural philosophy of 18th century. Based on and greatly expanding the <i>Ansfangs-Gr≈±nde<i> of 1710. Editions appeared in 1713 at Magdeburg, 1717 at Magdeburg, 1730 at Magdeburg, 1732 at Geneva, 1732 at Paris, 1735 at Geneva, 1741 at Verona, 1742 at Magdeburg, 1743 at Geneva, 1743 at Paris, 1746 at Verona. Each new edition required several years to complete, spanning as long as nine years. Reference to the <i>Optice<i> 1706; supports Newton on nature of light and color.
BP_Description_2: A teaching compendium on Mixed Mathematics in Latin. Based on and greatly expanding the <i>Anfans-Gr√ºnde<i> of 1710. The optics section (312 pages) includes: optics, the nature of light, shadow, and color; visual perception including size, shape, location, motion, and binocular vision; catoptrics including making and figuring glass and metal mirrors; burning mirrors and images from mirrors; mirrors for anamorphosis; dioptrics including refraction, lenses and their focal and imagining properties; lens figuring and polishing, making and use of microscopes and telescopes; magic lanterns. The treatment is thorough and mathematical. 270 figures on 39 engraved plates accompany the optics text.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 29-93.||Christian Wolff tussen Cartesianen en Newtonianen|Hakfoort, C.|<i>Tijdschrift voor de Geschiedenis der Geneeskunde, Natuurwetenschappen<i>, Wiskunde en Techniek 5, 1982, pp 27‚Äì38.||<i>Christian Wolff als Mathematiker und Universit√§tslehrer des 18. Jahrhunderts<i>|Sommerhoff-Benner, S|Shaker, 2002.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Johann Adolph Wedel (1675 - 1747) German professor of medicine and chemist.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A thesis on double vision; that is, diplopia.
BP_Description_1: The first work since Kepler/Aguil√≥n to discuss double vision, a thesis under the direction of Johann Adolph Wedel, prominent physician and professor at the University of Jena. One of many dissertations presented by students of Wedel at the University of Jena. As was the custom, the thesis was written by the presiding officer--in this case, Wedel.
BP_Description_2: A thesis on double vision, that is, diplopia. Though evidently unknown to Wedel-Din, the dissertation describes the horopter. Reference is made to William Briggs <i>Ophthalmographia<i> of 1686 and its concept of corresponding points in two eye. From this, Wedel-Din extend the idea to corresponding rays.
BP_Reference(s): Theories of Binocular Vision after Aguil√≥n|Ziggelaar, A.|<i>Strabismus<i>, Vol 20, No 4, 2012, pp 185-193.||Eye Representation and Ocular Terminology from Antiquity to Helmholtz|Raynaud, D.|Wayenborgh, Amsterdam, 2020, 635 pp, NB: pp 197.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A defense of the Peripatetic ideas concerning the nature of light and color.
BP_Description_1: Herculanus Karg CRL was the student respondent, a Canon Regular of the Lateran of the Order of St. Augustine. As was the custom, the disseration was written by the presiding officer, presented and defended by the student. An example of the late and lasting reach of Scholastic teaching.
BP_Description_2: A defense of the Peripatetic ideas concerning the nature of light and color.  Cartesian and Newtonian authors are cited, as well as Aristotelian. Conventionally disputatious, with no reliance on experiment or observations, only authority. The topics and disputations considered are: Nature of light, Is light corporeal?, Are the accendents of Lumens Absolute?, What is color?, Is Color Permanent?, Is Color identified with the modification of Light?, What are Visual Species?, Are Colored Visual Species different from Light?||In the process of considering these questions, Hausman cites many authors, principally Descartes.
BP_Reference(s): Geschichte der Philosophie bei den Katholiken in Altbayern, bayerisch Franken|Rixner, T.A.|Munchen, 1835, 175 pp, NB: pp 158-160.

BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, professor at the University of Ingolstadt

BP_Short or Common Title: The Young Gentleman's Trigonometry, Mechanicks, and Opticks
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary textbook of natural philosophy with an extensive section on optics with extensive figures.
BP_Description_1: Among the unwearying output of Edward Wells, was a three-volume course in Mixed Mathematics. The topics included Arithmetick and Geometry; Mechanicks, Opticks, and Trigonometry; and Astronomy, Chronology, and Dialling. Wells's purpose was to provide textbooks written in simple language that could be use by student and craft practitioner. His audience required an emphasis on the practical application of knowledge and though the material is mainly descriptive, geometry is used extensively. In optics, for example, Wells foundation is vision and his preface states that he wishes to be about not 'only explaining the Manner of Vision in a Geometrical Way, but also by the same Principles teaching how to supply or remedy the several Defects of the Sight, by the Help of proper Instruments, such as Spectacles.'||Wells's texts were standbys, widely used in England and America in the first half of the 18th century. The three volumes appears between 1712- and 1714. Between 1718 and 1736 parts of the books were reissued separately: The <i>Young Gentleman's Astronomy, Chronology, and Dialling<i> issued in 1718, 1725, and 1736; The <i>Young Gentleman's Arithmetick and Geometry<i> issued in 1723, and <i>The Young Gentleman's Trigonometry, Mechanicks, and Opticks<i> issued in 1731.
BP_Description_2: The optics section (74 pages) includes: elementary geometrical optics, ocular anatomy, euclidean-geometric visual perception; reflection, plane and spherical mirrors and the images created; refraction, lenses of convex and concave figure and the images created; the magic lantern, microscope, and telescope; and perspective. The optics material is complete in elementary essentials, geometry-based, and accompanied by 66 figures.
BP_Reference(s): The teaching of elementary geometry in the seventeenth century|Kokomoor, F.W.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 11, No 1, 1928, pp 85-110.||The Book Collections of Early American College Libraries|Kraus, J.W.|<i>The Library Quarterly<i>, Vol 43, No 2, 1973, pp 142-159.
BP_Title: The Young Gentleman's Trigonometry, Mechanicks, and Opticks. Containing such Elements of the said Arts or Sciences, as are most Useful and Easy to be known. By Edward Wells, D.D. Rector of Votesbach in Leicestershire.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, geographer, and theological disputant and author.
BP_Provenance: Signature of John Fleming, Oriel College, date 1777 on front pastedown

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Sir William Browne (1692 - 1774) English physician.
BP_Short or Common Title: Dr. Gregory's elements of catoptrics and dioptrics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: English translation of the Latin <i>Catoptric√¶ et dioptric√¶ sph√¶ric√¶ elementa<i> of 1695.
BP_Description_1: English translation of Gregory's Latin lecture notes on optics printed as <i>Catoptric√¶ et dioptric√¶ sph√¶ric√¶ elementa<i> in 1695, together with an extensive addendum. Browne's long introduction recounts the very basics of optics regarding lenses and cites the great utility of their use in telescopes and microscopes, and the discoveries made with those instruments. Browne was physician but, though competent in optics and mathematics, was not a specialist and so had John Desaguliers review his translation. Desaguliers encouraged its publication. Editions appeared in 1715 and 1735, the latter by Desaguliers who added an introduction and a history of the reflecting telescope.
BP_Description_2: Browne's translation of the Latin includes the entire text of the 1695 Latin edition as well as additions and corrections that he mentions as 'all along in the Translation explain'd such Passages as the  Author's Laconick Style has made something too puzzling for a Beginner, and corrected several considerable Faults of the Press, which has escaped his Care.' Browne also added an addendum that is as long again as the translated text. The first part of this adds some mathematical detail and missing steps to several proofs, particularly involving the Calculus, where Browne uses Leibniz's notation rather than fluxions. He also solves several of the problems Gregory left as an 'exercise for the reader,' gave a general method for finding mirror and lens foci, and provided extensive notes from Huygens regarding the function and use of the telescope and microscope.
BP_Reference(s): David Gregory and Newtonian Science|Eagles, C.M.|<i>The British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 10, No 3, 1977, pp 216-225.
BP_Title: Dr. Gregory's elements of catoptrics and dioptrics. To which is added, I.A method for finding the foci of all specula as well as Lens's universally. As also for Magnifying or Lessening a given Ojbect by a given Speculum or Lens in any assign'd Porportion, etc. II. A solution of those problems which are left undemonstrated. III. A particular account of microscopes and telescopes, from Mr. Huygens. With an introduction shewing the discoveries made by catoptrics and dioptrics. By W. Browne, A.M. & Med. Pract.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scothish mathematician. Taught at University of Edinburgh and Oxford. Promoter of Newtonian ideas in the university curriculum. [Pedantic, garrulus, prolific, learned]
BP_Provenance: This copy was clearly studied; ink splash on page 25 and extensive marginal notes in the first addendum.
BP_Publisher or Seller: E. Curll, J. Pemberton, and W. Taylor

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian translation of the <i>Physico-Mechanical<i> Experiments of 1709.
BP_Description_1: Italian translation of the <i>Physico-Mechanical Experiments<i> of 1709. Hauksbee‚Äôs book was widely read in the eighteenth century. Emerging from total obscurity, Hauksbee made his debut before the Royal Society at the meeting of 15 December 1703, the first to be presided over by the newly elected president, Isaac Newton. On this occasion Hauksbee showed a striking experiment: when mercury rushed into the evacuated receiver of his new model air pump, spilling over an inverted glass vessel, the result was a sparkling light, ‚Äúa Shower of Fire descending all round the Sides of the Glasses.‚Äù It seems clear that Hauksbee, an experimental genius but a scientific autodidact, derived his theoretical principles from Newton. In addition to Italian, translations appeared in Dutch and French.
BP_Description_2: Italian translation of the <i>Physico-Mechanical Experiments<i> of 1709.
BP_Reference(s): Early Electricity between Chemistry and Physics: The Simultaneous Itineraries of Francis Hauksbee, Samuel Wall, and Pierre Polini√®re|Freudenthal, G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1981, pp 203-229.||Francis Hauksbee's theory of electricity|Home, R.W.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 3, 1967, pp 203‚Äì217.

Colle spiegazioni di tutte le macchine. Opera di F. Hauksbee della Societa Regia tradotta dall'idioma inglese.

With the Explanations of all the Machines. A Work of F. Hauksbee of the Royal Society. Translated from the English.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Practical manual for glass grinding and lens making.
BP_Description_1: Christian Gottlieb Hertel made public what had long been the secret art of grinding lenses and building optical instruments. Christian Wolff provided a preface and supplements from J.F. Leutmann.
BP_Description_2: Practical manual for glass grinding and lens making. Including: preparation of grinding molds; glass types; spherical lens figuring and polishing; parabolic, hyperbolic, and elliptical figures; prisms and polyhedra faceting; optical machines; making concave and convex spectacles; microscopes; common (that is, Holland) lenses and the telescope;  helioscope, binoculars, polemoscope; camera obscura; refractive anamorphosis, magic lanterns; micrometers and compound microscopes.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Extensive prize essay  on luminescence for the Bordeaux Academy of Science. A chemical/alchemical consideration of phosphorus as elemental light, light bearer, or fire material, and luminescent sources.
BP_Description_1: Cohausen's <i>Lumen<i> was a serious scholarly effort submitted to the Bordeaux Academy of Science in competition of a prize granted by the Duke of force of 300 Livres for the best answer to a proposed question. In this case, the price committee requested an explanation for the cause of light from phosphorus, a topic of much current interest.
BP_Description_2: Extensive prize essay  on luminescence for the Bordeaux Academy of Science. A chemical/alchemical consideration of phosphorus as elemental light, light bearer, or fire material, and luminescent sources. These include: natural phosphors of air and land, animal phosphors, and hermetic phosphorus.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Notes meant to be used by attendees of lectures demonstrating aspects of natural philosophy. One of the earliest public courses in science printed in Britain.
BP_Description_1: By the time Desaguliers published these public lecture notes, he had been giving lectures at Oxford for 7 years. and had become the de factor curator of experiments to the Royal Society, a position once held by Robert Hooke and then Francis Hauksbee. The lectures were meant for both student and popular audience, explaining and advancing Newtonian science. As stated in the letter To the Reader, the notes--referred to as 'papers'--were printed at the request of the course auditors, were essentially only minutes taken at the lectures themselves, and were printed and made available to eliminate the need for attendees to take their own notes. Importantly, Desaguliers makes clear that the notes themselves should be considered only a memorandum, lacking many details, but promising that a fuller accounting of the contents of the lectures will be forthcoming.||Desaguliers's 'papers' appeared in 1717. In 1719 one of the lecture attendees, Paul Dawson, published a transcript of the Lectures with Desaguliers's knowledge or permission. Desaguliers failed to prevent the distribution of the book, but did force the publishers to include a Preface Desaguliers wrote, expressing his dismay, the errors he found in the text, and many corrections. In 1725 a short syllabus for the lectures appeared, being an advertising piece and not a rendering of content. Desaguliers's full course in natural philosophy eventually appeared in two volumes in 1734 and 1744. Though optics was originally intended to be treated in the second volume, by the time Desaguliers came to write it, Robert Smith's elaborate A Compleat System of Opticks of 1738 had appeared. Desaguliers decided to simply refer his readers to Smith's treatise.
BP_Description_2: The notes cover lectures on astronomy, mechanics, hydrostatics, optics, electricity and machinery. Lectures XVI to XXII cover optics (40 pages) and include: basic ocular anatomy and eye function; reflection and refraction; lenses and their imaging basic properties; microscopes; telescopes. Lecture XXII presents a summary of Newton's theory of heterogeneous, prismatic colors. The presentation is elementary, practical, and descriptive, without any mathematics. They are, as the preface states, minutes taken from the lectures, with each section accompanied by the recounting of one or more experiments for demonstration. The latter is at the heart of the notes and Desaguliers' method. He held that teaching natural philosophy required clear, observable demonstrations of facts, and that unornamented abstractions of theory do not suffice. Thus, the most important aspect of the notes are the descriptions of demonstrations. Generally, Desaguliers devised simplified equipment that could, in the case of optics, easily be obtained and used to demonstrate all significant optical phenomena that the lectures presented.
BP_Reference(s): <i>John Theophilus Desaguliers: A Natural Philosopher, Engineer and Freemason in Newtonian England<i>|Carpenter, A.T.|Continuum, 2011, pp 177-203.||Jean The!ophile Desaguliers (1683-1744) and eighteenth century vision research|Wade, N.J.|<i>British Journal of Psychology<i>, Vol 91, 2000, pp 275-285.||Competing to Popularize Newtonian Philosophy: John Theophilus Desaguliers and the Preservation of Reputation|Wigelsworth, J.R.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 94, 2003, pp 435-455.
BP_Title: Physico-mechanical lectures, or, An account of what is Explain'd and Demonstrated in the course of Mechanical and Experimental Philosophy, given by J.T. Desaguliers, M.A.F.R.S. Wherein the Principles of Mechanics, Hydrostatics and Optics, are demonstrated and explain'd by a great number of experiments. Design'd for the use of all such as have seen, or may see courses of experimental philosophy.
BP_Biographical Statement: British natural philosopher, engineer, Anglican priest. Popular lecturer on Newtonian physics, demonstrator at the Royal Society, prolific author.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1717 Desaguliers - Physico-mechanical lectures - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: Dissertation sur la cause de la lumiere des phosphores
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Brief prize essay on luminescence for the Bordeaux Academy of Science.
BP_Description_1: de Mairan's essay was part of the response to a development at the opening of the 18th century: scholarly societies began to offer prizes for essays dealing with general problems. The prize offered by the Bordeaux Academy of Science is an example. The prize was announced in 1714 and de Mairan submitted his winning entry not long after. The essay shows the thinking current at the time regarding the nature of light and the attempts to make either of them account for common luminous phenomena--in the case of the Academy's prize, the various forms of luminescence and phosphorescence. The first half of the essay presents the two then-current theories of light: wave propagated in an aether or the emission of luminous corpuscles. de Mairan believe in the latter, and the remainder of the essay attempts to explain a wide range of luminous phenomena on that basis.||de Mairan's essay was printed at Paris in 1715 and at Bordeaux in 1717.
BP_Description_2: Prize essay on luminescence for the Bordeaux Academy of Science. First part discusses the then-current theories of the nature and propagation of light: aetherial waves or luminous corpuscles. de Mairan held that the luminous corpuscles consisted of sulfur--one of the five chemical 'principles' known at the time. The second part considers phosphors and night lights and consider them in two groups: natural and artificial. Natural phosphors were animal, plant, and insect lights, as well as mineral and agitation-based lights such as rubbed diamonds of crushed sugar. Artificial phosphors were atmospheric phenomena as well as the burning phosphor of Kunkel and the Bolognian Stone. There is nothing experimental or demonstrative in de Mairan's essay; he threads together a set of explanations from a few basic ideas to cover a very wide range of phenomena.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>A History of Luminescence<i>|Harvey, E.N.|American Philosophical Society, Philadelphia, 1957, 692 pp, NB:  pp 151-154.
BP_Title: Dissertation sur la cause de la lumiere des phosphores et des noctiluques. Qui a remporteÃÅ le prix aÃÄ l'Academie Royale des Belles Lettres, Sciences & Arts de Bordeaux, pour l'anneÃÅe 1717. Par Mr. Dortous de Mayran.
BP_Title English Translation: Dissertation on the Cause of the Light of Phosphorus and of Luminous Plankton. Which Won the Prize of the Royal Academy of Belle Letters, Science and Arts of Bordeaus for the year 1717.  By Mr d'Oortous de Mairan
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer. Active experimentalist, author, and investigator of meterological questions that prompted Bouguer's work in photometry.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second English edition, first issue, of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. Third edition overall. Contains the queries in the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704, those new in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706, and eight new ones dealing with the aether.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 228. The Opticks would have vast influence, particularly in the form of its Latin translation that appeared in 1706 and this, the second English edition, each with additional Queries. Newton's fundamental propositions of the chromatic heterogeneity of white light and varying chromatic refrangibility was generally accepted by the time this edition appeared. The corpuscular theory of light's nature, proposed in the Queries, would set the terms of the debate with the wave theory of light for all of the 17th century. The Queries were renumbered in this and subsequent editions. English editions of the <i>Opticks<i> appeared in 1704, 1717, 1721, 1730, and 1931. A Latin translation appeared at London in 1706, 1719, at Geneva in 1740, at Padua in 1749 and 1773. A French translation appeared at Paris in 1720 and 1722.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 228. The second English edition of the Optics contains the original 16 Queries of the Opticks, the 7 added in the Optics of 1706, and 8 new ones. The 8 Queries new in the second English edition are placed after the original 16 and are number 17-24. The 7 Queries new in the Optice of 1706 are here numbers 25-31, and adds extensively to Queries 10 and 11. The Optice also provides an addendum describing luminescent light sources. Queries  25-31 were new in the Optice and deal with double refraction and, perhaps most importantly, the nature of space, the plenum, the aether, and luminous corpuscles. Query 31, new in the Optice, is the longest of all, by far, and deals with gravitational attraction and ends with Newton's remarkable paragraph linking the development of natural and moral philosophy.. Queries 17-24, new in the second English edition, deal with the Newton's idea of the aether or subtle, particular matter and its interaction with heat and light. Also new in the second English edition is reference to the "mercurial light" of Hauksbee's experiments.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Preface and Introduction|Cohen, I.B. and Whittaker, E.|In: <i>Opticks, Sir Isaac Newton<i>|Dover, New York, 1952, pp ix-lvii.||Les Queries de l'Optique|Koyre, A.|<i>Archieves Internationales d'Histoire des Sciences<i>, Vol 13, 1960, pp 15-29.||The methodological origins of Newton‚Äôs queries|Anstey, P.R.|<i>Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 35, 2004, pp 247-269.||Sir Isaac and the ingenious Mr. Hauksbee|Guerlac, H.|In: <i>M√©langes Alexandre Koyr√©: L'aventure de la science<i>|Hermann, Paris, 1964, pp 228-253, NB 250-253.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Contains the <i>De Optica Analytica<i>, a treatise on catoptrics and dioptrics. The treatise includes geometric optics for mirrors of conic sections and the dioptrics of lenses.
BP_Description_1: John Craig produced three important, pioneering treatises on the Calculus and a long series of works on the application of the calculus. The <i>De Optica Analytica<i> is an example of the latter: an early application of the Calculus to optical problems. Craig was the an early British user of Leibniz's notion for the calculus, but in <i>De Optica Analytica<i> he reverted to Newton's notation, probably in keeping with the work with which it was published. The <i>De Calculo Flentium Libri Duo<i> was reviewed in the <i>Acata Eruditorum<i> for April 1719: a favorable assessment and an extended summary.
BP_Description_2: Contains the <i>De Optica Analytica<i>, a treatise on catoptrics and dioptrics. The treatise (25 pages) includes: A first section on catoptrics, developing geometric optics for mirrors of conic sections, giving equations for evaluating and designing curves derived using the Calculus; A second section on dioptrics giving a mathematical analysis of spherical and elliptical lenses, including spherical aberration. In the case of both catoptric, and dioptrics, establishes equations expressing the properties of mirrored or lensed imaging systems and uses the calculus to find foci, distances, and radii of curvature. Examples are provided in each case.
BP_Reference(s): A history of the study of mathematics at Cambridge|Rouse Ball, W.W.|Cambridge, 1889, 264 pp, NB: pp 77.
BP_Title: De Calculo Fluentium Libri Duo (with) De Optica Analytica
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish methematician and theologian. Friend of Isaac Newton and promoter of the calculus.
BP_Provenance: Detailed table of contents, inscribed on front free endpaper. 'French 5Àù‚Çí' on the titlepage. Bookplate of W.C. Mylne.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the <i>Experiences de Physique<i> of 1709. A manual of 107 experiments in natural philosophy; given is great detail, the results are explained with equal care.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 245. The second edition of 1718 both introduces Newton's ideas regarding color, but also shows the lingering hesitancy about reliance on experiment. By the time of the third edition, Poliniere had become completely convinced of the soundness of the experimental method as the basis for physics. The experiments, their results, and conclusions drawn from them are now presented without the caution and hedging found in the earlier editions; he now asserts that the principles of physics can be discovered directly and reliably by experiment.
BP_Description_2: A manual of 100 experiments in natural philosophy; given is great detail, the results are explained with equal care. Experiments 84 through 100 deal with light and color. This includes: colors in chemical solutions and materials; refraction, prismatic colors, the rainbow and its production; burning mirrors; vision; lenses of convex and concave figure; camera obscura; spectacles and optical instruments; and phosphor. The treatment is Cartesian, elementary and qualitative, but very clear in presentation. In this edition, Newton's ideas concerning prismatic colors are introduced.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Notion of Experimental Physics in Early Eighteenth-Century France|Home, R.W.|In: <i>Change and Progress in Modern Science<i>|Reidel Publishing, 1985, pp 107-131.||Early Electricity between Chemistry and Physics: The Simultaneous Itineraries of Francis Hauksbee, Samuel Wall, and Pierre Polini√®re|Freudenthal, G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1981, pp 203-229.||Francis Hauksbee's theory of electricity|Home, R.W.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 3, 1967, pp 203‚Äì217.||Pierre Poliniere, Francis Hauksbee, and Electroluminescence: A Case of Simultaneous Discovery|Corson, D.W.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 59, No. 4, 1968, pp 402-413.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Samuel Clarke (1675-1729) English philosopher and cleric, correspondent, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fourth edition of Samuel Clarke's Latin translation of Jacques Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> of 1671, a complete textbook of Cartesian-based natural philosophy. Fully empirical, with numerous experiments and observations reported to test theory and hypothesis. Cartesian optics includes the nature of light, color, transparency and opacity.
BP_Description_1: At the end of his preface to the first French edition of the <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> of 1671, Jacques Rohault mentions that he was 'preparing a Latin version in favor of foreigners, in whom I dare promise myself a fairly favorable reception.' But Rohault never publish a Latin translation. The first was this very close translation produced by the Geneva physician TheÃÅophile Bonet which appeared at Geneva in 1674. It was reprinted at London and Amsterdam in 1682, at Amsterdam in 1691 and 1700 and at London in 1691 with notes by the Franciscan Antoine Le Grand, at Amsterdam in 1708 and Cologne in 1713 with notes by both Le Grand and Samuel Clarke. For use at English universities, Clarke made a second Latin translation that appeared at London in 1697 and preprinted in 1702, 1710, and 1718 (this edition). It was into these editions of his Latin translation of Rohault that Clarke added every more numerous and lengthy notes, augmenting, supplanting, and eclipsing Cartesianism with Newtonianism.||Clarke's translation was one of the most widely used textbooks in Europe in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. The influence of Clarke's translation and his notes rested on the way it introduced and propagated Newton's physics among all those who were not keen on mathematical details of physical processes, but interested in the new explanatory quality of Newtonian physics. This is a reprinting of the third edition of 1710, the last Clarke produced in his life time, and contains half-again as many notes as the previous edition, now comprising nearly one-fifth of the book, and eight additional plates of figures. This was the third and last revision and extension that Clarke made of his notes and since by this time the <i>Optice<i> of 1706 had appeared, it was heavily referenced in the optics section.
BP_Description_2: Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> is in four parts. Part 1 is in 35 chapters and covers principles of physics, nature of matter, motion and its analysis, forms of matter, heat and cold, the senses of taste, smell, and hearing, and finally the eye, optics, and vision. The Cartesian principles of extension, divisibility, motion, and rest are used to deduce general laws of statics, dynamics, and--via ballistic conceptions  of reflection and refraction--optics. Part 2 is in 29 chapters and covers cosmography, astronomy, selenography, the planets and their movements, the fixed stars, and finally the competing theories of the sun and planets. Rohault plumps for the Copernican as the most rational. Part 3 is in 17 chapters and covers geology in general, including the Earth and things that are part of it, such as the atmosphere, the seas, metals and minerals, fountains, winds, fogs and clouds, rain and hail, snow and frosts, lighting, and finally the rainbow. Part 4 is in 26 chapters and covers anatomy, muscles and movement, blood and circulation, digestion and breathing, and finally maladies and disease.||The optics material, though patterned closely after Descartes' essay La Dioptrique, it is fully empirical with experiments, demonstrations, and observations reported to test theory and hypothesis. The topics include: the nature of light, color, transparency and opacity. Direct, reflected, and refracted light are demonstrated as well as the simpler forms of image formation by mirrors and lenses. Descartes theory of vision is presented in full. All the optical topics are treated in an elementary but thorough manner. Thus, for example, the focusing properties of spherical convex lenses are demonstrated, but nothing is said of spherical aberration.||Experiment receives a double role: on the one hand, it is shown how it discriminates between conjectures pointing to the ones that are empirically confirmed; on the other hand, it is a powerful pedagogical tool that can convince the reader of explanations given and laws stated.||As with the other topics, Rohault's Cartesian optics is accompanied by Samuel Clarke's notes containing additions, amplifications, and corrections derived from Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 and the <i>Optice<i> of 1706.
BP_Reference(s): Samuel Clarke‚Äôs Annotations in Jacques Rohault‚Äôs <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>, and How They Contributed to Popularising Newton‚Äôs Physics|Volkmar Sch√ºller, V.|In: <i>Between Leibniz, Newton, and Kant<i>, Wolfgang Lefovre, editor,  2001, NB: pp 95-110.||Rohault's Cartesian Physics|Dobre, M.|In: <i>Cartesian Empiricisms<i>, Springer, 2013, pp 203-226.||Rohault's Traite de Physique and its Newtonian Reception|Dobre, M.|In: <i>Proceedings of the 4th International Conference of the ESHS<i>, 2010, pp 389-394.||The experimental physics of Jacques Rohault|Spink A.|<i>British Journal for the History of Philosophy<i>, Vol 26, No 5, 2017, pp 850-870.||The Study of Early Scientific Textbooks|Sarton, G.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 38, No 3/4, 1948, pp 137-148.||Motion and God in XVIIth Century Cartesian manuals: Rohault, R√©gis and Gadroys|Milani, N.E.|<i>Noctua<i> Vol 2, Nos.1-2, 2015, pp 481-516.
BP_Title: Jabobi Rohaulti Physica. Latine vertit, recensuit, & adnotationibus ex illustrissimi Isaaci Newtioni Philosophiae maximam partem haustis, amplificavit & ornavit Samuel Clarke, S.T.P.  Editio Quarta, in qua Annotationes sunt dimidia part auctiores, additaeque octo Tabulae aeri ineisae.

Translated into Latin, reviewed, enlarged and furnished with notes drawn in large part from the philosophy of the illlustrious Isaac Newton, by Samuel Clarke, S.T.P. The Fourth Edition, in which the notes are increased by half and eight incised plates are added.
BP_Biographical Statement: French natural philosopher and mathematician. Experimentalist and textbook writer, the first and greatest promoter of Cartesian physics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Encyclopedia of Pure and Mixed Mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Johann Weidler began teaching at the University of Wittenberg using Wolff's <i>Elementa Matheseos Universae<i> and Sturm's <i>Kurtzer Begriff der gesambten Mathesis<i>. Weidler considered both in need of revision and so produced his own textbook. Weidler's textbook is an early example of the influence of Newton's Latin <i>Optice<i> of 1706. Editions appeared in 1718, 1725, 1736, 1750, 1759, and 1784.
BP_Description_2: Comprehensive textbook of Pure and Mixed Mathematics, including: Arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, optics, perspective, spherical trigonometry, astronomy, geography, gnomics, mechanics, hydrostatics, aerometry, hydraulics, architecture, algebra and calculus. The optical sections (80 pages) include: ocular anatomy; nature of light, color, and shade; vision and perception; catoptrics involving plane and curved mirrors and their images; refraction and dioptrics involving lenses of convex and concave figure and their images; telescopes, microscopes, and magic lanterns. The material is elementary but detailed and thorough. Presented as problems with experiments, followed by descriptive conclusions reached from their solutions. Weidler's textbook is an early example of the influence of Newton's Latin Optice of 1706. Though citing Newton's color theory, Weidler still presents color as a mixing of white and black.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics in the Age of Euler: Conceptions of the Nature of Light, 1700-1795<i>|Hakfoot, C.|Cambridge University Press, 1995, 243 pp, NB: pp 23-26.||Christian Wolffs Lehre im √∂stlichen Europa|M√ºhlpfordt, G.|<i>Aufkl√§rung<i>, Vol 12, No 2, 2001, pp 77-100.
BP_Title: Jo. Frider. Weidleri Mathes Prof. Publ.  Institutiones Mathematicae decem et sex purae mixtaeque matheseos disciplinas complexae. Sub finem accedunt Tabulae Logarithmorum contractae et index generalis qui lexici mathematici instar esse possit.
BP_Title English Translation: Johann Friedrich Weidler, Professor of Mathematics. Ten Mathematical Instructions and Encompassing Six Disciplines of Pure and Mixed Mathematics. At the End are Added Abbrevidated Tables of Logarithms and a General Index from Which it is Possible to be Like a Mathematical Dictionary.
BP_Biographical Statement: German astronomer, mathematician. Taught at the University of Wittenberg, authored important textbooks.
BP_Provenance: Owner inscriptions dated  1792, 1801, and 1821 on front free endpaper

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A brief, practical manual for the construction of optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: The attribution to Agostino Dal Pozzo is a surmise. He was known as Mathesiphilo and the title page gives Mathesiphilo as the author. Dal Pozzo's dates are unknown, but his much earlier work, <i>Gnomonices Biformis<i> of 1679, was very well known. Certainly the present work derives, in part, of the <i>Gnomonices Biformis<i>, though it is not clear if Dal Pozzo is the author. It is clear that the author is a practiced hand at dialling and lens craft. The material on lens grinding and polishing is practical and detailed.
BP_Description_2: A brief, practical manual for the construction of optical instruments, in three parts. Parts one and two are devoted to horological instruments of various kinds. The third part, <i>De Optica Mechanica<i>  consisting of 20 pages, is devoted to the grinding and polishing of convex lenses. Details include molds and forms, glass assessment, grinding, and polishing. An appendix describes the generation of parabolic mirrors.
BP_Reference(s): Eine Optikeranweisung aus dem Ende des 17. oder dem Anfang des 18 Jahrhunderts (An optician's instruction from the late 17th or early 18th century.)|Rohr, M.V.|Deutsche Optische Wochenschr, 1931, Vol 17, pp 331-345.

Or, On the Art of Polishing Glasses to Server in the Telescope. Composed and brought to light by Mathesiphilo. With many figures incised on copper.
BP_Biographical Statement: Nothing is know of this Italian horologist and oculist. Presumably related to Andrea del Pozzo (1642-1709), an Italian architect and painter.
