BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Paul Dawson
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Unauthorized, pirated elaboration of the <i>Physico-Mechanical Lectures<i> of 1717. The preface by Desaguliers was inserted by booksellers at his insistence after he failed to prevent distribution of the book.
BP_Description_1: Unauthorized, pirated elaboration of the <i>Physico-Mechanical Lectures<i> of 1717. By the time Desaguliers found out about this pirated printing, 2/3 of the imprint had been sold. He insisted that in all the unsold copies the publishers include a Preface he  wrote and errata list he produced. Desaguliers Preface contains his grousing and references the book's many errors and refers the reader to the list of errata he provided. Some of these copies were issued with a new title Page, the original 'A System of Experimental Philosophy' changed to 'Lectures in Experimental Philosophy' and 'All Carefully Examined and Corrected by Mr. Desaguliers' added. This copy contains the first form of the title page, Desaguliers' Preface, and the Errata.
BP_Description_2: The optics section (45 pages) includes: reflection, catoptrics of plane and curved mirrors, burning mirrors; refraction, dioptrics of lenses of various figures and their images; ocular anatomy and eye function; spectacles; the microscope; the telescope; Newton's theory of white light chromatic heterogeneity. The Figures are detailed and superior to those in the publication of 1717, and the presentation geometric.
BP_Reference(s): Competing to Popularize Newtonian Philosophy|Wigelsworth, J.R.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 94, 2003, pp 435‚Äì455.||John Theophilus Desaguliers: A Natural Philosopher, Engineer and Freemason in Newtonian England|Carpenter, A.T.|<i>Continuum<i>, 2011, pp 32-37.

As performed by J.T. Desaguliers. M.A. F.R.S. Illustrated with several copper plates. BP_Biographical Statement: British natural philosopher, engineer, Anglican priest. Popular lecturer on Newtonian physics, demonstrator at the Royal Society, prolific author.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Practical manual for glass grinding and lens making.
BP_Description_1: Leutmann presents a Paralipomena to Hertel's <i>VollstaÃàndige Anweisung zum Glas-Schleiffen<i> of 1716. Leutmann had spent many years as professor of mechanics and optics at the Academy of Sciences at St. Peterburg and had developed machines and techniques for lens figuring, polishing, and assessment. He sets out descriptions of his machines and methods, and records his experience in this work. The <i>Neue Anmerckungen vom Glasschleiffen<i> was reviewed in the <i>Acta Eruditorum<i> for August 1719. Hertel would issue a corrected and revised edition of Leutmann's work in 1738.
BP_Description_2: Leutmann's <i>Neue Anmerckungen vom Glasschleiffen<i> is a practical manual for glass grinding and lens making. It is in 14 chapters. Chapter 1: A consideration of lens polishing machines, their defects, how they can be improved, and their proper use. Chapter 2: Preparing spherical lenses including various methods for grinding, figuring, and polishing. Chapter 3: A consideration of Hertel's method for figuring non-spherical lenses including paraboloid, hyperbolic, and elliptical. Chapter 4: Polyhedral lenses. Chapter 5: Sizing and polishing lenses to achieve specific focal lengths. Chapter 6: Plano-convex and concave lenses to correct vision. Chapter 7: Lenses for microscopes and the design, manufacture, and use of mirrors for illuminating specimens. Chapter 8: Meniscus lenses in telescopes. Chapter 9: Construction, function, and use of the Camera Obscura. Chapter 10: Use of a concave mirror in the Magic Lantern. Chapter 11: Dioptric viewers using polyhedral lenses to reconstruct separated images. Chapter 12: The micrometer. Chapter 13: Method for observing light refraction and the instruments of Johannes Zahn. Chapter 14: Various optical machines.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A Survey of the Newtorks Bringing a Knowledgge of Optical Glass-Working to the Londong Trade, 1500-1800<i>|Mc Connell, A.|Whipple Museum of the History of Science, 2016, pp 88-89.

BP_Title English Translation: Johann George Leutmanns, Professor at St. Petersburg. New Notes on Glass Grinding. Along with All Sorts of New Optical Instruments, Such as Those Made and Used and Others Already Known, But Improved.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, oculist. Taught mechanics and optics at the Academy of Sciences of St. Petersburg at the invitation of Tsar Peter I. Produced important mechanical and optical instruments.

BP_Description_2: A thesis on 'barometric light,' giving Bernoulli a chance sum what was known and to answer critics. Includes: a brief history, conditions which generate barometric light, the nature of light, consideration of causes, and potential uses.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Samuel Clarke (1675-1729) English philosopher and cleric, correspondent, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of Samuel Clarke's Latin translation of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. This edition of the <i>Opticks<i> contains all the new queries., famously dealt with the nature of light and related aspects of natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: See Entry 236. This second edition of the <i>Optice<i> contains a Latin translation of Newton's Letter to the Reader from the second English edition of 1717. It mentions the removal of the mathematical tracts that had appeared at the end of the book in previous editions and mentions the new Query (here number 31, number 23 in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706) regarding gravitational and other central forces. This edition of the <i>Optice<i> was reviewed in the Acta Eruditorum for April 1720.||Editions of the Latin translation appeared in London in 1706 and 1719, in Geneva in 1740, in Graz in 1747, and in Padua in 1749.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 236.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 236.
BP_Title: Optice: sive de reflexionibus, refractionibus, inflexionibus & coloribus lucis libri tres. Authore Isaaco Newton, Equite Aurato. Latine reddidit Samuel Clarke, S.T.P. Editio Secunda auctior.

BP_Biographical Statement: English natural philosopher, mathematician, alchemist, Mint Master. Genius of preternatural ability, the greatest physicist of the 17th century.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The <i>Physices elementa mathematica<i>, a handbook of physics covering virtually all of its subjects, is the basis for 's Gravesande's subsequent handbooks and textbooks.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> is the foundation of 's Gravesande's fame, and the basis for his subsequent other handbooks and textbooks which became the most important and influential of the Newtonian educational works on the continent and in England. It relied on what it presented as the Newtonian notion of dependence on only experiment and geometry. The content, scope, and style of the <i>Physices Elementa Nathematica<i> and it's various subsequent versions were both embodiment and extension of 's Gravesande's deeply influential teaching and the reason the books were so influential in the 18th century. They had sufficient compelling clarity to help eventually overcame the predominance of Cartesianism in France and the Leibnizian-Wolffianism of Germany and Russia.|The first edition of the Latin text appeared in 1720, the second edition of 1725 was enlarged and intended more for scientific peers rather than students, the edition of 1742 was extensively reworked and augmented, and the last edition appeared in 1748. The <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> was also translated into English by Desaguliers, appearing in six editions, and into French in 1745. A portable, one-volume abridgement of the Latin text appeared in 1723.
BP_Description_2: A handbook of physics covering: statics; dynamics; gravity; fluids; fire, heat, light, and electro-luminescence; optics; system of the world; and celestial motion. The optics section (90 pages or about 15% of the text) includes: the nature and propagation of light; refraction; Newtonian spectral refraction; spherical lenses; eye and vision; spectacles for vision correction; microscopes, telescopes, and their use; reflection and catoptrics; the magic lantern; color, chromatic heterogeneity of white light, spectra, the rainbow, colors of thin plates, colors in nature. The main points are demonstrated by experiments, their presentation detailed and geometry-based. Numerous detailed figures, descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable.||The physical optics that 's Gravesande's text presents has fire and light as manifestations of an 'elemental fire', with both sharing many of the same properties. The fundamental aspect of propagation is emission--as opposed to traveling waves--and the interaction of light with materials in reflection, refraction, and diffraction is ascribed to the effect of forces operating over very small distances. 's Gravesande's emission theory is a kind of filtered and simplified version of Newton's ideas; it avoids any mention of the aether that Newton mentioned in the later Queries of the Optice of 1706, does not deal with double refraction, and does not mention Newton's fits of easy transmission and reflection or his suggestion regarding 'sides' or 'poles' of the light particles. Also notable is the absence of consideration of any other theory of the the nature of light and its propagation.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ ‚Äôs Gravesande and Musschenbroek: Newtonianism at Leiden|Ruestow, E.G.|In: <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.||The impeccable credentials of an untrained philosopher: Willem Jacob 's¬†Gravesande's career before his Leiden professorship, 1688‚Äì1717|Jip van Besouw|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 70, No 3, pp 231‚Äì249.|http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4978728/
BP_Title: Physices elementa mathematica, experimentis confirmata. Sive Introductio ad Philosophiam Newtonianam Auctore Gulielmo Jacobo 'sGravesande; A.L.M. Fur. Vtr. & Phil. Doctore, Regie Societ. Lond. Socio, Astron. & Math. in Acad. Lugd. Bat. Professore ordinario.
BP_Title English Translation: The Mathematical Elements of Physics, Confirmed by Experiments. Or, An Introduction to Newtonian Philosophy. Author: Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande; [‚Ä¶] Doctor of Philosophy, Fellow of the Royal Society of London, Professor in Ordinary of Astronomy and Mathematics in the University of Leiden.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Pierre Coste (1668-1747) French theologian, writer, prolific and important translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A French translation of the second edition of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1718. The translator's prefaces gives a brief, general history of color theory, followed by a more detailed account of the effect of Mariotte's failure to replicate Newton's experimentum crucis and its eventual experimental verification demonstrated later by Desaguliers.
BP_Description_1: Though not explicitly linked, the origins of Coste's translation are likely rest on three things. First, the successful demonstration by Theophilus Desaguliers of Newton's 'experimentum crucis'--showing the heterogeneity of white light and the immutability of monochromatic light--at the Royal Society in London in Februrary 1715. Present were three members of the French Academy of Sciences: the mathematician Pierre R√©mond de Montmort, the astronomer Jacques-Eugene d'Allonville (Chevalier de Louville), and the chemist C.J. Geoffroy. Second, as mentioned in Coste's Preface, the repetition of this demonstration In Paris to several members of the French Academy. Third, the gradual eclipse of Mariotte's negative assessment of Newton's chromatic ideas as evidenced by changes in the content of French texts on natural philosophy regarding color, such as Pierre Polin√®re's Exp√©riences de Physique and the change of the optics material from Cartesian to Newtonian in the first and second editions of 1709 and 1718.||Coste's translation is based on the second English edition of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1718, including the 31 Queries; presented here as questions. The Coste's prefaces gives a brief, general history of color theory, followed by a more detailed account of the effect of Mariotte's failure to replicate Newton's experimentum crucis and its eventual experimental verification demonstrated later by Desaguliers. The preface also states that the translation was undertaken at 'the order of a great princess'--this was Caroline of Anspach, Princess of Wales. Newton granted permission for the translation and its publication and Desaguliers looked over the manuscript.||Coste's translation was reviewed in the May 1720 issue of Journal des S√ßavans. Importantly, the reviewer finds the translation important since very few persons in France had 'thoroughly explored the reasons Mr. Newton used to support his system.' This was a direct reference to the long, detailed description of the 'experimentum crucis' that was given in the experiments and propositions of Book I, Part I of the Opticks. Just as importantly, this was the first appearance in French of the Queries that appeared in the Opticks of 1704 and the Optice of 1706. Translations of Newton's Prefaces for the English editions of 1704 and 1717/1718 are provided. A second and far more elaborately produced edition of <i>TraiteÃÅ d'Optique<i> appeared in 1722.
BP_Description_2: The preface gives a brief, general history of color theory, followed by a more detailed account of the effect of Mariotte's failure to replicate Newton's experimentum crucis and its eventual experimental verification demonstrated later by Desaguliers. For the main text, Coste follows the English closely. The translation is in three Books. Book I is in two parts. Part I deals with prism experiments and the spectral heterogeneity of white light. It begins with definitions and axioms that review the basic aspects of geometric optics of reflection and refraction. This is followed by 8 propositions based on 16 experiments dealing with chromatic inhomogeneity and its consequences. Propositions 7 and 8 deal specifically with the limitations imposed on telescope objectives by what is now called chromatic aberration. Part II presents 11 propositions based on 17 experiments investigating the nature of color and the application of the theory of chromatic heterogeneity, particularly to the rainbow. It is here that Newton's 'experimentum crucis' of his letter of 1672 is presented in refined form and great detail.||Book II is in four parts. Part I presents 24 observations of the colored fringes produced by light passing through glass plates and thin lenses in contact in air and water. Part II presents a mathematical analysis of these observations, including Newton's method for determining small separating distances. Part III presents 20 propositions dealing with colors of natural bodies and their relationship to prismatic colors and color production in thin plates. it is here that Newton proposes that light has 'Fits of easy reflection and fits of easy transmission.' Part IV presents 13 observations of colors produced by thick plates.||Book III presents 11 descriptive observations of the color and placement of diffraction fringes produced by various objects. Queries--rhetorical questions--were Newton's means of proposing ideas about natural philosophy in general and the nature of light and color in particular. It is here that Newton dismisses wave theories of light as incapable of explaining its observed properties. The second English edition of the <i>Opticks<i> contains the original 16 Queries of the <i>Opticks<i>, the 7 added in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706, and 8 new ones. The 8 Queries new in the second English edition are placed after the original 16 and are number 17-24. The 7 Queries new in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706 are here numbers 25-31, and adds extensively to Queries 10 and 11. The <i>Optice<i> also provides an addendum describing luminescent light sources. Queries  25-31 were new in the Optice and deal with double refraction and, perhaps most importantly, the nature of space, the plenum, the aether, and luminous corpuscles. Query 31, new in the <i>Optice<i>, is the longest of all, by far, and deals with gravitational attraction. Queries 17-24, new in the second English edition, deal with the Newton's idea of the aether or subtle, particular matter and its interaction with heat and light. Also new in the second English edition is reference to the "mercurial light" of Hauksbee's experiments.

Lang,  New York, 1991.||Early eighteenth-century Newtonianism: the Huguenot contribution|Baillon, J-F.|<i>Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 35, 2004, pp 533‚Äì548.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A course in experimental natural philosophy, a successor to that taught by Johann Sturm and patterned after Sturm's work of the same title of 1676 and 1685.
BP_Description_1: Update of the <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> with Newtonian prismatic optics
BP_Description_2: A course in experimental natural philosophy, a successor to that taught by Johann Sturm and patterned after Sturm's work of the same title of 1676 and 1685. The material on optics (76 pages) includes: luminous rays and their propagation; linear propagation, inverse-distance-square density; reflection and plane mirrors; refraction in diverse media; lenses and their images; nature of vision, spectacles; microscopes, telescopes, and their use; the magic lantern; prismatic colors and the Newtonian theory of white light heterogeneity. The presentation is entirely practical and experiment/demonstration-based; other than the simplest geometry, no theory or mathematics is involved.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Culture of Experimentalism in the Holy Roman Empire: Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703) and the Collegium Experimentale<i>|Ahnert, T.|http://sammelpunkt.philo.at/308/||Das <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> sive curiosum und die Anf√§nge experimenteller Naturlehre in Deutschland [The <i>Collegium Experimentale<i> sive Curiosum and the beginnings of experimental natural philosophy in Germany]|Wiesenfeldt, G.|In: <i>Johann Christoph Sturm (1635-1703)<i>|Verlag Harri Deutsch, 2004, pp 184-203.||Experiment in Cartesian Courses: The Case of Professor Burchard de Volder|Nyden, T.|In: <i>4th International Conference of the European Society for the History of Science<i>, Barcelona, 2010, pp 384-390.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching compendium of logic, physics, and metaphysics. Book III contains optics material.
BP_Description_1: Though based on parts of his earlier work, the <i>Compendio Mathematico<i> of 1707-1715, Tosca's <i>Compendium Philosophicum<i> presents both a broader range of material, is written for the general university student, and in form and language--it is written in Latin--is a more traditional general university course in philosophy. Unlike the <i>Compendio Mathematico<i>, the <i>Compendium Philosophicum<i> contains virtually no mathematics. Editions appeared in 1721 and 1757.
BP_Description_2: The work is in five Books. Book I: On logic and Metaphysics. Book II: General Physics, Part One. Book III: General Physics, Part Two. Book IV: On the Elements, Meteorics, Fossils, Minerals, and Plants. Book V: On Animals and Metaphysics.||Book III contains the optics material (112 pages) including: the nature of opaque and transparent materials; the nature of light and lights, propagation; consideration of Aristotelian, Cartesian, and Newtonian theories of light's nature; reflection, plane mirrors; linear propagation, inverse-distance-square density, and the nature of illumination; color and Aristotelian, Cartesian, and Newtonian theories of color; the rainbow. The style is disputatious with propositions, proofs, and discussion. The presentation is entirely descriptive, no mathematics is used.

BP_Short or Common Title: Recueil de plusieurs pieces de physique
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A consideration and rejection of Isaac Newton's theory of gravity and its application to celestial phenomena.
BP_Description_1: Nicolaas Hartsoeker initially held with Descartes' theory of vortices and their role in the motion of comets. Though he would eventually move away from Cartesianism and establish his own conjectural system of natural philosophy, at the time these pieces, he held that planets and comets moved by vortices. The motion of  comets seemed to Hartsoeker to be a particular failure of Newton's system of gravity and that is what he argues in these pieces. Hartsoeker's ideas never acquired much reach, with Huygens and other prominent natural philosophers find his conjectures unsupported and strange.
BP_Description_2: The first section is a letter to Jean Le Clerc and outlines Hartsoeker's objections to then-current systems of natural philosophy. This is followed by "Reflections" in which Hartsoeker pursues his objections to Netwon's system, citing the motion of comets in particular. He then presents his own system, including that to explain planetary and cometary motion.
BP_Reference(s): Controversies over Comets: Isaac Newton, Nicolas Hartsoeker, and Early Modern World-Making|Abou-Nemeh, C.|In: Reading Newton in Early Modern Europe|Boran, E. and Feingold, M., editors|Brill, 2017, pp 147-191.||Nicolas Hartsoeker's Syst√®me of Nature: Physics by Conjecture and Optics by Design in Early Modern Europe|Abou-Nemeh, C.|Dissertation, Princeton University, 2012, 254 pp.

BP_Title English Translation: Collection of Several Physical Pieces
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch mathematician, natural philosopher, oculist, microscopist. Famous in his time, a member of  French Academy of Sciences and the Prussian Academy of Sciences.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Pierre Coste (1668-1747) French theologian, writer, prolific and important translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the French translation of the second edition of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1718. With a new preface by the translator.
BP_Description_1: The origins and production of the second edition of Coste's French translation of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1717/1718 rests principally with the mathematician and friend of Isaac Newton, Pierre Varignon. Varignon was asked by officials governing Royal Privilege for his opinion regarding publishing Coste's translation in France. Varignon approval contained high praise for the book and its author. Varignon would become overseer for the project of publishing the translation in France and to some extent Coste became somewhat of an unhappy bystander to the entire process. At one point, Varignon brought in the French Chancellor Henri Fran√ßois d'Aguesseau to bring the book's wayward publisher-bookseller to heel--a token of the importance given the book by a wide and influential audience. Abraham De Moivre was asked by Varignon to suggest changes to the text and submit them to Newton for approval. Coste also suggested changes but Varignon would take none of Coste's suggestions unless they were approved by Newton himself. In this way Newton became tangled up in the production of the book, eventually approving Coste's suggested changes, to the annoyance of Varignon, though the changes suggested by both De Moivre and Coste were not significant.||Varignon and Chancellor d'Aguesseau rejected early proof sheets and directed the printer to use new type. These sheets were shown to Newton for his approval and, at Verignon's suggestion, left significant space at the start of each Part for a vignette. At Varignon's request, Newton himself provided a sketch for the first of these; it and the others were drawn in final form by Jean Chaufourier and engraved by Antoine Herisset. As in the first edition, translations of Newton's Prefaces for the English editions of 1704 and 1717/1718 are provided. The new edition appeared in quarto at Paris in 1722 and marked the near-general acceptance of Newton's optical theories in France.
BP_Description_2: See Entry 283.

Lang,  New York, 1991.||Early eighteenth-century Newtonianism: the Huguenot contribution|Baillon, J-F.|<i>Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 35, 2004, pp 533‚Äì548.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of the most important and influential of the Newtonian textbooks. ¬¥s Gravesande based this on and condensed it from his <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> of 1720.
BP_Description_1: One of the most important and influential of European Newtonian textbooks. Based on and condensed from the <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> of 1720, it's spare and clear presentations in straightforward Latin aimed very specifically at students, disseminated Newtonian physics throughout Europe. The presentations were the essence of 's Gravesande's lectures and are notable for the accompanying instruments and demonstration/experimental apparatus. The presentations and apparatus were widely copied and used by authors of other books and professors of other university courses. Translations appeared in English, French, and Dutch. The Latin text appears in many editions: at Leyden in 1723, 1725, 1744, 1766, and 1774,  at Leyden and Amsterdam in 1728, at Venice in 1749, and at Vienna in 1760.
BP_Description_2: Textbook of Newtonian physics covering: matter, statics, and simple machines; dynamics; fluids, hydraulics, pneumatics; fire, heat, and light; color; system of the world, universal gravity. The optics section (89 pages) includes: refraction on plane and curved surfaces, dioptrics, and spherical lenses; eye function; microscopes and telescopes; reflection, catoptrics, plane and spherical mirrors; the magic lantern; color, Newton's theory of white light chromatic heterogeneity; the rainbow, colors from thin plates, colors in nature. The presentation is detailed and geometric. Numerous detailed figures, descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable.||The physical optics that 's Gravesande's text presents has fire and light as manifestations of an 'elemental fire', with both sharing many of the same properties. The fundamental aspect of propagation is emission--as opposed to traveling waves--and the interaction of light with materials in reflection, refraction, and diffraction is ascribed to the effect of forces operating over very small distances. 's Gravesande's emission theory is a kind of filtered and simplified version of Newton's ideas; it avoids any mention of the aether that Newton mentioned in the later Queries of the <i>Optice<i> of 1706, does not deal with double refraction, and does not mention Newton's fits of easy transmission and reflection or his suggestion regarding 'sides' or 'poles' of the light particles. Also notable is the absence of consideration of any other theory of the the nature of light and its propagation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics in the Age of Euler: Conceptions of the Nature of Light, 1700-1795<i>|Hakfoot, C.|Cambridge University Press, 1995, 243 pp, NB: pp 42-46.||<i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Ruestow, E.G.|Springer, 1973, 174p, NB: pp 113-139.||<i>The History of Science in the Netherlands: Survey, Themes and Reference<i>|Van Berkel, K., Van Helden, Al, Palm, L., editors|Brill, Leiden, 1999, pp 68-95, 450-453.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by John Clarke (1682-1757) English natural philosopher.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: John Clarke's English translation of a late edition of Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>. Rohault's Cartesian physics is accompanied by John's brother Samuel Clarke's notes containing additions, amplifications, and corrections derived from Newtonian physics.
BP_Description_1: By the time John Clarke produced this English translation of Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>, his brother Samuel Clarke's notes has been developing for nearly 25 years in the Latin form that accompanied Clarke's 1697 Latin translation of Rohault's text, having been thoroughly revised twice. The notes had become elaborate, themselves notated, and nearly 1/3 as long as Rohault's text. Three editions of this translation with notes appeared (1723, 1728/9, 1735) and were prompted, perhaps, by the rapidly fading Latin skills of English students, and the continuing need for textbook of natural philosophy in English Universities. The text was also used extensively in America. The book was presented as Cartesian physics with Newtonian refutation and was used widely until the middle of the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: John Clarke's English translation of a late edition of Rohault's <i>Traite de Physique<i>. The optics sections (90 pages) include: light, color, reflection and refraction in materials; ocular anatomy; eye function; dioptrics and lensed images; reflection, plane and spherical mirrors and their images; nine problems in visual perception. As with the other topics, Rohault's Cartesian optics is accompanied by John's brother Samuel Clarke's notes containing additions, amplifications, and corrections derived from Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 and the <i>Optice<i> of 1706.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An overview of diverse aspects of natural philosophy, culled from many sources. A type of guide to the literature.
BP_Description_1: A summary and analysis of previous works in a few areas of natural philosophy; a type of guide to the literature. The text is filled with references to authors and their works, including books, textbooks, and journal articles. Most of these are post-Renaissance, though a few, like Alhazen, are cited and considered timeless, standard sources and authorities. The optics section is important as one of the earliest examples of German Anti-Newtonianism, even though it give a full account of the Newton's prism experiments and his interpretation of the results. Barth is cited later by Goethe regarding Newton's theory of colors. In this regard, Barth's text is different from Johann Jakob Scheuchzer's <i>Physica oder  Natur- Wissen- schaft<i> of 1711, which not only describes but accepts Newton's color theory.
BP_Description_2: An overview of some aspects of natural philosophy, culled from many sources, that includes: nature and properties of matter; cosmography including the stars, planets, and comets; light, color, and fire; meteorics; and an appendix on 'barometric light.' The optics section (44 pages) includes: the nature of light, sunlight, and luminescence of various types; color and color theory. Newton's prism experiments and the heterogeneity of white light are presented, considered and skeptically dismissed, with Mariotte's work on color cited as a counter-example, along with Fabri, Sturm, and Boyle. Notable for the extensive citing of many contemporary and near-contemporary sources.
BP_Reference(s): Materialien zur Geschichte der Farbenlehre|In: Goethe's s√§mmtliche Werke: Vollst√§ndige, ausg, Volume 6|Stuttgart, 1866, 684 pp, NB: 420.||Newton‚Äôs Opticks and Brockes‚Äô Early Poetry|John, D.G.|<i>Orbis Litterarum<i>, Vol 38, 1983, pp 205-214.

Item von der Schwere und andern Bewegungen; von denen Sterenen, Planeten, Cometen und insonderheith unsern Svstemate; von der Sonne, Light, Farben, Warme und KaÃàlte, Feuer u. Von unsrer Erde, deren Feuer, Wassern und Lufft, und was in diesen sich sonderbares begiebt. Alles mit nothigen Anmerckungen under allerlen curieusen Experimenten erlautert. Woben auch denen die weiter nachlesen wollen. Die dazu gehorige Scripta angezeiget werden.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by John Chamberlayne (1666-1723) English writer and translator
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third edition of the English translation of the Dutch text of 1715, seeking to demonstrate the existence of God by teleological argument: Nature, by its purposiveness exhibits the hand of a creator.
BP_Description_1: Bernard  Nieuwentyt's best-known work. A widely read and influential physico-teleological book. Quite apart from any teleological success it may have had in converting atheists and skeptics, it was important in the spreading of knowledge of natural philosophy. The descriptions are clear, accompanied by detailed figures, and the content correct and up-to-date by contemporary standards, setting out 'all the late discoveries in anatomy, philosophy, and astronomy.' In this regard, the English editions include a supporting letter from John Desaguliers, who also approved of the editing the translator had done to tone-down the more forceful Christian aspects, leaving the work more aligned with Natural Religion and Deism, and thus open to a wider audience. The English translation appeared in five editions in 1718, 1720, 1724, 1730, and 1745.
BP_Description_2: Third edition of the English translation  of the Dutch text of 1715, seeking to demonstrate the existence of God by teleological argument (of nearly 1000 pages): Nature, by its purposiveness exhibits the hand of a creator.   The  text  is  concerned  with  medicine  (the  heart,  nerves, muscles, and hearing), natural history  (the earth, fire, botany, zoology, etc.) and science  (chemistry,  astronomy,  and  physics). Never before had this been tried on such a scale, and none among Nieuwentyt's numerous imitators equaled his completeness. Rather  than  relying  on  a  few  examples,  he reviewed  the  whole  of  natural  science to show in detail how marvelously things fitted in the world. His work looks like a manual of up-to-date science  One of many topics is light and vision (16 pages). Ocular anatomy is considered in detail. Light is treated as radiant linear rays that can be reflected and refracted. Biconvex lenses and their images are introduced to show how the eye functions as a camera obscura, and to show how sight can be corrected with spectacles. The descriptions are often accompanied by experiments. Those aspects that involve physical optics are Newtonian; including the corpuscular nature of light.
BP_Reference(s): The formation of the Newtonian philosophy: the case of the Amsterdam mathematical amateurs|Vermih, R.|<i>British Society for the History of Science<i>, Vol 36, No 2, 2003, pp 183-200.||Physico-Theology or Biblical Physics?|Vermij, R.|In: <i>Physico-theology: Religion and Science in Europe, 1650‚Äì1750<i>|Blair, A., von Greyerz, K., editors|NB: pp 162-165.
BP_Title: The religious philosopher: Or, the right use of contemplating the works of the creator. I. In the wonderful structure of animal bodies, and in particular man, II. In the no less wonderful and wise formation of the elements, and their various effects upon animal and vegetable bodies. And III. In the most amazing structure of the heavens, with all the furniture. Disegned for the conviction of atheists and infidels. In Tow Volumes. Throughout wich, all the late discoveries in anatomy, philosophy, and astronomy together with the various experiments made use of to illustrate the same, are most copiously handled by that learned Mathematician Dr. Nieuwentyt. Translated from the Low-Dutch. To which is prefix'd a letter to the Translator by the Reverned J.T. Desaguliers, LL.D. F.R.S. The Third Edition. Adorned with Cuts.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch physician, mathematician, philosopher. Important author in teleology.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'Abraham Poole' on front free endpaper

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Textbooks for a complete course in Philosophy. The material is Cartesian, the presentation is practical, detailed, and geometric, with little or no theory involved.
BP_Description_1: The final reworking of a complete course in philosophy. Fully committed to Cartesianism, Pourchot first produced a text for students at the University of Paris in 1695. The text and its teaching helped bring about the end of Aristotelianism at Paris and its complete eclipse by Cartesian ideas and thought. This extended and revised version of the textbook appeared in several editions: at Paris in 1700, 1733, at Lyons in 1711, 1716, at Venice in 1713, 1720, 1724, 1730, and at Padua in 1738.
BP_Description_2: Textbooks for a complete course in natural philosophy. The optics section (36 pages) includes: ocular anatomy and eye-function; ocular image formation and spectacles; perception of size, shape, depth; lenses, elementary consideration of the microscope and telescope; reflection, plane and spherical mirrors and their images. The material is Cartesian, the presentation is practical, detailed, and geometric, with little or no theory involved.
BP_Reference(s): The Moment of No Return: The University of Paris and the Death of Aristotelianism|Brockliss, L.|<i>Science & Education<i>, Vol 15, 2006, pp 259‚Äì278.||<i>Models of the History of Philosophy: Volume II: From Cartesian Age to Brucker<i>|Santinello, G., Piaia, G., editors|Springer, 2011, 604 pp, NB: pp 88-91.

Complectens Logicam & Metaphysicam. Tomus Secundus. Quo Element Geometriae, & Physica genrealis continetur. Tomus Tertius, Qui Physicamspecialem comprehendit.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first part of Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande's editing of Christiaan Huygens' works.
BP_Description_1: Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande's editing of various works of Huygens. The biography of Huygens provided by 's Gravesande was based on one written by Christiaan's brother, Contantijn Jr, which in turn was based on notes written by Constantijn Sr about his children. The preface makes clear that the publication project began with the desire of the Dutch publisher Jansson Vander Aa, expressed to ¬¥s Gravesande, to republish Huygens's <i>Horologium Oscillatorium<i>. ¬¥s Gravesande suggested a larger project, including all the Huygens's works, to which Vander Aa agreed. ¬¥s Gravesande was responsible for gathering all available manuscripts and works of Huygens written in French and Latin and put them order for Vander Aa to print.
BP_Description_2: The first part of Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande's editing of Huygens' work. This part includes ¬¥s Gravesande's Preface and a biography of Huygens, followed by works in mechanics, including several small pieces and letters as well as reprints of <i>Horologium<i>, <i>Horologium Oscillatorium<i>, <i>Systema Saturnium<i>, <i>Cosmotheoros<i>, and works dealing with instruments, mathematics, and few small works in optics related to 'Alhazen's Problem.'

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Musschenbroek's resume of his physics lectures, derived from the physics in Newton's Principia and the Opticks
BP_Description_1: While Musschenbroek was teaching at Utrecht, he produced this resume of his physics lectures. The preface makes clear that his lecture course is derived from the physics in Newton's <i>Principia<i> and the <i>Opticks<i>. The manner of presentation and demonstration benefits from the work of Giovanni Poleni, Willem Jacob 's Gravesande, Bernard Nieuwentyt, and Herman Borhaave, and that their publication is in the long tradition of the university. More so than his teacher 's Gravesande, Musschenbroek was a prolific textbook writer and this was the first in a long series of successful, widely used, textbooks in natural philosophy. But considered in light of those later works, the epitome is only an early essay in Musschenbroek's developing craft of exposition and explanation. The epitome is notable for establishing Musschenbroek's style: the material is not presented in the common oracular fashion, rather, all principal ideas and facts are accompanied, in a quite modern fashion, by footnotes. Their number and extent are some of the most remarkable aspects of Musschenbroek's Epitome, making it something of a summary and guide to the then-contemporary literature on natural philosophy.
BP_Description_2: A summary of a course of lectures in natural philosophy based on Newtonian ideas and theories. The material covered includes: history and progress of physics; space, bodies, and their nature; motion; Newtonian laws of motion; gravity; mechanics; material properties; motion under attractive power; fluids and their motion; fire; optics. The optics material (56 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; reflection and refraction; colors; the eye and eye-function; vision; catoptrics; and dioptrics. The optical material is essentially Newtonian, though reference is made to a wide range of optical works: Descartes, Huygens, Gregory, Wolff,  's Gravesande, Hauksbee, Molyneux, Mariotte, Desaguliers, Dechales, Gassendi, Briggs, Malebranche, Rohault, Traber, Cherubin d'Orleans, and numerous references to the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London, Memoires of the Royal Academy of Sciences, and the Journal de Scanvans. The presentation is extremely concise and entirely descriptive; no mathematics is involved and no figures are provided.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  ‚Äôs Gravesande and Musschenbroek: Newtonianism at Leiden|Ruestow, E.G.|In: <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.
BP_Title: Epitome Elementorum Physico-Mathematicorum,  Conscripta in usus academicos a Petro van Musschenbroek. Phi. & Matheseos Professore in Academia Trajectino-Batava
BP_Title English Translation: Epitome of the Elements of Mathematical-Physics. Written for Academic Uses. By Pieter van Musschenbroek. Professor of Philosophy and Mathematics in the Academy of Utrecht.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the Universities of Utrecht and then Leiden, developed the Layden jar, worked importantly in mechanics and electrostatics.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1726 Musschenbroek - Epitome Elementorum Physico-Mathematicorum - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A thoroughgoing attack on Newton's theory of colors and white light homogeneity.
BP_Description_1: The origins of Rizzetti's book is his paper <i>De Systemate Opticae Newtonianae et de Aberratione in Humore Chrystallino<i> that he submitted to the Royal Society in London in 1722 and to the <i>Acta Eruditorum<i> in 1724. The paper claimed to have found Newton's experiments either faulty or inconclusive and--in Rizzetti's view--failing to support Newton theory of heterochromatic white light and the immutability of monochromatic light. He reported his failure to reproduce Newton's experiment involving black thread on blue and red-colored cards and claimed that prismatic colors were the result of aberrations in the lens of the eye. In London, John Theophilus Desaguliers responded with an article in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society reporting the public demonstration of Newton's experiment and calling on Rizzetti to admit his errors. In Germany, the mathematician Friedrich Richter answered Rizzetti with a severely critical article that appeared in the same issue of the Acta Eruditorum as Rizzetti's. All this seems to have simply spurred Rizzetti: five years after his first paper, he published <i>De Luminis Affectionibus<i>, a book containing a large number of additional experiments and a long diatribe against Newton. Desaguliers responded with a 35-page paper in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society reporting the repetition of experiments before the Royal Society and several foreign visitors, including four Italian Abb√©s. Unlike his response to Rizzetti's paper of 1722, in 1728 Desaguliers is sharp, critical, and aggressively defensive of Newton. The response to Rizzetti's book in Italy was embarrassment and uniformly negative. It prompted Fracensco Algarotti to consider a public response which would take the form of his famous <i>Newtonianismo  per  le  Dame<i>. Rizzetti's book is important in that the swift, thorough, and unanimous negative response shows the extent and completeness with which Newtonian optical ideas had taken hold in Europe by the time of Newton's death.
BP_Description_2: Rizzetti's work contains two Books. Book One contains four chapters and a summary: The refraction of light; Refrangibility of colors; The dispersion of light; The reflection of light; The nature of light. Book two contains a prologue, four chapters, and a summary: Colors in general; Natural colors; Apparent colors; Celestial phenomena; Imaginary colors; The nature of colors||The work attempts to be a thoroughgoing attack on Newton's theory of colors and white light homogeneity. Rizzett's preface contains a long diatribe against Newton and sets the polemic nature of the entire work. A few of Newton's experiments are presented as either failing or false and so Rizzetti rejects all of Newton's optical theories. The nature of light and color that is presented is a throwback to Scholastic teaching and there are many polemically-presented experiments with results that were claimed to contradict the ideas of Newton. Remarkably, the idea of color dispersion is rejected entirely and the old theory that color is a modification or mixing of white and black in invoked. Prismatic colors are dismissed as the result of aberrations within the eye.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Reception of Newtonian Optics in Italy|Casini, P.|In: <i>Renaissance and Revolution: Humanists, Scholars, Craftsmen and Natural Philosophers<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1993, 308 pp, NB pp 215-228.||Optical Experiments Made in the beginning of August 1728, before the President and Several member of the Royal Society, and other Gentlemen of Several Nations, upon Occasion of Signior Rizzetti's Opticks, with an Account of the Said Book|Desaguliers, J.T.|<i>Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 25, 1727, pp 596-629.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second impression of the first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Volume six contains optics, perspective, catoptrics, dioptrics, and atmospheric optics.
BP_Description_1: Second, posthumous impression of the first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Tosca wrote for his students, and the style and clarity of the books benefited from his long practice in teaching. The nine volumes are meant to cover all of mathematics and philosophy: I Arithmetic and Geometry, II Algebra and music, III Trigonometry and conics, IV Statics and Hydrostatics, V Civil and Military Architecture, VI Optics and Meteorics, VII Astronomy, VIII Geography and Navigation, IX Gnomics and Astrology. Tosca's textbooks were widely used and responsible, in part, for the introduction of modern science in Spain. The volumes of the first edition appeared at Valentia between 1707 and 1715. The entire set was reprinted in Madrid in 1727 and 1757.
BP_Description_2: The first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Volume six contains five sections on optics and meteorics, treatises XVIII - XXII. Section I Optics: general considerations and definitions; nature and propagation of light; nature of colors; transparent and opaque bodies; view and vision; eye-function; perception of size and shape; binocular vision. Section II Perspective: principles, iconographic and orthographic projection; methods for representing objects in various orientations; linear perspective; perspective of light, shadow, and reflected bodies; perspective of curved surfaces. Section III Catoptrics: general considerations an definitions; plane mirrors and their properties; convex and concave mirrors; cylindrical mirrors; spherical mirrors, caustics. Section IV Dioptrics:  refraction and its effects; cause and properties of refraction; location of refracted images; refractive glasses and their properties; combining refracting bodies; convex lenses, concave lenses; refraction and the generation of colors. Section V Meteorics: the sea and the wind; atmosphere and clouds, all type of precipitation; lighting; lights generated in the air; the rainbow; other forms of light; comets. Though the basis is essentially Cartesian, also cited are Grimaldi, Kircher, Scheiner, Zahn, Dechales, Rheyta, Zucchi, but not Huygens (1690) or Newton (1704). The wave and corpuscular theories of the nature of light are presented, but each is considered unproven. Color theory follows Pardies and is a hybrid of Aristotelian and Cartesian. The material is detailed, descriptive, and presented with little mathematics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Chambers's single-handed compilation of his own articles covering a huge array of subjects but stressing the sciences, technology, and philosophy. The material is practical, concise, elaborately cross-referenced, and accompanied by detailed figures.
BP_Description_1: Most successful of the then-new genre of dictionaries of arts and sciences. Building on Harris's <i>Lexicon Technicum<i>, Chambers work provided not only definitions but also the option of systematic reading and research. This was the basis for the claim that the <i>Cyclopedia<i> was a book to be studied; a kind of ready-made commonplace book. Editions appeared at London in 1728, 1738, 1741, 1750, at Dublin in 1740, and enlarged by Abraham Rees at London in 1778 . An Italian translation appeared at Naples in 1747-1755.
BP_Description_2: The optics-related entries are: Camera Obscura (2 columns), Catoptrics (1 column), Colour (9 columns), Eye (4 columns), Eye (7 columns), Focus (4 columns), Lens (4 columns), Lens Grinding (2 columns), Light (6 columns), Microscopes (5 columns), Mirrors (7 columns), Optics (2 columns), Ray (2 columns), Reflection (5 columns), Refraction (10 columns), Telescopes (8 columns), Vision (10 columns). The material is up to date, practical, concise, elaborately cross-referenced, and accompanied by detailed figures. The physical optics is Newtonian and the geometric optics, though not deeply mathematical, is complete and entirely practical.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande (1688-1742) Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the University of Leiden, developer of extensive demonstrations for teaching Newtonian physics, author of important textbooks.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The second part of Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande's editing of Huygens' work. This part includes a printing of Latin renderings of <i>Trait√© de la lumi√®re<i> and <i>Discours de la cause de la pesanteur.<i>
BP_Description_1: The second part of Willem Jacob ¬¥s Gravesande's editing of various works of Huygens, including the first printing of <i>De Lumine<i>, the Latin rendition of <i>Trait√© de la Lumiere<i>. In his preface to this volume, ¬¥s Gravesande mentions the volumes published in 1724 and notes that they did not contain Latin renderings of Huygens' only published work on optics, his <i>De La Lumiere<i>.
BP_Description_2: This part includes a printing of Latin versions of <i>Traite de la lumiere<i> (<i>De Lumine<i>), <i>Discours de la cause de la pesanteur<i> (<i>De Causa Gravitatis Dissertatio<i>), and <i>Geometria Dissertatio<i>. The <i>De Lumine<i> is a Latin rendering of Huygens' principal printed work on optics. The <i>Traite De La Lumiere<i> is in six chapters. Chapter 1: On Rays Propagated  in Straight Lines. Chapter 2: On Reflection. Chapter 3: On Refraction. Chapter 4: On Refraction of the Air. Chapter 5: On the Strange Refraction of Iceland Crystal. Chapter 6: On the Figures of Transparent Bodies Which Serve for Refraction and Reflection.||Chapter 1 reviews the classic phenomena of optics and how their nature and properties comprise required outcomes for any theory of light. These include rectilinear propagation of rays, equal angle reflection, and the sine law of refraction. The chapter then sets out Huygens' theory of wave propagation: A wave front produces wavelets with all but motion locally perpendicular to the original wave cancel, the cumulative effect leaves a new, advancing wave front. Spherical wave fronts generated in this way radiate from each point on a luminous surface. Rays of light are taken as the perpendiculars to wave fronts. Chapter 2 applies this principle to explain the equal angle law of specular reflection. By invoking the finite speed of light wave travel, the perpendiculars to the series of reflected wave fronts (reflected rays) are are show to make angles with the surface perpendicular that are equal to those of the rays of the incoming waves. Chapter 3 applies the same analysis, based on finite light wave speed to explain the sine law of refraction. Wave front speed is slower in denser media; the denser, the slower. Wave fronts travel more slowly once in the denser medium and a geometric construction shows their perpendiculars (the refracted rays) form an angle with the refracting surface perpendicular whose sine in ratio to that of incident rays is the ratio of the media densities. That is, the sine law of refraction. Chapter 4 applies wave front refraction to atmospheric refraction, showing how it produces curved rays. Chapter 5 explains the double refraction observed in Icelandic spar. In this case, Huygens proposes that refracted waves propagate in two directions in the crystal.   The wavelets for waves propagating in the 'extraordinary' direction are not spherical but elliptical and the resulting non-spherical wave fronts have perpendiculars that are the extraordinary rays of double refraction. Chapter 6 uses wave front analysis to determine ideal figures for reflecting and refracting surfaces. It is here that the cause of spherical aberration is derived. Huygens was a practiced oculist and though he shows the theoretical benefits of elliptical and hyperbolic figures for lenses, he is aware that as a practical matter, they were essentially impossible to produce.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Lenses and Waves<i>|Dijksterhuis, F.J.|Kluwer, 2004, pp 213-253.

BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch mathematician, natural philosopher, oculist.  Reserved genius, gifted experimenter, careful reporter, keen observer.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Henry Pemberton?
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An English translation of the first part of the Newton's Optical Lectures of 1670-1672, covering the refraction of light and it mathematical and geometric analysis.
BP_Description_1: An English translation of the Part 1 of the second revised version of the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i>, titled <i>Optica<i>; corresponding to parts of Book I of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. The <i>Optica<i> is the longer, revised version of Newton's optical lectures and rearranges and separates the original material in the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> into two sections. The first deals with refraction and its analysis. The second section deals with Newton's theory of color. In the thrity years that had elapsed since the notes were written and when the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 appeared, Newton had considerably developed and refined his color theory. As the translator states in the Preface, it is for this reason, and that much of the mathematics in Part 1 of the <i>Optica<i> does not appear in the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704, that the translation was limited to Part 1 of the <i>Optica<i>. The translator apparently worked from an imperfect copy of the Latin text held by David Gregory which he received from Newton in 1701--the notes being nearly 30 years old by that time. The differences between a good copy of the original Latin text and that used by the translator is apparent when it is compared to the editio princeps that appeared in 1729, with the translator/editor having to patch and fill in a few places. The result was rushed into print after Newton's death and, as is clear from the preface, the publication of the translation was as much an act of tribute as of scholarship.||Though the intent was to make public the mathematical and geometric detail of that part of the optical lectures dealing with refraction, in the half-century since the notes were written, much of the material was, if not obsolete, then developed more extensively in later works.
BP_Description_2: An English translation of the Latin, Part 1 of the second revised version of the Optical Lectures, including: Part I Description of prismatic experiments, analysis of the results, and conclusions regarding the inhomogeneity of white light; Part II Theory, instruments, and practice of measuring refraction; Part III Refraction at plane surfaces and the consequences of heterogeneous light; Part IV Refraction at curved surfaces and the consequences of heterogeneous light. The translation presents that part of the optical lectures that are deeply mathematical and cover geometrical optics. He finds image points in a form equivalent to and preceding that of Gauss, and uses his own mathematical developments--series expansions and finding maxima and minima--to find spherical aberration and what is now called the circle of least confusion. In Part IV, Newton shows how large chromatic aberration is compared to spherical aberration--1500 times--emphasizing the importance of his discovery of heterogeneous light's varying refrangibility.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Optical Papers of Isaac Newton, Volume I: The Optical Lectures 1670-1672<i>|Shapiro, A.E., editor|Cambridge University Press, 1984, 624 p.
BP_Title: Optical Lectures Read in the Publick Schools of the University of Cambridge, Anno Domini, 1669. By the last Sir Isaac Newton, Then Lucasian Professor of the Mathematicks. Never before Printed. Translated into English out of the Original Latin.
BP_Biographical Statement: English natural philosopher, mathematician, alchemist, Mint Master. Genius of preternatural ability, the greatest physicist of the 17th century.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp of the Mechanics Institution, Rotherham on title page and verso of some plates

BP_Short or Common Title: A View of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An overview of Newton's ideas on natural philosophy. The first part presents the general principles of Newton's philosophy, followed by an exposition and summary of part of the <i>Principia<i>, and that followed by a similar analysis of the <i>Opticks<i>.
BP_Description_1: Henry Pemberton had been introduced to Newton in about 1720 and established a relationship such that Newton had Pemberton prepare the third edition of the <i>Principia<i> published in 1726. This work, and Pemberton's previous close study of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704, gave him a unique overview of Newton's ideas. Pemberton's interpretation of those ideas forms the basis for the book. He first began writing it in 1721, publishing it a year after Newton's death. The subscriber's list gives an idea of how high a place Pemberton held in the minds of the learned public, and the reach of the book's influence. This was an expensive book intended for an audience that was well-off and educated but not mathematical. The presentation is descriptive, with figures provided for clarity, and fully accomplishes a difficult task: giving a faithful impression of the content of Newton's works, without using mathematics. The book was translated in Italian, 1733, French, 1755, and German, 1793.||Bound at the end of this copy is a very scarce pamphlet compiled by William Whiston: Sir Isaac Newton's Coroliaries from his philosophy and chronology: In his own words. It is Whiston's extracted quotations from Newton's works, intended to clarify central issues of Newton's philosophy.
BP_Description_2: An overview of Newton's ideas on natural philosophy. The first part presents the general principles of Newton's philosophy. Next is an exposition and summary of part of the <i>Principia<i>, following by a similar analysis of the <i>Opticks<i>. Book III covers optics (87 pages) and includes: heterogeneity of white light, prismatic refraction; color of bodies; reflection, refraction, and diffraction; Lenses, telescopes, microscopes, reflecting telescope; the rainbow. The presentation is entirely descriptive, no mathematics is involved.
BP_Reference(s): Pemberton's Translation of Newton's Principia, With Notes on Motte's Translation|Cohen, I.B.|<i>Isis<i> Vol 54, No 3, 1963, pp 319-351, NB: pp 321-323.
BP_Title: A View of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy
BP_Biographical Statement: Englilsh physician, author, editor. Friend of Isaac Newton, editor of the third edition of the Principia Mathematica and fifth edition of the London Pharmacopoeia.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'Samuel Askton' on pastedown
BP_BibliographicNotes: First whole book printed in Caslon Roman type

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Poliniere, Pierre
BP_Description_1: See Entry 272. By the time of this, the third edition, Poliniere had become completely convinced of the soundness of the experimental method as the basis for physics. The experiments, their results, and conclusions drawn from them are now presented without the caution and hedging found in the earlier editions; he now asserts that the principles of physics can be discovered directly and reliably by experiment.
BP_Description_2: Third edition of the <i>Experiences de Physique<i> of 1709. A manual of 114 experiments in natural philosophy; given is great detail, the results are explained with equal care. Experiments 85 through 114 deal with light and color. This includes: colors in chemical solutions and materials; refraction, prismatic colors, the rainbow and its production; burning mirrors; vision and eye function; lenses of convex and concave figure; camera obscura; spectacles and optical instruments; simple microscopes and telescopes; uses of the microscope; and phosphor. Importantly, the optical material dealing with color is now entirely Newtonian, no vestige of Cartesianism remains.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Notion of Experimental Physics in Early Eighteenth-Century France|Home, R.W.|In: <i>Change and Progress in Modern Science<i>|Reidel Publishing, 1985, pp 107-131.||Early Electricity between Chemistry and Physics: The Simultaneous Itineraries of Francis Hauksbee, Samuel Wall, and Pierre Polini√®re|Freudenthal, G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1981, pp 203-229.||Francis Hauksbee's theory of electricity|Home, R.W.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 3, 1967, pp 203‚Äì217.||Pierre Poliniere, Francis Hauksbee, and Electroluminescence: A Case of Simultaneous Discovery|Corson, D.W.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 59, No. 4, 1968, pp 402-413.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An early treatise on the measurement of light using visual photometry. The distances of two sources that illuminated a split visual field were changed until the field was equally bright; the ratio of the square of the distances gave the relative luminous power of the two sources.
BP_Description_1: Bouguer's interest in the measurement of light began with articles by Dortous Mairan in 1719 and 1721 regarding the power of the sun to light and heat differently in summer and winter. Bouguer apparently borrows the visual comparator first shown in Aguilon's <i>Opticorum<i> of 1613, and Dechales's law of diminishing luminous power derived from the geometry of the sphere, to devise a reliable method of relative photometry based on equality of visual perception. The Essai formed the basis for the first part of Bouger's posthumously published TraiteÃÅ d'Optique of 1760. A modern reprinting of the Essai appeared at Paris in 1921.
BP_Description_2: An early treatise on the measurement of light using visual photometry. The distances of two sources that illuminated a split visual field were changed until the field was equally bright; the ratio of the square of the distances gave the relative luminous power of the two sources. This relative photometric method was used to determine the luminous power of a candle to that of the sun and other sources. It was also used to determine the reflectivity of surfaces and the absorption of light in air and water, giving Bouguer's exponential law of attenuation.
BP_Reference(s): La photom√©trie : les sources de l'Essai d'Optique sur la gradation de la lumi√®re de Pierre Bouguer, 1729|Mor√®re, J.-E.|<i>Revue d'histoire des sciences et de leurs applications<i>, Vol 18, No 4, 1965, pp 337-384.
BP_Title: Essai d'Optique sur la Gradation de la Lumiere. Par M. Bouguer, Professeur Royal en Hydrographie.
BP_Title English Translation: Optical Treatise on the Measurement of Light. By Mr. Bouguer, Royal Professor of Hydrography.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, astronomer, photometrist. Worked importantly in hydrography, naval architecture, metrology, geodesy.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of M. Chompr√© on verso of titlepage. Occasional notes and corrections to equations

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The editio princeps of the complete Latin text of Newton's <i>Optica<i>, the lecture notes prepared for Cambridge.
BP_Description_1: The editio princeps of the complete Latin text of Newton's Optica, the lecture notes prepared for the Lucasian lectures at Cambridge. The work of Huygens, Bernoulli and de L'Hospital, Halley, and Newton's own <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 superseded the <i>Optical Lectures<i> in many ways. The Publication of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> in 1728 made the eclipse entire.  The direct influence of the <i>Optical Lectures<i> was small and even then, short lived. But as is clear from the Preface, the publication was both an act of tribute and scholarship.||The printing is from a second-draft manuscript that had been prepared around 1671, two years after Newton began lecturing on optics. The original lectures did not appear in print until 1973. Six editions appeared: 1729, in the <i>Opuscula<i> of 1744, in the <i>Opera Omnia<i> of 1782, and four times in combination with the <i>Optice<i> and other optical papers in 1747, 1749, 1765, 1773.
BP_Description_2: editio princeps of the complete Latin text of Newton's Optica, the lecture notes prepared for Cambridge.  Lectures 1,2: prismatic refraction, heterogeneity of white light and unequal refraction. Lectures 3: Different colors linked to different refraction. Lectures 4,5: Experiments on the inhomogeneity of white light. Lecture 6: The experimentum crucis. Lectures 7,8: Additional experiments with prismatic spectra, and the generation of white light from colored lights. Lectures 9,10: Measuring refraction. Lecture 11: Presentation of a chromatic dispersion law. Lectures 12-17: An analysis of the consequences of the laws of the sine law of refraction and the dispersion law. Fundamentally mathematical and involving plane surfaces. Lecture 18: Refraction in prisms.||The Latin text contains all of the mathematics and geometric optics of the lectures, showing Newton's application of his own mathematical developments to solve problems in geometric optics including, image points, caustics, the circle of least confusion, spherical aberration, and chromatic aberration.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Optical Papers of Isaac Newton, Volume I: The Optical Lectures 1670-1672<i>|Shapiro, A.E., editor|Cambridge University Press, 1984, 624 p.
BP_Title: Isaaci Newtoni Eq. Aur. in AcademiaÃÇ Cantabrigiensi matheseos olim Professoris Lucasiani lectiones optic√¶, annis MDCLXIX, MDCLXX & MDCLXXI. in scholis publicis habit√¶: et nunc primum ex MSS. in lucem edit√¶

BP_Short or Common Title: Dissertation sur les Differens Accidens de la Vue
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An early consideration of some of the physiological and psychophysical aspects of vision.
BP_Description_1: La Hire's <i>Dissertation sur les Differens Accidens de la Vue<i> first appeared in 1694 in the Memoires of the Royal Academy at Paris. This monograph-lengh work was gathered into the present posthumous collection of his works. The collection includes La Hire's long dissertation on mechanics, that on ice and cold, a short work on marine trumpets, on painting, and a long dissertation on vision. This is volume 9 in the series <i>Memoires de L'Academie Royale des Sciences, Depuis 1666 jusqu'a 1699<i>, is the first edition of a collection of La Hire's works, and appeared at Paris in 1730. A second edition appeared at Amsterdam in 1759.
BP_Description_2: The work covers a wide range of aspects of vision: Color constancy, visual parallax (how near object's depths are distinguished), "mouches volantes" or visible "floaters" in the interocular media, accommodation, near and far-sightedness, and visual measurements.||There are two parts. The first part begins with a consideration of vision with two eyes, depth perception, and what La Hire terms "parallax." Next is a long section on myopia; its nature, cause, and correction with concave-lensed spectacles. Then follows an equally long section on hyperopia and presbyopia and it correction with convex-lensed spectacles. Part one ends with a consideration of several aspects of "perfect vision": acuity, depth perception, color perception, use of telescopes and microscopes, viewing multiple objects, and 'radiations' from luminous objects. This includes a revisiting of the Cartesian theory of ocular image formation as presented by Rohaut in his textbooks.||The second part considers the power of vision and how aspects of it can be measured, including accommodation, near point, and parallax.
BP_Reference(s): A Natural History of Vision|Wade, N.J.|MIT Press, 1999, 460 pp, NB: p 148.||Purkinje's Vision: The Dawning of Neuroscience|Wade, N.J.,  Josef Brozek, J., Hoskovec, J.|Taylor & Francis, 2008, 150 pp, NB: p 115.

BP_Short or Common Title: A Compendious and Methodical Account of the Principles of Natural Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An introductory text of natural philosophy covering Mechanics, Hydrostatics, Pneumatics, and Optics.
BP_Description_1: An introductory text of natural philosophy covering Mechanics, Hydrostatics, Pneumatics, and Optics. Benjamin Worster and Thomas Watts had been engaged by Richard Steele to deliver a course in natural philosophy at Steele's Censorium--his presentation theater. This course was design to offer the English equivalent to Desagulier's course given in French at the Censorium. Worster and Watt's course of lectures began in 1719. Watts later engaged Worster at his own Academy in Little Tower Street to teach experimental and natural philosophy, and this text was written expressly to accompany this course of lectures delivered by Worster. The first edition appeared in 1772 and the second edition produced from corrections and additions in Worster's hand. The long introduction, 'To The Reader,' is by the publisher and bookseller Stephen Austen and sets out the reason for the second edition and recounts some of Worster's ideas from the edition of 1722.||Worster's intent is clear from the introduction quoted by Austen: not to describe or recount experiments or their apparatus, but to show how philosophical principles are deduced from experimental results. In this regard, Worster is and adherent and admirer of Bacon. Austen also recounts Worster's summary of gravity and central attractive forces.
BP_Description_2: An introductory text of natural philosophy covering Mechanics, Hydrostatics, Pneumatics, and Optics, meant to accompany Worster's series of experimental lectures. There are six sections. 1: Of Natural Philosophy in General. 2: Mechanics. 3: Laws of Motion. 4: Hydrostatics. 5: Pneumatics. 6: Optics. The optics section is the longest and most detailed. Rays of light are considered 'streams of Aether' but treated in a purely geometric fashion. Reflection and refraction as plane and spherical surfaces are considered. Interestingly, Worster's text contains one of the earliest image of a light ray path encountering a surface repulsive force, thus producing reflection. To account for refraction, Worster employes an elaborate version of Newton's 'Fits'. Simple convex and concave lenses are considered with analysis limited to determining focal points. Simple ocular anatomy is presented, together with a summary of the visual process. Mirrors, prismatic colors, natural colors of bodies, and the rainbow are also discussed. It is shown on lenses can be combined to produce the telescope and the microscope. The treatment of geometric optics is descriptive, with only elementary geometry being invoked. Physical optics - the reason for reflection and refraction - is expressed in terms of attractive forces and their action on light rays. The last sections list brief descriptions the experiments in Worster's lecture course. Twenty-four experiments are listed for Optics.
BP_Reference(s): The Selling of Newton: Science and Technology in Early Eighteenth-Century England'|Stewart, L.|<i>Journal of British Studies<i>, Vol 25, No 2, April 1986, pp. 178-192.||'Richard Steele's Censorium'|Loftis, J.|<i>Huntington Library Quarterly<i> , Vol 14, No 1, Nov. 1950, pp. 43-66.||The Problem of Reflection in Eighteenth-Century Projectile Theories of Light|Breno Arsioli Moura|<i>Physics in Perspective<i>, Vol 22, 2020, pp 191-214.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by John Theophilus Desaguliers (1683-1744) British natural philosopher, engineer, Anglican priest. Popular lecturer on Newtonian physics, demonstrator at the Royal Society, prolific author.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fourth edition of the English translation of 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> of 1720.
BP_Description_1: Desaguliers was a friend of 's Gravesande and knew his work well. That it was thought likely that an English translation of 's Gravesande's book would sell well is clear from the fact that the booksellers Senes and Taylor asked Desaguliers to produce a translation. It was commercially successful, widely read and used and became one of the most important English textbooks on Newtonian natural philosophy. Six editions appeared: 1720, 1721, 1726, 1731, 1737, and the posthumous edition of 1747. The second edition followed the first rapidly, containing corrections to printing errors and mistakes in the plates. This, the fourth edition of Desaguliers's translation, was based on what was at the time the latest text of 's Gravesande. The Latin text would be greatly expanded by 's Gravesande in 1742 and Desaguliers would produce a greatly expanded translation.
BP_Description_2: Fourth edition of the English translation of 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> of 1720. 's Gravesande had produced a handbook of physics covering: statics; dynamics; gravity; fluids; fire, heat, light, and electro-luminescence; optics; system of the world; and celestial motion. The optics section (90 pages or about 15% of the text) includes: the nature and propagation of light; refraction; Newtonian spectral refraction; spherical lenses; eye and vision; spectacles for vision correction; microscopes, telescopes, and their use; reflection and catoptrics; the magic lantern; color, chromatic heterogeneity of white light, spectra, the rainbow, colors of thin plates, colors in nature. The main points are demonstrated by experiments, their presentation detailed and geometry-based. Numerous detailed figures, descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable.||The physical optics that 's Gravesande's text presents has fire and light as manifestations of an 'elemental fire', with both sharing many of the same properties. The fundamental aspect of propagation is emission--as opposed to traveling waves--and the interaction of light with materials in reflection, refraction, and diffraction is ascribed to the effect of forces operating over very small distances. 's Gravesande's emission theory is a kind of filtered and simplified version of Newton's ideas; it avoids any mention of the aether that Newton mentioned in the later Queries of the <i>Optice<i> of 1706, does not deal with double refraction, and does not mention Newton's fits of easy transmission and reflection or his suggestion regarding 'sides' or 'poles' of the light particles. Also notable is the absence of consideration of any other theory of the the nature of light and its propagation.
BP_Reference(s): John Theophilus Desaguliers: A Natural Philosopher, Engineer and Freemason in Newtonian England|Carpenter, A.T.|<i>Continuum<i>, 2011, pp 115-125.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Textbook giving a general course in all of philosophy, including: logic, general physics, particular physics, and metaphysics. Most of the presentation is elementary, practical rather than theoretical, with no mathematics other than geometry.
BP_Description_1: Corsini had taught philosophical disciplines for 15 years before he produced this series of textbooks. The concision and clarity of presentation reflects his long teaching experience, and the historical review (sometimes emphasis) included for nearly every topic reflects his abiding interest in history and ancient learning. Editions appears in 1731, 1743, 1754, 1764.
BP_Description_2: Textbook giving a general course in all of philosophy, including: logic, general physics, particular physics, and metaphysics. The optics section (62 pages) includes: very detailed ocular anatomy and eye function; the perfection of vision with magnifying glasses, telescopes, mirrors, and microscopes; the nature and origin of light; and color. Most of the presentation is elementary but complete and detailed, practical rather than theoretical with no mathematics other than geometry. The chapters on light's nature and color present the Peripatetic, Cartesian, and Newtonian views. The general eclecticism is reflected in the range of authorities cited: from Aristotle to Descartes and Newton.
BP_Reference(s): The General Histories of Philosophy in Italy in the Late Seventeenth and Early Eighteenth Century|Piaia, G.|In: <i>Models of the History of Philosophy Volume II: From Cartesian Age to Brucker<i>|Springer, 2011, 604 pp, NB: pp 292-297.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A theory purporting to show how the distance, size, and orientation of an object are perceived through vision; providing a general criticism of vision theories based on geometry.
BP_Description_1: Numerous changes were made in the 1732 editions of the original text of 1709. Citations of mathematicians and opticians with whom Berkeley disagreed were removed. The appendix that had appeared in the second edition was not included in the second edition of <i>Alciphron<i>. An Italian translation appeared at Venice in 1732 and a French translation appeared at the Hague in 1734.
BP_Description_2: A theory purporting to show how the distance, size, and orientation of an object are perceived through vision; providing a general criticism of vision theories based on geometry. The argument is made that, because all sensible objects are things we perceive by sense, and because nothing is perceived besides our own ideas, it follows that all sensible objects are ideas. Berkeley held that there were only four direct, immediate objects of visual sensation: shape, color, degree of faintness or clearness, and degree of confusion or distinctness. No others; all perceptions were held to arise from only these four--augmented perhaps by the sense of touch--and therefore perceptions involve learning and judgement. Additionally, the objects of sight and touch (or any two of the senses) are distinct and share no standard of measurement. These herald the later famed immatialism of Berkeley and his consideration of 'Molyneux's Question.'
