BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Lambert ten Kate
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary outline of Desaguliers' Netherland lectures, probably based on his <i>Physico-Mechanical Lectures<i> of 1717.
BP_Description_1: A short version of this work appeared at Amsterdam in 1731, written by an attendee to his widely-popular series of lectures on Newtonian natural philosophy, given during his tour of the Netherlands in 1730. The notes of 1731 were in great demand and a reworking and addition resulted in the present publication of 1732. The additional material included a description of Desaguliers' new demonstration planetarium and large plates showing the new equipment. Based on a reference in the Letter to the Reader, the editor/author is like to have been Lambert ten Kate, a well-known translator who worked for Isaak Tirion in Amsterdam. The reworked edition appeared twice in 1732.
BP_Description_2: As outlined in the Letter to the Reader, the lectures and experiments that are described relate to Newton's work in Mechanics and the motion of celestial bodies, mechanics applied to hydrostatics and aerometrics, and optics. The optics section includes: reflection, catoptrics of plane and curved mirrors, burning mirrors; refraction, dioptrics of lenses of various figures and their images; ocular anatomy and eye function; spectacles; the microscope; the telescope; Newton's theory of white light chromatic heterogeneity. The presentation is entirely geometric, consistent with the background of the intended popular audience.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Science for the public: the translation of popular texts on experimental philosophy into the Dutch language in mid-eighteenth century|Zuidervaart, H.J.|In: Cultural Transfer through Translation, Stockhorst, S., editor|Brill, 2010, pp 231-262.||Competing to Popularize Newtonian Philosophy|Wigelsworth, J.R.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 94, 2003, pp 435‚Äì455.||John Theophilus Desaguliers: A Natural Philosopher, Engineer and Freemason in Newtonian England|Carpenter, A.T.|<i>Continuum<i>, 2011, pp 32-37.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Experiments with mirrors of spherical, parabolic, and elliptical figure.
BP_Description_1: The 1736 Amsterdam printing of the Memoires of the Royal Academy of Science, first printed in 1728 at Paris. The annual summary of physical and mathematical works presented to the Royal Academy of Science in 1726. Subjects in this year include physics, anatomy, chemistry, botany, mathematics, and mechanics, including this report from DuFay on mirrors. This work was done by DuFay relatively early in his career and before he focused most of his experimental attention on electricity, the results of which made him famous.
BP_Description_2: Experiments with mirrors of spherical, parabolic, and elliptical figure. The experiments involve the movement of light between foci and elliptical mirror, or from the focal point of one mirror, to the focal point of a second mirror, with a consideration of this process for use in burning mirrors and as projection elements in magic lanterns. DuFay is interested in the process of gathering light at one place and sending it to another, possibly distant place, via a non-diverging parallel beam--a very early example of what would now be called energy transport. DuFay's earlier work in translating treatises on craft, lead to his work and experience with gold leaf. Among his experimental apparatus were spherical mirrors formed in plaster and covered with gold leaf. DuFay cites Zahn, Cavalieri, Niceron, and Descartes.
BP_Reference(s): What Difference does a Translation Make? The <i>Trait√© de vernis<i> (1723) in the Career of Charles Dufay|Bycroft, M.|In: Translating Early Modern Science|Fransen, S., Hodson, N., Enenkel, K.A.E, editors|Brill, Leiden, 2017, 344 pp, NB: pp 66-90.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching compendium on Mixed Mathematics in Latin. Based on and greatly expanding the <i>Der Anfangs-Gr√ºnde<i> of 1710.
BP_Description_1: A later edition of the greatest teaching compendia of mathematics and natural philosophy of 18th century. Editions appeared in 1713 at Magdeburg, 1717 at Magdeburg, 1730 at Magdeburg, 1732 at Geneva, 1732 at Paris, 1735 at Geneva, 1741 at Verona, 1742 at Magdeburg, 1743 at Geneva, 1743 at Paris, 1746 at Verona. Each new edition required several years to complete, spanning as long as nine years. Reference to <i>Optice<i> 1706; supports Newton on nature of light and color.
BP_Description_2: A teaching compendium on Mixed Mathematics in Latin. Based on and greatly expanding the <i>Anfangs-Gr√ºnde<i> of 1710. The extensive optics section of Volume 3 (290 pages) includes: optics, the nature of light, shadow, and color; visual perception including size, shape, location, motion, and binocular vision; catoptrics including making and figuring glass and metal mirrors; burning mirrors and images from mirrors; mirrors for anamorphosis; dioptrics including refraction, lenses and their focal and imagining properties; lens figuring and polishing, making and use of microscopes and telescopes; magic lanterns. The treatment is thorough and mathematical. 292 figures on 32 engraved plates accompany the optics text.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 29-93.||Christian Wolff tussen Cartesianen en Newtonianen|Hakfoort, C.|<i>Tijdschrift voor de Geschiedenis der Geneeskunde, Natuurwetenschappen<i>, Wiskunde en Techniek 5, 1982, pp 27‚Äì38.||<i>Christian Wolff als Mathematiker und Universit√§tslehrer des 18. Jahrhunderts<i>|Sommerhoff-Benner, S|Shaker, 2002.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

Autore Chrisitano Wolfio, in Academia Regia Fridericana Mathematum Professore Publico et ordinario, Societatum Regiarum Britannicae atque Boruusicae Sodali. Autore Christiano Wolfio, Potentissimi regis Buroussiae Consiliario Aulico, Mathematum Professore Publico et Ordinario, Societatum Regiarum Britainnicae atque Borussicae Socali. cum Privilegio Polonarum Regis er Saconiae Electoris.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Samuel Jebb  (1694-1772) German philosopher, educated at Oxford, professor at the University of Marburg.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first printing of the <i>Opus Majus<i> Bacon wrote between 1266 and 1267 and, responding to a request from Pope Clement IV.  It contains six of the original seven parts covering, among other things, natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Pope Clement IV requested of Roger Bacon a work he had promised on the reform of university education. Bacon wrote between 1266 and 1267 and, responding in secret as requested, sent the <i>Opus Majus<i> to the Pope. Jebb's edition of the Opus Majus was prepared from four medieval manuscripts; two at the British Library in London, one each from libraries at the universities at Cambridge and Dublin. In the case of Part Five, the <i>Perspectiva<i>, Jebb relied very heavily on Combach's 1614 edition of the <i>Perspectiva<i>.
BP_Description_2: The first printing of the <i>Opus Majus<i>. It contains six of the original seven parts: causes of human ignorance, philosophy related to theology, grammar and languages, mathematics, optics, experiential science. The seventh section on moral philosophy is not included in Jebb's editing. Part Four on Mathematics is the <i>De Multiplicatione Specierum<i>; on the propagation of light and other forces. Part Five, on optics, draws on the optical work of Robert Grosseteste and Arabic works of al-Kindi and ibn al-Haytham. It covers: the eye and its anatomy; conditions for seeing including light, distance, position, and size; visual perception from sense, memory, and reasoning; direct, reflected, and refracted vision; magnifying function of full and half-spherical refractors; propagation of light; finally the spiritual significance of optics. The rainbow is considered in Part Six.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>Roger Bacon and the Origins of 'Perspectiva' in the Middle Ages: A Critical Edition and English Translation of Bacon's 'Perspectiva' with Introduction and Notes<i>|Lindberg, D.C.|Clarendon Press, 1996||‚ÅÇùëª <i>Roger Bacon's Philosophy of Nature: A Critical Edition, with English Translation, Introduction, and Notes, of De multiplicatione specierum and De speculis comburnetibus<i>|Lindberg, D.C.|Clarendon Press, 1983

BP_Title English Translation: The Opus Majus of Brother Roger Bacon, Order of Friars Minor, For Clement IV, Roman Pontiff. From the Manuscript Codex Dublinensis, Compared with other Various Things, Published Now for the First Time. S. Jebb, MD.
BP_Biographical Statement: English¬†Franciscan, lecturer at Oxford and University of Paris. Interested in emperical natural philosophy and, prompted by the pope, wrote extensively on mathematics, optics, alchemy, and cosmology

BP_Short or Common Title: Elementa physic√¶ conscripta in usus academicos
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Textbooks for a course in natural philosophy based on Newtonian ideas and theories.
BP_Description_1: Musschenbroek reworked his <i>Epitome Elementorum Physico-Mathematicorum<i> of 1726, notes for a student course in physics, into this textbook. The topics and structure are same as those in the Epitome, but the treatment has been greatly expanded by including the experiments, demonstrations, and equipment Musschenbroek used in his lectures, as well as figures, geometry, and trigonometry to make the presentation clearer and more detailed. Given the inclusion of experiments and demonstrations, the textbook contains many fewer citations to other works than did the Epitome. Compared to other writers, and in particular to his fellow countryman Willem Jacob 's Gravesande, Musschenbroek was more daring with hypotheses, relying heavily on experiment and collected data rather than on formulating general laws. He was cautious not to introduce unverifiable hypotheses and expressed an honest acknowledgement of what was not known. He was also willing to tackle magnetism, electricity, heat, and other similar phenomena which were difficult to quantify or to cast into general laws, and which were, for that reason, often not considered by other textbook writers.||Editions of Musschenbroek's textbook appeared at Leiden in 1734,  1741 and expanded form  in 1748, at Venice in 1745, 1752, 1761, 1781, and 1794, at Naples in 1745, 1751, 1761, and 1771, at Madrid in 1807.  It was translated into English in 1774, German in 1747, and Swedish in 1747. This text is the basis for the Beginselen Der Natuurkunde, a more expansive and elaborated work Musschenbroek published in Dutch in 1736.
BP_Description_2: Textbooks for a course in natural philosophy based on Newtonian ideas and theories. The material covered includes: nature of natural philosophy and philosophizing; space, bodies, and their nature; motion; gravity; mechanics; motion under attractive power; percussion; electricity; fluids and their motion; fire; optics. The optics material (89 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; refraction; refraction at planar and spherical surfaces; differing refraction and colors; the eye and eye-function; vision; dioptrics, lenses and their images, the telescope; catoptrics, spherical mirrors and their images, reflecting telescopes. The optical material is essentially Newtonian. The presentation is detailed, mathematical, geometric, and accompanied by many detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Ruestow, E.G.|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.

BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the Universities of Utrecht and then Leiden, developed the Layden jar, worked importantly in mechanics and electrostatics.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Edmund Stone (1700-1768) Scots autodidact, mathematician, and translator.
BP_Short or Common Title: An Explanation of the Newtonian Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Textbook of Newtonian physics.
BP_Description_1: English translation of 's Gravesande's widely used and successful Latin textbook. The translation is based on the edition of 1728, is faithful to the spare and clear presentations of the Latin, and was clearly meant for students. The presentations were the essence of 's Gravesande's lectures and are notable for the accompanying instruments and demonstration/experimental apparatus. The Preface, content, and plates of figures are reproduced exactly from the Latin original, translated as necessary; Stone interposed himself not at all. A second edition of the translation appeared in 1741.
BP_Description_2: Textbook of Newtonian physics covering: matter, statics, and simple machines; dynamics; fluids, hydraulics, pneumatics; fire, heat, and light; color; system of the world, universal gravity. The optics sections (88 pages) includes: refraction on plane and curved surfaces, dioptrics, and spherical lenses; eye function; microscopes and telescopes; reflection, catoptrics, plane and spherical mirrors; the magic lantern; color, Newton's theory of white light chromatic heterogeneity; the rainbow, colors from thin plates, colors in nature. The presentation is detailed and geometric.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics in the Age of Euler: Conceptions of the Nature of Light, 1700-1795<i>|Hakfoot, C.|Cambridge University Press, 1995, 243 pp, NB: pp 42-46.||<i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Ruestow, E.G.|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.||<i>The History of Science in the Netherlands: Survey, Themes and Reference<i>|Van Berkel, K., Van Helden, Al, Palm, L., editors|Brill, Leiden, 1999, pp 68-95, 450-453.||‚Äòs Gravesande's Appropriation of Newton's Natural Philosophy, Part I: Epistemological and Theological Issues|Ducheyne, S.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 56, No 1, 2014, pp 31-55||‚Äòs Gravesande's Appropriation of Newton's Natural Philosophy, Part II: Methodological Issues|Ducheyne, S.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 56, No 2, 2014, pp 97-120.
BP_Title: An explanation of the Newtonian philosophy, in lectures read to the youth of the University of Leyden. Written in Latin by William-James s'Gravesande, Doctor of Laws and Philosophy, Professor of Mathematicks and Astronomy at Leyden, and Fellow of the Royal Society of London. Translated into English by a Fellow of the Royal Society.
BP_Biographical Statement: British natural philosopher, engineer, Anglican priest. Popular lecturer on Newtonian physics, demonstrator at the Royal Society, prolific author.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching manual covering General and Particular Physics, describing 'those things which are observed by the senses.'
BP_Description_1: A textbook describing 'those things which are observed by the senses.' By the time Ferrari wrote this, his thinking had evolved away from Scholastic Aristotelianism and had aligned with the natural philosophy of Gassendi, parts of Descartes and Malebranche, and the optics (but not the gravity) of Newton. In many sections, particularly those on optics and the physics of light, a summary history is given ranging from the ideas of Epicurus and Aristotle, through Descartes and Malebranche, to Huygens and Newton. The textbook shows that though Ferrari had moved away from most of the physics of Descartes and presents that of Newton, he continued to assume a fundamental mechanistic basis of physics and was unwilling to grant that (merely) the predictive accuracy of Newton's equation was evidence of the reality that was hypothesized to underlie them. In this sense, Ferrari's text is an example of the bridging that was taking place between Cartesian and Newtonian ideas. Widely used throughout Europe, the textbook was, for example, recommended as the physics text for use at the University of Seville in 1768. Editions appeared at Brexia in 1735, 1745, and 1751, posthumously at Venice in 1756, 1761, and in the Opera Omnia of 1792.
BP_Description_2: A teaching manual covering General and Particular Physics. General Physics includes: nature of bodies; motion; light and color; sound; touch; smell; motion of fluids and solids under gravity. Particular Physics includes: the heavens and the earth; meteorics; living organisms; the senses; human anatomy. The optics section of volume 1 (58 pages, the physics of light) includes: the aether and the wave nature of light; propagation of light; opaque and transparent materials; reflection of light and mirrors; refraction of light and lenses; dispersion; color. The optics section of volume 2 (55 pages, vision) includes: vision; ocular anatomy; direct vision; principles of reflected vision and catoptrics; principles of refracted vision and dioptrics including spectacles, the microscope, and the telescope. Done in the Scholastic style, with definitions, propositions, proofs, discussions, and corollaries. The presentation is detailed, geometric, and supported with many figures.
BP_Reference(s): Fortunato da Brescia|Baldini, U.|In: <i>Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani<i>, Vol 49, 1977.|http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/fortunato-da-brescia_(Dizionario-Biografico)/

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Sir William Browne (1692 - 1774) English physician
BP_Short or Common Title: Dr. Gregory's Elements Of Catoptrics And Dioptrics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Browne's translation of Gregory's Latin lecture notes on optics printed as <i>Catoptric√¶ et dioptric√¶ sph√¶ric√¶ elementa<i> in 1695.
BP_Description_1: English translation of Gregory's Latin lecture notes on optics printed as <i>Catoptric√¶ et dioptric√¶ sph√¶ric√¶ elementa<i> in 1695, together with an extensive addendum. Browne's long introduction recounts the very basics of optics regarding lenses and cites the great utility of their use in telescopes and microscopes, and the discoveries made with those instruments. Browne was a physician but, though competent in optics and mathematics, was not a specialist and so had John Desaguliers review his translation. Desaguliers encouraged its publication. The first edition appeared in 1715 at London. This edition of 1735 was brought out by Desaguliers since the first edition was out of print and there was sufficient demand for another. Desaguliers added a long appendix, an introduction and a history of the reflecting telescope. See Entry 262.
BP_Description_2: To this edition of Browne's translation of Gregory's Latin text of the 1695, Desaguliers added an introduction and an appendix, half as long again as Browne's original text, containing an account of reflecting telescopes, their history, inventors, improvers, and makers. He also added original letters between Isaac Newton and James Gregory relating to reflecting telescopes. See Entry 262.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 262.
BP_Title: Dr. Gregory's Elements Of Catoptrics And Dioptrics. Translated from the Latin Original, With a large Supplement, By William Browne, M.D. The Second Edition. To which is added, An Appendix, By J. T. Desaguliers, LL.D. F.R.S. Containing, An Account of the Reflecting Telescopes; and of the Inventors, Improvers, and Imitators of them, till they were brought to Perfection by John Hadley, Esq; Vice-President of the Royal Society. With Original Letters which passed between Sir Isaac Newton and Dr. James Gregory, relating thereunto. Now First Published.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scots self-taught mathematician. Taught at University of Edinburgh and Oxford. Promoter of Newtonian ideas in the university curriculum. [Pedantic, garrulus, prolific, learned]

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by John Clarke (1682-1757) English natural philosopher.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: John Clarke's English translation of a late edition of Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>. The book was presented as Cartesian physics with Newtonian refutation.
BP_Description_1: By the time John Clarke produced this English translation of Rohault's <i>Trait√© de Physique<i> of 1671, his brother Samuel Clarke's notes has been developing for nearly 25 years in the Latin form that accompanied Clarke's 1697 Latin translation of Rohault's text, having been thoroughly revised twice. The notes had become elaborate, themselves notated, and nearly 1/3 as long as Rohault's text. Three editions of this translation with notes appeared (1723, 1728/9, 1735) and were prompted, perhaps, by the rapidly fading Latin skills of English students, and the continuing need for textbook of natural philosophy in English Universities. The text was also used extensively in America. The book was presented as Cartesian physics with Newtonian refutation and was used widely until the middle of the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: Third edition of John Clarke's English translation of a late edition of Rohault's <i>Traite de Physique<i>. The optics sections (90 pages) include: light, color, reflection and refraction in materials; ocular anatomy; eye function; dioptrics and lensed images; reflection, plane and spherical mirrors and their images; nine problems in visual perception. As with the other topics, Rohault's Cartesian optics is accompanied by John's brother Samuel Clarke's notes containing additions, amplifications, and corrections derived from Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 and the Optice of 1706.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÄúMining All Within‚Äù: Clarke‚Äôs Notes to Rohault‚Äôs <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>|Hoskin, M.A.|<i>The Thomist: A Speculative Quarterly Review<i>, Vol 24, No 2, 1961, pp 353-363.||Samuel Clarke‚Äôs Annotations in Jacques Rohault‚Äôs <i>Trait√© de Physique<i>, and How They Contributed to Popularising Newton‚Äôs Physics|Sch√ºller, V.|In: <i>Between Leibniz, Newton, and Kant: Philosophy and Science in the Eighteenth Century<i>|Lef√®vre, W., editor|Springer, 2001, pp 95-110.
BP_Title: Rohault's system of natural philosophy, illustrated with Dr. Samuel Clarke's notes taken mostly out of Sir Isaac Newton's philosophy. Done into English by John Clarke, D.D. Dean of Sarum. The Third Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: French natural philosopher and mathematician. Experimentalist and textbook writer, the first and greatest promoter of Cartesian physics.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Forbes Library, Northhampton

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Prize-winning essay on the propagation of light.
BP_Description_1: In 1736 the French Royal Academy of Sciences proposed a prize question: How is Light Propagated? Johann Bernoulli II won the prize for the essay printed here by the Academy. The elaborate construct or vortices, oscillating corpuscles, and forces presented by Bernoulli is an example of the on-going desire for a fully mechanical explanation of light and its properties held in the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: Prize-winning essay on the propagation of light. A hybrid of Cartesian and Malebrachean ideas was proposed: An aether of small vortices is supposed to be interspersed with hard corpuscles of various sizes. Movement of a corpuscle in a particular direction compresses a neighboring vortex, transmitting the motion along a line in that direction; a kind of luminous fiber with corpuscles oscillating in the direction of propagation. The result is linear ray propagation. This model was used to explain reflection, refraction, and interference.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of Optics from Greek Antiquity to the Nineteenth Century<i>|Darrigol, O.|Oxford, 2012, pp 146-149.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Overview of natural philosophy Including: mechanics, gravity, fluids, optics, water and winds.
BP_Description_1: A popularization of natural philosophy written for the educated Dutch public. The scope and detail of the material indicates the interest in and market for information and instruction in the new experimental natural philosophy. This was more developed and expansive than Musschenbroek's detailed student text of 1734; and certainly more descriptive than the epitome of his lecture of 1726. A precis and commentary by van Hessom appeared in 1738, a second edition appeared in 1739, and a French translation appeared at Leiden in 1739.
BP_Description_2: Overivew of natural philosophy Including: mechanics, gravity, fluids, optics, water and winds. The optics section (119 pages) includes: nature of light; reflected and refracted rays; refraction in air and glass; color and differing refraction; the eye and eye-function; vision; catoptrics. The material on refraction and color is entirely Newtonian. The presentation is elementary but detailed, geometric, and accompanied by many elaborate figures.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Van Stevin tot Lorentz: Portretten van achttien Nederlandse natuurwetenschappers<i>|Kox, A.J., editor|Bert Bakker, Amsterdam, 1990, pp 93-105, NB: pp 97-98.|'s Gravesane and Musschenbroek: Newtonianism at Leiden|Ruestow, E.G.|In: <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.

BP_Title English Translation: Principles of Physics, Written in the Service of Countrymen, Accompanied by a Description of New and Lately Invented Airpump, with its use in Many Experiments. By J.v.M.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the Universities of Utrecht and then Leiden, developed the Layden jar, worked importantly in mechanics and electrostatics.
BP_Provenance: On front free endpaper: 'Donum Noblissima L.V.M. 8: Februarii 1737.' Bookplate of Buijnsters Smets.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Collected papers on dioptrics presented by Picard to the French Academy of Sciences.
BP_Description_1: A collection that contains a reprinting of the Fragmens Dioptrique of 1693. Between 1677 and 1679, Jean Picard presented a series of lectures on dioptrics to the French academy. In 1679 Pierre de Carcavi, mathematician and secretary of the National Library of France, proposed that Edm√© Mariotte, astronomer Philippe de La Hire and Picard produce a full treatise on optics for the Academy. Though the collaboration never took place, it was this project that apparent prompted Picard to begin a set of notes which he worked on until his death.||As the Preface makes clear, the volume collects works from several prominent authors in many areas, and in most cases is based on presentations made to the French Academy of Sciences. The editor was Philippe de la Hire, who had received several manuscripts from Jean Picard, who, in turn, had been entrusted with manuscripts of Bernard Fr√©nicle de Bessy, Christiaan Huygens, and Gilles Personne de Roberval for printing. Eventually, de la Hire would add the other works the volume contains, including works by Jean Picard. The Preface also states that at the time of Picard's death, Picard's collection of notes on dioptrics 'was in great confusion' and that the French mathematician and academician Laurent Pothenot oversaw their ordering and editing. This is likely the reason for their title: Les Fragmens de Dioptrique. Picard's extensive work with optical instruments in gnomics, astronomy, and surveying lead naturally to a keen interest in optics. The 77-page manuscript Pothernot worked on was a draft of Picard's text on dioptrics. It contained 49 propositions covering: refraction at spherical surfaces, focal characteristics of various types of lenses, and refraction at water, air, and glass interfaces. The text was based on presentations Picard had made to the French Academy in 1680.||Picard had carefully studies the optics of Christiaan Huygens and Isaac Barrow and wrote a summary of dioptrics expressly for applications to optical instruments.||This work on dioptrics by Picard would be printed again in 1730, pages 550-626 of volume 6, of the Memoires published by the French Academy that collected material from 1666 to its reorganization in 1699. It would appear again in 1736 in <i>Ouvrages de Mathematique de M. Picard<i>, a collection of astronomical and physical works of Picard.
BP_Description_2: Collected papers on dioptrics presented by Picard to the French Academy of Sciences. The <i>Fragmens Dioptrique<i> presents 49 propositions and proofs on the geometrical optics of lenses; of convex and concave figure, of single and multiple arrangement, and in oculars. The text deals with the essential aspects of the geometrical optical aspects of dioptrics. Propositions 1-3 cover the fundamentals of refraction as curved interfaces. Propositions 4-16 establish the basic properties of lenses, giving the relationship between figure, curvature, focal distance, and image position and size for many types of spherically-figured lenses, for rays that are parallel and oblique to the optical axis. It is here that Picard gives his expression for spherical aberration. Propositions 17-24 solve various problems that relate curvature radii and conjugate focal points for various types of lenses. Picard obtains essentially the same result as Edmond Halley regarding thin lenses. Propositions 25-35 consider similar problems, but with lenses fully or partially immersed in water.  Propositions 36-44 consider oculars and their interaction with objective lenses. Propositions 45-49 consider the effects of refracted rays that reflect off the interior surfaces of a lens, and how this effects lens use, particularly in surveying.||The 49 propositions are proved or demonstrated with detailed geometric analysis. They are often accompanied by corollaries that extend the utility of the proposition, and in some cases 'rules' are given that summarize characteristics or can be used to guide the construction of a lens. The material is entirely mathematical; though Picard was very much a practitioner, no practical aspects regarding lens making are presented. A serious and careful student of Huygens, these papers mainly derived from Huygens' theories.
BP_Reference(s): Recherches sur les travaux de dioptrique et de catoptrique de Jean Picard √† l'acad√©mie royale des sciences|Blay, M.|In: <i>Jean Picard et les d√©buts de l'astronomie de pr√©cision au XVIIe si√®cle<i>|√âditions du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, 1987, pp 329-344.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Six lively dialogues between Francesco Algarotti and a Marchioness on Newton's theories of light and color.
BP_Description_1: Finished after his trip to Paris and his stay with √âmilie du Ch√¢telet and Voltaire in 1735, Algarotti produced these six conversations with a fictional marchioness in which Newton's ideas and experiments on light and color are explained, questioned, and accepted. The complete embrace of Newtonianism was radical for the time, but the clarity, style, non-technical language, and form with which it was presented made the book important in the popularization of Newtonianism in Europe. This first edition--published without the usual permissions and with a forged title page--is interesting because its more radical aspects become more subdued in subsequent editions and translations; due, in part, to pressure from religious authorities. Algarotti began sketching the dialogues in the late 1720's and worked on them until the final edition of 1752. Algarotti write, in part, as a  response to Fontenelle's <i>Entretiens sur la pluralit√® des mondes<i> of 1686, which promoted Cartesian ideas using the format of a dialogue. Editions appeared in 1737, at Paris in 1738 and 1739, at London in 1739 and 1742, at Milan in 1739, at Amsterdam in 1741, at Naples in 1739 and 1752. A French translation appeared in 1738 and an English translation in 1739. The fame of the book was immediate and likely stoked by being placed on the Index of Forbidden Books for its radial promotion of socio-political change.
BP_Description_2: Six lively dialogues between Francesco Algarotti (the narrator) and a Marchioness on Newton's theories of light and color. These include: A general idea of physics and hypotheses concerning light and color; Light and color as qualities, general principles of optics; vision and discoveries in optics and their use in refuting Descartes; experimental philosophy and Newton's system of optics; further exposition of Newton's optics; Newton's principle of attraction and its application in optics. At the conclusion, the Marchioness abandons Cartesianism for Newtonian ideas.
BP_Reference(s): Science and Society: The Case of Acceptance of Newtonian Optics in the Eighteenth Century|Silva, C.C. and Moura, B.A.|<i>Science and Education<i>, Vol 21, No 9, 2012, pp 1317-1335.||Newton for ladies: gentility, gender and radical culture|Mazzotti, M.|<i>British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 37, No 2, 2004, pp 119-146.||<i>Translating Italy for the Eighteenth Century: British Women, Translation and Travel Writing (1739-1797)<i>|Agorni, M.|Routlage, 2002, pp 71-79.||The Triumphal March of a Paradigm: A Case Study of the Popularization of Newtonian Science|Feh√©r, M.|<i>Tractrix<i>, Vol 2, 1990, pp 93-110.
BP_Title: Il Newtonianismo per le dame, ovvero, dialoghi sopra la luce e i colori. --quae legat ipsa Lycoris. Virg. Egl. X.
BP_Title English Translation: Newtonism for the Ladies. Namely, A Dialogue on Light and Colors. --such as Lycoris herself may read. Virgil, 1oth Eclogue.
BP_Biographical Statement: Venetian polymath, philosopher, essayist, politician. Friend of Voltaire and Frederick the Great, prolific author and critic.
BP_Provenance: Algarotti' on titlepage

BP_Short or Common Title: A compendious system of natural philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A compendium of natural philosophy written specifically for students lacking higher mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Written specifically for students lacking higher mathematics, the content is drawn from Rowning's lessons given at Cambridge. The notes would have accompanied material taught by tutors, rather than being a textbook for a formal course. Descriptive and non-mathematical, it forms a stark contrast with French natural philosophy texts in use at the same time. The bibliography of this work is all but unresolvable; each part was issued separately, went through different editions, and was separately paginated. Overall, seven editions appeared between 1735 and 1772.
BP_Description_2: A compendium of natural philosophy including: properties of bodies, laws of motion, mechanical power;  hydrostatics and pneumatics; optics; astronomy; orreries, globes, and chronology. The extended optics section (215 pages) includes: light's nature and propagation; reflection; refraction at plane and spherical surfaces; lenses; the eye; vision; images from mirrors and lenses; color and differing refraction; colors of objects; the cause of opacity, transparency, and refraction in materials; microscopes and telescopes; the rainbow; camera obscura and the magic lantern. The treatment is entirely Newtonian but, despite the title, is generally descriptive and geometric, not mathematical. Though a few places in the optics section contain footnotes with analytic details and equations.||Rowning considers the mechanisms of reflection and refraction, taking up various theories prominent at the time including Newton's (ballistic),  Musschenbroek's (surface repulsive power), attractive force, and undulatory motion. Rowning plumps for Newton, but states that he finds none of these ideas satisfying or plausible. Indeed, in his Preface, Rowning states he is unable to present a theory based on existing principles of natural philosophy that explain reflection of light and the basic luminous power of radiant surfaces. Regarding refraction, Rowning invokes attractive cohesion force to account for the bending of light rays.
BP_Reference(s): The Problem of Reflection in Eighteenth-Century Projectile Theories of Light|Breno Arsioli Moura|<i>Physics in Perspective<i>, Vol 22, 2020, pp 191-214.
BP_Title: A compendious system of natural philosophy : With notes, containing the mathematical demonstrations, and some occasional remarks. In four parts. Part I. The properties of bodies. Their laws of motion. And the mechanical powers. Part II. Hydrostatics and pneumatics. To which are annexed some dissertations relating to these subjects. Part III. continued. Containing Catoptrics, and the Doctrine of Light and Colours. To this are added Dissertations on the following Subjects, Viz. Of the Cause of the Reflection of Light. Of Microscopes and Telescopes. And Of the Phaenomenon of the Rainbow. Part IV. Continued. Containing the Description of the Orrery and Globes, The Principles of Chronology; Together with the Physical Cause of the Motion of the Heavenly Bodies. By J. Rowning, M.A. Rector of Anderby in Lincolnshire, and late Fellow of Magdalen College in Cambridge.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, author, rector at Magdalene College, Cambridge.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the Turner Collection of the University of Keele

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Louis-Adrien Duperron de Castera (1705-1752) French translator and playwright.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: French translation of the Italian text of 1737 which was not just virulently Newtonian, but also anti-Cartesian.
BP_Description_1: Duperron de Castera's preface is an elaborate dance to justify a French version of a text that is not just virulently Newtonian, but also anti-Cartesian. Appealing to the general development of natural philosophy in which one idea develops into and is superseded by another, and calling for a general amnesty regarding nationalism, he points out the value of Algarotti's work and its value to French readers. Nevertheless, the preface ends with the translator posing two objections to Newton's law of gravitational attraction that is the topic the last of Algarotti's dialogues. In the second edition of the <i>Il Newtonianismo per le Dame<i> published in Milan in 1739, Algarotti commented on this French translation, disapproving of the translator's counter-claim regarding the differing ends of philosophy and religion, and the translation's reduced role of sensory perception.
BP_Description_2: French translation of the Italian text of 1737.

BP_Short or Common Title: Elemens de la philosophie de Neuton
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Voltaire's summary and popularization of Newtonian natural philosophy, covering optics and gravity.
BP_Description_1: At the time of publication, the natural philosophy of Newton was displacing that of Descartes in France, and being the first popularization in French the <i>Elemens<i> introduced a wide public to Newtonianism. Voltaire had  contracted for publication in Amsterdam and tried for simultaneous publication in Paris. But French authorities denied approbation and so the Dutch publisher was left with three hundred printed pages of an unfinished book.  An anonymous mathematician was commissioned to complete one chapter and write two more and the book was published without Voltaire‚Äôs knowledge. Importantly, this first edition contained none of the metaphysics that underpinned Newtonian natural philosophy; that would be added by Voltaire in later editions. Voltaire had an edition published in Paris soon after the Amsterdam edition appeared, having wrangled a <i>permission tacite<i> from the authorities. It was, essentially, a reproduction of the Amsterdam edition. Subsequent editions appeared in London and Paris, but it was not until 1741 that an edition fully under Voltaire's control was published in Paris. It differed dramatically from the first. Among other changes, Voltaire added an entire introductory part, La metaphysique de Newton, eliminated some chapters, and added others. In subsequent editions Voltaire continued to make substantial alterations. Editions appears at Amsterdam in 1738; at Paris in 1738, 1741, 1744, 1745, 1751, and 1757; at Dresden in 1748; at Rouen in 1751; at Geneva in 1756, 1757, 1764, 1770, 1773, 1775. A few republications appeared after 1775, but these had not been revised by Voltaire. Translations in English appeared in 1738, in Germain in 1741, and in Italian in 1741. This copy contains both a portrait of Voltaire and an allegorical one of Newton.
BP_Description_2: Voltaire's summary and popularization of Newtonian natural philosophy, covering optics and gravity. The chapters on optics (172 pages) include: light's nature and propagation, with a history and an attack on Descartes and Malebranche; reflection and refraction; eye and eye-function, refraction in the eye; telescopes; visual perception of distance, size, shape, and orientation; cause and consequences of refraction; colors and differing refraction; the rainbow; colors from thin plates and solid objects; prime colors and music scales. The material is entirely Newtonian.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Voltaire. Elements de la philosophie de Newton. BP_Title English Translation: Elements of the Philosophy of Newton. Put within Reach of the Entire World. By Mr. Voltaire.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by John Hanna (1696-?) Scottish mathematician and professor at Edinburgh.
BP_Short or Common Title: The Elements of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: English translation of the Amsterdam edition of Voltaire's summary and popularization of Newtonian natural philosophy, covering optics and gravity.
BP_Description_1: Voltaire's <i>Elemens<i> of 1738 was immediately recognized for its clarity of presentation, fidelity, and effective targeting of an educated but non-mathematic public. Though Newtonian natural philosophy had found its way into British universities, there were very few popularizations in English and so Hanna's translation was widely read. He added his own comments throughout the translation; which are usually just single sentences of further explication.
BP_Description_2: English translation of the Amsterdam edition of the <i>Elemens<i> of 1738. Voltaire's summary and popularization of Newtonian natural philosophy, covering optics and gravity. The chapters on optics (172 pages) include: light's nature and propagation, with a history and an attack on Descartes and Malebranche; reflection and refraction; eye and eye-function, refraction in the eye; telescopes; visual perception of distance, size, shape, and orientation; cause and consequences of refraction; colors and differing refraction; the rainbow; colors from thin plates and solid objects; prime colors and music scales. The material is entirely Newtonian.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Voltaire. Elements de la philosophie de Newton. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The collected works of Fabrizio, including <i>De Visione, Voce, Auditu<i> of 1600.
BP_Description_1: Girolamo Fabrizio's  <i>De Visione, Voce, Auditu<i> of 1600 is one of the last significant perspectivist works, resting as it does on medieval theories of vision. Within 5 years Platter and Kepler would clarify the function of the components of the eye and in 20 years Scheiner would establish modern ocular anatomy. The collected works of Fabrizio were first edited by Johann Bohn and appeared in Leipzig in 1687. This later edition of 1738 was edited by Bernad Albin, and includes a biographical sketch of Fabrizio. It had been nearly 150 years since Frabrizio's work and its first appearance; only scholarly, not practical, interest can explain the re-editing and re-issuing.
BP_Description_2: The collected works of Fabrizio, including <i>De Visione, Voce, Auditu<i> of 1600. Fabrizio held that one should describe Ô¨Årst the dissection and anatomy of a structure, then its independent action, and Ô¨Ånally its interdependent function in the body. That is, he aimed to discuss not just anatomy but physiology too. Thus the title: vision, voice, and hearing, rather than eye, larynx, and ear. The discussion of the eye and vision is entirely and completely medieval perspectivist. This involves: an upright image onto the crystalline lens, it being the seat of vision; perception based on geometric ideas originating at the beginning of perspectivism by Bacon, Alhacen, Witelo, and Peckham; the mechanisms of vision (lumen and lux) based on the Aristotelian idea of actualized potential qualities of materials. Only the anatomy presented is forward-looking and it presents a considerable advance, documented with exceptional plates of figures of the external anatomy of the eye. Some of these are reused by Platter and again by Kepler.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Hieronymus Fabricius d'Aquapendente : De visione, Ending of the Perspectivistic Tradition|De Nil, E. ,De Mey, M.|In: <i>Optics and Astronomy: Proceedings of the XXth International Congress of History of Science<i>|Brepols Publishers, 2001, pp 51-81.||Hieronymous Fabricius Ab Acquapendente (1533‚Äì1619)|Smith, S.B., Macchi, V., Parenti, A., DeCaro, R.|<i>Clinical Anatomy<i>, Vol 17, No 4, 2004, pp 540-543.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of the <i>Anmerckungen<i> of 1719, a practical manual for glass grinding and lens making.
BP_Description_2: Third edition of the <i>Anmerckungen<i> of 1719. A practical manual for glass grinding and lens making. Including: Glass grinding machines; figuring spherical lenses; lenses with one flat surface; burning glasses; eye-glasses; microscopes; telescopes; camera obscura; magic lantern; facetted metamorphosis lenses; micrometers; refractive instruments of Zahn; miscellaneous optical machines.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A history of spectacles.
BP_Description_1: Manni's book is the first on the history of spectacles and arises directly from his abiding interest in Tuscan and Florentine history and his unwearying effort to record what his researches revealed. This is the earlies version of Mannis' history, the second was published in 1741.
BP_Description_2: A history of spectacles. This includes: a review of the importance, names, and types of spectacles; previous attempts to attribute their invention; the assignment of the invention to Salvino d'Armato who was recorded to have died in 1317; The evidence; historical evidence of spectacles in literature and art; forms of spectacles and how they are worn. The text includes the historical essay on the history of spectacles by Francesco Redi, who assigned their invention to Allessandro della Spina who died in 1313. Redi is now known to have initiated the story of and presented the carefully selected evidence for the invention of spectacles by Spina of Pisa to Carlo Dati. In general, the evidence Manni presented later proved to be unsustainable.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Renaissance Vision from Spectacles to Telescopes<i>|Ilardi, V.|American Philosophical Society, 2007, pp 3-26.||The Invention of Eyeglasses. Part I|Rosen, E.|<i>Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 1, 1956, pp 13-46||The Invention of Eyeglasses. Part II|Rosen, E.|<i>Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1956, pp 183-218||

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The second, expanded edition of an epitome of natural philosophy, principally from the physical sciences, written for students and self-study.
BP_Description_1: Martin's first published book, written while he was running a boarding school and teaching everything from Writing to Astronomy. As with most of his work, he wrote books not meant to be texts, ancillary to and used in a formal course, rather he wrote for the autodidact: 'for those whose lot it is to pursue these studies without a master.' The <i>Philosophical Grammar<i> was his most successful book. The English original appeared in 1735, the second in 1738 with expanded text and additional plates. Eight editions appeared up to 1778, all printed essentially unchanged from the second. It was popular not only in England but in continental Europe. It was translated into Dutch with three editions, French with editions in 1749, 1764, and 1769, German in 1779, and Italian with editions at Venice and Naples in 1750, 1753, 1760, 1769, 1771, 1778, and 1807. Posthumous editions appeared in Greek and Russian. The text is interesting in that it is structured in two levels: the main dialogue in which the material is briefly presented, and copious notes that give detail, add mathematics, and explain the figures. In this way the book can be read at two levels; reading only the dialogue gives the overview, while the notes give the details and more advanced material.
BP_Description_2: The second, expanded edition of an epitome of knowledge, principally from the physical sciences, written for students and self-study. The wide range of topics were meant to provide a survey of most of natural philosophy. The material is prefaced with a general introduction to experimentation, natural philosophy, and a list of instruments and their uses. Part I: Nature and properties of matter, Newtonian physics and mechanics. Part II: Cosmology, including the planets, the moon, the stars, and comets. Part III: 'Aerology', including the atmosphere and meteorics. Part IV: Geology, plants, insects, birds, and animals. Part I contains chapters on light and color (25 pages), including: nature of light, reflection, refraction, simple mirrors and lenses, the microscope, telescope, camera obscura, the magic lantern, prismatic and thin-plate colors, heterogeneous white light. The presentation is elementary, with no mathematics, in the form of a dialogue of short questions and answers. Accompanying the dialogue is an elaborate and copious set of notes that give examples, clarify, cite authorities, and explain the figures. The details and more advanced material is in the notes.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Benjamin Martin: Author, Instrument-Maker, and ‚ÄòCountry Showman‚Äô<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Nordhoff Publishing, Lyden, 1976, pp 11-21.
BP_Title: The philosophical grammar; Being a view of the present state of experimented physiology, or natural philosophy. In four parts. Part I. Somatology, treateth of the universal Nature and Properties of Matter, or Substance, and the specifick Qualities of natural Bodies. Part II. Cosmology, exhibiteth a general View of the Universe, and its great constituent Parts ; the Sun, Moon, Planets, Comets, fixed Stars, &c. Part III. Aerology, compriseth the Philosophy of the Atmosphere, shewing the wonderful Nature and Properties of the Air, Wind, Meteors, and other Phaenomena therein. Part IV. Geology, containeth a Philosophical View of the terraqueous Globe, in all its Parts and Productions ; as Minerals, Metals, Stones, &c. The Laws of Fluids ; the Sea, its Tides, &c. Of Rivers, Springs, &c. Of Vegetation, and the Nature of Plants, Trees, &c. Of the Parts of animal Bodies ; and a Survey of the Nature of Beasts, Birds, Fishes, Insects, Reptiles, Shell-Animals, &c. The Second Edition, with alterations, corrections, and very large additions, by way of notes. By Benj. Martin,
BP_Biographical Statement: English sciencen lecturer, oculist, instrument maker, lexicographer.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Manual for the construction of reflecting telescopes and lensed microscopes.
BP_Description_1: Passemant's book appeared anonymously. Only later did it become generally know that he had produced the book. A pirated edition, again without Passemant's name, appeared in Amsterdam in 1741 and is the version which circulated more widely and was the most influential, triggering as it did the development of reflecting telescope making in the Netherlands. The book was specifically written for those 'who want to construct a telescope of their own.' The plate of figures was drawn and etched by J.B. Scotin.||Though Newton had demonstrated his reflecting telescope in 1668, metal mirrors were difficult to make, figure, polish, and keep from tarnishing. It was only in the 1720s and 1730s that this craft advanced enough for the construction of practical instruments. Passemant's book appeared the same year as Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i>. Though both texts detail the development of telescope optics, Passemant's book contains details regarding the making of telescope mirrors that only a practitioner could present.
BP_Description_2: Manual for the construction of reflecting telescopes and lensed microscopes. Includes: Molds and forms for metal mirrors; material for mirrors, how they are shaped, figured, and polished; construction of the other components of a reflecting telescope; using reflecting telescopes; examples of telescope construction; arrangement and orientation of telescopes with large mirrors; making objective and ocular lenses, simple and compound; making and using microscopes. The presentation is detailed and clearly the result of the extensive direct practice and experience of the author. Passemant built several instruments to the design depicted in the folding plate in the book.
BP_Reference(s): Reflecting ‚ÄòPopular Culture‚Äô: The Introduction, Diffusion, and Construction of the Reflecting Telescope in the Netherlands|Zuidervaart, H.J.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 61, 2004, pp 407-452.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A thorough treatment of the science of optics in the form of a textbook. Among the greatest in the 18th century.
BP_Description_1: Smith's text is clearly designed for teaching; it's content, scope, clarity, style, and concision reflect his ideas of what optics was and how it should be presented in full. Smith held optics to be a mathematical science and presented what he felt to be its core: light's behavior, optical materials, mirrors and lenses, and optical instruments. Next in importance was perception, hence the emphasis on images and the inclusion of Jurin's essay on vision. To help produce a coherent whole, sections of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> were extracted and refashioned, anchoring many of the sections in Books I and II, together with Smith's original material on geometrical optics. Coherence and clarity also demanded that details, mathematics, notes, sidelines, and alternatives ideas not interrupt the general presentation; thus their gathering in the section 'Author's Remarks' at the conclusion of the work. Smith's work became the principal textbook of optics in the 18th century and was read and used into the 19th. It was the greatest among the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics, the list of such texts is short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799.Montucla, Helmholtz, Mach, and Schmidt all cited Smith's <i>System<i>. Dutch editions appeared in 1753 and 1764, German in 1755 and 1775, and expanded French editions in 1767 and 1783. An English precis was produced in 1778 for use at Cambridge.
BP_Description_2: A thorough treatment of the science and mathematics of optics in the form of a textbook. Four treatises and additional remarks. Book I, A Popular Treatise, sets out Newton's natural philosophy of optics, including: nature of light, lenses and spectacles, vision, colors and differing refraction, the cause of reflection, refraction, and diffraction, color and optical properties of materials. Book II, A Mathematical Treatise, contains geometrical optics, including: foci and images from mirrors, the foci and images from lenses, analysis of multiple lenses, lens aberrations, the reflecting telescope, images from telescopes and microscopes. Book III, A Mechanical Treatise, is on optical instruments, including: lens grinding (Huygens' method reported by Molyneux), telescope sights, meridian sectors, mural arcs, image projectors, binoculars, telescope mirrors, mechanics of microscopes. Book IV, A Philosophical Treatise, give a history of discoveries made with the telescope. The fifth part, Author's Remarks, adds experimental details, elaborations, alternative ideas, and mathematical proofs to sections of the four Books. Jurin's essay on vision appears at the end. Book I is meant for a general audience and so demonstrations are not mathematical but rather experimental. In the other books the presentation is detailed, mathematical, and accompanied by hundreds of detailed figures. The text is the first in English on optical design and includes the first statement of the 'optical invariant' for lenses (product of image size and ray angle), first illustrations of spherical aberrations and caustics, and the introduction of marginal rays in lens analysis.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327.||Berkeley, Reid, and the Mathematization of Mid-Eighteenth-Century Optics|Cantor, G.N.|<i>Journal of the History of Ideas<i>, Vol 38, No 3, 1977, pp. 429-448, NB: pp 441-447.||The Beginnings of Commercial Manufacture of the Reflecting Telescope in London|Simpson, A.D.C.|<i>Journal for the History of Astronomy<i>, Vol 40, No 4, 2009, pp 421-466, NB: 431-439.||Early Books in Optics & Optical Design: A Compleat System of Opticks & The Edinburgh Encyclopedia|Thompson, K.P.|Optics and photonics news Vol 16, No10,  2005, pp 28-33.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Johann Christoffel von Sprogel (1686-?) German phycian living in Amsterdam.
BP_Short or Common Title: Grond-beginzelen van alle de mathematische weetenschappen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First Dutch translation of Wolff's <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde<i> of 1710. It was the first introductory teaching compendium in German on Mixed Mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Wolff and his writings were unknow in the Netherlands before the appearance of this translation. The translator, Christoffel von Spr√∂gel, was a German physician who moved to Amsterdam in 1736 and announced a series of lectures on Wolffian philosophy. Apparently, the response was sufficient to warrant a large translation project and working with another translator, Adolf Fredrick Marci, of Wolff's German (not Latin) works were translated into Dutch. The <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde<i> of 1710 was the first in this project. von Spr√∂gel states that he had studied mathematics since his youth and had come to hold that Wolff had written the best textbook on the subject and wanted the Dutch public to have access to his works. A second printing of this translation appeared in 1758.
BP_Description_2: First Dutch translation of Wolff's <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde<i> of 1710. It was the first introductory teaching compendium in German on Mixed Mathematics. Four volumes containing: I arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry and architecture; II artillery, fortification, mechanics, hydrostatics, aerometry, and Hydraulics; III optics, spherical trigonometry, astronomy, chronology, geography, and horology; IV rudiments of algebra and the differential and integral calculus. The optics section (118 pages) includes: optics, with a euclidean-geometrical explanation of perception; making and figuring glass and metal mirrors; burning mirrors and images from mirrors; mirrors for anamorphosis; refraction, lenses and their focal and imagining properties; making and use of microscopes and telescopes; magic lanterns. The treatment is practical and geometric, with the dioptrics receiving a more extensive and mathematical treatment.  The presentation is formal and very concise, with axioms, theorems and their demonstration, and comments in scholia introducing most material. Examples by way of problems are presented and solved. The optics material draws heavily from Dechales, Huygens, and Zahn. Newton's color theory is described, though Wolff freighted it with a mediumistic/mechanical basis.
BP_Reference(s): Leibniz and Wolff in the Netherlands. The Eighteenth-Century Dutch Translations of Their Writings|Wielema, M.R.|<i>Studia Leibnitiana<i>, Vol 25, No 1, 1993, pp. 55-69.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

Dl 2, Bevattende de Bouwkonst, Artilleries, Fortificatie, Mechanica, Huydrostatica, Aerometria, en Hydraulica. Dl.3, Bevattende de optica, catoptrica, dioptrica, perspectiva, sphaerische trigonometrie, astronomie, geographie, chronologie, en gnomonica. BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Elizabeth Carter (1717-1806) Friend of Samuel Johnson and member of the Bluestocking Society
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Elizabeth Carter's English translation of the <i>Il Newtonianismo per le dame<i> of 1737.
BP_Description_1: Elizabeth Carter's translation of Algarotti's <i>Il Newtonianismo per le Dame<i> gives evidence of her interest in and understanding of mathematics and astronomy. Her translation shows specialist knowledge of Newtonian ideas and is remarkable for footnotes that quote extensively from literary and scientific sources, including Pierre Bayle's General Dictionary. Carter's translation is not a rote one; she adopted strategies for altering Algarotti's text to make it more narrowly focused on the science it contained. She either smoothed over or eliminated the erotic or misogynistic portions of Algarotti's text and also eliminated many of the specific references to socio-political change in what was then known as 'Italy'. In these way, the English version of Algarotti was considerably different than the Italian. In the second edition of the <i>Il Newtonianismo per le Dame<i> published in Milan in 1739, Algarotti commented on this English translation, wishing it had been more faithful to the original--likely an objection to Carter's strategic changes. Editions of the translation appeared in London in 1739, 1742, 1772 and Glasgow in 1765.
BP_Description_2: English translation of the <i>Il Newtonianismo per le Dame<i> of 1737. Six lively dialogues between Francesco Algarotti (the narrator) and a Marchioness on Newton's theories of light and color. These include: A general idea of physics and hypotheses concerning light and color; Light and color as qualities, general principles of optics; vision and discoveries in optics and their use in refuting Descartes; experimental philosophy and Newton's system of optics; further exposition of Newton's optics; Newton's principle of attraction and its application in optics. At the conclusion, the Marchioness abandons Cartesianism for Newtonian ideas.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Translating Italy for the Eighteenth Century: British Women, Translation and Travel Writing (1739-1797)<i>|Agorni, M.|Routlage, 2002, pp 56-89.||Science and Society: The Case of Acceptance of Newtonian Optics in the Eighteenth Century|Silva, C.C. and Moura, B.A.|<i>Science and Education<i>, Vol 21, No 9, 2012, pp 1317-1335.||Newton for ladies: gentility, gender and radical culture|Mazzotti, M.|<i>British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 37, No 2, 2004, pp 119-146.

BP_Short or Common Title: Examen et reÃÅfutation des EÃÅleÃÅmens de la philosophie de Neuton de M. de Voltaire
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A chapter-by-chapter refutation of the first 14 chapters of Voltaire's <i>Elemens<i> of 1738
BP_Description_1: Banieres' <i>Examen et reÃÅfutation<i> is as much an attack on Newtonians as it is Voltaire. Banieres was an ardent Cartesian and had published his <i>Trait√© physique, de la lumiere et des couleurs<i> in 1738 and drew heavily from it for the  <i>Examen et reÃÅfutation<i>. By the 1740s, Cartesian ideas involving vortices and the plenum had been abandoned by many, so Banieres'  <i>Examen et reÃÅfutation<i> had little influence, other than to be the hallmark of the end of Cartesianism. The <i>Examen et reÃÅfutation<i> received a blistering review in the History of the Works of the Learned of February 1740.
BP_Description_2: A chapter-by-chapter refutation of the first 14 chapters of Voltaire's <i>Elemens<i> of 1738; that is, that portion dealing with Newton's optics. Banieres opens with a preface of 96 pages on the causes and laws of the reflection and refraction of light. He cites works of Hobbes, Mairan, John Bernoulli, and Descartes to show alternatives to Newton's ideas, to refute was Voltaire presented, to show the fallacies regarding forces of attraction, to champion the fundamentally mechanistic ideas of Descartes, and to show that Cartesian ideas regarding reflection and refraction are uppermost. Subject include: light's nature and propagation; reflection; visual perception; refraction; chromatic refraction; cause of refraction; light particles and their colors; the rainbow; the analogy between colors and musical tones.
BP_Reference(s): Eighteenth century optics: the Cartesian-Newtonian Conflict|Pav, P.A.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 14, No 12, 1975, pp 3102-3108.
BP_Title: Examen et reÃÅfutation des EÃÅleÃÅmens de la philosophie de Neuton de M. de Voltaire , avec une dissertation sur la reÃÅflexion et la reÃÅfraction de la lumieÃÄre. Dedie a Monseigneur le Duc de Chartres. par M. Jean BanieÃÄres
BP_Title English Translation: Examination and Refutation of Elements of the Philosophy of Newton of Mr. Voltaire. With a Dissertation on the Reflection and Refraction of Light. Dedicated to Monseigneur the Duke of Chartres. By Mr. Jean Banieres.
BP_Provenance: Curson Destranelle' inscribed on titlepage, bookplate of Karin Figala

BP_Short or Common Title: Vita fata et scripta Christiani Wolfi
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A biography and annotated bibliography of Wolff's writings
BP_Description_1: The title page lists no author, but this summary of Wolff's life and works has been attributed to Johann Christoph Gottsched whose prominence in literary Germany makes it likely to be his work. The importance of Christian Wolff in German intellectual life, the wide range of his comprehensive knowledge, and the influence of his written works no doubt prompted this life and bibliography.
BP_Description_2: A biography and annotated bibliography of Wolff's writings, listing eighty-eight works. Titles and publication place is given and usually (but not always) the publication date is given.
BP_Reference(s): Christian Wolff (1679-1754) A Biographical Essay|Drechsler, W.|<i>European Journal of Law and Economics<i>, Vol 4 No 2, 1997, pp 111-128.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Bryan Robinson (1680-1754)
BP_Short or Common Title: A course of lectures in natural philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A course in Newtonian mechanics and optics for university students.
BP_Description_1: From 1711 until his death in 1738, Richard Helsham taught natural philosophy at the new medical school at Trinity College Dublin. Helsham's pupil, Bryan Robinson, was also a medical doctor, had attended Helsham's lectures, and used the lecture notes to produce a teaching textbook for natural philosophy. Robinson's editorial work included adding a Preface that quotes Newton's method for natural philosophy which is taken from the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704, and adding an Appendix that brought mathematical detail to some of Helsham's articles. Helsham adheres closely to Newtonian science, specifically mechanics and its applications, and optics. The text does not cover heat, electricity, or magnetism--topics not found in Newton's Principia or Opticks.||The text became widely used and was in print for nearly a century, with the content remaining unchanged until the late editions. Editions appeared London in 1739, 1743, 1755, 1767, 1767, and 1777, at Dublin in 1739, 1778, 1793, and 1822, and at Philadelphia in 1802. A Latin translation appeared at Vienna in 1769. Several excerpts were also produced in the 19th century.
BP_Description_2: Helsham's textbook is in 23 Lectures. Lectures 1-11 cover forces, motion, and mechanics. Lectures 12-14 cover hydrostatics. Lectures 15-18 cover pneumatics and sound. Lectures 19-23 cover optics. The optics material (70 pages) Lecture 19 includes physical optics, the nature of light, reflection and refraction, and refractive properties of solids and liquids. Lecture 20 cover colors and relies heavily on Newton Opticks. Prismatic colors and colors produced by selected liquids is covered. Lecture 21 covers dioptrics including lenses and basic geometric optics. Lecture 22 covers the eye, eye function, vision, spectacles, and perception. Lecture 23 covers catoptrics including plane and both convex and concave spherical mirrors, and the calculation, size, and place of images.||Helsham's treatments are thorough, essentially descriptive, and particularly clear. The mathematics uses the geometry of ratios integrated into the text and never rises above that--though it is made to serve remarkably well in many cases. Robinson's Appendix adds considerable algebraic mathematics to many subjects, particularly enhancing and expanding the material of geometric optics. The concision and descriptive nature of the text makes the plates of figures an essential part of material.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ A Course of Lectures in Natural Philosophy|Roche, J.|<i>European Journal of Physics<i>, Vol 21, No 3, 2000, pp 275-277.
BP_Title: A course of lectures in natural philosophy. By the late Richard Helsham, M.D. Professor of Physick and Natural Philosophy in the University of Dublin. Published by Bryan Robinson, M.D.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish physicain, academic, natural philosopher. Professor at the University of Dublin, author of important textbooks.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first of Jurin's responses to the mathematician Benjamin Robins faulting and findings of Jurin's calculation in the latter's <i>Essay on Distinct and Indistinct Vision<i> which had appeared in Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: Jurin's Essay on Distinct and Indistinct Vision had been appended to and published with Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> in 1738. The mathematician Benjamin Robins faulted the findings of Jurin's calculations and he and Jurin began an acrimonious exchange. This is a printing of the first of Jurin's responses.
BP_Description_2: Benjamin Robins fault hunting and James Jurin's defense have all the hallmarks of academic squabbling over minutiae. In addition to point-by-point refutation, Jurin mocks and satirizes Robins with an imaginary question and answer exchange. Jurin and Robins had previously crossed swords about Newton fluxions after both had answered Berkeley's attack on Newton in his <i>The Analyst; or a Discourse Addressed to an Infidel Mathematician<i> of 1734. Jurin was the more techy of the two, easily provoked and often angry in tone. Benjamin Robins later responded to Jurin with his <i>A Full Confutation of Dr. Jurin's Reply to the Remarks on His Essay Upon Distinct and Indistinct Vision<i>. The back-and-forth would last until 1741.
BP_Reference(s): The Correspondence of James Jurin (1684-1750): Physician and Secretary to the Royal Society|Rusnock, A., editor|Rodopi, Amsterdam, 1995, 570 pp, NB pp 35-42.
BP_Title: Reply to Mr. Robins's remarks on the Essay upon distinct and indistinct vision Published at the Edn of Dr. Smith's Compleat System of Opticks. By James Jurin, M.D. Fellow of the College of Physicians, and of the Royal Society. Communis sensu plane caret, inquimus. Eheu! Quam temere in nosmet legem sancimus iniquam!
BP_Title English Translation: "The Plan Lacks Common Sense, We say.  Alas! How Rashly we Ourselves Ordain an Unjust Law!"
BP_Biographical Statement: English  physician, natural philosopher.  President of the Royal College of Physicians, Secretary of the Royal Society, combative adovate of Newtonian physics, contributor to Smith's Opticks.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the Macclesfield Library

BP_Description_1: Giovanni Lecchi's first published work; a thesis or disputation defended in the Jesuit College at Brera.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A general development of color theory applied to painting, perception, and sound.
BP_Description_1: The most famous work of Louis Bertrand Castel, presenting his theories of color; their nature, origin, and relationships to sound, brought together in his description of the 'ocular harpsichord.' In 1735 Castel wrote a series of articles for the Journal de Trevoux on new experiments in optics and acoustics. The <i>L‚ÄôOptique des couleurs<i> is an elaboration and explanation of those ideas. A firm Anti-Newtonian, Castel opposed virtually all of the new natural philosophy and his though can be considered the result of  grafting Cartesianism onto scholasticism. Widely read, the book received blistering reviews in the scientific press but the idea of an instrument that simultaneously presented sounds and their 'matching' colors appealed to many outside of such circles. Popularizing the idea of such an instrument was the only influence the book had; its color theory far too antiquarian to be considered seriously.
BP_Description_2: A general development of color theory applied to painting, perception, and sound. It presents: general consideration of color, separating artificial prismatic colors from the real colors of pigments and objects; white and black as the origin of colors; chromatic harmony and its basis in the 'primitive colors' of nature; specific shades of blue, red, and yellow as primitive colors; color circles, their application in art, and their relationship to musical scales; derivation of 144 true, real colors and their relation to the musical scale; previous letters giving several negative assessments of Newton's theory of colors; and the ocular harpsichord. The development is descriptive, no mathematics is involved, and the basis is a hybrid of scholasticism and Cartesianism.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>Louis-Bertrand Castel, Anti-Newtonian Scientist<i>|Schier, D.S.|Torch Press, 1941.
BP_Title: L'optique des couleurs, FondeÃÅe sur les simples observations, & tourneÃÅe sur-tout aÃÄ la pratique de la peinture, de la teinture & des autres arts coloristes. Par le R.P. Castel, Jesuite.
BP_Title English Translation: The Optics of Colors. Founded on Simple Observations, and Turned, above all ,to the Practice of Painting, Dyeing, and Other Colorist Arts. By the Reverend Father Castel, SJ.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, journalist, dilettante natural philosopher. Disagreed famously with Newton about the spectral nature of white light.

BP_Short or Common Title: A new and compendious system of optics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A compendium of practical optics, in three parts: Catoptrics, Dioptrics, and Optical Instruments.
BP_Description_1: This is Martin's first original contribution to natural philosophy. Though Martin was widely read and drew on other works, this is largely based on his own experience. He justifies the need for his optics text book by noting that Molyneux's book 'was too large, and too much perplexed with algebraic solutions', while in Gregory's <i>Elements<i>, 'the geometrical demonstrations of every proposition deter the reader,' and Browne's Supplement to Gregory's book was 'a labyrinth of analytical investigations and solutions,' and Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> too expensive. Martin was both a teacher and instrument maker, and his optics compendium bears the stamp of experience in each. The book is written with the very practical outcome of optical instruments in mind, and the concision, clarity of presentation, and use of detailed figures shows it to be specifically written for self-study. It was one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics; the list of such texts being short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799.
BP_Description_2: A compendium of practical optics, in three parts: Catoptrics, Dioptrics, and Optical Instruments. Catoptrics (56 pages) includes: definitions, rays and pencils of rays, reflection, plane and spherical convex and concave mirrors, the analysis of mirror foci and images, 'rules' for catoptrics derived from the analysis. Dioptrics (84 pages) includes: refraction at plane and curved interfaces, foci and images from lenses, analysis of lens images, 'rules' for the analysis of lenses. Optical Instruments (155 pages) describes mainly dioptric apparatus and includes: ocular anatomy, eye-function, and vision; spectacles and vision correction; camera obscura; microscopes, simple and compound; telescopes; colors and differing refraction, chromatic aberration; reflecting telescopes; micrometers; optical goniometer; magic lantern and binoculars. The presentation is practical with no laboring over theory, very detailed, and with an emphasis on experiments leading to 'rules', and those leading to practical optical instruments. Just enough mathematics is introduced to provide for practical computations. Much of Martin's material came from practical experience--he was a successful oculist and his instruments were commercially successful.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Benjamin Martin: Author, Instrument-Maker, and ‚ÄòCountry Showman‚Äô<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Nordhoff Publishing, Lyden, 1976, pp 28-30.||Benjamin Martin (1704-1782) and his Writings on the Eye and Eyeglasses|Goss, D.A.|<i>Hindsight, Journal of Optometry History<i>, Vol 41, No 2, pp 41-55.
