BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Samuel Clarke (1675-1729) English philosopher and cleric, correspondent, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The Third edition of the <i>Optice<i> of 1706. This edition contains all the queries of the final English edition
BP_Description_1: This is part of a hybrid set of, in all, 8 volumes of the first collected works of Isaac Newton. Published between 1739-1761 it consists of 'Geneva Principia' , 3 vols. (1739-42), Optice (1740), and <i>Arithmatica Universalis<i> (1761). This edition of the <i>Optice<i> contains a portrait of Newton made in 1728 when he was 84. The allegorical title vignette was drawn by Delamoncien and engraved by Jean-Louis Daud√©t. The Latin of Samuel Clarke was edited by Marcus-Michael Bousquet who dedicated it to Johannes Bernoulli.
BP_Description_2: The third edition of the <i>Optice<i> of 1706. This edition contains all the queries of the final English edition. Like the <i>Opticks<i>, the <i>Optice<i> is in three Books. Book I is in two parts. Part I deals with prism experiments and the spectral heterogeneity of white light. It begins with definitions and axioms that review the basic aspects of geometric optics of reflection and refraction. This is followed by 8 propositions based on 16 experiments dealing with chromatic inhomogeneity and its consequences. Propositions 7 and 8 deal specifically with the limitations imposed on telescope objectives by what is now called chromatic aberration. Part II presents 11 propositions based on 17 experiments investigating the nature of color and the application of the theory of chromatic heterogeneity, particularly to the rainbow. It is here that Newton's 'experimentum crucis' of his letter of 1672 is presented in refined form and great detail.||Book II is in four parts. Part I presents 24 observations of the colored fringes produced by light passing through glass plates and thin lenses in contact in air and water. Part II presents a mathematical analysis of these observations, including Newton's method for determining small separating distances. Part III presents 20 propositions dealing with colors of natural bodies and their relationship to prismatic colors and color production in thin plates. it is here that Newton proposes that light has 'Fits of easy reflection and fits of easy transmission.' Part IV presents 13 observations of colors produced by thick plates.||Book III presents 11 descriptive observations of the color and placement of diffraction fringes produced by various objects. Queries--rhetorical questions--were Newton's means of proposing ideas about natural philosophy in general and the nature of light and color in particular. It is here that Newton dismisses wave theories of light as incapable of explaining its observed properties.  The <i>Optice<i> ends with the original 16 Queries of the <i>Opticks<i>, adds 7 new ones, and adds extensively to Queries 10 and 11. The <i>Optice<i> also provides an addendum describing luminescent light sources. Queries  17-23 are new in the <i>Optice<i> and deal with the nature of space, the plenum, the aether, and luminous corpuscles. Newton makes reference to Hauksbee's mercurial light and, ever-skeptical of Huygens' wave theory of light, adds an explanation for double refraction of certain crystals; an explanation based the corpuscular assumption of the nature of light. Query 23 is the longest and most important of all, by far, pondering the existence gravitational, magnetic, and electrical forces by which bodies can produce action-at-a-distance. He argues why these cannot be dismissed as 'occult forces' and suggest that other, more powerful forces may exist that are responsible for the interaction of light and matter. It ends with Newton's remarkable paragraph linking the development of natural and moral philosophy.
BP_Reference(s): Les Queries de l'Optique|Koyre, A.|<i>Archieves Internationales d'Histoire des Sciences<i>, Vol 13, 1960, pp 15-29.||The methodological origins of Newton‚Äôs queries|Anstey, P.R.|<i>Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science<i>, Vol 35, 2004, pp 247-269.||Sir Isaac and the ingenious Mr. Hauksbee|Guerlac, H.|In: <i>M√©langes Alexandre Koyr√©: L'aventure de la science<i>|Hermann, Paris, 1964, pp 228-253, NB 250-253.
BP_Title: Optice: sive de reflexionibus, refractionibus, inflexionibus et coloribus lucis, libri tres. Authore Isaaco Newton Equite Aurato. Latine reddidit Samuel Clarke, S.T.P. Editio Novissima.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An anonymous work on the techniques of lens grinding and polishing for telescopes, eyeglasses, and other instruments.
BP_Description_1: An anonymous work on the techniques of lens grinding and polishing for telescopes, eyeglasses, and other instruments. There are references to Schott, Kircher, and Schyrlaeus de Rheita. The work also deals very briefly with matters of 'perspective'--actually anamorphosis. The material is devoted entirely to the craft of lens making. The text is highly detailed and clearly was written by someone familiar with lens-craft. Materials, griding and figuring machines, polishing, and lens testing are described. More than 60 figures accompany the text.||It was a popular, practical guide to the craft and mechanics of lens making. Christiaan Huygens library had a copy. This must have become something of a standard work; it was in print for more than 60 years. Editions appeared at Dresden in 1680, 1689, 1718, and 1741. Usually bound with Johann Georg Leutmann's <i>Neue Anmerckungen vom Glasschleiffen<i> that first appeared in 1718 and reviewed in the Acta Eruditorum of August 1719.
BP_Description_2: The book has three chapters. Chapter 1: Geometry required for the purpose of lens making (3 pages). Chapter 2: Conic sections (6 pages). Chapter 3: Grinding, figuring, and polishing lenses. Using them in instruments. (20 pages). Three-part Appendix.
BP_Reference(s): Litteratur der mechanischen und optischen Wissenschaften|Murhard, W.A.|Leipzig, Breitkof & H√§rtel, Vol 5, Part 3, p 125.
BP_Title: Kurtze Anweisung Die Glasser zu schleiffen und Prospective
BP_Title English Translation: Brief Notes on Glass Grinding and Preparing Perspective
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Leutmanns 1738 and Hertel, 1716
BP_BibliographicNotes: Frontispiece
BP_Binding: Contemporary Calf Rebacked Cambridge Style Binding

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by ?
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian translation of the <i>Elemens<i> of 1738, Voltaire's summary and popularization of Newtonian natural philosophy, covering optics and gravity.
BP_Description_1: This translation was made from the 1738 English translation of the <i>Elemens<i>. As such, it contains the corrections Hanna made in his English edition and the properly labeled figures. Voltaire's <i>Elemens<i> of 1738 was immediately recognized for its clarity of presentation, fidelity, and effective targeting of an educated but non-mathematic public. Though Newtonian natural philosophy had found its way into British universities, there were very few popularizations in English and so Hanna's translation was widely read. He added his own comments throughout the translation; which are usually just single sentences of further explication.
BP_Description_2: Italian translation of the the <i>Elemens<i> of 1738. Included is a new table of contents and material on tides that had appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Society of London. This is Voltaire's summary and popularization of Newtonian natural philosophy, covering optics and gravity. The chapters on optics (172 pages) include: light's nature and propagation, with a history and an attack on Descartes and Malebranche; reflection and refraction; eye and eye-function, refraction in the eye; telescopes; visual perception of distance, size, shape, and orientation; cause and consequences of refraction; colors and differing refraction; the rainbow; colors from thin plates and solid objects; prime colors and music scales.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Voltaire. Elements de la philosophie de Newton. Critical edition<i>|Walters, R.L. and Barber W.H.|Oxford: Voltaire Foundation, 1992, Introduction.||<i>The Newtonian Moment<i>|Feinbold, M.|Oxford, 2004, pp 94-117.||Notes on Voltaire's 'The Elements of Sir Isaac Newton' Philosophy'|Albert, D.M.|<i>Documenta Ophthalmologica<i>, Vol 94, 1997, pp 59-81||Voltaire, Newton, and the Law|Hanley, W.|<i>The Library<i>, Vol 13, No 1, 1991, pp 48‚Äì65.
BP_Title: Elementi della filosofia del Neuton. Esposti del Signor Di Voltaire. Tradotti dal Francese.
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of the Philosophy of Newton. Expounded by Mr. Voltaire. Translated from the French.
BP_Biographical Statement: French historian, philosopher,  writer. Famed polemicist and satirist, important popularizer of Newtonian optics.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Woodcuts in text, engraved plates

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Questions for consideration and preparation by university students, including natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Intended for university students, this is a collection of questions about the principles of physics, natural history, chemistry, meteorology, mechanics, hydrostatics, optics, astronomy, logic, metaphysics, and moral philosophy. Each question is accompanied by a bibliography of passages that the student should study. A wide range of authors are included in these lists. The appendix is a set of rules on legal disputation derived from Heereboord's <i>Hermeneia Logica<i>, a treatise on logic. Editions appeared in 1732, 1735, and 1741. The authors cited for the optics questions cover a remarkable range, from Roger Bacon to Isaac Newton, and indicate not only what Johnston had read, but what a university student would be expected to have access to and be able to comprehend.
BP_Description_2: Questions for consideration and preparation by university students. For each topic, several specific questions are posed, accompanied by a brief general consideration, followed by a detailed set of reading references for the student that support an affirmative, ambiguous, or negative answer. The book covers: Physics, natural history, chemistry, meteorology, mechanics, hydrostatics, optics, astronomy, logic, metaphysics, and ethics. The questions in the optics section (26 pages) include questions regarding: the nature of vision, perception, eye-function; the nature of light and color, how light propagates; the cause of reflection and refraction; color of objects; color and differing refraction; sine law of refraction; reason for sine law of refraction; behavior of convex and concave lenses; how microscopes and telescopes work; how spectacles work; nature of reflection; law of reflection; reflecting telescopes; how the rainbow is generated; reflected and refracted images; camera obscura and magic lantern operation; and the moon illusion. Cited references range from medieval to contemporary and cover virtually every major author on optics.
BP_Reference(s): A Source for Eighteenth-Century Harvard Master's Questions|Myers, M.|<i>The William and Mary Quarterly<i>, Vol 38, No 2,  1981, pp 261-267.
BP_Title: Qu√¶stiones philosophic√¶ in justi systematis ordinem disposit√¶; auctoribus adductis, et singulis in proprias hypotheses dispertitis. Editio tertia, prioribus Auctior, & ad Usus Philosophicos Accommodatior. Ad calcem subjicitur Appendix de legibus disputandi. Opera Tho. Johnson, A.M. Coll. Gad. Cantab. Soc.
BP_Title English Translation: Philosophical Questions Arranged in the Order of a Proper System. Authors Cited, and Grouped, Each by its Hypothesis. Third Edition, Larger than the Previous, and Adapted for the Use of Philosophers. Joined at the End is an Appendix of Debating Laws. A Work of Thomas Johnson, AM, Madelen College of Cambridge.
BP_Biographical Statement: English classics scholar and academic, Cambridge fellow, editor of important editions of classical tragedies, and author of moralist books.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'Thomas Preston' dated 1771 on pastedown

BP_Short or Common Title: A letter regarding the Essay upon distinct and indistinct vision
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The second of Jurin's responses to the mathematician Benjamin Robins faulting and findings of Jurin's calculation in the latter's <i>Essay on Distinct and Indistinct Vision<i> which had appeared in Smith's <i>Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: Jurin's 'Essay on Distinct and Indistinct Vision' had been appended to and published with Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> in 1738. In 1739 the mathematician Benjamin Robins published his Remarks on Mr. Euler's Treatise of Motion, Dr. Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i>, and Dr. Jurin's 'Essay Upon Distinct and Indistinct Vision'. In it he faulted the findings of Jurin's calculations and he and Jurin began an acrimonious exchange. This is a printing of the second of Jurin's responses.
BP_Description_2: Benjamin Robins fault hunting and James Jurin's defense have all the hallmarks of academic squabbling over minutiae. In addition to point-by-point refutation, Jurin mocks and satirizes Robins with an imaginary question and answer exchange. Jurin and Robins had previously crossed swords about Newton fluxions after both had answered Berkeley's attack on Newton in his <i>The Analyst; or a Discourse Addressed to an Infidel Mathematician<i> of 1734. Jurin was the more techy of the two, easily provoked and often angry in tone. Benjamin Robins later responded to Jurin with his <i>A Full Confutation of Dr. Jurin's Reply to the Remarks on His Essay Upon Distinct and Indistinct Vision<i>. This is Jurin's response.
BP_Reference(s): The Correspondence of James Jurin (1684-1750): Physician and Secretary to the Royal Society|Rusnock, A., editor|Rodopi, Amsterdam, 1995, 570 pp, NB pp 35-42.
BP_Title: A letter to ------ Esquire, in answer to Mr. Robins's Full confutation of the Reply to his remarks on the Essay upon distinct and indistinct vision. By James Jurin, M.D. Fellow of the College of Physicians, and of the Royal Society. Genus est hominum, qui se primos omnium rerum putant, Nec sunt.
BP_Title English Translation: "It is the Nature of Men to think they are the First in All Things. But they are Not."
BP_Biographical Statement: English  physician, natural philosopher.  President of the Royal College of Physicians, Secretary of the Royal Society, combative adovate of Newtonian physics, contributor to Smith's Opticks.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1741 Jurin - A letter regarding the Essay upon distinct and indistinct vision - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Manual for the construction of reflecting telescopes and lensed microscopes.
BP_Description_1: A pirated edition of the text of 1738. The text has been reset and the format reduced to octavo. Curiously, exactly the same plate has been used to print the folded page of figures. This edition would be reissued in 1756.
BP_Description_2: Manual for the construction of reflecting telescopes and lensed microscopes. Includes: Molds and forms for metal mirrors; material for mirrors, how they are shaped, figured, and polished; construction of the other components of a reflecting telescope; using reflecting telescopes; examples of telescope construction; arrangement and orientation of telescopes with large mirrors; making objective and ocular lenses, simple and compound; making and using microscopes. The presentation is detailed and clearly the result of the extensive direct practice and experience of the author. Passemant built several instruments to the design depicted in the folding plate in the book.
BP_Reference(s): Reflecting ‚ÄòPopular Culture‚Äô: The Introduction, Diffusion, and Construction of the Reflecting Telescope in the Netherlands|Zuidervaart, H.J.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 61, 2004, pp 407-452.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third edition of a handbook of physics, significantly expanded. The last touched by 's Gravesande.
BP_Description_1: Third edition of the <i>Physices elementa mathematica<i> which first appeared in 1720. Includes the Preface from the first two editions. An additional, new Preface cites many of the works presenting Newtonian physics that had appeared since the first edition: Giovanni Poleni, John Theophilus Desaguliers, Johann Bernoulli, Christian Wolff, and Petrus van Musschenbroek, and numerous articles that had appeared in journals. It also describes the many additions made to the text for the third edition; the title states 'doubled in size'. Indeed, this edition can be considered a new book, so numerous are the additions and extensive the details. The Preface was left unfinished at the death of 's Gravesande in the year of publication, 1742.
BP_Description_2: A handbook of physics covering: statics; dynamics; gravity; fluids; fire, heat, light, and electro-luminescence; optics; system of the world; and celestial motion. The optics section is considerably expanded in this edition (229 pages) and includes: The nature, propagation, and speed of light; sunlight and heliostats; refraction, a goniometer for its measurement; refractions at surfaces, lenses; ocular anatomy and vision; spectacles, microscopes and telescopes; reflection, spherical convex and concave mirrors; catoptric telescopes; magic lantern; colors and differing refraction; colors by reflection and refraction; the rainbow; colors in nature. The main points are demonstrated by experiments, their presentation detailed and geometry-based. Numerous detailed figures (significantly more than earlier editions), descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Ruestow, E.G.|Springer, 1973, 174 p NB: pp 113-139.||The impeccable credentials of an untrained philosopher: Willem Jacob 's¬†Gravesande's career before his Leiden professorship, 1688‚Äì1717|Jip van Besouw|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 70, No 3, pp 231‚Äì249.

BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Mathematical Physics, Confirmed by Experiment. Or, An Introduction to Newtonian Philosophy. Author:  Willem Jacob ¬¥sGravesande. Volume 1, 2. Third Edition doubled in size.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the University of Leiden, developer of extensive demonstrations for teaching Newtonian physics, author of important textbooks.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A text book of natural philosophy, being Wolff's teaching compendium in Latin, extracted and translated from the <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde Aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften<i> of 1710
BP_Description_1: First edition of Wolff's teaching compendium in Latin, extracted and translated from the <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde Aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften<i> of 1710. The first volume covers the basic sciences, the second volume covers their application in various fields. Widely used, particularly in Germany, editions appeared in Lausanne and Geneva in 1742, in Verona 1744, in Lausanne and Geneva 1758, in Lausanne 1774, in Geneva 1778, and Venice 1782.
BP_Description_2: A text book of natural philosophy covering: arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, hydrostatics, optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, perspective, astronomy, geography, gnomics, pyrotechnics, architecture, and algebra. The sections on optics (90 pages) include: nature and propagation of light; light rays, reflection and refraction; camera obscura images; ocular anatomy, eye-function; catoptrics, plane and spherical mirrors; mirror foci and images, burning mirrors; law of refraction; convex and concave lenses; lens images; microscopes and telescopes; magic lantern; lens making. The treatment is elementary and geometric. The presentation is formal and very concise, with axioms, theorems and their demonstration, and comments in scholia introducing most material. Examples by way of problems are presented and solved.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 29-93.||Christian Wolff (1679-1754) and his contribution for the Mathematics Education|Nobre, S|In: <i>Proceedings of the XXth International Congress of History of Science<i>|Brepols, 2002, pp 89-94.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An analysis and general refutation of Newtonianism
BP_Description_1: Ten years before the appearance of <i>Le Vrais System de Physique<i>, Castel announced in the Journal de Trevoux his plans to publish a work on Newtonian physics. Having read the <i>Principia<i> and the <i>Optice<i>, Castel admired Newton's mathematical ability but rejects his experimental method and resulting physics in favor of Descartes‚Äôs. The essential problem was Newton's attractive force, operating at a distance: it was without mechanism. Thus, Castel rejected Newton's conception of gravity and all those aspects of the optics which seemed to depend on this; that is, reflection, refraction, and prismatic color. Though the title implies a comparison between the ideas of Newton and Descartes, after the first of the nine analyses, Castel provides only refutations of Newton. The reception of the book was tepid, most reviewers feeling that Castel's Newtonian refutations were unconvincing and the system he offered in its place was too dependent on extending and rationalizing simple direct observations, and insufficiently grounded in experiment.
BP_Description_2: An analysis and general refutation of Newtonianism in nine analyses. These involve: comparison of Descartes's and Newton's mechanics; preparatory explanation and discussion of geometry, mechanics, and physics; Descartes's theory of vortices; refutation of Newton's analysis of vortices; criticism of Newton's experimental method of natural philosophy; Castel's method of observation, comparison, and analogy; and the superiority of a rationalistic method of investigation over the experimental. The optics section (100 pages) includes: nature of light according to Descartes and Newton; propagation of light; emission and mediumistic theories; the strength of Descartes's rational system and the weakness of Newton's experimental and inferential system; color according to Newton; problems both conceptual and experimental with the use of prisms; Grimaldi's diffraction opposing the emission theory; Castel's theory of color. Castel's objections to Newton's theory of color rest the mistrust of instruments (such as the prism) in experiments, and the use of abstraction and mathematics to build a theoretical system from the results.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>Louis-Bertrand Castel, Anti-Newtonian Scientist<i>|Schier, D.S.|Torch Press, 1941.
BP_Title: Le vrai systeÃÄme de physique geÃÅneÃÅrale de M. Isaac Newton, ExposeÃÅ et analyseÃÅ en parallele avec celui de Descartes, aÃÄ la porteÃÅe du commun des physiciens. Par le R.P. Lous Castel, de la Compagnie de Jesus, & de la Societe Royale de Londres.
BP_Title English Translation: The True System of General Physics of Mr. Isaac Newton, Exposed and Analyzed in Parallel with that of Descartes; Within the Reach of Ordinary Physicists. By the Reverend Father Louis Castel, of the Society of Jesus and the Royal Society of London.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, journalist, dilettante natural philosopher. Disagreed famously with Newton about the spectral nature of white light.

BP_Short or Common Title: Histoire de L'Academie Royal des Sciences
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A comparison of de Mairan's neo-Cartesian explanation of refraction and a Newtonian one based on light particles and attractive force.
BP_Description_1: In 1739 Alexis Claude Clairaut read a paper to the Royal Academy of Sciences comparing Cartesian and Newtonian explanations of refraction. The paper appeared in 1743 when the annual memoires of the academy were printed. This was the first of several investigations by French Newtonians (d'Alembert, Courtivron, and Maupertuis) that invoked Newton's light corpuscles and the force of attraction to explain refraction and show alignment with the sine law refraction. It is likely that this paper was to refute one presented a year earlier by Jean-Jacques Dortous de Mairan that presented a so-called neo-Cartesian explanation of refraction. Clairaut‚Äôs paper marked the beginning of the end of French adherence to Cartesian optics.
BP_Description_2: An examination and comparison of de Mairan's neo-Cartesian explanation of refraction, and a Newtonian one based on light particles and attractive force. The fundamentally mechanical nature of the neo-Cartesian explanation, based on a medium's resistance to light propagation, is rejected. James Bradley's discovery of stellar aberration is presented a proof of light's corpuscular nature. Particles and attractive force is then used not only to explain reflection and refraction, but also to present a simplified derivation of the sine law of refraction. Clairaut uses Leibniz's reformulation of Newton's mechanics and his calculus.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of Optics from Greek Antiquity to the Nineteenth Century<i>|Darrigol, O.|Oxford, 2012, pp 124-125.
BP_Title: Clairaut "Sur les Explications Cartesienne et Newtonienne de la Refraction de la lumiere"  In: Suite Des Memoires De Mathematique et de Physique; Tires des Registres de L'Academie Royale des Sciences. 1739. p 350-373.
BP_Title English Translation: On Cartesian and Newtonian Explanations of the Refraction of Light
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, astronomer, natural philosopher. Worked importantly in geophysics, optics, mathematics.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of 'P A Hansen' on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary treatise summarizing optics and vision and the first book containing material on ophthalmology printed in Spain.
BP_Description_1: Francisco Mart√≠n's <i>Ensayo Optico<i> is the first book containing material on ophthalmology printed in Spain.
BP_Description_2: An elementary treatise summarizing optics and vision in four chapters. The first three chapters present the physics of light: the nature propagation of light; reflection; refraction, lenses, lens images, and camera obscura.  The fourth chapter describes the physiological optics of vision, invoking the material covered in the first three chapters. The work cites Newton, Malebranche, Descartes, Tosca, and Castel. The presentation is elementary but detailed and geometric.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary textbook on physics in the form of dialogues, with volume three devoted entirely to optics.
BP_Description_1: Sixth edition of an elementary textbook on physics in the form of dialogues between Ariste and Eudoxe. Regnault, an adherent of Descartes, held that the core of 'modern physics' (that is, Cartesianism) arose from the Greeks. Though familiar with Newton's work, Regnault mentions it only to refute it. The material describing and dismissing Newtonian ideas is unchanged from the editions of 1729. The text reflects the idea that physics was the study of nature and that investigators discovered new marvels and mysteries and did not construct systems of explanation. This is in alignment with the refusal to invoke any mathematics, it being held that even geometry gets in the way of understanding. The entire impression is a work left behind by the advance of Newtonianism in France, one that is both marker and evidence of fading Cartesianism. Editions appeared at Paris in 1729, 1729, 1732, 1733, 1737, 1743, 1745, and 1755, at Amsterdam in 1732, an English translation appeared in 1731, an Italian translation at Venice in 1736, 1740, and 1749, and an Italian abridgement at Venice in 1751.
BP_Description_2: Volume three of this edition is devoted entirely to optics (304 pages). The dialogues are usually accompanied by propositions and their proofs. The material includes: propagation of light; refraction in general and at plane and curved surfaces; convex lenses; vision and eye-function; telescopes and microscopes; magnified images; illusions; binocular vision; plane and curved mirrors; anamorphosis and perspective. The treatment is elementary, detailed, and geometric. It is entirely Cartesian.
BP_Reference(s): Le Cartesianisme Chez les Jesuites Francais: au XVIIth et au XVIIIth Siecle|Sortais, G.|<i>Archives de Philosophie<i>, Vol 6, No 3, 1929, pp 1-10.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Early ideas about how the universal aether operated the nerves and muscles of the body and how it accounts for gravity and optical phenomena.
BP_Description_1: Bryan Robinson had developed early ideas about how the universal aether operated the nerves and muscles of the body, and taught such at Trinity College, Dublin. These ideas were developed and expanded into this book, which marks the beginning of a wide interest in the aether in the mid 18th century. Robinson would publish another book in 1745 on this same subject.
BP_Description_2: In Book three of the <i>Opticks<i>, Newton suggested the existence of an active, springy, non-material aether that is the cause of optical refraction. Robinson proports to prove that the presumed infinite, universal aether accounts for the attractive, repulsive, cohesive forces observed in nature (reflection, refraction, gravity, etc.). The treatment is haphazard, if not sophistical, with carefully extracted quotations and plausible mathematics used to in an attempt to prove the points.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Mechanism and Materialism: British Natural Philosophy in An Age of Reason<i>|Schofield, R.E.|Princeton University Press, 1970, pp 89-115.||<i>Conceptions of Ether. Studies in the History of Ether Theories 1740-1900<i>|Cantor. G.N., Hodge, M.J.S., editors|Cambridge University Press, 1981, pp 1-60.||Eighteenth-Century Conceptions of Gravitation|van Lunteren F.|In: International Archives of the History of Ideas, Petry M.J., editor, vol 136. Springer, 1993, pp 343-366.
BP_Title: A dissertation on the aether of Sir Isaac Newton by Bryan Robinson, M.D.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish physician, academic. Wrote innovatively on physiology and natural philosophy.
BP_Provenance: Gift dedication on free endpaper of Bryan Robinson dated 1743. 'Thomas Bell MD' inscribed on titlepage

BP_Short or Common Title: Mathematical Dissertaions on a Variety of Physical and Analytical Subjects
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of essays touching geographical, geological, gravitational, and atmospheric subjects
BP_Description_1: A collection of relatively short works on geophysical , mathematical, and atmospheric subjects. Simpson's preface makes clear his intention to gather his then most recent and original works and publish a miscellany for the benefit of the public. The audience would have been limited, as most of the material is highly mathematical. Though Simpson is interested in physical phenomena, his point of view is entirely mathematical.
BP_Description_2: The work contains 16 papers. These include:  On the Figure of the Earth,  A General Investigation of the Attraction at the Surfaces of Bodies nearly Spherical, Tides, Length of the Meridian, Determination of the Refraction which a Ray of Light Suffers in its Passage to the Earth, and Summation of Series and Approximations. The material on the figure of the earth had been presented to the Royal Society and appeared in its Transactions. The longest entry is the last and most elaborate: on series and approximations. The material on atmospheric refraction is based entirely on an analysis of presumed attractive force the Earth exerts on light passing near to its surface. Light is presumed to be particulate and the analysis is a mix of gravitational and optical analysis. Calculus ('fluxions') is used extensively.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇThomas Simpson: Weaving fluxions in 18th-centry London|Blanco, M.|In: <i>Historia Mathematica<i>, Vol 41, 2014, pp 38-81||<i>Thomas Simpson and His Times<i>|Clark,  FM|Columbia University Press, 1929, 215 pp.
BP_Title: Mathematical Dissertaions on a Variety of Physical and Analytical Subjects. The Whole in a General and Perspicuous Manner
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, teacher at Woolwich Military Academy, and author of the eponymous Simpson's Rule to approximate definite integrals.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A later edition of the greatest teaching compendium on Mixed Mathematics and natural philosophy of 18th century.
BP_Description_1: A later edition of the greatest compendia of mathematics and natural philosophy of 18th century. Editions appeared in 1713 at Magdeburg, 1717 at Magdeburg, 1730 at Magdeburg, 1732 at Geneva, 1732 at Paris, 1735 at Geneva, 1741 at Verona, 1742 at Magdeburg, 1743 at Geneva, 1743 at Paris, 1746 at Verona. Each new edition required several years to complete, spanning as long as nine years.
BP_Description_2: A teaching compendium on Mixed Mathematics in Latin. Based on and greatly expanding the <i>Ansfangs-Gr√ºnde<i> of 1710. The optics section of Volume 3 (290 pages) includes: optics, the nature of light, shadow, and color; visual perception including size, shape, location, motion, and binocular vision; catoptrics including making and figuring glass and metal mirrors; burning mirrors and images from mirrors; mirrors for anamorphosis; dioptrics including refraction, lenses and their focal and imagining properties; lens figuring and polishing, making and use of microscopes and telescopes; magic lanterns. The treatment is thorough and mathematical. 292 figures on 32 engraved plates accompany the optics text.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 29-93.||Christian Wolff tussen Cartesianen en Newtonianen|Hakfoort, C.|<i>Tijdschrift voor de Geschiedenis der Geneeskunde, Natuurwetenschappen, Wiskunde en Techniek 5<i>, 1982, pp 27‚Äì38.||<i>Christian Wolff als Mathematiker und Universit√§tslehrer des 18. Jahrhunderts<i>|Sommerhoff-Benner, S|Shaker, 2002.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first two book-length essays Beccari wrote describing his work with luminescent materials.
BP_Description_1: Beccari's early work in chemistry lead him to work with luminescent materials. Working with others he discovered a large number of common substances that were luminescent. The results of experiments to determine their properties appeared in a series of papers appearing in the Commentarii de Bononensi, the journal of the Bologna Institute of the Sciences and Arts between 1731 and 1747. These formed the basis for two book-length essays appearing in 1744 and 1747. This is the first. They were translated into English in 1776.
BP_Description_2: The work begins with a conspectus of all types of luminescence, including bioluminescence and luminescence caused by putrefaction. The a description of the many types of luminescent materials that emit light by excitation. Excitation by attrition, heat, admission of air ('barometric light'), and exposure to external light. This is essentially the modern classification of luminescence by excitation. Most of the work deals with the last type of excitation: what is now called photoluminescence. Experiments and equipment are described to determine the color, intensity, and duration of luminescence based the length and intensity of the excitation. It would not be until Edmond Becquerel that such careful measurements would be taken up again.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of Luminescence<i>|Harvey, E.N.|American Philosophical Society, Philadelphia, 1957, 692 pp, NB:  pp 155-158.
BP_Title: De quamplurimis Phosphoris nunc primum detectis Commentarius
BP_Title English Translation: Commentary on the Many Phosphors, Revealed Now for the First Time.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian chemist, lecturer. Worked importantly in phosphorescence and chemical effects of light.
BP_Provenance: Gilberto Govi' inscribed on the titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A treatise on the senses, with emphasis on vision.
BP_Description_1: A widely read treatise on the senses. Le Cat drew from Malebranche and adopted neo-Cartesian natural philosophy. Though covering all the senses, the chapter on vision is by far the longest. Reviewed in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Editions appeared at Rouen in 1739, at Paris in 1740 and 1742, the present work, a pirated edition at Amsterdam in 1744, and an English translation at London in 1750. The material was greatly augmented to produce a new, two-volume book in 1767.
BP_Description_2: A treatise on the senses, with emphasis on light, sight, and vision. The vision material (221 pages) includes: ocular anatomy; the nature of light; reflection and refraction; lenses; propagation of light; mechanisms for propagation, reflection, refraction; color, prismatic colors, Newton's prismatic experiments, review of the Newtonian system; shadows; eye-function, optics of the eye, eye and brain and optic nerve ; visual phenomena, depth perception, size and distance, views produced by lenses, binocular vision, distinct and indistinct vision, vision and spectacles; camera obscura; illusions. The material on light is neo-Cartesian, draws heavily on Malebranche, and is descriptive rather than mathematical. The material on ocular anatomy, physiological optics, and perception is particularly detailed and lengthy.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A Cultural History of the Senses in the Age of Enlightenment<i>|Vila, A.C., editor|Bloomsbury Publishing, London, 2014||Claude-Nicolas Le Cat (1700‚Äì1768): On the hearing abilities and on the education of deaf-mutes during the Enlightenment|H√©ral, O.|<i>Journal de R√©adaptation M√©dicale: Pratique et Formation en M√©decine Physique et de R√©adaptation<i>, Vol 30, No 2, 2010, pp 130-133.||On the late invention of the stereoscope|Wade, N.J.|<i>Perception<i>, Vol 16, 1987, pp 785-818.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean de Castillon¬†(nom de plume of¬†Giovanni Francesco Salvemini¬†) (1708-1791) Italian mathematician and astronomer.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Part of first collected works of Isaac Newton. The second volume contains the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> of 1729 and Latin translation of the papers related to Newton's experimentum crucis.
BP_Description_1: The three volumes of <i>Opuscula Mathematica<i> are part of a hybrid set of, in all, 8 volumes of the first collected works of Isaac Newton. Published between 1739-1761, it consists of 'Geneva Principia' , 3 volumes (1739-42); Optice (1740); Opuscula Mathematica, Philosophica et Philologica (usually found separately), 3 volumes (1744); and <i>Arithmatica Universalis<i> (1761). The <i>Opuscula<i> is the most important publication produced by its editor and translator Jean de Castillon during his stay in the Pays de Vaud. Notable for its completeness, de Castillon produced a thorough edition of the small works of Newton, having been helped by the mathematician Gabriel Cramer and the fact that de Castillon read English.
BP_Description_2: The second volume of the <i>Opuscula Mathematica<i> contains: the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> of 1729; Latin translations of papers Newton published in the Philosophical Transactions on the reflecting telescope and on the experimentum crucis; and the Tabula Refractionum that had appeared in an appendix to a paper by Halley on atmospheric refraction. The Latin translation of the papers related to Newton's experimentum crucis (papers and letters by Newton, as well as excerpts of papers of Christiaan Huygens, Robert Hooke, Ignace-Gaston Pardies, and Francis Linus), made this important debate  (the exchanges following his first letter on his new theory of light) available to the reader who read Latin but not English.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The publication of Newton‚Äôs Opera Omnia in Geneva and Lausanne (1739‚Äì1761): A chapter in the reception of Newtonianism|Guicciardini, N.|<i>History of Science<i>,Vol 55 No 4, 2017, pp 457‚Äì489.||The Reception of Newtonian Optics in Italy|Casini, P.|In: <i>Renaissance and Revolution: Humanists, Scholars, Craftsmen and Natural Philosophers<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1993, pp 215-228.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Concise, graphical encyclopedia of Mixed Mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Mayer produced this concise encyclopedia of mathematics and some of its applications while a young man working in Augsburg. The result of extensive study on his part, the atlas has an unusual format: an illustrated survey of arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry and analysis, applied to the practical sciences, in 68 engraved plates. Each contains a central graphic, accompanied by engraved lettered explanation on each side. The content shows the influence of the work of Christian von Wolff and his <i>Anfangs-GruÃànde aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften<i> in the choice of the applied subjects.¬†It is known that Mayer studied with the instrument maker and optician Georg Brander while in Augsburg and Brander likely deepened Mayer's optical knowledge. The atlas presents no new information but signals how wide Mayer's reading and study was, and indicates the range and level of information available in mathematics and natural philosophy to the autodidact of the time. This copy contains an additional 8 Tables in a supplement at the end.
BP_Description_2: Concise, graphical encyclopedia of Mixed Mathematics, including:  arithmetic, geometry, logarithms, plane and spherical trigonometry, mensuration, surveying instruments and methods, cartography, astronomy and cosmography, horography, military and civil architecture, optics and perspective, mechanics, presented in 60 plates. In addition, 8 plates present a mathematical supplement of problems and examples, including the calculus. The three optics tables cover: structure of the eye, eye-function, catoptrics of plane and curved mirrors, dioptrics of convex and concave lenses, the telescope. Table three of the supplement deals with conic sections and is related back to optics. The treatment is elementary and graphical-descriptive, clear and detailed.
BP_Reference(s): Tobias Mayer (1723-62): A Case of Forgotten Genius|Forbes, E.G.|<i>British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 5, No 1, 1970, pp 1-20.||<i>Tobias Mayer, (1723-62), pioneer of enlightened science in Germany<i>|Forbes, E.G.|Vandenhoeck und Ruprecht, Gottingen, 1980, pp 248.

BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, selonographer. Worked and taught at the University of Gottingen.

BP_Short or Common Title: Les Entretiens physiques d'Ariste et d'Eudoxe
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary textbook on physics in the form of dialogues, with volume three devoted entirely to optics.
BP_Description_1: Seventh, revised edition of an elementary textbook on physics in the form of dialogues between Ariste and Eudoxe. Regnault, an adherent of Descartes, held that the core of 'modern physics' (that is, Cartesianism) arose from the Greeks. Though familiar with Newton's work, Regnault mentions it only to refute it. This edition was prompted by the appearance of Voltaire's <i>Elemens<i> and Regnault specifically mentions it for what he considers its absurdity. The material describing and dismissing Newtonian ideas is unchanged from the editions of 1729. The text reflects the idea that physics was the study of nature and that investigators discovered new marvels and mysteries and did not construct systems of explanation. This is in alignment with the refusal to invoke any mathematics, it being held that even geometry gets in the way of understanding. The entire impression is a work left behind by the advance of Newtonianism in France, one that is both marker and evidence of fading Cartesianism. Editions appeared at Paris in 1729, 1729, 1732, 1733, 1737, 1743, 1745, and 1755, at Amsterdam in 1732, an English translation appeared in 1731, an Italian translation at Venice in 1736, 1740, and 1749, and an Italian abridgement at Venice in 1751.
BP_Description_2: Much of volume three is devoted to optics (179 pages). The dialogues are usually accompanied by propositions and their proofs. The material includes: the nature and propagation of light; transparent materials; phosphors; vision; example optical problems and their solution; mirrors, lenses, and burning glasses; Color, Descartes's and Newton's theory; other color theories (Malebranche); changing colors. The presentation is elementary and descriptive, no mathematics is used.
BP_Reference(s): Le Cartesianisme Chez les Jesuites Francais: au XVIIth et au XVIIIth Siecle|Sortais, G.|<i>Archives de Philosophie<i>, Vol 6, No 3, 1929, pp 1-10.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Elias de Joncourt (1697-1765) Dutch translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A handbook of physics, being a French translation from the 1742 edition of the <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i>  by 's Gravesande.
BP_Description_1: Elie de Joncourt produced this French translation from the 1742 edition of the <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i>. It marks the considerable advance of Newtonianism over Cartesianism in France and the market for Newtonian texts. The latest editions of Voltaire's <i>Elemens de la philosophie de Neuton<i> had appeared in 1742, but it was an introduction; neither written for nor appropriate as a textbook. The preface to the first edition of the <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> dated 1719 and the unfinished preface to the 1742 edition are included in the translation. The engravings of the 1742 Latin edition were used to print the plates for this translated edition. Editions of the French translation appeared at Leiden in 1745 and 1746, and at Paris in 1747. Elie de Joncourt also produced a French translation of Pemberton's <i>A View of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy<i> in 1755.
BP_Description_2: A handbook of physics covering: statics; dynamics; gravity; fluids; fire, heat, light, and electro-luminescence; optics; system of the world; and celestial motion. The optics section follows the considerably expanded edition of 1742 (229 pages) and includes: The nature, propagation, and speed of light; sunlight and heliostats; refraction, a goniometer for its measurement; refractions at surfaces, lenses; ocular anatomy and vision; spectacles, microscopes and telescopes; reflection, spherical convex and concave mirrors; catoptric telescopes; magic lantern; colors and differing refraction; colors by reflection and refraction; the rainbow; colors in nature. The main points are demonstrated by experiments, their presentation detailed and geometry-based. Numerous detailed figures (significantly more than earlier editions), descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Ruestow, E.G.|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.||The impeccable credentials of an untrained philosopher: Willem Jacob 's¬†Gravesande's career before his Leiden professorship, 1688‚Äì1717|Jip van Besouw|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 70, No 3, pp 231‚Äì249.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Explanatory text to accompany a course of lectures in physics.
BP_Description_1: Nollet was the leading experimental physicist for thirty years in mid-eighteenth-century France. His course of lectures, aimed at upper-class Parisian society, was accompanied by elaborate, if not spectacular, demonstrations of physical principles and the use of experimental apparatus. This was the source for the <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i>, which became as famous as the course itself and was the first step in establishing experimental physics in France. Nollet's work expressed in the <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i> led to a reorientation of physics teaching in French universities and was the model for a new generation of French physics textbooks, replacing those of Poliniere and Rohault. Though Nollet's physics was experimental, it was not, inherently, mathematical. He considered algebra and geometry helpful, but not essential.  The <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i> also had considerable influence outside France: in Italy, Spain, and Germany. Editions appeared at Paris 1743, 1745, 1749, 1754, 1759, 1764, 1767, 1771, 1775, 1783; at Amsterdam 1745, 1754,  and 1765;  in an Italian translation at Venice in 1746, 1751, and 1759; in a German translation at Erfurt in 1749; and in a Spanish translation at Madrid in 1757.
BP_Description_2: Explanatory text to accompany a course of lectures in physics. The material covered includes: material bodies and their properties; simple and compound motion under central forces; gravity; hydrostatics; mechanics; nature and properties of air; nature and properties of water; nature and properties of fire; light and optics; stars and their movement; magnetism; electricity. All of tome five is devoted to optics (579 pages).  It includes: the nature, properties, and propagation of light; catoptrics, plane and spherical mirrors and their images; dioptrics, refraction, lenses and their images; color and differing refraction; vision, the eye, eye-function; spectacles, microscopes, telescopes, and the magic lantern. Nollet used large sections of Newton's Optice dealing with prismatic colors, the heterogeneity of white light, and differing refrangibility. Nollet did not accept the corpuscular theory of light proposed in Newton's Queries, presenting instead a modified form of Descartes' ideas. Forty-one experiments are described in the text, demonstrating each principal idea. The presentation is detailed, geometric, and accompanied by detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Notion of Experimental Physics in Early Eighteenth-Century France|Home, R.W.|In: <i>Change and Progress in Modern Science<i>|Reidel Publishing, 1985, pp 107-131.

BP_Title English Translation: Lessons in Experimental Physics by the Abbe Nollet,  of the Royal Academy of Sciences, and the Royal Society of London, Volume 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
BP_Biographical Statement: French cleric, natural philosopher, teacher. Famed and gifted electrical experimentalist, lecturer, textbook author.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A theory of light based on propagating pulses in an aethereal medium. Considered the only complete wave theory of light until Fresnel's in the 19th century.
BP_Description_1: Leonhard Euler's theory of light and color was the first complete wave theory of light that accounted for propagation, reflection, refraction, dispersion, and color. Based on the analogy between light and sound, light was presented as a series of pulses in an aethereal medium, with different spaces between pulses (different frequencies) associated with different colors. Unlike the earlier theories of Descartes, Huygens, Malebranche, Bernoulli, and Mairan, that of Euler is complete and attempts to explain most, if not all, optical phenomena. As such, it was the first full alternative to the various emission theories of light and color, and initiated the 18th century debate on the nature of light. Lambert, for example, in his <i>Photometria<i> of 1760, compares Newton's theory and Euler's theory. Euler's <i>Nova Theoria<i> introduced the idea of frequency as fundamental aspect of light and which would be a permanent contribution to the ongoing development of the mediumistic theory of light.
BP_Description_2: A theory of light presented in five chapters. Chapter 1: an extensive consideration, comparison, and evaluation of the emission and mediumistic theories of light's nature. Only mechanical theories (emitted particles or disturbances in a medium) are considered; action-at-a-distance is dismissed entirely. The analogy between sound and light is considered and three objections to the emission theory are considered: loss of mass, non-interference of intersecting light rays, and the problem of explaining transparency. The result is a rejection of emission theories. Chapter 2: the mathematics of the formation and propagation of pulses in an aetherial medium. Chapter 3: the succession of pulses and rays of light and the transition to a wave theory.  As with sound where high and low tones are caused by differing pulse frequencies, light of differing pulse frequencies gives rise to differing colors. Chapter 4: reflection and refraction of rays, dispersion, and the composition of white light. Chapter 5: luminous, reflecting, refracting, and opaque bodies.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Optics in the Age of Euler: Conceptions of the Nature of Light, 1700-1795<i>|Hakfoot, C.|Cambridge University Press, 1995, 243 pp.||Leonhard Euler's Wave Theory of Light|Pdeersen, K.M.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 392-416.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A guide for the general public on the acquisition and use of spectacles.
BP_Description_1: A guide for the general public on the use of spectacles and the correction of imperfect vision.
BP_Description_2: A guide to the acquisition and use of spectacles in four sections. Section 1: spectacles for long-sightedness, signs indicating the need for correction, convex lenses that suit the need. Section 2: short-sightedness and the appropriate concave lenses. Section 3: conduct for the conservation of sight. Section 4: why the elderly with vision so effected as to be lost almost entirely, can still recover it at an advanced age. The book ends with a listing of the equipment, apparatus, mirrors, and lenses available at the manufactory of the author.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Spectacles and Other Vision Aids: A History and Guide to Collecting<i>|Rosenthal, J.W.|Norman Publishing, San Francisco, 1996.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An expanded teaching manual covering General and Particular Physics.
BP_Description_1: Second, expanded edition of the work of 1735. The first edition was in two volumes, this edition is in four volumes. A textbook describing 'those things which are observed by the senses.' By the time Ferrari wrote this, his thinking had evolved away from Scholastic Aristotelianism and had aligned with the natural philosophy of Gassendi, parts of Descartes and Malebranche, and the optics (but not the gravity) of Newton. In many sections, particularly those on optics and the physics of light, a summary history is given ranging from the ideas of Epicurus and Aristotle, through Descartes and Malebranche, to Huygens and Newton. The textbook shows that though Ferrari had moved away from most of the physics of Descartes and presents that of Newton, he continued to assume a fundamental mechanistic basis of physics and was unwilling to grant that (merely) the predictive accuracy of Newton's equation was evidence of the reality that was hypothesized to underlie them. In this sense, Ferrari's text is an example of the bridging that was taking place between Cartesian and Newtonian ideas. Widely used throughout Europe, the textbook was, for example, recommended as the physics text for use at the University of Seville in 1768. Editions appeared at Brexia in 1735, 1745, and 1751, posthumously at Venice in 1756, 1761, and in the Opera Omnia of 1792.
BP_Description_2: A teaching manual covering General and Particular Physics. General Physics includes: nature of bodies; motion; light and color; sound; touch; smell; motion of fluids and solids under gravity. Particular Physics includes: the heavens and the earth; meteorics; living organisms; the senses; human anatomy. The optics section of volume 1 (98 pages, the physics of light) includes: the aether and the wave nature of light; propagation of light; opaque and transparent materials; reflection of light and mirrors; refraction of light and lenses; dispersion; color. The optics section of volume 4 (57 pages, vision) includes: vision; ocular anatomy; direct vision; principles of reflected vision and catoptrics; principles of refracted vision and dioptrics including spectacles, the microscope, and the telescope. Done in the Scholastic style, with definitions, propositions, proofs, discussions, and corollaries. The presentation is detailed, geometric, and supported with many figures. The optics material in the second edition is more concise than in the first; there are fewer digressions, considerably less space devoted to history, and fewer references to authorities. There is more emphasis on and space devoted to experiments and discussion of their results. The style and presentation remains the same.
BP_Reference(s): The Tranditional Currents of Thought|Garin, E.|In: History of Italian Philosophy, Brill Rodopi, 2008, 1373 pp, NB: pp 749-762.||Fortunato da Brescia|Baldini, U.|In: <i>Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani<i>, Vol 49, 1977.|http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/fortunato-da-brescia_(Dizionario-Biografico)/

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by John Theophilus Desaguliers (1683-1744) British natural philosopher, engineer, Anglican priest. Popular lecturer on Newtonian physics, demonstrator at the Royal Society, prolific author.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Last and largest edition of Desaguliers' English translation of 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i>.
BP_Description_1: Desaguliers was a friend of 's Gravesande and knew his work well. That it was thought likely that an English translation of 's Gravesande's book would sell well is clear from the fact that the booksellers Senes and Taylor asked Desaguliers to produce a translation. It was commercially successful, widely read and used. Editions of Desagulier's translation of 's Gravesande appeared in 1720, 1726, 1731, 1737, 1741, and posthumously in 1747. The editions of the translation of 1731, 1737, and 1741 exhibit little change, reflecting the same states of the original Latin. But this, the sixth and last edition of the translation, is by far the most extravagant, detailed, and extensive. It is based on the third edition of 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> of 1742, which was double the size of previous Latin editions. Consequently, the translation's format and content are considerably expanded. Now quarto rather than octavo, there is considerable added detail regarding experimental apparatus and discussion of the results obtained from their use. Consequently, this edition uses newly engraved plates with many new figures. There are 39 quarto-sized folding plates in this edition of the translation, compared to 15 octavo-sized plates in the fifth edition.
BP_Description_2: Sixth and last edition of the English translation of 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i>, based on the third Latin edition of 1742. Contains the translations of 's Gravesande's prefaces to the first, second, and third editions of the <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i>. The optics section reflects the greatly expanded treatment in the third Latin edition. It is extensive (229 pages) and includes: The nature, propagation, and speed of light; sunlight and heliostats; refraction, a goniometer for its measurement; refractions at surfaces, lenses; ocular anatomy and vision; spectacles, microscopes and telescopes; reflection, spherical convex and concave mirrors; catoptric telescopes; magic lantern; colors and differing refraction; colors by reflection and refraction; the rainbow; colors in nature. The main points are demonstrated by experiments, their presentation detailed and geometry-based. Numerous detailed figures (significantly more than earlier editions), descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable. The number of experiments is greatly expanded, as is the experimental apparatus. The discussion of experimental results is extensive, and the number of supporting figures greatly enlarged.
BP_Reference(s): John Theophilus Desaguliers: A Natural Philosopher, Engineer and Freemason in Newtonian England|Carpenter, A.T.|<i>Continuum<i>, 2011, pp 115-125.
BP_Title: Mathematical elements of natural philosophy, confirm'd by experiments: Or, an introduction to Sir Isaac Newton's philosophy. Written in Latin by the late W. James s'Gravesande, LL.D. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary textbook on Mixed and Applied Mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Written to satisfy the need he saw during his long teaching career, Darjes produced this elementary textbook on Mixed and Applied Mathematics. He had been using Wolff's <i>Elementa Matheseos Universae<i> since he began teaching natural philosophy in 1736, but saw the need for a textbook in the vernacular. The text was very favorably received, praised by reviewers, and widely used. Editions appeared in 1747, 1757, and 1764.
BP_Description_2: A textbook covering mathematics and all of natural philosophy, including: arithmetic and computation; geometry and trigonometry; basis for size and speed; aeronometry; music; hydraulics; optics; perspective; pyrotechnics; military architecture; astronomy; chronology; geography. The optical material (57 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; light rays; illumination, shadows, and proportion; refraction, the sine law; plane, convex, and concave lenses; telescopes; reflection; plane and spherical mirrors; mirror foci. The style is Scholastic, with statements, followed by proofs, examples, and notes. The presentation is elementary and descriptive, with only the most elementary geometry being used, but well organized and with particularly clear explanations.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Joachim Georg Darjes (1714‚Äì1791): Der Kameralist als Schul- und Gesellschaftsreformer<i>|L√∂tzsch, U.|B√∂hlau Verlag, Vienna, 2016, 376 pp, NB: pp 187-264.

Hochfurstl. Sachsen-Weimer-Jena und Fisenachischen Hof-Rathe, der Wletmeisheit und Bender Rechten Doktor, wie auch der Sitten-Lehre und Staats-Klugheit ordentlicher Professor zu Jena, der Phil. BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Samuel Klingenstierna (1698-1765) Swedish mathematician, natural philosopher, academic. Taught at the University of Uppsala, famously found errors in the assumptions Newton made about refraction.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Klingenstierna's Swedish annotated translation of the 1741 edition of Musschenbroek‚Äôs <i>Elementa Physicae<i>.
BP_Description_1: Samuel Klingenstierna's Swedish annotated translation of the 1741 edition of Musschenbroek‚Äôs <i>Elementa Physicae Conscripta in usus Academico<i>.
BP_Description_2: Though Klingenstierna translates most of the text as Musschenbroek wrote it, he interjects his own understanding when he thought it necessary. In the preface Klingenstierna wrote: 'I am certain that Herr Musschenbroek would not begrudge that in some of my comments on this lovely work I am of another opinion than he, in as much as I have regarded his Physica as the Principal Book of its kind, the Swedish Translation of which could in the highest degree benefit and edify not only the Youth of the Fatherland but also more mature persons, of all ranks and circumstances.' The optical material is as Musschenbroek wrote it, with the same figures. Indeed, either the same plates appear to have been used; that, or pressings from the Latin edition of 1741 have been used.
BP_Reference(s): Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Torbern Bergman: The Science, Lives and Friendship of Two Pioneers in Chemistry|Lennartson, A.|Springer, 2020, 432 pp, NB: pp 61-62.
BP_Title: Inledning til Naturkunnigheten, Den akademiska ungdomen til tienst, Sammanskrefwen af  hr. Peter van Musschenbroek, M.D. Phys.och Math. Profess. i Leyden. BP_Title English Translation: Introduction to Natural Philosophy, for use by Young Academics, Written by Peter van Musschenbroek, M.D.,  Professor of Mathematics and Physics at Leyden. Now Translated into Swedish with the Author's Own Multiple Additions. With Accompanying Remarks by S. Klingenstierna, Professor of Mathematics in the Royal Academy of Upsala.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the Universities of Utrecht and then Leiden, developed the Layden jar, worked importantly in mechanics and electrostatics.
BP_Provenance: Signature of Jacob Hongelin on the title page. This likely the 18th century Swedish Merchant and industrialist.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Plate IX is a world map by Edmund Halley,  showing the compass variations. Its complete title reads: "Tabula Totius Orbis Terrarum Exhibens Declinationes Magneticas, ad Annum 1700 composita ab Edmundo Halleyo simul cum Inclinationibus a Poundio observatis et Ventis Universalibus". The dimensions are 235x485 mm. California is shown as an island, Australia is only partially mapped, New Zealand not at all.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection that contains the <i>Optice<i> of 1740, the Geneva edition, and the optics material from the second volume of the <i>Opuscula Mathematica, Philosophica et Philologica<i> of 1744.
BP_Description_1: Graz edition of the <i>Opera Omnia Optica<i> published in Padua in 1749. The printing of the <i>Optice<i>, the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i>, and the letters excerpted from the Transaction of the Royal Philosophical Society of London is identical to that of the Padua edition of 1749, but a new title page and preliminary material has been inserted. No date appears on the title page and though this edition is sometimes dated 1747, it must actually be after 1749.
BP_Description_2: A reprinting of the <i>Optice<i> of 1740, the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> of 1729, and Jean de Castillon's editing and translation of the exchange of letters that appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Philosophical Society of London prompted by Newton letter 'New Theory About Light and Colors.'
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of Newtonian Optics in Italy|Casini, P.|In: <i>Renaissance and Revolution: Humanists, Scholars, Craftsmen and Natural Philosophers<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1993, pp 215-228.

BP_Biographical Statement: English natural philosopher, mathematician, alchemist, Mint Master. Genius of preternatural ability, the greatest physicist of the 17th century.

BP_Short or Common Title: De iride et aurora boreali carmina
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Two didactic poems on the rainbow and the aurora borealis. Each are accompanied by extended notes and commentary by Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá.
BP_Description_1: Carlo Noceti and Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá both belonged to the Assembly of the Arcadians, an academy founded in Rome in 1690 and patterned after meetings held by Queen Christian of Sweden of scientists, poets, and litterati. The academy had as its purpose 'to cultivate more the study of sciences and to awaken throughout Italy the good taste in humanistic letters, particularly in vulgar Poetry.' Noceti's poems are an example of works both scientifically didactic and poetic. Noceti's <i>De Iride<i> was first written in 1729 and took its inspiration from Newton's <i>Optice<i> of 1706. The sources for Noceti's <i>Aurora Boreali<i> are the <i>Trait√© Physique et Historique de l‚ÄôAurore Boreale<i> by de Mairan  of 1731 and 1733, and the <i>De Aurora Boreali Dissertatio<i> by Bo≈°koviƒá of 1738. A new edition of <i>De Iride<i> was prepared for this appearance in 1747. The extensive and thorough commentary and annotations by Bo≈°koviƒá were prepared early in 1747 expressly for this publication. The poems and their reception (praised by de Mairan and Abb√© Nollet) evidence a time when interest and talent in both natural philosophy and literature was common, even expected.||The Latin text was translated into Toscano by Antonio Abrogi, the Tuscan and Latin text appearing side-by-side in the publication of 1755.
BP_Description_2: Noceti's <i>De Iride<i> presents and rejects the hypotheses of Pliny, Seneca and other ancient authors on the origin of rainbow. He give an explanation of the phenomenon using the laws of refraction and the Newtonian theory of multichromatic white light and its dispersion by prism--in this case by drops of rain. Bo≈°koviƒá's notes are part history, part exposition and he demonstrates a wide knowledge of authors and works dealing with the rainbow; from Seneca and Pliny to De Dominis, from Descartes to Newton and Halley, Bo≈°koviƒá presents most theories of the rainbow. He finally presents a theory based on Descartes and Newton to explain how the rainbow is formed. Particularly important is the clear understanding and presentation of the multiple refractions responsible for multiple rainbows. Bo≈°koviƒá's notes are accompanied by a plate of figures that are essential since the notes become mathematically detailed when presenting Descartes's and Newton's ideas. The notes on the aurora borealis follow de Mairan closely.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Boscovich: scientist and man of letters|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societa Astronomica Italiana Supplementi<i>, Vol 23, 2013, pp 34-54.||<i>The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics<i>|Boyer, C. B.|Princeton, 1987, 376 pp, NB: pp 269-270.
BP_Title: Caroli Noceti e Societate Iesu, De iride et aurora boreali carmina. Illustrissimo ac reverendissimo praesuli Bernardino Giraudio dicata. Cum notis Iosephi Rogerii Boscovich ex eadem societate.
BP_Title English Translation: Carlo Noceti of the Society of Jesus, His Song of the Rainbow and the Arora Borealis. Dedicated to the Most Illustrious and Most Reverend Bishop Bernardio Giraudio. With Notes of Joseph Roger Boscovich of the same Society.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jesuit, profeessor at the Collegio Romano, poet on subjects in natural philosophy.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of short, summative teaching essays on parts of mixed mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Johann Baptist Planck is not credited as the collector and editor of the material in the <i>Universae Matheseos Brevis Institutio<i> until his name appeared on the title page of the third edition of 1760. In his Preface, Planck cites the extensive history that Jesuits had in presenting condensations, summaries, and compendia of what came to be called Mixed Mathematics, written specifically for teaching. He cites the earlier works of Pierre Gaultruche (the <i>Philosophi√¶ ac mathematic√¶ Totius Institutio<i> appeared between 1656 and 1695) and Claude Francois Milliet Dechales, (the <i>Cursus seu Mundus Mathematicus<i> appeared in 1674 and 1690). He also notes that Gaultruche's work had been translated and used in Austria, France, and England.  Planck states that many developments have occurred and other Jesuit works appeared, and he has collected, summarized and cast them into a teaching text in the present compendium. Strangely, perhaps, he defends the very small images in the figures of plates--but suggests that they are simply provided as an aid and guide.||The text was expressly written for teaching, and (as Planck states) follows the format of definitions, postulates, axioms, hypotheses, theorems and proofs, following by problems giving examples. It is a mix of the up-to-date and the Peripatetic, giving insight into Jesuit teaching in eastern Europe at the time. Other authors are sometimes associated with this work: Johann Ivansics, SJ (1722-??) and Antal Reviczky (1723-1781). The text was popular enough that editions appeared in 1747, 1752, and 1760.
BP_Description_2: The works has two parts, each with separate title page and pagination, usually bound together. Part 1: Arithmetic, Geometry, Trigonometry, Mechanics, Statics, Hydrostatics, Hydraulics, Aereometry, Civil and Military Architecture. Part 2: Optics, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Spherical Trigonometry, Astronomy and Geography, Chronology, Horography.||The optics material (33 pages) is in three parts, devoted to direct, reflected, and refracted vision. Each has several paragraph-long chapters. Part One deals with the eye and vision. Several aspects of perception are described: size, shape, location, distance, and motion. This part ends with the presentation of a few example problems, the application to perspective, and light and shadow. In this last section, elementary physical optics is considered. Even at the late date of its publication, color theory is Aristotelian: being the result of the mixing of white and black. Part Two briefly considers reflection and the properties of plane and curved mirrors. Part Three deals with refraction, applied specifically to spherical lenses. Tables of lens sizes and curvatures are presented for several sizes of telescopes. The microscope and magic lantern are briefly mentioned in this context.||The material is elementary with no mathematics beyond ratios being used, and is a mix of the up-to-date and the Peripatetic. The figures, though small, are essential to the understanding of the tightly-concise text.
BP_Reference(s): The reception of classical literature in the literary production of the Universitas Tyrnaviensis|Karabov√°‚Äì≈†otkovsk√°, K.|In:  Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Congress of Neo-Latin Studies (Uppsala 2009), Brill, 2012, 1228 pp, NB: pp 613-623.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Textbook for the earliest Newtonian course in natural philosophy at the University of Paris.
BP_Description_1: Few of the French clergy were well disposed to Newton‚Äôs physics, but Pierre Sigorgne was an exception. The first course in experimental physics to be taught at the University of Paris with a more empirical Newtonian orientation was Pierre Sigorgne‚Äôs, which was first delivered at the Coll√©ge Duplessis around 1740. The course and its notes were the basis for the <i>Institutions Newtoniennes<i>. Sigorgne was an ardent and vociferous experimental Newtonian who railed against the prevailing dependence on Descartes' physics; in particular, the reliance on Cartesian vortices to explain planetary motion. Sigorgne advocated Newton's notion of action-at-distance and embraced the elaborate mathematics Newton devised to describe central forces. Sigorgne applied this physics of attraction to most aspects of mechanics, statics, and importantly to optics. Gravity and its characterization was at the center of the growing dispute between Cartesians and Newtonians in France. In 1740 Sigornge had written a tract 'A Physico-Mathematical Demonstration of the Impossibility and Insufficiency of Vortices' that was translated into English and appeared in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. He would famously tangle with Privat de Moli√®res on this same subject after the appearance of the <i>Examen et r√©futation des le√ßons de physique expliqu√©es pat M. de Moli√©res au coll√®ge royal de France<i> in 1741. Sigornge's career at the Coll√©ge du Plessis came to an abrupt end two years after the publication of this book, when he was dismissed after being implicated along with 14 others, and eventually imprisoned, for writing satirical verses about Louis XV and Madame de Pompadour.||Editions of the  <i>Institutions Newtoniennes<i> appeared at Paris in 1747 and 1769, and an Italian translation appeared at Lucca in 1757.
BP_Description_2: After his Preface, Sigorgne has a 25-page review of conic sections including their properties and geometric analysis. This is, no doubt, provided in anticipation of a consideration of Newton's exposition method in the Principia. This introduction is followed by 15 chapters. 1: The resistance of the plenum and the existence of the Vacuum; 2: Attraction, its mechanism and existence; 3: Law of Attraction at Great Distances; 4: Attraction and movement; 5: Circular Movement; 6: Movement in Conic Sections; 7: Metaphysical Exposition of the Preceding Chapter; 8: Movement of the Principal Planets; 9: The Figure of the Stars and the Earth; 10: Movement of the Moon and other Satellites; 11: Cause of the Procession of the Equinoxes; 12: Move of the Sea; 13: Attraction at very small distances, inverse-cube relationship, chemical effects; 14: Capillaries and Attraction; 15: On Light and Colors, the place of Attraction.||Regarding optics, Sigorgne uses attraction at very small distances to explain prismatic dispersion, equal-angle reflection, refraction, and diffraction. The use of attractive force to explain these phenomena had been suggested by Newton in the important Query on forces acting a distance that first appeared in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706.
BP_Reference(s): Eighteenth-Century Conceptions of Gravitation|van Lunteren F.|In: International Archives of the History of Ideas, Petry M.J., editor, vol 136. Springer, 1993, pp 343-366.||Aristotle, Descartes and the New Science: Natural philosophy at the University of Paris, 1600‚Äì1740|Brockliss, L.W.B.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 38, No., 1981, pp 33-69.||Newton‚Äôs optics and atomism|Shapiro, A.E.|In: The Cambridge Companion to Newton, Cohen, B.I., Smith, G.E., editors, Cambridge, 2004, 500 pp, NB: pp 227-255.
BP_Title: Institutions Newtoniennes, ou Introduction a la Philosophie de M. Newton. Par M. Sigorgne, de la Maison & Soci√©t√© de Sorbonne, Professeur de Philosophie en l'Universite de Paris.

BP_Biographical Statement: French cleric and professor at the Coll√©ge Duplessis in the University of Paris. Important early proponent of Newtonian physics in French higher education.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A lexicon of Mixed Mathematics in German and Latin, with concisely descriptive entries.
BP_Description_1: Third edition of a lexicon of subjects in Mixed Mathematics. Though the text of the entries is German, the title of each entry is in German and Latin; thus, a German reader could become acquainted with relevant Latin vocabulary. Arranged alphabetically, the entries are concisely descriptive and accompanied by 36 plates of figures that add clarity when it is required. The first part of more than 1450 columns, contains the lexicon propter; the second part contains nearly 700 pages of tables of data, including mensuration, trigonometry, logarithms, geography, civil and military architecture, factoring, and optical data. The second part contains an additional ten plates of figures that accompany the data tables. Editions appeared in 1734, 1742, 1747.
BP_Description_2: A lexicon of Mixed Mathematics. Included are entries for catoptrics and mirrors, camera obscura, dioptrics, lenses, optics, microscopes, and telescopes. The second part contains 20 pages of tables containing optical data, including gnomics, lens data, refraction angles, and lens specifications for microscopes and telescopes.
