BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A course in natural philosophy covering: mechanics, optics, hydrostatics, and astronomy. Springs from Rutherforth's <i>Ordo Institutionum Physicarum<i> of 1743, an outline of a course he taught to private students at Cambridge.
BP_Description_1: This text springs from Rutherforth's <i>Ordo Institutionum Physicarum<i> of 1743, an outline, in the form of 1034 propositions, of the course in natural philosophy he taught to private students at Cambridge. Accompanied by detailed figures, the <i>Ordo<i> is a concise, sentence-propositional outline meant to show the structure and content of this private course. <i>A System of Natural Philosophy<i> is an elaborate, descriptive extension of the <i>Ordo<i> and its figures, meant for English readers who had no mathematics. That there was a market for such a text is clear from the nearly 1000 subscribers listed in the preliminaries. The order and progression of ideas shows the hand and experience of a teacher and not just a compiler.
BP_Description_2: A course in natural philosophy covering: mechanics, optics, hydrostatics, and astronomy. The optics chapter's 296 pages have numbered sections; each section's heading corresponding closely to a numbered proposition in the <i>Ordo<i>, and then followed by a description.  The material covers: light rays and their propagation; cause and nature of refraction; refraction at plane and curved surfaces; the properties of convex and concave lenses, foci; the camera obscura; vision, the eye, eye-function; vision through lenses, correction of indistinct vision, their images; telescopes and microscopes; cause and nature of reflection; reflection at plane and spherical mirrors; images in mirrors; reflecting telescopes; dispersion and chromatic refraction; color, colors in this plates and from prisms; the rainbow. The treatment is completely Newtonian, very elementary, and entirely descriptive; no mathematics other than proportion is used. Unlike the <i>Ordo<i>, The <i>System<i> neither cites sources nor gives references.
BP_Reference(s): Cambridge: Newton Legacy|Hall, R.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 55, No 2, 2001, pp 205-226.
BP_Title: A system of natural philosophy. Being a course of lectures in mechanics, optics, hydrostatics, and astronomy; Which are read in St Johns College Cambridge, by T. Rutherforth D.D. F.R.S. Chaplain to his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales. In two volumes.  Vol I. Vol II.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A doctoral dissertation on the reflection of light, written by Samuel Klingenstierna, presented and defend by his student at Upsala.
BP_Description_1: Between 1730 and 1752 more than 60 doctoral dissertations were under the direction of Klingenstierna while he taught at the University of Uppsala. The long series of dissertations written by and under the direction of Klingenstierna covered topics that included heat measurement, wind, vision, optics, electricity, gravity, and mathematics.
BP_Description_2: The work begins with a brief summary of the history of theories of reflection, followed by sections 2-13, each dealing with an aspect of the reflection of light from a geometrical optics point of view. The second part of the dissertation, sections 14-27, consider reflection from the physical optics point of view. Newton and Descartes are cited; The <i>Optice<i> and the <i>Lecttiones Opticae<i> are the principal sources for Newton and the <i>Specimina Philosophiae<i>  for Descartes. Other authors cited include R√∏mer, Huygens, Wolff, Musschenbroek, and Bernoulli. The dissertation is a precis, analysis, and culling of theories of reflection and the experimental evidence that refutes or supports them.
BP_Reference(s): Klingenstierna' at Digitala Vetenskapliga Arkivet online at http://www.diva-portal.se/smash/resultList.jsf?dswid=0&language=en&searchType=SIMPLE&query=Klingenstierna&af=%5B%5D&aq=%5B%5B%7B%22organisation%22%3A%22Filosofiska+fakulteten%22%7D%5D%5D&aq2=%5B%5B%5D%5D&aqe=%5B%5D&noOfRows=50&sortOrder=author_sort_asc&sortOrder2=title_sort_asc&onlyFullText=false&sf=all

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Philippe-Florent de Puisieux (1713-1772) French lawyer and translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: French translation of Martin's <i>The Philosophical Grammar<i>, an epitome of knowledge, principally from the physical sciences, written for students and self-study.
BP_Description_1: First edition of the French translation of Martin's <i>The Philosophical Grammar<i>. Though unstated, the translator was Philippe-Florent de Puisieux, who followed the text of the second English edition of 1738 very closely. New plates were engraved for the translation, with additional figures produced by way of separating some of the English edition's figures into more than one. The translation retained the dual structure of the text: the dialogue presented an outline of the material, and the copious notes presented the detail and more advanced explanations.
BP_Description_2: The second, expanded edition of an epitome of knowledge, principally from the physical sciences, written for students and self-study. The wide range of topics were meant to provide a survey of most of natural philosophy. The material is prefaced with a general introduction to experimentation, natural philosophy, and a list of instruments and their uses. Part I: Nature and properties of matter, Newtonian physics and mechanics. Part II: Cosmology, including the planets, the Moon, the stars, and comets. Part III: 'Aerology', including the atmosphere and meteorics. Part IV: Geology, plants, insects, birds, and animals. Part I contains chapters on light and color (25 pages), including: nature of light, reflection, refraction, simple mirrors and lenses, the microscope, telescope, camera obscura, the magic lantern, prismatic and thin-plate colors, heterogeneous white light. The presentation is elementary, with no mathematics, in the form of a dialogue of short questions and answers. Accompanying the dialogue is an elaborate and copious set of notes that give examples, clarify, cite authorities, and explain the figures. The details and more advanced material is in the notes.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Benjamin Martin: Author, Instrument-Maker, and ‚ÄòCountry Showman‚Äô<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Nordhoff Publishing, Lyden, 1976, pp 11-21.

BP_Title English Translation: Grammar of the Philosophical Sciences, or, An Abreviated Analysis of Modern Philosophy, Resting on Experiments. Translated from the English of Benjamin Martin.
BP_Biographical Statement: English sciencen lecturer, oculist, instrument maker, lexicographer.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection that contains the <i>Optice<i> of 1740, the Geneva edition, and the optics material from the second volume of the <i>Opuscula Mathematica, Philosophica et Philologica<i> of 1744.
BP_Description_1: Assembled by an unnamed editor, this collection contains the Geneva edition of the <i>Optice<i> of 1740 and the material from the second volume of the <i>Opuscula Mathematica, Philosophica et Philologica<i> of 1744: the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> of 1729 and the excerpts of letters that appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Philosophical Society of London. Though the text of the <i>Optice<i> is that of the 1740 edition, none of the 35 pages of its preliminary material is included. The letter excerpts are in an appendix and are an exact resetting of the editing and translations of Jean de Castillon from the <i>Opuscula<i> of 1744. A half-title page with <i>'Isaaci Newtoni Opera Omnia Optica'<i> is present. A long letter to the reader from the printer is present, and though histories of the various editions of the included works are given, no attribution to the actual sources in made. A second edition appeared in 1773.
BP_Description_2: A reprinting of the <i>Optice<i> of 1740, the <i>Lectiones Opticae<i> of 1729, and Jean de Castillon's editing and translation of the exchange of letters that appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Philosophical Society of London prompted by Newton letter 'New Theory About Light and Colors.'
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of Newtonian Optics in Italy|Casini, P.|In: <i>Renaissance and Revolution: Humanists, Scholars, Craftsmen and Natural Philosophers<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1993, pp 215-228.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A practical exposition of optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: A practical treatise on the nature and use of optical instruments for a wide audience: artisans, the spectacle-wearing public, and any with indistinct vision. As with Thomin's other publications, this is, to some small extent, practical, popular science freighted with a bit of advertising for his own instruments and spectacles.
BP_Description_2: A practical exposition of optical instruments. The first part covers: general description of optical instruments; lenses; method of figuring lenses; plane, spherical, and burning mirrors; specifications for spectacles, binoculars, and opera glasses; telescopes and their lenses, using telescopes; microscopes and their lenses, using simple and compound microscopes; prisms; the camera obscura. The second part covers: the eye, vision, and eye-function; lenses for correcting vision; practical advice on obtaining and using spectacles to correct and conserve vision.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Spectacles and Other Vision Aids: A History and Guide to Collecting<i>|Rosenthal, J.W.|Norman Publishing, San Francisco, 1996.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by John Lowthorp (1659-1724), Henry Jones (?-1727), James Eames (1686-1744), and John Martyn (1699-1768)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A series of abridgements and translations of papers that appeared in the <i>Transactions of the Royal Society<i> from its founding 1665 to 1750.
BP_Description_1: In 1702, John Lowthorp, fellow of the Royal Society, devised a plan to collect, abridge, and publish papers that had appeared in the Philosophical Transactions up to 1700. He sought and received permission of the Society's Council to create and published abridgements of the accumulated back-run of the Transactions up to and including 1700. Interestingly, the Society did not expect or require and financial renumeration--considering acknowledgement and attribution sufficient, since it was primarily interested in the spread of knowledge. Lowthorp's project was a success, finding a wide audience, especially on the continent, among those interested in access to the papers in the back issues of the Transactions. The three-volume work first appeared in 1703-1708 and went through 5 editions. Commercial success and interest prompted a continued series of abridgements up to 1750. The Volume numbering started by Lorthorp was continued.  Vols. 4-5 have the title: <i>The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1700 to the year 1720<i> and were edited by Henry Jones. Vols. 6-7 have the title: <i>The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1719 to the year 1733<i> and were edited by James Eames and John Martyn. Vols. 8-9 have the title: <i>The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1732 to the year 1744<i> and were edited by John Martyn. Vol. 10 has the title: <i>The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1743 to the year 1750. Abridged and Disposed under General Heads. The Latin papers being translated into English<i> and was edited by John Martyn.||In 1721, Benjamin Motte published an unsanctioned abridgement of papers from the Philosophical Transactions for the years 1700-1720. This prompted the third, 1722 edition of Lowthorp's work to appear with an advertisement making clear that Lowthorp's edition had been approved by the Royal Society.||Lowthorp's and the subsequent series of collections, translations, and abridgements prompted a large project proposed to the Royal Society in 1803 by the mathematician and Society Fellow Charles Hutton: to select, abridge, and index the contents of the Transactions of the previous 135 years. Eventually the Society approved the project and in 1809 18 Volumes appeared, edited by Charles Hutton, George Shaw, and Richard Pearson. Henry Jones.
BP_Description_2: The Abridgements cover the Transactions from their beginning in 1665 to 1750, but in fact the most important papers are substantially complete. Volume 1: Mathematical Papers, Volume 2: The Physiological Papers, Volume 3 Part 1: Anatomical, Medical, and Chymical Papers, Volume 3 Part 2: Philological and Miscellaneous Papers. Volume 4 part 1: The mathematical papers; Volume 4 Part 2: The physiological papers. Volume 5 Part 1: The anatomical and medical papers; Volume 5 Part 2: The philological and miscellaneous papers. Volume 6-7, Part 1: The mathematical papers; Part 2: The physiological papers; Part 3: the anatomical papers; part 4: The philological and miscellaneous papers Volume 8-9, Part 1: The mathematical papers; Part 2: The physiological papers; Part 3, The anatomical and medical papers; Part 4; The historical and miscellaneous papers. Volume 10, Part 1, The mathematical papers; Part 2, The physiological papers; Part 3, The anatomical and medical papers; Part 4: The historical and miscellaneous papers.||Chapter III of volume 1 is entitled 'Opticks' and includes all of Newton's founding papers on the subject as well as the papers that contributed to the debate generated by Newton's theory, commencing with the famous 'A New Theory About Light & Colors' of 1672. Further papers on optics appear in subsequent volumes.
BP_Reference(s): Credit, Copyright, and the Circulation of Scientific Knowledge: The Royal Society in the Long Nineteenth Century|Fyfe, A., McDougall-Waters, J., Moxh, N.|<i>Victorian Periodicals Review<i>, Vol 51, No 4, 2018, pp 597-615.
BP_Title: The Philosophical Transactions and Collections, to the End of the Year MDCC, Abridged and Disposed under General Heads.  by John Lowthorp. The Fifth Edition, Corrected, in which the Latin papers are now first translated into English. The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1700 to the year 1720 in Two Volumes by Henry Jones. (Vols 4-5). The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1719 to the year 1733 Abridged and Disposed under General Heads. In Two Volumes, by James Eames and James Martyn. (Vols 6-7).  The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1732 to the year 1744, Abridged and Disposed under General Heads, by John Martyn. (Vol 9).  The Philosophical Transactions from the Year 1743 to the year 1750, Abridged and Disposed under General Heads. The Latin papers being translated into English,  by John Martyn,

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An early-to-mid 18th century summary of vision, optical instruments, geometric and physical optics.
BP_Description_1: An early-to-mid 18th century summary of vision, optical instruments, geometric and physical optics. The date is a conjecture: after Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1704 and before Dollond of 1750. A manuscript written in English in a small but clearly legible hand, on the recto only of 65 numbered leaves. The work is apparently a fair copy from an early 18th century text. The figures reproduced here have labeling copy directly from engraved plates. The marginal references to figures must have also been copied from the text. Produced in what must have been an empty-leaved notebook, In original binder's drab boards with paper spine.
BP_Description_2: The manuscript with a section on vision in near and far-sighed people, leaves 1-6. Then there are sections labeled: Of Vision through Glasses, leaves 7-20 ; Of Double Vision, leaves 20-24; Of Telescopes & Microscopes, leaves 24-34; Catoptricks, leaves 34-36; Of Sphaerical Mirrours, leaves 36-43; Sir Isaac Newton's Theory of Light & Colours, leaves 43-65. The last section includes a description of Newton's reflecting telescope and an analysis of the Rainbow. The material is brief, elementary, but complete. With the single exception of algebra used in the explanation of the rainbow's formation, no mathematics beyond geometry is invoked and at these points, there are marginal citations to the elements of Euclid.||The text appears to begin in the middle of a description of the physics and physiology of vision, which is not included in the list of contents; it begins on f. 2, refers in marginal notes to 'Lect[ure] 9' and 'Tab. 10', which are not included.
BP_Title: Optics and Vision
BP_BibliographicNotes: The first leaf before the existing blank and probably therefore also a blank, has been removed at some time as the eighth leaf of the first gathering has no conjugate leaf.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Drab Boards With Paper Spine
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1750 Anonymous - Optics and Vision - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Written for student use at the Gymnasium where Della Torre taught experimental physics. Its two volumes cover General and Particular Physics.
BP_Description_1: Della Torre wrote the <i>Scienza<i> for student use at the Royal ArchiGymnasium where he taught experimental physics. Its two volumes covered General and Particular Physics. Della Torre had a strong interest in the history  of ideas and his text contains long sections relating ancient concepts with then-current ideas. The work opens with an excursus into the history of philosophy, tracing ideas through three periods of history: from the ancients to late Rome, to late Medieval times; to the 18th century. Each major sections begins with a brief historical review, citing works and authors. Though patterned after 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i>, the <i>Scienza<i> contains biology, chemistry, geology, or meteorology; missing in 's Gravesande. Many of the figures are copied from those found in the 1748 edition of 's Gravesande.||Editions of the <i>Scienza<i> appeared at Naples in 1748, 1750, and 1774. The two-volume Scienza formed the basis for Della Torre's 8-volume <i>Elementa Physicae<i> which was published at Naples between 1767 and 1780.
BP_Description_2: The first volume covers general physics: matter, motion, mechanics, gravity, statics, hydraulics, electrostatics, ballistics, dynamics, fluids, heat and cold. The second volume covers particular physics: the earth and geology, interior of the earth, the surface of the earth, the atmosphere, sound and light. The optics material (60 pages) includes: nature of light and light rays, light sources, sound and light similarities, vision and eye-function, visual perception, reflection, plane and spherical mirrors and their foci, refraction, lenses and their foci, microscopes, telescopes, Newtonian prismatic refraction and colors. The presentation is detailed, geometric, and accompanied by figures.
BP_Reference(s): Spreading Newtonian Philosophy with Instruments: The Case of Atwood‚Äôs Machine|Salvatore Esposito, S., Schettino, E.|<i>Advances in Historical Studies<i>, Vol 3, No 1, 2014, pp 68-81, NB: p 71.
BP_Title: Scienza della natura generale [particolare] del P. D. Gio: Maria della Torre, C.R. Somasco Professore de Fisica nel Liceo Arcivescovile, e Membro dell' Accademia Reale Napoletana. Parte Prima.  Parte Seconda Il Mondo Terrestre.
BP_Title English Translation: The Science of Nature, General [Particular] of the Reverend Giovanni Maria Della Torre, CRS. Professor of Physics in the Bishop's High School, and Member of the Royal Academy of Naples. Part One. Part Two The Terrestrial World.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Somascan Father, natural philosopher, mathematician. Taught in cities throughout Italy, wrote copiously on natural philosophy, and famed for his microscopy and volcanology.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A detailed, mathematical examination of the conic sections and their applications.
BP_Description_1: A detailed, mathematical examination of the conic sections, including the history of their development, their characteristics, and their applications. Both Ampere and Laplace used the book and, as de la Chapelle had been recruited as an author by  d‚ÄôAlembert, some of the material was used in the Encyclop√©die. An edition appeared in 1745 but without optics applications. Editions appeared in 1750 and 1765. A German translation by Johann Bockmann appeared at Karlsruhe in 1771 and was reissued in 1791.
BP_Description_2: The work begins with a review of the algebra necessary for working with conic sections: powers and extraction of roots and working with radicals. Then the following curves are treated: parabola; ellipse; hyperbola; cissoid; conchoid; the quadratrix; spiral; and the cycloid. In each case, the history of the curve is given, method of generation, properties (tangents, directrix, focus), rotation into three dimensions, and applications. The applications of the parabola include cannon trajectory and a sound amplifier (porte-voix or megaphone). Most applications are in optics, and the various curves are applied to both mirrors and to lens surfaces for the construction of focusing and burning mirrors, lenses for spectacles and magnification. The section on the ellipse contains a dissertation of the sine law of refraction, its discovery, and the priority argument regarding Descartes and Snell. The section on the hyperbola contains a dissertation on the practicality of its use in lenses mirrors. The material is advanced and accompanied by the necessary mathematics and highly detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The¬†Encyclopedists¬†as¬†Individuals:¬†A¬†Biographical Dictionary¬†of¬†the¬†Authors¬†of¬†the¬†Encyclop√©die<i>|Kafker, F.A.|Oxford University Press, 1988, pp 181-184.
BP_Title: TraiteÃÅ des sections coniques et autres courbes anciennes appliqueÃÅes ou appliquables aÃÄ la pratique de diffeÃÅrens arts, tels que l'artillerie, l'architecture, la construction des miroirs ardens, des teÃÅlescopes, des lunettes, des porte-voix, des eÃÅchos, des cornets acoustiques, ou des instrumens qui servent aÃÄ corriger les deÃÄfauts de l'ouiÃàe, &c. Avec un petit traiteÃÅ de la cycloiÃàde, oÃÄu l'on fait voir comment cette courbe a contribueÃÅ aÃÄ perfectionner les horloges aÃÄ pendule. Le tout enrichi de notes ou de dissertations historiques & critiques sur l'origine & le progreÃÄs des sciences & des arts, qui sont entreÃÄs dans le plan de cet ouvrage.
BP_Title English Translation: Treatise on conical sections and other ancient curves applied or applicable to the practice of various arts, such as artillery, architecture, the construction of burning mirrors, telescopes, glasses, megaphones, echoes, acoustic horns, or instruments which serve to correct defects in hearing, & c. With a small treatise on the cycloid, where we show how this curve contributed to perfecting pendulum clocks. All enriched with historical & critical notes or dissertations on the origin & progress of the sciences & the arts, which are included in the plan of this work.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, teacher, and textbook writer, and contributor to the L'Encyclop√©die.

BP_Short or Common Title: Physic√¶ Experimentalis Elementa In Vsvs Academicos Conscripta
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary textbook on natural philosophy, written for students in Catholic German schools who had not studied mathematics.
BP_Description_1: An elementary textbook on natural philosophy, written for students in Catholic German schools who had not yet studied mathematics. It is a focusing and reworking of his earlier work <i>Philosophia Utilis et Jucunda<i> of 1745. In his long preface, Gordon claims that only demonstration and experiment determines the truth, and that the words, fame, or authority of a philosopher do not matter, whether it be 'Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Newton, or any other.' An accomplished inventor of instruments (electrical in particular), Gordon also mentions the importance of proper experimental instruments and their use, mentioning Musschenbroek and Nollet and their works as good examples in this regard. The first volume appeared in 1751, the same year as Gordon's death.
BP_Description_2: Contents of the first volume: bodies and their attributes; motion and its properties; gravity; gravitational mechanisms; magnetism; electricity; fluids; water; air; and sound. Contents of the second volume: fire and heat and their properties; light; cosmography; meteorics; fossils; plants; and animals. The optics sections (62 pages) include: nature and propagation of light; luminous objects; direct propagation; illumination; the eye and eye-function; shadow; reflection; plane and spherical mirrors and their foci; refraction and its properties; lenses and their foci and images; spectacles; the telescope and the magic lantern; color, colors by prismatic refraction, thin-film colors, chemical coloring and indicators. The material is elementary, descriptive, and detailed; with only simple geometry used. Though Newton is not mentioned, the material on color is entirely Newtonian, if imperfectly described.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Bibliography of the Gordons, Section I<i>|Bulloch, J.M.|University of Aberdeen Press, 1924, pp 105-107.
BP_Title: Physicae Experimentalis Elementa In Vsvs Academicos Conscripta ab Andrea Gordon O.S.B.
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Experimental Physics. Composed for Academic Uses by Andrea Gordon, OSB.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish Benedictine, natural philosopher, experimentalist, inventor.  Professor at the University of Erfurt.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed for the use of 'T. Withelm' on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A manuscript for a scholastic text on physics
BP_Description_1: A manuscript of a Latin text meant for teaching and likely for publication. The title implies this is the second volume of a text on philosophy and is devoted to physics. Though mid-18th century (that last page gives the date of completion as March 1751) the material is Aristotelian in most of its content and all of its style, with propositions and disputations, arguments and proofs. The manuscript has 453 quarto leaves, written recto and verso, presenting 900 pages in a small, tight hand using brown ink. The text appears to be a fair copy of a manuscript in the Municipal Library in Ko≈°ice Slovakia. This and other texts were part of the teaching apparatus developed at the Jesuit University of Ko≈°ice early in the 18th century. Scholastic teaching was still prominent in Eastern Europe in the first half of the 18th century and texts such as this would be replaced by those from Jesuits such as  Johann Baptiste Horvath, SJ only in the 1770s.
BP_Description_2: The three principal sections are <i>Prologium<i> with axioms and propositions, <i>Physica Generalis<i> in 378 numbered sections, and <i>Physica Specialis<i> in 252 numbered sections. The material is elementary and entirely descriptive. No mathematics of any kind is invoked and no figures are presented or referenced. The optics material is in the section on the senses, including vision, hearing, taste, smell, and touch. It defines the propagation of light, and describes reflection, mirrors, refraction, lenses, and color.
BP_Reference(s): On a Forgotten Diploma Thesis|M√©sz√°ros, O.|<i>Philosophy<i>, Vol 60, No 10, 2005, pp 819-828. (translated from the Slovak)
BP_Title: Tractatus Philosophiae 2dus Physica
BP_Title English Translation: Second Philosophical Tract - Physics
BP_Biographical Statement: A Jesuit teaching the the Jesuit University of Ko≈°ice.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Pierre Massuet (1698-1776) French-born Dutch physician, writer.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: French translation of the <i>Beginselen Der Natuurkunde<i> of 1736, Musschenbroek's popularization of natural philosophy written for the educated Dutch public.
BP_Description_1: A popularization of natural philosophy written for the educated Dutch public. The scope and detail of the material indicates the interest in and market for information and instruction in the new experimental natural philosophy. This was more developed and expansive than Musschenbroek's detailed student text of 1734; and certainly more descriptive than the epitome of his lecture of 1726. The first edition of the French translation first appeared immediately followed the appearance of the second edition of the <i>Beginselen Der Natuurkunde<i> in 1739.
BP_Description_2: French translation of the <i>Beginselen Der Natuurkunde<i> of 1736, being an overview of natural philosophy Including: mechanics, gravity, fluids, optics, water and winds. The optics section (119 pages) includes: nature of light; reflected and refracted rays; refraction in air and glass; color and differing refraction; the eye and eye-function; vision; catoptrics. The material on refraction and color is entirely Newtonian. The presentation is elementary but detailed, geometric, and accompanied by many elaborate figures which were used again in the translation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Van Stevin tot Lorentz: Portretten van achttien Nederlandse natuurwetenschappers<i>|Kox, A.J., editor|Bert Bakker, Amsterdam, 1990, pp 93-105, NB: pp 97-98.|'s Gravesane and Musschenbroek: Newtonianism at Leiden|Ruestow, E.G.|In: <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Springer, 1973, 174 p NB: pp 113-139.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian translation and abridgement of Regnault's <i>Entretiens MatheÃÅmatiques<i>, an elementary textbook on physics.
BP_Description_1: An Italian translation and abridgement of Regnault's <i>Entretiens matheÃÅmatiques<i>. The mathematical material and the optics from volume 3 of the French work are included in the translation.
BP_Description_2: The third tome is devoted to optics and includes: propagation of light; refraction; refraction at plane and spherical surfaces; lenses; vision, eye, and eye-function; the telescope, the microscope; magnification and apparent size; illusions; binocular vision; plane and spherical mirrors; shadow; perspective; iconography and projections. The material is elementary, descriptive, and invokes only simple geometry. The style is that of a dialogue, with propositions, proofs, and example problems. This abridgement is interesting in that no material on the nature of light or any mention of color is included; nothing either expressly Cartesian or Newtonian. Virtually all the material is geometrical optics, based solely on a few axioms regarding light rays.
BP_Reference(s): Le Cartesianisme Chez les Jesuites Francais: au XVIIth et au XVIIIth Siecle|Sortais, G.|<i>Archives de Philosophie<i>, Vol 6, No 3, 1929, pp 1-10.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Nicol√≤ Arrighetti, SJ (1709-1767) Italian Jesuit, natural philosopher and teacher.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A thesis written by Arrighetti and defended by Chigi, presenting the Cartesian theory that light as a tendency of movement in a supremely tenuous luminous fluid or aether.
BP_Description_1: Prince Sigismondo Chigi was a student of the Collegio Tolomei in Siena and student of Nicol√≤ Arrighetti. As was the custom, Chigi was listed as the defender of the thesis, but it was written by Arrighetti. The theory of light put forward here is fully Cartesian, and sprinkled with attacks and digs on 'Newtonians.' This thesis is derived from an earlier work of Arrighetti: his <i>Ignis Theoria<i> published at Siena in 1750.
BP_Description_2: The theory defended is that light is a tendency of movement in a supremely tenuous luminous fluid or aether. This fluid or aether is the 'fire' referred to by earlier authors, filling the plenum of infinite space. It permeates all space and bodies. Impulses in this fluid cause light's effects, and  unless they encounter the surface of a body, travel in straight lines at a great and uniform speed. These points are presented and defended in three propositions. Footnotes provide what is almost a running commentary.
BP_Reference(s): The <i>Storia Letteraria D'Itaia<i> and the Rehabilitation of Jesuit Science|Dooley, B.|In: <i>Jesuit Science and the Republic of Letters<i>|Feingold, M., editor|MIT Press, 2003, pp 433-473.

BP_Title English Translation: A Theory of Light. By the Great Mother of God, Ancient Protectress, Propositions Defended Under Public Auspices, With Many Added at the End from all of Philosophy, of Sigismuno Chigi. Member Of the College of Ptolemi and Humble Academician.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian nobelman, early dabler in natural philosophy, poet, and dramatist.

BP_Author full name: Gaspard Le Compasseur De Cr√©quy-Montfort,  Marquis de Courtivron
BP_Author last name first: Courtivron, Gaspard Le Compasseur De Cr√©quy-Montfort,  Marquis de
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Courtivron own digest and augmentation of Newtonian optics. Meant to be a general optical reference.
BP_Description_1: A general French reference for Newtonian optics. Unlike earlier French translations of Newton's optical writings, Courtivron produced his own digest and augmentation of Newton's material, adding details and mathematical demonstrations omitted by Newton. Courtivron's analysis of the rainbow is an example of this additional mathematical work.
BP_Description_2: The material is presented in three sections. Part One includes: light's nature; the nature and cause of reflection and refraction; comparison of Descartes's plenum and Newton's particles; law of refraction; prismatic refraction and color; paths of refracted light through surfaces; luminous properties of materials. Part Two includes: geometrical optics of lenses;  plane and curved mirrors; images in mirror; operation of the rainbow. Part Three includes: ocular anatomy, vision and eye-function; photometry; magnification and apparent size; lens and mirror analysis; lenses for aiding vision; reflecting and refracting telescopes; constructing telescopes. The material is detailed and mathematical, including the use of the calculus, with examples and solved problems. Newtonian forces are used to explain reflection and refraction, though Courtivron offers his own ideas regarding the cause for prismatic dispersion, relying on and extending the Alexis-Claude Clairut's explanation of refraction.
BP_Reference(s): The Velocity of Light and the color Changes of Jupiter‚Äôs Satellites|Pedersen, K.M.|<i>Research Publications on Science Studies<i>, 2017, pp 1-44, NB pp 23-26.|http://css.au.dk/fileadmin/reposs/reposs-040.pdf

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A dissertation on the nature of light and color with an additional consideration of sound and a theory of refraction.
BP_Description_1: Joseph Mangold was a Cartesian of Euler's type; holding to Descartes's plenum filled with a luminiferous aether, but subject to the constraints and adopting the similarities with sound laid out by Euler in his theory of light and color. Mangold began teaching at Ingolstadt in 1748, assuming the task of developing and teaching a course on 'rational and experimental philosophy,' after the German Jesuit finally began to adopt Cartesian natural philosophy. This is the dissertation Mangold presented to the faulty, for which he was granted his DD.
BP_Description_2: A dissertation on the nature of light and color with an additional consideration of sound and a theory of refraction. The dissertation presents and discusses three investigations. On Sound: definitions, properties of sound, collection and reflection of sound, the echo; nature of harmony, music, and voice. On Light: definitions and observations; various opinions regarding light's nature and their refutation; Euler's proposed theory of light based on pulses and it accounting for reflection and refraction; arguments for the correctness of Euler's theory. On Color: definitions and observations; colors distinguished from the modification of light; famous authorities on color; prismatic refraction and color; the rainbow; refuting Newton's color theory. The entire treatment is Eulerian and based on his <i>Nova Theoria Lucis et Colorum<i> of 1746. The treatment is descriptive with no mathematics involved. The style is that of a classic dissertation; assertions, questions, responses, confirmations, conclusions.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Electricity in the 17th and 18th Centuries: A Study of Early Modern Physics<i>|Heilbron, J.L.|University of California Press, 1979, pp 134-135.
BP_Title: Systema luminis et colorum novam de refractione theoriam complectens cum pr√¶via dissertatione de sono. Propositum a P. Josepho Mangold Soc. Jesu philosophi√¶ professore ordinario cum ab eodem in alma electorali Universitate Ingolstadiensi  ex Decreto Inclyti Collegii Philosophici. Suprema AA LL & Philosophiae Laurea insignirentur DD. Candidati, Virtute, Religione & Doctrina conspicui, & per legitimum examen approbati. Anno MDCCLIII. 1 Augusti. Cum FacuItate Superiorum.
BP_Title English Translation: A System of Light and Colors. Encompassing A New Theory of Refration, with a Previous Dissertation on Sound. Put Forward by Father Josef Jangold SJ, Professor in Ordinary of Philosophy, with Highest AAc, LL, and Philosophy Degress from the same [Society], In Accordance with the Kind Electors of the University of Ingolstadt, by Decree of the Celebrated College of Philosophy, Is Signified as DD Candiate, Approved by Virtue, Religion, Conspicuous Education, and through Legitimate Examination. 1 August, 1753. With Permission of Superiors.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, nautural philosopher. Embrased Woffian natural philosophy, produced important text books.

BP_Short or Common Title: Dictionnaire universel de matheÃÅmatique et de physique
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A French dictionary of Mixed Mathematics covering mathematics and its applications.
BP_Description_1: Sav√©rien had a long relationship with the Parisian publisher Jombert, who published a prospectus in 1749 of a 'Universal dictionary of mathematics and physics,' planned to appear in 1750. The prospectus listed Sav√©rien as the author and stated that the new dictionary would be 'drawn from the mathematical dictionaries of Ozanam, Wolf, Stone, and a large number of other works.' The large project took an additional three years: Though Sav√©rien lists nearly 800 authors and works he consulted in gathering material for his dictionary, Wolff's <i>Vollst√§ndiges Mathematisches Lexicon<i> of 1734. Sav√©rien divides the mathematical sciences in three branches: pure mathematics, physics and mixed mathematics. To Sav√©rien, Physics is  all 'the properties discovered by vision, touch, hearing, smell, and taste.' Thus, in Sav√©rien's schema, practically all fields of knowledge are related to physics and mathematics. But as it turned out, the dictionary is limited to Mixed Mathematics; the physics entries (mechanics, electricity, etc.) are limited in number and not extensively developed. A Spanish translation appeared at Madrid in 1775.
BP_Description_2: A French dictionary of Mixed Mathematics. It covers: basic mathematics, geometry, integral and differential calculus, astronomy, mechanics, hydrodynamics, optics, aerometry, acoustics, pyrotechnics, civil and military architecture. The entries are of both word and subject type, generally concise, but varying in length from a sentence to several pages. More than 100 plates containing more than 400 figures accompany the entries. The optics entries include: colors, catoptrics, catadioptrics, dioptrics, light, lenses, mirrors, optics, vision, the eye, view, perspective, reflection, refraction (the longest, by far), microscopes, telescopes. The longer entries are detailed, filled with examples, and contain considerable mathematics; amounting to small essays on their subject.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Forgotten Encyclopedia: The Maurists‚Äô Dictionary of Arts, Crafts, and Sciences, the Unrealized Rival of the Encyclop√©die of Diderot and d‚ÄôAlembert<i>|Holmberg, L.|Doctoral Dissertation, Department of Historical, Philosophical and Religious Studies, Ume√• University, Ume√• 2014, pp 136-144.|http://www.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:715277/FULLTEXT02.pdf

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Maarten Houttuyn (1720 -1798) Dutch naturalist, prolific author.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A Dutch translation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: By 1746 the Amsterdam publisher Isaac Tirion had produced a Dutch translation of John Desagulier's compendium of experimental natural philosophy. As it lacked any significant optics, the Dutch translator (never identified, but Jacobus Krighout (1703-1770) has been suggested), proposed a third volume: a Dutch translation of part of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738: the 'Popular Treatise.' Tirion's and the translator's plans eventually expanded to include publication of a translation of Smith's  entire work. The list of 176 subscribers in the front matter is evidence of the keen interest of the Dutch in Smith's detailed optical treatise. Dutch interest in optical matters in general and telescopes in particular was responsible, in part, for the popularity, success, and influence of the book. The Dutch translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1753 and reissued with a new title page at The Hague in 1764.
BP_Description_2: A Dutch translation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738. The Dutch is faithful to the English, neither adding nor removing. This included reproducing Smith's hundreds of figures.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327, NB p 323.||Science for the public: the translation of popular texts on experimental philosophy into the Dutch language in mid-eighteenth century|Zuidervaart, H.J.|In: <i>Cultural Transfer through Translation: The Circulation of Enlightened Thought in Europe by Means of Translation<i>|Stockhorst, S., editor|Brill, 2010, pp 231-262, NB. pp 243-247.
BP_Title: Volkomen samenstel der optica of gezigtkunde, Behelzende eene gemeenzaame, eene wiskonstige, eene werktuiglyke en eene natuurkundige verhandeling: Verrijkt met veele aanmerkingen van den schrijver, als mede met eene verhandeling van Jurin over het duidelyk en onduidelyk zien. Alles met zeer veele plaaten opgehelderd.  In 't Engelsch beschreeven door den Heere Robert Smith, Doctor in de beide Regten, Hoogleeraar in de Starrekunde en Natuurkunde, Meester van Trinity-College te Kambridge, en Mechanist van zyne Majesteit van Grootbrittannie.  Vertaald door een Liefhebber der Wiskonst en Natuurkunde, En met eenige Byvoegzels en Verbeteringen van den Schryver vermeerderd. Eerste Deel.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An introduction to optics in seven long articles, specifically written for student use.
BP_Description_1: Nothing is known of Jean Trabaud, other than he wrote three textbooks: <i>Le Mouvement des Corps Terrestres, Le Mouvement des Corps Celestes<i>, and <i>Le Mouvement de la Lumi√®re<i>. The three subtitles indicate the coverage:  Consid√©r√© dans les machines et dans les corps naturels, Premiers principes d'astronomie, and Premiers principes d'optique. Trabaud's works must have been widely known; in his  Plan d‚Äôune Universit√© pour le gouvernement de Russie ou d‚Äôune √©ducation publique dans toutes les sciences,  Diderot recommends Trabaud's <i>Le Mouvement des Corps Terrestres<i> as the mechanics text. They are expressly written for student use, and give a thorough, if elementary, introduction to their subject fields.
BP_Description_2: Trabaud's three volumes cover terrestrial motion, celestial motion, and luminous motion. The first volume covers terrestrial objects, friction, resistance of solids, horology, mills, pumps, and the movement of ships. Volume two covers movement of celestial bodies with a treatise on 'the sphere', apparent motion of the stars, motion of the sun and planets, systems of Ptolemy, Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, and Kepler, and eclipses. Volume three is an introduction to optics in seven Articles. I: light rays, shadow, sunlight, gnomic shadows and their movement. II: gnomics, solar calendars. III: vision, the eye and eye-function, simple perception, perspective. IV: reflection, plane mirrors, images in multiple mirrors, spherical mirrors, other convex mirrors. V: refraction, refraction at plane and curved surfaces, atmospheric refraction, lenses, geometric optics of lenses, spectacles, telescopes, microscopes, camera obscura. VI: colors, prismatic refraction and Newton's system of colors, the rainbow, meteorics. VII: the physics of light, light's propagation, wave theory, particle theory, cause of reflection and refraction, transparency, aurora borealis. The treatment presents the Descartes-Malebranche-Mairan and Newtonian theories equally, siding with neither. The material is detailed and descriptive, with mathematics limited to geometry.
BP_Reference(s): <i>La Mise en Place d‚Äôune Nouvelle Philosophie de la Physique au 18e Si√®cle<i>|Guyot, P.|Thesis, Universit√© de Bourgogne, 2012, p 331, NB: pp 60-63.|https://tel.archives-ouvertes.fr/tel-00796096/document

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook on mathematics, the third volume of which presents Boscovich's first thorough treatment of the principle of continuity
BP_Description_1: Boscovich published a two-volume textbook of mathematics in 1752, the <i>Elementa Universae Matheseos<i>. By 1754 he had written <i>Sectionnum Conicarum Elementa<i> and <i>De transformatione locorum geometricorum<i>. These last two works were added as a third volume to the entire work that appeared in 1754. In the 1740's, while teaching at the Collegio Romano, Boscovich became interested in the principle of continuity and the notion of a single, point-based force that attracted or repelled depending the distance over which it acted. These ideas took an form in an attempt to explain the nature of light and optical reflection and refraction.||The material in volume three contains the first thorough, detailed presentation of the principle of continuity and is Boscovich's attempt to establish continuity as a law, to be applied generally to all of natural philosophy. It, and the notion of a single continuous force, would become the beginning point for hs <i>Theoria philosophiae naturalis<i> of 1758.||This first edition of the three-volume work appeared at Rome in 1754 and was reissued at Venice in 1757.
BP_Description_2: In the first part of volume 3, the elements of conic sections, Boscovich picks up Johannes Kepler's idea of the continuous transformation of one conic section to another: from the straight line one passes through an infinity of hyperbolas to the parabola, and then through an infinity of ellipses and then to the circle. And vice versa. At the heart of this process is continuous transformation which Boscovich attempts to establish as a 'law of continuity' that can used as a foundation for a theory of forces. Transformations, bound by continuity, are formalized by a series of eleven rules. To support his law and to make clear the process of using it, Boscovich provides many geometric examples.||Though based in mathematics (geometry), Boscovich asserts that the law of continuity can be applied outside a purely geometric setting to those phenomena in natural philosophy that can be modeled with mathematics.
BP_Reference(s): Boscovich‚Äôs geometrical principle of continuity, and the 'mysteries of the infinity'|Del Centina, A., Fiocca, A.|In: <i> Historia Mathematica<i>, Vol 45, 2018, pp 131-175.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Francois De Bremond (1713-1742) Member of the French Academy of Sciences, translator. With notes by Nicolas Desmarest (1725-1815) French geologist and contributor to the Encyclop√©die.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: French translation of the second edition of Hauksbee‚Äôs <i>Physico-mechanical experiments<i> of 1719.
BP_Description_1: French translation of the second edition of Hauksbee‚Äôs <i>Physico-mechanical Experiments<i> of 1719. The manuscript of the translation was found in Francois De Bremond's papers after his death. Desmarest reorganized the material, added a considerable number of notes, and saw the work through the press. Desmarest's extensive notes are particularly interesting for their explanation of Hauksbee's experiments and what can be interpreted from their results. The work received a 9-page very favorable review and summary in the Journal des Scavans of April 1756. The reviewer remarks: 'The notes and additions of M. Desmarest are printed in characters so minute and so tight that they could be used in another form to fill a considerable volume.'
BP_Description_2: Francois De Bremond's text is a translation of the posthumous second edition of the <i>Physico-Mechanical Experiments<i> of 1709. Hauksbee's book presents experiments and resulting propositions regarding electricity and the generation of 'barometric light', sometimes referred to as 'mercurial light.'  These experiments involved partial vacuum, static electricity, and what is now recognized as electro-luminescence of low-pressure discharges. The experiments and apparatus are described in great detail, with elaborate engraved figures. Taken together, the discussions present a theory of electricity and established a source of light that challenged current theories about the nature of light. Hauksbee used an air pump of his own design and construction to evacuate rotatable glass globes and cylinders, creating 'a fine purple light' inside them by rubbing the outside surface. The light would disappear gradually when air was let into the vessels, but at atmospheric pressure, rubbing (and so electrifying) the glass would enable it to attract woolen threads, etc. Hauksbee reports a series of experiments in optics, some of them concerning the refraction indices for a variety of substances, as measured by Snell‚Äôs law. In one such experiment he determined the indices for common air, vacuum and compressed air, using a hollow prism as well as an air pump and a condensing engine. He also developed a special instrument, made up of the prism, a stopcock, a gauge and a telescope. The supplement (100 pages) contained in this edition adds experiments to measure the refractive power of liquids, attempts to generate mercurial light with sulfur and metals, and other experiments involving specific gravity, electrostatics, and capillarity. The extensive added in the form of notes by Desmarest make this essentially a new work.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Francis Hauksbee and his air pump|Brundtland, T.|<i>Notes and Records of The Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 66, 2012, pp 253-272.||Early Electricity between Chemistry and Physics: The Simultaneous Itineraries of Francis Hauksbee, Samuel Wall, and Pierre Polini√®re|Freudenthal, G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 2, 1981, pp 203-229.||Francis Hauksbee's theory of electricity|Home, R.W.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 4, No 3, 1967, pp 203‚Äì217.

BP_Short or Common Title: Anm√§rkning vid Brytnings-Lagen af s√§rskilta slags Ljus-str√•lar
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Samuel Klingenstierna's remarkable paper disproving Newton's assertion that chromatic dispersion and refraction were linked such that no series of refractions could bring light of 'different colors' to the same point of focus.
BP_Description_1: Samuel Klingenstierna's remarkable paper disproving Newton's assertion that chromatic dispersion and refraction were linked such that no series of refractions could bring light of 'different colors' to the same point of focus. That is, an image produced by lenses will always exhibit chromatic aberration. Newton's assertion arose from experiment 8 of Book I, Part II of the Opticks of 1704 and carried such authority that until Klingenstierna's paper was widely known, it was believed that no achromatic lensed instrument was possible. John Dollond and Leonhard Euler had a famous exchange regarding the correctness of Newton's experiment and after Klingenstierna reading this, he produced a Latin translation of his paper and, via his student Fredrik Mallet, sent it to John Dollond. Dollond wrote back to Klingenstierna: 'As soon therefore as I saw Reason to doubt of Sr. Isaac, I thought it high time to begin to think for my sled, and endeavor to find out the truth by Experiment.' A German translation of Klingenstierna's paper appeared in 1756 in the ongoing German translation of the proceedings of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences produced by Abraham Kastner. It by Kastner's translation that Klingenstierna's startling result became widely known.
BP_Description_2: Samuel Klingenstierna's analysis of Newton's assertion of the proportionality of refractive indices involved in refraction-dispersion rests on a simplified experiment considered by Klingenstierna: a wedge of glass with air above and water below. The sine law of refraction, the refractive indices, and the angle of the glass wedge, give the angles that describe a light rays air-prism-water path. All these are used to construct an ingenious geometric analog involving triangles within circular arcs. Klingenstierna used this to give a simple demonstration that Newton's statement regarding the proportionality of refractive indices could not be true in general, and applied only for prisms of small angle, and then only approximately.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  Samuel Klingenstierna and the Acchromatic Lens|Beckman, O.|<i>Journal of the Antique Telescope Society<i>, Vol 22, 2002, pp 9-16.||Skating on the Edge: Newton's Investigation of Chromatic Dispersion and Achromatic Prisms and Lenses|Shapiro, A.E.|In: <i>Wrong for the right Reasons<i>, Buchwald, J.Z., and Franklin, A., editors|Springer, 2005, pp 99-125.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A general course of philosophy for university students, generally following the Ratio Studiorum of the Jesuits.
BP_Description_1: A general course of philosophy for university students, generally following the Ratio Studiorum of the Jesuits, but with a significant increase in attention to Particular Physics and a lessening of that paid to Aristotelian General Physics. Editions appeared in 1750 and 1754.
BP_Description_2: A general course of philosophy for university students. Six volumes cover: Logic, metaphysics, general physics, particular physics 1, particular physics 2, ethic and morals. The optics material (volume 4, 104 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light, light as movement in a fiery or luminiferous aether, supporting phenomena; reflection, laws of reflection; refraction, laws of refraction; transparent and opaque bodies; color, color as variation in light's vibrations; Newton's opinion on color and its refutation. The material is Cartesian-Eulerian or Experimental-Cartesian, descriptive, and non-mathematical, with the only very occasional use of elementary geometry. Only physical optics is treated; no geometrical optics is presented. The style is Scholastic: propositions, objections, discussion, proofs, conclusions. Even at this late date, Lemonnier presents, describes and then rejects peripatetic ideas regarding light; generally adopting a late Cartesianism.
BP_Reference(s): The Notion of Experimental Physics in Early Eighteenth-Century France|Home, R.W.|In: <i>Change and Progress in Modern Science<i>, Reidel Publishing, 1985, pp 107-131.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A dissertation that discusses Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's theory on the nature of light.
BP_Description_1: A dissertation that discusses Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's theory on the nature of light. As was often the case, the dissertation was actually written by the student‚Äôs director; in this case, Carolo Benvenuti, SJ. This was one of two dissertations directed by Benvenuti, a pupil of Bo≈°koviƒá, that were presented in 1754. The other was <i>Synopsis Physic√¶ Generalis<i> and prompted the Jesuit superiors to attempt to suppress Bo≈°koviƒá's ideas.
BP_Description_2: A dissertation examining color and Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's theory on the nature of light. I: Properties of light. II: Colors in thin transparent films from refraction and transmission. An analysis of 'Newton's Rings.' III: Colors from thick transparent films. IV: Natural colors, the nature of light, and the cause of their properties. Early ideas regarding spectroscopy are presented, based (naturally) on the color appearance of the light (not its wavelength); light and its component colors being defined by the amount the colors are refracted in a standard optical arrangement and their intensity.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of a Theory: A Provisional Syllabus of Boscovich Literature, 1746-1800|Baldini, U.|In: <i>The Jesuits II: Cultures, Sciences, and the Arts, 1540-1773<i>|O'Malley SJ, J.W., Bailey, G.A., Harris, S.J., and Kennedy SJ, T.F., editors|University of Toronto Press, 2006, pp 405-450.||Early reception of Boskovic's natural philosophy: the 'Benvenuti case'|Martinovic, I.|<i>Synthesis Philosophica<i>, Vol 8, 1993, pp307-333.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An exposition and attack on Newtonian optics.
BP_Description_1: A passionate, table-banging, somewhat ill-informed attack on Newtonian optics. Unlike the furor caused by Giovanni Rizzetti's attack on Newton's optics, the <i>De Luminis Affectionibus<i> of 1727, Cominale's attack appears to have been ignored. To be expected, perhaps; by the middle of the 18th century, Newtonian optics was widely accepted in Italy. A century later in <i>A Budget of Paradoxes<i> the mathematician Augustus De Morgan would quip regarding Cominale's work: 'The first volume upsets the theory of light; the second vacuum, <i>vis inertiae<i>, gravitation, and attraction. I confess I never attempted these big Latin volumes, numbering 450 closely-printed quarto pages. The man who slays Newton in a pamphlet is the man for me. But I will lend them to anybody who will give security, himself in ¬£500, and two sureties in ¬£250 each, that he will read them through, and give a full abstract; and I will not exact security for their return. I have never seen any mention of this book: it has a printer, but not a publisher, as happens with so many unrecorded books.' The third volume, included here, is exceedingly rare and dated 1769.
BP_Description_2: An exposition and attack on Newtonian optics in 15 chapters. Chapters 1-4: nature of light; propagation, refraction, and reflection of light. Chapters 5-8: Newton's theory of color, its exposition, its refutation. Chapter 9: A new theory of Color. Chapters 10-13: Newton's experimental results shown to be wrong by new, counter experiments. Chapter 14: The rainbow. Chapter 15: Permanent colors. The first four chapters are an elementary presentation of light and its properties. The remaining chapters attempt to refute the idea that white light or sunlight is an inhomogeneous compound of diverse colors. The new theory of color that is offered is a modification of Malenbranche's Cartesian idea of modified size and vibration of light particles. Following Giovanni Rizzetti, Cominale reported experiments and described results that refuted Newton's experiments with prismatic refraction and dispersion. These experiments are either difficult to understand or have results that have clearly been misinterpreted.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of Newtonian Optics in Italy|Casini, P.|In: <i>Renaissance and Revolution: Humanists, Scholars, Craftsmen and Natural Philosophers<i>|Cambridge University Press, 1993, pp 215-228.
BP_Title: Anti-Newtonianismi Pars Prima, In qua Newtoni de coloribus systema ex propriis principiis geometrice evertitur, et nova de coloribus theoria luculentissimis experimentis demonstratur.  Pars Secunda, In qua Rejectis methodo, et philosophandi regulis Newtonianis, Totiusque Sectae Principiis Indicateis Evertitur prae caeteris, argumentis utplurimum ex adversariorum penu depromptis, vacuum, vis inertiae, mutua gravitas, et attractio. Pars Tertia. In qua Virium Universi Natura, Origo, Mensura, Propagatio &c, Enucleantur. Opera ac Studio Caelestini Cominale M.D. In Regio Archi-Gymnasio Neapolitano Philosophiae Professoris.

Part 3: In Which the Nature, Origin, Measure, Propabation, etc. of the Universal Power is Enunciated.  The Work and Study of Celestine Cominale M.D., Professor of Philosophy in the Royal Neapolitan High School.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicain,academic, private teacher. Taught at the Universities of Rome, Bologna, Padua, Pisa. Famously attacked Newton's theory of colors.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Part of a series of textbooks for use in Jesuit universities, the <i>Physica Particularis<i> adheres to the Ratio Studiorum and the constituion for Jesuit Schools promulgated by Geronimo Nadal nearly two centuries earlier.
BP_Description_1: As with many Jesuits, Andreas Jaszlinszky wrote a series of textbooks for use in the university where he taught. The <i>Physica Particularis<i> is one in a series that covered most of philosophy, adhering to the <i>Ratio Studiorum<i> and the constituion for Jesuit Schools promulgated by Geronimo Nadal nearly two centuries earlier. Jaszlinszky rejected Newtonian physics, remaining a Cartesian and, to some extent, an Aristotelian in that he kept the old structure of General Physics and Particular Physics. The texts give evidence of the lingering Cartesianism and Experimental-Cartesianism in Europe, particularly in the Jesuit schools.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Physicae Generalis<i> of Andreas Jaszlinszky covers: nature and properties of bodies; elementary fire; air; water and earth; composition of bodies; inertia, attraction, gravity; cohesion, elasticity, transparency of bodies; motion; fluids and their motion; qualities of bodies presented to the senses; sound; light and lights; color. The optics material (45 pages) covers: nature of light and luminous phenomena; various opinions on the nature of light; propagation of light; reflection on polished surfaces, law of reflection; refraction and the law of refraction; color and color phenomena; color of bodies; color sensation; arguments regarding the nature of color. The material is elementary, Cartesian-Aristotelian, descriptive, non-mathematical. The form is Scholastic: propositions, objections, responses, proofs, conclusions. The style is baroque; Jaszlinszky is fond of elaborately twisted questions and answers.
BP_Reference(s): A felvid√©ki fizika t√∂rt√©nete 1850-ig (A History of Physics in Upper Hungary to 1850)|Jol√°n Zempl√©n|<i>A Magyar Tudom√°nyt√∂rt√©neti int√©zet Tudom√°nyos k√∂zlem√©nyei<i>, No 122, p 441.|http://real.mtak.hu/34201/1/122_zemplen_fizika.pdf

BP_Title English Translation: Instruction in Physics Part Two, or Particular Physics. Concisely Arragned for the Use of Pupils. By Reverend Father Andrea Jaszlinszky of the Society of Jesus, Teacher of Philosophy, Public and Ordinary Professor of the Same in the University of Trnava.
BP_Biographical Statement: Hungarian Jesuit, acadmic. Taught at the University of Trnava, textbook author, a lingering Cartesian.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Abraham Kastner's adaptation, recension, and translation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Optics<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: Abraham Kastner's adaptation, recension, and translation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Optics<i> of 1738. Kastner omits most of Smith's material on the discoveries made with the telescope in Book 4 and substitutes material on the propagation of light; something related to the debate regarding the wave or particle nature of light and of keen interest in the middle of the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: Abraham Kastner's translated interpretation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Optics<i> keeps its structure, approximately.  Book 1 Experiments: light, direct, reflected, refracted;  mirrors and glasses, the eye and vision, reflections in mirrors, perceptions, origins and causes of color; cause of refraction, reflection, and emission of light; transparency, opacity, and colors of bodies. Book 2 The Geometry of Light: Analytical catoptrics, reflection on curved surfaces, theory of conical and cylindrical mirrors and their images; Analytical Dioptrics, refraction at planar and spherical surfaces, apparent large size of objects seen in one or more lenses; theories of the telescope; theory of the microscope; burning lenses; the rainbow; general properties of foci and images; apparent size, shape, and position of objects seen in lenses or mirrors. Book 3 Manufacture of Optical instruments: grinding and polishing metal mirrors, objective lenses; quadrants; sectors; Newtonian telescopes; binoculars; magic lanterns and solar microscopes; microscopes. Book 4: Propagation of Light. Notes:  On Books 1, 2, and 3; Jurin's notes on distinct and indistinct vision, general analytic theory of perspective, additional notes.
BP_Reference(s): Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first comprehensive, detailed anatomical description of the eye and the orbit.
BP_Description_1: The first comprehensive, detailed anatomical description of the eye and the orbit. The illustrations were engraved by Joel Paul Kaltenhofer and the book is dedicated to the Chancellor of the University of G√∂ttingen, Baron G.A. von Muenchhausen. Editions appeared in 1755 and 1780.
BP_Description_2: Johann Gottfried Zinn's comprehensive anatomical description of the eye and the orbit in 13 chapters: sclera, choroid, ciliary body, iris, retina, vitreous humor, crystalline lens, aqueous humor, eye muscles, optic nerve, ocular arteries, ocular veins, eyelids, lacrimal glands and ducts. The striking, elaborate figures are keyed to and accompanied by 14 pages of descriptions. Perhaps most importantly, Zinn showed that the optic nerve is a collection of fibers continuous with the fibers of the retina. Other anatomical discoveries were named after him: the zonules of Zinn, and the annulus of Zinn.
BP_Reference(s): Johann Gottfried Zinn|Strabismus , Vol 12, No 2, 2004 pp 124-125.||Should the annular tendon of the eye be named ‚Äòannulus of Zinn‚Äô or ‚Äòof Valsalva‚Äô?|<i>Acta Ophthalmologica<i>, Vol 93, No 1, 2015, pp 97-99.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A complete analysis of lenses used primarily as objectives for telescopes, before Dollond's work on achromatic lenses and before Klingenstierna's demonstration that contrary to Newton's assertion, achromatic lens systems were theoretically possible.
BP_Description_1: This was written and published before Boscovich traveled to France and England and before he learned of Clairaut's and Dollond's work on achromatic lenses. It is likely that at the time, Boscovich did not know of Klingenstierna's demonstration that contrary to Newton's assertion, achromatic lens systems were theoretically possible. Thus, this dissertation describes the state of the art of telescope lens analysis and design immediately before the development of the achromatic telescope objective. It is in this work that the importance of knowing the index of refraction of materials emerges for Boscovich; something that will be central to his remaining work in optics. This dissertation is important in that it is among the first works to quantify the effects of aberrations and uncertainty on astronomical observations.
BP_Description_2: A complete analysis of lenses used primarily as objectives for telescopes. Material includes: refraction at spherical glass surfaces; real and virtual images; equations relating lens curvature and foci for convex and concave figures; equations applied to lens design, examples; spherical and chromatic aberrations and their quantification; optics of the eye and eye-function; ocular images and lenses; ocular images, lenses, and the uses of telescopes; consequences of lens aberrations; aberrations and their effect on astronomical observations. Boscovich mentions Euler's 1747 claim regarding the achromatic nature of water-separated glass menisci modeled after the apparent achromatic optics of the eye, but given British and French work, considered this a vain hope.
BP_Reference(s): R. G. Boscovich and the Measurement of the Refractive Quality of Lenses|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana<i>, Vol 60, No 4, p 837-888.
BP_Title: De Lentibus et Telescopiis Dioptricis Dissertatio. Auctore P. Rogerios Josepho Boscovich S.J. Publico Mathesos Professore in Collegio Romano.
BP_Title English Translation: A Dissertation on Lenses and Dioptric Telescopes. Author: Father Rudjer Josip Boskovic, SJ.  Public Professor of Mathematics in the Collegio Romano.
BP_Biographical Statement: Croation Jesuit, natural philosopher, astronomer, mathematician. Inventive, prolific, peripatetic.

BP_Author full name: Abb√© Nicolas Louis de La Caille
BP_Author last name first: La Caille, Abb√© Nicolas Louis de
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An expansion of the optics textbook that De La Caille published in 1750, with an added third section on perspective.
BP_Description_1: This is an expansion of the optics textbook that De La Caille published in 1750, just before he left for his four year stay at the Cape of Good Hope to astronomically survey the Southern sky. On his return he produced this, a second edition, reusing the two sections of the 1750 with some expansion, and adding a third section on perspective. The 24 'Diverse Questions on Optics' at the end of the second part reveal not only what topics were considered important at the time but also how De La Caille thought as a teacher, using practical problems to exercise a students‚Äô understanding, and why his textbooks were so popular. Preceding his optics text, De La Caille had also produced textbooks on mathematics (1741), mechanics (1743), and astronomy (1746); all of them written for use at the Mazarin College. They were written in French, widely used, appeared in several editions. Though revised periodically to update the content, the enduring value of the text rested on its pedagogical structure and use of examples. It was an actively used textbook for more than 50 years. Editions appeared in 1750, 1756, 1764, 1766, 1773, 1802, 1808. A Latin translation appeared in 1757.
BP_Description_2: De la Caille's textbook on optics is in three parts. I Optics: demonstration principles on which optics is based, properties of light, of shadow, nature and properties of light related to vision and colors, perception. II: Catoptrics and Dioptrics: images and foci, laws of catoptrics and dioptrics derived from experiments, catoptric images and foci, plane and curved mirrors, dioptric images and foci, lenses, double refraction, vision and correcting spectacles, telescopes and microscopes, construction of telescopes and microscopes, optical problems, imperfections and their remedy, use and application of telescopes and microscopes, diverse optical questions. III Perspective: general principles, practical methods of perspective, shadows, light and shadows caused by the sun, light and shadows caused by a lamp. The material is almost entirely on geometric optics, is empirical in nature, and focused on instruments. Within that scope it is detailed, analytic, and supported by examples and detailed figures. Physical optics and color are mentioned only in passing; color being attributed to different 'species of light rays.'
BP_Reference(s): Teaching the mathematical sciences in France during the eighteenth century: a few examples from some of the most used textbooks|Confalonieri, S.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Third International Conference on the History of Mathematics Education<i>|Bjarnad√≥ttir, K., editor|University of Uppsala, 2015, pp 137-150.
BP_Title: Le√ßons Elementaires d'Optique. Par M. l'Abbe de la Caille, de l'Academie Royale des Sciences, de celles de Prusse, de Suede, and de l'Institut de Bologne; Professeur de Mathematiques au college Mazarin. Nouvelle Edition, revue, corregee & augmentee.
BP_Title English Translation: Elementary Lessons in Optics. By the Abbe de la Caille, of the Royal Academy of Sciences, those of Prussia and Sweden, and of the Institute of Bologna; Professor of Mathematics in the College of Mazarin. New Edition, Reviewed, Corrected, and Augmented.
BP_Biographical Statement: French deacon, astronomer, mathematician. Unwearying astonomical observer, calculator, textbook author.
BP_Provenance: Bookplates of the Turner Collection at the University of Keele and of the Marchese di Salza
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1756 La Caille - Le√ßons Elementaires d'Optique - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian translation of Abb√© Jean-Antoine Nollet's <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i> of 1745, explanatory text to accompany his course of lectures in physics.
BP_Description_1: Nollet was the leading experimental physicist for thirty years in mid-eighteenth-century France. His course of lectures, aimed at upper-class Parisian society, was accompanied by elaborate, if not spectacular, demonstrations of physical principles and the use of experimental apparatus. This was the source for the <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i>, which became as famous as the course itself and was the first step in establishing experimental physics in France. Nollet's work expressed in the <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i> led to a reorientation of physics teaching in French universities and was the model for a new generation of French physics textbooks, replacing those of Poliniere and Rohault. Though Nollet's physics was experimental, it was not, inherently, mathematical. He considered algebra and geometry helpful, but not essential.  The <i>Le√ßons de Physique<i> also had considerable influence outside France: in Italy, Spain, and Germany. Editions appeared at Paris 1743, 1745, 1749, 1754, 1759, 1764, 1767, 1771, 1775, 1783; at Amsterdam 1745, 1754,  and 1765;  in an Italian translation at Venice in 1746, 1751, and 1759; in a German translation at Erfurt in 1749; and in a Spanish translation at Madrid in 1757.
BP_Description_2: Explanatory text to accompany a course of lectures in physics. The material covered includes: material bodies and their properties; simple and compound motion under central forces; gravity; hydrostatics; mechanics; nature and properties of air; nature and properties of water; nature and properties of fire; light and optics; stars and their movement; magnetism; electricity. All of tome five is devoted to optics (579 pages).  It includes: the nature, properties, and propagation of light; catoptrics, plane and spherical mirrors and their images; dioptrics, refraction, lenses and their images; color and differing refraction; vision, the eye, eye-function; spectacles, microscopes, telescopes, and the magic lantern. Nollet used large sections of Newton's Optice dealing with prismatic colors, the heterogeneity of white light, and differing refrangibility. Nollet did not accept the corpuscular theory of light proposed in Newton's Queries, presenting instead a modified form of Descartes' ideas. Forty-one experiments are described in the text, demonstrating each principal idea. The presentation is detailed, geometric, and accompanied by detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Notion of Experimental Physics in Early Eighteenth-Century France|Home, R.W.|In: <i>Change and Progress in Modern Science<i>|Reidel Publishing, 1985, pp 107-131.
BP_Title: Lezioni di fisica sperimentale del signor abate Nollet, Membro dell' Accademia Reale delle Scienze, della Real Societa de Londra, dell' Instituto di Bologna, e Maestro de Fisica del Delfino, e Regio Professore de Fisica Sperimentae nel Collegio di Navarra. Tradotte dal francese. Tomo Quinto Parte Seconda.
BP_Title English Translation: Lessons in Experimental Physics of the Abbe Nollet, Member of the Royal Academy of Sciences, the Royal Society of London, the Institue of Bologna, and Physics Master to the Dauphin, and Royal Professor of Experimental Physics in the College of Navarre. Translated from the French. Volumen Five, Part Two.
BP_Biographical Statement: French cleric, natural philosopher, teacher. Famed and gifted electrical experimentalist, lecturer, textbook author.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate removed from titlepage verso
BP_Plates: Part 1: Plates [1-4, 1-10] all folding|Part 2: Plates [1-10] all folding

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An attempt at a comprehensive compendium of optics by way of an elaborate compilation of material from many sources.
BP_Description_1: The authorship of <i>VollstaÃàndiges Lehrgeb√§ude der ganzen Optik<i> is attributed to a C.L. Deneke, based solely on a listing of new books in volume 84 of the <i>Neue Genealogisch-Historische Nachrichten<i>, 'New Genealogical Historical News', of 1757 from publisher Johann Samuel Heinius. It lists the book as being available at the Leipzig 'Jubilate-Messe" (Spring trade fair) that year in Heinius' bookshop.||The title page shows only 'C.L.D.' as the author. The book was reviewed anonymously in the Gottingische Anzeigen of June 1757 and very negatively by Abraham K√§stner in the Hamburgisches Magazin for 1757. Deneke's book is an elaborate compilation of material on many topics in optics from many sources--often quoted at length, without comment or assessment. Fifty-five authors and works are cited as references. The central interest is the utility and application of optics; the work presents almost no theory, but an abundance of detail is supplied regarding some aspects of optical instruments. As the list of contents shows, the structure is scattered and appears driven by the source Deneke accessed, rather than any specific plan. A strange book without any apparent influence.
BP_Description_2: An attempt at a comprehensive compendium of optics. The book is in three parts. Part I Optics: the eye and eye function, optical experiments, optical instruments, anamorphosis, anamorphic adjustment of images in a plane, in a cone, and in a pyramid. Part II Catoptrics: mirrors, material and forms of mirrors, plane mirrors and experiments, anamorphosis with plane mirrors, spherical mirrors, concave and convex mirrors, preparing and polishing mirrors, mirror experiments, anamorphosis and curved mirrors. Part III Dioptrics: refraction, figuring and polishing lenses and prisms and menisci, experiments with images and foci, the microscope and objective lenses, compound microscope, telescopes, helioscopes, periscopes, micrometers, camera obscura, experiments, the magic lantern. The material, though detailed, is elementary and descriptive; no mathematics of any kind is used. Much of the material, all the tables of data, and most of the figures are simply copied from other sources.
BP_Reference(s): Neue Genealogisch-Historische Nachrichten, neunzehntn bandes viertes stuck, 1757, pp 408-428. (This is Abraham K√§stner's review)||Gottingische Anzeigen, 74 Stuck, June 1757, pp 724-728. (The anonymous review)
BP_Title: VollstaÃàndiges Lehrgeb√§ude der ganzen Optik. oder, der Sehe=Spiegel=und Strahlbrech=Kunst, darinn die GruÃànde derselben Theoretisch und Practisch, vorgetragen, die Verfertigung der Maschinen und Instrumente, die Zubereitung aller Arten von Spiegeln und optischen GlaÃàsern, deutlich gelehret, auch der Gebrauch derselben bey den Experimenten.
