BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A Latin translation of Nicolas de La Caille's <i>Le√ßons Elementaires D'Optique<i> of 1756 and a short treatise by Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá on the telescope micrometer objective.
BP_Description_1: A Latin translation of Nicolas de La Caille's <i>Le√ßons Elementaires D'Optique<i> of 1756. Included is a short treatise by Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá on the telescope micrometer objective. This is an expansion of the optics textbook that De La Caille published in 1750, just before he left for his four year stay at the Cape of Good Hope to astronomically survey the Southern sky. On his return he produced this, a second edition, reusing the two sections of the 1750 with some expansion, and adding a third section on perspective. The 24 'Diverse Questions on Optics' at the end of the second part reveal not only what topics were considered important at the time but also how De La Caille thought as a teacher, using practical problems to exercise a students‚Äô understanding, and why his textbooks were so popular. Preceding his optics text, De La Caille had also produced textbooks on mathematics (1741), mechanics (1743), and astronomy (1746); all of them written for use at the Mazarin College. They were written in French, widely used, appeared in several editions. Editions of the optics text appeared in 1750, 1756, 1764, 1766, 1773, 1802, 1808. This Latin translation appeared in 1757, 1766 and again at Venice in 1773.
BP_Description_2: De la Caille's textbook on optics is in three parts. I Optics: demonstration principles on which optics is based, properties of light, of shadow, nature and properties of light related to vision and colors, perception. II: Catoptrics and Dioptrics: images and foci, laws of catoptrics and dioptrics derived from experiments, catoptric images and foci, plane and curved mirrors, dioptric images and foci, lenses, double refraction, vision and correcting spectacles, telescopes and microscopes, construction of telescopes and microscopes, optical problems, imperfections and their remedy, use and application of telescopes and microscopes, diverse optical questions. III Perspective: general principles, practical methods of perspective, shadows, light and shadows caused by the sun, light and shadows caused by a lamp. The material is almost entirely on geometric optics, is empirical in nature, and focused on instruments. Within that scope it is detailed, analytic, and supported by examples and detailed figures. Physical optics and color are mentioned only in passing; color being attributed to different 'species of light rays.'||The Bo≈°koviƒá essay describes a telescope micrometer using two sliding half-lenses; the upper and lower halves separate the focused image horizontally, and from the separation of the lenses the size of a single object or the distance separating two objects can be determined.
BP_Reference(s): Teaching the mathematical sciences in France during the eighteenth century: a few examples from some of the most used textbooks|Confalonieri, S.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Third International Conference on the History of Mathematics Education<i>|Bjarnad√≥ttir, K., editor|University of Uppsala, 2015, pp 137-150.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian, with a basis that is essentially Cartesian.
BP_Description_1: Third, posthumous impression of the first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Tosca wrote for his students, and the style and clarity of the books benefited from his long practice in teaching. The nine volumes are meant to cover all of mathematics and philosophy: I Arithmetic and Geometry, II Algebra and music, III Trigonometry and conics, IV Statics and Hydrostatics, V Civil and Military Architecture, VI Optics and Meteorics, VII Astronomy, VIII Geography and Navigation, IX Gnomics and Astrology. Tosca's textbooks were widely used and responsible, in part, for the introduction of modern science in Spain. The volumes of the first edition appeared at Valentia between 1707 and 1715. It was reprinted in Madrid in 1727 and 1757.
BP_Description_2: The first teaching compendium of natural philosophy in Castilian. Volume six contains five sections on optics and meteorics, treatises XVIII - XXII. Section I Optics: general considerations and definitions; nature and propagation of light; nature of colors; transparent and opaque bodies; view and vision; eye-function; perception of size and shape; binocular vision. Section II Perspective: principles, iconographic and orthographic projection; methods for representing objects in various orientations; linear perspective; perspective of light, shadow, and reflected bodies; perspective of curved surfaces. Section III Catoptrics: general considerations an definitions; plane mirrors and their properties; convex and concave mirrors; cylindrical mirrors; spherical mirrors, caustics. Section IV Dioptrics:  refraction and its effects; cause and properties of refraction; location of refracted images; refractive glasses and their properties; combining refracting bodies; convex lenses, concave lenses; refraction and the generation of colors. Section V Meteorics: the sea and the wind; atmosphere and clouds, all type of precipitation; lighting; lights generated in the air; the rainbow; other forms of light; comets. Though the basis is essentially Cartesian, also cited are Grimaldi, Kircher, Scheiner, Zahn, Dechales, Rheyta, Zucchi, but not Huygens (1690) or Newton (1704). The wave and corpuscular theories of the nature of light are presented, but each is considered unproven. Color theory follows Pardies and is a hybrid of Aristotelian and Cartesian. The material is detailed, descriptive, and presented with little mathematics.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Antonio Matani (1730 - 1779)  Italian scholar, natural philosopher.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A redaction of Euclid's optics, meant as a brief introduction, produced by Damianus of Larrisa who edited the early Greek text of Heliodorus.
BP_Description_1: Damianus of Larrisa was (perhaps) the son or pupil of Heliodorus of Larrisa and edited the earlier Greek text of Heliodorus. All this is inferred from the title of the most complete title of extant manuscripts: Chapters of the Optical Hypotheses of Damianus of Heliodorus of Larissa. It is a redaction of Euclid's Optica, tinctured with a bit of optics from late antiquity, and apparently meant only as a brief introduction to optics. Its outline form and nature suggests that is was a prelude to a larger work. The Greek text is followed by Antonio Matani's slightly edited Latin translation of Egnatius Danti of 1573 and some notes added by Matani.
BP_Description_2: A redaction of Euclid's optics, meant as a brief introduction. The central premise is the identity of sight and light. There are 15 chapters.  1: Sight is something emitted from the eye. 2: What the eye emits is light or visual rays. 3: Sight moves in straight lines. 4-5: Visual rays comprise a right-angled cone. 6: The cone of vision is a discrete set of rays. 7: A viewed object is seen under an acute or right angle. 8: What is seen from a larger angle seems larger. 9: We see best along the axis of the cone. 10: Visual power is greatest in front of us. 11: The vertex of the visual cone is inside the pupil. 12: We see either directly or by rays broken by reflection or refraction. 13: Visual and solar rays behave similarly. 14: Our visual rays are reflected at equal angles. 15: Similarly for solar rays. The Greek and Latin text is followed by notes in which Matani discusses the history of Euclid's idea of visual rays emitted by the eye and how it was treated by subsequent authors. This is followed by a letter to the Archbishop of Turin discussing Heliodorus and a few others.

BP_Short or Common Title: Les propri√©t√©s remarquables de la route de la lumi√®re
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mathematical analysis of refraction through spherically concentric layered media with applications to atmospheric refraction.
BP_Description_1: It is know from Lambert's Monatsbuch (monthly diary) that he began working on aspects of refraction through the atmosphere in 1752, and from 1754 this work was carried out in parallel with his work on photometry. On the general subject of atmospheric refraction, Lambert cites the work of Bouguer, Smith, K√§stner, and in particular, Giovanni Domenico Cassini. He also cites a memoir by Euler on a related subject. Unlike previous work and unlike other optical work at the time, Lambert does not find it necessary to posit a theory of the nature of light to produce practical work in optics. His approach is what is now called phenomenological. He adopted the same stance in his <i>Photometria<i> of 1760. Optical phenomena can be measured, studied, and mathematicized without having to know their underlying physical nature or cause. In his Review of Optics, which serves as a preface, Lamber mentions the studies of authors listed above and the many phenomena that need examining. He notes that: 'The only case, which seemed even less examined, is the one where the light passes successively through several spherical and concentric media. I have tried in this treatise to make up for this defect'.||Lambert wrote to produce solutions to practical problems in astronomy and geodesy, specifically to provide equations that could be used to correct observations and measurements for atmospheric refraction. Consequently, his approach to optics is purely mathematical, and in the present work invokes physical experiment infrequently, and then only to gather phenomenological data. Following Euclid and to some extent Newton, Lambert proceeds by 'experiments', 'theorems', 'proofs', 'corollaries', 'lemmas', 'propositions', 'problems' and 'solutions'. Though the work is based on geometry, Lambert invokes the calculus with an off-handedness uncommon at the time. Editions appeared in 1758 and 1759.
BP_Description_2: The book is divided into three parts: 1 'The general properties of the route which light takes, passing through refractive, spherical and concentric media'; 2 'Astronomical refractions, how to approximate them as exactly as desired, and how they relate to various other problems'; and 3 'Circular refractions, their use in determining terrestrial refractions, and various other problems depending on both astronomical and terrestrial refractions.' Beginning with Snell's law, the first part establishes a differential equation that defines a light path through layered refractive concentric spheres, showing that the total effect of multiple layers can be modeled with a single layer of appropriate refractive power.  Importantly, Lambert does not invoke any theory regarding refraction related to atmospheric density. The path is defined to be the arc of a circle and the analytic problem is that of determining its center and radius.  The second and third parts are applications of this theory to practical problems. In each situation, approximate integration of the governing differential equation gives the desired result, making effective use of infinite series for these tasks. These problems include correcting observed astronomical positions, estimating the effect of atmospheric refraction on near-horizon positions from measurements at higher elevations, determining the true height of large objects from optical measurements, and other geodesic problems. Lambert compares predictions from his equations with data when they are available.

Band 6. Munich, 1916.||<i>Photometry, Translated from the Latin Photometria<i>|DiLaura, D.L., translator|Illuminating Engineering Society, 2001, [ccxx]+423 pp.
BP_Title: Les propri√©t√©s remarquables de la route de la lumi√®re par les airs et en g√©n√©ral par plusieurs milieux r√©fringens sph√©riques et concentriques, avec la solution des probl√®mes qui y ont rapport, comme sont les refractions astronomique et terrestres, et ce qui en depend. Par J.H. Lambert.
BP_Title English Translation: The remarkable properties of the route of light through the air, and in general through several spherical and concentric refractive media, with the solution of related problems, such as astronomical and terrestrial refractions, and that which depends on them. By J.H. Lambert.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss mathematicain, natural pholosopher, experimentalist. Important and prolific author in many fields of natural philosophy.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of Boscovich's theory of everything: point entities interacting and agglomerating by why of a single attractive-repulsive force.
BP_Description_1: Boscovich's <i>Theoria<i> has it's origins 15 years prior to its publication when Boscovich was at the Collegio Romano. His investigations into optics, particularly refraction, posed  long-standing explanatory problems of cause and origin that had had no solution. The earliest version of Boscovich's force law appears in the <i>Dissertatio de Lumine<i> of 1748 and an early version of the famous oscillating plot of repulsive and attractive force appears here. These optical problems, others of a more general nature, and the ideas of force of Newton and monads of Leibniz, motivated his work on the <i>Theoria<i>. Its success was immediate and widespread and remains one of the most important books in science history. It was highly influential on British physicists: Priestley, Robinson, Faraday, Clerk Maxwell, Lord Kelvin, J. J. Thompson, and Niels Bohr. All acknowledged its importance. In 1898 Lord Kelvin said 'My present assumption is Boscovichianism pure and simple.' The importance of this theory was widely recognized; in Britain, the <i>Encyclopaedia Britannica<i> devoted fourteen pages to it in 1801. Boscovich had been the first supporter in Italy of Isaac Newton's theory of gravitation, and the <i>Theoria<i> was looked upon in Britain as an interesting speculative extension of the Newtonian system. Editions appeared at Vienna in 1758 and 1759 and revised edition at Venice in 1763.
BP_Description_2: Boscovich theory has two fundamental components: extentless indivisible points (his 'puncta') that constitute matter, and a single continuous force that is attractive or repulsive depending on distance. This force law is such that repulsion and attraction alternate as distance from the point increases; the oscillating plot of this force is perhaps the most famous figure from text and was often reproduced in subsequent works. As point separation becomes negligible, the repulsive force become infinitely large and so points cannot touch. As point separation grows, the repulsive diminishes until at greater distance it becomes attractive, and then farther out the force again becomes repulsive and so on alternatively, until it becomes permanently attractive at large separations. Boscovich conceived of this force has a 'single species' but with positive or negative effect.||At a definite set of distances from a points, the force is neither attractive or repulsive and so mutual positions of 'cohesion' can be established between points and so can remain at a fixed distance from each other, even though they are moving. This allows Boscovich's points to have definite fixed orbits around one another. So, for example, two points can have a third orbiting around them in an elliptical orbit, with the two points at the foci of the ellipse. This allowed Boscovich to posit the existence of higher-order structures (molecules) consisting of nothing put his extentless indivisible points and his force law.||There were many consequences to Boscovich's theory, which provided a complete mechanical explanation for all of natural philosophy. One was that it allowed Boscovich to offer the image of a super-powerful calculating intelligence  that if it knew the precise location and momentum of every particle in the universe, it could in principle calculate the history and future of every particle.  Boscovich's  formulation of this principle of determinism is in the <i>Theoria<i> and is rooted in and elaborated by physical terms--rather than metaphysical arguments--like position, velocity, direction and center of mass. He also showed that the continuity of force is a necessary assumption for determinism, which he presented it in strict mathematical form. Another consequence of the theory were natural or innate distances (for such things as orbits) which scale-free Newtonian force law does not provide. More speculatively, the theory allowed permeability and penetrability of 'solid' objects, the existence of hyperdense matter, and an explanation (as was Boscovich's original inspiration) for the phenomenon of optical refraction.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Roger Joseph Boscovich, S.J., F.R.S., 1711‚Äì1787: Studies of His Life and Work on the 250th Anniversary of His Birth <i>|Whyte, L.L., editor|Fordham University Press, New York, 1961, 230 pp.||<i>Roger Boscovich: The Founder of Modern Science<i>|Stoiljkovich, D.|Anderton, R., translator and editor|Pentnica Science Center, Valjevo, 2014, 92 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A  textbook for Mixed Mathematics that filled the need for a technical book in the vernacular in German universities, and furthered K√§stner's demonstration of the importance and utility of applied mathematics.
BP_Description_1: Between 1758 and 1769 Abraham K√§stner published four parts to his <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde<i> series: I Mathematics, II Applied Mathematics, III Analysis of the finite and infinite, IV Mechanics and Hydrodynamics. The <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde der angewandten Mathematik<i> is Part Two, consisting itself of two parts: aspects of mechanics and optics, and astronomy, geography, chronology and gnomics. K√§stner's text not only filled the need for a technical book in the vernacular in German universities, but also furthered his program to demonstrate the importance and utility of applied mathematics. The initial preliminary material meant that beginning students could start their study with mathematics, while advanced students could begin with its applications. Editions of the the <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde der angewandten Mathematik<i> appeared in 1759, 1765, 1780/1781, and 1792. Each edition has a new preface and contains revisions by K√§stner, clarifying proofs, updating or adding material. The widespread and continuing use of these texts was due, in part, to K√§stner's interest in making sure they were up to date. Thus, each edition gives an accurate idea of what was thought to be important to teach regarding natural philosophy.
BP_Description_2: A  textbook for mixed or applied mathematics with chapters entitled: Statics, Hydrostatics, Aerometry, Hydraulics, Optics, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Astronomy, Geography, Chronology, Gnomics, Artillery, Fortification, Construction. The three chapters on optics (87 pages) contain the following.  I Optics: nature and spread of light, parallel rays, shadows, camera obscura, images and perceptions. II Catoptrics: mirrors, law of reflection, plane mirrors, spherical mirrors, higher-order mirrors. III Dioptrics: refraction, refraction at air and glass, finding the refracted beam from the incident, total internal reflection, types of lenses, foci, image of a point, image of an object, color, the eye, eye-function and spectacles, the telescope, the microscope, diffraction of light. The material is descriptive, elementary and entirely geometrical-optical; physical optics and the nature of light are mentioned only very briefly, but the material on color is Newtonian.

‚ÄúMathematische Anfangsgr√ºnde‚Äù|Kr√∂ger, D.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Third International Conference on the History of Mathematics Education<i>, Bjarnad√≥ttir, K., Furinghetti, F., Prytz, J., Schubring, G., editors, Uppsala University, 2015, 424 p.|http://www.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:794222/FULLTEXT03.pdf#page=235||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A supplement to Martin's previous optics book of 1740, incorporating important developments in optics theory and instruments and his own work in microscopes.
BP_Description_1: Benjamin Martin intended this to be a supplement to his previous optics book of 1740. Important developments in theory and instruments had occurred in twenty years since the previous book, and his own work in microscopes had also advanced considerably, so a new book was desirable. Apparently, the new book was written in two stages, Parts I, II, and II appearing in 1759, and Parts IV, V, and VI written later. The last three parts appeared with their own, undated title page, but all six parts are usually found bound together with the original title page of 1759 and the second title page separating the two sections. As with the earlier text of 1740, the material is detailed and focused on the practical aspects of optics, particularly regarding the design, construction, and use of optical instruments. The basis for Martin's involvement in the controversy over John Dollond's patent of the crown-flint glass achromatic lens appears in the later chapters of Part III on chromatic aberration. The material is highly detailed, analytic, and clearly evidences Martin's significant practical experience with telescopes and microscopes. This is one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics; the list of such texts being short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799.
BP_Description_2: A text on the design, construction, and use of optical instruments, in six parts. Part I: Lens foci and telescope chromatic aberrations; objective lenses, images, field of view; structure, magnifying power, and use of the astronomical telescope; Galilean telescopes; four-glass telescopes, the refracting microscope. Part II: Theory of spherical aberrations in lenses, correcting and improving spherical aberration. Part III: Chromatic aberration and achromatic lenses; designing achromatic lenses; prismatic refraction; telescopes with achromatic lens combinations; catadioptric telescopes; imperfect images from lensed telescopes; superiority of reflecting telescopes, general equations for the design of mirrors and lenses; lenses of figures of conic sections. Part IV: General theory of dioptrics, Newton's dioptric experiments. Part V: The eye and vision; spectacles; theory of the telescope; simple and compound microscopes; spherical and chromatic aberrations in microscopes. Part VI: Experiments and calculations with prismatic refraction; Huygens' theory of spherical aberration; aberrations in compound object lens systems; achromatic lens systems in practice; new microscopes.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Benjamin Martin: Author, Instrument-Maker, and ‚ÄòCountry Showman‚Äô<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Nordhoff Publishing, Lyden, 1976, pp 108-114.||<i>Francis Watkins and the Dollond Telescope Patent Controversy<i>|Gee, B., edited by McConnell, A.|Routledge, 2014, p 424.||Benjamin Martin (1704-1782) and his Writings on the Eye and Eyeglasses|Goss, D.A.|<i>Journal of Optometry History<i>, Vol 41, No 2, 2010, pp 41-49.

BP_Short or Common Title: Het Regt Gebruik der Werelt Beschouwingen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Eighth edition of the text of 1714
BP_Description_1: Eighth edition of the text of 1715. A widely read and influential physico-teleological book. Quite apart from any teleological success it may have had in converting atheists and skeptics, it was important in the spreading of knowledge of natural philosophy. The descriptions are clear, accompanied by detailed figures, and the content correct and up-to-date by contemporary standards, setting out 'all the late discoveries in anatomy, philosophy, and astronomy.'
BP_Description_2: Nieuwentyt was seeking to demonstrate the existence of God by teleological argument See Entry 294.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 294.

BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch physician, mathematician, philosopher. Important author in teleology.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An account of the anatomy and physiology of the eye, light, and optics as related to vision.
BP_Description_1: An account of the anatomy and physiology of the eye, and extensive material on light and optics as related to vision and perception. Porterfield has extensive knowledge of ophthalmological history, quoting widely from previous authors and correcting several errors then lingering in ophthalmological books. He is also aware of then-current and latest information; this is particularly the case regarding the nature of light and colors. Porterfield reports many of his original experiments and results on visual physiology, which advanced that field considerably. Importantly, he argued against the too-extensive use of the analogy of the eye as a camera obscura: the Mind does not see the images on the retina. Porterfield also did important work in accommodation, eye movement, visual pathways and binocular vision. He utilized an experiment of Scheiner to create the optometer, an instrument used to determine the eye's focal distance. These were the many reasons why Thomas Young and Hermann von Helmholtz would later cite the great usefulness of Porterfield's book.
BP_Description_2: A general treatise on the eye, vision, light, and visual perception. Two Volumes in five books. Book I Subservient Eye Parts: eye brows, eye lashes, lachrymal glands and ducts. Book II Body of the Eye: placement, connection, and motion of the eyes; fabric and structure; tunics; cornea; choroid; pupil, retina and optic nerve; humors; crystalline lens. Book III Vision: nature and properties of light; ocular optics; adaptation; pupil motion; function of the retina and optic nerve. Book IV Animal eyes: differing placements and structures. Book V Visual Perception: two eyes resulting in a single perception; erect appearance of objects; color of objects; size of objects; distance of objects; orientation of objects; shape of objects; motion of objects. Many sections begin with a general review and consideration of past works and their authors; Porterfield is clearly knowledgeable of the history of ophthalmology, theories of light and color, and geometric optics. The material on light and color is entirely Newtonian, though many previous works and authors are cited.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Vision of William Porterfield|Wade, N.J.|In: <i>Brain, Mind and Medicine: Essays in Eighteenth-Century Neuroscience<i>|Whitaker, Smith, C.U.M., Finger, S., editors|Springer, 2007,  pp 163-176.
BP_Title: A treatise on the eye, The manner and phaenomena of vision. In two volumes. By William Porterfield, M.D. Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians at Edinburgh. Vol I.  "-Whence is it that Nature doeth mothing in vain, and whence arises all that Order and Beauty we see in the World? --How came the Bodies of Animals to be contrived with so much Art, and for what Ends were their several Parts? Was the Eye contrived without skill in Opticks, and the Ear without knowledge of Sounds? &c"  Newton's <i>Opticks<i>, Query 28.   Vol II. "Quid tam mirabile, quam particulam corporis quandam ita fabricatam esse, ut ejus opera animal sentiat procul positorum corporum figuram, positum, motum quemlibet, distantiam; idque etiant cum colorum varietate, quo distinctius ea dignosceret? Nihil est, in quo manifestius Geometriae artem Deus exercuerit." Hugenii Cosmotheoros, p. 40.
BP_Title English Translation: "For what can be more amazing, than that a Particle of Body should be so devised and framed, as by its means to show us the Shape, the Position, the Distance, and all the Motions, nay and all the [46] Colours, distinguishing of a Body that is far remote from us? There is nothing in Which God more Clearly Exercises the Art of Geometry"  Huygens, Cosmotheros.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish physician, ophthalmologist, professor at the University of Edinburgh.
BP_Publisher or Seller: A. Miller in London, Gavin Hamilton and John Balfour in Edinburgh

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of the most important and influential of the Newtonian textbooks. ¬¥s Gravesande based this on and condensed it from his <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> of 1720.
BP_Description_1: Fifth edition of 's Gravesande's <i>Philosophiae Newtonianae Institutiones<i>. After the second edition of 1728.
BP_Description_2: A handbook of physics covering: statics; dynamics; gravity; fluids; fire, heat, light, and electro-luminescence; optics; system of the world; and celestial motion. Like the third edition, the optics section is considerably expanded in this edition (229 pages) and includes: The nature, propagation, and speed of light; sunlight and heliostats; refraction, a goniometer for its measurement; refractions at surfaces, lenses; ocular anatomy and vision; spectacles, microscopes and telescopes; reflection, spherical convex and concave mirrors; catoptric telescopes; magic lantern; colors and differing refraction; colors by reflection and refraction; the rainbow; colors in nature. The main points are demonstrated by experiments, their presentation detailed and geometry-based. Numerous detailed figures (significantly more than earlier editions), descriptions of demonstration apparatus and their use, and elaborate cross-referencing are notable.

BP_Description_2: A descriptive summary of the components, operation, and use of magnifiers and telescopes. The instruments described use simple lenses, this is before the time of achromatic lenses.  The second book--always found bound with the first--describes improvements, dealing principally with mountings, use, and operation. Emphasis is on projector microscopes that us reflected sunlight for illumination and telescopes used for land and navigation.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Bouguer's attempt to build on his earlier <i>Essai D'Optique<i> of 1729. A posthumous work, assembled and edited from Bouguer's papers by the Abbe De La Caille.
BP_Description_1: A posthumous work, assembled and edited from Bouguer's papers by the Abbe De La Caille, constituting Bouguer's last work on photometry, the measurement of light, and the determination of material's optical properties. A Latin translation appeared in 1762.
BP_Description_2: Bouguer's attempt to build on his earlier <i>Essai D'Optique<i> of 1729. The material is in three books. Book I: various methods to measure light, with many applications. This is essentially a reproduction of the earlier <i>Essai D'Optique<i> of 1729, showing how the inverse square law and brightness comparisons could be used to obtain the relative luminous power of different sources, determine the reflective power of surfaces, and the transmittance of transparent objects. Book II: Research on the reflection of light from polished and rough surfaces. This is an attempt to relate the amount and distribution of reflected light to the physical and optical properties of surfaces. Book III: Research on transparent and opaque bodies. Presents the law of exponential decay of light in absorbing transparent bodies of constant and varying densities. Book II is filled with lacunae which De La Caille left unfilled. Generally they are places Bouguer intended to fill with experimental results; making Book little more than a description of Bouguer's plan to gather data about reflectance of polished and rough surfaces and how it might be used to build a computational model of such reflections. The material is descriptive and analytic, but the vocabulary uncertain and nonuniform.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Notes to accompany most of the material presented by James Ferguson in his course of lectures.
BP_Description_1: By the time Ferguson wrote these notes, he was an established lecturer on experimental natural philosophy in London and their publication further secured his position. His standard course consisted of 12 lectures and though the book's contents lists 12 lectures, the course content on astronomy was displaced in the book by material on globes. Lecture attendees who wished for full written coverage also had to purchase Ferguson's earlier work, Astronomy Explained upon Sir Isaac Newton's Principles of 1756. Both books reflect the interest in experimental natural philosophy by the middle-class in mid 18th century England, as well has the subjects and depth of coverage that were popular and possible. Forty years after the first edition, David Brewster would recount in his updated edition how successful and widely used Ferguson's book was: 'Mr. Ferguson ... may be regarded as the first elementary writer on natural philosophy, and to his labours we must attribute that general diffusion of scientific knowledge among the practical mechanics of this country...' Editions appeared in 1760 and 1764,  and 1776, with updating and additions by David Brewster in 1805, 1806, and 1823.
BP_Description_2: Notes to accompany most of the material presented by James Ferguson in his course of lectures. The 12 lectures contain: Matter and its properties; central forces; mechanical powers; machinery; hydrostatics; pneumatics; optics; globes and the armillary sphere; principles of dialing; calculation of moon phases and eclipses. Lecture VIII on optics (50 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; reflection and refraction and their demonstration; simple lenses and their foci; images from lenses; eye, ocular anatomy, and eye-function; spectacles; the simple and compound  microscope; magnification; solar and projecting microscope; mirrors and their foci; images from mirrors; the telescope; construction and use of telescopes; reflecting telescopes; camera obscura; prismatic colors; the rainbow. The material on light and color is entirely Newtonian.  Generally, the material is elementary and descriptive, without use of mathematics. The demonstrations and optical instruments are descried in detail and accompanied by detailed figures, making it possible for a careful reader to reproduce the demonstrations.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Wheelwright of the Heavens: The Life & Work of James Ferguson, FRS<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Vade Mecum Press, 1988, pp 116-120.||James Ferguson's lecture tour of the English midlands in 1771|Millburn, J.R.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 42, No 4, pp 397-415.
BP_Title: Lectures on select subjects in mechanics, hydrostatics, pneumatics, and optics, with the use of the globes, the art of dialing, And The Calculation of the Mean Times of New and Full Moons and Eclipses. By James Ferguson.  Philosophia mater ominum bonarum aritum est. Cicero. I Tusc.
BP_Title English Translation: "Philosophy is the mother of every good art." Cicero, Tusculan Disputations.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish astronomer, instrument maker, author, autodidact.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A dissertation that attacks Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's idea of a single general law of force.
BP_Description_1: A dissertation in aggressive opposition to the ideas of a general force that had been developed and published by Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá in his <i>Theoria Philosophiae Naturalis<i> of 1758.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation that attacks Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's idea of a general law of force by way of demonstrating the apparent contradictions that arise when it is applied to the reflection and refraction of light. Such application are found in Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>Theoria Philosophiae Naturalis<i> where light paths are curved and warped, presumably by local forces, in the process of reflection and refraction. Gaudio asserts that the 'most beautiful and useful principle' of light's rectilinear propagation is altered only when light's path curves in a transparent medium with changing density, such as the atmosphere. He establishes and then dismisses three principle ways in which the certainty of rectilinear propagation could be questioned and refutes Bo≈°koviƒá's concept of local forces changing light's path. Wolff, Newton, and Euler are cited. The material is descriptive; no mathematics in invoked.
BP_Reference(s): The Sciences at the University of Rome in the 18th Century|Baldini, U.|In: <i>Universities and Science in the Early Modern Period<i>|Feingold, M., Navarro-Brontons, V., editors|Springer, 2006, pp 201-230.||<i>A Theory of Natural Philosophy Latin-English Edition<i>|Child, J.M., editor|Open Court Publishing, 1922, pp 331-354.|https://archive.org/details/theoryofnaturalp00boscrich

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The development of a complete system of ideas, concepts, quantities, and procedures for the measurement of light.
BP_Description_1: Lambert began systematic work in photometry and illumination in 1755 and five years later published this book on photometry. <i>Photometria<i> was the first work to accurately identify most fundamental photometric concepts, to assemble them into a coherent system of photometric quantities, to define these quantities with a precision sufficient for mathematical statement, and to build from them a system of photometric principles. These concepts, quantities, and principles are still in use today. It established what is now called illuminating engineering by showing how to photometrically compare light sources, measure the optical properties of materials, quantify aspects of vision, and calculate illumination. The book is fundamentally experimental and mathematical. One of the first to make extensive application of the calculus, Lambert's mathematical work was considered strange at the time; critics wondering of what possible use his results could have. Many of Lambert's equations found application early in the 20th century in illuminating engineering.
BP_Description_2: <i>Photometria<i> is in seven parts. Part I: First principles of photometry, visual photometry, illuminating power. Part II: Measurement of transmittance of plane glass and lenses, calculations of luminous power from lenses. Part III: Measurement of reflectance, calculation of light reflected from polished mirrors and rough surfaces, diffusely reflecting surfaces, calculations involving diffuse surfaces. Part IV: Luminous power, visual brightness defined. Part V: Dispersion in transparent media, calculation of path and luminous power in the atmosphere, calculation of twilight. Part VI: Illumination and brightness of the planets. Part VII: Brightness of colors, calculation of daylight. Forty experiments are described and their data analyzed. The material is advanced and elaborately mathematical. Equations are derived that express the solution to many practical problems in photometry and illumination.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Photometry, Translated from the Latin Photometria<i>|DiLaura, D.L., translator|Illuminating Engineering Society, 2001, [ccxx]+423 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian  translation of Martin's <i>The Philosophical Grammar<i>, an epitome of knowledge, principally from the physical sciences, written for students and self-study.
BP_Description_1: Third edition of the Italian translation of the French translation of 1749 of, in turn, the second English edition of Benjamin Martin's widely popular <i>Philosophical Grammar<i> of 1738. A reprinting of the text of the first edition of the Italian translation of 1750.
BP_Description_2: The second, expanded edition of an epitome of knowledge, principally from the physical sciences, written for students and self-study. The wide range of topics were meant to provide a survey of most of natural philosophy. The material is prefaced with a general introduction to experimentation, natural philosophy, and a list of instruments and their uses. Part I: Nature and properties of matter, Newtonian physics and mechanics. Part II: Cosmology, including the planets, the moon, the stars, and comets. Part III: 'Aerology', including the atmosphere and meteorics. Part IV: Geology, plants, insects, birds, and animals. Part I contains chapters on light and color (25 pages), including: nature of light, reflection, refraction, simple mirrors and lenses, the microscope, telescope, camera obscura, the magic lantern, prismatic and thin-plate colors, heterogeneous white light. The presentation is elementary, with no mathematics, in the form of a dialogue of short questions and answers. Accompanying the dialogue is an elaborate and copious set of notes that give examples, clarify, cite authorities, and explain the figures. The details and more advanced material is in the notes.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Benjamin Martin: Author, Instrument-Maker, and ‚ÄòCountry Showman‚Äô<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Nordhoff Publishing, Lyden, 1976, pp 11-21.
BP_Title: Gramatica delle scienze filosofiche, o, Breve analisi della filosofia moderna appoggiata alle sperienze. Di Beniamino Martin, Tradotta dall' Inglese in Fancese, e dal Francese in Italino; in questa quarta Edizione Veneta novellamente illustrata, e con somma diligdnza ricorretta.
BP_Title English Translation: Grammar of the Philosophical Sciences, or, An Abreviated Analysis of Modern Philosophy, Resting on Experiments. By Benjamin Martin. Translated from the English to French, and from French into Italian; In this the Fourth Venetican Edition, Newly Illustrated and Corrected with Great Diligence.
BP_Biographical Statement: English science lecturer, oculist, instrument maker, lexicographer.
BP_Plates: Plates [I-XXII] all folding, lacking VIII, IX, X, XIV, XVI,  Table: [2] folding

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching compendium of Mixed Mathematics with a large number of problems and detailed solutions.
BP_Description_1: Third and last edition of Johannes Planck's teaching compendium of Mixed Mathematics. The book is remarkable for the large number of problems with detailed solutions that are used to explain the material. Ideal for formal student or autodidact. Editions appeared in 1747, 1752, and 1760.
BP_Description_2: A teaching compendium of Mixed Mathematics in two parts. Part I: Arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, mechanics, statics, hydrostatics, aerometry, civil and military architecture. Part II: Optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, spherical trigonometry, astronomy, geography, chronology, horology, hydrography, problems and worked examples pertaining to several of the preceding sections. The optical material (58 pages) is in three parts. Optics: definitions, axioms, and basic data; the eye; perception of size, shape, number, place, distance, and motion; problems and solutions in perception; perspective; light and shade. Catoptrics: reflection and plane mirrors; convex and concave mirrors; various problems and solutions regarding mirrors. Dioptrics: refraction and the law of refraction; refraction at plane surfaces; refraction at curved surfaces; convex and concave lenses; telescopes; simple and compound microscopes. The material is elementary and descriptive, no mathematics above geometry is used. Large numbers of problems with complete and detailed solutions are used to explicate the material.
BP_Title: Univers√¶ Matheseos Brevis Institutio Theorico-Practica. Ex Operibus P. P. Societatis Jesu Collecta, Incipientium captui accommodata. A P. Joanne Baptista Planck S.J. Pars I. Editio Tertia. Cum Privilegio Caesaero.
BP_Title English Translation: Brief Theoretical-Practial Instruction in All Mathematics. Collected from the Works of the Society of Jesus, and Adapted to the Capacity of Beginners. By Father Johannes Baptista Planck, SJ. Part I. Third Edition. With Royal Privilege.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Pars II

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Caesareus Sommariva
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elaborate set of notes on geometrical optics, written for the benefit of Rampinelli's fellow professors, posthumously published.
BP_Description_1: Ramiro Rampinelli produced this elaborate set of notes on geometrical optics which, like his notes on mechanics, had been used in his teaching but was not published in his lifetime. Rampinelli lectured on optics between 1747 and 1753 at the University of Pavia and produced these notes for the benefit of other professors in his university. The <i>Lectiones Optic√¶<i> was edited and seen through the press after Rampinelli‚Äôs death by his student Caesareus Sommariva. The front matter contains a letter from Sommariva to the Senate of Milan about the work and a biography of Rampinelli by Francesco Torriceni. Clearly the work of a mathematician, the <i>Lectiones Optic√¶<i> are inspired by, and to some extent based on, the geometrical optics lectures of Isaac Barrow.  Rampinelli lectures present an elaborate demonstration of the principal aspects of geometric optics applied to mirrors and lenses. Though little new material is presented, the lectures are remarkable for their detail and the use of geometry in the elaborate proofs of theorems regarding the behavior of mirrors and lenses.
BP_Description_2: A compendium of geometrical optics consisting of fifteen lectures. I: Introduction; nature of light and light rays; angles of reflection and refraction; point sources; divergence and convergence; luminous bodies; the speed of light; theorems on illumination. II: Rectilinear propagation of rays; rays and angles of reflection; rays and angles of refraction. III: Reflection from conic sections; optic densities and angles of refraction. IV: Problems in reflected geometric optics of plane surfaces; near and distant sources. V: Problems in refracted geometric optics of plane surfaces. VI: Refraction at curved surfaces, foci and images. VII: Reflection from spherical surfaces; foci and images. VIII: Convex and concave mirrors and lenses; rays from point sources. IX: Other aspect of catoptrics. X: Lenses; geometric analysis; foci and images; distant point sources. XI: Problems in refracted geometric optics of lenses. XII: Law of refraction applied. XIII: Refraction at multiple surfaces and lenses; spectacles. XIV: Magnification by mirrors and lenses. XV: The telescope. The material is entirely geometrical optics; physical optics is touched on only briefly in the introduction. The 103 propositions (theorems) are proved in elaborate and exhaustive detail using only geometry. This, in turn, required 244 detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Un matematico bresciano: Ramiro Rampinelli, Monaco Olivetano 1697-1759|Succi, C.|<i>Commentari dell'Ateneo di Brecia<i>, 1992, pp 143-192.|http://www.ateneo.brescia.it/controlpanel/uploads/supplementi-ai-commentari/S-1992 SucciRamiroRampinelli.pdf
BP_Title: Lectiones Optic√¶ Ramiri Rampinellii Brixiani Congregationis Montis Oliveti Monachi Et In Gymnasio Ticinensi Matheseos Professoris.
BP_Title English Translation: Optical Lectures of Ramiro Pampinelli of Brescia. Monk of the Congregation of the Mount of Olives and Professor of Mathematics in the High School at Pavia.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Olivetan Benedictine, mathematician, and teacher. Taught the mathematician Maira Gaetana Agnesi and encouraged her to write her Instituzioni Analitiche.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A dissertation, under the direction of Carolo Benvenuti, defending Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's idea of a single force law to explain optical phenomena.
BP_Description_1: This is a printing of a dissertation defended under the direction of Carolo Benvenuti in Rome in 1754. This dissertation was actually written by Benvenuti and Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá, Benvenuti's teacher. It was one of two dissertations that finally prompted Jesuit superiors to attempt to suppress Bo≈°koviƒá's ideas by removing Benvenuti from his teaching position in the Collegium Romanum.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation is in four sections. I: The inherent properties of light. II: Colors exhibited by thin, clear plates and the alternate reflection and transmission which rays undergo. III: Colors from thick plates and the nature of their dependence. IV: Colors of natural bodies, or, the nature of light the properties of its cause. The fundamental Newtonian notions of light as emitted particles and the chromatic heterogeneity of white light is adopted, but Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's notion of local attractive and repulsive forces acting over exceedingly small distances between atoms is used to explain the colors produced by thin and thick plates and from the surfaces of objects. The presentation is highly detailed, with extensive examples and tables of calculated results, attempting to show alignment with experiment.
BP_Reference(s): The Early Reception of Bo≈°koviƒá's Natural Philosophy: the 'Benvenuti Case'|Martinoviƒá, I.|<i>Snythesis Philosophica<i>, Vol 8, No 2, 1993, pp 307-333.||The Reception of a Theory: A Provisional Syllabus of Boscovich Literature, 1746-1800|Baldini, U.|In: <i>The Jesuits II: Cultures, Sciences, and the Arts, 1540-1773<i>|O'Malley SJ, J.W., Bailey, G.A., Harris, S.J., and Kennedy SJ, T.F., editors|University of Toronto Press, 2006, pp 416-417.
BP_Title: R.P. Caroli Benvenuti Societatis Jesu dissertatio physica de lumine ex ed. romana anni M. DCC. LIV recusa.
BP_Title English Translation: Reverend Father Carolo Benvenuti, SJ.   Physics Disseration on Light. Reproduced from the Roman Edition of 1754.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jesuit, professor at the Collegio Romano, student of Boscovich. Work in Poland after the Jesuit suppresion of 1772.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of Paul Sabatier on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A vast collection of Jean le Rond D'Alembert's writings on mathematics, mathematical physics, and astronomy.
BP_Description_1: A vast collection of Jean le Rond D'Alembert's writings on mathematics, mathematical physics, and astronomy.  Jean le Rond D'Alembert wrote extensively on optics between 1760 and 1770 and much that is collected in the <i>Opuscules MatheÃÅmatiques<i> and virtually all of it was devoted to the theory of lenses, their various aberrations, and an analysis of various dispersion laws. Like Clairaut before him, D'Alembert was convinced that a useful theory of achromatic lenses could be developed if sufficient mathematical power was brought to bear on the problem. He and others recognized that the dispersion laws proposed by Newton could not be correct and that other mathematical statements expressing dispersion were required. He developed an elaborate mathematical apparatus of lens analysis and design, but it had little practical effect on telescope maters. Herschel groused in the Philosophical Transactions of 1821: '. . . from all the abstruse researches of Clairaut, Euler, D'Alembert, and other celebrated geometers, nothing hitherto has resulted beyond a mass of complicated formulae, which, though confessedly exact in theory, have never yet been made the basis of construction for a single good instrument, and remain therefore totally inapplicable, or at lease unapplied in practice.' In fact, it would not be until the more accurate determination of refractive index as a function of wavelength was possible that Clairaut's and D'Alembert's work could be used. This would happen only after the Fraunhofer's discovery of lines in the solar spectrum and the development of spectroscopy.
BP_Description_2: Tome I: Sound and vibration; fluids; logarithms of negatives; optical subjects; dynamics. Tome II: Calculus of probabilities; theory of comets and comet observations; lunar tables. Tome III: Lenses and the theory of lenses. Tome IV: Rotating bodies; miscellaneous; lenses; vibrating strings; calculus; theory of the moon and the three-body problem. Tome V: Motion of fluids; mathematical subjects; physics and astronomy subjects; law of refraction and the Newtonian explanation. Tome VI: Astronomy; theory of the moon; shape of the earth; physical astronomy; parallelogram of forces. Tome VII: Theory of springs; probability; attraction of elliptical spheroids; optical subjects; rotation of the earth.  Tome VIII: Fluids; miscellaneous; remarks on previous memoires.||Optics material comprises the entirety of Tome III (420 pages) and presents mathematical analyses of lenses, their spherical, chromatic , coma, and astigmatism aberrations, and methods by which they could be corrected or minimized. The basic method was to develop mathematical expressions for the figures of multiple lens faces with indices of refraction and dispersion as mathematical parameters, establish the simultaneous equations when the aberrations were null or minimum, and then solve the equations for the lens shapes.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ New insights into major theoretical research in optics in the Age of Enlightenment|Ferllin, F.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 59, 2018, pp 308-391.||Refractor Design: Clairaut's Forgotten Legacy|Church, J.A.|<i>Sky and Telescope<i>, Vol 66, No 3, 1983, pp 259-262.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Samuel Duraeus (1718 - 1789) Professor at the University of Uppsala.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A brief dissertation that considers the nature of light--one of many under the direction of Samuel Duraeus while he was professor of physics at Uppsala.
BP_Description_1: A dissertation written by Samuel Duraeus, defended by Otto Lindberg. One of at least 37 dissertations in physics under the direction of Duraeus while he was professor of physics at Uppsala between the years 1742-1782.
BP_Description_2: A brief dissertation that considers the nature of light--its corporeality, propagation, speed, interaction with objects, and color--by examining the theories and results of experiments presented by Newton, Grimaldi, Roemer, Huygens, and Bradley. Bouguer and his <i>Essai<i> of 1729 is cited regarding measurement of light and reflectance.
BP_Reference(s): For a listing of the theses directed by Dureaus, see: http://uu.diva-portal.org/smash/search.jsf?dswid=2802

Acad. Scient. Holm. Membro, Publico Examini Offert Otto Lindbert, Bahusia-Gothoburgensis. In audit. Gusaviano die XI. Aprils, Anni MDCCLXI. H.A.M.S.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook masquerading as a subject dictionary, meant for the autodidact and the student and to propagate the natural philosophical ideas of Newton.
BP_Description_1: Paulian produced his earlier <i>Dictionnaire de Physique Portatif<i> in 1758; a first attempt at propagating the ideas of Newton. Three years later it was expanded into the <i>Dictionnnaire de Physique<i>; a textbook masquerading as a subject dictionary meant for the autodidact and the student. Paulian drew from many sources and the Preface of first edition of the <i>Dictionnnaire<i> gives 3 and one-half, two-column pages of works and authors. Paulian's natural philosophy was not purely Newtonian, and unlike Desaguliers who presented Newtonian ideas without ornament or interference, Paulian was in an ongoing process of developing his own amalgam of Cartesian and Newtonian natural philosophy, and the <i>Dictionnnaire<i> reflects this free blending and extrapolation. The material in the <i>Dictionnnaire<i> is wide-ranging, with 'Physics' given a very wide compass--the first entry is 'Abdomen.' As new developments appeared Paulian augmented and revised the <i>Dictionnnaire<i>, and so each edition was significantly expanded. Starting as three volumes, it grew to four and eventually to five. An example is an article on achromatic telescopes added to the second edition of 1773. Editions appeared in 1761, 1773, 1781, and 1789. An Italian translation appeared at Venice in 1770, 1779, 1790, and 1794.
BP_Description_2: The optics entries in the <i>Dictionnaire<i> are among its most extensive and include the following Catoptrique: laws of reflection, reflected images, convex and concave mirrors. Coulerus: Newton's prismatic colors, object colors, Newton's explanation of color, Descartes's unsustainable system, the rainbow. Diffraction: definition, cause. Dioptrique: convex and concave lenses, convergent and divergent rays, burning lenses, analogies with mirrors, lens foci. Lumiere: nature and propagation of light; light as corpuscles traveling nearly infinitely fast; various atmospheric luminous phenomena. Microscope: simple and compound microscope, solar microscope, brief history. Ombre: shadows cast by large sources, shadows of the earth and moon, astronomical distances determined from shadows. Optique: direct light, visual perception, persistence, binocular vision, vision and spectacles. Reflexion: cause of reflection, elasticity. Refraction: atmospheric refraction, refraction in solids, law of refraction, cause of refraction. Telescope: dioptric and catoptric telescopes, the Newtonian and Gregorian telescope. Most of these entries are concise explications containing propositions and demonstrations accompanied by figures. The material is descriptive, invoking no mathematics above geometry.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A catalogue of colors and color phenomena that are not part of the Newtonian or objective color theory.
BP_Description_1: A very brief dissertation on accidental (that is, transient, passing, or generated) colors as opposed to objective colors. Colors generated by context, or contrast, or other phenomena, and not colorific effects of different species of light--as with Newton's prismatic colors. Scherffer cites contemporary sources and so the dissertation gives an idea of then-current understanding of these color-optical and physiological phenomena.
BP_Description_2: A catalogue of colors and color phenomena that are not part of the Newtonian or objective color theory. These include colored after-images, chromatic contrasts, simultaneous contrast, color mixing, phosphenes. An attempt is made to explain these phenomena.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A brief, but highly detailed account of the rainbow. Includes a brief history of rainbow theories.
BP_Description_1: A brief, but highly detailed account of the rainbow. This text would later be included in Scherffer's general text on optics, <i>Institutiones Opticae<i>. Like Boscovich, Scherffer is highly critical of De Dominis's explanation of the rainbow, and provides a thorough-going analysis and example calculations, based on the law of refraction and Newtonian prismatic colors.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation begins with a brief history of rainbow theories, including a criticism of De Dominis's ideas. The initial analysis is geometric optics and traces rays incident from a great distance onto a refracting sphere. The analysis is in cross-section so this analysis is two-dimensional. The multiple paths within the sphere involving incident refraction, total internal reflection, and exitant refraction are determined. These developments are used to explain multiple rainbows and halos. The development is highly detailed, with elaborate example calculations to show the alignment of theory and experiment and observation.

BP_Short or Common Title: Esposizione delle comuni, e nuove spezie di cannocchiali, telescopi, microscopi
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A series of discourses, written as advertising pieces and instructional booklets, that describe the instruments made and sold by Lorenzo Selva and two of his sons.
BP_Description_1: Written as both a sales or advertising piece and an instructional booklet, the <i>Esposizione<i> describes terrestrial and astronomical telescopes, helioscopes, lorgnettes, binocular telescopes, as well as more popular, less specialized instruments use such as reading lenses, mirrors, prisms and magic lanterns. Catalogues and descriptions such as this give an accurate view of optical craft in mid-eighteenth century, what instruments were commercially viable, and something of the distance between optical theory and practice.||The booklet was published by Lorenzo Selva, using the name of father, Domenico.
BP_Description_2: A series of discourses that describe the instruments made and sold by Lorenzo Selva and (eventually) two of his sons. The first discourse gives a general treatment of the eye, its optics and function, the nature of lenses, the correction of myopic, hyperopic, and presbyopic vision by spectacles, and the magnification of images by lenses in general. The second discourse, first part, is on spyglasses and telescopes, including: lensed telescopes, optical levels, catadioptric telescopes, catoptric telescope. The second discourse, second part, is on microscopes, including: simple microscopes, compound microscopes, solar microscopes, catadioptric microscopes, catoptric microscopes, the 'universal' microscope. The second discourse, second part, is on various lenses, burning mirrors, cameras obscura, and magic lanterns. The instruments are described in considerable detail, but without any elaborate theory or mathematics. Importantly, Selva describes his implementation of various instruments to measure refractive index and dispersion, based on the work of Boscovich. Selva was one of the earliest builders of a version of Boscovich's Vitrometer. His ties with Boscovich provided access to knowledge of the development of achromatic lenses in England. This, the technology of dispersion measurement, and access to Venice's Murano glass works and  high-quality flint glass, helped Selva produce some of the best achromatic telescopes in Europe.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ La Famiglis Selva, Ottici del '700 Veneziano|Lualdi, A.|<i>Nuncius<i>, Vol 16, No 2, 2001, pp 531 ‚Äì 546.
BP_Title: Esposizione delle comuni, e nuove spezie di cannocchiali, telescopi, microscopi, ed altri istrumenti diottrici, catottrici, e catodiottrici perfezionati ed inventati da Domenico Selva ottico in calle large a S. Marco : con un discorso teorico-pratico sulla formazione e su i difetti della visione; sulla utilitaÃÄ, e sul buon uso ed abuso degli Occhiali. Dedicata all'illustriss. sig. co: Francesco Algarotti, Ciamberlano di S. M. Il Re de Prussia, e Cavaliere dell' ordine del Merito.
BP_Title English Translation: Exposion of Usual and New Types of Looking Glasses, Telescopes, Microscopes, and other Dioptrical, Catoptrical, and Catodioptrical Instruments. Perfected and Invented by Domenico Selva. Optician in the Calle of San Marco. With a Theoretical-Practical Discourse on the Formation and Defects of Vision, and on the Utility and Proper Use and Abuse of Glasses.  Dedicated to the Illustrious Count Franceso Algarotti, Chamberlain to His Majesty the King Prussia, and Knnight of the Order of Merit.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian oculist, instrument maker. Son of famed Venetian optician Domenico Selva.
BP_Provenance: Ex libris Pagio Anslemi' on front pastedown

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Joachim Richtenburg, SJ (1736-1806) Viennese Jesuit, astronomer, mathematician, professor of philosophy.
BP_Short or Common Title: Optice de diversis lvminis gradibvs dimetiendis
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Latin translation of Bouguer's posthumous <i>Trait√© d'Optique<i> of 1760.
BP_Description_1: Latin translation of Bouguer's posthumous <i>Trait√© d'Optique<i> of 1760, assembled and edited from Bouguer's papers by the Abbe De La Caille, constituting Bouguer's last work on photometry, the measurement of light, and the determination of material's optical properties.
BP_Description_2: Bouguer's attempt to build on his earlier <i>Essai D'Optique<i> of 1729. The material is in three books. Book I: various methods to measure light, with many applications. This is essentially a reproduction of the earlier <i>Essai D'Optique<i> of 1729, showing how the inverse square law and brightness comparisons could be used to obtain the relative luminous power of different sources, determine the reflective power of surfaces, and the transmittance of transparent objects. Book II: Research on the reflection of light from polished and rough surfaces. This is an attempt to relate the amount and distribution of reflected light to the physical and optical properties of surfaces. Book III: Research on transparent and opaque bodies. Presents the law of exponential decay of light in absorbing transparent bodies of constant and varying densities. Book II is filled with lacunae which De La Caille left unfilled. Generally they are places Bouguer intended to fill with experimental results; making Book II little more than a description of Bouguer's plan to gather data about reflectance of polished and rough surfaces and how it might be used to build a computational model of such reflections. The material is descriptive and analytic, but the vocabulary uncertain and nonuniform.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>Pierre Bouguer's Optical Treatise on The Gradation Of Light<i>|Knowles Middleton, W.E.|University of Toronto Press, 1961, 247 pp.

BP_Short or Common Title: Constructio lentium obiectivarum ex duplici vitro
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Euler addresses the problem of simultaneously minimizing chromatic and spherical aberration in telescope lenses.
BP_Description_1: Euler provoked Newtonians with his paper 'Sur la Perfection des Verres Objectifs des Lunettes,' published by the Royal Academy at Berlin in 1747. It stated that, contrary to Newton's claim, telescope lenses could be constructed that did not exhibit chromatic aberration. This was the basis for Euler's later and more extensive work on lenses that minimized chromatic and spherical aberration, and was first submitted by Jacobi to the Berlin Academy in 1761 but it was never published in its memoirs. Euler submitted the work to the St. Petersburg Academy for its prize question regarding the perfection of telescopes. By the time this paper was submitted, John Dollond had published his paper on his prism experiments and the making of his achromatic telescope lens. But reducing both spherical and chromatic aberration remained a difficult problem and it was that which Euler addressed in his submission to the St. Petersburg Academy.
BP_Description_2: Euler addresses the problem of simultaneously minimizing chromatic and spherical aberration in telescope lenses. Two lenses with differing indices of refraction could produce an achromatic telescope objective, but the great curvatures required increased spherical aberration. Euler derives equations that, given glass refractive indices, yield the size, curvature, and focal length of a two-lens telescope objective. The paper ends with four examples, worked out in detail, considering four different pairs of refractive indices, the last involving water and glass. An appendix gives the resulting simplifications if some of the constraints are relaxed or removed.
BP_Reference(s): New Light on an Old Question: Who Invented the Achromatic Telescope?|Rudd, M.E., Jaecks, D.H., Willach, R., Sorrenson, R., and Abrahams, P.|<i>Journal of the Antique Telescope Society<i>, Vol 19, 2000, pp 3-12.
BP_Title: Constructio lentium obiectivarum ex duplici vitro quae neque confusionem a figura sphaerica oriundam, neque dispersionem colorum pariant, Auctore Leonhardo Eulero. Dissertatio occasione quaestionis de perfectione telescopiorum ab Imperiali Academia Scientiarum Petropolitana pro praemio propositae conscripta.
BP_Title English Translation: Construction of Objective Lenses from Two Glass (types), Such that no Confusion Arises From Spherical Shape nor Produced by Color Dispersion. Author: Leonhard Euler. A Dissertation Written on the Occasion of the Prize Question Poposed by the Imperial Academy of Sciences on the Perfection of Telescopes.
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss mathematician, natural philosopher. Among the greatest of mathematicians, brought analysis to mechanics, dynamics, optics, astronomy, music.

BP_Short or Common Title: De la Recherche de la Verit√© (a)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first edition to contain Malebranche's memoire read to the French Academy in 1699, which gave his theory of light as percussive vibrations, traveling with a finite speed, with 'promptitude' that determined its color and amplitude that determined its intensity.
BP_Description_1: Late edition of Malebranche's philosophical work describing human errors that affect the pursuit of truth: error of the senses, the imagination, the mind. Reset from a direct reading of the edition of 1712, the last produced by Malebranche before his death, in order to (From the Avis des Libraires) 'rectify the prodigious quantity of errors which had slipped into the editions that appeared since his death'.
BP_Description_2: By the time of the third edition of Malebranche's <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>, his ideas concerning light and color had under gone considerable development. In 1687 his writing reflected an idea he had introduced into Descartes' concept of light being a percussively transmitted pressure in the plenum: the pressure or 'tendency to motion' was not static but consisted of periodic variations, which he called 'pressure vibrations.' In 1699 Malebranche was elected an honorary academician of the French Academy of Science to which he read his memoire 'Reflection Light and Colors and the Generation of Fire.' By the time of this memoire he had significantly modified Descartes' ideas of regarding the nature of light in part because of Romer's discovery of light's finite travel speed Huygens ideas concerning wave propagation. Malebranche developed his idea of pressure vibrations to explain color: vibrations of different 'promptitude' (what would now be described as frequency) produced different colors, and different amplitudes produced different intensities. But however changed from Descartes' original ideas, it was fundamentally a mechanical philosophy.||This memoire would eventually become the 16th Elucidation Malebranche added to the 1700 edition of <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>. The final version of Malebranche‚Äôs ideas on light and color--informed by his reading of Newton's <i>Optice<i> of 1706--appeared in the 1712 edition of the <i>De la Recherche de la Verit√©<i>.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ ùëª <i>The Search after Truth¬†and¬†Elucidations<i>|Lennon, T.M. and  Olscamp, P.J.|Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1997, 775 p.||L'Optique de Malebranche|Duhem, P.|<i>Revue de Metaphysique et de Morale<i>|Vol 23, 1916, pp 37-91.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The most important and influential edition of Musschenbroek's textbook. Published posthumously and including his last writings.
BP_Description_1: The most important and influential edition of Musschenbroek's textbook. Published posthumously, it was completed by Johannes Lulofs, long-time colleague, from the last writings of Musschenbroek. The material was expanded, with, for example, the optical material nearly doubling in length. The <i>Introductio ad Philosophiam Naturalem<i> and 's Gravesande's <i>Physices Elementa Mathematica<i> were the principal representations of Dutch Newtonianism and among the most widely used and influential textbooks in Europe. Editions appeared at Leiden in 1762 and at Padua in 1768. A French translation appeared at Paris in 1769.
BP_Description_2: The material covered includes: nature of natural philosophy and philosophizing; space, bodies, and their nature; motion; gravity; mechanics; motion under attractive power; machines; gravity and inclined planes; central powers; hard, fragile, malleable, flexible, and elastic bodies; percussion; electricity; magnets; attraction of bodies; coherence and solidity; fluids and their motion; water; fire; optics; air; sound; meteorics; the wind. The optics material (145 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; luminous bodies; refraction; refracted light; refraction at planar and spherical surfaces; refraction between air and glass; differing refraction and colors; the eye and eye-function; vision; dioptrics, lenses and their images, the telescope; catoptrics, spherical mirrors and their images, reflecting telescopes. The optical material is essentially Newtonian. The presentation is detailed, mathematical, geometric, and accompanied by many detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): s Gravesane and Musschenbroek: Newtonianism at Leiden|Ruestow, E.G.|In: <i>Physics at Seventeenth and Eighteenth-Century Leiden: Philosophy and the New Science in the University<i>|Springer, 1973, 174 pp, NB: pp 113-139.
BP_Title: Introductio ad philosophiam naturalem. Auctore Petro van Musschenbroek. Tomus I. Tomus II.
BP_Title English Translation: Introduction to Natural Philosophy. Author:  Pieter van Musschenbroek. Volume I. Volume II.
BP_Biographical Statement: Dutch natural philosopher, experimentalist, pedagogue. Professor at the Universities of Utrecht and then Leiden, developed the Layden jar, worked importantly in mechanics and electrostatics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first continental description of Dollond's two-lens telescope objective.
BP_Description_1: A brief dissertation on the theory, function, and design of a telescope objective made from two lenses of differing indices of refraction. This was the first continental description of Dollond's two-lens telescope objective. Dollond's article <i>An Account of Some Experiments concerning the Different Refrangibility of Light<i> had appeared in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society in 1757. In it, Dollond describes repeating Newton's experiment regarding the inseparability of refraction and dispersion, and obtaining a different result than that reported by Newton in his Opticks of 1704. Taking this new result as a basis for correcting chromatic aberration, Dollond built a two-lens telescope objective with water between the lenses. Dollond's objective significantly reduced chromatic aberration. It is this work that Sherffer summarizes, adds to, and explains. This Latin text was the basis for Scherffer's <i>Neue Verbesserung dioptrischer Fernr√∂hren<i> that appeared at Leipzig in 1764.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation describes the Dollond two-glass telescope objective of convex and concave lenses of differing indices of refraction. An analysis is provided of the displacement of focal lengths for limiting red and violet rays, which in turn provides an estimate of the residual chromatic blur. Examples using typical lens sizes, curvatures, and indices of refraction are worked out in detail. References are made to the work of Boscovich and Clairaut on the problem of designing achromatic objectives.
BP_Reference(s): Dollond & Son's Pursuit of Achromaticity, 1758‚Äì1789|Sorrenson, R.|<i>History of Science<i>,Vol 39, No 1, 2001, pp 31-55.
BP_Title: De emendatione telescopiorum dioptricorum per vitrum objectivum compositum recens a Dollondo in Anglia inventa, dissertatio conscripta a P. C. Scherffer e S.J.
BP_Title English Translation: On the Emendation of Dioptrical Telescopes by means of Compound Glass Objectives, Recently Invented by Dollond in England. A Dissertation Written by Father Karl Scherffer, SJ.
BP_Biographical Statement: Austrian Jesuit, mathematician, natural philosopher.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Very brief descriptions of the elementary aspects of geometrical optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics and their role in microscopes and telescopes. This is followed by the propostions from the first six books of Euclid's Elements.
BP_Description_1: Very brief descriptions of the elementary aspects of geometrical optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics and their role in microscopes, telescopes, and the camera obscura. This very brief summary. The basic aspects of optics are presented in Latin, while the material on microscopes, telescopes, and the camera obscura is in Italian. The summary was written by faculty from the Jesuit College at Naples and may have been a kind of text used there.
BP_Description_2: A summary review of geometric optics. Reflection and refraction are mentioned in the context of mirrors and lenses. A strange blend of then-current optics, history, and summaries of extreme concision.

BP_Author full name: Abb√© Nicolas Louis de La Caille
BP_Author last name first: La Caille, Abb√© Nicolas Louis de
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second, that is 'Nouvelle', edition of De La Caille's expansion of the optics textbook he first published in 1750, with an added third section on perspective.
BP_Description_1: Second ('Nouvelle') edition of De La Caille's expansion of the optics textbook he first published in 1750, with an added third section on perspective.
BP_Description_2: De la Caille's textbook on optics is in three parts. I Optics: demonstration principles on which optics is based, properties of light, of shadow, nature and properties of light related to vision and colors, perception. II: Catoptrics and Dioptrics: images and foci, laws of catoptrics and dioptrics derived from experiments, catoptric images and foci, plane and curved mirrors, dioptric images and foci, lenses, double refraction, vision and correcting spectacles, telescopes and microscopes, construction of telescopes and microscopes, optical problems, imperfections and their remedy, use and application of telescopes and microscopes, diverse optical questions. III Perspective: general principles, practical methods of perspective, shadows, light and shadows caused by the sun, light and shadows caused by a lamp. The material is almost entirely on geometric optics, is empirical in nature, and focused on instruments. Within that scope it is detailed, analytic, and supported by examples and detailed figures. Physical optics and color are mentioned only in passing; color being attributed to different 'species of light rays.'
BP_Reference(s): Teaching the mathematical sciences in France during the eighteenth century: a few examples from some of the most used textbooks|Confalonieri, S.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Third International Conference on the History of Mathematics Education<i>|Bjarnad√≥ttir, K., editor|University of Uppsala, 2015, pp 137-150.
