BP_Short or Common Title: A New and Comprehensive System of Mathematical Institutions
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The collected articles on mathematics, written by Benjamin Martin, that appeared in <i>The General Magazine of Arts and Sciences<i> between 1755 and 1763.
BP_Description_1: Between 1755 and 1763 Benjamin Martin wrote 'The General Magazine of Arts and Sciences', published monthly by W. Owen. The original plan was for the Magazine to present material in four areas: A General Survey of Nature and Art; An Entire System of Natural History including Geography and Geology; A Compleat Body of Arts and Sciences not Mathematical; A Series of Mathematical and Mechanical Institutions of Geometrical Science. Generally, each issue contained material for all four areas, printed in such a way that each issue could be separated into sections dealing with each of the four parts and later collected into a more-or-less complete book. The volume titled <i>A New and Comprehensive System of Mathematical Institutions<i> appeared in two volumes; 1759 and 1764, containing all the material that had appeared related to part four of the general plan.
BP_Description_2: Martin's  <i>Mathematical Institutions<i> is in two volumes. The first (1759) contains all the preliminary mathematical material: Arithmetic, algebra, geometry, trigonometry, conics, and fluxions. Volume 2 (1764) contains: Phyico-mechanical mathesis, universal optics, universal perspective, loxodromics or navigation, ballistics or gunnery, horology of clockwork. The optics section (42 pages) is in three sections: catoptrics, dioptrics, and perspective. Each begins with a theoretical section, followed by applications. Catoptrics covers: reflection, foci and images from mirrors, burning mirrors. Dioptrics covers: refraction, refraction at plane and curved surfaces, convex and concave lenses, caustics, foci and images from lenses, geometric optics of lenses, the eye and eye-function, visual perception, color, prismatic colors, object color, chromatic aberration in lenses, the Dollond achromatic lens. The theoretical material is very concise, detailed, and mathematical; the application material is descriptive. A few in-text figures are present, but 30 figures appear on the plate accompanying the text.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Benjamin Martin: Author, Instrument-Maker, and ‚ÄòCountry Showman‚Äô<i>|Millburn, J.R.|Nordhoff Publishing, Lyden, 1976, pp 65-83.
BP_Title: A new and comprehensive system of mathematical institutions, agreeable to the present state of the Newtonian mathesis. Vol. II. Containing the institutes, or principles of 1. The physico-mechanical mathesis. 2. Universal optics. 3. Universal perspective. 4. Loxodromics, or navigation. 5. Ballistics, or gunnery. 6. Horology, or clockwork.

BP_Author full name: Ignace-Gaston and Qu√©riau, Fran√ßois Guillaume Pardies
BP_Author last name first: Pardies, Ignace-Gaston SJ and Qu√©riau, Fran√ßois Guillaume
BP_Short or Common Title: Examen du systeÃÇme de Monsieur Newton, sur la lumiere & les couleurs
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A very late attack on the Newtonian idea of the heterogeneity of white light and the significance of prismatic colors.
BP_Description_1: A very late attack on the Newtonian idea of the heterogeneity of white light and the significance of prismatic colors. The author behind the sobriquet 'Alethophile' has been determined to be Francois Guillaume Queriau, who worked from notes by Ignace-Gaston Pardies, SJ. A brochure form of the work appeared in 1766 which was mentioned in the Mercure De France of October 1766 and the Journal Encyclopedique of November 1766. The date of the first edition is unknown.
BP_Description_2: The work begins with a kind of boast that elaborate mathematics will not be necessary to question Newton's system of light and color. 'The physicist is in inverse ratio to the Mathematician.' Ten propositions are presented and argued. 1. Light rays are not emitted from luminous bodies; 2. Rays are not themselves differently colored and heterogeneous; 3. They are not equally refractable and reflectable; 4. When mixed, they do not give white light; 5. Prismatic colors are not primitive; 6. Reflection of prismatic colors does not impart color to a body; 7. Black is a true color properly called; 8. White is a true color properly called; 9. White is a single color, truly and only primitive; 10. The difficulties with Descartes system of light and color can be successfully defended.
BP_Reference(s): La th√©orie des couleurs de Newton et ses adversaires|Rosenfeld, L.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 9, No 1, 1927, pp. 44-65.
BP_Title: Examen du systeÃÇme de Monsieur Newton, sur la lumiere & les couleurs. Nouvelle Edition.
BP_Title English Translation: Examination of the System of Mr. Newton on Light and Colors. By M.J. Alethophile. A new edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit natural philosopher, famed for sparring with Newton over the latter's optics letter of 1672.
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Calf Gilt Over Marbled Boards

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A German translation of Carl Sherffer's essay on Dollond's achromatic telescope lens
BP_Description_1: German translation of a brief dissertation on the theory, function, and design of a telescope objective made from two lenses of differing indices of refraction. Sherffer's Latin text  was the first continental description of Dollond's two-lens telescope objective. This close German translation comes from the Latin. The translator is not identified.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation describes the Dollond two-glass telescope objective of convex and concave lenses of differing indices of refraction. An analysis is provided of the displacement of focal lengths for limiting red and violet rays, which in turn provides an estimate of the residual chromatic blur. Examples using typical lens sizes, curvatures, and indices of refraction are worked out in detail. References are made to the work of Boscovich and Clairaut on the problem of designing achromatic objectives.
BP_Reference(s): Dollond & Son's Pursuit of Achromaticity, 1758‚Äì1789|Sorrenson, R.|<i>History of Science<i>,Vol 39, No 1, 2001, pp 31-55.
BP_Title: Neue Verbesserung dioptrischer Femrohren, welche ohnlangst von dem beruhmten Dollond in England sind erfunden worden
BP_Title English Translation: New improvement of dioptric telescope tubes, which was lately invented by the famous Dollond in England
BP_Biographical Statement: Austrian Jesuit, mathematician, natural philosopher.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Maarten Houttuyn (1720 -1798) Dutch naturalist, prolific author.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A Dutch translation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: By 1746 the Amsterdam publisher Isaac Tirion had produced a Dutch translation of John Desagulier's compendium of experimental natural philosophy. As it lacked any significant optics, the Dutch translator (never identified, but Jacobus Krighout (1703-1770) has been suggested), proposed a third volume: a Dutch translation of part of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738: the 'Popular Treatise.' Tirion's and the translator's plans eventually expanded to include publication of a translation of Smith's entire work. The list of 176 subscribers in the front matter is evidence of the keen interest of the Dutch in Smith's detailed optical treatise. Dutch interest in optical matters in general and telescopes in particular was responsible, in part, for the popularity, success, and influence of the book. The Dutch translation appeared at Amsterdam in 1753 and reissued with a new title page at The Hague in 1764.
BP_Description_2: A Dutch translation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738. The Dutch is faithful to the English, neither adding nor removing. This included reproducing Smith's hundreds of figures.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327, NB p 323.||Science for the public: the translation of popular texts on experimental philosophy into the Dutch language in mid-eighteenth century|Zuidervaart, H.J.|In: <i>Cultural Transfer through Translation: The Circulation of Enlightened Thought in Europe by Means of Translation<i>|Stockhorst, S., editor|Brill, 2010, pp 231-262, NB. pp 243-247.

Alles met zeer veele plaaten opgehelderd.  In 't Engelsch beschreeven door den Heere Robert Smith, Doctor in de beide Regten, Hoogleeraar in de Starrekunde en Natuurkunde, Meester van Trinity-College te Kambridge, en Mechanist van zyne Majesteit van Grootbrittannie.  Vertaald door een Liefhebber der Wiskonst en Natuurkunde, En met eenige Byvoegzels en Verbeteringen van den Schryver vermeerderd. Eerste Deel.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A Prague reprinting of Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>De Lumine<i> of 1748, written while he was at the Collegio Romano.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting at Prague of Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>De Lumine<i> of 1748, written while he was at the Collegio Romano. The text appeared is more than one form. The <i>Pars Prima<i> first appeared as a dissertation written by Bo≈°koviƒá but defended by (future Cardinal) Andrea Archetti in the Collegio Romano and printed in August 1748. That is the text in the present volume. The <i>Pars Secunda<i> was defended in the Collegio Romano and published anonymously in September of 1748. It also appeared at Prague in 1765. The work is a vigorous proposal and defense of the idea that light is corpuscular and subject to local, point-source attractive and repulsive forces which result in reflection, refraction, and diffraction. The <i>Dissertatio de Lumine<i> shows the earliest development and expression of Bo≈°koviƒá's ideas regarding point-source forces on (in the present case) light. These ideas would eventually be refined and developed and appear in his <i>Theoria Philosophiae Naturalis<i> of 1763. The edition of 1766 of the <i>Dissertatio De Lumine<i> is the first time both parts appeared together under  Bo≈°koviƒá's name. The volume also contains brief summaries of propositions defended at the Jesuit Seminary at Prague.
BP_Description_2: The Dissertatio de Lumine presents a view of physical optics, that is, the nature of light, which for Bo≈°koviƒá  means light as particles, moving with finite speed, subject to forces from the matter with which it interacts, and with all changes in speed and direction of propagation obeying the law of continuity. Bradley's 1727 discovery and explanation of stellar aberration supported the ideas that light is an emitted stream of particles and that is travels with a finite speed.  Using then-available data, Bo≈°koviƒá calculates the speed of light to be something close to the modern accepted value--though his calculation benefited from compensating inaccuracies of astronomical distances and times. It is here that Bo≈°koviƒá proposes extending Bradley's experiment by using a telescope filled with water and thus allowing the determine of the speed of light in water. In Pars Secunda, reflection, refraction, diffraction, and chromatic dispersion are explained in terms of light particles, traveling at finite speeds, reacting to the attractive and repulsive forces from point-sources that comprise the matter with which they interact.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of a Theory: A Provisional Syllabus of Boscovich Literature, 1746-1800|Baldini, U.|In: <i>The Jesuits II: Cultures, Sciences, and the Arts, 1540-1773<i>|O'Malley SJ, J.W., Bailey, G.A., Harris, S.J., and Kennedy SJ, T.F., editors|University of Toronto Press, 2006, pp 408-508.

BP_Title English Translation: Dissertation on Light, First Part. Publiically Defended in the Collegio Romano of the Society of Jesus. Following Roman Copy.

BP_Short or Common Title: Abhandlung von den verbesserten dioptrischen FernroÃàhren
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A rendering into German of Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>De Lentibus et Telescopiis Dioptricis<i> of 1755
BP_Description_1: A rendering into German of Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>De Lentibus et Telescopiis Dioptricis<i> of 1755, with considerable additions by the translator Karl Scherffer, SJ. In the 10 years since the appearance of the Latin text, achromatic telescope objects made with multiple lenses had become a practical reality. To  Bo≈°koviƒá's geometric optics and analysis of aberrations, Scherffer added work that Bo≈°koviƒá had subsequently done on achromatic lenses; most importantly, the need to accurately measure indices of refraction and chromatic dispersion.
BP_Description_2: The most significant material added by Karl Scherffer to this German rendering was work on the achromatic telescope objective and the requirement for accurate knowledge of indices of refraction and the chromatic dispersion of different glasses. Bo≈°koviƒá was among the earlies to recognize the importance of this information and to devise instruments to make such measurements. Additional text and figures describe these developments. Scherffer's 40 page appendix contains commentary, detailed example calculations of lens chromatic analysis, as well as letters from Boscovich.
BP_Reference(s): R. G. Boscovich and the Measurement of the Refractive Quality of Lenses|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana<i>, Vol 60 No 4, p 837-888.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reprinting of Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>De Lumine<i> of 1748, written while he was at the Collegio Romano.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting of Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's <i>De Lumine<i> of 1748, written while he was at the Collegio Romano. The text appeared is more than one form. The Pars Prima first appeared as a dissertation written by Bo≈°koviƒá but defended by (future Cardinal) Andrea Archetti in the Collegio Romano and printed in August 1748. The <i>Pars Secunda<i> was defended in the Collegio Romano and published anonymously in September of 1748. The work is a vigorous proposal and defense of the idea that light is corpuscular and subject to local, point-source attractive and repulsive forces which result in reflection, refraction, and diffraction. The Dissertatio de Lumine shows the earliest development and expression of Bo≈°koviƒá's ideas regarding point-source forces on (in the present case) light. These investigations into optics, particularly refraction, posed  long-standing explanatory problems of cause and origin that had had no solution. To that end, Boscovich proposes a force law that first appears in the <i>Dissertatio de Lumine<i> of 1748. An early version of the famous oscillating plot of repulsive and attractive force appears here. These ideas would eventually be refined and developed and appear in his <i>Philosophiae Naturalis Theoria<i> of 1758. The edition of 1766 of the <i>Dissertatio De Lumine<i> is the first time both parts appeared together under  Bo≈°koviƒá's name. The volume also contains a reprinting of Carolo Benvenuti's <i>Dissertatio Physica de Lumine<i> of 1761.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Dissertatio de Lumine<i> presents a view of physical optics, that is, the nature of light, which for Bo≈°koviƒá  means light as particles, moving with finite speed, subject to forces from the matter with which it interacts, and with all changes in speed and direction of propagation obeying the law of continuity. Bradley's 1727 discovery and explanation of stellar aberration supported the ideas that light is an emitted stream of particles and that is travels with a finite speed.  Using then-available data, Bo≈°koviƒá calculates the speed of light to be something close to the modern accepted value--though his calculation benefited from compensating inaccuracies of astronomical distances and times. It is here that Bo≈°koviƒá proposes extending Bradley's experiment by using a telescope filled with water and thus allowing the determine of the speed of light in water. In Pars Secunda, reflection, refraction, diffraction, and chromatic dispersion are explained in terms of light particles, traveling at finite speeds, reacting to the attractive and repulsive forces from point-sources that comprise the matter with which they interact. This is the first application of the Bo≈°koviƒá's attractive/repulsive force law/

BP_Short or Common Title: Histoire des ProgreÃÄs de l'Esprit Humain dans les Sciences Exactes
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A history of the development of subjects in Mixed Mathematics; expressing Sav√©rien's belief that teaching the exact sciences by way of history can make them more interesting and appealing to the young and the general public.
BP_Description_1: Alexandre Sav√©rien had published his <i>Dictionnaire Universel de Physique et de Math√©matiques<i> in 1753; a subject dictionary with detailed articles on many aspect of natural philosophy. His subsequent study of the history of these developments prompted the writing of the Histoire des ProgreÃÄs. His view is that it is possible to find the beginning of each of the 15 exact sciences he covers, and gives a chronological reckoning of its development. In the preface, Sav√©rien makes clear his belief that the teaching of the exact sciences by way of history can make them more interesting and appealing to the young and the general public. Editions appeared in 1766 and 1776.
BP_Description_2: A history of the development of subjects in Mixed Mathematics: Arithmetic, Algebra, Geometrics, Astronomy, Gnomonics, Chronology, Navigation, Optics, Mechanics, Hydraulics, Music, Geography, and Civil, Military and Naval Architecture. The optics section (39 pages) begins with optics defined as 'the science of vision' and several pages describing the eye and eye-function. The chronology of optics begins at 590 BC with Pythagoras and his notion of vision and ends in 1764 with the work of Clairaut on achromatic lenses; years are marked in the margins. Though very concise, the chronology is detailed, with all major and many minor authors cited, along with their work. Since it is a chronology, there is little assessment or comparison; nevertheless, this is the first complete chronological history of optics to appear in print.
BP_Reference(s): Saverien Historien des Sciences|Bessmertny, B.|<i>Archeion<i>,  Vol 15, No 3-4, 1933, pp 369-378.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reprinting of the 1761 edition of Carolo Benvenuti's <i>Dissertatio Physica De Lumine<i>.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting of the 1761 edition of Carolo Benvenuti's <i>Dissertatio Physica de Lumine<i>. This is a dissertation defended under the direction of Carolo Benvenuti in Rome in 1754, actually written by Benvenuti and Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá, Benvenuti's teacher. It was one of two dissertations that finally prompted Jesuit superiors to attempt to suppress Bo≈°koviƒá's ideas by removing Benvenuti from his teaching position in the Collegium Romanum.
BP_Description_2: The dissertation is in four sections. I: The inherent properties of light. II: Colors exhibited by thin, clear plates and the alternate reflection and transmission which rays undergo. III: Colors from thick plates and the nature of their dependence. IV: Colors of natural bodies, or, the nature of light the properties of its cause. The fundamental Newtonian notions of light as emitted particles and the chromatic heterogeneity of white light is adopted, but Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá's notion of local attractive and repulsive forces acting over exceedingly small distances between atoms is used to explain the colors produced by thin and thick plates and from the surfaces of objects. The presentation is highly detailed, with extensive examples and tables of calculated results, attempting to show alignment with experiment.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of a Theory: A Provisional Syllabus of Boscovich Literature, 1746-1800|Baldini, U.|In: <i>The Jesuits II: Cultures, Sciences, and the Arts, 1540-1773<i>|O'Malley SJ, J.W., Bailey, G.A., Harris, S.J., and Kennedy SJ, T.F., editors|University of Toronto Press, 2006, pp 416-417.
BP_Title: Dissertatio physica de lumine auctore P. Carolo Benuenuti, Societatis Jesu.
BP_Title English Translation: Physical Dissertation on Light. By the Author Father Carolo Benvenuti, SJ.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Jesuit, professor at the Collegio Romano, student of Boscovich. Worked in Poland after the Jesuit suppresion of 1772.
BP_Provenance: Library stamp on titlepage

BP_Short or Common Title: De recentibus compertis pertinentibus ad perficiendam Dioptricam
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Boscovich overview of chromatic aberration in lenses and his Vitrometer for measuring chromatic dispersion in glass.
BP_Description_1: Boscovich's early interest in optics was rekindled in the early 1760s after visits to France and England in 1759 and 1760 60, during which he met Clairaut and Dollond. The development of achromatic objective lenses had become the most important topic of contemporary optics after Dolland reported his extinction of chromatic aberration in 1758 and Clairaut's work on designing achromatic lenses appeared in 1761 and 1762.  Achromatic lenses was the subject of Boscovich's inaugural lecture at Pavia in May 1764 after he returned from Vienna. This first dissertation on achromatic lenses was begun Vienna and eventually sent to the Accademia di Bologna, of which he had been a member since 1746. It was published in the <i>Commentarii<i> of 1767, Part 1.||This treatise also appeared in the <i>Dissertationes Quinque ad Dioptricam Pertinentes<i> that appeared at Vienna in 1767. In his <i>Analytische Dioptrik<i> of 1778, Georg Kl√ºgel mentions and praises Boscovich's vitrometer. Kl√ºgel probably learned of the vitrometer from the <i>Dissertationes Quinque.<i>
BP_Description_2: In this dissertation Boscovich reports his first work on achromatic lenses, spurred by his recent meetings with Clairaut and Dollond. The general characteristic of achromatic lenses are presented and, most importantly, the extent to which it is necessary to know the dispersive power of glasses if successful lenses were to be designed. This is the  first description of the apparatus with water prism known as the 'vitrometer', whose construction was carried out under Boscovich's supervision for the purpose of measuring and comparing with sufficient accuracy the refractive and dispersive qualities of prisms and lenses. Boscovich understood the need processes and equipment that would produce accurate data; data that, coupled with his own and Clairaut theories of  on achromatic and aplanatic objectives, would lead to better lenses.
BP_Reference(s): R. G. Boscovich and the Measurement of the Refractive Quality of Lenses|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana<i>, Vol 60, No 4, p 837-888.
BP_Title: De recentibus compertis pertinentibus ad perficiendam Dioptricam.  In: De Bononiensi scientiarum et artium instituto atque academia commentarii, Vol 5, Part 1, pp 169-235.
BP_Title English Translation: On Recent Discoveries Relating to Dioptric Performance
BP_Biographical Statement: Croation Jesuit, natural philosopher, astronomer, mathematician. Inventive, prolific, peripatetic.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1767 Bo≈°koviƒá - De recentibus compertis pertinentibus ad perficiendam Dioptricam - Images.JPG
BP_Image2: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1767 Bo≈°koviƒá - De recentibus compertis pertinentibus ad perficiendam Dioptricam - Images 2.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: De unione colorum aliorum post alios per binas substantias, ac unione multo majore per tres
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Boscovich presents theory, mathematics, and examples for designing achromatic lenses with two and three elements.
BP_Description_1: Boscovich's early interest in optics was rekindled in the early 1760s after visits to France and England in 1759 and 1760 60, during which he met Clairaut and Dollond. The development of achromatic objective lenses had become the most important topic of contemporary optics after Dolland reported his extinction of chromatic aberration in 1758 and Clairaut's work on designing achromatic lenses appeared in 1761 and 1762.  Achromatic lenses was the subject of Boscovich's inaugural lecture at Pavia in May 1764 after he returned from Vienna. This is the second dissertation on achromatic lenses begun Vienna and eventually sent to the Accademia di Bologna, of which he had been a member since 1746. It was published in the <i>Commentarii<i> of 1767, Part 2.||This treatise also appeared in the <i>Dissertationes Quinque ad Dioptricam Pertinentes<i> that appeared at Vienna in 1767. In his <i>Analytische Dioptrik<i> of 1778, Georg Kl√ºgel mentions and praises Boscovich's vitrometer. Kl√ºgel probably learned of the vitrometer from the <i>Dissertationes Quinque.<i>
BP_Description_2: In this dissertation Boscovich reports his first work on achromatic lenses, spurred by his recent meetings with Clairaut and Dollond, and follows his presentation of his Vitrometer for measuring the dispersive power of glass in a previous dissertation presented to the Bologna Academy. In this second dissertation, Boscovich presents theory and worked examples of using dispersion data to design achromatic doublets. He shows how even greater achromaticity can be achieved with three lenses, each of different materials. By the time he wrote this dissertation, Boscovich has redesigned by vitrometer three times, and his ever-patient collaborator, Giovanni Stefano Conti in Lucca, had produced working instruments to Boscovich's specifications. The data used in the present work was obtained with this latest of Boscovich's instruments.
BP_Reference(s): R. G. Boscovich and the Measurement of the Refractive Quality of Lenses|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana<i>, Vol 60, No 4, p 837-888.
BP_Title: De unione colorum aliorum post alios per binas substantias, ac unione multo majore per tres. In: De Bononiensi scientiarum et artium instituto atque academia commentarii, Vol 5, Part 2, pp 265-334.
BP_Title English Translation: On the Union of Colors one After Another by Means of two Substances, and the Union of Many More by Three.
BP_Biographical Statement: Croation Jesuit, natural philosopher, astronomer, mathematician. Inventive, prolific, peripatetic.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A treatise on the senses, with emphasis on vision.
BP_Description_1: A reworking and expansion of Le Cat's widely read treatise on the senses, <i>TraiteÃÅ des sens<i> of 1740. Le Cat drew from Malebranche and adopted neo-Cartesian natural philosophy. It is in this revised work that Le Cat, having seen the practice of Jacob Rodrigues P√©reire, the famed French teacher of the deaf, advocated that ‚Äúthe art of correcting the deficiencies of deaf-mutes by birth‚Äù be put into practice. Though covering all the senses, the material on vision is by far the most extensive. The first volume of the present work is actually the second volume of a treatise on physiology <i>Trait√© de l‚Äôexistence de la nature et des propri√©t√©s du fluide des nerfs, et principalement de son action dans le mouvement musculaire<i> of 1765 published in Berlin. The second volume of the present work is the expansion of Le Cat's <i>TraiteÃÅ des sens<i> of 1740.
BP_Description_2: A treatise on the senses, with emphasis on vision. The vision material in volume 2 (368 pages) includes: ocular anatomy; the nature of light; reflection and refraction; lenses; propagation of light; mechanisms for propagation, reflection, refraction; color, prismatic colors, Newton's prismatic experiments, review of the Newtonian system; shadows; eye-function, optics of the eye, eye and brain and optic nerve ; visual phenomena, depth perception, size and distance, views produced by lenses, binocular vision, distinct and indistinct vision, vision and spectacles; camera obscura; illusions. The material on light is neo-Cartesian, draws heavily on Malebranche, and is descriptive rather than mathematical. The material on ocular anatomy, physiological optics, and perception is particularly detailed and lengthy.
BP_Reference(s): The Senses in Philosophy and Science: Blindness and Insight|Roberts, L.|In: A Cultural History of the Senses in the Age of Enlightenment|Vila, A.C., editor|Bloomsbury Publishing, London, 2014, 288 pp.||Claude-Nicolas Le Cat (1700‚Äì1768): On the hearing abilities and on the education of deaf-mutes during the Enlightenment|H√©ral, O.|<i>Journal de R√©adaptation M√©dicale: Pratique et Formation en M√©decine Physique et de R√©adaptation<i>, Vol 30, No 2, 2010, pp 130-133.||On the late invention of the stereoscope|Wade, N.J.|<i>Perception<i>, Vol 16, 1987, pp 785-818.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Esprit P√©zenas, SJ (1692-1776) French Jesuit, astronomer, mathematician, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Esprit P√©zenas's French translation and augmentation of <i>A Smith's Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: Esprit P√©zenas's translation and augmentation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738. This is one of several French translations of major British works in mathematics and optics that P√©zenas produced, contributing significantly to the diffusion of English science in France. At the end of the second volume, P√©zenas added considerable material that described developments in optics made since Smith's original was published. Two French translations of Smith's work appeared in 1767: Esprit P√©zenas' being more concerned with the theoretical aspects while Duval-le-Roy's had a heavy emphasis on the practical, lens and instrument aspects. P√©zenas' translation was reviewed very positively in the Journal des S√ßavans for July, September, and December of 1767, with the December number focusing on the new material provided by P√©zenas. This translation was published at Avignon and at Paris.
BP_Description_2: P√©zenas keeps the structure and content of Smith's original text of 1738, and though not a slavishly literal translation, it does keep closely to Smith sense and style. In addition to comments and clarifications of Smith's text throughout the translation, P√©zenas appended 'Additions du Traducteur' at the end of the second volume, totaling 127 pages and six additional plates of figures. The additions cover: 1: Experiments conducted to determine the limits of distinct and indistinct vision. 2: Why the field of view of two eyes is greater than that of one; 3: Achromatic lenses. 4: Catadioptric Sector. 5: Solar Microscope. 6: Euler's method for perfecting magic lanterns and solar microscopes. 7: A new method to very easily measure star positions. 8: Nutation of the earth's axis of rotation. 9: Movement of the sun around its axis. 10: Angle determination with a micrometer. 11: Determining the vertical diameters of the sun and planets. 12: An astronomical quadrant. Most of the additions are translations from brief articles that had appeared in journals outside France. The exception is the third on achromatic lenses, which is the longest by far and a very detailed, highly mathematical consideration of then-recent developments regarding achromatic lenses, multiple glass telescope objectives, the work done to determine their design. The work of Newton, Zucchi, Klingenstierna, Mallet, Dollond, Euler, and Clairaut are quoted or summarized. Several lens design problems are worked out in detail.
BP_Reference(s): Inventaire chronologique des ≈ìuvres imprim√©es et manuscrites du p√®re Esprit Pezenas (1692-1776)|Boistel, G.|<i>Revue d'histoire des sciences<i>, Vol 56, No 1, 2003, pp 221-245.||Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327.
BP_Title: Cours complet d'optique, traduit de l'anglois de Robert Smith, contenant la theÃÅorie, la pratique et les usages de cette science. P. ancien Professeur Royal d'Hydeographie,a Marseille. Tome premier. Tomes econd.
BP_Title English Translation: Complete Course of Optics, Translated from the English of Robert Smith, Containing the Theory, Practice, and Uses of this Science. With Considerable Additions on All the New Discoveries Which Have Been Made in this Material Since the Publication of the English Work. By [Father Esprit P√©zenas], Former Professor of Hydrography at Marseille.  First Volume. Second Volume.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, academic. Plumian Professor Astronomy at Trinity College, Cambridge.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Nicolas Claude Duval-le-Roy (1739-1810) French mathematician and surveyor, professor at the French Naval Academy at Brest.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Nicolas Claude Duval-le-Roy's French translation and augmentation of <i>A Smith's Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: Nicolas Claude Duval-le-Roy's translation and augmentation of Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738. The author and the printer desired a single-volume work, so many of Smith's historical notes were removed and the entire last section, 'Author's Remarks Upon the Whole Work' were dispersed to the various sections they addressed and set in very small type. Two French translations of Smith's work appeared in 1767: Esprit P√©zenas' being more concerned with the theoretical aspects while Duval-le-Roy's had a heavy emphasis on the practical, lens and instrument aspects.||A pre-publication review of the translation appeared in the Journal des S√ßavans for June 1766. The review is coy about the quality of the translation; spending time describing the beautiful type, the quality of the paper, and the inexpensiveness of the book. It mentions at the end that another translation by Pezenas is about to appear, but Duval-le-Roy's will be the first. There is the whiff of faint praise about the entire review.
BP_Description_2: Duval-le-Roy's translation is, in part, a condensation of Smith's original text of 1738; preserving the essentials but not preproducing Smith's style of presentation. Duval-le-Roy updates the original is several places, the most important by far is the section on lenses, were Duval-le-Roy added material on achromatic lenses. The final result is not so much a translation of Smith's Opticks as it is an up-to-date optics text that uses Smith's original as a guide and framework.
BP_Reference(s): Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327.
BP_Title: TraiteÃÅ d'optique par M. Smith, professeur d'astronomie & de philosophie expeÃÅrimentale aÃÄ Cambridje, traduit de l'anglais et consideÃÅrablement augmenteÃÅ.  Quid tam mirabile, quam particulam corporis quandam ita fabricatam esse, ut ejus opera animal sentiat procul positorum corporum figuram, positum, motum quemlibet, distantiam; idque etaim cum colorum varietate, quo distinctius ea dignosceret? Nihil est, in qo manifestius Geomtriae artem Deus exercuerit. Hugenii Cosmotheoros, p. 40.
BP_Title English Translation: Treatise on Optics, by Mr. Smith, Professor of Astronomy and Experimental Philosophy at Cambridge. Translated from the English and Considerably Augmented. "For what can be more amazing, than that a Particle of Body should be so devised and framed, as by its means to show us the Shape, the Position, the Distance, and all the Motions, nay and all the [46] Colours, distinguishing of a Body that is far remote from us? There is nothing in Which God more Clearly Exercises the Art of Geometry"  Huygens, Cosmotheros. p. 40

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching text covering Mixed Mathematics, being a slight re-working of Steinmeyer's <i>Epitome Elementorum Matheseos Universae<i> of 1764.
BP_Description_1: A teaching text covering Mixed Mathematics. This is a slight re-working of Steinmeyer's <i>Epitome Elementorum Matheseos Universae<i> published in 5 volumes between 1764 and 1766. The same figures are used. A text meant to accompany a formal course of study, but the detailed presentation style and the inclusion of worked problems and figures allowed to fulfill the needs of the autodidact. The experimental natural philosophy presented is that of Christian Wolff, giving evidence to the final Jesuit move away from scholasticism that was completed in the decade before the Society's suppression. There are two volumes, <i>Pars Prima<i> and <i>Pars Altera<i>. The first deals exclusively with mathematics, the second with Mix or Applied Mathematics.
BP_Description_2: The material in the first two volumes of the <i>Succincta<i> includes: arithmetic, geometry, plane trigonometry, algebra, statics, hydrostatics, aerometry, hydraulics, optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, perspective, astronomy both practical and theoretical, geography, chronology, gnomics, and architecture. The optics material (91 pages) is in three chapters. 1 Optics: nature of light; direct, reflected, and refracted light rays; the eye, its anatomy, and eye-function; basic illumination; atmospheric refraction; practical problems using optics. 2 Catoptrics: foci and images from mirrors; plane and spherical mirrors; burning mirrors; practical problems with mirrors. 3 Dioptrics: refraction; refractive index; sine law of refraction; convex and concave lenses; foci and images from lenses; the telescope; construction and use of telescopes; the microscope; the magic lantern. The optics is that of Christian Wolff and though chromatic aberration in telescopes is mentioned, Newton's theory of light and color is not presented. The material is practical, detailed, and presented with no mathematics above geometry. Practical problems are presented and solved.
BP_Reference(s): German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-363.
BP_Title: Mathesis Succincta. Pars Altera. Complectens staticam, hydrostaticam, aerometriam, hydraulicam, opticam, catoptricam, dioptricam, perspectivam, astronomiam, geographiam, chronolgiam, gnomonicam, pyrotechniam, architectonicam militarem & civilem. Conscripta a P. Philippo Steinmeyer S.J. cum Facultate.
BP_Title English Translation: Mathematics Prepared.  Second Part, Encompassing Statics, Hydrostatics, Aerometry, Hydraulics, Optics, Catroprics, Dioptrics, Perspetive, Astronomy, Geography, Chronology, Gnomics, Pyrotechnics, Military and Civil Architecture. Composed by Father Philipp Steinmeyer,  SJ. With Approbation.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, mathematician, academic. Professor at the University of Freibug.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of PP. Kapuziner. Library stamps on titlepage
BP_Plates: Plates [I-V, I-II, I-III, I-III, I-II, I-II, I-VII, 1, I-II, V, II, I-IV, I-V]

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A concise summary of Newtonian optics and a general description of optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: A concise summary of Newtonian optics and a general description of optical instruments. This is one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics; the list of such texts being short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799.The Elements of Optics received a very favorable review in The Critical Review, or Annals of Literature of 1770.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in four books. Book 1 Simple Optics: the nature of light; prismatic colors; visual perception of size, shape, and position of objects; color; Newton's doctrine of fits; light interacting with bodies; light's propagation; strengths of various natural light sources considered from geometry. Book 2 Catoptrics: reflection from plane and spherical surfaces; foci and images from mirrors; burning mirrors; spherical aberration in mirrors. Book 3 Dioptrics: refraction; refractive indices; refraction at spherical surfaces; foci and images from lenses; calculating lens properties; burning lenses; aberration in lenses. Book 4 Instruments: multiple lenses; the eye and eye-function; telescopes, characteristics and construction; reflecting telescopes; magnification; microscopes, simple and compound; solar microscope; magic lantern; camera obscura; perspective viewers; the rainbow. The material is concise, detailed, and presents the fundamentals as propositions, usually with extensive mathematical proof. The text is accompanied by and makes extensive reference to 136 figures.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics After Newton<i>|Cantor, J.|Manchester University Press, 1983 pp 48-49.
BP_Title: The elements of optics. : In four books. Book I. Simple Optics, or Direct Vision. Book II. Catoptrics, or Reflected Vision. Book III. Dioptrics, or Refracted Vision. Book IV. The Construction of Optical Instruments.  "Discite o miseri,et causas cognoscite rerum."  Pers. Sat. III.
BP_Title English Translation: "Learn O Wretched People, and Know the Cause of Things."  Persius, The Satires. III.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, experimentalist. Excentric, prolific author.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Prespective

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A widely-used, two-volume text on Mixed Mathematics meant for use in the gymnasium but particularly for self-study.
BP_Description_1: A widely-used, two-volume text on Mixed Mathematics meant for use in the gymnasium but particularly for self-study. Clemm notes in his introduction that though Wolff's famed textbooks had long been in use, they had become outdated and so new texts were required that included new knowledge, however briefly (but clearly) presented. Clemm considered mathematics as the proper foundation and training for studying the other sciences--and thus the entire first volume is devoted to mathematics. Applications are found in the second volume. Interestingly, each topic is introduced with a consideration of its history. Editions appeared in 1769 and 1777.
BP_Description_2: The first volume is devoted to mathematical fundamentals, arithmetic and geometry. The second volume covers: statics, mechanics, hydrostatics, aerometry, hydraulics, optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, perspective, theoretical and practical astronomy, geography, chronology and gnomics, civil and military architecture, and natural history. The optics material (72 pages) includes the following. Optics: history, light rays, propagation, the eye, visual perception, prismatic colors, object colors. Catoptrics: history, reflection, plane mirrors, spherical and parabolic mirrors, foci. Dioptrics: history, refraction, lenses, calculating focal length, the telescope, the microscope, other optical instruments. Each section is very brief, and though only the most elementary concepts are presented, some descriptions are accompanied by geometric demonstrations; particularly those relying on a figure for clarification.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 31-62.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The most popular book of recreational mathematics published in the second half of the 18th century.
BP_Description_1: The most popular book of recreational mathematics published in the second half of the 18th century. Dilettante interest in science by polite society at this time was widespread in Europe. Lectures and books that presented aspects of physics and mathematics by demonstrations, games, tricks, and instruments as entertainments were very popular. Guyot wrote directly to this audience, stating in his Discours Pr√©liminaire that he 'preferred to compose recreations that were as easy in execution as they were surprising in effect, so that those who only want recreation and have difficulty studying, can increase their understand while relaxing.' In this Guyot's Recreations are different from Ozanam's which through their many editions never lost their serious didactic purpose. Guyot's <i>Recreations<i> are simpler, more accessible, more fun. The plates of figures were hand colored. The first edition appeared in 1769-1770 in four volumes, and this second edition, enlarged from the first, appeared in four volumes in 1772, 1773, 1774, 1775. A third edition appeared at Paris in 1786, which was reprinted in  1799. Translations appeared in Dutch at Rotterdam in 1771-1775, in German at Augsburg in 1772-1775, and English at London in 1774.
BP_Description_2: Guyot presents 'Recreations'--that is, demonstrations, phenomena, games, and instruments based on aspects of physics and mathematics. Eight parts are grouped in four volumes. Volume 1: part 1 covers magnets and their many applications; part2 covers numerical mathematics, combinations and permutations, and anagrams. Volume 2: part 3 covers geometry, light, optics, vision and perspective; part 4 covers electricity. Volume 3: part 5 coverts magnetics and new applications; part 6 coverts catoptrics and dioptrics. Volume 4: part 7 covers mechanical games, 'occult', water and fire; part 8 covers fire, phosphorous and chemistry, electricity, magic squares. The optics material in in part 6 (190 pages). There are 44 'Recreations' covering the catoptric and dioptric phenomena, instruments, perspective, and anamorphosis. The catoptric recreations include: Images in plane, convex and concave mirrors; multiple mirrors and interreflected image; anamorphosis and deformed images by deformed mirrors; conical mirrors; images in spherical mirrors. The dioptric recreations include: camera obscura; magic lanterns; images from lenses; shadows. Each recreation is presented as an entertainment based on an optical phenomenon. The presentations are purely demonstrative, with figures accompanying some of the recreations, showing the optical effect or, in some few cases, indicating how it is accomplished. There is no theory or mathematics  presented. Generally, the reader is introduced to the most basic of optical principles of reflection and refraction by way of description and a general figures. The recreations present sometimes ingenious applications of basic principles to produce visual effects.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Leonhard Euler, with the help of a student, gathered his works on geometrical optics from between 1746 and 1760 and put them into textbook form: A complete text on geometric optics, his three-volume <i>Dioptricae<i>.
BP_Description_1: Leonhard Euler had been occupied with geometrical optics questions since 1746 and had published many articles in the proceedings of the Berlin and St. Petersburg academies. Beginning in the early 1760's and with the help of one of his students, Georg Wolfgang Krafft, Euler gathered his works on geometrical optics and put them into textbook form: his Dioptricae. The manuscript was completed in 1765 and the first volume published by the St. Petersburg Academy in 1769. The intent was to produce a complete text on geometric optics. Euler's goal had always been to find the necessary mathematical apparatus that would relate image quality, as limited by spherical and chromatic aberrations in lensed optical instruments, to the parameters defining the multiple lenses involved. The result was a complete analytical-mathematical apparatus for modeling optical imaging lens systems.  Elaborately mathematical, Euler's Dioptricae considers geometric optics only from an analytic point of view, independent of many important practical issues, and so produced results that were often of only the most theoretical of interests--the analysis of high-order aberrations, for example. Significantly, Euler's work was not informed by the slightly earlier work of Clairaut and d'Alembert, who considered aberrations off the optical axis of a system of lenses, and to some extent superseded Euler's work. Sixty-five years later, George Airy would write that ' . . . after a general acquaintance with the principles of chromatic dispersion, it would be easier for any one to form a theory for himself, than to select the parts that are useful from the book of Euler.' Nevertheless, Euler's Dioptricae remained important as a theoretical compendium and nearly a decade later, Georg Simon Kl√ºgel would extract from it those things that had practical application into his <i>Analytische Dioptrik<i> of 1778.
BP_Description_2: Euler's <i>Dioptricae<i> is in three volumes. Volume 1 contains an extensive and general consideration of spherical lenses, used singly and in multiples, and the aberrations of the images they produce. Euler analyzed the indistinctness of images caused by spherical and chromatic aberration and changes in magnification. Importantly, spherical and chromatic aberrations were defined only on the optical axis of the lens(es) and the analytic process developed by Euler corrected them only on the optical axis. The only aberration considered off-axis was change in magnification. Volume 2 applies the general principles to telescopes; that is, involving the imaging and magnification of infinitely distant objects. Three telescope types are considered: with a concave ocular giving in erect image; with a convex ocular giving an inverted image; with an objective giving an erect image. An appendix describes the construction of a catadioptric telescope. Volume 3 applies the general principles to microscopes: that is, involving the imaging and magnification of very close-by objects. Simple and compound microscopes are considered, with the objectives and oculars that minimize aberrations. The style of all three volumes is the same: mathematical propositions, proofs, and corollaries followed by examples that are worked in complete numerical detail.
BP_Reference(s): Leonhard Eulers Stellung in der Geschichte der Optik|Fellmann, E.A.|In: <i>Leonhard Euler 1707‚Äì1783: Beitr√§ge zu Leben und Werk<i>, Springer, 1983, pp 303-330.||Betrachtungen zu Eulers Dioptrik|Habicht, W.|In: <i>Leonhard Euler 1707‚Äì1783: Beitr√§ge zu Leben und Werk<i>, Springer, 1983, pp 283-302.||<i>Leonhard Euler: Mathematical Genius in the Enlightenment<i>|Calinger, R.S.|Princeton University Press, 2016, 696 pp, NB: pp 469-471.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Latin manuscript of a complete course in physics
BP_Description_1: Latin manuscript of a complete course in physics at the University of Leuven, Belgium. Placement at Leuven is supported by the plates that were signed 'C.H. Becker, Lov' and astronomical plates and tables signed 'Louvainii apud Denique.' These appear to be notes, perhaps lecture notes, for a complete course in physics in 12 sections, including mechanics, motion, gravity, astronomy, electricity, acoustics, cosmographies, mineralogy, and hydrology. Seven sections begin with an engraving (from various sources) that acts as a half-title. Many of the same plates of figures are used here as appear in another student manuscript (T.J. Lemmens, 1771) and in the anonymous university text on optics that appeared at Leuven in 1775. Unlike the other sections which use the engraved plates of Becker, the section on astronomy includes 19 hand-drawn plates (18 folding) and some colored.||The texts and their use of commercial engravings gives insight into the nature of university study at the time.
BP_Description_2: Most of volume 2 is devoted to light, optics, and vision. The material on optics is very similar to other manuscripts produced at the same time from students at Leuven and they all use the same plates engraved by C.H. Becker. The material covers all elementary aspects of vision, geometrical, and physical optics. Sections cover  the nature and propagation of light; principles of optics; reflection and catoptrics (with headings on plane, convex, concave, and cylindrical and conical mirrors); refraction and dioptrics; diffraction, lenses and the camera obscura; vision and sight; microscopes and telescopes; and colours, and their mixing. Although the color material is Newtonian, there are citations of Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> and <i>Les Meteores<i> and some of the figures are copied from Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> of 1752.||The material is complete but descriptive, the only mathematics invoked is geometry.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Cours de l'Universit√© de Louvain<i>|Universit√© Catholique de Louvain, Archives de l'Universit√©|http://archives.uclouvain.be/atom//index.php/elementa-opticae-et-perspectivae-4

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Five-volume text covering mathematics through calculus, motion and equilibrium, optics, and theoretical astronomy.
BP_Description_1: Karl Scherffer had written descriptive texts on General and Particular physics  in 1750, meant for Doctor of Divinity students who did not have or need mathematics and the understanding it brought. This is a far more extensive, detailed set of texts covering mathematics through calculus, motion and equilibrium, optics, and theoretical astronomy. The order of the material, the manner of presentation, and the worked examples show that although the text made no assumptions about student-reader background, it intended to bring about a considerable development in understanding. The mechanics, optics, and astronomy material presumes the mathematics covered in the first three volumes.||Scherffer was professor of higher mathematics at Vienna for more than 30 years--and not a practicing or experimental natural philosopher. Thus, the <i>Institutiones<i> are so mathematical that the last three volumes can be considered something like modern mathematical physics. Any applied or practical aspects are absent from the presentation. Though Scherffer had 30 years earlier been a follower and teacher of Christian Wolff's natural philosophy, he introduced Newtonianism at Vienna. Sequential volumes of the texts appeared at Vienna between 1770 and 1776.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1: Elementary geometry, plane trigonometry, conic sections, algebra. Volume 2: Arithmetic, finite analysis, solving equations. Volume 3: Differential and integral calculus. Volume 4: Motion and equilibrium of solid bodies, motion of fluids. Volume 5: Optics. Volume 6: Spherical geometry. theoretical astronomy. Volume 7: Plates. The optics material (262 pages) in Volume 5 is in three parts. Optics: light and its effects, luminous bodies and propagation of light, speed of light from stellar aberration, heterogeneous light and prismatic colors, reflection, refraction, diffraction, phosphorus, optical principals, ocular anatomy, image formation, perception of size, distance and motion, binocular vision, consequences of linear propagation. Dioptrics: Lens refraction from near and far points, lens images, lens analysis, finding foci, telescopes, telescopic micrometers, camera obscura, magic lantern, some dioptrical problems solved, spherical aberration, spherical and chromatic aberrations compared. Catoptrics: Spherical mirrors, foci and images, mirror analysis, other mirror shapes, metamorphosis, reflection and refraction in the rainbow, lensed and mirrored telescopes, formulae for dioptric and catoptric spherical surface foci, multiple rainbows. The optics material is theoretical, advanced, and detailed; with elaborate mathematical demonstrations and worked examples. Absent is any detailed consideration of achromatic lenses, which is curious considering his <i>De Emendatione Telescopiorum Dioptricorum<i> published in 1762.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Biographisches Lexikon des Kaiserthums Oesterreich: enthaltend die Lebensskizzen der denkw√ºrdigen Personen, welche 1750 bis 1850 im Kaiserstaate und in seinen Kronl√§ndern gelebt haben<i>|Wurzbach, C. von|Volume 29|Vienna, Statsdruckerei, NB pp 214-216 on Karl Scherffer|At: http://austria-forum.org/web-books/wurzbach29de1875kfu/000223||The Role of Karl Scherffer in the Acceptance and Dissemination of Bo≈°koviƒá's Scientific Results (in Croatian, translated by Google)|Dadiƒá, ≈Ω.|Anali Zavoda za povijesne znanosti Hrvatske akademije znanosti i umjetnosti u Dubrovniku, No 27, 1989, pp 113-121.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reworking and updating of Boscovich's 1756 work giving a complete analysis of lenses used primarily as objectives for telescopes. The updating includes consideration of Dollond's telescope achromatic objective lens.
BP_Description_1: The basis of this work is Boscovich's dissertation on telescope lenses of 1756. At that time he was unaware of the developments in achromatic telescope lenes presumably  from the time of his journey to France and England he learned knew about Dollond's work published in 1758. And presumably on his return journey from Constantinopole while visiting Vienna a second time, from January to May 1763, he saw Clairaut‚Äôs dissertations on achromatic lenses that had appeared in 1761 and 1762. While in Rome, towards the end of 1763, he happened upon Klingenstierna's demonstration of 1761 that contrary to Newton's assertion, achromatic lens systems were theoretically possible.||Boscovich's subsequent work on achromatic lenses was reported in his his two dissertations <i>De recentibus compertis pertinentibus ad perficiendam Dioptricam<i> and <i>De unione colorum aliorum post alios per binas substantias, ac unione multo majore per tres<i> that appeared in the Commentarii Accademia di Bologna of 1767. Since producing those two dissertations, Boscovich had become director of the new Jesuit astronomical observatory at Brera near Milan. He wrote the current work while in Milan. Boscovich's letter to the reader makes clear is intent for this work: He wished to provide convenient design methods for producing achromatic simple telescope objectives and eye-pieces. Boscovich separated the first general overview (for 'those who had only a very subtle hint of geometry') from the second part with its more rigorous demonstrations.||This dissertation describes the state of the art of telescope lens analysis and design soon after the development of the achromatic telescope objective. It is clear from this and his earlier work, that the importance of knowing the index of refraction of materials emerges as a central issue of practical optics for Boscovich. This dissertation is important in that it offers simplified lens design procedures for achromatic telescope objects as well as other off-axis aberrations. This would be that last important optical  work produced by Boscovich before the dissolution of the Jesuits in 1773 and and his move to Paris.
BP_Description_2: A complete analysis of lenses used primarily as objectives for telescopes. The work is in two parts. The first is titled 'Elementary Information on the Nature and Principal Properties of Dioptric Telescopes'.  gives the general properties and characteristics of telescope objective lenses, defining the requirements for distinction, clarity, magnification, and field of view. The general principals are applied to the practical problem of a simple, two element objective. The second part is titled 'Clarification, and Demonstrations of Various more Essential Points from the First Part '. It consists of three sections, each giving proofs and detailed derivations or demonstrations of the components in Part One. Boscovich points out the need for achromatic eye-pieces since even for reflecting telescopes, eye-pieces will introduce chromatic aberration.||Material includes: refraction at spherical glass surfaces; real and virtual images; equations relating lens curvature and foci for convex and concave figures; equations applied to lens design, examples; spherical and chromatic aberrations and their quantification; optics of the eye and eye-function; ocular images and lenses; ocular images, lenses, and the uses of telescopes; consequences of lens aberrations and their effect on astronomical observations. Though the theoretical work of Clairaut, Klingenstierna, and Boscovich furnished the basis for designing and producing achromatic objective lenses and eyepieces, the greatest impediment, from the practical point of view, was that of the unavailability of English flint glass.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A Latin manuscript giving a complete summary of late 18th century optics.
BP_Description_1: A bound scholastic manuscript of student notes from the University of Leuven on the subject of light. As described on the title page, the lecturer was Ignatius Damas of Dinant, primary professor of philosophy at the university's now-defunct Lily College. The text is in Latin, in a small but entirely legible hand on very pale blue paper. The tables of figure are on 13 plates signed C.H. Becker of Leuven, with two dated 1766. This is probably Charles Becker. These are the same plates used in the anonymous printed Optics text from the University of Leuven dated 1775 and in another optics manuscript from the University of Leuven data 1770 at the Smithsonian containing this and other texts. The date is based on when Ignatius Damas received his license in civil and canon law mentioned on the title page.
BP_Description_2: The text covers all elementary aspects of vision, geometrical, and physical optics. Sections cover  the nature and propagation of light, pages [5]-[43]; principles of optics, pages [44]-[71]; reflection and catoptrics (with headings on plane, convex, concave, and cylindrical and conical mirrors), pages [72]-[129]; refraction and dioptrics, pages [129]-[146] ; diffraction, lenses and the camera obscura, pages [146]-[167]; vision and sight, pages [167]-[195]; microscopes and telescopes, pages [196]-[220]; and colours, and their mixing, pages [221]-[272]. Although the color material is Newtonian, there are citations of Descartes' <i>La Dioptrique<i> and <i>Les Meteores<i> and some of the figures are copied from Scheiner's <i>Oculus<i> of 1752.||The material is complete but descriptive, the only mathematics invoked is geometry.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Cours de l'Universit√© de Louvain<i>|Universit√© Catholique de Louvain, Archives de l'Universit√©|http://archives.uclouvain.be/atom//index.php/elementa-opticae-et-perspectivae-4

Lemmens of Brussels, arts baccalaurate alumnus of the same shool.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third Neapolitan edition of Musschenbroek's textbook. Contains new material from the greatly expanded, posthumous edition from Leiden in 1762.
BP_Description_1: Third Neapolitan edition of Musschenbroek's textbook. It differs from the first two in that it contains some of the new material that had appeared in the greatly expanded, posthumous edition from Leiden in 1762. See Entry 464.
BP_Description_2: Textbooks for a course in natural philosophy based on Newtonian ideas and theories. The material covered includes: nature of natural philosophy and philosophizing; space, bodies, and their nature; motion; gravity; mechanics; motion under attractive power; percussion; electricity; fluids and their motion; fire; optics. The optics material (89 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; refraction; refraction at planar and spherical surfaces; differing refraction and colors; the eye and eye-function; vision; dioptrics, lenses and their images, the telescope; catoptrics, spherical mirrors and their images, reflecting telescopes. The optical material is essentially Newtonian. The presentation is detailed, mathematical, geometric, and accompanied by many detailed figures.
BP_Reference(s): See Entry 464.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A vast summary and consideration of natural science and philosophy. Immensely successful in 18th century France and throughout Europe.
BP_Description_1: One of the great works in natural history in the 18th century. Though a work of a different type and style, Pluche's <i>Le Spectacle de la Nature<i> was as widely read as Buffon's <i>Histoire Naturelle<i>. Pluche wrote the <i>Le Spectacle<i> specifically for the young; to make them aware of the world around them, its natural and man-made wonders. It is in this sense that Pluche uses <i>Spectacle<i>. As Pluche worte: People don‚Äôt know how a windmill works or a watch . . . . but they spend a lot of time on quadrille or discussing monads of Leibniz. Particularly  important is Pluche's extensive treatment of the arts and crafts and his clear commitment to increase esteem for artisans and the mechanical arts. But Pluche's work is teleological, though in a milder, more pietistic form; unlike, say, the <i>Het Regt Gebruik der Werelt Beschouwingen<i> of Bernard Nieuwentyt. Nevertheless, the teleology of the work, and Pluche's rejection of Enlightenment thought likely account for the disaffection and his relative oblivion.  Pluche nevertheless deserves credit for reviving the study of natural history in France.||The style is that of a series of dialogues and letters  between the young knight of Breuil, the count and countess Jonval, the prior of Jonval. In his Preface, Pluche says this style of presentation is far better than '... a continuous speech, or a series of dissertations which often lead to disgust & boredom.'||The printing history of <i>Le Spectacle<i> is quite tangled. The initial volume appeared in 1732 and was reissued 3 times within 6 months. The remaining 8 volumes that define the complete work appeared between 1732 and 1751. Between 1732 and 1768, various volumes of Le Spectacle de la Nature were issued in at least 18 editions. Two abridgements and translations into English, Italian, Spanish, and German also appeared. The more than 200 plates were  engraved in intaglio by Jacques-Philippe Le Bas (1707-1783). This is a posthumous edition.
BP_Description_2: This edition includes the material in the original 7 volumes plus two on the sky and the heavens. The material on mechanics, machines, and optics in in Volume V||Volume I: Animals and Plantes, Insects, Birds; Volume II: Surface and Interior of the Earth, Part I, plants, gardens; Volume III: Surface and Interior of the Earth, Part II, plants, boats, and fish; Volume IV: The Heavens and Parts of the Universe, with numerous maps; Volume V: Man considered in himself, Mathematics and machines; Volume VI: Man and Society, Trades; Volume VII: Man and Society, Typography, Crafts; Volume VIII: Man and Society with God, Part I; Volume IX: Man and Society with God, Part II.||Pluche introduced into his physics elementary substances as foundational elements; particularly important was light. Pluche considered the Book of Genesis, in which light was created before the sun and starts, and so held that light was one of several elementary substances--the finest and first-created of the elements and notably distinct from fire.  Pluch held that 'the nature of light is an inconceivable marvel, a true abyss in which our spirit does not play any other part than admiring and adoring.' For Pluche, light is a fluid that fills the entire universe and without changing place it transmits the actions of the sun. Light is always around us, but it has to be 'shaken' by the sun or a lamp to activate vision.

Un chapitre de l'histoire des idees<i>|Mornet, D.|Colin, Paris, 1911, 290 p.||No√´l-Antoine Pluche and the Spectacularity of Nature|Drozdek, A.|<i>Roczniki Teologiczne<i>, Vol 67, No 4, 2020, pp 41-59.||Acknowledging Artisans and a New Social Order in Abb√© Pluche's Spectacle de la nature|Koepp, C.J.|The Princeton University Library Chronicle , Vol 68, No 3, pp. 791-816.||The Spectacle de la Nature in Eighteenth-Century Spain: From French Households to Spanish Workshops|Serrano, E.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 69, No 2, 2011, pp 257-282.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: "Editio Novissmi"  of Johann Horvath's physics textbooks, <i>Physica Generalis and Particularis<i> and first in quarto size. Horvath's texts give evidence of the final ascendency of Newtonian science in the Hungarian Kingdom.
BP_Description_1: Early editions of Horvath's physics textbook adhered closely to the earlier books of fellow Jesuits Andreas Jaszlinszky and P√°l Mak√≥. But in later editions, Horvath wrote more independently, adopted Newtonian physics fully and completely, and addressed the reader in a clearer and direct style, though adhering to a Scholastic format. The texts became the most important and widely used in Hungarian universities and appeared in other European universities due in part to their Latin, their style and emphasis on teaching, and adoption by fellow Jesuits in other schools. Editions appeared in 1767, 1769, 1770, 1772, 1775, 1776, 1782, 1817.
BP_Description_2: The texts cover forces, mechanics, statics, motion, gravity, hydrostatics, hydrodynamics, solids, liquids, gases ('airs'), heat, light, electricity, magnetism, and celestial mechanics. The extensive section on light includes seven chapters. I: Propagation and the nature of light. II: Reflection, refraction, and diffraction. This is entirely Newtonian. III: Thin films, chromatics rings, and Newton 'fits'. IV: Transparency and Colors including the rainbow. V: Optics, vision, eye function, and perceptions. VI: Catoptrics and dioptrics. VII: Photometry.||The physical optics material is entirely Newtonian. The geometrical optics is elementary but complete. Generally, the treatment is descriptive, with mathematics no higher than geometry being used.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A four-volume general course in natural philosophy that is both an encyclopedia of physics and a philosophy of the sciences.
BP_Description_1: Para Du Phanjas taught at the University of Franche-Comt√© in Besan√ßon France with great effect, acquiring a considerable reputation. He produced this 4-volume general course in natural philosophy that is both an encyclopedia of physics and a philosophy of the sciences from his work as a teacher. The work appeared only a year before the suppression of the Jesuits and Para Du Phanjas's move to Paris. Editions appeared in 1772, 1786,  and 1788. Translations appeared in Latin in 1782 and in Spanish at Valladolid in 1796.
BP_Description_2: A 4-volume general course in natural philosophy. Volume 1: Theory of matter and of movement. Volume 2: Theory of the earth, water, and air. Volume 3: Theory of meteorics, light, fire, and electricity. Volume 4: Theory of the sky, or geometrical and physical astronomy. The optical material (320 pages) includes four sections. Section 1 The nature of light: propagation and light rays; emission of light rays; Newton's system of light and color; light as fiery fluid; diversity of colors; efficacies of rays; color and diversity of rays. Section 2 Optics: Parallel, convergent and divergent rays; opaque and transparent materials; vision; law of reflection, inverse square density, diffusion; light rays and vision; problems in vision and perception; catoptrics; plane and curved mirrors; burning mirrors; cause of reflection; dioptrics; refraction; cause of refraction; convex and concave lenses; dioptric instruments; microscopes; telescopes; camera obscura, magic lantern; eye-function, hyperopia and myopia; astronomical refraction. Section 3 Light and fire. Section 4 Light and the Nature of Electricity. For physical optics, Para Du Phanjas presents a theory that light is related to or part of an elemental fiery substance or fluid that is also related to electrical fluid--adhering to neither the particle nor wave theory of light. Regardless of light's ultimate nature, light rays are used as practical manifestations of its properties. Thus, the geometric optics material is ray-based, elementary, detailed and accompanied by examples and many figures.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Catholic Encyclopedia, Volume 11<i>|Herbermann, C.G., and others, editor|The Encyclopedia Press, New York, 1913, NB: pp 469-470.

Par M l'Abbe Para du Phanjas. Tome Premier. La Matiere Et Le Mouvement. Tome Second. Theorie de la Terre, de L'eau, de L'Air.

BP_Short or Common Title: The History and Present State of Discoveries Relating to Vision, Light, and Colours
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A history of optics in six parts, from Ancient Greece to 18th century optics.
BP_Description_1: Joseph Priestley was prompted to write a history of optics after the critical and commercial success of his <i>History and Present State of Electricity<i> of 1767. The bibliography appended to his history of optics lists 265 titles of books and journals he assembled for study and consultation on the history of natural philosophy in general and optics in particular. Priestley adopted a method he described in the preface: 'I  have  adopted  the historical  method,  because  it  appears  to  me  to  have many obvious advantages over any other for my purpose; being peculiarly calculate to enlarge the attention, and to communicate knowledge with the greatest ease, certainty, and pleasure.' But Priestley's history is deeply tinctured with his assessments of past work, experiments, and theories; it is not an historiographically neutral chronology. This is implied in the remarkable fold-out chronological frontispiece ('Biographical Chart'), which lists workers who, as Priestly says: 'have most distinguished themselves by their discoveries relating to vision, light and colours'. Priestley knew little mathematics, so his ability to understand, assess, and intelligently summarize optics after Descartes was quite limited. This may account for the book's prolonged descriptions and quotations from other works--making tedious reading. From this and the figures it copied it is clear that the work is derivative, but Priestley's made no greater claim: 'Neither in this volume, nor in the history of electricity, shall I be found to have made a parade of quoting any author that I have not actually consulted.' The lack of concision and of mathematics likely contributed to the books critical and commercial failure. Nevertheless, the book was an important vehicle for knowledge of optics and vision; Priestley provided English translations of many important sections of works in other languages, and detailed many important ideas in optics and vision new in the 18th century.  A German translation appeared in 1776. There would not be another book-length general history of optics written until Giambattista Venturi's <i>Commentari Sopra la Storia e le Teorie dell'Ottica<i> of 1814.
BP_Description_2: Priestly divides his optics history in six parts. Part 1: From Ancient Greece to 1600 (30 pages). Parts 2: The telescope, microscope, and the discoveries of Kepler and his contemporaries (70 pages). Part 3: Descartes, vision, optical instruments, 17th century optical experiments. Part 4: Between Descartes and Newton, vision, reflection, refraction, diffraction (100 pages). Part 5: Newtonian optics, theory of light and colors, colors from thin and thick plates, cause of reflection and refraction, Newton's telescope (110 pages). Part 6: 18th century optics, the nature of light, phosphors, refraction and dispersion, birefringence, vision, optical instruments (420 pages). The long quotations and extracts give Priestley's history the style and tone of a commonplace book, with entries placed chronologically. Only Priestley's abiding interest in vision and optical instruments intrudes. Mathematics is avoided entirely. The geometrical optics that is presented is quoted from Smith's Compleat System of Opticks of 1738, and physical optics centers around Boscovich's theory of point elements of matter surrounded by spheres of attractive and repulsive force which is used to explain reflection and refraction.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The most popular book of recreational mathematics published in the second half of the 18th century.
BP_Description_1: The most popular book of recreational mathematics published in the second half of the 18th century. Dilettante interest in science by polite society at this time was widespread in Europe. Lectures and books that presented aspects of physics and mathematics by demonstrations, games, tricks, and instruments as entertainments were very popular. Guyot wrote directly to this audience, stating in his Discours Pr√©liminaire that he 'preferred to compose recreations that were as easy in execution as they were surprising in effect, so that those who only want recreation and have difficulty studying, can increase their understand while relaxing.' In this Guyot's Recreations are different from Ozanam's which through their many editions never lost their serious didactic purpose. Guyot's <i>Recreations<i> are simpler, more accessible, more fun. The plates of figures were hand colored. The first edition appeared in 1769-1770 in four volumes, and this second edition, enlarged from the first, appeared in four volumes in 1772, 1773, 1774, 1775. A third edition appeared at Paris in 1786, which was reprinted in  1799. Translations appeared in Dutch at Rotterdam in 1771-1775, in German at Augsburg in 1772-1775, and English at London in 1774.
BP_Description_2: Guyot presents 'Recreations'--that is, demonstrations, phenomena, games, and instruments based on aspects of physics and mathematics. Eight parts are grouped in four volumes. Volume 1: part 1 covers magnets and their many applications; part2 covers numerical mathematics, combinations and permutations, and anagrams. Volume 2: part 3 covers geometry, light, optics, vision and perspective; part 4 covers electricity. Volume 3: part 5 coverts magnetics and new applications; part 6 coverts catoptrics and dioptrics. Volume 4: part 7 covers mechanical games, 'occult', water and fire; part 8 covers fire, phosphorous and chemistry, electricity, magic squares. The optics material in in part 6 (190 pages). There are 44 'Recreations' covering the catoptric and dioptric phenomena, instruments, perspective, and anamorphosis. The catoptric recreations include: Images in plane, convex and concave mirrors; multiple mirrors and interreflected image; anamorphosis and deformed images by deformed mirrors; conical mirrors; images in spherical mirrors. The dioptric recreations include: camera obscura; magic lanterns; images from lenses; shadows. Each recreation is presented as an entertainment based on an optical phenomenon. The presentations are purely demonstrative, with figures accompanying some of the recreations, showing the optical effect or, in some few cases, indicating how it is accomplished. There is no theory or mathematics  presented. Generally, the reader is introduced to the most basic of optical principles of reflection and refraction by way of description and a general figures. The recreations present sometimes ingenious applications of basic principles to produce visual effects.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ R√©cr√©ations et math√©matiques mondaines au XVIII·µâ si√®cle: le cas de Guyot|Belhoste, B., Hazebrouck, D.|<i>Historia Mathematica<i>, Vol 41, No 4, 2014, pp 490‚Äì505.|At: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0315086014000779
