BP_Short or Common Title: Les Moyens de Donner la plus Grande Perfection Possible aux Lunettes
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A mathematical analysis of the achromatic doublet lens as advanced by Dollond.
BP_Description_1: In response to the Berlin Academy's announcement of an essay prize, Hennert planed a work to present the development of practical mathematical procedures to design achromatic doublet objective lenses that also minimized spherical aberration. He wrote that most craftsman and oculists were 'copying as blind workmen what once was prescribed' because they lacked the methods to make improvements.
BP_Description_2: The text begins with a summary of then-recent work in the analysis of chromatic aberration, the researchers involved, and the mathematics that had been developed as a basis for lens design. Hennert believes there is still a lack of practical mathematical tools. Following this are five articles devoted to the development of lens design tools. 1: The four qualities of good lenses, 2: The aberrations that affect lenses, particularly chromatic and spherical aberration, 3: The aberration of objects placed off-axis of the lens, 4: Glass for lenses, and 5: Application of the preceding developments to the construction of different types of lenses. Hennert limits his analysis to the use of Crown and Flint glass--as did Dollond in his commercial lenses--but considers chromatic and geometric aberrations on and off the optical axis. He also restricts his analysis to doublets, claiming 'All opticians agree in a preference for doublet objectives.'||Hennert's work is experiment and mathematics based; striving to give the craftsman a clear idea of analyses and how they are used for designing lenses. Examples are used throughout, especially in the last article where very detailed examples are given.
BP_Reference(s): The Early Development of the Achromatic Telescope Revisited|Zuidervaart, H., Cocquyt, T.|<i>Nuncius<i>, Vol 33, No 2, 2018, pp 265-344,

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean Nicolas SeÃÅbastien Allamand (1716-1787) French-born Dutch natural philosopher, eventually professor at the University of Leiden
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Reprinting of several of 's Gravesande's essays on various subject in natural philosophy, including his work on perspective.
BP_Description_1: s Gravesande helped found the <i>Journal litt√©raire de la Haye<i> in l713. It was a periodical of significance for twenty years in the history of science and in which 's Gravesande book reviews and essays. Those essays were reprinted by J.N.S. Allamand in the present work. Perhaps the two most famous being that on Perspective and that in which he broke his long-standing attachment to Newtonianism and adopted the Huygens-Leibniz concept of vis viva, affirming that ‚ÄúLa force d‚Äôun corps est proportionelle √† sa masse multipli√©e par le quarr√© de sa vitesse.‚Äù The second volume contains a 50-pages history of 's Gravesande's life and work. The work on perspective had been reviewed very positively by Johann Bernoulli in the <i>Acta Eruditorum<i> in 1711. 's Gravesande's work on perspective would later influence the British mathematician Brook Taylor's work on this subject.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1: Essay on Perspective, Usage of the Camera Obscura for Drawing, Elements of Universal Mathematics, Commentary on Newton's Universal Arithmetic, Essay on a New Theory of Impact of Bodies, Supplement to the Essay, Dissertation on the Force on Bodies by Mr. Calandrin, Remarks on the Construction of Pneumatic Machines, Various Letters. Volume 2: Reprinting of <i> Introductio ad philosophiam, metaphysicam et logicam continens<i>, Introduction to Philosophy, containing metaphysics and logic, of 1736 and some unprinted essays on similar topics discovered by Allamand.||The essay on perspective is an early work of 1711 which was translated in English in 1724. The work is in two parts: An elaborate geometric treatment of perspective and a consideration of the use of the camera obscura in drawing. 's Gravesande first introduces a mathematical model for perspectival  representations and associated concepts. From this he developed his theory of perspective, which he then used to describe and prove the correctness of a number of constructions. The application of the theory to constructions--that is, particular physical settings--is particularly elaborate. This included an application to sundials. Thirty-one plates of figures are devoted to these topics.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The geometry of an art: the history of the mathematical theory of perspective from Alberti to Monge|Andersen, K.|Springer, New York, 2007, 814 pp, NB: pp 328‚Äì360.||The impeccable credentials of an untrained philosopher: Willem Jacob 's Gravesande's career before his Leiden professorship, 1688‚Äì1717|van Besouw, J.|<i>Notes Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 70, No 3, 2016, pp 231-249.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A posthumously published work, from the manuscript collected by Harris‚Äôs friends, on optics, vision, and visual perception.
BP_Description_1: A posthumously published work on optics, vision, and visual perception. Harris‚Äôs Treatise started life as a book on microscopes in 1742, but work as assay master to the Mint likely left little time to compete it. After his death in 1764 his friends collected the manuscript and arranged for its publication 11 years later. Harris's text treats optics very briefly and concisely, and vision extensively. It is particularly important for its sections on vision and visual perception, where Harris refutes Berkeley's attack on visual perception based on geometry. Harris's is one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics. The list of such texts is short; in addition to that of Harris there is: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799.
BP_Description_2: The treatise is In two books. Book 1: Properties of light, reflection and refraction at plane surfaces, reflection and refraction at spherical surfaces, lenses, lens foci, lens images, chromatic dispersion. Book 2: The eye, limits of distinct vision, near and far-sightedness, images from plane and spherical mirrors, images from lenses, camera obscura. The optics material is a march or axioms, propositions, demonstrations, and corollaries--all of extreme concision. The material on the nature of light and color is Newtonian, and that on geometrical optics is detailed and mathematical with figures in the style of Smith's Compleat System of Optics of 1738. The material on the eye and vision is more extensive and detailed, particularly regarding the eye and visual perception. The sizes of the optical structures of the eye are given, as well as the size of the visual field, and reports of experiments Harris conducted on the limits of distinct vision off the visual axis. The section on visual perception defends a geometrical basis for perceptions of size, distance, and orientation, emphasizing the role of experience in perception--all contrary to Berkeley. The material on vision is also accompanied by long footnotes that amount to glosses on the main text.
BP_Reference(s): Image, eye, and retina|Wade, N.J.|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i> A, Vol 24, No 5, 2007, pp 1229-1249.||Berkeley, Reid, and the Mathematization of Mid-Eighteenth-Century Optics|Cantor, G.N.|<i>Journal of the History of Ideas<i>, Vol 38, No 3, 1977, pp. 429-448.||Perception in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries|Wade, N.J.|In: <i>Perception and Illusion: Historical Perspectives<i>|Springer, 2005, pp 78-79.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A vast, 8-volume set of teaching texts on mixed mathematics. Volume 7 deals with physical and geometric optics.
BP_Description_1: While he was teaching at the University of B√ºtzow, Wenceslaus Karsten began work on what would become his eight-part textbook on mathematics and natural philosophy. From his correspondence it is known that Karsten was charged with teaching mixed mathematics under very difficult conditions; students at B√ºtzow were many different courses of study, with little interest and no background in mathematics or natural philosophy. These texts were written in German, expressly for these students, since the provincial university at B√ºtzow drew few well-prepared students and neither university nor student could afford textbooks. Beginning in 1770 Karsten was in correspondence with Johann Heinrich Lambert and as a favor to Karsten, Lambert reviewed several sections as Karsten completed them. In 1778 Karsten moved to the University of Halle where he worked on the second edition of this textbook set. The first edition appeared between 1767 and 1777, and a second edition of the first six parts appeared between 1782 and 1790.
BP_Description_2: Part 1: Arithmetic and Geometry. Part 2: Additional Arithmetic, Calculations, Plane and Spherical Trigonometry, Additional Geometry. Part 3: Statics and the first Principles of Mechanics. Part 4: Mechanics of rigid bodies. Part 5: Hydraulics. Part 6: Hydraulics and Pneumatics. Part 7: Optics and Perspective. Part 8: Photometry. The optics material (109 pages of Part 7) has the general heading: General theory of light and shadow, the appearance of size, shape, and movement of objects, as perceived by the eye. Virtually all of the material is a presentation of a strictly geometric basis for visual perception. The eight sections are: Preliminary consideration of some features of light; Visual angle and appearances; Apparent form of remote objects; Apparent position of distant objects; Apparent movement; Phenomena causing the progressive propagation of light; Shadow and semi-shade; Sunlight in particular.
BP_Reference(s): Wenceslaus Johann Gustav Karsten (1732‚Äì1787): Von Neubrandenburg nach Halle ‚Äì Bewerbungen, Beziehungen, Berufungen|Schmidt, W.H.|<i>Martin‚ÄìLuther‚ÄìUniversit√§t Halle‚ÄìWittenberg, Reports on Didactics and History of Mathematics<i>, No 2, 2004, 33 pp.|http://webdoc.sub.gwdg.de/ebook/serien/e/reports_Halle-Wittenberg_math/04-02report.pdf||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.

Professor zu Butzow, der Churfl Bayerschen Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Munchen und der Hollandischen Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Harlem Mitglied. Der Ziebende Theil. BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by (attrib to Jan-Frans Thysbaert)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary optics and perspective text for Leuven University students with no background in mathematics.
BP_Description_1: There is no author cited, no preliminary material, no preface or forward, only a title page and index form the front matter. The book appears to be an optics and perspective text for Leuven University students with no background. It presents the elementary aspects of optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics and demonstrates them in simple applications, instruments, and experiments. An extant student manuscript titled Tractatus de Lumine is accompanied by plates of figures etched by C.H. Becker are nearly identical to those in the printed book; the earliest of these is dated 1766. Becker was also the engraver for the plates used in the 1775 printed text. The manuscript text is similar to the printed text and are from a course given at Louvain by  Ignatius Damas of Dinant. Apparently, the course and its text were in active use at the university for at least a decade before the printed text was produced. A similar student manuscript dated 1770 is in the Smithsonian.
BP_Description_2: The optics material (155 pages) is in five sections. Section 1: fundamental optical principles, properties of light, shadow, nature and propagation of light, vision. Section 2: Catoptric principles; plane, spherical, cylindrical, and conic mirrors. Section 3: Dioptric principles; refraction a plane and spherical surfaces. Section 4: The eye, distinct vision, myopia and hyperopia, 'artificial eye', Newtonian prismatic colors, the rainbow. Section 5: The simple and compound microscope,  the astronomical and terrestrial telescope, cata-dioptric telescope, achromatic telescope, magic lantern. The treatment is elementary but detailed and geometric. The style consists of definitions, experiments or demonstrations, theorems and corollaries.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Cours de l'Universit√© de Louvain<i>|Universit√© Catholique de Louvain, Archives de l'Universit√©|http://archives.uclouvain.be/atom//index.php/elementa-opticae-et-perspectivae-4
BP_Title: Elementa Opticae et Perspectivae
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Optics and Perspective

BP_Short or Common Title: Optick Catoptrick und Dioptrick in Zween Theilen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An optics text giving a general overview of the principles of optics, catoptrics and dioptrics. Accompanied by a longer and more detailed technical consideration of optical instruments including the microscope and telescope.
BP_Description_1: Spengler wrote several texts on mathematics and aspects of physics for use at the University of Dillingen, where he taught, and for other German universities as well. The first part of his optics text gives a general overview of the principles of optics, catoptrics and dioptrics. The second is much longer and is a detailed, technical consideration of optical instruments including the microscope and telescope. Spengler mentions visiting the great Augsburg instrument maker Georg Brander to examine his microscopes. Some of Spengler's figures are taken from Brander's literature.
BP_Description_2: The material is in two parts: Theoretical and Practical. The Theoretical part is in four sections. I: general properties of light, reflection, refraction, focal points, light and color.  II: catoptrics, focal points from mirrors, their calculation, images from mirrors. III: dioptrics, focal points from simple refraction, focal points from double refraction, lenses, their calculation. IV: optics, the eye, eye-function, images in the eye. The Practical part is in two  sections. I: The microscope, simple and compound, solar microscope. II: The telescope, achromatic telescope, mirror telescopes, magic lantern, camera obscura, 'universal ophthalmic machine'. The material is detailed, mathematical, and often accompanied by example calculations. The material on optical instruments gives typical examples, explains their operation, and gives general methods for construction. The figures are detailed and essential to the text, particularly for the optical instruments.
BP_Reference(s): Microscopes made in Augsburg|Keil, I.|In: <i>From Makers to Users: Microscopes, Markets, and Scientific Practices in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries<i>|<i>Proceedings of The International Workshop on the History of Microscopy<i>, 2007, pp 43-72.
BP_Title: Optick Catoptrick und Dioptrick in Zween Theilen. Der erste EnthaÃàlt die allgemeinen GrundsaÃàtze dieser Wissenschaften: Der Andere Giebt hinreichenden Unterricht von der Verfertigung, dem Gebrauche und den Vortheilen fast aller optischen Instrumente; Als der einfachen und zusammengesetzten Mikroscope, des Sonnenmikroscops, der hollaÃàndischen, astronomischen und gemeinen Fernrohren, der dollondischen Fernrohren, der gregorianischen und neutonianischen Telescope [et]c. und einer Neuen Optischen Universalmaschine. Geschrieben von Joseph Spengler, offentlichen Lehrer der Mathematik auf der hohen Schule zu Dillingen.
BP_Title English Translation: Optics, Catoptrics, and Dioptrics in Two Parts. The First Contains the General Principles of these Sciences:  The Other Gives Sufficient Instruction for the Making, the Use, and the Advantages of almost all Optical Instruments; Such as the Simple and Compound Microscope, The Sun Microscope, The Dutch and Common Telescopes, Dolland Telescopes, The Gregorian and Newtonian Telescopes, etc, and a New Universal Optical Machine.  Written by Joseph Spengler, Public Teacher of Mathematics in the High School at Dillingen.
BP_Biographical Statement: German Jesuit, mathematician. Taught natural philosophy and mathematics at Lucerne and Augsburg.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of short essays and treatises on wide-ranging and various mathematical subjects, including one devoted to optics which is Emerson's English translation of part of Newton's <i>Optical Lectures<i>.
BP_Description_1: William Emerson's final book is a collection of short essays and treatises on wide-ranging and various mathematical subjects. Eighteen 'articles' are presented. Regarding the 17th, which is his English translation of part of Newton's Optical Lectures  Emerson writes the Preface: 'I have here translated several papers of Sir I. Newton's Optical Lectures, Part II. which never was translated into English. The Phenomenon of the Rainbow is here computed in a way something different from what it is in his Optics, being here illustrated and wrought out in numbers, and therefore will  be more intelligible. I wonder this latter part of the Optical Lectures has never been translated. For tho' the substance of it is contained in the Optics, yet here are a great number of curious experiments not mentioned there, which deserve to be made public.'
BP_Description_2: The articles cover topics that included: I. Laws of chance; II. Annuities of lives; III. On forming Societies of common interest; IV. The Moon's motion and its irregularities; V. Construction of Arches; VI. Precession of equinoxes, universally solved; VII. Construction of logarithms by roots; VIII. Interpolation of quantities; IX. Finding the longitude at sea; X. Computation of interest; XI. Figure of sines and tangents; XII. Fortification and its general rules; XIII. Gunnery and its principles; XIV. Architecture, its rules and practice; XV. Music, its nature and principles; XVI. Rules of Philosophy and inquiry; XVII. Optical lectures; and XIII. Various problems and their solutions. The optical material consists of three sections from Newton Optical Lectures: Fundamental prismatic color experiment, colors generated by refraction from parallel surfaces, and the computation of the characteristics of the rainbow.
BP_Reference(s): The ‚ÄúPhilomaths‚Äù of 18 th Century England|Pedersen, O.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 8, No 1, 1963, pp 238-262.
BP_Title: Optics, being a Translation of some of Some Papers of Sir I. Newton's Optical Lectures, Part II. Never Englished before, p. 239 &c.. In: Miscellanies, or a Miscellaneious Treatise containing several mathematical subjects. "--Non ego paucis Offendor Maculis--" Horace
BP_Title English Translation: "I am not offended by a few stains" Horace
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, experimentalist. Excentric, prolific author.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Emerson's name does not appear on the titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary survey of physics with considerable Newtonian content.
BP_Description_1: Goldsmith's survey was prompted by Voltaire's <i>Lettres Philosophique<i>, and several passages in the general introduction to Book I are clearly from Voltaire. Though the main source for the material Goldsmith summarized was Diderot's <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, the emphasis, order, and level of detail in presentation was Goldsmith's own. Written for a general audience, the presentation is descriptive and only a very occasional bit of geometry invoked.  Apparently, Goldsmith began work on the survey in 1762 and sent the completed manuscript the publisher Newbery in 1766, long before his death. But only the first volume appeared before he died, the second being posthumous.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1: Book I Matter, attraction, magnetics, electricity, gravity, celestial forces, the earth, bodies descending to earth, motion, the pendulum, projectiles, mechanics, wheels, water, tides, hydrostatics, specific gravity, hydraulics. Volume 2: Book II Air, wind, and sound; Book III Fire, cold, light. The optics material (140 pages) in Book III includes: The nature of light, propagation, refraction, light through glass, lenses, the eye, eye-function, spectacles for correcting vision, simple and compound microscopes, the telescope and achromatic lenses, catoptrics, plane and curved mirrors, reflecting telescopes, colors, Newtonian prismatic colors, surface colors, the rainbow. The material is descriptive, elementary, and with only infrequent use of geometry. Goldsmith presents light as the flow of minute particles of an elemental fire, noting that heat and light are often found together.
BP_Reference(s): Oliver Goldsmith and Voltaire's 'Lettres Philosophiques'|Gargett, G.|<i>The Modern Language Review<i>, Vol 96, No 4 ,2001, pp. 952-963, NB: 959-960.
BP_Title: A survey of experimental philosophy, considered in its present state of improvement. Illustrated with cuts. In Two Volumes. Vol. I. Vol. II. By Oliver Goldsmith, M.B
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish novelist, playwright, poet. Dabler in natural philosophy, medicine.
BP_Collation: Vol 1:  œÄ¬≤ a‚Å¥ B-Z‚Å∏ Aa-Dd‚Å∏ Ee¬≤|Vol 2:  œÄ‚Å¥ B-Z‚Å∏ Aa-Cc‚Å∏ Dd‚Å∂

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The fourth and most complete edition of Johann Horvath's physics textbooks, <i>Physica Generalis et Particularis<i> and first in quarto size. Horvath's texts give evidence of the final ascendency of Newtonian science in the Hungarian Kingdom.
BP_Description_1: Early editions of Horvath's physics textbook adhered closely to the earlier books of fellow Jesuits Andreas Jaszlinszky and P√°l Mak√≥. But in later editions, Horvath wrote more independently, adopted Newtonian physics fully and completely, and addressed the reader in a clearer and direct style, though adhering to a Scholastic format. The texts became the most important and widely used in Hungarian universities and appeared in other European universities due in part to their Latin, their style and emphasis on teaching, and adoption by fellow Jesuits in other schools. Editions appeared in 1767, 1769, 1770, 1772, 1775, 1776, 1782, 1817.
BP_Description_2: The texts cover forces, mechanics, statics, motion, gravity, hydrostatics, hydrodynamics, solids, liquids, gases ('airs'), heat, light, electricity, magnetism, and celestial mechanics. The extensive section on light includes seven chapters. I: Propagation and the nature of light. II: Reflection, refraction, and diffraction. This is entirely Newtonian. III: Thin films, chromatics rings, and Newton 'fits'. IV: Transparency and Colors including the rainbow. V: Optics, vision, eye function, and perceptions. VI: Catoptrics and dioptrics. VII: Photometry.||The physical optics material is entirely Newtonian. The geometrical optics is elementary but complete. Generally, the treatment is descriptive, with mathematics no higher than geometry being used.
BP_Reference(s): A felvid√©ki fizika t√∂rt√©nete 1850-ig (A History of Physics in Upper Hungary to 1850)|Jol√°n Zempl√©n|<i>A Magyar Tudom√°nyt√∂rt√©neti int√©zet Tudom√°nyos k√∂zlem√©nyei No 122<i>, p 441: NB:|http://real.mtak.hu/34201/1/122_zemplen_fizika.pdf||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-363.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Georg Simon Kl√ºgel (1739 - 1812) German mathematician, natural philosopher. Student of K√§stner, Professor at the Universities of Helmstedt and Halle
BP_Short or Common Title: Geschichte und gegenwaÃàrtiger Zustand der Optik (a)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Georg Simon Kl√ºgel's German translation and augmentation of Joseph Priestley's history of optics in six parts, from Ancient Greece to 18th century optics.
BP_Description_1: Joseph Priestley was prompted to write a history of optics after the critical and commercial success of his <i>History and Present State of Electricity<i> of 1767. The bibliography appended to his history of optics lists 265 titles of books and journals he assembled for study and consultation on the history of natural philosophy in general and optics in particular. Priestley adopted a method he described in the preface: 'I  have  adopted  the historical  method,  because  it  appears  to  me  to  have many obvious advantages over any other for my purpose; being peculiarly calculate to enlarge the attention, and to communicate knowledge with the greatest ease, certainty, and pleasure.' But Priestley's history is deeply tinctured with his assessments of past work, experiments, and theories; it is not an hitoriographically neutral chronology. This is implied in the remarkable fold-out chronological frontispiece ('Biographical Chart'), which lists workers who, as Priestly says: 'have most distinguished themselves by their discoveries relating to vision, light and colours'. Priestley knew little mathematics, so his ability to understand, assess, and intelligently summarize optics after Descartes was quite limited. This may account for the book's prolonged descriptions and quotations from other works--making tedious reading. From this and the figures it copied it is clear that the work is derivative, but Priestley's made no greater claim: 'Neither in this volume, nor in the history of electricity, shall I be found to have made a parade of quoting any author that I have not actually consulted.' The lack of concision and of mathematics likely contributed to the books critical and commercial failure. Nevertheless, the book was an important vehicle for knowledge of optics and vision; Priestley provided English translations of many important sections of works in other languages, and detailed many important ideas in optics and vision new in the 18th century.  A German translation appeared in 1776. There would not be another book-length general history of optics written until Giambattista Venturi's <i>Commentari Sopra la Storia e le Teorie dell'Ottica<i> of 1814.||Kl√ºgel makes clear his reasons for translating Priestley's work: It is the only generally available text that presents and optics history and, with a few exceptions, presents the most important ideas and authors. Kl√ºgel notes that Priestley is shy with his mathematics and that when it was thought necessary, it has been added or corrected. Kl√ºgel substitutes Johann Lambert's history of perspective for that of Priestley's and notes that he has reduced the number of figures in the final German text in order to make it more practical. Kl√ºgel marks his additions and corrections with an asterisk in the German text.
BP_Description_2: Kl√ºgel translates Priestley's Preface and generally  produces a close translation, clearly marking his own changes. Priestly divides his optics history in six parts. Part 1: From Ancient Greece to 1600 (30 pages). Parts 2: The telescope, microscope, and the discoveries of Kepler and his contemporaries (70 pages). Part 3: Descartes, vision, optical instruments, 17th century optical experiments. Part 4: Between Descartes and Newton, vision, reflection, refraction, diffraction (100 pages). Part 5: Newtonian optics, theory of light and colors, colors from thin and thick plates, cause of reflection and refraction, Newton's telescope (110 pages). Part 6: 18th century optics, the nature of light, phosphors, refraction and dispersion, birefringence, vision, optical instruments (420 pages). The long quotations and extracts give Priestley's history the style and tone of a commonplace book, with entries placed chronologically. Only Priestley's abiding interest in vision and optical instruments intrudes. Mathematics is avoided entirely. The geometrical optics that is presented is quoted from Smith's Compleat System of Opticks of 1738, and physical optics centers around Boscovich's theory of point elements of matter surrounded by spheres of attractive and repulsive force which is used to explain reflection and refraction.||Kl√ºgel's work included editing, clarifying, and augmenting some of Priestley's more technical and less correct sections. These are either added notes or sections marked with an asterisk. Kl√ºgel also added a considerable section devoted to Johann Heinrich Lambert's Photometria of 1760; a book which Priestley knew of but claimed not to be able to acquire.
BP_Reference(s): Joseph Priestley and The History of Optics: Historiography for Science Education|Moura, B.A.|In: <i>Proceedings of the IHPST 13th Biennial International Conference<i>|IHPST, 2015|At: http://www.researchgate.net/publication/279852019_Joseph_Priestley_and_The_History_of_Optics_Historiography_for_Science_Education||<i>The Enlightened Joseph Priestley, A Study of His Life and Work from 1773 to 1804<i>|Schofield, R.E.|The Pennsylvania State University Press, University Park, 1997, 196 pp, NB pp 138-143.||The Scientific Background of Joseph Priestley|Schofield, R.E.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 13, No 3, 1957, pp 148-163.||Joseph Priestleys Optik in Newtons Bahnen und die Darstellung des Regenbogens|Busch, W.|In: Verfeinertes Sehen, De Gruyter Oldenbourg, 2008, 253 pp, NB: pp 79-89.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A modern, specialized text in natural philosophy, written to replace the Jesuit compendia previously used in courses in natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Labeled as the second, much improved and larger edition, this is essentially a new work. Erxleben's text was adopted by the University of Ingolstadt, after the suppression of the Jesuits of 1773. Erxleben's book was a modern, specialized text and replaced the Jesuit compendia previously used in courses in natural philosophy. Editions appeared in 1772, 1777, 1784, 1787, 1791, 1793, and 1796. A Polish translation appeared at Karkow in 1788 and Danish at Copenhagen in 1790.||On becoming interested in color, Wolfgang von Goethe turned to Erxleben's 'compendium' to read of the elementary facts of prismatic refraction and the camera obscura. It was probably the edition of 1787.
BP_Description_2: Thirteen chapters cover the following: Introduction to the science of nature, General examination of bodies in general, On motion, Statics and Mechanics, Hydrostatics, Attractive force in fluid bodies, On the Air, On Light, On Heat and Cold, On Electricity, On Magnetic Force, On World building and the Earth in general, On the Earth in particular. The optics material (88 pages) covers: General remarks about sight; theory of light, Newton and Descartes; apparent size, position, and orientation of viewed objects; reflection; mirrors, refraction; refraction at flat and curved surfaces; prismatic colors; object colors; optical instruments; the eye and indistinct vision; camera obscura; magnifying glass; magic lantern; diffraction. The material is concise, elementary and descriptive; no mathematics is used.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Electricity in the 17th and 18th Centuries: A Study of Early Modern Physics<i>|Heilbron, J.L.|University of California Press, 1979, pp 143-144.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-363.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A four-volume survey of experimental natural philosophy based on Sigaud de Lafond's experience as private instructor and demonstrator of physics. It was notable for its complete reliance on experiment and demonstration.
BP_Description_1: Joseph-Aignan Sigaud de Lafond was a student of Abbe Jean-Antoine Nollet and after Nollet's death succeeded him at the Coll√®ge Louis-le-Grand. He had acquired a deep understanding of the pedagogy of natural philosophy suitable for general audiences. The expulsion of the Jesuit from France in 1764 created an educational vacuum and Sigaud de Lafond began public lecturing and demonstrations. He assembled a famous experimental physics cabinet and in 1775 published a description of its contents and use. All of this was brought together in his four-volume survey of experimental natural philosophy published in 1777. It was notable for its complete reliance on experiment and demonstration, responding not only to the changing philosophical approach by professionals but also increased interest on the part of the public. Editions appeared in 1777 and 1787.
BP_Description_2: Sigaud de Lafond's survey of natural philosophy is in four volumes. Volume 1: Section 1 Principles of bodies, coherence of their parts; Section 2 General properties of bodies; Section 3 Movement and repose. Volume 2: Section 4 Statics; Section 5 Hydrostatics; Section 6 Fluids. Volume 3: Section 7 Air; Section 8 Motion of air; Section 9 Air and animal economy; Volume 4: Section 10 Fire, light, and electricity; Section 11 Magnetism. The optics material (165 pages) in Section 10 includes the following. Optics: the nature of light, propagation; optics; light rays divergent and convergent; inverse-square of distance density; rays forming images in the eye. Dioptrics: refraction at surfaces; lenses; foci; spectacles; simple and compound microscopes; magic lantern; camera obscura; telescopes. Catoptrics: reflection, mirrors; convex and concave spherical mirrors; reflected images; colors; prismatic colors; object color; color mixing. The material is descriptive with little or no mathematics and is accompanied by numerous experiments to explain and demonstrate principles. Past and current authors are  extensively cited, with alternative theories presented and evaluated. Not only a summary of natural philosophy, the work can be considered a 'guide to the literature.'
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Art of Teaching Physics: The Eighteenth-century Demonstration Apparatus  of Jean Antoine Nollet<i>|Pyenson, L., Gauvin, J.-F., editors|Les Editions du Septentrion, 2002, pp 22-27.

Sigaud de la Fond, Ancien Professeur de Math√©matiques, Demonstrateur de Physique experimentale en l'Universit√©; de la Societ√© Royal des Sciences de Montpellier, des Academies d"angers, de Baviere, de Valladolid, de Florence, de Saint-Petersbourg, &c. &c. 4 Vol. in8‚Å∞, avec figures, br. 24 liv.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A deeply mathematical and entirely analytic presentation of dioptrics for telescopes and microscopes.
BP_Description_1: Georg Simon Kl√ºgel was a mathematician and his presentation of dioptrics for telescopes and microscopes reflects that: deeply mathematical and entirely analytic. Kl√ºgel had studied Euler's <i>Dioptricae<i> and took a similar approach to the material, but often extending the analysis (as with off-optical-axis aberration analysis). The <i>Analytische Dioptrik<i> is dedicated to Euler. Another source for Kl√ºgel's book was his own German translation (1778) of the French text by Nicolas Fuss, friend and student of Euler, on detailed instructions for constructing an achromatic microscope objective. Kl√ºgel's book was widely known and used by opticians; Gauss had a copy in his library, Joseph Fraunhofer consider it the only book a 'Praktiker' of optics required.
BP_Description_2: The work is in two parts, theory and practice. Part 1: General theory of the telescope and magnifying instruments. Chapters cover: Refraction, refraction through several lenses, magnification, field of view, the eye, brightness; dispersion due to varying refraction; ray divergence from lenses; reflection of rays from spherical mirrors and through lenses. Part 2: Application of the general theory to special types of optical tools. Chapters cover: Methods for finding refraction and dispersion; achromatic lenses; the objective lens and beam deviation off the optic axis; refraction in general in the telescope; telescopes of the first kind in which no image is present, of the second kind or astronomical, of the third kind with two images; calculation of a telescope mirror; theory of the microscope; single lens microscopes; spherical lens; double, triple and quadruple microscopes with single lens; compound microscopes; achromatic objectives. The material is detailed, technical, and entirely analytical. One of the few practical aspects discussed is measuring refraction and dispersion; the method of Boscovich and his vitrometer are described.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Spectrum of Belief: Joseph Von Fraunhofer and the Craft of Precision Optics<i>|Jackson, M.W.|MIT Press, 2000, pp 57-58.||The Development of the Microscope Objective|Bennett, A.H.|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 33, No 3, 1943, pp 123-128.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Thomas Kipling (1748-1822) Fellow at Trinity College Cambridge, Senior Wrangler in mathematics in 1768.
BP_Short or Common Title: The elementary parts of Dr. Smith's compleat system of opticks
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An epitome and updating of Smith's Opticks of 1738. Written both as a text for students and as a guide to teachers for a course in optics.
BP_Description_1: The unnamed author of this work is Thomas Kipling (1748-1822), Fellow at Trinity College Cambridge and Senior Wrangler in mathematics in 1768. In his Preface he explains the need for a text on optics suitable for tutor use in universities. Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i>, printed only once in 1738 in a relatively small quantity, had long been unavailable. The only optics texts in English available at the time were those of Emerson and Harris. The former was judged too advanced and mathematical, the latter missing important topics. Kipling was guided by the topics in Smith's work, amended by recent developments and his own and other tutor's notes from the optics courses they taught. The result was a modest work of just over 100 pages, affordable and accessible by most students, and perhaps more importantly, serviceable as a guide to teachers for a course in optics. The 6 pages of subscribers make it clear how well the author judged the need and want for such a summary of optical principles.
BP_Description_2: The material is presented in 14 chapters. 1: nature and propagation of light. 2: color. 3: Refraction, reflection, diffraction and emission of light, and their causes. 4: Refraction of a ray at a plane, prism, or spherical lens. 5: Calculation of the focus from a mirror. 6: Images from mirrors. 7: Calculation of the focus of parallel rays refraction incident on a plane or spherical lens. 8: Images from lenses. 9: The eye and eye-function. 10: Spectacles. 11: Calculation of spherical and chromatic aberration of lenses. 12: Examples of refracting and reflecting telescopes; construction details. 13: The rainbow. 14: Telescopic discoveries in the start. As with Smith's text, the physical optics and the theory of light and color is entirely Newtonian. The geometrical optics is as detailed as that in Smith's text; the cases and conditions are fewer, but the explanations are more extended, detailed, and more accessible.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  Reading up on the Optics. Refashioning Newton's Theories of Light and Colors in Eighteenth-Century Textbooks|Dijksterhus, F.J.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 308-327.||<i>Admissions to the College of St. John the Evangelist in the University of Cambridge, Part III<i>|Scott, R.F., editor|Cambridge University Press, 1903, 722 pp, NB: pp 698-701.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An extended brochure summarizing Marat's experimental results involving heat, electricity, and light. Appropriate experiments are cited in support of each claim made about the nature of light and heat.
BP_Description_1: This is the first scientific work Jean-Paul Marat published after his return to France from 11-year stay in England in 1776. Marat held that fire, light, and electricity were the manifestation of an elemental fiery fluid and conducted many experiments between 1777 and 1779  involving heat, electricity, and light. A report of Marat's work was presented to the French Academie Royale des Sciences with a positive response. Encouraged by this, Marat immediately wove his experimental results into a text, with the appropriate experiment cited in support of each claim, and had it published as this extended brochure. The title states it is the second edition, but it is actually a reprinting of the first edition which appeared earlier that same year. The wording in the title page regarding the status of the experiments is changed slightly ('experiments that have just been verified' to 'experiments that have been verified') and the text has been corrected by Marat in a few places.
BP_Description_2: Marat hypothesized that electrical phenomena were manifestations of an electrical fluid, that heat was an igneous fluid, and light a luminous fluid. The text weaves together 116 experiments demonstrating the nature of these fluids and their interaction. The most striking was a large objective lens admitting solar light into a camera obscura. Flames and heated objects were placed in the beam and projected images onto a distant wall. The optical inhomogeneities caused in the air were seen rising from any object placed in the beam's path. The following year Marat would publish another optical work with an etching depicting this--the first representation of what is now known as Schlieren.
BP_Reference(s): Public Experiments and their Analysis with the Replication Method|Herring, P.|<i>Science & Education<i>, Vol 16, No 6, 2007, pp 637-645.||Du Marat In√©dit|Gottschalk, L.R., Connes, M.G.|<i>Annales historiques de la R√©volution francaise<i>, No 15, 1926, pp 209-216.||<i>Isaac Newton, Optique, Traduit de l‚Äôanglais par Jean-Paul Marat (1787)<i>|Blay, M.|Dunod, Paris, 2015, p 375, NB pp 50-69.||Jean-Paul Marat (1743-1793), cientista e tradutor de Newton|Tosi, L.|<i>Qu√≠mica Nova<i>, Vol 22, No 6, 1999, pp 907-912.|

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Marat's second work reporting experimental results involving light, on which basis he rejected Newtonian optics with its theory of the heterogeneity of white light.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Paul Marat followed the initial success and positive reception by the French Academie Royale des Sciences of his heat, light, and electricity experiments of 1779, with a more extensive set of experiments devoted exclusively to light. As with the earlier work, he wove together his experimental results with commentary to produce this text. He interpreted the results as requiring a rejection of Newtonian optics with its theory of the heterogeneity of white light and the nature of reflection, refraction, and diffraction. In its place was a fluid undergoing attractive interaction with objects around which it moved. Marat felt he was correcting Newton's theory of light and color and submitted a report to the Academie. It was rejected and Marat appended the report along with his comments at the end of this work. A German translation appeared at Leipzig in 1783.
BP_Description_2: Jean-Paul Marat's text describes the principle apparatus for his light experiments: a 'helioscope' that consisted of a large objective lens capable of creating large images on a distance wall in an otherwise darkened room. He interpreted the colors surrounding the weak shadows of prisms and spheres as the result of a kind of diffraction, a deflection of light's path as it passed close to the object. Marat held that this was the cause of color separation produced by prisms and thin films, not differing refraction or interference as Newton claimed.

BP_Author full name: Claude Etienne Baron de; & Goussier, Louis Jacques Marivetz
BP_Author last name first: Marivetz, Claude Etienne Baron de; & Goussier, Louis Jacques
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A five-volume, multiple-part overview of the physics of motion, light, heat, electricity, magnetism, and chemical transformation. All physical phenomena were explained by aether motion producing attractions and repulsion, usually in the form of vortices scaled either to move the planets or the tiniest bits of matter.
BP_Description_1: In 1779 Claude Etienne Baron de Marivetz and  Louis Jacques Goussier announced plans to produce a general theory of physical geography derived from fundamental principles--which meant the physics of motion, light, heat, electricity, magnetism, and chemical transformation. Seven parts in five volumes of <i>Physique de Monde<i> appeared from 1780 to 1787 before the project came to an end, having consumed much of de Marivetz's fortune but never having reached the point of applying basic physics to geography. The system of physics presented Marivetz and Goussier rests entirely on a universal, all-pervading aether and its motion. All physical phenomena were explained by aether motion producing attractions and repulsion, usually in the form of vortices scaled either to move the planets or the tiniest bits of matter. Though their system was essentially Cartesian, Marivetz and Goussier insisted it was new. The work is remarkable for its extended consideration of the history of contributions from eminent authors and so provides a late 18th century view of the history of physics. The work is also remarkable for the large and numerous plates, particularly for the material dealing with light, often hand colored. The drawing for these and much of the technical material in <i>Physique du Monde<i> was produced by Goussier--having produced the drawings for nearly one-third of the plates in Diderot's <i>Encyclop√©die<i>. Notices and reviews of  <i>Physique du Monde<i> appeared in Journal des S√ßavans, Journal encyclop√©dique, L‚ÄôAnn√©e litt√©raire, Observations sur la physique, Mercure de France, and the London Monthly Review. But, as the conspicuous official silence of the  French Academie Royale des Sciences suggests, the ideas of Marivetz never entered mainstream French science. The rarity of copies of <i>Physique du Monde<i> is probably because upon Marivetz's execution in 1794 during the French Terror, unsold copies in the bookseller's and Marivetz's home were confiscated and the paper used for wrapping and munitions manufacture.
BP_Description_2: Given the scope of what Marivtez and Goussier covered (and intended to cover) in <i>Physique du Monde<i>, 'Monde' is best understood as 'Universe.' The five tomes have contents as follows.  Tome 1: Cosmogony and history of theories; extended extracts from Buffon's system of cosmogony. Tome 2 Part 1: Space and the universal aether; the solar system; comets; the stars; vortices in the aether; nine propositions on vortices and motion in the solar system; density and weight. Tome 2 Part 2: Explanation of the plates. Tome 2 part 3: Tables of data on planetary orbits, vocabulary. Tome 3: Light and vision. Tome 4 Part 1: Various philosophical considerations, vision, color. Tome 4 Part 2: Theory of color. Tome 5 Part 1: Concerning fire. Tome 5 Part 2: Chemistry; chemistry and fire; chemistry and light; fire and light. Tome 5 Part 3: Theory of fire; heat; combustion and vitrification; transmutation of metals; various observations. The material on light and optics comprises all of Tome 3 (365 pages); that on vision, visual perception, and color is all of Tome 4 (544 pages); and that on phosphors, light sources, and light from hear is part of Tome 5 part 2 (90 pages). The entire theory and all its manifestations rests on the hypothesis that light is movement or tendency to movement in the universal aether. Reflection, refraction, and diffraction are caused by the aether's interaction with objects; Newton's theory of light and color is rejected. All sections dealing with light and vision contain extensive reviews of history and considerations of alternative theories. But even at this late date, the central argument is for an advanced form of a Cartesian theory of light and is ultimately mechanical rather than ballistic.
BP_Reference(s): Marivetz, Goussier, and Planet Earth: A Late Enlightenment Geo-Physical Project|Taylor, K.L.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 48, No 4, 2006, pp 258‚Äì283.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A 10-volume survey of Mixed Mathematics in Spanish; the result of Bails's translation and summarizing of the best contemporary European works on mathematics and natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Benito Bails produced a 10-volume survey of Mixed Mathematics between 1772 and 1783. He held a chair of mathematics at Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando (Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando), an institution devoted to the teaching of painting, sculpture, and architecture. The expulsion of the Jesuits from Spain created both an educational vacuum and opportunity. Renewed interest in Spanish texts written expressly for university student use resulted in Bails being commissioned to produce 'a great treatise of mathematics.' It was not intended that Bails produce an original work; rather (and expressly stated) he was charged with translating and summarizing the best contemporary European works. The result far exceeded the Academy's expectations, or even its need. Among other achievements, Bails introduced the Calculus into university education in Spain. Bails also produced the <i>Principios de Matem√°ticas<i>, a more concise and elementary 3-volume version in 1776. Both the <i>Elementos de Matematica<i> and the <i>Principios de Matem√°ticas<i> were widely used until the middle of the 19th century in Spain and in Latin American schools.||Though work on the early volumes of the first edition were was finished in 1772, they did not appear in commerce until 1779. The first edition appeared between 1779 and 1783. A second, slightly revised edition appeared between 1790 and 1793.
BP_Description_2: Tome 6 of Benito Bails survey of Mixed Mathematics is devoted exclusively to optics, including the following. Optics: nature of light, propagation, illumination, reflection, refraction, atmospheric refraction, photometry, burning mirrors. Catoptrics: Reflected rays and their calculation, reflected images, calculation of foci of various mirrors, reflected caustics. Dioptrics: Refracted rays, calculation of foci of lenses, refracted images, determining focus of oblique rays, chromatic aberration of spherical lenses.  The Eye and Vision: Ocular anatomy, eye-function, view and perception. Optical Instruments: spectacles, camera obscura, magic lantern, common glasses, simple and compound microscope, solar microscope, perfecting the magic lantern and the solar microscope, astronomical glasses. The Telescope and its Use: Calculating the focus of rays through any number of lenses, catadioptric telescope, theory of aberrations applied to microscopes and telescopes, images from catadioptric instruments, achromatic lenses. Practical Optics: Figuring lenses, polishing dishes, choosing glass, preparation before figuring and polishing, cutting lenses, polishing lenses, melting, forming and polishing lenses for telescopes, centering the objective lens.  The material is extensive, detailed, both theoretical and practical, and analytic. The work is particularly important as complete summary of all aspects of optics current at the time and considered important for study at the university.
BP_Reference(s): Construyendo la modernidad: Nuevos datos y enfoques sobre la introducci√≥n del C√°lculo Infinitesimal en Espa√±a (1717-1787)|Ausejo, E., Sanches, F.J.M.|<i>Llull: Revista de la Sociedad Espa√±ola de Historia de las Ciencias y de las T√©cnicas<i>, Vol 33, 2010, pp 25-56.||Mathematics Education in Spain and Portugal|Ausejo, E., Matos, J.M.|In:  <i>Handbook on the History of Mathematics Education<i>, Springer, 2014, pp 283-302.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An important, if not original, contribution to available textbooks. It was known for and used extensively in the study of physics because of its clarity and quality of presentation.
BP_Description_1: Mathurin Jacques Brisson wrote the <i>Dictionnaire Raisonn√© de Physique<i> while he at was at the Coll√®ge de Navarre as Nollet's disciple then successor and disseminator of the ideas of experimental physics. As with other of his works, the <i>Dictionnaire Raisonn√© de Physique<i> was an important not for any original contribution but for the clarity and quality of presentation and the extent to which is was used in the study of physics. Brisson's work was among the first to use the new chemical terms of Lavoisier, Morveau, and Fourcroy. He makes clear in his Discours Preliminaire that he considers dictionairies as the best and surest way to help educate the public in matters of science, since dictionaries proved for immediate and easy look-up. In this regard, Brisson's entries are not just words and definitions, but usually concise dissertations or treatises that often use figures for clarity. Like his teacher Jean-Antoine Nollet, Brisson strove for clarity and teacherly effectiveness.||Editions appeared in 1781 and with additions and revisions in 1787, the later was reprinted at Paris in 1800. Translations appeared in Portugese and Spanish.
BP_Description_2: <i>Dictionnaire RaisonneÃÅ de Physique<i> contains the following optical entries:  Apparent Distance, Appearance, Camera Obscura, Catoptrics, Colors, Diffraction, Eye, Focus, Lenses, Light, Microscope, Opacity, Optics, Prism, Propagation of Light, Rainbow, Reflection of Light, Refraction of Light, Shadow, Telescope, Transparency, View, Vision. The entries have the concision expected of a topical dictionary, but are detailed, geometric, and make extensive use of figures.
BP_Reference(s): Natural Philosophy and Public Spectacle in the Eighteenth Century|Schaffer, S.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 21, No 1, 1983, pp 1-43.

BP_Short or Common Title: Saggio de ricerche sull'intensita del lume
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elaborate treatise on photometry and the calculation of illumination.
BP_Description_1: An elaborate treatise on photometry and the calculation of illumination. One of many monographs produced by Fossombroni in a wide range of mathematical, scientific, and engineering subjects. Fossombroni appears to be unaware of Lambert's <i>Photometria<i> of 1760 that deals with the elementary aspects of the same subject but far more elaborately.
BP_Description_2: The work opens with a long <i>Discorso Preliminaire<i> in which the advances made in mathematics, particularly algebra and calculus, are outlined and how they can be applied to problems in physics. The main body of the work begins with general principles being presented: Defining light sources and giving the inverse-square of distance relationship for incident light density. The general principles are used to solve eight problems with increasingly complex geometric settings and are essentially geometric-computational problems, solved with algebra and calculus. Fossombroni problems involve point light sources and lines or surface over which minimum or maximum illuminance is to be found, or finding equations for surfaces of uniform illuminance. The eight problems presented showcase Fossombroni's power as a mathematician.
BP_Reference(s): Considerazioni sul Saggio di ricerca sull‚Äôintensit√† del lume di Vittorio Fossombroni|Bruni, B.|In: Societ√† Italiana degli Storici della Fisica e dell Astronomia: Atti del XXXV Convegno annuale; Proceedings of the 35th Annual Conference, Arezzo 2015|Esposito, S., editor|Pavia University Press, 2016, pp 3-13.
BP_Title: Saggio de ricerche sull'intensita del lume, di Vittorio Fossombroni Aretino. ". . . Haec ego mecum Compressis agito labris: ubi quid datur oti Illudo chartis . . ." Hor. Sat. IV, Lib. I.
BP_Title English Translation: Essay on Research on the Intensity of Light, of Vittorio Fossombroni of Arezzo. ". . . Thus with lips shut tight, I debate with myself when I've given a bit of leisure, fussing with my papers . . ." Horace Book 1, Satire 4.
BP_Biographical Statement: Itanlian mathematician, then statesman. Worked for the grand dukes of Tuscany, first as engineer then as Prime Minister.
BP_Provenance: Donation inscription dated 1802 on titlepage. Bookplate of Conte Prospero Balbo on pastedown.
BP_Nonce-volume: Bound with Equazionie de Condizione della Brachistrocrona 1791

BP_Short or Common Title: Elementa physic√¶ experimentalis usui tironum aptat√¶
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Posthumous publication of an extensive Latin manuscript of a what can be considered an elementary precis of Musschenbroek on the elements of physics.
BP_Description_1: Antonio Genovesi was well versed in physics and was responsible for the first Neapolitan printing of Musschenbroek's <i>Elementa Physicae<i> in 1745. At the time of Genovesi's death, an extensive Latin manuscript of a what can be considered an elementary precis of Musschenbroek on the elements of physics was nearly complete but unpublished. The Latin manuscript had been given to Niccol√≤ Fergola and with his editing it appeared in 1779. Subsequent editions appeared in 1781, 1791, and 1793. The market for an Italian translation of the book was evident and Abbot Marco Fassadoni produced one and published it in Venice in 1783.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1, Book 1: The nature of physics; Book 2: the properties of bodies in general; Book 3: The properties of bodies of smaller type. Volume 2 Book 4: The astronomical sphere; Book 5: The Earth and the sea; Book 6: Of animals and plants; Book 7: Of air and meteorics. The optics material (25 pages) includes: Opaque, transparent, and luminous bodies; reflection and rays of light; refraction of light; the eye and eye-function; colors. The material is entirely descriptive, only the elementary geometry is used. The nature of light is considered from both the Cartesian and Newtonian points of view. Only the most elementary aspects of geometrical optics are considered.
BP_Reference(s): Il Libro dei Antonio Gneovesi sulla Fisica|Bergamasco, I., Lippiello, M.|In: <i>Atti del XXIII Congresso Nazionale di Storia della Fisica e dell'Astronomia<i>|Tranucci, P, editor|Progedit, 2004, pp 64-82.||The Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica in Naples|Addabbo, C|In: <i>Reading Newton in Early Modern Europe<i>, Boran, E.A, and Feingold, M., editors|Brill, Leiden, 2017, pp 23-63, NB pp 43-45.
BP_Title: Elementa physicae experimentalis usui tironum aptatae. Tomus Primus. Tomus Secundus. Accedunt nonnulae Dissertations Phyico-Mathematicae constriptae.  A Nicolao Fergola.
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Experimental Physics Adapted for the User of Tyros. By the author Antonio Genovesi. First Volume. Second Volume. Added are some Physico-Mathematical Disserations that have been Written.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian philosopher, economist. Professor at the University of Naples.
BP_Collation: Vol 1: a‚Å∂ A-L‚Å∏ [M‚Å¥] (lacking L‚Çá L‚Çà)|Vol 2: A-M‚Å∏

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Theses defending aspects of the thought of Francisco de Villalpando
BP_Description_1: As was the custom of the time, the two disputants, Josep Miquel and Josep Prat of the University of Cervera, defend theses written by the presiding professor: Francisco de Villalpando (1740-1797). He was a pioneer in bring Enlightenment philosophy to Spain. Parts of the thesis deal with  his <i> Mathematicarum disciplinarum elementa in usum physicae candidatorum<i> of 1778.
BP_Description_2: In the section dealing with Particular Physics, article 4 deals with nature of light, its 'subtle rays' and their reflection, refraction, and color. The material is descriptive and elementary, covering mirrors, images, halos, and the rainbow. One plate of figures is devoted to these optical topics.

BP_Title English Translation: Theses Drawn From Philosophy
BP_Biographical Statement: Josep Miquel would become professor of literature at the University of Cervesa.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A single volume of 10 treatises abstracted from Para du Phanjas's larger 4-volume general course in natural philosophy of 1772.
BP_Description_1: A single volume abstract of the 4-volume general course in natural philosophy of 1772 by Para Du Phanjas. He taught at the University of Franche-Comt√© in Besan√ßon France with great effect, acquiring a considerable reputation. He produced a 4-volume general course in natural philosophy that was both an encyclopedia of physics and a philosophy of the sciences from his work as a teacher. This volume is his own abridgement of the large work.
BP_Description_2: Para du Phanjas constructed the 10 treatises by abstracting of his larger 4-volume general course in natural philosophy. Treatise 1 General theory of matter: its extent, division, divisibility, inertness, laws of action, homogeneity. Treatise 2 General theory of bodies: Solids, fluids, elasticity, weight and gravity. Treatise 3 General theory of motion: successive motion, obstacles to motion, laws of motion, communication of motion in bodies with and without 'spring.' Treatise 4 Particular theory of motion: composition of motion, linear and curvilinear motion, acceleration and retardation, ballistics, reflected and refracted motion. Treatise 5 Theory of mechanics and machines. Treatise 6 Theory of the earth. Treatise 7 Theory of water. Treatise 8 Theory of air. Treatise 9 Theory of light. Treatise 10 Theory of the heavens. The optics material in Treatise 9 (70 pages) includes: The nature of light, light a luminiferous fluid emitted by luminous bodies, objections and their refutation to this theory, diversity of colors, decomposition of light into colors, efficacy of light rays,  objections and their refutation to this theory, laws of light's propagation, light in the eye, vision, eye-function, visual perception of size, motion, orientation, distance, ocular anatomy, indistinct vision, astronomical refraction, twilight,
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Catholic Encyclopedia, Volume 11<i>|Herbermann, C.G., and others, editor|The Encyclopedia Press, New York, 1913, pp 469-470.
BP_Title: EleÃÅmens de physique : ou abreÃÅgeÃÅ du cours complet de physique, speÃÅculative et expeÃÅrimentale, systeÃÅmatique et geÃÅomeÃÅtrique. De M. L'Abee Para du Phanjas par l'Auteur.
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Physics: or Abstract of a Complete Course of Physics of Abbe Para du Phanjas. Speculative and Experimental, Systematic and Geometric, By the Author.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Jesuit, philosopher, mathematician, natural philosopher. Professor of philosophy at Embrun College, textbook author.
BP_Provenance: Three library stamps on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of 92 experiments involving colored shadows, intending to show their cause and from that, the nature of light and color.
BP_Description_1: A clearly presented collection of 92 careful experiments involving colored shadows. The intent is to deduce the causes of colored shadows, and from those the nature of light and color. The author is listed only as H.F.T., but the work has been attributed to Jean-Henri Hassenfratz. It is referenced in Part Three of the 1790 edition of Johann Samuel Traugott Gehler's <i>Physikalisches W√∂rterbuch<i> in the article on Shadows. And, more importantly, this in turn is referenced by Georg-Christof Lichtenberg in one of his letters to Johann Goethe in response to a copy of the 1793 <i>Beitr√§ge zur Optik<i> Goethe had sent him. Lichtenberg was a confirmed Newtonian and was gently urging  Goethe to consider alternatives to the theory in the <i>Beitr√§ge zur Optik<i>. Lichtenberg urged Goethe to get a copy of the book and study the many experiments is presented, since he was certain that the book presented ideas similar to and seemingly in support of Goethe's theory, but was subject to the same reservations that Lichtenberg presented (carefully and with due respect!) regarding Goethe's theory. Goethe did study Hassenfratz's book; he presents a summary of it in the history section of <i>Farbenlehre<i> of 1809 and credits Hassenfratz with the idea of complementary colors.
BP_Description_2: The material is presented in three parts, I: Conditions necessary to produce colored shadows. II: Different methods of producing colored shadows. III: The cause of colored shadows. Shadows of different colors are produced from the sun, from the sun and sky, from just the sky, from artificial sources, from artificial sources and the sky, from artificial sources and the full moon. In all, 92 experiments are described involving the production, observation and assessment of colored shadows and the implications of their results for the theory of light and color. The material contains the first description of complementary colors produced by light and shadow.
BP_Reference(s): Lichtenberg‚Äôs Letter to Goethe on ‚ÄúF√§rbige Schatten‚Äù|Joots, U., Lee, B.B., Zaidi, Q.|<i>Color Research and Application<i>, Vol 27, No 4, 2002, pp 300-303.
BP_Title: Observations sur les Ombres ColoreÃÅes, Contenant une suite d'ExpeÃÅriences sur les diffeÃÅrentes Couleurs des Ombres, sur les moyens de rendre les Ombres ColoreÃÅes, & sur les causes de la diffeÃÅrence de leurs Couleurs. Par H.F.T.
BP_Title English Translation: Observations on Colored Shadows. Containing a suite of Experiements on the Different Colors of Shadows, on the way of Rendering Colored Shadows, and on the Causes of their Different Colors. By H.F.T.
BP_Biographical Statement: French chemist, physics professor, mine inspector, and participant in the French Revolution. Took part in the creation of the √âcole Polytechnique and became its first professor of physics.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of 'D Ed. Pergens' on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Essentially, a translation of Edm√© Gilles Guyot's <i>Nouvelles r√©cr√©ations physiques et mathematiques<i> of 1769‚Äì70. An effort to instruct while entertaining.
BP_Description_1: William Hooper borrowed heavily from the four volumes of his French predecessor, Edm√© Gilles Guyot and his <i>Nouvelles R√©cr√©ations Physiques et Mathematiques<i> that appeared at Paris in 1769‚Äì70. Indeed, most of Hooper's Rational Recreations is a translation from Guyot. Hooper's presentations are based on his idea, expressed in the prefaced that science presented to the public should not be 'dull, tedious, disgustful, nor rugged and perplexing, not austere and imperious, but facile, bland, delightful, alluring, captivating.' His popularizations were very successful. Editions appeared in 1774, 1782, 1783, 1787, 1794, and 1801.
BP_Description_2: The optical material (195 pages) is contained in Volume II. Optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, optical instruments, colors, metamorphosis, and optical illusions are presented in 48 recreations. Though the main intent is to entertain and the emphasis is on apparatus, there is also a teacherly aspect to many of the recreations, being accompanied by a detailed figure showing the optical basis for the phenomena being demonstrated.
BP_Reference(s): Free Time, Free Spirit: Popular Entertainments in Gainsborough's Era|Terpak, F.|<i>Huntington Library Quarterly<i>, Vol 70, No 2, 2007, pp 209-228.
BP_Title: Rational recreations, In which the principles of numbers and natural philosophy are clearly and copiously elucidated, by a series of easy, entertaining, interesting experiments. Among which are all those commonly performed with the cards. By W. Hooper, M.D. Vol. I, II, III, IV. The Second Edition, Corrected.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Lockyer Davis, James Robson, Bedwell Law, and George Robinson
BP_Collation: Vol 1: A¬≤ a‚Å∏ B-R‚Å∏ S‚Å∂|Vol 2: A-S‚Å∏ T‚Å¥|Vol 3: A-T‚Å∏ U‚Å¥|Vol 4: A-Z‚Å∏ Aa‚Å∏

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An advanced text on the design of lensed optical instruments, giving equations and examples of their application, and using the advances regarding achromatic lenses made since Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738.
BP_Description_1: An advanced text on the design of lensed optical instruments. The book presents lens design theory and its application, considering the developments in dioptrics since the publication of <i>A Smith Compleat System of Opticks<i> in 1738--particularly regarding achromatic lenses. The work is a separate, complete, and self-contained and in that sense it is not a supplement. Duval-Le-Roy had produced a French translation and augmentation of Smith's work in 1767; much of the material on lenses is used again in the present work. The theory is essentially that found in Euler's <i>Constructio Lentium Obiectivarum ex Duplici Vitro<i> of 1762 and the Dioptrice of 1769-1770. As such, the material on aberrations is limited to optical axis analysis. The application material covers surveying and astronomical telescopes, and microscopes. The application material clearly shows the practical hand of a practitioner and user. Editions appeared in 1783 and 1800.
BP_Description_2: The material is in two parts, Theoretical: Lens foci, spherical aberrations, calculating foci and aberrations for light through several lenses, blurred vision, apparent size, brightness, field of view, eye-placement, chromatic aberration, achromatic objective lenses. Practical: Telescopes in general, telescopes producing reversed images, telescopes producing upright images, microscopes. The material is detailed and highly analytic. The application sections show the equations from the theoretical part applied to practical instruments, accompanied by numerical examples.
BP_Title: SuppleÃÅment a l'optique de Smith, Contenant une TheÃÅorie GeÃÅneÃÅrale des Instrumens de Dioptrique.
BP_Title English Translation: Supplement to the Optics of Smith, Containing a General Theory of Dioptric Instruments.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, hydrographer. Professor at the L'Ecole de Marine de Brest
BP_Publisher or Seller: Romain-Nicolas Malassis;  Pierre-No√´l Durand and Louis-Alexandre Jombert
BP_Binding: Contemporary Patterned Paper Over Paste Boards

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of memoires--a few previously unpublished--by Alexis Marie de Rochon on mechanical and optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: A collection of memoires--a few previously unpublished--by Alexis Marie de Rochon on mechanical and optical instruments. The collection contains works that were most important, influential, and responsible for his contemporary reputation. The precise measurement of angular size, position, and separation was important in late 18th century for surveying, navigating, and astronomical work. A common method for determining longitude was the measurement of star position with respect to the moon, or the eclipses of the moons of Jupiter. Rochon ingeniously used birefringent crystals,  prisms, and mirrors to significantly extend the measurement range and improvement of accuracy of optical instruments in navigating and astronomy.
BP_Description_2: The collection of memoires include the following. A new micrometer for objective lenses. Essay on the measure of small angles and the research on the achromatic lens. Research on the nature of light from the stars. Spherical glass surfaces. On the improvement of achromatic objectives. On Vision. Binocular vision. Improving Bouguer's Heliometer. Improving Hadley's quadrant. An instrument for the measurement of angles with great precision. An instrument for determining refraction and dispersion. A letter engraving machine. Achromatic lenses.  The most important of these are the memoires on the prismatic micrometer which greatly extended the range of angles of Bouguer's heliometer, on the quartz prism micrometer which greatly increased the accuracy of angle and size determinations, and on the achromatic objective. From his work with prisms of birefringent materials for use in micrometers comes the eponymous 'Rochon Prism,' still used in optical instruments.
BP_Reference(s): Alexis-Marie Rochon (1741-1817), savant astronome et opticien|Fauque, D.|<i>Revue d'Histoire des Sciences<i>, Vol 38, No 1, 1985, pp 3-36.||Andr√© Morellet's Library|Medlin, D.|Libraries & Culture, Vol 31, No 3/4, 1996, pp. 574-602.
BP_Title: Recueil de Memoires sur las Mecanqiue et la Physique; par M. l'Abbe Rochon, de l'Academie Royal des Sciences, & de celle of Marine.
BP_Title English Translation: A Collection of Memoirs on Mechanics and Physics; by the Abbe Rochon, of the Royal Academy of Sciences and that of the Marines.
BP_Biographical Statement: French astronomer, physcist, and optician. Famed for the polarizing prism he invented.

BP_Short or Common Title: An analysis of a course of lectures
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A revision of Atwood's notes for his Cambridge lectures on natural philosophy, including extensive additions and detailed notes to demonstrations. This allowed the material to be read at two levels: picking up only the main ideas, and reading the supporting details and examples.
BP_Description_1: George Atwood revised his notes for students who attended his Cambridge lectures on the principles of natural philosophy and produced this publication. The revision included extensive additions and detailed notes to demonstrations. As with other texts of this type, this allowed the material to be read at two levels: picking up only the main principles and ideas, and reading the supporting details and examples. It was for this course of lectures that Atwood developed the eponymous 'Atwood's Machine' for demonstrating many aspects of mechanics; and still used in elementary physics laboratory experiments.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in eight sections: Statics and mechanics, hydrostatics, pneumatics, heat, electricity, magnetism, optics, and astronomy. The optics material (45 pages) includes: light rays, reflection and refraction, convex lenses, spherical mirrors, calculating the foci of lenses and mirrors, position and size of images from lenses and mirrors, solar images and apertures, prismatic refraction and dispersion, achromatic lenses, rays through multiple lenses. The material is generally descriptive, though the material on lenses is analytic. Since there are no accompanying figures, many of the demonstrations have elaborate descriptive notes added.
BP_Reference(s): Spreading Newtonian Philosophy with Instruments: The Case of Atwood‚Äôs Machine|Salvatore Esposito, S., Schettino, E.|<i>Advances in Historical Studies<i>, Vol 3, No 1, 2014, pp 68-81, NB: p 71.
BP_Title: An analysis of a course of lectures on the principles of natural philosophy, read in the University of Cambridge. By George Atwood, M.A.F.R.S. late fellow of Trinity College.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician and academic, famed for his invention of a machine to demonstrate Newtonian laws of motion.
BP_Provenance: Atwood's biography and owners' signatures on pastedown and end paper, 1870
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Calf Over Marbled Boards Rebacked

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A book on the nature of light, its properties, and its effect, written while the author was imprisoned in the Bastille for two years. Reconsiders the long and otherwise long-ended debate between the Cartesian and Newtonian conceptions of light.
BP_Description_1: Simon Nicolas Henri Linguet was imprisoned in the Bastille for two years. This is the 'painful idleness that had consumed almost two years of my life' he refers to in his preface, where he describes the occasion for writing this book on the nature of light, its properties, and its effect. It is not that the book is strange; rather it is strange that Linguet should write it. A caustic journalist, provocateur, archconservative, and opponent of the Enlightenment, Linguet seems an unlikely author of a work to reconsider the long and otherwise long-ended debate between the Cartesian and Newtonian conceptions of light. But as the title makes clear, this is not presented as experimental natural philosophy but a set of reflections and conjectures about what light is and what it does, based on the work of Descartes and Newton. He cites the <i>Physique du Monde<i> of Marivetz Goussier as model and example. This edition of 1784 is the first, not that of 1787, as sometimes stated.
BP_Description_2: The conjectures are in 15 chapters. Vision; Consideration of the plenum and the vacuum; Movement in the universe, the two philosophical views of vortices or attraction; Conciliation of the Cartesian and Newtonian systems; The five properties of light, weightless, no solidity, susceptible to infinite compression and dilation, strong moment force, it is singular and the same everywhere; Light as universal agent of motion, maintaining the motion of celestial bodies; Consideration and response to objections; Weight; Satellites; Comets.
BP_Reference(s): Limits of Nonconformity in the Enlightenment: The Case of Simon-Nicolas-Henri Linguet|Vyverberg, H.|French Historical Studies , Vol 6, No 4, 1970, pp. 474-491.
BP_Title: ReÃÅflexions sur la lumieÃÄre, ou, Conjectures sur la part qu'elle a au mouvement des corps ceÃÅlestes. Par M. Linguet.
BP_Title English Translation: Reflections on Light. Or, Conjectures on that part of it which has to do with the Movement of Celestial Bodies. By Mr. Linguet.
BP_Biographical Statement: French journalist, lawyer, controversalist. Wrote widely, in unreliably, on many subjects and died during the Terror.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1784 Linguet - ReÃÅflexions sur la lumieÃÄre - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Marat's reworking and augmentation of his work on light of 1780. It was written to reach a wider audience, to appeal directly to interested amateurs and professional philosophers, and to list the equipment required for all the experiments along with instructions as to their execution.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Paul Marat had developed a theory of the nature of light and presented it to the French Acad√©mie Royale des Sciences in 1780. Marat's ideas were too far removed from accepted ideas to be endorsed by the Academy. Marat wrote the present work to reach a wider audience, to appeal directly to interested amateurs and professional philosophers, and, if the preface is to be believed, accede to many requests for a summary of his theory. Though written as a precis of the longer report to the Academy, it is also more argumentative and a direct appeal to repeat his experiments and verify his conclusions. In this regard, the equipment required for all the experiments is listed along with instructions as to their execution.
BP_Description_2: Marat begins with a brief summary of basic optical phenomena: linear propagation of rays, reflection and refraction, convergence and divergence, chromatic inhomogeneity, diffraction. Adding to catoptrics and dioptrics, Marat adds the neologisms 'peroptrics' and 'opisoptrics' to describe propagation direction change close to an object and change caused by moving into a different medium. The text deals with 'peroptrics' and how light is attracted to near-by bodies and therefore deviated from an otherwise rectilinear path. This, claims Marat, is the explanation for the results obtained by Newton in his experiments, and not refraction as he claimed. The text presents several experiments with results that are interpreted to support Marat's theory. A final section 'Essential Observations' lists the apparatus required to perform the experiments and how they are to be arranged.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Isaac Newton, Optique, Traduit de l‚Äôanglais par Jean-Paul Marat (1787)<i>|Blay, M.|Dunod, Paris, 2015, p 375, NB pp 50-69.||Jean-Paul Marat (1743-1793), cientista e tradutor de Newton|Tosi, L.|<i>Qu√≠mica Nova<i>, Vol 22, No 6, 1999, pp 907-912.|
BP_Title: Notions elementaires d'optique
BP_Title English Translation: Elementary Ntions of Optics.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physician, natural philosopher, radical journalist.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Pierre Amalric
BP_Publisher or Seller: Pierre Francois Didot and Nicolas-Leger Moutard
