BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Johann Jakob Ebert
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Comprehensive textbook of Pure and Mixed Mathematics updated, augmented, and edited by Johann Jakob Ebert.
BP_Description_1: The sixth edition of Weidler's textbook of Pure and Mixed Mathematics, augmented and edited by Johann Jakob Ebert. The text is based on the 1759 edition, with significant updating and an additional section on Chronology. The front matter includes and eulogy of Weidler and a listing of his works.
BP_Description_2: Comprehensive textbook of Pure and Mixed Mathematics, including: Arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, optics, perspective, spherical trigonometry, astronomy, geography, gnomics, chronology, mechanics, hydrostatics, aerometry, hydraulics, architecture, algebra and calculus. The optical sections (80 pages) include: ocular anatomy; nature of light, color, and shade; vision and perception; catoptrics involving plane and curved mirrors and their images; refraction and dioptrics involving lenses of convex and concave figure and their images; telescopes, microscopes, and magic lanterns. The material is elementary but detailed and thorough. Presented as problems with experiments, followed by descriptive conclusions reached from their solutions. Ebert's editing included removing some of the original material on the nature of light and color and including a brief section on Newton's theory of prismatic colors.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The Mathematical Sciences part of d'Alembert's <i>Encyclop√©die M√©thodique<i>, including Optics.
BP_Description_1: The <i>Encyclop√©die, ou dictionnaire raisonn√© des sciences, des arts et des m√©tiers<i>, edited by Denis Diderot and Jean le Rond d'Alembert had been finished in 1772, though supplements, revised editions, and translations appeared after that. In 1775, Charles Joseph Panckoucke obtained the rights to reissue the work, and he published supplements and an index. But Panckoucke's plane was of larger scope. In the <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, the articles on individual topics were arranged alphabetically; Panckoucke wanted the material arranged by broad subject. His new schema has 26 divisions, among them: Mathematics, Physics, Medicine, Botany, Theology, Philosophy, Law, and Commerce. Each would have its own multivolume dictionary, including expanded versions of appropriate articles from the original <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, updated as necessary, and articles of new developments. The result was the <i> Encyclop√©die m√©thodique par ordre des mati√®res<i>, 'Methodical Encyclopedia by Order of Subject Matter.' The first volume (of Law) appeared in 1782.||The volumes in the division on mathematics were edited by  the Abb√© Bossut, a disciple of d'Alembert. Though D'Alembert had prepared more than half of the articles on pure mathematics for the original <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, his death in 1783 prevented him participating in the new work. The three volumes of the mathematics dictionary appeared in 1782, 1785, and 1789. In the front matter of the last volume, Panckoucke declares the division of mathematics ended. Another volume in the division has been promised, Games and Recreational Mathematics, but Panckoucke states it would be added later. It was completed in 1792 as a follow-up to Volume III of Mathematics. It is bound in at the end of Volume III in this copy. The mathematical division included astronomy, geometry, mechanics, hydrostatics and hydrodynamics, optics, perspective and gnomonics; subjects long associated with mathematics. Bossut's long preliminary discourse (114 pages) gives a history of mathematics.||The project of producing all the volumes for all of the divisions would take 50 years to complete, comprising 166 volumes containing 119,000 pages from 2250 contributors.
BP_Description_2: Generally, Bossut's reproduced the original articles on mathematics from the  original <i>Encyclop√©die<i> and its Supplement. The many new entries, corrections, and additions were usually the work of Bossut. Lalande was the sole author of the entries on astronomy. Condorcet, who had been entrusted by Panckoucke with the articles on mathematical analysis in the Supplement and had written many new studies for it, corrected many of these in the <i>Encyclopedie Methodique<i> and prepared several new ones.||In optics, there are entries on: optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, reflection, refraction, diffraction, double refraction, mirrors, lenses and their manufacture including achromatic lenses, telescopes, microscopes, light, atmospheric refraction, and the rainbow and other meteorological optical phenomena.
BP_Reference(s): The Encyclopedie Methodique|Watts, G.B.|<i>PMLA<i>, Vol 73, No 4, 1958, pp 348-366.

BP_Short or Common Title: Opera pertinentia ad opticam, et astronomiam
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of 45 separate works, large and small, dealing with optics and its application to astronomy. Most of these describe work conducted during Bo≈°koviƒá's 10-year stay in Paris, though some date back to his earliest work in 1763.
BP_Description_1: After the dissolution of the Jesuits in 1773, Rudjer Josip Bo≈°koviƒá settled in Paris where he stayed for 10 years. During this time he resumed optical work he had begun while in Rome at the Collegium Romanum and conducted new and extensive work in optics, both theoretical and practical. Bo≈°koviƒá hand long been aware both of how important the presses of scientific societies and governments were in disseminating knowledge, and of the contrast between the prevalence and opportunity of such publishing in Italy compared to France, England, or Germany. After 10 years of optical work in France and with only occasional and widely-scattered publication, he was keen that all the work be published. But nothing came of an effort to get his optics works published by the royal press at the expense of the king of France. His works were highly mathematical, primarily in Latin, and narrow in scope so  there was no interest from commercial publishers in France. All of this appeared to play a role in his return to Italy in 1783; an extended search and negotiations had finally resulted in an agreement with Giuseppe Remondini of Venice. Bo≈°koviƒá moved to Bassano del Grappa to perform the two years of editorial work and oversight of the printing of all five volumes. Though printed in Venice, Bo≈°koviƒá was mindful of and grateful for his long stay in Paris; the work is dedicated to Louis XVI. This summary of Bo≈°koviƒá's highly technical optical work was a standard reference for opticians; Lorenzo Selva, for example, mentions the '5 Volumes of Bo≈°koviƒá' in the preface to his <i>Sei Dialoghi Ottici<i> of 1787.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Opera Omnia Optica<i> of  Bo≈°koviƒá contains 45 separate works, large and small, most of them describing work conducted during his 10-year stay in Paris, though some date back to his earliest work in 1763. Volume 1: Construction and use of an instrument for measuring refractive index; Formulas for calculating lens foci, with applications. Volume 2: Nine smaller works on lenses, micrometers, the velocity of light, and atmospheric refraction. Volume 3: Determining comet orbits from observations; On a new planet. Volume 4: Thirteen smaller works on the construction and use of astronomical instruments including secants, quadrants, mural telescopes, and micrometers. Volume 5: Fourteen smaller works on astronomical observations, and the mathematics of data reduction. The most important and influential optical work of Bo≈°koviƒá was his demonstration of the need to accurately measure the refractive indices of glasses and the development of instruments to do that; part of his work in achromatic telescope lenses. Volume 2 contains his treatise on the design and construction of achromatic lenses.  It is guided by Boscovich's considerable practical experience with optics and optical instruments, is a considerable practical improvement over the work of Clairaut, D'Alambert, and Euler 30 years earlier. No more complete, practical treatise on achromatic lenses would appear until George Airy incorporated Joseph Fraunhofer's work thirty-five years later.
BP_Reference(s): L‚ÄôOpera Omnia di Ruggiero Giuseppe Boscovich e problemi connessi: lunga storia di un progetto|Proverbio, E.|<i>Atti della 'Fondazione Giorgio Ronchi'<i>, Vol 66, No 1, 2011, pp 117-152.||R. G. Boscovich and the Measurement of the Refractive Quality of Lenses|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana<i>, Vol 60, No 4, p 837-888.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: William Enfield's text book for use in classes he taught in natural philosophy, including the mathematics thought necessary to provide more than a superficial understanding of the subjects.
BP_Description_1: The Warrington Academy was, from 1756 to 1782, was a prominent private teaching academy set up by and for those who dissented from the established Church of England. Natural philosophy was taught by John Holt, then by George Walker, and eventually by William Enfield in 1774. Enfield began assembling a course and 10 years later its notes and content formed the basis of his text book. He wrote this text book for use in classes he taught and his preface explains his reason and the need: he found other texts either 'materially deficient in mathematical demonstration'  or too 'copious and abstruse for elementary instruction.' Self-taught in mathematics, Enfield believed it and its application were essential to understanding natural philosophy if anything other than a thin superficiality was to be achieved. He stated he had no desire to be original (he had no formal training in natural philosophy), rather to effect a clear and useful presentation. To that end he used works of Newton, Keil, Whiston, Gravesande, Cotes, Smith, Helsham, Rowning, and Rutherford as it suited his plan for the text. He omits Chemistry from his scope, considering not part of 'mechanical philosophy.' The work is dedicated to Joseph Priestley, another dissenting cleric active in natural philosophy. Editions appeared in 1785, 1799, and edited American editions in 1802, 1811, and 1824.
BP_Description_2: William Enfield's text is in seven books:  Matter; Mechanics; Hydrostatics and Pneumatics; Optics and Vision; Astronomy; Magnetism; Electricity. The optics material in Book IV (95 pages) includes: The nature of light, refraction and images from lenses, reflection and reflected images, vision and eye-function, color and prismatic refraction, the rainbows, optical instruments including the telescope, microscope, magic lantern, and camera obscura. The physical optics is purely Newtonian, and the geometrical optics is a precis from Smith's Complete System of Opticks.  Generally, the material is elementary but detailed, geometric, and accompanied by extended demonstrations and discussions. The style is classical: presentation of axioms and definitions, proposition and proofs, examples and discussion.
BP_Reference(s): Science for Polite Society: British Dissent and the Teaching of Natural Philosophy in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries|Reid, D.A.|In: History of Universities: Volume XXI/2, Feingold, M., editor, 2006, 352 pp, NB: pp 117-158.
BP_Title: Institutes of natural philosophy, theoretical and experimental. By William Enfield, LL. D. "Omnis Philosophiae difficultas in eo versari videtur, ut a phaenomenis motuum investigemus vires Naturae, deinde ab his vivibus demonstremus phaenomena reliqua." Newon.
BP_Title English Translation: "The Difficulty in All of Philosophy is Seen in the Object in it, that if we Investigate the Powers of Nature from the Phenomenon of Motion, then from these Powers we can Demonstrate other Phenomena" Newton in the preface to the Principia Mathematica.
BP_Biographical Statement: English Unitarian claric, dabler in natural philosophy and mathematics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A 5-volume work on Philosophy written for use in the Lyon seminary. Volumes 4 and 5 deal with general and particular physics,
BP_Description_1: By order of the archbishop of Lyons, Antoine Malven de Montazet, Joseph Valla wrote this 5-volume work for use in the Lyon seminary. The first three volumes deal with logic, metaphysics, and morality.  Volumes 4 and 5 contain general and particular physics, respectively. Editions appeared at Lyon in 1785 and 1788, at Venice in 1791, at Madrid in 1793, and were reused by J.M. Doney for a course in Philosophy published at Paris in 1823.
BP_Description_2: Volume 5 contains the second book dealing with specific physics: fire and heat, solid and fluid bodies, sense of odor, sense of sound, sense of sight, magnetism, electricity, earthquakes and volcanos, water, meteorics, the rainbow, various bodies from the earth, salts and gems and metals. The optics material (75 pages) includes: the nature of light; Cartesian, Malebrachian, and Newtonian theories; propagation of light and light rays, illumination; reflection and its cause; plane and curved mirrors; refraction in different media; lenses; the eye and eye-function; color and prismatic refraction; phosphors. Consistent with the intension of educating seminarians, the material is purely descriptive, no mathematics is used.
BP_Title: Institutiones Philosophicae, Auctoritate D.D. Archiepiscopi Lugdunensis, ad usum scholarum suae dioecesis editae. Physicae Tomus Secundus.
BP_Title English Translation: Institutes of Philosophy, By the Authority of the Archbishop of Lyon, edited for use in his Diocesan School. On Physics. Second Volume.
BP_Biographical Statement: French Oratorian, theologian, philosopher. By order of his archbiship, author of two multi-volume works.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the College at Draguignan (France) with inscription on titlepage dated 1788

BP_Author full name: P√°l de Kerek Gede Mak√≥, SJ
BP_Author last name first: Mak√≥, P√°l de Kerek Gede SJ
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Italian Edition of the natural philosophy textbook of P√°l Mak√≥ that fully embraced Newtonian philosophy, modified by the ideas of Bo≈°koviƒá.
BP_Description_1: Italian Edition of the natural philosophy textbook of P√°l Mak√≥.  It was one of the earliest textbooks in naturally philosophy that fully embraced Newtonian philosophy, modified by the ideas of Bo≈°koviƒá regarding a universal law of attraction/repulsion. Mak√≥'s textbook and its revisions were part of the reformed curriculum at the Viennese Theresianum, where he taught. The experimental aspects of the 'new physics' gradually appeared in subsequent editions, though experimental physics would not be fully embraced in eastern European textbooks until the next generation of authors' books appeared in the 1790s. Mak√≥'s text was very successful; widely used, revised and republished. Editions of appeared at Vienna in 1762, 1766, 1773, and at Venice in 1786. This Italian edition was important as it spread the use of a textbook with the new physics to Italian schools via former Jesuits. It was printed cheaply, pocket-sized, and easily obtainable.
BP_Description_2: The optics material (200 pages) covers: The nature of light, its propagation, subtlety, rarity; reflection and refraction, the laws of reflection and refraction; changes by reflection and transmission; concave mirrors; the nature of light, various opinions; explanation of emission and propagation of light; explanation of reflection and refraction; diffraction; explanation of changes by reflection and transmission; transparency and opacity of bodies; object colors; rainbow and halos; direct light, optics and the eye; catoptrics, convex and concave mirrors; dioptrics, concave and convex lenses and their foci; the telescope; the microscope. The material is detailed and analytic. The style is the presentation of propositions, demonstrations, scholia, and examples. The geometric optics is elementary and conventional for the time. The physical optics is that of Boscovich, with his explanation for reflection, refraction, and diffraction.
BP_Reference(s): A felvid√©ki fizika t√∂rt√©nete 1850-ig (A History of Physics in Upper Hungary to 1850)|Jol√°n Zempl√©n|<i>A Magyar Tudom√°nyt√∂rt√©neti int√©zet Tudom√°nyos k√∂zlem√©nyei No 122<i>, p 441: NB:|http://real.mtak.hu/34201/1/122_zemplen_fizika.pdf

BP_Short or Common Title: Review of Coste's Optique de Newton
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A very critical assessment of Coste's early translation of Newton's Opticks and praise for the new translation by Marat.
BP_Description_1: A very critical assessment of Coste's early translation of Newton's Opticks and praise for the new translation by Marat. The unknown critic states that the new French translation makes it clear that Coste's was '‚Ä¶ poorly written and unfaithful and the turns of phrase are servilely rendered.' Coste's translations renders 'the work of the author unintellible.'  The new translation (that of Marat) is praised for privding a rigourous rather than a free translation.
BP_Description_2: The bulk of the review summaries the work of Newton as it was received late in the 18th century. Included are the corrections and additions that the intervening years produced, such as the development (contra Newton) of achromatic lenses, refinements to the ideas of prismatic colors, as well as a brief review of Newton's critics--such as Castel.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of Newton's Optical Work|Shapiro, A.E.|In: The Reception of Isaac Newton in Europe, Pulte, H., Mandelbrote, S., editors, Bloomsbury Academic, 2019, 1004 pp, NB: pp 415-417.
BP_Title: Review of "Optique de Newton" In: Mercure de France, July 1787, pp 79.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Abrahm Rees (1743 - 1825) Welsh nonconformist cleric and compiler of encyclopedias.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Chambers's single-handed compilation of his own articles covering a huge array of subjects stressing the sciences, technology, and philosophy. The material is practical, concise, elaborately cross-referenced, and accompanied by detailed figures. In this edition, Abraham Rees added a great deal of new material.
BP_Description_1: Chambers's single-handed compilation of his own articles covering a huge array of subjects but stress the sciences, technology, and philosophy. The material is practical, concise, elaborately cross-referenced, and accompanied by detailed figures. In this edition, Abraham Rees added a great deal of new material. Rees's revision of and additions to Chambers's Cyclopaedia reflects the standards set by Diderot's Encyclop√©die. Rees' new material includes articles with considerable coverage of the visual arts, and are much expanded from Chambers's first edition of 1728.||First printed at London in 1778 and at Dublin in 1787 (the present work).
BP_Description_2: Vol 1: A-C, Vol 2: D-J, Vol 3: K-P , Vol 4: Q-Z Scientifical Index (40 pages) Corrigenda et Addenda (14 pages), Vol 5: Arrangement and Analysis of the Plates (7 pages).||Among the optics-related entries are: Aberration (3 columns), Achromatic lens (1 column), Camera Obscura (2 columns), Catoptrics (1 column), Chromatic (2 columns), Colour (12 columns), Dioptrics (1 column), Eye (12 columns), Focus (3 columns), Glass (9 columns), Light (19 columns), Microscope (10 columns), Mirror (10 columns), Optics (1 column, many references), Perspective (19 columns), Rainbow (10 columns), Ray (3 columns), Reflection (6 columns), Refraction (17 columns), Telescope (16 columns), Visible (8 columns), Vision (5 columns).||The Scientifical Index lists more than 470 entries. Six plates are devoted to Opitcs, 4 devoted to Perspective.
BP_Reference(s): A Solution to the Multitude of Books: Ephraim Chambers's 'Cyclopaedia' (1728) as 'The Best Book in the Universe'|Yeo, R.|<i>Journal of the History of Ideas<i>, Vol 64, No 1, 2003, pp 61-72.||Ephraim Chambers's Cyclop√¶dia (1728) and the Tradition of Commonplaces|Yeo, R.|<i>Journal of the History of Ideas<i>, Vol 57, No 1, 1996, pp 157-175.||Ephraim Chamber's Cyclopaedia|Bradshaw, L.E.|In: <i>Notable Encyclopedias of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries<i>, Kafker, F.A., editor, Voltaire foundation, 1981, pp 123-141.

BP_Description_1: The <i>Encyclop√©die, ou dictionnaire raisonn√© des sciences, des arts et des m√©tiers<i>, edited by Denis Diderot and Jean le Rond d'Alembert had been finished in 1772, though supplements, revised editions, and translations appeared after that. In 1775, Charles Joseph Panckoucke obtained the rights to reissue the work, and he published supplements and an index. But Panckoucke's plane was of larger scope. In the <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, the articles on individual topics were arranged alphabetically; Panckoucke wanted the material arranged by broad subject. His new schema has 26 divisions, among them: Mathematics, Physics, Medicine, Botany, Theology, Philosophy, Law, and Commerce. Each would have its own multivolume dictionary, including expanded versions of appropriate articles from the original <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, updated as necessary, and articles of new developments. The result was the <i> Encyclop√©die m√©thodique par ordre des mati√®res<i>, 'Methodical Encyclopedia by Order of Subject Matter.' The first volume (of Law) appeared in 1782.||The volumes in the division on mathematics were edited by  the Abb√© Bossut, a disciple of d'Alembert. Though D'Alembert had prepared more than half of the articles on pure mathematics for the original <i>Encyclop√©die<i>, his death in 1783 prevented him participating in the new work.||Before Panckouke's project was finished, this French imitation edition began to appear at Padua, published by the Seminary of Padua. The mathematical volumes appeared between 1787 and 1790; two volumes of text and one of plates. The publication of this imitation edition was continue for 10 years until Nepolean occupied Padua.
BP_Description_2: Generally, Bossut's reproduced the original articles on mathematics from the  original <i>Encyclop√©die<i> and its Supplement. The many new entries, corrections, and additions were usually the work of Bossut. Lalande was the sole author of the entries on astronomy. Condorcet, who had been entrusted by Panckoucke with the articles on mathematical analysis in the Supplement and had written many new studies for it, corrected many of these in the <i>Encyclopedie Methodique<i> and prepared several new ones.||In optics, there are entries on: optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, reflection, refraction, diffraction, double refraction, mirrors, lenses and their manufacture including achromatic lenses, telescopes, microscopes, light, atmospheric refraction, and the rainbow and other meteorological optical phenomena.
BP_Reference(s): The Encyclopedie Methodique|Watts, G.B.|<i>PMLA<i>, Vol 73, No 4, 1958, pp 348-366.
BP_Title: Encyclop√©die m√©thodique par ordre des mati√®res. Nouvele √âdition enriche de Remaragues D√©di√©e a la S√©r√©nissime R√©public de Venise.  Mathematiques. Tome Preimer, Second.
BP_Title English Translation: Methodical Encyclopedia by Order of Subject Matter. New edition enriched with remarks. Dedicated to 'La Serenissima' the Republic of Venice. Mathematics. Toome First, Second.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, natural philosophyer, mechanician. Along with Diderot, edited the famed Encyclop√©die.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean Paul Marat (1743-1793) French physician, natural philosopher, political activist.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Jean Paul Marat's French translation of the fourth edition of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1730.
BP_Description_1: Jean Paul Marat's French translation of the fourth edition of Newton's <i>Opticks<i> of 1730. Marat's translation is generally judged to be superior to either edition of Coste's translation. Marat presents a more readable style while almost always conveying the correct meaning of the English text. Though Marat had developed his own theory of color which was in opposition to Newton's, the translation remains faithful to Newton. Marat does present his ideas regarding a theory of light and color at the end of the translation in the form of 30 questions with extended answers and discussion, and some additional observations. A facsimile edition appeared at Paris in 1989, reprinted in 2015.
BP_Description_2: Fourth edition of the <i>Opticks<i> of 1704. A reprinting of the 1721 edition with only a few minor changes made by Newton. This editions includes citations from the Lectiones Opticae which had just been published. The citations point to demonstrations and experiments in the Lectiones Opticae that were omitted by Newton when the Opticks of 1704 was composed. Like the first English edition of the Opticks, the fourth edition is in three Books. Book I is in two parts. Part I deals with prism experiments and the spectral heterogeneity of white light. It begins with definitions and axioms that review the basic aspects of geometric optics of reflection and refraction. This is followed by 8 propositions based on 16 experiments dealing with chromatic inhomogeneity and its consequences. Propositions 7 and 8 deal specifically with the limitations imposed on telescope objectives by what is now called chromatic aberration. Part II presents 11 propositions based on 17 experiments investigating the nature of color and the application of the theory of chromatic heterogeneity, particularly to the rainbow. It is here that Newton's 'experimentum crucis' of his letter of 1672 is presented in refined form and great detail.||Book II is in four parts. Part I presents 24 observations of the colored fringes produced by light passing through glass plates and thin lenses in contact in air and water. Part II presents a mathematical analysis of these observations, including Newton's method for determining small separating distances. Part III presents 20 propositions dealing with colors of natural bodies and their relationship to prismatic colors and color production in thin plates. it is here that Newton proposes that light has 'Fits of easy reflection and fits of easy transmission.' Part IV presents 13 observations of colors produced by thick plates.||Book III presents 11 descriptive observations of the color and placement of diffraction fringes produced by various objects. Queries--rhetorical questions--were Newton's means of proposing ideas about natural philosophy in general and the nature of light and color in particular. It is here that Newton dismisses wave theories of light as incapable of explaining its observed properties. The second English edition of the <i>Opticks<i> contains the original 16 Queries of the <i>Opticks<i>, the 7 added in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706, and 8 new ones. The 8 Queries new in the second English edition are placed after the original 16 and are number 17-24. The 7 Queries new in the <i>Optice<i> of 1706 are here numbers 25-31, and adds extensively to Queries 10 and 11. The <i>Optice<i> also provides an addendum describing luminescent light sources. Queries  25-31 were new in the <i>Optice<i> and deal with double refraction and, perhaps most importantly, the nature of space, the plenum, the aether, and luminous corpuscles. Query 31, new in the Optice, is the longest of all, by far, and deals with gravitational attraction and ends with Newton's remarkable paragraph linking the development of natural and moral philosophy. Queries 17-24, were new in the second English edition, and deal with the Newton's idea of the aether or subtle, particular matter and its interaction with heat and light. Also new in the second English edition was reference to the "mercurial light" of Hauksbee's experiments.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Isaac Newton, Optique, Traduit de l‚Äôanglais par Jean-Paul Marat (1787)<i>|Blay, M.|Dunod, Paris, 2015, p 375, NB pp 50-69.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Material on optical instruments, technical information, optical theory, and applications in astronomy, microscopy, and other sciences are presented in the guise of six dialogues that take place between a professor, a count, and a cleric.
BP_Description_1: The Six Theoretical-Practical Dialogues on Optics of Lorenzo Selva began as a second edition of the elaborate optical instrument catalogue, <i>Esposizione delle Comuni, e Nuove Spezie di Cannocchiali, Telescopi, Microscopi<i>, of  1761. Though he began it in 1771, he eventually decided to cast the entire work into 'a more pleasant form,' and wrote a set of dialogues, rather than just discourses. Though a draft was ready in 1785, he had heard that the Opera Omnia Optica of his friend Rudjer Bo≈°koviƒá was about to be published in near-by Bassano and delayed his own work two years so as to include the latest updates in theory and practice. The dialogues take place between a professor, a count, and a cleric. though similar to the catalogue of 1761--instruments, technical information, optical theory, and applications in astronomy, microscopy, and other sciences are presented--the scope is considerably enlarged, and two additional plates of figures were used.
BP_Description_2: A series of six dialogues in which three interlocutors discuss and describe the optical instruments made and sold by Lorenzo Selva and  two of his sons. The first dialogue involves the eye, its optics and function, the nature of lenses, the correction of myopic, hyperopic, and presbyopic vision by spectacles, and the magnification of images by lenses in general. The second dialogue involves spyglasses and telescopes, including: lensed telescopes, and optical levels. The third dialogue involves catadioptric telescopes, catoptric telescopes, Gregorian telescopes and micrometers. The fourth dialogue centers on glass properties, measuring refractive index, and Boscovich's vitrometer, flint glass, and achromatic lenses. The fifth dialogue involves microscopes, including: simple microscopes, compound microscopes, solar microscopes, catadioptric microscopes, catoptric microscopes, the 'universal' microscope. The sixth dialogue involves various lenses, burning mirrors, cameras obscura, and magic lanterns. The instruments are described in considerable detail, but without any elaborate theory or mathematics. Appended is the 1771 decree of the Venetian Senate, granting Lorenzo Selva the position of 'Public Optician' and an annuity.
BP_Reference(s): La Famiglia Selva, Ottici del '700 Veneziano|Lualdi, A.|<i>Nuncius<i>, Istituto e Museo di Storia della Scienza, 2001, Vol 16, No 2, pp 531-546.
BP_Title: Sei dialoghi ottici teorico-pratici. Dedicati all' eccellentissimo Senato da Lorenzo Selva ottica Publico Stipendiato
BP_Title English Translation: Six Dialogues of Optical Theory and Practice. Dedicated to the Most Excellent Senate. By Lorenzo Selva, Public Stipended Optician.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian oculist, instrument maker. Son of famed Venetian optician Domenico Selva.
BP_Binding: Modern 1/2 Vellum Over Marbled Paper Covered Boards
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1787 Selva - Sei dialoghi ottici teorico-pratici - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An undergraduate text in optics for students with no mathematics
BP_Description_1: Stack's textbook is clearly written for undergraduates with little or no mathematics, but who require an introduction to optics and optical instruments. Stack's interest in astronomy is clear from the emphasis placed on telescopes and their operation. Explanations are very brief and text seems suited as accompaniment to lectures, certainly not for self study.||Editions appeared at Dublin in 1787, 1793 and much enlarged in 1811 and posthumously in 1820.
BP_Description_2: Stack's text is in 10 sections. 1: Nature and Laws of Reflection and Refraction. 2: Foci of Reflected and Refracted Rays. 3: Colors. 4: Images Formed by Reflection and Refraction. 5: Eye and Vision. 6: Perception of Objects. 7: Telescopes. 8: Telescopic Errors. 9: Telescopic Improvements. 10: Microscopes and Other Instruments. Appendix: The Rainbow.  The text is devoted almost exclusively to geometrical optics. Physical optics is treated on briefly and descriptively in the Introduction. Reflection and Refraction as described from spherical mirrors and lenses. Chromatic and spherical aberration in lenses is briefly described. Several types of telescopes are described  and their operation indicated pictorially. The treatment throughout is descriptive, and elementary geometry is the only mathematics invoked.
BP_Reference(s): Dictionary of Irish Biography: From the Earliest Times to the Year 2010|McGuire, J., Quinn, J., editors|Royal Irish Academy, Cambridge University Press, 2019.
BP_Title: A short system of optics, principally designed for the use of undergraduates in the University of Dublin. By the Rev. John Stack, D.D. Rector of Kilskerry, County Tyrone, Late Fellow of Trinity College Dublin. Second Edition, Altered and Enlarged.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish academic, Fellow of Trinity College, Dublin and secretary of the Royal Irish Academy.
BP_Provenance: Owner's name on title page
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1787 Stack - A short system of optics - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook in the vernacular for a university course covering physics with particular emphasis on the application of mathematics.
BP_Description_1: A textbook for a university course covering four topics of physics with particular emphasis on the application of mathematics. Written in the vernacular and for use at the Piarist School in Florence, it is an advanced text that assumes considerable background in mathematics. It was likely assumed that students would have already studied the <i>Lezioni Elementari delle Matematiche<i> of 1781 by Canovai and Del Ricco. Editions appeared in 1788, 1799, and 1809. The textbook initiated the mathematical physics movement in the piarist schools in northern Italy at the end of the 18th century; moving beyond the Scholastic and Cartesian traditions and embracing experimental and analytic physics. The emphasis is on analytical demonstrations, rather than derivations, and many worked examples showed how mathematics was used to solve problems.
BP_Description_2: Mechanics: theory of motion, machines; Hydromechanics: theory of static fluids, fluids in motion; Optics: theory of light, reflection and refraction, optical instruments; Astronomy: theory of celestial bodies, mechanics applied to astronomy.  The optical material (113 pages) is in two parts. Part 1 includes: the nature of light; reflection and refraction; transparent and opaque bodies and their properties; direct light including light rays, rectilinear propagation, illumination; vision, distinct and indistinct; reflected light including geometry and magnitude, plane and spherical mirrors, images from reflection, calculation of mirror foci; refracted light including lenses, convex and concave lenses, calculation of lens foci, prismatic refraction and colors, dispersion, the rainbow. Part 2 includes: nature of optical instruments; the eye and eye-function; land and surveying glasses, magnification; telescopes, calculating the effect of multiple lenses, field of view, spherical and chromatic aberrations, calculating aberrations, achromatic lenses; microscopes, magnification, aberrations. The material is advanced, theoretical, detailed and highly analytic.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Stanislao Canovai e Gaetano Del Ricco. Il sodalizio umano e scientifico di due scolopi fiorentini fra XVIII e XIX secolo<i>|Barsanti, D.|Osservatorio Ximeniano, Firenze, 1988, 105 pp.
BP_Title: Elementi di Fisica Matematica. Dedicati All' Altezze Reali di Ferdinando-Giuseppe Carlo-Luigi Alessandro-Leopoldo, Archiduchi d'Austria Princip de Toscana, ec. ec. ec. Da Stanislao Canovai e Gaetano Del-Ricco Delle Scuole Pie.
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Mathenatical Physics. All Dedicated to his Royal Highness Ferdinand Joseph Charles Louis Alexander Leopold, Archduke of Austria, Prince of Toscany, et cetera. By Stanislao Canovai &  Gaetano Del-Ricco of the Piarist School.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian Piarist priests, educators, textbook authors. Taught in the Piarist School at Florence.

BP_Short or Common Title: Memoires academiques, ou nouvelles decouvertes sur la lumiere
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A collection of all of Jean-Paul Marat's works on optics published as academic memoirs.
BP_Description_1: A collection of all of Jean-Paul Marat's works on optics published as academic memoirs. This includes two memoires presented to the French Academy in Paris, the Royal Society of Society of Sciences at Montpellier, and the Academy of Sciences at Rouen. This was his last scientific work, after which he turned to journalism, radical French politics and the revolution.
BP_Description_2: Four memoirs are presented: New discoveries about light, relating to the most important points of optics; Memoir on the alleged refrangibility of heterogeneous rays; Memoir on the explanation of the rainbow given by Newton, and Memoir on the true causes of the colors that form in blades of glass, soap water bubbles and other extremely thin transparent materials. In all these works, Marat advances his idea that light is deviated from its rectilinear path by the attractive force of near-by material separating it into different colors. That, as opposed to differing refraction as advanced by Newton.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Isaac Newton, Optique, Traduit de l‚Äôanglais par Jean-Paul Marat (1787)<i>|Blay, M.|Dunod, Paris, 2015, p 375, NB pp 50-69.
BP_Title: Memoires academiques, ou nouvelles decouvertes sur la lumiere, relatives aux points les plus importans de l'optique. "Elles surnageront contre vent & mar√©e"  Prix, 8 Liv: broch√©.
BP_Title English Translation: Academic Memoires, or New Discoveries on Light, Relative to Points Very Important of Optics. "They Strove Against the Wind and Water". Price: 8 Livre stitched in paper.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physician, natural philosopher, radical journalist.
BP_Provenance: Notes concerning Marat on free endpaper and titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First American edition of Nicholson's text on natural philosophy, based on the 2nd, expanded London edition of 1787.
BP_Description_1: First American edition of Nicholson's text on natural philosophy. Based on the 2nd, expanded London edition of 1787. As stated in the preface, Nicholson wrote for an audience interested in 'pursuit of the highest utility and entertainment' and his book was 'intended to give a clear account of the present state of Natural Philosophy; in such as possess very little mathematical knowledge.' As with many popularizers of science, Nicholson wanted to avoid 'prolix disquisitions . . . less than intelligible' on the one hand and 'the affectation of familiarity . . . with lax and unsophisticated explanations' on the other. The American editions were widely used and influential, as evidenced by, for example, the many references to Nicholson's book in letters to and from Thomas Jefferson; the references being made in a manner that assumed everyone would know the work. Editions appeared at London in 1782, 1787, 1790, 1796, 1805, and at Philadelphia in 1788, 1793, 1795. An Italian translation appeared at Florence in 1800.
BP_Description_2: The material is arranged in 11 sections: Of mater in the abstract; bodies in motion; astronomy; causes of celestial motions; light; optics; fluids; air and the atmosphere; chemistry; magnetism; electricity. The optics material (84 pages) is in two sections. Section 1: propagation of light, light rays and differing refraction, chromatic colors, the rainbow, glass and optical materials, object colors, diffraction, reflective and refractive power.  Section 2: reflection and refraction at surfaces, dioptrics of lenses, the eye and eye-function, microscopes, telescopes, aberrations and achromatic lenses, catoptrics and mirrors. The material is elementary and descriptive, using no mathematics.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Papers of Thomas Jefferson<i>|Oberg, B., editor|Princton University Press, 1950-2012, Vol 23, p 364; Vol 30 p 594; Vol 31 p 68; Vol 32 p 180; Vol 38 p 134.
BP_Title: An Introduction to Natural Philosophy. Illustrated with Copperplates. By William Nicholson. "Non enim me cuiquam mancipavi, nullis nomen fero: multum magnorum virorum judicio credo, aliquid et meo vindico. Nam illi quoque, non inventa, sed quaerenda, nobis reliquerent."  Seneca.  The Third Edition, with Improvements.
BP_Title English Translation: "I have surrendered myself to no one, I bare no one's name. I believe in the judgement of great men, but I claim something of my own. For these too have left us not discoveries, but things requiring inquiry." Seneca, Letter 45 to Lucilius.
BP_Biographical Statement: English chemist, natural philosopher, journalist, publisher. Publisher of and contributor to 'Nicholson's Journal'.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed by Joseph Lee, dated 1798
BP_Binding: Modern 1/4 Calf Over Marbled Paper Covered Boards
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1788 Nicholson - An Introduction to Natural Philosophy - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An expanded, 5-volume general course in natural philosophy that is both an encyclopedia of physics and a philosophy of the sciences.
BP_Description_1: The second edition of the <i>TheÃÅorie Des EÃÇtres Sensibles<i> first published in 1772. This edition was expanded to 5 volumes, the fifth containing additions new discoveries and advances made since 1772.
BP_Description_2: A 5-volume general course in natural philosophy. Volume 1: Theory of matter and of movement. Volume 2: Theory of the earth, water, and air. Volume 3: Theory of meteorics, light, fire, and electricity. Volume 4: Theory of the sky, or geometrical and physical astronomy. Volume 5: new discoveries in physics and chemistry. The optical material (320 pages) includes four sections. Section 1 The nature of light: propagation and light rays; emission of light rays; Newton's system of light and color; light as fiery fluid; diversity of colors; efficacies of rays; color and diversity of rays. Section 2 Optics: Parallel, convergent and divergent rays; opaque and transparent materials; vision; law of reflection, inverse square density, diffusion; light rays and vision; problems in vision and perception; catoptrics; plane and curved mirrors; burning mirrors; cause of reflection; dioptrics; refraction; cause of refraction; convex and concave lenses; dioptric instruments; microscopes; telescopes; camera obscura, magic lantern; eye-function, hyperopia and myopia; astronomical refraction. Section 3 Light and fire. Section 4 Light and the Nature of Electricity. For physical optics, Para Du Phanjas presents a theory that light is related to or part of an elemental fiery substance or fluid that is also related to electrical fluid--adhering to neither the particle nor wave theory of light. Regardless of light's ultimate nature, light rays are used as practical manifestations of its properties. Thus, the geometric optics material is ray-based, elementary, detailed and accompanied by examples and many figures. The material on optics in the 5th, supplemental Volume is limited to citing new support for the elemental fiery substance theory of the nature of light.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Catholic Encyclopedia, Volume 11<i>|Herbermann, C.G., and others, editor|The Encyclopedia Press, New York, 1913, pp 469-470.
BP_Title: TheÃÅorie Des EÃÇtres Sensibles: Ou Cours Complet De Physique, SpeÃÅculative, ExpeÃÅrimentale, SysteÃÅmatique Et GeÃÅomeÃÅtrique, Mise A La PorteÃÅe De Tout Le Monde : Avec une Table alphabeÃÅtique des Matieres, qui en fait un vrai Dictionnaire De Physique. Nouvelle Edition, retifiee, perfectionnee, assortie aux modernes Decourverts, & augmentee d'un cinquiement Volume. Par M l'Abee Para du Phanjas. Tome Premier La Matiere Et Le Mouvement. Tome Second. La Terre, L'eau, et L'Air. Tome Troisieme. Les Meteores, la Lumiere, le Fluide Igne, le Fluide Electrique. Tome Quatrieme.La Theorie de Ciel, ou l'Astronomie geometrique et physique.
BP_Title English Translation: Theory of Sentient Beings, or A Complete Course of Physics; Speculative, Experimental, Systematic, and Geometric. Within the Reach of Everyone. With an Alphabetical Table of Contents, Which Makes This Entire Work a True Dictionary of Physics. By Abbe Para du Phnajas. Volume One. Theory of Matter and of Movement. Volume Two. Theory of the Earth, of Water, of Air. Volume Three. Meteorology, Light, Fire, Electric Fluid. Volume Four. The Theory of the Heavens, or Geometric and Physical Astronomy.

BP_Short or Common Title: Bibliotheque  universelle  des dames - Physique Generale, Physique particuliere
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Sigaud de Lafond provides a descriptive introduction of most aspects of natural philosophy for the politely interested.
BP_Description_1: Part of the <i>Biblioth√®que Universelle des Dames<i>, these 5 volumes covering general and particular physics constituted Classe 8 (of 11) and were written by Joseph-Aignan Sigaud de Lafond. He makes clear the purpose of these books in his preface: 'For more the than thirty years that I presented experimental physics in Paris, ladies almost always were the majority of my listeners; and they always distinguished themselves by their diligence and the particular attention with which they constantly honored me. Here I embrace a much larger plan, and embrace all physics, and treat several questions which I thought not to mention in my (previous work) <i>Elemens (de Physique)<i>' Written for ladies of leisure who presumably have no background in mathematics, Sigaud de Lafond provides a descriptive introduction of most aspects of natural philosophy for the politely interested.
BP_Description_2: General Physics is covered in 10 chapters. 1: Principles of bodies, 2: Properties of matter, 3: Movement, 4: Centripetal force, 5: Centrifugal force, 6: Reflected movement, 7: Obstacles to movement, 8: Cause and direction of movement, 9: Mechanics of solids, 10: Mechanics of liquids.  Particular Physics is covered in 4 chapters. 1: The Earth, 2: Air, atmosphere, gases 3: Water, 4: Fire, light, and electricity. The optics material (109 pages) includes: the nature of light, direct light or optics, refracted light, reflected light, theory of light and colors. The material is elementary and entirely descriptive, no figures or any mathematics are used.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Third edition of an Italian translation of a textbook masquerading as a subject dictionary, meant for the autodidact and the student and to propagate the natural philosophical ideas of Newton.
BP_Description_1: Third edition of the Italian translation of Paulian's <i>Dictionnaire de Physique<i> of 1761. Paulian produced his earlier <i>Dictionnaire de Physique Portatif<i> in 1758; a first attempt at propagating the ideas of Newton. Three years later it was expanded into the <i>Dictionnnaire de Physique<i>; a textbook masquerading as a subject dictionary meant for the autodidact and the student. Paulian drew from many sources and the Preface of first edition of the <i>Dictionnnaire<i> gives 3 and one-half, two-column pages of works and authors. Paulian's natural philosophy was not purely Newtonian, and unlike Desaguliers who presented Newtonian ideas without ornament or interference, Paulian was in an ongoing process of developing his own amalgam of Cartesian and Newtonian natural philosophy, and the <i>Dictionnnaire<i> reflects this free blending and extrapolation. The material in the <i>Dictionnnaire<i> is wide-ranging, with 'Physics' given a very wide compass--the first entry is 'Abdomen.' As new developments appeared Paulian augmented and revised the <i>Dictionnnaire<i>, and so each edition was significantly expanded. Starting as three volumes, it grew to four and eventually to five. An example is an article on achromatic telescopes added to the second edition of 1773. Editions appeared in 1761, 1773, 1781, and 1789. An Italian translation appeared at Venice in 1770, 1779, 1790 (the present edition), and 1794.
BP_Description_2: The optics entries in the <i>Dictionnaire<i> are among its most extensive and include the following Catoptrique: laws of reflection, reflected images, convex and concave mirrors. Colors: Newton's prismatic colors, object colors, Newton's explanation of color, Descartes's unsustainable system, the rainbow. Diffraction: definition, cause. Dioptrique: convex and concave lenses, convergent and divergent rays, burning lenses, analogies with mirrors, lens foci. Lumiere: nature and propagation of light; light as corpuscles traveling nearly infinitely fast; various atmospheric luminous phenomena. Microscope: simple and compound microscope, solar microscope, brief history. Ombre: shadows cast by large sources, shadows of the earth and moon, astronomical distances determined from shadows. Optique: direct light, visual perception, persistence, binocular vision, vision and spectacles. Reflexion: cause of reflection, elasticity. Refraction: atmospheric refraction, refraction in solids, law of refraction, cause of refraction. Telescope: dioptric and catoptric telescopes, the Newtonian and Gregorian telescope. Most of these entries are concise explications containing propositions and demonstrations accompanied by figures. The material is descriptive, invoking no mathematics above geometry.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Aim√©-Henri Paulian (1722-1802) et sa physique ¬´Newto-Cart√©sienne¬ª : l‚Äôoptique newtonienne revisit√©e<i>|Mulard, P. | Thesis, University of Lille, 2015, 359 pp, NB  pp 253-307. | http://ori-nuxeo.univ-lille1.fr/nuxeo/site/esupversions/1d61fb2c-cd98-4768-b91e-295d252d31f0

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Goethe's first publication on this theory of color. He reported the experiments he conducted and his interpretation of their results, which had convinced him that Newton's theory of prismatic colors was incorrect.
BP_Description_1: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's first publication on this theory of color. The experiments he conducted and his interpretation of their results, convinced him that Newton's theory of prismatic colors was incorrect. Rather than light being decomposed into colors by refraction, Goethe was convinced that color was the result of the interaction light and dark. This gave new polish to the Scholastic theory of the mixing of light and dark, white and black. The reaction of the scientific community was generally negative. Goethe later wrote 'As soon as my <i>Beitr√§ge zur Optik<i> had appeared, the whole fraternity felt obliged to fall upon me and to show that what I still regarded as problematic had long since been explained.' He would publish nothing further regarding optics for nearly 20 years; not until his <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i> of 1810.||When Goethe became interested is color, he knew his university education had not included discussion of prismatic colors or the camera obscura, so he read Johann Erxleben's <i>AnfangsgruÃànde der Naturlehre<i> (likely the 1787 edition) material on optics.||A large gray-scale and color path table and 27 color experiment demonstration cards were meant to accompany the text. These were not issued or sold with the text and had to be purchased separately. The book trade at the time did not bundle text and cards together. Consequently, the cards almost never found with the text. A facsimile set of cards and table was published in 1928.||This copy bound with Goethe's <i>Beytrage zur Optik Zweites Stuck<i> dated 1792.
BP_Description_2: The sections of <i>Goethe's Beytrage zur Optik<i> are titled: Introduction, Prismatic displays in general, Special prismatic experiments, Review and further work, Recapitulation, On the apparatus necessary for these experiments, and especially on cards issued with this work. Unlike Newton's experiments which evaluated the display of prismatically refracted light on a screen, all of Goethe's experiments involved looking through a prism at surfaces and objects. In the recapitulation section, Goethe states that viewing surfaces and object through a prism shows that color appears only at white/black, bright/dark boundaries and reaches the conclusion that (essentially) color is the interaction of light and dark, white and black, and is not a heterogeneous property of light. <i>Beytrage zur Optik<i> contains the first applications of Goethe's idea of 'Der Versuch als Vermittler von Objekt und Subjekt'--<i>experiment as mediator between subject and object<i>--not, as Newtonian science had it, the disinterested revealer of nature.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Goethe contra Newton: Polemics and the Project for a New Science of Color<i>|Sepper, D.|Cambridge, UK, Cambridge University Press, 1988, pp 46-57.||ùëª <i>Goethe‚Äôs Theory of Colour<i>|Schindler, M.|Sussex, UK: Steiner Press, 1970, pp 121‚Äì161.||The Nature of Light and Color: Goethe‚Äôs 'Der Versuch als Vermittler' versus Newton‚Äôs Experimentum Crucis|Marcum, J.A.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>,Vol 17, No 4, 2009, pp 457-481.||Goethe‚Äôs theory of colors between the ancient philosophy, middle ages occultism and modern science|Barsan, V., Merticarlu, A.|<i>Cogent Arts & Humanities<i>, Vol 3, No 1, 2016.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A  textbook for Mixed Mathematics that filled the need for a technical book in the vernacular in German universities, and furthered K√§stner's demonstration of the importance and utility of applied mathematics.
BP_Description_1: The fourth and last edition of the textbook first published in 1759. Between 1758 and 1769 Abraham K√§stner published four parts to his <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde<i> series: I Mathematics, II Applied Mathematics, III Analysis of the finite and infinite, IV Mechanics and Hydrodynamics. The <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde der angewandten Mathematik<i> is Part Two, consisting itself of two parts: aspects of mechanics and optics, and astronomy, geography, chronology and gnomics. K√§stner's text not only filled the need for a technical book in the vernacular in German universities, but also furthered his program to demonstrate the importance and utility of applied mathematics. The initial preliminary material meant that beginning students could start their study with mathematics, while advanced students could begin with its applications. Editions of the the <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde der angewandten Mathematik<i> appeared in 1759, 1765, 1780/1781, and 1792. Each edition has a new preface and contains revisions by K√§stner, clarifying proofs, updating or adding material. The widespread and continuing use of these texts was due, in part, to K√§stner's interest in making sure they were up to date. Thus, each edition gives an accurate idea of what was thought to be important to teach regarding natural philosophy.
BP_Description_2: A  textbook for mixed or applied mathematics with chapters entitled: Statics, Hydrostatics, Aerometry, Hydraulics, Optics, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Astronomy, Geography, Chronology, Gnomics, Artillery, Fortification, Construction. The three chapters on optics (87 pages) contain the following.  I Optics: nature and spread of light, parallel rays, shadows, camera obscura, images and perceptions. II Catoptrics: mirrors, law of reflection, plane mirrors, spherical mirrors, higher-order mirrors. III Dioptrics: refraction, refraction at air and glass, finding the refracted beam from the incident, total internal reflection, types of lenses, foci, image of a point, image of an object, color, the eye, eye-function and spectacles, the telescope, the microscope, diffraction of light. The material is descriptive, elementary and entirely geometrical-optical; physical optics and the nature of light are mentioned only very briefly, but the material on color is Newtonian.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A consideration of Molyneux's question: Is it possible that a person born blind might immediately identify a shape previously familiar to them only by touch if they were made to see.
BP_Description_1: Cristofano Sarti considered the questions asked nearly 100 years earlier by William Molyneux: Could a man who has been born blind and who has learnt to distinguish and name a globe and a cube by touch, be able to  distinguish and name these objects simply by sight, once he had been enabled to see?
BP_Description_2: The work is in four sections: Fundamental notes on Intelligence for the entire work; Optics of nature and of Education; Resolution of Molineux's problem using the Previous Principles; How inconsistent and absurd the positive answers to the Question are. Sarti introduces the idea of a maximum sensual force; its extent and power depends on how many and to what extent the senses are operating simultaneously and interactively. Such as smell and taste, hearing and head movement, or vision and hand motion. Sarti believed that sight and touch form different 'primary ideas' and no pure abstractions arose. For Sarti, touch was the dominant sense and informed vision. So, if the blind could suddenly see, but not touch, a globe and cube, they could not correctly name them.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Animation, Plasticity, and Music in Italy, 1770-1830<i>|Lockhart, E.|University of California Press, 2017, pp 120-125.||Molyneux's Problem|Marjolein, D., Lokhorst, G.-J.|In: <i>The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy<i> (Winter 2017 Edition), Edward N. Zalta, E.N. editor|https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2017/entries/molyneux-problem
BP_Title: L'ottica della natura e dell'educazione indirizzata a risolvere il famoso problema di Molineaux. Opera del D. Cristofano Sarti, pubblico professore nell'universita' di Pisa.
BP_Title English Translation: The Optics of Nature and Education Addressed to Solve the Famous Problem of Molyneux. A Work of Cristofano Sarti, Public Professor in the University of Pisa.

BP_Short or Common Title: Anleitung zur Optik, Katoptrik und Dioptrik
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An advanced textbook on most aspects of optics including, uniquely, material on illumination from Lambert's Photometria of 1760.
BP_Description_1: An advanced textbook on most aspects of optics including, uniquely, material on illumination from Lambert's <i>Photometria<i> of 1760. This textbook was part of an elaborate series that B√ºrja wrote on mathematics and physics. Though intended as a textbook, it is more of a compendium that presents derivations, gives results, and states equations. The forward provides a brief history of optics and lists the contemporary works B√ºrja consulted.
BP_Description_2: The work is in ten sections: Eye and Vision, Lighting, Illumination, Brightness, Clarity and Colors; Apparent Size, Distance, and Movement of Bodies; Shadows; Reflected light from Planar Mirrors; Spherical and other Non-Planar Mirrors, Foci and Images; Refraction; Refraction by Spherical and Planar surfaces and by Lenses, Foci and Images;  Uses of Single lenses; Telescopes and Microscopes; Chromatic and Spherical Aberrations in Lenses and Mirrors. The material is advanced, detailed, and highly analytic; particularly the analysis of lenses and aberrations. Rather than plates, figures appear within the text.
BP_Reference(s): Mathematics in Germany and France in the Early 19th Century: Transmission and Transformation|Dauben, J.W.|In: Epistemological and Social Problems of the Sciences in the Early Nineteenth Century, Jahnke, H.N., Otte M., editors, Springer, 1981, pp 371-399.
BP_Title: Anleitung zur Optik, Katroptrik und Dioptrik von Abel Burja
BP_Title English Translation: Instruction in Optics, Catoptrics and Dioptrics by Abel Burja
BP_Biographical Statement: Cleric of French-Hugenot decent. Teacher, textbook writer, member of the Royal Prussian Academy of Sciences.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Imperial Engineer Corps on titlepage

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of textbook on pure and applied mathematics which, though meant for high schools, is university-level.
BP_Description_1: Johann Friedrich Lorenz wrote this textbook on pure and applied mathematics while senior teacher at the P√§dagogium (boarding high school) at Burg bei Magdeburg. Though written for high school use, German P√§dagogia had very high standards, and the content, level, and expectations of the text reflect that. It is designed for a student with no background, taking them through the mathematics up differential and integral calculus. The applied mathematics deals with several aspects of natural philosophy. This second edition was revised and enlarged considerably from the first, expanding from 2 to 3 three volumes. Editions appeared in 1785, 1793, and 1822.
BP_Description_2: The second edition is in two parts in three Volumes. Part 1 is pure mathematics and is contained in volume 1, Part 2 is applied mathematics and is in volume 2 (mechanics and optics) volume 3 (astronomy). Volume 1: Arithmetic, algebra, geometry, stereometry, plane and spherical trigonometry, analysis, equations, functions, conics, differential equations, integral equations. Volume 2: Statics, hydrostatics, aerometry, mechanics, hydraulics, optics, perspective, catoptrics, dioptrics. Volume 3: Spherical astronomy, theoretical astronomy, geography, gnomics, chronology. The optics material (126 pages) includes: the nature of light, light rays and propagation, the eye and eye-function, reflection, plane and spherical mirrors, mirror images and foci and their calculation, other curved mirrors, theory of refraction, convex and concave lenses, refracted images and foci and their calculation, prismatic and object colors, the eye and spectacles, the telescope, the microscope, projectors. The material is very concise, detailed, and analytic.
BP_Title: Die Elemente der Mathematik, verfasst von Johann Friedrich Lorenz; Erster Theil Die reine Mathematik mit 10 Kupfertaflen, zwente ganzlich umgearbeitete Ausgabe;  Zweyter Theil Die angewandte Mathematik Erste Abtheilung die Mechanischen und optischen Wissenschaften, mit 9 Kufpertaflen, zwente ganzlich umgearbeitete Ausgabe.
BP_Title English Translation: The Elements of Mathematics, written by Johann Friedrich Lorenz. First Part: Pure Mathematics with 10 Copper Plates, Second Completely Reworked Edition. Second Part: Applied Mathematics, the First section of Mechanical and Optical Sciences,w ith 9 Copper Plates, Second Completely Reworked Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: German academic, professor, and prolific textbook author
BP_Provenance: Marginalia and corrections to equations

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Friedrich Kries
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: German translation and augmentation of Adams work on vision and spectacles
BP_Description_1: John Adams' <i>An essay on vision<i> first appeared in 1789. In his Preface he makes clear that the purpose of the work is to discourage both the premature use of eye glasses while vision is strong and the postponement of their use after vision has grown weak. The translator, Friedrich Christian Kries, was a teacher in Gotha with a keen sense for the importance of natural philosophy and its applications. He was committed to education in Germany and translated technical works from English, French, and Italian into German. He edited the writings of Georg Christoph Lichtenberg , Germany's first great professor of experimental physics.
BP_Description_2: Adams begins with a list of work he cites, including those by De la Caille, Harris, Le Cat, Porterfield, Priestley, Smith, Thomin, and Trabaud. The body of the work is in two sections. The first and shorter of the two is a description of ocular anatomy and the function of parts of the eye. The second considers the nature of light and vision. This includes aspects of image formation and the basic properties of  perception: size, position, motion, and color. How vision affected by the atmosphere and distance is also described. Accommodation and adaptation are described. Finally, imperfect sight and its correction by spectacles is described. The work ends with Adams' recommendations regarding the types of spectacles to purchase and how to use them; reading spectacles, spectacles with colored glass, spectacle use after cataract operations, spectacles for the near and far-sighted.
BP_Reference(s): German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-363.
BP_Title: George Adams's Anweisung zur Erhaltung des Gesichts und ihr Kenntniss der Natur des Sehens. Aus dem Englisch. uÃàbers. und mit ZusaÃàtzen und Anmerkungen versehen von Friedrich Kries, Lehrer an dem gothaischen Gymnasium. Mit einer Kupfertafel.
BP_Title English Translation: George Adams's Instruction on the Preservation of Sight and Knowledge of the Nature of Seeing. Translated from the English and Furnished with Additions and Notes by Friedrich Kries, teacher at the Gotha Gymnasium. With a Copper Plate.
BP_Biographical Statement: English oculist, instrument maker, natural philosopher. Wrote extensively, knowingly, but not inventively.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of J.B. Trommsdorf (1770-1837) German chemist and pharmacist.

BP_Short or Common Title: Lectures on Natural and Experimental Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A five-volume work, based on extended essays previously written, that covered several areas of natural philosophy for which Adams had built instruments. Tinctured with Adams's remarkable antipathy to mathematics.
BP_Description_1: George Adams the younger was a famed maker of instruments for the study and demonstration of natural philosophy in areas that included the microscope, optics and vision, electricity, magnetism, astronomy, and barometry. He had produced extended essays on each of these topics, focusing on the instruments involved. Near the end of his life, he produced this 5-volume work that covered all these areas. The work is tinctured with Adams's  Tory politics, religious convictions, and antipathy to mathematics. Adams was primarily an instrument maker and so relied heavily on other sources to assemble his material. In his Preface, Adams lists the 41 different authors and works he consulted, ranging in date from 1774 to 1792. The 52 lectures are simply descriptive and conversational--Adams speaks in the first person to the reader. No theory is given, just facts and principles, supported by figures and descriptions of how instruments can be used to demonstrate phenomena. Editions appeared at London in 1794 and 1799, and at Philadelphia in 1806. A German translation appeared at Leipzig in 1798.
BP_Description_2: Lectures in Volume 1: air and its properties, barometers and the vacuum, air pumps, absorption and movement of air, sound, properties of fire, heat, heat in bodies, chemical heat, fluids. Lectures in Volume 2: nature and properties of water, ice and steam, philosophical reasoning, optics and dioptrics, catoptrics, the eye and vision, visual perception, colors, phosphors, telescopes, microscopes. Lectures in Volume 3: matter in general, history of matter theory, mechanics and motion, acceleration, gravity, projectiles, collisions, mechanical power, practical mechanics, hydrostatics, specific gravity, hydraulics, astronomy. Lectures in Volume 4: Copernican solar system, the  seasons, planets and their orbits, eclipses, stellar parallax and refraction, solar and sidereal time, the planetarium, fixed stars, physical astronomy, electricity, Leiden jar, lightening, nature of electricity, magnetism, meteorology, rain and weather. The optical material (416 pages) includes: refraction and lenses, images and foci of lenses, use of multiple lenses, projection of images, convex and concave mirrors, images and foci of lenses, eye and eye-function, spectacles, apparent size, distance, position, and motion of objects, prismatic color, the rainbow, colors of objects, phosphors, astronomical and terrestrial telescopes, use of achromatic lenses, reflecting telescopes, simple and compound microscopes, solar microscopes. The material is elementary, descriptive, and practical; without theory or mathematics.
BP_Reference(s): Science in the Early Republic: The Society for the Study of Natural Philosophy|Kerber, L.K.|<i>The William and Mary Quarterly<i>, Vol 29, No 2,  1972, pp 263-280.
BP_Title: Lectures on Natural and Experimental Philosophy, Considered in it's [sic] Present State of Improvement. Describing in a Familiar and Easy Manner the Principal Phenomena of Nature; and Shewing that they all co-operate in Displaying the Goodness, Wisdom and Power of God.  by George Adams, Mathematical Instrument Maker to His Majesty, and Optician to His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales. In Five Volumes. The Fifth Volume consisting of the Plates and Index. Vol I. Vol. II. Vol. III. Vol. IV.  Vol. V.
BP_Biographical Statement: English oculist, instrument maker, natural philosopher. Wrote extensively, knowingly, but not inventively.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Applied mathematics text written to accompany lectures but also and expressly for student self-study.
BP_Description_1: Johann Heinrich Voigt wrote this text to accompany his lectures but also and expressly for student self-study. He makes it clear in his preface that the choice of material and the manner of presentation are dictated by this idea. He assumes the student has the necessary mathematics and if not, cites page and paragraph from his pure mathematics book of 1791. But Voigt also believes that demonstrations and models can help understanding and mentions their use in his lectures. For the self-studying student, figures accompanying the text must accomplish this. To that end he 'has not spared the copper (plates).' A second volume is promised, but it never appeared.
BP_Description_2: The material is in the following chapters: Dynamics, statics, mechanics; hydrostatics; aerostatics and aeronometry; hydraulics; optics and photometry; catoptrics; dioptrics; perspective. The optics material (113 pages) includes: optics and direct light, basic photometry, reflection, mirrors, mirror images and foci, refraction, properties of glass, lenses, calculating images and foci, prismatic colors, the eye and eye-function, the microscope, the telescope, diffraction of light. The material is detailed and analytic. Practical aspects dominate theory and many numerically worked examples are provided.
BP_Reference(s): The Culture Of Science And Experiments In Jena Around 1800|Breidbach, O.|In: <i>Hans Christian √òrsted And The Romantic Legacy In Science<i>, Brain R.M., Cohen R.S., Knudsen O., editors|Springer, 2007, 442 pp, NB pp 177-216.
BP_Title: Grundlehren der angewandten Mathematik von Johann Heinrich Voigt D.W.D. Professor der Mathematik in Jena un Corresspondent der konigl. Gesellshaft der Wissenschaftern zu Gottingen. Erste Abtheilung, welche die Lehren der Dynamik, Statik und Mechanik; Hydrostatik; Aerometrie; Hydraulik; Optik und Photometrie; Katoptrik, Dioptrik und Perspectiv, enthaÃàlt. Nebst 8 Kupfertafeln.
BP_Title English Translation: Fundamentals of Applied Mathematics of Johann Heinrich Voigt, D.W.D. Professor of Mathematics in Jena and Correspondent of the Royal Science Society of Gottingen. First Division, Which Contains Teachings on Dynamics, Statics and Mechanics, Hydrostatics, Aerometry, Hydraulics, Optics and Photometry, Catoptrics, Dioptrics and Perspective. Together with 8 Plates.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, natural philosopher, teacher. Professor at the University of Jena, textbook author.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: BuÃàsch' general updating of and replacement for Wolff's famous textbook. The title is 'Encyclopedia', but the work is much more of a bibliography and reference to authors and their works.
BP_Description_1: This work has its roots in Johann Georg  BuÃàsch's earlier work: <i>Encyclopedia of Historical and Philosophical and Mathematical Sciences<i> of 1775. The title is 'Encyclopedia', but the work is much more of a bibliography and reference to authors and their works.  BuÃàsch makes clear in his forward that the Encyclopedia was an expansion of the mathematical part of the previous work, augmented considerably and meant to update and replace Wolff's famous textbook. BuÃàsch notes that editions of the Wolff texts were only very slightly updated and stopped altogether in 1740. BuÃàsch relied on his own collection of books, which he considered to be very complete, and cites them extensively in the Encyclopedia. This adds to its importance, as it indicates what books were available and which were considered important regarding the sciences at the end of the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in three sections, pure, applied, and mixed mathematics. Pure Mathematics: geometry, arithmetic, algebra and analysis, trigonometry. Applied Mathematics: mechanical science, optical science, acoustics and music, astronomical sciences, astrology and fortune telling (sic!), geography and hydrography, gnomics, chronology. Mixed Mathematics: civil architecture, military science. The optics material (33 pages) includes: the phenomenon of light, reflection and refraction, theories of propagation of light, the eye and eye-function, basic photometry, optical references, catoptrics, plane and spherical mirrors, catoptrical references, dioptrics, diffraction of light, catadioptrical telescopes, optical and lens craft, the microscope, dioptrical history and references.  The topics are mostly practical and are described in the most concise way possible. The text is little more than a framework to support the many references to authors and works in optics. There are no figures that accompany the optical material.
BP_Reference(s): Zur Erinnerung an Johann Georg B√ºsch|Roscher, W.|Zeitschrift f√ºr die gesamte Staatswissenschaft (Journal of Institutional and Theoretical Economics), Vol 23, No 2/3, 1867, pp. 219-241.
BP_Title: EncyklopaÃàdie der mathematischen wissenschaften. Zweite durchaus umgearbeitete und mit einer mathematischen bibliographie, vermehrte ausgabe. Von Johann Georg Busch, Professor in Hamburg.
BP_Title English Translation: Encyclopedia of Mathematical Sciences. Second, Thoroughly Reworked Enlarged Edition with a Mathemtical Bibliography. By Johann Georg Busch, Professor at Hamburg.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematics teacher, statistician, and famed political economist. Professor at the Hamburg Gymnasium.
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Dark Morocco Over Green Boards

BP_Short or Common Title: Description of a Forty-feet Reflecting Telescope
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: William Herschel wrote this description of his huge telescope to acknowledge the financial support of King George III for its construction. At the time of this publication, its 4-foot diameter mirror was the largest ever made for a telescope.
BP_Description_1: William Herschel wrote this description of his huge telescope to acknowledge the financial support of King George III for its construction, to describe its details to interested telescope mechanics, and to declare to the community of astronomers what could be expected to be discovered, verified, disproved, and clarified in observational astronomy. The expectations proved impossible to satisfy with the instrument; sitting as it did outdoors, its mirror was subject to all the depredations of weather; the number of good viewing nights were limited; the time required to setup the instrument for viewing was so great that it was spent, rather, using Herschel's smaller telescopes; the mirror required refinishing at least every two years, if not more often. The use and reputation of the huge instrument would eventually recede to zero. But all this was in the future; at the time of publication Herschel's telescope was considered one of the wonders of the astronomical world, it 4-foot diameter mirror being the largest ever made for a telescope.
BP_Description_2: The article begins with a general history of instrument's development; the most important being the history of its mirrors. The first, weighing 1/2 ton, was able to take an excellent polish but proved to be too thin and the sag caused by gravity when tilted, changed it's figure enough to make it unusable. The second, weighing a full ton, was thick enough to hold its figure but its size and weight made it exceedingly difficult to polish. The first part also contains a description of its use in the discovery of new moons of Saturn. The rest of the article describes in great detail the mechanical aspects of the instrument as well as the method of its use in observations. In addition to the famous plate showing the full instrument, detailed figures accompany the mechanical description.
BP_Reference(s): Herschel's 40ft Reflector: Funding and Functions|Hoskin, M.|<i>Journal for the History of Astronomy<i>, Vol 34, Part 1, No 114, 2003, pp 1 - 32.||<i>The History of the Telescope<i>|King, H.C|Dover, New York, 1979, 456 pp, NB: pp 120-142.
BP_Title: "Description of a Forty-feet Reflecting Telescope" By William Herschel, LL.D. F.R.S.  In: Phil Trans, Part II, for 1795
BP_Biographical Statement: German-born English musician, astronomer, oculist, instrument maker. Prolific, active astronomer, famed for the discovery of Uranus.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Royal Artillery Library, Woolwich, dated 1795
