BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of K√§stner's two famous works: a history of pure, applied and mixed mathematics. His history spans a remarkable range of topics, including mechanics, optics, and astronomy and was a standard work in history for many years.
BP_Description_1:
Abraham Gotthelf K√§stner produced two famous works, both in four volumes; a general textbook in mathematics and natural philosophy, the <i>Mathematische Anfangsgr√ºnde<i> of 1758-1769; and a history of pure, applied and mixed mathematics, the <i>Geschichte der Mathematik<i> of 1796-1800. The history was to be part of a larger G√∂ttingen project to produce a history of the sciences. In his long introduction of volume 1, K√§stner maintains there is a strong connections between the history of mathematics and of philosophy, referring historians of mathematics to textbooks in the history of philosophy. K√§stner defines the subject of his history this way: 'History of a science
is, according to me, how science‚Äôs doctrines have been discovered, made known, determined, corrected, presented, explicated, and applied. All this can only be learned little by little through continuous dedication to this science.' For K√§stner, 'Mathematics' was very broad, and his history spans a remarkable range of topics, including mechanics, optics, and astronomy. It was standard work in history for many years; volume 2, published in 1787, is still considered one of the standard sources on the early history of mathematical optics.
BP_Description_2: Abraham Gotthelf K√§stner's history of mathematics is in three parts: from the restoration of the learning to about 1600, from 1600 to Descartes, from Descartes to the end of the 18th century. Volume 1: arithmetic, elementary geometry, algebra, and practical geometry. Volume 2: perspective, geometric analysis and higher geometry, mechanics, optics, astronomy. Volume 3: pure mathematics, analysis, geometric analysis, practical geometry, geometric instruments. Volume 4: mechanics, optics, and astronomy. The history of optics in volumes 2 and 4 is, consistent with the intention of the work, that of analytical optics and its development. This is not a descriptive history; rather it is framework built from citations of important books and a very brief analysis of their content. It is remarkable for the range and completeness of the works in geometrical optics that are cited.
BP_Reference(s): Science and the History of the Sciences. Conceptual InnovationsThrough Historicizing Science in the Eighteenth Century|Ziche, P.|<i>Berichte zur Wissenschaftsgeschichte<i>, Vol 35, No 2, 2012, pp 99-112.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.
BP_Title: Geschichte der Mathematik seit der Wiederherstellung der Wissenschaften bis an das Ende des achtzehnten Jahrhunderts. Von Abraham Gotthelf Kastner.  Erster Band. Arithmetik, Algebra, Elementargeometrie, Trigonometrie, Praktische Geometrie, bis zum Ende des sechszehnten Jahrhunderts. Zweiter Band, Perspectiv, geometrische Analysis und hoÃàhere Geometrie, Mechanik, Optik, Astronomie. Erster Zeitraum bis zum Ende des sechszehnten Jahrhunderts. Nachtrag zum ersten Bande. Dritter Band. Reine Mathematik, Analysis, praktische Geometrie, bis an Cartesius. Sammlungen von Werken fuÃàr unterschiedene Wissenschaften. Nachtrag zum sweiten Bande. Vierter Band. Mechanik, Optik, Astronomie. Zwenter Zeitraum vom Anfange des siebenzehnten Jahrhunderts, bis um desselben Mitte. Nachtrag zu vorigen Banden.
BP_Title English Translation: History of Mathematics from the Restoration of the Sciences to the end of the Eighteenth Century. By Abraham Gotthelf Kastner. First volume. Arithmetic, algebra, elementary geometry, trigonometry, practical geometry, to the end of the sixteenth century. Second volume. Perspective, geometric analysis and higher geometry, mechanics, optics, astronomy. First period to the end of the sixteenth century. Addendum to the first volume.  Third Colume.  Pure Mathematics, Analysis, practical geometry, up to Descartes. Collections of works for different sciences. Addendum to second volume. Fourth volume. Mechanics, optics, astronomy. Second period from the beginning to about the middle of the seventeenth century. Addendum to the previous volumes
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician. Professor at the University of Gottingen, textbook author, enclcypedist, translator.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the library of the Monastery of Lambacens

BP_Short or Common Title: Scoperte sul Gran Fenomeno della Colorazione
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A short treatise on the cause of color and, importantly, proposing a theory as to the cause of color perception.
BP_Description_1: Carlo Barattieri reports in this short treatise his answer to the question of the cause of color. Importantly, Barattieri proposed a theory as to the cause of color perception. That is, what is it about the components of heterogeneous light that, when dispersed by a prism, cause the appearance of color. A shorted, second part appeared in 1797.
BP_Description_2: Barattieri proposes a theory of light a color that is a step beyond Newton. Barattieri holds that 'A ray of light is an aggregate of tenuous homogeneous particles of highly elastic matter, vibrated by self-luminous bodies.' These particles are capable of exciting the sensation of vision. Further, he holds that color perception has a 'variety, and intensity, for my belief, depends on the speed, rotation, combination, quantity, and strength with which the aforementioned particles invest the indicated organ.' Barattieri hold that heterogeneous light is dispersed by a prism but that does not explain the phenomenon of the perceived colors. Importantly, he is presenting a theory of color perception. The bulk of the treatise describe a series of experiments with results that he interprets as supporting his ideas. The treatise ends with a table that organizes colors by Barattieri's theory. The prismatic colors of red, yellow, green, azure, violet, are 'radical' or 'clear', and are 'softened' in their combination to produce all colors.
BP_Reference(s): Books on Color 1495-2015|Osborne, R.|Thylesius Books, 2015, unpaginated.
BP_Title: Scoperte sul Gran Fenomeno della Colorazione Carlo Barattieri.
BP_Title English Translation: Discoveries Regarding the Grand Phenomenon of Coloring
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian natural philospher, from an ancient noble family in Piacenza, wrote on optics and color
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1797 Barattieri - Scoperte sul Gran Fenomeno della Colorazione - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: Ricerche meccaniche e diottriche sopra la causa della rifrazione della luce
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fusinieri proposes a theory of the cause of optical refraction in this work, rejecting Newton and Bo≈°koviƒá, he offers instead a mechanical theory.
BP_Description_1: Ambrogio Fusinieri proposes a theory of the cause of optical refraction in this work. He rejects the Newtonian (and Boscovich's) proposal of attractive forces acting at a distance, and offers instead a mechanical theory.
BP_Description_2: Fusinieri proposes that any acceptable explanation of refraction must be able to predict Snell's Law of Refraction. He devises an analysis of the attraction hypothesis that produces direct contradictions with Snell's Law and visual experience, and on this basis searches for a different cause of refraction. The material is in seven articles. 1: The motion of small bodies toward the surface of larger bodies. 2: General theory of refraction based on attraction. 3: Application this theory to refraction in lenses.  4: Consequences for refraction of lenses in air and water. 5: The falsity of the theory of refraction by attraction when applied to the refraction of the moon. 6: Propagation of small bodies in material of diverse resistance. 7: On the nature of light. An appendix contains two additional discourses: On the measurement of force, and on the essence of bodies and the idea of force. The material is detailed and highly analytic.
BP_Reference(s): Degli studi fisici di Ambrogio Fusinieri commemorazione per Enrico Dal Pozzo di Mombello|di Mombello. E.|Foligno, 1874, 300 pp, NB: pp 249-250.
BP_Title: Ricerche meccaniche e diottriche sopra la causa della rifrazione della luce, ove si dimostra che coll'attrazione introdotta da Newton non si puoÃÄ render ragione di questo fenomeno, ma che e necessario ripeterlo dalle resistenze dei mezzi rifrangenti.
BP_Title English Translation: Mechanical and Dioptric Research on the Cause of the Refraction of Light, by Ambrogio Fusinieri. Wherein it is Demonstrated that Attraction, as Introducted by Newton, Cannot Render a Reason for the Phenomenon, But it is Necessary to again (seek a reason) from the Resistance of the Refracting Material.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian lawyer turned natural philosoher. Autodidact, experimenter, journal editor. Famed for his pioneering work in catalysis.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Printer's Papers Wrapper, Unopened, Untrimmed, Unpressed
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1797 Fusinieri - Ricerche meccaniche e diottriche sopra la causa della rifrazione della luce - Images.JPG

BP_Author full name: Johann Tobias & Langsdorf, Karl Christian von Mayer
BP_Author last name first: Mayer, Johann Tobias & Langsdorf, Karl Christian von
BP_Short or Common Title: Neuer Auszug aus den Anfangsgr√ºnden aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A complete and update and revision-by-way-of-addenda of the 1755 edition of Christian Wolff's <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde Aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften.<i>
BP_Description_1: A complete and update and revision-by-way-of-addenda of the 1755 edition of Christian Wolff's <i>Der Anfangs-GruÃànde Aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften<i> performed by Johann Tobias Mayer and Karl Christian von Langsdorf. The new preface mentions that the mathematical part of Wolff's text needed little change, only some additions. The applied mathematical part required extended addenda. The added material is marked with a letter indicating which editor was responsible. The concision and culling was sufficient so that the textbook fit in a 900-page volume. As the preface states, the book arose from a need at Erlangen where both editors taught. Though there was only one edition of this textbook, it was the basis for Mayer's text <i>Anfangsgr√ºnde der Naturlehre zum Behuf der Vorlesungen √ºber die Experimental-Physik<i>, editions of which appeared in 1801, 1812, and 1827 and was widely used in German speaking countries.
BP_Description_2: The topics covered in the textbook and the editorial work was apportioned as follows: Mayer: Arithmetic, algebra, higher geometry, analysis, optics, catoptrics, dioptrics, perspective, astronomy, geography, chronology, gnomics, artillery, fortification; Langsdorf: Geometry, trigonometry, mechanics, hydrostatics, aeronometry, hydraulics, architecture. Wolff's original textbook was Scholastic in form and style, Mayer and Langsdorf's new edition is more modern, with theorems, proofs, notes, and experiments, followed by long descriptive observation sections and worked examples. The material in Mayer's optical sections (69 pages) is elementary with no mathematics above geometry involved. Notes are used extensively to cite works where the student reader can find more detail.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Teaching the Mathematical Sciences at French and German Universities during the 18th Century<i>|Confalonieri, S. and Kr√∂ger, D.|Cuvillier Verlag, 2016, pp 29-93.||Christian Wolff (1679-1754) and his contribution for the Mathematics Education|Nobre, S|In: <i>Proceedings of the XXth International Congress of History of Science<i>|Brepols, 2002, pp 89-94.||German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.
BP_Title: Neuer Auszug aus den Anfangsgr√ºnden aller Mathematischen Wissenschaften. Mit noÃàthigen VeraÃànderungen und ZusaÃàtzen. Mit Kupfern
BP_Title English Translation: New Excerpts from the Foundations of All Mathematical Sciences. With Necessary Changes and Addtions. By Johann Tobias Mayer and Karl Christian Langsdorf. With Copper Plates.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, astronomer, selonographer. Worked and taught at the University of Gottingen. & German mathematician, natural philosopher, engineer. Professor at the Universities of Erlangen, Vilnius, and Heidelberg.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary compendium of natural philosophy widely used in Eastern Europe.
BP_Description_1: An elementary compendium of natural philosophy widely used in Eastern Europe. Pankl patterned his textbook after Johann Baptiste Horvath's <i>Physica Generalis<i> and <i>Physica Particularis<i>. Editions appeared in 1790, 1793 and 1797.
BP_Description_2: The three volumes contain the following. Volume 1 Bodies Considered in the Abstract: common and universal properties of bodies, linear motion, curvilinear motion, light. Volume 2 Chemical consideration of bodies: Chemistry in general, fire, different kinds of air, different kinds of fluids, different kinds of solids. Volume 3 Physical consideration of bodies: The Earth in general, the atmosphere, electricity, physics of water, meteorics, animals, vegetables, and minerals of the earth. The optics material (94 pages) covers: the nature and propagation of light, reflection, refraction and diffraction of light, heterogeneous light, fits of easy reflection and transmission, colors, optics or direct light, the eye and eye-function, perception of size, shape, and motion, catoptrics, plane and curved mirrors, dioptrics, convex and concave lenses, dioptrical instruments, telescope and microscope, camera obscura, magic lantern. The geometrical optics material is elementary, descriptive and involves only basic geometry. The physical optics material is not completely Newtonian, particularly regarding prismatic colors, citing as it does, different theories. Though each section ends with citations of several contemporary works for reference, Pankl omits references to Huygens, Euler and the wave theory of light.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A history of mathematics and mathematical fields such as mechanics, physics, probability, astronomy, optics, music, geography, and navigation.
BP_Description_1: Second edition, improved and greatly enlarged, of the first classical history of mathematics that contains much information not found elsewhere. , is considered to be the author‚Äôs masterpiece. Not only does Montucla provide a comprehensive history of the development of mathematical ideas, but he also includes mechanics, physics, probability, astronomy, music, mathematical geography, and navigation. The first edition, published in 1758, covered mathematical history to the end of the 17th century. Montucla had intended to add a third volume covering mathematics to the mid-18th century but the did not continue. In the 1790s Montucla began working on the second edition, revising and expanding the first two volumes and adding a third devoted to 18th-century mathematics. But he died but died before the project was finished. The astronomer J√©r√¥ome De La Lande, his friend from childhood, assisted by others, completed the final two volumes. Volume 1 appeared in 1798, Volume 2 in 1799, Volumes 3 and 4 in 1802.
BP_Description_2: The material is diffusely spread out. Volume 1: Preface by Montucla, Ancient Greeks, The Far East, The 16th century (with Supplement). Volume 2: The 17th century (with Supplement), Table of contents and index of vols. 1 and 2, Additions, corrections, errata for vols. 1 and 2. Volume 3: Preface by La Lande, The 18th century: mathematics, optics, mechanics. Volume 4: The 18th century: Astronomy, Supplements: Capstan, Geography, Quadrature, Music. Table of Contents and Index of Vols. 3 and 4.||On the history of optics originally prepared by Montucla, the links with Joseph Priestley‚Äôs book <i>The history and present state of discoveries relating to vision, light and colours<i> of 1772 go both ways. Priestley borrowed heavily from the first edition of Montucla, and Montucla prepared his second edition after reading Priestley‚Äôs book. Each acknowledged his debt to the other. Montucla devotes two chapters to the optics of Johannes Kepler, both the <i>Ad Vitellionem<i> of 1604 and the <i>Dioprice<i> of 1611,  and Descartes <i>La Dioptrique<i> of 1637.||The additional optics material in the second edition appeared in Volume 3, book 2 and was edited by Fortia d‚ÄôUrban. The new material, requiring 177 pages, is in 16 sections: 1 General progress in optics; 2 Solutions to algebraic equations governing lens design; 3 Generation of images by reflection and refraction; 4 Optical phenomena and illusions; 5 Achromatic lenses; 6 Lens craft; 7 Telescopes; 8 Microscopes; 9 Micrometers and heliometers; 10 Optical instruments using reflection; 11 Physical optics regarding refraction and diffraction; 12 Photometry; 13 Fantasmagoria; 14 Visual phantoms; 15 Attacks on Newton's color theory; 16 Physical optics regarding light propagation. The books ends with a summary of Priestley's <i>The history and present state of discoveries relating to vision, light and colours<i> of 1772. The longest section is 5, dealing with achromatic lenses and their design, with Fortia d‚ÄôUrban relying heavily on the work of D'Alembert.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A comprehensive bibliography of the older literature in mathematics and related areas of mechanics and optics.
BP_Description_1: Murhard's bibliography is in five volumes, the first two appeared in 1797 and 1798, the last three in 1803, 1804, and 1805. This long-term project of Murhard's included the older works in mathematics and many related subjects, including bookkeeping, optics, physics, astronomy, navigation, hydraulics, mechanics, architecture, and fortifications. Approximately 10,000 titles are listed chronologically by subject. The first two volumes are dedicated to Abraham Gotthelf K√§stner, Hofrath Heyne. Each entry has a date, an author, and a brief description of the work.||The work apparently grew in scope and prompted the last three volumes: they are subtitled <i>Litteratur der mechanischen und optischen Wissenschaften<i>. Volumes 3 and 4 are devoted to mechanics. All of Volume 5 is devoted to the literature of optics. Murhard's bibliography is the first index of wide scope and temporal reach in mathematical and related works. Though now known to be somewhat inaccurate, the mathematician De Morgan mentions his indebtedness to Murhard's bibliography. It stands along side J.E. Scheibel‚Äôs <i>Einleitung zur Mathematischen B√ºcherkenntnis<i> of 1769-98 as the two principal mathematical bibliographic works of the 18th century.
BP_Description_2: Volume 5 is devoted to optics and has the following sections. I: introductory texts to the optical sciences, II: General works. III: Writings on individual subjects in the optical sciences. IV: Auxiliary sciences in optics. Section III includes subsections on the eye, vision, eye-function, light and light rays, physical optics, color, the rainbow, telescope, microscope, micrometers, mirrors, camera obscura and magic lantern, and lamps and photometry. Some of the entries are in the first decade of the 16th century, and it is clear that Murhard had extensive access to historical literature and the works themselves. Many of the entries give a remarkably detailed account of the work's content.
BP_Title: Litteratur der Mathematischen Wissenschaften. Von Fr. Wilh. Aug. Murhard.
BP_Title English Translation: The Literature of Mathematical Sciences. By Friedrich Wilhelm August Murhard.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, legal scholar, writer, translator, and librarian. The present works were written before his troubles with plagerism and discreting arose.
BP_Provenance: Bookplates of William P. Wreden and Erwin Tomash. Tiny handwritten auction notes in the upper and lower right-hand corners of the title page.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary course in mathematics and applied mathematics, including mechanics, optics, and astronomy.
BP_Description_1: In his Preface to the first volume, Shultz states that this text was the result of his lecture notes in pure mathematics. He discovered them to be beyond first year university students and so set out to write a extended textbook better suited for a first course for university students and for self-study. The second volume appeared seven years after the first and was the result of Schultz's teaching experience. He states in the the preface that the material on mechanics is presented with the requirement of the Calculus, believing that the essentials of statics and mechanics can be comprehended without advanced mathematics. The material on optics begins with and is anchored by material on the eye, vision, and the process of seeing. Only those aspects of Catoptrics and Dioptrics are presented which directly relate to vision. The third volume, presumably in press when Schultz died in 1805, presents elementary descriptive and observational astronomy. The optics material is indicative of the optics taught to beginning students, with its emphasis on geometric optics and physical optics before the advent of Fresnel's development of a complete wave theory of light.
BP_Description_2: The three volumes of Schultz's work cover the following  I: Arithmetic, Geometry, Trigonometry and Surveying. II: Mechanics and Optics.  III: Elementary Observational astronomy. The optics material (194 pages) in Vol 2 follows the traditional sequence of optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics. The optics section begins with and is largely focused on the eye, vision, and perception. Ocular anatomy and eye-function is covered. Light is treated in general terms, defined by the simple optical phenomena it exhibits: rectilinear propagation, reflection, refraction, diffraction, and dispersion. The greatest emphasis (by far) is on geometric optics and defines the material in the sections on catoptrics and dioptrics. Image formation and position in plane and curved mirrors is described with elementary mathematics. Refraction and lens function are similarly described, with reference made along the way to Newton's prism experiments and the nature of dispersion. Simple mathematical expressions for the location of foci for spherical convex and concave lenses are given. The telescope, microscope, and other optical instruments are described in an operational manner, using the material presented for lenses and giving some practical information for their construction. The rainbow is also described. Schultz references most of the standard works in optics, ranging from Risner's edition of Alhacen, Kepler, Newton's Optice, Traber, Zahn, Huygens, Boscovich, Euler, and Kl√ºgel.||The optics material is complete and sufficiently detailed for an elementary understanding that does not require mathematics beyond geometry, trigonometry and algebra.
BP_Reference(s): Physik im Lehrbuch 1700 -1850|Lind, G.|Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 1992, 403 pp, NB: pp 266-273, 297-310.
BP_Title: Kurzer Lehrbegriff der Mathematik I-III. I: Kurzer Lehrbegriff der Arithmetik, Geometrie, Trigonometrie und Landmesskunst. II: Kurzer Lehrbegriff der mechanischen und optischen Wissenschaften.Anfangsgrunde der Optik. III: Popul√§re Anfangsgrunde der Astronomie
BP_Title English Translation: Concise System of Mathematics I-III. I: Concise System of Arithmetic, Geometry, Trigonometry and Surveying. II: Concise System of Mechanical and Optical sciences. Fundamentals of optics. III: Popular Fundamental of Astronomy
BP_Biographical Statement: German Enlightenment, Protestant theologian, enlightenment mathematician and philosopher, and textbook writer.
BP_Provenance: Owners' signature dated 1906 on pastedown and free end paper

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Among the earliest works on the biological influences of light, particularly on the human body.
BP_Description_1: German physician Johan Christoph Ebermayer's book has its origins as the prize-winning entry <i>Commentatio de lucis in corpus humannm vivum praeter visum efficacia<i>, submitted to the G√∂ttingen Academy in 1797. The prize essay was reworked, with additions, to produce the <i>Geschichte des Lichtes und dessen Einfluss auf den menschlichen K√∂rper<i>. Ebermayer, son of a pharmacist and originally from D√ºsseldorff, was a botanist, pharmacologist and military surgeon. While on military duty in the Ruhr, he first investigated the nature of light according to the theories of ancient through major eighteenth-century authors, and then extensively studies the effects of light on various organic and inorganic bodies, with particular attention to the plant and animal world. From this came his hypotheses regarding the positive influence of light on the physiology of the human body.
BP_Description_2: There are three parts: On the Nature of Light, Light's Effect on Nature, and Light's Effect, other than vision, on Man. Throughout the entire work, "Light" for Ebermaier was daylight, principally sunlight. The first part is a brief history of the opinions regarding light's nature. The second part reports light's effect on the atmosphere, on minerals, plants, and animals in general. The third part describes light's effect on humans. These include chemical, physiological, pathological, dietetic and therapeutic effects. Sunburn is considered and  Ebermaier reports different degrees of sunburn depending on the time of exposure, and that paler skin types reacted more severely than darker skin types. He also noted that sun exposure could induce an increase in skin thickness. Aside from sunburn, Ebermaier notes the general healthful, if not therapeutic, effect of daylight.
BP_Reference(s): History of Therapeutic UV Radiation|Raab, W.|In: Skin cancer and UV Radiation|Altmeyer, P. Hoffmann, K., St√ºcker, M., editors|Springer, 1997, 409 pp, NBL pp 1-19.||History of Human Photobiology|Roelandts, R.|In: Photodermatology|Lim, H.W., Honigsmann, H., John L. M. Hawk, J.L.M., editors|CRC Press, 2007, 496 pp, NB: pp 1-14.
BP_Title: Versuch einer Geschichte des Lichtes in RuÃàcksicht seines Einflusses auf die gesammte Natur, und auf den menschlichen KoÃàrper ausser dem Gesichte besonderss. Von Johann Christoph Ebermaier.
BP_Title English Translation: Historical essay on light with regard to its influence on the whole of nature, and especially on the human body, besides vision. By Johann Christoph Ebermaier.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physician and pharmacist

BP_Short or Common Title: Analyse des refractions astronomiques et terrestres
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Kramp's elaborate treatise on atmospheric refraction.
BP_Description_1: Christian Kramp's elaborate treatise on atmospheric refraction. Though mindful of the important work in the past by Euler, Lambert and others, and describing it in detail, Kramp establishes his own analysis.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in six chapters: Layering of the atmosphere; General principles that determine light's path in air; Numerical analysis; Refractions at the horizon; Solutions proposed by Euler, Bradley, Mayer, and Lambert; Terrestrial refractions.  He proposes a strictly mechanical mechanism, with light particles interacting/refracting in elastic collisions with air particles. To make computations possible, he makes the simplifying assumption that the air's elasticity is proportional to its density. In the last chapter, Kramp poses and solves several practical problems in positional astronomy involving atmospheric refraction. Overall, the material is highly detailed and analytic.
BP_Reference(s): Astronomical Refraction‚ÄìSome History and Theories|Mahan, A.I.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 1, No 4, 1962, pp 497-511.
BP_Title: Analyse des refractions astronomiques et terrestres. Par le citoyen Kramp, Professeur de Chymie et de Physique experimentale a l'ecole central du Departement de al Roer.
BP_Title English Translation: Analysis of Astronomical and Terrestrial Refractions. By Citizen Kramp, Professor of Chemistry and Experimental Physics a the Central School of the Roer Department.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, natural philosophyer. Professor at the university of Strasbourg, famed for his work in the mathematics of factorials.
BP_Provenance: Library stamps from University of Halle, Imperial Prussian Archive House. Inscription on free endpaper.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Phillipe-Jacques Dannbach and Engelhart Benjamin Schwickert

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: From a series of textbooks for university courses in mathematics and natural philosophy, this is the text on optics in that series and one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics
BP_Description_1: James Wood produced a series of textbooks for university courses in mathematics and natural philosophy between 1791-1799, <i>The Principles of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy<i>; six parts in four volumes. This is the text on optics in that series and one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics, the list of such texts is short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799. Wood's intention was not to produce a full compendium of optics, but rather a concise text that covered the elementary aspects of the subject and could be covered in a single university course. Editions of Wood's Optics appeared in 1799, 1801, 1811, and 1828.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in 13 chapters: The Nature of Light and its Propagation, Laws of Reflection, Laws of Refraction, Reflection at plane and spherical Surfaces, Images formed by Reflection, Refraction at plane and Spherical Surfaces, Images formed by Refraction, The Eye and eye-function, Optical Instruments, Chromatic Aberrations, Spherical Aberrations, The Rainbow, Caustics. Considering when it was written, the form is rather old-fashioned: a concise march of Definitions, Propositions, Corollaries, and Discussions in Scholia. The material is elementary, detailed, and based on physical principles expressed in geometry, trigonometry and ratios; with very few equations. The physical and geometric optics material relies heavily on Newton, the <i>Opticks<i> and <i>Optical Lectures<i> being cited frequently.||Importantly, Wood does not make extensive use of analysis; something which by this time the French had developed to high level in optics. Wood's work was at the cusp of the transition that brought continental analysis to Cambridge in particular and British university education in general.
BP_Reference(s): William Whewell and Cambridge Mathematics|Becher, H.W.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 1, 1980, pp. 1-48.
BP_Title: The Elements of Optics designed for the use of students in the University. By James Wood, B.D. Fellow of St. John's Collect, Cambridge. The Second Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, clearic, academic. Senior Wrangler then Professor at St John's College, Cambridge for 60 years.
BP_Provenance: Stamps of the Athenaeum and Liverpool Library on the title page.

BP_Short or Common Title: Experiments on the Refrangibility of the invisible Rays of the Sun
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reprinting of Herschel's paper on the nature of the invisible heat radiation from the Sun.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting of Herschel's paper on the nature of the invisible heat radiation from the Sun. The paper had appeared a few months earlier in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. The papers were immediately translated in German. Given the cost and limited access to the Royal Society's Philosophical Transactions, it is very likely that many of those interested in natural philosophy first learned of Herschel's discovery from the Philosophical Magazine, selling as it did, 1000 copies each month.
BP_Description_2: William Herschel records that he was investigating the heating power of the visible prismatic spectrum produced by the sun using several thermometers, bulbs blacked with Japan ink, placed at a few positions in the visible spectrum. As a type of control, he had placed an additional thermometer beyond the red of the projected spectrum. The invisible radiation there produced the greatest temperature rise. As a check of his results, he conducted an investigation into the illuminating power of various parts of the spectrum, finding that pale green provided 'the maximum illumination' and that part beyond the read was invisible. He followed his initial discovery with a series of experiments he hoped would determine 'whether light be essentially different from radiant heat.' Herschel recorded the results from this series of experiments showing that the invisible heat radiation he had discovered beyond the red end of the prismatic solar spectrum suffer refraction, can be focused, can be reflected, and can be dispersed like visible radiation. Eventually, Herschel concluded that light and heat were similar but different radiant phenomena.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Herschel's Dilemma in the Interpretation of Thermal Radiation|Lovell, D.J.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 59, No 1, 1968, pp 46-60.||<i>The Lamp of Learning: Taylor & Francis and the Development of Science Publishing<i>|Brock, W.H., Meadows A.J.|London: Taylor and Francis, 1998, pp. 89‚Äì109.||<i>A History of Scientific & Technical Periodicals: The Origins and Development of the Scientific and Technical press, 1665‚Äì1790<i>|Kronick, D.|Metuchen: Scarecrow Press, 1976.
BP_Title: "Experiments on the Refrangibility of the invisible Rays of the Sun" In: Philosophical Magazine, Vol 8, October 1800, pp 9-15.
BP_Biographical Statement: German-born English musician, astronomer, oculist, instrument maker. Prolific, active astronomer, famed for the discovery of Uranus.
BP_Printer: Jonas Davis, John Taylor, and Robert Wilks
BP_BibliographicNotes: Quire A bound in after B‚ÇÅ
BP_Binding: Contemporary 3/4 Calf Rebacked Over Marbled Paper Covered Boards, Worn

BP_Short or Common Title: Experiments on the solar, and on the terrestrial Rays that occasion Heat
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reprinting of Herschel's paper on the nature of light and heat.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting of Herschel's paper on the nature of light and heat. The paper had appeared a few months earlier in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. The papers were immediately translated in German.  Given the cost and limited access to the Royal Society's Philosophical Transactions, it is very likely that many of those interested in natural philosophy first learned of Herschel's discovery from the Philosophical Magazine, selling as it did, 1000 copies each month.
BP_Description_2: William Herschel records that he was investigating the heating power of the visible prismatic spectrum produced by the sun using several thermometers, bulbs blacked with Japan ink, placed at a few positions in the visible spectrum. As a type of control, he had placed an additional thermometer beyond the red of the projected spectrum. The invisible radiation there produced the greatest temperature rise. As a check of his results, he conducted an investigation into the illuminating power of various parts of the spectrum, finding that pale green provided 'the maximum illumination' and that part beyond the read was invisible. He followed his initial discovery with a series of experiments he hoped would determine 'whether light be essentially different from radiant heat.' Herschel recorded the results from this series of experiments showing that the invisible heat radiation he had discovered beyond the red end of the prismatic solar spectrum suffer refraction, can be focused, can be reflected, and can be dispersed like visible radiation.||Herschel records his investigation into the similarities and differences between visible and invisible heat radiation. He uses both the sun and 'terrestrial' sources of heat radiation, such as a candle flame and a kitchen fire. Though he initially consider them both to be different manifestations of the same radiant phenomenon, he eventually concluded that heat and light 'have nothing in common but a certain equal degree of refrangibility.' Not withstanding this conclusion, Herschel provided in this series of papers  the enormous first impetus to the study of thermal radiation.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Herschel's Dilemma in the Interpretation of Thermal Radiation|Lovell, D.J.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 59, No 1, 1968, pp 46-60.||<i>The Lamp of Learning: Taylor & Francis and the Development of Science Publishing<i>|Brock, W.H., Meadows A.J.|London: Taylor and Francis, 1998, pp. 89‚Äì109.||<i>A History of Scientific & Technical Periodicals: The Origins and Development of the Scientific and Technical press, 1665‚Äì1790<i>|Kronick, D.|Metuchen: Scarecrow Press, 1976.

BP_Short or Common Title: Investigation of the Powers of the Prismatic Colours to heat and Illuminate Objects
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A reprinting of Herschel's paper describing  the discovery of invisible radiation beyond the red end of the prismatic solar spectrum which was capable of producing heat
BP_Description_1: A reprinting of Herschel's paper describing  the discovery  of invisible radiation beyond the red end of the prismatic solar spectrum which was capable of producing heat; what is now call infrared radiation. The paper had appeared a few months earlier in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. With In this series of papers, Herschel provided the enormous first impetus to the study of thermal radiation. The papers were immediately translated into German. Given the cost and limited access to the Royal Society's Philosophical Transactions, it is very likely that many of those interested in natural philosophy first learned of Herschel's discovery from the Philosophical Magazine, selling as it did, 1000 copies each month.
BP_Description_2: William Herschel records that he was investigating the heating power of the visible prismatic spectrum produced by the sun using several thermometers, bulbs blacked with Japan ink, placed at a few positions in the visible spectrum. As a type of control, he had placed an additional thermometer beyond the red of the projected spectrum. The invisible radiation there produced the greatest temperature rise. As a check of his results, he conducted an investigation into the illuminating power of various parts of the spectrum, finding that pale green provided 'the maximum illumination' and that part beyond the read was invisible. He followed his initial discovery with a series of experiments he hoped would determine 'whether light be essentially different from radiant heat.' Herschel recorded the results from this series of experiments showing that the invisible heat radiation he had discovered beyond the red end of the prismatic solar spectrum suffer refraction, can be focused, can be reflected, and can be dispersed like visible radiation.||Herschel records his investigation into the similarities and differences between visible and invisible heat radiation. He uses both the sun and 'terrestrial' sources of heat radiation, such as a candle flame and a kitchen fire. Though he initially consider them both to be different manifestations of the same radiant phenomenon, he eventually concluded that heat and light 'have nothing in common but a certain equal degree of refrangibility.' Not withstanding this conclusion, Herschel provided in this series of papers  the enormous first impetus to the study of thermal radiation.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Herschel's Dilemma in the Interpretation of Thermal Radiation|Lovell, D.J.|<i>Isis<i>, Vol 59, No 1, 1968, pp 46-60.||<i>The Lamp of Learning: Taylor & Francis and the Development of Science Publishing<i>|Brock, W.H., Meadows A.J.|London: Taylor and Francis, 1998, pp. 89‚Äì109.||<i>A History of Scientific & Technical Periodicals: The Origins and Development of the Scientific and Technical press, 1665‚Äì1790<i>|Kronick, D.|Metuchen: Scarecrow Press, 1976.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: German translation of Herschel's three papers on the discovery and properties of heat radiation.
BP_Description_1: German translation of Herschel's three papers on the discovery and properties of heat radiation. The translation was produced just a few months after Herschel's papers appeared in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. Though Harding was an observational astronomer, his interests were wide, and his translation is an early indication of the impetus Herschel's work provided for interest in and research into thermal radiation.
BP_Description_2: William Herschel records that he was investigating the heating power of the visible prismatic spectrum produced by the sun using several thermometers, bulbs blacked with Japan ink, placed at a few positions in the visible spectrum. As a type of control, he had placed an additional thermometer beyond the red of the projected spectrum. The invisible radiation there produced the greatest temperature rise. As a check of his results, he conducted an investigation into the illuminating power of various parts of the spectrum, finding that pale green provided 'the maximum illumination' and that part beyond the read was invisible. He followed his initial discovery with a series of experiments he hoped would determine 'whether light be essentially different from radiant heat.' Herschel recorded the results from this series of experiments showing that the invisible heat radiation he had discovered beyond the red end of the prismatic solar spectrum suffer refraction, can be focused, can be reflected, and can be dispersed like visible radiation.||Herschel records his investigation into the similarities and differences between visible and invisible heat radiation. He uses both the sun and 'terrestrial' sources of heat radiation, such as a candle flame and a kitchen fire. Though he initially consider them both to be different manifestations of the same radiant phenomenon, he eventually concluded that heat and light 'have nothing in common but a certain equal degree of refrangibility.' Not withstanding this conclusion, Herschel provided in this series of papers  the enormous first impetus to the study of thermal radiation.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A physics textbook suitable for high school and gymnasium, written to satisfy the need in the new secondary schools that were established soon at the end of the French Revolution.
BP_Description_1: A physics textbook suitable for high school and gymnasium, written to satisfy the need in the new secondary schools that were established soon at the end of the French Revolution. Science was an important part of the curriculum and textbooks with updated content were needed. The level of material is elementary but informed by the latest developments and the style and development appropriate for students with little background and no mathematics. Editions appeared in 1801 and 1813. An Italian translation appeared at Florence in 1803 and a Spanish one at Barcelona in 1827.
BP_Description_2: The material is distributed in three volumes as follows. Volume 1: The extent, divisibility, formability, impenetrability, and mobility of bodies; inertia; motion and machines; fluids; gravity; system of the world, celestial movement; terrestrial gravity and weight. Volume 2: Chemical affinity and attraction; heat; porosity, compressibility, elasticity; the atmosphere; chemical properties of air; water; nature of water; acids; combustion; respiration and animal heat; vegetable fermentation. Volume 3: The Earth; light; reflected light; refracted light; prismatic decomposition of light; electricity; magnetism; Galvanism. The optics material (165 pages) includes: nature and propagation of light; shadows; the appearance, size, shape, blur, number, and movement of objects; law of reflection; plane and spherical mirrors, convex and concave; mirrors of other shapes; law of refraction and its cause; refraction at a plane and spherical surfaces; lenses; the eye and eye-function; indistinct vision and its correction; telescopes and microscopes; prismatic colors; the rainbow; color of bodies. The material is elementary with the use of only the most elementary geometry. The style is entirely descriptive. The physical optics is Newtonian and the geometrical optics is elementary and patterned after Smith.
BP_Reference(s): Physics Textbooks and Textbook Physics in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries|Simon, J.|In: <i>The Oxford Handbook of the History of Physics<i>, Buchwald J.Z., Fox, R., editors|Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2013, 945 pp, NB: pp 651-678 .

BP_Biographical Statement: French physicist. Professor at the College Beziers and the University Toulouse.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Catholic High School of Lille

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second edition of a series of textbooks for university courses in mathematics and natural philosophy, this is a reprinting of the text on optics in that series and one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics.
BP_Description_1: A reprinting of the 1799 edition with very slight changes to wording. The coverage, content, and detail of the material is the same as the first edition. James Wood produced a series of textbooks for university courses in mathematics and natural philosophy between 1791-1799, <i>The Principles of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy<i>; six parts in four volumes. This is the text on optics in that series and one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics, the list of such texts is short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and Woods in 1799.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in 13 chapters: The Nature of Light and its Propagation, Laws of Reflection, Laws of Refraction, Reflection at plane and spherical Surfaces, Images formed by Reflection, Refraction at plane and Spherical Surfaces, Images formed by Refraction, The Eye and eye-function, Optical Instruments, Chromatic Aberrations, Spherical Aberrations, The Rainbow, Caustics. Considering when it was written, the form is rather old-fashioned: a concise march of Definitions, Propositions, Corollaries, and Discussions in Scholia. The material is elementary, detailed, and based on physical principles expressed in geometry, trigonometry and ratios; with very few equations. The physical and geometric optics material relies heavily on Newton, the Opticks and Optical Lectures being cited frequently.||Importantly, Wood does not make extensive use of analysis; something which by this time the French had developed to high level in optics. Wood's work was at the cusp of the transition that brought continental analysis to Cambridge in particular and British university education in general.
BP_Reference(s): William Whewell and Cambridge Mathematics|Becher, H.W.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 1, 1980, pp. 1-48.
BP_Title: The Elements of Optics designed for the use of students in the University. By James Wood, B.D. Fellow of St. John's Collect, Cambridge. The Second Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, clearic, academic. Senior Wrangler then Professor at St John's College, Cambridge for 60 years.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Faint optical diagrams on half-title

BP_Author full name: Abb√© Nicolas Louis de La Caille
BP_Author last name first: La Caille, Abb√© Nicolas Louis de
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A revision and updating of the fourth and last edition from the author, of La Caille's text on optics of 1766
BP_Description_1: A revision and updating of the fourth and last edition from the author, of La Caille's text on optics of 1766, which itself was a slight updating of the first edition of 1756. This text had the goal of keeping La Caille's pedagogical style but updating essential parts with modern developments. The new sections are interspersed with the text of 1766, and indicated with 'Addition or Note of the Editors.' The editing and amending was done by graduates of l‚ÄôEcole Polytechnique where the new book was to be used. The original text also contained material on perspective, and since this was deemed by the editors to be a separate subject and of insufficient utility to belong in the present text, it was removed from this edition. Editions appeared in 1802 and 1810.
BP_Description_2: The new material contained in this edition includes: the theory of spherical and chromatic aberration, refraction and dispersion measurement of glass, size and position of images from mirrors and lenses, updated material on telescopes and microscopes, achromatic objective lenses, and the rainbow. The text maintains its focus on utility and optical instruments, and its lack of material on theory and physical optics.
BP_Reference(s): Fresnel and the Emergence of Physics as a Discipline|Silliman, R.H.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 4, 1974, pp. 137-162, NB: pp 145.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Based on the second edition of <i>Syllabus of a Course of Lectures in Natural and Experimental Philosophy<i> of 1790, describing a series of 12 lectures covering most of natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Adam Walker was a self-taught, very successful, itinerant teacher and lecturer in natural philosophy. He became the most famous itinerant lecturer of the 18th century. His success depended, in part, on the popularity and utility of the several books he wrote. His manual to accompany his lectures, <i>Analysis of a Course of Lectures on Natural and Experimental Philosophy<i>, appeared in 14 editions between 1766 and 1807; his <i>Syllabus of a Course of Lectures in Natural and Experimental Philosophy<i> appeared in four editions between 1771 and 1790. The present text is based on the <i>Syllabus<i> of 1790 and describes a series of 12 lectures, and is a culmination of his teaching, writing, and travel experiences. Walker wrote 'not in an 'affected style', but rather in that of 'simplicity and clarity', which meant [that] the course is interesting and [could] be understood by all classes and social positions, and [was] particularly suited for gentlemen and ladies who [wished] to be familiar with the more rational parts and sublimes of knowledge, through the easiest and the least cost.' Editions appeared at London in 1799 and 1802, and a copied edition in 1801.
BP_Description_2: The 12 lectures cover the following. 1: General ideas regarding Nature. 2: Properties of Matter. 3: Mechanics. 4: Chemistry. 5: The Atmosphere. 6: Hydrostatics and Hydraulics. 7: Electricity. 8: Electricity continued. 9: Optics. 10: Astronomy. 11: The Moon. 12: Astronomy continued.  The optics material (72 pages) includes: light's nature and propagation, laws of reflection and refraction, lenses, images from mirrors and lenses, prismatic colors, catoptrics, vision, optical instruments, refracting and reflecting telescope, simple and compound microscopes, solar microscope, magic lantern, camera obscura, illusions. The material is elementary and descriptive, with no mathematics. The emphasis is on demonstrating phenomena and the operation of optical instruments, rather than presenting theory.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Adam Walker: Um Professor Independente e Iteinerante de Filolosfia Natural e Experimental na Inglaterra da Segunda Metade do S√©culo XVII|Soares, L.C.|<i>Scientiarum Historia<i>, Publication of the Congressos Scientiarum Historia, Vol VII, 2014, 8 p.||<i>Science and Technology in the Industrial Revolution<i>|Musson, E.A., Robinson, E.|Manchester University Press, 1969, 539 pp, NB: pp 104-106.
BP_Title: A System of Familiar Philosophy: in Twleve Lectures; being the course usually read by Mr. A. Walker. Contain the elements of the practical uses to be drawn from the chemical properties of matter; the principles and application of mechanics; of hyudrostatics; of hydraulics; of pneumatics; of manetism; of electricity; of optics; and of astronomy. Including every material modern discovery and improvement to the present time. Illustrated by forty-nine copper-plates, neatly and accurately engraved. New Edition; in Two Volumes.
BP_Biographical Statement: English autodidact, became a successful traveling science lecturer in the north of England. Wrote successful popularization of science, hob-nobed with member of the Lunar Society.
BP_Provenance: Title page signature of Elizabeth Hoffmister, dated 1802. Book Plate of E. Grand D'Hauteville

BP_Short or Common Title: A Method of examining refractive and dispersive Powers, by prismatic Reflection.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Wollaston reports on a procedure he had been using for some years to measure refractive index.
BP_Description_1: Wollaston reports on a procedure he had been using for some years to measure refractive index, but had not seen described in the scientific literature. His ingenious device determined index of refraction by direct sighting and alignment with a protractor-type apparatus--giving the desired index directly. The measurement of refractive index had been of great practical importance for the previous half-century, being essential data required for achromatic lens design. A notable attempt at such measurements being Boscovich and his vitrometer. Wollaston's instrument was a significant improvement over all previous methods, methods which required measurement, calculation, and some uncertainty. It was the basis for similar instruments for a century. While using his instrument to investigate chromatic dispersion, Wollaston famously observed dark lines in the solar spectrum and detected what is now called ultraviolet radiation. Wollaston's was translated into French and appeared in the Annales de Chimie the following year. The paper was widely read and reviewed and even the usually-negative Edinburgh Review praised the instrument and hailed the discovery of ultraviolet rays.
BP_Description_2: Wollaston reports the development of a total internal reflection refractometer. Using Snell's law or refraction, and the nature of total internal reflection, the instrument could determine the index of refraction of any material brought into contact with a flint-glass prism. The incident angle measurement mechanism (that angle that just produced total internal reflection) was ingenious and permitted values to be determined to within a few parts in a thousand. The paper is in three parts: The description of its construction and use and a reporting of measurements of the indices of 80 substances; Use of the same instrument to investigate chromatic dispersion; An analysis of the dispersion of totally internally reflected sunlight. It is in the last section that Wollaston notes the appearance of dark lines in the solar spectrum; they are shown in the last figure that accompanies the article. In a footnote, Wollaston remarks (prompted by Herschel's infrared studies) the he detected active radiation beyond the violet end of the solar spectrum, capable of darkening silver chloride. He acknowledges a similar and simultaneous discovery by Johann Ritter in Germany. Remarkably, Wollaston concludes that sunlight consisted of 'six species of rays,' four visible and two invisible.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Pure Intelligence: The Life of William Hyde Wollaston<i>|Usselman, M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 412 pp, NB: pp 67-79.
BP_Title: "A Method of examining refractive and dispersive Powers, by prismatic Reflection." In: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London for the year 1802.
BP_Biographical Statement: English chemist and natural philosopher, did important practical work in optics and optical instruments.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1802 Wollaston - A Method of examining refractive and dispersive Powers, by prismatic Reflection. - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: On the oblique Refraction of Iceland Crystal.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Wollaston reports on the use of his total internal reflection refractometer to measure the refractive indices of Icelandic spar in different planes of the crystal.
BP_Description_1: Wollaston reports on the use of his total internal reflection refractometer to measure the refractive indices of Icelandic spar in different planes of the crystal. He realized that this could be a test of Christian Huygens' prediction of light's propagation through the crystal. The results were is good agreement, and Wollaston very gingerly stated: 'The observations that I have made on this substance, accord throughout with this hypothesis of HUYGENS; the measures that I have taken, correspond more nearly than could well happen to a false theory . . .' The paper was widely read and reviewed and, not surprisingly, with its usual abuse and sarcasm the Edinburgh Review stated it was 'disappointed to find, that so acute and ingenious an experimentalist had adopted the wild optical theory of vibrations.' Nevertheless, Wollaston's measurements and delicately-stated conclusion boosted the stock of the wave theory of light, and with this paper and the accompanying one on his refractometer, ushered in the new developments in optics that would take place in the 19th century.
BP_Description_2: Wollaston reports being able to cut Icelandic spar in various planes and using such pieces in this total internal reflection refractometer. Transforming the measured angles with spherical trigonometry, the measured indices aligned with Huygens' proposed elliptical wavefronts for the special refraction in the crystal.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Pure Intelligence: The Life of William Hyde Wollaston<i>|Usselman, M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 412 pp, NB: pp 67-79.
BP_Title: "On the oblique Refraction of Iceland Crystal." In: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London for the year 1802.
BP_Biographical Statement: English chemist and natural philosopher, did important practical work in optics and optical instruments.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1802 Wollaston - On the oblique Refraction of Iceland Crystal.  - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: The Bakerian Lecture  On the theory of light and colours.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The second Bakerian lecture presented by Thomas Young, proposing a wave theory of light, based on an oscillating luminiferous aether and the wave-front propagation principle described by Huygens more than century earlier.
BP_Description_1: Thomas Young was given the Bakerian Medal and Prize Lecture of the Royal Society of London three times: 1800, 1801, and 1803. This is the second lecture and with it Young presents a wave theory of light, based on an oscillating luminiferous aether and the wave-front propagation principle described by Huygens more than century earlier. The paper presents a theory, consisting of hypotheses and propositions. It systematically evaluates Isaac Newton's wave-theory objections and refutes them. The papers was read before the Royal Society in November of 1801 and appeared half a year later in the first part of the Transactions published in 1802. There was little if any reaction to the lecture and its printing, and no support for the theory. Predictably, the Edinburgh Review was scornful, writing that the treatment was 'paltry and unsubstantial,' and urged the Royal Society not to lower its standards by admission of Young's papers. Though Young would subsequently present evidence of the theory's correctness, the to-and-fro between the particle and wave theories of light would continue for another 20 years. A 'free translation' into German of both the second and third lectures appeared in the <i>Annalen der Physik<i> in 1811.
BP_Description_2: Thomas Young lays out a wave theory of light in four hypotheses, nine propositions, and five corollaries. The hypotheses are as follows. 1: An all-pervading aether; 2: Luminous object excite undulations in the aether; 3: Color sensation depends on the frequency of the vibrations; 4: Aether is absorbed in various densities in various bodies and a layer of aether surrounds bodies due to their attraction. The propositions are as follows. 1: All impulses propagate with the same velocity; 2: Single luminous points produce spherical undulations; 3: Undulations through an aperture propagate rectilinearly; 4: Undulations partially reflect at interfaces of media with different densities; 5: Undulations propagate across the interface of different media in directions given by Snell's law; 6: Undulations can suffer total internal reflection; 7: Undulation velocity is affected by particle vibrations within the medium; 8: Undulation motions combine; 9: Radiant light is undulations in the aether. The corollaries rely in an essential way on the hypothesis that the aether accumulates in and surrounds bodies; using the theory they explain the following: Colors of striated surfaces, colors of thin plates, colors of thick plates, blackness, inflected colors. In this sense, the lecture is as much about the distribution of the aether as it is about waves propagating through it. Using his theory, the data Newton provided for thin-plate colors, and a presumed velocity propagation, Young calculated and reported the wavelength and frequency associated with prismatic colors. They are remarkably accurate.
BP_Reference(s): Men and Milestones in Optics II: Thomas Young|Barr, E.S.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 2, No 6, 1963, pp 639-647.||Was Thomas Young a wave theorist?|Cantor, G.N.|<i>American Journal of Physics<i>, Vol 52, No 4, 1984, pp 305-308.

BP_Biographical Statement: English physican, polymath. A wide-ranging genius, wrote kowingly and innovatively is many areas of science, especially optics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Written for use in high schools and gymnasia, the text is an accompaniment to lectures. Explanation and demonstration with equipment form the core of the 29 lessons. The text divides physics into 'fisico-chemica' and 'fisico-mathematica,'  rather than treating chemistry separately.
BP_Description_1: Giambattista Moratelli states in his Preface that physics had advanced to so great an extent that the usual textbooks used in Italy were out of date. His new textbook consists of 29 Lessons, from the work of chemists and physicists at the Collegio Clementino and the University of Ferrara where he taught. Explanation and demonstration with equipment form the core of the lessons. Unusually, Moratelli divides physics into 'fisico-chemica' and 'fisico-mathematica,' rather than general and particular physics, and does not, as other textbooks by this time had, separated chemistry into a different text. The work was written for use in high schools and gymnasia and was widely used in Italy. It is rather more like an accompaniment to lectures, like those books of Walker or Martin, rather than a book for self study like those of Farrari or K√§stner.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in four volumes. Volume 1: Knowledge and the study of physics, general properties of bodies; Attraction, chemical affinities; Simple substances in general, Caloric; Simple substances. oxygen, nitrogen, hydrogen, carbon, light, electrolytes, sulfur, phosphorus, alkalis, and earths; Metallic substances; Gases in general, gas components of atmospheric air, oxygen, and nitrogen; Acidic and alkaline gases; Hydrogen gases. Volume 2: Atmospheric air, its physical properties; Air as Earth's atmosphere, instruments to measure pressure and humidity; Sound; Water; Electricity; Electricity continued; Electro-motors, or Galvanism, application of electricity to medicine; Atmospheric electricity; Natural and artificial magnetism. Volume 3: Simple, compound motion, obstacles to its continuation; Communication of motion, causes which change its direction; Gravity, accelerated and delayed motion, motion of inclined planes; Curvilinear motion, swing of the pendulum, projection of bodies, central forces; Statics, simple, and compound machines; Hydrostatics, pressure and fluid balance; Hydraulics. Volume 4: Optics, Catoptrics, and Dioptrics; Vision, optical instruments; Color, luminous meteorics; Astronomy; Astronomy continued. The optics material (126 pages) includes: nature of light (Cartesian and Newtonian theories), propagation, reflection and mirrors, refraction and lenses, vision and spectacles, magnifying glasses, camera obscura, telescopes, simple and compound microscopes, magic lantern, solar microscope, colors in light and in objects, the rainbow, color in meteorics. The material is elementary, descriptive, and demonstrative; no theory is introduced and no mathematics is used.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jacopo Panzani Venesiano
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An Italian translation of Ebermaier's work on the biological influences of light, particularly on the human body.
BP_Description_1: German physician Johan Christoph Ebermayer's book has its origins as the prize-winning entry <i>Commentatio de lucis in corpus humannm vivum praeter visum efficacia<i>, submitted to the G√∂ttingen Academy in 1797. The prize essay was reworked, with additions, to produce the <i>Geschichte des Lichtes und dessen Einfluss auf den menschlichen K√∂rper<i>. Ebermayer, son of a pharmacist and originally from D√ºsseldorff, was a botanist, pharmacologist and military surgeon. While on military duty in the Ruhr, he first investigated the nature of light according to the theories of ancient through major eighteenth-century authors, and then extensively studies the effects of light on various organic and inorganic bodies, with particular attention to the plant and animal world. From this came his hypotheses regarding the positive influence of light on the physiology of the human body.||The translator Panzani points out that he has kept the old chemical nomenclature, now outdated, in order not to alter the original text.
BP_Description_2: There are three parts: On the Nature of Light, Light's Effect on Nature, and Light's Effect, other than vision, on Man. Throughout the entire work, "Light" for Ebermaier was daylight, principally sunlight. The first part is a brief history of the opinions regarding light's nature. The second part reports light's effect on the atmosphere, on minerals, plants, and animals in general. The third part describes light's effect on humans. These include chemical, physiological, pathological, dietetic and therapeutic effects. Sunburn is considered and  Ebermaier reports different degrees of sunburn depending on the time of exposure, and that paler skin types reacted more severely than darker skin types. He also noted that sun exposure could induce an increase in skin thickness. Aside from sunburn, Ebermaier notes the general healthful, if not therapeutic, effect of daylight.
BP_Reference(s): History of Therapeutic UV Radiation|Raab, W.|In: Skin cancer and UV Radiation|Altmeyer, P. Hoffmann, K., St√ºcker, M., editors|Springer, 1997, 409 pp, NBL pp 1-19.||History of Human Photobiology|Roelandts, R.|In: Photodermatology|Lim, H.W., Honigsmann, H., John L. M. Hawk, J.L.M., editors|CRC Press, 2007, 496 pp, NB: pp 1-14.
BP_Title: Saggio storico della luce in riguardo alla sua influenza sulla complessiva natura e particolarmente sul corpo umano oltre alla visione di Giovanni Cristoforo Ebermaier. Traduzione dal tedesco di Jacopo Panzani Veneziano
BP_Title English Translation: Historical essay on light regarding its influence on the whole of nature and particularly on the human body in addition to vision, by Giovanni Cristoforo Ebermaier. Translated from the German by Jacopo Panzani Veneziano.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physician and pharmacist

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A supplement to Moratelli's four-volume textbook of 1803, including the then-new discovery of infrared and ultraviolet radiation and their heating and actinic effects.
BP_Description_1: A supplement to Moratelli's four-volume textbook on chemistry and physics of 1803. Giambattista Moratelli states in his Preface that physics had advanced to so great an extent that the usual textbooks used in Italy were out of date. His new textbook consists of 29 Lessons, from the work of chemists and physicists at the Collegio Clementino and the University of Ferrara where he taught. Explanation and demonstration with equipment form the core of the lessons. Unusually, Moratelli divides physics into 'fisico-chemica' and 'fisico-mathematica,' rather than general and particular physics, and does not, as other textbooks by this time had, separated chemistry into a different text. The work was written for use in high schools and gymnasia and was widely used in Italy. It is rather more like an accompaniment to lectures, like those books of Walker or Martin, rather than a book for self study like those of Farrari or K√§stner. This supplement contains material that describes new developments in chemistry and physics.
BP_Description_2: The new optics material is devoted to the then-new discovery of infrared and ultraviolet radiation and their heating and actinic effects. The second memoire includes: On light, Physical properties of light, Light action on organic bodies, Light action on inorganic bodies, Invisible sunrays and their chemical action, Light produced by bodies by heat, and friction, Whether chemical effects produced by light are to be attributed to caloric. The text deals mainly with the discoveries of the infrared by Herschel in 1800 and of the ultraviolet by Ritter in 1801.

Maffei'|Montavani, R., Negrini, F.|In: Proceedings of the XXX National Congress of the Italian Society of Historians of Physics and Astronomy (Urbino 30 June - 3 July 2010), Mantovani, R., editor, 2012.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by David Brewster (1781-1868) Scottish physicist, mathematician, astronomer, science historian. Famed for his optics work, defense of Isaac Newton, invention of the kaleidoscope.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: David Brewster's updating, and augmenting of the lectures James Ferguson first published in 1760.
BP_Description_1: Second edition of David Brewster's updating, and augmenting of the lectures James Ferguson first published in 1760. Editions of Brewster's update appeared in 1805, 1806, and 1823.
BP_Description_2: Brewster's Appendix occupies most of the second volume and contains a section on optics that was meant to supplement Ferguson's optical material. The emphasis is on practical aspects of optical instruments: achromatic objective lenses with specifications for their construction, achromatic eye-pieces, grinding and polishing lenses, grinding and polishing mirrors, simple and compound microscopes, various telescopes, a large camera obscura. In keeping with Ferguson's original, no theory or mathematics is presented.

BP_Short or Common Title: Institutiones Mathematic√¶ in usum tironum conscript√¶
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A posthumous edition of a 7-volume textbook on mathematics and natural philosophy. Designed for self study, there are many examples, discussions, problems and solutions.
BP_Description_1: Metzburg wrote a 7-volume textbook, <i>Institutiones Mathematicae<i>, on mathematics and natural philosophy that appeared in 1775, 1780, and 1782. He wrote it after the dissolution of the Jesuits, having moved to Vienna and joined the faculty of mathematics. The book was designed for self study and so, as explained in the note to the reader, there are many examples, discussions, problems and solutions. From this series, a new work was extracted, the <i>Institutiones Mathematicae ad Usum Tironum Conscriptae<i> which appeared posthumously in 1807 and 1810. The new work was titled 'fourth edition.' The editor adds his own preface and remarks that the scope and style have been maintained, the text made more concise, outdated things removed and new developments added.  Volumes 5, 6, and 7 were also issue separately. A German translation appeared in 1808.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1: Arithmetic and Algebra; Volume 2: Plane Geometry and curves; Volume 3: Trigonometry and practical geometry; Volume 4: Mechanics and Hydrostatics; Volume 5: Aeronometry and Hydraulics; Volume 6: Optics, Dioptric and Catoptric; Volume 7: Astronomy.
BP_Title: Cl. Georg. Ign. L. B. de Metzburg in Universitate Viennensi  AA. LL. et Philosophiae Doctoris Matheseos Professoris Caes. Regii Publici et Ordinarii. Institutiones Mathematicae in usum tironum conscriptae. Tomus VI. Editio Quinta.
BP_Title English Translation: By The famed Georg Ignaz von Metzburg, at the University of Vienna, AA. LL. and doctor of philosophy, Royal Professor of Mathematics, Public and in Ordinary. Institutes of Mathematics written for the use of beginners.
BP_Biographical Statement: Austrian one-time Jesuit, mathematician, cartographer. Professor at the University of Vienna.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Bibliothek zu Eybesfeld

BP_Short or Common Title: A Course of Lectures on Natural Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Young's collecting and editing of 60 of the 91 lectures he gave at  London's Royal Institution from 1801-1803. In was in these published notes that 'Young's Modulus' of elasticity is presented, as well as his famed experiment demonstrating the interference of light.
BP_Description_1: Thomas Young was Professor of Natural Philosophy and Chemistry at London's Royal Institution from 1801-1803, delivering 91 lectures in those two years. Young wrote out notes for these lectures in 21 exercise books, 20 of which exist in the library of University College London. Young wrote '... it was most eligible to commit to writing, as nearly as possible, the whole that was required to be said on each subject ...' Young's interest in natural history or machines was small and his lectures were the views of other more competent authors, or copied descriptions from other sources. But in natural philosophy, mechanics, and especially optics, he was well-informed, and included the latest research, continental as well as his own. In the three years after he left the Royal Institution, he worked on his lecture notes and compiled the huge bibliography that makes up the bulk of the second volume. Young must have worked directly from his notes when preparing them for publication; large sections appear verbatim in the published lectures. In was in these published notes that 'Young's Modulus' of elasticity is presented, as well as his famed experiment demonstrating the interference of light. In addition to the edition of 1807, an edited edition of the first volume appeared in 1845 which did not contain the references.
BP_Description_2: Volume 1 is in three parts: Mechanics, Hydrodynamics, and Physics. Mechanics is covered in Lectures 1-20, the last being a history of mechanics. Hydrodynamics is covered in Lectures 21-40. Physics is covered in Lectures 41-60.  Volume 2 contains elements of mathematics, the catalogue containing some 20,000 references, and a reprinting of papers that had appeared in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, mostly on Optics. The mathematics material is in three sections: pure, applied to the motion of solid bodies, applied to the motion of fluids. The optics material is in Lectures 35-40: Theory of optics, optical instruments, physical optics, vision, nature of light and colors, history of optics. The material is purely descriptive with no mathematics involved. The each figure in the plates is accompanied by a caption that often is a paragraph long and amounts to significant further explanation.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Thomas Young's Lectures at the Royal Institution|Cantor, G.N.|<i>Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London<i>, Vol 25, No 1, 1970, pp 87-112.
BP_Title: A Course of Lectures on Natural Philosophy and the Mechanical Arts. By Thomas Young, M.D. For Sec R.S.F.L.S. Member of Emmanuel College, Cambridge, and Late Professor of Natural Philosophy in the Royal Institution of Great Britain.  In Two Volumes.
BP_Biographical Statement: English physican, polymath. A wide-ranging genius, wrote kowingly and innovatively is many areas of science, especially optics.
