BP_Short or Common Title: Sur une propriete de la lumiere reflechie
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: √âtienne-Louis Malus announces his discovery that light could be polarized by reflection.
BP_Description_1: √âtienne-Louis Malus announced his discovery that light could be polarized by reflection in this issue of the Memoires de Physique et de Chimie de la Societe D'Arcueil. The Societe d'Arcueil was what would now be called an advanced research seminar in the physical sciences. It met every two weeks at Claude Louis Berthollet's summer home and laboratory in Arcueil, a southern suburb of Paris. Malus was a member and it was from this group that the project to establish a corpuscular theory of light that accounted for double refraction arose.  Malus began working on this question of double refraction produced by crystals in 1807 and and accidently found that light reflected off a plate of glass, had the same properties as the extraordinary refracted ray from crystals.  Specifically, he showed that reflected light behaved similarly to that which had passed through a piece of birefringent Icelandic spar. This revealed that light had acquired a property that it carried with it after passing through the crystal or being reflected. This property Malus called 'polarization.' The discovery had a profound effect upon optical thought, experiment, and research efforts, and appeared to bolster the case for the wave theory of light. His work ushered in a significant change in the development of physical optics that would culminate in Augustine Fresnel's work a decade later. Translations of Malus's article appeared in German at Leipzig in 1809 and in English at London in 1812.
BP_Description_2: Malus begins with a recounting of his previous work with birefringent Icelandic spar. It has long been know that such crystals separated incident light into two different refracted beams. Malus found that these two beams were treated differently by a second crystal. He deduced that the first crystal was changing the characteristic of light; the two beams contained light that had some property that was different and that light carried this property with it after it left the first crystal. He then showed that this property could be produced in light upon reflection from glass or water. Malus held to the particle theory of light and believe that light particles had sides or poles and that the phenomenon he observed involved the orientation of these poles, attracted or repulsed by short-range forces within the crystal. In his next article he named the property created by Icelandic spar and by reflection 'polarization,' and that became the generally adopted term.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 41-66.||Etienne-Louis Malus: The Polarization of Light by Refraction and Reflection is Discovered|Pelosi, G.|<i>IEEE Antennas and Propagation Magazine<i>, Vol 51, No 4, 2009, pp 226-228.||'The Search for a Corpuscular Theory of Double Refraction: Malus, Laplace and the Price Competition of 1808'|Frankel, E.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 18, No 3, 1974, pp 223-245.||Etienne-louis Malus 1775-1812 Et La Theorie Corpusculaire De La Lumiere|Chappert, A.|Librairie Philosophique J. Vrin, Paris, 1977, 286 pp, NB: pp 58-62.
BP_Title: Sur une propriete de la lumiere reflechie' In: Memoires de Physique et de Chimie, de la Societe D'Arcueil, Tome Second, 1809, pp 143-158. BP_Description_1: The University of Coimbra was founded as a <i>Studium Generale<i> in Lisbon in 1290 but by 1537 was permanently located at Coimbra. In 1772, the Marquis of Pombal, prime minister of King Jos√© I, undertook a major reform of the university, where the study of the sciences assumed vast importance. The text was printed by the university and so its commissioning was undoubtedly part of that very large project. Interestingly, the edition that was reprinted was not the revised text of 1802 prepared for use at France's l‚ÄôEcole Polytechnique, but that of 1866; the posthumous forth edition of De La Caille's <i>Le√ßons El√©mentaires D'Optique<i>. The corrections and additions are from notes found in the author's copy.
BP_Description_2: The text is essentially that of the edition of 1756. Some changes were made to the material on dioptrics and spectacles.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Ludwig William Gilbert
BP_Short or Common Title: Erscheinungen welche von der Gestalt der Lichtheilchen adhangen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A German translation of the article by √âtienne-Louis Malus announcing the polarization of light by reflection
BP_Description_1: A German translation of the article by √âtienne-Louis Malus announcing the polarization of light by reflection. The translation was by the journal's general editor, Ludwid Wilhelm Gilber, and is rather free but conveys all the essentials. This translation appeared less than two years after Malus' original article and demonstrates the importance and speed with which Malus' discovery spread throughout Europe.
BP_Description_2: Malus begins with a recounting of his previous work with birefringent Icelandic spar. It has long been know that such crystals separated incident light into two different refracted beams. Malus found that these two beams were treated differently by a second crystal. He deduced that the first crystal was changing the characteristic of light; the two beams contained light that had some property that was different and that light carried this property with it after it left the first crystal. He then showed that this property could be produced in light upon reflection from glass or water. Malus held to the particle theory of light and believe that light particles had sides or poles and that the phenomenon he observed involved the orientation of these poles. In his next article he named the property created by Icelandic spar and by reflection 'polarization,' and that became the generally adopted term.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 41-66.||Etienne-Louis Malus: The Polarization of Light by Refraction and Reflection is Discovered|Pelosi, G.|<i>IEEE Antennas and Propagation Magazine<i>, Vol 51, No 4, 2009, pp 226-228.||Etienne-louis Malus 1775-1812 Et La Theorie Corpusculaire De La Lumiere|Chappert, A.|Librairie Philosophique J. Vrin, Paris, 1977, 286 pp, NB: pp 58-62.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Karl Brandan Mollweide
BP_Short or Common Title: Neue methode die brechenden und zerstreuenden kr√§fte  der korper vermittelst primatischer reflexion zu esforschen
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: German recension of Wollaston's report on a procedure he had been using for some years to measure refractive index.
BP_Description_1: Wollaston reports on a procedure he had been using for some years to measure refractive index, but had not seen described in the scientific literature. His ingenious device determined index of refraction by direct sighting and alignment with a protractor-type apparatus--giving the desired index directly. The measurement of refractive index had been of great practical importance for the previous half-century, being essential data required for achromatic lens design. A notable attempt at such measurements being Boscovich and his vitrometer. Wollaston's instrument was a significant improvement over all previous methods, methods which required measurement, calculation, and some uncertainty. It was the basis for similar instruments for a century. While using his instrument to investigate chromatic dispersion, Wollaston famously observed dark lines in the solar spectrum and detected what is now called ultraviolet radiation. Wollaston's paper appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Society in 1802, was translated into French and appeared in the Annales de Chimie in 1803, and in German in the Annalen der Physik in 1809. The paper was widely read and reviewed and even the usually-negative Edinburgh Review praised the instrument and hailed the discovery of ultraviolet rays.
BP_Description_2: Wollaston reports the development of a total internal reflection refractometer. Using Snell's law or refraction, and the nature of total internal reflection, the instrument could determine the index of refraction of any material brought into contact with a flint-glass prism. The incident angle measurement mechanism (that angle that just produced total internal reflection) was ingenious and permitted values to be determined to within a few parts in a thousand. The paper is in three parts: The description of its construction and use and a reporting of measurements of the indices of 80 substances; Use of the same instrument to investigate chromatic dispersion; An analysis of the dispersion of totally internally reflected sunlight. It is in the last section that Wollaston notes the appearance of dark lines in the solar spectrum; they are shown in the last figure that accompanies the article. In a footnote, Wollaston remarks (prompted by Herschel's infrared studies) the he detected active radiation beyond the violet end of the solar spectrum, capable of darkening silver chloride. He acknowledges a similar and simultaneous discovery by Johann Ritter in Germany. Remarkably, Wollaston concludes that sunlight consisted of 'six species of rays,' four visible and two invisible.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Pure Intelligence: The Life of William Hyde Wollaston<i>|Usselman, M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 412 pp, NB: pp 67-79.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Karl Brandan Mollweide
BP_Short or Common Title: Ueber die schiefe brechung des islandischen krystalls
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: German translation of Wollaston's report on the use of his total internal reflection refractometer to measure the refractive indices of Icelandic spar in different planes of the crystal.
BP_Description_1: Wollaston reports on the use of his total internal reflection refractometer to measure the refractive indices of Icelandic spar in different planes of the crystal. He realized that this could be a test of Christian Huygens' prediction of light's propagation through the crystal. The results were is good agreement, and Wollaston very gingerly stated: 'The observations that I have made on this substance, accord throughout with this hypothesis of HUYGENS; the measures that I have taken, correspond more nearly than could well happen to a false theory . . .'  Wollaston's paper appeared in the Transactions of the Royal Society in 1802, was translated into French and appeared in the Annales de Chimie in 1803, and in German in the Annalen der Physik in 1809. The paper was widely read and reviewed and, not surprisingly, with its usual abuse and sarcasm the Edinburgh Review stated it was 'disappointed to find, that so acute and ingenious an experimentalist had adopted the wild optical theory of vibrations.' Nevertheless, Wollaston's measurements and delicately-stated conclusion boosted the stock of the wave theory of light, and with this paper and the accompanying one on his refractometer, ushered in the new developments in optics that would take place in the 19th century.
BP_Description_2: Wollaston reports being able to cut Icelandic spar in various planes and using such pieces in this total internal reflection refractometer. Transforming the measured angles with spherical trigonometry, the measured indices aligned with Huygens' proposed elliptical wavefronts for the special refraction in the crystal. The Annalen editor, Ludwig Wilhelm Gilbert provided a long commentary and analysis that followed the translation of Wollaston's paper.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>Pure Intelligence: The Life of William Hyde Wollaston<i>|Usselman, M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 412 pp, NB: pp 67-79.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A combination educational treatise on spectacles and trade catalogue.
BP_Description_1: Paris optician Jean Gabriel Augustin Chevallier produced this combination educational treatise on spectacles and trade catalogue. Designed for customers and the public, it presented the essentials of vision, eye-sight, and the function and use of spectacles. Editions appeared in 1810, 1812, 1815, 1820, and 1845. This copy includes, on the verso of the half-title, the manuscript signature of the author to help prevent counterfeit editions. This was only done for the first edition and not all copies have it present.
BP_Description_2:
The 'custodian of vision' of the title is the optician and the spectacles he can provided. Chevallier small treatise begins with an elementary description of the anatomy of the eye and its optical function. normal vision, common visual deficiencies, and diseases of the eye are then described. Then a long section on optical aids of various types and how to chose them, including all types of lenses, spectacles, lunettes, magnifiers, glasses, and Franklin's bifocal spectacles. The microscope, telescope, binoculars, and other magnifiers are also described. The booklet ends with a 47-page  priced catalogue of the many optical, mathematical, and physical instruments manufactured
by the Chevalier firm.
BP_Reference(s): Chevallier'|Blancheton, E.|<i>Revue G√©n√©rale, Biographique, Politique et Litteraire<i>, Vol 5, 1843, pp 207-291.||The Moon for a twopence: street telescopes in nineteenth-century Paris and the epistemology of popular  stargazing|Aibin, D.|<i>Early Popular Visual Culture<i>, Vol 15, No 2, pp 125-151.||http://www.microscopist.net/ChevallierJGA.html

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Goethe presents his theory of colors and the experiments that supported it. His interpretation of color experiments and the role of experiment itself, convinced Goethe that Newton's theory of light and color, with is foundation of prismatic color experiments, was wrong. White light was not heterogeneous; color was produced by the blending of light and dark.
BP_Description_1: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe wrote <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i> nearly 20 years after his first publication on color, the <i>Beytrage zur Optik<i> of 1791. During the interval he had conducted extensive visual experiments involving color perception and developed his ideas regarding the role of experiment, set out in his essay of 1792: ‚ÄúDer Versuch als Vermittler von Objekt und Subjekt‚Äù--experiment as mediator between subject and object. For Goethe, experiment was not, as Newtonian science had it, the indifferent revealer of nature but an intermediary between nature and the investigator. His interpretation of color experiments and the role of experiment itself, convinced Goethe that Newton's theory of light and color, with is foundation of prismatic color experiments, was wrong. White light was not heterogeneous; color was produced by the blending of light and dark. Goethe's conviction of the correctness of his color theory and his antipathy to Newtonian science--its optics in particular--produced <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i>. The book was important not for the physical optics it proposed--which was rejected immediately and by nearly everyone--but for the aspects of color perception it clarified, and the ingenious color perception experiments is described. <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i> made clear that there was much more to color perception than what a prism detected: differing refraction. It was the initial step in the century-long process of separating color perception from mere physical or optical stimulus. This copy of the Atlas volume contains the plates of both the first and second editions of <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i>.
BP_Description_2: Goethe's text is divided into three parts: Didactic part, A Polemic Unveiling of Newton's Theory, and A History of Color Theory. The material in the didactic part contains much of what was in the <i>Beytrage zur Optik<i> of 1791 and is in six chapters: Physiological Colors; Physical Colors; Chemical Colors; General Characteristics; Relation to Other Pursuits; Color Effects and Associations. The material in the Polemical part is in two chapters: Newton's <i>Opticks<i> Book I, Part I; Newton's <i>Opticks<i>, Book I, Part II. The material in the history part is in seven chapters: The Greeks, Romans, Medieval, 16th century, 17th century, 18th century from Newton to Dollond, 18th century from Dollond to the present. The principal method of investigation was vision through a prism, though other simple optical apparatus is also used: simple lenses, glass plates, colored papers. In all cases, the experiments are described in elegant and clear detail. Goethe interprets the lack of color of uniform light or dark fields viewed through a prism, and color's appearance only at light/dark boundaries, as perceptual evidence that color results from the mixing of light and dark. The polemical section is strikingly strident and makes clear how deeply Goethe opposed the rise of experimental empiricism. The history of color theory is remarkable for its emphasis on social and biographical context, its refusal to engage in what is now called 'Whig History,' the attention to transition times, and its appreciation of the linguistic aspects in which color theories were expressed.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇùëª <i>Theory of Colours<i>|Goethe, J.W. von, Eastlake, C.L., translator, Judd, D.B., Introduction|MIT Press, Cambridge, 1970. (NB: Eastlake did not translate Goethe's polemic section or his history of color theory)||Newton and Goethe on Colour: Physical and Physiological Considerations|Duck, M.J.|<i>Annals of Science<i>, Vol 45, No 5, pp 507-519.||Exploratory Experimentation: Goethe, Land, and Color Theory|Ribe, N.|<i>Physics Today<i>, Vol 55, No 7, 2002, pp 43-50.||http://theoryofcolor.org/Vorwort NB: full German text and English translation)

BP_Author full name: Abb√© Nicolas Louis de La Caille
BP_Author last name first: La Caille, Abb√© Nicolas Louis de
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: New edition of the complete revision of 1802 of De La Caille's text of 1766.
BP_Description_1: A second edition of the complete revision of 1802 of De La Caille's text of 1766. A new cadre of students from l'Ecole Polytechnique produced this addition, adding three sections and correcting errors.
BP_Description_2: The new material contained in this second edition includes that material that was new in the first edition: the theory of spherical and chromatic aberration, refraction and dispersion measurement of glass, size and position of images from mirrors and lenses, updated material on telescopes and microscopes, achromatic objective lenses, and the rainbow. The text maintains its focus on utility and optical instruments, and its lack of material on theory and physical optics. New sections were added on the exponential absorption of light in media, a derivation of the sine law of refraction based on Newtonian concepts of light particles and  of attraction by media molecules, and a solution to 'Alhazen's Problem' in catoptrics.
BP_Reference(s): Fresnel and the Emergence of Physics as a Discipline|Silliman, R.H.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 4, 1974, pp. 137-162, NB: pp 145.

BP_Short or Common Title: Th√©orie de la double r√©fraction de la lumi√®re dans les substances cristallis√©es.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Printing of the prize-winning memoire of Malus giving a light corpuscular theory for double refraction.
BP_Description_1: Malus' monograph on double refraction has its roots in his discovery of polarization by reflection in 1808. This, in turn, was part of his work for the prize competition established by the Institut de France early in 1808. The prize required that the winner 'give a mathematical theory verified by experiments of the double refraction which light undergoes in crossing different crystallized substances.'  This was an attempt to promote work that would bolster the corpuscular theory of light, popular in France and pursued by Laplace, Arago, Poisson, Biot and Gay-Lussac. Malus' early work not only discovered polarization by reflection but verified Huygens' Law regarding refraction and further supported the wave theory of light. Thus the Institute's prize competition.||Malus constructed a theory that involved forces acting on light corpuscles as very short distances and, when coupled with what was still an arbitrary assumption involving the elliptical range and power of these forces, produced the result equivalent to Huygens Law. This gave a reasonable, but still somewhat arbitrary basis for a corpuscular theory of double refraction. Malus won the prize for the 1808 competition, and as was the custom, the prize was awarded two years later and his memoire was published by the Institute.
BP_Description_2: Malus theory begins with the notion, generally accepted in France at the time, that optical phenomena need to be explained by the motions of particles subjected to central forces. The goal was a theory, admitting to these constraints, that produced the equivalent of Huygens Law. Malus begins with the principle of least action applied to a corpuscle of light entering a crystal and establishes an algebraic expression for its motion along the crystal's principal axis.  Malus then begs the question, as it were, and establishes the algebraic equivalent of Huygens' ellipse; an ellipsoid from which the path of the extraordinary ray could be determined on the basis of central forces. The result was obtained by Malus with a blizzard of algebra, and importantly, indicated that the force that produced the extraordinary ray was repulsive, while that producing the ordinary ray was attractive. Laplace developed a similar corpuscular theory for double refraction--equivalent to that of Malus. Both were accepted as explaining double refraction, without having to abandon light corpuscles and invoke waves. All this would soon be swept aside by Fresnel's work in the following decade.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Search for a Corpuscular Theory of Double Refraction: Malus, Laplace and the Price Competition of 1808|Frankel, E.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 18, No 3, 1974, pp 223-245.||√âtienne Louis Malus (1775-1812) et la Th√©orie Corpusculaire De La Lumi√®re|Chappert, A.|Librairie Philosophique J. Vrin, Paris, 1977, 286 pp.||Corpuscular Optics and the Wave Theory of Light: The Science and Politics of a Revolution in Physics|Frankel, E.|<i>Social Studies of Science<i>, Vol 6, No 2, 1976, pp 141-184.||Etienne-louis Malus 1775-1812 Et La Theorie Corpusculaire De La Lumiere|Chappert, A.|Librairie Philosophique J. Vrin, Paris, 1977, 286 pp, NB: pp 157-193.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An undergraduate text in optics for students with no mathematics
BP_Description_1: Stack's textbook is clearly written for undergraduates with little or no mathematics, but who require an introduction to optics and optical instruments. Stack's interest in astronomy is clear from the emphasis placed on telescopes and their operation. Explanations are very brief and text seems suited as accompaniment to lectures, certainly not for self study.||Editions appeared at Dublin in 1787, 1793 and much enlarged in 1811 and posthumously in 1820.
BP_Description_2: Stack's text is in 10 sections. 1: Nature and Laws of Reflection and Refraction. 2: Foci of Reflected and Refracted Rays. 3: Colors. 4: Images Formed by Reflection and Refraction. 5: Eye and Vision. 6: Perception of Objects. 7: Telescopes. 8: Telescopic Errors. 9: Telescopic Improvements. 10: Microscopes and Other Instruments. Appendix: The Rainbow.  The text is devoted almost exclusively to geometrical optics. Physical optics is treated on briefly and descriptively in the Introduction. Reflection and Refraction as described from spherical mirrors and lenses. Chromatic and spherical aberration in lenses is briefly described. Several types of telescopes are described  and their operation indicated pictorially. The treatment throughout is descriptive, and elementary geometry is the only mathematics invoked.
BP_Reference(s): Dictionary of Irish Biography: From the Earliest Times to the Year 2010|McGuire, J., Quinn, J., editors|Royal Irish Academy, Cambridge University Press, 2019.
BP_Title: A short system of optics, principally designed for the use of undergraduates in the University of Dublin. By the Rev. John Stack, D.D. Rector of Kilskerry, County Tyrone, Late Fellow of Trinity College Dublin. Second Edition, Altered and Enlarged.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish academic, Fellow of Trinity College, Dublin and secretary of the Royal Irish Academy.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Thomas Burgh Turner. Pencil marginalia, annotations, and underlining throughout.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Half Calf Over Speckled Boards

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: From a series of textbooks for university courses in mathematics and natural philosophy, this is a reprinting of the text on optics in that series and one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics. Second edition.
BP_Description_1: Third edition of the first of 1799 with very slight changes to wording. This is a resetting of the text of the edition of 1801. The coverage, content, and detail of the material is the same as the first edition. James Wood produced a series of textbooks for university courses in mathematics and natural philosophy between 1791-1799, <i>The Principles of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy<i>; six parts in four volumes. This is the text on optics in that series and one of the few English texts in the 18th century devoted solely to optics, the list of such texts is short: Smith in 1738, Benjamin Martin in 1740 and 1758, William Emerson in 1768, Harris posthumously in 1775, Higgins in 1776, and the first edition of Woods in 1799. Editions of Wood's text appeared in 1799, 1801, 1811, 1818, and 1828.||This copy was bound interleaved with blanks, enabling note-taking and working through examples.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in 13 chapters: The Nature of Light and its Propagation, Laws of Reflection, Laws of Refraction, Reflection at plane and spherical Surfaces, Images formed by Reflection, Refraction at plane and Spherical Surfaces, Images formed by Refraction, The Eye and eye-function, Optical Instruments, Chromatic Aberrations, Spherical Aberrations, The Rainbow, Caustics. Considering when it was written, the form is rather old-fashioned: a concise march of Definitions, Propositions, Corollaries, and Discussions in Scholia. The material is elementary, detailed, and based on physical principles expressed in geometry, trigonometry and ratios; with very few equations. The physical and geometric optics material relies heavily on Newton, the Opticks and Optical Lectures being cited frequently.||Importantly, Wood does not make extensive use of analysis; something which by this time the French had developed to high level in optics. Wood's work was at the cusp of the transition that brought continental analysis to Cambridge in particular and British university education in general.
BP_Reference(s): William Whewell and Cambridge Mathematics|Becher, H.W.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 11, No 1, 1980, pp. 1-48.
BP_Title: The Elements of Optics designed for the use of students in the University. By James Wood, B.D. Fellow of St. John's Collect, Cambridge. Third Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, clearic, academic. Senior Wrangler then Professor at St John's College, Cambridge for 60 years.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed 'H.J. Hastings, Trinity College', on free endpaper. Many interleaved blank pages with inked drawings, notes, and comments in the same hand.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Copy bound with blank interleaves

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by A. F. L√ºdicke
BP_Short or Common Title: Ueber die Theorie des Lichts and Versuche und Berechnungen zur physicalischen Optik
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: German translation of The second and third Bakerian lectures presented by Thomas Young. The second lecture proposed a wave theory of light, based on an oscillating luminiferous aether and the wave-front propagation principle described by Huygens more than century earlier. The third lectures described his experimental demonstration of light interference.
BP_Description_1: Though the Bakerian Lectures of Thomas Young were either ignored or opposed in Great Britain, Ludwig Wilheml Gilbert, editor of the <i>Annalen der Physik<i>, recognized their merit. The second of Young's lectures proposed the wave nature of light, the third lecture records his famous experiment demonstrating the interference of light in support of the wave theory. The second lecture appeared in the Philosophical Transactions in 1802 and the third lecture appeared in 1804. Gilbert and had them translated in German by A. F. L√ºdicke, someone who did much translating for the Annalen, and the appeared in the Annalen in 1811.
BP_Description_2: Thomas Young lays out a wave theory of light in four hypotheses, nine propositions, and five corollaries. The hypotheses are as follows. 1: An all-pervading aether; 2: Luminous object excite undulations in the aether; 3: Color sensation depends on the frequency of the vibrations; 4: Aether is absorbed in various densities in various bodies and a layer of aether surrounds bodies due to their attraction. The propositions are as follows. 1: All impulses propagate with the same velocity; 2: Single luminous points produce spherical undulations; 3: Undulations through an aperture propagate rectilinearly; 4: Undulations partially reflect at interfaces of media with different densities; 5: Undulations propagate across the interface of different media in directions given by Snell's law; 6: Undulations can suffer total internal reflection; 7: Undulation velocity is affected by particle vibrations within the medium; 8: Undulation motions combine; 9: Radiant light is undulations in the aether. The corollaries rely in an essential way on the hypothesis that the aether accumulates in and surrounds bodies; using the theory they explain the following: Colors of striated surfaces, colors of thin plates, colors of thick plates, blackness, inflected colors. In this sense, the lecture is as much about the distribution of the aether as it is about waves propagating through it. Using his theory, the data Newton provided for thin-plate colors, and a presumed velocity propagation, Young calculated and reported the wavelength and frequency associated with prismatic colors. They are remarkably accurate.
BP_Reference(s): Men and Milestones in Optics II: Thomas Young|Barr, E.S.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 2, No 6, 1963, pp 639-647.||Was Thomas Young a wave theorist?|Cantor, G.N.|<i>American Journal of Physics<i>, Vol 52, No 4, 1984, pp 305-308.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A somewhat retrograde textbook covering General Physics, Particular Physics, and the Physics of Astronomy, Geography, and Meteorology.
BP_Description_1: Remigio D√∂ttler wrote this textbook for use at the University of Vienna. At the time, the university had come under state control and was considered a 'Hohe Schule' that was charged with training officials, advocates, doctors, and clerics. Latin had become the prescribed language, rather than the vernacular of the previous half-century.  D√∂ttler's textbook reflects these constraints and the general step backward the university was forced to take.  D√∂ttler's textbook stands in considerable contrast to those of Karl Scherffer and P√°l Mak√≥ which had been used at the university. The material is blend of Newton and Boscovich, with some Euler and Kant. Editions appeared in 1812, 1815, and 1823.
BP_Description_2: D√∂ttler's textbook has three sections: General Physics, Particular Physics, and the Physics of Astronomy, Geography, and Meteorology. General Physics covers: Universal properties of bodies, simple and compound motion, direct and oblique collisions, gravity, projectile and pendulum motion, geostatics, hydrostatics, hydraulics, fluid motion. Particular Physics covers: Mechanical properties of the air and atmosphere, air motion, physics of light, the mathematics of light including optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics, optical instruments, heat and caloric phenomena, chemical analysis and synthesis, various types of air, electricity, galvanic piles, magnetics. Astronomy covers:  The system of the world, the Earth, meteorics. The optics material (62 pages) includes the following. Physical optics: The Newtonian and Eulerian theory of light and propagation, opaque and transparent materials, reflection and refraction, prismatic colors, colors and pigments, object colors, diffraction. Geometrical optics: direct light and shadows, apparent size, lenses and their foci, calculating lenses, plane and spherical mirrors, the eye and eye-function, camera obscura, telescopes, microscopes. The style is descriptive, the material is elementary, very concise, and analytic only in the treatment of lenses and mirrors.
BP_Reference(s): German Physics Textbooks in the Goethezeit, Parts 1 & 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>,Vol 35, No 2, 1997, pp 219-239, Vol 35, No 3, pp 295-363, NB: pp 308-310.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Jean-Baptiste Labey (1750-1825) French mathematician, professor at l'√âcole militaire de Paris.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An edited collection of the 234 letters Euler wrote at the request of Frederick II of Prussia as a form of tutoring Frederick's niece, princess Sophie. The cover nearly all of natural philosophy, philosophy, logic, and important physical questions of Euler's time.
BP_Description_1: At the invitation of Frederick II of Prussia, Euler joined the Berlin Academy In 1741 and stayed until 1766. Frederick asked Euler to be a scientific tutor to his niece, Princess Sophie, who lived in Magdeburg. Euler obliged, writing between April 1760 and May 1762, 234 letters in French to the Princess. Beginning in 1762, there was tension between Frederick and Euler, and likely explains whey the letters were not published until Euler was in Saint Petersburg beginning in June 1766. The Lettres were published in Russia in French, their language of composition and the second language of most of Europe. Their popular style, scope, and clarity of presentation allowed them to reach a large readership. The first two volumes of the Lettres appeared in 1768 and the last in 1772. While in Russia, Euler prepared the first German translation, while between 1768 and 1774 Euler‚Äôs student Stepan Rumovskij translated the Letters from French into Russian, the first of five Russian editions leading up to 1808. By 1800 they had gone through thirty editions and were translated into seven other languages: Danish, Dutch, English, German, Italian, Spanish, and Swedish.|| The Lettres present Euler's mature positions on matters of natural philosophy, benefitting from earlier research and speculations. He begins simply but moves quickly to more difficult topics. Euler assumed his reader had little knowledge of natural philosophy or mathematics and so the Letters contain no mathematics. Important are Euler's examples; the text showing his insight, how he worked through problems, and the clarity of his explanations.
BP_Description_2: The initial three topics of the Lettres‚Äîextension, velocity, and sound‚Äîwere among the 79 dealing with general physical science and comprise the first of three natural divisions of the Lettees. The first division contains Letter 1-79.  Letters 4 to 17 proceeded to music, the air, and the atmosphere. Lettres 17 to 45 explained light, first considering the systems of Descartes and Newton on the subject. Euler rejected both and proceeded to his pulse theory, then to optics generally, the theory of colors, dioptrics, reflection, vision, and the structure of the eye. His opposition to Newton‚Äôs corpuscular optics did not mean that Euler was anti-Newtonian, rather he found fault with Newton's optics on questions of reflection and refraction.  Euler treated light as analogous to sound, as a vibration in the aether. Since the time of Galileo Galilei Light's speed had not been thought to be instantaneous. Euler calculated a value of light speed very close to the modern accepted value. The aether appears in Lettre 19 and Euler used it to explain most physical phenomena, including mechanical, optical, magnetic, and electrical. Lettres 45 to 79 addressed gravity and its effects, along with mechanics, cosmology, the tides, and the theory of matter.||The second division contains Lettres 80-133 and presents inquires into philosophy, religion, and logic. The third division contains Lettres 134 to 234 and is devoted entirely to physical questions. Electricity in 138-154, navigation and the longitude problem 155-169, and magnetism in 169-187.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Leonhard Euler: Mathematical Genius in the Enlightenment<i>|Calinger, R.S.|Princeton University Press, 2016, 696 pp, NB: pp 461-469.||Leonhard Euler's Wave Theory of Light|Pdeersen, K.M.|<i>Perspectives on Science<i>, Vol 16, No 4, 2008, pp 392-416.

BP_Short or Common Title: On a Property of reflected Light
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An English translation of the article by √âtienne-Louis Malus announcing the polarization of light by reflection.
BP_Description_1: An English translation of the article by √âtienne-Louis Malus announcing the polarization of light by reflection. As with many continental papers on science, Malus's articles in the Memoires de Physique et de Chimie de la Societe D'Arcueil were translated and gathered into Nicholson's journal. The translator is not identified.
BP_Description_2: Malus begins with a recounting of his previous work with birefringent Icelandic spar. It has long been know that such crystals separated incident light into two different refracted beams. Malus found that these two beams were treated differently by a second crystal. He deduced that the first crystal was changing the characteristic of light; the two beams contained light that had some property that was different and that light carried this property with it after it left the first crystal. He then showed that this property could be produced in light upon reflection from glass or water. Malus held to the particle theory of light and believe that light particles had sides or poles and that the phenomenon he observed involved the orientation of these poles. In his next article he named the property created by Icelandic spar and by reflection 'polarization,' and that became the generally adopted term.

Vrin, Paris, 1977, 286 pp.

BP_Short or Common Title: MeÃÅmoire sur les couleurs de l'iris
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A memoire attempting to bridge the gap that Bourgeois and other artists saw between their experience with color as painters and dyers, and the Newtonian theory of light and color based on prismatic colors.
BP_Description_1: Charles Guillaume Alexandre Bourgeois always presented himself as 'painter and physicist' and in this memoire attempts to bridge the gap he and other artists saw between their experience with color as painters and dyers, and the Newtonian theory of light and color based on prismatic colors. Bourgeois held that object colors and colors produced by pigment mixing and dying were incompatible with Newton's prismatic colors and the idea of heterogeneous white light. Bourgeois produced a series of experiments described in this and subsequent memoirs, interpreting the results as refuting the core of Newton's theory of light and color. This and several subsequent memoirs were submitted to the Royal Academy of Sciences for review by Fran√ßois Arago, Jean-Baptiste Biot, Ren√©-Just Ha√ºy, Andr√© Amp√®re, and Augustin Fresnel. After a first reading, Arago suggested that Bourgeois provide an analysis of the color theories of Brougham, Newton, de Gauthier, and Marat. Bourgeois complied and this is the reason for the second part of the printed version. Though Biot and Amp√®re were commissioned to review and report on Bourgeois' memoires, nothing was produced. The Academy ignored the memoires and when pushed by Bourgeois, Amp√®re wrote to him: ‚Äò‚ÄòWhat you have imagined is just a piece of nonsense.‚Äô‚Äô
BP_Description_2: Bourgeois describes a series of experiments involving sunlight, mirrors, prisms, lenses, and colored fluid filters. From the results he construes two types of reflection, refraction, and diffraction: simple and complex. In each case the 'simple' type results in colorless light, the 'complex' one generates color. Simple or complex is determined by the geometry of the surfaces involved; whether planar or curved. From these experiments and his own work with pigments, he proposes a primary color system of yellow, blue, and red. He further proposes that all colors contain some component of white and that when properly mixed and in equilibrium, these colors 'decompose each other' and leave only white. In this way he attempts to explain his own and Newton's experimental results. The experimental are presented only descriptively, no measurement are made, no quantitative data  generated, and no mathematics of any kind is used. All of these aspects of the memoire generated a negative reaction from virtually everyone in the academic and scientific community.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Charles Bourgeois (1759-1832), his Antinewtonian Colour Theory and the Reconcilement of Art and Science|Mertens, J.|<i>Nuncius <i>, Vol 22, No 1, 2007, pp 15 ‚Äì 48.

Biot et Arago, nommes Commissaires-Rapporteurs). Et examen des bases des doctrines de M. Henry Brougham, de Newton, de Gauthier et de M. Marat, sur la lumieÃÄre et les couleurs. Par Ch. Bourgeios, Peintre.

(Messers Biot and Arago appointed commisionaires-reporters. And an examination of the basis of the the doctrines of Mr. Henry Brougham, of Newton, of Gauthier, and Mr. Marat, on light and colors. BP_Short or Common Title: A Treatise on New Philosophical Instruments
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary of optical instruments and experiments principally involving refraction and dispersion.
BP_Description_1: By the time Brewster produced this treatise on instruments, he had twice revised James Fergeson's <i>Lectures on Select Subjects<i>, appearing in 1805 and 1806, and had produced the 125-page long entry 'Optics' for the <i>Encyclopaedia Britanica<i>, appearing in volume XV in 1810. He had already worked extensively on the optical properties of materials, the lenses of microscopes and telescopes, and the phenomenon of polarized light. Brewser's first paper in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society appeared in 1813. Much of this material was summarized, and the instrumental parts of it detailed, in this  treatise on instruments. It was Brewster's first book; he was 32 years old.||The material dealing with instruments recounts Brewster's work to improve performance and practicality including, achromatic lenses, micrometers, telescopes, and microscopes. It contains an introduction to those topics that would occupy Brewster for the next 55 years and be the topic of many of the nearly 1000 published works he produced.
BP_Description_2: Brewster's treatise is in five books. Book 1: On micrometers, Book 2: On Instruments for the measuring angles when the eye is not at their vertex, Book 3: On Instruments for measuring distances, Book 4: On optical instruments for different purposes, in which the rays are transmitted through fluids, and Book 4: On new telescopes and microscopes.  Book two on angle measurement is driven, in part, by Brewster's understanding the need for accurate angular chromatic dispersion data for materials, if the optical properties of lenses was to be improved. Book four is the longest and summaries many of the experiments Brewster had already conducted to determine the dispersive power of optical materials. Six sets of extensive tables are included. Book five is devoted principally to the improvement of the microscope. Form, illumination systems, use of fluids, and lens improvements are considered.
BP_Reference(s): Brewster on the Nature of Light|Cantor, G.N.|In:  <i>Martyr of Science, Sir David Brewster 1701-1868 <i>|Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, 1984, pp 67-76.||'Brewster, David'|Hentschel, K.|In: Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers|Hockey, T., and others, editors|Springer, 2014, pp 310-314.
BP_Title: A Treatise on New Philosophical Instruments for Various Purposes in the Arts and Sciences with Experiments on Light and Colours. By David Brewster, LL.D. Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and of the Society of the Antiquaries of Scotland.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish physicist, mathematician, astronomer, science historian. Famed for his optics work, defense of Isaad Newton, invention of the kaleidoscope.
BP_Publisher or Seller: John Murray, London and William Blackwood, Edinburgh
BP_BibliographicNotes: Half-title on œÄ‚ÇÅ

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A book-length report of color experiments with birefringent crystals showing how the results disproved Wolfgang van Goethe‚Äôs color theory both generally and particularly.
BP_Description_1: Christian Heinrich Pfaff wrote a paper that appeared in 1812 in the Journal f√ºr Chemie und Physik. In it he reported color experiments with birefringent crystals and showed how the results disproved Wolfgang van Goethe‚Äôs color theory both generally and particularly. Pfaff's <i>Newton's Farbentheorie<i> of 1813 was a direct development of that paper, written to report Pfaff's additional experiments and give a general refutation of Goethe's theory of colors. Pfaff's book is remarkable in that he was a respected and well-known members of scientific circles (famed for his work in chemistry and electricity) and a confirmed Newtonian, but was seriously and sufficiently interested in Goethe's theory to study it carefully and derive experiments to test its validity. By the time Pfaff's book appeared, Goethe's <i>Zur Farbenlehre<i> of 1810 had been reviewed in the scientific literature and roundly dismissed. But Pfaff was the first to study the theory and test it with experiments and to trouble himself to write an extended analysis, rather than simply pronounce Goethe's theory contrary to received wisdom.
BP_Description_2: Pfaff reports a series of experiments, both simple and complex, that give results incompatible with Goethe's theory of color. Each of books chapters describes these. 2: Goethe's ur-phenomenon is doubtful. 3: Refutation of Goethe's theory of secondary images. 4: Refutation of Goethe's description of the colored sun image. 5: Proof that colored rays already exist in the prism. 6: Lens phenomena refute Goethe's theory. 7: Newton's theory of heterogeneous white light defended against the objections of the new doctrine. 8: Different refrangibility of different colored rays proved by new experiments and Goethe's objects refuted. 9: The influence of margins on color formation. 10: The Occult qualities of Goethe's theory. 11: Remarks about Newton's presentation of his theory. In addition there are 4 appendices on technical details. The material is very detailed, especially the technical details of the experiments. The interpretation of the results is straightforward and Pfaff explains how they refute Goethe's ideas, particularly the special pleading that often characterized arguments in support of Goethe's theory.
BP_Reference(s): Another Kind of Light: The Work of T.J. Seebeck and His Collaboration with Goethe, Part I|Nielsen, K.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical and Biological Sciences <i>, Vol 20, No 1, 1989, pp 107-178, NB: pp 164-166.|\German Physics Textbooks in the <i>Goethezeit<i>, Part 1 and Part 2|Clark, W.|<i>History of Science<i>, Vo.l 35, No 2, 3 1997, pp 219-239, 297-263.
BP_Title: Ueber Newton's Farbentheorie, Herrn von Goethe's Farbenlehre und den chemischen Gegensatz der Farben ein Versuch in der experimentalen Optik. Von Dr. C. H. BP_Title English Translation: On Newton's theory of color, Goethe's theory of color, and the chemical contrast of colors. An essay in experimental optics. By Dr. C.H. BP_Short or Common Title: Ragionamento sopra La Legge con cui si Rifrange la Luce
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A text based for university students dealing exclusively with refraction and its cause.
BP_Description_1: Antonio Magarotto wrote this memoire while he was professor of physics in the Royal Lyceum of Vicenza, where he taught for nearly 30 years. In the preface he states that the memoire is a text based on a lecture he developed for his students dealing exclusively with refraction and its cause. Magarotto mentions that although many texts present the law of refraction, almost none present a theory as to its cause. The text is interesting and unusual in that it reviews the history of refraction and is devoted exclusively and in detail to this single topic in physical optics.
BP_Description_2: Magarotto begins with an historical review of refraction as considered by authors ranging from Aristotle, Alhacen, and Vitello, to Leibniz, and many major optical authors in between. The historical citations are extensive: the work of Kepler, Voss, Snell, and Descartes are considered and gives a segue to Leibniz's theory, which he presented in his paper Unicum Opticae Catoptricae & Dioptricae Principium and which Magarotto considers in detail. Finally, Newton's theory based on attractive forces is presented. The material is detailed and analytic, using its historical development as a framework.
BP_Reference(s): Giornale Dell'Italiana Letteratura|Vol 38, No 7, 1814, pp 53-54.
BP_Title: Ragionamento sopra La Legge con cui si Rifrange la Luce Passando da uno in altro mezzo di Diversa Densita, o Natura. Dell' Abate Antonio Magarooto, Professore de Fisica nel r. Liceo di Vicenze de Socio dell' Academia de Padova.
BP_Title English Translation: Reasoning on the Law by which Light Refracts Passing from One Medium to Another of Different Density or Nature. By Abbey Antonio Magarotto. Professor of Physics in the Liceum of Vicenza and Fellow of the Academy of Padua.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian cleric, experimentalist, teacher, translator.

BP_Short or Common Title: M√©moire sur de nouveaux ph√©nom√®nes d'optique [and] M√©moire sur les ph√©nom√®nes qui accompagnent la r√©flexion et la r√©fraction de la lumi√®re
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Two offprints of memoires on the nature of light and its polarization.
BP_Description_1: Between 1807 and 1809, Malus gave four seminal lectures at the Institute in which he disclosed his discovery of what came to be called Malus' law and the phenomenon of the double refraction of light in crystals. The lectures were first published in the 'Nouveau Bulletin des sciences par la Soci√©t√© Philomathique de Paris'. Malus earliest announcement of his discovery that light could be polarized by reflection appeared in the <i>Memoires de Physique et de Chimie de la Societe D'Arcueil<i> in 1807. By the time of the appearance of these two memoires, Malus had conducted additional experiments on polarization, including those involved refraction. The results are reported here. It is in the first memoire that Malus first uses the word 'polarization' to describe the property of light that had been discovered.
BP_Description_2: The first memoire describes basic experiments with light reflected from glass plates. The effect of the angle of incidence is noted. The second memoire defines and describes the degrees of polarization at various angles and a rudimentary specification involving maxima and minima. The second memoire deals as well with reflection from polished metallic surfaces.

BP_Short or Common Title: Commentari sopra la storia e le teorie dell'ottica
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first modern history of optics; the result of Venturi's scholarship and his book and manuscript collecting passion.
BP_Description_1: Giambattista Venturi traveled extensively between 1774 and 1813, engaged in teaching, diplomatic work, optics research, book collecting, and writing. On his return to Milan in 1813 he organized the extensive material he had collected and wrote, among other historical work, this history of optics. It is the first modern history of optics, the result of Venturi's scholarship and his book and manuscript collecting passion. Venturi had clearly conceived a very extensive history, the present work being only the first part, and all that was published. Venturi considers the history of optics up to and including the work of Ptolemy and does so with a very firm point of view: that of the ancients. The result is not a simple, continuous, extracted chronology of developments, but rather an examination of ancient works within their context. In that sense, it is a limited history.
BP_Description_2: Venturi begins this history of optics with a long, dedicatory remembrance of his fellow priest and scientist, Bonaventura Corti. The history is in three parts:  1:  Various parts of ancient optics: geometric optics, vision, reflection, refraction, and perspective. This is an overview of the principal components of optics in ancient times, up to the work of Ptolemy 2: Translation of The <i>Dioptra<i> of Hero of Alexandria from the Greek, with notes. An example of optics applied to practical instruments, in this case, the surveyor's tool and its later developments. 3: The rainbow, halos, and parhelions. A consideration of reports of and explanations for various meteoric phenomena given by ancient and contemporary sources. The work ends with an appendix in which the optics of Ptolemy is compared to that of Alkindi and Alhazen.
BP_Reference(s): <i>From Sight to Light<i>|Smith, A.M.|University of Chicago Press, 2015, 457 pp.
BP_Title: Commentari sopra la storia e le teorie dell'ottica, del cavaliere Giambatista Venturi, Reggiano. Membro del Cesareo Regio Istituto de Scienze etc. della societa' italiana di veraon e di piu' altre accademie. Tomo primo.
BP_Title English Translation: Commentary on the History and Theory of Optics. Of Sir Giambatista Venturi of Reggio. Member of the Imperial Royal Institute of Science, etc. of the Society of Italy of Verona, and of a few other academies.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicist, science historian, dipolmatist.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Portrait engraved by Giovanni Rocci after a drawing by P. Minghetti on œÄ‚ÇÅ·µõ

BP_Short or Common Title: On the laws which regulate the polarization of light by reflexion from transparent bodies
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: David Brewster's famed paper on polarization, the index of refraction, and the angles of incidence and refraction. The first explication of "Brewster's Angle."
BP_Description_1: David Brewster's famed paper that presents the relationship between partial and complete polarization, the index of refraction of the reflecting medium, and the angles of incidence and refraction. An unwearying experimenter in optics, Brewster took immediate notice of the 1812 announcement of Malus that light could be polarized by reflection and conducted an extensive series of experiments. The result allowed him to formulate the geometric and optical conditions of polarization, the most famous is the eponymous Brewster's Angle.
BP_Description_2: David Brewster used his considerable skill with instruments to conduct a large number of experiments involving transparent materials of various refractive indices, the geometry of incidence and refraction, and the measurement of polarization by reflectance. His experiments involved: polarization by front surface reflection from transparent materials, second surface reflection, polarization by reflection at media interfaces, polarization by successive reflections, practical polarization of heterogeneous light by reflection. From his experimental results Brewster adduced 29 propositions. The central result was expressed by what is now called Brewster's Angle; the relationship between the index of refraction of the reflecting material and the incidence angle at which reflected light is maximally linearly polarized. He also made clear the fact that heterogeneous light could not be completely polarized by reflection at any one angle since the index of refraction varied for its constituents. Though Brewster claims to make no hypothetical assumptions, several of his propositions involve Newton's idea of attractive force as the cause of refraction.
BP_Reference(s): Brewster on the Nature of Light|Cantor, G.N.|In:  <i>Martyr of Science, Sir David Brewster 1701-1868 <i>|Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, 1984, pp 67-76.
BP_Title: "On the laws which regulate the polarization of light by reflexion from transparent bodies" In: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Vol 105, 1815, pp 125-159.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish physicist, mathematician, astronomer, science historian. Famed for his optics work, defense of Isaad Newton, invention of the kaleidoscope.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A technical dictiionary of mathematics and natural philosophy. Long, detailed entries with historical background.
BP_Description_1: Hutton gives the reasons for his dictionary in the Preface: Mathematics and natural philosophy had advanced greatly and had become more important to society, and the previous dictionaries, Harris's Lexicon Technicum of 1704 and Stone's Mathematical Dictionary were, respectively, outdated and too incomplete. Though come contemporaries criticized it for 'unbalanced treatment' it was generally well-received. The historical content has long remained valuable. The first edition appeared in 1795/96 while Huttom was still active in his role a professor at Woolrich. This, the second edition, was worked on after his retirement from Woolrich.
BP_Description_2: Hutton's entries related to optics include:  Achromatic, Catoptrics, Diffraction, Dioptrics, Lens, Optics, Optical Rays, Microscope,  Mirrors, Rainbow, Refraction, Spectrum, Telescope. In general, these entries are extended essays on the topic, summarizing the principal points, and invoking mathematics as necessary. Entries such that for 'Lens' is particularly long and detailed. The material is up-to-date and, importantly, most entries are accompanied by extensive historical summaries of important authors and discoveries.
BP_Reference(s): Charles Hutton, 1737‚Äì1823: The prototypical woolwich professor of mathematics|Johnson, W.|<i>Journal of Mechanical Working Technology<i>, Vol 18, No 2, February 1989, pp 195-230.||Reading Encyclopedias: Science and the Organization of Knowledge in Dictionaries of Arts and Sciences, 1730‚Äì1850|Yeo, R.|<i>Isis<i>, vol 82, 1991, pp 24‚Äì49.
BP_Title: A Mathematical and Philosophical Dictionary Containing an Explanation of the Terms and Subjects Comprised undet the Heads of Mathematics, Astronomy and Philosophy with an Historical Account of the Sciences
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematics professor in the Royal Military Academy, Woolrich. A prominent figure in late 18th century practical British mathematics

BP_Short or Common Title: TraiteÃÅ de Physique ExpeÃÅrimentale et MatheÃÅmatique
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Biot attempted to produce a reference for the principal parts of physics which avoided elaborate mathematics when descriptions sufficed. More than 600 of the work's nearly 2400 pages are devoted to optics.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Baptiste Biot's preface makes clear his intention for writing the <i>TraiteÃÅ de Physique ExpeÃÅrimentale et MatheÃÅmatique<i>: to produce a durable reference to the principal parts of physics. He gathered the very latest information in the areas he chose to cover and wrote in descriptive detail on each, contacting authors (or in the cases of Lavoisier and Ampere, their widows) to obtain manuscripts and other material. Biot‚Äôs <i>TraiteÃÅ<i> covers gases, fluids, acoustics, electricity, light, magnetism, and heat. Areas in which he was interested and in which he had conducted research. For this reason the TraiteÃÅ lacks coherency and alternates between large principles and minute details.  One of Biot's abiding interests was optics, particularly the phenomenon of polarization; more than 600 of the work's nearly 2400 pages are devoted to optics. But Biot held to a molecular-corpuscular theory of light, as did his mentor Laplace, and all that would be swept aside in just a few years by Fresnel and his wave theory of light. The <i>TraiteÃÅ<i> is not bristling with mathematics, as was common in French works of that time. Biot mentions his intention to avoid elaborate mathematics when descriptions suffice, unless the mathematics can connect disparate phenomena or expresses a general law. In addition to the edition of 1816, a German translation appeared at Leipzig in 1825 and 1828 and a Spanish translation at Madrid in 1826.
BP_Description_2: Biot's material is in seven books gathered in four volumes. Vol 1 Book 1: General phenomena and observations, including the properties, manipulations, and measurements involving fluids and gases. Vol 2 book 2: Acoustics, including production and propagation of sound, instruments, acoustics in bodies, the voice. Vol 2 Book 3: Electricity, including attraction and repulsion, instruments, electric piles, light from electricity. Vol 3 Book 4: Magnetism, including magnetic attraction and repulsion, generating magnets, intensity of magnets, terrestrial magnetism. Vol 3 Book 5: Light, including catoptrics, dioptrics, dispersion achromatism. Vol 4 Book 5 continued: dioptrics. Vol 4 Book 6: Polarization of Light, including polarization in crystals, undulation theory and polarization, experiments in polarization. Vol 4 Book 7: Heat, including heat rays and latent heat, propagation, steam engines. Vol 4 Supplements: Diffraction of light, measurement of reflection. The optics material on geometrical optics is is brief, if not cursory, and very elaborate on physical optics, particularly on the nature of light polarization. Much of Biot's own work on a theory of polarization and chromatic polarization comprises the bulk of Book 6.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ J. B. Biot and the Mathematization of Experimental Physics in Napoleonic France|Frankel, E.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 8, 1977, pp. 33-72.||Corpuscular Optics and the Wave Theory of Light: The Science and Politics of a Revolution in Physics|Frankel, E.|<i>Social Studies of Science <i>, Vol 6, 1976, pp 141-184.
BP_Title: TraiteÃÅ de physique expeÃÅrimentale et matheÃÅmatique. Par J.B. Biot, Membre de l'Academie des Sciences, Adjoint du Burean des Longitudes, Professeur au College de France et a la Faculte de Sciences de Paris; de la Societe philomatique de paris; des Societes royales de Londres, d'Edimbourg, des Antiquaires d'Ecosse; des Acadmies royales de Turin, de Munich, et de l'Universite de Wilna.  "Omnis Philosophiae difficultas in eo versari videtur, ut a phaenomenis motuum investigemus vires Naturae, deinde ab his vivibus demonstremus phaenomena reliqua." Newton Princip. Prefat.  Tome Premier.

"The Difficulty in All of Philosophy is Seen in the Object in it, that if we Investigate the Powers of Nature from the Phenomenon of Motion, then from these Powers we can Demonstrate other Phenomena" Newton in the preface to the Principia Mathematica. Volume 1. Volume 2. Volume 3. Volume 4.
BP_Biographical Statement: French phyiscist, astronomer, mathematician. Professor of physics at the Coll√®ge de France

BP_Short or Common Title: Memoire sur la diffraction de la lumiere
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The second memoire Fresnel wrote, summarizing work in optics he began in early in 1815. He had not yet fully embraced either a wave theory of light and so this memoir was still essentially ray-based.
BP_Description_1: Augustin-Jean Fresnel began optics work early in 1815, experimenting, gathering data, and formulating an equation-based theory that would explain the position of the light and dark fringes produced by diffraction. Over approximately two years, Fresnel successfully produced such a theory. During that time he produced two memoires, neither of which were published until his Oeuvres were published in 1866. During this time Fresnel was in communication with Francois Arago of the Academy of Sciences, to whom the second memoire had been submitted for review by the Academy. Arago suggested some additional data-taking which Fresnel performed. The revised memoir was subsequently published. Fresnel had not yet fully embraced either a wave theory of light or Huygens‚Äôs Principle for its propagation, his early theory described in this memoir was still essentially ray-based. The agreement between prediction and measurement of fringe positions was convincingly accurate, something which both encouraged Fresnel and attracted the attention of the French scientific circle. This was Fresnel‚Äôs first publication and  would be followed by a ground-breaking series that would mark his subsequent very rapid advances and ultimately result in a complete transverse wave theory of light that would sweep aside all others. This memoire was reprinted in Fresnel's Oeuvres of 1866.
BP_Description_2: Fresnel's early theory was based on the assumption of the interaction of rays and though it did not promote a wave theory, it did make clear that diffraction was a phenomenon independent of the nature of the diffractor, depending only upon its size. This meant that diffraction was not the result of the interaction of light molecules (as they were referred to at the time) and forces produced by the diffracting body. It was for this purpose that Fresnel devised his eponymous Fresnel Mirrors; mirrors slight out of coplanarity, each reflecting half the light emanating from a diffracting slit to the same place on a screen and producing fringes. All of this lead to the notion that diffraction fringes were interference fringes. This publication lacks the elaborate mathematics would would later mark Fresnel's papers. Though he was very proficient in mathematics, he states in the memoire that he considered it a small virtue to use elaborate mathematics (the calculus in particular) to give algebraic or geometric results that could be obtained by simple reasoning and analysis of data.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light <i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 111-154.
BP_Title: "Memoire sur la diffraction de la lumiere, ou l'on examine particulariement le phenomene des franges colorees que presentent les ombres des corps eclairies par un point lumineux" Par Mr. A. Fresnel, Ingenieur de Ponts et Chaussees. In: Annales de Chimie et de Physique, Tome I, pp 239-281.
BP_Title English Translation: "Memoire on the Diffration of Light" by Mr. A. Fresnel, Engineer of Bridges and Roads.
BP_Biographical Statement: French engineer, physicist, experimentalist. Worked on optics, theoretical and practical.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain

BP_Short or Common Title: Bestimmung des Brechungs- und des Farbenzerstreungs-Verm√∂gens verschiedener Glasarten
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fraunhofer describes his discovery of the narrow dark lines in the solar spectrum--the Fraunhofer lines--and the process and instruments he used them to accurately determine glass's dispersion. Fraunhofer's paper was internationally influential, and changed optical measurement practice throughout the technical world.
BP_Description_1: Joseph Fraunhofer wrote the <i>Bestimmung des Brechungs- und des Farbenzerstreungs-Verm√∂gens verschiedener Glasarten<i> in 1814-1815. He had been directing all aspects of glass production of the Bavarian Optical Institute at BenediktBeuren, the secularized Benedictine monastery in Bavaria. It was producing the largest flawless blanks of the finest high refractive index flint glass in the world. As had been clear to Boscovich, Clairaut, and D'Alembert before him, Fraunhofer knew that what was required to produce fine achromatic lenses was not only flawless glass but an accurate knowledge of its dispersion; that is, its index of refraction for light throughout the spectrum. With the discovery of the narrow dark lines in the solar spectrum--the eponymous Fraunhofer lines--he was able to accurately measure their refractive shift in a glass sample, and from that accurately determine the glass's dispersion. Fraunhofer's process and instruments allowed him to determine refractive indices with a precision of one part in 1,000,000. No previous method could do better than one part in 1,000. This high-precision data about glass allowed the Optical Institute to produce the largest and finest achromatic lenses in the world. Fraunhofer's paper was internationally influential, and changed optical measurement practice throughout the technical world. Its influence was broader than instrumentational; it make clear the role and benefit of technology guided by craft and artisanal skill of the highest order.||Fraunhofer's article first appeared in Denkschriften der k√∂niglichen Academie der Wissenschaften zu M√ºnchen f√ºr die Jahre 1814 und 1815, Vol 5, which was published in 1817. It was much more widely known after its appearance in the Annalen der Physik, New Series, Vol 26, of 1817. English and French translations appeared in 1823.
BP_Description_2: Fraunhofer begins his article with a clear statement of the then-urgent need for a way to accurately determine refractive index of glass through the visible spectrum. His initial experiment was an ingenious variant of the method used by Clairaut 50 years earlier: establish the narrowest possible samples of the spectrum--what would now be called monochromatic light--and used them to determine the index of fraction of a glass sample. Rather than use color filters, Fraunhofer use six alcohol burning lamps, each illuminating a prism through narrow slits at a range of incidence angle . The incidence angles were such that a different portion of the prismatic spectrum of each lamp was sent in the same general direction toward a distant prism of the glass being measured, behind which was positioned a modified theodolite to accurately measure the angle produced by refraction in the sample. From this angle the index of refraction could be calculated. But however narrow the slit there was always sufficient spread and overlap to diminish the final precision. Then Fraunhofer used the sun as a single light source and discovered a continuous spectrum with narrow dark lines. Experiment showed the lines to be inherent and in fixed in positions in the solar spectrum and so could be used as precise spectral markers. Rather than use a narrow sample of the spectrum, Fraunhofer used its fixed, much more narrow dark lacunae. Indices of refraction could be determined to one part in 1,000,000. The article contains tables of values of indices for several optical materials.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>Spectrum of Belief: Joseph Von Fraunhofer and the Craft of Precision Optics <i>|Jackson, M.W.|MIT Press, 2000, pp 59-74.||From Theodolite to Spectral Apparatus|Jackson, M.W.|In:  <i>Instrumentation: Between Science, State, and Industry <i>, Joerges, B., Shinn, T., editors|Kluwer, 2001, 270 pp, NB: pp 17-29.||Buying the Dark Lines of the Solar Spectrum|Jackson, M.W.|In:  <i>Archimedes, Scientific Credibility and Technical Standards <i>, Buchwald, J.Z., editor|Kluwer, 1997, 178 pp, NB: pp 1-23.
BP_Title: "Bestimmung des Brechungs- und des Farbenzerstreungs-Verm√∂gens verschiedener Glasarten, in Bezug auf die Vervollkommnung achromatischer Fernr√∂hre"  In: Annalen der Physik, New Series, Vol 26, pp 264-313.
BP_Title English Translation: "Determination of the refractions and color-dispersion properties of various types of glass, with respect to the improvement of acrhomatic telescopes."
BP_Biographical Statement: German optician, glass and lens maker of revoluationary skill.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the British Museum of Natural History and 'Withdrawn' stamp

BP_Short or Common Title: Elementi di ottica e di astronomia
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook on optics that was part of a larger project which included a textbook on astronomy. The text covers only the principles, indicates sources for further study, and provides some history. A strikingly modern idea of the role of teaching, teachers, and textbooks.
BP_Description_1: Giuseppe Settele wrote this textbook on optics as part of a larger project which included a textbook on astronomy. He wrote with a very specific idea of what an introductory text for a single course should attempt and what its style should be. In his prefatory letter to the reader, Settele states that given limited time and attention, an optics text should cover only the principles, indicate sources for further study, provide some history, and prepare  'the young scholar' so that he can discover how much he does not know and how much more he needs to learn. It is a strikingly modern idea of the role of teaching, teachers, and textbooks. Though the grouping and coverage of subjects was innovative, generally the text is traditional, still including, for example, a large section on perspective; other textbooks had long ago separated perspective from optics. And Settele was unaware of Fresnel's work. There was considerable difficulty getting the Imprimatur for the second volume (on astronomy), owing to Settele's embracing and fully explaining the Copernican system. It was Settele's tussle to get permission to print his textbook and his appeal to the Holy See which in 1820 finally  prompted it to remove any stricture on the belief or teaching of the Copernican system.
BP_Description_2: The material is covered in 11 chapters and an appendix with 3 additional chapters. 1: The principal properties of light. 2: Foci of reflected and refracted rays. 3: Images formed by reflection and refraction. 4: Caustics of reflection and refraction. 5: Images from conic mirrors. 6: The eye and formation of images. 7: Spectacles. 8: Dioptric telescopes. 9: Catadioptric telescopes. 10: Microscopes. 11: Achromatic lenses. The appendix contains, 1: The rainbow. 2: Singular phenomena produced by reflection and refraction. 3: Perspective. The material builds as it proceeds, and avoids the leaps which Settele finds 'so fatal in the treatises of the exact sciences.' Settele often does not draw conclusions or provide detailed derivations, inviting the reader to work them out. Most sections contain a history of the topic, a background Settele believes necessary. The material on physical optics is very concise, sighting Descartes and Newton without plumping for any particular theory, but the cause of reflection and refraction is assigned to attractive and repulsive forces. The second chapter of the appendix discusses double refraction. Most of the material is on geometric optics with an emphasis on the analysis of lenses for dioptric instruments and the images produced by lenses and mirrors. Settele even describes Alhacen's solution to Alhacen's Problem. The style is descriptive and highly analytic, invoking the calculus when necessary.
BP_Reference(s): Giuseppe Settele and the final annulment of the decree of 1616 against Copernicanism|Casanovas, J.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana <i>, Vol. 60, No 4, 1989,  pp 791-805.
BP_Title: Elementi di ottica e di astronomia del Canonico Giuseppe Settele Professore nell' Archiginnasio Romno. Vol. I. Ottica.
BP_Title English Translation: Elements of Optics and of Astronomy. By Canon Giuseppe Settele, Professor in the University of Rome. Vol. 1. Optics.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian cleric, teacher. Professor of optics and astronomy at La Sapienzia. Famed for his astronomy book's imprimatur bringing the Roman Church to officially remove its objections to Copernicus' heliocentrism.
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Vellum Over Patterned-Paper Covered Boards

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The description of the Amici Prism, an improvement over that used by William Hyde Wollaston in his camera lucida.
BP_Description_1: Giovanni Battista Amici first used William Hyde Wollaston's camera lucida when in 1815 the instrument had been purchased for use in the physics laboratory of the University of Modena. Amici discovered the principal drawback of Wollaston's design: the field of view was exceedingly small, and the image disappeared with slight movement of the observer's eye. Amici devised five ways to improve the device and reported his work in a paper read before the Modena Royal Academy of Sciences, Letters and Arts on 27 February 1818. It was published in the Opuscoli Scientifici at Bologna in 1819. The present article is the offprint and is an example of Amici's ingenuity in the design of optical instrument in general and his inventiveness in the form and use of prims in particular.
BP_Description_2: Aimci's most successful improvement for the camera lucida was to bring light from a scene at 45 degrees incidence to a glass plate by total internal reflection within an isosceles prism. The glass plate 45 degrees with respect to the drawing surface below and viewed from above gave, by partial reflection of the light from prism, a combined image of the drawing surface below and the scene out in front.
BP_Reference(s): Professor Amici's Improved Camera Lucida|Brewster, D.|<i>The Edinburgh Journal of Science <i>, Vol 3, No 1, pp 157-159.||The production of achromatic objectives in the first half of the nineteenth century: the contribution of Giovanni Battista Amici|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana <i>, Vol 61, 1990,  pp 829-875.
