BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Francis Xavier Brosius (?-?) French cleric, teacher. Credited with introducing the chalkboard to schools in the United States.
BP_Short or Common Title: The Elements of Natural or Experimental Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A teaching summary of early 19th century natural philosophy
BP_Description_1: Cavallo was a prolix writer and, as the editor's Advertisement makes clear, he tightened up the writing and omitted some material from the original, taking into account the intended audience of the text. Cavallo cites many authors, giving references where ever necessary. Cavallo's reputation was wide-spread, being made a Fellow of the Royal Society, prolific author, and contributor of several articles to Rees' revision of Chambers Cyclopedia. Editions of the <i>The Elements of Natural or Experimental Philosophy<i> appeared at London in 1803 and 1809, a German translation appeared Erfurt in 1805, and posthumously in revised form at Philadelphia in 1819 and 1825.
BP_Description_2: The work is in 5 Parts.  Part 1: General properties of bodies. Part 2: Peculiar properties of bodies. Part 3: Caloric, Light, Electricity, and Magnetism. Part 4: Astronomy. Part 5: Few unconnected Subjexts. The material on optics (111 pages) comprises Section II of Part 3. It covers the nature of light, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Inflected light, Colors, Lenses, Eye and Vision, Optical Instruments, Light and Natural Phenomena||Consideration of physical optics is limited to the nature of light and though the wave hypothesis is presented, the author sides with Newton and light's particle nature. The geometrical optics material considers reflection and refraction. It is descriptive and though complete in topic, the mathematics is limited to ratios and geometry. The material on color references the work of Boyle and Newton, with the later presented as the most likely hypothesis. The material on lenses includes basic descriptions of lens types, chromatic aberration, and achromatic lenses. This includes formulae for the construction of achromatic lenses taken from Euler's <i>Dioptrice<i>. Some basic lens construction material is also taken from Smith's <i>A Compleat System of Opticks<i> of 1738. Basic ocular anatomy and eye function are presented. Aspects of visual perception are also described. The descriptions of optical instruments include the camera obscura, magic lantern, dioptric telescope, catadioptric telescope, microscope, and the photometer.||Each section consists of a main presentation, followed by more details, more advanced considerations, or experiments to demonstrate principles. The later is set in small type, so that at first reading it can be skipped. This permits the text to be used at two levels.
BP_Reference(s): Cavallo, Tiberius (1749-1809)|Bertucci, P.|In: Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
BP_Title: The Elements of Natural or Experimental Philosophy
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian-born English physicist, insrument maker, and prolific writer.

BP_Short or Common Title: Memoire sur la diffraction de la lumiere
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fresnel's memoire submitted for the prize announced by the French Academy in 1817 for a memoire explaining diffraction. Fresnel had adopted a wave theory based on Huygens‚Äôs Principle which he used to predict diffraction fringe placement and size. The agreement between Fresnel‚Äôs measurements and predictions were spectacular and his memoire was awarded the prize; the Memoire Couronn√©.
BP_Description_1: Augustin-Jean Fresnel's memoire submitted for the prize announced by the French Academy in 1817 for a memoire explaining diffraction. The original language of the prize announcement appeared to limit submissions to those based on rays or corpuscular theories of light, but Francois Arago wrangled a change that allowed Fresnel's work to be considered. Since the publication of his first memoir on diffraction in 1816, Fresnel's work has advanced in three significant ways: he had embraced Huygens‚Äôs Principle for modelling light propagation, thus abandoning rays and their interaction, he had increased the precision with which he measured the positions of diffraction fringe maxima, and he constructed a computational framework based on Huygens‚Äôs Principle of sufficient complexity to predict fringe maxima. From this latter development came the eponymous Fresnel Integrals. The agreement between Fresnel‚Äôs measurements and predictions were spectacular and his memoire was awarded the prize; the Memoire Couronn√©. Fresnel's work was a conceptual and analytic triumph; the wave-based theory of light could no longer be set aside. This printing of the Memoire Couronn√© did not include the introduction in which Fresnel delineated why a ray or corpuscular theory of light could not be correct. Fresnel's long work is printed in two parts in Volume 11 of the Annales de Chimie et de Physique; pp 246-295 and 337-376. The memoire was printed in full by the French Academy in 1826 and in the Oeuvres of 1866. J.C. Poggendorff's German translation appeared in the Annalen der Physik und Chemie in 1836 and an English translation in 1900.
BP_Description_2: Fresnel began the memoire delineating reasons why a ray or corpuscular theory of light cannot be correct, the essential problem being that rays and corpuscles are independent and only mechanical interactions can be used to explain optical phenomena. The rest of the memoire is essentially a series of lectures, giving background and detail appropriate for readers not familiar with wave analysis. The topics, in turn, are: all 'rays' are involved in diffraction, not just those near the diffractor; Huygens's Principle permits the necessary interactions to be modelled; a diffractor blocks part of an otherwise full wavefront and the resulting sub-wavefronts generate interference fringes; positions of fringe maxima can be predicted only by incorporating (integrating) the phase interactions along the wavefront that is not blocked by the diffractor; derivation of the integrals that express the necessary phase interactions; comparison of predictions of position of fringe maxima with experimental measurement. Fresnel's analyses included fringes produced by a half-infinite diffractor, a narrow slit, and a narrow diffractor. In most cases the agreement with position measurements was withing 1.5%.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light <i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 168-183.||Memoir on the Diffraction of Light 'Crowned' by the French Academy of Sciences in 1819 by A. Fresnel|Crew, H., translator|In:  <i>The Wave Theory of Light, Memoirs of Huygens, Young, and Fresnel <i>|American Book Co, New York, 1900|Reissued by Kessinger Publishing, 2010, 162 p.
BP_Title: "Memoire sur la diffraction de la lumiere" Par Mr. A. Fresnel, Ingenieur de Ponts et Chaussees. In: Annales de Chimie et de Physique, Vol 11, pp 246-296, 337-378.
BP_Title English Translation: "Memoire on the Diffration of Light" by Mr. A. Fresnel, Engineer of Bridges and Roads.
BP_Biographical Statement: French engineer, physicist, experimentalist. Worked on optics, theoretical and practical.

BP_Author full name: Andr√©s de Guevara y Basoaz√°bal SJ
BP_Author last name first: Guevara y Basoaz√°bal SJ, Andr√©s de
BP_Short or Common Title: Institutionum elementarium philosophi√¶ ad usum studios√¶ juventutis
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An extended textbook written after the suppression of the Jesuits and the author's return to Rome from Mexico. He wrote it specifically for young students in New Spain.
BP_Description_1: Andr√©s de Guevara y Basoaz√°bal began to write this extended textbook after the suppression of the Jesuits and his return to Rome from Mexico. He wrote it specifically for young students in New Spain, hoping to encourage them to study science, philosophy, and theology. In four volumes he covers: Philosophy and Mathematics, Metaphysics, General Physics, and Particular Physics. Hoping for his books to appear in print in Mexico, he sent a copy of his manuscript to Mexico City, dedicated to San Ildefonso College. Interestingly, rather than in the vernacular of his homeland, he wrote in Latin, hoping to prompt its study and so provide students with access to the vast literature of the humanities. The blend of philosophy, metaphysics, theology, and natural philosophy had the books widely used in Catholic schools. The first edition appeared at Venice in 1800, posthumous editions appeared at Venice in 1819, at Madrid in 1824, 1827, 1829, and 1833, at Valentia in 1824 and 1825, and at Barcelona in 1845.
BP_Description_2: The huge range of material is covered in four volumes. 1: History of Philosophy and Elementary Mathematics. 2: Logic and Metaphysics. 3: General Physics. 4: Particular Physics. The optics material (126 pages) is in Volume 4, Particular Physics. It includes: the nature and propagation of light, reflection, colors, optics or direct light, the eye and eye-function, vision and perception, catoptrics, cause of reflection and its law, plane and curved mirrors, refraction, cause of refraction and its law, convex and concave lenses, dioptric instruments. The material on physical optics considers the theories of Descartes, Newton, Euler, and Boscovich. The rest of the material is on geometrical optics. The material is elementary and descriptive, with only elementary geometry used occasionally.
BP_Reference(s): Entre v√≥rtices cartesianos y gravitaci√≥n newtoniana: la Cosmolog√≠a de Andr√©s de Guevara y Basoasabal S. J. (1748-1801)|Galindo, S.|<i>Revista Mexicana de F√≠sica <i>, Vol 58, No 2, 2012, pp 133-149.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fourth edition of Chevallier's 1810 text, but vastly expanded. It begins with the same brief instructional material, but the material devoted to practical optics and opticians is greatly expanded, as is the trade catalogue that appears at the end.
BP_Description_1: Fourth edition of Jean Gabriel Augustin Chevallier's text which first appeared in 1810. This edition, with its 511 pages, is a vast extension of the edition of 1810 which has 163 pages. It begins with the same brief instructional material, but the material devoted to practical optics and opticians is greatly expanded, as is the trade catalogue that appears at the end. New to this edition is an extensive optical vocabulary. Though the ultimate commercial purpose of the book is that same as that of the edition of 1810, the scope, level of detail, technical nature, and extent of information is considerably greater. By this time, Chevallier's firm was producing the finest microscopes available in Europe; achromatic doublets were combined to provide high magnification which was a significant advance since the small lens size and high curvature made achromatic microscope lenses difficult to make.
BP_Description_2: The 'custodian of vision' of the title is the optician and the spectacles he can provided. Chevallier treatise begins with an elementary description of the anatomy of the eye and its optical function. Normal vision, common visual deficiencies, and diseases of the eye are then described. This is followed by a 'Manual of the Optician-Engineer' which is a long, self-contained section on optical aids of various types and how to chose them, including all types of lenses, spectacles, lunettes, magnifiers, glasses, and Franklin's bifocal spectacles. The microscope and other magnifiers are also described as well as the achromatic lens. A thirty-five page Vocabulary of Optics follows, which gives definitions for most words commonly used in optics. Then is a 170 page catalogue of optical instruments. The book ends with a forty pages of extracts from journals and letters pertaining to practical optics.
BP_Reference(s): Chevallier'|Blancheton, E.|<i>Revue G√©n√©rale, Biographique, Politique et Litteraire <i>, Vol 5, 1843, pp 207-291.||The Moon for a twopence: street telescopes in nineteenth-century Paris and the epistemology of popular  stargazing|Aibin, D.|<i>Early Popular Visual Culture <i>, Vol 15, No 2, pp 125-151.||http://www.microscopist.net/ChevallierJGA.html

BP_Biographical Statement: French oculist, instrument maker. Celebrated for his inventiveness and the quality of his instruments.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A treatment of physical optics based entirely of the supposition of vibrations in a pervading aether and the actions of attractive and repulsive forces.
BP_Description_1: An early publication of Nobili. The result of his studies after he left the military in 1814 and his promise given in his mechanics book of 1819, to treat light from a mechanical point of view. The text deals exclusively with physical optics and rejects all radiant and action-at-a-distance theories, including the emission of Newtonian particles. Nobili's treatment of physical optics is based entirely of the supposition of vibrations in a pervading aether and the actions of attractive and repulsive forces. Pulses, such as those proposed by Euler are equated with light. Somewhat like the French theories of Fresnel and Cauchy, but based more closely on Biot, Nobili attempts to construct and entirely mechanical foundation for physical optics. But without any mathematics, French or otherwise, Nobili's elaborate treatise had little effect on optics. Though his strengths may not have been in theory, he was a master experimentalist and instrument maker. He would establish the science of electro-chemical colored optical coating, what he called 'metallocromia.'
BP_Description_2: The text begins with a 'Prospectus of Optics' followed by 9 Articles and a Conclusion. 1: On Reflection. 2: On Refraction. 3: On Color in General. 4: On the Permanent Colors of Bodies. 5: On Prismatic Colors. 6: Colors of Lamina 7: On Diffraction. 8: On Double Refraction 9: Extraordinary Vibrations that Couple with Ordinary Ones of Light, or The Polarization of Light. The prospectus presents Nobili's overarching theory of the nature of light, based entirely of the supposition of vibrations in a pervading aether generated by luminous objects and the actions of attractive and repulsive forces on those vibrations. The principle phenomena of physical optics--reflection, refraction, diffraction, double refraction, polarization--are described as resulting from vibrations the aether being affected by attractive and repulsive forces produced by and linking to physical objects such as glass, metal, air, and crystals. For many of details, Nobili relies heavily on Jean-Baptiste Biot's <i>Trait√© de Physique Exp√©rimentale Et Math√©matique<i> that had appeared in 1816.
BP_Reference(s): N√≤bili Leopoldo'|In: Dizionario biografico degli italiani, Vol 78, Natta - Nurra, 2013.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mansucrpt illustrations of the application of geometry to practical problems in physics.
BP_Description_1: Pair of manuscript volumes comprising 174 numbered leaves of careful pen-and-ink drawings and titles, plus indices, one or two with colour added by a near contemporary identifying himself as 'Gabrieli Giovanni', nearly 180 leaves in total. Though they have the look of student‚Äôs scientific drawings, recording the figures that accompanied lectures, they could also be for a professor‚Äôs notebook for his lectures.
BP_Description_2: The first volume covers all aspects of mechanics, including its application to screws, scales, pumps, cog wheels, motion on inclined surfaces, and pulley systems. Volume two begins with a section on astronomy, planetary motions and celestial mechanics. This is followed by the longest section (leaf 33 to 67), that on optics, comprising plates on refraction and lenses, eyesight, diffraction of sunlight, prisms, microscopes, and telescopes. The end of the volume is taken up by illustrations of the geometry of spheres, the Archimedean Screw, and a final chapter on ballistics, which is based on the eighteenth century mathematician and physicist Francois Jacquier.
BP_Title: Figure di fisico-mathematica.  Student scientific notebook.  2 Vols.
BP_Pagination: Vol1: 91 number leaves; Vol 2: 85 numbered leaves
BP_BibliographicNotes: Eace volume with an index on the last leaf

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fresnel's article on light for the supplement to Jean Riffault's French translation of the sixth edition of 1821 of Thomas Thomson's System of Chemistry. It is a full, detailed, and clear statement of his wave theory of light. Publication of the essay made the theory's description available to wide audience of technical readers, not just physicists and not just French scientific circles.
BP_Description_1: Augustin-Jean Fresnel was chosen to contribute the article on light for the supplement to Jean Riffault's French translation of the sixth edition of 1821 of Thomas Thomson's <i>System of Chemistry<i>. Completed in June of 1821, Fresnel's essay was the most comprehensive statement of his work in optics. Unlike the extracts and short articles to which he had been limited in the Annales de Chimie et Physique, Fresnel was given ample space to develop a full, detailed, and clear statement of his wave theory of light. Publication of the essay made the theory's description available to wide audience of technical readers, not just physicists and not just French scientific circles. Poggendorff published its German translation in the Annalen der Physik in 1825-1828. And Thomas Young's English translation was published by David Brewster in the Quarterly Journal of Science in 1827-1829. John Herschel read Fresnel's essay and to a large, but not complete extent, incorporated Fresnel's ideas in his own essay 'Light' which was generally available by 1828 and published in the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i> in 1830. Fresnel's essay became the most important instrument for the dissemination of his complete wave theory of light, which within 10 years was accepted by nearly the entire European scientific community.
BP_Description_2: Fresnel's essay contains sections on the nature of light, diffraction, thin-film interference, reflection and refraction, double refraction and polarization, chromatic polarization, and modification of polarization by reflection.  He developed in detail the wave theory of light he had described in summaries and extracts in the short memoires he had published in the Annals de Chemie et de Physique between 1816 and 1822.  Fresnel showed how his wave theory successfully explained and predicted all then-known optical phenomena except chromatic dispersion. In was in this essay that the full explanation of transverse waves was presented and a full description of polarized light was given. With it, Fresnel's complete wave theory of light was described in sufficient detail for other to follow, consider, and work on and marked the beginning of the wave theory of light's general acceptance in science. There is a 'Post-Scriptum' at the end of the volume regarding Fresnel's investigation into the chemical action of light.
BP_Reference(s): <i>History of the Principle of Interference of Light <i>|Kipnis, N.|Springer, Basel, 1991, 271 pp, NB pp 224-231.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook covering experimental physics.
BP_Description_1: Poli's work attempts to present a complete course of experimental physics. Being somewhat eclectic, there are parts of the material that were already quite dated when it first appeared. The presentation of the Phlogiston theory of heat and the Cartesian nature of light are examples; by 1780, physicists had abandoned both theories. Nevertheless, the work was widely popular and used throughout Italy. It was revised, reprinted, and condensed  in many subsequent editions. Twenty-three editions appeared between 1781 and 1837.
BP_Description_2: Vol 1: Material in General, On Motion, Laws of Motion and Central Forces, Dynamics, Reflection and Refraction of Motion, Cosmography, The Armillary Sphere, Central Forces and Celestial Motion. Vol 2: Gravity, Projectile Motion, Center of Gravity, Mechanics, Hydrostatics, Hydraulics. Vol 3: Air, Fluids, Gases. Vol 4: Sound, Winds, Water, Heat, Theories of Heat, Light. Vol 5: Optical Phenomena and Instruments, Color, Electricity, Magnetism||The optical material is contained in Lessons XXII-XXV of Volume IV (86 pages) and Lessons XXVI-XXVII in Volume V (112 pages). Lesson XXII presents 6 Articles. Art 1: The nature of light. Art 2: Propagation of Light. Art 3: Refraction and Dioptrics. Art 4: Lenses and their Properties. Art 5: The Eye and Vision. Art 6: Perception and aspects of View. Considering physical optics, Art 1 presents the Cartesian, Eulerian, and Newton hypotheses on the nature of light. Without settling the issue, Poli adopts light rays as a useful description of light for all practical purposes. He quotes the discover of R√∏mer as showing that light propagates in finite time, and several experiments that show it travels in straight lines. Dioptrics is described in geometric terms and its principles lead to the understanding of Lenses and their operation. Convex and concave lenses are discussed. Double refraction and polarization is mentioned, but aberrations are not. Art 5 presents elementary ocular anatomy and vison function. The material in Lessons XXVI-XXVI present Optical instruments include the microscope, magic lantern, telescope, and various types of mirrors. The material on color is Newtonian, with different rays considered as colored. The formation of the rainbow and halos is described.||The material is elementary and uses no mathematics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fraunhofer presents the first quantitative discussion of the diffraction of light.¬†
BP_Description_1: Fraunhofer had described his discovery of the narrow dark lines in the solar spectrum--the Fraunhofer lines--in his paper of 1817. By 1821 Fresnel‚Äôs work on the wave theory of light and interference had become widely known and and so Fraunhofer published two papers in which he observed and analyzed certain diffraction phenomena and interpreted them in terms of a wave theory of light. In the 1821 paper, contained in this volume of the Denkschriften, he discussed his examination of the spectra resulting from light diffracted through a single narrow slit and quantitatively related the width of the slit to the angles of dispersion of the different orders of spectra. An offprint of the paper appeared in 1821, the year Fraunhofer presented the paper. The Denkschriften was printed only every three years, so Fraunhofer's diffraction work did not appear in the journal until 1824.
BP_Description_2: In this paper Fraunhofer discussed his examination of the spectra resulting from light diffracted through a single narrow slit and quantitatively related the width of the slit to the angles of dispersion of the different orders of spectra. The papers begins with the claim that the advance of science depends on precision instruments, particularly in optics. He then described the phenomenon of diffraction and how it can produced by light passing through a small opening into a darkened room and the light viewed in on a distant screen. The illuminated part of the screen was larger than the opening and exhibited colored fringes at the edges. New experiments are then described, designed for measurements using a heliostat and a narrow slit that diffracted the light.  The results on the screen was examined by a theodolite, which could measure the angles involved, showing that the angle of diffraction is inversely proportional to the width of the opening. Similarly, using gratings of parallel silver or gold wires, he found that the diffraction is inversely proportional to the separation of the wires. Fraunhofer's grating had 260 wires, separated by about 0.004 Paris inch with wire thickness of about 0.002 inch. Fraunhofer made the first quantitative study of diffraction phenomena. The presence of the solar dark lines enabled him to note that the dispersion of the spectra was greater with his grating than with his prism. Hence, he examined the relationship between dispersion and the separation of wires in the grating. From the same study Fraunhofer was able to determine the wavelengths of specific colors of light.
BP_Reference(s): From Theodolite to Spectral Apparatus|Jackson, M.W.|In:  <i>Instrumentation: Between Science, State, and Industry <i>, Joerges, B., Shinn, T., editors|Kluwer, 2001, 270 pp, NB: pp 17-29.||Buying the Dark Lines of the Solar Spectrum|Jackson, M.W.|In:  <i>Archimedes, Scientific Credibility and Technical Standards <i>, Buchwald, J.Z., editor|Kluwer, 1997, 178 pp, NB: pp 1-23.||Lines of Light|Brand, J.C.D.|Gordon and Breach, 1995, 266 pp, NB: pp 37-47.

BP_Short or Common Title: On the principles and construction of the achromatic eye-pieces of telescopes
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Offprint of a detailed, practical treatise on the design and construction of achromatic telescope eyepieces
BP_Description_1: George Biddell Airy wrote this detailed, practical treatise on the design and construction of achromatic telescope eyepieces while at Trinity College, Cambridge. Airy's treatises is the first significant advance and compilation of theory and practical techniques since Boscovich's work thirty-five years earlier. This offprint from the Transactions of the Cambidge Philosophical Society, is presented in Airy's hand to 'Dr Godfrey.'
BP_Description_2: Airy begins his treatise with a general review of previous work and developments in achromatic lens systems. Beginning with Huygens, he traces the work of Newton, Dollond, Clairaut, D'Alembert, Euler, and finally Boscovich. As a brief historical overview is it interesting, but it is even more telling in the critical assessment Airy makes of the very theoretical--and to the practical optician, usless--work of Clairaut, D'Alembert, and Euler. The latter in particular is singled out for producing something so bristled with detail and complex mathematics as to render it unusable. On the other hand, Boscovich's work is Airy beginning point and guide. His process is to develop expressions for the visual angle of the axis of ray pencils through an eyepiece as functions of lens focal lengths that depend on the indices of refraction involved. These expressions are differentiated to determine minima that give the lens characteristics that provide the best achromatism that can be achieved. He does this for eyepieces of two, three, and four lenses. Importantly, Airy uses Joseph Fraunhofer's data that had appeared in the Edinburgh Philosophical Journal two years earlier. Airy's work shows the influence of practical experience: in addition to Fraunhofer's data, Airy is concerned with lens diameter and thickness given the unlikelihood of getting large pieces of flawless glass. Airy ends the treatise with the application of his method to practical telescope eyepieces.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light <i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 254-259.
BP_Title: On the principles and construction of the achromatic eye-pieces of telescopes and on the achromatism of the microscopes|Airy, G.B.|Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Scoiety, Vol 2, Part 2, 1827, pp 227-252.
BP_Biographical Statement: British mathematician, astronomer. Made important advances as Astronomer Royal.
BP_Provenance: Presetation in Airy's hand to 'Dr Godfrey'

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook on optics meant to upgrade the presentation of optical science and make it compatible with the mathematical skills of university students. It adopted the concision of algebra and the calculus.
BP_Description_1: Henry Coddington wrote this textbook on optics to upgrade the presentation of optical science and make it compatible with the mathematical skills of university students. Specifically, this meant the avoidance of discursive descriptions and elaborate geometric methods, and the adoption of concision and the methods of algebra and the calculus. In his Preface, Coddington states that his books is based on a syllabus and series of lectures delivered by William Whewell in 1819 and is a 'compilation rather than an original production' and refers to the works of Smith, Harris, Wood, Biot, and Young. Parts of Coddington's text are essentially transcripts of Whewell's lectures. Editions appeared at Cambridge in 1823 and 1825.
BP_Description_2: Coddington's textbook deals almost exclusively with geometrical optics. Six chapters are devoted to reflection: plane surfaces, spherical surfaces, spherical aberrations, general curved surfaces, caustics, images produced by reflection. Six chapters are devoted to refraction: plane surfaces, spherical surfaces, spherical aberrations, general curved surfaces, caustics, images produced by refraction. Separate chapters are devoted to the following: chromatic dispersion, the eye and vision, optical instruments, and optical phenomena such as the rainbow, mirages, Newton's rings, and double refraction. Coddington's textbook considers off-axis aberrations and contains the first appearance of an equation for lens astigmatism. The material on physical optics is Newtonian, though Thomas Young's work on a wave theory is mentioned. Interestingly, there is no mention of Fresnel and his work on transverse waves or polarization, but an Appendix gives an English translation of Jean-Baptiste Biot's competing emission theory. The material on geometric optics is extensive, detailed and highly analytic.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  Optical designing as an art|Taylor, H.D.|<i>Transactions of the Optical Society<i>, Vol 24, No 3, 1923, pp 143-167.||Early Books in Optics & Optical Design: A Compleat System of Opticks & The Edinburgh Encyclopedia|Thompson, K.P.|<i>Optics and Photonics News<i>, Vol 16, No10,  2005, pp 28-33.
BP_Title: An Elementary Treatise on Optics. Henry Coddington, M.A. Fellow of Trinity College. Second Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: English natural philosopher, cleric.  Senior Wrangler and tutor at Trinity College, Cambridge; wrote knowingly of optics.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by J.C. Poggendorff
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A German translation of Fresnel's essay <i>De La Lumiere<i> that had appeared in 1822 in the supplement to the French translation of the sixth edition of 1821 of Thomas Thomson's System of Chemistry
BP_Description_1: J.C. Poggendorff's translation of Fresnel's essay  De La Lumiere that had appeared in 1822 in the supplement to the French translation of the sixth edition of 1821 of Thomas Thomson's <i>System of Chemistry<i>. Poggendorff's note at the beginning of the translation makes clear the he felt it necessary to print a German translation of Fresnel's essay since other German journals had 'passed over in silence' Fresnel's important development. Of the German textbooks generally available at the time, only Andreas Baumgartner's <i>Die Naturlehre<i> of 1824 contained a presentation of Fresnel's research and a summary his wave theory of light.
BP_Description_2: Fresnel's essay contains sections on the nature of light, diffraction, thin-film interference, reflection and refraction, double refraction and polarization, chromatic polarization, and modification of polarization by reflection.  He developed in detail the wave theory of light he had described in summaries and extracts in the short memoires he had published in the Annals de Chemie et de Physique between 1816 and 1822.  Fresnel showed how his wave theory successfully explained and predicted all then-known optical phenomena except chromatic dispersion. In was in this essay that the full explanation of transverse waves was presented and a full description of polarized light was given. With it, Fresnel's complete wave theory of light was described in sufficient detail for other to follow, consider, and work on and marked the beginning of the wave theory of light's general acceptance in science.
BP_Reference(s): <i>History of the Principle of Interference of Light <i>|Kipnis, N.|Springer, Basel, 1991, 271 pp, NB pp 224-231.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of William Lewis's Catechisms of the Arts and Sciences; a series of short, descriptive summaries of topics in the sciences printed in small, inexpensive format, accessible by most any interested lay reader or beginner in science.
BP_Description_1: One of William Lewis's Catechisms of the Arts and Sciences. They were a series of short, descriptive summaries of topics in the sciences printed in small, inexpensive format, accessible by most any interested lay reader or beginner in science. Accompanied by simple figures, their purpose was the exposition of generally accepted facts without the labor of theory or mathematics. Though Lewis titled these 'Catechisms,' they were not written in a catechetical textbook style--that is, questions with answers to be learned by rote--and popular at the time. Lewis's books were more formally structured and part of the popularization of science movement. Catechisms 1-11 were usually bound together, as were 12-18. Editions appeared between 1824 and 1857.
BP_Description_2: By 1825 Lewis had produced a catechisms for the following. 1: Architecture, 2: Astronomy, 3: Mechanics, 4: Natural History of Man, 5: Natural History of Beasts part 1, 6: Natural History of Beasts part 2, 7: Natural History of Ornithology part 1, 8: Natural History of Ornithology part 2, 9: Natural History of Amphibia, 10: Natural History of Ichthyology, 11: Natural History of Entomology, 12: Hydrostatics, 13: Pneumatics, 14: Hydraulics, 15: Optics, 16: Acoustics, 17: Magnetism, 18: Electricity. Each was followed by a list question for testing understanding followed by 'An Etymological and Pronouncing Vocabulary of the Technical Terms.' particular to the topic.||The Catechism of Optics (72 pages) covers the elementary aspects of optics: nature of light and its propagation, reflection and refraction, lenses and their images, prismatic color, mirrors, the eye and vision, spectacles, the telescope, the microscope, the camera obscura, the magic lantern. Only the most elementary aspects of each topic is presented. The aspects dealing with physical optics are completely Newtonian.
BP_Reference(s): Some influences on the modern science text: Alternative science writing|Strube, P., lynch, P.P.|<i>European Journal of Science Education <i>, Vol 6, No 4, 1984, pp 321-338.||<i>The Physicsl Science Textbook since 1800: A Study of its Language, Structure, and Rhetorical Style <i>|Strube, P.|Dissertation, University of Tasmania, 1985, 378 p.|http://eprints.utas.edu.au/21837/1/whole_StrubePaul1986_thesis.pdf
BP_Title: A Catechism of Optics; On a New Plan, Illustrated with Engravings. To which is added, An Etymological and Pronouncing Vocabulary of the Technical Terms. By W. Greatheed Lewis, Author of a New System of English Grammar. "To hime who is unacquainted with the principles of experimental philosophy, the causes of hundres of every-day occurrences must remain for ever unknown."

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of John Farrar English translations of French mathematics and science texts early for use at American Universities, principally at Harvard College.
BP_Description_1: John Farrar produced English translations of several French mathematics and science texts early in the 19th century for use at American Universities, principally at Harvard College, including the texts of Legendre, Lacroix, Euler, Bezout, and Bourdon. His largest translation project was <i>A Course of Natural Philosophy in Four Parts<i>: mechanics, electricity, optics, astronomy, all drawn from Biot and each produced in a separate volume. The third, on optics, is a very close translation of Book Six of Jean-Baptiste Biot's <i>Pr√©cis √©l√©mentaire de Physique Exp√©rimentale<i> of 1817, which itself is extracted from Biot's much larger <i>TraiteÃÅ de Physique ExpeÃÅrimentale et MatheÃÅmatique<i>. Farrar's translation is an example of the considerable influence French mathematics and science had in American universities in the half-century following independence from Britain.
BP_Description_2: Farrar's text is a direct translation of Book Six of Biot's <i>Pr√©cis √âl√©mentaire de Physique Exp√©rimentale<i>. Following some general remarks, there is a brief section on catoptrics, followed by a much longer section on dioptrics, and then the longest section on the 'Analysis of Light.' This last is a collection of sections on the nature of light, optical instruments, telescopes, microscopes, vision, and Newtonian aspects of the theory of light and color. Farrar omits Book Seven of Biot's <i>Pr√©cis √âl√©mentaire de Physique Exp√©rimentale<i>, of which 100 pages devoted solely to the polarization of light. In his preface, Farrar argues that Biot's material on polarization is too detailed and off-target for the needs he considers his book will fill. Instead, Farrar adds a brief consideration of polarization to notes at the end of the text that cover aspects of optics not covered in Biot's text. This section on polarization is taken from Coddington's text of 1825 An Elementary Treatise on Optics. The French original and its English translation is entirely descriptive, without any of the elaborate mathematical analysis that usually defined French works. What analysis is present involves only elementary geometry. It is clear that Farrar imagined student who used the book would not have much if any background in mathematics.
BP_Reference(s): The Influence of French Mathematicians at the end of the Eighteenth Century upon the teaching of Mathematics in American Colleges|Simons, L.G.|<i>Isis <i>, Vol 15, No 1, 1931, pp 104-123.
BP_Title: An Experimental Treatise on Optics, comprehending The Leading Principles of the Science, and an Explanation of the more Important and Curious Optical Instrucments and Optical Phenomena. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: K√∂rner's detailed article on the preparation of flint glass and its use in making achromatic objectives.
BP_Description_1: Johann Christian Friedrich K√∂rner's detailed article on the preparation of flint glass and its use in making achromatic objectives. K√∂rner was an optical craftsman of great skill and gathered considerable experience in his quest to produce the flint glass necessary to make achromatic telescope objectives. Unlike Fraunhofer who kept his process secret and his glass for the optical instruments made at his optical institute, K√∂rner describes all the aspects of the full process in the parts of this article. An admirer of and follower of Goethe and Goethe took a keen interest in K√∂rner's glass making. K√∂rner also had the support of Grand Duke Carl August von Sachsen-Weimar. Goethe's cache and the Duke's money gave K√∂rner the support required to build a glass making facility at Jena. The first part of K√∂rner's article was published by K√§stner in 1826, the second in 1827.
BP_Description_2: K√∂rner's reports on his work to produce the flint glass for achromatic objectives and the process of grinding, figuring, and polishing that glass to make such lenses. The first part of the article (1826) describes the history of flint glass manufacture, mentioning Fraunhofer's work among others. K√∂rner gives chemical recipes for his glass and describes the process for melting and blank-making. The second part of the article (1827) describes the glass assessment process, lens design, grinding, figuring, polishing, and mounting.
BP_Reference(s): Platinum for Glass Making at Jena|<i>Platinum Metals Review<i>, Vol 38, No 2, 1994, pp 74-82.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Eduard Moritz Hahn (1781-1861) German mathematician, philosopher, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Hahn's German translation of Amondiue's <i>Essai d'un Cours √âÃÅleÃÅmentaire d'Optique<i> of 1826.
BP_Description_1: Eduard Moritz Hahn's translation of Amondiue's <i>Essai d'un Cours √âÃÅleÃÅmentaire d'Optique<i> of 1826. Hahn justifies his German translation of Amondieu's French work because of its concision, completeness, and even-handedness of treatment of the emission and wave theories of light without elaborate mathematics. He complains that many otherwise admirable German work on optics confuse verbosity with thoroughness. Through Hahn's translation, this is the first appearance of Fresnel's transverse wave theory of light in a German textbook--albeit without its elaborate mathematical underpinning. Interestingly, and perhaps confusingly, Hahn refers to the wave theory as Euler's--a reflection of the general labels 'Eulerian' and 'Newtonian' used to describe the wave and emission theories of light as they were discussed and debated in the second half of the 18th century. Johann Lambert used the same labels in his <i>Photometria<i> of 1760 to distinguish between the two theories.
BP_Description_2: Amondieu's book is in four parts: Presentation of most known optical phenomena; The wave theory of light and its explanation of these phenomena; The particle or emission theory of light and its explanation of these phenomena; Application of optics to meteorics and instruments. The first part describes: direct light, catoptrics, dioptrics, lenses, the eye and eye-function, chromatic dispersion, double refraction, polarization, diffraction, the thermal and chemical effects of the solar spectrum. The second and third parts present, respectively, the wave and emission theories explanations of reflection, refraction, dispersion, double refraction, polarization, and the thermal and chemical effects of the solar spectrum. The wave theory is that of Fresnel and the emission theory is Newtonian. The forth part briefly describes luminous atmospheric phenomena and optical instruments, particularly the application of achromatic lenses. Hahn adds some notes to this last section on instruments--considering it too brief given the importance of instruments.
BP_Reference(s): Joseph Louis Adrien Amondieu (1795-1849) Professeur de physique|In: Le Lyc√©e Clemenceau: 200 Ans d'Histoire, 2008.

BP_Short or Common Title: Nouvel essai sur la lumiere et les couleurs
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The second, elaborated and extended edition of Jean-Nicolas DeÃÅal's essay on optics.
BP_Description_1: The second edition of Jean-Nicolas DeÃÅal's essay on optics. In this the second edition, DeÃÅal elaborates and extends the text of the first edition. In the obsequious introduction directed to the French Academy, DeÃÅal makes clear he does not consider himself a scholar, only a compiler with, perhaps, a gift of explanation. A strange book, it is essentially an amateur's throw-back to the Cartesian-Newtonian debates of half a century earlier, with the author plumping for neither. No mention is made of the wave theory of light of the work of Fresnel, only Descartes percussive theory of light in the plenum, and Newton's theory of emission of light particles into empty space. In the end, DeÃÅal rejects the emission theory, allows that the wave theory can be admitted only in special cases. This leaves light as a luminiferous fluid emitted by sources. Editions appeared in 1823 and 1827.
BP_Description_2: The first part is a brief history of theories of light, ending with those of Descartes and Newton. Strangely, Huygens theory is considered a modification of Decartes'. This is followed by descriptions of a series of prismatic experiments and the colors produced. Then various and well-known objections and alternatives to the Newtonian theory are presented, particularly that of Euler. In the end, the emission theory is rejected and the wave theory only in special cases. DeÃÅal concludes that light must be a luminiferous fluid emitted by sources, capable of illuminating them and bringing about vision, with propagation that is 'instantaneous and successive,' and in which color is inherent. DeÃÅal's principle and constantly cited reference is the second edition of ReneÃÅ-Just HauÃày's <i>TraiteÃÅ √âleÃÅmentaire de Physique<i> of 1806, which was little changed from the first edition of 1803. This may explain the complete absence of the optical developments produced in the 20 years previous to DeÃÅal writing this book.
BP_Title: Nouvel essai sur la lumiere et les couleurs, renfermant la vraie theorie de ces grands phenomenes, fondee sur les resultats evidents et incontestables d'experiences infiniment simples. Ouvrage utile aux opticiens et aux peintres, et interessant pour tous ceux qui aiment a se render raison de leurs sensations. Second edition, corrigee et augmentee. Par J.-N. Deal.  " Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causes. Virgle, Georigiqu. Liv. II.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A revision of an earlier, more general paper, focusing the topic narrowly to the analysis of ray-systems and significantly extending the development and derivations. Though the table of contents lists three parts, the printed paper contains only the first, which deals with reflection.
BP_Description_1: William Rowan Hamilton's first published paper was read before the Royal Irish Academy on April 23, 1827. In many was it was a radical revision of the first paper he presented to the academy in 1824, On Caustics. The academy declined to publish it, complaining that (among other things)  ' . . . the discussions included in the Memoir are of a nature so very abstract, and the formulae so general, as to require that the reasonings by which some of the conclusions have been obtained should be more fully developed.' Adding to the difficulty was Hamilton's habit of providing no figures to aid the reader in understanding. The printed revised paper focused the topic narrowly to the analysis of ray-systems and significantly extending the development and derivation parts. Though the table of contents lists three parts, the printed paper contains only the first, which deals with reflection. The second and third parts on simple and extraordinary refraction were never printed in Hamilton's lifetime. Hamilton's paper set out a general theory of ray analysis based what he named the system's characteristic function. With it, any optical system's performance could be assessed. It was the first and most important development in what would eventually come to be called Hamiltonian Optics. For all its theoretical power and important implications, Hamilton's theory did not see practical application until it was linked to eikonal (image) and wave equations 70 years later.||This is the Offprint from the Transactions of the Royal Irish Academy, Vol 15 .
BP_Description_2: Hamilton begins with a general proof of the Theorem of Malus using the principle of least-action. It avoided the near-invincible tangle of mathematics that arose when trying to prove the theorem analytically from the laws of reflection and refraction or directly from the wave theory of light. Hamilton proved in full generality that if a system of rays is everywhere perpendicular to a surface (a real or imaginary surface or a geometric construct), the system of rays remains everywhere perpendicular to a (often different) surface after any number of reflections or refractions. From this, Hamilton derived what he named Characteristic Functions of an optical system. He gave algebraic expressions for reflection and refraction of a given system of rays involving any number of geometric surfaces. In the cases of simple surfaces of revolution this could be performed in closed form, for more complicated surfaces approximations were required. The generality of the procedure provided explicit expressions for optical aberrations.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Mathematical Papers of Sir William Rowan Hamilton, Volume I, Geometrical Optics <i>|Conway, A.W., Synge, J.L., editors|Cambrige University Press, 1931.||<i>A History of Optics from Greek Antiquity to the Nineteenth Century <i>||Darrigol, O.|Oxford, 2012, 326 pp, NB pp 264-271.||<i>An Introduction to Hamiltonian Optics <i>|Buchdahl, H.A.|Dover, 1993, 369 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A practical manual on all aspects of making a telescope with achromatic and aplanatic objectives.
BP_Description_1: Johann Joseph von Prechtl produced this practical manual on all aspects of making a telescope with achromatic and aplanatic objectives. A high craftsman himself, Prechtl was keen about the telescope and considered that 'the invention of the telescope and the achromatic in particular, is one of the greatest ornaments of human ingenuity.' Though Prechtl considers only algebra and geometry required to understand the practice of lens design, they are necessary if lens making is not be 'reduced to mere glass-cutting.' Prechtl presents Herschel's equations for lens design involving aperture, focal length, aberrations, and glass characteristics. Prechtl covers every step of the telescope-making process including all the materials, equipment, and instruments required. Prechtl was inspired by Joseph Fraunhofer and presents his legendary lenses as models and ideals, hoping in influence Viennese opticians. Prechtl believed that if a craftsman had good material and good practice, he could produce excellent lenses. Prechtl's book was widely used by opticians and astronomical observatory staff throughout the world; it was still being cited 50 years after its publication in the technical optical literature. In addition to the edition of 1828, WorldCat lists an earlier edition of 1823, but this is an error.
BP_Description_2: Prechtl's book is in five sections. 1: General consideration of refractive optics, single and multiple lenses, image formation. 2: Spherical and chromatic aberrations, how lens materials and figure are used to suppress aberrations. 3: Glass properties, index of refraction and chromatic dispersion, instruments for determining index of refraction and dispersion. 4: Characteristics of telescopes, relationships between aperture, brightness, magnification, field of view, multiple lens eyepieces. 5: Glass grinding by hand and machine, lens figuring and polishing, mounting and centering lenses, glass types and their manufacture. The book presents little theoretical development, only the result of Herschel's work in the form of algebraic lens design equations taken from his treatise on light. The material is practical in the extreme: all applications of the various lens equations are demonstrated in detailed examples, tables of data for glass are provided, parameters for a range of lenses and telescopes, and as a commercial example of what is practical, a list of apertures, focal lengths, and magnifications of ocular lenses available from Fraunhofer's Optical Institute.
BP_Reference(s): Buying the Dark Lines of the Solar Spectrum: Joseph Von Fraunhofer‚Äôs Standard for the Manufacture of Optical Glass|Jackson, M.W.|In: Scientific Credibility and Technical Standards in 19th and early 20th century Germany and Britain|Buchwald, J.Z., editor, Springer, 1997, pp 1-22.||Fraunhofer's work and its present-day significance|von Rohr, M.|<i>Transactions of the Optical Society <i>, Vol 28, No 5, 1925, pp 277-294.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A close French translation of Prechtl's practical manual for making dioptric instruments
BP_Description_1: A French translation of Johann Joseph von Prechtl's practical manual on all aspects of making a telescope with achromatic and aplanatic objectives. A high craftsman himself, Prechtl was keen about the telescope and considered that 'the invention of the telescope and the achromatic in particular, is one of the greatest ornaments of human ingenuity.' Though Prechtl considers only algebra and geometry required to understand the practice of lens design, they are necessary if lens making is not be 'reduced to mere glass-cutting.' Prechtl presents Herschel's equations for lens design involving aperture, focal length, aberrations, and glass characteristics. Prechtl covers every step of the telescope-making process including all the materials, equipment, and instruments required. Prechtl was inspired by Joseph Fraunhofer and presents his legendary lenses as models and ideals, hoping in influence Viennese opticians. Prechtl believed that if a craftsman had good material and good practice, he could produce excellent lenses. Prechtl's book was widely used by opticians and astronomical observatory staff throughout the world; it was still being cited 50 years after its publication in the technical optical literature. It seems likely that this translations was prepared for publication. A very close French translation, it reads as a fair copy in French of Prechtl's work of 1828. The manuscript is not dated and no printed French version of Prechtl's text is known.
BP_Description_2: Prechtl's book is in five sections. 1: General consideration of refractive optics, single and multiple lenses, image formation. 2: Spherical and chromatic aberrations, how lens materials and figure are used to suppress aberrations. 3: Glass properties, index of refraction and chromatic dispersion, instruments for determining index of refraction and dispersion. 4: Characteristics of telescopes, relationships between aperture, brightness, magnification, field of view, multiple lens eyepieces. 5: Glass grinding by hand and machine, lens figuring and polishing, mounting and centering lenses, glass types and their manufacture. The book presents little theoretical development, only the result of Herschel's work in the form of algebraic lens design equations taken from his treatise on light. The material is practical in the extreme: all applications of the various lens equations are demonstrated in detailed examples, tables of data for glass are provided, parameters for a range of lenses and telescopes, and as a commercial example of what is practical, a list of apertures, focal lengths, and magnifications of ocular lenses available from Fraunhofer's Optical Institute.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A treatise on optical instruments, principally the telescope, presenting the practical aspects of the theory of lens design for the Italian optics industry.
BP_Description_1: Giovanni Santini wrote this treatise on optical instruments, principally the telescope, to present the practical aspects of the theory of lens design for the Italian optics industry. Santini chose to base his work on that of Leonhard Euler and Georg Simon Kl√ºgel of 50 years earlier. He was either unaware or chose not to consider the work of George Biddell Airy, William Herschel, and others. Santini did not consider himself an inventor or originator, rather he wrote the fill the need he saw for a work that both gathered together the most important aspect of optical theory and presented it is a manner that supported practical application. Something for both the scholar and the optician. The two volumes separate the theory and development of lens design and construction, from descriptions of telescopes and microscopes. The material is entirely analytic, the practical aspects of glass cutting, grinding, figuring, and polishing are not considered. Santini's work, especially volume 1, was a significant influence on Italian opticians, particularly Giovanni Battista Amici and Ottaviano Fabrizio Mossotti. It was also influential with Joseph Johann Littrow at the Vienna observatory.
BP_Description_2: Santini separated the material into two volumes: the theory and practice of lens design, and descriptions of telescopes and microscopes. Volume 1: Glass properties and their measurement; single lens analysis; multiple lenses, their images, magnification, and clarity; spherical and chromatic aberrations; correcting off-optical-axis chromatic aberration; design and construction of achromatic multi-lens objective; spherical mirror. Volume II: General aspects of telescopes; Galilean telescopes; astronomical telescopes with multi-lens eye-pieces; terrestrial telescopes; micrometers and their use; catadioptric telescopes; simple and compound microscopes; instruments including the camera obscura, the lighthouse, magic lantern, phantasmagoria, diorama, and the kaleidoscope. The material in Volume I includes the use of Fraunhofer lines for measuring dispersion and the use of Euler's on-optical-axis analysis of aberrations augmented with the off-axis extensions of Kl√ºgel for general lens analysis. At all stages, the theory is applied to practical problems that are worked out in detail, particularly for the achromatic objective. The material in Volume II is equally analytic, with an emphasis on the analysis and properties of practical optical instruments.
BP_Reference(s): The production of achromatic objectives in the first half of the nineteenth century: the contribution of Giovanni Battista Amici|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana <i>, Vol 61, 1990,  pp 829-875, NB 837-839.||<i>Giovanni Santini: la sua vita e le sue opere <i>|Lorenzoni, G.|Tipografia del Seminario, Padua, 1877, 69 p.|http://books.google.com/books?id=yAFpnQAACAAJ

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Issues from the Library of Useful Knowledge delating with optics, double refraction, polarization, and Newtonian optics
BP_Description_1: In 1825 Henry Peter Brougham, 1st Baron Brougham and Vaux, along with Matthew Davenport Hill, founded <i>The Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge<i> to create a comprehensive and inexpensive range of educational literature for the masses. To oversee and publish this literature, Brougham appointed Charles Knight. He published a number of weekly and biweekly periodicals and pamphlets and a series of biweekly, sixpenny pamphlets:  The Library of Useful Knowledge. By 1829, the time of these publications on optics, each issue of these pamphlets was selling about 6000 copies. As evidenced by these issues devoted to optics, The Library of Useful Knowledge did not engage in political or religious issues but rather focused on popularizing other areas of knowledge.||As with the present topics, some required more than one issue to cover and in that case the signatures and pagination were consecutive, so that the issue could later be be gathered together to form a complete 'chapter.' The two 'chapters' on optics, which included the present issues on optics and double refraction, were gathered together along with issues that dealt with other topics, and at the end of 1829 formed  <i>Natural Philosophy<i>, a book published by the Society. The two issues on Newton's Optics became part of the Society's <i>Natural Philosophy, Vol 2.<i>  It is know that David Brewster wrote the two issues on Optics and is very likely the author of the issues on <i>Double Refraction and Polarisation<i>, and <i>Newton's Optics<i>. The Society eventually published six volumes in its series on Natural Philosophy.
BP_Description_2: The chapter on Optics gives a general overview of optics. It contains sections on: Light and its properties; Reflection, refraction, and dispersion: Lenses and elementary geometric optics; Plane and curved mirrors: Chromatics, dispersion, and achromatic lenses; Spectra; The eye and its function; Visual perception; The Rainbow, halos, atmospheric illusions, colors in nature. The chapter on double refraction and polarization is much more details and technical. It contains sections on: Single and double refraction; Crystals and laws of double refraction; Polarization; Production of polarized light; Detection of polarized light; Crystals and polarization; Chromatic polarization; Materials and polarization, coloration, detection. The chapter on Newton's optics is a summary of by-then the standard material on prismatic color and the heterogeneity of white light.||The material is detailed, descriptive, and elementary. Very little mathematics is used, and that never rises above simple algebra and ratios. The end of each chapters presents a list of references for further study.
BP_Reference(s): The World Wide Web of the Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge: On the Global Circulation of Broughamite Educational Literature, 1826‚Äì1848|Johansen, T.P.|<i>Victorian Periodicals Review<i>, Vol 50, No 4, 2017, pp 703-720.

BP_Short or Common Title: A Treatise on the Reflexion and Refraction of Light
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook on optics presenting the newest theories in optics and their application. It presents modern geometrical optics as a cogent, systematic whole, in a thorough and deeply mathematical manner.
BP_Description_1: Henry Coddington wrote this textbook on optics to present the newest theories in optics that were applicable to 'either the construction of telescopes and other optical instruments, or to the explanation of natural phaenomena.' Coddington draws heavily from earlier geometrical optics works: Barrow, Newton, Herschel, Young, the Encyclopedia Britannica, and most extensively Airy. Coddington presents modern geometrical optics as a  cogent, systematic whole. Though deeply mathematical, the book avoids digressions and inessential detail. Having drawn material from many sources, Coddington is forced to impose new but uniform notation, for which he apologizes in his preface. But his work proved so influential that his notation continues to be used. In each chapter, Coddington begins with fundamentals and builds generality and complexity in succeeding sections. The self-studying student is warned in Preface that the tyro should skip the advanced sections the first time through. This was one of the characteristics that made the book so influential. Coddingtion was not just a compiler; his generalizations, extensions, simplification, and (perhaps most importantly) the algebrization of earlier developments were a significant advance in geometrical optics. Importantly, from this book comes the eponymous 'Coddington Equations,' the 'Coddington Shape and Position Factors,' and the 'Coddington Lens.' Coddington was the first of provide a complete analysis of astigmatism and his equations are still used extensively in analysis and in ophthalmic lens design. He was also the first to formulate the 'circle of confusion' and measure of lens performance for telescopes. The books was long used as a university textbook and was influential among English-reading opticians.
BP_Description_2: Coddington's material is in seven chapters. 1: Reflection, spherical mirrors, aberrations, equations of aberrations, foci and image equations. 2: Refraction of homogeneous light, plane surfaces, spherical surfaces, aberrations, equations of aberrations, foci and image equations, combined refractions, prisms, lenses, types of lenses, lens equations, aberrations, equations of aberrations, combined lenses. 3: Refraction combined with Reflection. 4: Images from mirrors and lenses, magnification, brightness. 5: Caustics. 6: Chromatic dispersion, measuring dispersion, approximations for dispersion, achromatic lens analysis, multiple achromatic lens systems analysis, advanced theory of the rainbow. 7: Atmospheric refraction. The material is detailed and highly analytic and most results are derived, rather than simply presented, leading to long, detailed mathematical developments. The accompanying figures are essential to following the text.
BP_Reference(s): A historical perspective on understanding optical aberrations|Johnson, R.B.|In:  <i>Lens Design: A Critical Review, Proceedings <i>|SPIE, 1992, https://doi.org/10.1117/12.131966||Optical designing as an art|Taylor, H.D.|<i>Transactions of the Optical Society<i>, Vol 24, No 3, 1923, pp 143-167.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Pierre Frabcius Verhulst (1804-1849) Belgian-born Dutch mathematician, professor at the University of Ghent. And Adolphe Quetelet (1796-1874) Belgian astronomer, mathematician.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Verhulst's French translation of Herschel's 1827 article 'Light' written for the Encyclopedia Metropolitana. Widely regarded as a magisterial summary of physical optics; that is, the nature and properties of light.
BP_Description_1: John Frederick William Herschel's article 'Light' was composed in 1827 and appeared in Volume 2 of Mixed Sciences, Second Division (Volume 4 in the entire series), of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i> in 1830. But the article itself was privately distributed beginning in 1828 and had circulated widely before its appearance in the <i>Encyclop√¶dia<i>. It was immediately recognized both in England and on the continent as a magisterial summary of physical optics; that is, the nature and properties of light. Though Herschel considered his work an 'essay', it was 243 quarto pages with additional plates and an index, and was treated as a monograph in its subsequent and immediate reprintings and translations. Pierre Frabcius Verhulst produced this French translation aided by Adolphe Quetelet. The translation was undertaken because the complete encyclopedia was expensive and of very uneven quality, and so access to important parts of it was difficult. Quetelet and Verhulst considered the extraction and translation of Herschel's essay a necessity for French science because it was 'the most complete treatise on this important part of physics.' The translation corrected the many typographical errors in the first English printing (for which it was notorious), duplicated nearly all of the mathematics, benefited from corrections provided by Herschel himself, and ended with a long supplement by Quetelet containing notes, commentary, and reprint of articles related to then-recent developments in optics. Though the translation of the full article was completed, and the first volume published in 1829, problems with the published delayed the second volume‚Äôs appearance for nearly four years. It was this interval that prompted Quetelet to write  his supplement.
BP_Description_2: Herschel's essay is in four parts: Unpolarized Light, Chromatics, Theories of Light, Polarized Light. 1: Unpolarized Light including photometry, reflection from plane and curved surfaces, refraction at plane and curved surfaces, aberrations, images from lenses, the eye and vision. 2: Chromatics including dispersion, achromatic lenses, extinction from propagation in transparent media. 3: Theories of Light including Newtonian or corpuscular theory, general undulatory theory, interference, colors from thin and thick plates, diffraction. 4: Polarized Light including double refraction, interaction of polarized light, reflection of polarized light, refraction of polarized light, application of the undulatory theory, light in crystals, light's interaction with materials, properties of glass, colors of bodies, calorific and chemical rays in the solar spectrum. Herschel's treatments of the undulatory theory of light is a full statement of Fresnel's theory and the best presentation of the wave theory for 10 years after it appeared.
BP_Reference(s):
‚ÅÇ <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 291-296.||The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role
of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132.

BP_Short or Common Title: Treatise On Optics [Drawn up for the Edinburgh Encyclopaedia]
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Brewster's anonymous entry on optics for Volume XV of the Edinburgh Encyclopaedia.
BP_Description_1: This is David Brewster's anonymous entry for Volume XV of the <i>Edinburgh Encyclopaedia<i> which appeared in 1830. As was common among the several competing encyclopedias of the time, articles were often not summaries of the long agreed upon aspects of a topic, but included the very latest developments. Such was certainly the case with Brewster's article on optics. Since he did not consider the question between corpuscular and wave theories settled, the physical optics part of the article is theoretical; the other aspects are much more practical and include extensive tables of optical data, much of it from Brewster's own research. This was his first attempt at a complete summary of optics and would be a template of sorts for his subsequent mathematics-expunged textbook. Though this and other of Brewster's entries in the <i>Edinburgh Encyclopaedia<i> were of high quality and had the audience afforded by readers of the Encyclopaedia, it did not obtain the wide-spread readership and influence that Peter Barlow's article 'Optics' and J.F.W. Herschel's article 'Light' did in the <i>Encyclopaedia Metropolitana<i>.||Joseph Parker published an edited American Edition of the <i>Encyclopaedia<i> at Philadelphai in 1832.
BP_Description_2: Brewster's article begins with an extended history of optics (39 pages), from the Ancients up to Fresnel, Herschel, and Brewster's own research. Interestingly, Brewster settles a few scores with the French regarding priority for the discovery of certain optical phenomena. Part I (114 pages) covers the theory of optics including: dioptrics, catoptrics, chromatics, diffraction, thin and thick plates, double refraction and polarization. Part II (13 pages) covers the application of optics to natural phenomena including: the eye and vision, the rainbow, halos and coronas, atmospheric refraction, atmospheric and shadow colors, colors of natural bodies, photometry. Part III (35 pages) covers optical instruments and their construction including: magnifying and looking glass, anamorphosis refractors, mirrors, spectacles, camera obscura, magic lantern, microscope, microscope improvements, refracting and reflecting telescopes, achromatic objectives, analysis of achromatic and aplanatic lenses, analysis of telescope characteristics, photometers, measuring refractive index, optometer,  lens cutting, grinding, figuring, and polishing. The history material is important in part because it records in relative detail the development of the corpuscular and wave theories of light up to the time of the writing. The material on physical optics is extensive, detailed, analytic and presents both the corpuscular and wave theories with attempted even-handedness. Nevertheless, Brewster's preference for the corpuscular theory is clear. Material on geometric optics is limited to aspects of lens design. Though ostensibly for the general reader, the article is more of a research report or optics handbook, unsparing in its detailed mathematical developments and extensive tables of optical properties of materials.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Encyclopaedic Visions: Scientific Dictionaries and Enlightenment Culture<i>|Yeo, R.|Cambridge Universtiy Press, 2001, 341 pp, NB: pp 270-277.
BP_Title: Treatise On Optics, Drawn up for the Edinburgh Encyclopaedia.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish physicist, mathematician, astronomer, science historian. Famed for his optics work, defense of Isaad Newton, invention of the kaleidoscope.

BP_Short or Common Title: Memoire sur la Theorie de la lumiere
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: This memoir describes the first steps Cauchy took in the development of a theory of the luminiferous aether, extending and making more rigorous the initial conception by Fresnel.
BP_Description_1: Augustin-Louis Cauchy produced this very brief memoir to describe conditions he found necessary for the solution of the set of differential equations describing wave surfaces in birefringent materials. The near-complete success of Fresnel's theory of transverse waves and polarization brought to the fore the question as to the medium in which and the mechanism by which the wave moved. Fresnel had adopted the idea of a luminiferous aether that consisted of a 3-dimensional lattice of points or 'molecules' that interacted with by near-range forces. From this fundamentally mechanical conception of the aether and an unproved proposition regarding linear displacements, Fresnel derived expressions for his wave surfaces. Cauchy describes his reformulation of Fresnel's lattice mechanics and establishes conditions for the governing equations in conditions of birefringence. This memoir describes the first steps Cauchy took in the development of a theory of the luminiferous aether which would engage him for 20 years. This memoir was presented to the French Academy in June of 1830 which eventually appeared in the Bulletin de F√©russac. Cauchy also had it printed as a separate brochure by de Bure Fr√®res, the present edition, which was his last publication before his exile to Prague.
BP_Description_2: Cauchy established a rigorous theory of 3-dimension lattice dynamics involving sets of linear differential equations, expressed in vector-matrix form, and used the mathematical technique of eigenvectors and eigenvalues to solve the systems of equations. The memoir does not explicitly state the eigenvector/value technique, but its use can be inferred. The conditions for the parameters of the systems of equations if they are to yield wave surfaces are stated.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Optics and the Theory of the Punctiform Ether|Buchwald, J.Z.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 21, 1980, pp 245-274.
BP_Title: Memoire sur la Theorie de la lumiere, par M. Augustin-Louis Cauchy, Membre de L'Academie Des Sciences.
BP_Title English Translation: Memorie on the Theory of Light, by Mr. Augustin-Louis Cauchy, Member of the Academy of Sciences.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, mathematical physicist, engineer. Profound mathematician, prolific author, sometime Professor at the √âcole Polytechnique.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Stiched In Printed Title Wrapper

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First edition of Comstock's elementary but encyclopedic manual of natural philosophy written expressly for teaching. One of the most widely-used textbook in American schools in the first half of the 19th century.
BP_Description_1: Comstock makes clear in his Preface why he wrote his textbook. His consultation with experienced teachers revealed the lack of an adequate, up-to-date book on natural philosophy for use in schools. The texts on natural philosophy in use at the time were either translations of European texts or British imports, were in the form of conversations between teacher and pupil, and did not cover then-modern developments. Comstock adopted a method is strictly presentational--no derivations are provided--and the style is clear and uses simple language. Each section begins with the definition of words peculiar to the topic, followed by statements of general principles. There are often descriptions of machines, devices, or instruments that either demonstrate the principles or incorporate them. In addition, Comstock explicitly avoided the use of what he felt were overly complex diagrams, bristling with labels and letters. He chose, rather, to both simplify and increase the number of figures in the text. The simplicity of language, descriptive style, and large number of simple figures made the text popular and widely used In America for 40 years.||Editions appeared at Hartford in 1830, 1831, 1834, 1841, and at New York in 1836, 1837, 1838, 1839, 1841, 1843, 1844, 1845, 1846, 1847, 1848, 1851, 1852, 1854, 1856, 1860, 1863, 1864, 1869, and 1871.
BP_Description_2: Comstock's text contains a Preface and nine sections: Properties of Bodies--general physics (62 pages); Mechanics (27 pages); Hydrostatics (15 pages); Hydraulics (7 pages); Pneumatics (19 pages); Acoustics (9 pages); Optics (58 pages); Astronomy (75 pages); Electricity (23 pages); and Magnetism (4 pages). The section on optics establishes light as a substance emitted by luminous objects and rays as 'a single line of light.' Rays are then used to define and give examples of refraction and reflection. Plane and spherical mirrors are described using rays and simple geometric optics, showing focusing and image formation. The operation of convex and concave lenses are described in the same manner. The function of lenses is used to explain vision and to show the cause and correction of indistinct vision. Image formation and magnification by multiple lenses is used to describe the microscope and refracting telescope. The reflecting telescope and the camera obscura is also described. The optics section ends with a description of Newton's theory of color and its use in explaining the rainbow.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Stories of Nineteenth Century American Science Textbook Writers and the Concept of Physics and Chemical Change<i>|Palmer, W.P.|ResearchGate.net: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/William_Palmer8/publication/325472544||<i>The science of God's creation: Popular science and Christianity in the early republic<i>|Santoro, L.A.|Disseration, University of Delaware, 2011, 215 pp, NB: pp 62-76.
BP_Title: A System of Natural Philosophy; in which the Principles of Mechanics, Acoustics, Hydrostatics, Optics, Hydraulics, Astronomy, Pneumatics, Electricity, and Magnetism are Familiarly Explained, and Illumstrated by more than Two Hundred engravings. To which are added Questions for the Examinations of the Pupils. Designed for the use of Schools and Acadmies. By J.L. Comstock, M.D.
BP_Biographical Statement: American surgeon, teacher, editor. Important textbook author.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed C.W. Macomber
