BP_Short or Common Title: An Experimental Inquiry into the Number and Properties of the Primary Colours
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Crum, coming from a background of textile dying and pigments, presents the Aristotelian/Goethean idea that color is the result of the mixing of light and dark. It is an example of the ongoing dichotomy of romanticism's artistic color experiences and the theory built from them, and the chromatic physical optics originating with Newton.
BP_Description_1: Walter Crum produced this brief treatise color coming from a background of textile dying and pigments in 1822. Though Goethe is never mentioned, Crum presents the Aristotelian/Goethean idea that color is the result of the mixing of light and dark. Experiments are presented and their results are interpreted to support the basic idea and to attempt to soften, if not disprove, the Newtonian interpretation of prismatic colors. Crum both examined light dispersed by prism and how colors arose when view through a prism. Crum's treatise is an example of the ongoing dichotomy of romanticism's artistic color experiences and the theory built from them, and the chromatic physical optics originating with Newton. It also makes clear the difference between the industrial and commercial need to understand color and the philosopher's theories.  Crum's work is a condensation of part of the longer work by Joseph Reade, <i>Experimental Outlines for a New Theory of Colours, Light & Vision<i>, of 1816. After 1822, Crum was made aware of Reade's work, and finding the two works so similar decided not to publish. But the scant attention Reade's work attracted eventually prompted Crum to publish his own work. Crum was a significant figure in the textile dying and printing industry and his work and ideas were widely influential.
BP_Description_2: Crum presents experiments most of which are exercises in color perception on complex fields. The results are marshaled to support his principle ideas. 1: There are three primary colors, red, blue, and yellow. 2: Color is the result of the mixing of light and dark, with colors being 'drawn out' of dark by the presence of light. 3: The prismatic colors are not immutable, as Newton claimed.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Science Versus Practice: Chemistry in Victorian Britain<i>|Bud, R., Roberts, G.K.|Manchester University Press, 1984, 243 pp, NB pp 36-37, 121.||The Influence of Demand on the Emergence of the Dye Industry. The Roles of Chemists and Colourists|Homburg, E.|<i>Coloration Technology<i>, Vol 99, No 11, 1983, pp 325-333.
BP_Title: An Experimental Inquiry into the Number and Properties of the Primary Colours and the Source of Colour in the Prism. By Walter Crum, Esqu.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish chemist, businessman. Worked in the  business of printing and dying textiles.
BP_Provenance: Dedication by Crum to Alexander Grahm
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/4 Green Morocco Over Drab Boards Rebacked

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A narrowly practical treatise on dioptrics specifically for the construction of astronomical telescopes.
BP_Description_1: Johann Joseph Littrow's wrote this narrowly practical treatise on dioptrics specifically for the construction of astronomical telescopes. He notes that other than Santini's and Prechtl's, there had been few useful works on telescope lenses since Georg Simon Kl√ºgel's of half a century earlier. But in particular, there were very few works by practicing astronomers who were also opticians, tempering theory with practice in the spirit of Johannes Kepler and Christian Huygens. Littrow was well-know on the continent and in England; both for his astronomy and his optical work, having publishing several important works in the Memoirs of the Royal Astronomical Society of London, all of which display Littrow's practical optical experience and mathematical prowess.||Littrow sets the scope of his work based on what he considers practical constraints. In this regard, he notes the futility of working on either a telescope's objective or ocular separately, attempting to perfect either with regard to aberrations. He also considers objective and ocular lens systems with three or more lenses as superfluous, citing the perfection Fraunhofer achieved with his two-lens elements. Within this scope, Littrow gathers developments since Kl√ºgel's time and add some of his own. Littrow's book was a standard telescope lens reference for decades; until the development of telescope mirrors had them surpass the performance of lenses in all aspects.
BP_Description_2: Litttrow's text is in three parts: Theory of telescope objectives, theory of telescope oculars, and a brief history of optics. The theory of telescope objectives includes: prism and lens refraction, spherical and chromatic aberrations, four methods for designing and producing 2-lens objectives using equations from Euler, Kl√ºgel, Herschel, and himself. The theory of telescope oculars includes: ray tracing through multiple lenses, telescopes in general, telescopes with multiple lenses, simple lenses, telescopes with 2, 3, 4, and 5 lenses, accommodating the objectives and oculars, micrometers, microscopes, mirror and their images. The brief history of optics includes: the Greeks, Middle Ages, Kepler, Newton, Euler and Dollond, the 19th century. Littrow's text adopts the geometrical optical analyses of Euler, Kl√ºgel, Herschel, and his own. Most of the text is a detailed application of these to practical telescope objective and ocular design, with elaborate and complete examples. Littrow treats corrections for spherical and chromatic aberrations in only their simplest form, considering most high-order correction to be impractical.
BP_Reference(s): √úber die Achromasie optischer Apparate|Kr√ºss, H.|<i>Astronomische Nachrichten<i>, Vol 90, no 16, 1877, pp 241-256.||On Barlow's New Telescope|Littrow, J.J.|<i>Memoirs of the Astronomical Society of London<i>, Vol 4, 1830, pp 481-493.
BP_Title: Dioptrik oder Anleitung zur Verfertigung der Fernrohre. Von J.J. Littrow, Director der Sternwarte und O. O. Professor der Astronomie an der k. k. Universitat in Wien, Ritter des Kais. Russ. St. Annaordens der zweyten Klasse, Mitglied der k. k. Landwirthschafts-Gesellshcaft in Wien, der astronomischen Gesellschaft in London, der Academie der Wissenschafter in St. Petersburg, Prag, Krakau und Palermo, Ehrenmitglied der k. Universitat in Kasan etc.
BP_Title English Translation: Dioptrics, or Guidance for the Making of Telescopes. By J.J. Littrow, Director of the Observatory and Professor in Ordinary of Astronomy in the Royal Imperial University of Vienna, Knight of the Russian Imperial Order of St. Annaordens, Second Class, Member of the Royal Imperial Agricultural Society of Vienna, the Astronomical Society of London, the Academies of Science of St. Petersburg, Prague, Krackau, and Palermo, Honorary Member of the Imperial University at Kasan, etc.
BP_Biographical Statement: Austrian astronomer, celestial cartographer. Professor of astronomy at the University of Vienna and director of its observatory. Sometimes confused with his son Karl Ludwig Littrow, also an astronomer, who succeeded him as the Vienna observatory's director.

BP_Short or Common Title: On the Undulatory Theory of Optics, In Mathematical Tracts (a)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A long essay on the wave theory of light. Airy separates the simpler assumptions, which he calls the geometrical part of the wave theory and and which he considers certain, from what he calls the mechanical part of the theory, such as Cauchy's assumption of the aether as a 3-dimentional lattice of molecules--which he considers very uncertain.
BP_Description_1: George Biddell Airy wrote this long essay on the wave theory of light based on same certainty with which he held the theory of gravity. Of the wave theory of light Air held '... that it is certainly true, and that, by mathematical operations of general elegance, it leads to results of great interest. With regard to the evidence for this theory; if the simplicity of a hypothesis, which explains with accuracy a vast variety of phaenomena of the most complicated kind, can be considered a proof of its correctness, I believe there is no physical theory so firmly established as the theory in question.' Airy was one of the earliest British natural philosophers to accept the wave theory and he wrote extensively in its support. The current essay brought together aspects of the theory Airy considered to be its core, and presented them with his typical clear yet detailed manner. He believed that experimental data and phenomena needed to be considered along with mathematical theory; to that end Airy personally performed each experiment described in the essay. Interestingly, Airy separates the simpler assumptions  in the theory that have proven to be powerfully predictive--transverse waves, varying speeds, and such, all of which he calls the geometrical part of the wave theory--from what he calls the mechanical part of the theory--Cauchy's assumption of the aether as a 3-dimentional lattice and everything that followed from that. That later he considered probable but 'far from certain.' The essay appeared in the editions of the Mathematical Tracts of 1831, 1842, and 1858. It appeared as a separate book in 1866 and 1877. The essay did not appear in the first edition of the Mathematical Tracts of 1826.
BP_Description_2: Airy's Essay is in several unlabeled sections. 1: General theory of undulations including the theory and mathematics of waves, wave interference, wave length, wave phase. 2: Application of wave theory to unpolarized light, including diffraction pattern positions and intensities, wave fronts, reflection, refraction, reflection and refraction both, unequal (chromatic) refraction.  3: Experiments involving optical phenomena including interference fringes, chromatic interference, prismatic interference, phase shifting with glass plates, thin plates, Newton's rings, diffraction fringes, diffraction from a rectangular aperture, colored fringes, lenses and apertures and wire gratings, diffraction spectra. 4: Double refraction including crystal properties, experiments with polarized light, relation to the hypothesis of the nature of light, transverse waves, general explanation of double refraction, conical refraction. 5: Aspects of the wave theory including predicted values of reflection from glass, total internal reflection, circularly and elliptically polarized light, reflection from metals, colored polarization, polarization in crystals with multiple axes. The material is detailed and highly analytic, with experimental optical phenomena and mathematical developments closely coupled.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132.
BP_Title: On the Undulatory Theory of Optics. In: Mathematical tracts on the Lunar and Planetary Theories, The Figure of the Earth, Precession and Nutation, The Calculus of Variations, and The Undulatory Theory of Optics. Designed for the use of Students in the University. By George Biddell Airy, M.A. Late Fellow of Trinity College and Plumian Professor of Astronomy and Experimental Philosophy in the University of Cambridge. Second Edition.
BP_Biographical Statement: British mathematician, astronomer. Made important advances as Astronomer Royal.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the Laboratory of Mineralogy in the University of Oxford. Bookplate of James Walker, Christ Church. Signature of I. G. Howes Jr.

BP_Short or Common Title: Optics. Part of The Cabinet Cyclop√¶dia
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Brewster's elementary text as part of Dionysius Lardner's series <i>The Cabinet Cyclopedia<i>. He reworked much of the material in the optics article he wrote for the Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, as well as his supplement to Ferguson.
BP_Description_1: David Brewster wrote this elementary text as part of Dionysius Lardner's series <i>The Cabinet Cyclopedia<i>. Brewster had produced the long article on optics for the <i>Edinburgh Encyclopaedia<i> the previous year  and updated and augmented three editions of Ferguson's <i>Lectures on Select Subjects<i> between 1803 and 1823, so he had a practiced idea of what should be in a general exposition of optics for the lay reader. He reworked much of the material in the 1823 edition of his supplement to Ferguson. The composition is, as might be expected from Bewster's interest and commitment to the emission theory of light, heavily weighted to physical optics and the emission theory of light. It is also freighted with detailed descriptions of many of Brewster's experiments, about which Baden Powell would later comment on Brewster's text: '... and in regard to the more recondite experimental results, the student would feel rather overwhelmed with the multitude of details, than enlightened by a view of general truths.'  Editions appeared at London in 1831 and 1853, at Philadelphia in 1833 and 1841, and a German translation at Leipzig in 1836.
BP_Description_2: Brewster's treatise is in four parts: Reflection and refraction of light; Physical optics; Natural optical phenomena; Optical instruments. 1: Reflection and refraction of light includes plain and spherical mirrors, images from mirrors, refraction in general, lenses, rays convex and concave lenses, meniscus lenses, images from lenses, magnification, spherical aberrations.  2: Physical optics includes chromatic heterogeneity, dispersion, achromatic lenses, solar spectrum, diffraction, colors from thin and thick plates, double refraction, polarized light and polarization effects of different materials. 3: Natural optical phenomena includes the rainbow, halos and coronae, parahelia, object colors, the eye and eye-function, colored shadows. 4: Optical instruments includes mirrored instruments, single and compound lenses, prisms and magnifiers, magic lantern and camera lucida, microscopes, telescopes, achromatic telescopes. The material is weighted heavily to physical optics: 60 pages are devoted to geometric optics, 200 pages to physical optics, 40 pages to natural phenomena, and 50 pages to optical instruments. Much of the physical optics section is filled with reports of the many investigations Brewster made on light interacting with crystals and other materials. The imbalance in level of detail, compared to that in the geometrical optics section is striking; chromatic aberration, for example, is barely touched upon. The whole of the material is descriptive, with only elementary geometry used. The physical optics material is entirely Newtonian, adhering to the emission theory of light; explaining, for example, interference by appeal to fits of easy reflection and transmission.
BP_Reference(s): Scientific Revolutions and Scientific Rationality: The Case of the "Elderly Holdout"|Worroll, J.|In: <i>Minnesota Studies in the Philosophy of Science, Vol XIV, Scientific Theories<i>|Savage, W., editor|University of Minnesota Press, 1990, 410 pp, pp 319-354.
BP_Title: The Cabinet Cyclopaedia. Conducted by the Rev. Dionysius Lardner, LL.D. F.R.S. L.&E. M.R.I.A. F.R.A.S. F.L.S. F.Z.S. Hon. F.C.P.S. &c. &c. Assisted by Eminent Literary and Scientific Men. Natural Philosophy. Optics. By David Brewster, LL.D. F.R.S. &c.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish physicist, mathematician, astronomer, science historian. Famed for his optics work, defense of Isaad Newton, invention of the kaleidoscope.
BP_Publisher or Seller: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown, & Green, and John Taylor

BP_Short or Common Title: M√©moire sur la loi des modifications que la r√©flexion imprime √† la lumi√®re polaris√©e
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The printing of Fresnel's paper presented to the Acad√©mie on partial and total internal reflection
BP_Description_1: In January 1823 Fresnel read to the French Acad√©mie his final treatment of partial and total internal reflection. The full paper did not appear in the memoires of the Acad√©mie, only an abstract appeared in 1823 and 1825, and the paper was thought to be lost. After the death of Joseph Fourier in 1830, Fresnel's paper was found among Fourier's. It is conjectured that Fresnel had give the work to Fourier for review, but by that time Fourier was ill and, evidently, the review never took place. Francois Aragot and Joseph Louis Guy-Lussac, editors of the <i>Annales de Chimie et de Physique<i> printed it immediately after it was rediscovered. They added a footnote: 'This memoir, which was lost, has just been found in the papers of M. Fourier. As it is known only by extracts that are quite inadequate, we hasten to enrich the Annals.'
BP_Description_2: Fresnel's analysis show his mastery of the mathematics of wave analysis and his insight into the significance of phase shifts. It was this that provided him with the correct formulation for total internal reflection.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ  <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light <i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 387-394.||Memoir on the Diffraction of Light 'Crowned' by the French Academy of Sciences in 1819 by A. Fresnel|Crew, H., translator|In:  <i>The Wave Theory of Light, Memoirs of Huygens, Young, and Fresnel <i>|American Book Co, New York, 1900|Reissued by Kessinger Publishing, 2010, 162 p.
BP_Title: M√©moire sur la loi des modifications que la r√©flexion imprime √† la lumi√®re polaris√©e. In: <i>Annales de Chimie et de Physique<i> , Mars, 1831, pp 225-264.

BP_Biographical Statement: French engineer, physicist, experimentalist. Worked on optics, theoretical and practical.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Johann Karl Eduard  Schmidt
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Schmidt's very close German translation of Herschel's 1827 article 'Light' written for the <i>Encyclopedia Metropolitana<i>. Widely regarded as a magisterial summary of physical optics; that is, the nature and properties of light.
BP_Description_1: John Frederick William Herschel's article Light was composed in 1827 and appeared in Volume 2 of Mixed Sciences, Second Division (Volume 4 in the entire series), of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i> in 1830. But the article itself was  privately distributed beginning in 1828 and had circulated widely before its appearance in the Encyclopaedia. It was immediately recognized both in England and on the continent as a magisterial summary of physical optics; that is, the nature and properties of light. Though Herschel considered his work an 'essay', it was 243 quarto pages with additional plates and an index, and was treated as a monograph in its subsequent and immediate reprintings and translations. Johann Karl Eduard  Schmidt produced this very close German translation. duplicating all of Herschel's mathematics. Schmidt knew the material well and would eventually write his own textbooks in optics, as well as on astronomy, mathematics, physical geography, mechanics, and aerodynamics. Schmidt's translation was the first full presentation of Fresnel's wave theory of light in German.
BP_Description_2: Herschel's essay is in four parts: Unpolarized Light, Chromatics, Theories of Light, Polarized Light. 1: Unpolarized Light including photometry, reflection from plane and curved surfaces, refraction at plane and curved surfaces, aberrations, images from lenses, the eye and vision. 2: Chromatics including dispersion, achromatic lenses, extinction from propagation in transparent media. 3: Theories of Light including Newtonian or corpuscular theory, general undulatory theory, interference, colors from thin and thick plates, diffraction. 4: Polarized Light including double refraction, interaction of polarized light, reflection of polarized light, refraction of polarized light, application of the undulatory theory, light in crystals, light's interaction with materials, properties of glass, colors of bodies, calorific and chemical rays in the solar spectrum. Herschel's treatments of the undulatory theory of light is a full statement of Fresnel's theory and the best presentation of the wave theory for 10 years after it appeared.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 291-296.||The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132.
BP_Title: Vom Licht. Bearbeitet von J.F.W. Herschel. Ausdem Engoischen ubersekt von Dr. J.C. Eduard Schmidt, Privatdocent auf der Universitat in Gottingen. Mit 11 Lithographirten Tafeln.
BP_Title English Translation: On Light. By J.F.W. Herschel. Translated from the English by Dr. J.C. Eduard Schmidt, Private Lecturer in the University of Gottingen.
BP_Biographical Statement: English polymath, astronomer, mathematician, chemist. Asiduous astronomical observer, practical optician, scientific author.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of Dr. Ernst Heiss on free endpaper
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1831 Herschel - Vom Licht - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: A Treatise on Light and Vision
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook on physical and geometric optics, presenting contemporary experimental results and mathematical analyses, with an emphasis on their application to the design of optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: Lloyd worked on the manuscript for his <i>Treatise on Light and Vision<i> while a junior (that is, teaching) fellow Trinity College, Dublin. It was finished early in 1831, the same year he became Erasmus Smith's Professor of Natural and Experimental Philosophy. His Preface states he desired to assemble the experimental and mathematical developments in optics since the middle of the 18th century and present them in a form that could be used by those who design and construct optical instruments. He makes it clear that in most cases he presents results and not their derivation. Lloyd's interest is principally geometric optics, though enough physical optics is presented to give sufficient background to the theory and mathematics. He further limits the analyses he presents to that of two dimensions, particularly regarding aberration analysis. Lloyd considers this sufficient for the applications he considers.||Lloyd's text, and his demonstration in 1833 of the existence of conical refraction as predicted by Hamilton, established his reputation and was responsible, in part, for his being asked to prepare what became his 'Report on the progress and present state of physical optics' which he made to the British Association for the Advancement of Science at its meeting in Edinburgh in 1834.
BP_Description_2: Lloyd's text is in three parts. 1: On Simple or Homogeneous Light, 2: On Compound or Heterogeneous Light, 3: On Vision. Part One covers the nature of light, reflection a plane and spherical surfaces and the images produced, reflection at any curved surface, refraction at plane surfaces and prisms, refraction at spherical surfaces, aberration by spherical lenses, refraction at any curved surfaces, images formed by reflection and refraction. Part Two considers spectral optics, beginning with a consideration of the solar spectrum, dispersion by refraction at plane and spherical surfaces, and the colors of natural bodies. Part Three considers vision, restricted to a consideration of vision as aided by lenses and the subsequent development and use of the microscope and telescope of various types. An appendix considers atmospheric refraction.||The treatment is mathematical, with results clearly presented but seldom derived.

D.|Hermathena, No 130/131, 1981, pp 37-52, NB: pp 43-44.||Humphrey Lloyd (1800-1881) and the Dublin Mathematical School of the Nineteenth Century|

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A two-volume textbook on natural philosophy for use at universities. Widely used and in print for 50 years.
BP_Description_1: Denison Olmsted wrote this two-volume textbook on natural philosophy early in his long teaching career at Yale College. In his Preface he refers to himself not as author but as 'compiler.' His stated goal is to consult the the latest and most authoritative writers in important fields of natural philosophy in order  1) to assemble a textbook that would 'make the student thoroughly familiarly acquainted with the leading principles of natural philosophy.' and 2) to 'furnish the student with as much useful information as possible.' In Olmsted's text, 'principles' and 'useful' are in italics and are the bywords for the entire work. There are very few derivations, with principles simply stated and, when appropriate, expressed mathematically with geometric, algebra, or trigonometry. Most of the text is devoted to demonstrating the principles and applying them to explain phenomena, show how machines work, describe instruments, and explain craft and technique.||The work was tremendously successful, being widely used and preprinted, with editions appearing in 1831, 1835, 1840, 1842, 1844, 1852, 1855, 1859, and 1870. An extensively revised and expanded edition appeared in 1891 and 1895.
BP_Description_2: Olmsted's text is in six parts. Part 1 Principles of Mechanics (185 pages), covering laws of motion, gravity, projectile motion, and simple machines. Part 2 Applied Mechanics (157 pages), covering component motion, center of gravity, machinery, friction, and strength of materials. Part 3 Hydrostatics and Pneumatics (86 pages) covering fluids, fluid motion, cohesion and capillary action, fluid waves, properties of gases, air and steam, sound acoustics, and music. Part 4 Electricity (88 pages), covering general principles, electrical apparatus, Leyden jar, 'electrical light', electric battery, electrical phenomena, lightening, animal electricity. Part 5 Magnetism (35 pages), covering magnetic attraction and repulsion, 'directive' properties, the compass, magnetic navigation. Part 6 Optics (136 pages), covering nature and propagation of light, reflection, mirrors and their images, refraction, lenses and their images, Newton's chromatic heterogeneity, colors from this films, the rainbow, colors of objects, diffraction, double refraction and polarization, vision, microscopes, magic lantern, and telescopes.||For physical optics, both the wave and particle theories are presented, but both lead to the notion of the light ray, and it is used in all subsequent material. The geometric optics is elementary but thorough, accompanied by many small but clear figures.||Olmsted relies very heavily on the Encyclopaedia Metropolitana articles of Herschel, 'Light' and of Barlow, 'Optics'. He also relies on Brewster's 'Treatise on Optics'. Other sources included Newton, Huygens, Biot, Priestley, Euclid, Wood, and Ha√ºy. Interestingly, Fresnel is never used or cited.
BP_Reference(s): Denison Olmsted an early American astronomer|Treadwell, T.R.|<i>Popular Astronomy<i>, Vol. 54, 1946, pp 237-241.
BP_Title: An Introduction to Natural Philosophy: Designed as a Text Book, for the use of the Students in Yale College. In Two Volumes. Vol I - Mechancis and Hydrostatics. Vol II - Pneumatics, Electricity, Magnetism, and Optics. Compiled from various authorities. By Denison Olmstead, A.M. Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy.
BP_Biographical Statement: American physicist, astronomer, academic. Professor at Yale College.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Joseph Loring

BP_Short or Common Title: Die neueren Erfindungen und Verbesserungen in Betreff der optischen Instrumente
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary of British and Continental developments in optical instruments and craft in the early decades of the 19th century
BP_Description_1: An extensive summary of British and Continental developments in optical instruments and craft in the early decades of the 19th century, as described in then-recent publications. The emphasis is on dioptrics and lensed instruments and gives an interesting picture of what was considered important, or at least well-known, early in the 19th century.
BP_Description_2: Developments in Lenses and lens craft are described by entries that cite the reference and give a summary of the article or journal paper. The summaries are detailed, but very concise, and often include tables of important optical data or measurements. The material is practical, focused on optical materials, their properties, and the craft involved in lens and instrument construction.
BP_Title: Die neueren Erfindungen und Verbesserungen in Betreff der optischen Instrumente. Als der verschiedenen Arten optischer und periskipischer GlaÃàser, der Perspective, Teleskope, Mikroskope, Taschen- und Doppelmikroskope, Reflectoren, Camera lucida, Zauberlaternen, Operngucker, Lorgnetten, Brillen a.; Verbesserungen im Schneiden der krnstallglaser, im Drehen, Schleifen un Poliern der Linsen; sowie Belehrung uÃàber das Sehen, uÃàber die Mittel, den wahren Zustand der Augen zu bestimmen und jedes Individuum in den Stand zu setzen, sich die fur seine Augen passenden Brillen selbst zu wahlen; Beschreibung eines Instrumentes (Optometers), um die kurtz- oder Weitsichtigkeit der Augen zu messen; neue Analnse des Sonnenlights; a. BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Alexander Dallas Bache
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second American edition of David Brewster's optics text of 1831.
BP_Description_1: Second American edition of David Brewster's text of 1831. The American editor, Alexander Dallas Bache, intended to make the text more suitable for use in a university course in optics. This meant increasing the level of detail in the geometric optics material and elaborating the material on polarization of light. Bache did this in an appendix of 90 pages. The American edition appeared in 1833, 1838, 1844, and in 1845. This is a reprinting with only minor corrections of the first American edition of 1833.
BP_Description_2: Brache's edition corrected errors in Brewster's original text but is more significant for the 90-page, seven-chapter appendix of additional material on geometric optics and polarization. 1: Reflection by spherical mirrors. 2: Images by reflection. 3: Refraction by prisms and lenses. 4: Images by refraction. 5: Spherical aberration. 6: Double refraction and polarized light. 7: The rainbow. The added material is highly analytic, with lens design and analysis treated in extensive detail, spherical and chromatic aberration corrections described, and polarization considered from an analytic rather than a simply descriptive point of view. Interestingly, Brache's additional material is limited to analytic development and neither presents nor takes sides in the competing emission and wave theories of light.
BP_Reference(s): Scientific Revolutions and Scientific Rationality: The Case of the "Elderly Holdout"|Worroll, J.|In: <i>Minnesota Studies in the Philosophy of Science, Vol XIV, Scientific Theories<i>|Savage, W., editor|University of Minnesota Press, 1990, 410 pp, pp 319-354.

Associate Soc. of Newport, R.I.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Paul Vergnaud (1818-?) French writer, translator.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A very close French translation of Brewster's <i>Cabinet Cyclopaedia Optics<i> of 1831
BP_Description_1: A very close French translation of David Brewster's <i>Cabinet Cyclopaedia Optics<i> of 1831. That Brewster's optical text should be translated into French is explained by the work of Parisian publisher Nicolas-Edm√© Roret who began in 1825 to publish a 'collection of textbooks forming an encyclopedia of sciences and arts.' Much like Brewster's original, which was one of many books in Dionnysius Lardner's series <i>The Cabinet Cyclopedia<i>, Roret commissioned Paul Vergnaud to translate Brewster's English to produce an optics volume for what was known as 'La Librairie Encyclopeidique du Roret.' Vergnaud was a translator and not a natural philosopher, so the translation is accurate but slavish. Unlike Brewster's English original which at in-text figures, Roret's book gathered all the figures onto five plates.
BP_Description_2: Brewster's treatise is in four parts: Reflect and refraction of light; Physical optics; Natural optical phenomena; Optical instruments. 1: Reflection and refraction of light includes plain and spherical mirrors, images from mirrors, refraction in general, lenses, rays convex and concave lenses, meniscus lenses, images from lenses, magnification, spherical aberrations.  2: Physical optics includes chromatic heterogeneity, dispersion, achromatic lenses, solar spectrum, diffraction, colors from thin and thick plates, double refraction, polarized light and polarization effects of different materials. 3: Natural optical phenomena includes the rainbow, halos and coronae, parahelia, object colors, the eye and eye-function, colored shadows. 4: Optical instruments includes mirrored instruments, single and compound lenses, prisms and magnifiers, magic lantern and camera lucida, microscopes, telescopes, achromatic telescopes. The material is weighted heavily to physical optics: 60 pages are devoted to geometric optics, 200 pages to physical optics, 40 pages to natural phenomena, and 50 pages to optical instruments. Much of the physical optics section is filled with reports of the many investigations Brewster made on light interacting with crystals and other materials. The imbalance in level of detail, compared to that in the geometrical optics section is striking; chromatic aberration, for example, is barely touched upon. The whole of the material is descriptive, with only elementary geometry used. The physical optics material is entirely Newtonian, adhering to the emission theory of light; explaining, for example, interference by appeal to fits of easy reflection and transmission.
BP_Reference(s): Innover dans le texte. L‚ÄôEncyclop√©die Roret et la vulgarisation des techniques, 1830-1880||Gar√ßon, A.-F.|<i>Colloque Les Archives de l‚ÄôInvention<i>, May 2003, Paris, France|http://halshs.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-00003861/document

BP_Short or Common Title: Inquires concerning the Medium of Light and the Form of its Molecules
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A digest of a larger work dealing with the nature, form, and properties of the particles that make up medium that carries light.
BP_Description_1: Macvicar considered the corpuscular theory of light to be untenable, and while the undulatory one he though viable, little was known of the undulatory medium. He states that since this is the case, and no work has been done on the nature of the medium, he undertook a extensive analysis that leads him to propose "ethereal molecules" with shapes, forms, symmetries, structures, and propagation that explain optical phenomena. Color is inherent in these molecules, in that their "natural and achromatic symmetry can be developed by dispersion." This strange book is an indication of the lingering wave-particle controversy on the nature of light in Great Britain, and the wide range in the nature of those who took part in the long debate. Macvicar was certainly on the distant periphery, a dabbler--however committed--having no mathematics but mountains of curiosity and belief. In this regard, the difference between Macvicar's work to describe light's medium and the near-contemporaneous work of Augustin-Louis Cauchy could not be greater. Macvicar was an occasional correspondent with Michael Faraday, trying (unsuccessfully) to get Faraday to read his various treatises.
BP_Description_2: The first part of the book is "Analysis" and presents Macvicar's take on basic optical phenomena and experiments that reveal properties of light. The second part of the book is "Synthesis" and presents deductions from data and experiments that, it is contended, reveal the properties of "light's molecules." The material is entire descriptive--there is no mathematics of any type.
BP_Reference(s): Modern Metaphysicians: Rev. John Gibson Macvicor, A.M., D.D.|In: The British Controversialist and Literary Magazine, London, 1849, NB: pp 81-102.
BP_Title: Inquiries Concerning the Medium of Light and the form of its Molecules.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish natural philosopher, teacher, and minister.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1833 Macvicar - Inquires concerning the Medium of Light and the Form of its Molecules - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: M√©moire sur la Transmission libre de la Chaleur rayonnate par diff√©rens Corps solides et liquies
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Papers presenting instrumentation for heat measurements and heat transparency properties of materials. Contains the first description of rock salt lenses and prisms, presents new vocabulary for heat radiation quantities parallel to those in optics, and established infrared spectroscopy.
BP_Description_1: The first two in a long series of articles by Melloni on heat radiation and the thermal properties of materials. In the first article he described and used his sensitive thermopile and galvanometer to survey the infrared transmittance of a variety of materials. The instrument in its early form had been developed by Leopoldo Nobili but had been improved by Melloni sufficiently to detect very weak heat radiation. The instrument was called a 'thermomultiplicateur', was approximately 50 times more sensitive than any extant liquid and glass thermometer, and with the appearance of this paper, it and Melloni's work became widely known. Melloni presented this work to the French Academy of Sciences in February 1833.||The second paper reports more extensive experiments and the particularly important discovery that rock salt was as transparent to heat radiation as glass was to optical radiation. Melloni would make prisms and lenses of rock salt to discover the infrared parallel to geometric optics. Melloni's work would eventually show the unity of optical and heat radiation and lead to the unification of heat, optical, and chemical radition into a single spectrum. An English translations of the first paper appeared in the American Journal of Science, Vol 1, No 2, 1835, both papers appeared in German translations in the Annalen der Physik und Chemie, Ser 35, 1835.
BP_Description_2: Melloni's account of his survey of the infrared transparency of many materials. He reports using four heat sources: a so-called Locatelli lamp, an incandescent platinum spiral, and sheet copper at low and high temperature. He measured the relative infrared transmittance thin sheets of 36 materials. He reported that the heat radiation from the four heat sources differed in intensity and 'quality'--that is, what would now be called spectral power distribution. He also showed that heat transmittance was a property of the material alone. The experiments are described with detail and clarity sufficient to allow them to be repeated.  He showed that rock salt was highly transparent to heat radiation and built lenses and prisms from it to investigate the refraction, focusing, and dispersion of heat radiation. The second paper describes the eponymous Melloni Optical Bench which he developed to facilitate his experimental work. Melloni demonstrated broad parallels between visible and heat radiation, and to facilitate descriptions he proposed new vocabulary. Among these were: 'thermochrose', 'diathermy', and 'athermancy' as radiant heat parallels to the optical properties of color, transparency, and opacity.
BP_Reference(s): The Infrared Pioneers--II. Macedonio Melloni|Barr, E.S.|<i>Infrared Physics<i>, Vol 2, 1962, pp 67-73.||ùëª Memoir on the Free Transmission of Radiant Heat|In: <i>Scientific Memoires<i>, Taylor, R., editor and translator|London, 1837, pp 1-74.
BP_Title: "M√©moire sur la Transmission libre de la Chaleur rayonnate par diff√©rens Corps solides et liquid√©s", In: Annales de Chimie et Physique, Vol 53, 1833, pp 7-73.
BP_Title English Translation: Memoire on the Free Transmission of Heat by Different Solid and Liquid Bodies.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicist, ingenious experimenter in the infared spectrum, did significant work in showing the unity of ultraviolet, visible, and infared has different parts of a single radiant spectrum.
BP_Provenance: Tag of G.E. Stechert & Co on lower pastedown

BP_Short or Common Title: A Short Elementary Treatise on Experimental and Mathematical Optics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A text on geometric optics written specifically for university students in general, and Oxford students in particular.  It presents optics with the aid of the concision afforded by algebraic and trigonometric analysis, avoiding elaborate geometry.
BP_Description_1: Baden Powell wrote this text specifically for university students in general, and Oxford students in particular. Powell finds many then-available books 'too large and too difficult on the one hand, or incomplete and obscure on the other.' He cites texts by James Wood of 1799, Henry Coddington of 1829, Humphrey Lloyd of 1831, David Brewster of 1831, and Herschel's article in the <i>Encyclopaedia Metropolitana<i>. Though all are valuable, Powell find some too deeply based on geometry and so lack the concision of algebraic and trigonometric analysis, some too elaborate and detailed for a single university course. Powell's stated intension is to present optics with the aid of the concision afforded by algebraic and trigonometric analysis, and to avoid the usual distinction made between geometrical and physical optics. In this regard, Though Powell was committed to the wave theory of light, he insisted it was possible to present and describe all optical phenomena without recourse to a physical theory of light. Pointedly, the text is 'limited entirely to the experimental and mathematical part of optics, without entering in the small degree upon physical optics, properly so called.' For physical theories of light, Powell refers the student to Herschel's article Light of 1830 or Airy's Mathematical Tracts of 1831. Powell's text is interesting and was influential for its assiduous avoidance of physical hypotheses about light and its adherence to experimental fact and mathematical analysis.
BP_Description_2: Baden Powell's textbook covers the following. Light and its propagation; Reflection and refraction in general; Reflection and refraction at plane and curved surfaces; The mathematical theory of the Pencil of Rays; Application of pencil theory to lenses; On and off optical axis analysis; Spherical aberrations; Analysis of lens performance and image production; Optical instruments; The eye and eye-function; Chromatic dispersion; Chromatic aberration; Achromatic lenses; The rainbow and  halos; Double refraction; Interference; Colors in thin and thick plates; Polarization of light; Color and interference in polarized light; Types of polarization. The material is detailed and highly analytic, with algebra, trigonometry, and the calculus being used.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132, NB 124-131.
BP_Title: A Short Elementary Treatise on Experimental and Mathematical Optics. Designed for the User of Studnets in the University.  By the Rev. Baden Powell, M.A., F.R.S. or Oriel College. Savilian Professor of Geomeetry in the University of Oxford.
BP_Biographical Statement: English cleric, mathematician. Famously supported Darwin's Origin of Species.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of W. Mackenzie, inscribed 'From the author'
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1833 Powell - A Short Elementary Treatise on Experimental and Mathematical Optics - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Amondieu optics text, written expressly to present the then-recent work of Fresnel and the transverse wave theory of light. This optics work is taken from a basic general course in physics Amondieu was teaching at the time.
BP_Description_1: Joseph Louis Adrien Amondieu wrote this text expressly to present the then-recent work of Fresnel and the transverse wave theory of light. This optics work is taken from a basic general course in physics Amondieu was teaching at the time, but he judged developments in optics important enough to warrant a separate text. Written for beginning students, Amondieu assumes they have mastery of only trigonometry and geometry, and so decided to 'remove the very complicated calculus, and give only the results of the analysis; however, I have allowed some simple geometrical demonstrations to remain, which, far from obscuring the matter, can only clarify it, and which will be easily understood by the students.' Amondieu's is the earliest textbook to present Fresnel's theory of light--albeit without its elaborate mathematical underpinnings. Importantly, it is the first book to present a judicial-scientific evaluation of light theories: it sets out the principal phenomena of optics, and then presents how the two theories explain or model each phenomena. The text appeared in 1826 with a reissue of that printing in 1834; only the date on the title page has been changed.||Amondieu optics text first appeared in 1826 and was reissued in 1834 with the same title page, only the date being changed. A German translation appeared at Leipzig in 1827.
BP_Description_2: Amondieu's book is in four parts: Presentation of most known optical phenomena; The wave theory of light and its explanation of these phenomena; The particle or emission theory of light and its explanation of these phenomena; Application of optics to meteorics and instruments. The first part describes: direct light, catoptrics, dioptrics, lenses, the eye and eye-function, chromatic dispersion, double refraction, polarization, diffraction, the thermal and chemical effects of the solar spectrum. The second and third parts present, respectively, the wave and emission theories explanations of reflection, refraction, dispersion, double refraction, polarization, and the thermal and chemical effects of the solar spectrum. The wave theory is that of Fresnel and the emission theory is Newtonian. The forth part briefly describes luminous atmospheric phenomena and optical instruments, particularly the application of achromatic lenses.
BP_Reference(s): Joseph Louis Adrien Amondieu (1795-1849) Professeur de physique|In: Le Lyc√©e Clemenceau: 200 Ans d'Histoire, 2008.
BP_Title: Essai d'un cours eÃÅleÃÅmentaire d'optique, contenant les deux theÃÅories de la lumieÃÄre dans les systeÃÄmes des ondulations et de l'eÃÅmission. A l'usage des eÃÅleÃÄves qui eÃÅtudient la physique. Par Amondieu, Agrege pour les Sciences. "La nature en se devoilant a montre a l'homme un petit nombre de causes donnant naissance a lsfoule de phenomenes qu'il avait observes"  Laplace, Systeme du Monde. L. I.

BP_Short or Common Title: Notes sure la Polarization Par M. Delezenne
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An extended article of polarization measurements.
BP_Description_1: Offprint of the extended article of polarization measurements that appeared in M√©moires de la Soci√©t√© Royale des Sciences, de l'Agriculture et des Arts de Lille, Ann√©e 1834.
BP_Description_2: Delezenne reports an extensive set of experiments involving the production, detecting, and behavior of polarized light by and with various crystals, including birefringent Islandic spar and the dichroic crystal tourmaline. Delezenne indulges in no theorizing, only very detailed reporting of carefully conducted experiments to observe and record the behavior of polarized light with optically active crystal materials. He reports procedures and instruments that would be used by others investigating polarization including the eponymous Delezenne Polarizer and the Savart-Delezenne Plate. He studied the polarization of moonlight and produced an early, complete analysis of the polarization of the light from the sky.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Iceland Spar and its Influence on the Development of Science in the Period 1780‚Äì1930: Notes and References<i>|Kristj√°nsson, L.|Institute of Earth Sciences, University of Iceland, 2015, 472 pp, NB: pp 77-79.

BP_Biographical Statement: French teacher, inventor, physicst. Taught in Lille, author of numerous essays on science, famed for his work in musical acoustics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Exley's theory of attractive and repulsive forces used to explain known optical phenomena. The book provides a view of the last vestiges of support for the emission theory of light in Britain.
BP_Description_1: Thomas Exley <i>Physical Optics<i> follows upon and is a companion to his earlier book on gravitation, <i>A New Theory of Physics<i> of 1829. Exley's theory of attractive (gravitational) and repulsive forces is used to explain known optical phenomena. Though never mentioned (or perhaps even known to Exley), the idea is an echo of that of Boscovich of nearly a century earlier. Exley never acknowledges the wave theory of light, Fresnel‚Äôs' stunning quantitative success at explaining diffraction and polarization, or how his mechanical/ballistic theory was superior. A strange book, seemingly without influence, that provides a view of the last vestiges of support for the emission theory of light in Britain. Exley's <i>New Theory of Physics<i> and <i>Physical Optics<i> were reviewed in 'The Eclectic Review' for 1837: an extended summary coupled with a tepid and guarded reaction based on the lack of mathematics and experimental proof.
BP_Description_2: Exley's text is in 17 sections, the first two giving Exley's general optical-gravitational theory and all the rest covering a different optical phenomenon and how it is explained by the theory. 1: Definitions and general notions. 2: Deductions from physics. 3: Reflection and refraction. 4: Chromatic dispersion. 5: Absorption. 6: Thin plate colors. 7: Thick plate colors. 8: Diffraction. 9: Polarization. 10: Polarization by reflection. 11: Polarization by transmission. 12: Double refraction. 13: This plates from crystals. 14: Colors from crystals. 15: Circular polarization. 16: Absorption of polarized light. 17: The eye and eye function, colors of objects. Exley proposes that in addition to Newton's inverse-square-of-distance gravitational attraction, there is a related repulsive force that acts only over very small distances. The interaction of large 'atoms' of ordinary matter with the vanishingly small particles of the luminiferous aether are governed by these two forces. The material is entirely descriptive, with only elementary geometry occasionally used. In each section, the general theory is invoked to explain, in a qualitative manner only, the phenomena under consideration. No computations or analysis is given.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Optics After Newton: Theories of Light in Britain and Ireland, 1704-1840<i>|Cantor, G.N.|Manchester University Press, 1983, 265 pp, NB: pp 70-72.
BP_Title: Physical Optics. Or, the Phenomena of Optics Explained According to Mechanical Science; and on the Known Principles of Gravitation. By Thomas Exley, A.M. Associate of the Bristol Philosophical and Literary Society. "And God say the light that it was good." - Moses.
BP_Biographical Statement: English schoolmaster, mathematician, proponent of controversial theories of physics.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed Taylor Fzosufordt

BP_Short or Common Title: M√©moire sur la Transmission libre de la Chaleur rayonnate par diff√©rens Corps solides et liquies
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Reprint of the second of several papers presenting instrumentation for heat measurements and heat transparency properties of materials. Contains the first description of rock salt lenses and prisms, presents new vocabulary for heat radiation quantities parallel to those in optics, and established infrared spectroscopy.
BP_Description_1: Reprint of the second in a long series of articles by Melloni on heat radiation and the thermal properties of materials. In the first article he described and used his sensitive thermopile and galvanometer to survey the infrared transmittance of a variety of materials. The instrument in its early form had been developed by Leopoldo Nobili but had been improved by Melloni sufficiently to detect very weak heat radiation. The instrument was called a 'thermomultiplicateur', was approximately 50 times more sensitive than any extant liquid and glass thermometer, and with the appearance of this paper, it and Melloni's work became widely known. Melloni presented this work to the French Academy of Sciences in February 1833.||The second paper reports more extensive experiments and the particularly important discovery that rock salt was as transparent to heat radiation as glass was to optical radition. Melloni would make prisms and lenses of rock salt to discover the infrared parallel to geometric optics. Melloni's work would eventually show the unity of optical and heat radiation and lead to the unification of heat, optical, and chemical radiation into a single spectrum. An English translations of the first paper appeared in the American Journal of Science, Vol 1, No 2, 1835, both papers appeared in German translations in the Annalen der Physik und Chemie, Ser 35, 1835.
BP_Description_2: Melloni's account of his survey of the infrared transparency of many materials. He reports using four heat sources: a so-called Locatelli lamp, an incandescent platinum spiral, and sheet copper at low and high temperature. He measured the relative infrared transmittance thin sheets of 36 materials. He reported that the heat radiation from the four heat sources differed in intensity and 'quality'--that is, what would now be called spectral power distribution. He also showed that heat transmittance was a property of the material alone. The experiments are described with detail and clarity sufficient to allow them to be repeated.  He showed that rock salt was highly transparent to heat radiation and built lenses and prisms from it to investigate the refraction, focusing, and dispersion of heat radiation. The second paper describes the eponymous Melloni Optical Bench which he developed to facilitate his experimental work. Melloni demonstrated broad parallels between visible and heat radiation, and to facilitate descriptions he proposed new vocabulary. Among these were: 'thermochrose', 'diathermy', and 'athermancy' as radiant heat parallels to the optical properties of color, transparency, and opacity.
BP_Reference(s): The Infrared Pioneers--II. Macedonio Melloni|Barr, E.S.|<i>Infrared Physics<i>, Vol 2, 1962, pp 67-73.||ùëª Memoir on the Free Transmission of Radiant Heat|In: <i>Scientific Memoires<i>, Taylor, R., editor and translator|London, 1837, pp 1-74.
BP_Title: "M√©moire sur la Transmission libre de la Chaleur rayonnate par diff√©rens Corps solides et liquid√©s", Reprinted from: Annales de Chimie et Physique, Vol 54, 1834, pp 1-61.
BP_Title English Translation: Memoire on the Free Transmission of Heat by Different Solid and Liquid Bodies.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicist, ingenious experimenter in the infared spectrum, did significant work in showing the unity of ultraviolet, visible, and infared has different parts of a single radiant spectrum.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Carl Wolfgang Benjamin Goldschmidt (1807-1851) German astronomer, mathematician, physicist. Professor at the University of G√∂ttingen.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A posthumous publishing of Schmidt's material on geometrical optics and, unknown for optics books of that time, extensive material on lighting and visual perception.
BP_Description_1: Johann Carl Eduard Schmidt left on his death at T√ºbingen in 1832, an unpublished manuscript devoted to optics considered in broadest possible terms. His colleague at G√∂ttingen, Carl Wolfgang Benjamin Goldschmidt, extracted, edited, and saw Schmidt's manuscript through the press. Goldschmidt extracted the basic and complete parts of Schmidt's text, noting that Schmidt's manuscript hardly considered the topics of diffraction, interference, double refraction, and polarization. Those were not part of the edited text. What remained was material on geometrical optics and, unknown for optics books of that time, extensive material on lighting and visual perception. The subjects left untreated in the printed text resulted only from the lack of Schmidt's written material on these subjects. As a student of Gauss, Schmidt was eminently capable of the mathematics required to follow the then-modern development in the wave theory of light, and it is known that Schmidt had carefully studied and reviewed Cauchy's works in optics.
BP_Description_2: On light in general, propagation of light, reflection, parallax and shadows, lighting, catoptrics, dioptrics, refraction in lenses, chromatic dispersion, achromatic lenses, spherical aberrations, telescopes, mirrored telescopes, microscopes, atmospheric refraction, halos and sundogs,
BP_Reference(s): Cauchy und Gau√ü. Cauchys Rezeption im Umfeld von Gau√ü|Reich, K.|<i>Archive of the History of Exact Sciences<i> Vol 57, No 6, 2003 pp 433‚Äì463, NB: pp 447-448.

BP_Short or Common Title: Memoire sur le Dispersion de la Lumi√®re
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Cauchy's memoir presenting his expressions for the dispersion of light, using properties of the luminiferous aether treated as a 3-dimensional lattice of interacting particles. His equations yielded predictions of dispersion that matched well the measurements Fraunhofer had made.
BP_Description_1: Augustin-Louis Cauchy published his first work on a theory of the 3-dimensional lattice nature of the luminiferous aether in his M√©moire sur la Theorie de la Lumi√®re of 1830. Cauchy then worked to develop expression for the dispersion of light, using properties of the luminiferous aether treated as a 3-dimensional lattice of interacting particles. Cauchy's results were generally considered a success, as his equations yielded predictions of dispersion that matched well the measurements Fraunhofer had made for several types of glass. From this work came the eponymous 'Cauchy's Dispersion Formula.' Cauchy's work was widely influential, since it yielded a quantitative expression for chromatic dispersion, could account for selective absorption, and the elliptical polarization--all from the assumed 3-dimensional lattice structure of the aether. Cauchy's self-published Nouveaux Exercices de Math√©matiques from 1825 to 1836 at Prague, and in these he printed, in six 'Livraisons,' the eight parts of his M√©moire sur la Dispersion de al Lumi√®re. This copy is that edition, here in their original wrappers. The M√©moire was printed again in a single monograph and published under the auspices of Prague's Academy of Sciences  in 1836.
BP_Description_2: Cauchy's memoir begins with a description of the luminiferous aether as a 3-dimensional lattice. Elements in the lattice present repulsive forces to all neighboring elements. Displacement of an element results in forces exerted by all neighboring elements and it was this inclusion that made Cauchy's lattice model both more complicated and superior to Fresnel's. Cauchy assumed the displacements to be small and linear, and so allowed a simple, truncated expansion of the equations of lattice element motion. From this, the velocity of the wave--that is, the index of refraction--could be expressed as a function of wavelength. With a bewilderingly elaborate analysis, Cauchy showed that the refractive index could be expressed as an infinite series involving inverse wavelength to even powers; Cauchy's Dispersion Formula.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Cauchy‚Äôs Theory of Dispersion Anticipated by Fresnel|Buchwald, J.Z.|In: <i>A Master of Science History, Essays in Honor of Charles Coulston Gillispie<i>, Buchwald, J.Z., editor|Springer, 2012, 438 pp, NB: pp 399-416.||Optics and the Theory of the Punctiform Ether|Buchwald, J.Z.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 21, 1980, pp 245-274.
BP_Title: Memoire sur le Dispersion de la Lumiere. Par M.A.L. Cauchy, Membre de l'Academie des Sciences de Paris, des Societes Royales de Londres, de Berlin, de Prague, etc.
BP_Title English Translation: Memoire on the Dispersion of Light. By M.A.L. Cauchy. Member of the Academy of Sciences of Paris, of the Royal Societies of London, Berlin, Prague, etc. Publie par la Societe Royale des Sciences de Prague.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician, mathematical physicist, engineer. Profound mathematician, prolific author, sometime Professor at the √âcole Polytechnique.

BP_Short or Common Title: Report on the Progress and Present State of Physical Optics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An extensive report on physical optics presented at the fourth meeting the British Association for the Advancement of Science. It marked the final triumph in Britain of the wave theory of light over the emission theory.
BP_Description_1: Humphrey Lloyd prepared an extensive report on the state of physical optics which he presented at the fourth meeting the British Association for the Advancement of Science, held in Edinburgh in 1834. He had been invited to deliver the report after the notoriety of his experimental optics work. A year later the full proceedings of the meeting were published, including Lloyd‚Äôs 120-page report. Lloyd reviews optical phenomena and evaluates the ability of the wave and emission theories to account for them, with the wave theory, according to Lloyd, showing it full power and superiority to the emission theory. It marked the final triumph in Britain of the wave theory of light over the emission theory. By the time of Lloyd‚Äôs report, George Biddell Airy, John Herschel, William Whewell, William Rowan Hamilton, and Baden Powell had all embraced the wave theory. Among other successes attributed to the wave theory, Lloyd reports on Hamilton's prediction of 'conical refraction' in biaxial crystals and his own remarkable experimental verification of this phenomena. The report also signaled another change: the adoption of mathematics, at whatever complexity and depth was required, to support physics. That is, the emergence of mathematical physics.
BP_Description_2: Lloyd's states the purpose of his report: 'consider in some detail the present state of our knowledge with regard to the physical theory of light, and the successive advances which have, in late years, been made toward its establishment.' Lloyd's plan is to consider important optical phenomena and evaluate how far they are commensurate with the wave and emission theories. The phenomena considered are in two groups: 1) Propagation and interference, reflection and refraction, diffraction, thin and thick plate colors, and 2) polarization and transverse waves, reflection and refraction of polarized light, double refraction, crystal plate colors. The report considers each in turn, giving the principle experimental data and evaluating the development of the emission and wave theories to explain them. The development includes more-or-less recent history of the work performed on both theories, with extensive citation of the relevant references. For the modern emission theory Biot is cited extensively, for the wave theory Young, Fresnel, Arago, and Cauchy are. Unlike Herschel's article 'Light' that had appeared in the Encyclopaedia Metropolitana in 1830, Lloyd's report contains virtually no mathematics. The development and state of the two theories is given in purely descriptive form, in many ways making the case for the wave theory more compelling, certainly more approachable. The report is, in its essence, a vast review of the literature on physical optics.
BP_Reference(s): Waves, Philosophers and Historians|Buchwald, J.Z.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Biennial Meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association<i>, 1992. No 2, pp. 205-211||Humphrey Lloyd, 1800-1881|Spearman T. D.|Hermathena, No 130/131, 1981, pp 37-52, NB: pp 43-44.||<i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 105-107.||The prediction and discovery of conical refraction by William Rowan Hamilton and Humphrey Lloyd (1832‚Äì1833)|O'Hara, J.G.|<i>Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy, Section A: Mathematical and Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 82A, No 2, 1982, pp. 231‚Äì257.||Humphrey Lloyd (1800-1881) and the Dublin Mathematical School of the Nineteenth Century|O'Hara, J. Gl.|Thesis, The University of Manchester, 1979, 651 pp.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A text appropriate for an elementary, single semester course that provided an overview of geometrical optics.
BP_Description_1: Robert Phelps states in his title the purpose of his book: 'Intended chiefly to elucidate the principles of the construction of telescopes and some other optical instruments.' Given the elementary nature of the text, it would be more accurate to describe its goal as elucidating the operation of telescopes, for there is no optical design material as such.
BP_Description_2: Phelps's book contains 9 chapters that cover: 1 The nature and properties of light; 2-3 Reflection at plane and spherical surfaces; 4-5 Homogeneous light refraction at plane and spherical surfaces; 6 Images from lenses; 7 Composition of light and chromatic dispersion; 8 Reflection combined with refraction; 9 Telescopes and microscopes. Aside from a very cursory consideration of the nature of light (Descartes' hypothesis is mentioned!) the text deals entirely with geometrical optics. Fresnel's work, for example, is not mentioned.  For some of the material on telescope lens systems, Coddington's textbook of 1829 is referenced and quoted. The treatment is elementary and the analysis is a mix of elementary geometry and algebra. Results and working formulae are given without derivation. The scope and cursory coverage would, seemingly, make the text appropriate for an elementary, single semester course  that provides an overview of geometrical optics.
BP_Title: An Elementary Treatise on Optics: Intended Chiefly to Elucidate the Principles of the Constructions of Telescopes and some other Optical Instruments. By Robert Phelps, B.A. Trinity College, Cambrige.
BP_Biographical Statement: English academic, mathematician. Master of Sidney-Susses College, Cambridge.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the British Legation

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Schwerd was the first to make elaborate calculations to determine the amplitude and distribution in Fraunhofer diffraction patterns for many single apertures of various shapes, and arrays of apertures. He made drawings from his observations of the patterns, some reproduced in hand-colored plates in the book.
BP_Description_1: Friedrich Magnus Schwerd began work on this treatise in 1833 in the spare time from his teaching duties. Schwerd calculated and observed the angular and chromatic dispersion displayed by Fraunhofer diffraction; that is, the pattern produced by diffraction of a small aperture observed at a distance very large compared to the aperture size and the wavelength of the light involved. Fraunhofer's work with diffraction gratings allowed him to formulate relationships between wavelength, aperture size, and diffracted angle. Schwerd was the first to make elaborate calculations using these relationships to determine the amplitude and distribution in Fraunhofer diffraction patterns for many single apertures of various shapes, and arrays of apertures. Schwerd made drawings from his observations of the patterns, some reproduced in hand-colored plates in the book. He also made experimental observations using equipment of his own design and manufacture to verify his calculations. The agreement between Schwerd's calculations and observations was seen as another, independent verification of the wave theory of light. His work would later be copied by Am√©dee Guillemin in his Les Ph√©nomenes de la Physique of 1868 and the data in Schwerd's book became standard, being used in physics and optics texts until the third decade of the 20th century.
BP_Description_2: Schwerd calculated the Fraunhofer diffraction patterns produced by apertures with various geometric openings, including squares, rectangles, slits, circles, and combinations of these. The calculations produced the relative amplitude and positions of the patterns' forms and fringes. The calculations, done by summation approximations to the integrals involved, were comprehensive and reported in detail. Most interesting and influential was Schwerd's solution for a circular opening, the results for which was long quoted in optics texts, which he reports having obtained by approximating the circular opening with 180 trapezoids. The accuracy of Schwerd's calculations and drawings have been demonstrated by modern photographic and computational analysis.
BP_Reference(s): Die Beugungserscheinungen: a Tribute to F. M. Schwerd's Monumental Work on Fraunhofer Diffraction|Hoover, R.B., Harris Jr., F.S.|<i>Applied Optics<i>, Vol 8, No 11, 1969, pp 2161-2164.||<i>Friedrich Magnus Schwerd, als Geod√§t, Astronom und Physiker<i>|von Neumayer, G.B.|J. Rheinberger, Berlin (?), 1902, 30 p.
BP_Title: Die Beugungserscheinungen aus den Fundamentalgesetzen der Undulationstheorie Analytisch Entwickelt und in Bildern Dargestellt von F.M. Schwer. Mit 18 sum Theil illuminirten Tafeln.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An introduction to optics written for students to understand and use the optical instruments used in navigation.
BP_Description_1: Mateus Valente do Couto taught physics at Royal Academy of Marine Guards and had used a late edition of de La Caille's Trait√© d'Optique of 1810. The preface explains that the students need an introduction to optics that prepared them to understand and use the optical instruments in the Royal Academy's observatory. This text was written to satisfy that need. It was also part of the Academy-wide program to generate 'national texts' that would replace foreign texts in other languages and with other intentions that had been used at the Academy since its founding.
BP_Description_2: Couto's text is in four parts that present optical principles, followed by a chapter on the application of these principles to optical instruments. 1: Optics including nature and propagation of light, shadows, illumination, and pin-hole images. 2: Catoptrics including reflection at plane and spherical surfaces, and the images from convex and concave spherical mirrors. 3: Dioptrics including refraction at plane and spherical surfaces, Lenses, images from lenses, data giving focal length and magnification of various lenses, simple lens equations. 4: Vision including the eye and eye-function, images for distinct vision, optical illusions, spectacles. Applications including: artificial horizons, zenith sector, meridian circle, microscopes and telescopes. The material is elementary but thorough, sufficiently analytic to make clear how lenses and mirrors created images, and presented with a constant eye on applications and optical instrument usage. The brief material on physical optics is entirely Newtonian, and the bulk of the material on geometrical optics presents governing equations without derivations--appropriate for the intended purpose of the text.

BP_Biographical Statement: Portuguese physician, mathematician, teacher. Director of the Marine Academy Laboratory at Aviz.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by J.C. Poggendorff
BP_Short or Common Title: Ueber die Diffaction des Lichts; von A. Fresnel
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Poggendorff's German translation of Fresnel's prize Memoire sur la Diffraction de la Lumi√®re which appeared in 1819 and finally printed in full by the French Academy in 1826.
BP_Description_1: J.C. Poggendorff's German translation of Fresnel's prize Memoire sur la Diffraction de la Lumi√®re which appeared in 1819 and finally printed in full by the French Academy in 1826. This series of German translations included a few other shorter works of Fresnel that had appeared in the Memoires of the French Academy. Poggendorff notes that even though much of what had been developed and published by Fresnel had by then been incorporated and summarized by John Herschel in his article 'Light' of 1828 and Andreas Baumgartner's <i>Die Naturlehre<i> of 1824, it was still important to study the original work.
BP_Description_2: Fresnel began the memoire delineating reasons why a ray or corpuscular theory of light cannot be correct, the essential problem being that rays and corpuscles are independent and only mechanical interactions can be used to explain optical phenomena. The rest of the memoire is essentially a series of lectures, giving background and detail appropriate for readers not familiar with wave analysis. The topics, in turn, are: all 'rays' are involved in diffraction, not just those near the diffractor; Huygens' Principle permits the necessary interactions to be modelled; a diffractor blocks part of an otherwise full wavefront and the resulting sub-wavefronts generate interference fringes; positions of fringe maxima can be predicted only by incorporating (integrating) the phase interactions along the wavefront that is not blocked by the diffractor; derivation of the integrals that express the necessary phase interactions; comparison of predictions of position of fringe maxima with experimental measurement. Fresnel's analyses included fringes produced by a half-infinite diffractor, a narrow slit, and a narrow diffractor. In most cases the agreement with position measurements was withing 1.5%.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 168-183.
BP_Title: "Ueber die Diffaction des Lichts; von A. Fresnel" (Memoires de l'acad. Roy. des Sciences etc. T. V P. 100)  In: Annalen der Physik und Chemie. Dreissigster Band, 1836, pp 100-261.
BP_Title English Translation: "On the Diffration of Light" by A. Fresnel.  In: Annalen der Physik und Chemie. Dreissigster Band, 1836, pp 100-261.
BP_Biographical Statement: French engineer, physicist, experimentalist. Worked on optics, theoretical and practical.

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Gustav Adolf von KloÃàden, German geographer and teacher at the Berlin School of Arts.
BP_Short or Common Title: Abriss einer Geschichte der Fortschritte und des gegenw√§rtigen Zustandes der physischen Optik
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A close German translation of Humphrey Lloyd's extensive report on physical optics presented at the fourth meeting the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
BP_Description_1: Gustav Adolf von KloÃàden's close German translation of Humphrey Lloyd's extensive report on the state of physical optics which he presented at the fourth meeting the British Association for the Advancement of Science, held in Edinburgh in 1834 and which appeared in print in 1835.
BP_Description_2: Lloyd's states the purpose of his report: 'consider in some detail the present state of our knowledge with regard to the physical theory of light, and the successive advances which have, in late years, been made toward its establishment.' Lloyd's plan is to consider important optical phenomena and evaluate how far they are commensurate with the wave and emission theories. The phenomena considered are in two groups: 1) Propagation and interference, reflection and refraction, diffraction, thin and thick plate colors, and 2) polarization and transverse waves, reflection and refraction of polarized light, double refraction, crystal plate colors. The report considers each in turn, giving the principle experimental data and evaluating the development of the emission and wave theories to explain them. The development includes more-or-less recent history of the work performed on both theories, with extensive citation of the relevant references. For the modern emission theory Biot is cited extensively, for the wave theory Young, Fresnel, Arago, and Cauchy are. Unlike Herschel's article 'Light' that had appeared in the Encyclopaedia Metropolitana in 1830, Lloyd's report contains virtually no mathematics. The development and state of the two theories is given in purely descriptive form, in many ways making the case for the wave theory more compelling, certainly more approachable. The report is, in its essence, a vast review of the literature on physical optics.
BP_Reference(s): Waves, Philosophers and Historians|Buchwald, J.Z.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Biennial Meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association, 1992<i>. D.|Hermathena, No 130/131, 1981, pp 37-52, NB: pp 43-44.||<i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 105-107.

BP_Short or Common Title: M√©moire sur la Polarisation de la Chaleur
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: First of two memoires investigating the polarization of radiant heat
BP_Description_1: First of two memoires investigating the polarization of radiant heat. Using the apparatus developed for his heat flow experiments, Melloni demonstrates and investigates the polarization of radiant heat. Heat passing through plates of tourmaline is the principle method. This, and his second memoire on polarization, showed that radiant polarization was in all respects the same as optical polarization. This work was central in the eventual unification of light and heat as a single radiant phenomena. These papers attracted wide international attention, being translated almost immediately in German and English.
BP_Description_2: Melloni passes radiant heat from his Locatelli lamp, passing through plates of tourmaline, and falling on his very sensitive detector to  produce and detect radiant heat polarization. The experimental methods are remarkable for their elaborate care and precision, producing data that was reliable and reproduceable. The results show that fully polarized radiant heat falling on a tourmaline plate with its axis perpendicular prevents virtually all radiant transmission. This is identical to the luminous polarization phenomenon. As in the case of luminous polarization, the polarization effect produced by the tourmaline was dependent on the wavelength ("species of heat" as Melloni had it) of the radiant heat, which varied with the heat source Melloni used.
BP_Reference(s): The Infrared Pioneers--II.
