BP_Short or Common Title: Theory of Systems of Rays - Third Supplement
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Hamilton's last contribution to his analytic techniques encompassed by his 'Theory of Systems of Rays,' first presented in 1828. Famously, in this paper he predicts conical refraction which was observed by Humphrey Lloyd.
BP_Description_1: William Rowan Hamilton's first published paper was read before the Royal Irish Academy on April 23, 1827. The printed revised paper focused the topic narrowly to the analysis of ray-systems and significantly extending the development and derivation parts. Though the table of contents lists three parts, the printed paper contains only the first, which deals with reflection. The second and third parts on simple and extraordinary refraction were never printed in Hamilton's lifetime. But he wrote three supplements, read before the Royal Irish Academy at sessions in 1830, 1831, and 1832. All three were eventually published, the Third Supplement printed in volume 17  of the transactions of the academy in 1837; the present work.||By the time Hamilton was working on these supplements, Fresnel's optics was finding a wide audience in Great Britain, part of its new enthusiasm for French mathematical physics. In this third supplement, Hamilton reports that Fresnel's theory implies the existence of 'conical refraction.' He asked his friend Humphrey Lloyd to look for it and, famously, Lloyd showed the existence of the peculiar phenomena. This demonstration was a strong confirmation of Fresnel's theory. Lloyd's paper describing his detection of conical refraction was printed immediately following Hamilton's. From correspondence between Hamilton and Lloyd at the time, it is clear that Lloyd had a complete understanding of Hamilton's work and was a significant contributor to the final form of Hamilton's work.
BP_Description_2: Hamilton takes up Fresnel's theory of propagation of light in crystals; specifically Fresnel's wave surface, its orientation with respect to the optical axes of the crystal, the two sheets that comprise it, and the significance of their shape and intersections. Hamilton establishes his own algebraic form for these surface sheets and showed that at their intersections form conical cusps and at these points, the crystal should exhibit conical refraction. That is, a single incident ray will be refracted into a cone of rays. A remarkable prediction verified by the experimental work of Humphrey Lloyd.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ The Prediction and Discovery of Conical Refraction by William Rowan Hamilton and Humphrey Lloyd (1832-1833)|O'Hara, J.G.|<i>Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy. Section A: Mathematical and Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 82A, No 2, 1982, pp 231-257.||Discovery of Conical Refraction by William Rowan Hamilton and Humphrey Lloyd (1833)|Sarton, G.|<i>Isis<i>, 1932, Vol 17, No 1, 1932, pp 154-170.||<i>The Mathematical Papers of Sir William Rowan Hamilton, Volume I, Geometrical Optics <i>|Conway, A.W., Synge, J.L., editors|Cambrige University Press, 1931.||<i>A History of Optics from Greek Antiquity to the Nineteenth Century <i>||Darrigol, O.|Oxford, 2012, 326 pp, NB pp 264-271.||<i>An Introduction to Hamiltonian Optics <i>|Buchdahl, H.A.|Dover, 1993, 369 pp.

BP_Short or Common Title: M√©moire sur la Polarisation de la Chaleur Seconde Partie
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second of two memoires investigating the polarization of heat radiant heat
BP_Description_1: Second of two memoires investigating the polarization of heat radiant heat. Using the apparatus developed for his heat flow experiments, Melloni demonstrates and investigates the polarization of radiant heat. Heat passing through plates of tourmaline is the principle method. This, and his first memoire on polarization, showed that radiant polarization was in all respects the same as optical polarization. This work was central in the eventual unification of light and heat as a single radiant phenomena. These papers attracted wide international attention, being translated almost immediately in German and English. This second memoire was prompted, in part, by exchanges that had taken place in British scientific journals regarding work by J.D. Forbes of the University of Edinburgh that supported the existence of radiant heat polarization.
BP_Description_2: In this memoire, Melloni uses laminae of mica to produce and detect radiant heat polarized by refraction and conducts experiments to determine how it behaves upon reflection. Importantly, Melloni shows that maximum radiant heat polarization takes place at the angle of incidence predicted by Brewster in the luminous case, using the index of refraction for radiant heat for mica. Melloni also detects birefingent polarization of radiant heat. In all cases, Melloni shows that it is necessary to shield or remove the heat radiated by the warmed laminae, otherwise it is mixed with the transmitted polarized radiation and confounds measurements. In doing so, he demonstrates some of the problems with J.D. Forbes' experiments.
BP_Reference(s): The Infrared Pioneers--II. BP_Short or Common Title: These de Physique sur la Diffraction de la Lumiere
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A thesis presented to the science faulty at the √âcole Normale in 1838 making use of Fresnel's theory of diffraction.
BP_Description_1: A brief experimental thesis that adopts the mathematics of Fresnel's diffraction theory and uses it to perform calculations that predict the nature of circular diffraction fringes. These predictions are compared to experimental observations. The thesis shows the rapid impact of Fresnel's work on European optics in general and French university teaching in particular. This is the doctoral thesis of the physicist Jean-Joseph-Benoit Abria who, upon graduating from the √âcole Normale in Paris, joined the faculty of sciences at Bordeaux where he taught for 50 years, being Dean of Physics Faculty for 40 years. Abria would work in optics most his life, followed Melloni's work on radiant heat carefully, and in 1866 published <i>Sur l'identit√© de la chaleur et de la lumi√®re<i>; the final unification of light and heat into a single radiant phenomenon.
BP_Description_2: The thesis begins with an historical review of diffraction, beginning with Grimaldi's initial observations and culminating in Fresnel's theory and his eponymous integrals for performing calculation to predict diffraction fringes.  Fresnel's  mathematics is applied to circular diffraction fringes, predicting their position. The author reports experiments in which he determined the placement and color of the fringes and compares them with what Newton reported in his work on thin film fringes. The position of the observed fringes are in alignment with the calculations, and the colors observed are used to estimate the wavelength of the light involved.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Savant and the State: Science and Cultural Politics in Nineteenth France<i>|Fox, R.|Johns Hopkins Unversity Press, 2012, 393 pp, NB: pp 100-102.
BP_Title: These de Physique sur la Diffraction de la Lumiere presentee a la faculte des sciences de Paris par J.-B. Abria, ancien eleve de l'Ecole Normale.
BP_Title English Translation: Physical Thesis on the Diffraction of Light, presented to the Faculty of Sciences of Paris, by J.-B. Abria, former student of the L'Ecole Normale.
BP_Biographical Statement: French academic, professor of physics at the Bordeaux Society of Sciences, dean of this faculty from 1845 to 1887

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An introductory textbook on geometrical optics; one of a series of three textbooks on mathematics and physics written by Griffin for use at Cambridge.
BP_Description_1: An introductory textbook on geometrical optics; one of a series of three textbooks on mathematics and physics written by Griffin for use at Cambridge. The style and manner of presentation make it clear the text was written by an experienced teacher. It is also clear that the book was written to accompany a course or tutoring in optics--there is no forward or preface and nothing to aid the self-taught. The scope of the text is limited to geometrical optics and its application to optical instruments and is highly analytic, providing clear mathematical derivations of important results regarding lenses, images, and the characteristics of optical instruments. This is among the first optics textbooks to use pencils of rays throughout, rather than the simpler geometrical artifice of single rays. Griffin's optics textbook became a standard work and was in use for many years. Editions appeared in 1838 and 1842. Griffin's text was extensively revised and amended by Stephen Parkinson and appeared in 1859, 1870, and 1884.
BP_Description_2: Griffin's textbook has 189 articles in seven sections. 1: General properties of light, reflection and refraction, rays and pencils of rays, reflection and refraction at spherical surfaces, geometrical focus, spherical aberration, reflection and refraction at parabolas and hyperbolas. 2: Off-optical-axis of reflection and refraction of pencils. 3: Combined reflection and refraction, paths through multiple media, paths through prisms and lenses, foci. 4: Off-optical-axis pencils and image formation in lenses. 5: Dispersion, varying indices of refraction and Fraunhofer lines, chromatic aberration, achromatic lenses, on and off-axis analysis. 6: Vision and optical instruments, eye and eye-function, telescopes, field of view, magnification, lensed and mirrored telescopes, eye-pieces, simple and compound microscopes, 7: The rainbow, formation, primary and secondary bow.  Appendix: Examples. The material is detailed and analytic. The development of lens analysis is very detailed, particularly the off-optical-axis analysis and aberrations which was unusual for textbooks. Applications of analysis to telescopes and microscopes is concise in the extreme. More elaborate is the explanation and solution of problems in geometrical optics posed in the 20-page Appendix.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of the Study of Mathematics at Cambridge<i>|Ball, W. W. R.|Cambridge, 1889, 264 pp, NB: pp 130-131.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A compendium of practical instrumental optics to explain the nature, construction, and use of such instruments, particularly of the telescope and microscope.
BP_Description_1: Friedrich Wilhelm Barfuss produced this compendium of practical instrumental optics to explain the nature, construction, and use of such instruments, particularly of the telescope and microscope. Barfuss' approach is entirely practical; that is, based solely on the use of optics to clarify and extend vision. This, his preface explains, is the justification for the long initial section on sight, perspective, shadow, anamorphosis, and appearances. Reflection and refraction are introduced in their simplest form, and then exemplified by consideration of the operation of a large number of experimental arrangements and instruments. In an attempt to reach a large audience, Barfuss holds it to be a mistake to introduce mathematical abstractions early in optical study; being appropriate only after a more graphical or geometric understanding is achieved and then mathematics can be invoked to consider advanced ideas and detail. For the more advanced material, Barfuss cites then-recent works on optics and instruments. Intending to provide a complete guide to instruments, he includes material on all aspects of glass working and instrument construction. Editions appeared in 1839, posthumously in 1860, and much revised in 1889. Barfuss published his <i>Theorie der Spiegelmikroscope mit Sph√§rischen Glasspiegeln<i> in 1840 as an addendum to the present work.
BP_Description_2: Barfuss' compendium is in nine chapters. 1: Vision and sight, perception, projection, camera obscura. 2: Perspective, appearance, shadows. 3: Laws of reflection, mirrors, analysis of plane and curved mirrors, images from mirrors, description of mirrored instrument operation, mirror anamorphosis. 4: Laws of refraction, refraction and plane and curved surfaces, operation of prisms, prismatic colors, index of refraction and dispersion, measurement, description of refractive instrument operation. 5: Lenses, types of lenses, analysis of lenses, calculating focal lengths and image position and size, spherical aberration, chromatic aberration. 6: Simple lensed instruments, camera lucida, camera obscura, magic lantern, the eye and eye-function, spectacles for vision correction. 7: Lensed telescopes, general form, types, magnification, achromatic objectives, discussion of recent practical lens work, example telescopes, telescope configuration and use. 8: Mirrored telescopes, Newtonian telescope, Gregory's telescope, example telescopes. 8: Microscopes, simple and compound, field of view and magnification, objective and ocular combinations, chromatic and spherical aberration correction, illumination methods, mirrored microscopes, solar microscope. 9: Instrument making, optical glass, glass properties, lens grinding, figuring and polishing, machine and hand work, mirror making. Most sections begin with a general description, invoking only simple geometry, followed in some cases by formulae and worked examples using real data. Virtually all the material is geometrical optics; phenomena important for instruments are described without any attempt to invoke physical optics for explanation. Analytical results, such as lens specifications, from other works are presented without derivation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Carl Zeiss: A Biography 1816‚Äì1888<i>|Wimmer, W., Paetrow, S.|Zeiss Archives, 2016, 144 pp, NB: pp 61-62.
BP_Title: Optik, Catoptrik und Dioptrik oder theoretisch-praktischer Unterricht uÃàber den moÃàglichst vollkommenen Bau aller optischen Instrumente, besonders aller Arten von FernroÃàhren und Microscopen, nebst Angabe der praktischen Hilfsmittel zur technsichen AusfuÃàhrung derselben. Ein populaÃàres Lehrbuch fuÃàr alle diejenigen, welche mit geringen mathematischen Vorkenntnissen sich von diesen GegenstaÃànden eine moÃàglichst gruÃàndliche Kenntni√ü erwerben und vollkommene optische Instrumente verfertigen wollen. BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary optics textbook written for and tailored to cadets at the United States Military Academy.
BP_Description_1: William H.C. Bartlett states very clearly his purpose in writing this textbook: to produce an elementary optics textbook suitable for and tailored to cadets at the United States Military Academy. He is also clear that the book draws its material from the books of Coddington, Brewster, Herschel, and Powell, all of whom had recently produced either books or extended articles on optics. The geometric optics material comes from the textbooks of Coddington, Brewster, and Powell; the physical optics material comes from Herschel's article 'Light' in the Encyclopaedia Metropolitana of 1830. Though the substance of the material comes from these sources, the textbook is no mere compendium. Bartlett was a mathematician and astronomer and incorporated material he well understood, making the style and manner of its presentation his own: principle results are derived (rather than just stated), with geometry, algebra, and the calculus used as required. It is clear that Bartlett made (quite knowingly) the assumption that the cadets would have sufficient mathematical sophistication by the time that took the optics course based on this book. He held that textbooks has three purposes: exercise of mental discipline, generation of subject knowledge, and confirmation of mathematical power. But Bartlett's textbook is not all theory; there are extensive sections describing applications of theory to optical instruments, their construction, and their use. This general form and style was characteristic of the other textbooks he produced: Acoustics, Astronomy, Mechanics, and Molecular Physics. Editions of the optics textbook appeared in 1839 and much revised in 1893.
BP_Description_2: Bartlett's textbook as essentially two parts: geometric optics and optical instruments (175 pages), and physical optics (50 pages), though there are no separately labeled sections. The material is presented in a single, continuous stream. The material on geometrical optics begins with fundamental laws of reflection and refraction, interaction of both with plane and spherical surfaces, development of the pencil of rays as the basic geometric optics entity, lenses and their characteristics, spherical aberrations. These developments are then applied to image generation, the eye and eye-function, field of view and magnification, the description of several types of telescopes, surveying instruments, camerae lucida and obscura, the magic lantern, atmospheric optical phenomena. The physical optics material is entirely wave theory based and covers interference, diffraction, double refraction, polarization, and colors of thin plates. The geometrical optics material is detailed, highly analytic, and applied to characterizing optical instruments whenever possible. The physical optics material is more general and descriptive.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Biographical memior of William H.C. Bartlett 1804-1893<i>|Holden, E.S.|National Academy of Sciences, Biopgraphical Memoires, Vol VII, 1911, pp 173-193, NB: pp 181-186.

BP_Biographical Statement: American astronomer, mathematician, engineer. Professor at the United States Military Academy.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An advanced, highly mathematical treatment of the wave theory of light, constructed using the basic developments of Fresnel on transverse waves and polarization and the work of Cauchy on the 3-dimentional lattice nature and properties of the luminiferous aether.
BP_Description_1: Karl Wilhelm Knochenhauer considered the wave theory of light to be one of physics' great achievements, as worthy of being studied, appreciated, and understood as the theory of gravity. He cites the recent work in what is now called infrared radiation which showed that it too could be part of a general wave theory of radiation. But he considered available textbooks to be wholly insufficient and too elementary in their presentation of the modern wave theory, too timid in their willingness to use the necessary mathematics, and the availability of original sources too difficult to provide the necessary means of study. He wrote what considered to be the necessary supplement for physics textbooks. The result was an advanced, highly mathematical treatment of the wave theory of light, constructed using the basic developments of Fresnel on transverse waves and polarization and the work of Cauchy on the 3-dimentional lattice nature and properties of the luminiferous aether. Knochenhauer developed several new methods for approximating the elaborate integrals that expressed the consequences of the theory in the form of quantities that could be measured. His work was on the same level as that of George Biddell Airy. Knochenhauer's book became a standard references and was cited until the turn of the 20th century.  His work in wave theory lead to his work in electric field theory and his proposal in 1842 of electric oscillations.
BP_Description_2: Knochenhauer's treatise contains 17 sections. 1: Equations that determine the vibrations of light in a uniformly elastic medium. 2: Movement of light. 3: Diffraction of light. 4: Refraction and dispersion. 5: Oscillation Equations of the Reflected and refracted light, Circular and elliptic polarization. 6: Interference phenomena by reflection. 7: Reflection from metal surfaces. 8: Colors from Thin Plates. 9: Mathematical required for the equations for light oscillations one and two-axis media. 10: The vibrational equations of light in one and two-axis media. 11: Double Refraction. 12: Direction of polarization of the ordinary and extraordinary refracted rays. 13: Color decomposition in unequal elastic media. 14: Influence of surfaces of uniaxial crystals on reflected and refracted light. 15: Influence of Surfaces of Two-Crystals on reflected and refracted Light. 16: Interference of ordinary and extraordinary refracted rays after their passage through plates of one or two-axes crystals. 17: Rings of color around the axis of the quartz crystal.
BP_Reference(s): The Discovery of Oscillatory Electric Current|Gluckman, A.G.|Journal of the Washington Academy of Sciences , Vol 80, No 1, 1990, pp. 16-25.
BP_Title: Die Undulationstheorie des Lichtes

BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, teacher. Prolific worker and writer in electricity and optics.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A compendium providing a detailed, mathematical description of the wave theory of light.
BP_Description_1: F. W. Gustav Radicke produced this two-volume compendium to provide a detailed, mathematical description of the wave theory of light. He makes clear that since the time of Malus' discovery of polarization by reflection, the development of wave theory had been extensive and rapid, but the original works were hard to acquire, other books were insufficiently detailed, and the most rest developments had seen little recognition. Radicke's approach was entirely theoretical, coming to his subject as a mathematician with the task of accommodating the wave theory of light to experimental facts of optical phenomena. Radicke attempts to accommodate virtually all optical phenomena, and his list includes those described in the stream of journal articles produced by the unwearying David Brewster. One of nine parts of the two volume work deals with practical matters: optical instruments, with descriptions of applications of theory to image formation that are, as is the rest of the work, of dense and deep concision.
BP_Description_2: Radicke's two volumes encompass nine parts. 1: Laws of motion of homogeneous light. 2: Light propagation at media transitions. 3: Interference phenomena. 4: Interference phenomena due to unequal paths. 5: Reflection and Refraction. 6: Absorption. 7: Physiological optics. 8: Meteorological optics. 9: Optical instruments. The first two parts present a full development of the wave theory of light. Most of Parts 3, 4, 5, and 6 are devoted to applications of the theory to account for a long list of laboratory experimental results that reveal a particular optical phenomena. Parts 7, 8, and 9 apply wave theory to natural phenomena. The material is detailed and highly analytic.
BP_Reference(s): Radicke, F. W. Gustav|Karsten, G.|in: Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie Vol 27, 1888, pp 135 ; URL: https://www.deutsche-biographie.de/pnd116322721.html#adbcontent

BP_Short or Common Title: Sulla teoria della propagazione della luce¬†
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of the first Italian treatises on mathematical physics, Codazza presents Fresnel's wave theory of light.
BP_Description_1: Codazza wrote the <i>Sulla Teoria<i> while he was assistant professor of physics and chemistry at the University of Pavia. Based on his study of Fresnel, Cauchy, MacCullagh and others, he produced a full description of the wave theory of light. It assumed a high level of mathematics and was written in the vernacular specifically for Italian university students studying physics. He states in his Preface his desire to bring together the works of disparate authors, harmonize, eliminate confusion, and produce a concise and uniform presentation of light theory.
BP_Description_2: The <i>Sulla Teoria<i> is a treatise of mathematical physics giving a complete exposition of Fresnel's wave theory of light. In 19 chapters it presents in mathematical detail Fresnel's wave theory and its explanation of interference, diffraction, and polarization. Also included are descriptions of then-recent attempts of Cauchy and MacCullagh to define the mechanical properties of an aether in which Fresnel's wave could travel and exhibit their experimentally demonstrated properties. An Appendix gives the elementary aspects of Fresnel's theory.
BP_Reference(s): Codazza, Giovanni|Ferola, R.|In: Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani, Vol 26, 1982,
BP_Title: Sulla teoria della propagazione della luce omogenea nei mezzi omogenei
BP_Title English Translation: On the theory of homogeneous light propagation in homogeneous media
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian scientist and professor at the Politecnico of Milan and eventually director of the Royal Industrial Museum of Turin.
BP_Provenance: Dedicatiion by the author.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Gauss considers the paths of light rays through a system of lenses and produces his most remarkable result: the reduction of complex optical system to the analysis of a single, infinitely thin lens. This was the foundation of what has become Gaussian Optics
BP_Description_1: Carl Friedrich Gauss first became involved in optics in 1807 when a Hamburg instrument maker asked him about an achromatic telescope objective. Gauss's work in optics was always a mix of the theoretical and elaborately computational, particularly in optics. His work ended up be limited because of his resolute believe in the corpuscular nature of light. In this short but famous work, Gauss considers the paths of light rays through a system of thick lenses. His most remarkable result is the reduction of complex optical system to the analysis of a single, infinitely thin lens. This was the foundation of what has become Gaussian Optics
BP_Description_2: Gauss demonstrates that, if only paraxial rays are considered, a rotationally symmetric lens system of any degree of complexity can be analyzed by replacing it by two principal points and two focal points of an otherwise infinitely thin lens. Along with the nodal points, these are now called the cardinal points of the lens system. Gauss gives a process to determine the positions of these points experimentally, and an iterative method to determine their positions from surface curvatures. In the process of developing this iterative process, Gauss set down the two governing simultaneous linear equations that relate input and output ray position and angle. This would eventually lead to matrix methods in Gaussian Optics. The distances from the principal points to their respective focal points being the focal lengths of the lens. The paraxial assumption and the analysis shown to be possible in the present work has come to be know as Gaussian Optics and is still used today.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Lens Design Fundamentals<i>|Kingslake, R., Johnson, R.B.|Academic Press, 2010, 549 pp, NB: pp 67-68.||Correctly making panoramic imagery and the meaning of optical center|Johnson R.B.|In: <i>SPIE Proceedings, Optical Engineering + Applications, 2008<i>.||Numerical Work. Dioptric|B√ºhler, W.K.|Chapter 13 In: <i>Gauss<i>, Springer, 1981, 208 pp, NB: 142-145.

BP_Short or Common Title: Lectures on the Wave-Theory of Light
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A mid-19th century summary of the wave theory of light; after the theories of Young and Fresnel and before the electromagnetism of Maxwell.
BP_Description_1: Lloyd had worked on the manuscript for his <i>Treatise on Light and Vision<i> while a junior (that is, teaching) fellow Trinity College, Dublin. It was finished early in 1831. He had followed the developments of wave-based physical optics carefully and in 1834 produced his famed report on the state of physical optics for the meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science in that year. This included his description of the verification of conical refraction, predicted by Hamilton using Fresnel's theory. All of this work was summarized in these lectures on physical optics dealing with the wave theory of light. At the time of their publication, the wave theory of light had completely overtaken the emission and ray theories in England. Editions of Lloyd's lectures appeared in 1841 (the edition described here), in 1857 at London with the slightly changed title "Elementary Treatise on the Wave-Theory of Light," and again in 1873. The lectures remained a standard summary of the wave theory of light until Maxwell's electromagnetism.
BP_Description_2: lloyd's lectures on physical optics are in two parts: Unpolarized and polarized light. The six lectures of Part I consider the physical optics of unpolarized light, culminating in the theories of Thomas Young and the Augustin Fresnel. Along the way, a review of Newton's theory of Fits of easy Reflexion and Transmission is given. The six lectures of Part II consider the experimental phenomena that describe and define polarized light, including Fresnel's theory and experimental verification. The last two of these lectures consider polarized light in crystals, including double refraction and conical refraction.||The material is almost entirely descriptive, with only basic algebraic and trigonometric expressions being used to describe the the characteristics of polarized light in Part II. Though the results of Fresnel's work is described, none of his elaborate mathematics is presented.
BP_Reference(s): Waves, Philosophers and Historians|Buchwald, J.Z.|In: <i>Proceedings of the Biennial Meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association<i>, 1992. No 2, pp. 205-211|<i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 290-292.||Humphrey Lloyd, 1800-1881|Spearman, T. D.|Hermathena, No 130/131, 1981, pp. 37-52.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Schleiermacher cites the difficulty of using analytic optics in the design of dioptric instruments and attempts to remedy that by generating approximations for practical optical work. He was concerned with image sharpness, first and second order spherical and chromatic aberrations from optical elements with spherical surfaces.
BP_Description_1: Ludiwig Johann Schleiermacher published in the Annalen der Physik und Chemie of 1828 a long article on the use of analytic optics in the design dioptric instruments and the experimental assessment of the result. Schleiermacher cites it has the germ of his <i>Analytische Optik<i>, and like the article, is limited to analytical dioptrics. He also cites the many advances made in optical theory since the approximations that were used then, particularly in off-axis analysis and the determination of aberrations. But he notes the difficulty of using such analyses, their general lack of application, and the widening gap between optical theory and practice. What Schleiermacher recognized as necessary was an entirely new set of much more accurate approximations that would allow their practical application to the analysis of off-axis rays and the reduction of aberrations. Schleiermacher's book was written to fill that need; first by deriving in the fullest way the governing equations in a suitable form, and then generating from them approximations for practical work. Schleiermacher was concerned with image sharpness, first and second order spherical and chromatic aberrations from optical elements with spherical surfaces. He notes that the recent work of Gauss on paraxial analysis reached him too late to be included. Schleiermacher was famous for teaching models he built, used to demonstrate principles. One commentator calling them "equations in wood." Schleiermacher's work continued to be used and his book cited till the end of the 19th century. Though the title page contains 'First Part', a second part never appeared.
BP_Description_2: Schleiermacher's book has a long introduction and 10 chapters. The introduction begins with a brief historical review beginning with the work of Euler and Kl√ºgel. It then gives a descriptive outline of the processes used and the  general developments in the entire book. 1: Exact formulas for refraction. 2: Equations of multiple-orders of aberrations. 3: Chromatic aberrations. 4: Equations relating incident and refracted rays accounting for spherical and chromatic aberrations. 5: First order approximations. 6: Deeper analysis of aberrations. 7: Blur of small images. 8: Blur of large images. 9: Generating the greatest image clarity. 10: Instrument images. Schleiermacher establishes the governing finite-difference equations for refraction and integrates them. From these he extracts multiple-order approximations that have forms permitting practical application in lens design. This includes off-axis rays, blur of large images, field size, effect of eye position, and multiple orders of spherical and chromatic aberrations. Minimizing aberrations is accomplished by finding minima of the governing approximations involving lens parameters. The mathematical developments are elaborate and presented in considerable detail. Though highly theoretical, all the developments are informed by the goal of practical applicability.
BP_Reference(s): Ludwig Schleiermacher und seine optischen Arbeiten|Boegehold, H.|In:  Forschungen zur Geschichte der Optik (Supplement to:  Zeitschrift f√ºr Instrumenten¬≠kunde), Vol 2, No 3, 1937, pp 177‚Äì244.
BP_Title: Analytische Optik von Dr. L.J. Schleiermacher, Grossherzoglich Hessischem Oberbaudirector und Director des Grossherzoglichen Museums, des Ludewigsordens Ritter I. Classe.
BP_Title English Translation: Analytical Optics. By Dr. L.J. Schleiermacher, Grand Ducal Hessian Director and Director of the Grand Ducal Museums, Knight of the Order of Ludwig, First Class.

BP_Description_1: First description of the direct detection of polarized light.
BP_Description_2: The first to observe that the polarization of light is visible without auxiliary means was the mineralogist von Haidinger in the present work in 1844. He described as 'Lichtpolarisations-b√ºschel' the phenomenon which was later to become known as Haidinger's brushes. Under certain conditions of illumination and polarization, differential absorption of light by macular pigments is perceived as the entoptic phenomena of Haidinger‚Äôs brushes.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A memoir on the rotation of the plane of polarization of polarized light in quartz.
BP_Description_1: Jean-Baptiste Biot's 220-page memoir on the rotation of the plane of polarization of polarized light in quartz; the pinnacle of his long series of works on rotary polarization. From Biot's work would come a powerful analytical tool in organic chemistry.
BP_Description_2: In his investigation into the rotation of the plane of polarization in liquids, Biot measured rotation amount, handedness, and dependence on wavelength. From his vast collection of data he formulated the basic quantitative expressions for polarimetry, optical rotary chromatic dispersion, and optical superposition.
BP_Reference(s): A brief history of polarimetry|Lyle, R.E., Lyle, G.G.|<i>Journal of Chemical Education<i>, Vol 41, No 6, 1964, pp 308-313.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Doppler's full development of what is now called the Doppler Effect, invoked to explain the color difference of double stars
BP_Description_1: Christian Andreas Doppler full development of what is now called the Doppler Effect. To explain the color difference of double stars, Doppler proposed that their motion with respect to us (toward and away) was shifting the frequency of received radiation, and thus the apparent color. He first described his idea in a memoir published in 1842: '√úber das Farbige Licht der Doppelsterne und einiger anderer Gestirne des Himmels'. Though this is often cited as marking the appearance of the Doppler Effect, this is incorrect. This early memoir only accounted for motion of the emitting source. In the present treatise, Doppler developed his theory to include the motions of both the emitter and the receiver and thus allowed astrophysical applications.
BP_Description_2: Doppler's article is in three parts. 1: A method to determine the apparent diameter of the fixed start. 2: Optical determination of the distances and sizes of the fixed stars. 3: Determining the oscillation speed of light molecules based on motion. Doppler's complete development that accounts for motions of both emitter and received is in part three.
BP_Reference(s): Johann Christian Doppler and His Effect--A Brief History|White, D.N.|<i>Ultrasound in medicine and Biology<i>, Vol 8, No 6, 1982, pp 583-591.||<i>A Review of Redshift and its Interpretation in Cosmology and Astrophysics<i>|Dunning-Davies, J.|arXiv preprint arXiv:0806.4085 (2008)||<i>Moving the Stars: Christian Doppler, His Life, His Works and Principle, and the World After<i>|Schuster, P., Wilmes, L., translator|Living Edition Publilshers, 2005, 233 pp, NB: pp 60-65.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Early work on the effects of light on plant physiology and organic substances.
BP_Description_1: Zantedeschi wrote this essay after years of research on electromagnetism, finally turning to the study light's effects on plant physiology and organic substances more generally. This was a new field of research at the time. The <i>Richerche<i> is a summary of the work reported in several previously published papers dealing with light's effects and was the beginning of a larger work on optics that remained in manuscript at the time of Zantedeschi's death. The <i>Richerche<i> was printed in 100 copies.
BP_Description_2: The work has four chapters. Chapter 1: The influence of sunlight on the germination of plants and the generation of seeds; Chapter 2: Color changes that occur in organic and inorganic substances due to the action of light alone; Chapter 3: Results obtained from a new analysis of the light spectrum; Chapter 4: The transition from ponderable matter to the radiant state. Zantedeschi used a Silbermann heliostat and an upright prism and projecting lens to investigate the solar spectrum and its Fraunhofer lines.
BP_Reference(s): Fisici al Foscarini: Francesco Zantedeschi|Malfi, P.|Il Liceo Classico Foscarini di Venezia|online at: http://museo.liceofoscarini.it/museoreale/testi/zantedeschi.pdf||Zantedeschi-Porro Spectrometer ‚Äì the Oldest Preserved Two-armed Device for Observation of Line Spectrum|Jacek, R.|<i>Kwartalnik Historii Nauki i Techniki<i>, Vol 61, No 4, pp 145-163. (Google translated from the Polish).

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first of Potters two optics books, written for use in his courses in natural philosophy at University College London. The first and second books were specifically for use in elementary and advanced courses, respectively.
BP_Description_1: Richard Potter planed a two-volume work on geometric optics in 1845. Part One appeared in 1847. Part Two, in a second volume, appeared in 1851, along with a reprinting of the volume containing Part One. Potter's plan was to separate his textbook on geometrical optics into a first, elementary part which presented the basic aspects of reflection, refraction, mirrors, lenses, dispersion, vision, and instruments--no aspect of which reaching a level that required advanced mathematics. The second part was to treat the more advanced aspects of refractive image formation, lenses, and achromatic optics--any of which require the use of the calculus. Potter based this second part on Henry Coddington's <i>A Treatise on the Reflexion and Refraction of Light<i> of 1829 and to a lesser extent George Biddle Airy's work. Written for his own use in his courses in natural philosophy at University College London, Potter wrote the two parts specifically for use in elementary and advanced courses in optics at university. Uncharacteristically, Potters texts contain considerable material devoted to illumination and photometry which reflects, perhaps, the fact that though an experimentalist, he was a natural philosophy of the old school. But his textbooks were clear and vigorous, written long before his notorious decline. Editions appeared in 1851 and 1865.
BP_Description_2: Potter's textbook is in two parts, each in its own volume. Part I contains and introduction and nine chapters. 1: Photometry. 2: Reflection at plane mirrors, 3:Reflection a curved mirrors. 4: Refraction at plane surfaces. 5: Refraction at curved surfaces. 6: Refraction of homogenous light in lenses and their images. 7: Chromatics. 8: Eye and vision. 9: optical instruments. Part II contains seven chapters. 1: Photometry. 2: Reflection at plane and spherical mirrors. 3: Refraction at plane and spherical surfaces. 4: Images from lenses. 5: Achromatic and aplanatic lenses. 6: Eye pieces (oculars). 7: Caustics.  Part I presents the elementary aspects of optics, catoptrics, and dioptrics. The material is elementary but detailed enough to present principles. No mathematics above geometry and trigonometry is used. Most chapters conclude with questions for students to solve. Part II presents the advanced aspects of catoptrics and dioptrics, specifically image formation and the aberrations involved. Governing equations are presented, along with approximations that permit solutions useful in practice. Differential and integral calculus are required to follow the derivations. The material is detailed and analytic and accompanied by application of theory and equations in practical, worked-out examples.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A vast compendium of modern optics, literature review, and bibliography of physical optics.
BP_Description_1: Fran√ßois-Napol√©on-Marie Moigno began work on this vast compendium, literature review, and bibliography of physical optics, working for 5 years to complete it.
BP_Description_2: Part 1 contains 4 Sections. Section 1: Analysis of Cauchy's work on the mathematical theory of light. Section 2: Explication, analysis, and assessment of optical phenomena regarding the two systems on light's nature: emission and waves. Section 3: Meteorological optics. Section 4: Mineralogical optics. Part 2 contains 4 Sections. Section 5: Solution of various difficulties. Section 6: On colors themselves and in bodies. Section 7: Accidental or Subjective Colors. Section 8: Light's action other than on the eye. Part 3 contains 2 Sections: Section 8: (reconsidered and greatly expanded) Light's action other than on the eye. Addenda to the first two Parts, describing work done in 1847, 1848, and 1849. Part 4: Analysis of optical work of 1847, 1848, 1849. This part end with a 32-page index of author names and references to part and page number in the present work.||Moigno presents summaries of all the works he considers and when required, equations and data. Derivations are not presented. In that sense, the work is a directory and not a teaching instrument.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second printing of Barlow's 1829 article 'Optics', written for and published in the <i>Encyclopedia Metropolitana<i>. Widely regarded as a magisterial summary of geometric optics.
BP_Description_1: Peter Barlow's article 'Optics' appeared in Volume 1 of Mixed Sciences, Second Division (Volume 3 in the entire series), of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i> in 1830. It was one of several long articles Barlow wrote for the <i>Encyclop√¶dia<i>, including Astronomy, Magnetism, Electro-Magnetism, and Manufacturing. The optics article was  privately distributed before its appearance in the <i>Encyclopaedia<i> and was generally recognized as a useful, complete summary of geometrical optics. Though considered an 'essay', it was 98 folio pages with 10 plates of 135 figures and an index, and was the foundation and principle optics reference for many compendia and textbooks on natural philosophy in the 19th century. It was reprinted in this, the second edition of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i>. For the second edition,  original sections were published under separate titles, in the present case: <i>The Encyclopedia of Mechanical Philosophy<i> contained parts of Volume 3 and 4 of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i>. This included: Mechanics, Hydrodynamics, Pneumatics, Sound, Optics, and Light. Included were the 78 plates.
BP_Description_2: Barlow's essay begins with a long history of optics, beginning with Euclid and Aristotle and ending with with second decade of the 19th century. The history is followed by two Parts. Part I covers 'Simple Optics' and includes definitions, nature and propagation of light, shadows, light properties regarding vision and color, and perceptions.  Part II covers Catoptrics, Dioptrics, and Vision, including the foci and images from mirrors, image magnification and location, making mirrors, convex and concave mirrors and their images, analysis of mirror images, foci and images from lenses, analysis of lens images, ocular anatomy, distinct and indistinct vision, spectacles, telescopes of various types, microscopes, camera obscura, magic lantern, and other optical instruments.||The material on physical optics is very brief and just sufficient to establish light rays as the principle analytical device. The geometric optics is thorough and though achromatic lenses are discussed, aberrations in general are not treated in detail. The material on mirrors and lenses is extensive and presented in considerable mathematical detail. This material is analytical, rather than oriented toward design. The material on optical instruments is descriptive rather than analytic.||Throughout the text, Barlow introduces problems and their solutions as a way to demonstrate the application of the theoretical material.
BP_Reference(s): The Revival of the Physical Sciences in Britain, 1815-1840|Miller, D.P.|<i>Osiris<i>, Vol 2, 1986, pp 107-134.
BP_Title: The Encyclopedia of Mechanical Philosophy (Optics)
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, physicist. Mathematics Master at the Royal Military Academy, collaborated with George Dollond on achromatic lens development.
BP_Publisher or Seller: London: John Joseph Griffin, Glascow: Richard Griffin
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Brown Morocco Over Cloth Covered Boards, All Edges Marbled

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second printing of Herschel's 1827 article 'Light', written for the <i>Encyclopedia Metropolitana<i>. Widely regarded as a magisterial summary of physical optics; that is, the nature and properties of light.
BP_Description_1: John Frederick William Herschel's article 'Light' was composed in 1827 and appeared in Volume 2 of Mixed Sciences, Second Division (Volume 4 in the entire series), of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i> in 1830. But the article itself was  privately distributed beginning in 1828 and had circulated widely before its appearance in the Encyclopaedia. It was immediately recognized both in England and on the continent as a magisterial summary of physical optics; that is, the nature and properties of light. Though Herschel considered his work an 'essay', it was 243 folio pages with additional plates and an index, and was treated as a monograph in its subsequent and immediate reprintings and translations. It was reprinted in this, the second edition of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i>. For the second edition, the original sections were published under separate titles, in the present case: The <i>Encyclopedia of Mechanical Philosophy<i> contained parts of Volume 3 and 4 of the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i>. This included: Mechanics, Hydrodynamics, Pneumatics, Sound, Optics, and Light. Included were the 78 plates.
BP_Description_2: Herschel's essay is in four parts: Unpolarized Light, Chromatics, Theories of Light, Polarized Light. 1: Unpolarized Light including photometry, reflection from plane and curved surfaces, refraction at plane and curved surfaces, aberrations, images from lenses, the eye and vision. 2: Chromatics including dispersion, achromatic lenses, extinction from propagation in transparent media. 3: Theories of Light including Newtonian or corpuscular theory, general undulatory theory, interference, colors from thin and thick plates, diffraction. 4: Polarized Light including double refraction, interaction of polarized light, reflection of polarized light, refraction of polarized light, application of the undulatory theory, light in crystals, light's interaction with materials, properties of glass, colors of bodies, calorific and chemical rays in the solar spectrum. Herschel's treatments of the undulatory theory of light is a full statement of Fresnel's theory and the best presentation of the wave theory for 10 years after it appeared.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 291-296.||The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132.
BP_Title: The Encyclopedia of Mechanical Philosophy (Light)
BP_Biographical Statement: English polymath, astronomer, mathematician, chemist. Asiduous astronomical observer, practical optician, scientific author.

BP_Short or Common Title: Sur une experience relative a la vitesse de propagation de la lumi√®re
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Fizeau determines the speed of light within 5% of the modern accepted value.
BP_Description_1: In 1845, Fran√ßois Arago suggested to Fizeau and Foucault that they attempt to measure the speed of light. Sometime in 1849, however, it appears that Fizeau and Foucault had a falling out, and they parted ways pursuing separate means of performing this experiment. They would remain rivals.¬†In 1848‚àí49, Fizeau used a toothed wheel apparatus to perform an absolute measurement of the speed of light in air.¬†Fizeau's early ideas and, indeed, a clearer indication of his experiment than in his published paper, is found in his sealed description (pli cachet√©) of scientific plans handed to the Acad√©mie des Sciences. Fizeau‚Äôs pli cachet√© is dated 20 January 1849 with three further remarks dated 22 January. It was accepted by the Acad√©mie des Sciences as the pli cachet√© No. 878 on the same day. Such papers were produced and maintained by the academy to settle priority disputes.
BP_Description_2: In this paper of 1849, Fizeau presents his experiment and calculation of the speed of light, calculating a value to a better precision than the previous value determined by Ole R√∏mer in 1676. Fizeau determined the speed of light using an intense light source behind a partially silvered mirror, and a fully silvered mirrors about 8 km distant. Fizeau set up the source and partially silvered mirror at his parents' home at Suresnes and the other mirror on Montmartre, the hill on the right bank of Paris. These were 8633 meters apart. It is not usually noted that theses mirrors were in the eye pieces of two telescopes, allowing sighting, light concentration, and limited interference.  The light traveling between the mirrors was interrupted by a rotating cogwheel with 720 notches that could be rotated at a variable speed of up to hundreds of times a second. Fizeau adjusted the rotation speed of the cogwheel until light passing through one notch of the cogwheel would be completely eclipsed by the adjacent tooth. Spinning the cogwheel at 3, 5 and 7 times this basic rotation rate also resulted in eclipsing of the reflected light by the cogwheel teeth next in line. Given the rotational speed of the wheel and the distance between the wheel and the mirror, Fizeau was able to calculate a value of 315000 km/s for the speed of light from the 28 experimental runs he made. It was difficult for Fizeau to visually estimate the intensity minimum of the light being blocked by the adjacent teeth, and his value for light's speed was about 5% higher than the modern accepted value (299,792.458 kilometers per second).
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ 'Toothed wheels and rotating mirrors: Parisian astronomy and mid-nineteenth century experimental measurements of the speed of light'|Tobin, W.|<i>Vistas in Astronomy<i>, Vol 30, No 3, 1993, pp 253-294.||'Creativity and Technology in Experimentation: Fizeau's Terrestrial Determination of the Speed of Light'|Frercks, J.|<i>Centaurus<i>, Vol 42, No 3, 2000, pp 249-287.
BP_Title: Sur une experience relative a la vitesse de propagation de la lumi√®re. In: Comptes Rendus: Hebdomadaires de sc√©ances de l‚ÄôAcademie de Sciences (Paris, Vol. 29 [July‚ÄìDecember 1849], pp. 90‚Äì92).
BP_Title English Translation: On an experiment relating to the speed of propagation of light.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physicist famed for his optics work
BP_BibliographicNotes: Volume titlepage on œÄ‚ÇÅ ≥

BP_Short or Common Title: Methode g√©n√©rale pour measurer la vitesse de la lumi√®re dans l'air and les milieux transparents
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Foucault's determine of the difference in the speed of light traveling in air and in water
BP_Description_1: By the mid 1840's, a significant goal of French science was to experimentally decide between the corpuscular or wave nature of light. Fran√ßois Arago had adapted the rotating mirror apparatus invented in 1834 by Charles Wheatstone to determine the relative speeds of light in air and water. Faster/Slower for the wave supposition, Slower/Faster for the corpuscular. Arago's health was failing and his experimental worked ceased, but he challenged Fizeau and Foucault to devise their own experiments to settle this question. Foucault, assisted with instrument maker Paul-Gustave Froment, and Fizeau with Louis Breguet, began the competition to determine the relative speeds of light in air and water. Foucault obtained his results and reported them to the French Academy one week before Fizeau in 1850. Foucault used this experiment as the basis for his thesis submitted toward the <i>Docteur √®s Sciences<i> degree at the Sorbonne in 1853.
BP_Description_2: Foucault used a rotating mirror to provide for the comparison of two images of a single solar-illuminated aperture, each image produced by light traversing the same path length but one path was in air and the other had a portion of it in water. If the speed of light in water was faster or slow than that in air, the two images would appear shifted. Foucault's experiment gave a speed lower in water, and so favoring the hypothesis that light is a wave. The apparatus could not determine the absolute speeds of light, since it was not possible to accurate know the rotation speed of the mirror. Interestingly, both Foucault's and Fizeau's experiment could only be conducted in clear weather, as the Sun was required as a light source - the three meters of water used in one of the light-paths absorbed too much light to permit the use of any less powerful light source.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ 'Toothed wheels and rotating mirrors: Parisian astronomy and mid-nineteenth century experimental measurements of the speed of light'|Tobin, W.|<i>Vistas in Astronomy<i>, Vol 30, No 3, 1993, pp 253-294.
BP_Title: Methode g√©n√©rale pour measurer la vitesse de la lumi√®re dans l'air and les milieux transparents. Vitesses relatives de la lumi√®re dans l'air et dans l'eau. Project d'experieince sur la vitesse de propagation du calorique rayonnant. In: Comptes Rendus: Hebdomadaires de sc√©ances de l‚ÄôAcademie de Sciences (Paris, Vol. 30 [July‚ÄìDecember 1850], pp. 551-560).
BP_Title English Translation: General Method for the Determination of the Speed of Light in Air and Transparent Media. The Relative Speeds of Light in Air and Water.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physicist famed for his practical experimental work
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1850 Foucault - Methode g√©n√©rale pour measurer la vitesse de la lumi√®re dans l'air and les milieux transparents - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Summary of Melloni's life-long work in the characterization and measurement of thermal radiation.
BP_Description_1: Melloni's life-long work in thermal radiation is summarized and reported in this, the first part of his <i>La Thermochr√¥se<i>. He never wrote a second part. He showed that thermal radiation presented all the optical properties that had been attributed to light: linear propagation, polarization, reflection, refraction, dispersion, diffraction, and absorption. He would eventually propose a 'unitary theory' in which thermal radiation and light were manifestations of the same radiant phenomena, differing only in wavelength. His equipment and experimental procedures were ground-breaking and helped establish experimental thermal science.
BP_Description_2: Melloni summary of his work on heat radiation and the thermal properties of materials. He described and used his sensitive thermopile and galvanometer to survey the infrared transmittance of a variety of materials. The instrument in its early form had been developed by Leopoldo Nobili but had been improved by Melloni sufficiently to detect very weak heat radiation. The instrument was called a 'thermomultiplicateur', was approximately 50 times more sensitive than any extant liquid and glass thermometer. Based on this Melloni's work became widely known. The book includes more extensive experiments and the particularly important discovery that rock salt was as transparent to heat radiation as glass was to optical radiation. Melloni would make prisms and lenses of rock salt to discover the infrared parallel to geometric optics. Melloni's work would eventually show the unity of optical and heat radiation and lead to the unification of heat, optical, and chemical radiation into a single spectrum.||The work is in four chapters. 1: On the proper instruments to measure thermal radiation, 2: On heat sources and the equal absorption which their rays experience by the action of the black smoke, 3: Thermal radiation heat in vacuum and in atmospheric air, 4: Transmission of thermal radiation by solid and liquid media.||Melloni describes his unique and pioneering experimental apparatus and methods for producing and measuring heat. This included the 'Leslie Cube', a hot, black-painted metal plate, a glowing platinum wire, and the lamp of Locatelli. He describes his sensitive thermopile and the galvanometer to detect its current.  He also described his discovery and use of rock salt to form prisms that effected thermal dispersion and by which he detected the thermal spectrum. Numerous experiments are presented to show thermal transfer properties in vacuum, air, and through various materials.
BP_Reference(s): The Infrared Pioneers--II. Macedonio Melloni|Barr, E.S.|<i>Infrared Physics<i>, Vol 2, 1962, pp 67-73.||ùëª Memoir on the Free Transmission of Radiant Heat|In: <i>Scientific Memoires<i>, Taylor, R., editor and translator|London, 1837, pp 1-74.||Melloni‚Äôs Experiments and the Search for the Nature of Infrared Radiation|Carchon, R., Segers, D.|<i>European Journal of Physics Education<i>, Vol 6, No 4, 2016, pp 12-26.||For a listing of Melloni's articles, see: Catalogue of Scientific Papers, (1800-1863)|Royal Society of London, Vol IV, 1870, NB: pp 331-335
BP_Title: La Thermochr√¥se ou la Coloration Calorifique. D√©monstr√©e par un grand nombre d'exp√©riences, et consider√©e sous ses divers rapports avec la science de al chaleur rayonnate. Par Macedine Melloni. Permi√®re Parte.

BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicist, ingenious experimenter in the infared spectrum, did significant work in showing the unity of ultraviolet, visible, and infared has different parts of a single radiant spectrum.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Among the earliest optics textbooks produced in the United States.
BP_Description_1: As Jackson states in his Advertisement to the reader, he consulted the then-most important French and British works in optics in composing this textbook. In particular, he cites Biot, Lame, Airy, Lloyd, Herschel, and Coddingtaon. Like the works of Lloyd and Coddinton, Jackson separates the treatment of unpolarized and polarized light. Editions appeared in 1848, 1852, and 1867.
BP_Description_2: Jackson's text book is in two parts with chapters covering: Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Decomostion of Light, Eye and Optical Instruments, Meteorlogical Optics, Wave Theory, Colors in Plates, Diffraction, Polarization, Double Refraction, Phenomena and Laws of Polarization. The treatment is detailed, analytic, and written for the student with a background in physics and mathematics, including the calculus. The tight concision of the text makes the 130 figures an essential aspect of the presentation.||The material presents optics as it stood in mid 19th century: after Thomas Young and Augustin Fresnel and before Maxwell.
BP_Reference(s): Development of Optics Education in the United States|Thompson, B.J.|SPIE Proceedings, Vol 1603, Education in Optics, 1992, pp 9-26.

BP_Short or Common Title: On the Change of Refrangility of Light
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Stokes discovers, investigates, and charaterizes fluorescence.
BP_Description_1: The seeming ability of certain liquids to produce two colors of light from one, had been known since Kircher described the phenomena using an extract of 'lignum nephriticum' in his <i>Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae<i> of 1646. Though there was considerable interest in this phenomenon during the late 17th century, during the 18th century the phenomenon was eclipsed in importance by other optical questions. But at the beginning of 19th century, crystalline minerals such as fluorspar, were found to behave as did the solutions. It was initially thought the the additional color of light was produced by some type of scattering or dispersion. But Stokes showed the light to be a true emission, brought about by the action of incident light. This is now recognized as a type of phosphorescence of short duration. Stokes coined the term 'fluorescence' from the fluorspar used in his experiments.||Stokes noticed and described that the emitted light was always 'degraded'--that is, had longer wavelengths than the incident light. This became known as Stokes' Law of Fluorescence.' The shift in wavelength of the incident to the fluorescently emitted light came to be called the 'Stokes Shift.' Stokes' paper initiated wide-spread interest in fluorescence experimentation in the second half of the 19th century, notably by Eugen von Lommel. Stokes paper established the modern field of luminescence.
BP_Description_2: Stokes' paper was 100 pages long and one of the most thorough on the subject. It is based on earlier work of the mineralogist  Ren√© Just Ha√ºy, and that of John Herschel, and David Brewster. Stokes described two methods to study the phosphorescent phenomenon he called 'fluorescence.' The first used filters to select incident and detect fluorescently emitted light. The second was spectrographic: prismatic dispersion was used to select the illuminating light and observe any fluorescently emitted light. It was the second method that clearly showed the universality of the long wavelength shift of the emitted light. A solution of quinine showed this phenomena in a spectacular way: A test tube of solution glowed blue when illuminated by ultra-violet light.||Stokes experiments were very complete, studying the spectrum of fluorescently emitted light, the types and amplitude of fluorescence produced by various input spectra, the effect of various sources (such as electric sparks), the effect of concentration on amplitude of fluorescence, so-called quenching, and produced a long list of substances that fluoresced.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of Luminescence<i>|Harvey, E.N.|American Philosophical Society, Philadelphia, 1957, 692 pp, NB:  pp 352-355, 395-398.
BP_Title: On the Change of Refrangility of Light. In: Philosophical Transcations of the Royal Society of London, for the year MDCCCLII, Part II.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish mathematician and physicst, held the Lucasian Mathematics Chair at Cambridge for 54 years. Famous for contributions in optics, dynamics, and mathematical physics.
BP_Plates: Plates [XI-XXXV], XXIV is a folding map.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elaborate, carefully presented, mathematically detailed consideration of physical optics based on the undulatory theory of light.
BP_Description_1: August Beer was a mathematical physicist, with a particular interest in optics. Beer's text is an elaborate, carefully presented, mathematically detailed consideration of physical optics. The preface states his reason for writing the book: to bridge the gap between the 'less profound textbooks' and the the exhaustive, specialized treatises and articles of the various authorities. The preface also make clear that Beer considered the undulatory theory of light to be capable of explaining all optical phenomena: reflection, refraction, diffraction, dispersion, propagation, color, polarization, and double refraction.||Beer sees his task as not only presenting in necessary detail the undulatory theory of light but also showing its great explanatory power by using to analyze optical phenomena in crystals.||Beer's text achieved a high and widely-held reputation and, along with F√©lix Billet's <i>Traite d'Optique Physique<i>, would not surpassed until Paul Drude's <i>Lehrbuch der Optik<i> nearly 50 years later with its presentation of electro-magnetic theory. Editions of Beer's work appeared in 1853 and 1882. A French translation appeared in 1858.
BP_Description_2: Beer's text is in two parts, the first setting the principles of the undulatory theory of light and its propagation in isotropic media. The second part applies the theory developed in the first part to the derivation of mathematical expression for optical phenomena including dispersion and propagation in crystals and birefringence.||Part One is in 11 chapters. 1: Wave theory principles; 2: Propagation of light: 3: Refraction and change in media and dispersion; 4: Polarization in birefringence; 5: Mathematics of light propagation; 6: Interference of Polarized light; 7: Elliptical Polarization; 8: Unpolarized light; 9: Photometric analysis; 10: Partially Polarized light; 11: Apparatus for detecting polarized light.||Part Two is in 12 chapters. 1: Analytic derivation of propagation equations; 2: Law of dispersion; 3: Propagation in crystals; 4: Structures of crystals; 5 & 6: Propagation equations applied to crystals; 7: Law of dispersion; 8: Propagation equations applied to crystals; 9: Wave surfaces in crystals; 10: Refraction in biaxial crystals; 11: Optical properties of biaxial crystals; 12: Apparatus for studying propagation of light in crystals.||Part one sets out the undulatory theory in a descriptive but thorough way. Part two is deeply and elaborately mathematical.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Potter produced this textbook specifically to describe important optical phenomena and the experimental apparatus and processes that can demonstrate them. Avoiding mathematics, the material presents optical phenomena, the experiments that revealed them, and most importantly, to describes the bearing they had on determining the nature of light.
BP_Description_1: Richard Potter produced this textbook specifically to describe important optical phenomena and the experimental apparatus and processes that can demonstrate them. Potter believed that most texts that attempted to describe optics were also committed to explanations that were too mathematical for the student and interested lay reader. He wanted present optical phenomena, the experiments that revealed them, and most importantly, to describe the bearing they had on determining the nature of light. The subtitle of Potter's text is apt: <i>A Descriptive and Experimental Treatise<i>. Potter was among the last of British natural philosophers to hold with the corpuscular theory of light, and an additional reason for this text was to prepare the way for another book that appeared in 1859, explaining optical phenomena by way of the corpuscular theory.
BP_Description_2: Potters textbook has an introduction and four chapters. The introduction give a very brief history of physical optics the general nature of the properties of light. 1: Double refraction. 2: Polarization. 3: Interference, Diffraction, colors of thin plates, polarized interference, retarded interference. 4: Phosphorescence and photometry. The material is entirely descriptive, with experiments described in a clear and elementary manner, using no very special laboratory equipment.
BP_Reference(s): <i>A History of the UCL Physics and Astronomy Department from 1826 - 1975<i>|Fox, J.W.|UCL Department of Physics and Astronomy|http://www.ucl.ac.uk/physics-astronomy/about/history/departmental-history/history-ucl-physics-and-astronomy-department-1826-1975||<i>A List of Educational Books for Private and University Students<i>|George Bell and Sons, London, 40 pp, NB: pp 19-20.
BP_Title: Physical optics, or The Nature and Properties of light: A Descriptive and Experimental Treatise.  By Richard Potter, A.M. F.C.P.S. Late Fellow of Queens' College Cambridge; Licentiate of the Royal College of Physicians, London; Honorary Member of the Literary and Philosophical Society of St. Andrew's; Professor of Natural Philosophy and Astronomy in University College, London.
BP_Biographical Statement: English natural philosopher, academic.  Professor at University College, London.
BP_Provenance: From the library of William Thomson, Lord Kelvin, with a dedication from the author. Bookplate of Glasgow University, dated 1898.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: With Seidel's work, third-order wave aberration theory was finally cast into complete analytic form, and allowed for the significant advance of lens design
BP_Description_1: Philipp Ludwig von Seidel wrote this article to report his comprehensive study of lens aberrations and the equations he found relating lens properties and aberrations. With Seidel's work, third-order wave aberration theory was finally cast into complete analytic form, and allowed for the significant advance of lens design since the analysis was not constrained to near-optical-axis, as with Gaussian Optics. From this work come the eponymous Five Seidel Aberrations and the mathematical formalism that has been used to analyze them since Seidel's time. The article was printed in three sections in numbers 19, 20, and 21 of volume 43 of Astronomiche Nachrichten in 1856.
BP_Description_2: Seidel identifies five aberrations in spherical lens systems: spherical aberration, coma, astigmatism, curved field, and distortion. Seidel finds expressions for the coefficients used in expressing these aberrations, coefficients that can be expressed by lens' parameters: radii, thicknesses, refractive indices, and separating distances.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Reflecting Telescope Optics I: Basic Design Theory and its Historical Development, 2nd edition<i>|Wilson, R.N.|Springer, 2007, 569 pp, NB: pp 63-65.||Evidence supporting the primacy of Joseph Petzval in the discovery of aberration coefficients and their application to lens design|Rakich, A.|In: <i>Conference Proceedings, Novel Optical Systems Design and Optimization X<i>, SPIE, 2007.

BP_Title English Translation: Diptrics. On the development of the 3rd order terms which determine the path of a light ray outside the plane of the axis through a system of refracting media. In: Astronomiche Nachrichten, 1856, p 290-335.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, photometric astronomer, optician and colleague of Adolph Steinheil. Teacher of Max Planck.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Lissajous's description of his figures that display in a concise way magnitude and phase of vibrations
BP_Description_1: Lissajous was interested in demonstrating vibrations in way that were not did require the sense of hearing. This long article is his most important research, and describes his invention of a way to study acoustic vibrations by reflecting a light beam from the vibrating object onto a screen. The shapes came to be called Lissajous Figures and display in a concise way the frequency, phase, and amplitude of vibrations. This is an early example of the application of optics to use light as an investigative tool.
BP_Description_2: Lissajous produced two kinds of luminous curves. In the first kind, light is reflected from a tuning fork with a small mirror is attached and then from a large mirror that is rotated rapidly. The second kind of curve, named the 'Lissajous Figure,' is more useful and is still used in many acoustical applications. The light beam is successively reflected from mirrors on two forks that are vibrating about mutually perpendicular axes. Persistence of vision causes various curves, whose shapes depend on the relative frequency, phase, and amplitude of the forks' vibrations. Lissajous presents the mathematics that define the curves and from that develops concise ways to specify characteristics of the vibrations based on the number, orientation, ellipticity, and size of the loops of the figures. These are Lissajous curves. The memoire is accompanied by two large plates, the first showing the apparatus and the second showing the figures produced by various sounds.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Adventures with Lissajous Figures<i>|Greenslade, T.|IOP ebooks, 2018, NB: pp 2.1 - 2.14.
BP_Title: Memoire sur Etude optique des mouvements vibratoires. In: Annales de Chimie et De Physique 3rd Series, Vol 51, 1857 pp 147-231.
BP_Title English Translation: Memoire on the Optical Study of Vibratory Movements.  In: Annales de Chimie et De Physique 3rd Series, Vol 51, 1857.
BP_Biographical Statement: French academic mathematician and physicist
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of the University of Southern California

BP_Short or Common Title: Elementary Treatise on the Wave-Theory of Light (a)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Lloyd's treatise explains most optical phenomena using Fresnel's wave theory of light and Cauchy's theory of the luminiferous aether. An extraction and simplification of his earlier book on light.
BP_Description_1: Humphrey Lloyd delivered six lectures on the wave theory of light at Trinity College Dublin in 1835-1836. These were expanded and Lloyd published his <i>Lectures on the Wave Theory of Light<i> in 1841 to satisfy a requirement of the chair of natural philosophy he held at Dublin at the time. The need for a text in English on physical optics had grown considerably in the 15 years since the publication of those lectures, owing to many theoretical and experimental advances that had been made. Unlike the Lecture of 1841 which separated the study of unpolarized and polarized light, Lloyd's new treatise presents physical optics as a unity, eliminates references to Newtonian corpuscular theory, and explains most optical phenomena using Fresnel's wave theory of light and Cauchy's theory of the luminiferous aether. But like the <i>Lectures<i> of 1841, the new treatise is essentially descriptive, with results given without derivation and required mathematics never rising above trigonometry. Lloyd directs the reader interested in and capable of expositions involving higher mathematics to Herschel article 'Light' that had appeared in the <i>Encyclop√¶dia Metropolitana<i> in 1828 and to Airy's Tracts of 1831. For explanations of then-recent developments, Lloyd relies on his own report on the state of physical optics prepared for the British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting of 1834 and on Moigno's vast literature review and bibliography of 1847-1850. Lloyd‚Äôs treatise was used as a textbook for many years, was one of the most important sources in English for and introduction to the wave theory of light, and was only superseded with the advent of Maxwell's theory of electromagnetic fields. Though the title page states 'Second Edition, with Additions,' the reference is to Llyod's lectures of 1841; this is essentially a new work. Editions of the treatise appeared in 1857 and 1873.
BP_Description_2: Lloyd's treatise contains 218 articles in 13 chapters. 1: Propagation of light. 2: Reflection and refractions. 3: Dispersion. 4: Double refraction. 5: Interference. 6: Diffraction. 7: Colors of thin plates. 8: Polarization. 9: Transverse wave and reflection of polarized light. 10: Elliptic polarization. 11: Fresnel's theory of double refraction. 12: Interference of polarized light. 13: Rotary polarization. Though entirely descriptive, the material is very detailed. In each chapter there are two types of material: the first are detailed descriptions of optical phenomena and the way in which the wave theory accounts for or predict them; the second are citations and descriptions of works (mostly journal articles) that clarify or add important detail to the wave theory--mostly since the theory was first formed in the 1820's. The list of contributors in the latter case is extensive and among them is Foucault and Fizeau's work determining the relative speed of light in air and water the results of which aligned with the wave theory. The text takes the luminiferous aether as a given.
BP_Reference(s): The Dublin Mathematical School in the First Half of the Nineteenth Century|McConnell, A. J.|<i>Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy. Section A: Mathematical and Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 50, 1944-1945, pp 75-88.

BP_Biographical Statement: Irish natural philosopher, academic. Professor of Natural and Experimental Philosophy at Trinity College, Dublin.

BP_Description_1: Pierre Forthomme's close French translation of Beer's <i>Einleitung in die h√∂here Optik<i> of 1853. August Beer was a mathematical physicist, with a particular interest in optics. Beer's text is an elaborate, carefully presented, mathematically detailed consideration of physical optics. The preface states his reason for writing the book: to bridge the gap between the 'less profound textbooks' and the the exhaustive, specialized treatises and articles of the various authorities. The preface also make clear that Beer considered the undulatory theory of light to be capable of explaining all optical phenomena: reflection, refraction, diffraction, dispersion, propagation, color, polarization, and double refraction.||Beer sees his task as not only presenting in necessary detail the undulatory theory of light but also showing its great explanatory power by using to analyze optical phenomena in crystals.||Beer's text achieved a high and widely-held reputation and, along with F√©lix Billet's <i>Traite d'Optique Physique<i>, would not surpassed until Paul Drude's <i>Lehrbuch der Optik<i> nearly 50 years later with its presentation of electro-magnetic theory. English editions of Beer's work appeared in 1853 and 1882, this translation appeared in 1858.
BP_Description_2: Beer's text is in two parts, the first setting the principles of the undulatory theory of light and its propagation in isotropic media. The second part applies the theory developed in the first part to the derivation of mathematical expression for optical phenomena including dispersion and propagation in crystals and birefringence.||Part One is in 11 chapters. 1: Wave theory principles; 2: Propagation of light: 3: Refraction and change in media and dispersion; 4: Polarization in birefringence; 5: Mathematics of light propagation; 6: Interference of Polarized light; 7: Elliptical Polarization; 8: Unpolarized light; 9: Photometric analysis; 10: Partially Polarized light; 11: Apparatus for detecting polarized light.||Part Two is in 12 chapters. 1: Analytic derivation of propagation equations; 2: Law of dispersion; 3: Propagation in crystals; 4: Structures of crystals; 5 & 6: Propagation equations applied to crystals; 7: Law of dispersion; 8: Propagation equations applied to crystals; 9: Wave surfaces in crystals; 10: Refraction in biaxial crystals; 11: Optical properties of biaxial crystals; 12: Apparatus for studying propagation of light in crystals.||Part one sets out the undulatory theory in a descriptive but thorough way. Part two is deeply and elaborately mathematical.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 309-310.
