BP_Brief Summary of the Work: F√©lix Billet's 1200-page Trait√© is one of the last, extensive expositions of physical optics before the advance of the theory of electromagnetic fields
BP_Description_1: F√©lix Billet's 1200-page <i>Trait√©<i> is one of the last, extensive expositions of physical optics before the advance of the theory of electromagnetic fields. Billet excludes catoptrics, dioptrics, geometrical optics and aberrations, which he labels 'Old Optics' and also mentions his exclusion of Photometry, traditionally considered part of optics, but now left behind by developments in optics. Perhaps appropriately, he considers the development of the wave theory of light as a renewal of optics; beginning with Malus's discovery of polarization by reflection and then covering virtually all aspects of the subsequent development of the theory. Unlike some of the equally lengthy compendia of optics, the Trait√© has a unifying structure that topical and ordered from the fundamental to the complex, rather than chronological. Billet wrote his <i>Trait√©<i> to unify all the various data, equations, and phenomena in optics in the previous 30 years, providing for the mathematically-capable student a complete overview of wave optics. Among he several conceptual innovations was the coherence and incoherence of light--terms is first introduced. With this work, Billet established his reputation in the field of optics.
BP_Description_2: Bilett's <i>Traite<i> is in 24 chapters with additional notes. 1: Fundamental concepts including wave movement, propagation speed, amplitude. 2: Fundamental constants of optics including the speed of light in various media, wavelength, analogy with sound, Doppler effect. 3: Wave motion. 4:  Interference of unpolarized light including colors of thin plates and Newton's rings. 5: Diffraction including Fresnel's work and Schwerd's diffraction calculations and experiments. 6: Double refraction including its crystal geometry and analysis. 7: Linear polarization phenomena. 8: Modern optical instruments based on the 'new optics.' 9: Linear polarization theory for reflection and refraction. 10: Interference of polarized light. 11: Production and phenomena of circularly and elliptically polarized light. 12: Theory of circularly and elliptically polarized light. 13: Circularly and elliptically polarized light by total internal reflection. 14: Circularly and elliptically polarized light by reflection at metal and glass. 15: Linearly, circularly, and elliptically polarized light by crystalline reflection. 16: Measurement of polarization characteristics. 17: Circular double refraction. 18: Rotary chromatic polarization. 19: Chromatic polarization of circularly, and elliptically polarized light. 20: Rotary polarization experiments including magnetic polarization rotation. 21: Rotary polarization and chemistry. 22: Rotary polarization and crystallography. 23: Experimental methods of de S√©narmont. 24: Elliptical double refraction in quartz. 25: Theory of double refraction including conical refraction. Chapters 1 through 10 cover the more fundamental aspects of light's wave theory. In these early chapters Billet often provides historical commentary regarding the development and reception of the then-revolutionary ideas. Chapters 11 through 25 become increasingly narrower in scope, greater in detail, and generally more arcane. The overall work is highly detailed and analytic.
BP_Reference(s): <i>History of the Principle of Interference of Light<i>|Kipnis, N.|Springer, Basel, 1991, 271 pp, NB pp 124, 236-237.
BP_Title: Traite d'Optique Physique, Par M.F. Billet, Professeur de Physique on the Faculty of Sciences of Dijon. Tome Primier. Tome Second.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An elementary but systematic exposition of the properties of light and laws of Vision. Representative of mid-19th century school books covering aspects of natural philosophy.
BP_Description_1: Between 1835 and 1850 the Chambers brothers published the inaugural series consisting of 68 textbooks specifically written for grammar school use. By the time of the publication of this volume devoted to optics in 1858, the series consisted of 133 books. Subjects included English, Writing and Drawing, Geography, History, Arithmetic and Mathematics, Science, Latin, German, and Music. Since their inception, the books were intended to be read by students, adhering the the Chambers's belief that education must arise from the familiar, the practical, and the easily apprehended; not from abstraction and not by memorization. Often written by teachers, the books were specifically structured to assist the teacher, and the language used was commensurate with grammar school student skill and vocabulary. By 1860 Chambers brothers' textbooks began to be used in Canada and the United States.||The prefaces states the intention: 'to present a systematic exposition of the properties of light and laws of Vision.' The book covers all aspects of optics involving light and vision, presented in an elementary but thorough manner, at a level appropriate for students net yet in university. The style is descriptive--no mathematics above elementary geometry is used--and relies heavily on the figures that accompany the text. The structure and completeness of the material permitted the book's use for self-study or in a school course. This text optics first appeared in 1850.
BP_Description_2: The text is in seven sections. 1: General Observations, covering the nature and propagation of light. 2: Reflection, covering plane and spherical mirrors, images from mirrors. 3: Refraction, covering law of refraction, prisms, atmospheric refraction, spherical lenses, foci and images from lenses, compound lenses. 4: Prismatic colors. 5: Optical Instruments, covering magnification, solar microscope and magic lantern, telescopes, microscopes. 6: The Eye and Vision, covering anatomy, eye function, vision and perception. 7: Physics Optics, covering interference, diffraction, polarization, double refraction, chromatic phenomena, polarized interference.||The material is elementary and simply presentational; no derivations are presented. Light rays are presented as the principle manifestation of light, and are used in the geometric optics that is covered. Mirrors and lenses are simply described, with chromatic aberration described but not considered analytically. Most sections have at least one Example to demonstrate the principle or idea being presented.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Publishers for the People<i>|Cooney, S.M.|Dissertation, Ohio State University, 1971, 270 pp, NB: pp 153-213.|http://etd.ohiolink.edu/!etd.send_file?accession=osu1486661662987297&disposition=inline.||Business and Reading Across the Atlantic: W. & R. Chambers and the United States Market|Fyfe, A.|In: <i>Books between Europe and the Americas: Connections and Communities, 1620-1860<i>|Howsam, L., Raven, J., editors, Palgrave Macmillan, 2011, 316 pp, NB: pp 257-282.
BP_Title: Chambers's Educational Course, Natural Philosophy (Fifth treatise) Optics
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish publishers, geolosits, editors, and writers
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1858 Chambers - Optics - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A consideration of the theory of lens aberrations, their computational approximations, and application of those approximations to the design of an aplanatic lens.
BP_Description_1: In his 'Preliminaire,' Mossotti makes clear the value he places on the theoretical and mathematical apparatus in practical optics. He chides Thomas Young for his dismissal of Euler's early efforts at the mathematization of lens design. He outlines how basic principles and mathematical analysis can be used in lens design; specifically by building a practical mathematical apparatus for modeling off optical axis geometric lens aberrations (spherical and coma aberrations) . Using the aberration theory developed by Mossotti, Giovanni Battista Amici designed and built an achromatic triplet of 6-inch aperture and 52-inch focal length that was corrected for geometric aberrations. Mossotti summarized the events that lead up to this work by Amici and how he considered it a test of his aberration theory. Amici's successful lens that convinced Mossotti to publish this work. Parts of work appeared in the Annali delle Universit√† Toscane, and the forth part (on the design of an aplanatic lens) appeared as a long entry in the journal Il Nuovo Cimento for December 1859.||Mossotti's theory was recognized as a significant step forward in practical lens design and he was held to be one of the greatest optical theoreticians of his time.
BP_Description_2: Mossotti sets out a theory for the correction of geometric lens aberrations that can be applied to achromatic lenses involved multiple elements. The work is in four parts. 1: Ray-tracing through optical instruments of many surfaces. 2: First approximations to geometric lens aberrations. 3: Second approximations to geometric lens aberrations. 4: Application of the theory to a multiple-element aplanatic lens. The work is detailed, clearly laid out, and densely mathematical. Examples of the principles are given for microscopes and telescopes as they are developed. The fourth and final part is in bristling mathematical detail, including elaborately documented numerical calculations leading to the specification of the shape of all the lens surfaces involved.
BP_Reference(s): The Production of achromatic objectics in the first half of the nineteenth century: The Contributions of Giovanni Battista Amici|Proverbio, E.|<i>Memorie della Societ√† Astronomia Italiana<i>, Vol 61, No 4, p 829-875.||Su di un obiettivo costruito dall‚ÄôAmici se- condo la teoria del Mossotti|Morais, C|In:<i> Physis<i>, Vol 2, 1965, pp 202-210.
BP_Title: Nuova Teoria Degli Stromenti Ottici
BP_Title English Translation: A New Theory of Optical Instruments
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian-born physicist, taught at the University of Buenos Aires and then at Tuscany. Did important work in practical optics and dielectrics.
BP_Provenance: Dedicatiion by the author. Bookplate of DiGorgio Tabarroni on pastedown.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Parkinson's first extensive revision and emendation of the second edition of William Nathaniel Griffin's optics textbook that had appeared in 1842.
BP_Description_1: The first edition of Stephen Parkinson's extensive revision and emendation of the second edition of William Nathaniel Griffin's optics textbook that had appeared in 1842. Parkinson rearranged the material and made additions which altered the nature of the book considerably. Unlike Griffin's original text, Parkinson's book has enough additional explanation and detailed worked examples and problems--particularly in the second and third  editions--to make it accessible for self-study or a reading course in university. That is, it is considerably more independent of a course of lectures. To this end Parkinson provides a suggested course of reading for either self-study or to prepare for examinations. As with Griffin's original, Parkinson's revision deals only with geometrical optics. Parkinson's textbook became a standard and was used for many years. It was, for example, the text used by J.W. Strutt, Lord Rayleigh in his undergraduate optics course at Cambridge. Editions appeared in 1859, 1866, and 1870.
BP_Description_2: Parkinson's textbook has 11 chapters. 1: General properties of light, direct reflection and refraction, rays and pencils of rays, reflection and refraction at spherical surfaces, geometrical focus, spherical aberration, reflection and refraction at parabolas and hyperbolas. 2: Illumination of surfaces. 3: Aberration of pencils by refraction at spherical surfaces. 4: Focal lines and caustics of pencils. 5: Successive reflections and refractions in prisms and lenses. 6: Paths of pencils through systems of multiple surfaces. 7: Spherical aberrations. 8: Images from reflection and refraction. 9: Chromatic dispersion. 10: Vision and optical instruments. 11: The rainbow and halos. The material is detailed and analytic. The development of lens analysis is very detailed, particularly the off-optical-axis analysis and aberrations. Applications of analysis to telescopes, microscopes, and other instruments is concise in the extreme. More elaborate is the explanation and solution of problems in geometrical optics posed throughout the text.
BP_Reference(s): The Principles and Methods of Geometrical Optics: Especially as Applied to the Theory of Optical Instruments|Southall, J.P.C.|MacMillan, 1910, 626 pp, NB: pp v-vi.
BP_Title: A Treatise on Optics  by S. Parkinson, D.D.; F.R.S. Fellow and Tutor of St. John's College, Cambridge. Third Edition Revised.
BP_Biographical Statement: English academic. Tutor at St John's College, Cambridge, author of important textbooks.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Green Calf, Spine And All Edges Gilt. Kelly & Sons Binding With The Crest Of Queen Elizabeth's Free Grammar School In Wimborne Minster On The Upper Board. Marbled Pastedowns And Endpapers.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1859 Parkinson - A Treatise on Optics - Images.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Hermann Robert Gieswald (1824-1862) German scientist, Headmaster at St. John's school in Danzig.
BP_Short or Common Title: PopulaÃàres Lehrbuch der Optik, Catoptrik, und Dioptrik
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Gieswald's editing of Friedrich Wilhelm Barfuss' textbook of 1839. The text maintains the original focus on applications while updating the theoretical parts to align with optical developments in the 20 years since the last edition.
BP_Description_1: Hermann Robert Gieswald's editing of Friedrich Wilhelm Barfuss' textbook of 1839 appeared as the third volume in the series Neuer Schauplatz der K√ºnste und Handwerke (New Theater of the Arts and Crafts). Gieswald describes the need to update Barfuss's text, maintaining its focus on applications while updating the theoretical parts to align with optical developments in the intervening 20 years. The most significant changes being the elimination of the long introductory section on perspective and the added theoretical detail in the sections on physical optics. Another editing of Barfuss's text by Ferdinand Meisel appeared in 1889.
BP_Description_2: Gieswald's edition of Barfuss' compendium is in ten chapters. 1: General remarks on light, its generation and propagation, shadows, and reflection. 2: Laws of reflection, mirrors, analysis of plane and curved mirrors, images from mirrors, description of mirrored instrument operation, mirror anamorphosis. 3: Laws of refraction, refraction and plane and curved surfaces, operation of prisms, prismatic colors, index of refraction and dispersion, measurement, description of refractive instrument operation. 4: Lenses, types of lenses, analysis of lenses, calculating focal lengths and image position and size, spherical aberration, chromatic aberration. 5: Simple lensed instruments, camera lucida, camera obscura, magic lantern, the eye and eye-function, spectacles for vision correction. 6: Lensed telescopes, general form, types, magnification, achromatic objectives, discussion of recent practical lens work, example telescopes, telescope configuration and use. 7: Microscopes, simple and compound, field of view and magnification, objective and ocular combinations, chromatic and spherical aberration correction, illumination methods, mirrored microscopes, solar microscope. 8: Interference and diffraction.  9: Polarization. 10: Instrument making, optical glass, glass properties, lens grinding, figuring and polishing, machine and hand work, mirror making. Most sections begin with a general description, invoking only simple geometry, followed in some cases by formulae and worked examples using real data. Aside from chapters 8 and 9, virtually all the material is geometrical optics; phenomena important for instruments are described without any attempt to invoke physical optics for explanation. Analytical results, such as lens specifications, from other works are presented without derivation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Carl Zeiss: A Biography 1816‚Äì1888<i>|Wimmer, W., Paetrow, S.|Zeiss Archives, 2016, 144 pp, NB: pp 61-62.
BP_Title: PopulaÃàres Lehrbuch der Optik, Catoptrik, und Dioptrik. Theoretisch-praktischer Unterricht uÃàber den Bau aller optischen Instrumente. Zweite n√∂llig umgenrheitete Anflage von Dr. Hermann Gieswald, Oberlehrer an der St. Johannischule in Danzig. Mit einem Atlas, enthaltend 31 Quarttafeln.
BP_Title English Translation: Dr. F.W. Barfuss' Popular Textbook on Optcis, Catoptrics, and Dioptrics. Theoretical-Practical Lessons on the Construction of All Optical Instruments. Second Completely Revised Edition by Dr. Hermann Gieswald, Senior Teacher in the Johann-School in Danzig. With an Atlas Containing 31 Quarto Plates.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, experimentalist, and  author
BP_Provenance: Stamp of 'C.F. M√ºller, Optiker', Rathenow, on titlepage
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1860 Barfuss - PopulaÃàres Lehrbuch der Optik, Catoptrik, und Dioptrik - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: On the Theory of Compound Colours and the Relations of the Colours of the Spectrum
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Maxwell's paper on color perception, color specification, and what is now called colorimetry. It marks the final separation of color science from optics, establishing it as a separate field of study and research.
BP_Description_1: Maxwell's interest in color and color vision has its origin when he was a student at the University of Edinburgh and joined the color vision research program of the physicist J.D. Forbes. in 1849. Maxwell continued this work in 1854 when he was at Cambridge. He began with the trichromatic color theory of Thomas Young which was an important effect of the paper: drawing attention to Young's theory. Maxwell's initial experiments blended colors by using visual persistence and three colors presented on a rapidly rotating wheel. The proportion of each of the components was determined by the size of the wedge on the wheel. This method was replaced with evermore sophisticated viewing boxes that allowed three narrow bands of chosen from the solar spectrum to be combined in arbitrary proportion. This apparatus, the trichromator, was fundamental to the development and result of Maxwell's research and is described in the paper. One aspect of the instrument's design was the development of the eponymous 'Maxwellian View' that produced a uniform field for observation.||The paper introduced the concept of metameric color matches--different physical stimuli producing the same perceptual response. It also described dichromatic vision or 'color blindness.' and establishes the concept of a 'color space.' The paper marks the separation of color science and color perception from optics, establishing color, its specification, and its perception as a field of research and study in its own right.
BP_Description_2: Maxwell begins the paper with a review of color theory, adopting Thomas Young's trichromatic theory and establishing a three dimensional color space, each dimension corresponding to the stimulus of each of the three types of sensors in the eye. Importantly, he established 'The Principle of Univariance'--wavelength information is not retained, only the amount of light. This color space led to the linear algebra of color equations that would be used to described and specify metameric color matches. The paper then describes Maxwell's trichromator and its use in determining what are now called color-matching functions of normal human color vision. This included his 'Method of determining the Wave-length corresponding to any point the Spectrum.'  Interestingly, Maxwell's error analysis of his experimental results lead him to discover that vision is more sensitive to chromatic difference than to brightness difference. His experiments also revealed individual differences in color vision, the 'Maxwell Spot,' a description of dichromatic color vision or 'color blindness,' and the elaborate process he used to determine the spectral sensitivities of the three color sensors in the eye.
BP_Reference(s): Classical Articles in Color|Zaidi, Q.|<i>Color Research and Application<i>, Vol 18, No 4, 1993, pp 270-287.
BP_Title: "On the Theory of Compound Colours and the Relations of the Colours of the Spectrum." In: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, Vol 150, 1860.  Complete Vol 150 Part I, In original wrappers.
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish mathematical physcist, academic. Genius eclipsed only Newton and Einstein, famed for work in electro-magnetism, mechanics, color, thermodynamics.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1860 Maxwell - On the Theory of Compound Colours and the Relations of the Colours of the Spectrum - Images.JPG
BP_Image2: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1860 Maxwell - On the Theory of Compound Colours and the Relations of the Colours of the Spectrum - Images 2.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: Elements of Experimental and Natural Philosophy
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An example of mid-19th century British tracts written for a wide, general audience with an interest in the many aspects of natural philosophy but without any mathematical background.
BP_Description_1: Second edition of Jabez Hogg's text of 1853 was prompted by the success of the first edition--selling 10,000 copies in seven years. The book is an example of mid-19th century British tracts written for a wide, general audience with an interest in the many aspects of natural philosophy but without any mathematical background. Considerably expanded from its first edition, Hogg assembled the main components of the several topics he covered for exposition, sometimes uncritically. Though a medical man active in ophthalmology, he relies on other sources for most of the material he presents. For some topics, he is quite behind the times. He presents, for example, the wave theory of heat which most physicists had abandoned.||Editions appeared in 1853 and 1861. This second edition received some revision and updating by the author and included many new figures. Hogg's work was also issued as part of Bonn's 'Scientific Library.'
BP_Description_2: Hogg's optical material (166 pages) cover elementary optics including a descriptive definition of light, reflection, refraction, catoptrics, dioptrics, image formation by mirror and lens, prismatic colors, natural colors, the eye and ocular anatomy, eye-function and image formation, binocular vision, the telescope and other astronomical instruments, the microscope simple and compound, photography, the interference and polarization of light, polarized light and crystals. The material is elementary and entirely descriptive. The emphasis is on applications and the optical operation of instruments. The material on telescopes and microscopes is particularly detailed. No mathematics is involved.
BP_Reference(s): Hogg, Jabez (1817‚Äì1899)|Power, D'A.|In: Dictionary of National Biography, 1901 supplement, Vol 2, pp 432-433.||The Wave Theory of Heat: A Forgotten Stage in the Transition from the Caloric Theory to Thermodynamics|Brush, S.G.|<i>The British Journal for the History of Science<i>, Vol 5, No 2, 1970, pp. 145-167.
BP_Title: Elements of Experimental and Natural Philosophy: Being a Familiar and Easy Introduction to the Study of the Physical Sciences; Embracing Animal Mechanics, Pneumatics, Hydrostatics, Hydraulics, Acoustics, Optics, Caloric, Electricity, Voltaism, and Magnetism. Illustrated with Nearly Four Hundred Woodcuts. by Jabez Hogg, F.L.S., M.R.C.S., Fellow of the Medical Society of London, Member of the Pathological and Microscopical Societies of London, etc.
BP_Biographical Statement: English ophthalmic surgeon.
BP_Provenance: Inscribed Harry E. Woods, Boston, C.H.S, dated 1873
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1861 Hogg - Elements of Experimental and Natural Philosophy - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: D√©termination exp√©rimentale de la vitesse de la lumi√®re; parallaxe du Soleil
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Foucault's determine of the speed of light using a rotating mirror
BP_Description_1: In 1855, Foucault was appointed Laboratory Physicist at the Observatoire de Paris. In 1861 he began working on the experiment to measure the speed of light. As in 1850, Foucault was assisted by the instrument maker Paul-Gustave Froment. The apparatus was an extension and refinement of that of the 1850 experiment and after one year of work, Foucault announced his result.
BP_Description_2: Foucault used a rotating mirror to provide for the comparison of two images of a single solarly illuminated aperture. The mirror, rotating at 400 rps, slightly displaced the image of the aperture, as light traveled a distance of 40 meters, by way of 5 concave mirrors. A rotating toothed wheel allowed the sweeping images produced by the mirror to be interrupted, and so produced two adjacent but shifted image positions. Foucault announced his result in September of 1862: 'in round numbers, 298 millions' of kilometers per second, with an uncertainty of 1/2 million. The description of the apparatus appeared later that same year, on 17 November.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ 'Toothed wheels and rotating mirrors: Parisian astronomy and mid-nineteenth century experimental measurements of the speed of light'|Tobin, W.|<i>Vistas in Astronomy<i>, Vol 30, No 3, 1993, pp 253-294.
BP_Title: D√©termination exp√©rimentale de la vitesse de la lumi√®re; parallaxe du Soleil. In: Comptes Rendus: Hebdomadaires de sc√©ances de l‚ÄôAcademie de Sciences (Paris, Vol. 55 [July‚ÄìDecember 1862], pp. 501-503 & 792-796).
BP_Title English Translation: Experimental Determination of the Value of the speed of Light and parallax of the Sun.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physicist famed for his practical experimental work

BP_Short or Common Title: Essais sur la theÃÅorie matheÃÅmatique de la lumieÃÄre (a)
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Charles Briot's essays take up four topics within the wave theory of light, beginning with the pioneering work of Cauchy.
BP_Description_1: Charles Briot essays take up four topics within the wave theory of light, beginning with the pioneering work of Cauchy.
BP_Description_2: Briot's four essays cover the following. 1: General laws of vibratory motion, including plane waves, presumed properties of the luminiferous aether as 3-dimentionl lattice, integration of the governing differential equations. 2: Double refraction including vibratory motion in crystals with single and double axes. 3: Dispersion of light including changes of light-speed based on wavelength. 4: Circular polarization including vibratory motion in asymmetric media, crystals and circular polarization. Briot is a mathematician, not an optician, and so brings his considerable mathematical skills to bear on the four topics he considered with the abstraction of a mathematician. But he attempts to secure the validity and utility of his mathematical models by comparison with experimental data. Such as the comparison he make between the predictions of his elaborate, 5-th order approximation for polarization rotation and the otherwise inexplicable rotation data obtained with tartaric acid. To all but those possessing considerable skill in differential and integral calculus, the presentation is all but impenetrable.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Optics and the Theory of the Punctiform Ether|Buchwald, J.Z.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 21, 1980, pp 245-274.
BP_Title: Essais sur la theÃÅorie matheÃÅmatique de la lumieÃÄre. Par Charles Briot, Professeiur au Lycee Stain-Louit, Maitre de Conferences a l'Ecole Normale superieure.
BP_Title English Translation: Essay on the Mathematical Theory of Light, by Charles Briot, Professor at the Lycium Saint-Louis, Master of Conferences at the Ecole Normale Superieure.
BP_Biographical Statement: French mathematician.
BP_Provenance: With a dedication by Briot to 'mon ami Luiseux'

BP_Short or Common Title: On the Undulatory Theory of Optics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Airy added the monograph-length essay <i>On the Undulatory Theory of Optics<i> to the second, 1831 edition of his Mathematical Tracts.
BP_Description_1: George Biddell Airy added the monograph-length essay 'On the Undulatory Theory of Optics' to the second, 1831 edition of his <i>Mathematical Tracts<i>, first published in 1826 and appearing in all subsequent editions of the <i>Mathematical Tracts<i>. This is the first edition in book form, published with Airy's approval. Given the scope and intent of the work, the content is little changed from that in the Essay. Airy wrote on the wave theory of light with the same certainty of correctness with which he held the theory of gravity. He held the wave theory of light to be  '... certainly true, and that, by mathematical operations of general elegance, it leads to results of great interest. With regard to the evidence for this theory; if the simplicity of a hypothesis, which explains with accuracy a vast variety of phaenomena of the most complicated kind, can be considered a proof of its correctness, I believe there is no physical theory so firmly established as the theory in question.' Airy was one of the earliest British natural philosophers to accept the wave theory and he wrote extensively in its support. The current essay brought together aspects of the theory Airy considered to be its core, and presented them with his typical clear yet detailed manner. He believed that experimental data and phenomena needed to be considered along with mathematical theory; to that end Airy personally performed each experiment described in the essay. Interestingly, Airy separates the simpler assumptions  in the theory that have proven to be powerfully predictive--transverse waves, varying speeds, and such, all of which he calls the geometrical part of the wave theory--from what he calls the mechanical part of the theory--Cauchy's assumption of the aether as a 3-dimentional lattice and everything that followed from that. That later he considered probable but 'far from certain.' Editions appeared in 1866, 1877, and 1887.
BP_Description_2: Airy's book is in several unlabeled sections. 1: General theory of undulations including the theory and mathematics of waves, wave interference, wave length, wave phase. 2: Application of wave theory to unpolarized light, including diffraction pattern positions and intensities, wave fronts, reflection, refraction, reflection and refraction both, unequal (chromatic) refraction.  3: Experiments involving optical phenomena including interference fringes, chromatic interference, prismatic interference, phase shifting with glass plates, thin plates, Newton's rings, diffraction fringes, diffraction from a rectangular aperture, colored fringes, lenses and apertures and wire gratings, diffraction spectra. 4: Double refraction including crystal properties, experiments with polarized light, relation to the hypothesis of the nature of light, transverse waves, general explanation of double refraction, conical refraction. 5: Aspects of the wave theory including predicted values of reflection from glass, total internal reflection, circularly and elliptically polarized light, reflection from metals, colored polarization, polarization in crystals with multiple axes. The material is detailed and highly analytic, with experimental optical phenomena and mathematical developments closely coupled.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132.
BP_Title: On the Undulatory Theory of Optics
BP_Biographical Statement: British mathematician, astronomer. Made important advances as Astronomer Royal.
BP_Provenance: Blind stamp of Patent Office Library

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Reprint edition in which the first principles of chemical analysis by luminous spectrum and presented, including the interpretation of the Fraunhofer lines in the solar spectrum as markers of chemicals in the sun's hot inner core and its outer cooler sheath. A startling development, it revealed a method for chemical analysis at a distance.
BP_Description_1: Gustav Kirchhoff published a version of the <i>Untersuchungen uber das Sonnenspectrum<i> between 1861 and 1863. It was a reprint summary of work that had appeared in the Abhandlungen der K√∂niglichen Preu√üischen Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin. In this, the third edition, Kirchhoff modified his proof and explanation of his law of thermal radiation. In the reprint he laid down the first principles of chemical analysis by luminous spectrum and presented his interpretation of the Fraunhofer lines in the solar spectrum as markers of chemicals in the sun's hot inner core and its outer cooler sheath. Kirchhoff‚Äôs work was a startling and unexpected development, revealed a method for chemical analysis at a distance, and was the first evidence of how light was to become an investigative tool of science. Editions appeared in 1861, 1863, 1866, and 1875.
BP_Description_2: Gustav Kirchhoff brief treatise is in four parts with an appendix. 1: The solar spectrum. 2: Reversal of a flame spectrum. 3: Chemical composition of the sun's atmosphere. 4: Physical nature of the sun. Kirchhoff presents an explanation for the appearance of dark Fraunhofer lines in the solar spectrum: chemical elements (and some compounds) emit a unique signature of spectral lines when hot and absorb those same lines when cooler. The 'reversal of spectra' to is how absorption spectra were referred to; they absorbed rather than emitted.  Kirchhoff's experiments with Robert Bunsen created a link between the chemical elements, known and unknown, and a signature of spectral lines that could be detected with a spectrograph. The reprint contains a plate showing the instrument devised by Kirchhoff for this work, along with elaborate mappings of the solar spectrum, Fraunhofer lines, and the chemical elements and compounds associated with them.
BP_Reference(s): A Century of Spectrum Analysis|Shpol'ski, √â.V., Beyer, R.T., translator|<i>Soviet Physics Uspekhi<i>, Vo. 2, No 6, 1960  958-973.||<i>The Synthesis of the Elements: The Astrophysical Quest for Nucleosynthesis and what it Can Tell Us about the Universe<i>|Shaviv, G.|Springer, 2012, 683 pp, NB: pp 76-89.
BP_Title: Untersuchungen uber das Sonnenspectrum und de Spectren der Chemischen Elemente. von G. Kirchhoff I Theil, II Theil
BP_Title English Translation: Investigations into the Solar Spectrum and the Spectra of the Chemical Elements. By G. Kirchhoff. Part 1, Part 2.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, experimentalist, academic. Famed for work in electric circuits, spectroscopy.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate and stamp of the Physics Institute of the University of Leipzig
BP_Plates: Vol 1: Plates [I-III] 2 folding|Vol 2: Plates [Ia, III] folding

BP_Short or Common Title: Des images par reflexion et par refraction
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A textbook written to present Gaussian Optics without freighting it with mathematics any more advanced than geometry.
BP_Description_1: Louis Denis Jules Gavarret wrote this textbook to present Gaussian Optics without freighting it with mathematics any more advanced than geometry. That is, mathematics sufficient to use Gauss's work but not derive or prove its correctness. Gavarret's purpose was to provide a text that made Gauss's dioptric formulation available to students who needed to understand systems of lenses used in optical instruments and the functioning of the human eye. Gauss's developments allowed for the evaluation of complex lens systems with just a few parameters as well as accounting for the thickness of lenses. Although Gavarret's text considers images by reflection, the bulk of the material centers on image formation by lenses. This is one of many texts written by Gavarret covering a wide range of technical and subjects published by the great Parisian medical publisher Bailli√®re. A Russian translation appeared in 1891.
BP_Description_2: Gavarret's text is in two parts, the first is very brief and covers image formation by mirrors. It is entirely conventional catoptrics and serves only to review very basic geometrical optical notions and conventions. The bulk of the text is the second part on image formation by refraction; that is, by lenses. Gauss's cardinal points are introduced: the principal points, focal points, and the nodal points. The analysis of lenses using these basic parameters is demonstrated by increasingly complex practical examples. Many types of lenses are considered, including biconvex, biconcave, plano-concave and convex, and meniscus lenses. Each demonstration and example is accompanied by striking white-on-black geometric drawings. Gavarret's text is a thorough introduction to Gaussian Optics applied to lens analysis.
BP_Reference(s): The origins of medical physics|Duck, F.A.|<i>Physica Medica<i>, Vol 30, No 4, 2014 pp 397-402.
BP_Title: Des images par reflexion et par refraction.  Par J. Gavarret, Professeur de physique a la Faculte de medecine de Paris.
BP_Title English Translation: On Images by Reflection and by Refraction. By J. Gavarret, Professor of Physics on the Faculty of Medicine of Paris.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physican, academic, experimenter, and prolific author in medical physics.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Institut Catholique de Paris
BP_Binding: Modern Speckled Paper Over Boards, Original Printed Wrapper Bound In
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1867 Gavarret - Des images par reflexion et par refraction - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: 2-volume treatise that gathers together the results of Becquerel's nearly 30 years of experimenting with the generation of light and the assessment of its effects.
BP_Description_1: Alexandre-Edmond Becquerel 2-volume treatise <i>La Lumi√®re<i> gathers together the results of his nearly 30 years of experimenting with the generation of light and the assessment of its effects. Becquerel was not only a physicist but also a photographer and had long had an abiding interest in the chemical effects of light, particularly as it pertained to photography. In his preface he makes it clear that is had not written an optics book, but rather something 'purely experimental, the small number of theoretical considerations which it contains have been judged necessary to unite and explain the facts. It is accepted that the vibratory motion of matter is the cause of luminous phenomena, and that the transmission of light takes place at a distance through an ethereal medium which penetrates all bodies; The hypothesis of the undulations facilitating the explanations which can be given to account for all the effects which have recorded.' Becquerel's treatise presents his pioneering work in spectroscopy, actinometry, photometry, fluorescence, phosphorescence, and chemical analysis, a large amount of experimental data on the properties of light sources and materials, as well as descriptions of the experimental apparatus he developed for his work. There is virtually no mathematics. Becquerel's treatise was of general scientific interest for the skillful acquisition, arrangement, and coordination of seeming disparate facts. The treatise was particularly important to the nascent discipline of photography, the study of fluorescent and phosphorescent chemistry, and eventually to the electric lighting industry.
BP_Description_2: Becquerel's treatise is in two volumes. Volume 1 is devoted to sources of light and has seven books. 1: History of research in phosphorescence up to 1840. 2: Luminous effects produced by action and motion. 3: Luminous effects produced by heat. 4: Analysis of light by refraction. 5: Luminous effects produced by electricity. 6: Luminous effects produced by the action of light itself (phosphorescence and fluorescence). 7: Light produced by plants and animals. Volume 2 is devoted to the effects of light and has 5 books. 1: Heating effects. 2: Chemical effects including photoelectric effects. 3: Photographic effects. 4: Physiological effects. 5: On vision. The material in each chapter presents experiments that had been conducted by Becquerel, describing in detail the equipment and method and often accompanied by an etching showing the apparatus. These are usually followed by results and its analysis and commentary on significance.

BP_Short or Common Title: A Treatise on Electricity and Magnetism
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Maxwell's elaborate, unsystematic presentation of the physical ideas and governing mathematics of his theory of the electromagnetic field, which arose from his desire to develop a rigorous framing of Michael Faraday's idea that fields and lines of force can explain electrical and magnetic phenomena.
BP_Description_1: The intellectual origin of Maxwell's treatise is his study of and correspondence with Michael Faraday. Faraday, and subsequently Maxwell, held that theories of physics based on instantaneous action at a distance between particles of matter were incorrect. Maxwell developed a theory of the electromagnetic field and presented it, in its essential form, his famous paper of 1865: 'A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic Field.' A summary in his own words is in Maxwell's 1870 presidential address to annual meeting the British Association for the Advancement of Science. Regarding electricity and magnetism , he mentions vortex theory but described his won as 'Another theory of electricity which I prefer denies action at a distance and attributes electric action to tensions and pressure in a an all-pervading medium, these stresses being the same kind with those familiar to engineers, and the medium being identical with that in which light is supposed to be propagated.'||Between 1867 and 1870, Maxwell concentrated hid efforts on writing the <i>Treatise<i>. This was simultaneous with an effort to reform physics education at Cambridge. Examinations were expanded and a new chair of experimental physics was established. The reform, devoted mainly to electricity and magnetism, was powered, in part, by the rapid industrial developments in electricity and telegraphy. It was recognized that there were very few texts in English that could support such teaching and so the Clarendon Press accepted Maxwell's proposal for the <i>Treatise<i>. During its writing, Maxwell was in constant correspondence with Peter Guthrie Tait, Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh and Sir William Thomson, Lord Kelvin, asking advice and submitting ideas for review. Maxwell finished the book at the end of 1870. Printing of 1500 copies began in March 1871 and would take two years.||Maxwell's treatise was unsystematic, lacked a clear focus, and did not provide an orderly presentation. Central ideas were inadvertently camouflaged by descriptions of miscellaneous phenomena and so failed to stand out. The underlying physical ideas and the elaborate vector mathematics used made it inaccessible to most British physicists and to nearly all on the Continent. The power of Maxwell's ideas would only become widely known by the work and publications of 'Maxwellians' such as  G.F. Fitzgerald, Oliver Heaviside, and Oliver Lodge. Maxwell's theory would undergo continuous development and extension in its original form in the treatise of 1873 until 1890. The <i>Treatise<i> appeared in three editions: 1873, with the first nine chapters revised by Maxwell and the whole edited by W.D. Niven in 1881, and edited by J.J. Thompson in 1892.
BP_Description_2: Maxwell's Treatise has a preliminary and four parts. Preliminary On the Measurement of Quantities, Part I Electrostatics, deals with electrostatic fields produced by static electric charge and static electric displacement caused by electric polarization. Part II Electrokinematics is devoted to steady electric currents but does not consider displacement current or the magnetic fields produced by steady electric currents. Part III Magnetism, is devoted to magnetostatic fields produced by magnetization. Part IV Electromagnetism, treats magnetostatic fields of electric conduction currents as well as time-varying electromagnetic fields and sources including displacement current. This includes Chapter XX, Electromagnetic Theory of Light.||The central result of the Treatise are equations that both state and govern electromagnetic fields. Two of the equations state the laws valid for static electric and magnetic systems. The third provided a mathematical description of the laws governing magnetic induction: the generation of an electric field by a changing magnetic field. The fourth gave a description of Ampere's law: the magnetic field associated with a (steady) electric current. Remarkably, Maxwell added a term representing the magnetic field produced by a changing electric field. This seemed to be a symmetric requirement, complementary to the electric current induced by a changing magnetic field. This is one of the most remarkable developments in the Treatise: that the total current must be considered as the current of conduction and the time variation of the electric displacement.||Maxwell used vectors and vector notation (a notation subset of Quaternions) and the original formulation of his governing equations is in coupled differential equation form. Though he uses vectors and vector operators, the results are usually expressed in component form, often resulting in bristling complexity. Maxwell often states equations in their integral form. He summaries the equations of the Treatise in Article 619 (Volume 2) though, strangely, that equation governing electromagnetic induction (Faraday's Law) is not included.||The culmination of the Treatise is Chapter XX of Part IV, 'Electromagnetic Theory of Light'. Maxwell proposes that 'if the velocity of propagation of electromagnetic disturbances is the same as the velocity of light, and this not only in air, but in other transparent media, we shall have strong reasons for believing that light is an electromagnetic phenomenon.' He derives the velocity of an electromagnetic disturbance in a nonconducting medium as (Œº Œµ)‚Äæ¬π‚Ä≤¬≤, Œº and Œµ being its permeability and permittivity. Using measured values of Œº‚Çí Œµ‚Çí, the permeability and permittivity of free space, he compares  (Œº‚Çí Œµ‚Çí)‚Äæ¬π‚Ä≤¬≤  with the then generally accepted values for the speed of light in (empty) space and finds agreement within 10%, showing that light is an electromagnetic wave. Maxwell then considers plane-wave light propagation, the energy in a propagating light wave, radiation pressure in a light wave, and light waves in conducting media.
BP_Reference(s): Reflections on Maxwell's Treatise|Yaghjian, A.D.|<i>Progress In Electromagnetics Research<i>, Vol 149, 2014, pp 217-249.||<i>From Maxwell to Microphysics<i>|Buchwald, J.Z.|University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 1985, 339 pp, NB: ppp 20-40.||<i>The Maxwellians<i>|Hunt, B.J.|Cornell University Press, 1991, 266 p.
BP_Title: A Treatise on Electicity and Magnetism
BP_Biographical Statement: Scottish mathematical physcist, academic. Genius eclipsed only Newton and Einstein, famed for work in electro-magnetism, mechanics, color, thermodynamics.
BP_Provenance: With the signature of A W Ward, St John's College, 1880, and his underlinings, corrections, and marginalia. A.W. Ward (1858-1919) graduated BS from St John's College Cambridge in 1882, then work under J.J. Thompson at the Canvendish Laboratory, publishing his research in the Proceedings of the Physical Society of London in 1888. In 1889 he was appointed Professor of Mathematics and Physics in Canning College, University of Lucknow India. He became a prominent teacher and influential in Idian Educational matters, teaching at Lucknow for 30 years until his death in 1919.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A consideration of the nature of light, complete with descriptions and demonstrations, but without the mathematical details.
BP_Description_1: Lommel's work became a widely-read popular self-study text. Addressed to the interested, non-technical reader, Lommel attempts to answer the question 'What is the nature of light?' and to do so in a purely descriptive way. Optical phenomena and instruments are presented, followed by a description of Fresnel's theory. The material is presented  in the main section of each chapter in an entirely descriptive and qualitative way, without mathematics. A few chapters have an appendix that presents the elementary mathematics governing the material||Lommel's background has a high school and university teacher is apparent in the book's structure, style of presentation, and content. He wrote the book while teaching at the University of Erlangen. The appeal of the book was its clear descriptions, grounding in demonstration and experimental results, and numerous figures. It appeared as the eighth volume of the <i>Internationale Wissenschaftliche Bibliothek<i>. An English translation of Wesen des Lichts appeared at London in 1875 and 1880, and at New York in 1876 and 1903.
BP_Description_2: Lommel's work is in 25 chapters. The first 14 chapters present basic optical phenomena and instruments, including rectilinear propagation, reflection, refraction, dispersion and color. These are presented and described as experimental results, which any theory of light must account for. Lenses and dioptric instruments are described, including the theory of achromatic lenses. Spectral analysis, fluorescence, and phosphorescence are also described. The last 15 chapters present the undulatory theory of light, beginning with Huygens' principle, and aspects of dispersion, diffraction, interference, double refraction, and polarization. Fresnel's theory is presented and it is shown how it accounts for these optical phenomena. Lommel's text provides a view of physical optics just before Maxwell's electromagnetic theory is introduced.||The general style is to present experiments and their results and to discuss their significance in qualitative terms. Each experiment or demonstration is accompanied by at least one figure. In all, 187 figures appear in the text. Chromolithograph of chemical spectra bound at the back.
BP_Reference(s): Eugen von Lommel|Ludwig Boltzmann|<i>Jahresbericht der Deutschen Mathematiker-Vereinigung<i>, Vol 8, No 1, 1900, pp 47‚Äì58.
BP_Title: Das Wesen des Lichts:¬†Gemeinfassliche Darstellung der physikalischen Optik in f√ºnfundzwanzig Vorlesungen
BP_Title English Translation: The Nature of Light: Comprehensive presentation of physical optics in twenty-five lectures
BP_Biographical Statement: Bavarian Physicist and Mathematician. Professor at the Universities of Erlangen and Munich.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Chromolithograph of chemical spectra bound at the back

Addressed to the interested, non-technical reader, Lommel attempts to answer the question 'What is the nature of light?' and to do so in a purely descriptive way. Optical phenomena and instruments are presented, followed by a description of Fresnel's theory. The material is presented  in the main section of each chapter in an entirely descriptive and qualitative way, without mathematics. A few chapters have an appendix that presents the elementary mathematics governing the material||Lommel's background has a high school and university teacher is apparent in the book's structure, style of presentation, and content. He wrote the book while teaching at the University of Erlangen. The appeal of the book was its clear descriptions, grounding in demonstration and experimental results, and numerous figures. Editions of the English translation appeared at London in 1875 and 1880, and at New York in 1876 and 1903. The appearance in London and New York was as Volume XVII of the International Scientific Series.

These are presented and described as experimental results, which any theory of light must account for. Lenses and dioptric instruments are described, including the theory of achromatic lenses. Spectral analysis, fluorescence, and phosphorescence are also described. The last 15 chapters present the undulatory theory of light, beginning with Huygens' principle, and aspects of dispersion, diffraction, interference, double refraction, and polarization. Fresnel's theory is presented and it is shown how it accounts for these optical phenomena. Lommel's work describes optics just before Maxwell's electromagnetic theory is introduced.||The general style is to present experiments and their results and to discuss their significance in qualitative terms. Chromolithograph of chemical spectra bound at the back.

BP_Short or Common Title: On the Undulatory Theory of Optics
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Airy added the monograph-length essay <i>On the Undulatory Theory of Optics<i> to the second, 1831 edition of his Mathematical Tracts.
BP_Description_1: George Biddell Airy added the monograph-length essay 'On the Undulatory Theory of Optics' to the second, 1831 edition of his <i>Mathematical Tracts<i>, first published in 1826 and appearing in all subsequent editions of the Mathematical Tracts. This is the first edition in book form, published with Airy's approval. Given the scope and intent of the work, the content is little changed from that in the Essay. Airy wrote on the wave theory of light with the same certainty of correctness with which he held the theory of gravity. He held the wave theory of light to be  '... certainly true, and that, by mathematical operations of general elegance, it leads to results of great interest. With regard to the evidence for this theory; if the simplicity of a hypothesis, which explains with accuracy a vast variety of phaenomena of the most complicated kind, can be considered a proof of its correctness, I believe there is no physical theory so firmly established as the theory in question.' Airy was one of the earliest British natural philosophers to accept the wave theory and he wrote extensively in its support. The current essay brought together aspects of the theory Airy considered to be its core, and presented them with his typical clear yet detailed manner. He believed that experimental data and phenomena needed to be considered along with mathematical theory; to that end Airy personally performed each experiment described in the essay. Interestingly, Airy separates the simpler assumptions  in the theory that have proven to be powerfully predictive--transverse waves, varying speeds, and such, all of which he calls the geometrical part of the wave theory--from what he calls the mechanical part of the theory--Cauchy's assumption of the aether as a 3-dimentional lattice and everything that followed from that. That later he considered probable but 'far from certain.' The title pages labels this 'A New Edition', though it is essentially a reprint of that of 1866. Editions appeared in 1866, 1877, and 1887.
BP_Description_2: Airy's book is in several unlabeled sections. 1: General theory of undulations including the theory and mathematics of waves, wave interference, wave length, wave phase. 2: Application of wave theory to unpolarized light, including diffraction pattern positions and intensities, wave fronts, reflection, refraction, reflection and refraction both, unequal (chromatic) refraction.  3: Experiments involving optical phenomena including interference fringes, chromatic interference, prismatic interference, phase shifting with glass plates, thin plates, Newton's rings, diffraction fringes, diffraction from a rectangular aperture, colored fringes, lenses and apertures and wire gratings, diffraction spectra. 4: Double refraction including crystal properties, experiments with polarized light, relation to the hypothesis of the nature of light, transverse waves, general explanation of double refraction, conical refraction. 5: Aspects of the wave theory including predicted values of reflection from glass, total internal reflection, circularly and elliptically polarized light, reflection from metals, colored polarization, polarization in crystals with multiple axes. The material is detailed and highly analytic, with experimental optical phenomena and mathematical developments closely coupled.
BP_Reference(s): The Reception of the Wave Theory of Light in Britain: A Case Study Illustrating the Role of Methodology in Scientific Debate|Canntory G.|<i>Historical Studies in the Physical Sciences<i>, Vol 6, 1975, pp 109-132.
BP_Title: On the Undulatory Theory of Optics
BP_Biographical Statement: British mathematician, astronomer. Made important advances as Astronomer Royal.
BP_Provenance: With the signature of J.J. Thompson on free endpaper
BP_Binding: Contemporary Cloth Blind Stamped Spine Gilt

BP_Short or Common Title: Le proprietaÃÄ cardinali degli strumenti diottrici
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Ferraris was convinced that Gauss's developments in dioptrics could be presented without the advanced mathematics necessary to derive or prove results. Once simply presented, they could be used with only geometry.
BP_Description_1: Galileo Ferraris saw the need for a textbook on Gaussian Optics and was inspired by other textbooks on the subject, particularly that of Louis Denis Jules Gavarret of 1867. Like Gavarret, Ferraris was convinced that Gauss's developments in dioptrics could be presented without the advanced mathematics necessary to derive or prove results, but once simply presented they could be used with only geometry. Unlike Gavarret, Ferraris considered it necessary to show Gaussian Optics applied in detail to many practical problems if the student was to fully understand the concepts. To that end, Ferraris's book is in two parts, the first presents Gaussian Optics in outline, the second and considerably longer shows the analysis of several optical systems. The work was reprinted in 1902 as Volume 3 of his <i>Opere<i> and by Hoepli in 1921. A German translation appeared in 1879 and an English translation in 1919.
BP_Description_2: Ferraris introduces Gauss's cardinal points of a lens: the principal points, focal points, and the nodal points; and then shows how they are related to parameters of the lens involved and how they can be used to analyze it. The same analysis is then performed for a system of two lenses. In the second part of the book, the analysis of lenses using these basic parameters is demonstrated by increasingly complex practical examples, showing how image analysis is performed, giving magnification, clarity, field of view, and placement. Several types of lenses are considered, how they are analyzed, and how they are used in instruments including telescopes and microscopes. Like Gavarret's text, Ferraris's book is illustrated with diagrams of white-on-black.
BP_Reference(s): Ferraris, Galileo|Lerda, F.|Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani, Vol 46,  1996.||Numerical Work. Dioptric|B√ºhler, W.K.|Chapter 13  In: <i>Gauss<i>, Springer, 1981, 208 pp, NB: pp 142-145.
BP_Title: Le proprietaÃÄ cardinali degli strumenti diottrici: Esposizione elementare della teoria di Gauss e delle sue applicazioni. Dell 'Ingegnere Galileo Ferraris. Membro della facolta de scienze metematiche, fisiche e naturali della R. Universita de Torino, Incaricato dell'insegnamento della fisica tecnologica ne R. Museo Industriale italiano.
BP_Title English Translation: The Cardinal Properties of Dioptic Instruments, An Elementary Exposition of the Theory of Gauss and its Applications. By Engineer Galileo Ferraris, Member of the Faculty of Mathematical, Physical and Natural Sciences of the Royal University of Turin, Director of the Teaching of Technical Physics in the Royal Italian Industrial Museum.
BP_Biographical Statement: Italian physicist, electrical engineer. Famed for work in electricity, optical instruments.

BP_Short or Common Title: On the Electromagnetic Theory of the Reflection and Refraction of Light.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: The first application of Maxwell's theory of Electro-Magnetic fields to explain and predict reflection and refraction.
BP_Description_1: George FitzGerald was one of the earliest British physicists to understand and appreciate Maxwell's work in Electro-Magnetic fields. FitzGerald would communicate frequently with Heaviside, Hertz and Lorentz who were the other active developers of Maxwell's ideas. By 1880 FitzGerald has considerable command of the theory and its mathematics and states in its first paragraph why he wrote this paper: "In the second volume of his ‚ÄòElectricity and Magnetism‚Äô Professor J. Clerk Maxwell has proposed a very remarkable electromagnetic theory of light, and has worked out the results as far as the transmission of light through uniform crystalline and magnetic media are concerned, leaving the questions of reflection and refraction untouched. These, however, may be very conveniently studied from his point of view.' Maxwell himself was one of the referee's of FitzGerald's paper. After explaining that the difficulties involved in applying his theory to reflection and refraction were the reason why such an application did not appear in his treatise, Maxwell noted that FitzGerald's development paralleled that of Lorentz. FitzGerald's paper presents the first complete theory of reflection and refraction based on Maxwell's Electro-Magnetic fields.
BP_Description_2: FitzGerald formulated appropriate boundary conditions at the surfaces of media and then interpreted these conditions in terms of electro-magnetic variables. FitzGerald takes up the theory presented by James MacCullagh in 1839, which gave laws of reflection and refraction based on purely mechanical effects of the luminiferous aether. FitzGerald casts this in Maxwellian form. Working in both Cartesian and Quaternion forms, FitzGerald uses Lagrange's equations of motion to establish expressions for reflected and refracted waves. An elaborate application of integration by parts is used to render the required integrals and dropping vanishingly small terms gives the expected results, in alignment with Fresnel's equations. FitzGerals shows that his equations are able to predict the results obtained by John Kerr in his series of experiments conducted in 1877, now named the magneto-optic Kerr effect.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Maxwellians<i>|Hunt, B.J.|Cornell University Press, 1991, 266 pp, NB: pp 5-23.
BP_Title: On the Electromagnetic Theory of the Reflection and Refraction of Light.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish natural philosopher in the University of Dubin. Early theorist in relativistic effects of motion.
BP_Provenance: With a dedication by the author
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1880 FitzGerald - On the Electromagnetic Theory of the Reflection and Refraction of Light. - Images.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Viktor von Lang
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second, revised edition of Beer's text of 1853. An elaborate, carefully presented, mathematically detailed consideration of physical optics based on the undulatory theory of light.
BP_Description_1: August Beer was a mathematical physicist, with a particular interest in optics. Beer's text is an elaborate, carefully presented, mathematically detailed consideration of physical optics. The preface states his reason for writing the book: to bridge the gap between the 'less profound textbooks' and the the exhaustive, specialized treatises and articles of the various authorities. The preface also make clear that Beer considered the undulatory theory of light to be capable of explaining all optical phenomena: reflection, refraction, diffraction, dispersion, propagation, color, polarization, and double refraction.||Beer sees his task as not only presenting in necessary detail the undulatory theory of light but also showing its great explanatory power by using to analyze optical phenomena in crystals.||Beer's text achieved a high and widely-held reputation and, along with F√©lix Billet's <i>Traite d'Optique Physique<i>, would not surpassed until Paul Drude's <i>Lehrbuch der Optik<i> nearly 50 years later with its presentation of electro-magnetic theory.||As the editor states in his Forward, this edition keeps the principal pedagogical purpose of the Beer's book, unalters the structure and style, and only modifies content slightly and omits all the tables of data that had been included in the first edition and which had become obsolete. Notably, and consistent with the German hesitancy about Maxwell's theory at the time, the editor does not introduce any electro-magnetics into Beer's material on physical optics.
BP_Description_2: Beer's text is in two parts, the first setting the principles of the undulatory theory of light and its propagation in isotropic media. The second part applies the theory developed in the first part to the derivation of mathematical expression for optical phenomena including dispersion and propagation in crystals and birefringence.||Part One is in 11 chapters. 1: Wave theory principles; 2: Propagation of light: 3: Refraction and change in media and dispersion; 4: Polarization in birefringence; 5: Mathematics of light propagation; 6: Interference of Polarized light; 7: Elliptical Polarization; 8: Unpolarized light; 9: Photometric analysis; 10: Partially Polarized light; 11: Apparatus for detecting polarized light.||Part Two is in 12 chapters. 1: Analytic derivation of propagation equations; 2: Law of dispersion; 3: Propagation in crystals; 4: Structures of crystals; 5 & 6: Propagation equations applied to crystals; 7: Law of dispersion; 8: Propagation equations applied to crystals; 9: Wave surfaces in crystals; 10: Refraction in biaxial crystals; 11: Optical properties of biaxial crystals; 12: Apparatus for studying propagation of light in crystals.||Part one sets out the undulatory theory in a descriptive but thorough way. Part two is deeply and elaborately mathematical.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Rise of the Wave Theory of Light<i>|Buchwald, J.Z|University of Chicago Press, 1989, 474 pp, NB: pp 309-310.
BP_Title: Einleitung in die Hohere Optik von August Beer. Zweite Umgestaltete Auflage, Bearbeitet von Victor von Lang. Mit 201 in den Text eingedruckten holzstichen und einer tafel.
BP_Title English Translation: Introduction to Hight Optics by August Beer. Second, Redesigned Edition Edited by Viktor von Lang. With 201 in text wood cuts and one plate.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, chemist, mathematician, academic. Lecturer at the University of Bonn.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Library of the Imperial Technical High School at Brunn.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1882 Beer - Einleitung in die Hohere Optik - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: Notes of lectures on molecular dynamics and the wave theory of light
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Copy of the original, 'papyrographically' reproduced notes of William Thomson's presentations at a course of invited lectures by Thomson in Baltimore in 1884, stenographically prepared by a participant.
BP_Description_1: The occasion for these lectures was an invitation by Robert H. Gilman, then president of Johns Hopkins University, to William Thomson to present lectures on a topic of Thompson's choosing. He lectured on the wave theory of light, emphasizing it's incompleteness and faults. The idea was not to denigrate the theory but to challenge the attendees. This was what would now be called a master-class and the attendees were advanced students, professionals, and seasoned academics. A.A. Michelson and E.W. Morley were in the audience and the problems and uncertainties set out by Thomson prompted them to conduct the famed eponymous Michelson-Morley Experiment. Thomson focused on the the problem of electromagnetic wave propagation, and the nature of the medium, the luminiferous aether, that would be required to support such oscillations.||Arthur S. Hathaway, student at Johns Hopkins at the time and later instructor at Cornell, attended the meeting and, since Thomson provided no public notes, Hathaway recorded the entire proceedings, mathematics and all, in stenographic short-hand. He later transcribed his short-hand into a 328 page text with tables and index. onto the stencils required of the so-called papyrograph process for quick and low-cost reproduction. Copies of these reproduced notes appeared in December of 1884 and  were widely circulated. The demand was great enough for Hathaway to contact Thomson, attempting to arrange for letter-press printing. After long delays and revisions by Thomson, the notes finally appeared in printed form in 1904.||Thomson's lectures were delivered at the beginning of the twenty-year period in which physicists strove to rectify theory and experiment, all based on the presence of the luminiferous aether. By the time the printed version of the notes appeared, Thomson would consider most problems solved or soluble by the application of dynamics, save for one: the results of the Michelson-Morley experiment which had been conducted in 1887. Thomson wrote in the preface to the 1904 printing of the lecture notes: 'All of us will, I am sure, feel sympathetically interested in knowing that two of ourselves, Michelson and Morley, have by their great experimental work on the motion of ether relative to earth, raised the one and only serious objection against our dynamical explanations.' Thomson's lectures are one of the last, great summaries of classical physics and aether-based light-theory before the coming of relativity and the quantum revolution.
BP_Description_2: Thomsos's lectures stated and attempted to solve the known problems regarding light's propagation and other optical phenomena. He delivered 20 lectures. Lecture 1 on kinetic theory of gases, molecular dynamics (vortex atoms), wave theory of light and its difficulties, mechanical models. Lecture 2 on motion of elastic solids (the aether). Lecture 3 on isotropic elastic solids. Lecture 4 on motion in elastic solids. Lecture 5 on vibrating globes. Lecture 6 on velocity. Lecture 7 on dispersion. Lecture 8 on other dynamic solutions. Lecture 9 on light properties. Lecture 10 on plane waves. Lecture 11 more on elastic solids. Lecture 12 more on wave motion. Lecture 13 on mechanical models of molecules (the aether). Lecture 14 more on molecules. Lecture 15 more on molecules. Lecture 16 on double refraction. Lecture 17 on polarization. Lecture 18 on the theory of reflection and refraction. Lecture 19 problem solutions. Lecture 20 additional difficulties and summary.||Lectures 1-5 set out the dynamical properties of the presumed aether. Molecular dynamics is invoked, together with the presumed nature of the aether, to explain reflection, refraction, dispersion. Along the way, the difficulties are highlighted. Before the lecture notes appeared in their printed form, Thomson had revised lectures 12-15 and rewrote lectures 18-20, incorporating newer work, and adding to the completeness of his dynamical theory.
BP_Reference(s): Energy, dynamics, hidden machinery: Rankine, Thomson and Tait, Maxwell|Moyer, D.F.|<i>Studies in History and Philosophy of Science<i> Part A, Vol 8, No 3, 1977, pp 251-268.||Continuum mechanics and field theory: Thomson and Maxwell|Moyer, D.F.|<i>Studies in History and Philosophy of Science<i> Part A, Vol 9, No 1, 1979, pp 35-50.
BP_Title: Notes of lectures on molecular dynamics and the wave theory of light. Delivered at the Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore. By Sir William Thomson, Professor in the University of Glasgow. Stenographically Reported by A.S. Hathaway, Lately Fellow in Mathematics of the Johns Hopkins Univerity.
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematical physicist, engineer, inventor. Polymathic talent, contributed importantly in practical electrical problems.
BP_Provenance: Withdrawn from the University of Colorado
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1884 Thomson - Notes of lectures on molecular dynamics and the wave theory of light - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An advanced textbook on geometric optics
BP_Description_1: Heath wrote his treatise while professor of mathematics at Mason College in the University of Birmingham. Heath was not an originator in optics but a skilled compiler and expositor. His text was intended to bring together all developments in geometric optics presented in a textbook that could be used in advanced courses. His primary sources are Gauss, Listing, Maxwell, Helmholtz, and Abb√©. He also adopted sections from Humphrey Lloyd's <i>Treatise on Light and Vision<i> of 1831. The list of sources he consulted cites more than 60 works. The result is a compendium of geometrical optics as it stood at turn of the 20th century.||The considerable latter part of the text presents applications, worked problems, descriptions of the construction and use of optical instruments including microscopes, telescopes, and other practical applications of optics.||Editions appeared in 1887, 1895, and 1900. A German translation by  R. Kanthack appeared in 1894. Heath would abridge his text and remove advanced mathematics to produce <i>An Elementary Treatise on Geometrical Optics<i> in 1888.
BP_Description_2: Heath's treatise is in 13 Chapters. 1: Nature and Properties of Light. 2: Reflexion and Refraction of Rays of Light. 3: Reflexion and Refraction of Direct Pencils. 4: Elementary Theory of Refraction through Lenses. 5: Refraction through Lenses. 6: General Theorems. Caustics. 7: Aberration op Direct Pencils. 8: On the General Form and Properties of a Thin Pencil. General Refraction of Thin Pencils. 9: Dispersion and Achromatism. 10: The Eye and Vision through Lenses. 11: Optical Instruments. 12: Optical Instruments and Experiments. 13: Refraction through Media of Varying Density. Meteorological Optics.||Heath's treatment, especially in the initial theoretical chapters, is deeply mathematical, requiring a knowledge of calculus. The presentation order of the material reflects a sense of pedagogy and Heath's clear style is evidently informed by his teaching experience. An example of Heath's extensive use of mathematics is in Chapter 4 where he uses continued fractions to analyze place and size of images by refraction through any number of coaxial spherical surfaces. This is applied to the analysis of image formation by multiple, coaxial lenses.
BP_Reference(s): A Treatise on Geometrical Optics (Book Review)|Larmor, J.|Nature, Vol 36, 7 July 1887, pp 291-220.||Generalized Meridional and Sagittal Formulas|Roe, E.D.|<i>Journal of the Optical Society of America<i>, Vol 8, No 3, pp. 461-470.
BP_Title: A Treatise on Geometrical Optics
BP_Biographical Statement: English mathematician, professor at Mason College of the University of Birmingham, textbook author.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Blind Stamped Cloth, Spine Gilt
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1887 Heath - A Treatise on Geometrical Optics - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Heinrich Hertz's announcement of the production, detection, and analysis of electro-magnetic waves.
BP_Description_1: Before starting the experimental work that would make him famous, Heinrich Hertz had studied under Helmholtz's and knew the latter's generalized theory of electrodynamics. Popular on the continent, this purportedly subsumed the action-at-a-distance theories of Weber and Neumann and the electromagnetic theory of Maxwell. Helhmoltz had urged Hertz to study the problem of demonstrating whether electromagnetic waves existed; the Weber and Neumann theories did not predict their existence, Maxwell's did. Hertz began his experiments in 1886 while teaching at the Technische Kochschule at Karlsruhe. The instruments he perfected allowed him to generate and detect high-frequency electromagnetic waves, to investigate their nature, and to show them completely like the much shorter waves associated with light.||These first two papers appear in 1887. Their importance, indeed epochal nature, was recognized immediately by the British Maxwellians George FitzGerald, Oliver Lodge, and Oliver Heaviside. Hertz had demonstrated the existence of electromagnetic waves, the first physical evidence of the correctness of Maxwellian electromagnetic theory. Hertz's discovery was announced with great fanfare the 1888 meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science and Hertz's papers were quickly translated into English and appeared in British journals.||Hertz would produce a series of papers completely determining the properties of the waves demonstrating their velocity, reflection, refraction, focusing, and interference. These papers would be collected and, together with an introduction, appear as <i>Untersuchungen √ºber die Ausbreitung der Elektrischen Kraft<i> in 1891. An English translation of the collection, under the title <i>Electric Waves<i>, appeared at London and New York in 1893.
BP_Description_2: Hertz describes the apparatus he developed to produce electromagnetic waves. The long-understood difficulty had been to generate wave of sufficient frequency such that they had a wavelength of a size that made it possible to conduct experiments. Equally daunting has been the problem of detection. Hertz describes the modification of an existing combination spark-gap apparatus with induction coil, Leyden jar, and gap. Removing the capacitance of the Leyden jar increased the operating frequency significantly, and long wires leading to the gap became long-wavelength electromagnetic wave emitters. A remote, isolated moveable coil with a micrometer spark gap was placed in the radiated field would intercept the waves--acting as an antenna of sorts--inducing a current in the coil; the presence and size of the spark indicated the presence and size of the waves.||The second paper describes Hertz determination of the effect of ultra-violet light on the sensitivity of the spark-gap detector. When illuminated with ultra-violet light, the detector was more sensitive. There was no know explanation for this at time; only later would this be described as the photoelectric effect produced by light-electron interaction.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Pioneers of Electrical Communication part 5 - Heinrich Rudolph Hertz|Appleyard, R.|<i>Electrical Communication<i>, Vol 6, No 2, pp 63-77.||<i>The Maxwellians<i>|Hunt, B.J.|Cornell University Press, 1991, 266 pp, NB: pp 152-162.
BP_Title: √úber sehr schnelle electrische schwingungen WITH  Nachtrag zu der Abhandlung √ºber sehr schnelle electrische Schwingungen WITH √úber einen Einfluss des ultravioletten Lichtes auf die electrische Entladung. in: Annalen der Physik und Chemie 31, neue Folge, 1887, pp 421-448, 543-544, 983-1000.
BP_Title English Translation: On Very Fast Electric Oscillations With Addendum to the Treatise on Very Fast Electrical Oscillations WITH On the Influence of Ultraviolet light on the Electric Discharge. In: Annalen der Physik und Chemie. New Series, Volume 31.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, experimentalist. Student of Helmholtz, Professor at the University of Karlsruhe and the Physics Institute in Bonn.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Imperial Physical Chemistry Laboratory
BP_Binding: Modern 1/2 Cloth Over Printed Paper Covered Boards
