BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A printing of public lectures on optics intended to be accessible by the informed laymen, and so the presentations require no mathematical knowledge.
BP_Description_1: These lectures were supported by a 1784 endowment by John Burnett, merchant of Aberdeen and where originally to be given every 40 (sic) years. In 1883 the trusties revised the interval of the lectures to every 5 years, with the appointment of lectureship lasting three years, and the subject matters to include 'History, Archaeology, Physical Science, and Natural Science' in addition to Burnett's originally narrowly religious framing.  The first topic of the Burnett lectures under these new terms was Physical Science and George Gabriel Stokes was granted the lectureship for three years.  delivered a three courses of lectures on light at the University of Aberdeen in November of 1883, December of 1884, and November of 1885. These were public lectures intended to be accessible by the informed laymen, so the presentations require no mathematical knowledge. The second course is particularly interesting; it summarizes the growing application of light as a scientific tool of investigation. The three courses of  lectures were printed in 1884, 1885, and 1887 respectively. In 1887 all three were printed in a single volume. A German translation appeared in 1888.
BP_Description_2: The first course delt with the nature of light and contained four lectures, presenting the substance of physical optics. 1: The nature of light, the emission and undulatory theories, some optical phenomena, insufficiency of the emission theory. 2: Interference and diffraction, undulation theory. 3: Explication of the theory of undulations, double refraction, polarization. 4: Phenomena in multi-axial crystals.  The second course delt with light an investigative tool and contained four lectures. 1: Absorption of light, phosphorescence and fluorescence. 2: Polarimetry  3: Absorption and emission of light and chemical analysis. 4: Investigation of solar prominences and its corona. The third course delt with the beneficial effects of light and contained four lectures. 1: Fuller spectrum of 'light', mechanical, heating, and atmospheric effects of sun light. 2: Light as a source of heat and energy for plants and animals, the food chain. 3: Light and vision. 4: Teleological and religious aspects of light.
BP_Reference(s): Why Stokes never wrote a treatise on optics|Buchwald, J.Z.|In: An Investigation of Difficult Things, Harman, P.M., Shapiro, A.E., editors|Cambridge, 1992, pp 451-476, NB: pp 453-454.
BP_Title: Burnett Lectures.  On Light. In Three Courses. Delivered at Aberdeen in November, 1883, December 1884, and November 1885. by George Gabriel Stokes, M.A., F.R.S., &c. Fellow of Pembroke college, and Luciasian Professor of Mathematics in the the University of Cambridge.
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish mathematician and physicst, held the Lucasian Mathematics Chair at Cambridge for 54 years. Famous for contributions in optics, dynamics, and mathematical physics.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Cloth Blind Stamped, Spine Gilt
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1887 Stokes - On Light. In Three Courses - Images.JPG

These were public lectures intended to be accessible by the informed laymen, so the presentations require no mathematical knowledge. The second course is particularly interesting; it summarizes the growing application of light as a scientific tool of investigation. The three courses of  lectures were printed in 1884, 1885, and 1887 respectively. In 1887 all three were printed in a single volume, from which the present translation was made.
BP_Description_2: The first course delt with the nature of light and contained four lectures, presenting the substance of physical optics. 1: The nature of light, the emission and undulatory theories, some optical phenomena, insufficiency of the emission theory. 2: Interference and diffraction, undulation theory. 3: Explication of the theory of undulations, double refraction, polarization. 4: Phenomena in multi-axial crystals.  The second course delt with light an investigative tool and contained four lectures. 1: Absorption of light, phosphorescence and fluorescence. 2: Polarimetry  3: Absorption and emission of light and chemical analysis. 4: Investigation of solar prominences and its corona. The third course delt with the beneficial effects of light and contained four lectures. 1: Fuller spectrum of 'light', mechanical, heating, and atmospheric effects of sun light. 2: Light as a source of heat and energy for plants and animals, the food chain. 3: Light and vision. 4: Teleological and religious aspects of light.

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Ferdinand Meisel (1854-1938) Astronomer and director of the Commercial School at Halle.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Meisel's reworking and of Hermann Robert Gieswald's editing of Friedrich Wilhelm Barfuss' textbook of 1839.
BP_Description_1: Ferdinand Meisel's reworking and of Hermann Robert Gieswald's editing of Friedrich Wilhelm Barfuss' textbook of 1839. Like Gieswald's edition, Meisel's reworking appeared as the third volume in the series Neuer Schauplatz der K√ºnste und Handwerke (New Theater of the Arts and Crafts). Meisel describes the need to update Barfuss's text and the invitation by the publisher to do so. Though he maintained its focus on applications, considerable updating and additions were required to align with optical developments in the intervening 28 years. The most significant changes being spectral and chemical analysis and added theoretical detail in the sections on physical optics. Meisel had the assistance of Ernst Abbe in reviewing the large chapter on optical instruments, particularly telescopes and microscopes. In this edition, the plates of figures were bound separately as <i>Atlas sum Lehrbuch der Optik<i>.
BP_Description_2: Meisel's edition of Barfuss' compendium is in 13 chapters. 1: Basic considerations. 2: Reflection of the Light, catoptrics. 3: Refraction of light, dioptrics. 4: Chromatics dispersion. 5: Spectral analysis. 6: Transfer of absorbed light. 7: Practical application of lenses, the human eye. 8: Telescopes and microscopes. 9: Projection apparatuses 10: Refraction and reflection in the atmosphere 11: Construction technique in optics. 12: Interference phenomena and elements of the undulation theory. 13: Polarization and double refraction.  Most chapters begin with a general description, invoking only simple geometry, followed in some cases by formulae and worked examples using real data. Most of the material is geometrical optics; phenomena important for instruments are described without any attempt to invoke physical optics for explanation. Analytical results, such as lens specifications, from other works are presented without derivation.
BP_Reference(s): <i>Carl Zeiss: A Biography 1816‚Äì1888<i>|Wimmer, W., Paetrow, S.|Zeiss Archives, 2016, 144 pp, NB: pp 61-62.
BP_Title: Lehrbuch der Optik.  Dritte Auflage von Dr. F.W. Barfuss' "Populares Lehrbuch der Optik, Katoptrik und Dioptrik", vollstandig new bearbeitet von Ferdinande Meisel, Direktor der gewerblichen  Zeichenschule in Halle. Mit einem Atal von 17 Foliotafeln.
BP_Title English Translation: Textbook of Optics. The Third Edition of Dr. F.W. Barfuss' "Popular Textbook of Optics, Catoptrics and Dioptrics", Completely new, Edited by Ferdinand Meisel, Director of the Industrial Arts School in Halle. With an Atlas of 17 Large Plates.
BP_Biographical Statement: German mathematician, experimentalist, and  author
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1889 Barfuss - Lehrbuch der Optik - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mascart produced this advanced textbook on physical optics specifically for use in university courses. It was used in the famed course he taught at the Coll√®ge de France.
BP_Description_1: √âleuth√®re Elie Nicolas Mascart produced this advanced textbook on physical optics specifically for use in university courses. It was used in the famed course he taught at the Coll√®ge de France. The coverage is complete, presenting all aspects of physical optics and the wave theory of light, along with the numerous optical phenomena used to define and refine the theory. As Mascart notes, the text includes material taken from the optical lectures of √âmile Verdet given at l'√âcole normale sup√©rieure where Mascart studied. The text also includes much of Mascart's own work on spectral analysis. It was an advanced text, both in scope and in detail, and included advanced mathematics whenever Mascart though it was necessary. The mathematical sophistication presumed of the student reader is considerable. Interestingly, there is only very slight mention of Maxwell's electromagnetic theory, and then only to cite a brief calculation of dielectric constants. There was no more exhaustive treatment of physical optics until Max Born's <i>Optik: Ein Lehrbuch der Elektromagnetischen Lichttheorie<i> of 1933. Mascart's text's three volumes were published in 1889, 1891, and 1893.
BP_Description_2: Mascart's text is in three volumes. Volume 1 has nine chapters. 1: Preliminaries and overview of all significant optical phenomena. 2: Optical systems, components and characteristics of optical systems including lenses, prisms, objectives, oculars, and measurement instruments. 3: Interference, the work of Fresnel. 4: Wave properties. 5: Diffraction, the work of Fresnel, diffraction at various surfaces and openings. 6: Interference with thin plates. 7: Application of interference, instruments. 8: Polarization. 9: Double refraction, theory and experiments.  Volume 2 has chapters 10-13. 10: Chromatic polarization, glass and crystals, rotary chromatic polarization, thin plates, applications. 11: Diverse optical phenomena. 12: Rotary polarization, crystals, applications and crystallography. 13: Reflection and refraction explained by the wave theory of light, glass, metals, and crystals. Volume 3 has chapters 14-21. 14: Polarization by diffraction. 15: Propagation of light, light speed, propagation in various media. 16: Photometry, theory and practice, stellar photometry. 17: Atmospheric refraction. 18: Optical properties of the air. 19: Mists, clouds, and rain. 20: Role of ice crystals in atmospheric phenomena. 21: Refraction and dispersion, spectral analysis, chemical analysis, analysis of the stars, indices of refraction. Every aspect of the text is complete, detailed and highly mathematical. Wherever appropriate, descriptions of instrumentation are given that relate to a phenomenon or characteristic being presented.
BP_Reference(s): Optics education and training in France|Chavel, P.H., Froehly, C.|In: <i>Proceedings of the SPIE, Vol 1603, Education in Optics<i>, 1991, pp 41-47.
BP_Title: Traite D'Optique. Par M.E. Mascart, Member de l'Institut, Professeur au College de France, Directeur du Bureau Central Meteorologique. Tome Primier.
BP_Title English Translation: Treatise on Optics. By M.E. Mascart, Member of the Institut, Professor in the College de France, Director of the Central Bureau of Meteorology. Volume the First. Volume the Second. Volume the Third.
BP_Biographical Statement: French physicist, academic. Professor at the Coll√®ge de France.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Enoch Karrer, fiber physicist.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Lectures on physical geography including atmospheric and meteorological optics including photometry.
BP_Description_1: Bound manuscript, in German, in a very small but generally legible hand on very pale blue paper. Lecture notes on physical geography including atmospheric optics. From the title stamped on the spine and the content of the lectures, it is likely that these are lecture notes for a course in Physical Geography given by Friedrich Zschokke (1860-1936) professor at the University of Basel. The date is conjecture. This is evidently the fist in a series, as the spine is also stamped "I Physics."
BP_Description_2: These lectures cover 'Atmospherology' including instruments, measurements, and descriptions of various atmospheric phenomena. The instruments include the photometer, hygrometer, thermometer, cyanometer (measuring the blueness of the sky), and electrometer. Descriptions of atmospheric phenomena include the rainbow and the Fata Morgana.
BP_Reference(s): Early Ecology in the German-Speaking World Through WWII|Schwarz, A., Jax, K.|In: Ecology Revisited, Springer, 2011, 444 pp, NB: pp 233-235.
BP_Title: Physische Geographie, Athmosphaerologischen Theil
BP_Title English Translation: Physical Geography, the Atmospheric Part
BP_Biographical Statement: Swiss Professor at the Universtiy of Basel, grandson of the famed writer Heinrich Zschokke.
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Cloth Over Marbled Paper Covered Boards

BP_Translator or Editor: Edited by Kurt Hensel
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: An editing of notes from the lectures Gustav Kirchhoff gave on physical optics at the University of Berlin.
BP_Description_1: Kurt Hensel edited these notes from the lectures Gustav Kirchhoff gave on physical optics at the University of Berlin. Kirchhoff had hoped to publish the lectures of all his courses on mathematical physics, but only that on mechanics appeared before his death. Hensel's editing benefited from elaboration, review, and notes from Kirchhoff's former pupils. Hensel was meticulous regarding the lectures and only modified what was to appear in print when it seemed essential; and even then, he noted what he had changed in the book‚Äôs appendix. Interestingly, Maxwell's theory of electromagnetism is not mentioned. These notes on mathematical optics appeared in 1891 and again in 1897 when all of Kirchhoff's mathematical physics notes were published as <i>Vorlesungen √ºber Mathematische Physik<i>.
BP_Description_2: The book presents Kirchhoff's thirteen lectures in physical optics. 1: General overview of undulation theory, transvers waves, interference, polarization. 2: Propagation of light. 3: Reflected light, image formation. 4: Refraction of light, image formation, magnification, spherical aberration. 5: Diffraction, Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction, various apertures. 6: Fraunhofer diffraction, diffraction gratings, diffraction spectra. 7: Mathematics of slit diffraction. 8: Polarization by reflection and refraction, linear polarization, amplitude of reflection. 9: Polarization by thin plates. 10: Absorption and dispersion, spectral analysis, Cauchy's theory of the aether. 11: Birefringence, crystals. 12: Rays in a crystalline medium, direction and propagation, multi-axis crystals. 13: Reflection and refraction and crystal boundaries. Kirchhoff's treatment is entirely mathematical, consulting experimental results as way to verify mathematical predictions.
BP_Reference(s): The Electrodynamic Revolution in Germany as Documented by Early German Expositions of 'Maxwell's Theory'|Darrigol, O.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 45, No 3, pp 189-280.
BP_Title: Vorlesungen uber Mathematische Optik von Gustav Kirchhoff.  Herausgegeben von Dr. Kurt Hensel, Privatdocent der Mathemtik an der Universitat zu Berlin. Mit dem Bildnesse Kirchhoff's.
BP_Title English Translation: Lectures on Mathematical Optics by Gustav Kirchhoff. Edited by Dr. Kurt Hensel, Private Lecturer in Mathematics in the University of Berlin. With Kirchhoff's Portrait.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, experimentalist, academic. Famed for work in electric circuits, spectroscopy.
BP_Provenance: Stamp of the Library of the Imperial Technical High School at Brunn.
BP_BibliographicNotes: Portrait on œá‚ÇÅ·µõ
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Black Morocco Over Speckled Boards
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1891 Kirchhoff - Vorlesungen uber Mathematische Optik - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A compendium of physical optics, presenting the optical phenomena, experimental data, and the consequent theoretical formulations of the nature light and the luminiferous aether.
BP_Description_1: Basset's purpose is to present then-current understanding of dynamical theories of light. It relies on and is to some extent patterned after Mascart's <i>Trait√© d'Optique<i> of 1889. The first half of Basset's treatise presents the optical phenomena and experimental data which must be explained by any theory of light, that last half presents and evaluates the theories that had been put forward, including Fresnel, Green, and Maxwell his followers. Basset was an applied mathematician and can be regarded as an agnostic with respect to the theories he presents, seeking only mathematical rigor and explanatory power, and treating the entire subject as mathematical physics.||The results of the Michelson-Morley experiment had appeared in 1887 but it would be nearly 20 years until the aether was finally abandoned and Basset takes its existence as a given. The book received a drubbing by reviewers in The Academy of London in July 1893 and The London, Edinburgh, and Dublin Philosophical Magazine and Journal of Science for August 1892. The Edinburgh reviewer objected to the mathematical nature of the book and the "foolish process of writing down equations." The Academy reviewer complained that Basset could not have been a teacher and book could not possibly be used as a textbook. The journal Nature, on the other hand, welcomed the book. The Edinburgh review, and Basset's response a month later, highlights the lingering dispute concerning the role of mathematics in physics, particularly in optics.
BP_Description_2: The treatise is in 20 Chapters. The first 10 present optical phenomena and data: Interference, colored fringes from thin and thick plates, diffraction, double refraction, colors from crystalline plates, polarization, and reflection and refraction. Though data and phenomena are presented, the experimental details are omitted, which adds to the clarity of presentation. Chapters 11-20 present theories of light involving dynamics and the nature of the luminiferous aether. The aether is presented as a scientific given, but with its properties unknown. Green's theory, proposed in 1837, on the dynamics of isotropic media is presented in detail, attempting to show the properties of the aether and how they account for observed optical phenomena. Rayleigh's and Thomson's theories of electrodynamics are presented, followed by the electromagnetic theory of Maxwell and his followers. The last chapter discusses magnetism and light, and presents optical phenomena that were only partially explained: The Faraday effect, Kerr's experiment, and the Hall effect.||The presentation is detailed, deeply mathematical, and those aspects involving the various theories are closely argued. Some of the early chapters end with worked examples.
BP_Reference(s): Nineteenth-Century Aether Theories|Schaffner, K.F.|Peramon Press, Oxford, 1972, 277 p.
BP_Title: A Treatise on Physical Optics
BP_Biographical Statement: English applied mathematician, textbook author in geometry, hydrodynamics, and optics.

BP_Short or Common Title: Untersuchungen ueber die Ausbreitung der Elektrischen Kraft
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A corrected reprinting of 13 journal articles on Hertz's electromagnetic research, along with a long, preliminary overview and a concluding set of notes and corrections. Hertz showed demonstrated the wave properties predicted by Maxwell‚Äôs theory of electromagnetism and that they had a velocity equal to that of light.
BP_Description_1: Between 1886 and 1889, Heinrich Hertz conducted experiments to demonstrate the physical reality and properties of Maxwell's electromagnetic waves. Several papers reporting these experiments appeared in the Annalen der Physik und Chemie at that time. Though pressured by the publisher to produce simple reprints, Hertz decided that errors had to be corrected and additional commentary made, and so produced a corrected reprinting of 13 journal articles on his electromagnetic research, along with a long, preliminary overview and a concluding set of notes and corrections. As Hertz wrote, this reworking of his papers gave him 'the opportunity to acknowledge mistakes that had been made, to erroneously reject mistakes that had been attributed to me, and at the same time to have the opportunity to publicly answer a series of questions that have often been put to me orally or by letter.' In his work, Hertz showed that transverse free-space electromagnetic waves traveling at a finite speed, produced standing waves which showed the wave properties predicted by Maxwell‚Äôs theory of electromagnetism and had a velocity equal to that of light. Hertz also determined the electric field intensity, polarization and reflection of the waves and established that light and these waves were both a form of electromagnetic radiation obeying the Maxwell equations. An English translation appeared in 1893.
BP_Description_2: Hertz reproduced 13 of his papers, sandwiched between an introductory overview and corrective and explanatory notes. 1. Introductory overview including a consideration of the experiments and electromagnetic theory. 2: 'On very fast electrical vibrations.' 3: 'Investigations on electrical discharge. Provisional communication.' 4: 'O the influence of the ultraviolet light on the electrical discharge.' 5: 'On the action of a rectilinear electrical oscillation on an adjacent current path.' 6: 'Induction phenomena caused by the electrical processes in insulators.' 7: 'On the propagation speed of electrodynamic effects.' 8: 'On electrodynamic waves in air and their reflection.' 9: 'The forces of electrical vibrations, treated according to Maxwell's theory.' 10: 'On the transmission of electric waves through wires,' 11: 'On rays of electric power.' 12: 'On the mechanical effects of electric wire waves.' 13: 'On the basic equations of electrodynamics for bodies at rest.' 14: 'On the basic equations of electrodynamics for moving bodies.' 15: Subsequent Remarks.
BP_Reference(s): Preface to the English Edition|Thomson, J.J., Lord Kelvin|<i>Electric Waves<i>, Jones, D.E., translator, Macmillian, Londong, 1893, Dover, New York, 1962.
BP_Title: Untersuchungen ueber die Ausbreitung der Elektrischen Kraft. Von Dr. Heinrich Hertz. Professor der Physik an der Universitat Bonn. Mit 40 Figures im Text
BP_Title English Translation: Studies in the Propagation of Electric Force. By Dr. Heinrich Hertz, Professor of Physics in the University of Bonn. With 40 Figures in the Text.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, experimentalist. Student of Helmholtz, Professor at the University of Karlsruhe and the Physics Institute in Bonn.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A detailed, highly technical handbook of optical instrument design and practice. Based on the work of Ernst Abbe at the Zeiss optical works in Jena.
BP_Description_1: Siegfried Czapski became assistant to Ernst Abbe at the Zeiss optical works in Jena in 1886. With the approval of the Zeiss brothers, Czapski became Abbe's most trusted assistant, working with Abbe on the many projects and developments at Zeiss. Czapski began work on an optical treatise in 1888, Abbe having neither time nor interest in writing up his theoretical and practical developments. Czapski's treatise appeared 5 years later in two forms: as a contribution to Adolf Winkelmann's <i>Handbuch der Physik<i> and as a separated publication. It was immediately recognized as a major work in technological and instrumentational optics.||Czapski states his purpose in writing the book in his Forward: 'to communicate that which, in my opinion, can not be found elsewhere more completely and coherently; to mention only what is essential, and for my special purpose, of what is necessary; and to offer merely a literature reference for the study of these fields of geometric optics. Czapski presents Abbe's theory of optical images in dioptric systems--which included the effects of diffraction--but states that he does not present Abbe's later general theory of diffraction since it would take too much and it was Abbe's intention to produce such a work himself. Abbe's theory of optical imaging revolutionized microscopy in the last 19th century.||A revised version of Czapski's book appeared in 1904 and again in 1924.
BP_Description_2: The book is in nine Sections. L Geometric optics, II. Geometric theory of optical imaging after Abbe. III. Realization of an optical image. IV. Spherical aberrations. V. Chromatic aberrations in dioptric systems and the theory of achromatism. VI. Prisms and prism systems. VII. The limitation of the rays and their dependent properties of the optical instruments. VIII. Main types of optical instruments including projection systems, microscopes, and telescopes. IX. Methods for the empirical determination of optical instrument constants.||Czapski presents Abbe's theory of optical images and its use in optical instrument design. This includes consideration of spherical and chromatic aberrations. These general results are then used to generate a particular theory of optical instruments which, in turn, is then applied to the principal types considered: the eye, projection system, magnifying glass, microscopes, and telescopes. In each of these instruments, the basic dioptric function is described and the factors on which it depends are characterized. These are the optical instrument constants considered in the last section of the book.
BP_Reference(s): Ernst Abbe and the Foundation of Scientific Microscopes|Masters, B.R.|<i>Optics & Photonics News<i>, February 2007.
BP_Title: Theorie der Optischen Instrumente nach Abbe von Dr. Siegfried Czapski Wissenshaflichen Mitarbetier der optischen Werkstatte von Carl Zeiss in Jena
BP_Title English Translation: Theory of Optical Instruments after Abbe by Dr. Siegfried Czapski. Scientific collaborator of the Carl Zeiss Optics Works in Jena
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist and optician. Long-time ccolleague of Abbe and employee of Zeiss, famed for his research and publications.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Hubert de Martin, microscopist.

BP_Short or Common Title: DeÃÅtermination expeÃÅrimentale de la valeur du meÃÄtre en longueurs d'ondes lumineuses
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Michelson's official report to the International Bureau on Weights and Measures describing his determination of the length of the International Meter in terms of the wavelength of light.
BP_Description_1: In 1889 A.A. Michelson and E.W. Morely published their article 'On the feasibility of establishing a light-wave as the ultimate standard of length' in the American Journal of Science. Between 1890 and 1892 Michelson experimented with the interferometer developed for the Michelson-Morley experiment, seeking a way to use it to count the number of waves of light in the standard meter. It was necessary that the light source be stable, emit light of the narrowest possible wavelength spread, and be extremely coherent. Eventually, the red line emitted by cadmium vapor was found satisfactory and in 1892 Michelson succeeded in determining the length of the International Prototype Meter at the US National Bureau of Standards in terms of cadmium's red-line wavelength. The interferometer developed by Michelson for this work eventually became the standard instrument for measuring lengths and was adopted by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures (BIPM). The 1907 Nobel Prize in physics was awarded to Michelson 'for his optical precision instruments and the spectroscopic and metrological investigations carried out with their aid.'
BP_Description_2: Michelson's text is in 5 parts and six appendices. I: Introduction, II: Theory. III: Description of the apparatus. IV: Methods of observation. The appendices report the work of Michelson's Parisian collaborators in making the necessary measurements with Michelson's apparatus.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Comparison of the International Meter with the Wave Length of the Light of Cadmium|Michelson, A.A.|<i>Astronomy and Astrophysics<i>, Vol 12, 1893,pp 556-560.||On the feasibility of establishing a llight-wave as the ultimate standard of length|Michelson, A.A., Morley, E.W.|<i>American Journal of Science<i>, Vol 38, 1889, pp 181-.||Michelson and his interferometer|Shankland, R.S.|<i>Physics Today<i>, Vol 27, No 4, 1974, pp 37-43.
BP_Title: DeÃÅtermination expeÃÅrimentale de la valeur du meÃÄtre en longueurs d'ondes lumineuses. Par M. Albert A. Michelson, Professeur de Physique a l'Universite de Chicago. MeÃÅmoire traduit de l'anglais par M. J.-ReneÃÅ BenoiÃÇt, Directeur de Bureau Internation des Poids et Mesures. Extrait du Tome XI des Travaux er Memoires de Bureau International des Poids and Mesures.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Second, expanded edition of Thomas Preston's widely praised and used textbook for advanced students of the electromagnetic theory of light.
BP_Description_1: In his Preface, Preston makes clear his reason for writing his book on the theory of light: Most texts were too elementary regarding physical optics and the most current information was only available in difficult to access scientific journals. He wish to produce an complete, advanced text on physical optics for students British universities. The book is completely Maxwellian in its foundation and presents electromagnetism in service of explaining optical phenomena and providing a mathematical physics of light--that is, physical optics. All of this was written before the discovery of the electron and the large shift in Maxwellian theory which that discovery produced. Large sections of the book deal with aspects of polarization and interference effects and the only material in geometric optics is a brief section on the rainbow.||The first edition appeared in 1890 and this, the second edition, appeared in 1895. It was significantly augmented by Preston in sections dealing with the elementary phenomena of reflection, refraction, and diffraction. Posthumous edition appeared in 1901, edited by Preston's colleague Charles Joly, in 1912 edited by William Thrift, and 1928 edited by Alfred Porter. Preston's book was part of a remarkable series of textbooks published by Macmillan between 1890 and 1910. The book was widely used in physics courses in Great Britain until the 1930's. Many of the major names in physics at the time reviewed and praised the book: Thomson, Rayleigh, Fitzgerald, Wiedmann, Quincke, Poynting, and Michelson and later recalled with praise by Eddington.
BP_Description_2: The 21 Chapters of The Theory of Light present a complete, pre-electron electromagnetic theory of light. Chapters 1-6 present the elementary optical phenomena of propagation, reflection, refraction, and dispersion in terms of electromagnetism. Chapters 7-9 deal with interference and diffraction and Chapters 10-13 deal with polarization. Chapters 14-21 are somewhat more applied, covering application of polarization, instrumentation, measurements of properties, the velocity of light, and the rainbow.||The structure of the book reflects Preston's skill in ordering material and working out careful presentations, and is one of the reasons it was widely praised and widely used. The style is clear, detailed, and informed by history, with references to previous work throughout the text. Most sections that present theoretical material end with fully worked example problems that involve the theory. The mathematics required is presented in a matter-of-fact way that demands a complete knowledge of calculus. There are hundreds of figures in the text.
BP_Reference(s): Unfulfilled renown: Thomas Preston (1860-1900) and the Anomalous Zeeman Effect|Weatire, D., O'Connor, S.|<i>Annalas of Science<i>, Vol 44, No 6, 1987, pp 617-644.
BP_Title: The Theory of Light
BP_Biographical Statement: Irish scientist, professor at University College Dublin. Important researcher in electro-magnetic theory and spectroscopy.
BP_Provenance: Dedicatiion by the author in the year of publication.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1895 Preston - The Theory of Light - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A thorough introduction to geometric and physical optics in the mature and post-electron-discovery era of Maxwell‚Äôs theory of electromagnetism and sits on the cusp between it and the advent of quantum optics just five years later.
BP_Description_1: Paul Karl Ludwig Drude was asked by the publisher to produce an advanced, comprehensive textbook on optics, in the spirit of Mascart's <i>Trait√© D'Optique<i> of 1889. Drude agreed that a modern optics text was needed and even though, when the book was finished, he said 'I can make no claim to the completeness of the excellent textbook of Mascart . . .', his book was widely used, praised, and translated. Drude's text is a thorough introduction to physical optics in the mature and post-electron-discovery era of Maxwell‚Äôs theory of electromagnetism and sits on the cusp between it and the advent of quantum optics just five years later. In that regard, Drude describes the null result of Michelson's and Morley's experiment to detect the luminiferous aether in 1887 and he follows this with an explanation of the startling proposition of Lorentz and Fitzgerald that the length of a solid body may depend upon its absolute motion in space. Though Einstein‚Äôs suggestion of light quanta would eventually revolutionize physical optics, the mathematical power of the electromagnetic theory remained, and still remains, important in optics. Drude's book would not be superseded until Max Born's <i>Optik: Ein Lehrbuch der Elektromagnetischen Lichttheorie<i> of 1933. Editions of Drude's text appeared in 1900 and 1906, An English translation appeared in 1902, 1905, and 1907, and was reissued in 1917, 1922 and 1959, a French edition was published in 1911.
BP_Description_2: Drude's optics textbook is in two parts, Geometric Optics (104 pages) and Physical Optics (395 pages). Drude leans heavily on Siegfried Czapski's <i>Theorie der Optischen Instrumente<i> of 1893 for his material on Geometrical Optics in five chapters. 1: Fundamental experiments and laws. 2: Geometric optical imaging. 3: Images by mirrors and lenses. 4: Vison, photometry, and images. 5: Optical instruments. The Physical Optics part is in three sections: General Properties of Light, Optical Properties of Bodies, Radiation from Bodies. General properties include: Propagation and speed, interference, Huygens principle, refraction, polarization. Optical Properties include the theory of light, transparent bodies, optical properties of crystals, absorbing bodies, dispersion, optically-active bodies, magnetically-active bodies, moving bodies. Radiation from bodies includes energy interpretation of radiation, thermodynamics applied to blackbody radiation, glow of gases.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Theory of Optics, By Paul Drude. Translated from the German by C. Riborg Mann and Robert A. Millikan, of the University of Chicago<i>. New York, Longmans, Green & Co., 1902|Review In: <i>The Astrophysical Journal<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 1903, pp 75-76.||The Electrodynamic Revolution in Germany as Documented by Early German Expositions of 'Maxwell's Theory'|Darrigol, O.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 45, No 3, pp 189-280.||From Mawell to Microphysics|Buchwald|University of Chicago Press, 1985, 339 p.|
BP_Title: Lehrbuch der Optik von Dr. Paul Drude, Professor der Physik an de Universitat Giessen Mit 100 Abbildungen.
BP_Title English Translation: Textbook of Optics by Dr. Paul Drude, Professor of Physics in the University of Giessen. With 100 Figures.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, specialized in optics and electromagnectic theory.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Cloth, Blind Spamped, Spine And Title Gilt
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1900 Drude - Lehrbuch der Optik - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A summary of how light itself was used as an instrument of science at the start of the 20th century.
BP_Description_1: This is the third volume in a series published by the University of Chicago, commemorating first ten years of its existence. A. A. Michelson had given eight lectures given at the Lowell Institute in 1899, developed by Michelson specifically for a general audience. The lectures were accompanied by demonstrations, experiments, and 'lantern slides' to make the material accessible and engaging. In his preface to this printed version of the lectures, Michelson notes that he attempted 'to present the lectures as nearly as possible in the words in which they were originally given.' And so they retain an almost conversational tone. The purpose of the lectures was to present a summary of how light itself was being used as an instrument of science at the very end of the 19th century. The principal mechanism for this was the interferometer, a tool that Michaelson had developed and used in his famed Michelson-Morley experiment. The text is filled with figures and photographs of the experimental apparatus from the lectures. The sources of the material in the lectures were the many papers, technical and popular, that Michelson had published and part of the popularity of the lectures and the book was in the value of having brought all these different source to one place. The book was reprinted in 1907.
BP_Description_2: The book presents 8 lectures: 1 Interference; 2 Microscope, Telescope, and Interferometer; 3 Interferometer measurements of distance and angles; 4 Interferometry and spectroscopy; 5 Light waves as standards of length; 6 Interferometric measurement of magnetic effects on light; 7 Interferometric astronomy; 8 the Ether.  The first lecture starts with an elementary account of light waves, their properties, and the principle of interference and its consequences. The more familiar microscope and telescope are then evaluated with respect to resolving power and this leads to the interferometer and its resolving power. The following lectures present various applications of the interferometer, including heightened resolving power of telescopic measurements and the revealing of fine detail in spectroscopy. The last lecture presents the Michelson-Morely experiment and its attempt to detect the effect of the earth's motion through the luminiferous aether. Even then, it had become one of the most famous experiments to yield negative results.
BP_Reference(s): Michelson and his interferometer|Shankland, R.S.|<i>Physics Today<i>, Vol 27, No 4, 1974, pp 37-43.
BP_Title: Light Waves and their Uses
BP_Biographical Statement: Polish-born American physicist, astronomer, academic. Professor at Case School, Clark University, University of Chicago.
BP_BibliographicNotes: With erratum slip inserted at page 14

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A revision and extension of a detailed, highly technical handbook of optical instrument design and practice that first appeared in 1893. Based on the work of Ernst Abbe at the Zeiss optical works in Jena.
BP_Description_1: Siegfried Czapski became assistant to Ernst Abbe at the Zeiss optical works in Jena in 1886. With the approval of the Zeiss brothers, Czapski became Abbe's most trusted assistant, working with Abbe on the many projects and developments at Zeiss. Czapski began work on an optical treatise in 1888, Abbe having neither time nor interest in writing up his theoretical and practical developments. Czapski's treatise appeared 5 years later in two forms: as a contribution to Adolf Winkelmann's Handbuch der Physik and as a separated publication. It was immediately recognized as a major work in technological and instrumentational optics.||Czapski states his purpose in writing the book in his Forward: 'to communicate that which, in my opinion, can not be found elsewhere more completely and coherently; to mention only what is essential, and for my special purpose, of what is necessary; and to offer merely a literature reference for the study of these fields of geometric optics. Czapski presents Abbe's theory of optical images in dioptric systems--which included the effects of diffraction--but states that he does not present Abbe's later general theory of diffraction since it would take too much and it was Abbe's intention to produce such a work himself. Abbe's theory of optical imaging revolutionized microscopy in the late 19th century.||A revised version of Czapski's book appeared in 1904 and again in 1924. This revision follows the structure and intent of the 1893 text closely. Each of the original chapters was edited and revised by a specialist on the Zeiss staff. Chapters one, three, and four were revised only slightly. The others were updated more extensively, accounting for the developments in the decade since the text first appeared.
BP_Description_2: The book is in nine Sections. L Geometric optics, II. Geometric theory of optical imaging after Abbe. III. Realization of an optical image. IV. Spherical aberrations. V. Chromatic aberrations in dioptric systems and the theory of achromatism. VI. Prisms and prism systems. VII. The limitation of the rays and their dependent properties of the optical instruments. VIII. Main types of optical instruments including projection systems, microscopes, and telescopes. IX. Methods for the empirical determination of optical instrument constants.||Czapski presents Abbe's theory of optical images and its use in optical instrument design. This includes consideration of spherical and chromatic aberrations. These general results are then used to generate a particular theory of optical instruments which, in turn, is then applied to the principal types considered: the eye, projection system, magnifying glass, microscopes, and telescopes. In each of these instruments, the basic dioptric function is described and the factors on which it depends are characterized. These are the optical instrument constants considered in the last section of the book.
BP_Reference(s): Ernst Abbe and the Foundation of Scientific Microscopes|Masters, B.R.|<i>Optics & Photonics News<i>, February 2007.

BP_Title English Translation: Imagining in Optical Instruments from the Standpoint of Geometrical Optics
BP_Biographical Statement: German optician, instrument maker, optical historian. Worked at Zeiss and was associate professor at the University of Jena.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: A complete, highly analytic presentation of physical optics based on wave theory, but without any reference to or assumptions regarding the luminiferous aether. Presaging the later vector-based treatment of physical optics.
BP_Description_1: Walker makes clear the purpose of the book in his Preface: 'to give an account of physical optics without having recourse to any hypothesis respecting the nature of the influence that constitutes light or the character of the medium in which it is propagated.' In this sense it is almost entirely phenomenological--that is, an elaborate mathematical apparatus is erected to model clear experimental results--but not to form any underlying theory. It is based on and extends Fresnel's fundamental theory of transverse waves, frames the older theory in modern vector analysis, and makes no reliance on Maxwellian electromagnetic theory. In this sense it is quite unlike Paul Drude's <i>Lehrbuch der Optik<i> of 1900.||Walker sets aside considerations of a luminiferous aether, citing the contradictory properties it must exhibit depending on whether electrical or optical phenomena are considered, and that no suitable aether theory had been developed, whether corpuscular or of a continuum. The book presents an attractive (and uncommon) balance between analytic results and experimental facts. It was reviewed very favorably in the December 1905 issue of The London, Edinburgh and Dublin Philosophical Magazine and Journal of Science, in the January 1906 issue of Nature, and in the March 1906 issue of Science. Walker's text was widely read and recognized as the most complete treatment of analytical physical optics then extant. The analysis of the expressions he derived for modeling diffraction continue to be used and cited. Walker's heavy reliance of vector methods resulting in him citing Stokes's (then obscure) paper on the vector parameterization of polarized light. It was this reference in Walker's book that led Subrahamanyan Chandrasekhar to formulate his theory of atmospheric radiative transfer using the Stokes vector.
BP_Description_2: Walker's text is in 19 chapters. 1: Geometrical Propositions of the Wave Theory. 2: Analytical Expressions for a Train of Plane Waves. 3; Interference. 4: Interference Produced by Isotropic Plates. 5: Differential Equations of the Polarisation Vector. 6: Huygens Principle. 7: Fraunhofer's Diffraction Phenomena. 8: Fresnel's Diffraction Phenomena. 9: More Accurate Investigation of the Problem of Diffraction. 10: Reflection and Refraction at the Surfaces of Isotropic Media. 11: Double Refraction. 12: Determination of the Principal Wave Velocities. 13: Crystalline Reflection and Refraction. 14: Interference of Polarised Light. 15: The Study of Polarised Light. 16: Absorbing Media. 17: Dispersion. 18: Structurally Active Media. 19: Magnetically Active Media.||Walker's initial analysis is in Chapter 1-4 and begins with experimental facts and a reasonable mathematical model is constructed from known properties of waves. Chapters 5-19 present the subsequent analytic theory. Wave analysis is made more general, analytically easier, and more concise by Walker's artifice of a 'Polarisation Vector' and another vector perpendicular to it. These are akin to the later conception of an Electric and Magnetic vector. Walker shows that a beam of unpolarized light can be represented by two beams of polarized light, having their polarization vectors perpendicular. Another artifice of Walker's is the introduction of exponentially diminishing wave amplitude to model absorption and dispersion. Walker cites and uses the work of Rayleigh, Poincar√©, Stokes, Lommel, Weber, Sommerfeld, and MacCullagh. The work on diffraction is particularly extensive and uses Bessel, Struve, and Lommel functions. The general properties of these are presented in Appendices at the end of the text. The list of references is particularly extensive.
BP_Reference(s): The Intensity Distribution and Total Illumination of Aberration-Free Diffraction Images|Barakat, R.|In: <i>Progress in Optics<i>, Vol 1, 1961, pp 69-108.
BP_Title: The Analytical Theory of Light by James Walker, M.A., Christ Chruch, Oxford, Demonstrator of Physics in the Clarendon Laboratory, Oxford.
BP_Biographical Statement: English physicist, writher, teacher. Author of optical articles for the 11th Edition of the Encyclopedia Britanica.
BP_Binding: Contemporary Blind Stamped Cloth, Spine Gilt
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1904 Walker - The Analytical Theory of Light - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: √úber einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: One of the three papers Albert Einstein published in the Annalen der Physik in 1905, his famed <i>annus mirablis<i>. In it he advanced the 'heuristic' that light energy is carried in discrete quantized packets which he called light-quanta.
BP_Description_1: One of the three papers Albert Einstein published in the Annalen der Physik in 1905, his famed annus mirabilis. Einstein dealt with the statistical/quantum nature of radiation and from this came his radical idea of light quanta which explained the inability of the electromagnetic theory of light to account for the so-called photoelectric effect: experiment showed that the energy of electrons emitted from a metallic surface struck by incident radiation depended not on its intensity, but rather on its frequency. Further, electromagnetic theory predicted a time lag in electron emission if the intensity of incident radiation was very low; which was also not observed experimentally. Einstein's paper advanced the hypothesis (he called it a 'heuristic') that light energy is carried in discrete quantized packets which he called light-quanta. He stated 'Energy, during the propagation of a ray of light, is not continuously distributed over steadily increasing spaces, but it consists of a finite number of energy quanta localized at points in space, moving without dividing and capable of being absorbed or generated only as entities.' Initial reactions to Einstein's idea were quite dim; indeed, in a reference letter for Einstein, Planck assured the recipient of Einstein's knowledge and ability and urged him not be prejudiced by his more fantastic ideas, such as light quanta. But in 1914, Millikan's Experiment supported Einstein's model of the photoelectric effect and Einstein was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1921 for 'his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect.' In 1909, Einstein would propose the wave-particle duality for light in his paper 'Zum gegenw√§rtigen Stand des Strahlungsproblems' ('To the Recent State of Art of the Radiation Problem').
BP_Description_2: First, Einstein calculated the change in entropy when a volume filled with blackbody radiation of some total energy in the high-frequency region of the spectrum was reduced to a smaller subvolume, The requirement of 'high frequency' was required so that he could use Wien‚Äôs radiation law. He then used Boltzmann‚Äôs statistical expression for the entropy to calculate the probability of finding some number, N, of independent, distinguishable gas molecules moving in the large volume at a given instant of time in a the subvolume. He found that these two results were formally identical, providing that the change in entropy was a function of the frequency of the radiation. And so he concluded: ‚ÄúMonochromatic radiation of low density (within the range of validity of Wien‚Äôs radiation formula) behaves thermodynamically as if it consisted of mutually independent energy quanta ...‚Äù He then cited three experimental results to support his idea, the most famous of which was the photoelectric effect, the others were Stokes Law for photoluminescence and the generation of cathode rays by illuminated solid bodies.
BP_Reference(s): Einstein's Revolutionary Light-Quantum Hypothesis|Stuewer, R.H.|In: <i>American Physical Society, 36th Meeting of the Division of Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics<i>, May 17-21, 2005||‚ÅÇ ùëª  http://einsteinpapers.press.princeton.edu/vol2-trans/100
BP_Title: "√úber einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt" In: Annalen der Physik, Vol 17, 4th Series, pp 132-148.
BP_Title English Translation: "On a Heuristic Viewpoint Concerning the Production and Transformation of Light"  In: Annalen der Physik, Vol 17, 4th Series, pp 132-148.

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Three of Karl Schwarzschild's most important papers on the optics of reflecting telescopes.
BP_Description_1: With these three papers, Karl Schwarzschild advanced the theory and practice of reflecting telescope design. By 1900 the technology of telescope mirror manufacture had produced the 60-inch reflector at the Mr. Wilson Observatory and the promise of even larger aperture telescopes underscored the inadequacy of current design theory and practice. Beginning with Seidel's third-order aberration theory, Schwarzschild extended this with his Eikonal developments. This theory was applied to reflecting telescopes of single or multiple optically active mirrors. This was followed with procedures to design astrographic objectives for telescopes. Schwarzschild's work has been used in the theoretical design of multiple-mirror huge aperture telescopes.
BP_Description_2: Schwarzschild's work proved singularly important, particularly that in the second paper, in which he proved that a telescope using two aspheric mirrors could allow significant improvement in aberration correction, maintaining a wide field of view. More interesting and influential was his demonstration that a multi-mirror system could be designed that used a spherical primary mirror--rather than parabolic--something immeasurably simpler to design, manufacture, use, and maintain, since all of its segments would have the same figure.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ Karl Schwarzschild and Telscope Optics|Wilson, R.N.|<i>Reviews in Modern Astronomy<i>, Vol 7, 1994, pp 1-30.
BP_Title: Untersuchungen zur geometrischen Optik. I, Einleitung in de Fehlertheorie optischer Instrumente auf Grund des Eikonalbegriffs. II, Theorie der Speigeltelescope. III, Untersuchungen zur geo0metrischen Optik. Uber die astrophotographischen Objektive.
BP_Title English Translation: Studies in Geometrical Optics. I: Introduction to the Theory of Errors of Optical Instruments Based on the Eikonal Concept. II: The Theory of the Reflecting Telescope. III: On Astrophotographic Objective Lenses.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist and astronomer. Director of the G√∂ttingen and Potsdam Observatories, famed for his work in Relativity.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1905 Schwarzschild - Untersuchungen zur geometrischen Optik - Images.JPG

BP_Translator or Editor: Translated by Charles Riborg Mann (1869-1942) Professor at the University of Chicago, textbook writer. Robert Andrews Millikan (1868-1953) American experimental physicist, Nobel Laureate.
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: English translation of Drude's <i>Lehrbuch der Optik<i> of 1900. A thorough introduction to geometric and physical optics in the mature and post-electron-discovery era of Maxwell‚Äôs theory of electromagnetism and sits on the cusp between it and the advent of quantum optics just five years later.
BP_Description_1: Paul Karl Ludwig Drude was asked by the publisher to produce an advanced, comprehensive textbook on optics, in the spirit of Mascart's <i>Trait√© D'Optique<i> of 1889. Drude agreed that a modern optics text was needed and even though, when the book was finished, he said 'I can make no claim to the completeness of the excellent textbook of Mascart . . .', his book was widely used, praised, and translated. Drude's text is a thorough introduction to physical optics in the mature and post-electron-discovery era of Maxwell‚Äôs theory of electromagnetism and sits on the cusp between it and the advent of quantum optics just five years later. In that regard, Drude describes the null result of Michelson's and Morley's experiment to detect the luminiferous aether in 1887 and he follows this with an explanation of the startling proposition of Lorentz and Fitzgerald that the length of a solid body may depend upon its absolute motion in space. Though Einstein‚Äôs suggestion of light quanta would eventually revolutionize physical optics, the mathematical power of the electromagnetic theory remained, and still remains, important in optics. Drude's book would not be superseded until Max Born's <i>Optik: Ein Lehrbuch der Elektromagnetischen Lichttheorie<i> of 1933. Editions appeared in 1900 and 1906, An English translations appeared in 1902, 1905, and 1907, and reissued in 1917, 1922 and 1959, a French edition was published in 1911.
BP_Description_2: Drude's optics textbook is in two parts, Geometric Optics (104 pages) and Physical Optics (395 pages). Drude leans heavily on Siegfried Czapski's <i>Theorie der Optischen Instrumente<i> of 1893 for his material on Geometrical Optics in five chapters. 1: Fundamental experiments and laws. 2: Geometric optical imaging. 3: Images by mirrors and lenses. 4: Vison, photometry, and images. 5: Optical instruments. The Physical Optics part is in three sections: General Properties of Light, Optical Properties of Bodies, Radiation from Bodies. General properties include: Propagation and speed, interference, Huygens principle, refraction, polarization. Optical Properties include the theory of light, transparent bodies, optical properties of crystals, absorbing bodies, dispersion, optically-active bodies, magnetically-active bodies, moving bodies. Radiation from bodies includes energy interpretation of radiation, thermodynamics applied to blackbody radiation, glow of gases.
BP_Reference(s): <i>The Theory of Optics, By Paul Drude. Translated from the German by C. Riborg Mann and Robert A. Millikan, of the University of Chicago<i>. New York, Longmans, Green & Co., 1902|Review In: <i>The Astrophysical Journal<i>, Vol 18, No 1, 1903, pp 75-76.||The Electrodynamic Revolution in Germany as Documented by Early German Expositions of 'Maxwell's Theory'|Darrigol, O.|<i>Archive for History of Exact Sciences<i>, Vol 45, No 3, pp 189-280.||<i>From Mawell to Microphysics<i>|Buchwald|University of Chicago Press, 1985, 339 p.
BP_Title: The Theory of Optics. Paul Drude Professor of Physics at the University of Giessen. Translated from the German by C. Riborg Mann and Robert A. Millikan Assitant Professors of Physics at the University of Chicago.
BP_Biographical Statement: German physicist, specialized in optics and electromagnectic theory.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1907 Drude - The Theory of Optics - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Physical and geometric demonstrations of nearly all aspect of light and optical instruments.
BP_Description_1: An expansion and correction of Clay's earlier elementary textbook <i>Practical Exercises in Light<i> of 1902. The original work was written as a laboratory-based course in optics for technical schools and colleges and was based on notes Clay developed for his students. The spirit and style of the original has been retained, but the present work is a significant expansion, including advanced topics and instruments and supporting mathematics, all of which  made the treatise appropriate not only for university use but also to serve the optical industry.
BP_Description_2: Clay's text has 23 chapters. 1: Pin Experiments; 2: Mirrors and Lenses; 3: Focal Lengths for Mirrors and Lenses; 4: Optical Instruments; 5: Dispersion of Light; 6: Velocity of Light; 7: Optical Bench; 8: Compound Lens; 9: Aberrations of Mirrors and Lenses; 10: Diffraction Gratings; 11: Interference and Diffraction; 12: Interference; 13: Colors of Thin and Thick Plates; 14: Interferometers; 15: More on Diffraction; 16: Resolving Power of Optical Instruments; 17: Compound Microscope; 18: Photometry; 19: Color Measurement; 20: Eye and Vision; 21: Polarized Light; 22: Saccharimeters; 23: Experiments in Polarized Light. In addition there are five appendices: The Rainbow, Practical Work, Working with Mica, Light Sources.||Chapter one is interesting for the ingenious use of simple materials to demonstrate the basic aspects of geometrical optics. The emphasis through the chapters is on measurements, the equiipment necessarsy for those measurements, and the mathematics to manipulate the results. The examples are numerous and detailed. Aside from the briefest mentions in the material on interference and polarization, physical optics is not treated.||<i>Treatise on Practial Light<i> remained a standard textbook for many years.
BP_Reference(s): Review In: Science Progress in the Twentieth Century, Vol 6, 1911-1912, pp 500-501. Obituaries In: Nature, Vol 174, July, 1954, pp 16-17.
BP_Title: Treatise on Practical Light. By Reginald S. Clay B.A.(Cantab.), D.Sc. (Lond.) Principal of the Northern Polytechnic Institute Holloway, London.
BP_Biographical Statement: Principal of the Northern Polytechnic Institute Holloway, London. Author of practical texts and many journal articles in optics and successful exponent of practical technical education.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1911 Clay - Treatise on Practical Light - Images.JPG

BP_Short or Common Title: Procedings of the Solvay Conference of 1911
BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Papers presented by 18 leadings scientists from all over Europe at the first Solvay Conference held at Brussels in 1911. The cusp of the quantum age.
BP_Description_1: Walther Nernst, German chemist and physicist, was the principal architect of the first Solvay Conference. Nernst knew Ernest Solvay, chemist, industrialist and philanthropist, and lover of science, and suggested to Solvay that he fund an international conference. Nernst's proposal was to invite a select group of physicists from around the world to an international conference devoted to debating the new theories of physics and attempting to reconcile molecular-kinetic theory with Planck and Einstein's quantum approaches to energy and radiation. Solvay agreed and the first international invited conference in the history of science was arranged. This would be the first of a series of 'Solvey Conferences.'||The conference is considered a turning point in science since its titular topic, radiation and the quantum, had begun to challenge and remove the underpinnings of classical physics. The proceedings  included papers (and extensive commentary on papers) by Einstein, Lorentz, Nernst, Jeans, Warburg, Rubens, Planck, Knudsen, Perrin, Onnes, Sommerfeld, Rutherford, Poincare, Curie and Langevin. The patronage provided by Solvay and the prestige provided by the chair, Hendrik Lorentz, was sufficient to bring together the leading physicists of the time for a week-long discussion on the 'Radiation Theory and Quanta,' or the quantum theory of radiation. This was Albert Einstein's first public appearance in the international community of physicists, and though the youngest attendee, was already sufficiently successful and confident so as not to be overawed by all the great names. He referred to the conference as 'the Witches' Sabbath in Brussels.' At its end, he would be recognized as the new, young leader of the profession of physics. The conference papers were provided in typescripts in French, English and German, derived from submissions by the participants. These were eventually published, with revisions, in this, the conference proceedings, edited by Langevin and de Broglie. A German edition of the proceedings, edited by Arnold Eucken, appeared in 1914.
BP_Description_2: The essential aspects of the conference papers and the discussion that surrounded them was the existence and nature of quanta. Classical physics has famously failed to produce a theory that resulted in an equation that correctly predicted the the energy distribution as a function of wavelength of a blackbody radiator--a radiation formula. H.A. Lorentz presented a thorough review of why classical physics fails to produce a realistic radiation formula. In the process he references (and supports) Einstein's work on the quantization of energy. Max Planck presented a summary of the work that had been done on explaining his own successful expression of a radiation formula he had produced 11 years earlier. As Einstein had proposed in 1906, the only reasonable assumption was that of energy quanta. The discussion of Planck's report was particularly extensive and highlighted the difficulties faced by physics at the time. Einstein's report was ostensibly on specific heats, but its scope was much broader. He linked the problem of specific heats to that of the radiation formula. Einstein's comments on this own report and that of Lorentz and Planck show him to be perhaps the only physicist present to fully understand the depth of the problem facing physics. He mentioned that it was then quite apparent that classical physics could not explain important physical phenomena in radiation and there was no complete quantum theory to replace it. The conference ended with a general debate, but no conclusions or, more importantly, no progress or agreement.
BP_Reference(s): ‚ÅÇ On the first Solvay Congress in 1911| Straumann, N.|<i>The European Physical Journal H<i>, Vol 36, No 3, 2011, pp 379‚Äì399.
BP_Title: La th√©orie du rayonnement et les quanta. Rapports et discussions de la r√©union tenue √† Bruxelles, du 30 octobre au 3 novembre 1911, sous les auspices de M.E. Solvay. Publiee par MM. P. Langevin et M. de Broglie.
BP_Title English Translation: The theory of radiation and quanta. Reports and discussions of the meeting held in Brussels from October 30 to November 3, 1911, under the auspices of M.E. Solvay. Published by MM. P. Langevin and M. de Broglie.
BP_Biographical Statement: French aristocrat and physicist, made important contributions to quantum theory.
BP_Provenance: Bookplate of Enoch Karrer, fiber physicist.
BP_Binding: Contemporary 1/2 Morocco Over Printed Paper Covered Boards
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1912 de Broglie - Procedings of the Solvay Conference of 1911 - Images.JPG

BP_Brief Summary of the Work: Mach's clear and accessible description of physical optics, presented in the framework of its history and tinctured with Mach's phenomenological ideas regarding physics.
BP_Description_1: Mach states in his Forward that the purpose in his optics book is that same as that of his book on mechanics. Mach's comments in that earlier work apply equally to this optics work: 'The present volume is a treatise up the application of the principles of mechanics. Its aim is to clear up ideas, expose the real significance of the matter, and get rid of metaphysical obscurities. The little mathematics is contains is merely secondary to this purpose. Mechanics will here be treated, not as a branch of mathematics, but as one of the physical sciences.' Indeed, substituting 'optics' for 'mechanics' gives an accurate description of Mach's book. The material presented describes the development of the principles of of physical optics, specifically light's nature and properties. The framework is entirely historical, with care taken to trace the development of ideas that emerged from the consideration of experimental results.||Mach began this work while teaching in Prague in the late 1860's. It  was a more-or-less conventional textbook but in the intervening 50 years, its purpose and style changed considerably. It was completed in 1913 but not published until after his death. Famously, the introduction displays Mach's opposition to Relativity and the ideas of Einstein. The entire work is imbued with Mach's phenomenological ideas regarding physics.||Editions appeared in 1921, with an English translation in 1926 that was reprinted in 1953 and 2003.
BP_Description_2: Mach's text is in 14 chapters. I: Introduction, II: The linear-temporal propagation of light, III: Reflection and refraction, IV: Theories of Vision, V: Development of dioptrics, VI: Composition of the light, VII: Further development of the theory of colors and dispersion, VIII: Periodicity, IX: Further development of interference theory, X: Polarization, XI: Mathematical representation of the properties of light, XII: Further development of polarization, XIII: The enlightenment of straight rays, of reflection and refraction by the temporal propagation of light. XIV: Further clarification of light's behavior from periodicity and diffraction.||The style is descriptive and particularly clear. Consistent with the subtitle of the book (An Historical and Philosophical Treatment), the emphasis is on ideas, their development, how they were modified as new experimental facts arose, and how they led to modern concepts regarding light's nature. The mathematics of the subject is all but ignored.
BP_Reference(s): An Appraisal of the Work of Ernst Mach: Scientist-Historian-Philosopher|Hiebert, E.|In: <i>Motion and Time Space and Matter<i>,  Machamer, P.K.editor, 1976, Ohio State University Press, pp 360‚Äì389.
BP_Title: Die Prinzipien der physikalischen Optik. Historisch und erkenntnispsychologisch entwickelt von Ernst Mach. Mit 279 Figuren im Text und 10 Bildnissen
BP_Title English Translation: The principles of physical optics. Historically and epistemologically developed by Ernst Mach. With 279 figures in the text and 10 Plates.
BP_Biographical Statement: Austrian physicist and philosopher of science. Extensive experimenter in optics.
BP_Image1: F:/Bibliotheca Opticoria/Catalogue/BibliothecaOpticoria Images/Photo3rdDrafts/1921 Mach - Die Prinzipien der physikalischen Optik (b) - Images.JPG
